description: Hitachi Ltd., Japan's largest private employer, announced today that it would cut 4 percent of its work force, or 14,700 jobs, by March -- 10,200 in Japan and the remaining 4,500 overseas.

description: In an effort to increase public participation in policy decisions regarding the Internet's address system, two groups released reports this week with recommendations on how best to involve individuals in policy matters.

title: AMF BOWLING FILES PLAN FOR RECOVERY FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: AMF Bowling Worldwide Inc., the largest operator of bowling centers, filed a Chapter 11 recovery plan to emerge from bankruptcy. A unit of AMF Bowling Inc., AMF Worldwide and 24 company units sought Chapter 11 protection from creditors on July 3. The parent company, which is based in Richmond, Va., filed for bankruptcy on July 31. Under the plan, AMF's secured lenders owed about $622.6 million, which would be paid in cash, debt and new shares in the restructured company. The company's unsecured creditors, including bondholders owed more than $550 million, would receive stock options to buy 12 percent of the reshuffled shares. The plan is subject to approval by Judge David H. Adams of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Richmond.

title: Turkish Amnesty Draws Fire as Freed Man Is Linked to Killing
description: The killing of a prominent businessman, allegedly by a man freed in a large amnesty last December, has cast a sharply critical light on the traditional government practice of issuing such broad mass pardons.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Slight Economic Growth
description: Hong Kong's economy grew 0.5 percent in the second quarter compared with the second quarter of 2000, the government said. It was the smallest gain since the first quarter of 1999 and was just half of what analysts had expected. Hong Kong, whose 10.5 percent expansion last year was Asia's fastest, is now among the worst performers. The drop prompted Hong Kong's government to cut its 2001 growth forecast to 1 percent from 3 percent.

title: Court and State Differ Over Start Of Stricter Auto Insurance Rules
description: A judge issued an order yesterday temporarily blocking the start, scheduled for today, of stricter no-fault auto insurance regulations in New York State that the Pataki administration says are needed to fight fraud.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of the South African anti-apartheid leader Govan Mbeki misspelled the name of another leading opponent of apartheid. He is Walter Sisulu, not Sissulu.

title: New Accusations Of a Vatican Role In Anti-Semitism; Battle Lines Were Drawn After Beatification of Pope Pius IX
description: When the Vatican announced that it would beatify Pope Pius IX during its Jubilee celebrations last year, the Brown University historian David I. Kertzer had reservations. He knew that Pius IX, a staunch 19th-century critic of modernity who led the Roman Catholic Church during a tumultuous period that included the demise of the Papal States and the unification of Italy, was a favorite of the church's conservative wing.

title: A Voice That Shows Every Stage of the Singer's Life
description: Etta James, a hefty 63-year-old who has been singing professionally since she was a teenager, was helped onto the stage at the B. B. King Blues Club by an attendant on Thursday night, and she performed seated. She had the haughty, jaded expression of an empress overseeing workaday matters, as if she took her attentive band and the adoring audience for granted. And though her most recent album, ''Blue Gardenia'' (Private Music/BMG), is a set of jazz standards, she didn't sing any of them. Instead, her set stuck to songs she may have performed thousands of times, mostly her hits from the 1950's and 1960's.

title: Americans' International Lead in Hours Worked Grew in 90's, Report Shows
description: A United Nations agency provided some discouraging news yesterday to Americans who believe they are overworked, finding that American workers have increased their substantial lead over Japan and all other industrial nations in the number of hours worked each year.

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Count On Rematch In January
description: WHEN you are the defending conference champions, when you have been to the last Super Bowl and yearn for another, the real kickoff, the real adrenaline, the real games, cannot come fast enough.

title: MAYTAG TO SELL COMMERCIAL COOKING UNIT TO MIDDLEBY
description: The Maytag Corporation agreed to sell its commercial-cooking business to the Middleby Corporation for $95 million in cash and notes, less than Maytag paid for it four years ago, to focus on home appliances. The acquisition of the unit, G. S. Blodgett, will more than double revenue at Middleby, a maker of cooking and food-preparation equipment for restaurants and cafeterias. Maytag, which is based in Newton, Iowa, will record a noncash loss of about $60 million in the third quarter for liabilities and investments in the unit. Maytag bought Blodgett in 1997 for $148 million. The division, which had sales of $135 million last year, was put up for sale in May.

title: Pauline Koner Memorial
description: A memorial for Pauline Koner, the modern-dance choreographer, teacher and writer, will be held on Sept. 6 at 5:30 p.m. at Buttenweiser Hall in the 92nd Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. Ms. Koner died in February at 88. The memorial, which is open to the public, will include a performance by the Limn Dance Company, videos and photographs of Ms. Koner performing, and speakers. Information: (212) 725-3735.

description: The Bush administration today urged the Supreme Court to reject a request by the Microsoft Corporation to consider throwing out the findings that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly in the software industry.

title: Roche Reaches Accord on Drug With Brazil
description: The Swiss drug giant Roche Holding reached an agreement with Brazilian health authorities today to cut the price of the AIDS drug Viracept by a further 40 percent, putting an end to threats by the government to break the patent and produce the drug locally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERTOUZOS, MICHAEL
description: DERTOUZOS - Michael. Philips Research joins the faculty and students of the Laboratory for Computer Science at MIT in mourning the passing of Michael Dertouzos, Director since 1974. We extend our condolences to the family of Professor Dertouzos. Philips Research was pleased to have joined the Oxygen Alliance at MIT to share Professor Dertouzos' goal of a radical shift toward human centric computing. We rejoice in the knowledge that his work will continue at MIT. Ad Huijser CEO, Philips Research Barry Singer Managing Director, Philips Research USA

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Population Rebound Continues
description: The population increased to 3.84 million in April, the highest since 1881 and a rise of about 1.5 percent in the past year, the government said. Net migration reached a record high, as 26,300 more people moved to Ireland over the previous year than left. The Great Famine of the 1840's cut Ireland's population from 8 million to 4 million through starvation and emigration; the number continued to fall until reaching an all-time low of 2.82 million in 1961. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Point Given Is Retired Because of Tendon Strain
description: Point Given, who had been quickly emerging as a great racehorse, was suddenly retired today after a strained tendon was discovered in his left foreleg. The announcement came six days after Point Given, a 3-year-old colt, captured the Travers Stakes, his fourth consecutive victory in Grade I races worth $1 million or more.

title: Journal; Big Boys Should Cry
description: What does it say that more Americans watched Condit & Chung than any other TV show this summer or any other news broadcast in more than two years? Was ''Planet of the Apes'' really that bad?

title: The Other Schnabel, Reticent Composer
description: Artur Schnabel was arguably the most respected and influential pianist of the 20th century. His vibrant, probing, lucid performances of Beethoven and Schubert during the 1920's were altogether revelatory, bringing new light to repertory that was inadequately comprehended.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Dispute On Afghan Refugees
description: The United Nations has suspended its participation in the screening of Afghan refugees in Pakistan, saying the government forcibly deported more than 130. The two sides had agreed to work together to determine who deserved asylum. Instead, according to United Nations officials, refugees were tricked into boarding government trucks on the pretense of going to a screening center, when they were really being sent back across the border. The government denies the charge. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Developer to Run Ad Campaign Questioning Arena Deal
description: One of New Jersey's largest real estate developers is planning a statewide advertising campaign that raises questions about plans for a new arena in Newark and the redevelopment of the current arena site in the Meadowlands.

title: G.O.P. Debate Becomes Battle On Credentials
description: Meeting for the first time in a debate, the Republican mayoral candidates, Herman Badillo and Michael R. Bloomberg, played up their starkly different backgrounds yesterday and defended their party credentials. Each insisted he was the right kind of Republican to lead New York City, which is overwhelmingly Democratic, at a time of economic uncertainty.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Union Leader Unswayed By Bush
description: President Bush is spending Labor Day with union members at a picnic in Detroit, but Stephen P. Yokich, the president of the United Auto Workers, said that would not sway workers' views. ''Mr. Bush's political strategists may think that a few nice words at a carefully staged media event at a local union hall in Detroit on Labor Day will fool working families into thinking that Bush is on our side; it won't,'' Mr. Yokich said. He said Mr. Bush had put the interests of corporations ahead of workers with actions like repealing ergonomics rules and enacting a tax cut that Mr. Yokich said favored millionaires. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: CORINTHIAN COLLEGES STOCK FALLS ON LOWER FORECAST
description: Corinthian Colleges Inc. shares fell after the company, an operator of private colleges, forecast that fiscal first-quarter earnings would be at the low end of analyst estimates. Corinthian shares fell $13.50, to $39.35. The forecast means Corinthian will not beat analysts' expectations for the first time since the company, based in Santa Ana, Calif., offered shares to the public in 1999. Earnings for the quarter ending Sept. 30 will be 25 cents to 28 cents a share, Corinthian said yesterday. It was expected to earn 28 cents, the average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Xerox Settles Its Suit Over Patent Claims
description: The Xerox Corporation, the largest copier maker, said Copier Services Unlimited agreed to pay unspecified damages to settle claims that it infringed Xerox patents and copyrights, ending a seven-year legal fight.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE CLIMBS. Crude oil rose as OPEC prepared to reduce production for the third time this year. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 65 cents, or 2.5 percent, to $27.20 a barrel.

title: The Ponytailed Place-Kicker
description: Ashley Martin, ponytail dangling from the back of her helmet, made history Thursday night when she became the first woman to play and score in a Division I college football game. One reason her triumph was not front-page news may have been that there were no lawyers involved, an absence that makes the story all the more heartening.

title: Velarde Returns As Insurance
description: When Randy Velarde's name popped up on the waiver wire this week, Yankees officials never thought they would get a shot at him. They figured another team, like the Boston Red Sox, would place a claim on Velarde to block the Yankees from doing it. The Yankees' interest in Velarde, a veteran infielder with the Texas Rangers, had been reported for most of August after Scott Brosius broke his left hand.

title: Hamptons Restaurateur Killed When Car Hits Tree
description: The restaurateur who was the Nick in Nick & Toni's -- the summertime meeting place for the Hamptons' Hollywood set -- died early today when he drove his Volvo off a dark country road here, hitting a tree.

title: Paris and Provence
description: The company's name is Country Cottages, but a package that it is offering Oct. 1 to Nov. 27 includes two nights in a Left Bank hotel in Paris. The rest of the seven nights, however, are in the countryside, in a villa in Provence. Prices for two people sharing a one-bedroom villa start at $1,299 a person, with air fare from New York, Newark or Boston and a rental car in Provence. That can be cut to as little as $999 a person if eight persons share a four-bedroom villa. For two couples in a two-bedroom villa, it starts at $1,199 a person. The Paris hotel is the Holiday Inn St.-Germain, where daily breakfast and VAT are included. Transfer flights between Paris and Provence are $50 extra one way. Parties of six or more will get two rental cars. Information: (800) 674-8883 or www.villacentral.com .

title: PSC Eliminating 80 Jobs
description: PSC Inc. is eliminating 80 jobs, or 8.5 percent of its work force, as the slowing economy cools customer demand and as the company focuses on its main business, making bar-code scanners.

title: Little League Star Is 14, and Bronx Team Is Disqualified
description: Danny Almonte, the pride of the Bronx who pitched his Little League team into the World Series and into the hearts of millions of baseball fans this summer, was found yesterday to be 14 years old, not 12  a violation that invalidated all his team's victories this season and generated waves of dismay from the White House and City Hall to the sandlots of America.

title: Candidates Sound Out Core Republican Issues, as Well as Each Other
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate of the Republican candidates for mayor, as recorded by The New York Times. The debate was broadcast on radio station WNYC-AM (820) and was carried on www.wnyc.org. It was moderated by Brian Lehrer, host of WNYC's ''On the Line.''

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Auction Of Voting Machines
description: Palm Beach County officials have announced plans to auction up to 5,000 of the voting machines used in last November's presidential election. The county will offer ''memorabilia packages,'' to include a voting machine, the ''butterfly'' ballot, a certificate of authenticity and a signed photograph of the three-person county board responsible for overseeing the balloting. The county faces a state order to replace the machinery with modern, computerized equipment for future elections, which has a price tag of more than $15 million.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Higher Electric Rate
description: The Public Utilities Commission approved a request for a rate increase by Portland General Electric, the state's largest electric utility. The increases, effective Oct. 1, will raise residential rates by 26 percent and industrial rates by about 47 percent, the commission said. A residential customer using 1,000 kilowatt-hours per month will pay an additional $16. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Pressed by Media, China Accuses Mine Officials of Cover-Up
description: Eleven mine officials and four county political leaders have been arrested in connection with the deadly flooding last month of a tin mine in southern China and an attempt to cover up the disaster, government investigators said today.

title: Fed Is Trying to Determine How Assets Affect Spending
description: Hoping to get a better fix on how household wealth affects consumption, the Federal Reserve is trying to sort out the ways in which different assets -- stocks or homes, for example -- affect consumer spending, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said today.

title: U. of Alabama Delays Decision on Former CUNY Chancellor
description: The trustees of the University of Alabama system postponed a vote today on whether to keep W. Ann Reynolds as president of the system's Birmingham campus after an ardent outpouring of support by her defenders.

title: Bloomberg's Spending Is at $20 Million and Counting
description: The Republican Michael R. Bloomberg has passed the $20 million mark in his bid for City Hall, continuing to spend more than all of the mayoral candidates even as the four Democrats vying for their own party's nomination have accelerated their spending in recent weeks on television advertising, reports filed yesterday show.

title: As Leiter Pitches and Hits, Some Teammates Fret
description: Some Mets needed to get through last night to know if they would remain with the team or end up on a contender. The Mets, who have not been in the race for months, have hoped that contenders would take on Robin Ventura or Todd Zeile and their hefty contracts by midnight, the deadline to add players and have them be eligible for the postseason.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, NANCY GEORGETTE
description: PRINCE-Nancy Georgette. Age 60. Died on Tuesday, August 28, 2001 after a heroic fight with Leukemia. A longtime Manhattan and Westport CT. resident. Nancy is survived by her devoted friend and companion Pamela Perry, her loving family, sister Margot Rose and cousin Christine Jewel; and three beloved dogs, Buddy, Tyler and Hattie and many wonderful friends. A graduate of Boston University, she was an accomplished chef. Her parties always were enlivened by her irrepressible joie de vivre and panache. She was always open for a good laugh as well as a good meal. The family will receive friends Tuesday, September 4 from 5-8pm and Wednesday 6-9pm at Raymond Funeral Home, Norwalk, CT. 203847-7291. A memorial service will be held at 7:30pm on Wednesday, September 5. If anyone wishes, donations can be made in her memory to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Fairfield County, CT. Chapter, 25 Third Street, Stamford, CT. 06905

title: Cable TV Providers May Drop At Home's Internet Service
description: The At Home Corporation said today that the cable-television providers Cox Communications Inc. and the Comcast Corporation would stop selling its high-speed Internet service in June. The move may bring At Home a step closer to bankruptcy.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Tuesday about Bobby Sanabria, the leader of an Afro-Cuban jazz band, misstated the time of his band's performance tonight at the Chicago Jazz Festival, which will be broadcast live on about 100 radio stations. The performance begins at 6 p.m. Central Daylight Time, not Eastern Daylight Time. It can be heard in New York on WBGO-FM (88.3) starting at 7 p.m., not 6 p.m.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chancellor's Personal Journey
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder is to pay a private visit to his father's grave in western Romania, officials said. It was only this year that Mr. Schrder learned that his father, Fritz, was buried in a group grave in the village of Ceanu Mare. He died there while serving on the Eastern front for the German Army in October 1944. The trip will probably take place on Sept. 17 or 18. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULD, GOLDIE

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Nursing Home Study
description: Investor-owned nursing homes are almost 50 percent more likely than nonprofit homes to be cited for deficient quality in government inspections, a study in The American Journal of Public Health has found. Investor-owned homes also had fewer nurses and higher rates of severe quality problems, in which patients were harmed. Quality problems were especially acute at nursing-home chains, the study found. Almost two-thirds of American nursing homes are investor-owned, though tax dollars pay for more than four-fifths of all nursing home bills. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook column on Tuesday about an exhibition of works by the American abstract painter Clyfford Still at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington misstated the tenure of the museum's director, James T. Demetrion, for whom this is a farewell event. He became director in 1984; the founding director, who held the post from 1974 to 1984, was Abram Lerner.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Aid For Test Takers
description: Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift wants to help students who have trouble passing the state's high-stakes assessment tests, a requirement for graduation beginning in 2003. Her plan would give high school students who fail the Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System test grants of up to $1,000 to pay for private tutoring. On the 2000 exam, 45 percent of 10th graders failed the math portion of the test and 34 percent failed the English portion. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Talks On Food Deal
description: Ahold, a Dutch supermarket company, is negotiating to buy Alliant Foodservice for about $1.5 billion, with a deal possible as soon as next week, people close to the talks said. The acquisition would bolster Ahold's position as the second-largest food service in the United States, behind the Sysco Corporation. Ahold declined to comment, as did a spokesman for Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, the New York private equity firm that owns Alliant. The talks were reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Ethel Scull, a Patron of Pop and Minimal Art, Dies at 79
description: Ethel Redner Scull, who with her husband, Robert, achieved fame and social status in the 1960's by building one of the first major collections of Pop and Minimal art and becoming the subject of an Andy Warhol portrait, died on Monday at a retirement home in Manhattan. She was 79.

title: As Inconsistencies Pile Up, Paulino Denies All
description: Milagros Baez started noticing the Dominican youngster a few months ago while the boy was walking with Rolando Paulino and his wife, Carmen. Baez lived on the ground floor of their apartment building in the South Bronx, and she would watch as they passed through the dim lobby and into the elevators on their way to the 14th floor, where Paulino lived. The boy was tall and thin and quiet.

title: Bloomberg's Spending Surpasses $20 Million
description: Michael R. Bloomberg has passed the $20 million mark in his bid for City Hall, continuing to spend more than all of the mayoral candidates even as the four Democrats have accelerated their spending, reports filed yesterday show. But Mr. Bloomberg's opponent for the Republican nomination, Herman Badillo, got some good news: He appears to have raised enough to qualify for city matching funds.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: But Can You Find Bay Ridge?
description: In the streets of Brooklyn on Wednesday, not everybody knew who the courtly man was stretching out his hand to passers-by. But most people recognized the man with the red jacket and red beret by his side, Curtis Sliwa, the founder of the Guardian Angels, who talked at length with each person who claimed to be a registered Republican. ''Who are you voting for?'' he would ask. If he heard the name Michael R. Bloomberg, Mr. Badillo's rival, he would cover his face in mock horror. ''Were you born and raised here?'' he asked Florence Frost, 64. ''Well, Mr. Bloomberg couldn't find Bay Ridge on the map if his life depended on it.'' In fact, Mr. Bloomberg has been to Bay Ridge on several occasions, including a town meeting last week, his spokesman, Ed Skyler said yesterday. But Ms. Frost, who had been planning to vote for Mr. Bloomberg, didn't know that, and changed her mind. Mirta Ojito (NYT)

title: Fragile Calm Holds on Jerusalem's Edge
description: With an Israeli-Palestinian truce holding on Jerusalem's southern fringe today, diplomatic efforts were made to see if calm could be extended elsewhere to finally bring the conflict of the last year under control.

description: Afghanistan's ruling Taliban closed the offices of two Christian aid groups today, continuing a crackdown on workers accused of proselytizing.

description: A dehydrated James Blake had been hovering over a trash can during a fourth-set changeover and staggered through points with a rag doll's strength, all while Lleyton Hewitt continued to pump his arms and shout to the skies across the net.

It is in an 1896 school in East Poultney, not in the 1791 school.

A memorial service will be held at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Scarsdale, NY at 1PM September 4. Mrs. Dybing was a resident of Scarsdale all of her life, until her recent move to Rye, NY. title: The Over-Age Pitcher
description: On the surface, the Danny Almonte story looks like a collection of now-meaningless statistics  46 strikeouts and a perfect game in this year's Little League World Series, pitched by a 14-year-old boy playing illegally for a team from the Bronx against teams made up of 11- and 12-year-olds. Every one of his team's victories has been nullified, its third-place finish erased. What replaces those victories are painfully disturbing facts. Danny Almonte, it turns out, has not attended school since he came to this country 18 months ago. He may not have consistently attended school in the Dominican Republic, where he was born, and he and his father may be in the United States illegally. All Danny did, instead of going to school, was eat and play ball, his father admitted.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: AIDS Is Top Killer
description: Health Ministry officials said they had determined that AIDS is the leading cause of death in Thailand, accounting for 16 percent of all deaths in 1998 and surpassing accidents, high blood pressure and cancer. They said the finding did not necessarily reflect a rise in deaths but might be a result of improved monitoring. Nearly 1 million people in Thailand have been infected with the virus that causes AIDS and 300,000 have died. Thailand has 61 million people. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Forgiveness And Anger Over Plight Of a Pitcher
description: At the Frozen Ropes batting cages in New Rochelle, N.Y., Jamal Wright stood placidly outside one of the cages, balls thumping the canvas behind him, as he talked frankly about what he saw as the Big Betrayal.

title: Health Care Gap Has British Looking Abroad
description: Chris Davies, a 59-year-old businessman from the northern English city of Manchester, began suffering chest pains from a blocked artery in 1996, but, he said, when he sought surgery from Britain's state-run health service, he was told to wait. Three years later, he was still waiting.

title: Stephen Gorove, 83, Leader in Field of Space Law
description: Stephen Gorove, a jurist who was among the first to tackle the legal angles of the conquest of space, died on May 20 in Oxford, Miss., where he was a professor emeritus at the University of Mississippi. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBIN, SEYMOUR (''SKEE'')
description: TAUBIN-Seymour (''Skee''). On August 28, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Fanny. Loving father of Michael and his wife Robin. Cherished grandfather of Ian and Lance. Devoted brother of the late Debbie Herman. A founder and president of Trylon Realty, Inc. Graveside service Sunday, 11AM at Old Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to Lenox Hill Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Private Mass, Public Tribute for Singer
description: The funeral service for Aaliyah, the 22-year-old singer who died in a plane crash last Saturday, was closed to the public, but it did not matter, because, as is the way with pop stars, the real tribute was on the street.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: U.S. Not Satisfied
description: An American official said the United States would not resume full military ties with Indonesia until the killers of an American aid worker were properly punished. Carlos Caceres was among three United Nations workers hacked to death last September in a refugee camp in West Timor, a part of Indonesia. An Indonesian court sentenced six men to terms ranging from 10 to 20 months. The American official, James Kelly, assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific affairs, said that was inadequate. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: College Disorientation
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Choice column in the arts pages on Thursday that included remarks on Randall Hodgkinson's recordings of works by Rodger Sessions and Donald Martino for LP's in the 1980's that have now been reissued on a CD misidentified the pianist who plays Sessions's Sonata No. 3. He was Robert Helps, not Mr. Hodgkinson.

title: Denver Moves From Haze To a Clean-Air Milestone
description: Once known as one of the most polluted urban areas for its persistent brown cloud, Denver is about to become the first major city to achieve full compliance with the Clean Air Act by eliminating severe air pollution.

title: Not Shy on Mental Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurers Offering Pregnancy Benefits Now Must Cover Fertility
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed legislation today requiring insurance companies that offer pregnancy-related benefits to also provide coverage for a wide range of infertility treatments.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about a lawsuit filed against the fraternity Delta Kappa Epsilon by the parents of two students killed in a car crash after accepting a ride from a fraternity member who had been drinking misstated the college one of the students attended. The student, Emily Collins, attended Hobart and William Smith Colleges, not Colgate University. (The other student did attend Colgate.)

title: POLYONE, RUBBER COMPOUNDS MAKER, TO CLOSE PLANTS
description: The PolyOne Corporation, a maker of rubber compounds and chemicals, is closing three plants in the United States and Canada and eliminating at least 77 jobs. Plants in Tillsonburg, Ontario; Dyersburg, Tenn.; and Chicago will be closed by the middle of next year, the company said in a statement. The job cuts and shutdowns, which will cost $4.1 million, are in addition to at least eight plant closings and the reduction of 525 jobs announced by PolyOne in the last three months. The latest round of plant closings and job cuts are necessary because of weak demand for the company's rubber compounds used for automotive parts and construction materials, the company said. PolyOne is based in Cleveland.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with a front-page article on Thursday about an agreement to allow the Fish and Wildlife Service to act quickly to protect 29 species misspelled the name of one of the species. It is the Bonneville cutthroat trout, not Booneville.

title: Educators See No Layoffs From Cutting
description: Despite the warnings of significant disruptions in the school system, New York City school superintendents and union officials said yesterday that budget cuts ordered this week by Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy will not require layoffs and will not affect most day-to-day activities in regular classrooms.

title: Campaign Briefing | New Jersey Governor's Race: Ticked Off By Tolls
description: Bret D. Schundler, the Republican nominee for governor, is not expected to begin any major campaign advertising for another two or three weeks. But just in time for the Labor Day weekend traffic jams, a Washington advocacy group that supports lower taxes has purchased two billboards trumpeting Mr. Schundler's promise to remove tolls from the Garden State Parkway. The group, Club for Growth, said it spent $30,000 on the advertisements, which are not on the parkway but on roads in Irvington and Trenton. James E. McGreevey, the Democratic nominee for governor, and Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican, have described Mr. Schundler's proposal as unrealistic and fiscally unsound.

title: SOUTHTRUST TO BUY BANK OF TIDEWATER IN VIRGINIA
description: The SouthTrust Corporation will buy Bank of Tidewater for $67.8 million in stock to increase its presence in Virginia. SouthTrust will pay at least $28 a share for Bank of Tidewater, which is based in Virginia Beach. The price is a 15 percent premium to Thursday's closing price. SouthTrust, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., will exchange 1.0691 of its shares for each of the 2.42 million shares outstanding of Bank of Tidewater, which works out to $26.11 a share based on SouthTrust's closing price Thursday. To make up any shortfall, SouthTrust may convert the offer to all cash, or Bank of Tidewater may pay a special dividend, a SouthTrust spokesman, David Oliver, said. The transaction is scheduled to close in the fourth quarter.

title: Maker of Blood Substitute Says It Can Meet Supply Goals
description: Northfield Laboratories, which applied recently to the Food and Drug Administration for permission to market its blood substitute for use in trauma surgery, told investors yesterday that it would have no trouble meeting initial supply goals if its product is approved.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Survivors See Sunken Vessel
description: The Coast Guard showed videotape of a sunken fishing vessel to family members of 9 of the 15 fishermen who died aboard it in April. The ship, the Arctic Rose, sank without warning in the Bering Sea, killing all aboard. A remote-control vehicle obtained 45 minutes of videotape as it explored the wreck, which is 428 feet down. Part of the tape shows an open door connecting the processing area to the deck, which may have kept the ship from being watertight. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Industrial Slowdown
description: Industrial output declined in July for the second consecutive month, falling 5.9 percent from July 2000 and 1.4 percent from June, the National Statistics Office said. In percentage terms, the decline for July was more than double the 2.8 percent year-on-year decrease in June. The last time output fell for two consecutive months was September and October 1998, in the middle of a national economic crisis. The Korea Stock Exchange fell 3.1 percent, closing the month at 546.95, the lowest point since the last day of July. The Bank of Korea is expected to consider another cut in the interest rate next week. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: WORLD

title: Josef Fried, 87, Organic Chemist Noted for Tailored Compounds
description: Dr. Josef Fried, an organic chemist whose work with steroid hormones and other compounds was applied to pharmaceutical products, died on Aug. 17 in a retirement community in Chicago. He was 87.

title: Inconsistencies Pile Up But Paulino Denies All
description: Milagros Baez started noticing the Dominican youngster a few months ago while the boy was walking with Rolando Paulino and his wife, Carmen. Baez lived on the ground floor of their apartment building in the South Bronx, and she would watch as they passed through the dim lobby and into the elevators on their way to the 14th floor, where Paulino lived. The boy was tall and thin and quiet.

title: City Evaluates Providers at Group Homes
description: In an ongoing evaluation of its foster care system, the city released rankings yesterday of the agencies that run group homes for about 4,000 of the children who are in the custody of the city's Administration for Children's Services.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Answers, Complex And Confusing
description: There was more than a little confusion at a mayoral debate on Tuesday when the candidates were asked if they agreed with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's decision to boycott a racism conference because its agenda included some anti-Israel language. Mark Green endorsed Mr. Powell's decision. Alan G. Hevesi said initially that he thought the United States should attend, but latersaid he had misspoken because he did not know about the conference. Fernando Ferrer offered a murky response: ''The decision by Secretary of State Powell said the Bush administration, in fact, has been asleep at the switch, for example, on the Commission on Human Rights at the U.N., letting slave-trading nations like Sudan be in the driver's seat.'' What that meant, a spokesman said later, was that the administration should send someone to the conference -- and then denounce the policy. Peter F. Vallone promised that he would do whatever he could ''to understand how serious the problem of racism is.'' Mr. Vallone's spokesman admitted last night that Mr. Vallone, like Mr. Hevesi, did not know enough about the conference. ''Unlike Alan Hevesi, when Peter Vallone doesn't know something, he doesn't pretend he does,'' said the spokesman, Jordan Barowitz. Mr. Vallone agrees with Mr. Powell's decision, Mr. Barowitz said.

title: Joyce Gets a $1 Million Fund to Foster New Dances
description: A board member of the Joyce Theater has established a $1 million endowment for commissioning new dances.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRONSTEIN, MELVIN, MD.
description: BRONSTEIN-Melvin, MD. In rememberance of a devoted husband and loving father. Our thoughts remain with you always. We miss you dearly. Your loving wife and family

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Milosevic Loses Appeal
description: A Dutch district court rejected a claim by the ex-Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, who demanded to be freed from United Nations detention on the ground that the tribunal holding him on charges of genocide and other war crimes was illegal. The judge ruled that he had no jurisdiction. Dutch lawyers for Mr. Milosevic said they would appeal to a higher Dutch court and go to the European Court of Human Rights.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Americans Worked Longer Last Year Than in 1990

title: Woman Sentenced to Year in Prison for Stealing Debate Tape
description: A federal judge today sentenced a woman convicted of stealing practice materials for last fall's presidential debates to a year in prison, $3,000 in fines and three years on probation.

title: $10 Million to Give Away; The Big Question Is, How?
description: McDonald's is having a $10 million instant giveaway this weekend. But don't ask people at the restaurant counters about it. They might not have heard.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Unemployment Rises
description: France's unemployment rate edged up for the third consecutive month, to 8.9 percent in July from 8.8 percent in June. This brought the number of job seekers in France to 2.1 million, the labor ministry said. The news comes at a time when dozens of companies in Europe, including Alcatel and Danone, have announced plans to lay off thousands of workers. Job cuts are of particular concern to the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, above, who is expected to run for president against the incumbent, Jacques Chirac, next spring. In June, Mr. Jospin's government adopted legislation making it harder for companies to lay off workers. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Debating Down To The Wire
description: Next week, Democrats will be able to tune into the final pre-primary debates required of citywide candidates by the Campaign Finance Board. On Wednesday, the Democrats running for comptroller, Herbert E. Berman and William C. Thompson Jr., will square off at New York Law School at 7:30 p.m. The next night at 7:00 p.m., all seven Democrats vying for public advocate will face off at St. Francis College in Brooklyn. The comptroller's debate will be broadcast live on NY1 News and WNYC-AM (820); the public advocate's debate will air on WNYC radio. In the likely event of a runoff for public advocate, another debate is scheduled for the following Thursday at 7:30 p.m., to be broadcast on NY1 News and WNYC.

title: Massive Probe Begins Into Deadly Japan Blaze
description: TOKYO (Reuters) - More than 150 investigators began a probe into the devastating fire in a crowded Tokyo nightlife district that killed 44 people early on Saturday.

title: Lost Honor on Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Unilever Wants P.& G. Placed Under Monitor In Spy Case
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products company, has demanded that Procter & Gamble open itself to a third-party auditor to ensure that P.& G. does not act on information it obtained from corporate spies who took documents from trash bins, a Unilever spokesman said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULSKY, RUBIN
description: SHULSKY-Rubin. My beloved Daddy. We had a one of a kind journey together. I miss you and I will love you always. Take care of Mom and have a wonderful voyage. My love forever Rena

title: Troopers Seek to Question Judges on Discrimination
description: A lawyer for 13 black state troopers who have filed a job-discrimination lawsuit against New Jersey sought legal permission yesterday to question two state Supreme Court justices in hope of finding evidence to support the troopers' claims.

title: Saving Harlem's Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Master of the Mosaic That Is New York City; Expert Keeps Tabs on Changing Population
description: The chief demographer for New York City lives in Census Tract 274, a bucolic sliver of the Bronx next to Eastchester Bay, where an earlier generation of immigrants raised their children to believe that the sky was the limit but a good son stayed close to home.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: More Foot-And-Mouth Disease
description: With three new cases of foot and mouth disease detected in northeast England, the authorities said soldiers would again be used to dispose of carcasses of animals slain to combat the disease. The deployment, 30 soldiers, is smaller than earlier ones, but continued outbreaks of the highly contagious disease have defied officials' assertions that it is being wiped out. Since February, nearly 2,000 farms have been infected and almost 3.8 million sheep, cattle and pigs have been slaughtered. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Holiday on Monday; Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Top Hat and One Weird Cat
description: BELIEVE it or not, Christopher Walken, whose screen persona usually defines the phrase "unhinged wacko," is being compared lately to Fred Astaire. This is because Mr. Walken does some nifty, Astaire-esque hoofing in the video for Fatboy Slims "Weapon of Choice," which stands to clean up at the MTV Video Music Awards in New York on Thursday. Directed by Spike Jonze, the video leads all contenders with nine nominations, including one for best choreography.

title: Kicker Is Surprise for Jets, But They Could Have More
description: The Jets faced fourth-and-3 on Philadelphia's 41-yard line Thursday night when Coach Herman Edwards, pondering a punt with the first half about to end, called place-kicker John Hall to his side.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RISES. The yen rose on speculation that Japanese banks and other investors are pulling back funds from abroad to cover investment losses at home. In New York, the dollar settled at 118.80 yen, down from 119.47.

title: F.C.C. Disputes NextWave Plan
description: The plan by NextWave Telecom to reorganize and emerge from bankruptcy should be rejected because it lacks specific data on financing and the company's business model, the government said yesterday.

title: Schroders Ousts Chief as Funds Business Struggles
description: Schroders, a leading pension fund manager in Europe, ousted its chief executive today after big clients moved their accounts elsewhere and first-half profit plummeted by over two thirds. The move appeared unusually abrupt for a company like Schroders, which is family-controlled and likes to project a genteel upper-crust image.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Widow Seeks Husband's Seat
description: The widow of State Senator Pete Suazo has announced that she wants to fill the rest of her late husband's term. Mr. Suazo, 50, the Senate's only Latino Democrat, was killed in August in an all-terrain vehicle accident. His widow, Alicia Suazo, a 48-year-old elementary school teacher, has the support of Democratic Party leaders and will be the only name they submit to Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, a Republican. Mrs. Suazo said she wanted to carry on her husband's legacy by pushing forward hate-crimes legislation. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: White House Again Delays Reagan Files' Release
description: For the third time, the White House has delayed the release of thousands of documents from the Reagan presidency, including papers from senior advisers who serve in the current administration, officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about growing interest in New York City history misstated the name of an organization at the City University whose executive director, Joshua Brown, spoke of the need for a broader museum for New York history. It is the American Social History Project, not the American History Project.

title: Edward Rivera, 62, Writer and Teacher
description: Edward Rivera, the author of the autobiographical novel ''Family Installments: Memoirs of Growing Up Hispanic'' and an assistant professor at City College of New York, died on Aug. 25 in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 62.

title: Some Who Vote on Farm Subsidies Get Them as Well
description: At least five members of Congress who sit on the agriculture committees that are writing the new farm policy receive thousands of dollars in farm subsidies each year.

title: Back at His Old Haunt and Still Spooking the Red Sox
description: A few dozen fans pursued Roger Clemens when he breezed toward the press entrance at Fenway Park yesterday, but Clemens barely looked at them and claimed that he would sign their autographs on the field. Clemens might as well have told the fans to meet him by the batting cage for a photo session with Carl Everett. There was no time for Clemens to dabble with the same fans who would blister him verbally a few hours later. Not here. Not now.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PENTASTAR COMMUNICATIONS INC., Denver, a communications services provider, said it had received a waiver of defaults and a loan extension from Wells Fargo Bank West, San Francisco, and had begun a cost-reduction program to save it $2 million a year.

title: How Patients' Rights Became a Fight
description: When Congress reconvenes next Wednesday after a monthlong recess, preparations will begin for a conference of the House and the Senate to reconcile the differing versions of patients' rights legislation that they passed this summer. The negotiations are expected to be bitter and hard-fought, and it is unclear whether an agreement can be forged that will create a bill the president will sign.

title: 44 Die in Tokyo As Fire Sweeps Gambling Club
description: A fire swept through a crowded gambling club in Tokyo's busiest entertainment district early today, killing at least 44 people and injuring 3 others, the police said. It was the worst incident of its kind in Tokyo in two decades.

title: New Map Helps Democrats Tighten Grip on California
description: California's Legislature has proposed a new bipartisan map for the state's 53 Congressional districts that all but guarantees a big Democratic majority in the delegation for perhaps the next decade.

title: Officer Is Accused of Drunken Driving
description: A New York City Health and Hospitals police officer has been arrested on drunken driving charges after striking a pedestrian while headed the wrong direction on a one-way street, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALAWAY, JEFFREY H.
description: SALAWAY-Jeffrey H. Suddenly on August 31, 2001. Beloved husband of Toni. Devoted father of Sara and Noah. Cherished son of Agnes and the late Alexander. Dear brother of Marilyn Werner and Elizabeth Salaway. Loving nephew and dear friend to all. Services Sunday, Sept 2nd, 1:00 PM at the Jewish Center of East Hampton, 44 Woods Lane, East Hampton, NY. For additional information, call ''The Riverside,'' 212362-6600. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to the Hayground School, Bridgehampton, NY.

title: Staten Island Endorsements
description: For Borough President: Many New York City officeholders facing term limits are looking for ways to extend their influence. Some are trying to make sure that children, spouses or parents succeed them. Others are promoting protgs. Staten Island's borough president, Guy Molinari, is backing the candidacy of his deputy, James Molinaro, a top official of the state's Conservative Party. Mr. Molinaro is running for the Republican nomination against Assemblyman Robert Straniere.

title: Church, State and Joe Lieberman
description: President Bush once hoped that Congress would quickly pass his so-called faith-based initiative. The idea of providing federal subsidies for the charitable activities of religious groups was greeted enthusiastically when the White House first unveiled the plan. But now this seriously flawed legislation is in trouble. It lost support in July when it was rammed through the House in a manner that seemed offensively partisan. More recently, John DiIulio, the White House's chief adviser on the initiative, made a much-noted departure. Mr. DiIulio, a Democrat and an academic, said he wanted to spend more time with his family. But his sudden exit at this critical moment was a blow, since he gave the original proposal much of its credibility and bipartisan sheen. Ironically, it now falls to Mr. DiIulio's friend Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut to either rid the bill of its most dangerous provisions or shelve it.

title: A Faith-Based Effort to Save Ailing Marriages
description: An international gathering of Christian counselors here is undertaking an ambitious idea: reduce divorce among church members by training 100,000 married couples over the next five years to be ''marriage mentors'' for people getting married or working to keep their marriages going.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURELL, BROWN, RUTH
description: BURELL-BROWN-Ruth of Amagansett, N.Y. on August 30, 2001. Survived by Christopher Soldo, daughter-in-law Lisa Soldo, two grandchildren John and Carlile Soldo, all of Santa Barbara, CA. She was a realtor with Cook-Pony Farm Real Estate for 10 years in Amagansett. Funeral Sunday 4 PM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, East Hampton. Interment Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton. For info call Yardley & Pino Funeral Home 631-725-0251.

title: No Agreement Yet With Mexico On Immigration Plan, U.S. Says
description: After months of extensive negotiations, the White House was forced to acknowledge today that it would not reach a comprehensive new agreement with Mexico on immigration next week when President Bush meets with President Vicente Fox.

title: Star Is 14, So Bronx Team Is Disqualified
description: Danny Almonte, the pride of the Bronx who pitched his Little League team into the World Series and into the hearts of millions of baseball fans this summer, was found yesterday to be 14 years old, not 12 -- a violation that invalidated all his team's victories this season and generated waves of dismay from the White House and City Hall to the sandlots of America.

title: Self-Interest vs. Altruism: Labor's High Wire Act
description: Q. Has the whole idea of Labor Day and Labor Day parades become obsolete?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERICK, HAROLD
description: AVERICK-Harold. The Officers, Directors and members of The 100 Club regret the passing of our esteemed member, Harold Averick. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Gavin Grusd, President

title: Court in Iran Detains Filmmaker On Charges of Political Crimes
description: A hard-line court today announced serious charges against a feminist filmmaker arrested on Monday, accusing her of supporting counterrevolutionary groups.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New White House Web Site
description: The White House unveiled a new Web site today, offering a Spanish-language section, better access for disabled users and an area for children, who can learn about the first family's pets while studying history and current events. The designers of the Web site tried to make navigation easier, with quick home-page access to major areas of the site, a more powerful search engine and other technical modifications. The address, www.whitehouse.gov, is unchanged. David Stout (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: More Hours on the Job

title: Yanks Force Red Sox to Confront a History Lesson
description: Joe Kerrigan manages from the left corner of the Red Sox dugout, about the same spot where Boston managers stood in 1986 and 1978, 1967 and 1949. Kerrigan strongly believed in a decision in the eighth inning of tonight's game against the Yankees, the way Red Sox managers believed in their decisions in 1986 and 1978, 1967 and 1949.

title: Hevesi on the Defensive
description: The accusation in 1993 was blunt: Alan G. Hevesi, a candidate for city comptroller, was beholden to the bus companies that made millions of dollars in no-bid contracts each year for ferrying disabled children to and from preschool. But soon after taking office the next year, Mr. Hevesi silenced the charge by declaring that the lucrative contracts should be bid on competitively, putting some of his old donors out of business.

title: New Haven's Transition
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTOR WANTS CHANGES AT AMERICAN MEDICAL SECURITY
description: Caxton Associates, a leading investor in American Medical Security Group, has called for the company to be sold or undergo a change in management, a regulatory filing said. Caxton, based in New York and controlled by the investor Bruce Kovner, owns 5.8 percent of the company's shares. In the filing, Mr. Kovner called the shares undervalued, saying that company efforts to lift the stock price ''have been insufficient as it is believed that they may take too long to positively impact share value.'' Mr. Kovner made the comments in a Schedule 13D filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of the South African anti-apartheid leader Govan Mbeki misspelled the name of another leading opponent of apartheid. He is Walter Sisulu, not Sissulu.

title: Canada Warms to Wal-Mart; From U.S. Invader to Part of the Landscape in 7 Years
description: Maureen Donovan of Onoway, Alberta, warmed the hearts of Wal-Mart executives last month: she was the 50th Canadian to send in a petition begging the mass retailer to open a store nearby.

title: The Sacred Lotus Merely Looks Fragile
description: I FELL under the spell of the water lotus two weeks ago, on a visit to Chanticleer, a lavish public garden in Wayne, Pa., west of Philadelphia. I could see them from the top of a hill, their great blue-green leaves held aloft like parasols. The blossoms, pinkish white and pale yellow, were huge saucers of blowsy petals, like peonies. One big bud, as heavy as a melon, rested its head on top of a two-foot leaf.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: PALESTINIANS GIVE U.N. RACISM TALKS A MIXED MESSAGE
description: Yasir Arafat denounced Israel as a racist colonial power at a United Nations conference on intolerance tonight, just hours after one of his senior aides announced that the Palestinians would reject a proposed declaration that labeled Israel a racist state.

title: Yale's China Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Play or Defend? Declarer Made It, but Should He?
description: A familiar challenge for serious players is: ''Would you rather play or defend?'' Study the diagramed deal and decide which choice you would make in four hearts after the lead of the diamond ten.

title: PRIMESOURCE IN DEAL TO BE BOUGHT BY FUJI PHOTO FILM
description: The PrimeSource Corporation, a distributor of printing supplies, is in talks to be bought by the Fuji Photo Film Company for $63.6 million, 79 percent more than the company's market value, based on Thursday's closing price. Fuji approved the $10-a-share cash offer yesterday. Approval from the board of PrimeSource is needed before a tender offer will begin, PrimeSource, based in Pennsauken, N.J., said in a statement. PrimeSource shares rose $4.18, to $9.78. They had risen 36 percent in the last year.

title: Officials Look Into Whether Cadets Were Influenced on Abortion
description: The District of Columbia Fire Department has begun an internal investigation into whether agency officials influenced some employees to have abortions.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Airline Strike
description: Pilots at Sabena are planning a full-day strike on Thursday to protest management's refusal to accept a seniority plan, the Belgian Cockpit Association said. The pilots object to a decision by the chief executive, Christoph Mueller, to scrap a promotion plan under which pilots progress to fly bigger aircraft and earn higher pay, said Joel Gans, the association's vice president.

title: Japan's Electronics Slump Takes a Toll on Southeast Asia
description: Lean times for Japan's electronics giants used to mean good tidings for Southeast Asia. Often, they foreshadowed the opening of a Japanese factory somewhere in Malaysia, say, or perhaps the Philippines.

title: A Down-to-Earth Solution to Airport Gridlock
description: Air traffic delays have reached epidemic proportions. With jets coming into airports every few minutes -- at La Guardia, it's one every 110 seconds -- the slightest hiccup in the system sends air traffic controllers to Plan B: Hold everything.

title: WESTVACO TO TAKE $26 MILLION PRETAX CHARGE
description: The Westvaco Corporation, which agreed Wednesday to merge with the Mead Corporation, will take a $26 million pretax charge in its fiscal fourth quarter to close a paper mill in Tyrone, Pa., that employs 265 workers. Production will be moved to other manufacturing sites in Luke, Md., and Wickliffe, Ky., by October, the company said in a statement. Westvaco has about 17,000 employees. The rival paper makers are merging in a $3.26 billion transaction to reduce expenses and better manage production as demand and prices decline.

title: At Least the Giants Have Their Health
description: It was never billed as a rematch of Super Bowl XXXV, which is a good thing for the Giants. Given a second shot at the Baltimore Ravens, albeit in the preseason, the Giants lost by more points today than they did seven months ago.

title: Little League Star Is 14, and Bronx Team Is Disqualified

title: The Rebate Helps. Do It Again.
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Pooch Politics
description: If the mayoral candidates seem so alike that your head spins and you find yourself talking about Alan Vallone or Peter Ferrer, an anesthesiologist from the Upper West Side has some advice: think like a dog. Dr. Jeffrey Zahn, a founder of Nycdog, has helped put together a guide for voters based on candidates' views on things like off-leash recreation, crowded dog runs and money for bigger parks. The ''Paws Ranking'' of the candidates has been posted at www.nycdog.org. Two candidates (the real Vallone and Ferrer) got a perfect four paws, while three are in the doghouse for not responding to the questionnaire.

title: Republican Rivals Debate
description: Herman Badillo and Michael R. Bloomberg played up their different backgrounds while defending their party credentials at their first debate yesterday. Page B1.

title: Bayer Said to Have Pact to Buy CropScience for About $5 Billion
description: Bayer A.G., the German chemical and pharmaceutical company, has reached a tentative agreement to buy CropScience, an agricultural chemicals business, from Aventis for roughly $5 billion, people close to the discussions said today. Bayer would also assume some $1.7 billion in debt.

title: Conducting an Appraisal
The Hamptons It's Not
Heir to a Cuban Exile Leader Is Finding His Own Voice
description: On the day that Jorge Mas Santos buried his father four years ago, he vowed that his voice as an iconic leader of the Cuban exiles would not die with him.

title: Betty Boyle, Mark Duke

title: STYLE; Scraping the Bottom
description: The phrase ''classic modern'' may seem like an oxymoron, but it perfectly characterized the philosophy of T.H. Robsjohn-Gibbings. The British-born designer and author who moved here in 1929 became both a champion of contemporary American design and one of its sharpest critics. In two books -- Goodbye, Mr. Chippendale'' (1944) and ''Homes of the Brave'' (1954) -- Gibby, as he was known, skewered America's design pretensions from our obsession with antiques to Bauhaus modern, which left him cold. For clients like Doris Duke, he designed comfortable interiors with clean lines. But his love of modernity was always rooted in the past -- specifically in the Greek furniture that he first saw on some ancient pottery and reproduced in chairs and tables that are still in production. To Robsjohn-Gibbings, who died in 1976, the proliferation of oh-so-low furniture would be yesterday's news. He lampooned it 47 years ago in this excerpt from ''Homes of the Brave.'' Pilar Viladas

title: Credible Threat
description: When my pager sounded last October, I had enough time to grab an overnight bag and run. We had just been deployed to Yemen in the aftermath of the U.S.S. Cole bombing. As we climbed aboard a massive C-5 military transport plane, I left a message on our answering machine. ''This might take a couple weeks,'' I told my wife. ''Watch the news, and tell the kids I love them.''

title: Separate and Unequal on the West Bank
description: From my living room window in Ramallah, a Palestinian city, I see the lights of the Israeli settlement Pesagot on the opposite mountain. Across the eastern road of my neighborhood, there is an Israeli military base, protecting another settlement, Beit El. Had I wanted, as an Israeli Jew, born in West Jerusalem, I could have moved at any moment to any of these settlements. My Palestinian next-door neighbors in Ramallah, whose grandparents were born in what is now Israel, could not even think of moving to, say, Tel Aviv.

title: A Sculptor Displays His Art Till the Cows Come Home
description: Most Park Slope residents would not recognize Mark Ravitz's name. But they almost certainly have seen his artwork. It is hard not to. Since 1980, Mr. Ravitz has displayed large and often abstract sculptures he calls ''drips'' from the windows of his building on Seventh Avenue near Second Street.

title: A House's Walls Tell Tales of 200 Years of a Family's Fortunes
description: Marlpit Hall in Middletown Township, built in 1756, is an unusually long house that opens onto a side yard rather than onto Kings Highway. The Taylor family owned the property until the mid-1930's when a Monmouth County woman, Margaret Haskell, purchased and restored the property for the Monmouth County Historical Association. The association has spent the past eight years making structural repairs and restoring the interior to the way it looked when it was first built. The house reopened to the public last month and a grand opening celebration is scheduled for Sept. 16. The house is open on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays from 1 to 4 p.m. and on Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Lee Ellen Griffith, director of the Monmouth County Historical Association, talked recently about the house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, GALA MARA
description: GREENBERG-Gala Mara. Died September 1, 2001, after a valiant battle against angio sarcoma. Gale was 52 years old, she was a resident of South Florida for the past 25 years. Gale was born in New York City and raised in Roslyn Heights, Long Island where she graduated from the Wheatley School in 1966. She received her Bachelor of Arts with honors from the University of Wisconsin in Madison in 1971 and her Juris Doctor from the San Fernando Valley College of Law in 1978. Gale received her Masters in Social Work from Barry University in South Florida and was a doctoral candidate at Florida International University School of social work. Gale was deeply devoted to her family as well as her clients and friends. Throughout her illness she continued to demonstrate commitment and courage that was an inspiration to all who knew her. She traveled throughout the world with her family and shared wonderful memories that will always be remembered in our hearts. Her patients, students, colleagues and friends will miss her dearly. Gale Greenberg is survived by her mother and step father, Rozlyn and Sy Sadkin, her father; Mersh Greenberg, her sisters; Joy, Jill and Bonnie, her step sister; Donna, her nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, cousins and brothers-in-law. She will be missed deeply and will be remembered forever with love!!! In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the American Cancer Society. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, September 2, 2001 at 1 pm at Star of David Memorial Chapel with interment to follow at Star of David Memorial Gardens, 7701 Bailey Road, N. Lauderdale, Florida. (954) 722-9000.

title: On the Silk Road
description: To the Editor: I would like to add to the answer to C. Coleman Fisher's question in Q & A (''Along the Silk Road,'' July 22). I took a Silk Road tour last year with TCS Expeditions in Seattle, (800) 727-7477, fax (206) 727-7309. The trip is by private train, from Beijing to Moscow or the reverse, depending on the date. The Chinese portion of the trip is on the China Orient Express; the portion through the former Soviet Republics and Russia is on the Nostalgic Istanbul Orient Express, made up of vintage Orient Express carriages.

Her own love life, however, has been quiet since her husband died of AIDS a decade ago. They had met in school, married and had two sons. She is H.I.V. positive and has been alone since.

description: IN 1970, during a trip to England, Mary Elizabeth Combe came across a product called ''Fresh Sox.'' Though she didn't work at the company her husband, Ivan, had founded, she knew enough about the family business to be intrigued. She bought a pair, setting in motion the development of Odor-Eaters, which today earns the company close to $18 million annually.

title: Aug. 26-Sept. 1; Suit Over Nigerian Drug Trial
description: In the first American lawsuit seeking damages for an unethical overseas drug trial, 30 Nigerian families sued Pfizer in Manhattan's Federal District Court for treating their children with an experimental antibiotic during a 1996 meningitis epidemic in Kano, Nigeria, that took more than 15,000 lives. The families charge that Pfizer never told them the drug, Trovan, was experimental, or got their informed consent -- and that the study was never approved by any ethics committee. Of the 200 children in Pfizer's test, 11 died and others were left with partial paralysis, deafness or brain damage. Tamar Lewin

title: Bronx Team's Leader Had Prior Violations

The accusations against Mr. Paulino, whose team was later disqualified because its star pitcher was too old, were overlooked because of miscommunication, the official said.

title: Fans' Notes
description: WHEN it comes to criticism, H. L. Mencken wrote, there's only one way to tell the first-rate talents from the drones: ''They could make the thing charming, and that is always a million times more important than making it true.'' I've been unable to get Mencken's words out of my head this summer, and I've got Chuck Klosterman to blame. Klosterman is a young writer in Akron, Ohio -- he looks clean and wholesome, like one of the Waltons -- who has written a memoir called ''Fargo Rock City: A Heavy Metal Odyssey in Rural Nrth Dakta.'' It's easily the most implausible (and the most comically agile) piece of wildcat criticism I've come across in years.

title: Robin van Orman and Norberto Azqueta
description: GROWING up, Robin van Orman spent summers in Glacier National Park in Montana, in a rustic lodge built by her great-grandfather, Burton Kendall Wheeler, a United States senator from 1923 to 1947, a friend of the Blackfoot tribe and a man who believed children should begin the day with chores.

Their wives, Virginia and Ellen, sat down near them. Their teenage boys, between hanging out on the deck and going parasailing, briefly joined the adults at the table for sandwiches.

title: Jonathan Franzen's Big Book
description: Some days, Jonathan Franzen wrote in the dark. He did so in a spartan studio on 125th Street in East Harlem, behind soundproof walls and a window of double-paned glass. The blinds were drawn. The lights were off. And Franzen, hunched over his keyboard in a scavenged swivel chair held together with duct tape, wore earplugs, earmuffs and a blindfold. ''You can always find the 'home' keys on your computer,'' he says in an embarrassed whisper, explaining how he managed to type under such constraints. ''They have little raised bumps.''

Then, six years ago, this affable, youthful-looking Parisian decided to try his luck behind the camera. Not quite out of the blue, he became a movie director.

title: The Cat That Curiosity Can Never Kill
description: Since the 1980's, Amy Tan has spun tales from the cultural obstacles between Chinese women and their American-born daughters in novels like ''The Joy Luck Club'' and ''The Kitchen God's Wife.'' In the early 90's, she found inspiration in a female even closer to home: Sagwa, her 17-year-old Chinese Siamese cat (top right, with Ms. Tan).

title: Mouthing Off

''Eight Lipsticks,'' a small but powerful pastel by Wayne Thiebaud, set me to dreaming about all the lipsticks I had owned in my lifetime. Placed end to end, they would reach the moon, or at least Poughkeepsie.

title: The Way We Live Now: 09-02-01: The ethicist; Kiddie Scam
description: An old friend has fallen on hard times. She, her husband and three young children are on food stamps and a state-financed health plan. To help out, my husband and I hired her husband to paint our house. In the middle of the job, she said they wrote on an insurance form that we pay him $200 a week. In reality, it is much more. An official will call us to verify the figure. If we tell the truth, they will lose their insurance, so we intend to lie. How unethical are we? Anonymous, Portland, Ore.

It will also include a flotilla of six sailboats that left Quebec last month and has been stopping along the Hudson; the boats are scheduled to arrive in Manhattan Sept. 13.

However crestfallen Henman, the clean-cut Brit, was after Goran Ivanisevic hitched a ride on destiny through three days of rain delays in the Wimbledon semifinal, Henman snapped back like elastic.

title: Old Time Music Jam in Princeton
description: Thanks to the hit film ''O, Brother Where Art Thou,'' there has been a huge resurgence of interest in bluegrass and traditional country music filled with sweet harmonies and masterful picking. The Piper's Pub is hosting an Old Time Music Jam, which basically means folks will show up with their guitars, fiddles, Dobros, acoustic basses and mandolins, and try to keep this interest in real Americana from being a passing phase. The jam will take place at 7:30 p.m. Tuesday, at the Piper's Pub, Route 206, Princeton. And it's free. Robbie Woliver

description: Her weekends start on Monday, now that she has left her job. The thought of what she threw away makes her tense and her tiny feet, hanging over the bar stool, clench into claws.

title: She Straddles the Line Between Jazz and Cabaret
description: CONNOISSEURS of popular singing live to quarrel -- some of them seem to like it better than listening to music -- but most would probably agree that Ella Fitzgerald was a jazz singer and Bobby Short isn't. Between these two extremes, however, lies plenty of room for doubt, confusion and even creative ambivalence. ''I've always said that I'm a hybrid,'' said Mary Foster Conklin, a highly creative singer whose style blends cabaret and jazz so thoroughly as to defy any kind of easy categorization. ''I like to surround myself with jazz musicians -- but ones who know the lyrics. I like to be able to jump the fence and borrow from both camps.''

title: Ideas & Trends; Road Culture Literacy Test
description: The open road has long been an invigorating muse for American writers, musicians and screenwriters. Test your knowledge of road culture by matching the quotes to the appropriate source.

title: The Way We Live Now: 09-02-01: Gallery; Off-Court Singles
description: On courts around the world, the women on the pro tour are stars of a traveling stage production. Once the lights flick on and fans have packed the stands, glamorous players like Venus Williams stride out as if the court were a catwalk and then turn their femme facade upside down with vicious shots that crash-land in all corners of the court. Once a match ends, the players shake one another's hands before slipping off into the isolation of endless downtime that is rarely seen by their adoring fans. With the competition between players -- and the jealousy that exists on tour -- there is very little girl talk in the back halls.

title: As Travel Budgets Fall, So Do Comfort Levels
description: Out-of-town meetings and conventions are an integral part of doing business. So what happens when a company must cut its travel budget? Often, employees still are allowed to go, but their trips may not be very comfortable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALAWAY, JEFFREY H.

In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to the Hayground School, Bridgehampton, New York.

Adored grandmother of Cathy and Jon Fiebach, Lynn M. Sherman, Danny and Kirstin Stiebel and Susan and Les Morgenstein. Dear great-grandmother of Charles, Joshua, Aidan, James and Matthew. description: De MARIA-Nicholas. Died peacefully on August 31, 2001. Beloved father of Deborah Zboyan. Memorial service to be announced.

title: With a Racer's Foot On the Accelerator
description: ON a recent sticky afternoon, undaunted by a broken elevator and five flights of stairs, Sarah Skaggs cheerfully led the way to her beloved rehearsal space in a residential Canal Street loft. Even she admits that the studio is irritatingly narrow and deep, but truth is, the layout hardly matters. More than just a rehearsal space, the SoHo studio serves as a haven, where she has created her brisk, complex dances for conventional theaters as well as for parks and gymnasiums for more than 15 years. And the twin bed in the corner, she insisted, is not a nuisance but further evidence of the loft's charm.

title: Sports of The Times; U.S. Squanders Home Game That Wasn't
description: THEY marched into the stadium brazenly waving their arms to stoke up their fans. The players could tell they had a following by the blue-and-white Honduran banners flapping all over the stadium.

title: Science Fiction
description: In his quiet way, Robert Charles Wilson has produced one of the most impressive bodies of work in contemporary science fiction. His best novels, like ''The Divide'' and ''The Harvest,'' reimagine such standard themes as poor-lonely-superman and aliens-bearing-gifts in narratives that are both literate and suspenseful. Even when he misses the mark, as in the overheated ''Darwinia,'' he is worth reading for his sympathetic portraits of reasonable men and women confronting an untidy reality.

title: Laura Keyes, Patrick Ellsworth
description: Laura Elizabeth Keyes and Michael Patrick Ellsworth were married yesterday by the bridegroom's father, a probate judge for Eastford and Chaplin, Conn., at the bridegroom's parents' home in Eastford. The Rev. James Edward Link, a United Church of Christ minister and a cousin of the bride, also participated in the ceremony.

title: Haunted by Mold
description: Lisa Belkin (Aug. 12) illuminated what may be the health crisis of the decade. She focused on residential molds, but we must not overlook the workplace. Aging structures, neglected ventilation systems and soiled carpets support the growth of molds.

title: Private Sector; Now You Have It, Now You Don't
description: Michael A. Grimaldi, a vice president at General Motors, experienced every golfer's dream last weekend: he scored a hole in one. It happened in a charity golf tournament in Lake Orion, Mich. -- on the 18th hole, no less. Even better was the prize for anyone who aced a hole at the event: $1 million.

title: ATTACKING WEST NILE
description: Four Bergen County towns will be sprayed with the pesticide Scourge beginning this week to combat the mosquito-borne West Nile virus. State health officials said last week that a 72-year-old Bergenfield woman had contracted the disease, the first confirmed case in New Jersey this year. Ground spraying is planned in Bergenfield and three neighboring towns, Dumont, Cresskill and Tenafly, from 3 a.m. to 6 a.m. on Thursday and then again on Sept. 11.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Frank and Mike DeMaio; Diamonds in the Rough
description: THE DeMaio twins say, ''And then I got in a fight'' the way someone else might say, ''And then I met this beautiful girl.'' It's a happy recollection for them. They turned 34 last week and have been bouncing since they were 18.

The law was needed because ''advances in technology have given stalkers new tools to reach their victims,'' said Norman M. Robertson, a Republican from Clifton and one of the bill's sponsors.

title: CLASSROOM EXODUS?
description: Almost half of New Jersey's new teachers say that while they plan to remain in the field of education, they do not intend to stay in the classroom, according to a study made public last week by the Harvard Graduate School of Education. The study also showed that 46 percent of New Jersey's new teachers have had other careers first. In the group that chose teaching as a first career, 93 percent said they expected to stay in education. But 43 percent said they eventually wanted to be promoted into positions such as curriculum development or administration. The study comes at a time when many of the state's districts are struggling to find teachers for math, science and Spanish, along with certified pre-school teachers and substitutes. Debra Nussbaum

Mr. Coles was a retired Commodities Broker, a member of the Sugar and Coffee Exchange and the Yale Club of 1944. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. Surviving are his sons, Richard Coles of New York, NY and David Coles of Philadelphia, PA; daughters, Karen Turell of Boston, MA, Cindy Magnuski of Harrisburg, PA and Kim Coles of Brunswick, ME; companion, Jesse Czech of Vero Beach, FL and 15 grandchildren. title: See the Board, Dent the Wall

This season, there's help, in the form of several new children's eyeglass lines by Sesame Street, Stride Rite and Carrots. Made of lightweight, flexible plastic or titanium, with spring hinges, the newest specs are designed to take a licking and keep on, well, just keep on. In an at-home test, a pair of Sesame Street frames and a pair of Sand Dollars ($69.95 to $119.95 at all For Eyes stores) were stepped on, rolled over with a tricycle and thrown against a wall, with no visible damage -- save for a small nick in the wall.
