title: Aug. 26-Sept. 1; Endangered Species Action
description: The government made an unusual arrangement with some of the most litigious environmental groups in the country. The Fish and Wildlife Service agreed to take immediate action to protect 29 imperiled plants and animals, while environmental groups agreed to give the service more time to comply with court orders won in earlier suits. This means that instead of spending $588,000 on complying with the court orders, the service can use it to protect species like the Tumbling Creek cave snail, now found in just one cave in Missouri, and the Mississippi gopher frog, once prevalent across the Deep South but now found only in a single pond in Harrison County, Miss. title: WORLD FOOTBALL CHAMPIONS

The boys from the Camden County town won the national championships in December in Orlando, Fla., and went on to Berlin to represent the United States in the National Football League-sanctioned event. They went 6-0 against teams from Asia, Australia, Europe and Canada. This version of flag football is played with five on a side on a 60-yard field. The league is hoping it will help other countries learn about, and then follow, American football.

I am sure I speak for many investors like myself who lost a small fortune believing in the advertising and integrity of this man. What is puzzling is how easily we as a nation allow our pockets to be picked all over again.

title: Grand Illusions
description: Trompe l'oeil painting on a small scale may serve as mere decorative detail for interiors, but when it's done on a monumental scale and united with exterior architecture, a reinterpretation of the urban landscape emerges. For the past 25 years, Richard Haas has used trompe l'oeil, the art of illusionary painting, as a means of commenting on architecture and urban history in cities across the country. In THE CITY IS MY CANVAS (Prestel, $39.95), Haas presents his architectural murals, including before-and-after photographs of the spaces he has transformed. Haas's interest in murals grew from his making drypoint etchings of architecture and small diorama boxes of street scenes of his SoHo neighborhood. His use of trompe l'oeil to recreate the facades or even the shadows of long-gone buildings remind the viewer of both present and past, thus inviting contemplation of urban change. ''It was my hope,'' Haas writes, ''that, once thus engaged, the viewer might seek other layers of meaning and be able to read the larger story told by the artwork.'' It is this illusion that captures us, and when the trick is revealed, Haas has already compelled us to see our cities in a different way. M. Cameron Arnold

title: What Beijing Can Learn From Moscow
description: Just how much the world has changed, at least on the surface, becomes clear to me somewhere above Irkutsk, on board an Air China flight from Beijing to Moscow. My fellow passengers are mostly Chinese with a scattering of Russians. The in-flight entertainment consists of contemporary Chinese soap operas and old movies about revolutionary heroes battling various fascist enemies. But above Irkutsk we are provided with a History Channel documentary about the superiority of United States Navy destroyers. Phrases like ''fighting for freedom'' and ''the American spirit'' come gushing through our headphones as Navy helicopters release torpedoes and the guns of freedom boom. I look around to gauge Russian and Chinese reactions. Most people are fast asleep.

title: 'Frantz Fanon'
description: Early in May 1962, a French journalist working for the daily Le Monde arrived in Ghardimao, a small Tunisian town only a few kilometres from the border with Algeria. Once a French military base, Ghardimao was now the headquarters of the Algerian Armée de Libération Nationale (ALN) (National Liberation Army) and the situation there was tense. Two photographs decorated the otherwise bleak walls of the political commissariat. They were of Fidel Castro and Frantz Fanon. In the last week of June, Paris-Presse ’s Jean-François Khan also travelled to Ghardimao to report on the situation there. He too saw a photograph on the wall. It was of Frantz Fanon, ‘the pamphleteer from Martinique’. Algeria’s long war of independence was virtually at an end; the Evian agreements had been signed by the French government and the Gouvernement Provisoire de la République Algérienne (GPRA) (Provisional Government of the Algerian Republic) on 18 March and a ceasefire had come into effect the following day. Relations between Algeria’s ‘forces of the interior’ and the ‘frontier army’ penned behind the Morice Line of electrified wire entanglements, floodlights and minefields, had long been strained and were now almost at breaking point. Tensions between the GPRA, headed by Ahmed Ben Bella, and Colonel Houari Boumédienné’s ALN were also dangerously high. Khan was convinced that a coup led by Boumédienne was in the offing. He was both right and wrong; Boumédienne’s Armée Nationale Populaire entered Algiers in triumph on 9 September 1962, but the coup against Ben Bella did not occur until 1965. Boumédienne remained in power until his death in December 1978; Ben Bella remained in detention until 30 October 1980. He then spent ten years in exile, returning to Algeria only in September 1990.

description: While people of all stripes read your article about gay and lesbian ''rainbow families'' at Cherry Grove [Aug. 26], another set of rainbow families was celebrating in that other Long Island beach resort: the Hamptons. The first annual Rainbow Family Day was held by the East End Gay Organization in East Hampton at the site where the Boy Scouts hold their annual campout. It's good to know that families of all kinds can enjoy the beauty Long Island has to offer in gay enclaves like Cherry Grove and at not-so-gay-friendly campgrounds used by the discriminatory Boy Scouts.

title: More on Cuba
description: To the Editor: I just read Marian Burros's article on Cuba. One of the most amazing omissions in the article is the fact that Cubans who live in the island cannot eat in those paladares in private homes, nor in any government-run restaurant. This inhuman tourist apartheid has been created in Cuba so natives cannot mix with tourists, and it is a shameful situation.

title: Cynthia George, Jonathan O'Hara
description: Cynthia J George, a daughter of Davis M. George of Babylon, N.Y., was married on Friday to Jonathan Simon O'Hara, the son of Kathleen and John O'Hara of London. The Rev. David Addison performed the Anglican ceremony at St. Peter's Church in Clearwell, England.

title: Separation Anxiety
description: I PULL into my driveway on a dark Sunday evening after driving my two kids 40 miles to where they live with their mother and her husband. The headlights spot a football lying motionless in the yard, from when my son and I had been playing earlier in the sunlight. That seems long ago now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, LORRAINE
description: BERKOWITZ-Lorraine. Of Hampton Bays, N.Y. and Sarasota, FL. Passed away suddenly on Friday morning, August 31, 2001 at Southampton Hospital at the age of 69. Lorraine was a New York City school teacher for 25 years and a long-time resident of Flushing, N.Y. She is survived by her husband Seymour, children Lynn, Ted and her late son, Michael, her daughters-in-law Jo and Lisa, sonin-law Brad, grandchildren Sara, Sam, Greg and Alana, brother Murray and wife Millicent, sister Shirley and husband Leo as well as many nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends in New York and Florida. Lorraine loved to dance, enjoyed reading and traveling, had many interests including a love for Judiasm and family. Services Sunday 1PM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. Donations may be made to the Michael Berkowitz Lung Cancer Research Fund, Beth Israel Hospital, NYC, 212-387-6800.

title: Handcuffed By History
description: The shotgun blast that struck Lillie Belle Allen in the chest was so powerful that it blew her out of her sneakers. While she lay half-dead beside her family's Cadillac, a group of about a dozen young men fired more than 100 rounds at the car. Allen's sister, brother-in-law and parents remained trapped inside. ''So many pings, so many booms -- oh, God!'' the sister, Hattie Dickson, would recall many years later. ''We asked Jesus to come and help us.''

title: Where Indian Art Goes Up and Down With the Market
description: AT a time when the world's cultural borders are becoming increasingly fluid, artists are finding they no longer have to depend on a single market for reputations and livelihoods. Filmmakers can seek distribution at festivals in Cannes, Venice and Berlin. Contemporary artists can waltz through the global biennial circuit. But for American Indian art, there is only Indian Market.

title: Son of Wallpaper
description: WALLPAPER, the British design and lifestyle magazine that in its five years has come to define a generation of peripatetic hipsters, is now trying to dress those young hyperconsumers through a new fashion offshoot, Spruce.

title: 'The Currymooners'? 'I Love Indira'? It Needs Something
description: THE SETTING -- An S.R.O. crowd at the Indo Center of Art and Culture on West 25th Street near 10th Avenue. Most audience members are Indian-American, young, well dressed and ready to laugh at jokes about the clash between first- and second-generation Asian immigrants. They are here to see 10 actors do a reading of an episode of ''New York Spice,'' a would-be television sitcom about an Indian-American family living in ''the cultural confusion of Queens,'' as the press packet says. The producers hope to videotape a pilot episode to show television executives.

title: SURGE IN PRISONERS
description: The state's prison population increased 65 percent since 1990 despite an overall drop in crime, according to census 2000 data. The state prison population is now 47,941, up from 29,093 in 1990. Some say the increase is not related to the crime rate. ''The prison population is basically driven by building of prisons,'' said Marcus Felson, a professor at the Rutgers University School of Criminal Justice. In the past decade New Jersey has added two federal correctional institutions and expanded the halfway house system. Anne Ruderman

title: Teaching Tour Guides the Trivia Behind the Trivia
description: Last Monday night, about 50 tour guides milled outside the Seventh Avenue Street offices of NYC & Company, a nonprofit group that promotes tourism in the city. A charter bus arrived, and in they filed. None had cameras. Most carried notebooks.

title: Aug. 26-Sept. 1; She Jumped, as Urged
description: This is a nation in a hurry, its roaring motorists notoriously impatient with any snag. That haste took a particularly dark turn when -- in laid-back Seattle, no less -- a woman climbed onto a highway bridge above a ship canal. While the police tried to talk her down, rush-hour drivers were less understanding, taunting her and urging her to jump. After three hours, she did just that. As she began recovering in a hospital, though, a shudder of remorse rippled through the city, and bouquets and cards poured in.

title: Little League Missed Signs Paulino Had Broken Its Rules Before
description: During this year's Little League World Series, league officials learned that Rolando Paulino had been barred from Little League in Latin America for using over-age players. But that violation was overlooked because of miscommunication, a Little League spokesman said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALF, ROBERT
description: HALF-Robert. 82, passed peacefully in Palm Beach on August 31, 2001. Cherished husband of Maxine, devoted father of Nancy and Peggy, father-in-law of Donny and Marc. Loving grandfather to Stephanie, Kevin, Ryan, Adam, Lauren and Stephanie. As the founder and Chairman of Robert Half International in 1948, Bob was an industry pioneer as he became the first to specialize in the placement of accountants and finance professionals. The author of numerous books and articles, Bob also represented the professional placement industry on television and radio. Bob championed the elimination of gender requirements in job listings and the elimination of agency fees charged to job seekers. A former President of the Association of Personnel Consultants of NY, Bob also received the coveted Madden Memorial Award from NYU where he financed scholarships for deserving accounting students. His business achievements, while substantial, pale against the true test of his humanity: the loving advice and guidance given to his daughters and grandchildren and the friendships he spawned throughout the world. His kindness, wit and magic tricks will be missed by all who were fortunate to know him. Graveside services at Maimonides Cemetery, 90 Elmont Rd, Elmont, NY at 3 P.M. on Sunday, September 2, 2001.

title: On Greek Stage, Another Papandreou
description: A statue of Harry Truman that was sawed off at the ankles here during the American intervention in Kosovo still has not been restored -- and may not be. ''We don't know what he looked like,'' Americans pressing for repairs were told.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on Aug. 5, about the Meeting House of the Society for Ethical Culture on Central Park West, misstated the content of the meetings led by the group's founder, Felix Adler, after its establishment in 1876. They did not include prayers.

title: Upper West Side Journal; Seafarers, of a Sort, Lease a Mooring but Lack a Major Accessory, a Boat
description: Somewhere due south of the George Washington Bridge bobs a buoy in the mighty waters of the Hudson River, its exact location and purpose as mysterious as any legend of the sea.

title: HORSESHOE CRAB TROUBLES
description: The population of horseshoe crabs in the Delaware Bay remains low, according to the state Division of Fish and Wildlife. Kathleen Clark, principal biologist of the division's Endangered Species Program, said that means there are not enough crab eggs to feed shore birds, particularly the red knot, a robin-like bird that stops only on the Delaware Bay on its migration from Tierra Del Fuego at the southern tip of South America to the Arctic. The crabs have probably been over-harvested by fishermen looking for bait for eel and conch, she said, but the division is also looking investigating the possibility of biological or environmental causes. Robert Strauss

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Breaking Old Soviet Ties, Letter by Letter
description: Hasan Firuzi was only a boy when the Soviets went on book-burning rampages throughout Azerbaijan to eradicate the Arabic language. His memories are clearer of events a decade later, in 1939, when Stalin ordered the Latin alphabet replaced with Cyrillic letters.

title: Corrections

title: 'The Corrections'
description: The Madness of an autumn prairie cold front coming through. You could feel it: something terrible was going to happen. The sun low in the sky, a minor light, a cooling star. Gust after gust of disorder. Trees restless, temperatures falling, the whole northern religion of things coming to an end. No children in the yards here. Shadows lengthened on yellowing zoysia. Red oaks and pin oaks and swamp white oaks rained acorns on houses with no mortgage. Storm windows shuddered in the empty bedrooms. And the drone and hiccup of a clothes dryer, the nasal contention of a leaf blower, the ripening of local apples in a paper bag, the smell of the gasoline with which Alfred Lambert had cleaned the paintbrush from his morning painting of the wicker love seat.

title: Lower Peaks, And Lighter Traffic
description: IT was an early October morning in the Adirondacks' Great Range, and the previous night's hard frost lingered, a diamond-white blanket wrapping the summits of Algonquin, Colden and Wright Peaks. The ice contrasted sharply with the deep alpine-blue sky, the scarlet and gold of maples, beech and birches, and the greens of spruce and fir that carpeted the base of the peaks.

description: WHEN it was built in 1910, the Remington Arms Company factory with its nine-story tower in Bridgeport was the tallest building in Connecticut. The plant produced ammunition for the United States and its allies during World Wars I and II, employing 30,000 people at its peak.

description: MARIA SOMERS, a guidance counselor at Port Chester High School, is about to become the owner of a three-bedroom home in the affluent Westchester area where she works -- something she never imagined on her annual salary of $56,000.

description: The latest product seeking to capitalize on the Harlem Renaissance has arrived -- a beer called Sugar Hill, a reference to the neighborhood's most famous district, where figures as diverse as Duke Ellington, Ralph Ellison and Adam Clayton Powell Sr. lived.

description: They came East with Came Home to win the Hopeful Stakes. That was the plan. But late Friday night, Trudy McCaffery, a co-owner of the 2-year-old colt, was in a panic. description: Stock cars roared around the track on practice runs here at the Stafford Motor Speedway. Kelly Sullivan, 26, was unpacking her flameproof racing suit, getting ready to go out there. She started racing in 1994 on a dare. ''Now,'' she said, ''it's in the blood.''

description: In his first state-of-the-union address, a reserved President Vicente Fox avoided triumphant pronouncements -- a signature of his political style -- to acknowledge that he needs more time to live up to the promises that helped him win power.

title: Aug. 26-Sept. 1; Back to the Oval Grindstone
description: The president's vacation is over. Boy, is it over -- he returns to Washington with no surplus to spend on new programs. The president laid out his agenda for the fall: pass the military and education spending bills first, then haggle over the remaining funds for other programs. That, of course, would put his priorities at the head of the line; Democrats have other ideas.

title: When Guilt Divorced The Facts
description: IN late November 1952, one of the most bizarre media spectacles of the 20th century began its eight-day run. The show, broadcast live from a Czech tribunal to an international audience, took the form of a legal proceeding in which a number of prominent government officials confessed to crimes of treason and espionage as heinous as they were nonexistent. They had been required to memorize their lines, as had 35 witnesses. At the conclusion of the proceedings some 80,000 copies of the transcript (or, rather, the script) -- helpfully translated into four languages -- were instantly available for distribution. Then, 11 of the 14 defendants were hanged and their ashes scattered to the winds.

title: No Permit Required
description: Jon Denning, 14, from Springfield, isn't old enough to drive -- on the road. But he will be racing a stock car in one of the toughest short courses in the nation a few weeks after starting his freshman year in high school at Jonathon Dayton High School in Springfield. He began his racing career at the age of 9 in go-carts, and graduated to the stock cars. He will be a contender in the Hickory Motor Speedway Fall Brawl in Hickory, N.C., on Oct. 13, in a 250-lap race that attracts some of the best drivers in the world. The 0.4-mile track requires expert driving; other racers in the Fall Brawl, the season finale for stock car racing, will be in their 20's and 30's. In addition to being featured in television specials and winning many of the races he enters, Jon was named rookie of the year earlier this year by Whip City Speedway in Massachusetts for his outstanding first-season performance. Karen DeMasters

title: Clarence Clemons in the Spotlight
description: Clarence Clemons, whose latest album, ''Rescue/Hero,'' was released last week, is best known for his searing, funky saxophone playing with Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band from 1973 through 1989. That stint led to a successful solo career, and work with other musical icons,like Aretha Franklin. His latest album ''Rescue Hero'' was released last week. And to make it all come full circle, he will be singing, strutting and honking away, tonight, at The Boss's old haunt, the Stone Pony, 913 Ocean Avenue, Asbury Park. Robbie Woliver

title: An Ode to Medelln's Madness, Made at Gunpoint
description: WHILE directing the tumultuous tragicomedy ''Our Lady of the Assassins'' in Medelln, Colombia, Barbet Schroeder learned from a crumpled note hurled into a production car that he was in danger of being gunned down by the same sort of teenage hit squads whose exploits he was busy restaging. Maybe they'd take him for ransom; or maybe, if he didn't pay up, they'd simply ''waste'' him, turning the famous filmmaker into another casualty of the cocaine-inspired carnage that had ravaged the city for two decades.

title: Critic's Notebook; Putting a Pictorial Eye On Nature's Byways
description: The painters Frederic Edwin Church and Jasper Francis Cropsey outlived many of their Hudson River School colleagues. Born early in the 19th century, both died in 1900. By then, they were half-remembered relics of a bygone era.

title: Aug. 26-Sept. 1; The Last Surplus
description: During last year's campaign, George W. Bush made a promise: the government would not tap the growing surplus in the Social Security system to pay its bills. But new projections from the Congressional Budget Office strongly suggested that -- short of an abrupt economic turnaround this year -- the promise would have to be broken. The nonpartisan budget office found that a sour economy and Mr. Bush's $1.3 trillion tax-cut package were eating up the non-Social Security surplus, and that the government would need $9 billion from the retirement program to make up the difference this year. Philip Shenon

title: QUICK BITE/Whitesboro; Where Flip Wilson Lived, Chicken and Ribs
description: Whitesboro is a place that most often gets quickly passed by vacationers heading down to Wildwood and Cape May on Route 9. It is a small, primarily African-American town founded at the end of the 19th century by George White, one of the few black congressmen of his era. The trailer that houses the Whitesboro Historical Museum has a fine display about Mr. White, along with others about two more famous Whitesboro natives: Steadman Graham, the motivational speaker who is Oprah Winfrey's longtime beau; and Flip Wilson, the late comedian. Just down the street from the Museum is Wilson's boyhood home, which has been transformed in the last year into Tiffany's Southern Style, the best soul food joint around. While eating at the shore can be an enervating experience of high prices, long waits and small portions, you will find none of that at Tiffany's. Chopped barbecue is a mountainous portion of shredded meat with tangy-sweet dark sauce clinging to it. Fried chicken is lightly fried as is the pork chop sandwich. Lunch sandwiches run between $3 for a burger to $5.75 for a sparerib sandwich. Dinners -- $10.75 and $8.75 for everything else -- come with two mountainous portions of sides like cheddar macaroni and cheese, black-eye peas, dirty rice or mashed sweet potatoes. Desserts -- sweet potato pie, peach cobbler, pecan pie -- are homemade and go for $2.50 to $2.75. There is a six-person counter and a few booths, but a lot of folks sneak Tiffany's food back onto the expensive barrier islands. Robert Strauss

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: Deals and Discounts; POCONO SAVINGS
description: The four Caesars Pocono Resorts will take 50 percent off the rate for Thursday or Sunday night when couples book a Friday and Saturday stay, starting this week and continuing through Oct. 28. Prices at the resorts -- Cove Haven, Paradise Stream, Pocono Palace and Brookdale -- include breakfast and dinner and all activities, including golf and tennis, and nightly entertainment; all but Brookdale are couples only. Three nights in a Garden of Eden Apple suite at one of the couples-only resorts, for example, comes to $838 a couple ($670 for Friday and Saturday, $168 for the third night). title: Fort Worth
description: Cowboys and culture don't clash in Fort Worth; they coexist peacefully and even symbiotically. Bluejeans and cowboy boots are acceptable attire in some of the fanciest restaurants, and a weekend's activities can encompass both cheering the bull riders at the rodeo in the Stockyards National Historic District and contemplating Picassos and Rembrandts in the Cultural District.

title: Rooted or on the Go, Furniture as Art
description: FURNITURE that merits the adjective ''artful'' is at two museums here. At the Katonah Museum, ''Britain's Portable Empire'' is a crisp exhibition of campaign furniture used by the British army while enlarging its empire. In contrast to that furniture on the go, the pieces on exhibition at the House Museum at Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts are rooted in place.

description: Cunard is offering round-trip air fare and savings up to 50 percent on six one-way cruises from January through April 2002 as the QE2 makes its way around the world. A 14-day trip leaves New York Jan. 7 for Los Angeles, with a Panama Canal transit; rates start at $1,998 a person, double occupancy. On Jan. 21, the ship leaves Los Angeles on a 22-day voyage to Sydney, with fares starting at $3,298 a person, double. The longest segment is a 26-day trip from Hong Kong to Cape Town beginning March 10, costing $4,627 a person and up. The final segment, leaving Cape Town April 5 for Southampton, England, starts at $2,487 a person, double, for 13 days. Information: (800) 728-6273 or www.cunard .com.

title: Habitats/East 89th Street; An Apple for the Teacher: The Rent Is $427 a Month
description: KATE SHEVLIN'S apartment is light and airy, with a small bedroom, living room and kitchen, perfect for a young woman starting out in New York. It is on the Upper East Side, close to many of her friends from college and from her years growing up in Bronxville.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Little Silver, N.J.; Riverfront Borough That Prizes Stability
description: LITTLE SILVER, on the Shrewsbury River in Monmouth County, is in the throes of a home renovation and expansion boom. Throughout the 2.8-square-mile borough, roofs are being ripped off ranch houses and small Cape Cods, as they are converted into sprawling two-story colonials. Many homes -- sometimes several on one block -- are being torn down to make way for larger ones.

title: In the Region/Long Island; State Aid Rise Spurs Major School Building Projects
description: AS a result of a change made three years ago in the way the state distributes school construction aid, major new projects are beginning this year in many of Long Island's school districts.

title: The Design Student
description: When Nicky Hilton -- starts her first year at a New York design school next week, she'll be just another student: attending freshman assemblies, skipping early classes and worrying about what to wear to fit in. To be sure, fitting in hasn't seemed to be a major concern for Ms. Hilton, 17, who, with her older sister, Paris, has become a dewy old standard on the party circuit and in gossip columns. Still, while Ms. Hilton's rather too-fabulous lifestyle has received a torrent of finger-wagging press, her clothing style is, well, shockingly reasonable. ''I like casual,'' Ms. Hilton said. ''Jeans and white tanks, comfortable turtlenecks in the winter. Oh, and I'm constantly wearing a hooded sweatshirt under a jean jacket.'' Stocking her closet with moderately priced designers like Daryl K, Noir and Marc by Marc Jacobs, Ms. Hilton likes to ''wear summer as long as possible,'' keeping her beachy tops and Prada platform sandals in use well after Labor Day. For classes, she favors easy pieces like a Marc Jacobs graffiti sweatshirt ($98 at Language), Helmut Lang jeans ($170 at Helmut Lang), New Balance sneakers and last spring's Louis Vuitton Speedy bag. Her current obsessions are a monogrammed tank top by Cabana 16 ($68 at Olive & Bette's), Miss Sixty jeans ($139 at NYSE in Los Angeles) and the Noir Patch bag ($110 at Henri Bendel). ''I don't like plain,'' she said. ''I like color. I like excitement. I like rhinestones.''

title: The Hamptons It's Not

Then abruptly, almost at the waterline, the car seems to skim right across the top of the waves. It's as if a gust of wind could swirl up and tip it over. Hitting open water in a crowded New York City subway car is one of the strangest satisfactions of metropolitan life.

description: Prosecutors for the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague said they would charge the former Yugoslave president Slobodan Milosevic with genocide in Bosnia and as yet undisclosed war crimes in Croatia, widening the scope of the trial expected next year. The chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, announced the new charges after Mr. Milosevic's second court appearance. Playing -- at least in his own mind -- to an audience back home, he complained that he was being isolated in prison, cut off from friends, family, lawyers and journalists. Mr. Milosevic, in fact, has had visits from six lawyers, a delegation of his political party, his wife and other relatives. He is also mingling with other detainees, some of them Muslim and Croat former enemies.

description: ACROSS the street from the main entrance to the Toros de la Maestranza, the Baroque gold and white bullring here, stands a bronze, life-size statue of the legendary Carmen, a shawl wrapped around her shoulders, her sensual features set in a resolute expression. It is a shady spot near the Guadalquivir River, close to the center of the city, where she supposedly died, stabbed by a jealous lover. No one grows up in this city without knowing her story. But what the Sevillians learn is not the tale made famous by Georges Bizet's opera.

He stared at the dirt, meandered around the front of the mound, took a new baseball and returned to work. One fat pitch does not a poor start make, Hernndez realizes.

title: More on Cuba
description: To the Editor: Regarding Frank Bruni's article ''Bush Administration Showing Willingness to Enforce Law on Visiting Cuba,'' (Aug. 5), travelers whose trip to Cuba is marred by a United States Treasury letter requesting information or threatening fines are advised to promptly contact the Center for Constitutional Rights in New York City, (212) 614-6464. The center will either take the case or refer it to a team of civil rights attorneys that it has formed with the help of the National Lawyers Guild and Global Exchange, organizations that vigorously defend citizens' right to travel freely. The guild's Web address is www.nlg.org.

title: Editorial Observer; The Slave Reparations Movement Adopts the Rhetoric of Victimhood
description: My great-grandfather John Wesley Staples was born in Bedford County, Va., on July 4, 1865. Independence Day of that year was laden with symbolism because it heralded the end of slavery through the 13th Amendment. Family legend has it that John Wesley was one of the first free Negroes born in his county. But three of his siblings were born into slavery, as was his mother, Somerville, who was known in the family as an Ethiopian.

description: A new generation of music fans, too young to remember Buddy Holly or Otis Redding, lost its own rising star when the 22-year-old rhythm-and-blues singer Aaliyah was killed in the crash of a small plane in the Bahamas. Although her stage persona was hardly prudish, Aaliyah never embraced the raunchy sexuality that many singers of her generation favor. Her three albums and starring role in the film ''Romeo Must Die'' won her a wide following, yet she was still a work in progress. Stephen Kinzer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULSKY, RUBIN
description: SHULSKY-Rubin. The Mirrer Yeshiva mourns the grievous loss of our esteemed Chairman of the Board Emeritus, Mr. Rubin Shulsky. He was a man of great foresight, strength, generosity and caring whose love for his family and the Jewish people were equaled only by his vision for the future. Mr. Shulsky was indeed a rare individual whose integrity, honesty and ''menschlichkeit'' inspired all those who had the good fortune of dealing with him. The tremendous growth that the Yeshiva has enjoyed is built upon the foundation that the Shulsky family has established for eternity. In fact, the educational wing in our building which bears his name continues to inspire all those who study and pray there. We wish to extend to Rena Shulsky our heartfelt prayers and profound sympathy. It is our fervent wish that you find comfort in your father's kind and noble deeds and that his shining example continues to guide us all. Mirrer Yeshiva Central Institute

Designers are again taking ideas from the world of the noble horse. This afternoon, the Hampton Classic Grand Prix, a jumping event, will continue a tradition of elaborate luncheons and hostesses in Ascot-style hats (scenes from last year, left). The Coaching Club of America weekend in Newport (below left), has a dress code for riders on coaches and carriages: hats for everyone and jackets and ties for men. The drivers wear apron blankets and gray top hats for day. In the paddock area of the Saratoga Springs track (right), women in picture hats mingle with jockeys in bright racing silks. But in the stands and at the rails, T-shirts and shorts prevail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHING, ROBIN F.
description: CUSHING-Robin F. 76, a devoted and loving mother of R. Hunter Cushing and Hilary Cushing Block. Adoring grandmother to Alexander and Brooke Block. Beloved wife of the late Robert M. Cushing, MD, passed away peacefully at her Manhattan home on August 27, 2001, after a full accomplished and caring life. Her enthusiasm for all that life has to offer was contagious to all who knew her. Born and raised in New York she thoroughly enjoyed contributing to every facet of life. After graduating from Barnard College her sense of commitment led her to serve with the Red Cross in India and China at the end of WWII undertaking assignments in Calcutta, Peking and Shanghai. Upon her return to New York she began her involvement with Irvington House, now the Irvington Institute for Immunological Research. She served on the Board of Directors for many years and has remained a Director Emeratti. She was instrumental in the development of the very successful Thrift Shop and in initiating the first Art and Antiques Benefit Auction at Sotheby's, for which she served as Chairman for many years. She was also active in a number of other charitable organizations including South Hampton Hospital for which she hosted several benefits at her home in Quogue, as recently as last year. She was always known for her gracious entertaining. Above all she will be remembered for her optimistic outlook on life, selflessness and ready smile. In lieu of flowers donations should be sent to the Irvington Institute, 212576-1005, in her memory.

title: The Dirt in the New Machine
description: To the remote Congolese frontier, the free-market system (Blaine Harden, Aug. 12) brings women galore, one might assume plenty of drink, probably drugs -- but food? For that, the coltan miners of the region must turn to the slaughter of innocent apes.

title: Just Don't Put Britney's Name on Your Homework
description: Forget nerdy Lands' End monograms -- and silver paint-pen writing on Frisbees. Noir, the company that co-opted the juvenile practice of putting names on clothing and made it hip for adults, is now circling back, customizing school gear for kids. The 80's retro-dazzle look, which long predates the gear's young owners, includes ''crystallized'' combination locks and calculators, as well as custom airbrushed jean jackets, binders and backpacks ($50 to $150). This brand of name-calling appeals to kids of all ages: Madonna's daughter, Lourdes, chose a crystal belt buckle bearing her nickname, Lola, while Britney Spears had a picture of her Yorkie airbrushed on a bag. For parents wary of letting children wear their names on the street, Noir owner Leeora Catalan suggests using the name of a favorite pop star, pet or sports figure. Unless, of course, the child actually is Derek Jeter.

description: This

title: The Way We Live Now: 09-02-01; Our Lies, Our Selves
description: A couple of years ago, for professional reasons, I found myself in midair above the stomach of a man who worked for an insurance company. I stomped; the man lay motionless; I stomped again. I had enrolled in a professional wrestling school, to pursue an assignment, but also a personal obsession. At the time, wrestling was changing its focus, from the fake grappling in the ring to an intricate web of ''story lines'' that writers were fabricating around it, often filmed as behind-the-scenes revelations. These added a second or third layer of unreality commenting on the first. It was addicting and, in its play on the borders between truths and untruths, quite revealing. You can tell a lot about a culture by the lies it embraces.

title: When in Pennington . . .
description: AVANTI feels like a secret. Turn into a side street, pull into a parking lot, then walk past an umbrella-draped table and a kitchen door through the little garden of small trees, herbs and flowers. Pull open the glass storm door, and you're in a small hallway that seems just like the back entrance with its cabinets and coat hooks and an empty side room with a few tables and chairs. It's not until a server notices you on her way to do something else that you find that you are in the right place -- there is a little Italian restaurant down the hall and up a few steps and judging by the crowd on a weekday night, the whole neighborhood knows about it.

title: A Primary Choice: Mark Green
description: Nearly eight years with Rudolph Giuliani have helped New Yorkers appreciate what their city needs  and needs to avoid  in the next mayor. He has to be a leader, capable of taking the heat and pushing doggedly for his goals. He must hold onto the success in lowering crime and boosting business while reaching out to those who have been left behind. He should also be able to step outside his own ego to forge coalitions and listen to critics.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 19 about presidential oratory through history misstated the form of George Washington's farewell address. It was not a speech; Washington gave the text to a Philadelphia publisher, David Claypoole, who printed it in his newspaper, The American Daily Advertiser. The address was then reprinted in major newspapers around the country.

title: Aug. 26-Sept. 1; 64, After All
description: It was the other shoe to Mr. Bush's Aug. 9 announcement that federally financed researchers could use human embryonic stem cells, but only ones already created. The National Institutes of Health surprised many researchers by issuing a list of 10 institutions around the world that had as many as 64 cultures of the cells. It remains to be seen if all are viable, but many biologists think there will be enough to start research and to test the promise of stem cells for replacing worn tissues and organs. But many also think that more lines will be needed for future clinical trials. Nicholas Wade

title: 'Grammars of Creation'
description: We have no more beginnings. Incipit: that proud Latin word which signals the start survives in our dusty "inception." The medieval scribe marks the opening line, the new chapter with an illuminated capital. In its golden or carmine vortex the illuminator of manuscripts sets heraldic beasts, dragons at morning, singers and prophets. The initial, where this term signifies beginning and primacy, acts as a fanfare. It declares Plato's maxim—by no means self-evident—whereby in all things natural and human, the origin is the most excellent. Today, in Western orientations—observe the muted presence of morning light in that word—the reflexes, the turns of perception, are those of afternoon, of twilight. (I am generalizing. My argument, throughout, is vulnerable and open to what Kierkegaard called "the wounds of negativity.")

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ROBERTA
description: BERGER-Roberta. The family of Roberta Berger regret to announce her passing on August 31, 2001 at 5:55 PM in her home in Rhinebeck, New York. She is survived by her husband Joseph Simchowitz, her mother Florence Babitz, her brother Harvey Babitz, her two daughters Amy and Elise Berger, three step-sons Marc, Mitchel, and Stuart Simchowitz, and five grandchildren to whom she will always be known lovingly as Bubby Bobbie. Roberta was a deeply respected member of the insurance and financial planning communities. Among her many professional accomplishments and associations, Roberta was past president of the New York City Chapter of Chartered Life Underwriters, an active member of the New York City Estate Planning Council and was active in many womens organizations. Roberta was a great friend and confidant to many who will miss her great strength, wisdom, humor and courage. In lieu of any gifts, contributions can be sent to Hospice of Ulster County, 34 Broadway, Kingston, NY 12401. Services Tuesday at noon ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ.

title: Aug. 26-Sept. 1; East Timorese Vote
description: One thing the East Timorese people have learned how to do is vote. Exactly two years ago they defied threats and violence to vote overwhelmingly for independence from a quarter century of Indonesian occupation. Now, more than 90 percent of registered voters have voted again -- for an 88-member council that will draw up a constitution in preparation for full nationhood. The day was peaceful, orderly and joyous. Next year, the United Nations, which has run East Timor since 1999, will withdraw and the world's newest nation will rule itself.

title: No Talking!
description: The Blackberry -- may appeal to hip-hop stars and the Al Gores of the world, but AOL's souped-up Mobile Communicator (a k a MC) hits teenagers and tweens where they live -- right in the Buddy List. Along with e-mail, Web access and personal organizing features, the MC also has that crucial function for the Internet set, instant messaging, which lets users ''talk'' with online pals. Introduced this summer (and embraced by such young-at-heart gearheads as Madonna), the MC has been upgraded -- and priced down to $99 -- for the back-to-school crowd. Messagers would be smart to keep the volume down, so they won't be betrayed mid-class by that telltale plink.

title: Aug. 26-Sept. 1; No Autism Link to Vaccines
description: A large study of two vaccines has shown they do not cause autism or other developmental disorders. The vaccines are standard: one prevents diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough, and the other measles, mumps and German measles. The study, financed by the Centers for Disease Control, found that the vaccines could cause fevers, and seizures in rare cases. But the children who had the vaccine-induced seizures did not go on to have a higher rate of neurological problems. Groups worried that vaccines cause such problems, however, said more study was needed. Philip J. Hilts

title: Meet Me at the Boutique (You Can Dust While You Wait)
description: LAST Thursday, after returning from a business trip that took me to Boston and back by 3 p.m., I didn't go to the office. I played hooky instead, and spent the afternoon at Hadu, my favorite dress shop in NoLIta. I didn't browse through the culottes and halter dresses. I walked straight to the rear room, threw back a couple of tuna fish sandwiches, ate about a pound of pretzels and went to work. Reorganizing the sale rack. Cleaning up the dressing room. And -- though I have no more design experience than any other New Yorker with an anthropology degree -- cutting pink leather swatches for a dress sample. I was acting as if I owned the place, even though I don't. It belongs to my friend Amy McCracken, a designer. And she doesn't pay me for my work.

An assistant store manager, Mr. Baricko named his daughters Audrey, Angelica and Allison. That way they could hand down their monogrammed clothing because, said Mr. Baricko, ''I figured we'd be poor for the rest of our lives.'' Now Mr. Baricko, 42, and the others at the Pathmark supermarket each plan to take at least $800,000 in winnings as a lump sum, after taxes. Everyone in their lottery pool chipped in $30 each over the past three weeks. Like Mr. Baricko, 42, all of the employees except one plan to keep their jobs. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTY, SUSAN NOBERT
description: PETTY-Susan Nobert. Died August 31, 2001, at her home in Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA, after a long illness. Mrs. Petty was a graduate of Brown University, class of 1965, and Northfield Mount Hermon, class of 1961. Raised in Haddam, CT, Mrs. Petty worked for Harcourt Brace in NYC after college where she met her husband of 34 years, Barrett Reed Petty. The Pettys lived in New York, London, Greenwich, CT, before moving to Manchester in 1997. Mrs. Petty was a member of the Junior League of New York and London, as well as the Greenwich Garden Club. She was an active member of St. John's Church in Beverly Farms, MA. She is survived by her husband, her daughter Mrs. Jennifer Mann of New York, her son Alec W.B. Petty of San Francisco, two young granddaughters, Campbell and Hollis Mann, and her brother Peter B. Nobert of Virginia. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Wednesday, September 5, at St. John's Church in Beverly Farms, MA.

Roberta was a deeply respected member of the insurance and financial planning communities. Among her many professional accomplishments and associations, Roberta was past president of the New York City Chapter of Chartered Life Underwriters, an active member of the New York City Estate Planning Council and was active in many womens organizations. Roberta was a great friend and confidant to many who will miss her great strength, wisdom, humor and courage. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALF, ROBERT
description: HALF-Robert. 82, passed peacefully in Palm Beach on August 31, 2001. Cherished husband of Maxine, devoted father of Nancy and Peggy, father-in-law of Donny and Marc. Loving grandfather to Stephanie, Kevin, Ryan, Adam, Lauren and Stephanie. As the founder and Chairman of Robert Half International in 1948, Bob was an industry pioneer as he became the first to specialize in the placement of accountants and finance professionals. The author of numerous books and articles, Bob also represented the professional placement industry on television and radio. Bob championed the elimination of gender requirements in job listings and the elimination of agency fees charged to job seekers. A former President of the Association of Personnel Consultants of NY, Bob also received the coveted Madden Memorial Award from NYU where he financed scholarships for deserving accounting students. His business achievements, while substantial, pale against the true test of his humanity: the loving advice and guidance given to his daughters and grandchildren and the friendships he spawned throughout the world. His kindness, wit and magic tricks will be missed by all who were fortunate to know him. Graveside services at Maimonides Cemetery, 90 Elmont Rd, Elmont, NY at 3 P.M. on Sunday, September 2, 2001.

title: What We Work for Now
description: Despite all our concerns with self-fulfillment, most Americans work to earn money, just as their forebears did 100 years ago. The relative costs of necessities have changed, and so has a fair definition of what is necessary. But even with all our economic growth, and even with some items much cheaper than they once were, families still spend about four-fifths of their budgets for core needs, just as their counterparts did a century ago. Perhaps there should be some national introspection about how much we have really gained.

description: After the fifth game in the final round of World Cup qualifying, the United States had 13 of a possible 15 points. Now, with two losses in a row and a tough match in Costa Rica tomorrow night, there is concern that the road to the World Cup finals next year in Japan and South Korea could be rather treacherous.

title: New Economy; House to Focus On Net Access And Competition

title: Tournament's Funniest Deal Brings Mysterious Bidding
description: The funniest deal of the Summer National Championships last month in Toronto was surely the one shown in the diagram. It was reported in The Daily Bulletin, the tournament newspaper, by Ray Lee of Toronto, and Hugh Ross, a former world team champion, held the South cards. ''I have just been part of the silliest auction I have ever seen,'' Ross said later. His partner, in the North seat, was Kyle Larsen, who will be contending for a world title in Bali, Indonesia, next month.

Not to worry. It could just be the latest in backpacker accessories.

description: Many Europeans like to imagine Americans as snickering, giggling prudes who were much too harsh in their judgment of President Clinton, but photographs of two prominent European politicians have created a late summer sensation in both Germany and France.

description: The full span of a shaky romance, from the swooning infatuation to the crockery smashing against walls, arrives all at once in the songs of Herbert, an English songwriter, disc jockey and producer who brought his group to the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, on Saturday afternoon.

They beat a field of 30 qualifiers by posting a fault-free score in the first round over 14 numbered obstacles requiring 17 jumping efforts within the 1 minute 36 seconds allowed.

title: Portofino Bay Hotel
description: For parents who appreciate some quiet, the Portofino Bay Hotel at the Universal theme park in Orlando, Fla., will provide a second room at half price for families. The Family Plan, as it's called, is good for stays of at least two nights in the Portofino Bay, a 750-room resort designed to resemble a seaside Italian village. It provides admission to the two adjacent Universal theme parks, entry to all the clubs at the CityWalk entertainment area, a movie ticket and a meal voucher. Package rates start at $385 a person for adults, $105 ages 3 to 9, and $135 ages 10 to 17; the second room starts at $120 extra, with the discount. Rates are good through Dec. 27. Some restrictions may apply. Information: (800) 407-4275 or www.universalorlando.com .

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Swissair Raising Prices
description: The chief executive of the financially struggling Swissair Group says it plans to raise its ticket prices to reduce its huge debt. The executive, Mario Corti, indicated that Swissair, based in Zurich, would direct its efforts at the high end of the market. He said Switzerland's passenger market was too small to support the cheapest-fare tickets. In addition, the long-term debt of Swissair, which recorded a $140 million loss for the first half of the year, was downgraded by Moody's Investors Service to B1 from Ba3. Moody's confirmed a short-term debt rating of ''not prime'' and said Swissair was under review for further possible downgrading. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

Women now hold the presidencies at three of the eight Ivy League institutions: Dr. Tilghman at Princeton, Judith Rodin at the University of Pennsylvania and Ruth J. Simmons at Brown.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Venezuelan's View On Oil Output
description: The Venezuelan energy and mines minister, Alvaro Silva, said yesterday the Organization of the Oil Producing Countries did not plan to make any changes in production levels at its meeting later this month because oil prices were likely to rise as a result of the group's most recent production cutback. ''We expect prices to move into the upper half of the $22-to-$28-a-barrel range,'' Mr. Silva said at a news conference. ''We don't expected changes at the next meeting.'' OPEC, which pumps about 40 percent of the world's oil, cut production by 1 million barrels a day, or 4.1 percent, effective Sept. 1.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Ascom Posts Loss
description: Ascom Holding, Switzerland's largest telecommunications equipment maker, reported a net loss of $15.5 million for the first half of 2001, disappointing some analysts who had forecast net earnings of that level, or more. Ascom Holding, based in Bern, had $36 million in earnings in the similar period last year. It said the losses had been caused by the flagging telecommunications market, restructuring costs and costs linked to its terminals division. First-half revenue rose 3.3 percent, to $932 million, and the backlog of orders fell. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: America's Close Allies Decide to Stick It Out in Durban to Save the Meeting
description: The European Union, determined to remain at the Durban conference on racism, scrambled tonight to help the host, South Africa, salvage the meeting as the United States and Israel made good on their threats to walk out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, GLORIA
description: WIENER-Gloria, died August 25th, 2001 after a valiant battle with cancer. She was predeceased by Don, her husband of 48 years, in November 2000. Gloria had a long, successful executive career in marketing and communications with Paine Webber and Merrill Lynch where she impressed her staff, peers and senior management with her ability to create relevant, quality materials to support the overall goals of the company. She retired from Merrill Lynch in 1987 as Vice President of Advertising and Sales Promotion. Gloria and Don divided their retirement years between Manhattan and their country home in Andes, NY in the Western Catskills. They also traveled extensively both nationally and internationally. Gloria was a lover of art, music and literature; she was an accomplished writer and classical and folk guitarist. Gloria was an avid birder and lover of nature; she catalogued the flora & fauna of her country home and wrote frequent articles for ''Hunting House News'', a publication of the Andes Society. Gloria loved crosscountry skiing with her husband and friends. She was a talented chef and a great hostess. Gloria is survived by her loving sisters, Ella May Ablahat & Louise Del Savio, and her loving brother, Gordon Cason; by five nieces and nephews and an extended family of longtime, loving friends-all of whom will miss Gloria's warmth, intelligence and good humor. There will be no service. Contributions in Gloria's memory may be made to the Beaverkill Valley Fire Department, HCR 1, Lew Beach, NY 12758, or to the Audubon Society of New York State, 46 Rarick Road, Selkirk, New York 12158

title: Johnson and Palmer Have the Chemistry
description: In April, Don Johnson's doubles partner, Piet Norval, was hurt in an auto accident. Johnson needed a new partner, at least for a while.

title: Ida Russ Schwartz, 86, a Purveyor of Delicacies
description: Ida Russ Schwartz, one of three sisters who with their father, Joel Russ, sliced smoked salmon, pickled herrings and weighed out caviar at Russ & Daughters, their renowned appetizer store on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, died on Aug. 24 in Pembroke Pines, Fla. She was 86.

title: Crash Davis, 82, 'Bull Durham' Model, Dies
description: Crash Davis, an obscure 1940's infielder who emerged as something of a celebrity when Kevin Costner became his namesake playing a shrewd but fading minor leaguer in the movie ''Bull Durham,'' died last Friday at his home in Greensboro, N.C. He was 82.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechnya Leaders Escape Bomb
description: A bomb set in a bathroom beneath a conference room where pro-Russian Chechen leaders were meeting killed a woman who was working nearby and blew out windows in the highly fortified government compound in Grozny, the capital of the Russian territory where rebels are fighting for independence. The head of the Chechen administration, Akhmad Kadyrov, and Prime Minister Stanislav Ilyasov escaped injury one floor above.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIVER, RUTH BLAKE OLIVER
description: OLIVER-Ruth Blake Oliver. Of Boston, died in Mattapoisett, Massachusetts on September 1, 2001. Widow of the late Andrew Oliver, she is survived by three children, Andrew Oliver, Jr. of Chevy Chase, Maryland, Daniel Oliver of Washington, D.C. and Ruth Oliver Morley of Cambridge, Massachusetts, seven grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and a brother, Benjamin S. Blake Jr., of Boston. She was born in Weston, Massachusetts on December 22, 1911, was married in 1936, and lived in New York City from then until 1970 when she moved to Boston. She was a member of the Chilton Club in Boston, the Orton Society, the Fragment Society, the Tuesday Club, the Fortnightly Club, the National Society of the Colonial Dames, the Colonial Society, and the Massachusetts Historical Society. She was a great-granddaughter of Francis Blake, of Weston, who invented the telephone transmitter used for many years by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Funeral services will be held at the Church of the Advent, 30 Brimmer Street, in Boston, on Thursday, September 6 at 11:00 AM. Contributions may be made to The Fragment Society, C/O Mrs. W. Scott McDougal, 39 Proctor Street, Manchester, Massachusetts 01944.

title: Long Island Man Dies in Cesspool Cave-In
description: The ground over a cesspool caved in yesterday, swallowing up a man in his backyard in South Huntington, N.Y., the police said. Rescue workers were still struggling to retrieve his body nearly 12 hours later.

title: Parade Has Carnival's Spirit, but New York's Rules
description: Carnival blossomed in the heart of Brooklyn yesterday under unspoiled sunny skies. For the 34th year in a row, Eastern Parkway turned into a festive thoroughfare of lavishly plumed, sequined masquerade bands. An unusually crowded pack of politicians came to woo the West Indian vote. And the wide sidewalks turned into an open-air bazaar, with enterprising vendors hawking everything from codfish cakes to pirated CD's to shaved ice.

description: Bacterial meningitis is not a common disease, striking about 1 person in 100,000 in the United States each year. But for several reasons, it causes alarm far out of proportion to the number of people affected.

title: Dental Exam May Offer Clues on Stroke
description: A routine dental exam in some offices can now yield more than just tooth and gum information. Many dental X-rays, a recent study says, can also be used to detect the hardening of the arteries in the neck that can foreshadow a stroke.

title: Curing the Patients' Bill of Rights
description: During their monthlong recess back home, members of Congress have no doubt been hearing from constituents about the need for a strong patients' bill of rights and from state officials about the need for a bill that does not thwart state efforts to protect those wronged by their health care plans. As they reconvene in Washington this week, they should take the message to heart. A patients' rights bill is headed for a House-Senate conference committee. Congress must ensure that the version that ultimately emerges sticks close to the Senate's proposal rather than the weak alternative adopted in early August by the House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSLOY BLANK, SHARON
description: COSLOY BLANK-Sharon, 56, the perfect daughter, wife, mother and friend passed peacefully with her family by her side on September 2. She will be missed and loved forever by husband, Edward Blank; children Rebecca and Michael; mother Florece Cosloy and brother and sister-in-law Barry and Sherry Cosloy. After growing up in Paterson, NJ, Sharon graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Elmira College and received a doctoral degree from NYU at a time when relatively few women were in Science. Sharon was a respected member of the CCNY Biology faculty for 27 years and served as Chair of the Biology Department for six. A passionate scientist, professor and mentor. Sharon was dedicated to both her research and her students. A lover of life, she enjoyed going to the theater, traveling and bringing friends and family together with great cooking. Because of her courage to battle and endure her illness while still enjoying life she was and continues to be an inspiration to her family. Services are on Wednesday 11:30AM at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: For the Kursk, a Risky Resurrection
description: For nearly 400 days since two mysterious torpedo room explosions ripped open the nuclear submarine Kursk, causing the deaths of all 118 Russian crewmen, the 505-foot vessel has been nestling into the sediments on the bottom of the Barents Sea.

title: Sometimes, Generic Drug Swaps Matter

title: If Oak Malady Moves East, Many Trees Could Die
description: A disease that has killed many thousands of trees on the West Coast could pose a threat elsewhere if it spreads east because northern red oaks and pin oaks, classic trees of the Midwestern and Eastern forests, also seem susceptible, a plant pathologist has warned.

title: Map That Named America May Call It Home
description: The only known surviving copy of the first map to bear the name of America, often called ''the baptismal certificate of the New World,'' has found its way to America from Germany as an acquisition of the Library of Congress.

title: Motorola to Announce Advance in Chips
description: Motorola plans to announce today a breakthrough in the manufacture of semiconductors that allows high-performance materials like gallium arsenide to reside on top of standard silicon, a decades-old dream for microchip designers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINTHAL, NANCY
description: STEINTHAL-Nancy, on August 30th, 2001. Loving daughter of Doris and Jules Stein, devoted and loving mother to Susan and grandmother to Michael and Benjamin. Also loving niece of Maurice Wagner. You will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONOWITZ, LINDA
description: ARONOWITZ-Linda. It is with deep sorrow that the family of Linda Greenstein Aronowitz announce her passing on September 3, 2001. Linda will be greatly missed by her devoted husband, Joel, her beloved daughters Susanne and Pamela, her son-in-law Robert as well as her niece Elissa, nephew Mark and his wife Barbara. A graduate of the University of Michigan, Linda was a true inspiration to all who knew her. In her six-year battle with cancer, Linda fought with tremendous courage and great spirit. She never lost sight of her goal-to continue to live her life to the fullest potential despite the obstacles that were put in her path. Linda was a true friend and confidant to all whom she encountered. She never missed a birthday, special event, or her Thursday night Mahjong game. Linda always had a smile, was the first to offer assistance, and made all her friends and family members feel as though they were truly special. Linda's knack for entertaining, combined with her sincere thoughtfulness, always left people feeling good about themselves and grateful to have her in their lives. Linda was a dedicated member of Temple Sholom in River Edge, New Jersey where she served on many committees over the past twenty-five years. Her sincere and direct approach to life offered those around her the opportunity to learn from her. Linda's great wit, sense of style, pragmatic approach to the daily conflicts of life, ready smile, thoughtful note, and most importantly, her courage to face strife head-on without looking back is how she will be remembered. Though Linda is now at peace in the arms of her mother Sarah, father Alex and brother Larry, there will always be something special that lives on in each of us who knew and loved her, and that something special is Linda. Services will be held 1PM Wednesday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fairlawn, NJ. Donations can be made to Temple Sholom, 385 Howland Avenue, River Edge, NJ 07661.

title: 1999 Survey on Gene-Altered Corn Disclosed Some Improper Uses

title: Recovering Japan's Wartime Past -- and Ours
description: Celebrations this Saturday of the 50th anniversary of the San Francisco Treaty of Peace, which established the postwar relationship between Japan and the world, will focus on Japan's emergence as a pacifist market economy under the tutelage of its conqueror and later ally, the United States. Little attention will be paid to questions of historical memory or of liability for Japan's behavior during the war. The 1951 treaty, largely through the efforts of America's principal negotiator, John Foster Dulles, sought to eliminate any possibility of war reparations. This undoubtedly cemented Japan's alliance with the United States and helped its economic rebirth. But Dulles's and Japan's strategy also fostered a deliberate forgetfulness whose consequences haunt us today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIGSBERG, MAYNARD
description: KOENIGSBERG - Maynard. We mourn the passing of our former vice president and honorary member of the Board of Trustees, Maynard Koeningsberg, who ''shed round him in the common strife and mild concerns of ordinary life, a constant influence, a peculiar grace.'' Maynard was concerned with not only the structure of the synagogue but more importantly, all of the programs that elevated the human condition. We're thankful for his personal qualities of mind and heart and spirit. He leaves his family and friends a treasure of memories that will never lose their luster, that will deepen and mellow as the years go by. It is in the hearts of all those who knew and loved him that the best and purest part of Maynard Koenigsberg now lies eternally enshrined. Dr. Robert S. Widom, Rabbi Sandor C. Schweiger, Co-President Mandell Dalis, Co-President Temple Emanuel of Great Neck

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Officer Injured

He was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where he was treated and released, officials said. The shot may have been fired from the rooftop of a building on nearby Wheeler Avenue, officials said. ''There are two countries, real and fictional, occupying the same space, or almost the same space. My story, my fictional country exist, like myself, at a slight angle to reality. title: World Briefing | Africa: Seychelles: President Retains Power
description: President France Albert Ren won an election victory that will extend his rule of the Indian Ocean archipelago for another five years. Mr. Ren, who seized power in a coup om 1977, won 54 percent of the vote. Wavel Ramkalawan, an Anglican priest, had 45 percent. Mr. Ren called the vote two years early in an effort to demonstrate political stability and attract investors. Mr. Ramkalawan accused him of bribing and intimidating voters; he denied the charge. The announcement was made despite a spate of technical problems involving the company's trial of the service begun in May and skepticism abroad about its viability, at least in the near term. The new cellular phone service, with which users can send and receive data at up to 40 times the conventional speed, had originally been planned for late May. But the trials were ridden with problems: customers complained of short battery life, frequent disconnections and display freezes. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission said its executive director for policy and markets regulation would leave at the end of the month to become an assistant managing director at the Monetary Authority of Singapore, making him the only foreigner in the authority's senior management. Last week, Singapore Telecommunications said it had appointed an Australian to its board in connection with its bid of 14 billion Australian dollars, or $7.42 billion, to acquire the Australian telecommunications operator Cable and Wireless Optus. title: Gramm Says He Won't Seek Re-election
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a conservative Republican who preached the gospel of low taxes, balanced budgets and a strong military to stand up to Communism, said today that he would not seek re-election to a fourth term next year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KPN Reports Loss
description: The Dutch phone company Royal KPN posted a second-quarter loss yesterday that was more that twice that for the comparable period last year. It also warned that it could receive less from selling assets than originally expected. On Friday, Royal KPN abandoned a plan to merge with a Belgian counterpart, Belgacom. KPN is under pressure to reduce 22.8 billion euros in debt, or $20.8 billion, six times its market capitalization. For the second quarter, KPN lost 536 million euros, compared with 207 million euros in the comparable period last year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Team Says It Coaxed Human Stem Cells to Produce Blood
description: Biologists at the University of Wisconsin report today that they have transformed human embryonic stem cells into blood-making cells, a step that they say lays the basis for an ''entirely novel'' set of therapies based on fabricating laboratory-made tissues and organs from embryonic cells.

title: U.S. Missteps Wasted Investments in Central Asian Economies, Critics Say
description: As Communism crumbled, the United States set up investment funds to foster start-up companies and other ventures in fledgling market economies. But many of those efforts were undermined, financial experts say, when Washington appointed individuals with little business experience -- politicians, lawyers and academics -- to make investment decisions.

Just about everything appears to be in shape and ready to begin working again. And now, this is the week it all has to be put back together.

title: For Public Advocate: Betsy Gotbaum
description: The job of public advocate of New York City tends to come in for a lot of sniping. The position has a vague mandate -- to ''represent the consumers of city services'' -- and a grab bag of seemingly unrelated responsibilities, from taking over if the mayor resigns to serving as an ex officio member of every City Council committee. The present occupant, Mark Green, turned the job into a platform for this year's mayoral campaign, and his departure has attracted a raft of candidates, some of whom may be hoping to follow in his footsteps.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Schoolgirls Attacked
description: As they walked to their first day back at elementary school in northern Belfast, Roman Catholic girls and their parents faced a barrage of stones and bottles thrown by Protestant residents of homes near the school. Some 200 Protestants tried to block the street and clashed with the police, who cleared a path to the school entrance. Similar clashes in June forced the closing of the school for several days and were followed by sporadic episodes of violence that lasted through the summer. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Executives Replaced
description: The new chief executive of Gazprom, Russia's gas monopoly, reshuffled top management yesterday, his first major reform step since his appointment by President Vladimir V. Putin in May. The executive, Aleksei Miller, left, replaced four other Gazprom executives, three of whom had been part of a group of managers who ran the company under Mr. Miller's predecessor, Rem Vyakhirev. Minority shareholders have accused Mr. Vyakhirev and his team of funneling property and cash out of Gazprom into companies linked to them. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

A police spokesman, Lt. Elias Nikas, said the officers in the car were interviewed and were found to be fit for duty. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

A museum like the Palais des Beaux-Arts at Lille was given 46 paintings from the Louvre and Versailles to add to its collection of works salvaged from churches and convents in disuse after the revolution. It then became part of the national system of museums that to this day report to a central director in Paris.

The chief executive of the wireless business, Peter Erskine, called the new name ''modern and universal.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITAKER, DR. JOHN N.
description: WHITAKER-Dr. John N. The volunteers and staff of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society wish to express deep sorrow on the passing of Dr. John N. Whitaker, 60, of Birmingham, AL, who died August 29. Dr. Whitaker had served as professor and chair of the Dept. of Neurology at the Univ. of Alabama since 1985, and was president of the American Neurological Association from 1995-97. Since 1998 he served on the National Board of Directors of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society (NMSS), where he was previously chairman of the Medical Advisory Board. Dr. Whitaker, an internationally known researcher and deeply caring physician, was dedicated to the NMSS' mission to end the devastating effects of MS. He had over 200 papers published about MS, was principal investigator in three advanced trials of MS drugs, and was involved in clinical programs on providing the best care for patients. Dr. Whitaker is survived by his wife, Elaine, daughters Amy and Stacy, and son Jeff. The family asks that in lieu of flowers contributions be made to: John N. Whitaker, M.D., Endowed Chair, UAHSF, attention: Audie White, 500 22nd St South, Birmingham, AL 35233, or to the Alabama Chapter of NMSS. National Multiple Sclerosis Society Richard B. Slifka Chairman of the Board Mike Dugan, General, USAF, Ret. President and CEO

title: British Phone Gear Maker to Cut Another 2,000 Jobs

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUEL, SUSAN
description: SAMUEL-Susan, 94. Of Boca Raton, FL., formerly of New York City, passed away September 4, 2001. Pioneer in mainstreaming handicapped children. Her motto was Loving, Caring and Sharing. She received a Bachelor of Science degree in Physical Education from New York University and a Master of Arts degree in Special Education from Hunter College. Came to the New York Philanthropic League in 1943 as Co-Director of Camp Carola and Director of Recreation. In 1954 was appointed Director of Camp Carola and Executive Director of the New York Philanthropic League. In 1962, initiated a Development Training Program for the multihandicapped child and a NurseryKindergarten for bright pre-school handicapped children. Primary goal for all activities was to prepare the child to become an active member in his or her community. Acted as an advisor to professionals, to parents and to college students. Guest lectured at Hunter College, Long Island University and the City College of New York. Participated in panel discussions and numerous interviews on radio and television espousing innovative recreational concepts for the handicapped in camping and community life. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Services Wednesday 2:15 at Star of David Cemetery and Funeral Home, 7701 Bailey Road, North Lauderdale, FL., phone 954-722-9000.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Storms Cut Power
description: Thunderstorms and high winds thrashed parts of central New Jersey last night, sending trees and branches crashing into power lines and causing scattered electrical failures to about 6,000 customers in the Princeton area. Power was gradually restored to most customers over the course of seven hours, said Paul Rosengren, a spokesman for Public Service Electric & Gas. Either lightning or power lines downed by a fallen tree ignited a brief fire in a gas main on Harrontown Road in Princeton Borough, but caused no injuries or interruption in service, he said. title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Aid Workers' Case In Court
description: A month after eight foreign relief workers, including two Americans, were arrested on charges of preaching Christianity, court proceedings began in Kabul, though neither the accused, their relatives nor the press have been allowed in court. Fifteen Islamic clerics are reviewing the evidence, said Chief Justice Noor Muhammad Saqib. Details of the legal procedures are still being worked out. It remains to be seen whether the defendants will be permitted to testify or allowed use of lawyers, Justice Saqib said. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: National Secrets, Too Frequently Told
description: Few things were more frustrating to me as secretary of defense than reading in the morning papers about memos addressed to me that had yet to reach my desk. Few were more disturbing than leaks that jeopardized our sources and methods of gathering intelligence or even the conduct of military operations.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Janitors Get 3-Year Contract
description: Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union said that it had unionized 500 janitors in Newark who will be covered by a new three-year contract. The janitors' wages, which are now $5.50 to $9.40 an hour, will climb to $11.75 after three years. The dozen companies that signed the new contract also agreed to convert all part-time janitors to full-time work in office buildings of more than 400,000 square feet. The companies recognized the union after pledging they would when cleaning companies with more than 55 percent of the city's janitors agreed to unionize. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Contamination Concerns
description: State environmental officials have asked the federal Department of Energy to investigate possible radiation contamination on and around Amchitka Island, where the military detonated three atomic devices from 1965 to 1971. The island, in the Aleutians, is uninhabited, but people who live on nearby islands travel near Amchitka to fish or hunt and have for many years expressed concern that radiation from the island could contaminate marine life in the area. The Energy Department has previously said it does not believe there is any such leakage, but it has not conducted radiation tests there since the 1970's. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

When he departed for Le Cirque, the hotel imported the Rostang clan from France to keep the restaurant in the top rank. But with their departure, Le Rgence slipped into overstuffed, overdecorated mediocrity.

title: New Program Planned at Biosphere 2
description: Since taking over the management of Biosphere 2, the three-acre terrarium-like research structure near Tucson, Columbia University has gradually expanded its programs there. Next summer, it will introduce a one-year master's degree program in earth systems science, policy and management, the first graduate program at the center. Students will first take a summer immersion program in science, followed by courses in management and policy with case studies drawn from topics in earth science. The program is aimed at closing a growing divide between scientists and policy makers, said STEVEN COHEN, its designer and director. To accommodate the growth in the number of students at Biosphere, Columbia is building a $10 million minicampus, including residences for 300 students. Karen W. Arenson
