title: Roddick Continues Rise With a Display of Might
description: Andy Roddick darted out to the practice courts yesterday afternoon with the energy of a sugar-loaded toddler only to run right back inside when a downpour hit the United States Open.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about a couple attacked by a shark off the Outer Banks of North Carolina misstated the victims' marital status in some copies. They were unmarried.

title: New Plan for Recruiting Principals
description: Expecting a large number of school administrators to retire in the next five years, the New York State Education Department is beginning its first statewide campaign to recruit principals and other school leaders, and has hired the Syntax Communication Group in West Sayville, N.Y., to assist its efforts. Syntax will provide public service announcements and a presentation that can be used statewide and assist with the creation of a Web site. The cost, $75,000, is being paid for with a grant from the Dewitt Wallace Reader's Digest Foundation. Allison Fass

description: HILZINGER-Florence. Beloved daughter of the late Charles and Daisy, sister of the late Daisy. Reposing at the First Baptist Church (265 West 79th Street and Broadway), NYC at 9:00 AM. Religious service at the church at 10:00 AM. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, BERNARD
description: WHITE-Bernard. The American Zionist Movement mourns the passing of Bernard White. He served the Jewish community with distinction for over 50 years. He was a lifelong Zionist and served as a past National Treasurer of the AZM and a recipient of our Lifetime Achievement Award in 1999. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife, Ruth.

title: A Free Night in Maui
description: It's a long flight to Hawaii from most cities in the United States, so why not stay a while once you get there? The oceanfront Kaanapali Beach Hotel on Maui makes it a little less expensive by offering a free night for stays of seven nights or more in a partial ocean view room. The offer is good through Dec. 18. Information: (800) 262-8450.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Groups Urge Toxic Cleanup
description: Environmental groups urged the New York State Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday to investigate hundreds of sites on Long Island that may contain poisonous chemicals that may have leaked into the drinking water from commercial dry cleaners. A Department of Environmental Conservation spokeswoman did not respond directly, but noted that the governor had called for a special legislative session on the cleanup of toxic sites. The groups, the Citizens Environmental Coalition and the New York Public Interest Research Group, told reporters that the groups believed that as many as 270 sites in Nassau and Suffolk Counties might need cleanup.

title: Rangers' Fleury Cleared To Return for This Season
description: Theo Fleury's presence here today with the Canadian men's Olympic hockey team basically ensured that he was preparing to come back from a stint in rehabilitation to resume his N.H.L. career this season.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Windows XP Orders Accepted
description: Gateway Inc., the second-largest direct seller of personal computers, said it would begin accepting orders today for Microsoft's newest operating program, Windows XP, the subject of a coming antitrust hearing. Gateway is tentatively scheduled to begin shipping the new system on its PC's on Sept. 24, said Lisa Emard, a company spokeswoman. Profit and revenue are falling at Gateway, which is based in San Diego, because of declining demand and fierce competition for computer sales. Rival PC makers like Dell Computer have said they also intend to begin shipping Windows XP by the end of this month. A federal judge is scheduled to begin a hearing on Sept. 21 on a request by federal prosecutors to force Microsoft to change its operating system, which they say is anti-competitive because it places restrictions on competing software programs.

description: CEMBALEST-Arnold. Grandfather of Nikki and Ryan Banner and Cody White. Brother of Stanley and Anne, Howard and Hazel. Father-in-law of Fred Banner and Tom Perfilio. Services held Wednesday.

title: U.S. Factories Offer Hints Of Revival
description: Manufacturing, the weakest part of the United States economy, began showing signs of improvement last month, according to a survey of corporate executives released yesterday.

title: Bensonhurst To Hollywood In One Leap For Actor, 17
description: Less than two months ago James Guidice was sitting at the dining room table of his family's apartment in Bensonhurst in Brooklyn when he heard that there was an ad in the show business newspaper Backstage for an acting role that seemed to fit him like a glove.

title: Republicans' Bitter Words Are Flying in Staten Island Borough President Race
description: For years, the Republican Party in Staten Island has been known for harmony within its ranks. Whether endorsing a candidate for City Council or Congress, the Republicans on the island have always presented a show of unity in order to beat Democrats.

title: A Bold Move Beyond Grilled Beef and Koreatown
description: KOREAN restaurants have now established themselves in Manhattan beyond their familiar Herald Square zone. The next step, Dae Jin Hwang says, is to show Americans that Korean restaurants have a lot more to offer than grilled beef.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS. Cocoa declined as wet weather improved prospects for crops in West Africa. The December contract slipped $39, or 4.1 percent, to $910 a metric ton on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Arrest In Businessman's Slaying
description: A soldier suspected of killing a prominent Turkish businessman was arrested in Kayseri in a case that prompted criticism of the government's policy of mass pardons. Uzeyir Garih, co-founder of the powerful Alarko Holding, was found stabbed to death in an Istanbul cemetery on Aug. 22. A police official said the suspect, Yener Yermez, confessed after he was arrested after a nationwide manhunt. Mr. Yermez was one of 35,000 prisoners freed in an amnesty in December. Doug Frantz (NYT)

title: Tom Colicchio
description: FOR our wedding dinner, my fiance, Lori Silverbush, wanted a meal that would include all of her favorite foods. Most of all she wanted corn. Her first idea was to serve corn ice cream for dessert and start with a pea soup with crab. But we're getting married on Sept. 15, when peas are out of season, so I persuaded her to use the corn for the soup instead.

title: The Browser as a Cookie-Control Key
description: To many privacy advocates, the most sensible place to offer privacy protection is precisely where the online privacy furor began: the Internet browser. Both Netscape and Microsoft, which make the leading browsers, designed their early versions to accept cookies by default, requiring consumers who want more privacy to change software settings -- something most of them dread.

title: N.F.L. Sets A Deadline For Referees
description: National Football League executives and a representative for the more than 100 locked-out officials met for three hours yesterday in Manhattan to try to resolve the labor impasse, but walked away with little progress.

title: 4 Publishers Agree to Sale Of E-Books On Yahoo
description: Four major publishers have agreed to open an online clearinghouse on the Internet portal Yahoo to sell their electronic books directly to readers, advancing their efforts to liberate themselves from reliance on online retailers in the nascent business of selling books in digital form.

title: The Ponytailed Place-Kicker
description: Ashley Martin, ponytail dangling from the back of her helmet, made history Thursday night when she became the first woman to play and score in a Division I college football game. One reason her triumph was not front-page news may have been that there were no lawyers involved, an absence that makes the story all the more heartening.

title: The Danger of Walking Out at Durban
description: The walkout by the United States and Israel from the United Nations conference on racism in Durban, South Africa, was a predictable and unfortunate consequence of the irresponsibility of those in the Arab world who sought to make Israel a central issue. In supporting this shortsighted choice, the Arab states have played into the hands of right-wing politicians, in both Israel and the United States, who will benefit from the moral discrediting of the antiracist efforts that many had hoped would be the center of the conference.

title: California Company Acquires Researcher
description: Knowledge Networks in Menlo Park, Calif., said yesterday that it had acquired Statistical Research in Westfield, N.J., a media research company. Statistical Research has 50 employees working for clients like ESPN, Radio Disney, Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio. It will operate as an autonomous unit be called Knowledge Networks/Statistical Research.

We wish to extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Constanzia, and to his children, Katharina, Edward, Melena and Bernadette. David M. Burke, MD President, Medical Staff

title: Teacher Exodus Documented
description: The United Federation of Teachers has come up with a new estimate of how many New York City teachers leave for the suburbs, suggesting that nearly 1,300 left for other districts in New York State last year. A separate survey by the schools chancellor, HAROLD O. LEVY, found that about 1,100 teachers leave for the suburbs each year and SOL STERN, a fellow at the Manhattan Institute who has studied such departures, came up with a much smaller figure, closer to 150. The union's figure was based on a comparison of the Social Security numbers of teachers who left in 2000 with the numbers of all current members of the state teachers' union, which represents teachers in most of the state's other school districts. It found 1,282 matches, most of them in the nearby suburbs. Using the same method, the union determined that 991 teachers left for other New York State districts in 1999, and 777 did so in 1998. Abby Goodnough

title: Work by Expert Witness Is Now on Trial
description: Fred S. Zain sat keenly attentive in court here today, looking every bit the polished state crime laboratory expert whose testimony has helped convict hundreds of defendants across a dozen states.

title: Rivals Covet Giuliani's Crime Data, Not His Ways
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gets mixed reviews from many of the men who want his job, but not when it comes to crime. All six major candidates have acknowledged his crime-fighting prowess. Yet even as they assure voters that they will retain successful anticrime strategies, the Democratic candidates on the Tuesday primary ballot are outlining tactics that differ sharply from Mr. Giuliani's approach.

title: French Court Backs Chirac On Elements Of Graft Case
description: A French court handed President Jacques Chirac a victory today, annulling central elements of a case that had implicated him in an illicit fund-raising scheme when he was mayor of Paris.

description: Iarrived at Newark International Airport at 8:25 on Sept. 11, 2001, thinking about Barry Bonds. One day earlier, I had been assigned to cover Bonds's pursuit of Mark McGwire's single-season home run record, so I was about to get on an airplane, travel to Houston and attend a press conference that Bonds was scheduled to conduct that afternoon.

title: F.B.I. Employee Admits Stealing Case Files
description: A former low-level security analyst with the F.B.I.'s Las Vegas office admitted today that he stole agency records that were later sold to mob figures, criminal defendants, lawyers and the targets of grand jury investigations in New York and elsewhere.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Linens And Knot Form Alliance
description: Linens'n Things, a retailer of home textiles, housewares and home accessories with 284 stores in 40 states, yesterday announced a partnership with the Knot, a popular wedding registry Web site that provides content to America Online and MSN. Linens'n Things will offer more than 2,000 bedding and bath products through the Knot's Web site, www.theknot.com. As a part of the deal, wedding guests will also be able to view and purchase gifts for Knot-registered couples at Linens'n Things retail locations nationwide. Shares in Linens'n Things rose 25 cents, to $26.25. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: A Voyage With an Ulterior Purpose
description: Looking as though he had just won the lottery, SHAQUAN DELEON, 10, was hoisted high above the Hudson River in a harnessed chair as his temporary shipmates tugged on the ropes that bound him to their schooner. It was a mock man-overboard exercise, showing 13 students how a person who falls into the sea is rescued. Grinning in delight, Shaquan called out, ''We're doing this all night, right?'' The answer was yes. Last Friday, the Police Athletic League brought Shaquan and 12 other students from Washington Heights and the Bronx aboard the ships Pioneer and Wavertree for an overnight stay. The sleepover is part of the South Street Seaport Museum's Penny Project, which provides programs for children helped by social service agencies throughout New York City. After a sail in New York Harbor on the schooner Pioneer, during which the students raised sails and read nautical maps, they boarded the Wavertree, a 325-footer cargo vessel built in 1885. They cooked dinner, kept a ship's log and slept in sailor bunks. CHARLIE RITCHIE, a chaperon from the Police Athletic League, said such programs gave children from the city an opportunity for ''constructive risk taking, and more positive adventure'' than what they often saw on the street. Kathleen Carroll

title: Civil Court Endorsements
description: The disappointing field of candidates in this year's handful of contested races for seats on New York City's Civil Court leaves defenders of the current system of electing judges a lot to answer for. However, these are our recommendations in the all-but-decisive Democratic primary next Tuesday.

title: Defending a Merger
description: Executives from Hewlett-Packard, a company synonymous with printers, and Compaq Computer, known for personal computers, defended their plans to merge into the world's largest computer maker today on the ground that they would like to be known not for selling hardware, but for selling advice and service.

title: Report Says Macedonians Killed Civilians in Revenge
description: That night's newscast showed Ljube Boskovski, the hard-line Macedonian minister of the interior, planted behind a stone wall in the village of Ljuboten, surrounded by soldiers and the sound of gunfire. He was there, the newscast said, as part of a military operation to sweep the village of the ethnic Albanian ''terrorists'' who had planted the antitank mines that had killed eight Macedonian soldiers two days before.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Ex-Governor Has Cancer
description: Former Gov. Lester Maddox, best remembered for his ardent stand against integration, said he was dying of prostate cancer. ''I'm having trouble just living,'' he told The Associated Press, describing his chemotherapy regimen. Mr. Maddox, 85, fought government-ordered integration for years. But when he was governor from 1967 to 1971, he hired the first black state troopers. He was recently defended by several black legislators who tried to get him a pension. His four years as governor and four years as lieutenant governor fell short of the 10 years required for a pension. David Firestone (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: L'Oreal's Profit Is Up
description: The European cosmetics and perfume giant, L'Oreal of France, reported first-half net profit soared 26 percent to 587 million euros, or $528 million, from 465 million euros a year ago, on a 14 percent revenue increase to 6.9 billion euros, or $6.2 billion, from 6.1 billion euros last year. Operating income rose 12 percent, to 814 million euros. Citing strong growth in the United States, Lindsay Owen-Jones, the chairman and chief executive, said he expected a very good year. ''People may be less willing to buy a car, for example,'' he told analysts, ''but they'll still spend on things like our products to make everyday life a little better.'' John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Bush Aides Urge Congress to Back White House Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  While they did not use the words "guns and butter," two of President Bush's most trusted advisers told lawmakers today that there is room in the federal budget for both, and a need for them too.

title: Thomas Dewart, 90,; Publisher of The Sun
description: Thomas W. Dewart, former president and publisher of The Sun, the long-defunct New York newspaper, died on Sept. 2 at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 90.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: End To Water Measures
description: Citing improved conditions, Mayor Paul Schell declared an end to Seattle's drought and to voluntary measures intended to reduce water use by 10 percent. The statewide drought is not over, and the mayor and other city officials said citizens should continue to conserve water even though the official call for a 10 percent reduction was being rescinded. Despite major population increases, officials said, the Seattle regional system was using about the same amount of water as it did 25 years ago, thanks to conservation. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, SIR ARTHUR
description: GILBERT-Sir Arthur. The American Friends of The Hebrew University & The Hebrew University of Jerusalem deeply mourn the passing of Sir Arthur Gilbert, member of AFHU Council of Trustees and Hebrew University Board of Governors. Arthur's involvement with the University began when as a teenager he traveled to Palestine to attend the opening ceremony of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem in 1925. Since then, many of the programs at the University have benefited from his & his family's generosity, most notably the Rothberg International School, where The Rosalinde and Arthur Gilbert Cafeteria was dedicated in honor of its benefactor and his late wife. He and his present wife Marjorie also made a generous gift, naming new tennis courts in their honor. In 1997, Arthur received an Honorary Fellowship from The Hebrew University, and in 1999, he received an Honorary Doctorate for his ''unstinting support for the advancement of culture and higher education.'' We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Marjorie, son Colin, granddaughter Windy Lee Gallagher, step daughter Susan Waring, and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menachem Magidor, President Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, Rector Yigal Arnon, Chairman of the Board of Governors

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sanmina Issues Earnings Warning
description: The Sanmina Corporation, which builds electronic equipment for other companies, said yesterday that sales and earnings this quarter would be less than forecast as customers reduce spending. Sales will be $600 million to $620 million for the fourth quarter, ending Sept. 29, the company said. Excluding acquisition-related expenses and charges, Sanmina expects to have a profit of 1 to 2 cents a share. The company was expected to earn 9 cents on sales of $734 million, according to the average estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Sanmina, which makes mobile telephones, personal computers and telecommunications gear, is experiencing falling demand for its products as sales slow for its customers. The company has been buying the manufacturing operations of other companies to add more services and increase efficiency to combat dropping sales.

title: New Indictment Of Ex-Officer Counts Baby Among Victims
description: The Brooklyn district attorney filed a new indictment yesterday against a former city police officer accused of drinking all day and then running down a family, including a woman who was eight months pregnant. The indictment charged the former officer with manslaughter in the death of the woman's baby, delivered by emergency surgery after she died.

description: In the beginning of the Yankees' five-game winning streak, they beat Toronto in extra innings. On the second, third and fourth days, they created a seemingly insurmountable lead in the American League East, sweeping the Boston Red Sox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARUCH, MARCEL
description: BARUCH-Marcel. The Board of Trustees, administration and staff of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center and the Schulman Schachne Institute for Nursing and Rehabilitation record with profound sorrow the untimely death of our beloved and distinguished past Senior Vice President for Long Term Care. Mr. Baruch joined Brookdale in 1965 and in 1970 was appointed Administrator of the Samuel and Bertha Schulman Institute. In 1993 he became Senior Vice President for Long Term Care until his retirement in 1999 due to illness, but continued to provide his wisdom and guidance as our consultant until his death. Although combating cancer for many years, he was a man with an abiding concern for the welfare of others. Marcel Baruch was a valued friend to all who knew him. May the memory of his countless good deeds help ease his family's pain. We will sorely miss him. Our condolences to his wife, Miriam, daughters, Karen, Susan and Rona, and their families. Alvin I. Kahn, M.D., FACP, Chairman, Board of Trustees David P. Rosen, President and CEO Edwin L. Schulman, President Emeritus, Board of Directors, Schulman Schachne Institute Dr. David I. Schachne, President, Executive Committee Cosmo J. LaCosta, FACHE, Executive Vice President for Long Term Care Richard J. Fogler, M.D., Senior Vice President and CMO

It is 1199/ S.E.I.U., New York's Health and Human Service Union, not District 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union.

title: Posada's Fate in Robinson's Hands
description: Frank Robinson has received reports the umpires wrote about Monday's confrontation between Yankee catcher Jorge Posada and the umpire Andy Fletcher. Robinson said today that he would watch videotape of the incident, and that he intended to speak with Posada before rendering a decision in the matter. ''That's something I would want to do, talk to the player involved,'' said Robinson, who oversees on-field operations for Major League Baseball.

description: In the 1970's and 1980's one often read about remote mountain villages where people stayed healthy and vigorous into their 90's, with some individuals reaching extraordinary ages. How did people in these simple, traditional societies achieve such longevity?

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Immigrant Dispute With Britain
description: The dispute over how to handle the growing number of illegal immigrants in France who want to get to England continued with French officials lashing out at the British, saying they should take action of their own. In Paris, the foreign ministry spokesman, Franois Rivasseau, called on Britain to examine its relatively generous policy toward refugees, which he said was out of line with mainland Europe and encouraged migrants to try to sneak across the Channel using the Channel Tunnel. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: MYKROLIS CUTS REVENUE ESTIMATE AND POSTS LOSS
description: The Mykrolis Corporation, a former Millipore Corporation unit that sold shares to the public last month, said that it would post a third-quarter loss and that revenue would be lower than previously forecast. The company, based in Bedford, Mass., said its loss would be 38 cents to 45 cents a share, on sales of $36 million to $40 million. Its revenue was $56.4 million in the second quarter. The company makes filtering and purification equipment for liquids and gases used in microelectronics.

title: An Assault on the Press
description: The Justice Department's clumsy maneuver to obtain the home telephone records of an Associated Press reporter betrays an alarming insensitivity not only to free-press principles but to the department's own investigative policies. The incident blots the reputation of Robert Mueller, the newly installed director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who approved the subpoena earlier this year when he was acting deputy attorney general.

title: Business Health Group Names President
description: The Washington Business Group on Health, an association of large employers, named Helen Darling, an expert on health policy and managed care, as its president yesterday. She had been a senior consultant on group benefits and health costs for the Watson Wyatt consulting firm.

title: For Hingis, Stress Now and Serena Williams Later
description: Under a white sailor cap borrowed from Gilligan, Melanie Molitor flashed a series of disapproving grimaces as she fixed her eyes on the student who happens to be her daughter. Only when Martina Hingis began to use her racket as a stickpin to Daja Bedanova's spirits, and her daughter's advancement to the United States Open semifinal was secure, did Molitor's furrowed brow relax yesterday.

title: Where Word of Mouth Went. Pass It On.
description: Word of Mouth, a popular shop and cafe on the Upper East Side, closed last year, but its catering operation still flourishes. Alicia Reinish, who ran Word of Mouth's catering for more than 10 years, now owns the Catered Word, which has a kitchen in the East Village and continues to deliver treasured Word of Mouth specialties, like herb-flecked meat loaf, lush macaroni and cheese, chicken salad studded with pecans and fennel, apricot-glazed ham, chicken pot pie and lemon mousse. Most main dishes are $12 a pint, and delivery is free. To order: (212) 260-6455.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: U.S. Attacks Again
description: For the fourth time in less than two weeks, American warplanes struck at Iraq, firing at surface-to-air missile sites, antiaircraft batteries and radars in the northern and southern no-flight zone, military officials said. The strikes were carried out ''as a self-defense measure in response to Iraqi hostile threats and acts against coalition forces and their aircraft,'' according to a statement by the United States Central Command. title: Psst, Comrade, Check Out the Erotica in the State Library

"Sex didn't exist in the Soviet Union," said Marina Chestnykh, recalling the upside-down logic that prevailed for much of the Soviet era as she led the way into a cagelike storage area of the Russian State Library here.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Port Handling More Cargo
description: General cargo moving in and out of the New York and New Jersey port increased 11 percent in the first six months of this year compared with the same period last year, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The increase was paced by a 17 percent increase in container trade between the East Coast port and Far Eastern ports throughout Asia. The total value of cargo passing through the port was more than $38.29 billion during that period, said Neil D. Levin, executive director of the Port Authority. The port agency is preparing to spend millions of dollars to deepen and widen channels to accommodate a new generation of larger cargo ships in an effort to maintain the region's dominance among East Coast ports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, BELLE K.
description: BERNSTEIN-Belle K. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deepest sorrow the death of our cherished member Belle K. Bernstein. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Back to the Garage, Again
description: Hewlett-Packard, Silicon Valley's first start-up, still does not seem sure what it wants to focus on when it grows up. Last year it tried unsuccessfully to buy the consulting business of PricewaterhouseCoopers. Then yesterday H-P, the company that two Stanford engineering graduates, William Hewlett and David Packard, started in 1938 with $538 in a now fabled one-car Palo Alto garage, announced that it would spend $25 billion of its stock to acquire Compaq, the world's second-largest personal computer maker.

description: Sweeping changes in the top management of Gazprom, Russia's giant gas monopoly, clear the way for Aleksei Miller, the company's new chief executive, to begin a long-awaited revamping of the company, industry analysts said today.

title: Talks Fail to Reach Agreement on More State School Aid
description: A day of negotiations behind closed doors between the governor and legislative leaders failed to produce an agreement today on more state aid for schools. Afterward, the Republican Senate majority leader said he saw no point in giving school districts more money now that they have sent out their tax bills.

title: PROVIDIAN FINANCIAL CUTS EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The Providian Financial Corporation, a leading issuer of Visa and MasterCard credit cards, cut its 2001 earnings outlook, saying customer purchases and loan demand had weakened. The announcement set off a 22 percent decline in the company's stock price, which fell $8.70, to $30.36 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Providian said it would earn $3.20 to $3.25 a share for the year, short of the $3.28 estimated by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Mexico Takes Small Steps To Improving Its U.S. Ties
description: The United States and Mexico said today that they had agreed on measures to improve food safety, enhance law-enforcement and fight money laundering, but conceded that the thornier job of revamping immigration policy could take years to complete.

title: Fox, on State Visit, Calls for Migration Pact This Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  President Bush welcomed President Vicente Fox of Mexico today for the first state visit of the Bush administration. Mr. Fox pressed the United States to speed its timetable and reach an agreement this year on politically sensitive proposals about the treatment of millions of Mexican immigrants.

title: An Awards Host Deep in Training
description: MTV's Video Music Awards have become such an enormous event, seen in the United States by more than 27 million people (and worldwide by at least three times that), that the host of the show has an opportunity to ignite a career -- or burn it to the ground.

title: Green to Observe Jewish Holy Day
description: Shawn Green, the star right fielder for the Los Angeles Dodgers, said tonight that he would sit out his team's Sept. 26 game against San Francisco in observance of Yom Kippur.

title: Scientists Say Frenzy Over Shark Attacks Is Unwarranted
description: With a summer season framed by a shark attack on a boy in Florida two days after the Fourth of July and the death of a man on Labor Day on the Outer Banks of North Carolina, the danger from sharks could easily be seen as rising dramatically.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Decrease In Chip Sales
description: Worldwide sales of semiconductors fell more than 37 percent in July, to $10.86 billion, said a prominent industry trade group yesterday. The quarterly global sales report, from the Semiconductor Industry Association, attributed the slackening to the economic slowdown and excess inventories, but also indicated that highly expected new products could lead to a turnaround by the end of the year. ''We expect sales of personal computers, communications products and a variety of hand-held devices, including newly introduced digital audio products, will accelerate demand for a broad range of semiconductors,'' said George Scalise, president of the group, in a statement. July sales in the European market dropped 34 percent from the month a year ago; the Americas market was down 51.2 percent, and the Asia-Pacific market was down 29.7 percent. In the Japan market, sales declined 28.6 percent from last July. More than 90 percent of semiconductor producers based in the United States are members of the industry group. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: Gramm Will Leave Senate

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLCHOK, SAUL
description: VOLCHOK-Saul. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn with profound sorrow the passing of an outstanding leader and devoted friend and supporter of the State of Israel. Saul served with great distinction as a National Campaign Vice-Chairman of Israel Bonds and as General Chairman of its Philadelphia campaign. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Susan Weikers-Volchok, Israel Bonds' former National Campaign Chairman, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Gideon Patt President and CEO Burton P. Resnick Chairman of the Board Irwin Hochberg National Campaign Chairman Michael Siegal Vice-Chairman of the Board Roberta Goldstein Nat'l Assoc. Campaign Chrmn.

title: ARTS ABROAD; Psst, Comrade: Check Out the Erotica in the State Library
description: In the official Soviet world all families were happy families and there was no interest in or place for sex outside the nuptial bedroom. ''Sex didn't exist in the Soviet Union,'' said Marina Chestnykh, recalling the upside-down logic that prevailed for much of the Soviet era as she led the way into a cagelike storage area of the Russian State Library here.

title: Leaving Durban: Who Gained?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cable TV Acquisition
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said it had sold its remaining broadband cable holdings to the Liberty Media Corporation for about 5.5 billion euros ($5 billion) as part of its strategy to spin off its noncore assets. Liberty Media will acquire Deutsche Telekom's network of six German cable TV regions, which have more than 10 million subscribers. The sale will include Telekom's TV cable business subsidiaries: its regional operators' holding company, the so-called last-mile distribution networks and an information technology services provider. If the German government approves the agreement, Liberty Media will be the leading TV cable operator, serving 40 percent of German customers. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Woodbury: Group Vandalizes Research Lab
description: The Earth Liberation Front, an underground environmental group, is claiming responsibility for vandalism at a new Long Island cancer research laboratory, Craig Rosebraugh, a spokesman for the group, said yesterday. The Aug. 21 attack, apparently protesting research into biotechnology, left graffiti, $20,000 in broken windows and damage to a water chiller. The vandalism was directed at the Woodbury facility of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, a leading research institution. No arrests have been made. The group has claimed responsibility for similar vandalism on Long Island in recent months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENETAR, BEATRICE
description: BENETAR - Beatrice. Mother, grandmother, great grandmother. Always the best. Memorial gathering at her residence, Saturday, September 8, 3-6PM. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to Cancer Care.

title: Hearst to Start at Tailback for the 49ers
description: The San Francisco 49ers said yesterday that Garrison Hearst would start at tailback for Sunday's season-opening home game against Atlanta, capping his comeback effort of more than two years. The 49ers also released quarterback Rick Mirer after he lost his backup job to Tim Rattay.

title: Detroit's Big Three May Shuffle as Chrysler Struggles
description: General Motors. Ford. Toyota?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOROBIOV, MASHA
description: VOROBIOV-Masha. Of Manhattan, died peacefully at age 67 on September 1 at the home of friends in Plattsburgh, NY. Masha taught Russian language and literature at Vassar College (1977-2000). She provided translation and other invaluable assistance to many Russian emigres, including the poet Joseph Brodsky and the theologian Georges Florovsky. Masha's passing will be mourned by her cousin Longinas Krechinas, her colleagues, her students, and her many friends whose lives were enriched by her gentle-but-firm character, intelligence, sympathetic understanding and generosity of spirit. Contributions in her memory may be sent to the Hospice of the North Country, Plattsburgh, NY.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Reducing Jail Populations
description: Gov. Donald Siegelman said his administration had met a state judge's deadline to reduce the number of state prisoners in county jails. In July, Judge William A. Shashy of Circuit Court threatened to fine the state up to $30,000 if it did not lower the number of prisoners in county jails to fewer than 459 from 1,445 by Sept. 3. County sheriffs had complained that the jails were overcrowded because the state had no room in its prisons. The state filed papers stating that only 398 prisoners remained in jails, with the rest absorbed by state prisons or put into work or restitution programs. Judge Shashy did not rule on whether he considered the state in compliance. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Theater, Old Friends and Merit Badges
description: My father died when I was 2 1/2. Two years later, in 1960, my entire family -- I, my four brothers and my mother and stepfather -- moved from Chicago to the Jersey Shore in Deal. It was like being on a spaceship, coming to this new place from downtown Chicago.

title: Boeing Moves Into Chicago Headquarters
description: The Boeing Company opened a new headquarters in downtown Chicago today, four months after the company chose the city as its new base to underline an expansion beyond aircraft building.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Bankruptcies On the Rise
description: Bankruptcies surged in New York State in the last quarter, rising slightly faster than the national average, according to the American Bankruptcy Institute. In New York, bankruptcies rose by 26 percent in the three months ended in June, to 20,192, while nationally, bankruptcies rose 24.5 percent in the same stretch. The biggest increase in the state, 29.6 percent, was in the Western District, which includes Buffalo and Rochester. In the Southern District, which covers New York City, bankruptcies rose by 24.8 percent. But given its size, New York has a relatively low level of bankruptcy filings, said the institute, which ranks the state 30th in bankruptcies over the past 12 months, after adjusting for population size.

title: CLOROX SAYS THAT TRASH-BAG SALES HELPED LIFT PROFITS
description: The Clorox Company, the nation's leading maker of household bleach, said yesterday that profit in its current quarter would top expectations because lower prices for Glad trash bags were leading to an unexpected increase in sales. Profit in the quarter, which will end Sept. 30 and is the first quarter of the company's fiscal year, will be 36 cents to 38 cents, 2 cents more than Clorox's forecast a month ago and more than the 35-cent estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Clorox, whose products have been losing sales to cheaper store brands, had lowered estimates twice since December before the revision yesterday. Price cuts ranging from about 5 percent to 10 percent on trash bags have been passed on by retailers faster than expected, leading to higher sales, a spokeswoman, Kathryn Caulfield, said.

title: In France, Few Pickers May Mean No Nouveau
description: IT'S harvest time in the vineyards of France, and the growers are facing serious shortages. Not of grapes, but of people to pick them.

title: Few Details On What Deal Might Mean To PC Users
description: In announcing their proposed merger, the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Compaq Computer Corporation gave few clues about how the agreement would affect the average buyer of their computer products.

title: Beyond Catfights
description: To the Editor:

title: Lightning Strikes More Than Twice
description: Lightning -- the atmospheric discharge of electricity -- occurs about 100 times a second worldwide. Scientists speculate that number could double or triple by mid-century.

title: BUSH AND DASCHLE AGREE NOT TO TAP SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The White House and the Senate Democratic leader said today that they had agreed not to tap the Social Security program to pay the government's other bills, an agreement that economists insist is almost certain to be broken this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONDREN, ALICE B.
description: CONDREN-Alice B. Age 98, a retired teacher with the N.Y.C. School System died on August 30, 2001 in Port Jefferson, N.Y. Sister of the late Mary Conway. Aunt of Ann Clancy, Mary Jane Conway Matier and the late John Conway. Great Aunt of Barbara Clancy, Mark Conway, Susan Conway Abbate, Catherine, Kevin, John and Major Paul Matier U.S.A.F. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday September 7, at 12 P.M. at St. Andrew's Church in Colchester, CT. Burial to follow in Old St. Andrew's Cemetery. A memorial Mass will be held 12 P.M. on September 15, at the Corpus Christi Catholic Church, 529 West 121 St., N.Y.C. on Saturday. Memorial donations to Friends of Liturgical Music, C/O Corpus Christi Church in her memory.

title: A Round of Applause for Riesling
description: FOR many people, Alsatian wine comes as a revelation. Usually, it is the extravagant perfume of the love-me-or-hate-me gewrztraminer, so different from all other wines, that receives the initial attention. But in Alsace, as in Germany, all roads eventually lead to riesling.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages on Monday about ''Tales of Hoffmann,'' scheduled to open the Washington Opera's season on Saturday at the Kennedy Center, misstated the position of Marta Domingo. She is the director; the conductor is Emmanuel Villaume.

title: Parker Hannifin in Deal
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation, a maker of hydraulic equipment, has bought the Aeroquip air-conditioning and refrigeration unit of the Eaton Corporation for an undisclosed price. The unit, with annual sales of about $75 million, makes mechanical controls and fluid systems for commercial and residential air-conditioners and refrigeration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, JUDY SLIFKA
description: ROBINSON-Judy Slifka. With deepest sorrow we mourn the loss of our beautiful, loving daughter. Wife of David, mother of Shana, and sister of Jerry. Naomi and Phil Slifka

title: Archiving the Past, but Embracing the Future
description: DEEP in the bowels of the New York Public Library, Rodney Phillips leafed through the call cards shot down from the Rose Reading Room upstairs into the stacks by a pneumatic tube: ''The House and Garden Book of Interiors,'' a scholarly work on Africa and ''The Last Romantic,'' a biography of Max Eastman, editor of the leftist magazine The Masses, by William L. O'Neill.

title: Loften Mitchell Memorial
description: A memorial for Loften Mitchell, a playwright, author and teacher and an early leader of the black theater movement, will be held on Sunday at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street, Harlem. Ossie Davis will be the host. Mr. Mitchell died on May 14 at 82.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Sought In Rape Of Woman, 77
description: The police said yesterday they were searching for a handyman wanted in the rape of an elderly woman in Williamsburg. The authorities said the handyman, Santos Flores, 34, entered a 77-year-old woman's home last Thursday to do routine maintenance. Once inside, he beat, choked and raped the woman, and then stole jewelry from her, said Capt. Salvatore Magaddino of the Brooklyn major crimes squad. The woman was released from the hospital on Monday. Mr. Flores, a day worker with no permanent address, is also a suspect in a Queens sex attack that took place in February. The police asked that people with information about Mr. Flores call (800) 577-TIPS.

title: 20 Hurt in Jerusalem In Suicide Bombing
description: A man who apparently was a Palestinian dressed like an ultra-Orthodox Jew blew himself up in central Jerusalem, injuring 20 people.

title: Panic as Bomb Explodes Near Belfast Catholic School
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 5  Protestant residents on a flashpoint street in North Belfast threw a homemade bomb at Roman Catholic girls on their way to elementary school just before 9 this morning, sending a group of 100 students and parents into panic and seriously injuring two police officers.

title: Early Rally Mostly Fades As Tech Shares Stumble
description: Stocks tried to stage a robust rally yesterday, but lost momentum in the last hour of trading.

title: When Is Bomb Not a Bomb? Germ Experts Confront U.S.
description: A former senior government lawyer yesterday vigorously disputed the Bush administration's assertion that the global treaty banning biological weapons permits nations to test such arms for defensive purposes.

title: Bold Move Will Test Executive's Skill
description: Only a month ago, there were doubts about Carleton S. Fiorina's longevity as the chief executive of the Hewlett-Packard Company. H.P., as the big computer and printer maker is known, was suffering badly in the industry slump. The Silicon Valley rumor mill, analyst comments and media reports all suggested that Ms. Fiorina, 46, was in trouble.

title: Investors in Russian Oil Are Lured With Dividends
description: Eager to live down their poor reputations, Russian oil companies are taking up a practice that has fallen out of fashion in Western corporate boardrooms: paying shareholders a rich dividend.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Homeless Are Ordered To Move
description: Portland officials ordered the residents of Dignity Village, a collection of tents and other shelters housing about 75 homeless people, off state property downtown. But the residents have voted to stay, saying a new site chosen by the city is unacceptable. The new site is on the edge of town and is ringed by barbed wire. The police may be called in to evict the residents. The tent city was created 10 months ago to protest Portland's shelter system and has since occupied a handful of sites downtown. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: A Top Jeweler In Britain To Divide
description: Asprey & Garrard, jeweler to royalty and maker of baubles for the very rich, said today that it would split itself in two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIGSBERG, MAYNARD
description: KOENIGSBERG - Maynard. We mourn the loss of our friend, brother-in-law, and uncle. His joie de vivre, laughter and warm smile will be missed. Our love goes out to Elaine, Jeri and David, Kim and Barry, Craig and Jill and his grandchildren. David and Harriet Barbara and Wayne Carol and Andy Ellen and David

title: The Path to Diversity? Different Differences
description: A federal appeals court ruling last week striking down the University of Georgia's use of racial preferences in its freshman admissions program once again places the issue of affirmative action at the forefront of America's legal agenda. If Georgia appeals, and if the Supreme Court chooses to hear the case, the resulting decision could well be the court's most decisive statement on race since its landmark 1978 ruling in Regents of the University of California v. Bakke.

title: Safin Finally Catching Up to Last Season
description: The procrastination of Marat Safin has left him scurrying to catch up to the player he was a year ago, when winners came as easily as wishing for them and a United States Open title arrived with the overnight speed of express mail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, MONTE A.
description: POSNER-Monte A. Passed away September 3rd, 2001 after a long illness. Taught social studies 30 years in Far Rockaway High School. Served with distinction in U.S. Air Force Intelligence. Cherished by family and friends for his sense of humor and love of books. Renaissance man and opera lover extraordinaire. Pre-deceased by wife Ruth. Survived by wife Barbara, brother Ronald, daughters Marla and Felicia, stepchildren Lisa, Eric and Scott, grandchildren Melissa, Samantha, Justin. Funeral Service at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, at 10 A.M. Wednesday, September 5th.

description: SCHRECK-Rae. SAR Academy mourns the loss of the beloved mother of Michael Schreck, Executive Director, and to his father Aaron and brother Jerry, grandchildren and to the entire family, may they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President Rabbi Joel Cohn, Principal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COZZOLI, MICHAEL P.
description: COZZOLI-Michael P. Of Sands Point, NY on September 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Lucille. Loving father of Michelle DiBlasi, John Cozzoli and Dina Falzone. Cherished grandfather of seven. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial, on Thursday, 9:30 AM at St. Peters RC Church, Port Washington.

title: Bungee Jumping to Save Minutes: It's Called Reality
description: The first scenes of ''The Amazing Race'' may seem familiar to many New Yorkers. After getting some important documents at the official starting point, Bethesda Fountain in Central Park, 22 determined people grab their luggage and rush to make a flight. Some immediately hail taxis; one couple decide they'll make better time taking the subway; others stop to find a pay phone and inquire about schedules. Looks like just another rush hour in Midtown Manhattan. Soon the voice-over announces, ''The 11 teams are now approaching Johannesburg, South Africa, and they have no idea what's in store for them.''

title: Once-Strong Pillar of Houston's Economy Looks Shaky
description: There were few bright spots here during the energy slump of the mid- to late 1980's, when oil prices crashed and shiny new downtown office buildings stood half-empty. At one point, average home prices had dropped by one-fourth, and the joke was that only the seller had to bring a checkbook to real estate closings.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Chatham: Bridge Repair Bill Signed
description: New Jersey's 21 counties will get $100 million of $145 million in state transportation money to repair or rebuild bridges under a law signed here yesterday by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco. The money is the last installment from a $500 million bond issue approved in 1999. Some $100 million will go to county or municipal road and bridge work and $45 million will go to structures overseen by the state. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS AGAIN EXTENDS BID FOR SHIPBUILDER
description: The General Dynamics Corporation extended its $2.6 billion offer for Newport News Shipbuilding, the military contractor, for a sixth time because federal regulators need more time to review the proposal. The $67.50-a-share offer for Newport News, the only maker of nuclear aircraft carriers in the nation, expired Friday. About 22.5 million, or 76 percent of Newport News's shares have been tendered, General Dynamics said. The new offer expires Sept. 14. General Dynamics and the Northrop Grumman Corporation are competing to acquire Newport News. Northrop Grumman, which is based in Los Angeles, extended its offer Thursday, to Sept. 13.
