description: BANKRUPTCIES ON THE RISE

title: E.P.A. Faults Ohio Agency Headed by a Bush Nominee
description: The Environmental Protection Agency released a preliminary report today that found severe flaws in several Ohio environmental programs, some of which were supervised by a former official who has been nominated to become the agency's top enforcement officer.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They accuse me of being present there and watching when civilians were murdered. That is a monstrous accusation. Who would bring a camera with him if he wanted to do something like that?''

title: Julian Scheer, 75, a Leader In Selling the Space Program
description: Julian W. Scheer, whose deft handling of public relations helped foster America's fascination with the space program from the early orbits of Earth until the first Moon landing, died on Saturday at his cattle ranch in Catlett, Va. He was 75.

title: The Invention That Led Sailors Not to Feel at Sea
description: THE RIDDLE OF THE COMPASS

title: Ernst & Young Has Formed Investing Arm
description: Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, announced yesterday that it had formed Ernst & Young Corporate Finance L.L.C., a wholly owned subsidiary with licensed broker dealers, which would be able to act as a private placement agent as well as assist in mergers and acquisitions, buyouts and revampings.

title: Bush Administration Announces Patent Deal on Stem Cells
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5  The Bush administration announced today that it had reached an agreement with the university that owns the patent on embryonic stem cells that will allow government scientists broad access to them for basic research.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the screenwriter Lawrence B. Marcus misspelled the surname of a star of ''Petulia,'' for which he wrote the script. The actor is Richard Chamberlain, not Chamberlin.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Newark Arena Plan Faces Tough Legislative Fight
description: Two days before a critical committee meeting, the ambitious plans to build a $385 million sports arena in Newark and redevelop the Meadowlands are in the middle of a fierce political struggle that could scuttle the whole project before it ever gets to the full Legislature.

title: China Reckons With AIDS
description: Until this summer, Chinese officials called AIDS a product of capitalist decadence and pretended that the virus was not a threat in China. While the United Nations estimated that a million Chinese had the AIDS virus, China tried to silence those who talked about it. Fortunately, that charade has ended. China's health minister acknowledged in June that 600,000 Chinese were infected, and his deputy recently admitted that China had an AIDS epidemic. Greater openness and aggressive measures to combat AIDS should now be possible.

title: Footlights
description: Off the Wall

title: Rain Delay Can't Dull Kuerten's Sharpness
description: Gustavo Kuerten heard the alarm late Sunday night. It shook him, charged him and finally, taught him. By overcoming a two-set deficit to Max Mirnyi in the third round, Kuerten approached last night's fourth-round match against Albert Costa with perspective.

title: A Packed, and Raucous, Hearing on the Millennium Pipeline
description: Hundreds of people filled a school auditorium tonight to denounce the proposed Millennium Pipeline, a natural gas line that would cut across New York and, in the view of many here, ruin the environment and threaten homes with leaks or explosions.

title: Australia Lowers an Overnight Interest Rate
description: Citing sluggish global growth, the Reserve Bank of Australia lowered its benchmark overnight interest rate, the fourth time this year that it has cut borrowing costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, JANIS YATES SIMMS
description: NORTON-Janis Yates Simms. The Travel Pals lost their irreplaceable Queen of Hearts. Her joy in life touched all who knew her. Love to Jeff, Jennifer, Brad and Bill for sharing her. Evelyn Cunningham, Norma Leach, Martha Lewis, Jeanne Lofton, Ersa Poston, Mary Burke Washington, Joyce Wein and Audraine Wilson

title: Executive Changes in Media and Advertising
description: Mike Nash was named account supervisor at the Orange Zone, Irvine, Calif., a unit of the T&O Group that specializes in youth marketing. He had been senior account executive at McElroy FCB, Newport Beach, Calif., part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Western TV May Be Nearer For Chinese
description: After a series of meetings with top-level Chinese officials, AOL Time Warner and the News Corporation said yesterday that they had moved closer to a long-sought goal of receiving permission from the Chinese government to broadcast their television programs in China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODEST, OTTO WILLIAM
description: MODEST-Otto William. Devoted husband of the late Dorothy (nee Wendell). Beloved father of Rosemarie Antoni, Barbara Eyrich, and Virginia Modest. Loving grandfather of Edward Antoni, Jr., and Christopher Antoni. Reposing at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Avenue, Bronx, NY until Friday 10:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Frances de Chantal Church, Bronx, NY 11 AM. Interment is at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting on Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Makeup Store In East Harlem
description: When Susan Van Brackle received a $100,000 loan last year from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a federal, state and city economic development program, she hoped to open a cosmetics store at Harlem U.S.A., the new shopping center at West 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. But the rent proved out of reach. Instead, Ms. Van Brackle's store, Miksu, will open next week in East Harlem, in a 700-square-foot space at Lexington Avenue and East 123rd Street. Customers will be able to have makeup applied or custom-blended, said Ms. Van Brackle, who created her cosmetics line while studying at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Health Union Puts Weight Behind Ferrer
description: A powerful union representing health care workers has decided to abandon its neutrality and endorse Fernando Ferrer's bid for mayor, giving him a potentially major boost in the waning days of the primary race.

title: Rockets' Taylor Could Miss Season
description: Maurice Taylor, the Houston Rockets forward who recently signed a $48 million contract over six years, injured his right Achilles' tendon while playing in a pickup game in Detroit and could miss the entire season. Rockets General Manager Carroll Dawson said the tendon was apparently torn, and if that is the case, Taylor will have surgery today. The injury will be evaluated by team physicians when Taylor arrives in Houston. The 6-foot-9, 260-pound Taylor averaged 13 points and 5.5 rebounds for the Rockets last season. (AP)

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Seeking End To College Suit
description: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove and Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, both Democrats, asked a federal judge in Oxford to approve a $500 million proposed settlement in a 26-year-old college desegregation lawsuit. But in a hearing on the proposed settlement, Judge Neal Biggers of Federal District Court questioned whether desegregation had been put on the back burner by the proposal, which seeks to improve three historically black universities. Opponents of the settlement are expected to testify today.

title: Study Details Decline In Spending on Ads
description: In another sign that the advertising economy is still struggling, spending by advertisers in traditional media fell 5.9 percent in the first half of 2001 compared with the corresponding period a year earlier, according to CMR in New York, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSON, JAMES L.
description: WATSON-James L. The Board of Directors and members of the Customs and International Trade Bar Association (CITBA) offer our condolences to the family and friends of Judge Watson, a Judge of the United States Court of International Trade for more than 3 decades. Judge Watson was a man of compassion and a true believer in the rule of law. His decisions were fair, well reasoned, and beautifully written and always garnered the respect of the litigants before him and of the bench and bar. He always was helpful to the attorneys practicing before him and always taught the lesson of understanding and presenting the facts and the law fully and fairly. We will all miss his wisdom, friendship, and counsel. Sidney N. Weiss, President CITBA

title: What Ancient Iran Did for Laughs
description: ''Wit and Wine,'' an exhibition of ancient Iranian ceramics, which opens on Friday at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, has plenty to make the visitor smile, like the object at left. It is a wine vessel with two feet and, unlike most of the 45 objects in the show, appears to be in the form of a human, not of a stag, ram or bull. The pieces, from the Arthur M. Sackler Foundation, date from 5,000 to 100 B.C. They are on view through Dec. 30 at the museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000.

title: Dell Founder Gains 4.2 Million Shares
description: Michael S. Dell, the founder and chief executive of the Dell Computer Corporation, has exercised options to acquire 4.2 million shares of the company, the No. 1 personal computer maker, for a gain on paper of about $81 million.

title: Finding Fault
description: Wall Street frowned on the proposed merger of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer yesterday, viewing the deal as an admission of weakness rather than strength and as an indication that a shakeout has begun in the brutally competitive computer business.

title: Summer's Bounty, the Kitchen's Alchemy
description: MY mother always told me my eyes were bigger than my stomach. The only thing that has changed is that I have become more discriminating about what I can't get enough of.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Suit Over Voting Machines
description: A group representing disabled people said it planned to file suit today against the District of Columbia for buying new voting machines that are inaccessible to blind people. Jim Dickson, vice president of the American Association of People with Disabilities, said the suit contended that the purchase violated the Americans With Disabilities Act, which says a jurisdiction's new equipment must be accessible to the blind and the disabled. The district bought optical scan voting machines, in which spaces are marked with a pencil, making it difficult for Washington's 16,000 blind people to vote. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Stake In Carmaker
description: The Daihatsu Motor Company, a unit of the Toyota Motor Corporation, and Mitsui & Company, agreed to buy a controlling stake in Malaysia's second-largest carmaker to help expand small-car production in Southeast Asia. UMW Holdings Bhd., MBM Resources Bhd. and other shareholders of Perusahaan Otomobil Kedua Nasional Sdn., or Perodua, will set up a company for the carmaking units, and then sell 51 percent of it to the Japanese companies, UMW said. Daihatsu already owns 20 percent of Perodua.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Corrections
description: A set of driving directions in Weekend on Friday with an article about visiting Poultney, Vt., omitted a step. From New York City, drivers may take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to Exit 24 (not Exit 20), then the Adirondack Northway to Exit 20. The trip continues up Route 9 north to Route 149, east to U.S. 4, then north to Route 30 and east into Poultney.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: Watching For Weapons At School
description: Junior and senior high school students in Rock Springs are carrying transparent mesh bags to school rather than traditional backpacks, under a new rule that should allow school officials to detect weapons more easily. Since the shootings at Columbine High School in Colorado in 1999, schools in Rock Springs have been repeatedly disrupted by bomb threats. There have been about 18 such threats in the school district since 1999. Metal detectors that were installed last year have been put aside while the new backpack policy is tested. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Durban Walkout: Who Gained?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Last Rose of Summer, Dipped in Sugar Crystals
description: Women pin fake camellias and roses on stylish suit jackets all the time. Now you can adorn a special cake with a real rose, a crystallized edible work of art. Toni Elling, who owns Meadowsweets in Middleburg, N.Y., and has for years crystallized pansies and violas, a type of pansy, is preserving heirloom roses that are grown organically in California. Most of her flowers, which can be ordered from (888) 827-6477 or www.candiedflowers.com, are $3 to $7 each. The rose on the left, the Betty Boop, is $14. Meadowsweets also sells kits ($24) for crystallizing your own flowers. It includes material for about 75 pansies, a crystallized sample and a phone number for help. Prices exclude shipping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAND, LILLIAN
description: STRAND-Lillian. On September 3, 2001. Beloved sister of the late Anna. Memorial service Thursday, at 10 AM, St. Mark's Lutheran Church, Yonkers, New York.

title: F.I.T. Names 2 Deans
description: The Fashion Institute of Technology has named two new deans. JOSEPH S. LEWIS III, an artist and writer, has been appointed dean of the School of Art and Design, overseeing 16 academic departments including the accessories, display and exhibit design and toy design departments. Mr. Lewis was previously chairman of the art department at the California State University at Northridge. F.I.T. also named MARIA ANN CONELLI as dean of its School of Graduate Studies, which includes programs in cosmetics and fragrance marketing and in management, gallery and retail art administration. Dr. Conelli was formerly chairwoman of the history of decorative arts master's program, which is run in collaboration with the Parsons School of Design, the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum and the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Isles and Yashin Set $87.5 Million Deal; Lindros Hits the Ice
description: A franchise mired in obscurity for nearly two decades stole a little thunder from the Olympics today.

title: Sir Arthur Gilbert Dies at 88; Gave Art Objects for Museum
description: Sir Arthur Gilbert, a British-born real estate developer and philanthropist who donated his valuable collection of silverware and other decorative arts to a new museum in London that carries his name, died on Sunday in Los Angeles, his home for the last five decades. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACLEOD, DR. NORMAN W.
description: MacLEOD-Dr. Norman W. On September 3, 2001. Beloved uncle of many nieces and nephews, and dear friend to many. Funeral services Friday, 3:30 pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Family will be receiving friends on Thursday 6:00-8:00 at Frank E. Campbell.

title: 14 Girls Tied to Hazing Case Are Suspended From Team
description: For school officials here, the first tipoff came last week in an anonymous letter that said members of the girl's field hockey team had hazed younger teammates weeks ago during a visit to a summer hockey camp.

title: Finding Depth in Simplicty in Rural Iran
description: Hassan Yektapanah's ''Djomeh'' offers the latest evidence that the spirit of Italian neorealism has taken up residence in Iran. At first glance ''Djomeh,'' which won the Camera d'Or (for best first feature) at the 2000 Cannes International Film Festival, is a simple, almost anecdotal story embedded in the daily rhythms of rural life in a dusty, mountainous corner of Iran. But on reflection it proves to be an investigation, at once lucid and enigmatic, of exile, loneliness and the fragile possibility of friendship.

title: Consensus in Reading War If Sides Would Only Look
description: A SENSELESS war over reading instruction still rages between proponents of phonics, who emphasize skills like sounding-out words, and of whole language, who emphasize that reading motivation and fluency come from exposure to literature. In truth, there is little difference between the two camps.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Dot-Commers Trade Options for Books
description: Back in the reign of the dot-coms, Colvin Pitts, 22, left his computer science classes and backpack behind at Stanford University for a job as a programmer at Media3k, a San Francisco streaming media Web site that set him up with a $45,000 salary and stock options worth $70,000.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Vodafone To Cut Spending
description: Europe's largest wireless-phone company, Vodafone, will cut investment in building networks for faster mobile-phone services by at least 1 billion ($1.4 billion), said analysts who attended a briefing on Monday. The company said two months ago that it would reduce base stations in Britain by the end of the year to about 750 from its previous goal of 1,200. Vodafone will also spend at least 10 percent less than the 10 billion set for network construction over a two-year period.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Havas Extends Offer
description: Havas Advertising said that it would extend its 425 million ($615 million) offer for the Tempus Group to Sept. 17, having failed to receive enough shares to take control. Havas needed more than 50 percent of the shares and had received 29.3 percent. The Havas offer was topped last month by a 437 million bid from the WPP Group of Britain. Havas has the option of raising its bid but will probably wait until WPP releases its offer documentation next week before making a move, people close to the discussions said. Most of the shares tendered come from Tempus executives, who agreed to turn them over when the Havas offer was announced July 19. Havas said the deadline could be extended again. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLSTEIN, ELIZABETH M.
description: ULLSTEIN-Elizabeth M. Born July 4, 1905. Died August 24, 2001. Survived by Klaus and Julia Saalfeld, and Kurt Ullstein.

title: As Fresh as a Soybean Can Get
description: Most of the year, frozen is the only way you can get those high-powered cocktail nibbles edamame, which are soybeans in the pod. Fresh ones are now available and will be in season until the first frost, usually in October, and are also good for adding to salads, soups and pilafs. They are grown in Peconic, on Long Island's North Fork, by Sang Lee Farms, which has been in business for more than 50 years and specializes in Asian produce. The soybeans are a bright green and come two or three to a small pod. They can be boiled or steamed in the pod for about 10 minutes. Dust the pods with coarse salt and serve them warm. Pop them open and eat the beans, which have a rich, almost honeyed taste. They are $6.99 a pound at Citarella stores, and $2.49 a half-pint at the farm, 25180 Country Road 48, Peconic, N.Y.; (631) 734-7001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOOBIN, LEO
description: DOOBIN-Leo. Age 79, of Charlotte, NC, formerly of Cedar Grove, NJ. Former general manager of Yonkers Raceway, past president of Monticello Raceway. Husband of Thelma, father of Stanley, Beth Blazek and the late Donald Doobin. Beloved grandfather of Brian, Sara, David and Michael. For time of services please call Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel (201)843-9090.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, DR. BERNARD
description: GOLD-Dr. Bernard. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York mourns the passing of our beloved member, Dr. Bernard Gold. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Denise, and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Rose Schecter, President

title: Business Travel; The debate over airport runways continues as readers respond to proposals by Delta's chief.
description: This is the second installment of comments from readers responding to Leo F. Mullin, chief executive of Delta Air Lines. In an interview in an earlier column, Mr. Mullin had insisted that the best way to deal with mounting airport delays and congestion was to build 50 miles of new runways at major airports.

title: Report Warns Against Plan For Changes In Astronomy
description: The National Academy of Sciences has apparently yesterday headed off a move by the Bush administration that could have revamped the financing and management of the nation's astronomy research, issuing a report saying that the changes would ''seriously weaken the intellectual roots of the discipline'' and that they should not be adopted.

title: Alfonzo Is Hitting, Which Means Mets Are Finally Winning
description: Dave Engle noticed it about three weeks ago. The player he had studied on videotape -- the one who stayed upright in his stance and still with his head, who stomped the dirt with his front foot and drove balls to the gaps -- had finally arrived in person.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Yemen: F.B.I. Is Back
description: A team of F.B.I. investigators returned to Yemen last week to resume their inquiry into the bombing of the Navy destroyer Cole that was interrupted in June when the agents left the country because of terrorist threats, law enforcement officials said. The officials said the agents will operate under tighter security arrangements negotiated between Yemen and the State Department. The Oct 12, 2000, blast killed 17 sailors. David Johnston (NYT)

title: Our Towns; Compassion Is Told to Take A Walk
description: WHEN we last left Amy Mogel, she was trying to persuade state officials to allow her son to take the school bus even though they live too close to Chatterton Elementary School to qualify. Two houses too close.

title: How Powell Decided to Shun Conference
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell first heard of the United Nations conference on racism when, while learning the ropes of the State Department in January, he was urged by a senior Clinton administration official to mark the date in his calendar and go to Durban to tell his own remarkable story as emblematic of progress in civil rights in this country.

title: Charleroi Journal; A Rust-Belt City's Mean Streets Keep Their Edge
description: In Charleroi, they have a name for the city's most dangerous district: it's called ''Chicago.'' Belgians apparently watch a lot of old gangster movies.

title: From Champ Gymnast to Medical School Mentor
description: Francine E. Garrett had performed jumps and back flips atop the balance beam perhaps 1,000 times with smooth landings.

title: Whole Grain Defined
description: The Truth About Rye

title: Teacher Exodus Documented
description: The United Federation of Teachers has come up with a new estimate of how many New York City teachers leave for the suburbs, suggesting that nearly 1,300 left for other districts in New York State last year. A separate survey by the schools chancellor, HAROLD O. LEVY, found that about 1,100 teachers leave for the suburbs each year and SOL STERN, a fellow at the Manhattan Institute who has studied such departures, came up with a much smaller figure, closer to 150. The union's figure was based on a comparison of the Social Security numbers of teachers who left in 2000 with the numbers of all current members of the state teachers' union, which represents teachers in most of the state's other school districts. It found 1,282 matches, most of them in the nearby suburbs. Using the same method, the union determined that 991 teachers left for other New York State districts in 1999, and 777 did so in 1998. Abby Goodnough

title: Fruitier And Lighter Than Beer
description: Magners Irish cider is a light but complex new refresher, which comes in long-neck beerlike bottles and provides a mild 4.5 percent alcoholic boost. The cider has a pale toast color and the subtle applelike fruitiness of a good chardonnay. Not so filling as beer, it is delightfully easy to drink on its own or with food. It is made and bottled in Ireland by Bulmers. Magners is the company's export label. The cider is about $6.99 for a six-pack at supermarkets and delis.

title: Where Word of Mouth Went. Pass It On.
description: Word of Mouth, a popular shop and cafe on the Upper East Side, closed last year, but its catering operation still flourishes. Alicia Reinish, who ran Word of Mouth's catering for more than 10 years, now owns the Catered Word, which has a kitchen in the East Village and continues to deliver treasured Word of Mouth specialties, like herb-flecked meat loaf, lush macaroni and cheese, chicken salad studded with pecans and fennel, apricot-glazed ham, chicken pot pie and lemon mousse. Most main dishes are $12 a pint, and delivery is free. To order: (212) 260-6455.

title: Finding Perfection in a Lumpy Little Round
description: IT was more than 35 years ago, alas, when I first visited La Pyramide in Vienne, south of Lyon, the great restaurant where Fernand Point trained so many of today's three-star French chefs. I was in the formative years of my career as an eater, still relatively slim, as yet unacquainted with 12-course tasting menus and uninstructed in the catechism of gourmandise.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JONES, ROBERT
description: JONES-Robert. A memorial service for Robert Jones, Editor-inChief of HarperCollins, will be held on Monday, September 10 at The University Club at 3:00 p.m. The University Club is located at One West 54th Street, New York, N.Y. Jacket and tie required.

title: U.S. Restates Its Stand On Missiles In China
description: The Bush administration issued a new set of statements today about how it views the buildup of Chinese nuclear forces, declaring that it would not ''seek to overcome China's opposition'' to Mr. Bush's missile defense plan by dropping any objections to the modernization of China's nuclear forces.

title: At Race Talks, Delegates Cite Early Mistrust
description: As South Africa and the European Union scrambled tonight to salvage a United Nations conference on racism here, the delegates who had gathered from across the world were trying to figure out what went wrong and how.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIVER, RUTH BLAKE
description: OLIVER-Ruth Blake Oliver. Of Boston, died in Mattapoisett, Massachusetts on September 1, 2001. Widow of the late Andrew Oliver, she is survived by three children, Andrew Oliver, Jr. of Chevy Chase, Maryland, Daniel Oliver of Washington, D.C. and Ruth Oliver Morley of Cambridge, Massachusetts, seven grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and a brother, Benjamin S. Blake Jr., of Boston. She was born in Weston, Massachusetts on December 22, 1911, was married in 1936, and lived in New York City from then until 1970 when she moved to Boston. She was a member of the Chilton Club in Boston, the Orton Society, the Fragment Society, the Tuesday Club, the Fortnightly Club, the National Society of the Colonial Dames, the Colonial Society, and the Massachusetts Historical Society. She was a great-granddaughter of Francis Blake, of Weston, who invented the telephone transmitter used for many years by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Funeral services will be held at the Church of the Advent, 30 Brimmer Street, in Boston, on Thursday, September 6 at 11:00 AM. Contributions may be made to The Fragment Society, C/O Mrs. W. Scott McDougal, 39 Proctor Street, Manchester, Massachusetts 01944.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASKILL, CHARLOTTE
description: HASKILL-Charlotte. September 2, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Charles, dearest mother of Carol, artist, a friend to all who knew her. Memorials may be made to Birmingham Bloomfield Art Center, Cranbrook Rd, Birmingham MI.

title: Reno Makes Official Entry Into Race for Florida Governor
description: For months, Janet Reno sure looked like a candidate for the Florida governor's race. Today, she officially became one.

title: Newspapers Announce Mayoral Preferences
description: Several newspaper editorial boards have made their mayoral primary preferences, with The New York Times backing Public Advocate Mark Green in the Democratic contest, praising him for his "political courage" and saying he would evolve into the most successful mayor.

title: Hayes at Home in West Coast Offense
description: In this West Coast summer for the Jets, nearly every bit of offensive minutiae has been examined. We know that quarterback Vinny Testaverde has worked on his footwork, that running back Curtis Martin is so comfortable with the offense now that he no longer feels like a student with too much homework and we know intimate details about Santana Moss's meniscus.

title: Downsized Executive Looking for Work. Will Do (Almost) Anything.
description: When times were good, executives did not hesitate to reach for the brass ring, even if it should have been beyond their grasp. Now that many of them are worrying more about job security than remodeling their retirement homes, they have become more willing to scale back their ambitions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Food Stuff column last Wednesday about Alexandra and Nicolay Mazhirov, who manufacture chocolates in Brooklyn, misstated the location of Odessa, where they used to own a factory. It is in Ukraine, not Russia.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CREDIT SUISSE GROUP, Zurich, Switzerland's second-largest bank, agreed to buy Frye-Louis Capital Management Inc., Chicago, a fund manager that overseas about $1.5 billion, to increase its business of running accounts for wealthy families. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Leaving Durban: Who Gained?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, JOSEPH SILL, JR.
description: CLARK-Joseph Sill, Jr. Age 82. Died peacefully at home in Manhattan of Parkinson's Disease on September 1, 2001. Dearest husband of Mary Lincoln Bonnell. Caring father of Story Clark Resor of Wilson, WY., Joseph Sill, III of Venice, CA., Christopher Avery of New York City and Laurance Reed of Marble Head, MA. Brother of Noel Clark of Washington,D.C.. Fond grandfather of eleven. Joe was a graduate of The Middlesex School, Harvard College and The Harvard Business School. He was a valued energy analyst at Wertheim-Schroeder and Company from 1961 until his health forced his retirement in 1985. He was associated with H.G. Wellington and Company as a consultant until the spring of this year. A service will take place at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave on Thursday, September 6th at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the Middlesex School, Concord, MA., or to the Parkinson's Foundation of Columbia University Medical School, 710 West 168th Street, N.Y.C.

title: Today's Special? Discounts All Around
description: IN the heyday of New York restaurants -- which faded something like the day before yesterday -- there was often that tendency to beg just a little. You might turn on your most charming telephone voice to negotiate a reservation, for instance. Or act just a little too grateful for small favors in the dining room.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chopping Up The Kursk
description: A successful test of a powerful underwater saw cleared the way for cutting off the bow and forward torpedo compartment of the nuclear submarine Kursk, which sank a year ago, taking 118 crewmen to their death on the bottom of the Barents Sea. The remote-controlled bow-cutting operation, which made a one-yard cut initially, still faces uncertainties as it tries to slice through cracked and torn high-tensile steel and debris from the explosion that sank the vessel. The operation is the last major task facing salvage engineers before the submarine is lifted from its 350-foot depth later this month, weather permitting. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Serbian Horns, Blaring for Joy
description: Last week, 350,000 people descended on this small Serbian valley town, home to 3,000 inhabitants and one hotel. The occasion was the 41st annual Trumpeters Festival, one of the most frenetic and freewheeling folk festivals of its kind or perhaps any kind. For four days, revelers drank large amounts of alcohol, ate spit-roasted lamb and pig and danced around and on their tables, as some 40 blaring brass bands wrought chaos on the town until the wee hours.

title: Pitcher's Father May Face Charges
description: A prosecutor in the Dominican Republic is looking into whether to bring criminal charges against the father of Danny Almonte, the ace pitcher for the Rolando Paulino All-Stars, for falsifying two birth certificates, a Dominican official said yesterday.

title: Gramm Joins Republicans Who Plan to Quit Senate
description: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, an ardent conservative whose intellect, tenaciousness and willingness to buck consensus made him a major figure in two decades of Washington budget battles, announced today that he would not seek re-election next year.

title: Text: Remarks by President Bush and President Fox
description: The following remarks by President George W. Bush and Mexican President Vincente Fox were made today at a White House ceremony and were recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: This Time, the Giants Don't Pass on a Kicker
description: In the fifth round of last spring's draft, the Giants spurned the highly rated place-kicker Owen Pochman of Brigham Young and selected John Markham, an unheralded choice from Vanderbilt. Pochman was drafted two rounds later by the New England Patriots.

title: Kim Struggles As Ministers Quit in Seoul
description: As President Kim Dae Jung struggled to rebuild his government after a mass cabinet resignation, it appeared today that the big loser may have been his ''sunshine policy'' toward North Korea, the outstretched hand that is widely admired overseas but increasingly derided at home.

title: Sports of The Times; Opponents Had Met Before
description: AROUND the tight little world of tennis, the Williams sisters are often viewed as an aberration because they seemed to emerge from the laboratory of their father's will. That's not the way you're supposed to do it. You're supposed to play the youth circuits, check into some intense academy, get with the program.

title: The Tasty Fruit of Our Labors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, MIRIAM
description: REISS-Miriam. Died suddenly on Tuesday, September 4, 2001. She survived her true love, Joseph Reiss, by 24 years. Adored mother of Ed and Liz, mother-in-law of Phyllis Reiss and Alan Jaffe. Grandmother of David and Janette; Bob and Beth; Richard, Joey and Erica. Great grandmother of Zach, Ari and Natan (born on August 25 in Jerusalem). Her beloved sisters, Ruth Hyman and Thelma Jassem, were enriched by her devotion. Miriam's 88 vibrant years of life were dedicted to her family, many friends, philanthropy and Israel. She was an expert in all that she did including general repairs, grammar, crossword puzzles, the Internet and, most of all, golf. All of those who were touched by her love and generosity will miss her forever. Services will be held 1 PM Thursday at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made to the Miriam and Joseph Reiss Memorial Fund of UJA-Federation, 130 East 59th Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10022 or a charity of your choice.

title: Larry King's Weekly Column For USA Today to Be Dropped
description: Larry King's USA Today column, a weekly offering studded with plugs, superlatives and dropped names -- all usually in close proximity to one another -- will cease publication at the end of this month.

title: New Jobless Centers Offer More Than a Benefit Check
description: Ginny Velarde can still recall the snaking lines and pervasive gloom of the state unemployment office she visited weekly for three months in 1970. It was ''horrible, horrible, horrible,'' said Ms. Velarde, who lost her job in the sales office of a manufacturing company when it left New York. ''Dismal, depressing, dehumanizing. I don't know how else to say it.''

title: The Steak That Swam To Dinner
description: FOR many home cooks, tuna involves a quick soak in soy sauce and ginger, followed by a visit to the grill. There is nothing wrong with that, but tuna takes equally well to the skillet. At the top of my list for tuna steak possibilities is tuna au poivre, a recipe that plays on tuna's similarity to beefsteak.

title: Dollar Rallies; Interest Rates Rise Sharply
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday while the dollar rallied against the euro and the yen after investors were surprised by an unexpectedly strong report on manufacturing.

title: 18th-Century French Meets American Modern
Is All Fair in Germs and War?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Global Warming May Bring New Variety of Class Action
description: Taking a cue from broad-based class-action lawsuits like those filed on behalf of Holocaust survivors or against tobacco companies, a group of environmental lawyers is exploring novel legal strategies to adopt against global warming.

title: Economic Scene; A vital economy is one that suffers lucky fools gladly.
description: THE dot-com bubble has burst. The stock market keeps taking scary plunges. Even well-established technology companies are suffering from surprising downturns. The cynics of a few years ago are laughing. All that ''irrational exuberance,'' they say, was not just irrational but downright stupid. Grown-ups don't become carried away with the idea of striking it rich.

title: XEROX CREATES OFFICE TO MONITOR ETHICS PRACTICES
description: The Xerox Corporation, amid a regulatory investigation into its bookkeeping, named Allan Dugan as executive vice president to lead a new office that would monitor compliance with ethics and accounting policies. Mr. Dugan, 60, started at Xerox in 1990 and previously was vice president for worldwide business services. He will report to the chief executive, Anne Mulcahy, and the board. Xerox has been under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission since last year. The S.E.C. is investigating whether the company's Mexican unit improperly accounted for bad debts, Xerox said.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

description: KEMPNER-Dr. Ivan. 18 Elul Loved, missed, remembered. Wife, Arline, daughters Robbi, Juli, Lani.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKER, FEROZA
description: MARKER-Feroza. The staff, patients and patients' families of the Mount Sinai Hospital of New York City express their sadness and condolences to the family of Feroza Marker on her untimely death. Ms. Marker was employed as an occupational therapist in the Alzheimer's Disease Caregiver Program for the past four years. She will be remembered for her kindness, gentleness, caring and humorous nature with all people with whom she came in contact. She will be sorely missed.

title: Local Rivalry on Minor Scale
description: In their first season, the Brooklyn Cyclones set New York-Penn League attendance records, captured first place in their division and established themselves as a legitimate landmark to stand beside Nathan's and the Cyclone.

title: From a Crisp Web Image To a Blur, Via the Printer
description: Q. Why do some pictures I see online look fine on my screen but get blurry when I try to print them?

title: The Path to Diversity? Different Differences
description: A federal appeals court ruling last week striking down the University of Georgia's use of racial preferences in its freshman admissions program once again places the issue of affirmative action at the forefront of America's legal agenda. If Georgia appeals, and if the Supreme Court chooses to hear the case, the resulting decision could well be the court's most decisive statement on race since its landmark 1978 ruling in Regents of the University of California v. Bakke.

title: Setting Out The Snares For Hackers
description: THE break-in came on June 4, 2000, at 11:37 a.m. The target was a Sun Sparc5 computer sitting in the spare bedroom of a suburban Chicago house.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about the use of linear induction motors in a roller coaster referred incorrectly to efforts to develop rail and transit systems using such motors. They are indeed already used, by transit systems in several cities, including Detroit, Tokyo and Vancouver, British Columbia.

description: BUTCHIN-Kenneth. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Plan for New Times Building Is Subject of a Public Hearing
description: State officials have scheduled a public hearing for Sept. 24 on a proposed deal to build a 52-story headquarters building for The New York Times across Eighth Avenue from the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

title: Wall St. Remains Cool to Hewlett-Compaq Merger
description: Investor skepticism about a proposed merger between Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer turned to concrete fallout today as both companies' stocks continued to slide, and a major rating service downgraded Hewlett-Packard's creditworthiness.

title: Sheldon Datz, 74, Pioneer in Molecular Chemistry, Dies
description: Dr. Sheldon Datz, who helped develop a technique to observe the interplay of molecules during chemical reactions, died on Aug. 15 in Oak Ridge, Tenn. He was 74.

title: Strike at VW in Mexico Ends Unusually
description: When Volkswagen reached a settlement with union leaders early this morning, the strike at its Puebla plant ended in a most unusual way: without being stopped by the government.

description: A Day in Court, at the Very Least

title: Locked-Out N.F.L. Referees Get New Offer and Set Vote
description: The National Football League yesterday increased its offer to its 119 locked-out officials, and gave them 24 hours to make a decision. Early this morning, the referees were still huddling in an emergency session in Manhattan to vote on the new proposal.

title: Ford Said to Be Considering Merging Engineering Operations
description: Ford Motor may merge its North American car and truck engineering operations as part of its efforts to cut costs, The Detroit News reported earlier today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENKES, LOIS NEE IZENBERG
description: MENKES-Lois nee Izenberg. Of Verona, NJ, on September 5. Beloved wife of Marvin. Devoted mother of Nancy Clayman and Neal Menkes. Dear sister of Jerry Izenberg. Loving grandmother of five grandchildren. Services will be held at Temple Ner Tamid, 936 Broad St., Bloomfield, NJ on Friday, September 7 at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lois Menkes Scholarship Fund, c/o Project Pride, Inc. P.O. Box 1012, Newark, NJ 07102. For information contact Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, NJ.

title: STAPLES NAMES SUCCESSOR TO ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Staples Inc., the office supply retailer, said its president and chief operating officer, Ronald Sargent, would succeed the co-founder, Thomas Stemberg, as chief executive next year. Mr. Stemberg, 52, was named executive chairman, and will oversee public and investor relations as well as new growth opportunities, Staples said. He helped to found Staples with Leo Kahn in 1985 and has been chief executive since 1988. The promotions are effective Feb. 3.

title: In Coffin Making, an Abbey Finds Fiscal Rebirth
description: When he is not in prayerful contemplation, the Rev. Timothy Welsh gives glory to God by laboring in the orchards here at the New Melleray Abbey. But a nonagenarian can do only so much; these days he mostly tools about on his tractor, mowing circles in the monastery's grass.

title: Refereeing Grown-Ups Who Meddle in Child's Play
description: HOW about appearing on ''Oprah'' to explain why a father would beat another parent to death at youth hockey practice? Or gently informing an overeager caller that it is just too early for his 9-year-old son to show the potential to be a major league pitcher? Or telling hyper-competitive suburban parents that the answer to their problem is Silent Sundays -- where adults, essentially, are given a time out?

title: An Analytic Casebook Full of Animal Instincts
description: IN THE FLOYD ARCHIVES

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Telecommunications Deal
description: Portugal Telecom withdrew a $2.4 billion offer to buy the shares it did not own of the Brazilian cellular provider Telesp Celular Participaes, after the stock dropped below a level set as a condition for the bid. Portugal Telecom said it might make a new bid once market conditions improved. In May, Portugal Telecom offered to buy the remaining 58.8 percent of Telesp Celular in a stock swap. The move was intended to strengthen Portugal Telecom's position in a joint venture with Telefnica of Spain that combined both companies' holdings in Brazil. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Many Welfare Recipients Ordered to Reapply to Continue Receiving Aid
description: Welfare recipients reaching their five-year limit for receiving federal benefits must reapply for state-financed aid, according to a memo issued by state officials barely three months before tens of thousands of the state's poorest families are scheduled to reach the end of their entitlements.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Bush Seeks Delay In Wireless Sale
description: The Bush administration said yesterday that it would push for legislation to delay for two years the deadline for selling airwaves for advanced mobile wireless services. The auction of some airwaves was to be completed by September 2002. But the Federal Communications Commission, among other agencies, said more time was needed to determine the appropriate airwaves for third-generation wireless services. Nancy J. Victory, who manages the National Telecommunications and Information Administration at the Commerce Department, said the administration was working to consider shifting wireless spectrum to commercial operators from the government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAW, RALPH ''RAFE''
description: WARSHAW-Ralph ''Rafe''. On August 25, of New York City, formerly of Lawrence, MA. Well-known Costume Consultant to Stage and Television productions, and former Vice President of the New York Theatre Wardrobe Union. Loving brother of Robert B. Warshaw and Thayer S. ''Ted'' Warshaw. Services in Lawrence, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUT, ALAN S.
description: HUT-Alan S., 81. In Palm Beach, FL, on Sept. 3rd. Adored husband of Betty for 58 years. Beloved father of Steve (Margaret), Peggy Diggs (Bradley), Ginny Cartwright (Robert), and Tom (Eve). Cherished Grandpa of Nick, Chris, Matt, Katie, Benjy, Ryan, Willa, and Grace. Contributions in his memory may be made to Planned Parenthood of the Palm Beach & Treasure Coast Area Inc., 5312 Broadway, West Palm Beach, FL 33402, or a charity of choice. Funeral private.

description: To the Editor:

title: Companies Change Shops for Accounts
description: Several advertisers are making decisions on accounts.

title: Songs of Inexperience: Phillies Are Struggling
description: The easy answer, and maybe the right one, is obvious to the Philadelphia Phillies. The team is falling apart, losing sloppily when the games matter most, and the reason must be inexperience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, LOUISE
description: JACKSON-Louise Russell Willauer of Westwood and Nantucket Mass. September 3, age 92. Wife of Ambassador Whiting Willauer, deceased 1962, wife of Edmund B. Jackson, deceased 1990, survived by a son, Whiting Russell Willauer, a daughter, Sally Willauer Nash, a sister, Phoebe Gregg, 6 grandsons, Whiting R. Willauer Jr, William A. Willauer, Peter W. Nash II, Thomas W. Nash, Lewis R. Nash, Andrew O. Nash, and 6 great grandchildren. Funeral service 11:00AM, September 7 at St. Pauls Church, Nantucket. Private burial at Old North Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Nantucket Cottage Hospital, 57 Prospect St, Nantucket, MA 02554, Nantucket Conservation Foundation, Inc., 118 Cliff Road, Nantucket, MA 02554, Nantucket Historical Assoc, 2 Whalers Lane, Nantucket, MA. 02554 or Hospice Care of Nantucket, 57 Prospect St, Nantucket, MA. 02554.

title: Bending Design To Ape Nature
description: Plants aren't boring, so why do planters have to be? Paula Hayes, a New York designer who advocates ''soft'' landscapes, offers pliable silicon plant containers that, she said, ''adapt and morph.'' She calls silicone ''an interesting and friendly material.'' In ''we're not trying to look like clay pot'' colors like chartreuse and pink, the planters are $850 for one cubic foot and $2,000 for the four-cubic-foot size (shown on the gallery owner Marianne Boesky's terrace, above). From Story, (646) 685-0996. LINDA LEE

title: Executive Changes in Media and Marketing
description: Steve Bryant, chief creative officer for public relations for Publicis in the United States, based in Seattle, was named to the additional post of president at the Seattle office of Publicis Dialog, part of the United States Publicis operations. He takes on the president's post from Jeff Hasan, who is leaving, the agency said, to pursue other interests. The United States Publicis operations are part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: A Congressman's Mayoral Pick
description: Representative John Lewis, a Democrat popular in Atlanta politics, endorsed Shirley Franklin, left, in the city's mayoral race. Ms. Franklin, who was a top aide to Mayors Maynard Jackson and Andrew Young, is running against two fellow Democrats in the November election: Robb Pitts, president of the City Council, and former City Councilwoman Gloria Bromell-Tinubu. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Mexico President and Bush Wrestle With Immigration Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  President Bush and President Vicente Fox of Mexico called today for ever-deeper friendship and trust between their two countries and a resolution of the immigration issues that divide them.

title: Gory Details of Surviving Whaler Wrecked in 1819
description: Here's good news for all you young scholars who arrived back in the classroom to find ''Moby-Dick'' on the must-read-by-Monday list: There's a made-for-television movie tomorrow night that covers practically the same ground in only two hours. Trouble is, this gruesome real-life tale may leave you with nightmares far worse than the ones brought on by the prospect of having to read Melville's thick book.

title: EBay Chooses I.B.M. Net Software as Cornerstone Technology
description: I.B.M. will announce today that eBay Inc., the big online auction house, has chosen I.B.M.'s Internet software as its new building-block technology. The Silicon Valley company decided to use I.B.M.'s technology over offerings by Microsoft, Sun Microsystems, BEA and others, after a fierce competition over the last three months.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Start-Up Shows Off First Product
description: Danger Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up, will show off its first product today, a hand-held device called the Hiptop. The device lets users make telephone calls, surf the Internet, send e-mail and instant messages, and store address-book and calendar information. Danger, based in Palo Alto, Calif., intends to start selling the Hiptop for about $200 later this year. It expects the Hiptop, which will be introduced at the DEMOmobile trade show in La Jolla, Calif., to compete with devices like the Blackberry pager. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEGARELLI, EDWARD V.
description: ZEGARELLI-Edward V. Dean Allan J. Formicola, Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, records with profound sorrow the death of Dean Emeritus Edward V. Zegarelli on September 2. Dr. Zegarelli was a renowned oral pathologist who served Columbia with distinction for 41 years, the last 5 of which he served as dean. In 1958 he was appointed to an endowed chair with the title of the Dr. Edwin S. Robinson Professor of Dentistry. He was known as an inspiring teacher and a considerate leader. Dr. Zegarelli authored and co-authored more than 175 articles in professional journals and several dental textbooks. His many contributions to education and research will serve as his legacy to the profession of dentistry. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Irene, his sons Edward V. Jr., David, Philip and Peter and his extended family. Allan J. Formicola, D.D.S., Dean Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BARBARA
description: COHEN-Barbara. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Barbara Cohen, who earned enormous admiration and respect for her exceptional generosity and leadership on behalf of Jewish and other humanitarian causes. Jointly committed to philanthropy, Barbara, and her beloved husband, Joseph, have been exemplary leaders of UJA-Federation. Barbara will be remembered for generations to come for her kindness, wisdom, and caring. We extend our deepest sympathies to Joseph; to Barbara's son, Jarrod, & daughterin-law, Audrey; to her son, Jon; to her grandson, Jordan; and to the entire Cohen family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Nairobi Journal; A Song About Corruption Takes Kenya by Storm
description: When a Kenyan asks for a little tea, he may or may not have a hot beverage in mind.

title: YankeeNets Awaits Baseball's Approval
description: The investors putting an estimated $360 million into the YankeeNets' cable network were expected to reach final agreements last night and were awaiting approval by Major League Baseball, executives involved in the deal said.

title: Clemens Is Reaching Milestones and Recording Victories
description: Toronto's Alex Gonzalez swung confidently and fouled a ball in the first inning tonight, a near miss, and Roger Clemens turned his head and barked out in disgust, realizing how vulnerable his pitch had been. It was going to be one of those days -- a salad day, Clemens calls it, when his fastball lacks meat and he is forced to improvise.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Downgrade Adds to Fallout Over Hewlett-Compaq Deal

title: World Briefing | Europe: Report On U.S. Spy System
description: The United States-led spying system known as Echelon can monitor virtually every communication in the world -- by e-mail, phone or fax -- that bounces off a satellite, the European Parliament was told. But in reporting on a yearlong study of the system that was prompted by concern that American companies were using data from the system to gain a competitive edge, Gerhard Schmid, a German member of the Parliament, said that many European countries had similar abilities and that the very high volume of traffic made exhaustive, detailed monitoring of all communications impossible. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Cyclones Are Minor League, But Not in Merchandising
description: So far, it has been a very good inaugural year for the Brooklyn Cyclones. After winning the final game of the season last night, the team that brought baseball back to Brooklyn had won 52 games and lost only 24, for a won-lost percentage of .684 (a better record than those perennial near-champs the Brooklyn Dodgers ever posted).

title: New Security Webcam Has A Direct Line to the Net
description: Anyone alarmed by the rising level of surveillance in the world may have a new reason to worry. Panasonic has introduced the KX-HCM10, a Web camera that can work while your computer rests. That's because the camera is also a computer. The $499.95 KX-HCM10 has a built-in Web server, software and e-mail program. Attached through an Ethernet connection, the camera's 640 by 480 live video can be viewed from any remote computer and, if the camera is wired to the Internet, from any Web-enabled device (including cell phones) in the form of video downloaded on a Web page or through single images sent by e-mail. The camera can also be wired to a home alarm and will send you an e-mail message if the device goes off. Imagine the excitement when ''You've Got Intruders'' pops up on your screen. Bruce Headlam

title: Venus Williams Is Next In Capriati's Comeback
description: Ten years ago, wearing a look of innocent determination, a 15-year-old Jennifer Capriati waltzed into the United States Open semifinals against Monica Seles with a career yet to mold.

title: Grubman Appears in Court, and the Press Swarms
description: Traffic here has eased, cool ocean breezes have begun to blow and a season that some locals refer to as the ''Summer of Lizzie'' has ended. But in an instant today, an appearance in Town Court by Elizabeth S. Grubman, the Manhattan public relations executive, pierced the post-Labor Day serenity and recalled the hot July days that many said they would rather forget.

title: Candidates Trade Charges Over Fitness
description: In a heated televised debate that focused on credentials more than issues, the two men running for city comptroller accused each other last night of being unfit for the job.

title: Evidence Points to Black Hole At Center of the Milky Way
description: An orbiting observatory has recorded an immense flare at the heart of the Milky Way galaxy, providing what scientists say is the strongest evidence yet that a black hole with millions of times the mass of the Sun lurks there.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I continue being a revolutionary who pursues ideals, growing in the understanding and learning that what is desired is not always possible.''

title: Fox News Fires A Star Host Over CNN Bid
description: The Fox News Channel fired Paula Zahn, one of its prime-time talk show hosts, yesterday after learning that she had received an offer from CNN.

title: Corrections
description: Aheadline on Tuesday about the Labor Day activities of James E. McGreevey and Bret D. Schundler, campaigning for governor of New Jersey, misstated the place of Mr. Schundler's Monday appearances. While Mr. McGreevey campaigned at the beach, Mr. Schundler was in South Plainfield and Rutherford.

description: EISENBERG-Florence. Of Croton on Hudson, NY (formerly Jersey City). Loving aunt of Susan Cabral, Judith Becker, Helaine Schechtman, Alan, Joseph, Michael, Richard and Harry Eisenberg. Services Thursday. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

description: BERNSTEIN-Belle K. On September 4, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Cherished mother of Tennie Leonard and Dr. Richard Bernstein and his wife Dr. Anne Bernstein. Loving grandmother of Julie Borhani, Lauren Menkes, Laura Bernstein, Jeffrey Bernstein and Lili Bernstein and great grandmother of Jodi, Leila, Nate and Madeleine. The beauty of her heart and loveliness of her spirit are everlasting gifts she bequeathed to us. Funeral services will be held on Sunday 10AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Interment to follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation or the Cancer Treatment Research Fund at New York Hospital.

title: AngloGold Makes Offer For Miner In Australia
description: In the boldest move yet to broaden its mining interests beyond South Africa, AngloGold said today that it had offered to buy Normandy, Australia's largest gold miner, for $1.66 billion in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ROBERT
description: LEVY - Robert. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to his family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, FRED
description: BENJAMIN-Fred. Automobile executive, on September 3, 2001. Loving husband to Anita. Devoted father of Damaris and Candice. Former husband of the late Marguerite Benjamin. Survived by brothers Robert and Donald Benjamin. Proud grandfather of Marnie, Jodie, Wendy & Amanda and great granddaughter Callie Marguerite.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARAN, SUZANNE
description: MARAN-Suzanne. Two years gone from us. You are missed and loved each day and you are in our hearts forever. Larry, Andy and Carolin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELOWITZ, TRUDY (GER TRUDE)
description: MENDELOWITZ - Trudy (Ger trude). The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Trudy (Gertrude) Mendelowitz, beloved sister of Murray Charash. We extend our deepest condolences to Murray and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Hyperbole Goes Global for Hopkins-Trinidad Bout
description: Bernard (the Executioner) Hopkins looks at the pomp and circumstance surrounding the biggest fight of his career and senses nothing but disrespect.

title: Following Grandma's Rule, With Spectacular Results
description: A century ago, children learning auction bridge were told by their grandmothers: ''Always lead the highest card of your partner's suit.'' Modern children, more sophisticated, know that this is often nonsense. Leading, say, the queen from Q x x sometimes gives away a trick. But there are some occasions when grandmother is proved sensationally right. Consider the diagramed deal from a game at the Bridge Deck in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: Sit Down And Be Counted
description: The government ordered that Bolivians stay at home yesterday to take part in only the fifth national census in the nation's history. President Jorge Quiroga went on national television to say that the census would help the government assure that assistance goes to the neediest among the country's estimated eight million people.

title: COLEMAN JOINS YANKEENETS
description: The YankeeNets named Leonard Coleman, the former National League president who served in New Jersey government during the 1980's, to lead construction of a proposed $355 million arena in downtown Newark. The arena is projected to be the home of the Devils and Nets for the 2004-5 season.

title: Laptop Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Vermont Governor Won't Seek Re-election
description: Howard Dean, the longtime Vermont governor who gained a reputation as both a fiscal conservative and a social liberal, announced yesterday that he would not seek re-election next year.

title: Court TV Sues to Void Law Banning Televising of Trials
description: Court TV sued New York State yesterday, charging that the state's ban on cameras in the courtroom is unconstitutional and must be lifted.

title: Switch to the Euro Is Forcing Suitcases of Cash to Surface
description: The two Dutchmen in the aging Mercedes looked haggard but betrayed no anxiety when German border guards asked if they were carrying large sums of cash.

title: My Principles, My Minivan
description: Twisting the seductively elegant gold band from Tiffany's (57th and Fifth, New York) on my left hand, I find myself thinking about the recent announcement that Fay Weldon, the British author, has been paid an ''undisclosed sum'' by a certain Italian jeweler to mention its name at least a dozen times in her new novel. So-called product placement has long provided significant revenue for motion pictures, but books . . . books! As a writer, I'm shocked.

title: Oklahoma Prosecutor to Seek Death for Bombing
description: Facing the old elm tree that survived the Oklahoma City bombing and some of the parents and children of the victims, the Oklahoma County district attorney said today that he would go ahead with the prosecution of Terry L. Nichols on 160 state charges of murder. He said he would seek the death penalty.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about gentrification in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, misstated the surname of a nurse who lives in a house her parents bought in 1953. She is Gail Peterson; Fields is the name of her daughter Tanyika.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCAN, DANIEL
description: KOCAN-Daniel. Of Frederick, MD, formerly of Potsdam, NY, died September 4, 2001. Survived by his wife, Teresita, & daughters, Stacey Kocan-McCormick of Rockville, Maryland, and Elizabeth McHenry of Zephyr Hills, FL. Memorial services Saturday, September 8th, 2 PM, from the Keeney & Basford Funeral Home, 106 East Church St., Frederick, MD. Contributions to Potsdam College, Potsdam, New York 13676.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Capital May Be Frozen In Time
description: The Supreme Court ruled that daylight saving time is unconstitutional in Mexico City. The capital, a district of nearly 20 million people, will be on a different time from the rest of the nation next year unless Congress decides otherwise. Mexico City's government was alone in challenging a federal decree to match Mexico's time zones with those of the United States, so the ruling applies only to the capital, which had argued that daylight saving time disrupted the rhythm of life. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Troubled A.T.M. Networks
description: A day after Citibank's network of 2,000 automated teller machines failed because of a software problem, some consumers still had trouble using its A.T.M.'s yesterday. At the same time, an unrelated software flaw briefly hit some of Chase Manhattan's A.T.M.'s yesterday morning. Kristen Batteria, a Chase spokeswoman, described the problems as isolated and unrelated to the Citibank slowdown. Mark Rodgers, a spokesman for Citibank, said at least some terminals were operating at every Citibank branch by late afternoon. On Tuesday, the bank's A.T.M. network failed from 5 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. Mr. Rodgers described the problem as an ''internal software issue.''

title: 6 Democrats Seek Council Nomination in an Increasingly Diverse Area
description: In a Brooklyn Council district that stretches from the Coney Island Boardwalk up to the historic houses of Gravesend, what had once been a contest of one is now a race among six candidates who say they want to unify an increasingly diverse area.

description: BASEBALL

description: Laptop Learning

title: Designed to Be Almost as Welcoming as a Mother's Arms
description: ON Tuesday, as thousands of students in New York began a new school year, 34 girls and boys, infants to 17-year-olds, slipped unceremoniously through the side door of the city's new Children's Center on First Avenue near 29th Street, brought there by social workers, police officers and families no longer able to care for them.
