title: Louis Loves Duane St.
description: A SURPRISING new look in home furnishings -- on display in a crop of new stores in New York -- is emerging this season, and it's light-years away from the bare-bones modern of recent years. Call it 18th-century Euro-American Mod.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From car stereos to whiplash, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Handicaps in Jockeying For Position in Playoffs
description: The Yankees have a rock-solid advantage in the American League East, but their hold on the second seeding for the playoffs is much more shaky. They will play without shortstop Derek Jeter for about a week and Jorge Posada faces a lengthy suspension.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. In Deal With Avaya
description: Avaya Inc., which sells phone cables and data-networking gear to businesses, said yesterday that I.B.M. would provide consulting and design services to help sell its Unified Messenger program. Terms were not disclosed. Avaya, based in Basking Ridge, N.J., was spun off from Lucent Technologies a year ago.

title: Rangers Explore Signing of Berard
description: The Rangers have had exploratory negotiations for the past two weeks with the agent for Bryan Berard, the former rookie of the year who has not played since nearly losing his right eye in March 2000, according to several N.H.L. officials.

title: Airline Warns on Earnings
description: Frontier Airlines, a low-fare carrier based in Denver, said yesterday that its fiscal second-quarter earnings would miss analysts' estimates because of the slowing economy and intense competition.

title: Hevesi Sticks to His Record
description: Alan G. Hevesi released a new ad yesterday, his seventh in the mayoral campaign.

title: Nuclear Tests Not Planned, China Diplomat Says
description: China has no plans to test its nuclear weapons, a Chinese diplomat said today, responding to statements by Bush administration officials that tests were likely.

title: Arabs, Israelis and Fateful Choices
description: Arabs, Israelis and Fateful Choices

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Mcdata Acquires Sanavigator
description: The McData Corporation, a vendor of networking products for data storage devices, said it would acquire SANavigator Inc., a subsidiary of the Western Digital Corporation that makes storage management software, for $29.75 million. McData said the acquisition would begin adding to its earnings in the first quarter of 2003, excluding some noncash charges. The acquisition is expected to dilute the company's earnings by 2 cents a share in the fourth quarter and 5 cents to 6 cents a share for 2002. Barney Feder (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest Of Rape Suspect
description: A man wanted in the rape of a 77-year-old Williamsburg woman last week was arrested yesterday in New Jersey. The suspect, Santos Flores, 34, was arrested at 5 a.m. in West New York, N.J., by officers of the Brooklyn Special Victims Unit and the police in West New York. Mr. Flores had been sought in the rape of a woman who had asked him to repair a sink. After entering the woman's apartment, Mr. Flores attacked her, stole several pieces of jewelry and fled, the police said. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Sri Lankan President Makes a Deal to Save Her Government
description: To save her government from collapse, Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, made a deal today for the support of a small leftist party. But her dependence on the party could curtail her ability to undertake peace initiatives in the conflict that has killed more than 62,000 Sri Lankans.

title: Got a Train to Catch And a House to See
description: ''IT'S like building a ship in a bottle,'' said Carol Sheehan, editor in chief of Country Home magazine, which has sponsored the building of two model homes inside Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. The largest streetside opening into the station is 6 feet wide by 8 feet tall, and every trough sink, party island, wine refrigerator, canopy bed and freestanding fireplace -- not to mention the beams and floorboards for the city penthouse and two-story country cottage -- had to fit through openings that size.

title: MoMA's Store Has an Offspring
description: The new offshoot of the MoMA Design Store, which is on West 53rd Street, is to open next Thursday in SoHo. It is double the size of the uptown store. ''We were never able to show furniture in vignettes or such a large assortment of pieces,'' said Bonnie MacKay, creative director for both MoMA stores.

title: Almonte Faces Arrest; His Wife Seeks Mercy
description: Hours after receiving an arrest warrant for her husband today, Felipe Almonte's wife asked her country and the United States for forgiveness for his mistakes involving his son Danny's participation on a Bronx Little League team this summer.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Hearing On Loan Fraud
description: A House subcommittee announced yesterday that it would hold a public hearing in Harlem on Monday on a federal home loan program that was defrauded by mortgage lenders and real estate speculators, leaving hundreds of properties in Harlem and Brooklyn in default. Several dozen people have been arrested in connection with schemes involving the Department of Housing and Urban Development's 203(k) program. Among those expected to testify before the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee are would-be homeowners who were unable to take possession of the Harlem brownstones they had intended to buy. The hearing is set for 10:00 a.m. in the art gallery of the Adam Clayton Powell State Office Building at 163 West 125th Street. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: This Land

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALAWAY, JEFFREY
description: SALAWAY-Jeffrey. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of Jeffrey Salaway, son-in-law of Carol and Arthur Maslow, grandson-in-law of Doris Rosenthal, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Corey B. Rabin, President Ronald M. Stuart, Secretary

title: Jets-Colts Opener Has Extra Spin on the Ball
description: Vinny Testaverde bristles at the cobweb-covered memory of the background noise that accompanied the Jets' demise last year.

title: Party Animals And Ravers In a Free And Easy Mood
description: It's been a disappointing summer for live dance music, with major festivals canceled left and right and nightspots striving to resist the hostile advances of the club-unfriendly Giuliani administration. Leave it to MTV, though, to wipe away distressing realities with its powerful corporate hand.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Inquiry Fells Cabinet Member
description: For the second time this year a senior cabinet minister has resigned in the face of a corruption investigation. Housing Minister Koray Aydin, a senior figure in the Nationalist Action Party, said, ''I am resigning so as not to give any more opportunities to those who want to pour out their hatred of the nationalist community.'' Earlier this year, the energy minister resigned in the face of a corruption inquiry. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: A Rabbi Who Serves Satmars Is Backing Vallone for Mayor
description: Peter F. Vallone won the endorsement yesterday of Rabbi David Niederman, head of the Council of Jewish Organizations, an umbrella of social service groups for the Satmar sects of Williamsburg, Brooklyn. In announcing his decision, Rabbi Niederman prefaced his remarks this way: ''I'm sure you know the expression. Two Jews, three minds.''

title: Government Is Wary of Tackling Online Privacy
description: Mozelle W. Thompson took a stroll last summer through the Silicon Alley Street Fair, a celebration of New York City's dot-coms back when they had something to celebrate. His T-shirt and shorts belied his high office as a member of the Federal Trade Commission, the federal agency that has taken the lead in consumer privacy protection online. He met the chief executive of a high-technology company that gathers personal data on Internet users, a man who was, Mr. Thompson said, ''treating people as data instead of treating people as people.''

title: FISHER SCIENTIFIC WILL BUY COLE-PARMER FOR $205 MILLION
description: Fisher Scientific International Inc., which sells laboratory equipment, said it had agreed to buy the Cole-Parmer Instrument Company for $205 million in cash to add products and expand overseas manufacturing. The closely held Cole-Parmer, which also distributes tools used in scientific research, had sales of about $170 million in fiscal 2001. Fisher, which is based in Hampton, N.H., expects the acquisition to have no effect on 2001 earnings and to add 3 cents a share to profit next year. Cole-Parmer is based in Vernon Hills, Ill., a Chicago suburb.

title: William Thompson for Comptroller
description: In a year when New York City voters have so many choices in other races, the field for the important job of city comptroller is disappointingly small. With no Republican candidate, the only two serious contenders are running in next Tuesday's Democratic primary election. They are William Thompson, the former president of the Board of Education, and Herbert Berman, who has been chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee since 1990.

title: Blasphemy in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: More on Microsoft Windows XP
description: Every time Microsoft releases a new version of Windows, were told that this time, "it just works." Each time, Microsoft tells us how it studied focus groups and human psychology -- and that this time, it got Windows right.

title: At G.E., Whither The House Jack Built?; His Successor Faces Skeptics And a Market Less in Awe
description: Officially, the baton does not pass until tomorrow. That's when Jeffrey R. Immelt takes over the top spot at the General Electric Company, and John F. Welch Jr. leaves. Tonight, there are the going-away festivities: some 200 people will gather at Crotonville, G.E.'s management school, for a roast of their departing chairman and chief executive. ''I'm going to get hammered,'' Mr. Welch laughingly predicted.

title: The Politics of a Promise
description: For all the partisan fighting over the disappearing federal budget surplus, Republicans and Democrats are in lock step on one issue: the desirability of sticking to their promises not to use any money intended for Social Security to pay for other programs.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: An Idea For Busy O'Hare
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is considering a proposal to cut arrival delays at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago by squeezing approaching planes closer together, but at two different altitudes. Currently planes must sometimes line up for 60 miles, flying out of their way to join the end of the line. ''Instead of putting them into one long stream like a conga line, we'd have a dual stream, but with 1,000 feet difference in altitude,'' said Anthony Molinaro, a spokesman for the agency.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WABASH NATIONAL CORP., Lafayette, Ind., a maker of truck trailers, said it had received an order from J. B. Hunt Transport Services Inc., Lowell, Ark., a trucking company, for cargo containers and chassis for more than $70 million.

title: Polanski Film About Holocaust and Suffering in Poland
description: Roman Polanski's life has been shaped by the maxim that art often has its roots in great suffering. After fleeing the oppressive rule of Communism in his native Poland in 1961, Mr. Polanski made two of his most powerful films, ''Repulsion'' and ''Cul-de-Sac.'' Later, after Charles Manson killed Mr. Polanski's wife, the actress Sharon Tate, and their unborn child in 1969, he went on to make his bloody adaptation of ''Macbeth.''

title: In Historical Games, Truth Gives Way to Entertainment
description: IT'S wartime in ancient Rome. There are battles to fight, palaces to build, rulers to overthrow. But though the setting seems in order, there is at least one notable difference. The emperor at the helm is not Julius Caesar of Rome, it's Joe Sixpack of Secaucus. And he's holding a keyboard and a mouse.

title: Now You See the Modern's Construction, Now You Don't
description: Construction sites aren't pretty, so the Museum of Modern Art commissioned Olafur Eliasson, a 34-year-old Icelandic artist who lives in Berlin, to create a kind of fun- house mirror to disguise its expansion. Vertical strips of mirror are sandwiched between layers of transparent glass for a two-story window facing the former sculpture garden. The project, called ''Seeing Yourself Sensing,'' was organized by Roxana Marcoci, right, and Claudia Schmuckli, curatorial assistants. It opens Sept. 13. A glimpse yields a reflection of the viewer, the museum interior and West 53rd Street. ''The view changes continuously, depending upon people going in front of it, the angle and the light,'' Ms. Marcoci said. Domestic-size mirrored installations start at $40,000, said Tanya Bonakdar, the artist's representative in Manhattan. The museum is at 11 West 53rd Street. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Arabs Expect No Wider War, but Fear U.S. Coolness
description: Arab governments do not see any prospect of a wider war growing out of the violence in Israel, but they view the disengagement of the Bush administration as dangerous and the bloodshed as unstoppable as long as Palestinians live in stateless misery.

title: Text: Justice Department Statement on Microsoft
description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The following is the text of a statement released on Thursday by the U.S. Justice Department on its decision to no longer pursue a breakup of Microsoft Corp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIER, EDITH
description: BAIER-Edith. We mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague and friend. She was a director of the National Mah Jongg League, Inc. for many years and gave unselfishly of her time and energy. We will all miss her. Our deepest condolences to her daughter Susan and family. Ruth Unger, President and Board of Directors

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Vacation Souvenirs, Part 1

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Run For The Senate
description: Alex Sanders, former president of the College of Charleston, announced that he would seek the Senate seat to be vacated in January 2003 by Strom Thurmond. Mr. Sanders, 61, is a Democrat who has served as a state legislator and chief judge of the State Court of Appeals. The only other announced candidate is a Republican, Representative Lindsey Graham.

title: Essay; Sharon in Moscow
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon returns to Israel today after two days of meetings in Moscow with Russia's president, Vladimir Putin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, JANIS YATES SIMMS
description: NORTON-Janis Yates Simms. On September 4, 2001, age 75, beloved wife of Jeffrey, mother of Jennifer and Bradford and dear friend of William Simms. Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church St., Guilford.

title: A 2nd Venture Set in On-Demand Film Rental
description: The Walt Disney Company and the News Corporation said today that they would join forces to create an Internet video-on-demand service, Movies.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLSTEIN, ELIZABETH M.
description: ULLSTEIN-Elizabeth M. Born July 4, 1905. Died August 24, 2001. Survived by Klaus and Julia Saalfeld, and Kurt Ullstein.

title: George M. Skurla, 80, Grumman Executive
description: George M. Skurla, a former president of the Grumman Corporation who led a unit that put the finishing touches on six small spacecraft that carried the astronauts from the Apollo capsule to the moon landings, died on Sunday at Holmes Regional Medical Center in Melbourne, Fla. He lived in Satellite Beach, Fla. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JONES, ROBERT
description: JONES-Robert. A memorial service for Robert Jones, Editor-inChief of HarperCollins, will be held on Monday, September 10 at The University Club at 3:00 p.m. The University Club is located at One West 54th Street, New York, N.Y. Jacket and tie required.

title: Mr. Fox Comes to Washington
description: All the pomp and circumstance of Vicente Fox's arrival on the South Lawn of the White House yesterday could not mask the diminished expectations of the Mexican president's state visit to Washington. With both the American and Mexican economies stalled and the blush off Mr. Fox's reform presidency, a lot less will come of the visit than the two leaders hoped when they set the date earlier this year. Given the depth and complexity of the relationship between the neighboring nations, that may not be a bad thing.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about a new standard for the interior architecture of personal computers misstated the maximum data-transfer speed of the current standard, known as Personal Commputer Interconnect, or P.C.I. It is 133 megabytes per second, not 133 megabits.

title: Getting an Early Jump on College; The First 260 in the City's Newest School Experiment
description: Elizabeth Dempsey wanted to avoid the College Board tests and other pressures of the last two years of high school. Gillian Grude was seeking more serious students like herself, eager to talk about their ideas in class. And Rizwan Munawar wanted to shorten the long path to becoming a doctor.

title: U.S. Concedes Some Cell Lines Are Not Ready
description: Nearly a month after President Bush announced that he would permit federally financed scientists to study more than 60 colonies of human embryonic stem cells, the administration acknowledged today that fewer than half those colonies were fully established and ready for research.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the growing influence of Alliance Atlantis, a producer of television shows, misstated the timing of Goldman, Sachs's recommended rating for the company. It was February 2000, not last week.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Inflation Slows
description: Philippine inflation slowed in August, opening the door for a rate cut by the central bank as soon as today, as increased farm production kept down food prices. The consumer price index rose 6.3 percent from a year earlier, the slowest pace since November.

title: Music Stars Complain About Stringent Contracts
description: LeAnn Rimes, the 19-year-old country music star, has been under contract to Curb Records since she was 12. Today, she startled the 150 people at a state Senate hearing here when she said that she might be 35 years old before she finished delivering the 21 albums that she owes the record company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCIS, THAYER, JR.
description: FRANCIS-Thayer, Jr. Of Marion, MA., and Aiken, SC. Died at his home in Marion with his family by his side on September 3, 2001. Tim, an engineer, was a founder, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer of the Sippican Corporation and a member of the Massachusetts High Technology Council. As an entrepreneur himself, he loved to encourage and guide fledgling companies. In addition to his family and friends, his passions were playing the piano, flying, and sailing. He is survived by his wife, Nancy, six children and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Beverly Yacht Club in Marion on Saturday, September 15 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Marion or Aiken Emergency Medical Services.

title: Metro Matters; Bringing a Pal Up to Speed On Politics
description: HI! Welcome back. Hope you had a great summer in Vermont.

title: INSIDE
description: Sandinista Seeks Comeback

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Lies, Damned Lies

title: Ventura Helps Mets Sweep Phillies
description: Robin Ventura was not told in advance that he would have a day off Tuesday, but he guessed he would. The Philadelphia Phillies would be starting a tough left-hander, Omar Daal, and with the way Ventura had been hitting, he doubted he would play.

title: Where Bigger Was Better, Small Wonders
description: The landscape of eastern Long Island is long and low, with the brown expanse of potato fields and dunes sweeping down to the sea. New houses stand out for all to admire, straining as high as zoning laws permit, competing for water views. Over the last 10 years, 30,000-square-foot mansions have been going up like Levitt prefabs in varying styles of shingle and pop Palladian and, recently, Miami stronghold style with white stucco walls.

title: After Four Years, Settlement In Swindler's Bankruptcy Case
description: The tangled, six-year-old bankruptcy case of Robert E. Brennan, the imprisoned former penny-stock mogul, was resolved today in a settlement expected to provide about $27 million to help pay $140 million in claims against him.

title: Executive Changes in Media and Marketing
description: Steve Bryant, chief creative officer for public relations for Publicis in the United States, based in Seattle, was named to the additional post of president at the Seattle office of Publicis Dialog, part of the United States Publicis operations. He takes on the president's post from Jeff Hasan, who is leaving, the agency said, to pursue other interests. The United States Publicis operations are part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: President Orders New Spy Trial
description: President Hosni Mubarak ordered the retrial of an Egyptian engineer acquitted in June on charges of spying for Israel, which denies any connection to the case. Sherif Filali, who had been accused of trying to collect information on the military, tourism and an agricultural development plan, was acquitted because he told Egyptian officials he had been asked for information. The acquittal had been greeted as a sign that Egypt's courts can avoid political interference.

title: Arabs, Israelis and Fateful Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Port Chairman Likely to Lead Sports Agency
description: Lewis M. Eisenberg, the New Jersey investment banker who has been chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for the last seven years, plans to resign from the bistate agency to become chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, state officials said yesterday.

title: Disruption For Schundler And His Tour Of a 'Miracle'
description: Today was supposed to be Bret D. Schundler's day in the sun, a chance to show off what he brashly calls the Jersey City Miracle: the buildings built, homes renovated, strip malls developed, streets cleaned up, neighborhoods ridded of crime and charter schools opened during his eight and a half years as mayor.

title: DEFENDING BUDGET, BUSH AIDES TAKE FIGHT TO CONGRESS
description: President Bush's budget director and defense secretary mounted a vigorous defense of the Bush budget today in separate appearances on Capitol Hill, insisting that the administration and Congress could protect the Social Security surplus and still increase military and education spending.

title: Message to China
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, PATRICIA (TAILER)
description: WHITNEY-Patricia (Tailer). Of New York City, formerly of Southampton, NY and Marion, MA, August 30, 2001. Mother of Barbara Lovejoy Spring of Concord, MA and the late Christopher Winslow Lovejoy. Sister of James Bogart Tailer of Florida. Grandmother of Elizabeth Stoddard Spring, Amanda Atkins Spring, William Claflin Lovejoy Spring and Katharine Winslow Spring. Also survived by her close friend, Robert Garrett of Princeton, NJ and her nephew, James Bogart Tailer IV. Memorial services in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Ave. and 73rd St., NYC, Tuesday, September 25 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be sent to the Scleroderma Research Fund, One Robert Wood Johnson Place, M.E.B., Room 556, New Brunswick, NJ 08903.

title: Is Theft in the Eye of the Beholder?
description: IN the last few years search engines have started to scan the Web not only for text but for pictures too. Today, with a few keywords, anyone on the Web can gain access to a trove of images, from cartoons and graphics to personal photographs and celebrity shots. So if you are one of the few Americans who have not yet passed judgment on Jennifer Lopez's risqu dress from the 2000 Grammy Awards, you now have your chance.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gas Pipeline Planned
description: TransCanada Pipelines and National Fuel Gas plan to build a 215-mile natural gas pipeline from Ontario to Pennsylvania to profit from growing demand for fuel in the Northeast United States. The project will cost $350 million to $400 million and is expected to be completed in late 2004, said TransCanada Pipelines, based in Calgary, Alberta, and National Fuel Gas, based in Buffalo. The line would start in Kirkwall, Ontario, enter the United States near Buffalo and end in the Ellisburg-Leidy area of Pennsylvania. The capacity would be 500 million cubic feet a day.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Escaped Murderer Surrenders
description: The police arrested an escaped murderer after he turned himself in yesterday at the offices of The Times of Trenton, six days after he convinced guards he was an injured visitor and left the Mercer County Correctional Center in an ambulance. The prisoner, Terence M. Brewer, 38, called the newspaper and spoke to a reporter who had written articles about him, said the newspaper's managing editor, Peter G. Callas. ''He was tired and injured and knew they were closing in on him,'' Mr. Callas said. ''He wanted to give himself up, but wanted to talk to us first.'' The police brought Mr. Brewer to the hospital for treatment for a leg injury suffered in the escape, and he was to be taken to Trenton State Prison, county officials said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Grand Bahama Island
description: Through Dec. 23, the Our Lucaya Beach and Golf Resort on Grand Bahama Island is taking 35 percent off suites that normally cost $530 a night, making the rate $345, in single or double occupancy. The deal also includes $50 toward the two 18-hole golf courses or the Senses Spa. The price does not include 12 percent tax and a service charge of $7.20 a night per person. Information: (877) 687-5822 or www.ourlucaya.com .

title: New Bishop Is Installed For Long Island Diocese
description: With several standing ovations and hours of pageantry and prayer at St. Agnes Cathedral here, William Francis Murphy was installed today as Long Island's fourth Roman Catholic bishop, the new spiritual leader of a sprawling diocese that was without a permanent prelate for almost a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIMEL, ALBERT
description: SCHIMEL-Albert. Age 80. Of Boynton Beach, FL. Formerly of Jersey City, N.J. Beloved husband of Rose (Sis). Devoted father of Richard (Barbara) and Julie. Grandfather of Grant. Contributions in his memory may be made to Yad Kenny, C/O P.E.F. Israel Endowment Funds, 317 Madison Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10017.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: China: Brother Knows Best
description: Returning to China after his first visit to North Korea, President Jiang Zemin declared that the brotherhood between the Communist nations was still strong but hinted that Beijing's isolated neighbor was ready to follow China's path of economic reform. The friendship ''will blossom more colorfully and yield more fruits with the joint efforts by both sides,'' he said. Mr. Jiang encouraged North Korea to improve ties with the United States and Japan and to continue to work on reunification with its longtime rival, South Korea. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: Doing Palladio Proud (in Concrete)
description: UNDER silvery moonlight, the Doric temple in Carlo Marchiori's garden looks as if it were hewn from Carrara marble. Fluted columns pose heroically on a romantically crumbling foundation. Soaring above are elaborate friezes and fragments of traditional entablature. There's even a broken pediment. All that's missing is the oracle.

title: DIAL SAYS IT GOT $12 MILLION FOR UNITS IT SOLD
description: The Dial Corporation said it was paid $12 million in the sale last month of the Sarah Michaels lotions and Freeman cosmetics lines, which the company purchased for $260 million in 1998. Terms were not disclosed. Dial, which also makes Purex detergent and Renuzit air freshener, received $8 million in cash and two promissory notes of $2 million each from the closely held Hathi Group of Chicago, Dial said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Dial, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said previously that the sale would result in a charge of about $200 million.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Woes For E.P.A. Nominee
description: In a new sign of trouble for Donald R. Schregardus, the nominee to be the top enforcement official at the Environmental Protection Agency, Senator James M. Jeffords said he was ordering an extensive review of Mr. Schregardus's record in Ohio, where he was the top environmental official. Mr. Schregardus's nomination has already cleared a Senate committee led by Mr. Jeffords, but because of a procedural snag it must be reconsidered. Mr. Jeffords said a new report critical of Ohio's environmental programs was prompting a long look. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Judge Refuses Plea for Retrial In Torture Case
description: A federal judge rejected former Police Officer Charles Schwarz's bid to win a new trial in the Abner Louima case yesterday, saying that the testimony of a former police sergeant who came forward after four years on Mr. Schwarz's behalf was riddled with misperceptions and inaccuracies.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Bahamas: Fire Consumes Tourist Site
description: A fire in Nassau that raged for hours as it crept along rooftops destroyed the capital's renowned handicrafts market as well as the offices of the Tourism Ministry. The blaze, which took eight hours to control, started Tuesday afternoon in the Straw Market, a crowded and popular tourist destination. No one was reported injured, although the authorities had to evacuate 300 guests from a hotel, as well as remove artifacts from the nearby national museum, which is in an 18th-century building. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Palm (the Butter Version) Is Up for Auction at EBay
description: Butter-sculpture fans, rejoice: The Butter Palm VII P.D.A. sculpture from this year's Minnesota State Fair is for sale at eBay. Rebooting this particular Palm may be a bit messy, but it certainly tastes better than those plastic models.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Police Move Against Tent City
description: The Portland police evicted all 75 residents of a tent city from state land under a downtown bridge and began busing many of them to a site on the edge of town. The camp, Dignity Village, was created 10 months ago to protest Portland's shelter system, which the village's organizers call inadequate. Ibrahim Mubarak, a village spokesman, said he was among some who now expected to return to sleeping on the streets; he scoffed at the relocation site, a fenced lot far from commercial or social services. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Overshadowed, Slavery Debate Boils in Durban
description: The negotiators huddled in Room 10 in the gleaming convention center here, poring over a four-page paper entitled ''Injustices of the Past and the Way Forward.'' Tonight, as the clock ticked steadily, some of the most powerful nations in the world considered atoning for the sins of their ancestors.

title: In America; Doomed to Irrelevance
description: It was inevitable. There was no chance that the United Nations World Conference Against Racism, Racial Discrimination, Xenophobia and Related Intolerance would end up being more than a grandiose gathering of the cynical and the nave.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Abortion Fight
description: Planned Parenthood of South Carolina has filed suit against the issuance of state license plates that read ''Choose Life.'' Proceeds from the sale of the optional plates, which cost $70 every two years, are intended to help finance crisis pregnancy centers that do not provide or promote abortions. Planned Parenthood, which does provide abortions, argued that the law authorizing the plates violates constitutional guarantees of free speech and equal protection. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSLOY, BLANK, SHARON
description: COSLOY - BLANK - Sharon. The American Friends of the Rambam Medical Center mourn the untimely death of Sharon Cosloy Blank, supporter with her husband Edward Blank, our esteemed Board member. Together with our friends and colleagues in Israel, we remember Sharon's and Ed's visit to the hospital in Haifa. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Ed, children Rebecca and Michael, and her mother and brother.

title: The Statistical Shark
description: A simple truth of human existence is that it is vastly easier to amplify fear than it is to assuage it. Consider the shark attacks that have occurred in Florida, Virginia and North Carolina this summer. The temptation is to call them not merely shark attacks but ''a spate of shark attacks'' or ''a wave of shark attacks,'' or even ''a summer of shark attacks.'' The temptation is also to say that they have ''culminated'' in the fatal attacks, separated by only two days, on David Peltier, a 10-year-old boy, in Virginia Beach and Sergei Zaloukaev, a 27-year-old graduate student, on the Outer Banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, PAULINE
description: SMITH-Pauline. Passed away September 4 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Hy, devoted mother to Stuart/Joan, Roberta/ Arnie Ursaner, Floyd/Ilyse. Cherished grandmother. She will remain forever in our hearts. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to American Cancer Society. Funeral Thursday 12:30 at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus NJ.

title: What Comes Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: Work Time Becomes Playtime With a Gym Near the Desk
description: There's no place like . . . the office. Tom Silverman, the founder of Tommy Boy Records, a hip-hop label in Manhattan, said, ''It was my idea to design an environment where people would want to come in at 9 on Monday and not want to leave Friday at 5.''

title: Squint No More: A Smart Window Awaits Your Command
description: LIKE many other travelers this month, passengers on flights out of Fort Lauderdale International Airport may continue to fasten their seat belts, look out the window and wait for the air conditioning to kick in. But on one charter jet that flies out of the airport, passengers will no longer have to lower those rickety plastic window shades to block the sun's glare.

title: Wrong Tool for the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Phone Company Profit
description: France Tlcom, Europe's second-biggest phone company, said first-half profit fell 49 percent as acquisition costs offset gains at its Orange S.A. mobile phone unit. Net income fell to 1.95 billion euros ($1.73 billion), from 3.8 billion euros a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, France Tlcom's profit climbed 2.8 percent. The chief executive, Michel Bon, spent $50 billion last year on mobile phones and Internet services to offset falling revenue from long-distance calls. The company, based in Paris, said sales rose 33 percent in the first half and should increase more than 25 percent for the full year. Analysts say, however, that they remain concerned about the company's debt, which totaled 64.9 billion euros at the end of June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUDZINSKI, ALFRED E.
description: STUDZINSKI-Alfred E. Of Peabody, Sept. 3, 2001, beloved husband of Jennie M. (Gaieski) Studzinski of Peabody, father of Edward A. and Anne Studzinski of Chicago and John J. Studzinski of London, England, son of the late Cezary and Frances (Jaworska) Studzinski, and brother of the late William Studzinski, Stella Studzinski and Regina Falkowski. His funeral will be held on Saturday at 8:15 AM from the Cahill-Brodeur facility at 20 Church St. of the Conway, Cahill-Brodeur Funeral Home, Peabody, followed by a Funeral Service at 9 AM in the St. John's Prep Chapel, 72 Spring St., Danvers, MA to which relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend. A visitation will be held in the funeral home on Thursday from 7 to 9 P.M. and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Burial will be in St. Mary's Cemetery, Salem. Memorial donations may be made to the Alfred E. Studzinski Memorial Library Fund C/O St. John's Prep, 72 Spring Street, Danvers, MA. 01923.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, MIRIAM
description: REISS-Miriam. Died suddenly on Tuesday, September 4, 2001. She survived her true love, Joseph Reiss, by 24 years. Adored mother of Ed and Liz, mother-in-law of Phyllis Reiss and Alan Jaffe. Grandmother of David and Janette; Bob and Beth; Richard, Joey and Erica. Great grandmother of Zach, Ari and Natan (born on August 25 in Jerusalem). Her beloved sisters, Ruth Hyman and Thelma Jassem, were enriched by her devotion. Miriam's 88 vibrant years of life were dedicted to her family, many friends, philanthropy and Israel. She was an expert in all that she did including general repairs, grammar, crossword puzzles, the Internet and, most of all, golf. All of those who were touched by her love and generosity will miss her forever. Services will be held 1 PM Thursday at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made to the Miriam and Joseph Reiss Memorial Fund of UJA-Federation, 130 East 59th Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10022 or a charity of your choice.

title: Australian Case Shows Rescues Can Be Costly : In Migrants' Plight, a Sea Of Trouble for Skippers
description: SINGAPORE  The global shipping industry and United Nations refugee officials are deeply disturbed by the ramifications of the incident involving the Tampa, the Norwegian-registered freighter that rescued 430 refugees from a sinking Indonesian ferry and spent eight days caring for them at sea because Australia refused to grant the refugees asylum.

title: Faith-Based Initiative
description: To the Editor:

title: Daly's Swing And His Life Straighten Out
description: Even in his darkest days, John Daly was always loved by the galleries. So it was no surprise to hear loud cheers as Daly was introduced for today's pro-am, still riding the euphoria of his victory Sunday at the BMW International in Germany, his first victory in six long years.

title: Yashin, With Big Pact, Is Also Thinking Big
description: Aleksei Yashin was about two minutes into his monstrous, new 10-year contract when he found a spot behind a podium loaded down with microphones and carefully opened a folder of notes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Plans New Headquarters
description: Barclays agreed to lease a million-square-foot headquarters to be built by the Canary Wharf Group in an office park three miles east of London's financial district. The developer's shares rose 3.5 percent. Barclays, one of Britain's largest banks, joins other companies, including HSBC Holdings and Citigroup, that are setting up operations in the area developed by Paul Reichmann. Barclays is still negotiating the financial terms of the 30-year agreement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Beaten Near Gay Bar Dies
description: A man who was beaten as he left a gay bar has died of his injuries, the authorities said. The man, Edgar Garzon, 35, of Jackson Heights, died Tuesday at Elmhurst Hospital Center, where he had been treated since the Aug. 15 attack. Mr. Garzon was attacked around 3:50 a.m. as he left the Friends Tavern, on Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, the police said. A man in a red car beat Mr. Garzon on the head with a blunt object, took Mr. Garzon's wallet and fled, the police said. Mr. Garzon, who was active in a gay civic association, never regained consciousness. The police have labeled the beating a bias attack. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACLEOD, DR. NORMAN W.
description: MacLEOD-Dr. Norman W. On September 3, 2001. Beloved uncle of many nieces and nephews, and dear friend to many. Funeral services Friday, 3:30 pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Family will be receiving friends on Thursday 6:00-8:00 at Frank E. Campbell.

title: MTV at the Met: When Worlds Elide; The Opera House Gets All Hipped Up for Tonight's Awards Ceremony
description: When a visiting diva takes center stage at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight, her perch will be a giant Erector set of scaffolding borrowed from a lavish new production of the Richard Strauss opera ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten.''

title: Courting Blacks and Latinos, Ferrer Is Walking Fine Line
description: Fernando Ferrer leapt onto a stage at the headquarters of the hospital workers union yesterday and declared that his candidacy was built on the support of an ideological ''coalition of conscience,'' and not simply a coalition of black and Latino voters seeking to elect New York's first Puerto Rican mayor.

title: Sony Announces the Fate Of Its EVilla: Landfilla
description: It's one thing to take a product off the market if it's not selling well. But it's another thing entirely to wipe it from the face of the earth.
