description: To the Editor:

title: Answering an Age-Old Cry: When Will I Use This Math?
description: The designer Jhane Barnes wants mathematics students to connect textiles, like the one at left she designed for Herman Miller, with something called fractal geometry: patterns that repeat on a diminishing scale. She calls the fractal schemes that have been developed for her by two theoretical mathematicians her ''recipes'' for new designs. A new textbook and video from Ohio Math Works that shows students in Ohio how math can have practical applications features Ms. Barnes's use of fractals. For students, especially young women, who ask their teachers, ''When will I ever use this?'' the answer may be: when you design textiles for Herman Miller. A Web site (www.ohiomathworks.com) offers free software for designing carpet and textile patterns, and the program will go national next year. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: Islanders Improve Radio Signal, Too
description: For the first time in four years, Islander games will be heard on a station that its fans won't have trouble hearing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULANOV, JOAN BEL GEDDES
description: ULANOV-Joan Bel Geddes. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 7, at 2 PM, at NYU Catholic Center, Washington Square South, NYC. Reception will follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UNICEF, 1800-FOR-KIDS, or 333 East 38th St, NY, NY 10016, or The Authors Guild, 31 E. 28th St, NY, NY 10016.

title: Macedonian Lawmakers Back Peace Plan
description: By CARLOTTA GALL

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: More Camps For Illegal Migrants
description: French officials said they would move quickly to set up more camps for illegal immigrants heading for Britain despite British fears that such camps only encourage asylum seekers to make dangerous attempts to cross the English Channel through the Channel Tunnel. The employment and solidarity minister, Elisabeth Guigou, said action would have to be taken to ease the situation at the one center that exists now, at Sangatte, which is housing 1,700 people but was designed for 1,000.

title: Arabs, Israelis and Fateful Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Whites' Land Offer Accepted
description: Vice President Joseph Msika said the government had accepted an offer from the largely white Commercial Farmers' Union to sell more than two million acres to the state for resettlement of landless blacks. It was unclear if the agreement had the genuine blessing of President Robert Mugabe, whose party has spearheaded the often violent resettlement effort. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Costa Rica Qualifies for Cup at Expense of U.S.
description: The nightmare continued for the United States national team tonight while the celebration only just began in Costa Rica.

title: National Briefing | Religion: A Drive Against Gossip
description: Two Orthodox rabbis are starting a national campaign to curb gossip and slander, and they have some of the sharpest tongues in politics and entertainment agreeing to hold their fire. The rabbis' group, WordsCanHeal.org, released a poll showing that 117 million Americans shared gossip at least once or twice a week. The group's advertisements will urge people to refrain from deriding others. Among those signing on are President Bush, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Bette Midler, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, above.

title: Concerned Parent With a Camera, Aimed at Schools
description: Like many other upper-middle-class parents in Los Angeles, New York or most other urban centers, Davis Guggenheim, a television director, faced a personal dilemma two years ago about his young son's education. ''The ideals of the kind of life I wanted to lead were hitting up against the reality of where I was going to send him to school,'' Mr. Guggenheim recalled. ''The private schools we visited were incredible -- but so removed and detached.''

title: School-Building Delays Signal Troubles
description: At Public School 178 in upper Manhattan, a new elementary school, construction workers were scrambling yesterday to clear out garbage, install computers and hook up telephones before the arrival of students in less than 24 hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMENNA, JEANNETTE GRANATELLI
description: DiMENNA-Jeannette Granatelli. Of Mt. Vernon, NY on September 4, 2001. Wife of John J. DiMenna, mother of Nicholas, John and Joan. Sister of Yvette Villamana and Rosalie DiMenna. Grandmother of 13, great-grandmother of six. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 4 to 8 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial, Sts. Peter & Paul Church, Fleetwood, on Friday, September 7 at 10 AM.

title: Tax Increases Would Cost Jobs, Mayor Warns
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, interjecting himself again into the contest to succeed him, warned yesterday that the Democratic mayoral candidates who have advocated tax increases risk hurting the city economy by forcing the elimination of thousands of jobs.

title: The Ponytailed Place-Kicker
description: Ashley Martin, ponytail dangling from the back of her helmet, made history Thursday night when she became the first woman to play and score in a Division I college football game. One reason her triumph was not front-page news may have been that there were no lawyers involved, an absence that makes the story all the more heartening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDLER, RICHARD
description: BANDLER-Richard, 84. Died peacefully September 2, 2001 at his residence on Fisher Island, FL. Richard was Founder and President of the Richard Bandler Co., Inc, a Directory Advertising company in New York City, 1949-1987. He had a love, and a passion, for horses, especially Fox Hunting. He was Master and Co-Founder of the Greenville County Hounds, Greenville, SC; a Member of the Masters of Foxhounds Association and Treasurer of the Golden Bridge Hounds, North Salem, NY. Richard was an avid bridge, backgammon and tennis player. He was a former member of the Edgartown Yacht Club, Union League Club, Metropolitan Club, Lotus Club, Surf Club and La Gorce Country Club. Richard served with the U.S. Army from 1942 to 1945 where he was decorated a Purple Heart with Three Battle Stars. He was a devoted husband to Eleanor. He is survived by his four daughters: Judith B. (Henry) Velenchik of Wilton, CT; Patricia B. Hornblower of Dedham, MA; Elise deS. of Mill Valley, CA; and Tatiana S. (Paul Mischenko) of NYC; along with four grandchildren. Richard will be greatly missed.

title: Parents Are Charged After Party For Teenagers Includes Stripper
description: On the first day of the new school year, students descending on Horace Greeley High School today had an unlikely escort: television news trucks. The police had announced that the parents of a high school senior faced criminal charges stemming from a weekend party at their home where they watched as a stripper performed for their teen-age son and several classmates, with some participating in a lewd act.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LEONORE OLINSKY
description: MILLER-Leonore Olinsky, 94. On September 4, in Kent, CT, widow of Henry, mother of John and Richard, grandmother of Ivan, Lucas, and Emily, mother-in-law of Joan McD Miller and Carol Schneider. She was the daughter of an artist, an artist herself, a lover of the arts, and most compellingly, a lover and protector of her family & friends. Her remains will be buried at Mt. Pleasant.

title: Israeli Party Is Bickering After Near-Tie In Its Primary
description: Already reeling from the devastating defeat of its last prime minister seven months ago, Israel's venerable Labor Party found itself in deeper trouble today when an election for a new leader dissolved into charges of ballot-box rigging and theft.

title: U.S. Diplomat Said to Protest China Actions On First Boston
description: The United States ambassador to China, Clark T. Randt Jr., decided not to attend a dinner with Chinese officials tonight, apparently in protest over China's recent blacklisting of Credit Suisse First Boston. The investment bank angered Beijing by inviting senior Taiwan government officials to speak at conferences it sponsored earlier this year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sunday Styles this week about an increase in nudity at American beaches and in other realms of popular culture misstated the position of Corinne Wood, who is leading a boycott of the retailer Abercrombie & Fitch because of nudity in its summer catalog. She is lieutenant governor of Illinois, not Indiana.

title: Leonard Wright Jr., 78, Writer Who Dared to Change Fishing
description: Leonard Marshall Wright Jr., a former New York advertising executive whose many writings about trout fishing were initially seen as blasphemous by traditional anglers, died Aug. 24 on the way to a hospital near his summer home in Claryville, N.Y., in the Catskills. He was 78. A former resident of the West Village, he lived in Islamorada, Fla.

title: Sports of The Times; A Message To All, a Duel For the Ages
description: THE stadium was full and the stars were out but the new kids with the blustery serves and the windmill forehands who grew up watching Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi were awake late in their hotel rooms, watching the masters at work. On a cool and vintage United States Open night in New York, Sampras versus Agassi in the quarterfinals would become that rarest of tennis events, turning phenoms to fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAPPER, HOPE LUNIN
description: KLAPPER-Hope Lunin. On August 5, 2001. Very much loved and greatly respected by friends, colleagues and family. A truly outstanding person and professional. Her insightful thoughts and perceptive comments, her warmth and sense of humor will be greatly missed. A Ph.D. in Sociology from Columbia University, formerly a Professor in the Sociology Department of New York University teaching Mass Communications and related subjects. The first instructor selected in a trial of teaching regular college classes via television. The first woman to be elected President of the American Association for Public Opinion Research. Widow of Joseph T. Klapper, head of Social Research at CBS. Deeply mourned by family members and friends. Service on Friday, September 7th, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Interpublic Continues to Realign Operations
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies ( news/quote ) in New York continues to reorganize after its recent acquisition of True North Communications ( news/quote ) as it merges agencies within one of its four main units, the McCann-Erickson World Group.

title: DiFrancesco Adding Projects To Widen Arena Bill's Allure
description: Aides to the acting governor unveiled an amended proposal today for a new arena here that would include more projects for towns ranging from Vineland to Vernon Valley and Harrison to Hackensack -- all meant to broaden support for the measure.

title: Cheap Tickets to Close L.A. Call Center
description: Cheap Tickets Inc., the seller of discounted airline tickets and hotel rooms being acquired by the Cendant Corporation, is closing its Los Angeles call center as it consolidates the number of reservation centers it operates.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Democrats Gain Redistricting Edge
description: A Democrat was named the tiebreaking member of a special redistricting committee when his name was pulled from a replica of a stovepipe hat owned by Abraham Lincoln. The new member, Michael A. Bilandic, a former justice of the State Supreme Court, joins four Democrats and four Republicans on the committee, which deadlocked along party lines last month in trying to draw new Congressional and state legislative districts. The committee was appointed by the legislature, control of which is split between the parties, when the lawmakers themselves were unable to come up with a redistricting plan. The State Constitution calls for an eight-member redistricting committee in such a case, and also requires that any needed tiebreaking member be chosen randomly. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: New Evidence of Early Humans Unearthed in Russia's North
description: Stone tools, animal bones and an incised mammoth tusk found in Russia's frigid far north have provided what archaeologists say is the first evidence that modern humans or Neanderthals lived in the Arctic more than 30,000 years ago, at least 15,000 years earlier than previously thought.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Under pressure from a Dutch court, the fight over control of the Gucci Group may be resolved.
description: The dispute between the French billionaires Franois Pinault and Bernard Arnault for control of the Gucci Group has proved something of an embarrassment for the Dutch legal system.

title: Hilliard Is Questionable, But Pain in His Toe Is Not
description: Ike Hilliard did not sprint off the line or execute a pass route with the kind of sudden change of direction that has been his trademark as a receiver. He did not run a play with the starting offense and spent much of his day standing behind the offensive huddle watching.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEL, GARY CHARLES
description: SEIDEL-Gary Charles. With deepest sorrow we mourn the loss of the beloved son of Joan and Ken, husband of Sherrie, brother of Eric (Debra) uncle of Eric Jr. and Alexis, due to Cushing's Disease.

title: HERCULES TO LAY OFF 300 WORKERS IN COST-CUTTING MOVE
description: Hercules Inc., a top producer of paper-making chemicals, said it would lay off at least 300 workers, or 3 percent of its work force, as part of a plan to save $100 million a year. The job cuts are mostly in the United States, which has about half of Hercules's 9,600 workers, with fewer reductions in South America and Asia. They will occur by Sept. 30. Separate job cuts affecting about 3 percent of the company's European work force may be announced soon, a company spokesman said. The cuts are part of a cost-cutting program announced in June that would save $100 million annually starting the end of the second quarter of 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MORTON
description: ROSENBERG-Morton. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the passing of its beloved member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Margery and son Daniel, and their loved ones. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Ellen R. Saxl, Co-President Michael H. Laufer, Co-President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, GLORIA FAY
description: MARTIN-Gloria Fay, 75. Of Coconut Creek, FL. formerly of Monroe Township, NJ and Jericho, NY on Wednesday, September 5, 2001. Wife of the late Melvin Jay. Mother of Robert B. Martin, DMD (Suzanne), Neil I. Martin (Barbara) and Michelle Martin-Gonzales (Manuel). Sister of Rita Piecyk and the late Yvette Jourden. Grandmother of five. Graveside service Friday 11:15 AM Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, under direction of Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. Memorial contributions to the Wellness Community, 5700 N. Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL 33487.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEREZ, ROBERT C.
description: PEREZ-Robert C. On September 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Mary Jean (nee Howard), devoted fathfather of Barbara Ellen Perez, Frederic Royce Perez & Moira Ann Angelini, loving brother of Jeanette Perez Henderson, adored grandfather of Nicholas, Megan, Jeffrey, Lisa and Michael, great-grandfather of Ethan. A memorial service will be held at Christ and St. Stephens Church, 122 West 69th St, NYC on Friday, Sept. 7 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to your favorite charity in his memory.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 1
description: Abreakdown of every game in Week 1 of the 2001 N.F.L. season.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Olivetti Financing
description: Olivetti said it would sell up to $15 million in new stock and bonds the next five years in its first major move since Pirelli took a controlling stake in the company. The news set off a 16 percent decline in Olivetti's stock, and analysts said they were concerned because the company, which owns a controlling stake in Telecom Italia, would not disclose what it planned to do with the money. ''The award of proxies to seek more debt and equity opens up the options of the company to restructure the Telecom Italia-Olivetti group, but there has been little indication what the new owners plan to do,'' said Robert Grindle, an analyst with Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. Olivetti's shares have fallen nearly 40 percent since Pirelli took a 23 percent stake at the end of July.

title: Scholars' Group Is Attacked For Sponsoring Cuban Official
description: As the Latin American Studies Association opens its annual conference here on Thursday, gathering thousands of scholars to panels featuring top speakers from across the Americas, the influential group is under fire for sponsoring a Communist Party official from Havana instrumental in a recent purge of Cuban intellectuals.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From rafting in the Grand Canyon to shopping in Madrid, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Under The Spell Of Jefferson
description: ONCE again, in the Great Hide and Go Seek Garden, Karen Van Lengen was ''it.'' She counted to 40 as she sat on a bench with her eyes closed at Thomas Jefferson's Academical Village -- better known as the Lawn at the University of Virginia. The Lawn forms the neo-Classical heart of the university's sprawling campus. Jefferson's master plan put student dormitories, faculty houses (pavilions) and colonnades on either side of a quadrangle. At one end he placed his rotunda, modeled on the Pantheon in Rome.

title: Telling the Story Of Congo's War, Amid the Chaos
description: ''For every life saved by vaccination or food relief, one is lost to starvation or war,'' writes Barbara Kingsolver in ''The Poisonwood Bible,'' her wonderful epic novel of Congo 40 years ago. ''Poor Africa. No other continent has endured such an unspeakably bizarre combination of foreign thievery and foreign good will.''

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: A Rsum Distinguished By What It Didn't Mention
description: For three years, Dr. Seymour I. Schlager worked as a top executive scientist at Becton Dickinson, one of the nation's largest medical device companies, where he supervised the development of many new products.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nuclear Plant Help
description: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Japan's biggest machinery maker, agreed to help build nuclear reactors for Westinghouse Electric, which is trying to revive orders for nuclear power plants. Westinghouse, which made equipment for the world's first nuclear power plant in 1957 and is owned by British Nuclear Fuels, hopes stricter environmental regulations on the use of fossil fuels will revive interest in nuclear power. No new reactors have been ordered in the United States in more than 20 years, but Mitsubishi Heavy Industries said it hoped to manufacture major equipment for Westinghouse, which is trying to obtain permission from United States authorities to build a nuclear plant.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Soccer Club Offering
description: Italy's most successful soccer team, Juventus F.C., which is controlled by the Agnelli family, won investor approval to sell at least 35 percent of its shares in an initial public offering. The sale would consist of a combination of new shares sold by the club, based in Turin, and existing stock offered by current investors. The club's chief executive, Antonio Giraudo, said it had been planning a stock offering since 1994; he did not say when the offering would be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCKMAN, SUSAN
description: BROCKMAN-Susan. September 4. Funeral service at Riverside Funeral Home, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Friday, September 7. Viewing at noon, service 1PM.

title: Justice Department Will Not Seek to Break Up Microsoft
description: The Justice Department, seeking a conclusion to the antitrust case against Microsoft ( news/quote ) that it can call a victory, said today that it would no longer seek to split the software company in two or contend that it illegally tied its Internet browser to its dominant computer operating system.

title: Inspired by Jesus, Sandinista Tries for a Comeback
description: Daniel Ortega is not running for president as much as he is power walking. In his brisk campaign swings through neighborhood bastions, he strides for miles drenched in sweat and basking in the cheers, hugs and handshakes that greet him as he embraces grandmothers and kisses babies.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel To Supply Cingular
description: Nortel Networks said yesterday that it would provide equipment to Cingular Wireless to help build an asynchronous transfer mode network that will connect 87 markets. Cingular Wireless, a partnership of SBC Communications and BellSouth, has 21 million subscribers. Terms were not disclosed. Nortel says the deal will help Cingular develop third-generation networks, reduce costs and deliver voice and data services more efficiently. Nortel shares closed down 33 cents, to $5.67. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Moscow Insists ABM Treaty Must Be Preserved
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 6  A senior Russian official said today that Moscow is willing to consider amendments to the "present-day system of agreements on strategic stability" with the United States. But he insisted that the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 must be preserved in talks that are likely to be long term and complex.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Tuesday about the Labor Day activities of James E. McGreevey and Bret D. Schundler, campaigning for governor of New Jersey, misstated the place of Mr. Schundler's Monday appearances. While Mr. McGreevey campaigned at the beach, Mr. Schundler was in South Plainfield and Rutherford.

title: Four-Way Contest for Council In Borough's Latino Heartland
description: A seemingly endless number of restaurants selling Colombian cuisine along Roosevelt Avenue in Corona, Queens, are punctuated with travel agencies advertising special fares to Mexico and storefronts promoting discount shipping rates for packages to Peru. Shoe stores alert shoppers that their sales clerks speak Spanish and few store signs fail to promote their wares in both Spanish and English.

title: As the economy falters, the tensions between advertisers and agencies rises, a new survey says.
description: THE sluggish advertising economy is already causing rifts in relations between agencies and advertisers, according to an annual survey, as those reporting they have felt the slowdown describe serious consequences ranging from lower-quality campaigns to less teamwork to more of a focus on money.

title: Petition Urges U.S. to Ban Supplements With Ephedra
description: A consumer advocacy group and a prominent pharmacologist filed a petition today asking the Food and Drug Administration to ban dietary supplements containing the stimulant ephedra, saying reports of illness from the supplements had doubled in recent years, reaching 407 in 1999.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: A Spicy Welcome to the White House
description: In their first state dinner, President and Mrs. Bush tonight offered President Vicente Fox of Mexico and his wife, Marta, a spicy meal of upscale Tex-Mex cuisine, an exclusive gathering and a fireworks display.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, JOSEPH SILL, JR.
description: CLARK-Joseph Sill, Jr. Age 72. Died peacefully at home in Manhattan of Parkinson's Disease on September 1, 2001. Dearest husband of Mary Lincoln Bonnell. Caring father of Story Clark Resor of Wilson, WY., Joseph Sill, III of Venice, CA., Christopher Avery of New York City and Laurance Reed of Marble Head, MA. Brother of Noel Clark of Washington,D.C.. Fond grandfather of eleven. Joe was a graduate of The Middlesex School, Harvard College and The Harvard Business School. He was a valued energy analyst at Wertheim-Schroder and Company from 1961 until his health forced his retirement in 1985. He was associated with H.G. Wellington and Company as a consultant until the spring of this year. A service will take place at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave on Thursday, September 6th at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the Middlesex School, Concord, MA., or to the Parkinson's Foundation of Columbia University Medical School, 710 West 168th Street, N.Y.C.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column yesterday about an agreement by Deutsche Telekom to sell its remaining cable television systems to the Liberty Media Corporation misstated the value of the deal in dollars. The price, 5.5 billion euros, is equivalent to about $5 billion, not $5 million.

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Hearing a Composer Practice What He Taught
description: As a composer and a teacher of composers, Earl Kim espoused a principle so simple it should have seemed obvious. He maintained that every sound in a piece should be precise, purposeful and above all faithful to the composer's sensibilities. Kim, who died in 1998 at 78, lived during an era of contention and dogma in contemporary music, a challenging time, he knew, for composers, especially impressionable students, to cultivate their musical identity. Still, Kim found it discouraging that so many composers simply latched on to intellectually intriguing systems and trendy styles or filled their works with notes and energy rather than looking deeper and working harder to find their own voice.

title: Manugistics Shares Drop After Hours
description: Shares of Manugistics Group Inc. fell as much as 35 percent in after-hours trading after the software maker said it expected a fiscal second-quarter loss because of a slowdown in customer spending and order delays.

title: Research Not to Be Hidden
description: What do advances in biotechnology have in store for international relations? Consider the following. At a once-secret military research center near Moscow, a new type of anthrax has been developed that can overcome the standard Russian and American vaccines. In Ohio, a military contractor laboratory is awaiting final approval from the Bush administration to replicate the Russian work by creating its own genetically modified version of the disease. And in an academic laboratory in Australia, scientists exploring ways to sterilize mice have discovered how a highly lethal biological agent might be made.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in World Business yesterday about increases in the dividends paid by some Russian oil companies misspelled the given name of an analyst at Aton, a Moscow investment bank. He is Steven Dashevsky, not Stepan.

title: Rivera Says Rise in Polls Influenced Endorsement
description: In endorsing Fernando Ferrer yesterday, Dennis Rivera, the president of New York City's giant health care union, acknowledged that he had a huge change of heart over the last week.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Manchester: Lawmaker Sentenced
description: State Representative Kevin Ryan of Montville was sentenced to a mandatory four-month jail sentence yesterday after being arrested for drunken driving for the second time in four years. Mr. Ryan, who has supported legislation to toughen drunken driving laws, was arrested in July and pleaded guilty to operating a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. A judge ordered a two-year prison term, suspended after Mr. Ryan serves four months, the required minimum sentence for a second-time offender.

title: Dear User: This Bootleg Copy Will Self-Destruct in 30 Days
description: WINDOWS XP has many features designed to make it easy for home users to customize and copy their own digital movie and music files, but there is one thing they will not be able to copy: Windows XP itself.

title: The Twisting Path To a New Front Door
description: MY wife and I wanted a new front door. When we bought our little house in New Jersey a year ago, the battered door with its peeled wood veneer was one of the least attractive things about it -- that, and the fact that it had been painted a shade of pink rarely found outside a Pepto-Bismol bottle. But we spent the move-in budget on painting over the pink and fixing up the basement so that we would have bedrooms for all three children. The door would have to wait.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Replaytv Adds More Storage
description: The ReplayTV subsidiary of Sonicblue Inc. is readying a new version of its ReplayTV digital video recording system that can store up to 320 hours of television, the most yet of any such device -- as well as connect to broadband networks, allowing users to share videos over the Internet. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said the updated version, called ReplayTV 4000, would allow viewers to collect movies and programs as well as compile videos and photographs. Prices range from $699 for 40 hours of storage to $1,999 for 320 hours, the company said. It expects to ship the device in November. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: MEXICO PRESIDENT URGES U.S. TO ACT SOON ON MIGRANTS
description: Making the first state visit of the Bush administration, President Vicente Fox of Mexico today urged the United States to commit to a speedy timetable for agreement this year on broad, politically sensitive proposals for the treatment of millions of illegal Mexican immigrants.

title: Big Belgian Beer Maker Posts 63% Rise in Profit
description: With an economic slowdown threatening, everything from computers to camisoles may be piling up unsold on store shelves. But consumers are still in the mood for a cold one, especially in the United States, if the earnings reported today by Interbrew, the giant Belgian brewer, are any guide.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Rochelle: Firefighter Accused Of D.W.I.
description: An off-duty firefighter has been arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated and fleeing the scene of a three-car accident, a spokesman for the New Rochelle Police Department said yesterday. The firefighter, Lt. Michael Maye, 40, hit one unoccupied car and another car with two passengers on Sunday, around 3 a.m., the spokesman, Lt. Robert Gazzola, said. The passengers suffered minor injuries. The Associated Press reported that Lieutenant Maye was suspended without pay and is free on $250 bail. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALATSKY, MORTON
description: KALATSKY-Morton. The Board of Directors, Trustees, Officers, staff and members of the Yad Avraham Institute mourn the passing of Morton Kalatsky, father of our cherished Dean and teacher, Rabbi Yosef Kalatsky. We express our profound sympathy to his wife, Jennie, & the entire Kalatsky family. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yad Avraham Institute Ira Rennert, Trustee Louis Glick, Trustee David Lobel, President

title: Fresh From Factory Parts, A Populist Backdrop for Folk Art
description: ''Folk art, like a sign for a dentist in the shape of a tooth, is populist stuff,'' said Adam Kalkin, an architectural designer responsible for the Collector's House, below, a new exhibition space at the Shelburne Museum in Shelburne, Vt. So he used a populist material, prefabricated parts from Butler Manufacturing in Kansas City, Mo. The 1,600-square-foot metal shed has a canvas curtain on the patio. Inside, there are 50 pieces of folk art chosen by Albert Hadley, the Manhattan interior designer, and furniture designed by John Danzer, president of Munder-Skiles, Manhattan. Admission: $17.50, adults; $10.50, students; $7, children 6 to 14. Information: (802) 985-3346. ELAINE LOUIE

title: James Lopez Watson, 79, Judge on U.S. Trade Court
description: Judge James Lopez Watson, one of the most senior black members of the federal judiciary, died Saturday at his home in Harlem. He was 79.

title: Exit at Durban
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Improve Radio Signal
description: For the first time in four years, Islander games will be heard on a station that its fans will not have difficulty hearing.

title: New York City Schools Opening Under a Financial Pall
description: Paul Nieves arrived at John Dewey High School in Coney Island for the first day of school yesterday under brilliantly sunny skies, wearing an outfit chosen to so blind his classmates with his sense of style that they would forget he was just a puny freshman: an oversize Paco sports shirt and a gold stud in one ear.

title: Counting Rules to Be Examined
description: A City Hall task force is urging the Board of Elections to reconsider a proposal by four Democratic mayoral candidates to loosen the vote-counting rules for Tuesday's Democratic primary, participants in the talks said yesterday.

title: Windows XP: Microsoft's New Look for Fall, in Size XXL
description: IF you could choose only one word to sum up Windows XP, ''big'' would come to mind. Microsoft's new operating system is physically big, requiring two gigabytes of hard-drive space and more than an hour to install. It's big in scope, too: XP is Microsoft's attempt to merge its home line (the friendly but cranky Windows 95, 98 and Me) with its corporate line (the unattractive but rock-solid Windows NT and 2000) into a unified operating system that offers the best of both.

title: Another Clash of the Titans
description: Andre Agassi walked out of the tunnel in Arthur Ashe Stadium first last night, with his fit, 31-year-old body cloaked in black. A few loping strides behind, Pete Sampras emerged in his trademark baggy white shorts to meet the standing ovation awaiting both of them.

title: A 4-Year-Old Bronx Boy Is Stabbed to Death
description: A 4-year-old boy was fatally stabbed yesterday afternoon while he was taking garbage to the trash chute in his Bronx apartment building, the authorities said.

title: Kissinger Receives Olympic Award
description: Henry A. Kissinger, who received the United States Olympic Committee's Douglas MacArthur Award yesterday, recalled that his lifelong love of sports had been obscured by his career in diplomacy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Catholic Schools' Strike Vote
description: Teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools in New York City and its suburbs have voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike beginning Monday, the day the schools are scheduled to open. The vote was 122 to 22 on Tuesday night. Nearly 450 teachers work at the schools, but only 300 of them belong to the union. Henry Kielkucki, business manager for the Lay Faculty Association, said the teachers, who are paid an average of $32,000 a year, would strike unless the archdiocese offered a significant raise. Archdiocese officials said they were ready to bargain. The most recent bargaining session was on July 18. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Advance By The G.O.P.
description: In a rebuff to the longtime speaker of the Georgia House, a coalition of black Democrats and white Republicans in that chamber passed a Congressional redistricting plan that would help Republicans retain a majority in the state's delegation. The State Senate has yet to pass a plan, so the House map will not necessarily become law. Georgia has 11 seats in the United States House, with 8 held by Republicans and 3 by Democrats. After reapportionment, it will have 13. Under the plan passed over the objection of Speaker Tom Murphy, a Democrat, Republicans would most likely hold 8 or 9. Under Mr. Murphy's plan, the Republicans would have been favored to hold only 6 or 7.

title: Rock Stars Oppose Bush's Energy Plan and Ask Fans to Join Them
description: David Crosby, the mustachioed, silver-haired third of Crosby, by Stills & Nash, claims not to think when he plays. ''Gets in the way,'' he said.

title: Target of Attack in Belfast: Little Girls Going to School
description: Four police officers were seriously injured this morning when militant Protestants, who have been trying to prevent Roman Catholic girls from reaching their elementary school in North Belfast, hurled a homemade bomb at the children and their police escorts.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE SAYS ITS EARNINGS WILL INCREASE
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, which last month reported its first loss in eight years, said fiscal first-quarter earnings would rise as the company cuts costs. Profit excluding expenses for revamping will rise by a percentage rate in the low- to mid-single digits, or about 1 percent to 6 percent, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Fiscal 2002 earnings will rise at least 6 percent.

title: Interpublic Continues To Realign Operations
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York continues to reorganize after its recent acquisition of True North Communications as it merges agencies within one of its four main units, the McCann-Erickson World Group.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Kevin Kline, Hotel Flaubert, Trouville, France, 1981

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERLING, MAURICE E.
description: SERLING-Maurice E. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed life member and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Clarice, and his family. Corey B. Rabin, President Ronald M. Stuart, Secretary

title: Justice Official Denies Pressure to Settle Tobacco Suit
description: A senior career Justice Department official who manages the government's civil case against the tobacco industry said at a Senate hearing today that no one in the Bush administration had ever pressured him to consider settling the huge lawsuit.

title: Handheld2 + Calculator2 = A New Curve for Students
description: Try this on an abacus: a new calculator from Texas Instruments may not only help students in math class, it may also remind them to show up in the first place. The TI-83 Plus Silver Edition is a hybrid of a graphing calculator and a personal digital assistant. In addition to the standard graphing functions, the $129.95 Silver Edition offers scheduling and contact software, to-do lists and several educational software programs. It also has twice the speed and nine times the memory of the previous Texas Instruments model.

title: A Keyboard Puts Shortcuts Within Fingers' Reach
description: Keyboards are, by definition, touchy-feely. Microsoft's new model, called the Microsoft Office Keyboard, may be the most touchy-feely yet. Straight out of the box, the keyboard reveals a new set of buttons and keys alongside all the familiar Qwerty ones.

title: The Harvard Club Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Wary Of Laws on Privacy
description: Washington is not creating new laws and regulations that might restrict the use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities.

title: Chinese Country Treasures Wend Their Way to Harlem
description: Asiarustic, selling Chinese country furniture, has opened in Harlem. The owner, Ana Wong-McNuer, was raised in Peru but makes collecting trips to China, which her parents left in the 1930's. The cash-box chair (left) is $1,100; bamboo or wood chests are $1,400 to $1,900; side tables and coffee tables, $1,300 to $2,500. From Sept. 10 to 15, the gallery will give 20 percent of its revenues to help restore the Colonial kitchen in the Morris-Jumel Mansion, a 1765 house and museum in Harlem. Asiarustic is at 1028 St. Nicholas Avenue (162nd Street), (212) 795-4403 and www.asiarustic.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIGSBERG, MAYNARD
description: KOENIGSBERG-Maynard. Our beloved brother-in-law and uncle will be fondly remembered and deeply missed by all our family as the unique and loving person that he was. Our most heartfelt sympathy to Elaine, Craig, Kim and Gerry over the loss of their dear husband and father. Lillian, Jane, Allan, Diane and Amy Goldman

title: Making the Case For Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Move The Home Page To a New Home
description: WITH all the turmoil in the Internet industry, those who have built a home -- or rather, a home page -- online are finding that some of the same rules of terrestrial real estate still apply. Namely, sometimes you have to move, because your landlord has decided to sell your house or is raising the rent, or maybe you feel it's just time to move on.

title: Playing with History
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: To the Editor:

title: UNB, NORTHEAST OHIO BANK, TO PURCHASE BANCFIRST OHIO
description: The UNB Corporation, a bank with 21 branches in northeast Ohio, agreed to buy the BancFirst Ohio Corporation for $193.4 million in stock to move into the central and southwestern parts of the state. UNB will exchange 1.325 shares for each BancFirst Ohio share, or $22.13 a share, based on UNB's closing price. The offer was 17 percent higher than BancFirst's share price before the acquisition was announced. UNB will add branches in Zanesville, Columbus, Newark and Dayton for a total of 48 branches. It will have $2.7 billion in assets and will manage $1.4 billion in trust assets.

title: It's Time For Tiznow To Make His Run
description: They called her Cee, and for 40 years while owning and breeding horses, she tried to do what every racetrack enthusiast does: find the right horse. On Nov. 4 at Churchill Downs, Cecilia Straub-Rubens watched one of her homebreds, Tiznow, lead the best horses in the world almost every step of the way to win the Breeders' Cup Classic.

title: Missile Shield Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: New Campaigns
description: * The Association for Investment Management and Research, Charlottesville, Va., is beginning a worldwide print campaign with spending estimated at $3 million to promote its designation of chartered financial analysts. The campaign, created by Citigate Albert Frank, New York, part of the Incepta Group, will run in the September and October issues of business, financial and lifestyle publications.

title: Snapple Picks Agency For Fruit-Flavored Soda
description: The Snapple Beverage Group in White Plains, a unit of Cadbury Schweppes, has named Decker in Glastonbury, Conn., as the first agency to handle assignments for its Stewart's line of fruit-flavored sodas.

title: Belfast's Little Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: A Thai Volleyball Team That Vives Its Diffrence
description: Who could argue with a giddy feel-good comedy (based on a true story, no less) about a Thai volleyball team composed mostly of gay men, transvestites and transsexuals that defies expectations to win the national championships? Only the most intransigent sexual bigot could fail to feel a twinge of vicarious glee when the defiantly mincing and prancing Iron Ladies, as they call themselves, trounce their sneering macho opponents and embarrass a homophobic sports official who has been looking for any excuse to disqualify them from the games.

title: New Republic Says Top Editor Will Take Over For Columnist
description: Andrew Sullivan, the gay conservative commentator with a knack for unnerving any constituency that might embrace him, is losing his berth as the ''TRB'' columnist in The New Republic, he and the magazine's editor announced yesterday.

title: It Seems Only a Matter of Time
description: The afternoon pickup games at Hoops the Gym near Chicago's West Loop include at least nine current N.B.A. players and one retiree -- a team executive approaching middle age.

title: Rambling and Gambling by Rangers' Sather
description: A colleague of Glen Sather's today described the Rangers' president and general manager as something of a gambler when it comes to putting together a hockey team. Sather did not seem to mind that assessment.

title: Hard Hit, But Still No Hard Feelings
description: When Kerry Collins and Bill Romanowski got together in an N.F.L. preseason game in 1997, their encounter left memories for both of them.

title: Robert M. Brown, a Champion Of Ecumenism, Is Dead at 81
description: Robert McAfee Brown, a Presbyterian theologian who played a prominent role in the ecumenical and liberation theology movements, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Greenfield, Mass. He was 81.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: White House Sets Up Clash Over Congressional Inquiry
description: The Bush administration affirmed today that it would not cooperate with a Congressional inquiry into the preparation of the president's energy plan, setting up a possible court battle that would test the right of lawmakers to investigate details of White House policy making.

title: Hingis Has a Goal: Foil the Sisters Again
description: The shadows that Venus and Serena Williams cast practicing in the early morning sun had long faded by yesterday afternoon, when Martina Hingis took the far court with her mother. Hingis used all 90 minutes of her allotted time. And then some.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: In the churning turmoil of creativity that is New York dining, pockets of peace and quiet can be found. Not every neighborhood aches for the next thing after coffee-chicory foam. Carnegie Hill is one of these. High up on the Upper East Side, whom you're eating with is often more important that what you're eating, and 92, Ken Aretsky's latest venture, reads the mood correctly.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., the military contractor, said it had won a contract to build three satellites for General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn. G.E.'s American Communications unit will use them to broadcast cable television programming. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Con Edison Sells Indian Point 2, Its Last Major Electricity Plant
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, owned for nearly 30 years by Consolidated Edison, was officially sold today to the Entergy Corporation. Entergy promptly installed new managers and weighed the possibility of shutting the troubled plant for repairs.

title: Bush Confronts Unsettling Economic News
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Trying to turn today's unpleasant news about the economy to his political advantage, President Bush said today he sympathizes with any American who loses a job but has no sympathy for Democrats who get in the way of his "pro-growth agenda."

title: A Man and His City Share A Creeping Conflagration
description: ''God doesn't exist,'' scoffs Fernando (Germn Jaramillo), the middle-aged lapsed-Catholic protagonist of ''Our Lady of the Assassins,'' Barbet Schroeder's indelible, blood-dripping portrait of the Colombian city of Medelln. A fiftysomething homosexual writer who has returned to the city of his youth after 30 years abroad, Fernando sardonically describes himself as his country's ''foremost grammarian.'' He has returned there to die, he explains with a self-deprecating nonchalance that conceals an underlying grandiosity.

title: Senate Votes to Relax Rules On the Exporting of Computers
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to ease restrictions on the export of mass-marketed computers and other high-technology products to countries like China and Pakistan, calling the current law a relic of the cold war.

title: F.B.I. Searches Internet Concern In Inquiry Into Mideast Terrorism
description: A federal antiterrorism task force has been searching the Texas office of a computer server that is host to a variety of Web sites of Islamic groups and charities as part of an investigation into the alleged support of terrorism by American Islamic networks, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Joint Venture
description: Hynix Semiconductor, talking with creditors for a fresh rescue plan covering more than $3 billion of debt, plans to sell 80.1 percent of its liquid crystal display unit to a group led by the Cando Corporation, a manufacturer of electronics products in Taiwan. Hynix said the deal was a joint venture in which it would earn $650 million from the Cando group while keeping 19.9 percent of equity. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Russia Tells of Plan to Ease Sales of Shares in Gazprom
description: Russia unveiled a preliminary plan today that would give foreign investors easier access to shares of Gazprom, the world's largest gas company. But crucial details were not provided, which will delay the plan, investors and analysts said.

title: The Ponytailed Place-Kicker
description: Ashley Martin, ponytail dangling from the back of her helmet, made history Thursday night when she became the first woman to play and score in a Division I college football game. One reason her triumph was not front-page news may have been that there were no lawyers involved, an absence that makes the story all the more heartening.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Parliament Opens After Suspension
description: Almost two months after President Chandrika Kumaratunga suspended Parliament to avoid a no-confidence vote, she reconvened it. The main opposition party immediately revived its efforts to bring down the government, but at least for now it appears the ruling coalition will survive with the votes of a small leftist party that drove a hard bargain for its agreement to support the government. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Snag In Trade Talks
description: China's 15-year effort to join the World Trade Organization has stalled because of a dispute between the United States and Europe over the treatment of the American International Group, a large insurance company, after the country joins the global trading system. The United States says its trade organization agreement with China should permit A.I.G. to continue expanding as a wholly foreign-owned company, which is how it operates now. The European Union says that A.I.G. should be held to the same restrictions as Europe's insurers are under an agreement Europe signed with China. That agreement requires insurers to have a Chinese partner. The three sides will meet next week in Geneva to try to reach an agreement that will permit the organization's 142 members to approve China's membership at a meeting of trade ministers in November in Qatar. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JONES, ROBERT
description: JONES-Robert. A memorial service for Robert Jones, Editor-inChief of HarperCollins, will be held on Monday, September 10 at The University Club at 3:00 p.m. The University Club is located at One West 54th Street, New York, N.Y. Jacket and tie required.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAPPER, HOPE LUNIN
description: KLAPPER-Hope Lunin. On September 5, 2001. Very much loved and greatly respected by friends, colleagues and family. A truly outstanding person and professional. Her insightful thoughts and perceptive comments, her warmth and sense of humor will be greatly missed. A Ph.D. in Sociology from Columbia University, formerly a Professor in the Sociology Department of New York University teaching Mass Communications and related subjects. The first instructor selected in a trial of teaching regular college classes via television. The first woman to be elected President of the American Association for Public Opinion Research. Widow of Joseph T. Klapper, head of Social Research at CBS. Deeply mourned by family members and friends. Service on Friday, Sept. 7th, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Goal for McGovern: Securing His Card
description: As the only full-time New Jersey resident competing on the PGA Tour, Jim McGovern is constantly asked one question by his peers. When will he move to a warmer climate?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOZAN, CHARLES W., M.D.
description: BOOZAN-Charles W., M.D. Age 82. Died peacefully at home in Sea Girt, N.J. on September 5, 2001. A graduate of Princeton University and Cornell Medical College, he practiced ophthalmology for 40 years in Elizabeth, N.J. He was an inspiration to his three sons who all attended Princeton and became physicians. He is survived by his wife Mona, sons William, John and James, sister Doris Lynch and seven adoring grandchildren. A funeral mass will be said Saturday, September 8th 9:30AM at Saint Mark's Church in Sea Girt, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACHTMAN, DOROTHY
description: PACHTMAN-Dorothy, 92. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL passed away on September 6, 2001. Survived by sons Edward (Toni) Pachtman and Alan (Patty) Pachtman; grandchildren Lisa Schlesinger, Cori Pachtman, Daniel Pachtman and Jeffrey Pachtman; greatgrandchildren Ari Schlesinger and Noah Schlesinger. For information contact Baird-Case/Jordan-Fannin Funeral Home, Fort Lauderdale, FL, phone 954-492-4000.

title: Technology Briefing | Semiconductors: Fairchild Raises Sales Forecast
description: Fairchild Semiconductor International raised its third-quarter sales forecast after semiconductor orders rose more than expected. Sales will fall about 15 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter, the company, based in South Portland, Me., said. It had expected sales to fall 15 percent to 20 percent. Fairchild had a second-quarter loss of $8 million on sales of $372.4 million.

title: Here's the Windup: Pitcher Starts 8th Grade
description: Pitcher Danny Almonte, who became famous first for his 46 Little League World Series strikeouts, and then for his 14 years, spent some time yesterday morning with Rolando Paulino, his mentor in baseball, and, many now say, in mendacity. Then they parted, each beginning a quest to reclaim his pre-scandal life.

title: Intruder at White House
description: The Secret Service arrested a 44-year-old man this afternoon after he climbed a fence at the northwest corner of the White House grounds.

title: Plan to Build Newark Arena Falls Apart
description: The proposal to build a $355 million sports arena in Newark and redevelop the Meadowlands fell apart today when a key Assembly committee canceled a hearing on the issue, effectively derailing the legislation.

title: High Ratings for Match
description: Pete Sampras's four-set victory over Andre Agassi in Wednesday night's quarterfinals of the United States Open was the most-watched tennis match in cable television history.

title: New Observations of Sun Add to Split Over Birth of Planets
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  New observations have revealed that just after the Sun was born, it was almost certainly much more violent than previously believed, repeatedly erupting with storms of particles and radiation that may have influenced the formation of planets and salted the early solar system with radioactive particles.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Namibia: A Century Later, Tribe Sues
description: The Herero tribe, which was nearly wiped out during German colonial rule in the early 20th century, has filed a class-action suit in the United States against three German companies that the Hereros say were party to ''enslavement and genocidal destruction of the Herero tribe.'' The suit, filed in District of Columbia Superior Court earlier this year, seeks $2 billion. The plaintiffs, led by the Herero People's Reparations Corporation, filed their suit in the United States because they believe they have a greater chance of success there. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Bush Picks Envoy to Seek Peace in Sudan
description: President Bush today denounced the Sudanese government's ''brutal and shameful war against its own people'' and appointed former Senator John C. Danforth as a special envoy to seek peace in the African nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSON, JAMES LOPEZ
description: WATSON-James Lopez. His friends and colleagues at HEAF (The Harlem Educational Activities Fund) note with profound sorrow the loss of Judge James L. Watson. A founding director of HEAF and a continuing source of encouragement and support, Skizz brought wisdom, compassion and unfailing good humor to our deliberations. He will be sorely missed and long remembered. The Harlem Educational Activities Fund Daniel Rose, President Courtney Welsh, Exec. Director

title: Havens for Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Rules Britain Violated Rights of 4 Kurds
description: LONDON, Sept. 7  In an unexpected blow to Britain's tough immigration policy, a British court declared today that four Kurdish asylum-seekers forcibly placed in a government detention center had been held there in violation of their human rights.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about Al Gore's fund-raising efforts misspelled the surname of a Gore adviser who has been courted by potential Democratic rivals for the 2004 presidential nomination. He is Michael Whouley, not Whooley.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the visit of President Vicente Fox of Mexico referred incorrectly in some copies to Democratic control in Congress. The Democrats control the Senate, not the House.

title: The Thompson Spot
description: Mr. Thompson began running this ad on Wednesday; he also has a positive ad about his experience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHNER, SAMUEL J., ESQ.
description: KIRSHNER-Samuel J., Esq. Born August 7, 1925, Altoona, PA. Died September 1, 2001, N.Y. Beloved husband of 51 years to Betty (Berman); father to Mark, Karen and Abby; grandfather to Rachel and Jonathan. WWII veteran, graduate of James Monroe H.S., Bronx, CCNY, Brooklyn Law School. Founder of Zam and Kirshner, Inc. advertising agency.

title: Heywood Hale Broun, 83, a Writer With Flair
description: Heywood Hale Broun, the television commentator, sports correspondent and writer known for his wit and elegant commentary, died Wednesday at Kingston (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 83.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. No Longer Seeking A Breakup of Microsoft

title: $2.2 Million for Parkinson's Research
description: While scientists await federal financing to study human embryonic stem cells, the Michael J. Fox Foundation is making an unusual offer: $2.2 million in grant money to produce a cell line specifically designed to study and treat Parkinson's disease.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: INSURANCE LIMITS POSTPONED

title: A Region's Workers Go From Flush Time To Hard Times, Fast
description: In the spring of last year, the Century Furniture Company ran a help-wanted advertisement for upholsterers in six area newspapers. The company was offering good pay in a region with thousands of experienced furniture workers, but not one applicant responded.

title: Green Says His Initiatives Nudged City Council and Mayor to Action
description: By his account, Public Advocate Mark Green has brought so much to the legislative table on a variety of issues, from campaign finance reform to domestic violence to police misconduct, that he considers his actual job description irrelevant.

title: Afghans Present Aid Team's Sins, Complete With Theology Lesson
description: Most foreign ministers do not begin news conferences with religious commentary, but Wakil Ahmad Muttawakil seemed compelled today to explain that the people of Afghanistan have great respect for Jesus Christ. After all, Jesus was not only a man of wisdom, but also someone who ''cured lepers'' and ''brought the dead back to life.''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Congressman Slain
description: Jairo Rojas, vice president of a congressional peace commission, was shot dead outside his home in Bogot by unidentified gunmen, the second member of the commission to be slain in nine months. In December, the president of the commission, Diego Turbay, was shot in southern Colombia. The government has accused Colombia's largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, in the Turbay killing. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: School Construction Debate Pits City Against Rest of State in Albany Budget
description: The way the state pays for school construction has become one of the main stumbling blocks in negotiations between the governor and legislative leaders over a supplementary budget, and the debate is pitting upstate and suburban lawmakers against their urban colleagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, MARY M.
description: DOYLE-Mary M. On September 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Lester T. Doyle. Loving mother of Kevin Doyle. Cherished grandmother of Virgil and Eliza Doyle. Dear sister of Patricia Nielsen and Catherine Meyer. Family will be receiving friends Friday 2-4 and 79 at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Mass Saturday 10 AM at St. John Evangelist, 348 East 55 St. Interment to follow at Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers family requests donations to be made to the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021.

description: NEW YORK

title: Compaq and Hewlett Face More Skepticism
description: As Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer marshaled forces today to defend their proposed merger into the world's largest computer company, investors continued to express skepticism about the union, taking another bite out of the companies' shares for the third consecutive day.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Child Car-Seat Law
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco yesterday signed a law requiring small children to ride in a car seat or booster. Previous state law required only boosters or car seats for children under 18 months, but the new law extends the requirement to children under the age of 8 and weighing less than 80 pounds. The penalty for noncompliance is a fine of up to $44.

title: The Big City; In Campaigns, Not a Peep On Noise Issue
description: SUPPOSE you are one of four Democratic candidates for mayor desperately trying to attract attention. You have not yet found any remotely interesting issue that distinguishes you from the other candidates. You are not all that sure yourself what distinguishes you from the other candidates.

title: Conferees Fail To Resolve Their Disputes At Race Talks
description: A last-minute effort to break an impasse over the Middle East at the United Nations racism meeting here faltered tonight as European and Arab nations failed to agree on a declaration proposed by the South African government.

title: Another U.S. Citizen Held in China
description: BEIJING, Sept. 7  A 66-year-old naturalized American citizen has been imprisoned here for the last 18 months on suspicion of gathering state secrets, his relatives and American officials revealed today.

title: Equity in Tennis
description: To the Editor:

title: An Intricate Tapestry Of a Heroic Age
description: THE opening credits of ''Band of Brothers'' captures the pretty romanticism of war-in-the-movies. Parachutes cascade slowly to the ground, soldiers move in gauzy stop-action, lyrical music floats in the background, and HBO's expensive, enormous miniseries about an American parachute unit in World War II gets off to a disheartening start. The world doesn't need one more knee-jerk paean to the greatest generation.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON DECLINES. Cotton fell after a U.S. government report predicted a 15 percent increase in the Chinese cotton crop from a year ago. Cotton for December delivery fell 1.17 cents, or 3 percent, to 38.41 cents a pound.

title: It Is Third and Long For Fox's Summerall
description: Pat Summerall does not want to stop being John Madden's partner on Fox's National Football League broadcasts, nor does he think he deserves to be left dangling by network officials who refuse to commit to him beyond this season.

title: Hindu Rituals On Display
description: ''Meeting God: Elements of Hindu Devotion,'' which opens tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, displays daily rituals of Hindu worship as practiced in the home, in the temple and on the street, evoked through shrines, photographs, textiles and statues like that of the goddess Gauri, right, worshiped for successful crops and healthy families.

title: House Passes Broad Trade Pact With Vietnam
description: The House voted today to approve a wide-ranging trade agreement with Vietnam that would end decades of economic sanctions imposed by the United States against its former enemy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, PETER
description: HARRIS-Peter. The Episcopal Actors' Guild mourns its beloved Vice President Emeritus Peter Harris, whose gentle dedication defined the Guild for 53 years.

title: Your Homework, Class: Read This
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEGARELLI, EDWARD V.
description: ZEGARELLi-Edward V., D.D.S. Renowned dental educator and pioneer in Oral Medicine on September 2, 2001. Dean Emeritus of Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery. Devoted husband for 62 years to Irene M. (Ceconi) and father of Edward V., Jr., Dr. David J.; Philip E. and Dr. Peter J. Grandfather of 11 and brother of Lillian Stivali and Anne LaPorte. Visitation Friday at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY from 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Saturday 11:00 AM, Immaculate Conception Church, Sleepy Hollow, NY.

title: Many ABC Programs to Be in High-Definition TV Format
description: ABC disclosed plans yesterday to offer most of its prime-time programs this season in a high-definition television format, a potentially significant step in advancing a technology for improved television pictures that has been slow to catch on.

title: Dr. Edward Victor Zegarelli, 88, An Authority on Mouth Diseases
description: Dr. Edward Victor Zegarelli, a retired Columbia University dean and oral pathologist who cataloged and documented the more than 400 known diseases of the mouth and jaw, died on Sunday at his home in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 88.

title: Foreign Affairs; Reforming Success
description: I'm the last person who should be giving President Bush political advice. As his father used to say to Jim Baker, ''If you're so smart, why am I president?'' But Mr. Bush might want to study the parallels between himself and the former British Conservative Party leader William Hague, who recently lost in a landslide to Tony Blair.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Insurance Limits Postponed
description: The New York State Insurance Department said that an Appellate Division justice has postponed its stricter no-fault auto insurance regulations, which were to go into effect last Saturday. The New York State Trial Lawyers Association, one of the groups seeking to permanently block the new regulations, said yesterday that the postponement would be in effect at least until a Sept. 27 hearing on its lawsuit in State Supreme Court. The regulations would reduce to 30 days from 90 the period that an injured person has to report an accident to an insurance company, and to 45 days from 180 the time for a doctor to submit a compensation claim for treatment. The Pataki administration has said the tighter deadlines are needed to curb fraud, while legal and medical groups have said that the deadlines will penalize honest accident victims and medical providers and will not deter fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOURIEZ, PHILIPPE
description: BOURIEZ-Philippe. Beloved husband of Edith Scott Bouriez. Father of Anne Bouriez Brunet & Laure Bouriez Cuvillier. Father-inlaw of Edouard Brunet and Emmanuel Cuvillier. Grandfather of seven and stepfather of three. On September 4 in St. Jean de Luz, France.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the state dinner given for President Vicente Fox of Mexico misstated the leadership position held by Senator Trent Lott. He is the minority leader, not the majority leader.

title: Judge Rejects Sale of Raytheon Unit
description: Washington Group International said today that a bankruptcy judge in Nevada had agreed to throw out a $503 million pact to buy a Raytheon construction unit because of accusations of hidden cost overruns.

title: A New Avenue For Musicals
description: As president of Polygram Video, Bill Sondheim appreciated one thing above all else about performing-arts titles. ''They sold as strongly in north central Ohio as on the two coasts,'' he said. Of course, ''The Three Tenors,'' with Luciano Pavarotti, Plcido Domingo and Jos Carreras, sold all over the country, as did ''Cats,'' ''Les Misrables'' and ''Lord of the Dance,'' all of them Polygram videos.

title: Hudson County Leader Quits Amid Signs of Federal Inquiry
description: Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County executive, abruptly resigned today, throwing into political upheaval a bastion of Democratic politics that has often been tarnished by scandal.

title: Morgan Stanley May Face Sex-Discrimination Suit
description: Executives of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter expect the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to file a sex discrimination suit against it as soon as next week, people inside the firm said yesterday.

title: Court Rules Britain Violated Rights of 4 Kurds
description: LONDON, Sept. 7  In an unexpected blow to Britain's tough immigration policy, a British court declared today that four Kurdish asylum-seekers forcibly placed in a government detention center had been held there in violation of their human rights.

title: A Huge 4-Year Crusade Gets Credit for a Coup
description: If the Microsoft Corporation won at least a partial victory today, its corporate adversaries were quick to argue that the company's huge and far-reaching lobbying crusade of the last few years should receive a healthy share of the credit.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Big Retail For South Bronx
description: New York City has chosen the Related Companies, one of the partners in the AOL Time Warner Center project, to develop a $36 million retail and office complex on a city-owned site at the edge of a South Bronx commercial district known as the Hub. The complex is planned for Third Avenue from 153rd to 156th Streets. Robert M. Harding, the deputy mayor for economic development and finance, said this week that the planned complex, which is expected to provide 540 permanent jobs, would be ''the cornerstone of the revitalization of the Hub.'' He said Kmart had expressed interest in being the anchor tenant of the retail space, which is to occupy two of the complex's three levels, with offices on the third. Related Companies will also renovate a nearby parking garage, officials said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: More Trouble For Ex-Official
description: Former Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who was sentenced to jail earlier this year for his part in a government corruption scandal, has been placed under investigation again, this time over the contested sale of some Alberto Giacometti sculptures. French investigators suspect that Mr. Dumas, who acted as the executor of the estate of Giacometti's wife, was given an illegal ''commission'' by the auctioneer he hired to sell off several sculptures. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Report Counts Computers In Majority of U.S. Homes
description: More than half of the households in the United States had at least one computer last year, and more than 40 percent were connected to the Internet, a Census Bureau report released today said.

title: Retailers Report Disappointing Sales for August
description: The federal tax rebates, which were supposed to stimulate demand for consumer goods, failed to transform America's shoppers into bigger spenders in August, resulting in disappointing sales for many stores and renewing fears that the December holiday shopping season will be one of the most lackluster in years.

title: A Salomon Analyst Sues Over Demotion
description: The beverage analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, Jennifer Solomon, has sued the firm, accusing it of committing fraud and sex discrimination when it rescinded a promotion.

description: An official in Connecticut's Department of Economic and Community Development admitted in federal court today that he took bribes from a company he had recommended for millions of dollars in state grants.

description: The place will probably not be called The Shah's Motel.

title: Avon Chief Adds Post
description: Avon Products Inc., the largest direct seller of cosmetics, gave Andrea Jung the additional title of chairman, after profit climbed during her nearly two years as chief executive. Ms. Jung, 42, is one of five female chief executives of Fortune 500 companies, according to the research group Catalyst, and is one of three holding the titles of chairman and chief executive. She replaces Stanley Gault, former chairman of Rubbermaid Inc. and the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company. Her appointment is effective immediately, Avon said.

title: Florida Curbs the Operators Of Popular Shark Excursions
description: Under the glare of publicity over shark attacks this summer, the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission today banned operators of popular ''interactive'' shark dives from using bloody bait to lure the fish so that people can frolic with them.

title: Kremlin Willing to Review Missile Accords, Aide Says
description: A senior Russian official said today that Moscow was willing to consider amendments to the ''present-day system of agreements on strategic stability'' with the United States, but he insisted that the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 had to be preserved in negotiations that were quite likely to be long-term and complex.

title: FINWICK & WEST, A LAW FIRM, ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS
description: Fenwick & West, a prominent law firm in Palo Alto, Calif., that grew rapidly during the dot-com boom, announced the layoffs of 32 associates and 15 paralegals yesterday as a result of the slowdown in the economy. The firm, the latest to show signs of the strain of retaining high-wage young lawyers when business is slow, will provide a severance package that includes full salary and benefits through the end of the year and outplacement assistance. Fenwick & West has also told about half of the lawyers starting work this fall that they may elect to receive a similar package and look for a job elsewhere, said Gordon K. Davidson, chairman of the firm. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: China's Nuclear Agenda
description: What had been an internal debate in the Bush administration about the strategic nuclear relationship between the United States and China went public last week, when troubling statements attributed to ''senior administration officials'' suggested that they were not opposed to China's increasing its nuclear stockpile. Then came White House backpedaling. At the heart of these mixed signals is the question of how the United States should counter China's small nuclear force, in the context of China's abilities to develop new weapons and its opposition to missile defense.

title: Celebrating the Love Of Bad Rock in the 80's
description: One of the most impressive -- and annoying -- features of contemporary American popular culture is its ability to recycle its own waste products, to regard the trash and ephemera of earlier eras with affection and nostalgia. ''Rock Star,'' a loose, happy-go-lucky mlange of VH1 rockumentary and rags-to-riches melodrama, tries to do for the bad arena rock of the mid-1980's what ''Almost Famous'' did for the bad arena rock of the previous decade.

title: 2 Big Names in Hong Kong Get Some Rare Good News
description: For two of Hong Kong's most embattled executives, this week has brought a welcome respite from months of bad news.

title: Colombian Anticipating New Talks With Rebels
description: President Andrs Pastrana said today that he believed that peace negotiations with leftist rebels could proceed in the last year of his presidency, despite the lack of tangible results after two years of talks and a growing conflict that has left many Colombians pessimistic.

title: A Free Spirit Romps in the Music Room
description: It was as relaxed an atmosphere as you are likely to find at a classical music performance. As listeners milled around, chatted and ordered drinks in Studio 54's small upstairs cabaret theater on Wednesday evening, a young quartet played Mozart, occasionally stopping between movements so that its members could get up to greet friends.

description: BARUCH-Marcel. The Board, members and staff of the Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourn the passing of Marcel Baruch. Marcel devoted himself, for over three decades, to the care of the aged and disabled in our community, serving since 1970 as an Administrator, Senior Vice President for Long Term Care and consultant for the Schulman and Schachne Institutes of the Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center. Marcel brought immense thoughtfulness, compassion and genuine personal concern to his vital work as a leader in the field of continuing care services. title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Probation For Guard In Sex Case
description: A former prison guard was sentenced to five years of probation after pleading guilty to having had sex with Susan Smith, who is serving a life sentence for drowning her two sons in a lake in 1994. Alfred Rowe Jr., a former captain at the Women's Correctional Institute in Columbia, acknowledged having sex with Ms. Smith in summer 2000, and apologized to his wife and family for the hardship he had caused. Another guard, Houston Cagle, pleaded guilty last month to having had sex with Ms. Smith and is awaiting sentencing. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: The Weldon Connection
description: In Fay Weldon's novels there are no ads in the margins of the pages, none on the dust jacket, unless you count the publisher's name and logo, and none on the flyleaves or endpapers. That is one of the things we expect from books, a clean space in which the words can do their work, uncluttered by the visual din of advertising. But in Ms. Weldon's newest novel, ''The Bulgari Connection,'' some of the words themselves are an advertisement -- for the jeweler Bulgari. Ms. Weldon's novel was commissioned by Bulgari as a private literary bauble to celebrate the opening of a new store on Sloane Street in London. Ms. Weldon's task was to stud her work with references to the jeweler.
