All summer long, the boys from the first floor of her apartment building in the Bronx were bothering her, she said, and it started up again on Wednesday afternoon after she went into the hall with her little brother to dump a soiled diaper down the trash chute.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Flogging For Islamic Militant
description: In a rare move, a court in the northeastern city of Mashad sentenced the leader of an Islamic vigilante force to 25 lashes and a five-month prison term for attacking and beating spectators at a comedy show in July. Hamid Ostad is a leader of the hard-line Ansar-e-Hizbollah, whose members have attacked pro-reform meetings and public shows. description: Nearly 4 percent of American households consist of three or more generations, Census Bureau figures show. Two-thirds of the nation's 3.9 million multigenerational family households consisted of the householder and or her children and grandchildren, and one-third of the householder, children, and parents or in-laws. Hawaii has the highest proportion of multigenerational households, at 8.2 percent; North Dakota has the lowest, at 1.1 percent. Nationwide, about 78,000 households consisted of four generations. description: ON the surface, ''The Flying Dutchman'' is about two ships in port. But Stephen Lawless, who is directing this Wagner work for the New York City Opera, was attracted to the piece for its larger themes, namely romance and redemption.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Crime-Fighting Strategies
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed new crime-fighting strategies yesterday. Twenty investigators have been assigned to a new unit to search exclusively for the 100 most wanted violent criminals in the city. The police department also plans to spend more time on domestic violence by making return visits to households to see if there have been other violent incidents. More officers will also try to arrest suspects wanted on domestic violence-related warrants. The mayor also reported that since January, citywide crime dropped 13 percent from the year-ago period and dropped 63 percent since 1993. Through the end of last month, 412 murders were reported, down from 1,304 at the same time in 1993.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the debate over productivity of the economy attributed a phrase erroneously to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. While Mr. Greenspan's statements have implied that he believes the economy can achieve a maximum growth rate near 3.5 to 4 percent a year without rising inflation, he he has not publicly specified rates.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Signs Of West Nile Virus
description: Two dead crows found in the Chicago area last month have tested positive for the mosquito-borne West Nile virus, state health officials said. This is the first time the virus has been detected in the state since 1999, when it was first discovered in New York. Although the virus was found in birds in Ohio, Michigan, Indiana and Wisconsin last month, Illinois officials said they had not expected it until next year. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: International Traveler : Airlines Wake Up to Coach Class
description: PARIS  As they compete for passengers in a slowing economy, airlines are focusing more closely on the one component of an airplane outside the cargo hold that makes money: the seat.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: More Layoffs At Motorola
description: Motorola said yesterday that it would add 2,000 more workers to its previously announced job cuts, bringing the total in the last year to 32,000. The company said that sales had been slower than expected and that it now expected revenue to be roughly equal to the second quarter instead of 5 percent higher as previously projected. Motorola's stock fell $2.46, to $13.94. Robert L. Growney, Motorola's president and chief operating officer, expressed surprise at the size of the drop. He noted that despite the soft sales, Motorola expected to match or come close to Wall Street's estimate that the company would lose 5 cents a share in the quarter. In addition, Motorola said that orders for semiconductors were starting to balance with production. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Displaying Hindu Ritual With Reverence and Graciousness
description: Visitors to ''Meeting God: Elements of Hindu Devotion,'' which opens tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, may or may not encounter the divine presence in its galleries. But they can easily enter into the show's mood of euphoric reverence and spiritual graciousness while also learning quite a bit about one of the world's great religions. And because nearly everything on display comes from India, which is 82 percent Hindu, visitors can also get a palpable sense of the completely fluid fusion of faith, visual creativity and daily life that saturates Indian culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENTSCHNER, DR. ESTHER MELTZER,
description: LENTSCHNER-Dr. Esther Meltzer, retired Professor of the Wurzweiler School of Social Work of Yeshiva University, died April 15, 2001, at the age of 87. Born in Malden, Massachusetts, the sixth of seven children of William and Bessie Meltzer, and their first born in the United States to which they had come with five children from Russia, Dr. Lentschner was a magna cum laude Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Radcliffe College. She received a Master of Arts in Teaching from Harvard University Graduate School of Education, a Master of Social Work from Western Reserve University, and a Doctorate in Social Work from Columbia University. She worked in the field of family and children's services in Cleveland, Boston, and New York. In New York City she worked first for Spence-Chapin Adoption Service and headed a project to develop adoptive homes for African-American children in Washington, D.C. and New York City. Subsequently, she moved into the field of aging, and accepted a position to establish and direct the social services of the Workmen's Circle Home for Aged. In 1964, she joined the faculty of Yeshiva University's Wurzweiler School of Social Work. In addition to teaching, she was appointed the first Director of Admissions for the School. She retired in 1978. The following year she did a study for the Ford Foundation on a special educational program for foster parents. She was active in professional and community organizations, serving in particular as an officer and member of the board of directors of New York Service Program for Older People, the West-Side Inter-Agency Council on Aging, and the New York State Association of Gerontological Educators. She published on foster care and on services to the elderly and aging. Dr. Lentschner was the widow of Walter S. Lentschner, who died in 1986. Mr. Lentschner came to the United States from the French concentration camp Le Vernet, in 1941. He worked for 25 years as a research photographer in the department of ophthalmology of New York University Medical Center. The couple had no children. Dr. Lentschner is survived by four generations of nieces and nephews, as well as cousins in Montreal, the United States, and Israel. Interment was at Eretz Ha'Haim in Jerusalem. Contributions may be made to The Esther M. and Walter S. Lentschner Award for Excellence in Writing, C/O Wurzweiler School of Social Work, Yeshiva Univ., 500 W. 185th Street, New York, New York 10033. A memorial service will be held at the Wurzweiler School of Social Work, Belfer Hall, 2495 Amsterdam Avenue, October 11, 2001 at 1:30 PM.

title: A City Indebted To Its migrs
description: Ten years ago this week, when the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of Russia returned the historic name of St. Petersburg to Leningrad, the city's citizens did not feel universal delight. A referendum had found only 54 percent of voters in favor of the change. The still-powerful Communist Party had asked that ''there be no mockery of the name of glorious Leningrad, hero-city, warrior- and laborer-city.'' The newspaper Sovest (Conscience) demanded hysterically: ''Why rename our city? So that dead tsarism can breathe on us again?'' In reply, liberals organized a noisy demonstration under the slogan ''Lenin's name shames a great city!''

On Wednesday, Westchester County reported mosquitoes testing positive for the first time this year. According to Clare Bradley, the Suffolk health commissioner, the virus season ends only after two frosts.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Russian Rocket Vaporizes
description: An arcing bright light in the pre-dawn sky over the East Coast yesterday morning, first thought to be a meteor, was identified by United States space officials as a small Russian rocket re-entering the atmosphere. Witnesses from New York to Maryland reported the light around 6 a.m. when, officials say, the rocket entered the atmosphere 100 miles off the Delaware coast. Cmdr. Rod Gibbons of the United States Space Command said the rocket was launched in 1975 and probably vaporized in the upper atmosphere. More than 17,000 manmade objects have fallen to earth in the last 40 years.

title: National Briefing | Washington: University To Shut Campus For Meetings

Trachtenberg, said. The Foggy Bottom campus will close from the evening of Sept. 27 until the morning of Oct. 2. All students, faculty and staff have been instructed to leave during that period, including 5,400 students who live in dormitories. The campus is blocks from the site of a meeting expected to draw more than 100,000 protesters.

description: Commissioner Won't Stay

title: Executive Changes in Media and Marketing
description: Kathryn Carter was named to lead a new New York office of Envision, the marketing unit of the Anschutz Entertainment Group, as vice president. She had been vice president for sales and marketing at the United States operations of ISL, based in New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Denville: Interstate 80 Repairs
description: A key portion of Interstate 80, where traffic has been slowed for more than two months since a tractor-trailer accident, is expected to be completely repaired by Monday morning, officials said. But tonight the section will be temporarily closed, further snarling the evening commute. The State Department of Transportation said all westbound lanes between Parsippany and Denville will close at 8 p.m. tonight, and traffic will be diverted to Route 46 West for 24 to 36 hours while construction crews remove a temporary two-lane bridge over Den Brook. The temporary bridge was installed after a June 22 crash cracked concrete supports for the original 50-foot-long bridge.

title: U.S. ABANDONING ITS EFFORT TO BREAK APART MICROSOFT, SAYING IT SEEKS RESOLUTION
description: Reversing the government's strategy in the landmark antitrust case against Microsoft, the Bush administration announced today that it would no longer seek a breakup of the company. The government also abandoned a central claim of the lawsuit: that Microsoft had violated federal antitrust law by integrating its Internet Explorer browser software into its Windows operating system.

title: A Meeting Of Gadflies Who Mostly Play Nicely
description: Six of the seven Democratic candidates for public advocate yesterday formally debated for the last time before Tuesday's primary, struggling to distinguish themselves and even tossing a few genial barbs at each other in what has otherwise been a relatively cordial contest.

title: Scoopful of Ice Cream to Help Truancy Go Down
description: First there was whole language. Then there was constructivist math. Now ice cream may be the latest weapon in the arsenal of raising student achievement.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Software Maker Buys Rival
description: The Cerner Corporation, which makes software for health care companies, said yesterday that it would buy Dynamic Healthcare Technologies for about $17.4 million in stock to add more pathology services to its software packages. Cerner, based in Kansas City, Mo., will offer 363,000 shares at $48.06 for all shares of Dynamic Healthcare, which provides clinical and diagnostic software and Internet services for pathology, laboratory and radiology services.

title: Fireworks No Treat for Washington
description: When President Bush followed his first state dinner on Wednesday night with a thunderous fireworks display, hundreds of Washington residents voiced anger and confusion over the unexpected barrage.

title: Pendulum Swings to Microsoft, But the Degree Remains Unclear
description: The Bush administration, by adopting a measured, conservative approach in the Microsoft antitrust case, clearly increased the chances that the two sides would reach a settlement.

title: In Durban Morass, Who Is to Blame?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hewitt Hangs On in Another After-Midnight Epic
description: The court deserved to be sealed after the unforgettable Agassi-Sampras match that had unfolded a night before, but there were Andy Roddick and Lleyton Hewitt last night at the United States Open, doing their version of an intense epic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, MICHAEL E.
description: CALLAHAN-Michael E. Of Tivoli, N.Y. on August 28, 2001. Send ''In Memory Of'' to: Catholic Worker, 36 East 1st St., N.Y., N.Y. 10003

title: Staten Island Wins First Game of Series
description: During the regular season, the Brooklyn Cyclones boasted the best pitching staff in the New York-Penn League, and Luz Portobanco was a particular thorn in the side of the Staten Island Yankees. On the mound he was nearly unhittable, and in the clubhouse, he sent barbs their way with quotations that found their way onto the locker room bulletin board last night.

title: Citigroup to Pay Up to $20 Million in Deceptive-Lending Case
description: Citigroup has agreed to pay up to $20 million to North Carolina customers of the Associates First Capital Corporation to settle allegations that Associates illegally tricked them into buying expensive and unneeded credit insurance as part of their mortgage loans, a practice at the center of a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit against Associates.

title: With Net Off, Swiss Insurer Plans to Shed Zurich Re
description: With its profits badly eroded by woeful performance in its asset management business, Zurich Financial Services, a large insurer based in Switzerland, said today that it would spin off its reinsurance unit this year.

title: Roddick on Davis Cup Team
description: The emerging star Andy Roddick heads the six-member Davis Cup team chosen by the captain Patrick McEnroe yesterday for the United States' matchup against India in Winston-Salem, N.C., on Sept. 21-23.

title: A Croatian Chapel Full of Sculpture
description: Now that peace has been restored in Croatia, the world is rediscovering the architectural gems in the towns on Croatia's Istrian and Dalmatian coasts on the Adriatic Sea. The British architect Robert Adam awakened interest in the area in 1764, when he collaborated on a book about the ruins of the fourth-century palace of the Roman Emperor Diocletian in Split. That classical complex has inspired Western architects ever since, from Palladio to Thomas Jefferson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDELMAN, PHYLLIS K.
description: SEIDELMAN-Phyllis K. Of Scarsdale, N.Y., passed away on September 5, 2001 from cancer at the age of 76. She is survived by her loving husband of 53 years, Robert; son Richard and daughter Carole Anne and cherished grandson William, as well as brother Marvin Kent, several cousins, nephews and nieces and additional relatives living abroad. She was a woman of exceptional beauty and artistic talent who was the recipient of many awards for her paintings. For many years she was a member of the National Association of Women Artists, Inc., the Mamaroneck Artist Guild, Working Artists and many, many charitable organizations. Services are private.

title: In Durban Morass, Who Is to Blame?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BABS
description: COHEN-Babs. All of us at the Jackson Laboratory are deeply saddened by the loss of Babs, beloved wife of Joe, a dedicated member of our Board of Governing Trustees. We wish to express our heartfelt sympathies to Joe and his family.

title: Muscling In And Letting Anger Out The Door
description: The American fascination with power extends down to its lowest levels, which in the case of Steven Cantor's documentary ''Bounce: Beyond the Velvet Rope'' would seem to consist of the burly, battle-scarred young men whose job it is to chuck unruly patrons out of nightclubs.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: First Euro-Robbery
description: Robbers looted an armored truck carrying newly minted euro notes and German marks. The robbery, which came one week after central banks began shipping the new currency to commercial banks, confirmed worries of the police about their ability to protect the thousands of armored trucks that must deliver the currency before it enters circulation on Jan. 1. The police did not say how many euros were taken. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: The Social Security Debate Plays San Diego
description: Before a sparse crowd and in a sober setting that felt more Washington than Southern California, a presidential commission dedicated to overhauling Social Security convened its first public hearing today, absorbing darts and laurels from academics, lobbyists and local residents.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Another Shrinking Surplus
description: A sharp decline in tax revenues means that Ireland's budget surplus, expected to be $2.83 billion at the end of the year, will fall by $1.13 billion. Through the end of August, government spending was running 24 percent above last year's level, while tax revenue increased by only 3.7 percent. The news put pressure on Finance Minister Charlie McCreevy, who has proposed to increase government spending in the budget for 2002, an election year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the budget debate in the Senate reversed the names of two men who appeared before a subcommittee to speak about military spending, and misspelled one speaker's name. Gen. Henry H. Shelton was at the left and Dov Zakheim (not Don Zavkheim) at the right.

title: Your Homework, Class: Read This
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Sox Involved in a Family Feud
description: The best pitcher on the team has bickered with the general manager about the severity of a shoulder injury and whether he should keep pitching. The best player, who is usually as cautious as a presidential press secretary, criticized the organization for demoting the acting pitching coach. That coach, in turn blasted the general manager, refused to accept his demotion and was fired. The $160 million hitter apparently wonders if he should have elected to play somewhere else.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Shake-Up At Airline
description: The 15 directors of Thai Airways International fired the company's president, Bhisit Kuslasayanon, left, and then resigned because they failed to resolve internal conflicts. Thai Air shares rose 9.7 percent. Thai Air, Thailand's national carrier, appointed Somchainuk Engtrakul, the finance minister's permanent secretary, as acting president until a replacement is found. ''We have to accept the reality that the company has internal conflicts, which have gone beyond control,'' Mr. Somchainuk said.

title: Old School Meets New, at Sword Point
description: The chief claim to fame of ''The Musketeer,'' the latest and probably least necessary screen adaptation ever of ''The Three Musketeers,'' is its allegedly groundbreaking fusion of swashbuckling swordplay and aerial Hong Kong-style choreography. The attempted pice de rsistance in this hybrid style comes only at the very end of the movie, in a room so crowded with ladders it suggests an overstuffed circus warehouse for trapeze equipment.

title: Rule No. 1: Don't Tolerate Straying Boyfriends
description: ''Two Can Play That Game'' is a likable, featherweight romantic comedy that hardly asks to be taken seriously, but its very triviality is, in some ways, quite significant. In 1986, Spike Lee's ''She's Gotta Have It'' seemed downright revolutionary: a grown-up sex comedy about upwardly mobile, socially secure black people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPPES, ROBERT
description: KAPPES-Robert. September 4, 2001. Retired Detective Lieutenant NYPD. Beloved husband of the late Elaine, devoted father of David and Harold, cherished grandfather of Robert, Jean and Gabrielle. Private funeral services were held.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about the visit of President Vicente Fox of Mexico referred incorrectly in some copies to Democratic control in Congress. The Democrats control the Senate, not the House.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: In a soft economy, the National Football League changes direction and tries to woo casual fans.
description: TO expand its fan base -- and not so incidentally, to help counter slipping ratings and declining advertising sales for the telecasts of its games -- the National Football League is taking a walk on the mild side.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Pollution Settlement
description: Celebrity Cruise Lines has agreed to pay the state $55,000 to settle claims that it violated state air emission standards twice in the 2000 cruise season, Attorney General Bruce Botelho said. The state Department of Environmental Conservation issued 15 citations for air pollution to virtually every major cruise line that operated in Alaskan waters last year. In July, Gov. Tony Knowles signed legislation intended to give the state greater regulatory authority over the environmental impact of large cruise ships. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Residential Real Estate; Church Rents Out a Redone Building
description: Just behind the Gothic stones of Grace Church at Broadway and East 10th Street, an eight-story church-owned commercial building is at the end of a renovation that reshaped its 5 vacant upper stories into 10 rental lofts and retained the second and third floors for use by Grace Church School.

title: Agencies Limit New Memorials On Coveted Washington Mall
description: Sprawl on the Mall may soon be over.

title: Snapple Picks Agency for Fruit-Flavored Soda
description: The Snapple Beverage Group in White Plains, a unit of Cadbury Schweppes ( news/quote ), has named Decker in Glastonbury, Conn., as the first agency to handle assignments for its Stewart's line of fruit-flavored sodas.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Bank of England kept its benchmark interest rate at 5 percent as strong consumer spending offset a downturn in manufacturing. The bank has cut rates four times this year, most recently in August. Since the last reduction, retail sales rose at the fastest pace in nearly five years and house prices increased for the eighth consecutive month.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Theft At Italian Consulate
description: The official seal of the Italian consulate on the Upper East Side has been stolen, consulate officials said. The seal was taken off the front door but surveillance cameras at the consulate, at 690 Park Avenue near East 69th Street, did not record the theft because they were being repaired. The theft was discovered around 8 a.m. when consulate employees began to arrive. The seal depicts a star and is inscribed ''General Consulate of Italy.''

title: P.& G. Said to Agree to Pay Unilever $10 Million in Spying Case
description: Procter & Gamble will pay Unilever about $10 million and agree to an unusual third-party audit to settle a dispute that arose after P.& G. acknowledged that it had taken documents from trash cans outside the Chicago offices of Unilever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ECKER, JOSEPH
description: ECKER-Joseph. On September 5, 2001. Beloved husband of Edna. Devoted father of Martha and Minna. Loving brother of Lottie Shapiro. Cherished grandfather of Ruth, Max, Hannah and Dominic. Former Secretary/Treasurer of Manhattan/Bronx Postal Union.

title: Your Homework, Class: Read This
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Semiconductors: National Semiconductor Reports Loss
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, the microchip maker, has reported a loss for its first quarter as sales of chips have fallen by almost half. The loss was in line with Wall Street expectations. For the quarter ended Aug. 26, the company reported a loss of $54.6 million, or 31 cents a diluted share, in contrast to net income of $144.2 million, or 74 cents a diluted share, for the period a year earlier. Sales fell 47 percent, to $339.3 million.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Sports of The Times; Pete-Andre Didn't End The Open
description: THIS is just a guess that an all-Russian final at the United States Open would be a disaster to the kindly gents who hawk tickets out on the boardwalk, to say nothing of the friendly folks from CBS. Safin-Kafelnikov is not exactly Pete-Andre.

title: Newark Arena Plan Derailed in Trenton
description: The proposal to build a $355 million sports arena in Newark and redevelop the Meadowlands fell apart when a key legislative committee canceled a hearing on the issue, effectively derailing the plan.

title: Brazil to Exempt Stock Trades From a Tax
description: Waving Brazilian flags and carrying signs reading ''Save Our National Market,'' workers at the So Paulo stock market, the Bovespa, interrupted trading for an hour this afternoon to protest government measures that they say have caused trading volume on the exchanges to plummet, as investors switch to trading stocks of Brazilian companies in New York, where transaction costs are lower.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen declined after Moody's said it might cut Japan's credit rating because deflation is making it hard for Japan to repay its debts. The yen dropped to 121.08 per dollar from 120.73 on Wednesday in New York.

title: Investment Service Closes Its Web Site
description: Netfolio, a New York company that sold customized baskets of stocks to investors over the Internet, has shut down that operation less than a year after it started.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The department is seeking to streamline the case with the goal of securing an effective remedy as quickly as possible.''

title: Secret Weapon Research
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Phone Maker Penalized
description: China may ban Japan's largest maker of mobile phones, the Matsushita Communication Industrial Company, from making and selling its mobile phones in China for a year because the company's Panasonic handsets referred to Taiwan as the Republic of China. Beijing considers Taiwan a province and has often punished companies or countries that refer to the island as a separate country. The ban would coincide with action against Credit Suisse First Boston for inviting Taiwan officials to Credit Suisse conferences. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Hearing Set On Labor Nominee
description: The Senate Labor Committee will hold what promises to be a contentious hearing on Sept. 20 to consider the nomination of Eugene Scalia to be the solicitor for the labor department, who is opposed by segments of organized labor. The A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nation's largest labor organization, which had been critical of Mr. Scalia, has formally opposed his nomination. John J. Sweeney, the president of the labor federation, said in a letter to the Senate that Mr. Scalia, a Washington lawyer and son of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, was ''simply the wrong person for the job.'' Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: North and South Korea to Restart High-Level Talks
description: After a six-month freeze, high-level talks between North and South Korea are to resume here next month, both sides confirmed on Thursday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit Falls At TV Concern
description: Kudelski, the Swiss digital television technology group, said first-half net profit fell 8 percent because of operating and acquisition costs, but it still expects higher profit for the year. Net income fell to $13 million, but the chief executive, Andre Kudelski, said the company had a record increase in demand for smart cards, which subscribers use to gain access to cable service. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, ESTELLE
description: SANDLER-Estelle. Died peacefully on September 6, in her 97th year. Beloved wife of the late Eli. Mother of Howard and Joseph. Grandmother of eight. Great grandmother of eight. Graveside services 9:30 A.M. Sunday, September 9, Beth-David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Upgrades Pocket Software
description: Microsoft announced yesterday that it planned to release a new version of its software to run hand-held organizers, updating a product that has taken sales from Palm Inc. The Microsoft Pocket PC 2002 operating system will go on sale Oct. 4 in hand-held computers from Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft said. Others using the software -- Compaq Computer, Toshiba and Casio Computer -- will also make devices with it, as will several new partners, a vice president at Microsoft, Ben Waldman, said. He would not identify the new partners. The Pocket PC has been gaining share since it was released in April 2000. Also yesterday, Hewlett-Packard and Intel announced that an Intel processor, the StrongARM, and a memory chip, the StrataFlash, would be used to power Hewlett-Packard's new line of Jornada hand-held computers.

title: Deadly Attacks Traded Over West Bank Line
description: Israelis and Palestinians traded lethal blows today across their disputed boundary, while Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said he was considering creating a buffer zone along the same sad line in hopes of foiling terrorists by further separating the snarled populations.

title: Dim Rawlings Report
description: The Rawlings Sporting Goods Company, the maker of Major League baseballs, said today that it had lower-than-expected fiscal 2001 earnings as sales were little changed.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: For the U.S. Team, Never an Easy Night
description: It will take more than two months to see whether the dark cloud hanging over the United States national soccer team does in fact have a silver lining.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARFF, JAGNA WOJCICKA
description: SHARFF-Jagna Wojcicka, 67. Died suddenly on September 2, 2001 in Kingston, NY. Devoted mother of Adrian and Jennifer Benepe and Matthew Sharff and daughters-in-law, Charlotte Glasser and Collin Leech, loving grandmother of Alexander and Erik Benepe, sister of Andrei Sarna-Wojcicki, sweet auntie to Mathew, Martin, Janine, Daniel, Margie, and Nina. Professor of Anthropology, activist, advocate, wonderful cook, and friend to many. Memorial service Sunday, Sept. 9, 1 PM, St Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. Burial Monday, Sept. 10, 12 noon Woodstock Town Cemetery, Woodstock, New York.

title: Virus Is Killing Thousands of Salmon
description: A virus that kills Atlantic salmon but is harmless to people is spreading in fish farms in eastern Maine, forcing the destruction of hundreds of thousands of valuable fish and threatening endangered wild salmon, state and federal officials say.

title: Stylists Of the Epic And the Surreal
description: CUBA, shaped like a scythe, lies in the Caribbean 90 miles off Florida. For centuries it has been a kind of fantasy island to the outside world. Columbus thought it was the prettiest place he had ever seen. Later adventurers went there for gold and found it: ''white gold,'' sugar. With African slaves to harvest the cane, they lived like grandees. By the 19th century and well into the 20th, the capital city, Havana, with its thick sea walls and rococo facades, was a cosmopolitan magnet for businessmen, artists and tourists alike. Its casinos were lavish; its night life was tireless. It was where you went to be extravagant, liberated and bad.

title: Yankees Looking Past Boston To Playoffs
description: The tension is drained out of this weekend's games at Yankee Stadium, with the Yankees nine and a half games ahead of Boston in the American League East. The sidelights are in place -- Mike Mussina against David Cone again tomorrow in a reprise of last weekend's near-perfect matchup, Roger Clemens likely to shoot for his 20th victory on Monday -- but the games have little real value.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Kevin Kline, Hotel Flaubert, Trouville, France, 1981

title: The Rocking-House Builder
description: Bill Hedberg likes to move. The 42-year-old Hedberg, who walks, jaunts up and down steps and sits with an easy, straight posture, has been a modern dancer since the age of 20, working for the renowned company of Elisa Monte and David Brown. Evidenced by the international knick-knacks displayed around his home, he loves to travel and tour. He has also spent the past 15 years teaching Gyrotonics, a form of exercise that, like Pilates, uses machines that strengthen and stretch the body with rotational motions. Even his soft-spoken manner and magnetic blue eyes give the impression of a simmering activity underneath.

title: Trying to Get Past Numbers on Stem Cells
description: In science, the term ''embryonic stem cell line'' has a specific meaning: a self-perpetuating colony of cells, grown over a period of months, that exhibit biological characteristics showing they can become any tissue or organ. In announcing his plan for federal financing of stem cell research, President Bush used a looser definition.

title: Hired to Be the Taster, but Not to Finish the Task
description: ''A Matter of Taste'' gives new meaning to the term ''control freak,'' a concept that seems to have been invented for the era of overpaid, overly empowered corporate royalty. This deliciously nasty French deconstruction of male pecking orders, directed by Bernard Rapp, should send a pleasant shiver down the spine of anyone who has ever obsessed about wanting to please a devious and manipulative boss.

title: A Court Blocks Drug Discounts
description: Acting at the request of chain and community drugstores, a federal district judge today temporarily blocked the Bush administration's program to encourage Medicare beneficiaries to acquire prescription-drug discount cards.

title: Intel Says Sales For the Quarter Are on Track
description: The Intel Corporation said today that its sales would remain on target for the third quarter, signaling that the industry continues to bump along the bottom of the sharpest decline in its history.

title: Miscellany
description: * Donald J. Holtz and Andrea D. Shantz opened Benchmarketing Analytics, Fairfield, Conn., which offers data analysis and communications planning for the customer relationship management programs of marketers. Mr. Holtz, who will be chief executive, had been executive vice president and chief technology officer at Yankelovich Partners, Norwalk, Conn., and Ms. Shantz, who will be president, had been vice president and business manager at Yankelovich.

title: Secret War Game Eases Concerns Over Readiness
description: A classified war game conducted by the nation's senior commanders has determined that even with the current levels of troops and weapons, the American military could topple one adversary while halting an offensive by a second aggressor, officials said today.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A World Of Animals

title: Operatic MTV Show Rules Stage At the Met
description: Hip-hop beats, power chords and waves of squeals echoed across Lincoln Center Plaza last night as the MTV Video Music Awards telecast began from the Metropolitan Opera House. Rappers and rockers held forth on an outdoor stage while singers like Britney Spears walked the runway to cheers and camera flashes. Inside the opera house, the screams were louder, or at least higher-pitched, than anything Luciano Pavarotti ever induced. And the performers and the audience were the least-dressed contingent to occupy the opera house since MTV last rented the place in 1999.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Delay For Charleston Elections
description: A state judge postponed municipal elections in Charleston for six months because the population of outlying city council districts had grown much larger than downtown districts. Judge Danny Pieper of Circuit Court said the imbalance violated the one-person, one-vote rule, and said the districts would have to be redrawn before elections could be held. The city proposed new districts this year, but the Justice Department has not approved them yet under the federal Voting Rights Act. The change would reduce the number of seats likely to be held by blacks to five from six, reflecting the growing proportion of whites in the city. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Allendale: Inquiry Widens In Hazing Case
description: Fourteen senior girls have been permanently removed from the field hockey team at Northern Highlands Regional High School for hazing sophomore players when the younger girls attended a summer hockey camp in Pennsylvania, officials said. The seniors ordered the younger girls to bark like dogs while crouching on restaurant tables, and simulate oral sex on a banana while they were being videotaped. Detective Lt. Ernest Kastner of Upper Saddle River also said the police were investigating threatening e-mail messages sent to two of the younger girls. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: Two Amigos Visit Toledo And Court Its Mexicans
description: Toiling 72-hour weeks in a tomato-packing plant near here, Noelia Reynoso doesn't have much time for politicians. But she said she was warming to President Bush and to President Vicente Fox of Mexico after both leaders today praised the contributions of Mexican migrants and pledged to improve their lives.

title: Straight to Video
description: Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a theater release, appeared on television or been on videocassette in earlier editions.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Rare Stake In Airline
description: China Airlines of Taiwan agreed late Wednesday to take a 25 percent stake in China's first all-cargo airline, although both sides need approval from their respective governments to complete the $45 million deal. If completed, the deal would represent the first time a foreign air carrier was permitted to buy a stake in a mainland airline and would stand as a minor milestone in the growing economic integration between China and Taiwan. China considers Taiwan a province, although the island has had a separate government since 1949. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Reviews of Current Releases
description: For all New York Times film reviews since 1996, go to the Film Archive .

title: Metro Business Briefing | In The Cab, But Plugged In
description: USA Technologies, a company based in Wayne, Pa., has won a $20 million contract with the United Taxi Alliance, a large New York taxi company, to install about 15,000 electronic credit card readers in New York City taxis. Besides being able to accept most credit and bank cards, the readers, called E-Ports, will allow passengers to watch news, weather and sports programs. The E-Ports are expected to begin appearing in cabs by January 2002, officials said.

title: Keeping Up With the Fashions Set by Royalty
description: Like many a woman of worldly station, Queen Alexandra of Britain (1844-1925) did not take her plumage lightly. As Princess Alexandra in 1863, the year of her marriage to the Prince of Wales, later Edward VII, this fashion plate launched the ''princess'' style dress, fitted at the waist with a row of buttons down the front.

title: Lurking Below the Surface, the Pleasures and Treasures of the Shore
description: One of the greatest thrills of my childhood was catching sharks -- really small sharks. I spent family vacations at the Connecticut shore, and sometime around age 9 or 10, I discovered the pleasures of the drag net, or hand seine.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Jenna's Law Aftermath
description: In a case that prompted a major change in parole for felons, a civil lawsuit by a murder victim's family has ended in failure. In 1997, Nicholas Eugene Pryor, a parolee, stabbed and strangled Jenna Grieshaber, a murder that led to passage of Jenna's Law, eliminating parole for violent felons. Yesterday, the Court of Appeals refused to hear an appeal of the Grieshaber family's suit, which had been dismissed. The family sued the Albany police, who waited more than 40 minutes to enter Ms. Grieshaber's apartment because of a barking dog and then did not immediately move a bed crushing her neck, though signs were later found that she might still have been alive. The city argued that she would have died, regardless of police actions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LEONORE OLINSKY
description: MILLER-Leonore Olinsky, 94. On September 4, in Kent, CT, widow of Henry, mother of John and Richard, grandmother of Ivan, Lucas, and Emily, mother-in-law of Joan McD Miller and Carol Schneider. She was the daughter of an artist, an artist herself, a lover of the arts, and most compellingly, a lover and protector of her family & friends. Her remains will be buried at Mt. Pleasant.

title: U.S. MAY EASE REIN ON NURSING HOMES
description: Bush administration officials want to ease regulatory requirements on nursing homes, reducing the frequency of inspections and lessening or eliminating some penalties, according to government documents.

title: One Woman's Serenity In the Thick of Things
description: An art form of chameleonesque elasticity, video can adapt to a bewildering variety of formats, from tiny television monitors to whole-wall, wraparound projections. It can mimic narrative approaches from real-world documentation to surrealistic montage to Hollywood-style fantasy, and it can readily absorb the colors and patterns of digital abstraction.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Foreign Ministry Scandal
description: The police arrested a foreign ministry official on charges of defrauding the government of tens of thousands of dollars in illegitimate hotel bills. The arrest marked the third major fraud scandal to hit the foreign ministry in recent months. Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka, who has struggled to clean house at the ministry, apologized for the new incident. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: The Path to Diversity? Different Differences
description: A federal appeals court ruling last week striking down the University of Georgia's use of racial preferences in its freshman admissions program once again places the issue of affirmative action at the forefront of America's legal agenda. If Georgia appeals, and if the Supreme Court chooses to hear the case, the resulting decision could well be the court's most decisive statement on race since its landmark 1978 ruling in Regents of the University of California v. Bakke.

title: World Bank Presses Inquiry On Economist Who Dissents
description: The World Bank is conducting a disciplinary investigation of one of its most senior economists, who sharply criticized the bank's record on fighting poverty in a recent book and newspaper opinion article.

title: Buffalo Gazes Back To a Time When Fortune Shone; Much-Maligned City Celebrates The Glory of a Century Ago
description: It is hard for outsiders to imagine that before the steel mills died, the young people fled and the Bills choked, Buffalo was unbowed and proud.

title: The Highway Is the Least of This Hero's Troubles
description: ''L.I.E.'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 6. The film opens today at the U.A. Union Square 14, 13th Street at Broadway, Manhattan.

title: LATHAM & WATKINGS ADDS 95 LAWYERS IN PARIS
description: Latham & Watkins, a national law firm with its largest office in Los Angeles, said yesterday that 95 lawyers from the Paris office of Stibbe, an Amsterdam-based firm, would join Latham & Watkins. The deal will nearly double the number of lawyers Latham has in Europe. The addition of an office in Paris ''will greatly enhance our capacity to handle complex, cross-border matters for our global and local clients,'' Joseph Blum, managing partner of Latham's London office, said in a statement. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: With Pressure Growing, Zimbabwe Agrees to Stop Land Seizures
description: With international pressure, particularly from other African nations, intensifying, Zimbabwe agreed tonight to stop the land occupations that have fed the country's political turmoil and fueled its economic crisis for more than a year, according to news reports. In exchange, Britain has agreed to provide money for Zimbabwe's efforts to resettle poor blacks on much of the country's fertile land, most of which is owned by the country's small white minority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORT, RABBI ROBERT S.

Loving father of Reva Imm, Andrew Port, Lisa Weiss and the late Joan Cohen. Cherished grandfather of eight. Dear brother of Yale Irwin Port. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALA, JEROME GINO
description: SALA-Jerome Gino, 78. Died on Sept 6. Born in Palermo, Sicily. He graduated from Juilliard School of Music and Teachers College Columbia University. Conducter of the Yonkers Philharmonic Orchestra, The Lehman College Community Band and other music ensembles. He was also a renowned clarinetist and the recipient of many awards, recognizing musical contributions and service. Associate Professor of music at Lehman College, and former music teacher at Woodlands High School, Professor Sala had a tremendous following of devoted students and proteges. He lived life with a passion for his family and for music. He is survived by his wife Shirley (nee Schiffman) Sala of Hartsdale, NY, 3 daughters, Janet Tahiraj and husband Jimmy of Scarsdale, NY, Karen Michaels and husband Burt of Littleton, MA, Linda Sala of White Plains, NY, 1 sister Gina Angione of Norwalk, CT and 3 granddaughters, Marissa, Sophia and Alexandra. Reposing Saturday 9:30-11:00AM, Hawthorne Funeral Home 914-769-4404. Funeral Services will be held 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Jerome Gino Sala Scholarship Fund, C/O Yonkers Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Diageo's Profit Rises
description: Diageo, the British liquor company, said its second-half profit rose 26 percent, helped by strong sales of spirits, including Smirnoff Ice. Earnings fell at Burger King, delaying plans to sell the chain, the company said. Excluding one-time charges, net income rose to 576 million ($836 million), or 16.9 pence a share, compared with 458 million ($667 million), or 14.3 pence a share, last year. Sales rose 13 percent, to 5.8 billion ($8.5 billion). Diageo has been shedding its food businesses to focus on beverages. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: WESTVACO IS SET TO CLOSE TWO PACKAGING PLANTS
description: The Westvaco Corporation, which agreed last week to merge with the Mead Corporation, said yesterday that it would close two packaging plants, eliminating 430 jobs, and take a $65 million pretax charge in the fourth quarter. The plants, in Richmond, Va., and Memphis, make packaging for consumer products and will be closed by mid-November, Westvaco said. The work will be moved to other Westvaco plants. Both Mead and Westvaco are shutting plants and cutting jobs ahead of their planned $2.6 billion merger, which they have said will reduce expenses and make production more efficient as demand and prices decline. Mead is based in Dayton, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, ESTHER ELLEN GREENLEIGH
description: PRINCE-Esther Ellen Greenleigh, 63, who was a teacher, customer service representative and member of the Weston area community, died of cancer at Rutland Regional Medical Center on Wednesday. Ms. Prince was born in Los Angeles, CA in 1938, and moved with her family to Larchmont, New York in 1948. She graduated from Vassar College in 1960 where she was the editor-in-chief of the college newspaper. For the next 30 years Ms. Prince was a teacher in various public and private school programs in the New York City area. After spending annual vacations in the Weston area for several years she made it her permanent home in 1995. During her time in Vermont, she was a customer service representative at area department stores and a devoted and active member of the Weston community. She is survived by a son, Josh, of San Francisco, CA and a brother, Stephen Greenleigh of Rockville, Maryland. Graveside services will be held at 2PM on Sunday, September 9, 2001 at the Maple Grove Cemetery in Weston.

title: Reforming Microsoft
description: Faced with a federal appellate court ruling unsympathetic to breaking up Microsoft, the Justice Department abandoned that goal yesterday. While that decision may be a pragmatic move, it must not turn into a wholesale retreat from efforts to curb Microsoft's monopolistic practices. Alternative remedies are available and should be pursued, either through a settlement with the company or a court order.

title: END OF OLDSMOBILE PRODUCTION IS SET FOR 2004 MODELS
description: The General Motors Corporation will end Oldsmobile production with 2004 models, phasing out the unprofitable century-old brand starting with the Intrigue sedan next year. Production will end for the Intrigue and the Aurora sedan with a V-6 engine in 2002, the Aurora with a V-8 in 2003 and the Alero small car, Silhouette minivan and Bravada sport-utility vehicle in 2004, G.M. said in a statement. General Motors said in December that it would phase out Oldsmobile in a few years because the division had failed to turn a profit.

title: Ghosts of Ellis Island
description: The Ellis Island Immigration Museum recalls a time when this deserted patch of earth in New York Harbor was teeming with immigrants waiting to be processed and sent ashore as Americans. The two million people who visit the museum each year spend an hour or so among the exhibits and then leave, unaware that they have seen just one of 33 buildings that make up the sprawling but largely forgotten Ellis Island complex. The hospital buildings on the south side of the island were fenced off long ago to protect tourists from falling bricks, collapsing timbers and passageways that were knee-deep in dangerous debris. Temporary repairs have gotten under way. But until permanent restoration is undertaken, these magnificent buildings and the stories they have to tell are in danger of being swept away.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: BP Exits China Project
description: BP P.L.C., China's biggest foreign investor, said it pulled out of the bidding to help build a $14 billion natural gas pipeline, reflecting concern about the plan's profitability. The 2,500-mile east-west pipeline across China is part of the government's $48 billion program to develop its 11 western provinces, where a quarter of the country's population generates just one-seventh of its wealth. Investors are concerned that the pipeline's political importance may take precedence over financial returns, analysts said. BP's exit leaves groups led by Exxon Mobil and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group as the remaining contenders for the contract, expected to be awarded after Sept. 20. The pipeline would ship gas from fields in northwestern Xinjiang province to the eastern coastal provinces and cities like Shanghai.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Bribery Sentence
description: Former Prime Minister Akezhan Kazhegeldin of Kazakhstan was sentenced in absentia to 10 years in prison on charges of abuse of authority and taking bribes. Mr. Kazhegeldin's supporters said the charges were fabrications to neutralize him as a potential challenger to President Nursultan Nazarbayev. The State Department noted earlier this year that the investigation of Mr. Kazhegeldin, ''while possibly grounded in facts, appeared motivated politically.''

title: A Buyer's Market for Work

Companies were so desperate for new hires that they abandoned dress codes, encouraged telecommuting and invited pets into the workplace. Now the tight labor market is loosening up, with painful side effects for workers and the economy.

title: Ex-Los Angeles Mayor Talks Of Cancer and 2002 Race
description: Richard J. Riordan, 71, the former mayor of Los Angeles and a likely Republican candidate for governor next year, disclosed on Thursday that he underwent secret treatment for prostate cancer last year as mayor. But he said that the treatment, 44 radiation sessions, was successful and that he was healthy enough to run for office should he choose. Mr. Riordan, along with his doctors, said the cancer was discovered at an early stage last October during a routine examination and that he received radiation treatments from February until May. They said no evidence of the disease had been found since then.

title: Campaign Briefing | New Jersey Politics: Creating Debate Over Getting Shut Out Of One
description: The State Election Law Enforcement Commission, which oversees New Jersey's campaign finance system, ruled yesterday that State Senator Bill Schluter failed to qualify for public matching funds and would not be allowed to participate in two televised debates with the major party candidates for governor, James E. McGreevey, the Democrat, and Bret D. Schundler, the Republican. The commission said Mr. Schluter had missed the deadline to raise $260,000 in contributions, which is required to qualify for public funds and participation in the debates. Mr. Schluter, a longtime Republican who quit the party to make an independent bid for governor, said that his campaign had raised only $170,000 by the Sept. 1 deadline. Mr. Schluter had appealed to the commission, arguing that the deadline was a false one. But election officials ruled yesterday that the deadline was unambiguous. Mr. Schluter said that he would fight the commission's decision in court.

This compared with $1.8 billion in the period last year. The Zurich company, however, had a 43 percent rise in operating profit from other units, including health and life insurance. Swiss Re, which assumes insurers' risks for disasters, is expected to sell some $2.6 billion in new shares to help pay for the purchase of the reinsurance unit of Lincoln National in Philadelphia.
