title: Data on Genetically Modified Corn
description: Genetically modified corn poses a ''negligible'' risk to monarch butterflies, according to a package of six papers that will soon be published in a scientific journal.

title: Many Microsofts Weren't the Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Norman D. Forster, 87, Owner Of Lron, a Luxury Linen Shop
description: Norman D. Forster, owner and president of Lron Inc., a luxury linen shop in Manhattan, died on Aug. 30 at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In the past it has been the United States that made all the specific proposals, and the Mexicans who said 'yes,' but never said when. This time, President Fox made all the proposals, and it was his good friend President Bush who had to say 'yes,' but couldn't say when.''

title: Toomer Could Get The Star Treatment
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel and Denver Coach Mike Shanahan, two old friends, have been playing a cat-and-mouse game over starting lineups for most of this week. Shanahan refuses to name his starting running back for Monday night's game, letting the Giants guess between the Broncos' Terrell Davis, Olandis Gary and Mike Anderson.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: WOMEN AND POWER

title: Hevesi Is Cleared of Bribery Allegation but Loses Fight With Campaign Finance Board
description: The mayoral campaign of City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi got good news yesterday when Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, said his office had found ''no credible evidence to support the allegation'' that Mr. Hevesi accepted a bribe in 1997.

title: On the Road, Updated
description: To the Editor:

title: The Red Sox Are in Pain, and It Starts With Martnez
description: He threw with guile, his fastball crawling to more than 90 miles an hour twice all night. He changed speeds to confuse the hitters, trying to compensate for what his shoulder would not allow him to do. He tried to jam Randy Velarde, and twice Velarde ducked under wayward fastballs, fouling the ball inadvertently as he fell backward.

title: Oops! Bank Will Write Off $1.75 Billion
description: How did National Australia Bank, the country's largest bank, bungle its foray into the American mortgage market so badly that it had to write off $1.75 billion this week?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, ESTELLE
description: SANDLER-Estelle. Died peacefully on September 6, in her 97th year. Beloved wife of the late Eli. Mother of Howard and Joseph. Grandmother of eight. Great grandmother of eight. Graveside services 9:30 A.M. Sunday, September 9, Beth-David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: CHEVRON PURCHASE OF TEXACO WINS APPROVAL
description: The Chevron Corporation's $46.3 billion purchase of Texaco Inc. to form the world's fourth-largest investor-owned oil company was unanimously approved by the Federal Trade Commission. Texaco agreed to sell the refining and marketing assets in the United States that in 1998 were placed in joint ventures with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Saudi Arabian oil company. Those assets will be placed in a trust because negotiations have stalled over the price Shell would pay for Texaco's share in the two ventures. Trustees will oversee the sale of Texaco's shares in Equilon Enterprises LLC and Motiva Enterprises LLC. Texaco owns 44 percent of Equilon, which was formed with Shell to serve the U.S. Midwest and West.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Admiral Is Found Guilty
description: The commander of a naval training center has been found guilty of misusing Navy money. Rear Admiral David Polatty 3rd, commander of the Great Lakes Naval Training Center, was stripped of his duties and will forfeit $1,000 in pay after the Navy said on Thursday that it had determined he violated regulations for accepting gifts and collected travel expenses that did not meet Navy guidelines. The Navy began an inquiry after the Defense Department received a tip accusing the admiral of misusing funds.

title: Equal Time in Tennis
description: To the Editor:

title: Before Ranger Camp, a Cruise
description: Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, still sees it as his duty to change the culture of the Rangers, who have not qualified for the Stanley Cup playoffs since the 1996-97 season. So he is kicking off the preseason with a boat cruise around Manhattan on Wednesday night, and it is not for players only.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Heart Patient Leaves Intensive Care
description: Robert Tools, the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart, has shown such improvement since the July 2 implant that he has been moved from an intensive care unit to a transitional monitoring area, Jewish Hospital officials in Louisville, Ky., said. Mr. Tools, 59, works with a physical therapist daily and ''continues to have ups and downs,'' including intestinal bleeding, said Dr. Laman A. Gray Jr. But, Dr. Gray added, ''you would never know how gravely ill he was 10 weeks ago.'' Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Senate Committee Cuts Money From Missile Defense Plan
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee, in an uncharacteristically partisan vote, cut $1.3 billion from President Bush's proposal for missile defense today and adopted language requiring any test that would violate the Antiballistic Missile Treaty to gain Congressional approval.

title: Belfast Outrage: They're Little Girls, Not Pawns
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs; In the venture into stem cell research, just where are the ethical limits? And will they prove lasting?
description: Nearly a century ago, in the preface to his play ''The Doctor's Dilemma,'' George Bernard Shaw laid down a simple rule that no medical researcher caught up in the current controversies over embryonic stem cells or therapeutic cloning would think to challenge.

title: Lost Files Jeopardize Choices By Clinton for Kennedy Center
description: It is not unusual for Washington's elite to jockey for the best seats in the house at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. But in an unusually bitter cultural contretemps, Clinton loyalists and the Bush White House are fighting over who should occupy seats on the center's socially and politically influential board of trustees.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Hong Kong Journal; A Battle of Wills Rivets a Money-Loving City
description: Patrick Cheng squinted at the rows of Chinese characters. His hand traced the swooping vertical and horizontal strokes, comparing one character to another. Finally Mr. Cheng, an expert in Chinese handwriting, rendered his verdict. The signatures ''were probably not written by Mr. Wang.''

title: Surprise, and Jittery Nerves, Over Official's Departure
description: The announcement was brief and muted: in a one-sentence letter, Robert C. Janiszewski, the powerful Hudson County executive, said he was resigning his post because of ''personal reasons.''

title: Campaign Briefing | Connecticut Politics: Toned-Down Life After Politics
description: In the two years, since he pleaded guilty to federal bribery and corruption charges, Paul J. Silvester, the former state treasurer and rising star in Gov. John G. Rowland's administration, has kept out of public view while awaiting a prison sentence. So when he was spotted in Norwich at a recent baseball game between the Norwich team, the Navigators, a Yankees AA farm club, and the Trenton Thunder, a small political buzz followed. Mr. Silvester even received a very public happy 39th birthday wish over the ballpark's loudspeakers. After the game, Mr. Silvester, a man with country-club tastes who once haplessly demanded that the Rowland administration give him a coveted three-digit state license plate to keep him from talking to investigators, drove off in his shiny if modest new car, a Ford Focus, fitted with a decidedly more common four-digit plate.

title: The Dutch Uncle Of Groceries; Some Worry That Ahold Is Expanding Too Quickly
description: Seventeen gleaming aisles with scarcely a cart among them. Only 2 of 14 checkout aisles open, and neither has more than two customers waiting in line. It is 5:30 on a weekday afternoon but the newly converted Stop & Shop in Hackensack, N.J., is nearly empty.

title: 11 Miami Officers Facing U.S. Charges In 3 Shooting Deaths
description: Nearly a dozen current and former Miami police officers have been charged with planting evidence and covering up their actions in a string of police shootings that killed three people, including a 73-year-old man who died in 1996 in a barrage of 123 bullets, the authorities said today.

title: Many Microsofts Weren't the Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Faria Makes Bid As MetroStars Win
description: Rodrigo Faria of the MetroStars enhanced his strong bid for rookie of the year honors last night, scoring two first-half goals to lead the MetroStars to a 3-1 triumph over the New England Revolution before a crowd of 13,679 at Giants Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, BELLE K.
description: BERNSTEIN-Belle K. On September 4, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Cherished mother of Tennie Leonard and Dr. Richard Bernstein and his wife Dr. Anne Bernstein. Loving grandmother of Julie Borhani, Lauren Menkes, Laura Bernstein, Jeffrey Bernstein and Lili Bernstein and greatgrandmother of Jodi, Leila, Nate and Madeleine Alivia. The beauty of her heart and loveliness of her spirit are everlasting gifts she bequeathed to us. Funeral services will be held on Sunday 10AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Interment to follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation or the Cancer Research & Treatment Fund at New York Hospital, 1440 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

title: An Island of Peace in the Midst of an Abortion Debate
description: AN air of peace surrounds Jill Stanek, sitting here in the living room of her Victorian-style suburban home, her two cats, Fifi and Belle, roaming from the windowsills to the carpeted floor on a sunny day when the last breaths of summer stir leaves outside.

title: Many Microsofts Weren't the Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC., Woodbury, N.Y., a supplier of equipment to fiber optic component makers, said it would acquire the closely held Applied Epi Inc., St. Paul, a maker of equipment for semiconductor manufacturing, for about $132 million in stock and cash to bolster its manufacturing capabilities.

title: EXPECTATIONS FOR REST OF THIS YEAR WORSEN
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines and Trans World Airlines, expects a third-quarter loss greater than analysts forecast and a ''significant'' fourth-quarter loss because of higher costs and fewer passengers. The company said the third-quarter loss would be ''considerably larger'' than its loss of 68 cents a share in the second quarter. AMR, which also said it would retire some jets earlier than planned, was forecast to lose 39 cents, based on the average analyst estimate in a Thomson Financial/ First Call poll. AMR and other United States airlines are expected to have a combined loss of $2.6 billion this year, in contrast to net income of $2.9 billion in 2000, according to James Higgins, a Credit Suisse First Boston analyst.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Airline Wins Court Battle
description: Belgium's struggling airline Sabena won a court order yesterday imposing hefty fines on pilots striking against a restructuring plan intended to save the company from bankruptcy. The unofficial two-day strike broke up at the end of the afternoon, after 130 long- and medium-haul flights were canceled yesterday alone. A spokesman, Wilfried Remans, said the cost of the strike had been ''immense,'' adding: ''We are seeing lower load factors on our aircraft than last year. The strikes are hurting our reputation.'' The restructuring will cut 1,600 jobs, roughly 10 percent of Sabena's work force. It is due to begin next month and is being financed by a recapitalization of 430 million euros ($383 million) from the airline's two shareholders, the Belgian government and the Swiss Air Group. But it can begin only when it has been approved by trade unions. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYLE, MARY M.
description: DOYLE-Mary M. On September 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Lester T. Doyle. Loving mother of Kevin Doyle. Cherished grandmother of Virgil and Eliza Doyle. Dear sister of Patricia Nielsen and Catherine Meyer. Family will be receiving friends Friday 2-4 and 79 at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Funeral Mass Saturday 10 AM at St. John Evangelist, 348 East 55 St. Interment to follow at Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers family requests donations to be made to the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Election Overturned
description: Andrs Bermdez, a Mexican immigrant who built a multimillion-dollar tomato business in the United States, then returned to his tiny hometown and won election as mayor in July, was stripped of his victory by an electoral court. Mr. Bermdez was legally a resident of the United States, not the hamlet of Jerez, in Zacatecas, the court ruled. The residency requirement was a year; Mr. Bermdez was four months shy. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: JOHNSON TOLD TO PAY $8.3 MILLION IN PATENT CASE
description: A jury decided that Johnson & Johnson must pay a rival medical device maker, the Boston Scientific Corporation, $8.3 million, a fraction of the $226 million it sought, for infringing a patent on stents that prop open clogged blood vessels. After an 11-day trial, the federal jury in Wilmington, Del., concluded that Johnson & Johnson unintentionally breached one patent and did not infringe two others. Boston Scientific, which is based in Natick, Mass., had sought a finding of intentional infringement, which would have allowed Federal District Judge Sue Robinson to triple the damage award.

title: Sports of The Times; The Father Really Did Know Best
description: RICHARD WILLIAMS held court late yesterday afternoon. With the sun setting and stadium cleanup crews fanning out, Williams was surrounded by well-wishers in an all-but-empty Arthur Ashe Stadium. This, he said, was the happiest day of his life.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Do Stairs Matter?
description: It was a picture-perfect endorsement scene: several dozen law enforcement officers in pressed white shirts standing six deep on a staircase behind a beaming candidate. In this case, the officers were members of the New York State Court Officers Association, the candidate was Michael R. Bloomberg, and the staircase was outside 60 Centre Street, the State Supreme Court in Manhattan. There was one glitch: none of the 1,400 members of the union actually works at 60 Centre Street. A separate union represents workers there, and that union has not endorsed Mr. Bloomberg, a Republican contender. ''Normally anyone who wants an endorsement wants steps,'' said Dennis Quirk, president of the New York State Court Officers Association. ''There was no significance to those steps.'' Mr. Bloomberg's campaign had proposed the steps outside the federal courthouse, he said, but those steps were ruled too congested. Incidentally, Mr. Quirk's union has no members working at that court either. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Warning On Terrorism
description: The United States Embassy warned citizens of a possible terrorist attack against American military bases or places frequented by military personnel in Japan. ''We have received unconfirmed information that terrorist actions may be taken against U.S. military facilities or against establishments frequented by American military personnel,'' the embassy said. A similar warning was issued in South Korea. The two countries are host to more than 85,000 American troops. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Reading (Gasp) for Enlightenment, Without Snobbery or Shame
description: We are all of us snobs. We are readers not just of tabloids, viewers not just of the newest blockbuster films, ticket buyers not just to WWF events. No, if I may be so presumptuous, we read the finest publications and enjoy the best of new fiction; we have studied classic literature and occasionally discuss it with friends; popular culture pales in comparison with the spiritual and aesthetic glories awaiting elsewhere. Meanwhile, those with more mundane tastes, who restrict their cultural pleasures to lesser activities, are often seen as members of a lower intellectual and social class whose tastes and knowledge are grievously limited.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: A Diverse Coalition, In Terms Of Music
description: In perhaps the first mayoral campaign event featuring guests in gold spandex, Warren Beatty and Annette Bening held a musical benefit for Mr. Beatty's pal Mark Green last week, a sold-out show with tickets costing $50 to $1,000. The list of performers at the Town Hall event supported Mr. Green's claims of his multiethnic, multiracial coalition: The first performers, Jon Bon Jovi and Richie Sambora, were followed by Mary J. Blige -- who sang a single torch song before sauntering off -- the singer Jewel and finally, the singer and actor Mandy Patinkin, another friend of the mayoral candidate's, who sang ''It's Not Easy Being Green.'' Mr. Beatty said he loved Mr. Green. Mr. Green said his children loved the performers. And the audience loved the hip-hop mogul Russell Simmons, whose remarks drew some of the biggest applause of the night.

title: Can the Mideast and NATO Mix?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLIEG, ESTHER
description: FLIEG-Esther. On September 6, 2001 in Houston, TX. Beloved wife of the late Leo Flieg. Cherished mother of Augusta Levine and her husband, Sidney. Loving grandmother of Leslie. Esther Flieg was a longtime resident of New York City and a devoted member of the Brotherhood Synagogue. She worked for many years for the Jewish Labor Committee. Esther will be greatly missed by her family and friends. Service on Sunday, September 9, 10:00 AM at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave., NYC. Interment to follow at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. Contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Debate On Chechnya
description: President Vladimir V. Putin clashed with parliamentary critics over how to end the war in Chechnya, asserting that peace talks would begin only after all rebels laid down their weapons and ''especially notorious'' rebel leaders surrendered. He said parliamentary leaders, like Boris Nemtsov, who advocate negotiations without preconditions, should ''stop hustling and bustling on the country's political stage and give up'' their parliamentary seats. Mr. Nemtsov responded, saying, ''Putin evidently mistook me for his subordinate. He did not elect me, so he cannot dismiss me.'' Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Hoping Swoons Mean Votes
description: When he was 14, Tony Bennett got his first paid singing gig, courtesy of a political man-about-town in his local Astoria. The gig was at the Taminent Democratic Club. The man was Charles Vallone. The year was 1940. Last Thursday, Mr. Bennett was at the side of Charles's son, Peter Fortunate Vallone, on a tour of centers for the elderly in Ridgewood and Jackson Heights, Queens. Campaign aides described Mr. Bennett as Mr. Vallone's ''longtime friend.'' In the Vallone campaign's bid for the heart of the white ethnic voters in Queens, could there possibly be a greater Casanova? Mr. Bennett sang, too -- a number called ''Just a Little Street Where Old Friends Meet.'' Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Stocks Slump on Fears Economy Won't Recover Quickly
description: A weak employment report further depressed stock prices in both the United States and Europe yesterday as hopes faded for a quick economic recovery.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: A Run Not Taken
description: The field of Democratic candidates hoping to challenge Gov. Jeb Bush narrowed, as Representative Jim Davis of Tampa, 43, left, said he would not run for governor next year but seek re-election instead. Former Attorney General Janet Reno announced her entry into the Democratic race this week, which includes at least four other candidates.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday and one in the New Jersey section on Sunday about fears over sharks referred incorrectly to the inspiration for the 1974 novel ''Jaws.'' Its author, Peter Benchley, says the book was not inspired by attacks off New Jersey in 1916.

title: Corrections
description: Pictures in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about vanishing native species in Hawaii carried an incomplete credit. They were from David Liittschwager and Susan Middleton with Environmental Defense.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Benefits Bill Goes To Governor
description: The Legislature sent to Gov. Gray Davis a union-supported bill to increase benefits for employees hurt on the job. The bill, passed by the Senate on Thursday, would raise the maximum weekly temporary disability benefit to $230 from $140 over the next five years. Twenty-two states pay more than California. Mr. Davis, a Democrat, has twice vetoed similar measures, saying that increased workers' compensation benefits would hurt the state's economy. Robert B. Gunnison (NYT)

title: Fox Urges Scrapping of 54-Year Treaty Between U.S. and Mexico
description: President Vicente Fox of Mexico called today for the dismantling of a 54-year-old defense treaty between the United States and Latin American nations that was aimed at protecting the hemisphere against Communism and replacing it with pacts that would combat widespread social ills and organized crime.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Airlines Bid Lowered
description: Air New Zealand's hopes for financial rescue have suffered a new setback. Singapore Airlines will reduce the price it is offering to raise its stake in the troubled carrier, according to Air New Zealand's board. In June, Singapore Airlines said it wanted to raise its 25 percent stake in New Zealand's largest airline and offered 1.31 New Zealand dollars (57 United States cents) for each share. The New Zealand government, which would have to approve the increase because foreign ownership is capped at 25 percent, has not made a decision. In recent months, however, Air New Zealand's financial troubles have worsened. Its share price has tumbled and its market share has slipped. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: In Western Queens, Problems Beyond Schools Cited
description: In an area of western Queens where quiet streets give way to an ethnically tinged commercial bustle, the race to succeed Councilman John D. Sabini, which had originally attracted several immigrant and minority candidates, has been winnowed to three leading candidates with longstanding ties to the community.

title: Colombia Extradites 1980's Trafficker to U.S. to Face Drug Charges
description: Fabio Ochoa, who in the 1980's helped run a cocaine empire that terrorized Colombia with a wave of bombings and assassinations, was extradited to the United States tonight to face federal drug trafficking charges.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Commitment On Farms
description: Determined to dispel lingering doubts, Foreign Minister Stan Mudenge reiterated his country's commitment to end the country's widespread land occupations, a day after an agreement was signed in Nigeria following talks among Zimbabwe, Britain and several other countries. If implemented, the agreement would pave the way for a renewed international effort to redistribute much of the country's farmland, most of which is in the hands of the small white minority. As part of the agreement, Britain, the former colonial power, agreed to make a ''significant financial contribution'' toward land reforms.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Ex-Official Arrested
description: Law enforcement officials arrested Victor Joy Way, who served as chief of the former President Alberto K. Fujimori's cabinet, on corruption charges. Mr. Joy Way appeared on several videotapes captured from the former intelligence chief Vladimiro Montesinos showing him serving as a go-between for Mr. Montesinos and senior business leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, SYLVIA
description: REINER-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Michael and Andrea. Adored grandmother of Randi. Interment private. Loved and treasured, missed by all, we love you.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Moulinex Seeks Bankruptcy
description: The big European household goods maker Moulinex of France announced it was filing for bankruptcy after failing to reach agreement with its principal shareholder over financing a reorganization to counter big losses. Moulinex, best known in the United States for its food processors and Krups coffee makers, said in April that it would shut factories and lay off workers -- last month it foresaw closing 3 of 31 plants worldwide and laying off 2,900 of its 20,000 employees -- because of mounting losses from flagging sales and strong competition from inexpensive Asian manufacturers. Patrick Puy, the chief executive, said Moulinex was forced to seek the French equivalent of Chapter 11 after El.Fi S.p.A., the Italian group that holds 74 percent of Moulinex shares, refused pay for the reorganization. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Lost Chance at Durban
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, RONALD E.
description: SIMON-Ronald E. The Members, Board of Governors and Officers of the Preakness Hills Country Club mourn the loss of a good friend and fellow member of longstanding and extend their deepest sympathies to his wife Lillian and the family. Morton Klein, President

title: Can the Mideast and NATO Mix?
description: To the Editor:

title: Poly Prep, a Local Power, Draws National Attention
description: Poly Prep of Brooklyn has long been one of the top high school football teams in New York City, but this year the Blue Devils are being touted as one of the country's top teams and are ranked 23rd in the USA Today poll.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Miner's Earnings Fall
description: Anglo American, the giant mining company, announced that net earnings for the first half, before exceptional items, were down 7 percent, to $884 million, from $951 million during the period a year earlier. The company said a steep decline in diamond sales and a fall in base and ferrous metal prices had eaten into the company's earnings. With the prices of platinum and palladium plunging in recent weeks and little prospect of a big bump in diamond sales, the second half of the year does not appear likely to deliver better news. Anglo American holds a 45 percent stake in De Beers, the world's biggest diamond miner. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Her Boyfriend's Back, But He Looks a Little Pale
description: Like the last rose of a sorry cinematic summer or the first pallid pumpkin to presage Halloween, a bleeding heart of a horror movie titled "Soul Survivors" plopped into theaters yesterday.

title: Heywood Hale Broun, a Sports Commentator Who Put Some Spin on the Ball, Dies at 83
description: Heywood Hale Broun, the television commentator and writer who cast an irreverent eye on the world of sports with a flair reflecting yet another career as an actor, died Wednesday at Kingston Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KELL, YETTA
description: KELL-Yetta. ''The great lady.'' Gone 15 years today. Her love and wisdom so greatly missed by her children and all who knew her.

title: INSIDE
description: Nursing Home Plan Rejected

title: Martin Is Still a Big Part of the Jets' Plans
description: He is perhaps the most talented running back in Jets history, yet it has taken Curtis Martin a good part of the past year to realize that on Sunday, in the season opener against the Indianapolis Colts, he will remain a very important person.

title: New Jersey to Require Boosters For Car Passengers Under Age 8
description: Just a few months ago, New Jersey showed up at the bottom of a national report card that ranked all 50 states for their child passenger safety laws. But legislation signed on Thursday by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco puts the state at the forefront in protecting children in vehicles, child safety experts said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOURIEZ, PHILIPPE
description: BOURIEZ-Philippe. Beloved husband of Edith Scott Bouriez. Father of Anne Bouriez Brunet & Laure Bouriez Cuvillier. Father-inlaw of Edouard Brunet and Emmanuel Cuvillier. Grandfather of seven and stepfather of three. On September 4 in St. Jean de Luz, France.

title: Second Thoughts on First Impressions
description: What if the theater gods turned cruel and enforced a terrible quota: you've had just about enough theatergoing for one lifetime. You've got 15 minutes left.

title: Four Candidates File Suit Over How To Count Votes
description: Supported by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the four main Democratic candidates for mayor sued the Board of Elections yesterday in what they said was an effort to avoid vote-counting delays in Tuesday's primary.

title: In Courting Black Voters, Candidates Try Ubiquity
description: With just days to go before the Democratic primary, the mayoral candidates Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer are intensively battling for the support of one of the most far-flung and diverse voting groups: black New Yorkers.

title: Bloomberg Philanthropy Cuts Two Ways as Campaign Issue
description: Last year, when Michael R. Bloomberg was consulting political advisers and gearing up for a bid for mayor, his charitable giving doubled from the year before. Compared with three years earlier, the increase was nearly fourfold, growing to $100.5 million from $26.6 million.

title: Blame Flies After Collapse of Arena Bill
description: The state broke out into a round robin of recriminations today after the collapse of a proposal to build an arena in Newark.

title: The Only Game in Town: Lincoln Awaits the Irish's Return
description: Two years ago, when he was a high school junior in this old college town, Barrett Ruud of Nebraska made an impromptu visit to Notre Dame. A star football player, he was intrigued by the tradition of the Fighting Irish and considered enrolling. The Notre Dame coaches were interested in him, too.

title: Mayor Pushes Chancellor for Better Reporting
description: In his latest swipe at Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was trying to push a bill through the City Council that would require the chancellor to submit reams of statistics to the mayor every month and meet with the school system's 1,100 principals at least four times a year.

title: Underruff, A Rare Play, Brings Home A Part Score
description: There are some varieties of Stayman in which the opener can show a five-card major. If he does not have one, his rebid after the two-club response is always two diamonds. The original version, devised by Kit Woolsey, is Puppet Stayman, useful to those who often open one no-trump in preference to bidding a five-card heart or spade suit.

title: Is No Adoption Really Better Than a Gay Adoption?
description: ''I pray my correspondence does not offend you, but it is my understanding that you are a practicing homosexual,'' the message in my e-mail said. ''It is also my understanding that you and your partner have adopted a child into your home.'' The author, a fundamentalist Christian who lives in West Virginia, was deeply concerned for the physical and spiritual well-being of my 3-year-old son. He walked me through some familiar Bible quotations and ended his letter with this startling offer: ''My wife and I would be very willing to adopt the child you have adopted.''

title: GENOMIC SOLUTIONS TO CUT 25% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Genomic Solutions Inc. will cut 25 percent of its work force and close a plant in Lansing, Mich., as the maker of instruments and software used to develop gene-based drugs tries to become profitable next year. The company, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., said in a statement that the moves, along with a separately announced agreement to buy the closely held Cartesian Technologies Inc., would result in 2002 profit of $1 million to $2.8 million. Genomic Solutions, which markets its products to drug makers and universities, said it would move research and manufacturing from Lansing to Ann Arbor, and trim positions in the United States and Britain by the end of this year.

title: The Bush Merry-Go-Round
description: Washington is aflutter with speculation about the rising and falling fortunes of President Bush's quartet of top national security aides. According to the latest buzz, Vice President Dick Cheney is losing influence, Secretary of State Colin Powell is a disappointment, Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld has cratered at the Pentagon and Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, is ascendant.

title: British Court Rules Detentions In Asylum Cases Violate Rights
description: In an unexpected blow to Britain's tough immigration policy, the High Court declared today that four Kurdish asylum seekers sent to a government detention center had been held in violation of their human rights.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: A New VW Chairman
description: Volkswagen confirmed yesterday that Bernd Pischetsrieder, left, will succeed Ferdinand Pich, who is retiring, as new management board chairman by April 17, 2002. His unanimous election by Volkswagen's supervisory board had been widely expected, because he was Mr. Pich's favored candidate. Mr. Pischetsrieder, the former chairman of BMW who was ousted in 1999 because of BMW's Rover debacle, entered Volkswagen's management board the same year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: U.S. in Supporting Role for NATO Force in Macedonia
description: This is the new world of NATO peacekeeping. Dutch troops stand guard on the commanding hills. The Italians protect the road. British soldiers form a defense cordon in the valley, as they wait for Albanian fighters to march in and turn in their weapons.

title: Can the Mideast and NATO Mix?
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Judge Denounces Aid Workers Now on Trial
description: Although the trial of eight foreign aid workers accused of preaching Christianity has recently begun, the chief justice of the Supreme Court, the mullah who is presiding over the case, broadly suggested in a sermon today that his mind was made up and that the verdict was guilty.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Depot Reports Leaks Of Sarin Gas
description: Ten rockets were found to be leaking small amounts of deadly sarin gas at the Anniston Army Depot, officials said. More than 800 such leaks have been discovered in the last 20 years, but it is unusual to find 10 in one week, and Army officials said the leaks bolstered their contention that a newly completed incinerator should begin destroying the gas next spring.

title: SHARON DOUBTFUL TALKS CAN BRING TRUCE IN MIDEAST
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel said today that even though he had authorized high-level talks with Yasir Arafat to try bringing about a cease-fire in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, he doubted they would amount to anything.

title: Columnist Biography: Bill Keller
description: Bill Keller became Op-Ed columnist and senior writer for The New York Times Magazine as well as other areas of the newspaper in September 2001. Previously, he served as managing editor from 1997 to September 2001 after having been the newspapers foreign editor from June 1995 to 1997. He was the chief of The Times bureau in Johannesburg from April 1992 until May 1995.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Calendar column of the House & Home section on Thursday about a lecture series on bamboo beginning on Tuesday at the Japan Society misstated the society's telephone number. It is (212) 752-3015.

title: Sampras Eyes Yet Another Ex-Champion In His March
description: A year ago, Pete Sampras ducked off the court at Arthur Ashe Stadium in resignation, greeting his soon-to-be-wife, Bridgette Wilson, and clasping the silver plate in consolation. Marat Safin followed him with the winner's trophy, his eyes barely blinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSON, JAMES LOPEZ
description: WATSON-James Lopez. His friends and colleagues at HEAF (The Harlem Educational Activities Fund) note with profound sorrow the loss of Judge James L. Watson. A founding director of HEAF and a continuing source of encouragement and support, Skizz brought wisdom, compassion and unfailing good humor to our deliberations. He will be sorely missed and long remembered. The Harlem Educational Activities Fund Daniel Rose, President Courtney Welsh, Exec. Director

title: Haste, Errors and a Fallen Star
description: The plane crash on Aug. 25 in the Bahamas that killed Aaliyah, the 22-year-old singer and actress, followed a decision by the officials managing her travel not to use two professional charter services with planes nearby and instead to rely on a small charter company.

title: Holiday in Naples
description: Visitors to Italy often overlook Naples, but a TourCrafters off-season package may make them take a second look. For $599 a person, based on double occupancy, it includes air fare from New York, Newark, Boston, Miami or Chicago; five nights in the Hotel Garden; daily breakfast, and hotel service charges and taxes. The price is good Nov. 1 to Dec. 15 and Jan. 3 to March 23, 2002, and is subject to availability. Airport taxes are extra. Information: (800) 482-5995 or www.tourcrafters.com .

title: Police Supervisor Who Used Slur for Blacks Is Sent to Harlem
description: A supervisor in one of the Police Department's elite units who used racial epithets while on duty has been transferred to Harlem, assuming command of night patrols in the city's most prominent black neighborhood.

title: Skepticism Follows Court Ruling In Favor of Inmate Procreation
description: A federal appeals court declared this week that male prisoners have a constitutional right to procreate. Yesterday, that ruling drew criticism around the country, with some lawyers predicting it would be overturned by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: N.F.L. Bans A Popular Stimulant
description: The National Football League has added the stimulant ephedra, used by dozens and perhaps hundreds of its players, to its list of banned substances, making the N.F.L. the first major professional sports league to ban the drug.

title: The Vanishing Surplus, Barely Noticed
description: Judging from recent political discourse, ''Who lost the budget surplus?'' threatens to become the ''Who lost China?'' question of our times -- the focus of finger-pointing for years to come. But there is a problem with that parallel: The American public knew about the loss of China -- not so with the surplus.

title: Bush Swiftly Denounces Nursing Home Plan
description: President Bush's spokesman denounced a plan to ease regulatory requirements on nursing homes today and said the White House had rejected the proposal, devised at the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Can the Mideast and NATO Mix?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Court Removes Spending Limits
description: A federal appeals court has ruled that Albuquerque cannot impose spending limits in its current mayoral race. The ruling effectively upholds a 1976 Supreme Court ruling that found election spending caps unconstitutional. Under the Albuquerque city charter, no candidate can spend more than double the salary of the mayor, which set this year's cap at $175,000. The court granted a preliminary injunction against caps in a case brought by Rick Homans, a Republican candidate who said he intended to spend $500,000 before the Oct. 2 election.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Sidelined Take Front And Center
description: Alternative candidates often grouse that they are not invited to mayoral forums. But on Thursday, they were the stars of the show at a Midtown breakfast for candidates held by the Manhattan and Bronx chapter of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants. Christopher X. Brodeur, a candidate in the Green Party, Kenny Kramer, a Libertarian candidate, Bernard Goetz and George N. Spitz were all given their chance to explain their views alongside Herman Badillo, who is on the Republican primary ticket. The rest of the candidates sent representatives in their stead, including Alan G. Hevesi, whose son, Dan, went to the event. ''This election is about ensuring the successes over the last several years are maintained,'' said the younger Mr. Hevesi. The group, in its Web site report on the event, found Mr. Green's representative to be presenting initiatives that seemed ''fundamentally Giuliani-like.'' No word on the cost of Mr. Brodeur's proposals to install fans in the subway. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: New Delhi To Intervene In a Dispute With Enron
description: India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, said today that the national government would intervene in a bitter dispute between the Enron Corporation and the state-run utility in Maharashtra state over power from the Dabhol Power Company, which Enron controls.

title: These Rock Stars Burn a Little Too Bright
description: To the Editor:

title: Union for Prison Guards Wants Hepatitis C Tests
description: The union representing New York State correction officers is calling for mandatory testing of all 32,000 prison employees for hepatitis C, citing fears that they could contract the disease from inmates' bodily fluids.

title: Torture Charge Pits Professor Vs. Professor
description: Felipe Agero says the nightmarish evening in late September 1973 is forever fixed in his mind. Then 21 and a student at Catholic University, Mr. Agero had been arrested for having leftist pamphlets in his car five days after the military coup led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet. At the National Stadium in Santiago, a hood was put over his head, and he was stripped, burned and beaten, he said. When his captors allowed him to dress, the hood came loose for a moment, and he caught a glimpse of one of his torturers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAINER, SHIRLEY
description: WAINER-Shirley, 86. Of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, passed away suddenly on September 6, 2001. Survived by her son, Paul Feinstein, & his wife Martha; daughter, Lorna Sarrel & her husband Philip; grandchildren Emily & Samantha Feinstein, Laura Robertson, Marc Sarrel and Jennifer Voelker; and great-grandchild, Evan Voelker. She survived three husbands, Bertram Feinstein, Louis Rudolph, and Harry Wainer. She was a truly exceptional and beloved woman who made important contributions to her community, particularly in her later years in Florida. She was an indefatigable fundraiser for charities, especially Jewish Federation. She served as campaign chair for the Woodlands Women's Division, was President and a director of the Women's Division of Greater Fort Lauderdale from 1994 to 1996 and was honored by them for her outstanding work. She was on the Board of Directors of Jewish Federation, Greater Fort Lauderdale and then the newly formed Broward County Board. She helped to establish Friends For Life in the Woodlands community. Funeral service on Sunday, September 9th, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. 212-362-6600. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gauging the Vote of the Satisfied
description: Few things rankle Josephine Harkay more than seeing garbage thrown on the streets of her beloved Jamaica Estates. A leafy enclave of Tudor and colonial-style homes in eastern Queens, this is a neighborhood where residents worry most about the little things, those quality-of-life issues that have been such hallmarks in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Report On Welfare Teenagers' Jobs
description: Teenagers in families receiving welfare are much less likely to work than other youths their age, while those in families that recently left welfare tend to work longer hours than other teenagers, according to Child Trends, a nonpartisan research group. In the survey of youths aged 14 to 17, only 6 percent from families receiving public assistance had jobs during the school year, and few worked long hours. But in families that recently left welfare, 25 percent of the teenagers were employed, most working more than 20 hours a week. Tamar Lewin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOUK, SALLY HOMER
description: HOUK-Sally Homer. Of New York City, died November 16, 2000. Born September 8, 1910. A teacher at the Midtown Ethical Culture School until 1976, she ran a summer camp in the U.S. and abroad. Mother of the late Rudy, survived by sons Bruce of NYC and John of Vermont, six grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Her ashes are on the Atlantic today.

description: THE AMERICAS

title: Mexico's President Rewrites the Rules
description: Rarely has a foreign leader shown up on the South Lawn of the White House and declared that he and the president of the United States ''must'' remake the fundamental rules that have governed his country's uneasy relationship with the United States -- and get it done in the next four months.

title: Questions Raised Over a Gag Gift to Bloomberg From 1990
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican businessman running for mayor, was confronted yesterday with allegations of sexism, racism and homophobia based on revelations about a birthday present he received 11 years ago.

title: States Press U.S. to Take Tough Stand On Microsoft
description: Some of the leading state attorneys general in the Microsoft antitrust case said yesterday that they would press for tough sanctions against the software maker, including ones that apply to the company's new operating system, Windows XP.

title: A Cycle of Hatred Is Visited on a New Generation in Northern Ireland
description: When 9-year-old Amanda Bowes walks to her girls-only Catholic school in north Belfast, she first takes her mother's hand, slips past a British Army roadblock, then marches past a phalanx of armored cars.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Ex-President Accused
description: President Fernando de la Ra, struggling to contain an economic and political crisis, accused the former president Ral Alfonsn of conspiring with opposition politicians to form a new government after congressional elections next month. Given that Mr. Alfonsn is the chairman of the president's party, the accusation was a startling admission of Mr. de la Ra's political weakness just as he tries to reassure foreign investors that Argentina's leadership will support difficult budget cuts to avoid a default on its $130 million in debt. He promised such cuts as a condition for $8 billion in aid from the International Monetary Fund. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Japan's Figures Officially Show A Contraction
description: Japan, the world's second-largest economy, is falling into another recession. Statistics released today by the government showed that output of goods and services in the second quarter contracted at a 3.2 percent annual rate.

title: No-Strike Offer From N.F.L. Refs Is Rejected
description: The National Football League Referees Association, in a last-minute effort to prevent replacement officials from taking the field tomorrow, offered a no-strike promise on Thursday in exchange for a deal from owners that would send the dispute to binding arbitration following the Super Bowl.

title: Corrections
description: An automobile review of the Lincoln Blackwood on Sunday misstated the type of wood trim in the interior and the type of material that lines the cargo trunk. The interior is dark-stained oak, not African wenge; the trunk is stainless steel, not aluminum. The review also referred incorrectly to the operation of Lincoln's navigation system. Although it provides audible directions, it is not voice-activated.

title: Alice Yiu, David Hunt
description: Alice Park Yiu and David Alexander Hunt were married last evening by Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, an ecumenical minister, at a nondenominational ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in New York.

title: Main Men in the Middle
description: After years of being in the shadow of the outside linebacker, the middle linebacker, led by the Baltimore Ravens Ray Lewis, is making a comeback. Mike Freeman rates the top 10.

title: Diana Clark, Peter Stroble
description: Diana Forrester Clark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher T. Clark of Rye, N.Y., was married last evening to Peter Alden Stroble, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Stroble of Seattle. The Rev. Dr. Arnold T. Hollis, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of St. Michael in Sandys Parish, Bermuda.

title: Corrections
description: An art gallery listing on Page 91 of Arts & Leisure today misstates the location of an exhibition of Richard Pousette-Dart's works on paper. It is at the Schirn Kunsthalle in Frankfurt, Germany, not the Knoedler Gallery in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTNEY, JOHN L.
description: WESTNEY-John L. A longtime resident of Riverdale, the Bronx, died peacefully on September 4, 2001, at the age of 88. Jack was greatly beloved and respected by so many family and friends. His life will be celebrated in a service at Riverdale Presbyterian Church, at 11:00 AM on Saturday, October 6, 2001.

title: Women Among Women
description: In 1973, I was 10 years old and spending the summer at a Girl Scout camp called Sycamore in Ashland City, Tenn. It was there that I was given my first copy of Ms. magazine by a counselor named Tree, who tried to explain to me the basic tenets of feminism. I sat on my bunk and carefully studied the pages. What the magazine seemed to be saying was that some people thought that women weren't equal to men, and so it was important as a women to stand up with other women and raise our voices against the injustice. It made no sense whatsoever. Weren't the woods full of girls? The lake? Didn't we band together and rule at both the best and worst tables in the dining barn? We were never to set out alone. Alone, we were told, it was too easy to stray off the path. We operated on the buddy system, the team. We were 6 girls in a canoe, 20 girls on a midnight raid to a neighboring cluster of tents, 200 girls belting out Carole King songs around a bonfire, our voices so extraordinarily loud that we shook the upper branches of the sycamore trees.

title: To Juice the Offense, Teams Turn to the Slot
description: Winning with defense is on the mind of every National Football League team this season, but in their hearts, offense still rules. Offense, and particularly the passing attack, remains the sexy part of the game, the fans' favorite, the league rule makers' desire, the players' fancy.

title: Mowing Lawns Wasn't Enough
description: WITH Mark Jansen, a friend who still lives in Ohio, I formed a high-end custom landscaping business in Chagrin Falls, an affluent suburb of Cleveland, in 1970. We were only in high school.

title: Eureka! Labs With Profits
description: DEEP within I.B.M.'s Almaden Research Center, a stunning hillside campus tucked away in a nature preserve south of Silicon Valley, Donald M. Eigler presides over a three-room nook that bristles with tools to pick up, move and corral individual atoms.

title: Where Pets Rest and Human Beings Remember Them
description: Twenty years ago, the International Association of Pet Cemeteries designated the second Sunday of September as National Pet Memorial Day. This year at Abbey Glen Pet Memorial Park, a 13-acre pet cemetery in Lafayette, pet owners whose pets have been buried or cremated there will gather for graveside visits and a program in which they share memories of beloved pets. David Cooke, president of the cemetery, talked about Abbey Glen.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: East

title: The Fashionista as Sex Pistolera
description: ''I've always had a little rocker chick in me,'' said Winnie Beattie as she sifted through racks of studded, ripped and vinyl outfits at Trash and Vaudeville, the St. Marks Place landmark for punk-rock fans and performers. Ms. Beattie, the president of her own publicity company representing the beauty industry, cultivates a look that is fashionista meets the Mudd Club. ''I lived in London during my senior year of college and was really into the whole Piccadilly punk thing,'' she said, holding up a pair of Harley-Davidson boots.

description: To the Editor:

title: PATERSON SECURITY
description: William Bratton, the former New York City police commissioner, has been hired by the Paterson schools to conduct a 45-day study on how to prevent violence in the city's three high schools. The district, which has been taken over by the state, had 228 violent incidents among its 25,000 students last year, including one outside the school that ended in the death of a homeless man, for which 13 students from John F. Kennedy High School have been charged. The study, by Bratton Group will cost $62,000, said Pat Chalmers, district spokeswoman. Karen DeMasters

title: In the Region/Long Island; Helping New Buyers Cope With High Housing Costs
description: COOPERATION involving government, banks and nonprofit groups is helping Long Islanders who thought they might not be able buy homes to become homeowners, in some cases with aid payments that more than match the buyers' savings.

title: Pointing the Way
description: Despite discomfort with alcohol issues, the Legislature and Governor Pataki have acted to help travelers find their way to the wineries in New York's four grape-growing regions: Long Island, the Hudson Valley, Finger Lakes and Chautauqua.

title: CHILD CAR SEATS
description: Acting Governor DiFrancesco last week signed legislation requiring children who are 7 years old or younger and who weigh less than 80 pounds to be secured in child passenger restrain systems or booster seats. ''This legislation will make New Jersey's child passenger restraint laws the strongest in the nation,'' Mr. DiFrancesco said. Assemblyman Guy F.Talarico, one of three who opposed the bill in the Assembly, called the law the beginnings of an ''elaborate police state.'' Previous legislation only required that children under 18 months be required to ride in a car seat. Anne Ruderman

title: At 31, Already a Master Director
description: WES ANDERSON has only two previous features, "Bottle Rocket" (1996) and "Rushmore" (1999), but it's already clear that this 31-year-old writer-director possesses one of the freshest voices in American movies. Mr. Anderson is a master of blending tones, able to layer comedy and tragedy, high stylization and sharp realism, bursting joy and haunting melancholy, not only within films but also within scenes and even single shots. His is a talent that Jean Renoir might have admired.

title: After Several Volleys, They're Feeling No Pain
description: The sporting field, it is said, is the one place in life where you cannot lie. Either you punch or you're pummeled.

title: Sept. 2-8; Candidate Reno
description: From her weather-worn back porch, without fuss or fanfare, the former Attorney General Janet Reno announced that she would run for governor of Florida. ''I am seeking the office,'' she said, promising ''strong, independent leadership.'' Should she win the Democratic primary, Ms. Reno, 63, will face Jeb Bush, the president's brother. His supporters reacted with relish. ''Two words,'' said one Republican operative. ''Elin and Waco.''

title: Corrections
description: A response to a letter to the editor on Aug. 12, about driving in the Republic of Ireland, gave an incorrect maximum age from the Irish Tourist Board in New York for renting a car in Ireland. The age varies with the rental company; it is not uniformly 75. (A sampling showed the ages could range from 65 to 79.)

title: Like Father, Bush Is Caught in a Politically Perilous Budget Squeeze
description: Eleven years ago during a fierce budget battle with Congress, President George Bush reneged on one of his main campaign promises -- his read-my-lips pledge not to raise taxes. This proved disastrous politically and contributed to his failure to win re-election.

title: A Speculator's Life Is Still Elusive
description: THERE may be no more enigmatic figure in Wall Street history than Jesse Lauriston Livermore, an elegant but austere New Englander who became one of the nation's earliest celebrity investors.

title: Salisbury Journal; A Tourist Attraction, Then Feed for the Cows
description: It started out as a secret because Allen Cockerline, a veteran dairy farmer, was too embarrassed to talk about his latest cash crop -- a giant maze carved into his cornfield.

title: Civil War Unfolds Item by Item
description: WHEN museums spin a collection around a specific theme, a transformation takes place and the objects become a chorus of stories.

title: Q AND A
description: Family Tour in Japan

title: Candidate for Moakley Seat Is Cut From Same Southie Cloth
description: John Joseph Moakley Jr., the late United States Representative from Massachusetts, was known as a regular guy from South Boston, a Democrat who did right by many. Now that it is time to choose his successor, voters are saying they would not mind a refill of the same.

title: Ordez Gains Strength as Offensive Force
description: MIAMI, Sept. 8 — Dave Engle was beaming. Standing in the corner of the visitors' clubhouse at Pro Player Stadium late Friday night, Engle, the Mets' hitting coach, poured himself a beer and smiled as Rey Ordóñez walked nearby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIER, EDITH
description: BAIER-Edith. Suddenly and unexpected. A dear friend and dedicated Hadassah member. Lenny and Sonia Lipton

title: Verplank, Leading by a Stroke, Is Making Strange Look Smart
description: Scott Verplank has already achieved one goal this year, but he has positioned himself to attain another.

title: Thieves Find Ill-Gotten Green In a Popular Blue Garden Flower
description: Regina Mooney used to survey the pillowy blooms of purplish blue on the four-foot-tall hydrangea bushes next to her brick Tudor house in Little Neck and appreciate their beauty. Now, thanks to a rash of recent flower thefts, she sees money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADDOCK, ROBERT ROWE
description: PADDOCK-Robert Rowe, 87. Theatrical and Television Designer, 87, longtime resident of Greenwich, died Monday, September 3, at Greenwich Woods Health Care Center, Greenwich, Connecticut. Born August 12, 1914 in Mansfield, Ohio he was the son of the late Reverend Joseph Paddock and Myrtle Rowe Paddock. He was a graduate of Western Reserve University and the Cleveland Institute of Art. He was a member of the Scenic Artists' Union in which he served in many capacities including President, Business Manager and Treasurer. He is survived by a daughter, Victoria Chane of Oak Bluffs, Ill; a son, Robert Rowe Paddock II of New Canaan and five grandchildren, two brothers, James and Joseph of Ohio. His wife, Mary Virginia Leithizer Paddock and a brother, Richard, predeceased him. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Sept. 2-8; Some Fun
description: Along with shark-bite fascination, interest in death by roller coaster has increased this summer -- at least among scientists. Several people across the nation died or suffered brain damage after riding coasters that reach speeds up to 100 m.p.h. and inflict G-forces worthy of astronauts. In the most recent case, a 20-year-old woman died from a ruptured brain aneurysm after a ride on Montezooma's Revenge at Knott's Berry Farm in California.

title: Schiano's Reception Is Cool In Miami
description: Once the rout began tonight, the only question was whether the University of Miami's players would take it easy on Greg Schiano, Rutgers's first-year head coach and the Hurricanes' former defensive coordinator.

title: BUSINESS: DIARY
description: A One-Time Adjustment For Changing Tastes

title: Sehorn and Collins Motivated by Defeat
description: Super Bowl XXXV had ended and the Giants had returned to their Tampa hotel just past 11 p.m. on Jan. 28. Kerry Collins -- his four record-tying interceptions in the game fresh in every vivid detail -- turned to his family and friends, including his fiance, Brooke Isenhour, and asked if he could be left alone.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: Waves, the Old, the New and the Hormonal; Sex and Its Comic Karma
description: WITH his first film, ''Slo con Tu Pareja'' (''Love in the Time of Hysteria''), the Mexican director Alfonso Cuarn managed some lewd, melodramatic twists in a bleak comedy of manners about how a man's appetites can become his curse. Even Mr. Cuarn's American studio films, ''A Little Princess'' and ''Great Expectations,'' invoke the dangers faced by a protagonist whose reach exceeds his or her grasp. For the forthcoming ''Y Tu Mam Tambin'' (''And Your Mother Too''), opening in March. Mr. Cuarn has returned to Mexico to fashion another corrosive, comic melodrama.

title: Katharine Christopherson, Andrew Calderwood
description: Katharine Elizabeth Christopherson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul C. Christopherson of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew Hohlweg Calderwood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Calderwood of Sydney, Australia. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Church in New York.

title: The Freshman
description: In so many ways her life seems smaller now. The stages are smaller, the crowds are smaller and the planes are certainly smaller. Long motorcades with blaring sirens have become just a couple of cars. And the crush of reporters and Secret Service agents has thinned, making room for ordinary people seeking a handshake, an autograph, a hug. Once a singular figure, as famous as any woman on earth, she now waits -- feet up, cell phone pressed to her ear -- for men who used to be at her beck and call.

description: GREENWICHTOWN

title: U.S. Walkout: Was It Repudiated or Justified by the Conference's Accord?
description: Now that delegates from nearly all nations have agreed to a declaration on the legacies of colonialism and slavery as well as the conflict in the Middle East, questions are inevitable about whether the United States should have walked out of the United Nations conference last week.

title: Fleetwood Mac And Back
description: Stevie Nicks has won as much musical acclaim as a solo artist as she has with Fleetwood Mac, the group she has returned to several times since 1975's ''Dreams'' and ''Rhiannon.'' She released her first solo album in 1981, ''Bella Donna,'' which reached No. 1 on the charts and continued to write and release solo work even as Fleetwood Mac reunited for a tour in the 1990's. On her latest album, ''Trouble in Shangri-La,'' she performs with female singers like Macy Gray, Sarah McLachlan, Natalie Maines and Cheryl Crow. Ms. Nicks will perform at the Arena at Trump Taj Mahal Sept. 15. Karen DeMasters

title: Bomb Expodes in Northern Israeli Railroad Station
description: JERUSALEM -- A bomb exploded Sunday at the railroad station in the northern Israeli coastal town of Nahariya, killing three people and wounding many more, police and witnesses said. Initial reports said the blast was set off by a Palestinian suicide bomber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, NEISON
description: HARRIS-Neison. The membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, Florida, announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend and esteemed member Neison Harris and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Bette and their family. Robert P. Adler, President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc.

It is a mystery to the neighbors at West 114th Street and Riverside Drive, and most have greeted it with unwelcome surprise. It arrived last month, but last week it left city officials scrambling for answers. No one, it seems, invited bus shelter No. MNO1324.

title: How Punctual is Amtrak?
description: A major reason trains run late, Amtrak says, is that almost all of its tracks are owned and operated by freight railroads, which control scheduling. Amtrak's definition of on time is based on the length of the journey. Trains that travel 500 miles or less are considered on time if they arrive within 15 minutes of the scheduled time; those that travel 501 miles or more are on time if they are 30 minutes late. Here is the average for each route in both directions.

title: Corrections
description: Alisting of commemorative events on Page 12 of the New Season issue of Arts & Leisure today with an article about the composer Richard Rodgers on his 100th birthday refers incorrectly to his collaboration with Oscar Hammerstein II in "The King and I," which will be performed in Japanese in April in Osaka, Japan. Rodgers wrote the music; Hammerstein alone wrote the book, as well as the lyrics.

title: Economy of Desire
description: It's not clear if the Genoa city fathers knew what they were in for when they asked Vanessa Beecroft, a young, provocative artist best known for her photo-documented performances, to do one on the occasion of the G-8 summit this past summer. (It's pictured above.) She typically presents a cluster of young women in states of undress and semi-undress standing and lying in a carefully arranged group pose for up to three hours. The combination of nudity and emotional impassivity, formality and suggestiveness, in Beecroft's tableaux vivants variously evokes the art class model, the soldier, the Victoria's Secret vamp, the dancer at the Bada Bing.

title: Commercial Property/MacArthur Airport; Busy Runways Spur Development, and Vice Versa
description: PAUL T. FORTUNATO remembers driving his car to Long Island MacArthur Airport in Islip about 20 years ago and parking on the grass in front of the terminal to take a ''little twin-prop Mohawk Airlines plane to Albany.''

title: Lining Up the Blocs Isn't Easy This Year
description: It's that time of the campaign season when only one thing matters: the carefully staged production -- part science, part fantasy -- to get out the vote.

title: In This Hobby, Sometimes You Must Tread Lightly
description: NORMAN E. FARMER of Bristol has been keeping honeybees for almost 40 years. He's had as many as 800 hives, which produce about 20 tons of honey a year, and he buys another 30 tons from hobbyists, bottling and distributing it to farm stands around the state.

title: Ken's Eyes May Wander

title: Fiction and 'Literary' Fiction

In its July/August issue, The Atlantic Monthly brought out one purporting to represent the point of view of the average reader. ''A Reader's Manifesto: An Attack on the Growing Pretentiousness of American Literary Prose'' was one of those Angry Indictments of Contemporary Fiction that address important questions of style and sociology. The author, an unknown named B. R. Myers, declared that the American novel had become convoluted and self-consciously ''literary.'' He drove his point home with merciless dissections of passages by Annie Proulx, David Guterson, Cormac McCarthy, Paul Auster and Don DeLillo, and he accused the literary establishment of eschewing good clean writing and advancing affected, artsy prose instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEAKE, CAMERON
description: PEAKE-Cameron. John Hugh Cameron Peake, aged 82, died at home in Essex, CT on September 7. The cause of death was heart failure. He leaves his beloved wife, Doris; two sons, Christopher of Greenwich, CT and Nicholas of Alexandria, VA; a daughter Alison of West Hartford, CT; eight grandchildren; and his former wife, Barbara. He is survived by his sister, Alison (Mrs. Basil) Henning of New Haven, CT; two stepsons: Pierre Brunschwig of Boulder, CO; Joseph Brunschwig of North Branford, CT; and a stepdaughter, Turie Norman of Boulder, CO. His eldest stepson, Jean-gar Brunschwig of Pine, AZ, predeceased him. Born in Rye, NY on July 3, 1919, Cameron graduated from the Lawrenceville School in 1938 and attended Yale until mid-1941, when he enlisted in the Navy. He later served in West Africa and the Sudan with PAA-Africa, Ltd., and entered the Foreign Service in 1945. Together with his wife and children, the latter of whom were born abroad, he served as Vice Consul in Buenos Aires and Cuidad Trujillo, as Consul in Oslo and San Pedro Sula and as Second Secretary in Madrid. He served as Chief of Biographical Intelligence at the Department of State and in 1961 he was retired for permanent medical disability. From 1963-1965 he was Director of the Pan American Congress of Architects, held in Washington, D.C. and later with the Citizens Committee for a Free Cuba and the Puerto Rico Information Service. In 1968 he moved to Camden, SC and then to Hilton Head where he developed his reputation for creating historical and maritime dioramas. In 1980 he settled in Essex. A memorial service will be held at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Old Lyme, CT on Saturday, September 15, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name can be made to the Connecticut River Museum, Essex, CT 06426. For information, contact Abbey Funeral and Cremation Service.

title: 'Chesty'
description: The 231 handpicked enlisted men marched into the gymnasium at the Marine Corps base in Quantico, Virginia, for their last muster as a unit. It was June 16, 1919, graduation day for the 3d Officers' Training Camp (OTC). After five months of strenuous effort, each man had earned a commission as a second lieutenant in the Marine Corps Reserve. The post band opened the ceremonies with a medley of martial tunes capped by John Philip Sousa's march "Semper Fidelis." The music turned out to be the most stirring portion of the program, which otherwise consisted of short speeches and the presentation of commissions. A reporter noted that the "striking feature of the proceedings" was their solemnity and simplicity in comparison with graduations at West Point and Annapolis. Although the writer ascribed this difference to "that precision and lack of fuss so characteristic of the doings of Marines," in truth there was little to celebrate at the moment. Seven months earlier there had been rejoicing when an armistice ended the "war to end all wars." Now the United States was rapidly demobilizing its forces. The Commandant of the Marine Corps, Major General George Barnett, pointedly noted in his speech that this placed the class "in a peculiar position." This commissioning ceremony would not launch the lieutenants on a grand and glorious new career; rather, for most of them it marked the end of their service as Marines.

title: Citations

And while we are indeed responsible for the high quality of our slang and for an unfortunate predilection for using like as a form of punctuation, Americans, I am here to say, are not all bad for English. The ultimate repository for the history of the language is greatly indebted to Americans for much of what makes the Oxford English Dictionary what it is: the citations, or the quotations of language that illustrate the use of every sense of every word in the O.E.D. ''Every quotation,'' wrote Dr. Johnson in the preface to his great Dictionary of the English Language, ''contributes something to the stability or enlargement of the language,'' and so for the O.E.D. finding good citations is its primary goal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, GLORIA
description: WIENER-Gloria, died August 25th, 2001 after a valiant battle with cancer. She was predeceased by Don, her husband of 48 years, in November 2000. Gloria had a long, successful executive career in marketing and communications with Paine Webber and Merrill Lynch where she impressed her staff, peers and senior management with her ability to create relevant, quality materials to support the overall goals of the company. She retired from Merrill Lynch in 1987 as Vice President of Advertising and Sales Promotion. Gloria and Don divided their retirement years between Manhattan and their country home in Andes, NY in the Western Catskills. They also traveled extensively both nationally and internationally. Gloria was a lover of art, music and literature; she was an accomplished writer and classical and folk guitarist. Gloria was an avid birder and lover of nature; she catalogued the flora & fauna of her country home and wrote frequent articles for ''Hunting House News'', a publication of the Andes Society. Gloria loved crosscountry skiing with her husband and friends. She was a talented chef and a great hostess. Gloria is survived by her loving sisters, Ella May Ablahat & Louise Del Savio, and her loving brother, Gordon Cason; by five nieces and nephews and an extended family of longtime, loving friends-all of whom will miss Gloria's warmth, intelligence and good humor. There will be no service. Contributions in Gloria's memory may be made to the Beaverkill Valley Fire Department, HCR 1, Lew Beach, NY 12758, or to the Audubon Society of New York State, 46 Rarick Road, Selkirk, New York 12158.

The society's first season kicks off next Saturday at the Boces Auditorium, with a benefit screening of a film that is surely not at the megaplex: ''The Cameraman,'' starring Buster Keaton, first shown in 1928. Ben Model, who accompanies silent films at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, will play piano, and Bill Irwin, a Nyack resident, will speak about Keaton's influence on his work as an actor and ''physical comedian.'' Admission to the event, which also includes desserts afterward, is $45. Tickets for the film alone, if available, are $8, as they are for subsequent films. She is survived by her three sons: H. Mason Hicks, Alan T. Hicks and James B. Hicks, all of Manhattan, & by six grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Mrs. Hicks was a talented singer & banjo player who studied music in Washington, D.C. and in Paris, and performed folk music in New York City in the 1930s. Her remarkable beauty, charm, generosity and love of life were inspiring to everyone who ever met her. A memorial service will be held in Tennessee on November 3rd. title: 'Out of the Jungle'
description: When James Riddle Hoffa was born in Brazil, Indiana, on February 14, 1913, American socialism had reached its apex. Just twelve years after its founding, the Socialist Party could boast of a membership of more than 100,000, the election of 1,200 party members to public offices across the United States, and the ongoing publication of more than 300 periodicals. Most impressive was the widespread popularity of another native of west-central Indiana, Eugene Debs, who received more than 900,000 votes as the party's nominee in the 1912 presidential election. But over the next several years, during Hoffa's childhood, the United States provided a stark answer to the query posed by Friedrich Engels at the close of the nineteenth century. title: 'Emergence'
description: In August of 2000, a Japanese scientist named Toshiyuki Nakagaki announced that he had trained an amoebalike organism called slime mold to find the shortest route through a maze. Nakagaki had placed the mold in a small maze comprising four possible routes and planted pieces of food at two of the exits. Despite its being an incredibly primitive organism (a close relative of ordinary fungi) with no centralized brain whatsoever, the slime mold managed to plot the most efficient route to the food, stretching its body through the maze so that it connected directly to the two food sources. Without any apparent cognitive resources, the slime mold had "solved" the maze puzzle.

title: QUICK BITE/Vorhees; Selling Like Crab Cakes
description: People will go a long way for a good crab cake, but they've discovered that they don't have to go all the way to Baltimore. In the three years Bobby Sliwowski has been operating Bobby Chez in South Jersey, the combination of take-out convenience and crab cakes has built a clientele that includes the famous and the harried. David Copperfield and Molly Ringwald have pulled up to the Margate store in a limo, and Billy Joel and Calvin Klein have had them shipped. Mr. Sliwowski closed his Chez Robert restaurant (most recently in Westmont) three years ago because of financial troubles, then opened Bobby Chez in Voorhees, one in Cherry Hill a year later and, this summer, a third in Margate. The menu in each includes fried and coconut shrimp ($3.50 each), grilled fish and fried scallops ($8 a half-pound), along with side dishes like lobster mashed potatoes ($5 or $10), coleslaw ($3 or $6) and roasted red peppers in basil and garlic ($3). The crab cakes, the size of tennis balls, are $5.95 apiece. At home, the cakes go into a 450-oven and bake for 12 minutes. Mr. Sliwowski sells 20,000 a week, including to restaurants. The limo-less have been known to stand in line for up to 90 minutes to buy them, particularly at holidays. Karen Piccinini, of Cherry Hill, said ''During Lent, you can forget it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMELL, MARGARET HOLMES
description: HAMMELL-Margaret Holmes. Age 78, of Charlottesville, VA, died peacefully in her sleep on August 28, 2001. Born January 11, 1923, in Augusta, GA, she was the daughter of the late Dr. L. Palmer Holmes and Minnie Thomas Groover Holmes. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Captain Richard Hammell, USN retired. She attended St. Catherine's school in Richmond, VA, Dana Hall in Wellesley, MA, and Wellesley College, where she earned her BA degree in English in 1944. Mrs. Hammell lived for 45 years in Summit, NJ, until she retired to Charlottesville, VA, in 1994. A devoted wife, mother and pillar of the Summit and Charlottesville communities, she was truly beloved by all who knew her for her always sunny disposition, selfless devotion to others, and deep religious faith. She is survived by four sons, Robert Hammell of Alexandria, VA; Douglas Hammell of Atlanta, GA; Stephen Hammell of Philadelphia, PA; and John Hammell of Floyd, VA; and two grandchildren, Hilary Hammell, currently a student at Yale University, New Haven, CT; and Davis Hammell, a student at Episcopal High School in Alexandria. There will be a memorial service in Summit, NJ, in early October. Inquiries may be directed to Robert Hammell at 703-548-1466 or 703-807-2570.
