title: Cars
description: I am always certain that I will never have to buy another car because the one I have is just right and it is only a set of wheels and it is not important to my sense of myself, but then it always turns out that there is just one thing wrong with the car I have. When I was 16 I owned a Chevrolet Corvair convertible, which was a lovely car, except that it was universally known to be unsafe at any speed. My next try, some years later, was a Fiat, which was wonderful when it ran. I sold it knowing it needed a ring job. The purchaser declined my urging that he take it for an inspection because he knew all about Fiats and he was sure this one would be fine. I was thus not terribly remorseful when he told me a week after he bought it that it needed a new transmission. I got my father's car after he died intestate. It was a two-door Datsun. When it arrived, it was full of the evidence of my father's life -- every possible gadget that could be plugged into the lighter socket, lots of tools, a pair of sunglasses. Deep under the passenger's seat was a single plastic flip-flop in a large size, obviously my father's sandal. At his death, I hadn't seen or spoken to my father in 28 years. His flip-flop gave me a turn. I traded the Datsun in for a Chevy Cavalier wagon, because it was very hard to get the baby seat into the back seat of the Datsun. I lost the Chevy in a divorce, which was fine with me because various parts of the electrical system had caught fire over the years. A year after the divorce, the Chevy was stolen and driven into a water-filled quarry. After it was lifted by crane from its watery submersion, the Police Department representative who was supervising the operation said, ''Wait a minute!'' A few minutes later, they pulled out another Chevy Cavalier wagon, same year, same model.

title: Head of The Class
description: My first year teaching, I had a bizarre fantasy: I wanted to be fat. In charge of 32 fourth graders, many of whom were bigger than I was, I was desperate for heft in the classroom. The extra tonnage, I imagined, would make up for what I couldn't provide through sheer weight of personality. As the moment demanded, I liked to picture myself as either a benign earth mother, reading to her students on her gargantuan lap, or a skirted colossus, wheeling around to strike terror in the heart of any child who dared to throw a spitball. My distorted body image resulted, I think, from outdated notions of femininity and motherhood. As it was, in my funky miniskirts and purple clogs, I looked more like a skinny teenager than a woman with gravitas. Was it even possible to be both an authority figure and a member of the MTV generation?

description: Nostalgia for the look and feel of an earlier New York is evoked by the illustrations, graphic novels, set designs and drawings that make up ''Ben Katchor: Picture-Stories,'' an exhibition that opens today at the Jewish Museum (1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street). The dominance of the older generation will continue at this month's New York Film Festival, which will add Eric Rohmer to the Cannes roster of New Wave old masters. It is, of course, a blessing that they are still with us, but their presence also encourages those who take an elegiac view of the state of the art.

title: THE NEW SEASON/ART: Pictures That Move, and Pop and Ping; Proponent of the Fine Points
description: PAUL SIGNAC, who was born in 1863 and died in 1935, is the ''other'' Pointillist, or Neo-Impressionist, perpetually in the shadow of the style's chief innovator, Georges Seurat. Signac is known primarily for his luminous marine paintings from the late 1880's, which can be almost indistinguishable from Seurat's, and for one portrait, in the Museum of Modern Art, of a dear friend, the art critic Flix Fnon. It shows the slim. dandified Fnon standing in profile in front of spiraling stripes and waves, elaborated from a Japanese print, that pay irreverent homage to the scientific color theories behind Neo-Impressionism, in part by exaggerating its retinal pops and pings.

title: Women And Power In 2001.
description: The most powerful women in my life are my sister and my baby sitter. My sister is eight years older than I am, so when I was a child and she was a teenager, she enjoyed the status of a queen as far as I was concerned. She had waist-length blond hair, boyfriends, an abundance of purple garments, important moods -- and political beliefs that sometimes prevented her from going to school. (During the Vietnam War, she once persuaded my mother to write a note to her high-school principal that read: ''Please excuse Cindy's absence yesterday. She was sick -- sick of war.'') As we got older, the age gap between us seemed to narrow, and we grew steadily closer. But in the meantime, Cindy had become a doctor, adding a layer of professional expertise to her big-sisterly mystique, and I had become, among other things, a hypochondriac and a mother. Cindy is an uncannily good diagnostician, quick to piece together scattered clues and reveal truths about underlying ailments in a way that strikes me as magical, though I suppose it has as much to do with how attentively she listens as with any actual occult powers.

(Robertson's, which denied that Golly was racist, simply said the near century-old character no longer appealed to children.) But the move also meant that Golly tote bags, T-shirts, brooches, dolls and other merchandise issued by the company over the years would soon be scarce. And few things cause the free market to quiver like scarcity -- even when the shortage is arguably a sign of social progress.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: Waves, the Old, the New and the Hormonal; At 31, Already A Master Director
description: WES ANDERSON has only two previous features, ''Bottle Rocket'' (1996) and ''Rushmore'' (1999), but it's already clear that this 31-year-old writer-director possesses one of the freshest voices in American movies. Mr. Anderson is a master of blending tones, able to layer comedy and tragedy, high stylization and sharp realism, bursting joy and haunting melancholy, not only within films but also within scenes and even single shots. His is a talent that Jean Renoir might have admired.

title: Lacking a Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Jewish Salonika
description: To the Editor: Reading Benedict Nightingale's panegyric to Greece -- and especially to Salonika -- ''Antiquity's Enduring Power'' (Aug. 12), I was struck by the concession that when it comes to his favorite travel destinations ''there's still much to discover.''

title: BackTalk; Exercise Is More Than Surfing TV
description: Since I spent the last month working out my own version of the Ironman Triathlon (the Paperman Triglyceride) I was delighted that AARP has institutionalized my summer vacation without intruding on it. Today, at Centennial Beach in Naperville, Ill., outside Chicago, the organization for the old and older is holding the first of seven events in various cities to get people over 50 fit enough to go the distance from its boomer magazine, My Generation, to its crone site, Modern Maturity.

title: CORZINE'S INCOME
description: Senator Jon S. Corzine last week reported an adjusted gross income of $71 million in 2000, almost $10 million more than he spent on his 2000 Senate campaign. The majority of Mr. Corzine's 2000 income came from his $59.4 million sale of 750,000 shares of Goldman, Sachs stock in August 2000. David Wald, a spokesman for the senator, said there was ''no direct connection'' between the stock sale and the campaign. In 1999, Mr. Corzine reported an adjusted gross income of $43.9 million. Anne Ruderman

title: A Poet's Bridge, Pedestrian Only in Function
description: THE bridge has become a highly compelling image for a historical moment suspended, as ours often seems to be, between Post- and Next. It has fallen to Santiago Calatrava, the Spanish architect and engineer, to give this moment a suitably exalted form. His designs for bridges and railway stations elevate urban infrastructure to supreme heights of poetic expression.

title: Bulgari the Book, by Fay Weldon
description: To the Editor:

title: Eat Your Nice Iron
description: In the preface to SHIFU, YOU'LL DO ANYTHING FOR A LAUGH (Arcade, $23.95), a compact collection of stories selected by his gifted longtime translator Howard Goldblatt, Mo Yan, the author of ''Red Sorghum,'' reflects on his difficult childhood and recalls feasting with his classmates on a load of coal dumped outside their school. It's only a short step from there to ''Iron Child,'' a story in which a hungry waif meets a strange rust-covered boy who teaches him to survive lean times by eating iron. Mo Yan's blunt portrayal of the suffering in recent Chinese history has occasionally rankled his government. And these stories do indeed brim with the vagaries of life under Communist rule: mandatory attendance at executions in ''The Cure,'' the bitter inequities of the Cultural Revolution in ''Love Story,'' callous treatment of unwanted infant girls in ''Abandoned Child.'' But beneath his unsentimental depiction of peasants and workers lies a deep affection for the downtrodden. In the masterly title story, a laid-off factory worker prospers by converting an abandoned bus in the woods into a cozy love shack and renting it out for quick trysts; like this resourceful soul, Mo Yan transforms the wreckage of everyday life into something useful, cheering and rare. Michael Porter

title: A Life of Looking at Little Things
description: WHEN the beekeeper Ernest Jennings was killed by bees last month, one of the first experts called to look into the death was Louis A. Magnarelli, the State Entomologist. Mr. Magnarelli, in essence the state's bug expert, has held the position since 1987 and is the fifth person to hold the job since the position was created 100 years ago.

title: No Contradiction Seen In Bishop's Outreach
description: In the article about the new leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre [''New Bishop Comes Ready to Do His Homework,'' Sept. 2], Bishop William Murphy is described as ''steeped in church orthodoxy but committed to interfaith understanding.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCU, SANDU
description: MARCU-Sandu. On August 29, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Maria. Loving father of Mihai and Elizabeth. Adoring grandfather of David, Stephen and Amanda. Formerly, violinist at the Plaza Hotel. Private service.

title: Tastemakers Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Eleanor Bauza, Edward Rusher
description: Eleanor Lissette Bauza and Dr. Edward John Rusher were married Friday afternoon at the Hoxie House, a museum in Sandwich, Mass. The Rev. John Thomas, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The Cost of Doing Business
description: OUT OF THE JUNGLE

title: Study Suggests Soot Particle Size and Content Seem to Count
description: As the Environmental Protection Agency moves to tighten restrictions on tiny particles of air pollution, new research shows that it may need to put even more stringent limits on soot from some industrial sources.

title: The Killing Fields a Memory, a Lush Land Is a Draw
description: MATT DILLON first set foot in Cambodia in April 1993, while on vacation. Unwittingly, he had chosen a time when a fragile peace formed the backdrop to the country's first election in decades, and the atmosphere was explosive: runaway inflation, skyrocketing AIDS infections, the unsettling presence of thousands of international troops monitoring the election.

title: Brand-Name Lit: Call Me Tiffany.
description: REMEMBER the good old days when commercials stopped once you turned off the television? Now it's not even safe to curl up in an armchair with a good book anymore. With the announcement last week that the jewelry concern Bulgari commissioned Fay Weldon's new novel, it seems advertising has trumped fiction. Appropriately titled ''The Bulgari Connection,'' the book includes a plot involving the sale of a painting containing a Bulgari necklace, vivid descriptions of pieces made by the Italian jeweler and one character obsessed by Bulgari's overwhelming aesthetic.

title: Web Project Is a Success At Libraries
description: WHEN Westchester's public libraries made it possible for patrons to reserve materials from any area library via their home computer two years ago, they expected a good response. They didn't, however, expect what they got: near pandemonium.

title: Middle Linebackers Make a Comeback
description: It was a warm Saturday night last month when Baltimore's Ray Lewis, the leader of a middle linebacker renaissance not seen in the National Football League since the days of the single-bar face mask, terrorized his first New York running back of the preseason. When the Jets' Curtis Martin caught a screen pass and began to scramble left, Lewis, in pursuit from the opposite side of the field, evaded two blockers and caught Martin from behind.

title: Short Story Noir
description: THE SELECTED STORIES OF PATRICIA HIGHSMITH

title: Grateful Jews Help Care for a Holocaust 'Guardian Angel'
description: When Elissa Blaser visited her mother at the Amsterdam Nursing Home on 112th Street late last year, she discovered that her mother had a new roommate. The roommate appeared to be sleeping, but later that night began to moan.

title: 'Fury'
description: Professor Malik Solanka, retired historian of ideas, irascible dollmaker, and since his recent fifty-fifth birthday celibate and solitary by his own (much criticized) choice, in his silvered years found himself living in a golden age. Outside his window a long, humid summer, the first hot season of the third millennium, baked and perspired. The city boiled with money. Rents and property values had never been higher, and in the garment industry it was widely held that fashion had never been so fashionable. New restaurants opened every hour. Stores, dealerships, galleries struggled to satisfy the skyrocketing demand for ever more recherch produce: limited-edition olive oils, three-hundred-dollar corkscrews, customized Humvees, the latest anti-virus software, escort services featuring contortionists and twins, video installations, outsider art, featherlight shawls made from the chin-fluff of extinct mountain goats. So many people were doing up their apartments that supplies of high-grade fixtures and fittings were at a premium. There were waiting lists for baths, doorknobs, imported hardwoods, antiqued fireplaces, bidets, marble slabs. In spite of the recent falls in the value of the Nasdaq index and the value of Amazon stock, the new technology had the city by the ears: the talk was still of start-ups, IPOs, interactivity, the unimaginable future that had just begun to begin. The future was a casino, and everyone was gambling, and everyone expected to win.

title: Diving Safety
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Exploring Two Sides of Cuba's West'' (Aug. 5): Diving remains one of the world's safest sports because members of the Professional Association of Dive Instructors and other international diving associations commit themselves to safe practices and universal standards. Instructors like me do this because of a commitment to safety, not because of the ''wet blanket'' liability fears Carey Goldberg accuses us of.

title: France Liberated, Laughs Generated and Reality Revisited
description: A * indicates an event of special note.

title: Making Jazz and Family, Home and the Road Work Together
description: HER luggage already packed for a late afternoon flight to San Francisco, Geri Allen, a jazz pianist, still had several precious hours remaining before her departure out of Newark, so she was filling the morning in the company of three children, ages 3 to 11.

title: THE NEW SEASON/DANCE: From Inner City Moves to Outback Modes; In the Australian Style
description: NEW YORKERS can sample the richness of Australian dance in premieres by three companies. Visits by the Australian Ballet, Sydney Dance Company and several independent choreographers have already demonstrated that dance thrives in Australia. Now, three largely unfamiliar troupes will suggest how Australian choreographers are both international in outlook and proud of their country's identity.

title: A Son and Six Others Seek a Council Seat
description: Donald T. Wooten, a candidate for a City Council seat, took his campaign entourage to a senior center recently, playing a game of pool with a group of men and giving his fliers to another group eating a meal of chicken and sweet potatoes.

title: Private Sector; On the Road Again, Happily
description: John F. Welch Jr., once known for hot-tempered volatility, seems almost unflappable these days. He smiles a lot, jokes a lot, teases visitors, absolutely exudes relaxed bonhomie. But that's not because his grueling 20-year tenure at the helm of General Electric ended on Friday. It's because his book, ''Jack: Straight From the Gut,'' hits stores this week, and he doesn't have to tweak it anymore. ''Writing a book is brutal, exhausting, tormenting, but everyone should do it when they leave a company,'' Mr. Welch said on Tuesday. ''It lets you reflect on things and close the chapter. Now I can really do the things that I love.''

description: ALMOST

title: For Price Break on Drugs, Congress Looks to Canada
description: Congress is taking steps to allow imports of prescription drugs from Canada, in the hope of giving American consumers access to lower-priced medicines.

title: Regrets for Past Wrongs And Hopes for Peace
description: Following are excerpts from the Middle East declaration approved yesterday by the United Nations conference in Durban, South Africa, and from the Program of Action.

description: This

description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Might Meet Arafat If Truce Talks Yield Results
description: President Bush could meet with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, in New York later this month, but the encounter most likely would happen only if some progress were made in high-level talks between the Palestinians and Israelis, administration officials and diplomats said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the guitarist Arlen Roth misidentified the instrument he is best known for having mastered. It is the Telecaster, not the Stratocaster.

title: A Laid-Back Manic Type Who Hates, Loves Work
description: LOOK at this,'' says Jeff Bridges, fishing a pair of snapshots from his wallet. One shows a young blond woman in a blue scarf and plaid shirt, a fine-featured beauty, the rival of any of Mr. Bridges's leading ladies despite the evidence of a recent car wreck: two bruised eyes and a scraped-looking nose. In the second photo the same woman, radiantly smiling, faces a young Mr. Bridges, who is in profile, wearing a Stetson and a peculiar, slack-jawed expression. The setting, Mr. Bridges explains, is a Montana dude ranch where one of his colleagues on the 1975 movie ''Rancho Deluxe'' happened to be standing by with a camera when Mr. Bridges asked the woman, a waitress, out on a date.

title: Next, It's Cavity Week
description: The fashion corps -- has always had a love affair with sweets, and New York's Fashion Week, running through Friday, will be catering to it. ''Candy is like a little piece of naughty wrapped up in pretty packaging, just like clothing,'' as the designer Rebecca Taylor put it. ''We always keep our showroom and studio stocked with candy,'' said Ms. Taylor, who will be stocking gift bags with seashell- and fish-shaped Plimoth lollipops at her runway show. ''Lollipops are delicious and sexy,'' she added, ''so they go perfectly with my collection.''

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Douglas Coupland; Escape From Gen X
description: ''I'M going to keep that door open,'' Douglas Coupland said nervously. ''I'm agoraphobic. I can't deal with crowds.'' It was not long before a party Thursday evening at the Totem Gallery on Grand Street, to celebrate the publication of Mr. Coupland's new novel, ''All Families Are Psychotic,'' and the opening of a show of his sculptures called ''Spike.''

title: In Praise of Melody, and Rodgers
description: There may be some enchanted evenings ahead for admirers of the melodies of Richard Rodgers. A yearlong centennial in the composer's honor began in June, and there will be major revivals around the world of some of his Broadway shows. ''Oklahoma!'' begins previews in New York in February, one of many classic musicals that Rodgers wrote with the lyricist Oscar Hammerstein II and, earlier, Lorenz Hart.

title: Career Centers
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/Norwich; Tired of Interruptions, Schools Ban Cell Phones
description: KAYTE HOLZTHUM, a senior at Mercy High School, is unique among her peers, not just because she is president of the National Honor Society chapter at the Catholic girls school, but because she does not own a cell phone. For in the halls of this Middletown school, cell phones seem to be almost as common as notebooks.

title: A Decade or So Later, a Brazilian Encore
description: FABIO'S has come back from the dead. The Island's first Brazilian restaurant that tried and failed in 1986 has been resurrected. The new, smaller, more sophisticated version is a monument to the persistence of its principal owner, the Brazilian-born Fabio Machado, who is the chief executive of the Pomodoro Restaurant Group.

title: Sept. 2-8; Senate Attrition
description: Robbing the Republicans of an incumbent in the battle for control of the Senate, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, an ardent fiscal conservative, announced that he would not seek a fourth term. Senators Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina and Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, both Senate fixtures, have also said they are not seeking re-election. And Republicans are nervously awaiting a decision from Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee. Alison Mitchell

title: Deborah Diamond, Ian Chernichaw
description: Deborah Lynn Diamond, a daughter of Maxine Budris of Geneva, N.Y., and Seymour Diamond of Roslyn, N.Y., is to be married today to Ian Chernichaw, a son of Pauline and Mark Chernichaw of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Rabbi Bruce Ginsburg is to perform the ceremony at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Liberties; I Can't Take It Anymore
description: If you thought it would be hard for TV to top the Summer of the Insatiable Sharks, Ravenous Bears, Killer Bees and Stampeding Lizzie Grubman, you were wrong.

title: Frequent Fliers: Takeout Menus Can't Compete With Politics
description: Ballots in this election may or may not be stuffed, but mailboxes in this city have been that way for months. The culprit, of course, is campaign literature.

title: Force Majeure
description: Q: How young were you when you first realized you were almost freakishly much stronger than other girls?

title: Where 'Rest in Peace' Is a Hollow Phrase
description: THERE'S a nasty new line of thinking floating around in the cyber-cellular-McMansion age. Those who would succeed today, this view goes, must look ahead and only ahead if they are to keep pace; the past stands in the way of progress.

title: 'Jefferson's Pillow'
description: Less than a mile from my home in Washington, on a little peninsula jutting out into the Tidal Basin, inside a neoclassical temple, there is an awesome statue of Thomas Jefferson. He is on a high pedestal, standing easily and tall in a long coat with a gaze that seems fixed somewhere far beyond tomorrow. Some of Jefferson's most memorable words are set in the great stone panels that surround the statue. They are the throbbing phrases at the core of the American hymn to freedom that Jefferson composed and flung out against the sky. These are words that have enlarged the hearts and emboldened the spirits of generations of freedom-loving people across the globe.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WHEN SPACE COWBOYS (2000) opened a year ago, Clint Eastwood was 70 years old, James Garner 72, Donald Sutherland 65 and Tommy Lee Jones 54 (but willing to pass for older). As four astronauts well past their prime, they manage to perform a surprising marriage of genres: geezer comedy and space adventure. These former colleagues are called into action to repair a 1950's satellite that none of the hot young 21st-century astronauts would know what to do with. Reunited, the old guys make a convincing argument for the joys of maturity. and although it's Mr. Jones's character who gets the love interest (Marcia Gay Harden, then 41), Mr. Sutherland should win a prize for making sexagenarian libido so appealing -- Saturday at 8 p.m., Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:50 a.m. on HBO.

title: A Part-Time Super? Does This Lower the Christmas Tip?
description: One building, one superintendent, is how Nathaniel remembers his job. ''You'd wake up in the morning and take care of your building like it was your own,'' said Nathaniel, who asked that his last name not be used.

title: Plans for Asbury Park Began in the 1950's
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Reds From Israel
description: To enrich Rosh Hashana dinners, beginning Sept. 17, serve vivacious Israeli reds from the Golan Heights Winery. The medium-bodied Yarden 2000 Mount Hermon Red, a four-grape blend, is berrylike and smooth. The sumptuous Yarden 1998 merlot (14 percent cabernet sauvignon) resembles a compote. Hermon costs $11, the merlot $18, at Astor, 12 Astor Place (Lafayette Street) in Manhattan. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: OPINION; Skewed Priorities in Republic Plan
description: IN July a Baltimore freight tunnel caught fire, shut down a city, endangered railroad workers and sent a screaming message to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority about the lack of adequate firefighting equipment in the East River tunnels used by most Long Island Rail Road trains. Yet rather than finally focus on this stark and potentially disastrous mass transit threat to Long Islanders, the debate continues over whether to build a new $20 million L.I.R.R. station at Republic Airport, a mile from the existing Farmingdale station.

title: Devils Must Regroup
description: Reaching the Stanley Cup finals last season proved the quality of the Devils and it cost them four players to free agency. When they open training camp on Wednesday, they will also be without goaltender John Vanbiesbrouck, who retired after 18 full seasons in the National Hockey League.

title: A Moral History of Chicago
description: METEOR IN THE MADHOUSE

title: Sept. 2-8; Peres to Meet With Arafat
description: Shimon Peres, the Israeli foreign minister, said he would meet with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, in hopes of ending almost a year of conflict. But the when, where, and about what were uncertain, and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said he even had doubts about the why. Mr. Arafat, he predicted, would not give up his ''kingdom of terror.'' James Bennet

title: Sept. 2-8; 64, Minus . . .
description: After weeks of questions about the quality of the human embryonic stem cells that President Bush has approved for federal research, the administration acknowledged that of the 64 cell lines that scientists may study, only about two dozen are ready. Lawmakers who want to expand the policy said that put Mr. Bush's credibility in doubt. But Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, countered that there were plenty of cells. ''Let's get on with it,'' he said, ''and stop quibbling about the numbers.'' Sheryl Gay Stolberg

title: A Spin Down Memory Lane
description: To lead off the international spring 2002 collections, which started last Friday in Bryant Park, American designers sent a diversity of skirt shapes and lengths down the runways. One of the most interesting developments is the revival of the 1940's knee-covering full skirt, which was already being worn by some women in New York this summer, in pleated, gathered and flounced styles. It has even appeared in one-piece dresses, especially for dancing evenings.

title: Bites Worse Than the Barks, These Dogs' Neighbors Say
description: Harry Theodore, a former shepherd from Greece who has made a home for himself and a pack of German shorthaired pointers in a parking lot, strikes some people as an urban eccentric. But to others, especially fellow dog owners who live near his makeshift kennel on 11th Avenue and 36th Street, he is a homeless menace whose flock is an accident waiting to bite.

title: Pettitte Wins for First Time in a Month
description: NEW YORK -- Andy Pettitte won for the first time in nearly a month, and Tino Martinez and Nick Johnson homered as the streaking New York Yankees beat the reeling Boston Red Sox for the seventh straight time, 7-2 Sunday.

description: This

title: 3 From the East End: Lodging, Love, Murder; Coffee Table Version Of a Successful Exhibit
description: When Alastair Gordon was a boy of 10, a magazine ad for the prototype of a small, simple beach house caught his eye. He persuaded his parents to abandon their traditional shingled home here and construct a Techbuilt prefabricated house on a bluff.

title: Powell Will Visit Colombia With Reassurances About U.S. Aid
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell travels on Monday to South America, where he will witness firsthand Colombia's struggle with an intensifying, four-sided war and the American efforts to support its government.

title: The End of a Fund, and of a Losing Streak
description: One of the longest but least-enviable streaks in the mutual fund industry has ended, according to Morningstar Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCNEIL, JACK
description: McNEIL-Jack. Gone one year today & missed every day. Teacher to many, companion to Bob Reid, friend to all who knew him. Thanks for illuminating our lives.

title: Tracie Rozhon, Wint Aldrich
description: Tracie DeBisschop Rozhon and John Winthrop Aldrich were married yesterday at Christ Church in Middle Haddam, Conn. The Rev. Mark Given, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: 'Venus Envy'
description: Across between a green room and a rec room, the players' lounge is the equivalent of backstage in tennis. With no home clubhouse or permanent locker room, it is here that the nomads on the WTA Tour while away downtime at tournaments and minimize their social displacement between matches. They shoot pool, gab on their cell phones, surf the Net, play Ping-Pong, nap on comically overstuffed couches, and nibble snacks as they await their next court call.

title: CRIME
description: It's Christmas time in the city and all the naughty boys and girls in Ed McBain's gaily wrapped crime caper MONEY, MONEY, MONEY (Simon & Schuster, $25) know exactly what they want from Santa: the $1.9 million payoff from a sweetly executed drug deal in Mexico. Cass Ridley, the United States Army pilot who flew this dodgy mission, hangs onto her share long enough to buy two fur coats, which are promptly stolen by one of those goof-up burglars who thrive in the morally askew metropolis that McBain calls Isola. But when the hapless burglar is caught passing a phony $100 bill and Cass turns up dead in the lions' den at the zoo, Steve Carella and the cops at the 87th Precinct (not to mention Fat Ollie Weeks, who claims Cass's leg for the 88th) can kiss this holiday goodbye.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 26 with an article about living in Shelter Island misidentified a street scene. The street shown with stores is in Shelter Island Heights, not Dering Harbor.

title: Taking a Chance on TV; Getting the Chance to Play Himself
description: THE 1990's were hard times for Richard Dreyfuss. He was growing older, roles were getting scarcer and the films he did make were often disappointing. And worse, he said, he simply grew tired of acting. ''I felt desolate because I was so indifferent to my work,'' Mr. Dreyfuss said. ''I just stopped. I kept thinking, 'How is this happening to me?' ''

title: 2 Dead in Murder-Suicide
description: A 23-year-old man fatally shot his girlfriend in her parked car outside his home yesterday in Calverton, N.Y., while her young daughter sat in the back seat, the Suffolk County police said. The man then got out of the car and killed himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUST, IRVING
description: RUST-Irving. The Board of Directors, staff, volunteers and clients of Planned Parenthood of NYC express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our dear friend and esteemed colleague Dr. Irving Rust. As the former Medical Director of our South Bronx Hub Center and a longtime member of our staff, Dr. Rust was a compassionate provider of healthcare for women, teens and families and a courageous plantiff in our landmark Rust v. Sullivan Supreme Court challenge to censorship of medical providers in Title X funded health centers. We are profoundly grateful for his lifelong dedication to reproductive freedom and extend our sincere sympathy to his family. Cathy A. Cramer, Board Chair Joan Malin, Chief Exec Officer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANENHAUS, JOEL
description: TANENHAUS-Joel. Beloved husband of Joan, loving father of Amy and husband Jay, and Andrew and wife Renee, proud and devoted grandfather of Bari, Erika, Avery and Cooper. His spirit, humor, wisdom and guidance will be missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: Sept. 2-8; A Clue to Hoffa's Fate
description: Mystery has surrounded the fate of Jimmy Hoffa, the Teamsters leader, since he disappeared on July 30, 1975. Last week, there was a clue: F.B.I. scientists matched DNA from a hair taken from Mr. Hoffa's hair brush with one found in a car driven, on the day of his disappearance, by his long-time friend, Charles (Chuckie) O'Brien, who has long denied any link to the disappearance. Steven Greenhouse

title: Seascapes and Fairways
description: BANDON-BY-THE-SEA, a small, remote town on the southern Oregon coast, might seem like an odd place to start a golf resort, but it possesses in abundance the key elements for great seaside or links golf.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/The Financial District; In Wall Street's Canyons, Cliff Dwellers
description: IN ''The Death and Life of Great American Cities,'' her famous treatise on the liveliness of city neighborhoods, Jane Jacobs deplored central business districts that were not also used for residential or cultural purposes. As the primary example of one such neighborhood, she described downtown New York, noting the restaurants there that were mobbed at lunch but did not offer dinner at all.

title: The Stuff of Life
description: LIFE SCRIPT

title: Wait for Luggage? Not When You Rent a Jet.
description: AIRPLANE travel can be a headache. The check-in lines. The wait on the runway. Delays for bad weather. Cramped seats. Missed connections. Lost luggage. Add finding seats together for six children and a commute to Kennedy, La Guardia or MacArthur airport from his home in Sag Harbor, and it's almost not worth it for John Novak to take a trip. With the Hamptons traffic, sometimes he feels as if he needs a helicopter just to cross the Shinnecock Canal.

title: After a Postseason Look at the Tapes, Some Changes Fill the Air
description: Only a year ago, the talk of TV sports -- if not the world membership of Mensa -- was the coming of the comedian Dennis Miller to ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' booth.

title: THE NEW SEASON/JAZZ & POP: By Way of Iceland, Nigeria and the Net; Bjork as Never Heard Before
description: HOW do avant-gardist tendencies sell out Radio City Music Hall in five minutes? With the convergence of three factors: novelty, packaging and a big heart behind the strangeness. Bjork's current tour is coming to New York on Oct. 4 and 5 with one of the rare musical combinations that appear genuinely unprecedented. Her forces include not only a 54-piece orchestra something any singer could hire but an Inuit choir (from Greenland); an electronica duo from San Francisco, Matmos; and an electric harpist, Zeena Parkins, playing an instrument she invented herself. It's a lineup only Bjork would concoct.

title: Wear and Wash
description: Blue Raven's Cap in a Box -- is a chic shower cap ($17 at Random Accessories) for women who wash their hair about as often as they dry-clean their cashmere bathrobes. Made of soft, clothlike plastic with a natty black elastic band and topstitching, the cap comes in four retro patterns. The Lounge Cap, for instance, is patterned with bubbles and martini glasses; the Kitty Cap features a 1960's graphic with feline silhouettes. And a closer, trimmer cut allows wearers to avoid that poofy village idiot effect. It's just what Janet Leigh would have worn in the ''Psycho'' shower if she had needed her hair to look good for later scenes.

description: Nora Kathleen O'Connell, a daughter of Ann L. O'Connell and James A. O'Connell of Florence, Ore., was married yesterday to Adam Lee Strasberg, a son of Anna Strasberg of New York and the late Lee Strasberg, the acting coach. The Rev. David Macy officiated at Evermay, a historic estate house in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: Bulgari the Book, by Fay Weldon
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Values
description: Louise McIntosh Slaughter, New York congresswoman, 72 years old: ''Even though I was a student of microbiology with a master's in public health, when my three girls were young, I stayed at home with them. In the early 70's, I sort of stumbled into politics in the midst of trying to save a wooded area near my home. At first, I ran for county legislator. People always thought that being a mother might somehow hamper me, but the things I learned as a mother at home with young kids prepared me for being in government: management, budget, the importance of cleaning up after yourself and how to keep the peace. Of course it was hard at times, but I never stopped being a mother. When I ran for Congress in 1986, women were still not considered Congress material. Even then, women going into politics got questions like, What are we wearing? Do we have children?

description: To the Editor:

title: Jim Drake, 63, an Organizer Of Workers and a 60's Boycott
description: Jim Drake, who helped conceive the grape boycott of the 1960's and went on to organize workers and citizens in Mississippi, South Texas, the Bronx and Boston, died on Monday at a hospital in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 63 and lived in Manhattan and Spencertown, N.Y.

title: Sport of The Times; Jets Must Show Giants' Respect For the Coach
description: IN pro football, fights occasionally break out in training camp between an offensive lineman who objects, shall we say, to a defensive lineman's aggressive manner. But when a fight flared at the Giants' training camp this year, Coach Jim Fassel flared too.

title: How to Be a Boulevardier
description: Merriam-Webster's Online Dictionary defines ''flaneur'' as ''an idle man-about-town.'' But Lawrence Levi had a broader meaning in mind when he created a Web zine that pays homage to the French word. ''As Moli'ere saw it, and writers today like Edmund White,'' Mr. Levi said, ''he is an urban wanderer, a detached observer who immerses himself in the pleasure of observation and the scrutiny of street life.''

title: Paperback Fiction
description: This

title: Beheld
description: Everyone knows that a room changes when a beautiful woman walks into it. But exactly how it happens is hard to define, in part because it's hard to record. In order for the camera to capture the way beauty changes a room -- a moment immortalized by dozens of carefully set-up 1970's shampoo ads -- it seems the woman herself has to be as aware of her impact as everyone else is.

title: SoHo Lands a Library, and Calls It Overdue
description: For most SoHo residents, imported oysters and Anna Sui frocks can seem more readily available than a bottle of aspirin. The closest thing to a deli is a Dean & Deluca sidewalk stand. There are no schools, no places of worship and no fire station. And there isn't a library, though that will be changing.

title: The State by Ear
description: Between finding the left turn that might lead to a historic village and reciting the guidebook entry about the church you passed five miles ago, a car tour can be less than relaxing. A company called Travelog has put out a series of tapes and CD's that provide in-car narration, and one of them, due out this month, is a tour titled ''New Jersey's Skylands.'' The trip starts in Morristown and ends up at the Delaware Water Gap. Along the way, some of the sights are the Frelinghuysen Aroboretum, Washington's Headquarters, Chester, Waterloo Village, Newton and Stokes and Worthington State Forests. A Web site, www.travelog.com, includes a tour map and local links, plus a trivia quiz and scavenger hunt that might engage children. A card provides discounts at lodging and some merchants along the route. Tours, $19.95, will be sold on the site or at (800) 367-7201.

title: Knowing Her Place
description: Sitting in her creamy Wall Street office in a creamy Wall Street outfit, Alexandra Lebenthal seems to have been born to be right where she is. Having moved smoothly from Princeton University to the Kidder Peabody municipal-bond department to her father's brokerage firm, where she is now, at 37, president and chief executive, the only hurdle she appears to have faced is working in a world where female executives are still the exception.

title: Polishing Columbia's Bad-Neighbor Image

title: Stranger in the House
description: On a sweltering Monday morning, Barbara Bryant gets a visit from Carleen Miller-Verna, just as she has once a month, without fail, for two years. At 55, done rearing seven kids of her own, Bryant is about to adopt three more: Daishawn, 9; Shawanna, 7; Faith, 3. Miller-Verna, 32, is the social worker assigned to her case.

description: This is not your mother's Miss America Pageant.

title: Hard Time
description: In May, Sgt. Sarah Lehane was overseeing evening chow in the mess hall at Souza-Baranowski, a large Massachusetts maximum-security prison for men, when an inmate hit another officer in the face with a tray. Fights in a prison mess hall are like sparks in a powder keg: officers know they can lead to full-scale riots unless they are quickly contained. As officers (there were 10 in the room and a few more just outside) rushed to subdue the inmate and inmates (there were more than 200 in the mess hall) rushed to his defense, Lehane, standing across from the gates that computers had begun to close automatically, chose not freedom but the fight -- she ran to the defense of a young officer who was down and getting kicked. After three minutes, the melee was over, and Lehane extricated herself from what she describes as ''a pig pile.'' Nine officers had been injured, including her (a twisted knee and a banged-up shoulder); the one most badly hurt is still out with a fractured skull and swelling of the brain. Though the knee quickly healed, Lehane now admits that the incident rattled her. As it did her husband, Capt. Tom Lehane, who happened to be watching the mess hall on a video monitor as the incident took place. ''That was about as ugly a jump-off as I've ever seen,'' he says. And while at the time he extolled her bravery to friends, privately he felt she should quit. ''The incident really put a strain on our marriage,'' Sarah Lehane says.

title: New Research Fuels Debate Over Genetic Food Altering
description: New scientific studies on the impact of genetically engineered corn on monarch butterflies say the corn is having virtually no effect. The papers also make the provocative claim that earlier studies raising the question might have been flawed.

title: How a Troupe Puts Together The Puzzle Of a New Year
description: ONE morning in early August, several graceful young women in summery dresses anxiously hurried into Ballet Hispanico's headquarters on the Upper West Side of Manhattan to audition. Tina Ramirez, the company's director and founder, was eager to hire two new dancers. She was on a tight schedule because rehearsals were already under way, costume fittings would soon begin, and within a matter of weeks the Spanish choreographer Ramn Oller would be arriving to create his new ballet, and he needed the full company of 13 dancers.

title: Harry and the Hobbit: Wizardry in the Timing
description: OF all the literary and cinematic genres, fantasy ought to come closest to plumbing the depths of the human mind. Its rules are the rules of dreams, its monsters the stuff of nightmares. But with rare exceptions the 1933 ''King Kong'' comes to mind few live-action fantasy films have taken full advantage of the genre's possibilities. The release of two eagerly anticipated fantasy films, ''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring'' and ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone,'' may change all that, making this the winter of the wizard.

title: THE NEW SEASON/CLASSICAL MUSIC: Heights to Be Scaled And Peaks to Revisit; A Pianist of Modernist Flair
description: SOME musical events are exciting to anticipate because you already have a good idea what they will be like. I know that James Levine conducting Berg's ''Wozzeck'' and ''Lulu'' at the Metropolitan Opera this season will be tremendous, because I have heard him conduct them before, several times each. I think I can even imagine what Elliott Carter's new Cello Concerto for Yo-Yo Ma and the Chicago Symphony will be like: ingenious and engrossing.

title: You Can Love Him Tender, But Not for His Acting
description: FORTY-FIVE years ago, Elvis Presley made his first movie, a musical Civil War drama in which he marries his dead brother's girlfriend and later finds out his dead brother is alive. That Civil War caused people so much trouble! The movie was called ''Love Me Tender.'' It features the song of the same name for which Elvis, in a mind-boggling collaboration, wrote the lyrics to a Stephen Foster melody. Elvis knew so little about moviemaking that when he arrived for the first day of shooting, he had memorized not only his dialogue but also the entire script. By 1969, when he walked through ''Charro,'' a western so execrable that the horses look embarrassed, he does not appear to have learned even his own lines.

The music makers are upset about a state law that binds artists to long-term contracts, which they say give too much power to the recording companies who distribute their music.

title: 'All Id' and Proud of It, Macy Gray Sings On
description: MACY GRAY can be a pretty good liar. On a recent Saturday night in New York City, giving an interview at an Upper East Side bistro, she was asked what she'd do afterward. ''I'm going to go home to the hotel,'' she deadpanned in her scratchy, sibilant voice. ''I'll drink my vitamin B-12 drink and my vitamin C and watch the science channel, and then I'm going to read the Bible. This is my 30th time reading the Bible. And I'm going to go to sleep and get up in the morning and exercise, and have an apple. That's pretty much the way I live.''

title: SELF-DEFINITION; Garden Party
description: Comparisons between Laura Bush and Hillary Clinton were inevitable. New presidents are judged against the promises they made while campaigning, but with little or no public record of their own, first ladies are measured against a different yardstick: the legacy of their predecessor. As inevitable as the comparisons are, however, they are also irrelevant. Each first lady, depending wholly on her temperament and inclinations, puts her unique stamp on the position -- one that remains as undefined today as it was in the early days of the Republic, when she was sometimes called ''presidentress'' or ''Mrs. President.''

What she discovered was that she shared a kinship, as she put it, ''a kind of identification with all parts of the continent.''

title: Sept. 2-8; Back to School

In Belfast, a Protestant paramilitary group threw a homemade bomb as Catholic girls tried to make their way to school; four policemen were hurt. And as Israelis and Palestinians continued to trade fatal fire, thousands of Israeli children traveled fearfully to school in armored vehicles. Brian Lavery

description: Information about every building in the database of the New York City Department of Buildings is now available online free of charge at the agency's Web site, www.NYC.gov/buildings.

title: Letting Go
description: When I was 18, I fell in love with a musician who lived in another country. He would send me presents -- a doll, a Fatima Zorro 45, a small, bony lump of gold (from someone's tooth?), a water gun -- that he bought in the Arab flea market near his house. One day he wrote and told me to destroy them all. He had decided his gifts weren't good enough for me. I loved them, but I threw them away anyway. He'd given me a command, and that was more personal than any record or doll. I had to follow it.

If they are deemed guilty, the case will go to a larger panel for a final verdict -- and then for review by the Taliban's supreme leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar. Sixteen Afghans will be tried later. Barry Bearak

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAINER, SHIRLEY
description: WAINER-Shirley, 86. Of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, passed away suddenly on September 6, 2001. Survived by her son, Paul Feinstein, & his wife Martha; daughter, Lorna Sarrel & her husband Philip; grandchildren Emily & Samantha Feinstein, Laura Robertson, Marc Sarrel and Jennifer Voelker; and great-grandchild, Evan Voelker. She survived three husbands, Bertram Feinstein, Louis Rudolph, and Harry Wainer. She was a truly exceptional and beloved woman who made important contributions to her community, particularly in her later years in Florida. She was an indefatigable fundraiser for charities, especially Jewish Federation. She served as campaign chair for the Woodlands Women's Division, was President and a director of the Women's Division of Greater Fort Lauderdale from 1994 to 1996 and was honored by them for her outstanding work. She was on the Board of Directors of Jewish Federation, Greater Fort Lauderdale and then the newly formed Broward County Board. She helped to establish Friends For Life in the Woodlands community. Funeral service on Sunday, September 9th, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. 212-362-6600. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, SAMUEL W., JR.
description: MURPHY-Samuel W., Jr. 73, of Menauhant, MA, and Boca Grande, FL, died peacefully on September 7, from a stroke. Loving husband of Barbara (Boyer) Murphy; father to Constance Perna of Redding, CT, Samuel III of Woodland, MN, and Rebecca Flynn of Owings Mills, MD, and grandfather to Andrew, Ellen, Matthew, Jeffrey and Cort. He was with the law firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton and Irvine, where he became Senior Partner; was General Counsel at both Gulf Oil and RCA, and President of the Gasparilla Island Conservation and Improvement Association. He was noted as a top corporate litigator and for his pro bono work representing death row inmates. His strength of character and integrity was noted by all. There will be a service Saturday, September 15, at 4 PM, at the Grace Memorial Chapel in Menauhant, Massachusetts. The family requests donations be sent in his honor to the conservation fund of the Gasparilla Island Conservation and Improvement Association, Box 446, Boca Grande, FL 33921, or to a charity of your choice.

She was wearing turquoise patent leather stilettos, clutching a turquoise traveling bag and looked to be in a terrible rush. She was being followed by a Rolls-Royce (and a camera, of course). When the video in which these events took place was finished, the lights came up at the Heatherette show in the Chelsea club Twirl, and the woman who used to be a man came tearing in from stage left. She ran down an improvised catwalk, posed for a clutch of press photographers and then -- naked, painted pink, yellow hair, turquoise shoes -- demurely took a seat in the front row.

title: Power Politics in the Senate

The House of Representatives swallowed the Cheney-Bush scenario whole and produced an alarmingly unbalanced energy bill with $33 billion in tax breaks -- $27 billion for traditional energy producers, only $6 billion for conservation.

title: Omnicom Acquires Davie Brown
description: In another effort by Madison Avenue to expand its services in the growing fields of product placement and entertainment promotion, the Omnicom Group in New York has acquired Davie Brown Entertainment in West Los Angeles, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: At Odds With Europe
description: In a reflection of the government's hardening attitude toward its possible European Union membership, Foreign Minister Ismail Cem refused to give ground in disputes over Cyprus and a European defense force. The European Union wants Turkey to press Turkish Cypriots to resume talks over the division of Cyprus and to drop its veto of the use of NATO assets by the planned union defense force. Mr. Cem said Turkey, a NATO member, would not compromise regardless of the effect on its candidacy to join the union. Doug Frantz (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Airlines Block Rules On Pilots' Hours
description: A plan by the Federal Aviation Administration to strictly enforce rules on the number of continuous hours a pilot may work has been blocked by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, on a motion by the airlines. The F.A.A. said in May that it would give the airlines six months to reform their schedules to ensure that pilots had a minimum of 8 hours rest in any 24-hour period or they would have to delay their next flight. The agency said this was a re-statement of existing rules, but the airlines said the F.A.A. had changed its rules without soliciting comment from them, and they sued. The airlines asked that the agency's interpretation of its rules be thrown out, along with its plan to conduct strict enforcement. A three-judge panel stayed the strict enforcement, pending a hearing in January. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bidding For Tempus
description: The advertising concern, WPP Group, sent its official takeover proposal for Tempus, a British media buying concern, to Tempus's shareholders, as a rival bidder, Havas Advertising of France, considered its options. Havas will have 46 days to raise its offer for Tempus, and is expected to take some time before making a decision, people close to the negotiations said. WPP Group, the large British advertising firm run by Sir Martin Sorrell, offered 5.55 a share, or 434 million ($634 million) for Tempus last month, exceeding Havas's earlier bid of 425 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Disco Near Auschwitz To Close
description: The owner of a building now used as a disco but once a tannery where Nazis sorted the luggage and clothes of Jews at Auschwitz said he would not renew the club's lease when it expires in November. Jewish groups and the government protested the disco's location in the town of Oswiecim as being too close to the death camps Auschwitz and Birkenau, where an estimated 1.5 million Jews died during World War II. The owner said a shopping center, and a plaque memorializing the victims, would be built in place of the disco. Ian Fisher (NYT)

description: Two or three times a week, 9-year-old Lauren Ross of Biloxi, Miss., goes through an intensive exercise routine designed by her father.

title: Foreplay That's So Funny, Sex Is Just Superfluous
description: Time is doing us in more quickly than it used to. In 1988, when Howard Korder's play ''Boys' Life'' first appeared, it came across as a mordant satire on the flabby selfishness of modern young men's search for emotional safety and sexual satisfaction with women -- in that order. Only 13 years later, whole patches of its once-resonant dialogue can leave you wondering what the play is all about.

description: To hear commercial fishermen tell it, fishing curbs are leaving sharks free to prey on bathers.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Ellen Abramowitz, associate publisher at Seventeen magazine, New York, was named publisher at Teen magazine, part of the Teen Magazines group at Primedia. She succeeds Beth Press, who left, the company said, to pursue other interests. In addition, Lauren Fisher, associate publisher at Soap Opera Digest and Soap Opera Weekly, part of the consumer group unit of Primedia, was named to the new post of publisher at the Youth Entertainment Group, including Bop, Tiger Beat and Teen Beat magazines.

title: Violence in Mideast, Despite Plans to Talk
description: With truce talks tentatively set for today, Palestinians and Israelis did not wait for dawn to resume their all-but-declared war. Two Israeli soldiers were slain by Palestinian snipers near the checkpoint separating the Palestinian town of Tulkarm from Israel, and soon Israeli tanks were ringing Jenin, also in the West Bank, shelling Palestinian positions outside the town.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Hearing On Property Measure Begins
description: The State Supreme Court began hearing arguments on the constitutionality of Measure 7, an initiative approved by voters that would force local governments to compensate private property owners for regulations that adversely affect the value of their land. Local governments say the measure would put a heavy price on regulations. The court heard arguments from local governments and the measure's proponents about whether the initiative was adequately presented to voters as a constitutional amendment. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Steel Maker
description: Europe's third-largest steel maker, the Corus Group, said its first-half loss more than doubled as production cuts failed to stem a one-third decline in the price of carbon steel in the last year. The company reported a net loss excluding one-time items of 195 million ($285 million), compared with a loss of 72 million a year earlier. Corus, formerly British Steel, last turned a profit in 1998. Tony Peder, the chief executive, said the company, which has announced large layoffs to offset the economic downturn, does not expect a turnaround until 2002.

title: Stalinist's Disputed Victory in Belarus Vote Is Denounced
description: With the prominent exception of Russia, foreign leaders, diplomats and human rights groups today condemned the officially overwhelming re-election of Europe's last Stalinist leader, President Aleksandr Lukashenko of Belarus, as fundamentally flawed. Several said the outcome was destined to ostracize still further a nation already shunned by much of the democratic world.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cisco and Verizon In Deal
description: Cisco Systems and Verizon said they were teaming up to provide high-speed Internet services for employees working at home. The companies said they would focus on Fortune 1000 companies and governments seeking network access at home and the office. Cisco said it would provide equipment from the Cisco 800 and SOHO product lines, while Verizon would provide service over a network. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Guilty Plea In Loan Fraud
description: A Brooklyn man has pleaded guilty to federal fraud charges for being part of a group that prosecutors said bilked hundreds of people out of more than $500,000 by collecting advance fees for promised loans that were never made. The United States attorney's office in Manhattan said yesterday that the man, Michael Castellano, admitted in his plea on Friday that he ''never had any intention of issuing any loans'' to the victims, who had responded to advertisements offering loans to people with poor credit histories. The advance fees ranged up to about $3,000 during the eight-year scheme, according to court papers. Mr. Castellano, 35, faces up to 15 years in prison and up to $1.5 million in fines, the prosecutor's office said. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, WILLIAM I.
description: SPENCER - William I. The Trustees, faculty and staff of NYU Medical Center mourn the passing of William I. Spencer, a Life Trustee, valued friend and a generous benefactor. A successful businessman and a leader in the financial industry, Mr. Spencer was elected to the Medical Center Board of Trustees in 1969 and was appointed a Life Trustee in 1995. He was an esteemed and active member of the Board who offered leadership and vision by serving as Executive Vice Chairman of the Board and as a member of key committees. Mr. Spencer's tenure as a Trustee was marked by many acts of generosity including the establishment of the Susan and William Spencer Scholarship Fund to help support medical education. Mr. Spencer's warm and gracious personality, his dedication and his strong support earned the enduring respect and admiration of his fellow trustees and the entire medical center cummunity. Mr. Spencer will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Susan, his family and the many people who were fortunate to know him as a friend. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman NYU School of Medicine Foundation Board of Trustees and NYU Hospitals Center Board of Trustees Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean, NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff, President, NYU Hospitals Center

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Goto.com Changing Name
description: Trying to separate itself from other sites, the Internet search service GoTo.com said yesterday that it would change its name to Overture Services. The company, which is based in Pasadena, Calif., will also change its site on the World Wide Web to www.overture.com and its stock symbol to OVER beginning Oct. 8. A spokeswoman for GoTo.com attributed the change to the crowded field of Internet companies using the word ''go,'' including Go.com, Go2Net.com and Go2 System. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: NIKE TO CREATE PANEL ON LABOR AND ENVIRONMENT
description: Nike Inc. will create a committee to oversee the company's labor, environmental and diversity policies. Jill Ker Conway, 66, a Nike director and a visiting scholar at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's program in science, technology and society, will lead the committee, the company said. Nike, the biggest maker of athletic shoes, is trying to address complaints that its factories engaged in unfair labor practices, like hiring child labor. The panel will be called the Corporate Responsibility Committee.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Africa: Coffee Growers Form Group
description: Six coffee-growing countries in East Africa have formed a private organization to market their product to American and European consumers. The group, called the Eastern African Fine Coffee Association, is made up of Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi, Rwanda and Ethiopia. Based in Kampala, Uganda, the association will seek to increase the sale of coffee from the region. Kenya is one of the oldest coffee producers yet it represents only 2 percent of the world market. Marc Lacey (NYT)

description: Thirty years after a black-power revolutionary hijacked a jetliner from Ontario to Cuba and disappeared, Canadian and federal authorities matched the fingerprints he left on a can of ginger ale in the airplane with those of a teacher in Westchester County and charged the teacher with the crime yesterday.

title: Caution On Sehorn
description: Cornerback Jason Sehorn's absence from tonight's game means Sehorn may also miss next week's game against Green Bay as he recovers from arthroscopic surgery performed Aug. 27. The procedure removed debris from Sehorn's right knee, which had been surgically rebuilt in 1998. The knee had swelled mysteriously during training camp last month, although Sehorn said he was not in pain. Immediately after the surgery to flush the knee of the debris, the Giants said Sehorn would be able to play in the opening game, and as late as Saturday, the team was still listing him as probable for the Denver game. But two weeks was an optimistic estimate, and Sehorn did not progress as quickly as hoped.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Sri Lanka: Politics Won't Stop Peace Effort
description: The government said a deal it made for the support of a small Marxist party would not hamper its efforts to start talks with separatist Tamil rebels. Foreign Minister Lakshman Kadirgamar said the government was consulting Norway about how to get the peace process moving. The rebels recently rejected talking to a government that it described as unstable and insincere, and the Marxist party, which the government needs to survive in power, opposes any talks brokered by Norway. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: MICHELIN TO CUT 2,000 JOBS IN NORTH AMERICA
description: Michelin North America said yesterday that it would cut 2,000 jobs, or about 7 percent of its work force, citing a downturn in tire markets and the need to increase its long-term competitiveness. The company hopes to complete much of the reduction through normal attrition and voluntary severance programs, Michelin said. The moves will affect employment at the company's plants in Granton, Bridgewater and Waterville, Nova Scotia, and Kitchener, Ontario. The job cuts had been expected for months after Michelin North America announced this spring it would cut $125 million in operating costs. The company, a subsidiary of Michelin of France, has since announced it needs to cut costs by an additional $75 million.

title: Buckyball Success May Lead the Way to Practical New Superconductors
description: In a surprise to many, molecules of carbon in the shape of soccer balls have been turned into superconductors that can carry electricity with virtually no resistance at temperatures higher than even many of the so-called high-temperature superconductors.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - An airliner crashed into the Pentagon, the massive building that is the very symbol of the American military establishment, today about an hour after the conflagration began at the World Trade Center in New York. The attack on the military complex killed dozens of people, injured many more and brought an immediate shutdown of the government.

title: The Politics of Panic
description: The summer has barely ended, but President Bush and his Congressional allies are already frantically rewriting their script for the fall. This was supposed to be a season for Mr. Bush to talk about ''values,'' not fiscal policy. But with a sinking economy, evanescing surplus and tottering budget, Republicans are going back to the drawing board. Some, like Trent Lott, the Senate minority leader, want to cut the capital gains tax. House Republicans are talking about broad spending cuts. The White House says Mr. Bush would listen to these and other ideas to revive the economy. There is a whiff of panic in the air, and panic can lead to bad policy.

title: There Is Ryan, There Is Clemens, Then There Is Everbody Else
description: Roger Clemens would have to pitch for another nine seasons to match Nolan Ryan for major league longevity, but what Clemens has done this season has already matched Ryan for a remarkable performance by an old pitcher.

title: COSTA RICA INVESTIGATING COCA-COLA AND BOTTLER
description: The Coca-Cola Company and Panamerican Beverages Inc. are being investigated by Costa Rica's antitrust commission to determine if they engaged in illegal sales practices to shut out competitors. The investigation follows a complaint by PepsiCo Inc. and three other beverage companies in Costa Rica. The complaint said Coca-Cola and its bottler, Panamerican, sought to squeeze competition through exclusive agreements with retailers, the commission said. Panamerican Beverages, Latin America's biggest bottler, and Coca-Cola could be fined as much as 10 percent of their annual sales in Costa Rica if found in violation.

title: Cutting a Conscience And, Oh Yes, Clothes
description: When did frivolity become a sin in fashion? What happened to the times when, in stylish circles, otherwise competent adults could be heard to utter such delightfully blithe inanities as, ''Now that's a sleeve?'' In the director Douglas Keeve's documentary ''Unzipped,'' Isaac Mizrahi both embodied and, one hoped, satirized himself as the quintessential flibbertigibbet, swanning around with his curls in a do-rag, his wrist exaggeratedly cocked, and with a gravity defying ash tilting from the tip of his Marlboro Light.

description: One of the country's best professional bass anglers, a former Bronx teacher, was talking about some colleagues in an ice-fishing tournament last year who were thrown into the rough waters of Lake Erie when the ice collapsed. And what happened? ''They kept fishing,'' said Judy Israel, ''until someone rescued them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, JAMES JOSEPH JR.
description: RYAN-James Joseph Jr., 58, of Little Silver, NJ on September 10, 2001. Husband of Roberta (nee Pisani), father of James J. III, Kimberly Ann Ryan and Mrs. Elizabeth Ryan Benedict. Grandfather of Coleman J. Benedict, III. Brother of Timothy Ryan. Senior Vice President of GMS Group, Livingston, NJ. Visitation Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9pm at the Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad St., Red Bank, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10am Holy Cross R.C. Church, Rumson, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society, Broad St., Shrewsbury, NJ 07702 are preferred.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Korea: Gas Pipeline Study
description: Engineers from North and South Korea will work together on a feasibility study of a pipeline that would deliver natural gas from Siberia, through northeastern China, and on to North and South Korea. North Korea's National Economic Cooperation Federation agreed on the joint study in talks in Pyongyang last week with a six-man delegation from the South, according to South Korea's commerce, industry and energy ministry. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Taxpaying Young Look for Gift Pony
description: The Treasury Department is considering letting some children take advantage of the tax break that resulted in a $300 rebate check this year for most other income-tax payers.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Stress Fracture Leaves O'Neill's Status in Doubt
description: Paul O'Neill limped around the Yankees' clubhouse with a stress fracture in his left foot yesterday, wearing a protective boot. Derek Jeter walked and called it progress. Chuck Knoblauch nursed a strain in his rib cage.

title: Dutch Phone Executive Resigns After 18 Months
description: The excesses of Europe's rush to build new digital wireless networks claimed another casualty today, when the chief executive of Royal KPN, the Netherlands' debt-laden telephone company, abruptly resigned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN MENTS, MARION (WOLF)
description: van MENTS-Marion (Wolf). Of NYC on September 8, wife of the late Henry, sister of the late Loni Katz of Forest Hills & Ilse Boraks of Boston, beloved aunt of Elaine Kadets and Steven Boraks of Boston. Funeral service Wednesday 2PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SYLVAN M., ESQUIRE
description: COHEN-Sylvan M., Esquire. ICSC, its Trustees, Staff and Members mourn the passing of our beloved Trustee, friend and shopping center pioneer. A founding member, ICSC Chairman 1976-1977, member of the Law Conference Committee, Chairman of the Government Affairs Committee and Chairman of the Political Action Committee, Sylvan was one of the earliest recipients of the ICSC Trustees Distinguished Service Award. If a life can be described in two words, then ''distinguished'' and ''service'' are the ones for Sylvan Cohen. We send our heartfelt sympathy to his wonderful family on their loss. Michael Kercheval, President John Riordan, Vice Chairman International Council of Shopping Centers

title: BANKATLANTIC AGREES TO BUY COMMUNITY SAVINGS
description: The BankAtlantic Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Community Savings Bankshares Inc. for $170 million in cash to become the largest Florida-based bank. BankAtlantic, based in Fort Lauderdale, will pay Community Savings shareholders $19 a share. That represents a 31 percent premium to Community Savings' closing share price Friday. BankAtlantic shares rose 6 cents, to $9.09, today and Community Savings shares increased $4.12, to $18.62. The 21 branches, $948 million in assets and $670 million in deposits of Community Savings will give BankAtlantic a total of $5.7 billion in assets, $3.1 billion in deposits and 82 branches in Florida.

title: Lasting Effects of Bullying Observed
description: A new Australian study has found that adolescents who are bullied, especially girls, are more likely to develop emotional problems.

title: Wall Street Is Slim Pickings for M.B.A. Class of '02
description: Second-year M.B.A. students are used to receiving signing bonuses and Wall Street job offers during the fall semester. But these days, just landing an interview slot is considered a coup.

title: High and Dry in Denver
description: The Denver Broncos tonight welcomed more than 75,000 of their fans to celebrate the opening of their new football palace, Invesco Field at Mile High. They also welcomed the Giants, an opponent obliged to attend by the National Football League schedule makers.

title: Where Styles, Generations And Politics Happily Meet
description: Puerto Rican pride and New York City innovation danced into the night at the 26th annual New York Salsa Festival on Saturday at Madison Square Garden. The concert doubled as a political rally, with appearances by candidates for mayor (Fernando Ferrer) and City Council (Felipe Luciano) and a performance by Willie Coln, the only candidate for public advocate who sings, plays trombone and has been transforming Caribbean music for decades.

title: DELTA FLIGHT ATTENDANTS TO VOTE ON UNION
description: Delta Air Lines flight attendants will be able to vote on whether to join a union, the Association of Flight Attendants said. The National Mediation Board which oversees labor relations in the industry, said that at least 35 percent of the 20,000 attendants at the airline had signed cards seeking a representation election, the union said. The association petitioned the board last month for an election at Delta, the only major carrier at which attendants are not represented by a union. Delta is based in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAJEWICZ, ANNE
description: SAJEWICZ-Anne. On Sept. 7, 2001, in her 88th year. Predeceased by her sister Mary. Visitation Wednesday, 6-9 PM, John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave., NYC. Mass of Christian burial on Thursday, 9:30 AM at St. Stanislaus Church, 101 East 7th Street. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHONBERG, GEORGE
description: SCHONBERG-George 5/26/22-9/11/95. Gone 6 years, so absent-so present. Love always Dori

title: Fetal Tissue Implanted Safely, Doctors Say
description: Researchers at the University of Florida reported today that transplanting human embryonic or fetal tissue into people with spinal cord injuries appeared to be safe.

title: Simple Strategies for a Choke-Proof Home
description: When my son asked me what his 14-month-old twin sons had eaten while I was baby-sitting, I rattled off the food he had left for them, then added that they had also eaten some of my yogurt and prunes. ''Prunes!'' he exclaimed in horror. ''You gave them prunes? They could choke on prunes!''

title: Arsenic Standard for Water Is Too Lax, Study Concludes
description: The National Academy of Sciences has concluded that arsenic is so dangerous in drinking water that stringent levels set by the Clinton administration and later suspended by the Bush White House were justified but perhaps not strict enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, ADELE
description: BRODY-Adele. A remarkable woman, vivacious, intelligent and witty, generous and concerned, brave and beautiful, memorable to all who met her. Her many friends will miss her companionship. Wife of the late Andrew Brody for 49 years. Mother of Cora B. Marcus and Ellen K. Brody. Grandmother of Ezra A. Marcus, Joseph W. Marcus and Amy M. Savath, who will always feel the loss but will cherish the years and memories. She made a difference. Memorial service at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11:30 AM, Wednesday, September 12.

title: In a Nation of Early Risers, Morning TV Is a Hot Market
description: How much morning television can one nation watch?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Two Shot After Dispute
description: A gunman fired on a man and a woman inside a garage at Lefrak City last night after a dispute, the police said. The wounded couple were inside a car that then sped out of the garage and collided with another car at the corner of 57th Avenue and 97th Street. The man, whose name was not released but who the police said is 32 years old, was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center in critical condition with a gunshot wound to the chest. The woman, 21, also unidentified, was in serious condition with a wound to her face, the police said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANSOHN, ELIZABETH
description: EVANSOHN-Elizabeth. Your husband, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren will carry their love for you to the end of time. Jacob Evansohn

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Governing Party Falters
description: The governing Labor Party suffered a serious setback in national elections, gathering about one-fourth of the vote and causing speculation that the Conservative Party or the centrist Christian Democratic Party would lead a weak coalition government when Parliament returns next month. Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg said he would not resign immediately as a result of his party's worst showing in decades, but would wait to see how the other seven parties lined up. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: Primary Choices
description: This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County today. All are Democratic primary choices except for the borough presidency in Staten Island, where there is only a Republican primary. Poll hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.
