description: LAZERWITZ-Beverly. Truly a valiant woman. On September 9, 2001. Beloved wife of Miles. Adored mother of Alison, Michael and Larry. Mother-in-law of Ali and Jennifer. Grandmother of Catherine, Emily, Sam, Claire, Max and Harry. She was a great and wonderful friend to all those she cared for and will be missed by all whose lives she touched. Services today, 1:30PM Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W. 150 Route 4 (East), Paramus, N.J. Donations may be made to Gilda's Club Worldwide, 95 Madison Ave, Suite 609, N.Y., N.Y. 10016.

title: Plane Crashes Collapse World Trade Center Towers
description: Within a span of 18 minutes, planes crashed into each of the twin towers of the World Trade Center in Manhattan soon after 9 this morning in what President Bush said in a short announcement was "a national tragedy and an apparent act of terrorism against our country."

title: Behind a Political Brawler, a Bare-Knuckles Past
description: WE all cultivate an image, one we peddle to the world to define and promote ourselves. It gives those around us a quick, easy-to-read version of a complex and fickle existence. One of the city's master image peddlers is Hank Sheinkopf, a political consultant who has his fingers in a slew of primary races, including that of the mayoral candidate Mark Green.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURELL, EVELYN R.
description: TURELL-Evelyn R. On Sept. 9, 2001. Wife of the late Dr. Robert Turell. Mother of Mikal Berry Buscher. Sister of Helene Katzen. Grandmother of Ian Berry and Alina Lentz. Great-grandmother of Jonathan. Aunt of Jacqueline Katzen and great-aunt of Corina. Funeral service on Tuesday 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Entombment to follow at the Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: arrests Trouble U.S. Envoy
description: President Bush's special envoy to Northern Ireland, Richard Haass, said he would raise last month's arrest in Colombia of three suspected Irish Republican Army men charged with giving weapons instruction to guerrillas there when he meets with Gerry Adams, president of the I.R.A.'s political wing. Mr. Haass, who said the United States had ''important national interests'' in Colombia, spoke after meeting Britain's Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, in London. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Larry Gilbert; Plotting an Aerial Attack On Marauding Fire Ants
description: On a recent morning, Dr. Lawrence E. Gilbert, a professor of integrative biology at the University of Texas and director of its Brackenridge Field Laboratory, was standing over a glass tank at in his office, watching a swarm of Brazilian phorid flies make buzzing attacks on some very unhappy South American fire ants.

title: Paris Journal; Petition in Hand, Chirac's Pursuer Gains Ground
description: Last spring, a young Socialist legislator, Arnaud Montebourg, spent his days wandering the cramped halls of the office buildings behind France's National Assembly, leaving behind what came to be known as ''Le coupon.''

title: Toward a Chicago Open To Sances and Masks
description: If you make your living running a dating service or a matchmaking business, better stay out of Chicago. Anyone who accepts a fee to ''promote a marriage between a man and a woman'' is breaking city law.

title: Polling Information
description: For questions about voting eligibility or to determine your district or polling place in New York City, call the City Board of Elections: (212) VOTE-NYC.

title: Teachers Threaten to Strike At 10 Catholic High Schools
description: Teachers at 10 Catholic high schools in New York City and its suburbs have threatened to go on strike as early as today, charging that the Archdiocese of New York has ignored their demand for a steep raise and delayed negotiations.

title: National Briefing | Northeast: Massachusetts: Lawyer Challenges F.B.I.
description: A lawyer for a North Carolina bank robbery suspect charged with killing three men in Massachusetts and New Hampshire said there was evidence that his client, Gary Sampson, left, called the Boston office of the F.B.I. offering to turn himself in the day before the slayings began. The lawyer, Stephanie Paige, said she would ask a judge to force the F.B.I. and the Verizon telephone company to turn over records of a call she said Mr. Sampson made on July 23. An F.B.I. spokeswoman said the bureau was investigating the matter. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: U.N. Certifies First Election In the Newly Born East Timor
description: The United Nations today certified the results of East Timor's first democratic election, and a newly chosen constituent assembly prepared to start drafting a Constitution that will set the stage for full independence.

title: Blasts Deal Blow to Northeast Phone Services
description: The explosions in Manhattan and Washington prompted significant disruptions in telephone service in the Northeast region. Major telecommunications carriers said that most of the interruptions were caused not by physical damage but by network overloads caused by extraordinary numbers of people trying to make calls at once.

title: Clemens Must Wait Another Day
description: Roger Clemens's quest to become the first pitcher to ever achieve a 20-1 record was delayed by a day, after the Yankees' home game against the Boston Red Sox last night was rained out. Clemens will pitch against Chicago tonight. ''We'll try it against the other Sox tomorrow,'' said Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager.

title: Spoiling the Broth
description: When Frank Flynn, a Columbia University professor of organizational behavior, drafted a fictitious letter to 240 New York restaurants, he did so in the hope of studying ''vendor response to consumer complaints.'' The letter stated that he had been stricken with ''extended nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal cramps'' in each of the restaurants after a wedding anniversary dinner. Those symptoms were nothing compared with the headache Professor Flynn must have had last week when he realized how badly his research had gone awry. His letter caused a reign of terror in many of the city's top restaurants, as management tried to ferret out the culprits. If his subject had been culinary paranoia or perhaps the temper of the high-profile chef, the letter would have been perfectly crafted.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline's Woes Continue
description: Air Transat, the Canadian charter company whose Airbus ran out of fuel in both engines near the Azores last month, had several mishaps over the weekend. On Saturday night, a flight from Toronto to Paris was held up for three hours because of a fuel spill and passengers were transferred to another aircraft. Late on Friday, two other Air Transat flights were delayed by mechanical problems. The airline said it was hiring more maintenance instructors. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: School Dress Codes vs. a Sea of Bare Flesh
description: In the tumult of bare skin that is the hallway of Millburn High School, Michele Pitts is the Enforcer.

description: DALSIMER-Dorothy. Loving widow of Philip, active and devoted mother, caring and supportive grandmother, adoring great grandmother, a sister and good friend of many, died September 9, 2001 at a youthful 88. She was a cherished part of our lives. Memorial service to be held Sunday, October 21, 1:00 PM at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation for the South Fork, Water Mill, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to the Peconic Land Trust, Southampton, NY, or the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of the South Fork, Building Fund, Water Mill, NY 11976.

description: To the Editor:

title: City Voters Have Heard It All As Campaign Din Nears End
description: The first time the phone rang, Victoria Ehigiator was elbow deep in a sink of soapy dishes. She dried her hands and picked up the phone. It was Al Sharpton on the line, calling about the primary election. He said his piece, and she went back to the dishes. A few minutes later, the phone rang again, and she lifted herself from the bubbles once more.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Rating Falls
description: Standard & Poor's has lowered the credit rating for Hynix Semiconductor while creditors debate a proposal to exchange nearly $3 billion in debt for equity and provide another $1 billion in new loans. An official with the agency said the company needed $2 billion in new operations just to keep up with the competition, notably Samsung Electronics and Micron Technologies, which are first and second worldwide in memory chip production. Hynix stock, however, rose 8.5 percent on the Korea Stock Exchange, closing at 1,400 won, up 75 percent in a week. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Buffalo Still Shines
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 INVESTOR GROUPS TO BUY AMERICAN COIN MERCHANDISING
description: American Coin Merchandising Inc., the owner of vending machines that dispense stuffed animals, watches and jewelry, agreed to be bought for $55 million by two investment companies, Wellspring Capital Management L.L.C. and Knightsbridge Holdings L.L.C. The companies will pay $8.50 a share for American Coin's 6.5 million shares outstanding, or about $55.3 million, the chief executive, Randall Fagundo, said. The purchase price is 43 percent more than American Coin's closing price of $5.96 on Friday. American Coin and its franchises service more than 26,000 vending machines in retail stores, Mr. Fagundo said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAUER, HYMAN
description: KNAUER-Hyman. The partners and employees at Thurm and Heller express their sincere sympathy to Mr. Edward Knauer and family on the death of his father, Hyman Knauer.

title: X-Ray Orbiter Becomes a Particle Physics Experiment
description: Scientists launched NASA's Chandra X-Ray Observatory so that, as the name implies, the observatory could probe regions in the cosmos that are hot or violent enough to emit X-rays, which are blocked by Earth's atmosphere. Two years later, Chandra is looking a lot like an orbiting particle-physics experiment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARRETT, SCOT
description: SHARRETT-Scot. Beloved son, brother, friend, gifted musician and mentor, died Sunday September 2, 2001. Donations can be made in Scot's memory to: NYU School of Continuing & Professional Studies or The North Shore Animal League.

title: Pinault Wins Long Battle To Control Gucci Group
description: Ending one of the most bitter fights in corporate history, the French billionaire Franois Pinault took effective control of the Gucci Group today with an agreement to buy much of the stake held by the rival tycoon Bernard Arnault.

title: No Regrets for a Love Of Explosives; In a Memoir of Sorts, a War Protester Talks of Life With the Weathermen
description: ''I don't regret setting bombs,'' Bill Ayers said. ''I feel we didn't do enough.'' Mr. Ayers, who spent the 1970's as a fugitive in the Weather Underground, was sitting in the kitchen of his big turn-of-the-19th-century stone house in the Hyde Park district of Chicago. The long curly locks in his Wanted poster are shorn, though he wears earrings. He still has tattooed on his neck the rainbow-and-lightning Weathermen logo that appeared on letters taking responsibility for bombings. And he still has the ebullient, ingratiating manner, the apparently intense interest in other people, that made him a charismatic figure in the radical student movement.

title: Time Wears Heavily on Wife Of a Man Detained in China
description: Limping slightly with one finger in a splint and her right eye blood-tinged, Sylvia Fong looks as if she has been the victim of a mugging. Standing in the living room of her impeccable split-level house here, she apologizes to a visitor for her appearance. ''I keep falling and hurting myself,'' she says, her voice stripped of emotion. ''I've been very absent-minded lately.''

title: Interpublic Units Get Bigger Roles
description: Two large advertisers are expanding relationships with units of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Despite Plan for Talks, Mideast Violence Explodes
description: With truce talks tentatively planned for later today, Palestinians and Israelis did not wait for dawn to resume their all-but-declared war.

title: Jet Defense Goes Back To School
description: With visions of missed tackles, blown assignments, cushions as big as mattresses on the Colts' receivers, and Edgerrin James, still fresh from Sunday's 45-24 shellacking, the Jets began the process of rejuvenating the defense today, knowing that the Oakland Raiders loom next week.

title: The Big City; Check, Please. And for You, Here's My Bill.
description: LEAN times have come to corporate America, but you would never know it from Ethan Casey's expense account. Mr. Casey has not been intimidated by the memos on cutting costs. He is not afraid of bean-counters and belt-tighteners. He is the man with the golden bag.

title: Russian Defense Chief Stresses Opposition to Antimissile Plan
description: Ronald Reagan liked to say, ''Trust, but verify,'' in a world that bristled -- and still does -- with nuclear weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESSLER, MARTIN J.
description: BRESSLER-Martin J. Attorney, 53, died on September 8, of cancer at home in New York, surrounded by his beloved family. Survived by his wife and best friend, Jane, children Amy, Lee, and Scott, parents Anne and David, sisters Bonnie Bressler and June Osterman, and parents-in-law Hannah and Norbert Blechner. A devoted and adoring husband and father, his passion, humor, and loyalty will be eternally missed. ''And you, my father, there on the sad height, curse, bless me now with your fierce tears, I pray. Do not go gentle into that good night. Rage, rage against the dying of the light.'' Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, Monday, September 10, 11:45 AM.

title: California Energy Crisis Hits Scottish Power
description: Scottish Power said today that it had miscalculated so badly in the California power shortages and the resulting wild swings in American energy prices that it would have to take a $300 million charge to cover its losses. The company is Britain's biggest electric utility and owns PacifiCorp, which serves 1.5 million customers in eight Western states.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONOCO INC., Houston, the fifth-biggest oil company in the U.S., said that Schlumberger Ltd., New York, the second-biggest oil field services company, would run its computer systems for about $300 million for six years.

title: Rape Charges Against Mayor Of Waterbury
description: State prosecutors today charged Philip A. Giordano, the imprisoned three-term mayor of Waterbury, with raping two young girls, ages 9 and 10, with whom he is accused of having repeated sexual encounters earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKENSTEIN, DOROTHY (SHUPACK)
description: FRANKENSTEIN-Dorothy (Shupack). Passed away in her 90th year at North Shore Hospital, Forest Hills, after a recurring illness. A Brooklyn-born, New York native, she was the daughter of the late Usher and Charna Shupack. A child prodigy and unique for her time, she graduated Hunter College at age eighteen and subsequently completed her postgraduate studies at Barnard College and Columbia University as a geology scholar. She then spent her career teaching geology, under her maiden name, Dorothy Shupack, at Barnard and then Hunter and assumed administrative duties at the latter. Dorothy was married to and survived by her husband of fifty-three years, Benjamin Frankenstein, a retired electronics manufacturer wellknown for his involvement in civic affairs and activism. She is also survived by her three sons, Robert, Michael, and Charles, as well as five grandchildren all of Massachusetts. Graveside services Tuesday, September 11th, 1:20 PM at Old Montefiore Cemetery in Queens, New York. Shiva will be observed at the Frankenstein residence at Atria, 117-01 84th Avenue, Kew Gardens, 11418. For further information, call (718)441-0300.

title: Biden Opens Wide Critique Of Bush Plan For a Shield
description: Declaring a profound difference with President Bush, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., said today that plans for missile defense sacrifice national security for the sake of a ''theological'' belief -- and that the effort to make such a system work would cost astronomical amounts of money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, ROGER S.
description: STARR-Roger S. on September 10, 2001 in Easton, PA. Son of Frederick and Lillie Bernhardt Starr. Devoted husband of Joanne (Jody) W. Starr. Father of Adam, Barnaby, and the late Alexandra, father-in-law of Judy and Monica; grandfather of Robin, Zachary, Brittany, Thomas, and Luke; stepfather of Douglas Green and Patty Shaheen. Roger was a unique human being whose intelligence, thoughtfulness and good humor will be missed by all who knew him and read his work. A veteran of World War II, he served in Asia with the Office of Strategic Services. For many years Roger Starr was Executive Director of Citizens Housing & Planning Council, was Housing & Development Administrator of New York City, and was a member of the Editorial Board of The New York Times. Roger wrote numerous articles and books, and taught at Pratt Institute, City College, and New York University. After moving to Stroudsburg, PA, he was active in that community as a member of various county boards and commissions. Services will be held at noon on Thursday, September 13 at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

title: Nets Pick Tripucka As Radio Analyst
description: The Nets hired the former N.B.A. All-Star Kelly Tripucka as their radio analyst. Tripucka, who played for Detroit, Utah and Charlotte before retiring in 1991, joins Chris Carrino, who will begin his first season as New Jersey's play-by-play voice.

title: In Arena Plan, DiFrancesco Mentions Bias
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco suggested today that racism might have played a role in the collapse of plans for a downtown arena here that he had hoped would be his political legacy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Utility's Director Voted Out
description: The general director of Mosenergo, Moscow's power utility and one of the most actively traded Russian stocks, was dismissed in a vote by shareholders, according to the Unified Energy System, which is Russia's main power company and Mosenergo's biggest shareholder. Unified Energy has been calling for the general director, Alexander Remezov, to resign since conducting an audit that it said showed financial mismanagement. Mr. Remezov denied the charge and refused to step down, citing a court injunction that had banned shareholders from meeting, Russian news agencies reported. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Leaves Ireland and Britain
description: Gateway, a direct seller of personal computers, said yesterday that it would dismiss all of its 1,050 employees in Ireland and Britain as part of a plan to concentrate on sales in the United States. The company will lay off 900 workers at its Dublin plant, which also served as its European headquarters, and 150 in Britain, where it has 14 stores, a spokeswoman, Noeleen Murray, said.

title: New York Area Blood Donation Centers
description: The Red Cross is advising interested blood donors to call 1-800-GIVE-LIFE or to visit www.redcross.org . They are currently in need of types O and RH negative blood.

title: KEY LEADERS TALK OF POSSIBLE DEALS TO REVIVE ECONOMY
description: Key figures in both parties responded to the darkening economic outlook today by exploring possible compromises on additional tax cuts, and the Democratic chairman of the Senate Budget Committee suggested that such a deal could involve the politically perilous step of tapping temporarily into the Social Security surplus.

title: Times Names Andrew Rosenthal As Assistant Managing Editor
description: The appointment of Andrew Rosenthal as an assistant managing editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Howell Raines, the executive editor. Mr. Rosenthal, who was the paper's foreign editor, will coordinate daily coverage by the paper's principal news desks.

title: Physicists Strive to Build A Black Hole
description: To see black holes, those gravitational whirlpools that suck in matter and even light, you need not just a powerful telescope but a bit of imagination. You can't observe the holes themselves, just the bad effects they have on their neighborhoods: gobs of stellar matter screaming out radiation as they are pulled toward what appears to be an omnivorous, bottomless pit.

title: ASSOCIATED BANC-CORP TO BUY SIGNAL FINANCIAL
description: The Associated Banc-Corp, a leading bank in Wisconsin, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Signal Financial Corporation for $176 million to acquire more branches in Minnesota. Associated said it would pay 30 percent in cash and the rest in stock for the privately held company. The purchase will give Associated nine more branches in Minnesota for a total of 17 in the state. Signal had $1.1 billion of assets at the end of June, with $11.7 million of annual profit. Associated has more than 200 branches in Wisconsin, Illinois and Minnesota, and about $13.2 billion of assets.

description: Like the last rose of a sorry cinematic summer or the first pallid pumpkin to presage Halloween, a bleeding heart of a horror movie titled ''Soul Survivors'' has plopped into theaters.

The attack on the military complex killed dozens of people, injured many more and brought an immediate shutdown of the government.

title: Life and Death Stakes in the Numbers Game
description: At a recent conference at the hospital where I work, a senior cardiology fellow started things off with the following case: an 82-year-old man with worsening chest pains had been transferred to our hospital to have coronary bypass surgery. He had diabetes, high blood pressure, poor kidney function and anemia, and in the past he had suffered a heart attack, a stroke and congestive heart failure. Could the surgeons operate?

title: Federal Agency Says Verizon Broke Law Regarding Union
description: The National Labor Relations Board is preparing a complaint against Verizon Communications saying the company violated federal labor law by seeking to prevent efforts to unionize employees, according to a letter sent to union officials.

description: BERLIN, Sept. 11  NATO ambassadors will also meet.

title: French Tycoons Strike a Deal to End Bitter Feud Over Gucci
description: PARIS  The lengthy and bitter public battle between two of the richest men in France for control of one of Europe's most famed fashion houses appeared Monday to have ended in a multibillion dollar compromise.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Level 3 Tries To Cut Debt
description: Seeking to improve its balance sheet, Level 3 Communications, which operates a broadband communications network, has offered to buy back some of its debt for a fraction of its face value. Level 3, based in Broomfield, Colo., said it would try to acquire about one-fifth of its $8 billion in debt for 27 cents to 57 cents on the dollar. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: The Side Effects of Speaking for a Living
description: Voice problems are an occupational hazard for telemarketers, according to a study by researchers from the University of Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha.

title: The New Home Economics; All-Important Housing Market Softens at the Top End
description: In a neighborhood on one side of Clover Basin Drive, here in this Denver suburb, nearly all the new homes are taken. Closely bunched production houses on small lots, they have drawn buyers like Ryan Bonino, a 25-year-old salesman of luxury cars, who was gratified to find something affordable in one of the nation's hottest markets. In April, flush with a $44,000 profit from selling his first house here after just a year, Mr. Bonino snapped up a two-story, three-bedroom frame home for $268,000.

title: MetroStars Have Winner In Rookie Faria
description: The MetroStars may not earn a trophy as a team this season, especially if they fail to earn the home-field advantage in the first round of the Major League Soccer playoffs, but they may have the rookie of the year, something they have never had.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Man Accused In Billing Scheme
description: A man who the authorities said tricked elite law firms into sending him money by impersonating partners at those firms was indicted yesterday. The suspect, Jonathan Ghertler, 39, of Ocala, Fla., was accused of duping six law firms, including Sullivan & Cromwell; Willkie Farr & Gallagher; and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom L.L.P., whose main offices are in New York City, and Arnold & Porter, whose main office is in Washington, into paying him at least $220,000. Federal authorities say Mr. Ghertler had the money transferred to bank accounts he controlled, by impersonating partners at the firms and arranging over the phone to have retainer fees or payments for expert witnesses sent to a nonexistent Florida law firm he called Dixon Stokes. In one instance, Mr. Ghertler called the New York office of Skadden Arps, identifying himself as a partner in the firm's Los Angeles office, according to the United States attorney's office in Manhattan, and instructed the firm's controller to transfer $65,000. Officials at Skadden, Arps did not immediately return calls seeking comment. Mr. Ghertler was charged with wire fraud and faces a maximum of five years in prison if convicted, officials said.

title: Candidate Expands the Assault on Spending Limits
description: It can be difficult enough for first-time candidates, informing voters who they are and what they stand for. Here in Albuquerque, the challenge for some is compounded by an unusual city charter statute that limits campaign spending on local elections.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Kidnapping Case Advances
description: A judge yesterday allowed a kidnapping case two decades old to go forward, a spokeswoman for the Queens district attorney, Richard Brown, said. Justice Joseph Grosso denied a motion to dismiss kidnapping charges against Barry Smiley, left, and Judith Smiley, formerly of Queens. The couple is accused of abducting Matthew Propp, now 22, and taking him to New Mexico in 1980. The Smileys, who lived under aliases, turned themselves in this year and asked for leniency, claiming poor health. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Crowd Beats Truck Driver for Killing a 4-Year-Old
description: The driver of a tow truck that accidentally struck and killed a 4-year-old boy on Saturday was then severely beaten by a crowd of more than 20 people angered by the boy's death, the police said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Confession Heard In Court
description: In a videotaped confession, an Upper East Side landlord, Louis Hubrecht, calmly explained that he shot a belligerent longtime tenant, Barbara B. Kenna, last autumn in self-defense, then took out the garbage while she lay bleeding to death. The videotape was shown yesterday during pretrial hearings. Mr. Hubrecht is charged with murder. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

description: In New York City and Nassau and Suffolk Counties, polls will open at 6 a.m. and close at 9 p.m.

title: British Columbia Ferries
description: From Sept. 15 to Oct. 8, B.C. Ferries, which serves 46 ports along the British Columbia coast, is taking 20 percent off ferry fares and up to 40 percent off accommodations on its self-drive tour packages. Starting at about $170 a person, based on double occupancy, the packages include a one-way ferry cruise, a rental car and two nights' lodging in the coastal towns of Port Hardy and Prince Rupert. Scenery includes mountains, forests and fjords. Prices are in U.S. currency. Information: (250) 386-3431 or www.bcferries.com .

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Has New Midrange Server
description: I.B.M. introduced a midrange server yesterday in an effort to gain market share from Sun Microsystems and Hewlett-Packard. I.B.M. said the server, the eServer p660, was the world's most powerful midrange server. Separately, I.B.M. named Michel Mayer to lead I.B.M. Microelectronics, its semiconductor business. Mr. Mayer, 41, was general manager of pervasive computing. I.B.M. shares fell 12 cents, to $96.47.

title: If AT&T Cuts a Cable Deal, Will AOL Cut In?
description: In the wake of Comcast's unsolicited offer in July for its cable business, AT&T may indeed welcome AOL Time Warner's making a bid now. But AOL Time Warner's expression of interest in buying 40 percent of the telephone giant's 14 million cable subscribers does not necessarily signal a bidding war, several industry experts said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGENT, ROBERT A.
description: PAGENT-Robert A. Of Greenwich, CT., 87. Noted dancer/ choreographer, on September 4, 2001 of a stroke. His career began at the Chicago Opera Ballet and continued with both the De Basil and Massine Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo companies. He was featured dancer in the original productions of such Agnes De Mille shows as ''Carousel,'' ''Oklahoma,'' ''One Touch of Venus'' and with the Jerome Robbins productions of ''Call Me Madam'' and ''Two's Company.'' A pioneer in early television, he choreographed such series as ''The Bell Telephone Hour'' and ''Voice of Firestone Hour'' and ''Miss America Pageants.'' He is survived by his companion and business partner of many years, William J. Schneider. It is suggested that contributions be made in his name to the Connecticut Ballet in Stamford or your own special charity.

The resolution to lift the sanction, which was proposed by the United States, said Yugoslavia had satisfied the conditions to end the ban and further the ''difficult security situation'' along the Kosovo border. title: France's Shock Novelist Strikes Again
description: Michel Houellebecq readily admits that he enjoys attacking, insulting and provoking, so while it is not his style to look cheerful or sound optimistic, the French writer cannot fail to be chuckling at the reaction to his latest novel, ''Plateforme.'' In the three weeks since it was published, it has won praise and stirred outrage. And with some 240,000 copies sold, it has also completely overshadowed the 574 other new novels of France's fall literary season.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST OREGON: HEARING ON PROPERTY MEASURE BEGINS The State Supreme Court began hearing arguments on the constitutionality of Measure 7, an initiative approved by voters that would force local governments to compensate private property owners for regulations that adversely affect the value of their land. Local governments say the measure would put a heavy price on regulations. The court heard arguments from local governments and the measure's proponents about whether the initiative was adequately presented to voters as a constitutional amendment.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: JDA Buys Rival Software Maker
description: The JDA Software Group, which makes Internet-based software that helps retailers keep track of sales, inventory and distribution, will buy a rival, the E3 Corporation. JDA, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., will pay about $58.6 million for the company -- $20 million in cash, about $20 million in shares of common stock and $8.6 million in assumed debt. The company expects to spend an additional $10 million to $12 million in the acquisition.

title: Professors at the Color Line
description: As the academic year gets underway at our nation's colleges, the student body will be fairly diverse -- about 56 percent women, 11 percent African-American, 8 percent Hispanic and 6 percent Asian-American. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, SAMUEL W., JR.
description: MURPHY-Samuel W., Jr. 73, of Menauhant, MA, and Boca Grande, FL, died peacefully on September 7, from a stroke. Loving husband of Barbara (Boyer) Murphy; father to Constance Perna of Redding, CT, Samuel III of Woodland, MN, and Rebecca Flynn of Owings Mills, MD, and grandfather to Andrew, Ellen, Matthew, Jeffrey and Cort. He was with the law firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton and Irvine, where he became Senior Partner; was General Counsel at both Gulf Oil and RCA, and President of the Gasparilla Island Conservation and Improvement Association. He was noted as a top corporate litigator and for his pro bono work representing death row inmates. His strength of character and integrity was noted by all. There will be a service Saturday, September 15, at 4 PM, at the Grace Memorial Chapel in Menauhant, Massachusetts. The family requests donations be sent in his honor to the conservation fund of the Gasparilla Island Conservation and Improvement Association, Box 446, Boca Grande, FL 33921, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Monroe: High School Player Recovering
description: A high school football player critically injured in the opening game of the season on Saturday should regain at least some of his mobility, although he will not play again, his doctor said. Sean Denehy, a Monroe High School junior, fractured a vertebra while making a tackle on the opening kickoff of the second half. Dr. Steven Reich at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick said that Mr. Denehy had no function in his left leg, some function in his right leg, and minimal function in his arms. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Review/Fashion; Nilsson, New at Blass, Shows Talent, Not Ego
description: For the most part, fashion isn't the place to turn for life lessons a great-grandmother could impart -- you will find no one handing out the manual on the virtues of humility, civility or largesse. But every now and then from the world of the mink purse some wisdom manages to leak. Fashion is just the place to learn, or be reminded, that those in possession of the most prodigious egos are generally those in possession of the fewest actual gifts. The designers who truly merit the name genius, the Hussein Chalayans, say, are never the ones who turn up in movie cameos or channeling George Clooney in ads for Absolut.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Parks 2001, a campaign that lobbies for park improvements, misstated the amount received annually by the city general fund from private concessions. It is $60 million, not $60,000.

title: In Struggle With Officials, The League Wins Round 1
description: It was no surprise that Philadelphia fans, considered among the toughest in sports, booed the replacement officials, flanked by a small army of security guards, as they left the field at Veterans Stadium after the Rams-Eagles game on Sunday.

title: A Keyboardist Who Goes His Own Assured Way
description: Contrary to some reports, the jazz mainstream has come quite a distance in the last 30 years. Or even 15 years, which is about how long the pianist David Berkman has been living in New York. His sextet, which played at Smoke on Friday night -- it was almost the same group as heard on his last album, ''Communication Theory'' (Palmetto) -- demonstrated which disparate elements can comfortably share a bandstand without recourse to irony as an isn't-this-weird framing device.

title: National Democrats Begin Ad Campaign for McGreevey
description: National Democrats fired the first shot today in the air war of the New Jersey governor's race, unveiling a television advertisement that attacks the Republican record over the last eight years in Trenton, where the Republican Party has controlled both the governor's office and the State Legislature.

title: YankeeNets Getting Own Cable Network
description: A year of battling in court and wooing investors spawned yesterday what YankeeNets coveted since it was formed two years ago: a cable television channel of its own, called Yankees Entertainment and Sports Network.

title: BLOCKBUSTER TAKING CHARGE TO REDUCE VHS INVENTORY
description: Blockbuster Inc. said yesterday that it would take a charge of about $450 million to eliminate 25 percent of its VHS-tape inventory and increase space for DVD titles, which have a higher profit margin. Blockbuster, a unit of Viacom Inc., said the profit margin on rentals of DVD's is 10 percentage points higher than on VHS tapes because they are not covered by the company's revenue-sharing agreements with Hollywood studios. Giving more store space to DVD titles will widen profit margins 2 to 3 percent annually by the end of next year, said Blockbuster's chief executive, John Antioco.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Contaminants In Water Systems
description: Drinking water from at least a dozen systems in the Rio Grande Valley are contaminated with a chlorination byproduct that has been associated with cancer, miscarriages and brain defects, The San Antonio Express News reported on Sunday. The byproduct, trihalomethanes, is also formed when chlorine reacts with organic matter in water. Federal standards limit trihalomethanes to 100 parts per billion, but levels as high as 391 parts per billion were found in one water system by the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Nikkei Plunge Has Investors On the Edge
description: After the biggest plunge in a month pushed the Nikkei 225 stock index down 321 points on Monday, this popular economic barometer had long left behind ''the Koizumi effect'' -- the gains surrounding the emergence of Junichiro Koizumi as prime minister five months ago.

title: Official Says Deal Is Near on Housing Scandal
description: Federal and city housing officials are working out the details of an agreement to prepare for the rehabilitation and resale of hundreds of properties in Harlem and Brooklyn that were caught up in a federal home mortgage scandal, the city housing commissioner testified yesterday.

title: Reports Disagree on Fate of Anti-Taliban Rebel Chief
description: The day after a suicide bombing aimed at Ahmed Shah Massoud, the leader of the last remaining opposition to the ruling Taliban, conflicting reports persisted today over whether he had survived.

title: No Margin for Error Left, But the Mets Still Play On
description: He is a coach who would rather not say anything, but the circumstances caused him to open up. When the third-base coach John Stearns spoke to reporters in the visitors' clubhouse at Dodger Stadium on Aug. 17, after the Mets' seventh loss in a row, the words flowed out, the frustrations of a torturous season spilling over. Things had gotten so bad, Stearns said, that he was starting to believe the team was cursed.

title: In Address, Bush Says Those Responsible Will Be Punished
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  Speaking to the nation, a somber President Bush tonight condemned the terrorist attacks against the World Trade Center and the Pentagon as "despicable evil" and said that those responsible would reap the justice of a great country.

title: Hewitt Is No. 3 In the ATP Race
description: Lleyton Hewitt advanced two places to third in the ATP Champions Race after beating Pete Sampras in the United States Open final Sunday for his first Grand Slam title.

title: Scientists Urge Bigger Supply Of Stem Cells
description: A panel of scientific experts has concluded that new colonies, or lines, of human embryonic stem cells will be necessary if the science is to fulfill its potential, a finding that is likely to inflame the political debate over President Bush's decision to restrict federally financed research to the 64 stem cell lines that are already known to exist.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: South Windsor: 25 Test Positive For TB
description: More than 25 people at a company in South Windsor have tested positive for tuberculosis after a mail carrier came down with the disease last month, said Gerald L. Schwartz, the South Windsor health director. But none of the employees at the company, Output Technology Solutions, have developed the disease and some test results may be false positives because of childhood vaccinations. T. Warner Hudson, the company's health director, said the company's 400 employees did not work particularly close to one another. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Mets Heading Home by Bus
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12  At long last, the Mets escaped the hotel rooms and the televisions and the often futile attempts to telephone home. Today, they returned to a baseball field. They took to the grass of PNC Park here, amid the quiet and the late-afternoon sunshine, and for 90 minutes they threw and hit and joked and ran and played.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: More Development Urged
description: President Kim Dae Jung called for overall economic development as the best antidote to declining exports to the United States, Japan and the European Union. Mr. Kim warned of growing economic difficulties while welcoming a new cabinet that he formed after the breakup of his ruling coalition last week. Korean manufacturers, he said, should not rely so heavily on export of products like semiconductors, whose fall on world markets is blamed for Korea's plummeting export figures. Several hours later, at a reception for the country's top business leaders, Mr. Kim said his government would remove some of the restrictions that they say have impeded them since the economic crises of 1997 and 1998. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Japanese Stocks Struggle to Recover
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 13  After a steep plunge on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index bursting downward through psychologically important 10,000-point level in very heavy trading, the Japanese stock market struggled to recover today.

title: For Some, Out of the Frying Pan Into a Classroom
description: For most of the school's history, students at the Culinary Institute of America have happily scurried into their experimental kitchen with little more than a kit of chef's knives and perhaps a sprig of fresh basil in hand.

title: Spilled Blood Is Seen as Bond That Draws 2 Nations Closer
description: Israeli officials and most Palestinian leaders condemned the attack on the United States today. But Israelis also took cold comfort in concluding that Americans would now share more of their fears, while some Palestinians rejoiced at the same thought.

title: Talk Show Figure and TV Producer Among Lost Passengers
description: One was a Washington figure known across the country from rough-and-tumble talk shows, who called her husband as the terrifying events unfolded in the sky.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Awaiting the Aftershocks
description: Today's devastating and astonishingly well-coordinated attacks on the World Trade Center towers in New York and on the Pentagon outside of Washington plunged the nation into a warlike struggle against an enemy that will be hard to identify with certainty and hard to punish with precision.

title: A Trend Toward Attacks That Emphasize Deaths
description: For a quarter-century now, terrorism has been a constant concern all around the world, but in general it is Americans at home and abroad who have been the targets of the largest and most destructive attacks.

title: KEY3MEDIA GROUP LOWERS 2001 REVENUE FORECAST
description: Key3Media Group, a producer of information-technology trade shows and conferences, pared its 2001 sales estimates and said that the company would cut 10 percent of its staff to reduce costs. Third-quarter revenue will be $50 million to $55 million, down from $60.5 million in the year-earlier period, the company said. Sales for 2001 will be $275 million to $285 million, down from $286 million last year. The company said that it would cut 10 percent of its workers in an effort to save $5 million a year.

title: Pataki Orders Postponement Of Primaries Across State
description: Barely five hours after the polls opened in New York City, Gov. George E. Pataki ordered primary elections across the state postponed indefinitely yesterday as city officials struggled to cope with the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Growth Slows
description: France's economy expanded at the weakest pace in more than four years during the second quarter of this year as the faltering in world growth weighed on exports. Consumer spending slowed and investment also stalled. Gross domestic product in France, which has Europe's third-largest economy, rose 0.3 percent from the previous quarter, the national statistics office said. First-quarter growth was revised to 0.4 percent from a previously reported gain of 0.5 percent.

title: Dispatches From a Day of Terror and Shock; The World Grieves, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Wardell B. Pomeroy, 87; Aided Kinsey's Studies on Sex
description: Dr. Wardell B. Pomeroy, a prominent psychologist who half a century ago helped Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey rechart the sexual landscape of America, died on Sept. 6 at the retirement community where he lived in Bloomington, Ind. He was 87 and had been suffering from Parkinson's disease, his family said.

title: Three (Singers) Plus Two (Backups) Equals a Night of Hollywood Nostalgia
description: Imagine a pop-jazz singer who combines the manly growl and perfect enunciation of the much missed Joe Williams with the wit and comic timing of a natural clown and you have an idea of the engaging blend of music and horseplay that the veteran singer and actor Bill Henderson brings to the cabaret revue ''Made for the Movies: A Hollywood Songbook.''

title: Officials Say They May Have Identified Attackers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Justice Department officials said today that they thought they have identified the people behind the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, and that some of the hijackers who commandeered the planes were trained as pilots in the United States.

title: Fresh Turmeric Leaves Its Zesty Mark
description: UNTIL last week, I thought of turmeric as nothing more than kitchen Clairol. It has only the faintest flavor, but everything it touches -- curries, relish, wooden spoons -- is colored vibrant yellow on contact. As a spice, it makes a good dye.

title: President Vows to Exact Punishment for 'Evil'
description: Hijackers rammed jetliners into each of New York's World Trade Center towers yesterday, toppling both in a hellish storm of ash, glass, smoke and leaping victims, while a third jetliner crashed into the Pentagon in Virginia. There was no official count, but President Bush said thousands had perished, and in the immediate aftermath the calamity was already being ranked the worst and most audacious terror attack in American history.

title: Liberties; A Grave Silence
description: If you called yesterday afternoon to the White House switchboard, that famously efficient Washington institution, you would hear a brief recording saying to hold for an operator and then the line would go dead.

title: A Battered Retreat On Bridges To the East
description: They came all morning, all afternoon and well into dusk, an exodus of survivors whose only way out of Manhattan was over the bridges that stretch across the East River.

title: Doughnuts Filled With Reveries Of Hamptons Sun and Surf
description: Dreesen's doughnuts have legions of fans in the Hamptons, where they are made in the window of a decades-old butcher shop at 33 Newtown Lane in East Hampton. These light caky doughnuts, sometimes crispy around the edges, are often warm when you buy them. And you don't have to go to the Hamptons for them. From 7:30 to 9 a.m. tomorrow and Friday, they will be given away, with coffee and milk, at 92, the restaurant at 45 East 92nd Street in Manhattan, which is making the doughnuts from Dreesen's mix with Dreesen's equipment. Ken Aretsky, 92's owner, is a longtime fan. Powdered sugar, cinnamon-sugar or plain doughnuts, 85 cents each, will be sold to go every morning, and the restaurant will also have them at breakfast, 2 for $2. The doughnuts are also made by Ottomanelli Meat Market, 1549 York Avenue (82nd Street), 50 cents each.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Australia: Let Refugees In, Court Says
description: A federal court judge ruled that the government had illegally turned away more than 400 refugees who remain stranded at sea and should allow them to land in Australia. The government, which has already made arrangements to send them elsewhere, said it would appeal the ruling.

title: From Galilee Olives, An Oil Kosher Enough For Passover
description: A kosher olive oil from Israel has just been introduced at Oliviers & Company stores. It is pressed on Eger Farm in the Galilee region of northern Israel from this year's harvest of olives grown on the farm. The oil has a golden color, a honeyed aroma, a fairly viscous consistency and a mellow flavor with a pleasingly nutlike hint of bitterness in the aftertaste and is best used as a condiment on grilled vegetables, poached fish and grain or bean salads. It is a high-quality extra virgin oil, like many others, but is produced under rabbinical supervision and stamped with a kosher seal. It is even kosher for Passover. The price is $19 for 8.4 ounces at the company's shops in Grand Central Terminal, at 198 Columbus Avenue (69th Street) and 249 Bleecker Street (Seventh Avenue South).

title: For One Firefighter's Friend, a Desperate Search Pays Off
description: Shortly after noon today, M. J. Magbanua walked up to the firehouse of Squad 18 at Avenue of the Americas and 10th Street in Manhattan. Ms. Magbanua, a 31-year-old Upper East Side resident, was looking for information on a friend, Daniel Murray, a firefighter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, ROGER S.
description: STARR-Roger S. on September 10, 2001 in Easton, PA. Son of Frederick and Lillie Bernhardt Starr. Devoted husband of Joanne (Jody) W. Starr. Father of Adam, Barnaby, and the late Alexandra, father-in-law of Judy and Monica; grandfather of Robin, Zachary, Brittany, Thomas, and Luke; stepfather of Douglas Green and Patty Shaheen. Roger was a unique human being whose intelligence, thoughtfulness and good humor will be missed by all who knew him and read his work. A veteran of World War II, he served in Asia with the Office of Strategic Services. For many years Roger Starr was Executive Director of Citizens Housing & Planning Council, was Housing & Development Administrator of New York City, and was a member of the Editorial Board of The New York Times. Roger wrote numerous articles and books, and taught at Pratt Institute, City College, and New York University. After moving to Stroudsburg, PA, he was active in that community as a member of various county boards and commissions. Services will be held at noon on Thursday, September 13 at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

title: With City Transit Shut Down, New Yorkers Take to Eerily Empty Streets
description: It was the kind of announcement New York subway riders had never heard.

title: A Flood of Anxious Calls Clog Phone Lines
description: The explosions in Manhattan and at the Pentagon yesterday prompted significant disruptions in telephone service in the Northeast in the morning, but by late in the day most calls were getting through.

title: UNITEDHEALTH SAYS IT WILL MEET EARNINGS ESTIMATES
description: The UnitedHealth Group, a leading health insurer, said it would meet analysts' earnings estimate of $2.74 a share this year. UnitedHealth, which raised the profit target in July, said it had set a goal of increasing 2002 earnings per share by as much as 18 percent over this year. The company has raised premiums and added customers, particularly in health plans it runs for self-insured businesses. Its shares have risen 8.2 percent this year.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Qantas Surges
description: Shares in Qantas Airways rose 15 percent on optimism that the airline, Australia's biggest, would buy a portion of its ailing rival, Ansett, and take majority control of the nation's $2.6 billion aviation market. Qantas and its discount competitor Virgin Blue are in talks to take over the assets of Ansett, which is an unprofitable subsidiary of Air New Zealand. Virgin Blue said that it might buy Ansett's services to outlying regions and operate 10 of Ansett's 57 planes. Qantas and Virgin Blue, which is controlled by Richard Branson, are likely to wrangle over which of the Ansett assets they want. Virgin Blue's willingness to take part in any sale will help Qantas satisfy regulators concerned that it will take too much of Ansett's 41 percent market share.

title: Prospect of U.S. Attack Raises Fears in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Sept. 12  If there are Americans clamoring to bomb Afghanistan back to the Stone Age, they ought to know that this nation does not have so far to go. This is a post-apocalyptic place of felled cities, parched land and downtrodden people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHISGALL, JAMES (JIM)
description: SCHISGALL-James (Jim). Truly a remarkable, intelligent and funny guy. Died at age 67 on September 10, 2001, after a lengthy and brave battle with cancer for seven years. Beloved and dedicated husband of Beth. Devoted and loving father of Stuart, Alex and Robbie. Son of the late Lillian and Oscar Shisgall, brother of the late Dr. Richard Schisgall. A wonderful friend and uncle to all those he cared for and will be missed by all whose lives he touched. Service Friday 1 PM, Temple Chaverim, Plainview.

title: Attackers Believed To Be Sane
description: To a nation suddenly plunged into horror and grief, they seemed acts of unspeakable madness.

title: Jews on Panel Examining Wartime Pope Say Vatican Singled Them Out for Blame
description: The three Jews on a Catholic-Jewish commission studying Pope Pius XII and the Holocaust have accused Vatican officials of singling them out for blame when the panel fell apart, and of responding to the group ''with particular virulence towards the Jews.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENFELD, RON
description: ROSENFELD-Ron. To my late great one. Nothing even comes close to what we had. I'll miss you forever. With Love, Tonelah

title: A World Where All Is Not Sweetness and Light
description: Mandy Patinkin keeps slipping off to Hollywood to appear in films and television shows. But if lovers of musical theater had their way they would keep Mr. Patinkin on Broadway, where his astonishing gifts as a singer and actor have found ideal outlets.

title: Cashman Accounts for Players as Stadium Is Evacuated
description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman could see the smoke rising from the World Trade Center as he drove to Yankee Stadium about 9:30 this morning, and as he began to realize the enormity of the damage and tragedy, he began the work of accounting for members of the team who live in Manhattan, networking with others.

title: Trying to Command an Emergency When the Emergency Command Center Is Gone
description: Government at all levels cast tens of thousands of people into its response to the World Trade Center attacks yesterday, but the magnitude, timing and location of the assault overwhelmed even the well-practiced emergency plans of a city and state conditioned by years of terrorist threat and violence.

description: 'Don't Look Outside'

title: Many Sporting Events Called Off or Postponed
description: The terrorist attacks yesterday caused the cancellation or postponement of numerous sports events in the United States.

title: Personal Accounts of a Morning Rush That Became the Unthinkable
description: A Single Question

title: Corrections
description: There are no corrections today.

title: The War Against America; The National Defense
description: As the nation assays the horrific human and physical losses of yesterday's brutally efficient terrorist attacks, it must also begin the urgent work of determining how an open and democratic society can better defend itself against a threat that conventional armies and weapons cannot defeat.

title: MORE ON THE ATTACKS
description: RESCUERS BECOME VICTIMS -- Firefighters who rushed to the trade center were killed. PAGE A2

title: In Search of a National Style
description: ALMOST all wine regions, even the less historic ones, have a signature. Argentina has taken the lead in malbec production. South Africa stands almost alone with pinotage. Australia has created its own style of shiraz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, ERNEST
description: GOODMAN-Ernest. On Sept. 10, 2001 after a long illness. Beloved father of Marion Monteleone and Spencer Mosse. Dear father-inlaw of Joseph Monteleone. Services on Thursday, at 12:45PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Jets Still Plan To Practice Today
description: The Jets, who are set to play a game in Oakland on Sunday, had a regularly scheduled day off yesterday. Frank Ramos, a team spokesman, said that the Jets planned to practice as usual today, as they await word from the National Football League about this weekend's schedule.

title: Essay; New Day Of Infamy
description: On Sept. 11, 2001 another date that will live in infamy -- the U.S. suffered war casualties on its own soil not experienced since the bloody Battle of Antietam.

title: Web Offers Both News And Comfort
description: The major news Web sites were quickly overloaded. Many links to the not-so-major news Web sites stopped working. But more than news, what people all over the world craved in the wake of yesterday's terrorist attacks was connection to each other, and many of them found that most easily achieved by going online.

title: Fund Drive for Graduate Center
description: Now that the Graduate Center of the City University of New York has settled into its new home in the former B. Altman Building on Fifth Avenue at 34th Street, it is embarking on its first capital campaign. AMABEL B. JAMES, an economist, will be chairwoman of the fund-raising drive, and MARTIN E. SEGAL, the former chairman of Lincoln Center, will be vice chairman. The drive, which will seek to raise $30 million, will run through 2004. The money will be used for student fellowships, endowed faculty chairs, distinguished professorships, research programs and other projects. Established in 1961 as the doctorate-granting institution for all of City University, the center has 3,500 students. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Correspondent; America's Emergency Line: 9/11
description: An Israeli response to America's aptly dated wake-up call might well be, ''Now you know.''

title: Rescue Workers Rush In, And Many Do Not Return
description: New York firefighters, impelled by instinct and training, rushed to the World Trade Center yesterday to evacuate victims. Then the buildings fell down. The firefighters never came out.

title: Personal Accounts of a Morning Rush That Became the Unthinkable
description: Fallen Giants

title: A Detective in Seoul Dogs a Killer's Trail
description: A tired, morose police detective (Han Suk-gyu), in trouble with his boss and trying to recover from some vague personal trouble, is drawn into the tangled psychological web of a vicious serial killer. Such is the wildly original premise of ''Tell Me Something,'' a grisly, by-the-numbers thriller from South Korea that opens today at Cinema Village.

title: Pirate Militias From Somalia Spill Into the Gulf of Aden
description: Somalia's political instability has spilled into the surrounding seas, where armed militias have been terrorizing ships in the waters off the Horn of Africa.

title: Left to Fend for Themselves, a Nation of Travelers Scrambles for Transit Options
description: The United States went into gridlock today as the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington led to the virtual shutdown of the nation's transportation system.

title: HIJACKED JETS DESTROY TWIN TOWERS AND HIT PENTAGON IN DAY OF TERROR
description: It kept getting worse.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEMPLE, HAROLD
description: TEMPLE-Harold. September 19, 1920-September 12, 1976. We have all missed so much these twenty-five years. We cherish your memory and will love you forever. Your Family

title: Stocks Tumble Aboard; Exchanges in New York Never Opened for the Day
description: Financial markets plunged in two hemispheres before trading was halted yesterday after the attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center and damaged the Pentagon.

title: Quiet Day for Giants
description: When pro football players are preparing for a game, the most important day is Wednesday, when they receive the game plans and heavy practices begin. But yesterday at Giants Stadium, things were mostly quiet for the Giants. For the second straight day, there was no practice, part of a plan Coach Jim Fassel devised weeks ago because he felt his players would benefit more by rest after their Monday night game in Denver.

title: The War Against America; An Unfathomable Attack
description: Remember the ordinary, if you can. Remember how normal New York City seemed at sunrise yesterday, as beautiful a morning as ever dawns in early September. The polls had opened for a primary election, and if the day seemed unusual in any way, that was the reason -- the collective awareness that the night would be full of numbers. All the innumerable habits and routines that define a city were unbroken. Everyone was preoccupied, in just the way we usually call innocence.

title: Transportation, City Service and Business Closing Updates
description: This list will be updated as more information becomes available. Last updated 11:30 a.m. EST.

title: Selig, in a Sense of Mourning, Cancels Baseball Games
description: In the wake of yesterday's terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center towers and the Pentagon, Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig called off last night's full schedule of 15 games and said he would make subsequent decisions on future games. It was the third time in history that a warlike act prompted postponement of major league games.

title: Myself by Any Other Name
description: BELKIN is the name I was born with. It means squirrel in Russian, and my great-grandfather carried it with him to America when he fled the czar. Gelb is my husband's name. It means yellow in German, and Bruce's great-grandfather brought it out of Hungary, allowing it to live on in defiance of Hitler. On our application for a marriage license I declared that my legal name would be Lisa Belkin Gelb, linguistically turning myself into a yellow squirrel. This was my way of navigating the rocky questions of identity and commitment, independence and tradition that modern marriage brings. What it doesn't say on that paper is that I planned to be Lisa Belkin at work and Lisa Gelb at home -- a tidy division of two worlds that I've since learned cannot be tidily divided.

title: Eaten Any Good Books Lately?
description: IF Jacqueline Susann were writing today, her characters would probably be busier in the kitchen than in the bedroom.

description: Adapted from "Bread Alone" by Judith Evan Hendricks

title: No Secret's Safe From These Sharp Eyes
description: When Stephen J. Wade goes to a social gathering of fellow oil-industry executives, he is not there just to schmooze. He is there to snoop.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Japanese Beef Banned
description: Beef imports from Japan were banned by officials worried about mad cow disease. The ban was imposed after Japanese health officials reported a suspected case of the disease. The Agriculture Ministry said the ban would last ''until the country feels safe from the disease.'' Earlier this year, the government banned import of beef from European Union countries where the disease had broken out. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: 'I Love This Country'

title: As Important as the Corporate Disaster Plan Is How Fast the Employees Carry It Out
description: For most large corporations, preparing for disaster is an unpublicized part of a sound business strategy. They hold training workshops, rehearse their responses, send memos to their employees and managers, and plan for the day that there might be a fire, flood, earthquake, hurricane or some other event that upsets their operations.

title: New York Rescuers Find Some Survivors
description: Rescuers said that they pulled seven people today from the rubble of the devastated World Trade Center as an intense search continued for survivors and victims of Tuesday's airborne attacks.

title: $10 Million for Fashion Institute
description: A $10 million gift to the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City is the largest received by a community college of the State University of New York system and the second largest personal gift to any of the State University's 64 campuses. The institute will use the gift from PATTY and JAY H. BAKER for scholarships and for construction projects, and will name its School of Business and Technology for the Bakers. Mr. Baker, who started to learn retailing in his parents' millinery store in Flushing, Queens, and studied management and marketing as an undergraduate at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, was president of Kohl's department store for 13 years.

title: Somber Day for Islanders
description: These are supposed to be optimistic days for Peter Laviolette because he has his first head-coaching job and because the Islanders believe they have much more talent this year.

description: Call for Revenge

description: To the Editor:

title: Survivors Are Found In the Rubble
description: In a desperately needed dose of hope during a long night of frustration, two men were pulled alive from beneath 30 feet of debris near the World Trade Center. But even that small victory came at an awful price: Doctors needed to amputate the leg of at least one of the men in order to free him, the authorities said.

title: Bush Vows to Avenge Attacks
description: Aday after hijackers commandeered commercial jetliners and crashed them into two of the most visible symbols of America's financial and military might, President Bush once again condemned the terror strikes, while investigators followed what Attorney General John Ashcroft called "numerous credible leads" in their hunt for those who had planned the attacks and aided the attackers.

title: A Somber Bush Says Terrorism Cannot Prevail
description: President Bush vowed tonight to retaliate against those responsible for today's attacks on New York and Washington, declaring that he would ''make no distinction between the terrorists who committed these acts and those who harbor them.''

title: Physical and Psychological Paralysis of Nation
description: Attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon shut down much of the United States yesterday, compelling Americans to acknowledge that nameless terrorists can serve up multiple acts of war -- live on national television -- inside the world's most powerful country.

title: Sashimi That Isn't: A Star Is Born
description: I WAS trained as a chef in Japan, but I have worked in kitchens all over the world and that is probably why I am so open to different ideas and flavors. Take what I call new-style sashimi, for example. It's an adaptation that came to me when I was trying to accommodate American tastes without completely compromising the concept of sashimi.

title: ANIXTER REDUCES SALES AND PROFIT FORECASTS FOR YEAR
description: Anixter International Inc., which makes communications wire and cables, reduced sales and profit forecasts for the rest of this year and said it would cut 14 percent of its work force and close some warehouses. The company, which is based in Skokie, Ill., said it expected third-quarter profit, excluding some costs, of 18 cents to 20 cents a share. The company was expected to earn 50 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Anixter cited slowing economic growth and fewer sales to telecommunications and technology companies. Customers are spending less, especially on expensive projects, Robert Grubbs, the chief executive, said in the statement. Anixter employs 5,000 to 6,000 people, the chief financial officer, Dennis Letham, said.

title: Attacks Halt Meeting
description: At the time the Pentagon and World Trade Center were being attacked yesterday, Joe Allbaugh, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and representatives from the 50 state emergency management agencies were attending an annual conference of emergency response officials at a resort in Big Sky, Mont.

title: Disruptions and Closings Are Expected to Continue
description: Lower Manhattan is expected to remain cut off from the rest of the city today, and schools and stock exchanges will be closed.

title: Towers Believed to Be Safe Proved Vulnerable to an Intense Jet Fuel Fire, Experts Say
description: The cause of the twin collapse yesterday of the World Trade Center towers in downtown Manhattan was most likely the intense fire fed by thousands of gallons of jet fuel aboard the two jetliners that crashed into the buildings, experts on skyscraper design said.

title: Footlights
description: Carmen Revisited

title: When an Open Society Is Wielded as a Weapon Against Itself
description: The terrorist attacks yesterday were intricately planned and carried out with precision. But what made them so devastating, physically and psychologically, was the way terrorists willing to sacrifice their lives swiftly turned unarmed civilian airplanes into guided missiles and left America with no obvious response.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sumitomo Lowers Outlook
description: Sumitomo Electric Industries said its full-year profit might fall more than 20 percent short of projections on slumping demand for fiber optic parts. The company, which is based in Osaka, will post group operating profit as low as 80 billion yen ($660.9 million) for the fiscal year that began April 1, said Shintaro Mitake, a director of Sumitomo, which is Japan's biggest maker of fiber optic products. That would be 22 percent short of Sumitomo Electric's May forecast and would be 16 percent below its year-earlier operating profit.

title: Personal Accounts of a Morning Rush That Became the Unthinkable
description: 'Like Zombies'

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DOLLAR TREE STORES, Chesapeake, Va., named Macon Brock, chief executive, to the additional post of chairman. He succeeds Douglas Perry, who is retiring. In addition, Bob Sasser, chief operating officer, was named to the additional post of president.

title: Bush Aides Say Attacks Don't Recast Shield Debate
description: An hour after the first jetliner crashed into the World Trade Center, the Pentagon's top policy official, Douglas J. Feith, said the ballistic missile defense shield that is the centerpiece of the Bush administration's national security planning could not prevent the kind of assaults that occurred in New York and Washington today.

title: Reinsurance Companies Wait to Sort Out Cost of Damages
description: The attacks on the twin towers of World Trade Center could cost insurers more than $5 billion, making the suspected terrorist attack on the 110-story skyscrapers the most costly man-made catastrophe ever, analysts said yesterday.

title: In U.S., Echoes of Rift Of Muslims and Jews
description: Muslim women in headscarves were advised to stay indoors. Mosques and Muslim schools in Los Angeles were shut down, and Muslim leaders in Michigan and other states reported receiving telephone threats.

title: A Hijacked Boeing 757 Slams Into the Pentagon, Halting the Government
description: A hijacked passenger plane sliced into the Pentagon today, triggering a thunderous explosion and fierce fires at the defense complex and killing and wounding an unknown number of people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEFE, THOMAS EDMUND
description: KEEFE-Thomas Edmund. On September 9, 2001. Retired Sergeant NYPD Mounted Unit. Served with USN WWII. Guadalcanal survivor. Volunteer First Marine Division. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Loving brother of John and the late Frank, Charlie, George and Bernadine. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Cherished friend of Beth and Alex Curtin. Reposing David J. Hodder and Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave, Yonkers. Visiting hours Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:45am St. Barnabas Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Calling for Help Or to Give Help
description: At least three businesses in the trade center have set up phone numbers for those looking for friends or relatives:

title: Violence Flares in West Bank and Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 12  In a surge of violence today in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, 10 Palestinians, including a 9-year-old girl, were killed by Israeli army gunfire, and an Israeli settler was shot dead by Palestinian gunmen.

title: People Were Seen Falling From Upper Floors of the 110-Story Buildings : Near Towers, Scenes of Chaos and Fear
description: NEW YORK  Witnesses described scenes of utter chaos in lower Manhattan on Tuesday as the slender spires of the World Trade Center crumbled into smoking, dusty ruins.

title: Pictures of Medical Readiness, Waiting and Hoping for Survivors to Fill Their Wards
description: As emergency vehicles careered through smoky chaos and triage centers and morgues sprouted wherever space allowed, it became sorrowfully clear that the hundreds of people bloodied and burned by yesterday's destruction of the trade center towers may have been the lucky ones.

title: Condemning Attacks, Taliban Says bin Laden Not Involved
description: In a series of statements on Tuesday night, this nation's Taliban rulers, hosts to the terrorism suspect Osama bin Laden, condemned the attacks on America and said that their notorious guest was not involved.

description: KEBBE-Sally Gracie. Memorial service will be held on Friday, September 14 at 10AM, Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89 St. Reception will follow. All are welcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEET, BARBARA MCGRAW
description: SWEET-Barbara McGraw, 83, died September 10 at her home in Lake Placid, NY. Born December 6, 1917, in Madison, NJ, she was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. McGraw, Jr. (Kathryn Jones Decker) of New York. Her father was President and Chairman of the Board of McGraw-Hill and the son of the founder of that company. Her husband, Stanley Adams Sweet, Jr., President and Chairman of Sweet-Orr, Inc., predeceased Mrs. Sweet. Mrs. Sweet attended Nightingale - Bamford School, Miss Porter's School (class of 1936), and Sarah Lawrence University (class of 1940). She worked tirelessly for many years for the American Red Cross and oversaw nurses' aide volunteers in the New York metropolitan area during and after World War II. She had been an active member of the Colony Club and the Junior League in New York, the Lake Placid and Essex County Garden Clubs, and the Lake Placid Club. She did volunter work for the Lake Placid Center for the Arts. Survivors include a daughter, Mrs. Lawrence L. Master (Nancy Adams Sweet) of Weston, Mass.; a brother, James H. McGraw III of Hobe Sound, FL, and two grandchildren, Miss Kathryn I. Master of San Francisco, CA, and Peter O. Master of New York, NY. Funeral services will be held Wednesday afternoon, September 12, 2001, at 2:00 P.M., from the St. Eustace Episcopal Church in Lake Placid. Rev. Jud Peeler, Rector, will officiate. Burial will be in the North Elba Cemetery in Lake Placid. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Lake Placid Center for the Arts, Saranac Ave., Lake Placid or the High Peaks Hospice, P.O. Box 840, Saranac Lake, NY 12983-0840. Call The Clark Funeral Home in Lake Placid, NY for further information.

title: A Soba Noodle Wrap to Stay and a Table to Go, Please
description: At the back of the Apartment, a home furnishings and accessories shop at 101 Crosby Street (Prince Street) in SoHo, is a large square of heavy glass with a big box of flourishing herbs for a centerpiece. Shoppers sitting at it on a dozen high metal stools can indulge in light but tasty salads, sandwiches and a few hot dishes, from $5 to $10. They include a soba noodle wrap with dabs of wasabi sauce, a sprightly arugula salad with goat cheese crostini and smoky-tasting eggplant salad on a well-garnished plate. There are daily specials, crepes and deliciously tart fresh lemonade. More seating is available at tables around the store. The Kitchen at the Apartment is open 11 a.m. to 7 p.m., Monday through Saturday, and noon to 6 p.m. on Sunday. And that heavy glass counter is just about the only thing in the store that's not for sale.

title: Troubled Ansett Airways Files For Bankruptcy Protection

title: A Last-Minute Letter Ends Up the First
description: When Merlin Holland was editing ''The Complete Letters of Oscar Wilde,'' he placed an advertisement in The New York Review of Books soliciting letters of his grandfather. In August last year, just as the volume was about to be printed, a reply was mailed by a man in Houston saying he had a Wilde letter. Mr. Holland immediately called and learned that he had Wilde's earliest surviving letter, written to his mother in 1868 when Wilde was 13 and away at school.

Nokia has already said it plans to cut 1,500 jobs this year to reduce costs. Its shares fell 4 percent after the news.

title: SALTON REPORTS $11.4 MILLION 4TH-QUARTER LOSS
description: Salton Inc., the maker of George Foreman grills and Timex clocks, said it lost $11.4 million, or 99 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year. The results were in contrast to net income of $15.3 million, or 98 cents, a year earlier. Sales in the quarter, which ended June 30, fell 4 percent, to $169.1 million from $176.1 million. Sales suffered as demand for Salton's higher-priced products declined and consumers opted for lower-priced grills, clocks and other housewares, the chief executive, Leonhard Dreimann, said in a statement.

title: Keeping the Wine Genie In the Bottle a Bit Longer
description: Sometimes the bottle holds a little more than you want to drink at one sitting. With still wine you can force the cork back in, but not with sparkling wine or Champagne. Wine shops and housewares stores carry gadgets to stopper a bottle, including some of a clamp-on-top variety for sparkling wines. The Velvet Wine and Champagne Sealer, a new suede-finish device made by Metrokane, the company that makes the Rabbit wine opener, is particularly effective. Place it in the bottle and turn the top clockwise to expand a rubberized inner stopper until it seals the bottle tightly. It is tight enough to lay the bottle on its side in the refrigerator. Turn counterclockwise to release. Zabar's sells it for $6.98.

title: U.S. PANEL BACKS USE OF IDEC CANCER DRUG
description: The radioactive cancer drug Zevalin from the Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation won the backing of a United States government advisory panel for use in treating an advanced form of lymphoma. The panel voted unanimously to recommend that the Food and Drug Administration approve Idec's application. Panel members voted against recommending use of the drug as an initial therapy, saying patients should try other drugs first because of toxicities that accompany Zevalin's benefits. Zevalin is designed to treat non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.
