title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Adviser On North Rehired
description: President Kim Dae Jung appointed Lim Dong Won as special adviser on national security and reunification of the divided Korean peninsula just a week after Mr. Lim was forced to resign as unification minister because of a no-confidence vote in Parliament. Mr. Lim, the architect of South Korea's efforts at reconciliation with North Korea, was expected to advise on ministerial-level talks set for this weekend in Seoul between South and North Korean officials. His opponents say he has made concessions while getting little in return. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: VITESSE LOSS WILL BE WIDER THAN PREVIOUSLY REPORTED
description: The Vitesse Semiconductor Corporation, a maker of chips for fiber optic networking gear, said its fiscal fourth-quarter loss would be wider than previously forecast. It was the third straight quarter that Vitesse has lowered its targets before the period ended. Customers of Vitesse, which is based in Camarillo, Calif., are ordering fewer chips because of an inventory glut and lower spending by telephone and Internet-service companies. Sales will be $37 million to $40 million, compared with a previous forecast of $50 million, the company said. In the year-earlier period, Vitesse reported net income of $11.6 million, or 6 cents a share, on revenue of $138 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, PETER
description: ROSENTHAL-Peter, 54. Of New York City. The Senior Executive Vice President of Rubenstein Associates, died Sept. 10, after a long illness. Howard J. Rubenstein and the staff of Rubenstein Associates mourn the loss of Peter & extend their condolences to his family, loved ones and many friends. His integrity, skill, intelligence and work ethic earned him admiration throughout our industry. His colleagues and clients will miss his wise counsel, sense of humor and uncompromising commitment to his profession. A consummate public relations practitioner and industry leader, he played a key role over the last 25 years in working with Mr. Rubenstein to build the agency into one of the largest independent public relations firms in the U.S. Joining the firm as an account executive in 1976, he rose to become the firm's ranking executive behind Mr. Rubenstein and created and grew the firm's business-financial practice into one of the premier groups in the PR industry. Peter was born in New York City to Walter and Rita Rosenthal and educated in the New York City public schools, graduating from the Bronx High School of Science. A graduate of City College, he obtained a Master's Degree in Journalism from Ball State University. He was the beloved husband of Terri Thompson and devoted father of Joel, 21, and Daniel, 8. In addition to his wife and children, he is survived by his mother, his brother, Tom, & sister-in-law, Estelle Rosenthal; nephew, Joseph Rosenthal; uncle and aunt, Herbert & Helen Horn, & cousins, Evelyn Horn and Larry Horn. A service will be held Thursday, September 13th, at Riverside Memorial, Amsterdam Avenue and West 76th Street, at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, please direct donations to the Bronx High School of Science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITALE, DR. ALBERT G.
description: VITALE-Dr. Albert G. A prominent Cardiologist and Medical Educator at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York for nearly 50 years, died Sunday, September 9, 2001, of Convent Station, NJ, formerly of Summit, NJ. He was devoted to his beloved wife, Helen of 46 years, his three children and their spouses, Drs. Albert T. and Patricia A. Vitale, currently residing in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Thomas W. and Gaysu Stanton-Vitale of Reston, Virginia, Helen F. Vitale of Summit, NJ; four grandchildren, and his late sister, Frances White. A Mass of Christian Burial is to be held at St. Thomas More Catholic Church in Convent Station, NJ, on Friday, September 14, 2001, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a fund in his name, to support medical education at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York. Dr. Vitale created and directed the CardioPulmonary Department at St. Vincent's, as well as that at Overlook Hospital in Summit, NJ, served as Chief of Medical/Surgical Cardiology at St. Vincent's and as President of the medical staff. He was well known for bringing a unique humanistic perspective to his students and patients. His legacy is the fruit from a live lived with love; of medicine & of his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, WILLIAM I.
description: SPENCER-William I. The Board of Directors, Executive Director, staff, children and families of Berkshire Farm Center and Services for Youth express our deepest sorrow on the passing of William I. Spencer. He was a vital and generous member of our Board of Directors for 48 years. He held various positions including assistant treasurer from 1953 to 1954, treasurer until 1962, vice president until 1963, president until 1968 and has been honorary chairman of the Board for the past 27 years. Mr. Spencer's hard work and generous support of the Cottage Building Campaign in the late 1960's resulted in the naming of Spencer Cottage in his honor. Spencer Cottage is a living unit for boys located on the grounds of the Residential Center at Canaan, NY. In addition he was instrumental in bringing the Hess Automotive Facility, a vocational training program, to the Center. He worked tirelessly to ensure a stronger and brighter future for thousands of children and families in New York State. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Susan, and the entire family. Charles H. Mott, President, Board of Directors

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Governors Back Hodges
description: Southern governors meeting in Lexington, Ky., endorsed the position of Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina on plutonium disposal, calling on the Bush administration to fully finance a 1998 Department of Energy decision to build plutonium reprocessing facilities at the Savannah River site near Aiken, S.C. Governor Hodges, a Democrat, has threatened to use the Highway Patrol to block plutonium shipments if the Bush administration's cuts in the energy budget are not restored. Mr. Hodges said the bipartisan resolution by 18 governors showed that the region was united in its determination to protect its population and environment. An Energy Department spokesman said that financing was controlled by Congress.

title: Put Tab A in Slot B, Tab C in Slot D . . .
description: Felissimo, the small department store at 10 West 56th Street, has become a design studio with a small shop on the first floor. There it sells packages of sturdy paper decorated with fruit, flowers, leaves and teddy bears, which are meant to be assembled into boatlike containers for food. They resemble the disposable baskets that fast-food places use for serving French fries. The trick, for parents about to give a child's birthday party, or for dexterous young partygoers, is to punch out the forms, fold them and insert the tabs in the slots to make their own dishes for holding hot dogs, sandwiches and even slices of birthday cake. The kit, which comes in a fabric sack, includes directions printed entirely in Japanese but also has easy-to-follow diagrams. It contains the material for 45 plates in three sizes. The price is $35.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Closed Party Primaries
description: Each of the state's six political parties -- Republicans, Democrats, Greens, Alaskan Independence, Libertarians and Moderate Republicans -- will have its own primary ballot in 2002 under new state guidelines. In May the Legislature directed the Division of Elections to close each party's primary, limiting voting to party members and independents, unless a party asked that its primary remain open to all voters. Three of the six parties protested the system, but none asked to keep an open primary. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Honors for a Historian
description: KENNETH T. JACKSON, the Columbia University history professor and editor of the Encyclopedia of New York City, seems to be the man of the moment. Last year he was named president of the Organization of American Historians. In May, he was tapped as president of the New-York Historical Society. This month, the New York Council for the Humanities designated him as its scholar of the year. He will deliver the honorary address, ''The End of Sprawl: The City Beckons Once Again,'' at the Donnell Library Center in Manhattan on Oct. 17. Reservations can be made at (212) 233-1131, extension 43. Past scholars include the legal theorist RONALD DWORKIN, the biographers RON CHERNOW and BLANCHE WEISEN COOK, the historians SIMON SCHAMA and ERIC FONER, the economic historian ROBERT HEILBRONER and the art historian LINDA NOCHLIN. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: An Acquisition
description: Air Liquide, the world's largest maker of industrial gases, said it bought Balazs Analytical Laboratory to broaden its analytical services to the semiconductor industry. Air Liquide, which is based in Paris and makes nitrogen used to create a sterile environment for semiconductor manufacturing, did not say how much it paid for the company. The companies will create a technology center in Fremont, Calif., where Balazs has an operation, Air Liquide said.

description: The demand for blood for victims of the attacks on the World Trade Center was less than originally feared, said Dr. Robert L. Jones, chief executive and president of the New York Blood Center.

description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman could see the smoke rising from the World Trade Center as he drove to Yankee Stadium about 9:30 this morning, and as he began to realize the enormity of the damage and tragedy, he began the work of accounting for members of the team who live in Manhattan, networking with others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, BELLE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Belle. AMIT is deeply grieved by the passing of our most beloved Honorary President and activist in the creation of the State of Israel and a pioneer in the development of religious Zionism. Belle Goldstein was an early leader of Mizrachi Women, and its third National President. She guided, counseled and mentored the organization and its volunteers as it grew and evolved into AMIT, the world's leading supporter of religious Zionist education and social services for needy Israeli youths. Belle played an ongoing leadership role in AMIT's uneaqualled history of ''saving the forgotten children of Israel.'' At the age of 102, Belle Goldstein realized the Zionist dream in making Aliyah to Israel, where she continued her Jewish communal activities. A true ''Woman of Valor'', Belle Goldstein possessed such charm, grace, warmth and oratory skill, that she mesmerized her audiences and moved them to a deeper love for Torah Israel, and religious Zionism. She held the ideals of Zionism and her passion for Klal Yisrael close to her heart. We express our very sincere condolences to her entire family. May they comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Horror Knows No Party As Lawmakers Huddle
description: Dozens of members of Congress from both parties stood side by side on the East Front of the Capitol tonight and declared they would stand united behind President Bush and not bow to an attack on the nation's freedom.

title: France Refuses To Shut Shelter Near Tunnel
description: A French court refused today to shut down a Red Cross shelter, just a few kilometers from the Channel Tunnel, where a growing number of refugees have been massing in the hope of sneaking through the tunnel to Britain.

title: Doughnuts Filled With Reveries of Hamptons Sun and Surf
description: Dreesen's doughnuts have legions of fans in the Hamptons, where they are made in the window of a decades-old butcher shop at 33 Newtown Lane in East Hampton. These light caky doughnuts, sometimes crispy around the edges, are often warm when you buy them. And you don't have to go to the Hamptons for them. From 7:30 to 9 a.m. tomorrow and Friday, they will be given away, with coffee and milk, at 92, the restaurant at 45 East 92nd Street in Manhattan, which is making the doughnuts from Dreesen's mix with Dreesen's equipment. Ken Aretsky, 92's owner, is a longtime fan. Powdered sugar, cinnamon-sugar or plain doughnuts, 85 cents each, will be sold to go every morning, and the restaurant will also have them at breakfast, 2 for $2. The doughnuts are also made by Ottomanelli Meat Market, 1549 York Avenue (82nd Street), 50 cents each.

title: UTAH RATE AWARD IS REDUCED FOR SCOTTISHPOWER
description: ScottishPower P.L.C., the owner of Pacificorp, will have to return $22 million to customers in Utah after state regulators granted the company a smaller rate increase than first announced seven months ago. The British company won permission for an increase worth $40.5 million, less than the $70 million the Utah Public Service Commission granted in a preliminary decision in February. The ruling comes a day after ScottishPower said it would take a charge of $300 million for misjudging Western electricity prices and was a setback for the plan of the chief executive, Ian Russell, to recoup the loss with rate increases.

title: In the Day's Attacks and Explosions, Official Washington Hears the Echoes of Earlier Ones
description: Many of the capital's elder statesmen heard an echo of the sudden attack on the country's most important naval base 60 years ago in today's explosions at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Displaying All Wilde's Many Sides; A London Show Moves to the Morgan Library, Continuing the Rise In the Assessment of His Multiple Talents.
description: At 21, Oscar Wilde, a prodigy looking forward to a prodigious career, summarized his ambition in life as ''success: fame or even notoriety.'' Twenty-five years later, as death approached, he said, ''I wrote when I did not know life, now that I do know the meaning of life, I have no more to write.'' And: ''My time is short -- my work is done -- and when I cease to live, that work will begin to live.'' His work, he predicted, would be his ''great monument.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: W.T.O. Still Snagged On China
description: Negotiators trying to put the final touches on China's entry into the World Trade Organization appeared to be stymied by some last-minute problems, including the conditions that will govern the expansion of American International Group, the insurance company. Envoys insisted they could meet tomorrow's deadline to usher in one of the organization's biggest members. Among the remaining differences were exactly what goods China wanted on its list of those subject to price controls.

description: Tonight's opening episode of ''Wolf Lake'' on CBS begins with some hints of what's to come. But you could easily miss the foreshadowing, overshadowed as it is by the show's mandatory exercise of its nighttime network leeway to engage in -- wink, wink, nudge, nudge -- adult content.

Staff Sgt. Timothy Woodland, 24, said: ''It was consensual. I didn't rape her. There was no assault or violence or any other thing involved in this either.'' Howard W. French (NYT)

description: MOSKOWITZ-Philip. On Sept. 10, in Tamarac, FL. Greatgrandfather of twenty-four. We will all miss Grandpa Phil, our mentor, confidant & cheerleader. Services are at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre, New York, at a time to be announced.

title: A Shortcut Turns Down the Heat On a Vibrant Favorite
description: A BOWL of chilled borscht laced with sour cream seems like an ideal late-summer soup, right up there with gazpacho made from the last of the ripe tomatoes. But unlike gazpacho, which can be whipped together in a blender without once turning on the stove, traditional beet borscht requires a pretty lengthy stint of simmering. Ideal, maybe, to make in the chilly dawn of a Russian winter but not something you would want to bother with during the still-warm September days here in New York.

title: Officials Say They Saw No Signs of Increased Terrorist Activity
description: Counterterrorism officials said electronic eavesdropping intercepts obtained in the hours after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon indicated that the terrorist operation was carried out by the militant Islamic organization headed by Osama bin Laden.

title: A Dream of a Classic Bistro, Or Nearly
description: IN one of his casual essays, George Orwell once rhapsodized about a pub called the Moon Under Water. It had everything: good beer, a quiet atmosphere, dark wood burnished by time. There was only one thing wrong with the Moon Under Water. It didn't exist. It was a fantasy pub, the repository of all the pub virtues at a time when traditional pubs were falling fast.

title: Viva Mxico and Stuff Those Chilies!
description: WHEN I was a little girl, tearing through the legs of laughing, shouting, inattentive grownups at a family reunion in Arizona, I would often be brought up short by a yank on my party dress.

title: Mark Morris Dance Center Adds Luster To Brooklyn
description: The official opening was not scheduled until this week, but the dazzling new Mark Morris Dance Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is already up and running. Its dance classes -- for children and adults -- filled up in less than a week, and its available studios have been snapped up by dance companies looking for affordable work space.

title: In Chinatown, a Cantonese Seafood Celebration
description: UNTIL a recent Tuesday night visit to Sunrise 27, a glossy new Cantonese seafood house east of the Bowery in Chinatown, I don't think I had ever sat down to dinner in the middle of a stranger's wedding celebration. But there we were, with the other ordinary customers, in the front of the big street-level dining room, near the tanks of live lobsters, eels and other future treats, watching a pair of newlyweds celebrate.

They took to the grass of PNC Park here, amid the quiet and the late-afternoon sunshine, and for 90 minutes they threw and hit and joked and ran and played.

description: Within an hour of the attack on the World Trade Center, scores of other buildings and institutions -- from nearby schools to the Empire State Building to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to the United States Military Academy at West Point -- closed their doors, sent workers home and took measures to heighten security.

description: BRET D. SCHUNDLER, former mayor of Jersey City and Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey, wants to give vouchers to parents for private school tuition. It would be easy to pay for them, Mr. Schundler says, because public education bureaucracies are so wasteful.

description: On Tuesday, September 11, the NYTimes.com's Readers' Opinions area opened a forum for readers from around the world to share their thoughts on the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Meeting On Tunnel Migrants
description: The French interior minister and his British counterpart met in Paris to discuss the continuing rush of illegal immigrants from France into Britain, many of whom have sneaked through the Channel Tunnel as stowaways on trucks and trains. Britain has blamed France because it has allowed refugees to be housed in a Red Cross shelter near the tunnel while France says Britain's asylum policy is the real magnet for them. Britain wants the French shelter closed; France proposes to set up another shelter farther from the tunnel entrance.

description: SOLYOM-Richard L. of Fort Lee, age 93 on Tuesday September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Edna (nee Lazar). Loving brother of Phyllis Lane. Cherished uncle of Steven Lane. Funeral services were held privately at the request of the family at Frank A. Patti and Kenneth Mikatarian Funeral Home, Fort Lee, NJ.

title: Bush to Come To New York When Rescue Effort Eases
description: White House officials said today that President Bush would visit New York City ''at the first opportunity,'' but that he did not want to hamper rescue operations under way in Lower Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, ROGER S.
description: STARR-Roger S. on September 10, 2001 in Easton, PA. Son of Frederick and Lillie Bernhardt Starr. Devoted husband of Joanne (Jody) W. Starr. Father of Adam, Barnaby, and the late Alexandra, father-in-law of Judy and Monica; grandfather of Robin, Zachary, Brittany, Thomas, and Luke; stepfather of Douglas Green and Patty Shaheen. Roger was a unique human being whose intelligence, thoughtfulness and good humor will be missed by all who knew him and read his work. A veteran of World War II, he served in Asia with the Office of Strategic Services. For many years Roger Starr was Executive Director of Citizens Housing & Planning Council, was Housing & Development Administrator of New York City, and was a member of the Editorial Board of The New York Times. Roger wrote numerous articles and books, and taught at Pratt Institute, City College, and New York University. After moving to Stroudsburg, PA, he was active in that community as a member of various county boards and commissions. Services will be held at noon on Thursday, September 13 at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Talks On Fishing Dispute
description: After talks between senior officials, Russia and Japan said they were confident that they would settle a dispute over fishing rights around the southern Kurile Islands, Russian-controlled islands north of Japan that are the object of a longstanding territorial dispute between the nations. Japan protested after Russia allowed fishing boats from Taiwan, South Korea and Ukraine to fish within its exclusive economic zone around the four southernmost Kuriles, which are claimed by Japan. Japan calls the islands its Northern Territories. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Dance Music Pumped Full of Helium
description: For American pop fans, Jamiroquai's song ''Virtual Insanity'' was a fancy slice of birthday cake: it caused a serious craving, but after a few bites its sugary intensity made people feel rather sick. The poppy funk hit and its video, featuring the Mad Hatter-like antics of Jamiroquai's singer, Jason Kay, was everywhere in 1998, but Mr. Kay's trickster act soon proved grating, and subsequent musical efforts earned little interest. It seemed Jamiroquai would be remembered as only empty calories.

title: Common Materials, Uncommon Twists
description: THERE is a time for exotic woods, fragile textiles and precious metals. But from the looks of the merchandise last month at the New York Gift Market in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, this does not seem to be the season. The wholesale market was full of colorful designs, many for children, in ordinary materials like plywood, nylon, textured sisal and natural cotton. As a bonus, many have a handmade look.

title: Alice Trillin, 63, Educator, Author and Muse, Is Dead
description: Alice Stewart Trillin -- an educator, film producer and author also known as the muse of her husband, the humorist Calvin Trillin -- died on Tuesday evening at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She was 63.

title: Loads of Body Bags Hint at Magnitude of Grisly Task
description: The police sealed the streets to most traffic, but the man in the tractor-trailer leaned out his cab window yesterday afternoon, shipping papers in hand. His cargo was needed by the people working in the New York City medical examiner's office just across 30th Street, at 520 First Avenue.

title: The Prints and the Pager: Software for the Blackberry
description: Many users of the tiny Blackberry e-mail pagers still lug laptop computers when traveling for a single reason: their wireless hand-held gizmos aren't very good at dealing with e-mail attachments. This week Research In Motion and Hewlett-Packard announced a system that will allow wandering Blackberry users to print out attached spreadsheets, letters and other documents at hotel and airport business centers or while visiting branch offices of their employers. HP Mobile Enterprise Printing is a software package that is installed both on corporate servers and within the pagers.

title: Hospital Treks, Fliers and the Cry: Have You Seen . . . ?
description: Naomi Konovitch was unapologetic, barging up to anyone on First Avenue wearing medical scrubs, a clerical collar or an official name tag. To each, she displayed color snapshots of her missing brother-in-law, Andrew Zucker, and pressed on them a photocopied fact sheet.

Bush on Wednesday promised a "monumental struggle" against the attackers as the authorities estimated that the death toll would rise into the thousands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEEHAN, WILLIAM M.
description: FEEHAN-William M. On September 11, 2001. First Deputy Fire Commissioner. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth (nee Keegan), Loving father of Elizabeth Feehan, William B., Tara Davan and John Feehan. description: NORMAL, Ill., Sept. 12  By the hour, they came: Mothers popped from vans; an Army recruiter emptied his wallet and went back to the bank for more; two postal workers left $660 collected from colleagues; a shift of firefighters gave $125.

title: Mychal Judge, 68, Chaplain for Fire Dept.
description: The Rev. Mychal F. Judge, a chaplain with the New York City Fire Department since 1992, died amid a rain of debris at the World Trade Center on Tuesday as he ministered to victims. He was 68 and lived in a Franciscan friary across West 31st Street from a firehouse.

title: Cyclones Accept Odd End to Season
description: Brett Kay lives in Chelsea, a long toss from the Brooklyn Cyclones' home at KeySpan Park at Coney Island. But when the team returned home at 4 a.m. Tuesday from the first game of the New York-Penn League championship series in Williamsport, Pa., Kay, the Cyclones' catcher, stopped at the Staten Island home of first baseman Jay Caliguiri and decided to spend the night there.

description: GOLDENHAR - Maurice, M.D. Born January 15, 1924. Died September 11, 2001 after a long illness. Loving and beloved husband of Paulette, father of Francine and Edith, grandfather of Lucas and friend to many. Retired family physician and Professor of Family Medicine at SUNY Stony Brook. He dedicated his life to healing and teaching. A memorial will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to an organization of your choice.

description: Lower Manhattan will remain cut off today, with access severely restricted below 14th Street.

title: New Aibo Puppies From Sony: Motherboards Doing Nicely
description: When Sony unleashed its robotic dog, Aibo, in June of 1999, the unusual creature was met with widespread gadget-lust. Since then there has been a flurry of robotic pet toys, including many cheaper knock-off hounds, but last week Sony announced a new litter of purebreds: two models called Latte and Macaron.

title: A Personal Audio Player That Won't Tip the Scales
description: Picking up a portable MP3 player quickly is something like picking up an empty milk carton from the refrigerator: you just don't expect it to be so light. Compaq has released a new competitor in the ultrafeatherweight division that weighs in at three ounces. The pager-size Compaq Ipaq Personal Audio Player PA-2, with an aluminum case and rubberized grips, appears to have been designed with gym rats or joggers in mind. It will run for 14 hours on batteries and store up to 2 hours of digital music in either MP3 or Windows Media Audio files. Compaq dropped on-board memory -- the player operates with 64 megabytes of flash memory -- and other extras

title: Powerful Emotions Distilled
description: Grief, more often than not, is a reaction to the unspeakable; it is not surprising that dance, a nonverbal art, has easily found the resources to express what words cannot.

title: On Doomed Flight, Passengers Vowed To Perish Fighting
description: They told the people they loved that they would die fighting.

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, click here .

title: A Symbol Was Destroyed, Not America's Financial System
description: SYMBOLICALLY, it was the heart of the world financial system. And now there is a void where the tallest buildings in New York had stood so solidly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, ANDREW L. WAGNER
description: GRAY-Andrew L. Wagner friends mourn the death of the translator of Richard Wagner's ''My Life''. His scholarship will keep his name alive, and those who loved him will love him always.

title: Traditional Spirits Block a $500 Million Dam Plan in Uganda
description: The churning rapids that surge past a hillside lookout here explode into a ferocious storm of water, beckoning with thrills for some, and power and profit for others.

title: At Art Centers, Bringing Out the Best
description: It seems that almost every art institution in Los Angeles has hired a world-class architect to design a building. The Otis College of Art and Design is about to open a 40,000-square-foot fine arts center by Frederick Fisher & Partners (architects of the P.S. 1 art center in New York); there will soon be a student pavilion (part of a new master plan by Frank Gehry and Alvaro Siza) at the Art Center College of Design by Hodgetts & Fung; and an abandoned freight depot is being transformed into an 89,000-square-foot school building for SCI-Arc (Southern California Institute of Architecture) by staff members and alumni.

title: Amid the Soot and Uncertainty, Officials Try to Portray Business as Usual
description: As hundreds of firefighters continued to fight tenacious fires through the Pentagon's slate roof, military and civilian personnel returned to a building where the principal business today was drawing up plans to retaliate.

title: Way Beyond Any Balance Sheet, Traders Deal With Losses of the Most Painful Kind
description: Fred Alger founded a mutual fund business the year after John F. Kennedy was assassinated and ran it for more than three decades, through good markets and bad. Six years ago he handed the business over to his younger brother, David, and he has moved to Switzerland.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Wife Succeeds Husband
description: Alicia Suazo was sworn in to succeed her late husband, State Senator Pete Suazo, a popular Democrat who was killed in August in an all-terrain vehicle accident. Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, a Republican, approved the nomination on Tuesday. The Salt Lake County Democratic Party submitted only the name of Mrs. Suazo, 48, an elementary school teacher, for approval. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Tighter Airport Security Will Slow Business Fliers
description: With the nation's airports closed, thousands of travelers struggling to return home from business trips, and conferences and corporate meetings canceled, the business travel industry faces turmoil for the coming week and uncertainty about the near future.

title: Air Shutdown in U.S. and Canada Strands Travelers Worldwide
description: HONG KONG  Passengers faced confusion and prolonged delays across Asia and Europe as airlines canceled hundreds of flights bound for and coming from North America.

title: William Feehan, Fire Dept. Leader, Dies at 71
description: William Feehan, the Fire Department's second-highest official, whose knowledge and cunning in battling fires himself made him the stuff of legend to his firefighters, died Tuesday when the south tower of the World Trade Center collapsed on his command station. He was 71 and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Give Us Choices, Yes, But Not Too Many
description: MY grandmother, who lived in the hills of eastern Kentucky, had many skills. Food preparation was not among them.

title: Metro Matters; In a Crisis, The Giuliani We Wanted
description: MARY CITARELLA had something to say, and though she couldn't quite believe that she was saying it, she did so without qualification. ''I am not a supporter of Mayor Giuliani, but he was so elegant,'' the scenic artist said yesterday in Union Square Park as she visited a makeshift memorial. ''I have newfound love for him, for what he said about how we are a multicultural city, we can't begin to single out cultures, harbor ill feelings. He sounded like a real leader. I didn't feel that way about President Bush. Did you hear him?''

title: Threats Empty Malaysia's Petronas Towers : U.S. Facilities in Asia On Alert After Attack
description: SEOUL  Shock waves from the terrorist attacks in the United States reverberated through Asia on Wednesday, raising fears that terrorists would strike at huge U.S. military facilities in Japan and South Korea, at U.S. embassies and consulates and at the tall buildings that dominate the skylines of the region's largest cities.

title: Sports of The Times; In Time, Games Can Offer Escape
description: LIFE must go on and sports are obviously part of it. The ballparks will soon reopen and the players will talk about trying to make sense of it all and then they will go out and take batting practice, and preoccupy themselves with driving the ball into the gap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSEN, DON
description: NELSEN-Don. Died September 8th at 75. Former Daily News jazz and drama critic. Survived by his wife, Ricki Fulman, mother Olive, son Bobby, three grandchildren. Contributions can by made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: An Emblem of Concern and Anxiety
description: Until Tuesday, few people beyond the rarefied world of the government bond market had ever heard of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., a 57-year-old firm that is an important piece of the backstage machinery of the Treasury market. But in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center, the firm has emerged as a magnet for Wall Street's concern about the devastation and personal tragedy that the financial community has experienced.

title: Rites, Not of Spring, But of a Midlife Autumn
description: MIDDLE AGE

title: Lending Everything From Ears to Elbow Grease
description: The volunteers came by the hundreds. There was the Argentine merchant mariner on vacation, and the nun from India; the computer programmer from Taiwan who lives in Queens, and the Ohio couple who cut short their visit to the Finger Lakes to drive east. Some once worked at the World Trade Center, now vanished in rubble.

title: Tories Choose a New Leader Fiercely Opposed to Europe
description: LONDON, Sept. 13  The Conservatives today declared their new leader to be Iain Duncan Smith, a former military man known for his fierce opposition to Britain's further integration into Europe.

title: Sometimes a Tentative Note In the Bidding Saves a Hand
description: When groups of infantry clash in modern warfare, there is hardly ever a drummer to ''beat the retreat,'' as happened in days of yore. But in clashes of pasteboard armies it is often necessary to beat a retreat, or at any rate seek another path.

title: Rangers and Lindros Open Training Camp
description: ERIC LINDROS took part in his first official workout with the Rangers yesterday in Rye, N.Y., during a subdued practice as rescue efforts continued in the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center on Tuesday.

title: A City Awakes, Only to Reflect On a Nightmare
description: New York woke up to another day yesterday, but it wasn't another day. It couldn't possibly be.

title: Arabs and Muslims Steer Through an Unsettling Scrutiny
description: On a quiet block in Brooklyn Heights yesterday, a small cluster of men and boys gathered inside a mosque for afternoon prayers. Outside, a man drove past slowly and yelled, ''Murderers.''

title: New York, New York, a City of Triumph Even as a City in Pain
description: It's hard to admit at a time like this, but something there is in New Yorkers that secretly boasts even as we openly weep. The price we must pay for being biggest and best is being hated the most and suffering greatly. If terror defines the new century, obviously New York must lead the way.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: National Briefing | Washington: Stamp Price May Rise
description: The board of governors of the Postal Service said it would propose increasing the price of first-class stamps by three cents. A request for an expedited decision, part of an overall rate increase of roughly 9 percent, will be submitted to the Postal Rate Commission this month, officials said. ''We simply don't have the basic tools necessary to operate in a modern businesslike manner,'' said Robert F. Rider, chairman of the board of governors. The cost of mailing a letter went up by one cent in January to 34 cents. The service projects a deficit this year of $1.65 billion, officials said, because of the economic slowdown and high labor, fuel and health care costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLLER, ELIAS R., M.D.
description: STOLLER-Elias R., M.D. On September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Beatrice and the late Ruth. Loving father of Robert and Philip. Dear brother of Sydney and the late Norman. Cherished uncle, great-uncle, godfather, treasured friend and mentor to a generation of doctors. Services Friday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections

description: Barbara K. Olson, who was killed on Tuesday on the commercial jetliner that was hijacked and flown into the Pentagon, was well known to television viewers across the nation as a combative and confident political commentator representing the conservative Republican point of view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ALVIN
description: SCHWARTZ-Alvin. 89 years old. Died peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family on September 12, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Spear Schwartz. Loving father of Jane and Edward Stein, Amy and Charles Spielman, and Thomas and Lonnie Schwartz. Adored by his grandchildren Philip and Frances Stein, Laura, Eric and Jenny Spielman, and Ilyse and Adam Schwartz. Also survived by his sister Carol Rozen and brothers Lester and Henry Schwartz. Brother-in-law of Henry Yusen and ''big brother'' to Ellen Spear Smith. He left our world better than the way he found it. In lieu of flowers, contributions to his favorite charities, ''Temple Beth El of Great Neck'', or North Shore LIJ Health System, or the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

Mara attended Juilliard School of the Arts. She was a Naumberg Prize winner and played under Stokowski, Steinberg, Previn and Beecham. She was associate concertmaster for the Pittsburgh Symphony from 1969-1979. She is survived by one daughter, Margaret Dvonch Swingle, Bainbridge Island; three grandchildren and one great granddaughter. Memorial services will be held at Kass Funeral Home, 163 Wyatt Way, Bainbridge Island, on September 14 at 1:00PM.

description: American Airlines Flight 11 to Los Angeles took off on schedule out of the tangle of construction choking Logan International Airport in Boston, right on time at 7:59 Tuesday morning.

description: In the art of Rembrandt, grief is secular and spiritual emotion. In the dozens of self-portraits he painted over nearly half a century, sadness develops like an ache of suppressed tears. For this man, who lost the people he loved most, mourning wasn't an event; it was a state of mind, always there, shifting forward, retreating, always growing, like the shadows that move across the artist's aging face.

title: Controllers Say Flow of Information on Hijacked Planes' Course Was Slow and Uneven
description: The controllers assigned to United Airlines Flight 175 on Tuesday suspected that it had been hijacked as it flew off its assigned route. But they did not learn that another plane had been hijacked and had hit the World Trade Center until a minute or two before Flight 175 struck the center, people involved in the air traffic system said.

description: The stunning loss of life in Tuesday's terrorist attacks and the sense, expressed by President Bush, that these were ''acts of war,'' have freed the administration to broaden potential retaliation beyond the low-risk, unmanned cruise missile strikes of the past, military and civilian officials said today.

description: ODD as it may seem, Amadou Diallo came to mind yesterday as New York sifted through the physical and emotional rubble of the World Trade Center nightmare.

description: The coverage of the terrorist attacks in Manhattan and in the Washington area brought tens of millions of Americans to television sets throughout Tuesday, peaking with President Bush's address to the nation, which reached about 80 million viewers, according to preliminary figures.

title: A Buffer For the Terror

In her 1965 essay ''The Imagination of Disaster'' the literary critic Susan Sontag reflected on psychological meaning of such escapism.

title: Placed Products, And Their Cost
description: Just days ago, but it seems so much more faraway than that, Bulgari's commissioning Fay Weldon to write a novel was the consuming topic of conversation in publishing circles. Since Tuesday, it seems trivial and extraneous, but nonetheless it did set off all kinds schismatic debates among publishers and writers, raising such uneasy questions as whether the whole concept is a literary sellout or simply a not-too-consequential ingenious public relations promotion by Bulgari. Most of the comment came from those who hadn't read the work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERWOOD, CHARLES G. (CHUCK)
description: SHERWOOD-Charles G. (Chuck). Age 85. Of North Bellmore, N.Y. On September 11, 2001. Cherished husband of Agnes. Devoted father of James, Thomas, Nancy and Richard. Adored grandfather of Mary Kate, Monica, Nicholas, Elizabeth and John Francis. Loving father-in-law of Edith, Nancy and Ruth. Member of Pearl Harbor Survivors Association, U.S. Army (winner of The Bronze Star), Life Member of Lucent Pioneers, Charles Ambron Chapter, member of Retired Knights of Columbus. Reposing at C.S. Bartholomew and Son Funeral Home, 302 South Bedford Ave, Bellmore, N.Y. 2-4 and 7-9PM Thursday and Friday. Mass of Christian Burial 9AM Saturday at Saint Barnabas R.C. Church, Bellmore. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITALE, DR. ALBERT G.
description: VITALE-Dr. Albert G. A prominent Cardiologist and Medical Educator at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York for nearly 50 years, died Sunday, September 9, 2001, of Convent Station, NJ, formerly of Summit, NJ. He was devoted to his beloved wife, Helen of 46 years, his three children and their spouses, Drs. Albert T. and Patricia A. Vitale, currently residing in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Thomas W. and Gaysu Stanton-Vitale of Reston, Virginia, Helen F. Vitale of Summit, NJ; four grandchildren, and his late sister, Frances White. A Mass of Christian Burial is to be held at St. Thomas More Catholic Church in Convent Station, NJ, on Friday, September 14, 2001, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a fund in his name, to support medical education at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York. Dr. Vitale created and directed the CardioPulmonary Department at St. Vincent's, as well as that at Overlook Hospital in Summit, NJ, served as Chief of Medical/Surgical Cardiology at St. Vincent's and as President of the medical staff. He was well known for bringing a unique humanistic perspective to his students and patients. His legacy is the fruit from a live lived with love; of medicine & of his family.

title: For First Time, NATO Invokes Joint Defense Pact With U.S.
description: NATO invoked a mutual defense clause in its founding treaty for the first time today, strongly suggesting that the United States would have the support of the allies if it takes military action against those responsible for attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINES, ADRIENNE (SAVOCA)
description: MARTINES-Adrienne (Savoca). Of Boynton Beach, formerly of Brooklyn, died peacefully at home in Boynton Beach, FL. title: As Remnants Collapse, Workers Run For Cover
description: The stalagmite remnants of the fallen World Trade Center towers collapsed entirely yesterday, sending rumbling debris and clouds of smoke billowing again through Lower Manhattan and prompting rescue workers to flee from the site of the destruction. Officials declared a zone of roughly eight more blocks in the area unstable.

title: Allies Against Terror
description: If the United States is to combat terrorism effectively in the weeks ahead it will have to act in concert with other nations, including a number of Islamic countries. President Bush has recognized the need for international cooperation in his public statements and conversations with foreign leaders since the terror attacks on New York and Washington. Like his father in the Persian Gulf war, he must build a coalition of nations that is prepared to act.

title: Demands of Leadership
description: George W. Bush is facing multiple challenges, but his most important job is a simple matter of leadership. The nation, reeling from this week's terrorist attacks, needs to see its president in control, ready to make tough decisions for the right reasons. Expressing determination to punish the people who organized the assaults on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon is important, but not nearly enough.

title: In Wounded Financial Center, Trying to Head Off Defections
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met with business leaders yesterday afternoon to ask for their help in rebuilding the city after the World Trade Center collapse.

title: Giuliani Says Thousands Are Missing as Rescuers Push On
description: Rescuers combed mountains of rubble at what had been the World Trade Center in a grim search for survivors among the thousands presumed dead in its collapse. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said today that there are at least 3,700 people missing.

title: 'Worse Than Pearl Harbor,' And the Words Ring True
description: The phone rang at Ray Emory's home here on the south shore of Oahu just after 5:30 Tuesday morning. ''Get your radio on,'' a friend told Mr. Emory, 80. ''It's worse than Pearl Harbor.''

title: Helping the Victims
description: At a time of great tragedy, many of us yearn to help and feel the frustration that comes with not being able to find a way to lend a hand. The lines of people offering to give blood and the crowds trying to volunteer stand as tributes to this, the best of our human instincts. To provide some tangible assistance to the families left in great need after the World Trade Center tragedy, The New York Times is establishing a one-month campaign to collect contributions for victims and their families.

title: In the Sorrow, The Seeds of Joy
description: Grief in jazz is rarely monolithic: outside of Billie Holiday's ''Strange Fruit,'' which in many ways is barely a jazz song at all, jazz for sad moments usually contains the thought that life goes on, and not necessarily a life bereft of pleasure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, PHILIP J., DDS.
description: SPECTOR-Philip J., DDS. Peacefully on September 12th, 2001, after a long illness. Husband of Leona, father of Susan, Linda (Peter Jacobson) and Warren (Caroline), grandfather of Alexander and Hannah Jacobson, brother of Lillian Raiten, Sylvia Fiegelman and Irving Spector. He also will be missed by his patients, friends, colleagues and students.

title: Uneven Edges and Dots, For Dining With a Catch
description: Some might liken the irregular shape of his plates to melted Frisbees. But the Japanese-born ceramicist Mineo Mizuno, based in Los Angeles, thinks of his plates as landscapes. ''I hate perfectly thrown plates,'' he said. ''They look machine made.'' He works in black and white (''Food is color,'' he notes) and makes a half dozen patterns, many with polka dots. A set is $400; a dinner plate is $150, a salad plate $100, a bowl $75 and a tea cup $75, available by e-mail: mineo@mineomizuno.com. JAMIE DIAMOND

title: Billions of Dollars in Claims Expected, But Compensation Could Vary Widely

title: As Witnesses to Tragedy, Students Confront Fears
description: A 10-year-old boy is afraid to go back to his school -- ever. A 7-year-old girl wants to know whether the World Trade Center will be rebuilt, and insists that it was empty and that no one was hurt, despite her parents' gentle attempts to tell her the truth.

description: ''Be near me when my light is low. . . . And all the wheels of Being slow.''

title: Central Banks Inject Billions In Move to Stem Risks of Panic
description: Central banks around the world swung into action today in a coordinated effort to calm financial markets and reduce the chances that the attack on the United States would lead to a global economic crisis.

description: The first uniformed employees usually arrive around 1 o'clock. Don Zimmer, the Yankees' bench coach, strolls into Yankee Stadium and strikes up a card game with other coaches. Manager Joe Torre arrives by 3 and works out. Players take the field shortly before 5 for batting practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, ROBERT EMMET
description: FLYNN-Robert Emmet. On Monday, September 10th, 2001. Loving husband of Loretta. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATT, BILLIE LOU
description: WATT-Billie Lou. On September 7th. Billie Lou Watt, wife of actor Hal Studer, died of lung cancer. Ms. Watt, a George Abbott ingenue, appeared in numerous Broadway plays, including Kiss and Tell and Barefoot Boy With Cheek. She had a thirteen year run on Search For Tomorrow and appeared on other soap operas and live television shows. She was the voice for Elsie the Cow in Borden's commercials. Ms. Watt provided the voice for a number of cartoon series, including Astroboy, Kimba and Gigantor and played in numerous regional theaters. She can still be heard in the animated series Courage The Cowardly Dog on the Cartoon Network. Contributions in her memory can be sent to The Actors Fund, 729 7th Ave, New York, NY 10036

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUDGE, O.F.M. MYCHAL F
description: JUDGE-O.F.M. Mychal F., Father. On September 11, 2001. New York City Fire Department Chaplain, New York Press Club and other various fraternal organizations. Beloved brother of Dympna Jessich and Erin McTernan. Family will be receiving friends Thursday and Friday 2-9 PM at St. Francis of Assisi. R.C. Church, 135 W. 31 Street Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday 10:30 AM at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church. Interment to follow at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Father Mychal's memory to the St. Francis of Assisi Bread Line, 135 W. 31 St., NY, NY 10001. Prayers, thoughts and condolences may be shared at www.mem.com. For futher information, call Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 212-288-3500.

title: A Numbing Search, and a Yearning for Answers; The Cause Was Hatred
description: To the Editor:

title: The Kite Meets the Surfboard, And a New Sport Is Born
description: Engineers have tried combining kites and surfboards for years, but now the experiment has become a serious sport, both here on the West Coast and in Hawaii. The technology is evolving fast -- an early innovation was construction of bladder kites, in which the leading edge is inflated and can float in the water, enabling people to relaunch themselves. Shown is the 2001 Fuel kite by Slingshot, a kite-board maker in White Salmon, Wash. It gives a ''lot of boost skyward,'' said Chris Wyman, Slingshot's marketing director. Board, kite and accessories are $1,700; a list of retailers is available from Slingshot (509) 493-3979 or www.slingshotkiteboarding.com.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an arrest in a 30-year-old jet hijacking case gave an incomplete name in some copies for the middle school in Mount Vernon, N.Y., where the suspect was working as a summer school teacher. It is the A. B. Davis Middle School, not the A. B. Middle School.

title: Reopenings Today
description: Broadway theaters are to reopen today, as is the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Many museums and cultural institutions are resuming their normal schedules and operations today and tomorrow. At the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the exhibition ''American Identities: A New Look'' will open today as scheduled. But some concerts and other cultural events, including tonight's opening of the Rachmaninoff Revisited Festival at Lincoln Center, the opening night gala of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and the annual CMJ Music Marathon, have been canceled or postponed. Most touring Broadway shows are expected to resume performances today. Article, page 3.

title: Aides Say Bush Was One Target Of Hijacked Jet
description: Stung by suggestions that President Bush had hurt himself politically by delaying his return to Washington on Tuesday, the White House asserted today that Mr. Bush had done so because of hard evidence that he was a target of the terrorists who hijacked airliners and slammed them into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Differences Are Put Aside As Lawmakers Reconvene
description: The Congress that reopened today was transformed into a unity government, its bitter divisions erased overnight by the worst act of terrorism on American soil and the widespread sentiment that the nation was at war.

title: A Few Moments of Hope In a Mountain of Rubble
description: They found themselves in the landscape of nightmare, with jagged stumps marking where mighty buildings once stood, with the sky shrouded by smoke and the ground coated in ash, and search dogs overwhelmed by the smell of flesh in the acrid air. But there was no time to comprehend it all, not with the driving if faint hope that buried somewhere beneath there breathed survivors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBNER, SOL
description: LEIBNER-Sol. A kind and gentle man-a man of impeccable integrity. Prominent CPA in New York for more than 60 years. Died September 12, 2001 in Long Beach, NY. Devoted father of Richard and his wife Carole Cooper of New York City, and Jerry and is wife Denise of Baldwin Harbor, NY; loving grandfather of Adam and his wife Amy, Jonathan and his wife Mimi, Matthew, David, Elizabeth, Evan and Jordan; greatgrandfather of Lily Sky and dear brother of Julian. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 59 years Eleanor, and a brother Phil. Graveside funeral service, 11AM, Sunday, September 16th, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Wellwood Ave, Pinelawn, NY (Exit 49S on LIE, right on Pinelawn Rd). In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Mercy Hospice, 1220 Front St., Uniondale, NY 11553 or Beth Shalom of Kings Bay, 2710 Ave X, Brooklyn, NY 11235.

title: A Numbing Search, and a Yearning for Answers; Lesson From History
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: House Whip Will Resign
description: Representative David E. Bonior said he would resign as House minority whip on Jan. 15 to work on his campaign for governor. His decision opens the post to a race between Representative Nancy Pelosi of California and Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, who have declared they are interested in the job. Last month, Mr. Bonior, left, announced he would enter the race to replace Gov. John Engler, a Republican. Recent polls show Mr. Bonior trails two declared Democratic candidates, Attorney General Jennifer Granholm and former Gov. James J. Blanchard. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Bush Says Attack Was 'First War of the 21st Century'
description: President Bush today called the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon "the first war of the 21st century," and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell named the Islamic militant Osama bin Laden as a prime suspect in engineering them.

title: Below 14th Street, Silence but an Eerie Disquiet
description: New York City stopped at 14th Street yesterday. South of that artificial border between a city alive and a city of ghosts, an eerie serenity took hold.

title: A Numbing Search, and a Yearning for Answers; Security on Flights
description: To the Editor:

title: Weary of Gadgetmania? Just Dial M for Mockery
description: IT looks like the result of a miscommunication at an industrial design lab: a household steam iron with a cell-phone keypad and display punched into its metal plate. It's not much use as an iron, but it's a perfectly good cell phone, if a little heavy. Just dial a number and grab the handle as if you are about to iron your face.

title: Former Gehry Associate Designs Chairs of His Own
description: Joel Stearns, who at one time ran an art-publishing firm that produced cardboard chairs designed by Frank Gehry, has developed his own line, using a laminated cardboard five-eighths of an inch thick. ''I wanted to build something that was inexpensive, well designed and that would last,'' he said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: More Prisoners Released
description: The military government released six more political prisoners in what it called ''a good-will gesture in the process of political transition.'' It said the releases brought to 167 the number of political prisoners freed this year before the end of their terms, including 48 opposition members of Parliament. The opposition says about 1,500 political prisoners remain in detention. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: To Chill the Lily

title: Powell Says It Clearly: No Middle Ground on Terrorism
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell marshaled a broad diplomatic effort today, talking to allied governments and sending stern messages to other countries that they can no longer remain neutral in the fight against terrorism.

title: Text of Mayor Giuliani, Governor Pataki and Police Commisioner Kerik
description: Following is the text of a news conference today by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik, as recorded by The New York Times :

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCKLEY, FRANCES A.
description: BUCKLEY-Frances A. On Sept. 11, 2001 of Seaford. Beloved wife of Donald E., devoted mother of Donna, William and Francine. Loving sister of James E., John M. and the late William J. McCarthy. Reposing at the Charles G. Schmitt Funeral Home, 3863 Merrick Road, Seaford (2 traffic lights E. of Rt 135). Mass of Christian Burial Sat. 9:30 AM St. William the Abbot RC Church. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Hours Thurs. 79:30 PM, Fri. 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Donations to Parish Outreach, St. William the Abbot RC Church, 2000 Jackson Ave, Seaford, NY 11783 would be appreciated.

title: In Times of Crisis, Debates About Whether to Play Games
description: Until the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon on Tuesday, the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963 was the pivotal event in determining the way sports leagues react to a national tragedy or natural disaster.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about Emilio Meneses, a Chilean professor who was recently accused of torture during the military coup in Chile in 1973, misstated the New York University affiliation of Patricio Navia, who wrote a letter denouncing Mr. Meneses. Mr. Navia is a graduate student, not a professor.

title: Fellow Americans Opening Hearts, Wallets and Veins
description: By the hour, they came: Mothers popped from vans; an Army recruiter emptied his wallet and went back to the bank for more; two postal workers left $660 collected from colleagues; a shift of firefighters gave $125.

title: A Reality Show as Both Mirror and Ploy
description: Company is likely to come looking for the misery that propels the absorbing reality show that is Nina Davenport's documentary ''Always a Bridesmaid.''

title: Japan Has Little Time for Its Old-Time Religion
description: Dressed smartly in a black skirt and a turquoise silk shirt with wide lapels, Yuka Sugimoto receives visitors in a sleek suite of offices these days, handing them a business card taken from a fancy zebra-skin wallet.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Bryon Lesmann, Liz Graham, Jeff Lindquist, and George Isakson, July 7, 2001, Billings County, N. D., rig No. 49

title: Now, Follow the Bouncing Nucleotide
description: IT sounds like a question in a Barbara Walters interview: If you were a song, what song would you be? Now, thanks to the availability of human DNA data on the Internet, and software programs that convert DNA sequences into music, you can find out.

title: Shock and Anger Among Arab-Americans
description: Sara Saleh's eyes were red and puffy below the blue and white kerchief that covered her hair, and she looked exhausted as she sat in the waiting room of an Arab community center in this Detroit suburb. ''I pray to God they catch whoever did this and kill them,'' said Mrs. Saleh, an immigrant from Lebanon.

title: Bush Labels Aerial Terrorist Attacks 'Acts of War'
description: President Bush declared today that the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were ''acts of war.'' He spent much of the day trying to rally an international coalition for what could become a massive military response -- once the enemy was identified.

title: Barest Count, by Three of Hundreds of Companies, Has 1,500 Missing
description: Rescuers combed mountains of rubble at what had been the World Trade Center today in a grim search for survivors among the thousands presumed dead in its collapse. Investigators meantime cast a worldwide net for those behind the hijackers who slammed jetliners into the twin towers in New York City and the Pentagon in Virginia in the worst terrorist attack in American history.

title: Department's Cruel Toll: 350 Comrades
description: They are trained to rush toward disasters, even as others are running away, and so death, in the minds of many New York City firefighters, is a regrettable, but at times unavoidable, part of their difficult job.

title: A Numbing Search, and a Yearning for Answers; Beyond Retaliation
description: To the Editor:

title: Golf Events Canceled
description: The PGA Tour has canceled its entire weekend schedule, including the American Express Championship in St. Louis, a World Golf Championships event with a $5 million purse, and a field that was to feature Tiger Woods and many of the world's top players. The Tampa Bay Classic, the Senior Tour Vantage Championship, and the Buy.Com Oregon Classic were also canceled.

title: Reaction From Around the World
description: EUROPE

title: Still Reeling From Losses, New York Looks for Makeshift Solutions
description: New York City and State struggled yesterday to provide critical services to the five boroughs, patching holes in staffing and equipment with borrowed suburban firefighters and National Guard troops, police officers on 12-hour shifts, and makeshift headquarters for agencies forced to flee the destruction downtown.

title: Multiple Microphones Create Order Out of Sonic Chaos
description: THE trouble with modern microphones is that they are just too sensitive. In noisy settings in particular, they can pick up too much sound, making it difficult to distinguish speech. And for the most part, screening out unwanted sounds has involved either bulky and hard-to-use directional microphones or inconvenient headsets.

title: Arafat Angrily Insists Palestinians Didn't Rejoice Over Terror Attack on U.S.
description: Yasir Arafat angrily rejected tonight any suggestion that Palestinians had rejoiced over the terrorist attack on the United States on Tuesday, declaring that the Palestinian reaction was one of identification and not satisfaction with American suffering.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Reformers Jailed
description: The hard-line judiciary continued its pressure on reformist politicians by upholding a 19-month prison term for a journalist, Massoud Behnoud, and a one-year prison term for a member of Parliament. Hossein Loghmanian is the fifth member of Parliament to receive a jail sentence in recent months. A second journalist, Mahmoud Shams, who has been jailed for seven months, was sent back to jail this week after a five-day leave. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Over 2,500 Register Information on Missing Persons
description: Michael Rodriguez, a lieutenant with the Army National Guard, had spent the last two days digging through the rubble at the World Trade Center helping the seach for survivors and directing crowds around the area. Today, he was given the day off and he spent the time again searching for one of the missing - his sister.

title: Closing the Window On Pop-Up Advertising
description: Q. How can I disable or block those pesky pop-up advertisements from Web pages?

title: Mets Travel Home by Bus
description: At long last, the Mets escaped the hotel rooms and the televisions and the often futile attempts to telephone home. Today, they returned to a baseball field. They took to the grass of PNC Park here, amid the quiet and the late-afternoon sunshine, and for 90 minutes they threw and hit and joked and ran and played.

title: Police Commissioner Says Arrest Made at Kennedy Airport
description: One person carrying false identification was arrested at New York's Kennedy Airport Thursday, and "five or six" others had been detained, said New York Police Commissioner Bernard Kerik.

title: Towers Lent City a Lift, Adding Postcard Panache And an Air of Resilience
description: In that awful void in the Lower Manhattan skyline -- which memory and the mind's eye still try desperately to fill again -- stood not only New York's twin-limbed Colossus of Rhodes but a community every bit as electric, as coursing, as nimble and sometimes as maddening or as neighborly as the city it had come to symbolize in only 28 years of existence.

title: Tearful Firefighters Mourn for Brothers
description: In a teary corner of the brotherhood, firefighters here in the western Chicago suburb tested 300-foot fire hoses on South Boulevard today, white water spouting in the sun. But the hearts of Lt. Pat Biswurm and his men were many miles away.

title: Bayer Names New Chief Executive
description: LONDON, Sept. 13  Defying expectations, Bayer A.G. said today that it would not sell its embattled pharmaceuticals unit after all, and it named a longtime executive, not a fresh face from outside the company, to succeed its chief executive, Manfred Schneider.

title: Getting in Close, Yet Standing Apart
description: A photographer depicting grief is not like an artist, a playwright or a musician doing the same thing. If a photographer catches a family in mourning, a soldier overcome, a mother in agony, you know a few things about that photographer. He was there, holding a camera and standing apart, literally. His eyes were focusing his subject, framing a shot. His hands were on the shutter release.

title: G.E. and Honeywell Appeal Europe's Rejection of Deal
description: The General Electric Company and Honeywell International Inc. have appealed the European Commission's rejection of their $45 billion merger, the European Court of Justice said today.

title: Companies Nationwide Try To Operate Despite Odds
description: Across corporate America yesterday, senior managers and executives grappled with trying to restore at least a semblance of business as usual -- even though they knew that, emotionally at least, it was anything but.

title: Caught Behind Barricades And Waiting to Go Home
description: The road from homeless to home led through a squad of Nassau County police officers guarding a barricade at Hudson and Houston Streets.

title: In Parking Garages, Putting an End to the Space Race
description: IT is a common annoyance for air travelers: you are already late for a flight and you can't find a space anywhere in the airport parking garage. As the minutes tick away to takeoff, you trail travelers strolling back to their cars as you scout out the next aisle.

title: Stadiums Are Empty as Athletes Take a Timeout
description: Major League Baseball, continuing to tread sensitively following Tuesday's terrorist attacks, postponed two more days of games yesterday and left open the strong possibility that the season will be extended beyond the scheduled Sept. 30 finish.

title: A Modernist Temple Replaces a Dive
description: In recent years it had iconic status and few customers. Now the Brig, a 40-year-old bar on Abbot Kinney Boulevard in Venice, has been transformed from a seedy dive for old-timers into a seething hangout for 20-somethings who like their beer served in an environment with attitude. It was designed by the architect John Friedman (of John Friedman Alice Kimm Architects), who previously displayed a penchant for plastic and metal in designing the Santa Monica nightspot Club Sugar.

title: Our Towns; Unclaimed Cars in a Train Station Garage, and Suburban Lives in Limbo
description: UNDER the smooth skin of this suburb that thrives on Wall Street money, the chaotic reverberations of Tuesday's terrorism have rearranged life.

title: Foreign Affairs; World War III
description: As I restlessly lay awake early yesterday, with CNN on my TV and dawn breaking over the holy places of Jerusalem, my ear somehow latched onto a statement made by the U.S. transportation secretary, Norman Mineta, about the new precautions that would be put in place at U.S. airports in the wake of Tuesday's unspeakable terrorist attacks: There will be no more curbside check-in, he said. I suddenly imagined a group of terrorists somewhere here in the Middle East, sipping coffee, also watching CNN and laughing hysterically: ''Hey boss, did you hear that? We just blew up Wall Street and the Pentagon and their response is no more curbside check-in?''

title: BIN LADEN TIE CITED
description: The hijackers who commandeered commercial jets that attacked the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were followers of Osama bin Laden, the Islamic militant who has been blamed for some of the bloodiest attacks against Americans, federal authorities said today.

title: Corrections
description: An Arts Abroad article last Thursday about Roman Polanski and a film he is making adapted from ''The Pianist,'' an account of surviving the Warsaw ghetto, referred imprecisely to the death of Sharon Tate, his wife, in 1969. She was killed by followers of Charles Manson. Mr. Manson was not present when Ms. Tate was killed but was convicted of having masterminded the murder.

title: Corporate Paper Trails Lie Buried in Soot
description: As businesses began to digest the loss of life yesterday, they also had to address the loss of records.

title: Hopes Are Raised, and Dashed, About Rescue of Firefighters
description: In a town eager for miracles, the news that five firefighters had been pulled out alive today from a sports utility vehicle buried under debris from the collapsed World Trade Center seemed for a moment to be an answer to those prayers.

title: Tagliabue And N.F.L. Undecided On Playing
description: The National Football League, faced with many players opposed to playing and with the specter of a controversial decision made nearly four decades ago hanging over its head, spent yesterday trying to decide whether to play this weekend's games.

title: Devils Open Camp
description: The Devils opened their training camp at South Mountain Arena today with 57 players, all trying to stay focused.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRILLIN, ALICE. WIFE OF CALVIN
description: TRILLIN-Alice. Wife of Calvin, mother of Abigail and Sarah, September 12, 2001. Friends are welcome at a Memorial Service 11am, September 21st, Celeste Bartos Forum at the New York Public Library, 42nd St and 5th Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to The Hole In The Wall Gang Camp.

title: A Numbing Search, and a Yearning for Answers; This Is War
description: To the Editor:

title: Reopenings and Postponements
description: Broadway theaters are to open again today. The League of American Theaters and Producers, the trade organization for Broadway, encouraged ticketholders to exchange tickets for canceled performances for another date by bringing them to the box office. Refunds will also be available on presentation of tickets. Most nationally touring productions will also resume performances; theatergoers with questions about those productions were advised to call the show's box office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIMM, KAREN
description: GRIMM-Karen. Beloved daughter of the late Claire and Frank. Loving sister of Bruce and Elena Shifren. Adored aunt of Elyssa, Chelsea and Steven. Cherished niece, cousin and friend to many. Service Friday 2PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NY NY.

title: The Expression of Grief and the Power of Art
description: Nothing provokes the artistic sensibility like grief. In the artist, events like those of Tuesday morning bring about a meeting of universal emotions and an individual will to unearth them, expose them, understand them and accept if not outlast them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSZ, ALEXANDER
description: KRAUSZ-Alexander. On September 11, 2001 at the age of 82. Beloved son, husband, father, grandfather and all-around wonderful soul. With all our love from Ida, Diane, Robi, Sophie, Lucy and Sammy. Service Thursday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: About the Calendar
description: In the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center, some events listed in the Calendar may have been canceled or postponed. Readers are advised to telephone the sponsors.

title: For Pine Nuts
description: SOME like it because it's chic ---- a refuge from all-white -- and others because it's cheap. Here's where to find knotty pine, real and fake.
