description: SCHWARTZ-Alvin. All of us at Helmsley-Spear, Inc. mourn the loss of Alvin Schwartz, the company's co-chairman and a giant in the real estate industry. During the last 55 years, Mr. Schwartz earned the respect and enjoyed the admiration of his colleagues at Helmsley-Spear, Inc. His friendship was invaluable. He will be remembered for his kindness, generosity and compassion. Condolences are extended to his daughters Jane and Amy, his son Tom, his grandchildren and the entire Schwartz Family. In Alvin's memory, the offices of HelmsleySpear, Inc. will be closed on Friday September 14, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEERIN, RAYMOND THOMAS
description: SHEERIN - Raymond Thomas. Born February 18, 1934. Died August 13, 2001 after a long and brave battle with prostate cancer. Survivers include his beloved wife Barbara, children and step-children Laurie, Raymond Jr. (Pat), Matthew (Eileen), Mark, Lisa (Jussi) Melartin, Michael Waitzman, eight grandchildren, brotherin-law Dr. Robert (Barbara) Margolis. Niece Dr. Jennifer (Dr. Eric) Fryer, nephew Steven (Jenifer) Margolis. Donations to Fordham Prep in his memory would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an arrest in a 30-year-old jet hijacking case gave an incomplete name in some copies for the middle school in Mount Vernon, N.Y., where the suspect was working as a summer school teacher. It is the A. B. Davis Middle School, not the A. B. Middle School.

title: A Personal Peace For Every Mourner
description: When people mourn, they immediately turn to music. The most popular single of all time is not ''White Christmas'' or anything by 'N Sync but an elegy: Elton John's rendition of ''Candle in the Wind'' at the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales. Beyond the world's shock over the tragedy that took her life, the song struck a deeper chord of loss in those who heard it, touching a place that sometimes only music can reach.

title: Challenges and Dangers in Disposing of Two Fallen Giants
description: New York's twin World Trade Center towers were considered a triumph of engineering and ambition as they rose in the late 1960's and early 70's. Cleaning up the vast mountain of debris at the 16-acre site, all that remains of the trade center's dream after a terrorist attack on Tuesday morning, presents a challenge no less daunting than the construction itself, engineers and environmental cleanup experts say.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Raising The Kursk
description: Deep-sea divers freed a specially built cable saw that had been snagged in an anchor chain of the submarine Kursk for much of the last day, and officials said the sunken submarine's damaged bow could be completely severed from the rest of the ship as early as today. The rest of the submarine is to be fitted with custom-designed cables and raised beneath the bow of a retrieval ship, perhaps as early as late this month. The bow is to be left on the Barents Sea floor for recovery later. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Stadium Catches Fire
description: A small fire broke out atop a stadium being built for the Seattle Seahawks of the National Football League. Fire officials say workers on the roof of the elevator control room, about 150 feet above ground, started the fire when sparks from a welding torch ignited the roof. The fire was extinguished 30 minutes after it began. No injuries were reported. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Designers Say Knotty Is Nice
description: THE big debate began -- as debates often do -- with the decision to save money.

title: The New World Order Is a Clash of Civilizations
description: BERLIN  The clash of civilizations that appears to have brought a monstrous terror attack to the United States has left no neutral corners where countries or individuals can hide from new choices in what is a suddenly different world.

title: How to Help The Neediest Of Cases
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had begun a special campaign to raise money for the victims of the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Instincts to Flee Competed With Instructions to Remain
description: When the first jet struck 1 World Trade Center at 8:48 a.m. on Tuesday, the people in 2 World Trade Center with a view of the instant inferno across the divide had the clearest sense of what they, too, must do: get out fast.

title: Upset Votes In Primaries For Mayors
description: While turnout on Tuesday for mayoral primaries in three major cities was unsurprisingly low on a day when the nation's attention was turned to terrorist attacks, the results were anything but predictable.

title: September 16th: Closings and Openings
description: All streets below Canal Street are closed. Streets and businesses between 14th Street and Canal Street have been reopened and routes yet to be determined will be opened to Wall Street by Monday.

title: A City of Quiet: Nothing Is Same One Day After
description: New York woke up to another day yesterday, but it wasn't another day. It couldn't possibly be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, MARY M. (NEE MAGUIRE).
description: DONOVAN-Mary M. (nee Maguire). Of Spring Lake, NJ, formerly of Scarsdale, NY and Astoria, Queens, NY on Monday, September 10, 2001. Mrs. Donovan worked as a senior field vice-president with Mutual of America in New York City. Beloved wife of Thomas J. Roach. Devoted mother of John, Stephen, Patricia and Michael. Step-mother of Thomas Roach and Deborah Yobs. Dear sister of Sr. Virginia Maguire, OP, and the late Sr. Beatrice Maguire, OP. Loving grandmother of Meghan, Ryan and Michael. Funeral from the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd, Wall, NJ on Friday, Sept 14 at 8:30 AM. Mass St. Catharine's RC Church at 9:30 AM. Entombment St. Catharine's Cemetery Mausoleum, Sea Girt, NJ. Visiting hours, Wed Sept 12 from 7-9 PM and Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Cancer Society, 801 Broad St, Shrewsbury, NJ 07701 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDMOND, FRANCES JONES
description: REDMOND-Frances Jones. On September 11, 2001 at the Osborn retirement home in Rye, NY. She was 101 years old. Born on June 25, 1900 in Brooklyn, NY she was the daughter of the late Sally and Matthew Carpenter Jones and sister of the late Matthew Carpenter Jones, Jr. Mrs. Redmond graduated from the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn and was a long time member of the Junior League of Brooklyn and the Colony Club in Manhattan. She maintained summer residences for many years in Bellport, New York and, later, in Westhampton Beach, New York. As well as her parents and brother she was predeceased by her husband, Cyril J. Redmond and a daughter, Barbara Redmond Ryan of New York. She is survived by a daughter, Jean Dalzell Cushing of Riverside, CT, five grandchildren, Deborah Zinn Prouty and Kathryn Zinn Cerussi of Riverside, CT, Sally Ryan Shaw of Hamilton, MA, Allan A. Ryan IV of Palm Beach, FL and Melissa Ryan Kaiser of New York, NY. She also leaves eleven greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date.

description: EUROPE

title: Where to Go For Assistance
description: At least three businesses in the World Trade Center have set up phone numbers for those looking for friends or relatives:

title: Columbia and Fordham See Game as a Catharsis
description: At Columbia's campus on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, it was business as usual yesterday. Classes, for the most part, went on as scheduled. Students milled about, moving from building to building with backpacks slung over their shoulders. From the Morningside Heights campus, there were barely any signs of the tragedy that had taken place Tuesday at the World Trade Center. The smoke and dust over Lower Manhattan were barely visible on 116th Street. Life went on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANCI, PETER J., JR.
description: GANCI-Peter J., Jr. (Chief of the Department F.D.N.Y.) of North Massapequa on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Kathleen (nee Koster). Devoted father of Peter Ganci III (L 111 F.D.N.Y.), Christopher M. Ganci and Danielle K. Ganci. Cherished brother of Mary Dougherty, James Ganci, Daniel Ganci and Ellen Ganci. Loving brother-in-law of Ronald Koster, Richard Koster, Theresa Giametta and Cheryl Szilagy. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends Thursday and Friday 2-5 & 7-9:30pm at The Farmingdale Fire Department, 361 Main Street, Farmingdale. Mass of The Christian Burial Saturday 11 AM at St. Kilian RC Church. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. For information please contact The McCourt & Trudden Funeral Home, Inc., 385 Main Street, Farmingdale at 516-249-1303.

title: A Desktop-Quality Screen Takes Its Act on the Road
description: When computer buyers hear the name Sharp, they probably think of flat-screen monitors for desktops or maybe a microwave oven for the office kitchen. Lately, however, the company has made a big push into the notebook computer market on the strength of its reputation as a screen maker. Last week Sharp unveiled its newest entry, the PC-UM10, which comes with a Pentium III 600 megahertz processor, 128 megabytes of RAM, a 20-gigabyte hard drive and Sharp's anti-glare technology for its 12.1-inch monitor. What makes the PC-UM10 stand out, however, is its relative size. At under three pounds and less than three-quarters of an inch thick (excluding its diskette and CD-ROM drives), the notebook, which starts at $1,999, is as light and slender as many of the slightest notebooks. It could be the perfect companion for road warriors whose obsession with dropping weight rivals that of hot-air balloonists. Bruce Headlam

title: Struggling to Find Words for a Horror Beyond Words
description: Language failed this week.

title: Powell Says It Clearly: No Middle Ground on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell marshaled a broad diplomatic effort today, talking to allied governments and sending stern messages to other countries that they can no longer remain neutral in the fight against terrorism.

title: A Numbing Search, and a Yearning for Answers; A Muslim Plea
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets, Awaiting Word From the League, Say It's Time to Mourn, Not Play
description: With some players still waiting to learn of the fates of friends and neighbors after Tuesday's attacks on the World Trade Center, the Jets said today that they did not want to play a game on Sunday. The team is scheduled to play at Oakland, and the National Football League was expected to make an announcement on Thursday about the weekend schedule.

title: Renting Wheels and Riding Rails as Skies Stay Off Limits
description: Federal authorities, initially hoping to reopen the skies to airplanes this afternoon, said today that most planes would remain grounded until extra security measures could be put in place.

title: STUNNED RESCUERS COMB ATTACK SITES, BUT THOUSANDS ARE PRESUMED DEAD; F.B.I. TRACKING HIJACKERS' MOVEMENTS
description: Rescuers combed mountains of rubble at what had been the World Trade Center yesterday in a grim search for survivors among the thousands presumed dead in its collapse. Investigators meantime cast a worldwide net for those behind the hijackers who slammed jetliners into the twin towers in New York City and the Pentagon in Virginia in the worst terrorist attack in American history.

title: Peter J. Ganci, 54, Fire Chief, While Leading Tower Rescue
description: Peter J. Ganci, the New York City Fire Department's highest-ranking uniformed officer, died on Tuesday in the collapse of the World Trade Center towers. He was 54.

title: 8 Palestinians and an Israeli Settler Killed in a Surge of Violence
description: A surge of violence punctuated by an Israeli tank thrust into a West Bank town left eight Palestinians dead today, including a 9-year-old girl, as well as an Israeli settler shot dead by Palestinian gunmen.

title: Berry Berenson Perkins, 53, Photographer Known for Fashion
description: Berry Berenson Perkins, a photographer and eclectic fashion plate of the 1970's before she settled into marriage with the actor Anthony Perkins, was killed on Tuesday, a passenger on American Airlines Flight 11, which was the first jetliner to strike the World Trade Center, a spokeswoman for the family said. She was 53.

title: Text of Bush's Phone Conversation
description: Following is the text of a telephone conference call today among President Bush, Governor George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: The Expression of Grief and the Power of Art
description: Nothing provokes the artistic sensibility like grief. In the artist, events like those of Tuesday morning bring about a meeting of universal emotions and an individual will to unearth them, expose them, understand them and accept if not outlast them.

title: Trying to Find A Name On a List Of the Living
description: It was nearly midnight Tuesday when Richard Su, a volunteer driver who had been shuttling people from hospital to hospital in search of injured relatives and friends, came for Lynette Mohammed. She was looking for her husband, Boyie, a stock trader at Carr Futures, on the 93rd floor of 2 World Trade Center.

title: Islanders Put Punch Into Training Camp
description: The Islanders were finally allowed to slam into one another at practice today, and Eric Cairns, the grizzled and intense defenseman, was so excited that he twice dropped his gloves and began pounding on his teammates.

title: Ace Bailey, 53, Hockey Scout and Player
description: Garnet (Ace) Bailey, a scout for the Los Angeles Kings of the National Hockey League and a former player in the league, was among the passengers killed when the hijacked United Airlines Flight 175 crashed into the World Trade Center on Tuesday. He was 53.

title: A Place of Solace in a Time of Grief
description: YOU can hear the sound of water before you see it, burbling out of the fountain at the newly restored biblical garden at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The garden, tucked behind the church that towers over Amsterdam Avenue at 113th Street, offers solace to those in search of calm, a place to do some soul-searching or simply to contemplate a flower. This week, many people sought its benches and the shade of its grapevine-covered arbors.

title: Investigators Begin Examining Wreckage for Data Recorders
description: Dozens of investigators began today what they said would be a long, arduous effort to reconstruct the final minutes of United Flight 93, which was hijacked on Tuesday morning and crashed into an open field in this mountainous rural region of western Pennsylvania.

title: Better Networks: Look to Nature
description: THE Internet is an engineering feat of no small magnitude. It operates using a method of data transmission invented in the 1960's called packet switching. Send e-mail, for instance, and your message is broken into any number of little bundles; each takes a separate route and reunites with the others at the destination.

title: Taliban Plead for Mercy to the Miserable in a Land of Nothing
description: If there are Americans clamoring to bomb Afghanistan back to the Stone Age, they ought to know that this nation does not have so far to go. This is a post-apocalyptic place of felled cities, parched land and downtrodden people.

title: A Numbing Search, and a Yearning for Answers; Explaining Evil
description: To the Editor:

title: Gentle Choruses, Bold Affirmations
description: In the last months of his life, a friend of mine in Boston who was steadily succumbing to AIDS listened to music, all kinds of music, constantly. But what he kept coming back to was a tape of a performance of Mozart's Piano Quartet in E flat that I, at the piano, had given along with three string-player colleagues. So when my friend died in May 1990 at 35, the obvious piece to play at his memorial service was that Mozart quartet.

title: Pentagon Official Outlines Plan to Put Military on War Footing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  A senior Pentagon official laid out today in the starkest terms yet the outline of a plan to put the American military on a war footing for the next year, describing a "a campaign, not a single action," that would attack terrorists and their havens and bring down governments that support them.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages last Thursday about preparations for the MTV awards ceremony that night referred incorrectly to ''Smooth Criminal.'' It is the title of a song by Michael Jackson, not a band.

title: Quiet Day for Giants
description: When pro football players are preparing for a game, the most important day is Wednesday, when they receive the game plans and heavy practices begin. But yesterday at Giants Stadium, things were mostly quiet for the Giants. For the second straight day, there was no practice, part of a plan Coach Jim Fassel devised weeks ago because he felt his players would benefit more by rest after their Monday night game in Denver.

title: Trauma, Felt Directly or Not, Takes a Psychic Toll
description: The subway car slowed, stopped briefly, then abruptly lurched forward on its way to Times Square.

title: U.S. Current Account Deficit Narrowed in Latest Quarter
description: The United States current account deficit narrowed in the second quarter as slowing economies around the world reduced the level of trade, government figures showed today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wreckage on Wall Street Is Emotional and Practical

title: A Route Out of Washington, Horribly Changed
description: Most of the seats were empty on American Airlines Flight 77, a twin-engine Boeing 757, and the people who sat near windows for the flight from Dulles International Airport to Los Angeles had a crystal-clear view of the Blue Ridge Mountains and then the Ohio River Valley far below.

title: In America; 'It Wasn't a Dream'
description: For the first 24 hours -- as the horrifying images exploded again and again on television screens across the nation -- there was the numbness and the disbelief that accompanies shock.

title: The Yukon's Wide Open Spaces Luring Europeans
description: Two Romans posed for summer vacation snapshots, bundled against a chill wind and straddling the imaginary line of the Arctic Circle.

title: A Rending Scream That Spoke for All
description: Those who were there when the scream was sounded offstage said they could still hear it decades later.

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, click here .

title: Reliving the Andrea Doria Collision, From Dry Land
description: EIGHT cadets at the United States Merchant Marine Academy and their teacher peered from a ship's bridge into the foggy night. Radar showed a vessel approaching, and the cadets' ship swerved to starboard to avoid a crash. Out of the mist, a ship's bow slid in front of them.

title: A City Awakes, Only to Reflect On a Nightmare
description: New York woke up to another day yesterday, but it wasn't another day. It couldn't possibly be.

title: New York City Transportation Emergency Changes
description: Cover --> Express Bus

title: Rangers Halve Camp Dates
description: The Rangers yesterday announced that they had pushed back their opening of training camp another day, out of respect for the victims of Tuesday's terrorist attacks.

title: National Airport Information
description: The following is a list of the country's major airports, with information on airport status. Always call your airline to check flight status before proceeding. More information can be found at Travel Bulletin Central .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ANN
description: ROSENBERG-Ann. The Merrick Jewish Centre, Congregation Ohrtorah, mourns the passing of our beloved member Ann Rosenberg and extends heartfelt condolences to her dear family. We pray they will be consoled with all the mourners of our people. Service at Boulevard Funeral Home in Hewlett, Long Island, New York. Alan Sussman, President Rabbi Charles A. Klein

title: Flights Resume in the U.S., but Service Far From Normal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Air travel resumed across the United States this morning, but it will be some time before things are normal. Indeed, the very definition of ``normal'' has changed.

title: Russia Joins NATO in Condemning Terrorist Attack Against the U.S.
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 13  President Bush's call for a global coalition against terrorism continued to garner foreign support today as Russia, in a rare joint statement with NATO, expressed its anger over Tuesday's attacks in New York and Washington and called for a worldwide effort to combat such acts.

title: F.A.A. Announces Stricter Rules; Knives No Longer Allowed
description: While it is illegal to carry cans of hairspray, sparklers and rat poison onto passenger jets, Federal Aviation Administration regulations have for many years allowed passengers to carry knives with blades up to four inches long on commercial flights.

title: Middleweight Fight Postponed
description: The biggest middleweight fight in years, a grudge battle between Felix Trinidad and Bernard Hopkins, has been postponed. The bout, which was scheduled to take place Saturday at Madison Square Garden, was the culmination of Don King's middleweight world championship series. No new date has been set for the bout, but King, who said he consulted with both fighters before making his decision, said he hoped to hold the event on Saturday, Sept. 29, at the Garden.

title: Part of Subway Tunnel May Have Collapsed Under Weight of Debris, Officials Fear
description: Inspectors surveying subway damage under the World Trade Center came up against a solid wall of debris yesterday in one tunnel on the No. 1 and 9 line, and transit officials said they feared that sections of the tunnel had collapsed. If that happened, the officials said, it could take years to reopen that stretch and restore service to the tip of Manhattan.

title: Lisa J. Raines, 42, a Lobbyist for Biotechnology
description: Lisa J. Raines, one of the earliest and most prominent lobbyists for the biotechnology industry, died on Tuesday in the crash of the hijacked airplane that hit the Pentagon. She was 42 and lived in Great Falls, Va.

title: An Electronic Bass Turns Everything Into 'Silent Night'
description: Funny, when most people listen to music, they want the bass turned up. Yamaha has developed a new bass -- an upright string bass -- whose volume control can be turned down to almost nothing, perfect for the urban musician with co-op problems or complaining neighbors.

title: Entombed for a Day, Then Found
description: For a brief moment yesterday morning, amid the suffering that engulfed the World Trade Center, a cheer rang down the ruined streets.

title: A Numbing Search, and a Yearning for Answers; Firefighters, Heroes
description: To the Editor:

title: Huge Events Are Close to Home
description: The very nature of television changes in times of national tragedy and grief. A medium that usually treats death with murder-of-the-week flippancy suddenly brings its reality into our homes and offices with disturbing immediacy. As a country, we watched an inconceivable number of lives disappear before our eyes along with the World Trade Center, a horrifying shared experience. But there is always a second wave, which will play out again in the days to come.

title: Second Plane to Strike World Trade Center Tower Took a Deliberate Path
description: Of the four crashes, the one of Flight 175 seemed, in some ways, the most chillingly deliberate.

title: Card-Size Cameras That (Mostly) Measure Up
description: WHEN normal people see the movie ''Robocop,'' they immerse themselves in metaphysical contemplation: ''Oh, how can a man retain his soul when half of him is a machine?'' Gadget freaks like me, on the other hand, snuggle happily into our seats. ''So cool! This guy has all his personal electronics built right in!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELL, SAMUEL
description: TELL-Samuel. On September 11,2001. Beloved husband of the late Leah. Dear father of Elaine. Services Friday, September 14th, 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Eggesin Journal; Yearning for a Big Army, if Only for the Paycheck
description: Ute Kokot has worked at the Eggesin military barracks since 1972, when the Ninth Panzer Division of the German People's Army had nearly 19,000 soldiers training here, prepared to fight their brothers in West Germany in the great superpower confrontation that never came.

title: Terrorists Were Well Trained, But Not Necessarily in Flying
description: Whoever planned the airplane attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon was knowledgeable about aircraft, architectural engineering, aviation fuel and the characteristics of planes in flight, several experts said yesterday. But there was disagreement about whether the hijackers themselves needed any special expertise beyond rudimentary ability at the controls.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Bosnian Serbs To Plead Guilty
description: Two Bosnian Serbs accused of atrocities at a prison camp in 1992 have agreed to plead guilty to a charge of persecution as a crime against humanity, a spokesman for the United Nations war-crimes tribunal said. In exchange, prosecutors agreed to drop all other charges against the men. As part of the deal, prosecutors will ask for 10 to 17 years' imprisonment for Dusko Sikirica, above, commander of the Keraterm camp, and for 5 to 7 years for one of his lieutenants, Damir Dosen. In sentencing, tribunal judges are not bound by deals between prosecutors and defendants. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: A Rush to Adjust Entertainment in the Light of Some Real Events
description: The devastation brought about by the country's worst confrontation with terrorism continued to reverberate through the nation's culture yesterday as numerous media organizations announced changes to long-established and often extremely expensive plans for the coming days and weeks.

title: A World in Mourning

Reaching Out
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: In His Kingdom, Sun Always Shines
description: ''Walt: The Man Behind the Myth,'' a documentary about Walt Disney to celebrate the 100th anniversary of his birth, is what you might expect from a production assembled with the blessing of the Disney family (complete with home movies). Appearing this Sunday on ABC, a Disney-owned television network, it is a Disneyland-style biography, a sunny, homogenized version of reality.

title: Watching a Creation From Infancy to Rubble
description: Forty years ago, when Minoru Yamasaki received a letter from the Port Authority about a potential project in Lower Manhattan, he held it up to his staff as an example of careless writing. Clearly, there was an extra decimal point in the budget.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Advocate Drops Flag Effort
description: The leader of a movement to amend the State Constitution to preserve the state's flag, which includes the Confederate battle emblem, says he will halt the drive. The leader, Greg Stewart of Tunica, said he would not submit the more than 90,000 signatures he had gathered on a petition to put on the ballot a measure keeping the flag as it is, saying a referendum last April when two-thirds of voters said they did not want change is protection enough.

title: Stories of a Stricken City, and a Grieving Land; Remember Our Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLENTUCH, ADA.
description: ALLENTUCH-Ada. On September 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Barbara, Karin and the late Leslie. Cherished grandmother of Joshua. Services Sunday, 11:30AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Tightened Inspections Mean Delays From Maine to West
description: The United States and Canada have long boasted that they had the world's longest undefended border. But the porous nature of that 5,525-mile boundary came in for close scrutiny today, as F.B.I. agents swept through Maine to investigate whether hijackers responsible for the terrorist attacks on Tuesday had entered this country from Canada.

title: Prices of Imported Goods Fell in August
description: Prices of imported goods fell in August for the sixth time in seven months, government figures showed today, in a sign that the threat of inflation remains subdued.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. Because of the attacks on Manhattan, some events may be canceled. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: A Play Date With History
description: One of the most intriguing play areas for children recently opened in a place where young visitors are more often exhorted not to touch anything, much less try it on: a museum for adults.

title: Elite Force Aims to Avert Air Attacks
description: Virtually all airlines and pilots agree that one way to enhance security in the air would be to expand an obscure federal program that covertly places specially trained, armed guards on select commercial flights.

title: Relieved, Giants Support Commissioner's Decision
description: Wellington Mara was a 25-year-old Giants executive when Pearl Harbor was attacked on Dec. 7, 1941. The first word of the attack filtered into the Polo Grounds while the Giants played football that day.

title: Citing Mutual Defense Clause, Allies Say Attack Was Directed at All : NATO Commits to Supporting U.S.
description: PARIS  America's allies have invoked the mutual defense principle of the North Atlantic Treaty for the first time, declaring that the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington were attacks on them all, and the European Union vowed to help identify and "punish" those behind the atrocities.

title: Reckonings; After The Horror
description: It seems almost in bad taste to talk about dollars and cents after an act of mass murder. Nonetheless, we must ask about the economic aftershocks from Tuesday's horror.

title: Outpouring of Grief and Sympathy for Americans Is Seen Throughout Europe and Elsewhere
description: Dmitry Danilov, 44, a real estate broker, showed up outside the flower-strewn American Embassy in Moscow bearing a special Russian Orthodox icon for commemorating the departed.

title: Stories of a Stricken City, and a Grieving Land; Understanding Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: F.C.C. Proposals About Cable TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission proposed alternatives today to a limit on cable television ownership and began reviewing a ban on ownership of a newspaper and broadcast station within one city.

title: Mara Sebrionsky Dvonch, Violinist, Dies at 87
description: Mara Sebrionsky Dvonch, a violinist, died on Aug. 30 at her home in Bainbridge Island, Wash. She was 87.

title: Around the World
description: ASIA

title: Disaster May Tax Charities
description: Agencies supported by The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund said yesterday that they were preparing for a wave of need for food, clothing, shelter and emergency cash that is more profound than anything they had seen. ''We anticipate that there's going to be a need far greater than our agencies are prepared to deal with,'' said Edmund Moore, chief operating officer of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Economy Minister Cleared
description: A federal judge cleared Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo of any responsibility for Argentina's smuggling of arms to Croatia in the early 1990's in violation of a United Nations arms embargo. Mr. Cavallo was questioned because he had signed documents authorizing the sales of arms while serving as economy minister in the previous government. Former President Carlos Sal Menem and other senior officials have been accused in the case, and Mr. Menem has been under house arrest for three months. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com .

title: Defense Department Says 126 Are Missing, Raising Total of Crash Victims to 190
description: As rescue workers clawed through wobbling wreckage, the Pentagon announced today that 126 service members and civilians were missing and, officials said, presumed dead, raising the death toll from Tuesday's terrorist attack near Washington to 190.

title: For Troops at Fort Bragg, War Is No Longer an Abstract Idea
description: Already, at least 1,000 troops at this sprawling Army base have been ordered to shift to a 24-hour duty cycle meant to replicate life as it might be if the soldiers were sent into combat as part of any American response to Tuesday's terrorist attack.

title: Our Towns; For Arab-Americans, Flag-Flying and Fear
description: SAMI MERHI came here from Lebanon 27 years ago, and one of his second thoughts when hearing about the attack on the World Trade Center was this: ''I said to myself, truthfully, I hope this is not anybody connected to the Middle East.''

title: DEVILS
description: Most jobs on the Devils are fairly secure, but on the second day of training camp yesterday, Coach LARRY ROBINSON, exaggerating a little, said that every spot on the team was open.

title: Modell, Ravens' Owner, Says Decision Is Tagliabue's 'Finest Hour'
description: Because the National Football League is America's sports business and entertainment icon, and because its players view themselves as the toughest, most macho athletes in all of sports, there was an inclination among some of them to not let terrorism dictate to their game.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: After 13 years as the executive chef at Aureole, Charlie Palmer has passed the baton, but not very far. His successor, Gerry Hayden, comes from the same laboratory of American cooking as Mr. Palmer, the River Cafe, and helped open Aureole in 1988. Now, after stints at TriBeCa Grill, Aqua and Marguery Grill, Mr. Hayden returns.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Deal For Hyundai Stake
description: The terrorist attacks in the United States helped drive down Hyundai Securities shares so much yesterday that its board readily agreed to sell a controlling block of shares to the American International Group. The company had hesitated earlier to accept A.I.G.'s offer of 7,000 won ($5.50) a share because it was more than 10 percent below the stock's market price before the attacks. Controlling stakes in two other Hyundai financial businesses will also be acquired by A.I.G., which will spend $850 million in all; the Korean government will invest $750 million for minority interests. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Incandescent Views Of a Dreamscape
description: New York's big fall show of Chinese painting is installed in a very small space: two galleries at the China Institute, which together could fit in a coat-check room at the Met.

title: Loyalty to Communism Rewarded by Execution
description: In 1952 Rudolf Slansky, the former secretary general of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia, was put on trial, along with 13 co-defendants, on charges of espionage and treason. Eleven of the defendants were Jewish, and 11 of the defendants, although not all the Jews, were sentenced to death and hanged. As ''A Trial in Prague,'' Zuzana Justman's sensitive, intelligent new documentary makes clear, the accused were not simply victims of communism. They were also passionate believers in it, devoted adherents of the system that betrayed them.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Rebel Leader Denies Charges
description: Abdullah Ocalan, the Kurdish rebel leader on death row for treason and terrorism, denied similar charges brought against him related to crimes committed more than 20 years ago. Mr. Ocalan, who was condemned to death in June 1999 for leading a 15-year separatist war against the Turkish government, said in written testimony in the new case that he had never personally killed anyone, according to the Anatolia news agency. The judicial authorities said they forgot to include some pre-1980 crimes in Mr. Ocalan's first trial. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: In This Section
description: PLANNING THE RESPONSE

title: Stories of a Stricken City, and a Grieving Land; Sponsors of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 U.S. Tourists Die In Mexico Air Crash
description: Sixteen American tourists and two Mexican crew members died in the crash of a twin-engine turboprop plane carrying them to see Mayan ruins on Wednesday, Mexican aviation officials said today.

title: Phone Service Improves, but Many Are Still Without Power
description: Telephone service in Manhattan apparently improved yesterday, but it was far from normal and many people still had trouble placing calls.

title: Bush Leads Memorial Service for Victims of Terror Attack
description: Speaking on a national day of prayer and remembrance for the victims of the worst terrorist attack in this country's history, President Bush declared today that the American people would move beyond ``the middle hour of our grief'' and shoulder the commitment of their forefathers to rid the world of evil.

title: Jet Fighters Force Down 3 Small Planes
description: Jet fighters forced down three single-engine propeller planes today for violating a flight ban in separate incidents in Maryland, West Virginia, and near President Bush's ranch.

title: Workers Are Able to Enter Tall Buildings, Hesitantly
description: And then there was one.

title: Financial District Vows to Rise From the Ashes
description: Wall Street is not merely the financial nerve center of capitalism, but also a community of fierce competitors, colleagues and friends. It is a community shaken, humbled, angry and determined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREI, LUCIAN
description: ANDREI-Lucian. The friends and family of Mircea Lucian Andrei regret to announce his untimely death on September 7, 2001. Architect, artist and writer, Lucian will be mourned by many who share their condolences with his wife, Anda, and his parents, Ana and Virgil Andrei.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANCI, PETER J., JR.
description: GANCI-Peter J., Jr. (Chief of the Department F.D.N.Y.) of North Massapequa on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Kathleen (nee Koster). Devoted father of Peter Ganci III (L 111 F.D.N.Y.), Christopher M. Ganci and Danielle K. Ganci. Cherished brother of Mary Dougherty, James Ganci, Daniel Ganci and Ellen Ganci. Loving brother-in-law of Ronald Koster, Richard Koster, Theresa Giametta and Cheryl Szilagy. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast. In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks this week, some events may be canceled.

title: No Middle Ground
description: Sketching in the outline of an aggressive new American foreign policy, the Bush administration today gave the nations of the world a stark choice: stand with us against terrorism, deny safe havens to terrorists or face the certain prospect of death and destruction.

title: A Full Reopening Of Stock Trading Is Set for Monday
description: Stock markets in the United States will remain closed until at least Monday, as Wall Street continues to reel from Tuesday's devastating terrorist attack.

title: Earl of Carnarvon, 77, Royal Racing Manager
description: The seventh Earl of Carnarvon, the racing manager for Queen Elizabeth II for more than 30 years, died Tuesday at his family seat, Highclere Castle, in Newbury, Berkshire, England. He was 77.

title: Trade Center's Past In a Sad Paper Trail
description: A crumpled page of cleaning instructions with a reminder to damp-wipe smudges and smears. A blank check from a financial firm on the 101st floor. A tattered rsum, shreds of a faxed message, a cell-phone bill, a note about school, a bank statement, an expense report. A request for a promotion dated 1979.

title: Peru, Pressing Japan, Issues an Order for Fujimori's Arrest
description: Peru issued at international arrest order today for Alberto K. Fujimori, the exiled former president, on charges that he shared responsibility for 25 death-squad slayings in the early years of his decade-long rule.

title: 'Carmen' With Bugles, Drums and Horse
description: Carmen is a political activist, not a tramp, in the odd entertainment that a Spanish company, La Cuadra de Sevilla, is presenting at City Center as ''Carmen, an Andalusian Opera With Bugles and Drums.''

title: Closings Snarl Travel to Manhattan Again
description: The busiest subway lines between Brooklyn and Manhattan  some of which had been reopened on Wednesday  were severed again yesterday, throwing millions of commuters back into turmoil that had seemed to be easing. Officials warned that getting around the New York region would not return to normal again for a long time.

title: The Weak at War With the Strong
description: This is the end: the end of an era, the era of our invulnerability. We will recover physically and even psychologically, but nothing will ever be quite the same again. A barrier has been irrevocably breached: a barrier against the world outside. Until this week our enemies never seriously penetrated our continental shores. But in the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the proud symbols of our global power and influence were violated.

title: Rangers and Lindros Open Training Camp
description: ERIC LINDROS took part in his first official workout with the Rangers yesterday in Rye, N.Y., during a subdued practice as rescue efforts continued in the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center on Tuesday.

title: Ready To Die, And Then To Love
description: Not the least of the handicaps weighing down Dana Lustig's sardonic thriller ''Kill Me Later'' is the sour personality of its heroine, if heroine is the right word for such a disagreeably sullen character. Shawn (Selma Blair) is a depressed young woman who dresses in black, works as a loan officer in a bank, and in the movie's opening scenes is shown carrying on a miserable affair with her married boss (D. W. Moffett).

title: Old Motorcycles Take the Stage
description: AFTER years in the shadows of collector cars, vintage motorcycles are getting their place in the sun. Two years after the first North American auction of vintage and high-performance motorcycles, Sotheby's is back for a second round tomorrow in Chicago. And the Guggenheim Museum will open its Las Vegas branch next month with a reprise of its most successful exhibition ever, the Art of the Motorcycle.

title: Trading Restart Likely to Be Choppy
description: NEW YORK  The enforced closure of the U.S. stock markets after the destruction of the World Trade Center is not expected to hurt stocks, but trading is likely to be erratic when it resumes at the beginning of next week, as investors remain jittery, analysts said Thursday.

title: Airlines Seek to Limit Lawsuits Over Attacks
description: As rescue workers continued to search yesterday for survivors in the smoking wreckage of the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, representatives of American Airlines and United Airlines began lobbying Congress to restrict lawsuits seeking compensation.

title: U.S. Presses Pakistan to Help Pry a Suspected Terrorist From Afghanistan Haven
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 13  The terrorist attacks on the United States appear increasingly likely to touch off a moment of reckoning for Pakistan, which has long supported the fundamentalist Taliban militia in Afghanistan, protector of the United States' prime terrorist suspect, Osama bin Laden.

description: While the world has yet to learn precisely who is responsible for the terror that engulfed New York City, there is little doubt about who is containing the aftermath.

title: Now, Jersey City Has Room to Show Its Treasures
description: While spectacular new cultural cathedrals like the Guggenheim Bilbao or the Tate Modern attract big money and worldwide attention, small museums in small cities and towns all across America are barely surviving, if not slowly dying. They may be blessed -- or burdened -- with troves of artworks by once-semifamous, now-forgotten names and tons of decorative objects, artifacts and memorabilia donated by local citizens, but they usually have little space to display their treasures and limited resources for preservation and proper storage. Then, every so often, one of these beleaguered institutions gets lucky.

description: President Bush's call for a global coalition against terrorism continued to gain support overseas today as Russia, in a rare joint statement with NATO, expressed its anger over Tuesday's attacks in New York and Washington and called for a worldwide effort to combat such acts.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: No Haven
description: The government said it would not open a second refugee center near the English Channel and work with Britain to dissuade the rush of asylum-seekers trying to sneak into Britain through the Channel Tunnel. The interior ministers of both countries announced that they would tighten security at the tunnel's railroad and road terminal and France would toughen sanctions against the many Afghan, Kurdish and other would-be immigrants who try to get into Britain as stowaways on trains and trucks. British immigration officials plan to move to the French side to dissuade the hundreds of people gathered at a Red Cross refugee center, waiting to for a chance to cross. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: You've Seen Giant Pandas? Not This Giant
description: What could be more adorable than a giant panda? How about a really giant panda, say about the size of a modest townhouse. This seems to have been the thinking behind the new 2-D Imax feature ''China: The Panda Adventure,'' in which a family of the roly-poly creatures frolic in the picturesque, mist-shrouded forests of their native land, munching bamboo and tumbling playfully out of the branches of trees.

title: Jim Lambie -- 'Boy Hairdresser'
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Posts Gain
description: One of the world's biggest insurers, AXA, reported its first-half results and said it expected the destruction of the World Trade Towers to cost it $300 million to $400 million this year. The company said first-half profit rose 12 percent, helped by gains in British and Asian life insurance income. AXA said net income at the company, which is based in Paris, increased to 1.22 billion euros ($1.11 billion), or 0.69 euro a share (63 cents), from a restated 1.09 billion euros, or 0.70 euro, a year earlier. The chief executive, Henri de Castries, has focused on improving the profitability of existing operations after AXA spent 21 billion euros ($19 million) on acquisitions last year. Growth in the Asian life and property insurance units helped offset falling stock markets, which made it harder to sell savings plans.

title: Super Tuesday of Big Hits
description: DVD's Super Tuesday is Sept. 25. A digitally remastered "Citizen Kane" from Warner leads a half-dozen big releases, among them "The French Connection," William Friedkin's 1971 film that has largely set the standard for crime drama ever since. "The best action film of the modern era," said Bruce Goldstein, repertory director of Film Forum, which will show it from Sept. 28 through Oct. 4.

title: Agreement on $40 Million for Aid and a Response

They were also working toward a Congressional resolution giving President Bush support for military retaliation against terrorists who masterminded the attacks.

description: Reports of the scale of the carnage in the United States sobered reactions across the Middle East today. Although some Arabs said they hoped that the toll would provoke a hard assessment by the United States of its policies in the region, others braced for possible retaliation.

Now, eight months later, she's here, at the Toronto International Film Festival, the star of the latest David Lynch movie, ''Mulholland Drive,'' doing interviews in her luxury suite overlooking the glittering vistas of downtown.

title: A Generation Unfamiliar With Feeling Vulnerable

He had, he said, hung a poster on his door that said, ''Forgive.''

title: U.S. Says Hijackers Lived in the Open With Deadly Secret

Some took classes at a high-tech aviation center here, while at least one learned to handle passenger jets at an aeronautical college in Daytona Beach. Still others took lessons on propeller planes at a flight school on Florida's Gulf Coast.

title: Mayor of the Moment
description: Whatever he has been before or will be in the future, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani became the leader New York City needed in its worst moment. With little rhetoric and less poetry, he consoled a stunned populace trying to make sense through the smoke and beyond the jagged skyline. With phrases aimed at people rather than the history books, Mr. Giuliani rallied a city to ''go back to normal,'' to start going to restaurants, to try to work or go to school as a way to show its unbroken spirit.

title: Where Drama Is a Broken Fax Machine
description: ''Haiku Tunnel,'' billed as ''an office comedy,'' asks the question: can a feature-length movie be built on minutiae like jammed copying machines, unsent business letters and orientation programs for new employees? This innocuous wisp of a film, as weighty as a scrap of fax paper caught in an updraft, suggests that the answer is no. If yes, it would need the manic inventiveness of a Chaplin or a Sellers to power its hard drive.

title: A Shaken Nation Struggles to Regain Its Equilibrium, but Remains on Edge
description: The skyways of America reopened to travelers with limited flights and restrictive new security measures yesterday as a worldwide investigation chased thousands of leads, identified 18 hijackers and made other substantial progress in unraveling the mysteries of the worst terrorist attack in the nation's history.

title: Foraging in the Mind, Where Slavery's Scars Linger
description: It may sound like a stretch. A black child is practicing his basketball moves in a laundry room and a white woman compliments him on his athletic skill. But his mother responds by insisting he has no talent whatsoever.

title: Rendezvous With Afghanistan
description: Anyone wondering how the United States is likely to respond to this week's terrorist attacks on New York and Washington should consult a map of Central Asia -- like the one on this page. Unless the evidence trail takes an unexpected turn, it will lead American diplomacy, and quite possibly American combat forces, into one of the world's most volatile and tangled regions. At its epicenter lies Afghanistan, an impoverished and backward nation that over the centuries has been a battleground and graveyard for the interests of great powers. To avoid a similar fate, Washington will have to act with exceeding care and skill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANARGEROS, MARY (SOTOS)
description: ANARGEROS-Mary (Sotos)/ Died September 11, 2001. Mary was born in New York City. Her husband Michael, predeceased her August 11, 1991. He owned Flowers By Anargeros in Brooklyn, NY. Mary is survived by two nephews T. Sotos and J. Paraskos, three grandnieces and and grandnephews and many God children. Mary worked for the Commissioner of Baseball as the personal secretary and administrative assistant for 46 years. She served every commissionerincluding Ford Frick and Bowie Kuhn. She was well known to many baseball players and owners. She was often referred as the ''Real'' Commissioner of Baseball for her extensive knowledge and understanding of the game. Funeral services will be held at the Greek Orthodox Holy Trinity Cathedral at 319 East 74th St. on Monday at 10:30 AM. Visiting will take place one hour prior to the service. Burial at the Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn. She requested in lieu of flowers, a contribution to your favorite charity.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Strike Threat Postponed
description: Two unions representing state employees have agreed to postpone a threatened strike, saying the time is not right, after the terrorist attacks. In a meeting on Wednesday with state authorities, officials of the Minnesota Association of Professional Employees and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees Council 6 agreed to extend a strike deadline by two weeks, to Oct. 1, in a dispute over wages and health benefits. The unions have nearly 30,000 members, representing about 60 percent of state government workers.

description: DVD's Super Tuesday is Sept. 25. A digitally remastered ''Citizen Kane'' from Warner leads a half-dozen big releases, among them ''The French Connection,'' William Friedkin's 1971 film that has largely set the standard for crime drama ever since. ''The best action film of the modern era,'' said Bruce Goldstein, repertory director of Film Forum, which will show it from Sept. 28 through Oct. 4.

title: As Activity Resumes in the Bond Market, Investors Send Interest Rates Plummeting
description: Investors ran to the safety of the American Treasury market yesterday as trading resumed for the first time since the World Trade Center crumbled on Tuesday morning.

title: A Change of Heart Postpones Games
description: Acknowledging that the country appeared in no mood for major college football at the moment, several conferences reversed themselves in a matter of minutes yesterday and postponed the games they had scheduled for tomorrow. As a result, there will be no Division I-A games anywhere in the nation this weekend, and no crowds filling up large stadiums while rescue workers continue their efforts in New York City and Washington D.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELMER, MARION S.
description: ELMER-Marion S. 85. Died on September 9, 2001. Loving wife of Arthur Elmer (deceased), mother of Joan Mellon and Steve Elmer, grandmother of Josh Mellon, and sister of Sidney Solomon.

title: Tagliabue Decides To Put Off Week 2 After Much Debate
description: National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said yesterday he had no choice but to call off this weekend's games, citing the inappropriateness of playing Week 2 so soon after Tuesday's terrorist attacks.

title: Stories of a Stricken City, and a Grieving Land; Getting Out
description: To the Editor:

title: German Officials Link 3 Arab Men to Attack
description: German authorities said today that three men suspected in the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington had plotted the operation while living in Hamburg.

title: New York's Theaters and Museums Open in a Bold Resolve to Persevere
description: STILL reeling from Tuesday's deadly attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, some of New York City's cultural institutions have decided to fight the grief and fear in the only way they know, with an array of special concerts, benefits and bold displays of creative energy and perseverance.

title: Residents Miss Their Homes Near the Ruins
description: On one side of a barricade at Pier 40, Cheryl Morris beamed as her tabby cat, Beau, purred in a carrier set on Ms. Morris's bike. He had just been retrieved by Ms. Morris from her ash-filled apartment in Battery Park City.

title: Alvin Schwartz, an Owner Of Helmsley-Spear, Dies at 89
description: Alvin Schwartz, long prominent in New York City's real estate industry as an associate of and successor to the real estate magnate Harry Helmsley, died on Wednesday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Bayer Won't Sell Drug Unit And Picks Insider as Chief
description: Defying expectations, Bayer A.G. said today that it would not sell its embattled pharmaceuticals unit after all, and it named a longtime executive, not a fresh face from outside the company, to succeed its chief executive, Manfred Schneider.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 5.

title: Closings Snarl Travel to Manhattan Again
description: The busiest subway lines between Brooklyn and Manhattan -- some of which had been reopened on Wednesday -- were severed again yesterday, throwing millions of commuters back into turmoil that had seemed to be easing. Officials warned that getting around the New York region would not return to normal again for a long time.

title: Information on Closings and Openings
description: All streets below Canal Street are closed. Streets and businesses between 14th Street and Canal Street have been reopened Friday and routes yet to be determined will be opened to Wall Street by Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, GUS
description: LEVY-Gus. Born on February 23, 1907. Died September 13, 2001 after a long and happy life. Beloved husband of Frances and the late Beatrice. Loving father of Elaine (Eric) and Marjorie (Richard). Cherished grandfather of Adam (Jessica) and Beth. Gus was adored by his many siblings as well as his nieces, nephews and friends. He will be truly missed by all of those whose lives he touched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGARIAN, NAZARETH
description: MAGARIAN-Nazareth, 71. A founding partner of the law firm Nobile, Magarian and DiSalvo, died on September 11, 2001 at home in Briarcliff Manor, NY. Naz was born on November 30, 1929 in the Bronx, NY, to Karl and Victoria (Soovajian) Magarian. He received his Bachelor of Arts degree from the City College of New York in 1951 and his law degree from New York University in 1954. He served as Presidential Honor Guard under the Eisenhower Administration. Nazareth married Phyllis Wolkoff on November 6, 1955 at St. Mark's Lutheran Church in Yonkers, NY, and they shared a loving marriage of nearly 46 years. Naz enjoyed an active law practice, serving as First Assistant Corporation Counsel for the City of Yonkers, NY, then in private practice in the areas of Wills, Trusts and Estates, Probate, Construction Law, Real Estate, Elder Law, Nonprofit Organizations Law, Religious Institutions, and College and University Law. Nazareth was continually active as a member of the Board of Directors and Advisor to the Board for Manhattan Savings Bank and Republic National Bank, General Counsel and Chairman of the Board of Directors for the Wartburg Adult Care Community, General Counsel for Concordia College, General Counsel for the Atlantic District of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod, and long-time member and President of the Board of Directors for the Unity Center in New York City. Naz was a member of the Yonkers, Westchester and New York State Bar Associations, as well as Past President of the Board of Directors of the Yonkers Public Library, Past President of the Kiwanis Club and member of the Yonkers Rotary Club. Naz was semi-retired and enjoyed the ocean, dolphins and long walks along the beach with his wife at their second home in Palm Beach, Florida. He was also a passionate speaker, graceful dancer, lover of the outdoors and provided many inspiring ''Circles of Light'' at Unity services in Avery Fisher Hall. In addition to his wife Phyllis, Naz is survived by his three children: Dr. Glenn A. Magarian, Dr. Karen S. Magarian, and Lorna B. Magarian, as well as his sister Dorothy Bahtiarian, two nephews, two nieces and six grandnieces and nephews. In memory of Nazareth Magarian, gifts, in lieu of flowers, may be made to the Wartburg Adult Care Community at Wartburg Place, Mt. Vernon, NY 10552, or the Unity Center at 213 West 58th Street, NY, NY 10019. A memorial service will be held at the Unity Center at 213 West 58th Street on Sunday, September 23 at 1 PM.

title: M.L.S. Decides To End Season
description: Major League Soccer canceled the final 10 games of its regular season yesterday in light of the terrorist attacks on Tuesday and will start its playoffs on Thursday.

title: U.S. Force vs. Terrorists: From Reactive to Active
description: If the terrorist attacks this week, as George W. Bush says, mark the first war of the 21st century, waging that fight will require new military thinking and bolder tactics, allied experts say.

title: Three Killed as Israelis Move Into Two West Bank Towns
description: Stepping up its raids in Palestinian-controlled areas, the Israeli Army sent armor and bulldozers into Jericho today and pushed again into Jenin, where three Palestinians were killed in fierce gun battles.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: United Nations To Resume Work
description: The United Nations said it is preparing to resume operations at a refugee camp in West Timor, part of Indonesia, a year after a mob attack left three of its workers dead. An Indonesian court sentenced six men to light prison terms in the killings. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Forensics Lab Is Prepared For Up to 20,000 DNA Tests
description: Faced with the heart-rending but essential task of identifying victims of the attacks on the World Trade Center, the New York City medical examiner's office has made preparations to perform DNA testing on as many as 20,000 tissue samples recovered from the rubble, officials said yesterday.

title: Vintage Events, Old Clothing Optional
description: THE Goodwood Revival Meeting this weekend in Sussex, England, offers total immersion in the world of vintage cars. Famous racing drivers of the past, including Stirling Moss, Phil Hill, John Surtees, Dan Gurney and Jackie Stewart, are expected to drive the same cars in which they achieved victories decades ago. World War II planes, including Spitfires and Mustangs, will perform flyovers.

title: A Play Outside the Mainstream of Its Time and Ours
description: The first nominee for most anachronistic play of the season is ''The Voice of the Turtle,'' a play about single life in New York City in World War II that was a hit when it opened on Broadway in 1943. Oddly enough, though, in the tidy and surprisingly touching Off Off Broadway revival at the Blue Heron Arts Center, the sentiments of the play are refreshing and sensible.

title: Agreement on $40 Billion for Aid and a Response
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Sept. 14  Congressional leaders and the White House agreed early this morning on a $40 billion emergency aid package to respond to Tuesday's attacks in New York and near Washington. They were also working toward a Congressional resolution giving President Bush support for military retaliation against terrorists who masterminded the attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELLO, CHRISTOPHER D.
description: MELLO-Christopher D. A victim of the American Airline Flight 11 catastrophe, Christopher D. Mello, 25, of Boston, Mass, formerly of Rye, New York, died September 11, 2001. Chris was born June 22, 1976 in Greenwich, CT to Douglas and Ellen Mello. Chris was an outstanding student and athlete at Rye High School graduating in 1994. Chris was Vice President of the senior class and a member of the National Honor Society. Chris was co-captain of the varsity football team in 1993 which went on to the New York State finals. He was voted the most valuable defensive player of the tournament. He was also presented with the Golden Dozen Scholar Athletic Award for both his on-field and academic achievements. He was also ConEdison's athlete of the week in 1993. Chris graduated from Princeton University in 1998, where he majored in Psychology and was Vice President of the University Cottage Club, and a member of the men's Rugby Club, Kappa Alpha Order Fraternity and the 21 Club. Chris, who enjoyed playing golf with his family, was a member of The Apawamis Club in Rye, New York and the Rye YMCA. He worked as a financial analyst at BT Alex Brown in Baltimore, Md, before moving to Boston, Mass, where he worked as an analyst for Alta Communications. In addition to his parents Douglas and Ellen Mello of Rye, NY, Chris is survived by his brother, John Douglas Mello, also a graduate of Princeton and an avid athlete, who resides in Manhattan. Chris is also survived by his paternal grandmother, Alice Mello, of Barefoot Bay, FL. Visiting hours will be held on Sunday, September 16, 2001 at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY between the hours of 2-4PM and 7-9PM. A memorial service will be held at 11:00AM on Monday, September 17, 2001 at the Resurrection Church at 910 Boston Post Road in Rye, New York, (914) 967-0142. In lieu of flowers the family would like donations made to the Rye YMCA at 21 Locust Street, Rye, NY 10580, in Chris' memory.

title: The Call
description: Of all the heart-rending stories that emerged from Tuesday's disaster, what resonates most, somehow, is the thought of those phone calls that went out in the all-too-brief gap between the first airliner's crash into the World Trade Center and the towers' final collapse.

title: Seeking New Space, Companies Search Far From Wall St.
description: Just five hours after a jet slammed into the north tower at the World Trade Center on Tuesday, at least one corporation that was still comforting its weeping employees began negotiating with a landlord for new office space -- far from Lower Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, ROGER S.
description: STARR-Roger S. on September 10, 2001 in Easton, PA. Son of Frederick and Lillie Bernhardt Starr. Devoted husband of Joanne (Jody) W. Starr. Father of Adam, Barnaby, and the late Alexandra, father-in-law of Judy and Monica; grandfather of Robin, Zachary, Brittany, Thomas, and Luke; stepfather of Douglas Green and Patty Shaheen. Roger was a unique human being whose intelligence, thoughtfulness and good humor will be missed by all who knew him and read his work. A veteran of World War II, he served in Asia with the Office of Strategic Services. For many years Roger Starr was Executive Director of Citizens Housing & Planning Council, was Housing & Development Administrator of New York City, and was a member of the Editorial Board of The New York Times. Roger wrote numerous articles and books, and taught at Pratt Institute, City College, and New York University. After moving to Stroudsburg, PA, he was active in that community as a member of various county boards and commissions. Services will be held at noon on Thursday, September 13 at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

title: Rumsfeld Asks Call-Up of Reserves, as Many as 50,000
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld has recommended calling up as many as 50,000 military reservists, the largest number since the 1991 Persian Gulf war against Iraq, initially to support air patrols over New York and Washington and on alert elsewhere in America, officials said today.

description: The Bush administration today singled out Osama bin Laden, the Islamic militant who operates from Afghanistan, as a prime suspect in Tuesday's catastrophic terror attacks and vowed a comprehensive military campaign to demolish terrorist networks and topple regimes that harbor them.

title: Agencies and their clients walk a careful line as they move toward expressing condolences.
description: MESSAGES of grief, condolence and support are beginning to emerge from advertisers, agencies and media companies in the aftermath of Tuesday's terrorist attacks. Those involved say they are trying to proceed carefully so as not to be perceived as crossing the line between sincere expressions of concern and shameless exploitation.

title: Multinationals Will Protect Workers, but Plan to Remain in Hot Zones
description: As evidence suggests that Tuesday's attacks were conducted by terrorists with ties to the Middle East, multinational corporations that do business in the region said they were making sure that their employees were safe. But few plan to remove Americans working in the Mideast or make changes to their business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DE MAELE, JOAN
description: VAN DE MAELE-Joan. The Board of Directors of The Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation mourns the death of Joan Van de Maele on Tuesday, September 12, in Miami Beach. She was born September 3, 1912, and was the daughter of Harry Frank Guggenheim and Helen Matzinger. Mrs. Van de Maele was a Captain in the Women's Army Air Force and served in the Pacific in World War II. She was instrumental in starting the Boys Club of St. Croix, of which she was a resident. Mrs. Van de Maele was a Director of the Florence and Daniel Guggenheim and The Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundations and a member of the Advisory Board of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice, Italy. James M. Hester, President The Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation

title: David Angell, 54; A Creator and Writer For 'Frasier' Sitcom
description: David Angell, a creator and executive producer of the NBC series ''Frasier,'' died on Tuesday on American Airlines Flight 11 from Boston. He was 54 and lived in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Survivors Who Barely Made It Out in Time Try to Cope With Grim Fact That Others Did Not
description: What piled on him Tuesday morning, said Roger Parrino, was wind and dust, not flame and steel. So he washed it off and marched back to work as the lieutenant in a detective squad, looking just about the same as he did a week ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, KAREN (NEE KNOEBEL)
description: SIEGEL-Karen (nee Knoebel). On September 12, 2001 at age 31 of breast cancer. Wife of Steven, daughter of Todd & Linda Knoebel and sister to Christian. Reposing on Saturday and Sunday from 24PM and 7-9PM at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck. Funeral mass Monday 10AM at Most Holy Trinity R.C. Church in Mamaroneck followed by interment at Greenwood Union Cemetery.

title: A Firefighter's Story
description: The south tower of the World Trade Center has just collapsed. I am helping my friends at Ladder Company 16, and the firefighters have commandeered a crowded 67th Street crosstown bus. We go without stopping from Lexington Avenue to the staging center on Amsterdam. We don't talk much. Not one of the passengers complains.

title: Op-Art
National Briefing | West: California: State Limits Loan Rates
description: California has become the second state, after North Carolina, to pass a law restricting what is known as predatory lending, the granting of loans with excessive fees and high interest rates to people with poor credit. The law would prohibit lenders from forcing borrowers, who are frequently minority members and the elderly, to buy certain kinds of loan insurance. It would also limit the number of ''points'' lenders can charge to 6 percent of the loan amount, prohibit repeated refinancings and prohibit loans to people who do not have the means to repay them. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Attacks and Harassment of Arab-Americans Increase
description: People of Middle Eastern and South Asian descent -- or even those who appear to be -- are increasingly becoming the targets of harassment and violence by civilians and of intense scrutiny by police officers under pressure to track down suspects in the terrorist attacks.

title: Spiritual Power Carved in Wood
description: Seven newly acquired wooden sculptures are the highlight of an exhibition of traditional regional Indonesian artifacts to open at the Dallas Museum of Art on Sept. 22.

title: Postcards From Eternity
description: IN 1849, Maxime Du Camp and his friend Gustave Flaubert set off for Egypt. Du Camp had wangled an assignment from the French government to photograph monuments and sites, even though he had never taken photographs before. Flaubert, for his part, ignored his brief from the Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce to collect information about Egyptian crops and ships. Instead he kept a diary, wrote letters and eagerly plunged into the sort of local entertainment that required him to receive mercury treatments for the remainder of his life.

title: Readers Comments' From the Asia-Pacific
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com . I woke up on the morning of September 12th to the 6 o'clock news, and the horror of what had happened in America. I could not believe it, I prayed it was not true. I logged on to the internet at 6.15 am and I felt sick to my stomach to see the picture of the destruction of the WTC. I spent the rest of the day in shock - all I could think of were the poor victims and their loved ones. Many Australians felt the same shock and horror - I listened to people who rang in to radio stations and I shed tears along with them. Even though we are many miles away, we feel your pain and suffering. I cannot bear to think of the grief of the relatives still searching for their loved ones. Since that morning when I heard the news, I have not stopped thinking about this carnage. It is not just Americans that have been affected - hundreds of people of other nationalities were involved. It was a day that the world changed for me. In my lifetime, I had not experienced an event like this that has caused such horror and fear worldwide. What are we to do now? Do we let the perpetrators go unpunished because it will cost more lives to go to war? Yes, we want peace but are people so naive as to think that these terrorists are content with this one act of destruction? Do you really think they will not attempt greater acts of terrorism ? I am a Christian and I do not believe in vengeance,but I don't want to live my life in fear, always looking over my shoulder, wondering when the next evil act will occur. And this is how everyone has been affected by this tragedy. The toll goes well beyond the 5000 who may have been killed. There were thousands injured, and there are tens of thousands of family and friends whose lives will never be the same again. Then there are people like us around the world who did not directly know the victims, but who feel the grief and the fear of potential war and conflict. And what about the financial impact? Businesses have been destroyed and many will continue to slide. Jobs will be lost and the effects will ripple. One evil act has done this. No one will feel safe again until these terrorists are hunted down. Yes, America should retaliate and the world should stand with you. Do this, for the sake of our children and their children.

title: No Middle Ground
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Sketching in the outline of an aggressive new American foreign policy, the Bush administration today gave the nations of the world a stark choice: stand with us against terrorism, deny safe havens to terrorists or face the certain prospect of death and destruction.

title: Normality Proves Elusive Amid Bomb Scares and Transit Woes
description: On the third day, New York tried to move toward some semblance of normality, but too often it seemed to fail. Frazzled police officers found themselves responding to dozens of false bomb scares, mass transit officials worked to keep a fractured system up and running, and people everywhere struggled to shake the paralysis of fear.

title: New York-Area Airports Reopen
description: New York's three major airports  which were reopened on Thursday only to be closed only hours later  reopened again this morning, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Grief Is Lessened by Sharing and Solace From Strangers
description: Lorna Dolci took herself from North Plainfield, N.J., to Union Square in Manhattan yesterday for no other reason than to mourn. She wanted something to make what had happened feel real; the smoke still choking the air did that. But even more, she wanted companions in her grief. At Union Square, she found hundreds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, DONALD F.
description: GREENE-Donald F. Of Greenwich, CT, on September 11, 2001. The Safe Flight Instrument Corporation, its management and staff are grieved and shocked by the tragic loss of Donald F. Greene, our Executive Vice President, in the crash of United Air Lines Flight 93. Victim of a terrorist attack on the United States, Don was never a victim in life. His dynamic leadership and direction helped shape Safe Flight's transition to the 21st century. An experienced pilot himself, he promoted safety in aviation through his work for Safe Flight. The company invented and manufactures numerous aviation safety devices, which have been credited for saving thousands of lives. Born in New York City on May 21, 1949, he was graduated from Suffield Academy in Suffield, CT in 1967, received a B.S in Engineering from Brown University in 1971, and obtained an MBA from Pace University in 1983. A loving father, husband, brother, son, Donald Greene lived his life with love, integrity, intelligence, humor and compassion. He leaves many whom he loved and who loved him. He is survived by his wife, the former Claudette Beaulieu, and their children, Charles Freeman and Jody Cecilia; his father, Leonard M. Greene, and stepmother, Joyce Meller Greene; his siblings, Douglas F. Greene (Carla), Randall A. Greene (Anne), Charles F. Greene (Gail), Bonnie G. Le Var (John), Jeffrey B. Meller (Christine), William Meller, Gary Meller (Maureen), Laurie G. Baldwin (Norman), Stephen F. Greene (Truddi), Amy Gerbe (Thomas), Terry A. Greene (Beth Radcliffe); numerous nieces and nephews; and a host of devoted friends and co-workers. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 14th, at 9:30 A.M. at Temple Shalom, 300 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Alliance of Breast Cancer Organizations, 9 East 37th Street, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10016 or to the Corporate Angel Network, Westchester County Airport, One Loop Road, White Plains, New York 10604.

title: Juggling Being a Father To a Son and a President
description: He is a former president but also a father, and he commingled those roles today, speaking protectively of his son while also reflecting on the burden of confronting a global challenge from the loneliness of the Oval Office.

title: First Inspections Show Most Buildings Are Structurally Sound
description: Shortly before 2 p.m. yesterday, a deep rumble was heard within the American Express building near the remains of the World Trade Center. People yelled and scrambled into the street. Radio reports predicted the imminent collapse of the skyscraper's roof. In the end it turned out to be a piece of masonry falling from a nearby building's facade.

title: U.S. Seeks Canada's Reassurance on Security
description: Canada and the United States, which have often differed over the treatment of asylum seekers, refugees and immigrants, may be drawn closer to common policies after the terror attacks on New York and the Pentagon this week, the Canadian foreign minister said today.
