title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHMAN, ISAAC
description: HOCHMAN-Isaac. Born in Poland December 2, 1913. Died September 8, 2001. Son of mill owners in Poland. Beloved husband of 63 years to Genevieve. Father of Dr. Joseph Hochman, Michael Hochman and Irena Hochman. Fatherin-law to Dr. Regina Lichtsztral, grandfather to Eva and Mark. Survivor of the Holocaust and labor camps in Siberia. Came to the USA in 1968 as a result of an antisemetic campaign in communist Poland, and at the age of 55 started a new life in the USA. A true philanthropist, always ready to help others. His wisdom, kindness and humor will be missed and will never be replaced. We will all miss him. Contributions may be made to Yiddishe Kultur, 1133 Broadway, Room 820, New York, N.Y. 10010.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JACK
description: SHAPIRO-Jack. Of Forest Hills, N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Devoted father of Mark. Dear brother, uncle & great-uncle. Graveside services Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, N.J. Friday 11 AM. For info Bloomfield-Cooper Jewish Chapels 800-247-5235.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Make no mistake about it, this nation is sad. But we're also tough and resolute, and now's an opportunity to do generations a favor by coming together and whipping terrorism, hunting it down, binding it and holding them accountable.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, BARBARA
description: OLSON-Barbara. The Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University mourns the tragic and untimely passing of Barbara Bracher Olson, 1989 Cardozo graduate who died in the terrible terrorist attack on the Pentagon. At CSL she was chapter president of the Federalist Society, then became chief counsel for the House Government Reform and Oversight Committee. She went on to be a commentator at CNN and an author. Her career was marked by integrity, courage, and infectious enthusiasm. Our sympathy is extended to her husband, parents, brother, and sister as well as the families of the many innocent victims of the horrible attack on our country. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Earle I. Mack, Chairman, CSL Board of Directors Stewart Sterk, CSL Acting Dean

I was on the concourse level of the World Trade Center on 9/11/01 at 8:50am. In my 34 years on this earth I have NEVER experienced the TERROR I now know. My prayers go out to each and every person affected by this cowardly act.

title: No Car Show for Rockefeller Center
description: THERE will be no rare collector cars in Rockefeller Center this fall, and none of the glamour that accompanied the Louis Vuitton Classic the last five years.

title: Christian Adams, 37, Promoter for Wines
description: Christian Adams, a prime promoter of German wines as deputy director of the German Wine Institute, a quasi-governmental organization, died on Tuesday aboard the hijacked plane that crashed in southwestern Pennsylvania, the institute said. He was 37.

title: On Doomed Flight, Passengers Vowed to Perish Fighting
description: They told the people they loved that they would die fighting.

title: Amid Anxiety, Markets Edge Back Toward Routines
description: Citing new figures suggesting that the economy was tipping into recession even before the terrorist attacks on Tuesday, economists said yesterday that the ripple effects from the assault would almost surely bring to an end the record-setting expansion that began more than a decade ago.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Drunken Driver Arrests Drop
description: The number of reported drunken driving violations has decreased since the state lowered the threshold for blood alcohol content to .08 on Jan. 1, 1999, from .10, the state's Traffic Safety Commission said. A spokeswoman for the commission, Jonna VanDyk, attributed the drop in citations to successful public education programs for drivers and bartenders, such as the .08 signs that began showing up on state roads in 1998. Since 1998 the number of citations issued annually has fallen by about 1,000, to 37,661 for 2000. There has also been a 10 percent drop in accidents involving drunken drivers and an 18 percent drop in fatalities from accidents involving these drivers since 1998. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Bryon Lesmann, Liz Graham, Jeff Lindquist, and George Isakson, July 7, 2001, Billings County, N. D., rig No. 49

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: A Victory For Mugabe
description: The governing party of President Robert Mugabe won a special parliamentary election, its fourth victory in less than a year. The seat was left vacant when Defense Minister Moven Mahachi died in a car accident earlier this year. The leading opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, also had a victory this week, winning a mayoral election in Bulawayo, the country's second largest city. But it has been unable to make significant inroads in rural areas, where most people in the country live. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Lawmakers Approve $40 Billion in Emergency Aid
description: Congress unanimously approved a $40 billion emergency aid package for relief and counter-terrorism measures today — twice the amount the Bush administration had requested — as law enforcement officials named the 19 hijackers they said had commandeered the jetliners in Tuesday's attacks.

title: Stories of a Stricken City, and a Grieving Land; A Senator's Remark
description: To the Editor:

title: Ree Morton
description: Alexander and Bonin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRILLIN, ALICE
description: TRILLIN-Alice. The New York Public Library mourns the passing of its friend and supporter, Alice Trillin, the beloved wife of the Library's esteemed Trustee, Calvin Trillin. We will always remember her many accomplishments as an educator, film producer, and author, for her role as her husband's partner and muse, and for her volunteeer work helping children with cancer. We offer our deepest sympathy to her husband, her daughters, and members of her extended family. Samuel C. Butler, Chairman Mrs. Vincent Astor, Honorary Chairman Andrew Heiskell, Marshall Rose, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Chairman Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President

title: Phone Service Improving, But Many Still Lack Power
description: Telephone service in Manhattan apparently improved yesterday, but it was far from normal and many people still had trouble placing calls.

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com .

title: Albany Votes $8 Billion For Relief And Recovery
description: State and city lawmakers authorized $8 billion in spending yesterday to relieve suffering and aid in the recovery from the attack on the World Trade Center, though they acknowledged that they still had little idea just how the money would be spent, or how much would be needed.

title: Authorities Have Learned the Identities Of 18 Hijackers, Attorney General Says
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft said the federal authorities had identified 18 men who hijacked the commercial jets used in Tuesday's terror attacks, while investigators accelerated a nationwide manhunt for dozens of accomplices believed to have supported the assaults on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: The Big City; Restore the Skyline, but Do It the New York Way
description: ''THE skyline will be made whole again,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said, and it was one of the finer moments this week. The skyline is our pyschic equivalent of the cathedrals and temples and mosques that other cities rushed to rebuild after other attacks. Civic symbols are crucial at times like this. But just how do we go about making the skyline whole?

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOORE, JOHN MCDONALD
description: MOORE-John McDonald. January 11, 1919-September 14, 1999. Devoted teacher, beloved parent, grandparent and brother, cherished husband. ''Set up no stone to his memory. Just let the rose bloom each year for his sake.'' R.M. Rilk

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REEVES, DAVID MARTIN
description: REEVES-David Martin, 52. Of Upper Montclair on September 12, 2001, son of Claire Steedly Reeves, brother of Claire Reeves LaRoche, & Elizabeth Reeves Wells, companion of John V. Moore. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Nature Conservancy of New Jersey, 200 Pottersville Road, Chester, New Jersey 07930.

title: Monitors Say Health Risk From Smoke Is Very Small
description: The persistent pall of smoke wafting from the remains of the World Trade Center poses a very small, and steadily diminishing, risk to the public, environmental officials and doctors said yesterday.

title: U.S. 'Secular' Groups Set Tone For Terror Attacks, Falwell Says
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said yesterday that the American Civil Liberties Union, with abortion providers, gay rights proponents and federal courts that had banned school prayer and legalized abortion, had so weakened the United States spiritually that the nation was left exposed to Tuesday's terrorist attacks.

title: 'Jane Peterson: Around and About, 1910-1930'
description: Hirschl & Adler Galleries

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBNER, SOL
description: LEIBNER-Sol. A kind and gentle man-a man of impeccable integrity. Prominent CPA in New York for more than 60 years. Died September 12, 2001 in Long Beach, NY. Devoted father of Richard and his wife Carole Cooper of New York City, and Jerry and his wife Denise of Baldwin Harbor, NY; loving grandfather of Adam and his wife Amy, Jonathan and his wife Mimi, Matthew, David, Elizabeth, Evan and Jordan; greatgrandfather of Lily Sky and dear brother of Julian. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 59 years, Eleanor, and a brother, Phil. Graveside funeral service, 11AM, Sunday, September 16th, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Wellwood Ave, Pinelawn, NY (Exit 49S on LIE, right on Pinelawn Rd). In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Mercy Hospice, 1220 Front St., Uniondale, NY 11553 or Beth Shalom of Kings Bay, 2710 Ave X, Brooklyn, NY 11235.

title: Parents Are Navigating an Emotional Tightrope Over How Much or How Little to Say
description: From New York, where the nightmare of the terrorist attacks was inescapable, to small towns, where the burning buildings and the grim search for bodies could seem so remote as to be unreal, parents have been trying to cope with the question of what, and how much, to tell their children. Should they insist on discussing the events? Should they reassure their children? Should they show their own fears?

title: All for One! One for All! Everybody Up the Ladder!
description: The Musketeer

title: Foreign Affairs; Smoking Or Non-Smoking?
description: If this attack on America by an extensive terrorist cell is the equivalent of World War III, it's not too early to begin thinking about what could be its long-term geopolitical consequences. Just as World Wars I and II produced new orders and divisions, so too might this war. What might it look like?

title: About the Guides
description: In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks this week, some events listed in the Weekend guides may be postponed or canceled, and museum hours may vary. Readers are advised to telephone the sponsors and institutions.

title: Robert Pagent, 87, Dancer and Choreographer for Stage and TV
description: Robert Pagent, a dancer and choreographer who appeared in the original productions of ''Oklahoma!'' and ''Carousel'' and a pioneering director of dance for television during its early years, died on Sept. 4 in Greenwich, Conn., where he lived. He was 87.

title: Stories of a Stricken City, and a Grieving Land
description: To the Editor:

title: British Conservatives Choose 'Euroskeptic' Leader; Facing Fractious Party
description: The Conservatives announced today that they had chosen as their new leader Iain Duncan Smith, a former military man known for his fierce opposition to Britain's further integration into Europe.

title: Even Workers Can See Flaws In Airlines' Screening System
description: Even before the hijackings on Tuesday, Kevin McCree, who has worked for four years in the critical job of checking airline passengers for guns, bombs and knives, said he knew that the airport screening system was failing badly.

title: Delivery Still Relies on Ground Travel
description: The United States Postal Service said today that despite experiencing some disruptions to service, it would continue to use ground transportation to deliver mail even as the Federal Aviation Administration cleared the way for air travel.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Proposal For Poor Farmers
description: A study by the labor department proposed a minimum wage for farm workers in an effort to improve the lot of the lowest-paid workers in the country's lowest-paying industry. While the average farm worker's wages -- about $63 a month -- fall in the proposed range of $46 to $87, a survey found that some workers are being paid as little as $6 a month, and it is those workers that the labor department says it wants to help. The proposal is part of a government effort to begin redressing the country's income inequality. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Museums' Windfall
description: The Annenberg Foundation has announced $45 million in grants in the last week to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: ISLANDERS
description: Minutes into an intrasquad scrimmage yesterday morning in Lake Placid, N.Y., Islanders goaltender RICK DIPIETRO fired the puck over the glass by accident, then punctuated the error with a choice epithet. It was the last mistake he made.

title: Album of the Week
description: ISLEY BROTHERS: -- ''Eternal'' (Dreamworks). Ronald Isley must let out a big chuckle whenever he hears the youngsters in Destiny's Child sing ''Survivor.'' The patriarchal tenor has smooth-stepped through more tricky trend shifts than those twentysomethings can fathom. Making hits since the 1954 ''Shout,'' the Isley Brothers (now reduced to Mr. Isley and his guitar-god junior, Ernie) helped shape the history of funk, political soul, slow jams and black crossover pop. Most recently, Ronald has found a presence in hip-hop by starring in various hip-hop soul videos as the ultimate mack daddy, Mr. Biggs. Now this potent rhythm-and-blues brand has returned, achieving sales most of its peers can barely remember enjoying.

title: Jack Youngerman
description: 'Wood Relief Paintings and Watercolors'

title: Need for Emotional Counseling Is Expected to Rise
description: Within hours of the attacks on the World Trade Center, mental health workers at Lenox Hill Hospital had set up a walk-in counseling center. The following day, a handful of people came through, but yesterday that number had quadrupled. Dr. Molly Poag, a psychiatrist and the assistant director for education and training in the hospital's department of psychiatry, said she expected the numbers to increase rapidly with each passing day.

title: Struggling Against Fanaticism
description: A tide of religious and nationalistic fanaticism is on the rise throughout Islam, from the Philippines to Gaza and Libya and Algeria, from Afghanistan and Iran and Iraq to Lebanon and Sudan. Here in Israel we have been on the receiving end of this lethal fanatic tide: almost every day we witness the link between hateful incitement and mass murders, between religious sermons that celebrate jihad and its fulfillment in suicide bombs against innocent civilians.

title: Early Estimates: Dead and Missing
A Range of Donors Help Those in the Rescue Effort
description: From the $4.37 that a 4-year-old girl emptied out of her Pokmon wallet to a $10 million pledge from the Starr Foundation, donations small and large flowed into New York yesterday.

title: Wall Street Journal Finds a Way to Print
description: The Wall Street Journal reached 1.6 million readers on Wednesday and 1.7 million today.

title: Senate Backs Military Retaliation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 - The Senate and the House voted today to approve a $40 billion emergency aid package to hunt down the terrorists who struck at New York and Washington and to help in the recovery.

title: Shield Plan Appears Buoyed By a New Bipartisan Mood
description: The suicide attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon appear to have strengthened, not weakened, the prospects for Congressional support of President Bush's missile defense plan.

title: Sports of The Times; The Toy Department Of Life
description: VINNY TESTAVERDE spoke a simple put penetrating truth yesterday afternoon as the Jets ended practice. At a time when so many of us grapple with the still unfathomable dimensions of Tuesday's tragedy, Testaverde said: ''This is uncharted waters for all of us. We're all taking it day by day and seeing where it takes us.''

title: Events of Day Return As Ghosts in the Night
description: Steve Lockwood, a paramedic, wakes up in the morning and, for a few blessed seconds, thinks that his life is as it was before, a routine of stabbings, shootings, heart attacks and bloody car accidents. ''I think it has to be a dream,'' he said, but reality jerks him awake. ''Nothing's normal anymore.''

title: Stories of a Stricken City, and a Grieving Land; The Heroes of Flight 93
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling Los Angeles Police To Step Up Recruiting Efforts
description: With morale sapped and hiring growing more difficult at the Los Angeles Police Department, the force's newly installed civilian oversight body has announced it will focus on recruitment in an effort to restore some luster to the tarnished department.

title: W.T.O. Tries to End Work in China Case
description: Set back by last-minute squabbles and thrown off schedule by ripple effects of the terror attacks in the United States, trade negotiators here are racing to tie up a host of technical loose ends by Monday so that China can join the World Trade Organization.

title: Mets Delay Return to Shea
description: Citing respect for the city's rescue and recovery efforts after Tuesday's terrorist attacks, the Mets said they would not begin play in New York until next Friday. The team was scheduled to begin a three-game series with the Pirates on Monday at Shea Stadium, but the games will be shifted to Pittsburgh.

description: Andrew Kreps

title: Rumsfeld Ordering Call-Up Of Up to 50,000 Reservists
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld has recommended calling up as many as 50,000 military reservists, the largest number since the 1991 Persian Gulf war against Iraq, initially to support air patrols over New York and Washington and on alert elsewhere in America, officials said today.

title: The Primly Austere, and Occasionally Dark, Side of the Moon
description: ''Caspar David Friedrich: Moonwatchers,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a small gem of an exhibition, a bit of fanfare played pianissimo. With a mere 19 works installed in a single gallery, it honors the acquisition of the museum's first painting by Friedrich, the supreme German painter of the Romantic era, who made nature his cathedral and placed figures before it as before an altar.

description: The following is a list of the country's major airports, with information on airport status. Always call your airline to check flight status before proceeding. More information can be found at Travel Bulletin Central .

description: Last weekend, there were 50 sports events on local television.

description: With his gentle eyes, skeletal frame, long black beard and habitual Kalashnikov, Osama bin Laden has become the world's most reviled symbol of terror.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Shuts Down
description: Ansett Australia, the only national competitor to Qantas, said early on Friday that it would immediately suspend all flights. The airline, a subsidiary of Air New Zealand, filed for the equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection earlier this week and is being run by administrators from PricewaterhouseCoopers, who said the daily losses were so high and the finances so weak that Ansett had no choice but to stop flying. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

description: ROSENZWEIG-Phil. We mourn the loss of our son Phil who was on Flight 11 out of Boston. We grieve with his wife Lauren, his sons Jeremy and Max, his brother Allan and all the people who loved him. He was a beautiful, special person and we will miss him forever. Harold and Evelyn Rosenzweig

title: Barest Count, by Three of Hundreds of Companies, Has 1,500 Missing
description: Rescuers combed mountains of rubble at what had been the World Trade Center today in a grim search for survivors among the thousands presumed dead in its collapse. Investigators meantime cast a worldwide net for those behind the hijackers who slammed jetliners into the twin towers in New York City and the Pentagon in Virginia in the worst terrorist attack in American history.

title: The Meadowlands, Forever Changed
description: I had wanted to visit the Meadowlands for years. Every time I had driven on the New Jersey Turnpike I had glimpsed these marshes, wondered about what was dumped there and how the egrets and herons you can see from the highway were managing to thrive.

title: New Perspective on the Issue Of Cell Phone Use in Planes
description: The debate over the use of wireless phones on commercial airline flights may intensify in light of news this week that passengers aboard the hijacked airliners that crashed in Pennsylvania and Washington called loved ones from the air shortly before they died.

title: For Many, Sorrow Turns to Anger and Talk of Vengeance
description: Having donated more blood than victims needed, having wallpapered their towns with flags, and with little choice but to stew over television reruns of terror in their homeland, more than a few Americans are beginning to obsess about how to get even.

description: SCALA-Maria. On September 13, 2001. Dear grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of fourteen. Reposing at The McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains on Friday, 5-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10AM, Our Lady of Sorrows Church. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

description: After leading the nation at the National Cathedral in Washington in a day of prayer and mourning, President Bush arrived in New York City today and received an emotional reception from rescue workers at the devastated site of the World Trade Center.

description: A 70-year-old Kentucky man became the world's second recipient of a self-contained artificial heart yesterday, in an operation performed at Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky.

description: Many more planes took to the skies today as airlines and airports lumbered through the first full day of operation after Tuesday's terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEFFIELD, R. GENEVIEVE
description: SHEFFIELD-R. Genevieve. Of NYC, died on September 12, 2001. Survived by her niece Julian Sheffield. At St. Mary's Episcopal Church, 521 West 126 St., NYC, friends will be received 5-8PM Sunday, Sept. 16, and a funeral will be held at 11AM Monday, Sept. 17.

title: The Formula For Portraying Pain in Art; Building Chairs or Forging Tools to Ease Suffering Can Transform It Into a Creative Force
description: ''To have pain is to have certainty; to hear about pain is to have doubt,'' Elaine Scarry wrote in her classic, ''The Body in Pain: The Making and Unmaking of the World.'' One reason that pain is hard to understand from the outside is that a body in pain is often reduced to moans, cries and whispers. Physical pain, Ms. Scarry writes, is language-destroying.

title: Presiding Bishop Frank T. Griswold III, Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine
description: Each of us the past few days have thought about the sacrifices we need to make as a nation to fight terrorism and ensure our security. Perhaps sacrifices will have to be made as well in terms of our self-interest as a nation for the well-being of a larger world . . . May each one of us . . . be caught up in such a wave of being for the healing of our shattered and broken world.

title: Hunt For The Conspirators Widens With New Arrests;19 Hijack Suspects Named : Bush Mobilizing Up to 50,000 Reserves
description: WASHINGTON  President George W. Bush on Friday authorized the Pentagon to call up as many as 50,000 military reservists to help with domestic security after the devastating attacks in New York and Washington. Congress supported the administration with a $40 billion emergency reconstruction and counterterrorism package, and the pursuit of the conspirators accelerated in Europe, with the arrests of more suspects.

title: Surrounded by Grief, People Around the World Pause and Turn to Prayer
description: There will be thousands of funerals in the days to come, thousands. And grief and anger will continue to envelop those who are unable to block out one Tuesday in September, when terrorist attacks crushed a government building in Washington and reduced the storied financial towers of Manhattan to dust.

description: EUROPE

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hospital Equipment Unsafe
description: Nearly 30 percent of all anesthetic machines in hospitals in England and Wales are unsafe, according to research published in the British Medical Journal. Some 370 of 1,357 machines studied by researchers at the Royal Victoria Infirmary at Newcastle-Upon-Tyne were found to lack crucial devices that regulate the mix of gases to ensure the proper concentration of oxygen. The researchers conducted the survey after an incident in February in which a child died after being given pure nitrous oxide. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: It's Supposed to Be Scary, You See, Not Humorous
description: There is one intentionally sort-of funny line in ''The Glass House,'' a thriller that does not mean to be comical but that inspires more howls of laughter than shivers of dread. A gaggle of San Fernando Valley teenagers emerge from a showing of a slasher flick called ''Prom Nightmare.''

description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks yesterday at a prayer service at Washington National Cathedral for victims of the terrorism Tuesday, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair To Meet Africans
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair is to meet informally with a group of African leaders next week to discuss economic and political issues. A spokesman for the British High Commission in Pretoria, South Africa, told Reuters that the talks, with leaders from Botswana, Mozambique, Nigeria, Senegal and Tanzania, would include topics like economic development, debt and health. Mr. Blair has promised to help Africa through a new partnership with the West. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the path of some of the men who hijacked and crashed four planes on Tuesday misstated the response of employees at a store in Bangor, Me., where five of the men tried to buy cellphones before the attacks. When the employees refused to sell the phones because the men lacked proper identification and were not Maine residents, the men displayed a large amount of cash. But the employees did not accept an offer from the men to buy the phones for $3,000.

title: Dr. Abdullah Khoui, Islamic Center
description: What took place, no sound mind would approve of it, and no religion at all in the world would accept it. . . . We do condemn in the strongest terms these attacks. We condemn these attacks as human beings, and Islam does not approve of what took place.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Immigration And Soccer
description: The government wants to revise its immigration law to deny entry to hooligans during next year's World Cup soccer championship, which is to be held in Japan and South Korea. The government wants to refuse entry to foreigners who have served short jail sentences or who have been convicted of violence related to soccer matches. Current immigration law allows Japanese consular officials to deny entry to those who have been sentenced to more than a year in jail in Japan or abroad. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Invest in Global Policing
description: LYON, France -- While the important work of rescuing and treating the many victims of Tuesday's terrorist crimes continues, people are asking: How could this have happened? Was there a way to prevent such a crime?

description: To the Editor:

title: Selig Plans To Tighten Security At Ballparks
description: Major League Baseball, demonstrating a serious concern for the security of fans and players in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on Tuesday, adopted a series of stringent security measures yesterday that will be implemented when the season resumes on Monday.

title: Fordham and Columbia Reconsider, Halting Game
description: Even as the nation mourned and remembered those affected by the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon on Tuesday, Fordham and Columbia had planned to be among the tiny group of universities in the top two levels of college football that would be playing today. But after a conversation yesterday between the universities' presidents about the continuing repercussions of the attacks, they agreed to call off the game.

description: Stocks Plunge in Europe Amid Uncertainty in U.S.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Exports Slow
description: China's export growth slowed in August, narrowing the monthly trade surplus, as the global economic slowdown cooled demand for China-made goods. Exports rose 0.9 percent from a year earlier to $23.5 billion, according to figures released by the government's Xinhua news agency. That was in line with economists' expectations and followed a 6.6 percent increase the previous month. The trade surplus fell to $1.4 billion from $1.9 billion in July. Chinese exports have slumped this year after they increased 28 percent last year as demand in its major markets, like the United States and Japan, cooled because of deteriorating economic conditions. Exports account for about one-fifth of the Chinese economy.

title: Justice Dept. Identifies 19 Men as Suspected Hijackers
description: Justice Department officials today disclosed the names of 19 men who they said had commandeered four commercial jets in Tuesday's terror attacks, and the officials said they wanted to question more than 100 other people who are associated with the hijackers.

title: One Contingency Plan in Action: Amex Bank Keeps Money Moving
description: In the first stunned moments when the horror of the planes crashing into the World Trade Center slowly registered on the people in lower Manhattan, Madhavan Ramaswamy found something that would later be in very short supply: a taxicab.

description: LEIMAN-Hilda. The Officers, Directors, Administration and Staff of Gurwin extend deepest sympathy to David Leiman, Member of our Gurwin Jewish-Fay J. Lindner Residences Board of Directors, on the loss of his mother, Hilda. Our condolences to his father, Sol and the entire family. Martin Eglow, President, Lindner Residences Lawrence Simon, President, Gurwin Center Joseph Gurwin, Chairman, Gurwin Center Herbert H. Friedman, Exec. V.P.
