description: PRAYER AND REMEMBRANCE

title: Richter Looks Sharp in Scrimmage
description: After participating in his first scrimmage since undergoing his second reconstructive knee surgery in two years, MIKE RICHTER rushed off to see a doctor yesterday. ''I had poison ivy in my eye,'' he said.

title: The Rev. Bert Breiner, Grace Church
description: It's much better to direct our anger toward him, as he will have just as much love for us. It's much better than to direct it at some human being who might not understand why or who might not survive  literally  the force of our rage and anger. . . . Let us please go forth into this world with love as though everything depended on it, because as we now know, everything does depend on it.

title: Nations Step Up Efforts to Watch Radical Muslim Elements
description: Across the NATO alliance, the terrorist strikes in New York and Washington have mobilized intelligence and police forces to monitor more closely radical elements of the region's large Muslim population and to probe other potential sources of crucial information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRWIN, GLENN
description: KIRWIN-Glenn. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Amy Lemle, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Kenneth Chasen, Associate Rabbi

title: Construction in City Stalled After Attack
description: Building in Midtown Manhattan has been stalled and some of the premier New York projects on the drawing board have been thrown into doubt because of the devastation wreaked downtown by the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, officials and construction executives said.

title: Back in the Air Again, And Feeling a Special Rush
description: When David J. Bronczek, who runs the FedEx Corporation's air operations, went out to get his newspaper this morning, he found a note on his mailbox from a neighbor. ''The most wonderful sound I've heard in a lot of years was the sound of your planes coming over my house last night,'' it read, ''because it made everything seem right again.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLITZMAN, KAREN JOYCE
description: KLITZMAN-Karen Joyce, 38. Beloved twin sister of Donna, sister of Robert and Susan, daughter of Joan and the late Joseph and aunt of Joseph Elliott, died while working at e-Speed, a division of Cantor Fitzgerald, on the 105th floor of the World Trade Center, Tower One, Tuesday, September 11th, 2001, when the building was attacked. She was working in research on commodities futures. A graduate of Princeton University, Class of 1984 and Columbia University SIPA. She had previously been the Vice President of Research at New York Mercantile Exchange. Memorial Service will be held at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue at 30 West 68th Street in Manhattan at 7:30 P.M. on Sunday, September 16th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, ILENE
description: ZUCKER-Ilene. The New York County Democratic Committee mourns the passing of our longtime friend and leader, Ilene Zucker, who died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Her dedication as executive director of the County Democratic Party, as chief of staff for Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell, as a top aide to city comptrollers, Elizabeth Holtzman and Alan Hevesi, and earlier as a school teacher, was unmatched. We miss her already. Assemblyman Herman D. ''Denny'' Farrell Chairman New York County Democratic Committee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ALVIN
description: SCHWARTZ-Alvin. We mourn the loss of our mentor, long time partner and dear friend. Earle S. Altman Gregg Schenker Steven Hornstock Joseph DelVecchio Arnold Schonfeld

title: A Pledge of Support in a U.S. War Against Terrorists
description: Pakistan has promised to "cooperate fully" with the United States in its effort to forge an international coalition against the terrorists behind the attacks this week on New York and Washington.

title: Bogot Journal; Conflict Rages, but Capital Basks in Good Times
description: Thirty-seven years of conflict has left Colombia with two million displaced villagers. In some cities, urban warfare rages between rebels and right-wing militia members. Farms lie fallow. The economy suffers.

title: The Rev. Billy Graham, Washington National Cathedral
description: We all watched in horror as planes crashed into the steel and glass of the World Trade Center. Those majestic towers built on solid foundations were examples of the prosperity and creativity of America. When damaged those buildings eventually plummeted to the ground, imploding in upon themselves. Yet underneath the debris is a foundation that was not destroyed. Therein lies the truth of that old hymn . . . "How Firm a Foundation."

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Documents Detail the Movements of 19 Men Believed to Be Hijackers
description: The men believed to have hijacked the planes used to attack the World Trade Center and the Pentagon employed many conveniences available to ordinary business travelers, booking reservations on the doomed flights through Internet Web sites, using their frequent-flier numbers and paperless electronic tickets and, in some cases, relaxing in first- or business-class seats before they commandeered the planes.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; Falwell's Comments
description: To the Editor:

title: Marooned U.S. Travelers Down but Not Out in Paris
description: April and Rachel Eades of Toledo, Ohio, were early recipients of a wave of French generosity in the wake of the attack on the United States.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; A Public Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Shops Raise Shutters, But Barriers Remain
description: Officially, Canal Street was open for business, for a return to its colorful routines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, MARION
description: MANN-Marion. Our most sincere condolences to Michael, Meryl, Betsy and Adam. Your devotion to Marion will be an inspiration to us forever. Diane and Frank Lederman

title: 2 Disasters Lead a Cruise Ship Into 2 Nights of Vigils and Prayer
description: For more than 1,100 fans of the University of Washington's football team who boarded a cruise ship in Florida on Sunday, a week of glorious fun seemed to lie ahead: a seven-day Caribbean cruise, ending up back in South Florida in time to see their school's Huskies take the field on Saturday against the University of Miami Hurricanes, the No. 1 team in the nation.

title: Heroes Amid the Horror
description: The cruel list of those missing and presumed dead at the World Trade Center now hovers at around 5,000. But as President Bush noted during his visit to the site yesterday, that toll would have been even higher were it not for the extraordinary valor of the firefighters, police officers and emergency service workers who ran to the disaster scene to help. Some dashed into the collapsing towers to pull out people trapped in the chaos and falling debris. Many lost their lives.

title: Chief Steps Down At Alex. Brown
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Europe's largest bank, said Mayo Shattuck III quit as head of its United States securities unit, Alex. Brown.

title: Ban on Airliners' Freight Has Businesses Scrambling
description: One of the new security measures imposed by the Federal Aviation Administration in the wake of Tuesday's terrorist attacks -- banning cargo from passenger planes -- threatens to severely disrupt the electronics industry and other businesses for weeks to come, according to shipping agents, exporters and airlines.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; The Voices of Children
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Wireless Job Cuts
description: A provider of high-speed wireless networking products, Wi-LAN, is cutting 55 percent of its work force of about 120 people in response to weakening market conditions. In a further austerity measure, the jobs of chairman, president and chief executive will be combined. Wi-LAN, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, reported an operating loss of 18.9 million Canadian dollars in the six months to April 30. Revenues fell 11 percent in the period, to 44.1 million Canadian dollars. Results for the three months to July 31 have not yet been published. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: AFTER THE ATTACKS
description: CHILLING FINDS -- Rescue workers in lower Manhattan carried body bags from piles of wreckage to refrigerated trucks. One worker said he had found the remains of people strapped into what seemed to be airplane seats. Another reported finding the body of a flight attendant, her hands bound. PAGE A5

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITAY, BETTI
description: KITAY-Betti on September 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Victor Kitay. Cherished mother of Arlene and Robert Kaplan and Madeline and Monte Wolfson. Loving grandmother of Marc, Wendy and Jim, David & Jessica, Ricky and Courtney. Great grandmother of Vanessa. Sister of Sylvia Glassman and the late Edward Brooks. Betti's remarkable beauty, charm and loveliness are everlasting gifts to us all. She will always be remembered as the most loving, caring and sharing human being. She was the ''ultimate lady!''. Funeral services will be held at The Boulevard Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY on Sunday, September 16th at 1:30 PM. Contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, New York 10601, 914-949-4800.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, BARBARA
description: OLSON-Barbara, 45, former Federal prosecutor, legal analyst, dies in Pentagon crash. Wife of U.S. Solicitor General, Theodore Olson, partner at Balch & Bingham LLP, commentator for CNN, MSNBC and Fox, author of bestseller ''Hell To Pay'' and ''The Final Days'' to be released posthumously. Memorial Mass Saturday, September 15, at 10:30AM, Cathedral St. Thomas Moore in Arlington, Virginia. Memorial donations to The Barbara Olson Memorial Scholarship Fund, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, Office of Development, 55 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10003.

title: At Toronto Festival, Documents of Damage
description: Movies didn't much matter at the Toronto International Film Festival on Tuesday. By noon the word had spread, and moviegoers wandered the streets or congregated with friends to discuss the events reported on television. People gathered in hotel lobbies and bars to gasp at images of the unfolding tragedy at the World Trade Center or to watch silently as they were brought up to date.

title: Hundreds of Foreign Nationals Are Among the Victims in New York : Many Countries Share Terrible Losses
description: PARIS  Countries around the globe sought to locate citizens who might have been caught in the suicide attacks on the World Trade Center in New York, with a growing number of foreign nationals feared missing beneath the 450,000 tons of rubble of the World Trade Center.

title: F.B.I. Holds Men Traveling With Knives
description: Two men with box cutters, hair dye and a large amount of cash who were seized by federal authorities on an Amtrak train in Fort Worth on Wednesday remained in custody today for immigration violations, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Grief for Fallen Rescuers, But It's Just the Beginning
description: Two of New York City's most senior Fire Department officials were mourned at separate wakes today as men who gave their lives to save others in Tuesday's attack on the World Trade Center.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank To Trade On Big Board
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. said its shares would begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Oct. 3. The bank, which is based in Frankfurt, has said it wants to list shares in the United States to pay for acquisitions and broaden its investor base. The bank said Thursday that it was in ''advanced'' talks with Zurich Financial Services A.G. about acquiring its Scudder asset management unit in the United States.

title: Front-Line Workers Are Happy to See the Commander in Chief
description: For some New Yorkers, the hurt was so deep that no one, not even the president of the United States, could make it feel better yesterday. For others, the three days since Tuesday might as well have been an eternity; they were unwilling to make allowances for a commander-in-chief only now assuming his post on what they regarded as the front line.

title: Companies Pledge $100 Million In Relief
description: The nation's largest corporations have pledged more than $100 million to relief efforts since the disaster on Tuesday, with several of them earmarking multimillion-dollar donations for the families of dead or injured rescue workers.

title: On the Economy
description: To address concerns about the United States economy, three prominent business figures have agreed to appear on ''60 Minutes'' on CBS tomorrow. Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway; John F. Welch Jr., the former chairman of General Electric; and Robert E. Rubin, the former treasury secretary and now co-chairman of Citigroup, will appear together. The three men were invited by Leslie Stahl, who has been covering the business aspects of the World Trade Center attack since Tuesday.

title: Abroad at Home; Beware Unintended Results
description: The American government has sounded two main themes in its response to the terrorist onslaught: The United States is going to war against terrorism, and we expect all other countries to support us in the struggle.

title: Hoard of Metals Sits Under Ruins Of Trade Center
description: Buried under 4 World Trade Center, near ground zero of the terrorist attack, is 379,036 ounces, or 11.8 metric tons, of gold.

title: BUSH LEADS PRAYER, VISITS AID CREWS; CONGRESS BACKS USE OF ARMED FORCE
description: President Bush met mud-streaked rescue workers and inspected the smoking mountain of rubble that had been the proud World Trade Center in New York City yesterday as he led a grieving, angry nation in an emotional day of mourning and remembrance for the thousands of victims of the terrorist attacks.

title: As Hard Hats Volunteer in Rubble, City's Building Boom Falls Into Doubt
description: Construction in Midtown Manhattan has been stalled and some premier New York projects on the drawing board have been thrown into doubt because of the devastation wreaked downtown by the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, officials and construction executives said yesterday.

title: Heartened By a Visit By Bush
description: YOU may recall that George W. Bush was nearly six months into his presidency before he decided that New York City was worth a few hours of his time.

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com .

title: Where to Get Information: A List of Emergency Numbers and Web Sites
description: Searching for missing loved ones. Finding a place to stay.

title: Sports of The Times; In New York, It's Too Soon For Cheering
description: IT looked like a no-brainer: New York City and the rest of the nation were in no mood to watch any sporting events this weekend. The National Football League and Major League Baseball agreed. Even the high priests of college football in the South and the Midwest concurred that tailgating and rivalries were not the best way to resume normal life while horror and heartbreak emanated from Lower Manhattan.

title: Bomb Scares Are Fraying Nerves
description: In the wake of the World Trade Center attack, hundreds of reports of potential bombs -- all of them unfounded -- have frayed nerves and forced the evacuation of a number of buildings, including the Empire State Building and, yesterday morning, Grand Central Terminal.

title: Taliban Leader Talks Tough, Saying 'I Am Ready for Sacrifice'
description: Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban's supreme leader and their commander of the faithful, matched tough talk out of America with tough talk out of Afghanistan today, asking his people to remain strong or see their ''courage turn to dust.''

title: Richter Looks Sharp in Rangers' Scrimmage
description: After participating in his first scrimmage since undergoing his second reconstructive knee surgery in two years, MIKE RICHTER rushed off to see a doctor yesterday.

title: As Train Service Limps Back, Worries About Monday
description: The subway and many other parts of the region's transportation network limped back to some kind of normalcy yesterday, with busy train lines and bridges back in operation. But officials said they were worried about what would happen on Monday, if Wall Street reopens as planned and thousands of commuters try to return to a crippled and isolated part of the city.

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: Refugees Start To Return
description: About 1,000 refugees returned from camps in Indonesian West Timor, the first of what officials said they hoped would be large-scale returns after East Timor's peaceful election last month. At least 50,000 people remain in the camps, where 250,000 East Timorese fled or were forced after a vote for independence two years ago. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: The Lives They Lost: Passengers and Crew of the Hijacked Jets
description: For Yeneneh Betru, life seemed to be clicking on all cylinders. Last week, Dr. Betru, a 35-year-old specialist in internal medicine, returned to his native Ethiopia and married a young woman named Zelalem, with whom he had fallen in love.

title: Airlines, in Search of Relief, Warn of Bankruptcy
description: Airline executives and analysts expressed grave concern for the industry yesterday, warning that mounting losses stemming from this week's terrorist attacks could force most of the country's major carriers into bankruptcy.

title: Championships May Be Postponed
description: USA Wrestling is seeking to postpone the world wrestling championships, scheduled for Sept. 26 to 29 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLGER, JANE
description: FOLGER-Jane. The members and staff of Herzfeld & Rubin PC join with our colleague Michael Folger in mourning the death of his mother who perished with his aunt in the unspeakable September 11 terrorist attack on their plane. We pray that he and his family will take comfort in the memory of her love and kindnesses. Herbert Rubin, Sr. Member

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMARS, ANDREW BART
description: LOMARS-Andrew Bart. Of Miami on September 12, 2001. Beloved husband of Eileen. Adored son of Renee and Harold Lomars. Loved by Uncle and Aunt, Mel and Bess Brenner, and his cousins & family. Best friend of many people. Wellknown in the hotel industry in NYC and Miami. A member of Les Clefs d'or. Funeral this Sunday, Royal Palm Memorial Garden, 5601 Greenwood Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. at 11:30 AM.

title: Bewildering Array of Lines, But Which Makes the Slam?
description: On some hands the declarer is hard pressed to find any line of play that has a chance to make the contract, but on others there is a bewildering array of possibilities.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Rescue
description: Creditors of Hynix Semiconductor agreed yesterday to exchange $2.3 billion in debt for equity and roll over $2.9 billion in loans as part of a $5.2 billion rescue plan for the computer chip maker. The company failed, however, to obtain another $384 million in new loans that its financial adviser, Salomon Smith Barney, said was needed to guarantee survival. Creditors, led by the government-controlled Korea Exchange Bank, balked at the extra credit while deciding that rejection of the rest of the plan would jeopardize the entire Korean economy. Their reluctance led to a 15 percent drop in the company's share price. Don Kirk(NYT)

title: Problems and Protests as Sky Traffic Gradually Resumes
description: The three major New York airports began again to gingerly handle a very limited number of flights yesterday, a day after they had suddenly been ordered closed by law enforcement officials who detained at least 10 people for questioning, arresting one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, PEARL
description: FOX-Pearl. On September 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late David. Dear mother of Jay and Marshall. Grandmother and great grandmother.

title: Tragedy Reunites Clinton and Gore
description: The terrorist attacks have fostered all kinds of political unions, the latest being that between former President Bill Clinton and his estranged vice president, Al Gore.

title: S.E.C. Waives Some Rules to Try to Ease Market Volatility
description: Hoping to avoid a wave of panicked selling when the stock exchanges open next week, the government issued an order today waiving certain regulations to permit companies and executives to help prop up the prices of their shares.

title: Bellevue Psychiatry Chief Creates Action Plan to Tame a Horrendous Nightmare
description: When Dr. Manuel Trujillo got home to his East Side apartment late Tuesday night, there were 39 messages on his machine from friends and family members expressing concern or wanting to talk. Many had called from his native Spain.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: U.S. Charges In Blast
description: A federal grand jury in Seattle has indicted two companies and three employees on negligence charges stemming from a pipeline explosion in June 1999 that killed three people near downtown Bellingham. The indictment says the companies -- the Olympic Pipe Line Company and the Equilon Pipeline Company -- were responsible for the leak of about 236,000 gallons of gasoline from a 400-mile pipeline. The leak ignited, killing two 10-year-old boys and an 18-year old man. The companies are accused of violating the Clean Water Act and the Hazardous Liquid Pipeline Safety Act. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Death, Terror and Business Journalists
description: ''Sorry if Street Life seems a little weary today, it's just that I'm, well, really getting run down,'' Andrew Serwer, a financial journalist at Fortune magazine, wrote in his daily e-mail newsletter on Thursday afternoon. ''I have lost friends and acquaintances. Who have kids,'' he wrote on Tuesday, shortly after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: A Terrorist Profile Emerges That Confounds the Experts
description: They were adults with education and skill, not hopeless young zealots. At least one left behind a wife and young children. They mingled in secular society, even drinking forbidden alcohol, hardly typical of Islamic militants.

title: Metro Matters; Last Week, Profiling Was Wrong
description: JUST a week ago, it seemed so simple, so universally accepted that it had become the received wisdom. Racial profiling was wrong. The mayor of New York said the city never engaged in it; the men running to succeed him denounced it.

title: Heart-Rending Discoveries as Digging Continues in Lower Manhattan
description: Swarming with volunteers and soaked through by a chilly rain, the area of the World Trade Center disaster has become a muddy, malodorous and frenetic village built around shifting mounds of debris that, yesterday, yielded only the dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBNER, SOL
description: LEIBNER-Sol. He was a lovely man and he is missed. Nancy, Bruce and Emily

title: Pentagon Tracked Deadly Jet But Found No Way to Stop It
description: During the hour or so that American Airlines Flight 77 was under the control of hijackers, up to the moment it struck the west side of the Pentagon, military officials in a command center on the east side of the building were urgently talking to law enforcement and air traffic control officials about what to do.

title: As Rescue Work Continues, Flight Recorders Are Found in Pentagon Rubble
description: Search and rescue teams uncovered the flight data and cockpit voice recorders early this morning in the rubble of the section of the Pentagon hit by a hijacked jet on Tuesday.

title: Stuyvesant High Students To Attend Brooklyn Tech
description: With parents wondering where students displaced by this week's terror attack would end up, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy announced yesterday that Stuyvesant High School's 3,000 students would move across the river to Brooklyn Technical High School and that several thousand other students would be dispersed to schools around Manhattan.

title: Morton's Forecasts a Loss
description: The Morton's Restaurant Group said that it expected to report a third-quarter loss and closed its Wall Street-area restaurant indefinitely in the aftermath of terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; The Giuliani Balm
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, DOUGLAS B.
description: GARDNER-Douglas B. Adored husband of Jennifer, loving father of Michael and Julia, cherished son of Charlotte and Joseph and treasured brother of Danielle was lost in the tragedy at the World Trade Center. He was a graduate of Riverdale Country Day School and Haverford College, where he was a co-chairman of Haverford's current capital campaign. Douglas was an Executive Managing Director and Vice Chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald/Espeed. He was an active partner in his family's real estate firm, DG Equities. He was a board member of the charitable organizations The Educational Alliance and Student Athletes, Inc and a generous supporter of many others. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 16 at 4:30 at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street. Donations may be made to Haverford College, The Douglas B. Gardner Basketball Facility, 370 Lancaster Avenue, Haverford, PA. 19041.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about negotiations in Congress over emergency money for Tuesday's terror attacks misstated the proposed amount in some copies. It is $40 billion, as the article said, not $40 million.

title: Learning Where Suspects Studied Is 'Trickier Than It Sounds'
description: As at aviation schools around the country, it is not uncommon to find students from abroad at the Vero Beach campus of FlightSafety Academy, one of several flight schools that may have unwittingly trained some of the men suspected of involvement in this week's terrorist attacks. Indeed, the student dormitories here are virtually subdivided by nation, with Koreans at one end of the hall and Saudis at the other.

title: Falwell's Finger-Pointing Inappropriate, Bush Says
description: Did God allow the terrorist attacks?

title: Editors' Note; Today's Sections
description: Section A today is devoted to the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, with the editorial and Op-Ed pages, A22-23. Other international, national and metropolitan news is in Section B, with Arts & Ideas and Religion. Section C consists of Business Day and SportsSaturday (Section D does not appear). Corrections appear on Page B2.

title: A Growing Realization of an Unspeakable Loss
description: The garage bay in Rescue 1's station house is empty, and many coat hooks are unused.

title: Citing a Need for Normalcy, A Few Colleges Will Play On
description: Just before the telephone rang, Dr. William Steinbrecher of Valparaiso sent an e-mail reply to what he called a disgruntled alumna who did not think the football team should play today. So he was prepared to defend in a conversation his school's decision to play Wisconsin-Eau Claire. The game comes less than a week after the terrorist attacks in New York and near Washington that killed many and caused most sporting events to be postponed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Wireless Agreement
description: The German wireless units of Telefnica Mviles S.A. and Royal KPN N.V. agreed to cooperate in building high-speed mobile-phone networks in Germany to cut the cost of introducing the new technology. The agreement with KPN's E-Plus Mobilfunk G.m.b.H. will allow Group 3G of Moviles to save as much as 2.5 billion euros ($2.3 billion), or 40 percent of the 6.2 billion euro cost of building its network. The wireless unit of Telefnica, Spain's biggest phone company, and its partner in Germany, Sonera Oyj, want to extend the agreement to a third company, possibly the Vodafone Group, Telefnica said earlier this month. Mobile-phone companies in Germany piled up debt last year after spending a combined 50.5 billion euros on six licenses to provide a service that allows faster Internet connections and video images on wireless phones. They are now competing for customers ahead of the network starting dates in 2002 and 2003 while demand for their products cools.

title: Nervous Traders Push European Shares Sharply Lower
description: Europe's leading stock markets dropped sharply today amid uncertainty about the reopening of United States markets on Monday and the effect of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBSON, DONALD ARTHUR
description: ROBSON-Donald Arthur. Tragically lost at the World Trade Center. Husband and loving partner of Kathy. Loving, devoted and supportive father of Geoffrey and Scott. Dearest son of Joan Robson and the late Charles J. Robson. Beloved and cherished brother of John (Esther) and Nancy (Richard) Hamm, fun-loving uncle to Michael, Stephen, Jennifer, Carolyn, Peter, Patrick and Katherine, dear brother-in-law of Bob Kreek and his wife Sherry and son-in-law of MIL. Funeral Mass to be held at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, N.Y. on Saturday, September 15, 2001 at 2:30PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to any fund established for the police and firemen who lost their lives at the World Trade Center.

title: Lights On, Broadway Dispels The Dark
description: Some in the audience waved American flags. Some cried during comedies. Some just stayed away.

title: New Enemy Challenges the Academy's Old Curriculum
description: Most cadets at the United States Military Academy were here all summer, waging war games on the school's 16,000 forested acres, preparing, perhaps, for careers as peacemakers or peacekeepers in Balkan hills not unlike the Hudson Highlands.

title: For Insurers, Some Failures And Rate Jumps
description: The terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center will cause the cost of commercial coverage to rise by at least 20 percent as insurers struggle to recoup losses in the worst insurance disaster in history, insurers and analysts said yesterday.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; A Missile Shield
description: To the Editor:

title: As Brahms Goes By: It's Oddly Comforting
description: As television viewers surfed from one disaster coverage to the next on Tuesday, they might have come across a performance of a Brahms symphony in midswing. The juxtaposition was startling, the shock palpable. At one moment, experience of the world seemed to spread exponentially: questions breeding more questions, anxieties unresolved and trailing away into new anxieties. With three measures of music, indeterminacy and the unknown condensed suddenly into a small, dense, unreal ball of certainty. Brahms in the midst of exploding buildings was gloriously irrelevant, a foreign world. One could not bear, or afford, to dwell on it and so surfed on. Yet to know that it had been there was comforting.

title: China Clears Last Hurdle On Path to Trade Group
description: The United States, Europe and China removed the last remaining obstacle blocking China's admission to the World Trade Organization tonight, as the Bush administration scrambled to show that its engagement in international affairs was undiminished by terrorist attacks.

title: Text of Joint Resolution Allowing Military Action
description: Following is the text of a resolution approved by the House and Senate yesterday authorizing military action against the terrorists who attacked the United States on Tuesday:

title: Glimpses of the Normal Even as Obstacles Grow Clearer
description: In the wounded city yesterday, the school day returned to normal, people and cars flooded back into Greenwich Village and SoHo, and streets through the financial district were cleared in hopes of resuming trading on Monday.

title: Robert Speisman -- Executive, 48
description: Robert Speisman, executive vice president at Lazare Kaplan International in New York, a worldwide diamond manufacturer, was among the passengers killed when the hijacked American Airlines Flight 77 crashed into the Pentagon on Tuesday, his family said. He was 48.

title: A Pledge of Support in a U.S. War Against Terrorists
description: Pakistan has promised to "cooperate fully" with the United States in its effort to forge an international coalition against the terrorists behind the attacks this week on New York and Washington.

title: Outside U.S., Families Keep Tortured Vigil For Their Own
description: The hijackers who destroyed Manhattan's twin towers may have had America in their sights, but, judging by the list of victims, they ended up taking on the world.

title: Flinty Bond Trader Leads His Firm Out of the Rubble
description: Brass-knuckled deals and stiletto insults are prized in normal times on Wall Street. And by all accounts, Howard W. Lutnick of Cantor Fitzgerald fit that world perfectly, edging out his rivals at other bond trading firms and grabbing profits with the best of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, ROGER S.
description: STARR-Roger S. on September 10, 2001 in Easton, PA. Son of Frederick and Lillie Bernhardt Starr. Devoted husband of Joanne (Jody) W. Starr. Father of Adam, Barnaby, and the late Alexandra, father-in-law of Judy and Monica; grandfather of Robin, Zachary, Brittany, Thomas, and Luke; stepfather of Douglas Green and Patty Shaheen. Roger was a unique human being whose intelligence, thoughtfulness and good humor will be missed by all who knew him and read his work. A veteran of World War II, he served in Asia with the Office of Strategic Services. For many years Roger Starr was Executive Director of Citizens Housing & Planning Council, was Housing & Development Administrator of New York City, and was a member of the Editorial Board of The New York Times. Roger wrote numerous articles and books, and taught at Pratt Institute, City College, and New York University. After moving to Stroudsburg, PA, he was active in that community as a member of various county boards and commissions. Services will be held at noon on Thursday, September 13 at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, DONALD O.
description: STEIN-Donald O., 77. died Sept. 13, 2001. A man of quiet greatness, a loving and kind husband, father, grandfather and friend. Beloved husband of Bette Stein. Loving father of Barbie (Steven) Jaffe, Billy Stein (Rebecca Weis), Jamie (Steven) Walker. Adored by his grandchildren Melissa, Amanda and Samantha Jaffe, Jesse & Sydney Stein & Meghan, Alex, Brandon and Thomas Walker. We will miss you so much. You will be in our hearts forever. Services Sunday, September 16, 11:30 A.M. Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Camp Vacamas, 256 Macopin Road, West Milford, NJ 07480.

title: Dorothy McGuire, Steadfast Heroine of Film, Dies at 83
description: Dorothy McGuire, who came to Hollywood from Broadway to repeat her 1941 stage success in the title role in ''Claudia,'' and went on to have a long and distinguished film career playing sensitive, intelligent and steadfast women, died yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 83.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; Gorbachev Is With Us
description: To the Editor:

title: A Race for Space, and Incentives, to Keep Companies in City
description: The Giuliani administration, desperate to keep companies displaced by Tuesday's disaster from fleeing New York City for good, is putting on a full-court press to keep them, administration officials said yesterday.

title: Two Strangers, Bush and New York City, Meet and Embrace in Calamity's Wake
description: To President Bush New York City has been a foreign place populated by Democrats, cultural elites and two complicated Republican alpha males, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki. But yesterday as the president descended the steps of Air Force One to throw his arms around the mayor and governor, the world, already changed, seemed to change again.

title: Marines Reprimand 2 Officers in Osprey Case
description: The Marine Corps announced today that it had reprimanded two officers for their involvement in the falsification of maintenance records for the V-22 Osprey, the experimental aircraft that was involved in two crashes last year that killed 23 marines.

title: New Delhi Eager to Join U.S. in Fighting Terror
description: India has long felt the bitter hurt of terrorist attacks on civilians in the Himalayan state of Jammu and Kashmir. For just as long, it has been frustrated that the United States has not leaned more heavily on Pakistan, which India holds responsible for sponsoring the Islamic fighters it blames for atrocities in the Himalayas.

title: War Without Illusions
description: There is no doubt that this week's terrorist attacks on New York and Washington were the opening salvos in the first American war of the 21st century. Less clear is just what sort of war this will be and how the United States can ensure that it prevails. George W. Bush, suddenly thrust into the unaccustomed role of commander in chief, faces fateful decisions about the use of American military power in distant, difficult corners of the world. He must design an effective battle plan and couple it with a skillful diplomatic campaign that sustains strong international support.

title: Early Estimates: Dead and Missing
description: As of 9 p.m. yesterday.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; Grace Under Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELMER, MARION S.
description: ELMER-Marion S. 85. Died on September 9, 2001. Loving wife of Arthur Elmer (deceased), mother of Joan Mellon and Steve Elmer, grandmother of Josh Mellon, and sister of Sidney Solomon.

title: Candles and Hope Burn for Those Who Did Not Return on Tuesday
description: There are few communities in America as fortunate and seemingly sheltered as this affluent, green slice of Connecticut suburbia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, MICHAEL JUSTIN
description: McCABE-Michael Justin, 42. Of Rumson was killed Tuesday at the World Trade Center in New York City. Mr. McCabe had recently joined Cantor Fitzgerald in the equity trading department. Prior to that, he worked at Prudential Securities in New York City for 18 years, where he served most recently as Senior Vice President and Manager of Nasdaq Trading. Born at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, Mr. McCabe was a lifelong resident of Rumson. He graduated from Christian Brothers Academy in Lincroft and received a B.S. from Rutgers University. Mr. McCabe was predeceased by a daughter, Shannon. He is survived by his wife, Lynn (nee Hemberger); his daughters, Cassidy and Regan; and his son, Liam, all at home. He is also survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. McCabe of Rumson; his sisters, Mary Ellen Kirschner and Suzanne McCabe both of New York City; his brothers, Eugene J. of Newport, R.I. and Nicholas of New York City; several sister-in-laws and brother-in-laws; and several nieces and nephews. The family will receive visitors on Sunday from 1:00-5:00 PM at the Monmouth Beach Club. There will be a memorial mass on Monday, 12:00 Noon at Holy Cross Church, Ward Ave., Rumson. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you make donations in Mr. McCabe's memory to the Daily News Charities, Inc., PO Box 3307, New York, NY 10001, for the children and families of the rescue workers who lost their lives while helping to save others.

title: Journal; The Day Before Tuesday
description: Being human, you first think of those you love. Then, if you are lucky enough to find them safe, you grieve for those who are lost -- their faces still smiling out expectantly from downtown's new quilt of mass death, the vast patchwork of fliers headlined MISSING.

title: Wilson Flagg, 62, A Retired Admiral
description: Wilson Flagg, a retired rear admiral who was one of three admirals censured by the Navy over the 1991 Tailhook sexual-assault scandal, died in the American Airlines plane that crashed into the Pentagon, his family said yesterday. His wife, Darleen, also died in the crash. Both were 62.

title: George Carey, Archbishop of Canterbury, St. Paul's Cathedral
description: Another, older, American icon was not submerged. The September morning sun continued to shine on the Statue of Liberty, her torch raised like a beacon, a symbol of all that is best in America.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Mommy, why are there millions of flowers?''

title: Japanese Are Playing Favorites
description: All summer, as he led the American League batting race, or came in first in fan balloting for the All-Star Game, Japan's Ichiro Suzuki's exploits for the Seattle Mariners have been the lead item in sports broadcasts here -- that is when they have not been the top news item outright.

title: Yankees' Game Is Pushed Back
description: The Yankees had been scheduled to play the only American League game Monday when the season resumes after a six-day break, but baseball officials yesterday postponed the Yankees' game at Tampa Bay to avoid having them fly to Florida for one game.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Demands Air and Land Access to Pakistan
description: In intensive talks here and in Washington over the last 72 hours, American officials have demanded that Pakistan agree if necessary to allow American ground troops and special forces units to operate from this country, senior officials said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Talks On Chechnya
description: Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov met the Council of Europe's human rights commissioner in Moscow, opening talks aimed at resolving European charges that Russian conduct of the war in Chechnya has ignored basic rules for shielding civilians and captured Chechen guerrillas from wartime abuses. The commissioner, lvaro Gil-Robles, was given a list of 100 Russian servicemen, 15 of whom have been sentenced, charged with crimes against Chechen civilians. Russia is a member of the council, which is to take up the Chechnya situation at a session beginning Sept. 24. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: The Working Life of Two Towers
description: Death and destruction on the scale of what happened on Tuesday would be real and terrible wherever it occurred. But the terrorists also were seeking to strike at a symbol of America. Like other parts of their plan, the choice of the World Trade Center was well thought out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLCKHAUSEN, WILLIAM
description: VOLCKHAUSEN-William. Bill Volckhausen, a member of the Assocation's Board of Governors and its Secretary for many years, was a supporter of its college scholarship program and an enthusiastic advocate of public service. He was a friend whose counsel will be missed. He was, above all, a gentleman. Richard A. Cook, President The Hundred Year Association of New York

title: The Sound Was 'Like a Jet Engine Right in My Ear'
description: Howard W. Lutnick, chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, gave an interview to the New York Times on Thursday evening at the Pierre Hotel. Here is an excerpt:

title: National Briefing | West: California: No-Solicitation List
description: The Legislature sent Gov. Gray Davis a bill that would establish a list of residential and wireless telephone subscribers who do not want to receive solicitations from businesses. Mr. Davis has promised to sign the bill, supported by retailers, bankers and groups of retirees. It is opposed by newspaper publishers, direct marketers and phone companies. It would allow telephone subscribers to place their numbers and ZIP codes on a list effective Jan. 1, 2003. Telemarketers who called someone on the list could be sued in small-claims court. Robert B. Gunnison (NYT)

title: Irving S. Shapiro, 85, Lawyer And Ex-Chairman of DuPont
description: Irving S. Shapiro, a former chairman of the DuPont Company who evolved into corporate America's lead liaison to Washington in the 1970's, died on Thursday. He was 85.

title: Some Foresee A Sea Change In Attitudes On Freedoms
description: The political pressure to do something anything -- to ensure that there is never a repeat of this week's terrorist attacks is immense on Capitol Hill. And civil liberties advocates are watching with quiet concern.

title: Franco, a Native Son, Is Touched by His 'Big Family'
description: It was the longest bus ride most of them had experienced since the minor leagues, eight hours from Pittsburgh to the parking lot at Shea Stadium. Players watched a movie or listened to music through headphones, but there was none of the usual upbeat chatter.

title: An Unobtrusive Man's Odyssey: Polite Student to Suicide Hijacker
description: He was diligent. He was polite. He had, until quite recently, a taste for black jeans and a liking for a hangout here called Sharky's Billiard Bar, which calls itself ''The Bar With Mega-Possibilities.''

title: Senate Votes To Confirm Bush's Choice For U.N. Post
description: Moving to fill a pivotal position in the Bush foreign policy team, the Senate confirmed John D. Negroponte today as the United States ambassador to the United Nations.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; Grace Under Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.S. Extends Its Tax Deadlines for Some
description: Individuals, businesses and nonprofit organizations affected by Tuesday's terrorist attacks will be given as long as 10 months to file their tax returns and pay their taxes, the Internal Revenue Service said.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead; The Giuliani Balm
description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban Opponent Reported to Have Died
description: A flurry of fresh reports today said that Ahmed Shah Massoud, leader of the anti-Taliban alliance in Afghanistan, had died of shrapnel wounds he sustained when two Algerians posing as a television crew detonated a bomb during an interview on Sunday at Mr. Massoud's headquarters in northern Afghanistan.

title: U.S. Demands Arab Countries 'Choose Sides'
description: Moving swiftly in America's new war on terrorists, a senior State Department official today met with 15 Arab representatives and gave them a stark choice: either declare their nations members of an international coalition against terrorism, or risk being isolated in a growing global conflict.

title: Seeing Arafat Hurt by Attack on U.S., Sharon Cancels Plan for Peace Talks
description: Despite President Bush's request that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon hold peace talks soon, Mr. Sharon decided today that he was in no hurry to ease the Palestinians' political predicament in the wake of Tuesday's terror attack in the United States, and he canceled talks planned for Sunday without suggesting a new date.

title: Snapshots of Their Lives With Family and at Work
description: It has been four days since the World Trade Center was destroyed. Thousands of people who were in the towers at the time are assumed to be dead. But the official body count stands at 124, and the medical examiner has identified only a few dozen victims. It could be months before many of those killed can be officially confirmed dead.

title: A Pledge of Full Support from Islamabad in a U.S. War Against Terrorists
description: Pakistan promised today to "cooperate fully" with the United States in its effort to forge an international coalition against the terrorists behind the attacks this week on New York and Washington.

title: Battle Against Terrorism Tests Fragile Relationship Between U.S. and Saudis
description: Saudi Arabia's track record in previous terrorism investigations has been one of keeping its distance from the United States. It is a distance that illustrates a challenge: how does Washington square Saudi Arabia, the loyal ally and vital oil supplier, with Saudi Arabia, the guardian of Islam, a power of the Arab world and birthplace of suspected terrorists?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOEPFER, CARL V.
description: TOEPFER-Carl V. The firm of Sacks and Sacks mourns the death of our beloved friend and associate, Carl V. Toepfer. We love you, Buddy. Evan and Kenny, Sacks & Sacks, 150 Broadway, New York City

title: Diverted Flights Welcomed at Canada's Airports
description: Perched on the northeastern tip of North America, in Newfoundland, the town of Gander has long been a favorite trans-Atlantic refueling stop and convenient layover point for flights diverted from their intended destinations.

title: A Field Trip Before Planes Turned Into Missiles
description: The day before terrorists flew two planes into the World Trade Center, a colleague and I toured Kennedy Airport with Neil D. Levin, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates both the airport and the World Trade Center. We didn't even bother asking him about security. We had what seemed like far more pressing issues on our minds, namely congestion and the preservation of the landmark T.W.A. Flight Center designed by Eero Saarinen. Now I feel as if top Polish military leaders had given me a tour of the German border on Aug. 31, 1939, and all I'd inquired about was the region's flora.

title: Viewers Again Return To Traditional Networks
description: Sometime around 9 a.m. yesterday a television milestone was reached: three broadcast networks had covered one news event for more consecutive hours than any previous event in American history.

title: Islanders
description: MICHAEL PECA has been in training camp for all of four days, and his new teammates are already campaigning to be his linemate when the season begins.

title: Connections to a Tragedy: Creating a Record of Awful Days
description: When the first plane hit the World Trade Center on Tuesday morning, just about every New Yorker -- every American, in fact -- went through a mental check list of friends and family. So did I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIRMER, REVEREND THOMAS E.
description: SCHIRMER-Reverend Thomas E., Cleveland native, died New York City May 27th, 2001 after a brief illness. He was 59 years old. Father Schirmer was the Rector of All Saints Episcopal Church in Parma before taking over as Priest in Charge at St. Andrews Church in Astoria, New York. Noted for his commitment to serving the poor, he was dubbed ''The gallant radical'' in a New York Times article profiling him in 1998. He is survived by his longtime companion, Paco Schiraldi of New York City, as well as three brothers Charles Schirmer of Lexington, Kentucky; Robert Schirmer of Liverpool, New York; and William Schirmer of Ashland, Ohio. A sister, Margaret Schirmer, lives in Phoenix, Arizona. A Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, September 15, 2001 at All Saints Episcopal Church, Cleveland, OH. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Gods Love We Deliver, 166 Ave of the Americas, New York, NY 10013.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Job Cuts at Chip Maker
description: The biggest computer chip maker in Europe, STMicroelectronics N.V., has reduced its work force by 2,500 people, or 6 percent, this year in an effort to cut costs as demand slumps for semiconductors. Most of the reductions have been through attrition, the company said. Some workers at a wafer plant in Ottawa that is closing might leave the company, while several are being offered transfers. At most, about 650 workers will lose their jobs involuntarily this year, the company said.

title: U.S. Investor Wins Legal Ruling Over Czech TV Station
description: In one of post-Communist Europe's most avidly watched business disputes, Ronald S. Lauder, the New York cosmetics heir, won an arbitration ruling against the Czech government for failing to protect Mr. Lauder's company, Central European Media Enterprises, from being squeezed out of TV Nova, the Czech Republic's most popular television station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUIB, LEONARD W.
description: SUIB-Leonard W. Of New York City, age 87, died September 9, 2001 after complications from a lengthly illness. A master puppeteer of national renown, Mr. Suib was a teacher, author and creator of the Puppet Playhouse at the Mazur Theater, Asphalt Green, on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Born Leonard William Suib in NYC, September 20, 1913, he was the son of Joseph, artist and sculptor, and Lilly. Devoted father to his loving daughter Nancy of Oakland, CA, fondly remembered by his partner, Karen Sundheim, caring son Peter and cherished father-in-law of Susan Merguerian and loving and adoring grandfather of Alexis of Bronx, NY. Dear brother of Sidney of Olean, NY and his wife Shirley, who cared for him as her own brother. He leaves behind nephew Steven, and nieces Sandy Suib-Dutcher and Sally. Leonard graduated from Pratt Institute in 1936. He served in the U.S. Navy during WW II as Quartermaster, First Class. His career in puppetry spans over 50 years; touring the Suib Marionettes throughout the US and performing on Broadway, and television. The Puppet Playhouse was renamed The Lenny Suib Puppet Playhouse in 1996 ''a place for all children''. He taught puppetry at Hunter College's School of Continuing Education. He co-authored ''Marionettes on Stage'', Harper & Row 1975 and wrote numerous articles and reviews for puppetry journals and magazines. He received the Renaissance Award from the Puppeteers of America in 1979. Mr Suib was a stage manager for Hunter College's theaters from 1955 through 1978. Lenny is remembered for his devotion to his family, generosity with his friends and fellow puppeteers. We will all miss him dearly. Memorial services will be held September 16, 11 AM at Krtil Funeral home, 1297 First Ave, NYC. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Puppetry Guild of Greater NY, PO Box 117, NYC 10116 and Puppeteers of America Inc, Endowment Fund, Len Gerwick, 184 Hildreth Street, Marlborough, MA 01752.

title: The Little Fox
description: On most star charts Vulpecula, the Little Fox, seems to be nothing more than a formless splattering of dim stars. But Dr. Hugh Rice, who worked at the Hayden Planetarium in New York in the 50s, showed part of this group on his star maps as something resembling a cowboy boot.

title: America Mourns, and Looks at the Path Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Journal; Clergy of Many Faiths Answer Tragedy's Call
description: Ever since terrorists attacked the United States literally out of the blue sky on Tuesday, members of the clergy have found themselves called to fulfill their roles as spiritual and community leaders. Although hardly as visible as the rescue workers sifting through debris in New York and at the Pentagon, they have been deeply involved in the aftermath of the tragedy.

title: Invest in Global Policing
description: While the important work of rescuing and treating the many victims of Tuesday's terrorist crimes continues, people are asking: How could this have happened? Was there a way to prevent such a crime?

title: At 20, a Conservative Gadfly Can Still Bite
description: Multiculturalism, feminism, affirmative action, political correctness and ''a culture besotted by Newspeak'' have come in for a hard drubbing over the past two decades in the pages of The New Criterion, the conservative monthly review. While liberals are prone to choke on its punditry, conservative-minded friends, contributors and subscribers plan to celebrate the journal's longevity on Wednesday evening at a reception at the Union League Club in Manhattan.

title: Mara Sebrionsky Dvonch, Violinist, 87
description: Mara Sebrionsky Dvonch, a violinist, died on Aug. 30 at her home in Bainbridge Island, Wash. She was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATERA, BARBARA
description: MATERA-Barbara. Costume maker and designer, died September 13, 2001 at New York University Medical Center. She is survived by her husband and business partner, Arthur Matera, her sister, Pauline Ritchie-Fallon, her nieces, Ann Wills, Eve Grasham, and Lynn Ritchie-Fallon, 3 great nephews and a great niece. A Requiem Mass will be celebrated on Friday, September 21, 2001, at Holy Cross Church, 329 West 42nd Street, beginning at 10 A.M. Mr. Matera requests that in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights Aids, 1650 Broadway, New York 10036.

title: A Tragedy Spawns Charity Fraud and Price Gouging at the Gasoline Pumps
description: Amid a sea of support for victims of Tuesday's terrorist attacks, the authorities in several states are investigating complaints of price gouging by gasoline retailers and of people posing as telephone solicitors for relief agencies and charities.

title: Jumpy Giants Welcome a Respite and the Chance to Pitch In
description: With their outdoor practice field drenched and rain still falling, the Giants moved into the plastic bubble adjacent to Giants Stadium for today's light practice.

title: An Indiana Town Reconsiders New York, and Finds It Soulful and Admirable
description: After some 200 worshippers had cleared from the prayer service in front of the Montgomery County Court House at noon today, some women and children lingered on the steps, clutching flags, wearing red white and blue. They were talking about New York.

description: The day before terrorists flew two planes into the World Trade Center, a colleague and I toured Kennedy Airport with Neil D. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, SHEPARD L.
description: ALEXANDER-Shepard L. On September 12, 2001. He was 100 years old. Beloved husband of Patricia. Loving father of Michael, father-in-law of Ann-Marie and step-father of Paul. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date.

title: Leaders Face Challenges Far Different From Those of Last Conflict
description: The last time leaders named Bush, Cheney and Powell faced foreign aggression, their challenge was to marshal a skeptical public, a divided Congress and a reluctant alliance to fight the Persian Gulf war against a known foe on clear turf. Now a new President Bush -- and a Dick Cheney and a Colin L. Powell indelibly shaped by that experience a decade ago -- confront almost the opposite task.

description: To the Editor:

title: Some Planes Are Turned Back as U.S. Installs Tougher Security Measures : Flights to North America Slowly Restart
description: HONG KONG  International air links to North America slowly reopened Friday as U.S. authorities permitted limited civil aviation for the first time since the airborne terror attacks Tuesday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lending Unit Sold
description: The Toronto-based Sun Life Financial Services is selling its British mortgage lending unit, Sun Bank P.L.C., to the Portman Building Society for 95 million. Sun Life said the bank, with total assets of 1.1 billion and about 75,000 customers, did not fit its overall growth strategy, which is focused on life insurance and asset management. Proceeds of the sale will be used for general corporate purposes. Portman is Britain's fourth-biggest building society. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Devils
description: With the retirement of JOHN VANBIESBROUCK, finding a backup for goaltender MARTIN BRODEUR is a priority for Devils Coach LARRY ROBINSON and is the most important task for JACQUES CARON, starting his ninth season as the team's goaltending coach. FREDERIC HENRY and JEAN-FRANCOIS DAMPHOUSE, both of whom played in Albany of the American Hockey League last season, are the front-runners. With ARI AHONEN of Finland and SCOTT CLEMMENSEN, who played at Boston College, as the other goaltenders in training camp in West Orange, N.J., the Devils have four players younger than 25 battling for the backup spot.

title: A Pianist With Sustenance At an Anniversary Concert
description: The eerie hush that held the city for two days had begun to dissipate by Thursday night, when life and traffic on the Upper West Side seemed, on the surface, nearly normal. The barriers cordoning off Lincoln Center had been taken down.

title: Searchers Find Plane Cockpit Voice Recorder
description: As the families of those killed in the crash of United Airlines Flight 93 began to gather here, investigators found the crucial cockpit voice recorder deep in the crash crater and sent it to Washington for analysis.

title: Parents Fear Their Children Will Be the Targets of Bigotry
description: Salmah was walking down the hall at John Adams High School in Queens Wednesday, about 24 hours after the attack on the World Trade Center, when she felt a pen pressed into her head and a pencil hurled at her back.

title: A Wounded City Struggles to Discover How to Carry On
Portraits of Grief
The Way We Live Now: 9-16-01; Apology Dot-Com
description: In the wake of the dot-com collapse, fortunes have been lost, and companies have evaporated. Yet the biggest disruptions in Silicon Valley are not financial but personal, and the men and women who inflated the Internet bubble are now surveying its ruins and trying to make sense of what has happened to their lives.

title: Private Sector; In Antitrust, Stress on Restraint
description: SITTING on the coffee table in his spacious office at the Justice Department, next to a stack of newspapers, are ''The Art of War'' and ''Who Moved My Cheese?'' -- two books that Charles A. James says provide vital insights for his job as the nation's top antitrust enforcer.

Cherished father-inlaw of Joyce and Diane. Much adored grandfather of Abigail, Kathryn, Michelle and David. For information contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 212288-3500.

description: Pact on China and W.T.O.

title: Paris East: The Bastille And Beyond
description: Some 40 years ago, when I first saw Paris, few tourists braved the east side of the city, and virtually everything in that direction beyond the Htel de Ville was terra incognita, except on Bastille night, when you might attend the huge rally in the tacky place. Now, though, much of the area has been renovated, beautified and boutiqued (some would say with a vengeance). A walk through it, along the Canal St.-Martin to the Bois de Vincennes, by way of the Promenade Plantee, gives the stroller a long view of this reinvented part of the city.

title: Reports From the Notebook, and From the Heart
description: As the terrible week unfolded, reporters recorded what they could and editors made sure that most of that voluminous report appeared in the paper. But often, powerful observations, bits of telling dialogue or deep personal experiences were, for one reason or another, not in the newspaper. They remained in notebooks or indelibly in the mind.

title: Blaire Streit, Mark Catalano
description: Blaire Streit, a daughter of Peggy Brown of Darien, Conn., and Raymond Streit of Liberty Township, Ohio, was married yesterday to Mark William Catalano, a son of Karen and William Catalano of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. James A. Kowalski performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

description: Jane Ellen Ubell and Richard Alan Meyer are to be married this evening by Rabbi Douglas Krantz at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Reliving Old Passions in 'Best Kept Secret'
description: PITY the cold war. So dominant in its day, yet now nothing but a vague concept to anyone younger than 30 and a distant memory to anyone older than that. Katharine Houghton, though, had a greater personal stake in the cold war than most Americans, and her new play at the New Jersey Repertory Company, ''Best Kept Secret,'' depends on resurrecting the passions and frustrations of those decades.

description: ON Tuesday afternoon, in front of the Food Emporium on 68th Street and Third Avenue, a weary clerk in a green uniform jacket stands in the doorway forewarning prospective customers that the store is out of milk, water, bread and other staples.

Be patient: Edward Burns, who was a rifleman in ''Private Ryan'' and the director-screenwriter-star of ''Sidewalks,'' will explain.

Humber of Mississauga, Ontario. The Rev. David W. Good performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme in Connecticut.

description: THE WORLD TRADE CENTER towers were not instantly lovable or easily cherished buildings. At least, that was the reaction a generation ago of many New Yorkers, people who, like me, had their first jobs in the city in the 1960's or the early 70's and whose memories stretched back into pre-twin towers days.

title: Ellen Casey, Stephen Boyd
description: Ellen Williams Casey, a daughter of Sally W. Casey of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Rev. Craig W. Casey, was married yesterday to Bronly Stephen Boyd Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boyd of Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Charles B. Houghtlin, a United Church of Christ minister, took part in the ceremony.

Panetta looked around shortly after the boat left the dock -- all points of reference had vanished behind a gray shroud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATERA, BARBARA
description: MATERA-Barbara. Peter Martins and the New York City Ballet mourn the passing of our dear colleague and cherished friend, Barbar Matera. We shall always remember her compassion, her elegance, and, most certainly, her extraordinary talents. Barbara not only brought beauty to our stage, but also to our lives. Our hearts go out to dear Arthur, Jared, and all of those who knew and loved her as we did.

title: SOAPBOX; What Were They Thinking?
description: THE story of those parents who allowed a stripper at a party full of 15-year-old boys sure gave the news media interesting fodder, didn't it? The fact that it was so close, in Westchester, involving parents who are so much like us, was the real puzzling part of it all. We all pretty much scratched our heads and said, ''How can they be so dumb?''

title: New Jersey Calls It a Night; After Work, the Work Never Stops
description: TOM COOK'S life reads like a 1950's television show, except for the cable modem. He met his wife at 18, when he was working in a shoe store in Freehold and she was working in a title insurance agency next door. The two married in their early 20's, and by the time he was 31, he had three sons. He now owns a home within walking distance of the house in which he grew up. Raised in a large Irish Catholic family, he has about 70 first cousins. He says he tries to go to church on Sundays, but it doesn't always work out that way.

title: In One Vote, a Call for Restraint

title: 'We Share Certain Images From the 11th. They Won't Go Away.'
description: IT won't happen now, but all along they should have charged admission to New York. Not just bridge and tunnel tolls, but the price of theater tickets to the Greatest Show on Earth.

title: An Island At The Far End Of The Earth

Private jets, Sea Otters, any of the specialized aircraft usually relied upon to provide shortcuts will find nowhere to land here, amid the island's chaos of mountains and glaciers. Lying in the South Atlantic Ocean, at the edge of the Scotia Sea, and roughly 100 miles long by only 25 miles wide, South Georgia is reached from points in South America or the Falkland Islands. From the outset, therefore, one is aware of making a journey toward the end of the earth.

title: Midnight's Children
description: Night has fallen at last. The moths have come out, the cicadas are starting to hum -- and the air is filled with the jittery laughter of children. The kids who have gathered here are febrile with anticipation: they have been waiting all day for the sun to set, waiting for the moment when they can play together in the dark. Twilight shadows cause these scattering figures to blur as they assemble around a trampoline. A 9-year-old girl named Katie Mahar clambers onto the taut fabric; dimly illuminated by crisscrossing shadows, she rises and falls in the air, looking like an antic ghost. She wears a T-shirt with a curious inscription: ''I'm an X.P. star! We've got the sun on the run!'' All around Katie, beams of flashlights swivel and cross. ''Look,'' she shouts at her companions, ''I'm going to do a double somersault with my eyes shut!''

title: Wouldn't Want to Live There, Though
description: The British painter Francis Bacon (1909-92) is best known for expressionistic triptychs and portraits of himself, screaming popes, absent friends and vanished lovers. In 7 REECE MEWS: Francis Bacon's Studio (Thames and Hudson, $24.95),+a series of photographs of the studio where Bacon lived and worked for the last 30 years of his life, Perry Ogden has produced what feels like a landscape of Bacon's interior -- a catalog of the modern artist's psyche. Crumpled photographs and letters splashed in paint flood the room. Frayed boxes long since emptied of bottles of port and Champagne disgorge newspapers and pages ripped from magazines onto the floor. Hundreds of dirty paintbrushes, dried in their butter bean and orange juice cans, perch next to books on Seurat and Velzquez. The corduroy rags Bacon sometimes used to paint textures drape on top of paint-encrusted trays. Books on skin disorders and forensics sprawl across the floor. A bare bulb hangs next to its nooselike toggle string, an image familiar from several Bacon portraits. Canvases stacked in one corner reveal only their white or splattered backs; several slashed canvases lie scattered with the other detritus on the floor. The slightly sinister aura seems appropriate, given that Bacon's estate has been involved in lawsuits charging art world skulduggery, and leads one to wonder if Bacon really did leave his studio just like this. Is there any way to know? John Edwards, Bacon's sole heir, says in the book's foreword that the studio was left untouched from Bacon's death until 1998, when it was removed to Dublin, Bacon's birthplace. Turn the page and any doubts evaporate: Bacon the artist re-emerges in the light, color and composition of the unfinished work left on the easel at his death. In Ogden's photos, one almost smells the sulfuric remnants of Bacon's imagination. Elissa Meyers

''Townes is somebody who looks a little like Hank Williams -- even writes like Hank Williams probably would have written,'' Mr. Newbury said. ''But, I tell you, I think Townes is better.'' It's a statement that would indirectly be echoed later by another songwriting great, Steve Earle, who, while still in his teens, learned many lessons, both good and bad, from Mr. Van Zandt. ''Townes Van Zandt is the best damn songwriter in the whole world,'' Mr. Earle insisted. ''And I'll stand on Bob Dylan's coffee table in my cowboy boots and say that.''

I will number these boxes from one to sixty. When the books come out again, I will arrange them in an altogether different order. Their overall setting will be different, too. There is a certain sweetness to the whole enterprise in which I am involved, for I realize how much my library and I have changed together this past decade. The air was cool on this early spring evening as he stood and reflected on his current dilemma, surrounded by the massive three-story brick façade of an unfinished fort. Overhead, the stars twinkled and a waxing crescent moon hung low in the sky; Saturn and Jupiter were paired closely in the constellation Leo, suggesting to some an omen. A chilling breeze passed over the harbor every few minutes, adding to the grim anticipation. Chester, a youthful Scot, had emigrated to the United States and joined the army in 1854, just as tensions over the expansion of slavery threatened to tear the country apart. Now he was standing in the hotbed of secession and all was quiet as could be. "Except that the flag was hoisted, and a glimmer of light was visible at the guardhouse," he later wrote, "the fort looked so dark and silent as to seem deserted."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAGAZZONI, GIAN DOMENICO
description: RAGAZZONI - Gian Domenico. The Attending and Professional Staffs of the Department of Medical Physics of the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center mark with deep sorrow the passing of our colleague and friend, Gian Domenico Ragazzoni, M.S., D.A.B.R. Mr Ragazzoni came to the United States after World War II from Italy and always retained his love of his native Bologna. He received his M.S. from the Medical Physics program at Columbia University. Mr. Ragazzoni was certified in Radiological Physics by the American Board of Radiology in 1965. He was appointed to the Medical Staff of the Memorial Hospital where he achieved the rank of Associate Attending Physicist. A gifted teacher, he was responsible for the teaching programs in physics for residents in diagnostic and therapeutic radiology for over twenty years. He educated hundreds of radiologists, radiation oncologists and medical physicists, many of whom became leaders in their professions. He also fostered the careers of many graduate fellows in medical physics by his personal involvement in their education and in their professional development. Some of these fellows have stayed in the metropolitan area as leaders of their respective groups while others have assumed positions of leadership across the United States and abroad. We will miss his unfailing good humor, his love of teaching and the many gifts that he shared so freely with all who encountered him. We celebrate his life and extend our deepest sympathies to his grieving family.

title: On The Seine, A Houseboat Of One's Own

When he realized that we sought a barge moored at the Port de Suffren and not a hotel on the Avenue de Suffren, he complimented me on my attempt at the French word for ''barge,'' ''peniche.'' ''It is not an easy word,'' he said generously, yet not without some self-congratulation. He seemed flattered in his Parisian-ness by the mention of peniche, as if peniches are a secret only initiates know. And it came to seem to me after living on one for a week, entertaining friends and relatives on board, that this was true: the peniche is a secret about Paris that lifts the heart of everyone it touches.

title: Migrant Father
description: My 12-year-old Navajo son had AIDS. I knew he did when I adopted him last year. It wasn't news. Neither was the fact that Awee had had a hard life. It comes with the territory. His parents agreed that they couldn't take care of him anymore. So he came with me. I have wiped the tears of such children before. The disturbed and the vulnerable. The throwaways. Children from migrant camps. The barefoot ones with worms. I was one of them, too, even if I did have cowboy boots back then. I have been a migrant worker all my life. As children, we lived in barns, barracks, Quonset huts, chicken coops and pickup trucks. This summer, I drifted with my son from Michigan to Florida, picking oranges, cherries, anything, as long as the farm boss paid me in cash at the end of the day.

Almost against their will, they find themselves taking comfort in an offering of fresh cinnamon rolls. They are embarrassed by their behavior: how can they even think of food? Yet the eating, and the homey pleasures it brings, are the couple's tie to humanity, their respite from unfathomable despair. In its incidental savor, eating is a small, good thing.

title: Small but Numerous
description: This phenomenon is known to every pregnant woman: when you are pregnant, the world is suddenly, mysteriously full of other pregnant women. Susan Meyers (author of the middle grade ''P. J. Clover, Private Eye'' series) experienced an almost identical effect with the birth of her first grandchild: she noticed babies everywhere. Her heightened awareness soon led her to write EVERYWHERE BABIES (Harcourt, $16; ages 1 to 4), a joyful ode to the everyday miracle of babies, with illustrations by Marla Frazee. ''Every day, everywhere, babies are born -- fat babies, thin babies, small babies, tall babies, winter and spring babies, summer and fall babies.'' These first lines are a microcosm of the book. Each double-page spread begins with the comforting repetition of ''Every day, everywhere, babies are . . .'' kissed, carried, etc., and each spread absolutely revels -- in the words and in the illustrations -- in the endless variety of babies and of the ways they are loved and cared for. All the scenes depicted are utterly commonplace, with topics like dressing, feeding and rocking. But by their loving presentation, these ordinary scenes take on the glow of the extraordinary; they gently persuade the reader to see babies, and perhaps even child-rearing, in a newly appreciative way. Meyers's rhymes are fresh and heartfelt. Frazee (the illustrator of Mem Fox's ''Harriet, You'll Drive Me Wild!'') wields pencil and watercolors with a child-pleasing realism and the knowing wink of a parent. Yes, the babies are cute, but not cutesy. The contrast of a skinny-legged, bald baby girl in a fussy dress keeps sentimentality in check, as do a howling baby trapped in a high chair and several sleep-deprived, disheveled mommies and daddies. Frazee's eye for real-world details extends to the myriad types of families she portrays. Her vignettes are decidedly multicultural, with families of all types, ages, and races, including interracial. Indeed, the subjects mirror the book's potential audience. Babies will respond to the soothing rhyme scheme, while older children will relish the interactive possibilities of a stanza like this: ''Every day, everywhere, babies are kissed -- on their cheeks, on their ears, their fingers, their nose, on the top of their head, on their tummy, their toes.'' Kiss every part mentioned and you're going to have a happy, giggling toddler who's picked up some vocabulary too. Julie Yates Walton

title: 'Savage Beauty'
description: Camden, with its ring of mountains rising behind the white clapboard houses facing Penobscot Bay, made the most of its view. Nowhere else on the coast of Maine was there such dramatic natural beauty. The houses were like weathered faces turned to watch the sea. The upland meadows of ox-eyed daisies, timothy, and sweet fern, the dark green woods of balsam and fir swept to the gentle summit of Mount Megunticook, and the rock face of Mount Battie rose from the edge of the sea as if to hold it. But it was a far less generous time than the early days of shipbuilding, upon which the town's wealth had been founded. Now even the great woodsheds along the wharves were mostly abandoned, permanent reminders of the long death of shipbuilding. The wool mills looming behind the town offered scant wages and long hours. Later in her life Edna St. Vincent Millay would say she was "a girl who had lived all her life at the very tide-line of the sea," but in the fall of 1904, she moved with her family into 100 Washington Street on the far edge of town, in a section called Millville because it was near the mills. It was the smallest house in the poorest part of town, but it was one their mother could afford when she brought her girls to Camden after her divorce.
