Consequently, prosecutors try to dispose of many, if not most, cases by plea bargain. Guilty or innocent, it is a brave defendant who will refuse a sentence of 3-to-9 years and risk 25 to life.

title: Exclusive Preview Of The World's Seven Travel Wonders
description: Here they are, as chosen by the Official International Sightseeing Selection Committee, that anonymous, secretive, some say tyrannical but unquestionably all-powerful group of self-appointed Benelux-based bureaucrats, fresh from five cholesterol-packed years of globe-girdling junketeering and gift sorting -- the Seven Wonders of the Travel World for the new millennium. Let's ignore the instant critical hailstorm, the ugly rumors, the travel industry's own lawsuit just filed with the World Court at The Hague, bandying buzzwords like ''nutball,'' ''idiotic'' and ''suicidal'' in its attempt to overturn the committee's choices. The O.I.S.S.C. has rendered its verdict on the seven absolute must-see wonders of the travel world. So stop quibbling and start packing!

title: Sept. 9-15; A Tennis Titan
description: For the second straight year after winning the U.S. Open, Venus Williams had a whirlwind Monday, appearing on talk shows, posing for photo shoots and greeting sponsors. Nearly 23 million households tuned in for her victory over sister Serena in the first prime-time women's final. Ms. Williams, who has won four of the last six major tournaments, said a fuller schedule next year should raise her No. 4 ranking. She controls her growing financial opportunities like her opponents, with a $40 million Reebok deal heading the list. Liz Robbins

title: Gravestone State
description: To paraphrase a tourism slogan now defunct, ''You've Got a Fiend in Pennsylvania.'' And to make those devils, ghosts and other scary creatures easier to find, the state operates a Web site, www.hauntedpa .com, listing Halloween events, ghost tours and the location of famous persons' gravesites, among other things. Stephen Foster, for example, is buried in Allegheny Cemetery in Pittsburgh, not far from St. John the Baptist Catholic Cemetery, resting place of Andy Warhol. ''Ghoulish Getaways'' includes a listing of bed-and-breakfasts that are supposedly haunted.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-16-01: On Language; Muggles
description: Muggles of the world, unite,'' a Variety review begins, invoking a 1997 noun from J.K. Rowling's magical novels about a boy wizard named Harry Potter. While younger readers already know their Potterese, parents and those less fluent may welcome some lexical help. Muggles, for example, is a word that Rowling says she invented for ''nonmagical humans.'' It may derive from mug, a 1708 term for ''face'' drawn from drinking cups decorated with grotesque visages, but the Potter word is not without controversy. Nancy Stouffer, another author of children's books, lays earlier claim to the same word in her 1984 book, ''The Legend of Rah and the Muggles.''

title: New Targets For the Muse Of Gay Wit
description: PAUL RUDNICK, the playwright, has an important piece of advice for actors seeking to play the older man's parts in future productions of ''Rude Entertainment,'' his new evening of one-acts: do them exactly the way they are performed by the man for whom he wrote them.

title: Travel Shorts
description: HOTEL

title: Bookshelf
description: SHAKE, RATTLE & ROLL: The Founders of Rock & Roll. By Holly George-Warren. Illustrated by Laura Levine. Houghton Mifflin. $15. (Ages 8 and up) Brief profiles of 15 men and women whose music ''created a sound that changed our culture forever,'' including Bill Haley, Fats Domino, Little Richard, Elvis Presley, Carl Perkins, Wanda Jackson and Ritchie Valens. Children will be able to guess your age by asking which of them you remember seeing or hearing yourself. The framed acrylic and mixed-media portraits and decorations are very witty.

title: Private Sector; In Grief, an Outpouring of Generosity
description: Condolences from the corporate world for the victims of the terrorist attack have been accompanied by charity, from some of the bluest of the blue chips to e-businesses in the troubled dot-com world. Automakers have donated sport utility vehicles to the rescue workers and motorcycles to the police. Food makers and grocery chains are providing meals. Technology companies have offered wireless phones, e-mail, Internet access and online video conferencing. And virtually all have given money. ''We owe a huge debt to our firemen, policemen, rescue workers, doctors, nurses and others who have done so much for our country, our city and for all of us,'' Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chief executive of the Goldman Sachs Group, which is donating at least $10 million, said in a memorandum to employees.

title: The Little Miracles Performed by Cover Crops
description: NOT many home gardeners know about cover crops. They are plants traditionally grown to prevent soil erosion, conserve nutrients and improve tilth, but they also present exciting alternatives to weeding, hauling mulch, even fertilizing.

title: On an Adventure Of Exotic Colors And Age-Old Art
description: AS a boy in London, Simon Peers dreamed of going to Madagascar, the mysterious island in the Indian Ocean off the southeast coast of Africa, where exotic birds, snakes, butterflies and rare plants still flourished, as pirates like Captain Kidd once did. In 1981, when he was 22 and had an art history degree from Edinburgh University and a promising future as an art dealer at the prestigious Fine Arts Society gallery in London, he made inquiries about going to Madagascar to see whether adventures could still be found and fortunes made there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, GRACE (GOLDIE)
description: BLOCK-Grace (Goldie). On September 13, 2001 at 90. Beloved wife of the late Irving Block. Loving mother of Delores and William Berger and the late Jon Block. Cherished sister of Diane Block Levine. Adored grandmother of Emily and Lawrence Turtil and Susan and Stuart Ellman, and great grandmother of Benjamin Ellman. An indomitable spirit. Service will be private.

title: The Living Room as Concert Hall
description: WHILE most jazz aficionados will say the best way to experience America's great musical idiom is to hear it performed ''live,'' listening to jazz recordings stands as a good alternative. Recordings, after all, capture musicians ''in the moment'' and freeze their work in time, allowing fans and students to enjoy the music and carefully regard song structures, improvisations and stylistic interpretations over and over.

title: Amid the Ruins, Some Hope, But Little Sign of Survivors
description: Losing ground in the battle between hope and harsh reality, rescue workers spent a frustrating fifth day yesterday removing bodies and body parts from the pile where the World Trade Center once stood. They have found only five people alive, the last of them on Wednesday. Nearly 5,000 more remain missing, presumed buried under tons of steel and debris.

title: Watching A Game Rule A Town
description: IN Massillon, Ohio, where everything takes a back seat to high school football, newborn boys receive a visit from the head of the local booster club, who places a miniature pigskin in their crib.

title: Here's a Starter Kit For the New Season
description: New Jersey audiences have a good attitude about feeling welcome at concerts. They arrive in a friendly mood, they don't cough and rattle candy like their New York counterparts, and they are usually willing to give different music a try. (They may complain after they've heard it, but voicing a fairly earned opinion is appropriate.)

title: The Little Miracles Performed by Cover Crops
description: NOT many home gardeners know about cover crops. They are plants traditionally grown to prevent soil erosion, conserve nutrients and improve tilth, but they also present exciting alternatives to weeding, hauling mulch, even fertilizing.

title: A Tuscan Menu in a Warm, Stylish Setting
description: OH, you've been here before?'' I asked my friends after we were seated at Il Palio, a new restaurant in Shelton. The welcoming warmth and friendliness of the hostess at the door made me think they were recognized patrons.

title: Naples: An Insider's Address Book
description: PICK-ME-UPS

title: Despite the Light, Astronomers Survive
description: PETER CHAPIN, an amateur astronomer, was lecturing several newcomers before a balmy, cloudless night of stargazing at Waterfront Park in Freeport. There was no moonlight to obscure the sky's bounty, and Mr. Chapin promised to deliver hard-to-find nebulae that he called ''faint fuzzies.''

title: Blood and Tears: a Chinese Family's Ordeal in a Nation in Denial of AIDS
description: Shen Jieyong was happy to buy his pregnant wife transfusions when she returned to their rural hometown to give birth in 1998. The doctor said she needed blood, and the couple -- owners of a hair salon in this bustling tourist town -- saw being able to afford it as a sign of their prosperity.

title: New Jersey Calls It a Night.; Tending to Children, Making Dinner at 10
description: SANDRA WALKER'S life is in a perpetual state of motion. By day, she works as a detective for the Union County Prosecutor's Office, helping find witnesses in child abuse and sexual abuse cases. At night, her job is as mother to two Robert Jr., 8, and Tyler, 3, and a teenage girl, Chanell, 16, as well as wife and homemaker to her husband, Robert.

title: Mary Matthews, Stephen Hunt
description: Dr. Mary Elizabeth Matthews, the daughter of Mary Elyn and Roger Matthews of Mendham, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dr. Stephen Austin Hunt, a son of Judith and Walter Hunt of New York. Msgr. Kenneth E. Lasch performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church.

title: Corrections
description: A map and chart on Friday cataloging damage to buildings in Lower Manhattan misstated the condition of 14 Wall Street. It is not on city inspectors' list of buildings with confirmed structural damage, and the owner expects to reopen it on Monday.

title: Dolphin Debate
description: To the Editor: Why must we burden a travel story about dolphin encounters with the polarizing issue of dolphins in captivity?

title: Old War Escalates on a New Front: The Trail of Relentless Martyrs
description: The airborne assault on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon is the culmination of a decade-long holy war against the United States that is escalating methodically in ambition, planning and execution.

title: Staging Shakespeare, Or Something Like It
description: HOW deep a knowledge of Shakespeare does it take to stage operas based on Shakespeare? The answer will vary from case to case, and the cases are legion. The Shakespeare entry in The New Grove Dictionary of Opera lists ''Shakespearean'' operas by the hundreds: a vertiginous catalog of the vanity of human wishes.

title: Surrounded by Sounds Beyond Classical
description: IN the beginning, when high-priced, world-class entertainment began arriving on Long Island, it was culture with a capital C; that is, the Classics. But times -- and demographics -- are changing and as the performing arts season opens this month, the Island's concert halls and series will not just offer the same old, same old.

title: Finding the Wild Heart of Long Island
description: ORDINARILY, the Long Island Expressway has all the glamour of the rush-hour traffic jams it's famous for, but in Michael Cuesta's remarkable debut film ''L.I.E.,'' which opened here on Sept. 7, the commuter artery feels banal and menacing by turns. It's the unexpected locale of danger and desire, where baby-faced hustlers ply their trade behind a billboard that says ''Welcome to Long Island'' and a teenage boy flirts with suicide on an overpass railing near Exit 52, where his mother died in a fiery, headline-making crash.

title: Anatomy of a Verdict
description: Burnett's account of his experience as a jury foreman has changed me from a duty dodger to (henceforth) a willing citizen, ready to take my turn.

title: Horror Steals The Starry Eyes From a Visitor
description: THIS is a time when hours and even minutes change the way we feel about everything. So Nicole Hemmings may once again believe that the New York City she discovered when she arrived from Australia in April is still alive, still feisty and funky and enchanting despite the horror.

title: Saving the Weekend: Doing Repairs After 5
description: IT'S the weekend and the choices are familiar: do maintenance and home-improvement chores, or take time off to relax. People being people, many chores, particularly preventive-maintenance tasks, are often neglected in favor of leisure.

title: Despite a National Rush of Emotion, Recruiting Centers Aren't Seeing a Rush to Enlist
description: Workers at the collapse site in Lower Manhattan greeted President Bush by chanting ''U.S.A., U.S.A.!'' At memorial sites, there have been spontaneous outbreaks of ''God Bless America.'' American flags sprout from window boxes and moving trucks, on the helmets of rescue workers and the electronic marquees of Times Square.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-16-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Nikki Oden, Diana Scott, Murrells Inlet, S.C., July 18, 2001

title: Girl Crazy
description: STILL SHE HAUNTS ME

title: War Zone; What Would 'Victory' Mean?
description: NO sooner had the great towers collapsed than talk of war began billowing from the twisted wreckage. ''Attack on America,'' screamed the banners in the media. American flags sprouted over the wounds. These were not just acts of terror, proclaimed President Bush, ''they were acts of war.'' Others saw the opening shots of World War III, the first war of the 21st century.

title: Will Europe Be Ready for the Euro on Jan. 1?
description: BUYING an international train ticket at this city's main station is already a nightmarish experience on some days, with travelers often waiting for as long as an hour to talk to an agent.

title: M.L.S. Gets Ready to Begin Playoffs
description: Major League Soccer, which canceled the final 10 games of the regular season because of last Tuesday's terrorist attacks, will begin the playoffs Thursday. All playoff teams will wear Statue of Liberty patches and black armbands on their uniforms.

title: A.A.R.P. Recruits
description: MIDDLE AGE

title: STRAINING TO RING THE OPENING BELL
description: Debris littered some streets of the financial district. National Guard members in camouflage uniforms manned checkpoints. Abandoned coffee carts, glazed with dust from the collapse of the World Trade Center, lay on their sides across sidewalks. Most subway stations were closed, most lights were still off, most telephones did not work, and only a handful of people walked in the narrow canyons of Wall Street yesterday morning.

title: How Do You Take Your Coffee?
description: ALMOST every night, a line trails out the entrance of Cafe Eclectic, a coffee bar in Montclair. Sometimes, admission can be gained in a manner of minutes. But sometimes, people will wait half an hour for what is arguably the coolest cup of coffee in Montclair.

title: Hardcover Nonfiction
description: This

title: Like a Moth to the Flame
description: SAVAGE BEAUTY

title: Taking a Chance At Hartford Stage
description: IT must be impolite, if not uncivil, to say a disparaging word about a new play by the venerable Horton Foote, the theater's last authentic articulator of a bygone time.

title: Envisioning an Expensive Future in the Brave New World of Fortress New York
description: Late Friday afternoon, pausing amid the swirl of commuters in the main lobby of Grand Central Terminal, a young man leaned into his girlfriend and whispered a thought that in an earlier America would have sounded alarmist and paranoid: ''What's to stop a suicide bomber from taking out this whole place?''

title: Karen Holmberg, Riccardo Bracco
description: Karen Geneil Holmberg, a daughter of Beverly Grant Holmberg and Neil A. Holmberg of Mathews County, Va., was married on Friday to Riccardo Giovanni Bracco, a son of Barbara and Renzo Bracco of Milan. Francisco Aurelio, a judge of the registry of Tulum, Mexico, officiated with Moises Chin Oyil, a Maya elder, in Tulum.

title: A Gradual Return for Mutual Funds
description: Mutual fund companies began reopening money market and bond funds last week, with equity funds scheduled to resume operations tomorrow.

title: Reckonings; Paying the Price
description: Right now most Americans are focused on punishing the perpetrators. But Tuesday's tragedy was partly self-inflicted. Why did we leave ourselves so vulnerable?

title: Cape Town
description: Even during the days of apartheid and South Africa's tense transition to full democracy, Cape Town was best known for surf and sun, something like Southern California without the glitz of Hollywood, or the Riviera without its shimmer of sophistication. No one would have described it as hip.

title: Anxiety Knocks the Wind Out of a Once-Brash City
description: Everything seemed to be going right.

title: Let Me Entertain You
description: STRIP CITY

title: Leadership, Put to a New Test
description: THERE is leadership, and there is leadership when the world is wrenched by a calamity of unimaginable dimensions. Most of America's chief executives got to the top by following the how-to manual -- business school, foreign postings, long hours, on and on.

title: Weekend of Heartache: Let Us Honor the Dead; Defending Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Reports From the Notebook, and From the Heart
description: As the terrible week unfolded, reporters recorded what they could and editors made sure that most of that voluminous report appeared in the paper. But often, powerful observations, bits of telling dialogue or deep personal experiences were, for one reason or another, not in the newspaper. They remained in notebooks or indelibly in the mind.

title: Under a Car, Inside a Deli, the Ash and Debris Found Us
description: I was in Flushing, Queens, taking photographs for a feature on polling places. When I was paged I drove behind a caravan of at least 10 emergency vehicles to the vicinity of the World Trade Center, where the police indicated that I should park a couple of blocks away. I did, on Church Street.

title: Guiding Merrill's Troops to Safety, and Regrouping
description: The troops commanded by David H. Komansky, the chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, have long been described in military terms. On Wall Street, the firm's hard-charging investment bankers were once known as the Irish marines. Its global force of 15,000 stockbrokers, the biggest in the business, is often called an army.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEHRER, NAOMI ANN LAMPORT
description: NEHRER-Naomi Ann Lamport. A very special lady passed away suddenly on Monday, September 10, 2001. She was devoted to her family, its history, her friends and colleagues at work. Daughter of the late Estelle and Morris Satin, beloved wife of Arthur, wonderful mother of Jonathan and Sarah Nehrer, & Roger & Robin Nehrer, loving sister of Kyla and the late Morton Lamport, and Samuel and Marjorie Lamport, delighted grandmother of Joshua, Esther and Tovah, and a caring friend to so many. She was pure goodness. She was a source of strength and wonder. We will miss her dearly every day of our lives.

title: Moving Past All Fears, in Markets and Life
description: he only thing we have to fear is fear itself, nameless, unreasoning, unjustified terror, which paralyzes needed efforts to convert retreat into advance."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, PAUL J.
description: FRIEDMAN-Paul J. 45, died aboard AA Flight 11 on September 11. Born in Brooklyn, he resided in Belmont, MA. Survived by wife Audrey Ades, son ''Rocky,'' mother Selma, and siblings Iris & Alan, Amy & Mitchell, James & Krista, Meryl & David. He will be missed for his wonderful sense of humor, his brilliance and his caring and warm ways as a husband, father, son and brother.

title: Weekend of Heartache: Let Us Honor the Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Fighting an Elusive Enemy
description: September 11, 2001, like December 7, 1941, is surely a date that will live in infamy. But despite superficial similarities, Tuesday's events were no kind of Pearl Harbor. Harrowing as it is to contemplate, they may ultimately prove even more challenging, perhaps even more insidiously consequential, than the notorious sneak attack that plunged the United States into World War II. To think otherwise is not merely misleading, but dangerous.

title: The Makeup Artist
description: Jeanine Lobell assembles her wardrobe with the ease and efficiency that define her cosmetics line, Stila. She chooses separates that are simple, streamlined and aesthetically consistent. ''If I find something I like,'' Ms. Lobell said, ''I buy it in every color and wear it to the ground.''

title: Abby Miller, Michael Pecoriello
description: Abby Miller, the daughter of Susan and David Miller of Manhattan, was married last evening to Michael Louis Pecoriello, a son of Iris and Louis Pecoriello of Great Kills, Staten Island. Rabbi Josh Zweiback officiated at the Stepping Stones Children's Museum in Norwalk, Conn.

title: As North and South Korea Open Discussions, the Issue of Terrorism Takes Center Stage
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 15  A ministerial delegation from North Korea arrived here today to begin a four-day series of meetings heavily dominated by the issue of terrorism. It is the first-high level dialogue between the two countries in six months.

title: Weekend of Heartache: Let Us Honor the Dead; Divisive Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Antiterror Support Avoids Vow of Military Aid
description: Pakistan today pledged its ''full support'' in the hunt for those responsible for the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, but carefully avoided any specific commitment to provide the United States with military assistance in an operation against terrorist bases in neighboring Afghanistan.

title: Being Ichiro
description: Every Seattle post-intelligencer vending machine has a placard featuring a photo of Ichiro running the bases, underneath which is written, ''Read his every move.'' But his appeal is precisely that he is unreadable. The tired, wired world we live in seems instantly explicable, knowable, one-dimensional, ceaselessly cacophonous, shoddily made. Here comes Ichiro: pseudosilent, precise, contradictory, sphinxlike, a cat in a doggy-dog universe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFIERI, FRANK
description: ALFIERI-Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Alfieri, associated with The Times from 1956 until 2001.

title: Blair Fowlkes, Thomas Childs
description: Isabel Blair Fowlkes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Winston Fowlkes III of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Carl Christoph Childs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. P. Childs of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Robert L. Ficks III performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, Conn.

title: An Accessory to Writhe For
description: Snakeskin and python prints are last year's news; this year, the fashion world seems to prefer the real thing. Long and colorful reptiles can be seen writhing their way around jewelry, footwear and some famous necks.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 16, 2001
description: Weeks

title: For the Fire Department, the First Three Farewells
description: They were knights of the New York Fire Department, two senior commanders and a chaplain who had rushed toward danger many times through curtains of smoke and flame to save lives and comfort the stricken. Like more than 300 comrades, they died in Tuesday's collapse of the World Trade Center.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 16, 2001
description: Weeks

title: A Suitcase Education
description: BALZAC AND THE LITTLE CHINESE SEAMSTRESS

title: Reports From the Notebook, and From the Heart
description: As the terrible week unfolded, reporters recorded what they could and editors made sure that most of that voluminous report appeared in the paper. But often, powerful observations, bits of telling dialogue or deep personal experiences were, for one reason or another, not in the newspaper. They remained in notebooks or indelibly in the mind.

title: The Faces Emerge
description: It took almost a day, after the bitter shock of Tuesday morning, before it began to become clear who might be missing, who might be presumed dead and who, in the case of the passengers and crew on the four hijacked planes, must certainly have died. The streets around the hospitals near Lower Manhattan began to fill with stricken people trying to locate friends, co-workers or family members who had gotten to work at the usual hour on Tuesday and had not been heard from since midmorning that day. Some people on the streets carried snapshots, wedding photos, graduation pictures. Some had already printed fliers asking, ''Have you seen this person?''

title: Before & After; Awakening to Terror, and Asking the World for Help
description: OF all the offers of support that Americans received last week from friends and acquaintances abroad, one of the most remarkable came from the editors of Le Monde, the French daily newspaper often noted for wariness of the United States. ''We are all Americans,'' the paper declared in a banner headline.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS/for KERRY J. SULKOWICZ; As Many Ways to Grieve as There Are Desks in the Office
description: TOMORROW, many people will be returning to work for the first time since last week's terrorist attack, and they will be carrying the burden of the horrible things they have seen on television or perhaps in person. The psychological state of employees affects how they approach work, and how managers handle the situation can make the adjustment easier or harder.

title: Hardcover Advice
description: This

title: In This Section
description: PLANNING COUNTERATTACK

title: Weekend of Heartache: Let Us Honor the Dead; Don't Give In
description: To the Editor:

title: Style, With Echoes
description: Are houseware stores by fashion designers, like Armani Casa and Ralph Lauren Home, a good idea? Not according to Murray Moss, owner of the home design emporium Moss in SoHo, which has begun displaying made-to-order dresses as a rejoinder to what Mr. Moss calls the ''dumbing down of product design by fashion designers.''

title: A Newcomer Offers Fusion-Style Dishes
description: MOST of Harrison's restaurants seem to be clustered on the blocks around its train station. But along Halstead Avenue to the south, almost out of town, Halstead Avenue Bistro joins the venerable Gus's and creates a fresh dining outpost very much worth knowing about.

title: A Look at the Destruction and the Rescue Effort
description: This satellite image was taken yesterday at 11:54 a.m.

title: The Fiber Optic Network: Not Exactly a Railroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Spending the Night In a Flower Bed
description: IN the 1981 book ''Green Thoughts,'' Eleanor Pernyi describes a familiar scene: the devoted gardener arrives at her weekend retreat on a Friday night and goes straight out to inspect the garden by flashlight.

title: POSTINGS: $525,000 to $1.3 Million in Hoboken; From a Stable To Condos
description: A late-19th-century stable in Hoboken, N.J., that became a three-story mill and then a warehouse has been turned into a 14-unit loft condominium. With prices ranging from $525,000 to $1.3 million, the building at 610-612 Clinton Street, called the Castiron, is also one of Hoboken's more expensive condo buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, FRIEDMAN, ANNE
description: O'ROURKE - FRIEDMAN - Anne. Of Brooklyn, NY, suddenly on September 13, 2001. Beloved wife of Bruce, sister to Brian, Denis and Virginia McLaughlin, sister-in-law to Charles & Deborah Friedman, Camie O'Rourke, Nancy O' Rourke and the late William McLaughlin. Devoted and loving aunt to twelve nieces and nephews, their spouses and children. Cherished friend and confidante to a countless number. Committed and vital employee of the New York City Board of Education for 30 years, Assistant Principal at High School Redirection. Viewing at Parkside Chapel 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York, on Sunday 7-9:30PM, Monday 910AM, burial to follow at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: The Lights Are the Action
description: In a city that is suddenly somber, Go, a new nightclub at 73 Eighth Avenue (near 14th Street), offers a gentle antidote. Its interior is suffused with light and color, with none of the exotic Asian woods and thick velvet upholstery typical of bull-market hot spots; instead, there is a stark white space, almost devoid of furniture except for a few white vinyl seating areas atop Plexiglas platforms. The main emphasis at the club, which was last the home of Chicago Blues, is on the lighting system, which can produce an almost limitless combination of colors and requires the attentions of a special light jockey, a k a L. J. ''Changing lights supply the same basic effect as a new coat of paint,'' said Shawn Kolodny, one of Go's owners, who also runs the uptown clubs Cream and Venue. The pared-down look feels similar to downtown New York discos of the 80's, whose atmosphere depended on deft dancing, flashing lights and a booming sound system.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 19 about the origins of the personal computer referred incorrectly to the first use of the term ''personal computer'' in advertising. A 1968 ad for a Hewlett-Packard desktop calculator was not the first occurrence. The term was used at least as far back as 1959, in an advertisement for the PACE TR-10 transistorized computer made by Electronic Associates Inc.

title: Online Help
description: To the Editor: Not included in Alice DuBois's article ''Web Can Shrink a Big World'' (Practical Traveler, Sept. 2), was the Michelin Guide Web site, www.viamichelin.com.

title: Taking a Trip by Bicycle
description: RODNEY GRAHAM says his most recent project -- ''a mishmash of things about the discovery of LSD and the early origins of cinema'' -- began as a stupid joke.

title: A Woman, a Man and Rent Rules
description: Q A man and a woman, a couple, have been living for many years in the same small apartment building. The man lives in his own apartment and the woman lives in hers, both on the same floor. Each has a separate lease, and both apartments are rent-stabilized. If these two people were to marry, and they wanted to continue the same living arrangements, with two separate leases on two apartments, and with each continuing to live in one of the apartments as a primary residence, can they do so without losing their rent-stabilized status and without getting evicted? . . . Selma Friedman, Manhattan.

title: Nina Knowles, Michael Mills
description: Nina Nebulae Knowles, a daughter of Susan and Michael Knowles of West Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael John Mills, the son of Barbara and John Mills of Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. David Kunselman, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony on Chapoquoit Island at West Falmouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVLER, MARTIN
description: KOVLER-Martin. Sutton Place Synagogue extends heartfelt condolences to our devoted Trustee and benefactors Sam and Judy Kovler on the passing of Sam's beloved father. Our sympathies to the bereaved family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: Lack of Training Rattles Trumbull Police
description: THE recent disclosure that 49 Trumbull police officers -- nearly 80 percent of the department -- were lacking in state training certification may have come as a shock to the town's 34,000 residents, town officials and even many of the department's 62 officers.

title: President Seems to Gain Legitimacy
description: With the eyes of a nervous nation fixed upon him, George W. Bush began coming of age as president this weekend.

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: A Long Day in the Life of a 'Law and Order' Juror
description: CONSIDERING the effort I've put in over the years trying to dodge jury duty, there's a certain irony in my longing to serve as a juror on ''Law and Order.'' To explain this fixation, I could say I admire the series for its complex handling of up-to-the-minute legal issues blah blah blah. It would even be true. But the larger truth is that it's always looked like fun to sit in a box while Sam Waterston or Jill Hennessey or Angie Harmon argues for the prosecution and someone like Tovah Feldshuh or Tony Roberts argues for the defense. What better way to be close to that action than to be smack-dab in the middle of the set?

title: At 8:48 a.m., Two 'Normal Guys' Met a Moment of Transformation
description: John Paul DeVito was just sitting down to some paperwork and a second cup of coffee after meeting with a client. Harry Ramos, just back from a week's leave after the death of his mother-in-law, was exchanging greetings with his assistant.

title: Sports of The Times; Can American Sports Ever Get Back to Normal?
description: The nation is in mourning and has shut down most of its games. After the first wave of mourning, people must gravitate back toward some semblance of normalcy, or else the terrorists have really won something. Baseball resumes its season tomorrow, with football returning next weekend, but what are the implications after a weekend nearly devoid of organized sports? How bad has it been without rushing into stadiums to root for the good guys against the bad guys? Could we learn to do without some of this organized aggression? Or all of it?

title: An Insignificant Spectator
description: HUNDREDS of people stood in front of my Greenwich Village apartment house on Tuesday morning, staring downtown as about a mile away the World Trade Center towers burned and disappeared. The view down the avenue was clear; it has always been a pleasant feature of the neighborhood. And the weather was glorious, if you recall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ANDREW
description: STERN-Andrew. Died tragically at the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Katie. Adored father of Danny and Emma. Cherished son of Barbara and the late Sheldon. Loving brother of Michael Stern and Lisa Burch. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 11:30 AM, Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLITZMAN, KAREN JOYCE
description: KLITZMAN-Karen Joyce, 38. Beloved twin sister of Donna, sister of Robert and Susan, daughter of Joan and the late Joseph and aunt of Joseph Elliott, died while working at e-Speed, a division of Cantor Fitzgerald, on the 105th floor of the World Trade Center, Tower One, Tuesday, September 11th, 2001, when the building was attacked. She was working in research on commodities futures. A graduate of Princeton University, Class of 1984 and Columbia University SIPA. She had previously been the Vice President of Research at New York Mercantile Exchange. Memorial Service will be held at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue at 30 West 68th Street in Manhattan at 7:30 P.M. on Sunday, September 16th.

title: Edna St. Vincent Millay
description: From the archives

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: A Show About Nothing. Oh, and Superheroes.
description: THERE'S something familiar about the quartet of self-absorbed thirtysomethings sitting around the restaurant table.

title: Raymond E. Johnson, Radio Host, Dies at 90
description: Raymond Edward Johnson, a versatile radio and stage actor who provided a signature moment for radio as the ghoulish host with the creaking door in the long-running ''Inner Sanctum,'' died on Aug. 15 in Wallingford, Conn. He was 90.

title: Text of Vice President Cheney's Remarks on 'Meet the Press'
description: Following is the full text of comments by Vice President Dick Cheney on today's broadcast of "Meet the Press," in response to questions from the program's host, Tim Russert, as distributed by NBC:

title: Sept. 9-15; The Week That Wasn't
description: For days the front pages have had one topic, and one topic only -- a gruesome focus that the world, almost as one, wishes would vanish like a bad dream. Suppose, for a moment, that it could be made to vanish -- that we could escape to a horror-free parallel universe. What would the news have been?

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: MIKE NICHOLS had directed only two films before he took on CATH-22 (1970), but those first two were ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woof?'' and ''The Graduate.'' So it wasn't a big surprise that his film version of Joseph Heller's darkly comic novel was a darkly comic success. Alan Arkin plays Yossarian, a bombardier who wants to quit flying because, he says, he's insane. But if he wants to give up flying, the Air Force theories, he can't be all that crazy. The cast includes Martin Sheen, Richard Benjamin. Jon Voight (young, young, young), Bob Newhart, Orson Welles and Buck Henry (who also wrote the script) - Thursday at 8 p.m. and Thursday/Early Friday at 2:35 a.m. on AMC.

title: Reports From the Notebook, and From the Heart
description: As the terrible week unfolded, reporters recorded what they could and editors made sure that most of that voluminous report appeared in the paper. But often, powerful observations, bits of telling dialogue or deep personal experiences were, for one reason or another, not in the newspaper. They remained in notebooks or indelibly in the mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, MICHAEL JUSTIN
description: McCABE-Michael Justin. 42, of Rumson, was killed Tuesday at the World Trade Center in New York City. Mr. McCabe had recently joined Cantor Fitzgerald in the equity trading department. Prior to that, he worked at Prudential Securities in New York City for 18 years, where he served most recently as Senior Vice President and Manager of Nasdaq Trading. Born at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, Mr. McCabe was a lifelong resident of Rumson. He graduated from Christian Brothers Academy in Lincroft and received a B.S. from Rutgers University. He was a member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick (NYC) and a member of the Monmouth Beach Bath and Tennis Club. Mr. McCabe was predeceased by a daughter, Shannon. He is survived by his wife, Lynn (nee Hemberger); his daughters, Cassidy and Regan; and his son, Liam, all at home. He is also survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. McCabe of Rumson; his sisters, Mary Ellen Kirschner and Suzanne McCabe both of New York City; his brothers, Eugene J. of Newport, R.I. and Nicholas of New York City; several sisters-inlaw and brothers-in-law; and several nieces and nephews. The family will receive visitors on Sunday from 1:00-5:00 PM at the Monmouth Beach Club. There will be a Memorial Mass on Monday, 12:00 noon at Holy Cross Church, Ward Ave., Rumson. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you make donations in Mr. McCabe's memory to the Daily News Charities, Inc., PO Box 3307, New York, NY 10001, for the children and families of the rescue workers who lost their lives while helping to save others.

title: Reports From the Notebook, and From the Heart
description: As the terrible week unfolded, reporters recorded what they could and editors made sure that most of that voluminous report appeared in the paper. But often, powerful observations, bits of telling dialogue or deep personal experiences were, for one reason or another, not in the newspaper. They remained in notebooks or indelibly in the mind.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WINIKOFF, ELLEN
description: WINIKOFF-Ellen. On your 53rd birthday and every day, we think of you and miss you terribly. All of our love. Marcia, Stanley, Linda, Amy, Ken and Sam

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, BARBARA
description: RUBENSTEIN - Barbara. The membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, Florida, announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend Barbara Rubenstein and extend our sincerest condolences to her husband and our esteemed member, Mark and their family. Robert P. Adler, President Boca Rio Golf Club, Inc.

title: Flying a Flag, if You Can Find One
description: The American flag has become a symbol of resolve to carry on after the terrorist attacks, but it is also in short supply in many parts of the country.

title: POSTINGS: From 2-Bedrooms to 6-Bedroom Maisonettes; Condo High-Rise for Park Slope
description: A 16-story condominium named for the Shinnecock Indians who once inhabited the area is rising on Union Street between Eighth Avenue and Grand Army Plaza in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Snapshots of Their Lives, Told With the Pain of Those Who Loved Them
description: The official number of deaths in the destruction of the World Trade Center stands at 159, and the medical examiner has identified only a few dozen victims. It could be months before many of those killed can be officially confirmed dead. Nearly 5,000 are missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, BELLA
description: SIMON-Bella. Born in Germany, May 26, 1903, and died peacefully on September 15, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Walter Simon. She is survived by her son & daughterin-law Dr. Manfred and Susanne Simon. Adored by grandsons Mark, Daniel and Erik and their spouses Melissa & Jody. Devoted great-grandmother to William and Oliver. Special friends of Elizabeth and Angela. She fled Nazi Germany in 1939 and immigrated to America which she adopted as her home. She witnessed her share of good and evil in the world; nevertheless, her optimism was constant and enduring to the end, and leaves a legacy to all of us who have known and loved her for so long. She will be greatly missed by all. Funeral information from ''The Riverside,'' For further information please call at 212362-6600.

title: An Extended Clan in Queens, Clinging to Hope at the Edge of Grief
description: Just blocks from each other in the Queens enclave of Douglaston, with its stately homes, tree-sheltered streets and waterfront views, the Lynch and Mackell families raised their children, nine in all, a handsome, athletic brood that seemed destined for charmed lives.

title: Elizabeth Schwarz and Gregory Boison
description: Elizabeth Anne Schwarz, the daughter of Maryellen and Carl Schwarz of Garden City, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Gregory LeRoy Boison, a son of Lynn and LeRoy Boison, also of Garden City. The Rev. Joseph M. Schlafer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Joseph.

title: A Ban on Memorabilia Auctions
description: EBay sells just about everything on its Internet auction site, but out of deference to the victims of the terrorist attacks, it has temporarily banned sales related to the World Trade Center or the Pentagon.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: YOU DON'T KNOW ME

title: Footlights; Crafts From a Curator's View
description: There are crafts shows, and then there are fine crafts shows. At least that's how Betsy Kubie, curator of the Westchester Craft Show, sees the distinction between her show, which is held at the Westchester County Center in White Plains, and other shows sprinkled around the metropolitan area.

title: A Body Blow to the Economy
description: THE attacks that destroyed the World Trade Center towers and damaged the Pentagon brought the American economy to an unprecedented halt and made a recession far more likely than before.

title: Disasters Leave but a Small Footprint on the Markets
description: HORRIBLE as Tuesday's terrorism was, it is not likely to have a lasting impact on the overall level of the stock market.

title: SHOPPING WITH -- Andy Dick; Buy Clothes and Behave, Too?
description: USUALLY the well known are lured into designer shops, not asked to leave. But it was under those unusual circumstances that the tousle-haired comedian Andy Dick found himself on the sidewalk outside the Paul Smith shop on lower Fifth Avenue in the glaring afternoon sun the Friday before last.

title: Perspective; Some Lessons in Grieving From a Long-Distance Runner
description: In a fog of grief and confusion after a sudden death, a middle-age man attempts a simple yet hard physical feat to test and center himself. He cannot do it alone; his sister and his brother, with whom he has lost touch, make his effort and his eventual healing possible.

title: No Cover Or Charge To Workers
description: At St. Charlie's restaurant on Albany Street, two blocks south of the World Trade Center, the tables were still set for a lunch that was never served. In the bar, some of the stools were still perched upside down on a table, but St. Charlie's had a new name scrawled in the dust of one of the few unbroken windows. ''Ground Zero Bar, Open 24 hours, no cover.''

title: As North and South Korea Open Discussions, the Issue of Terrorism Takes Center Stage
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 15  A ministerial delegation from North Korea arrived here today to begin a four-day series of meetings heavily dominated by the issue of terrorism. It is the first-high level dialogue between the two countries in six months.

title: Sept. 9-15; Trial of Christians Continues
description: Afghanistan's concerns over the possibility of an American military strike did not interrupt the trial of eight foreign aid workers -- two Americans, two Australians and four Germans -- on charges of allegedly preaching Christianity. But three of the defendants' parents, who had come to Kabul in support of their daughters, left the country. All but one trial session have been behind closed doors, with 22 justices sifting evidence that includes confiscated Bibles and audio tapes about the life of Jesus. The eight have hired a Muslim scholar to plead their case in the Taliban's Shariat Court. Barry Bearak

title: 'All Families Are Psychotic'
description: Janet opened her eyes -- Florida's prehistoric glare dazzled outside the motel window. A dog barked; a car honked; a man was singing a snatch of a Spanish song. She absentmindedly touched the scar from the bullet wound beneath her left rib cage, a scar that had healed over, bumpy and formless and hard, like a piece of gum stuck beneath a tabletop. She hadn't expected her flesh to have healed so blandly -- What was I expecting, a scar shaped like an American flag?

title: Spending the Night In a Flower Bed
description: IN the 1981 book ''Green Thoughts,'' Eleanor Pernyi describes a familiar scene: the devoted gardener arrives at her weekend retreat on a Friday night and goes straight out to inspect the garden by flashlight.

title: A Time to Wed or a Time to Postpone
description: TWO were a couple that had hoped to marry in historic Holy Trinity Church, which George Washington attended. And there was the millionaire investor in the twin towers, what was once the very symbol of New York's vitality, looking forward to his son's bar mitzvah. Another was a mother of two, planning a birthday party for her 8-year-old son.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PEARL

title: The Picture Tube And the Bigger View
description: WHEN I was in high school, in the late 1950's and early 60's, a friend and I set up a television repair business. We con tracted with surplus-inventory stores that would buy used black-and-white sets from hotels. They would buy, say, 100 broken sets and tell us, ''Any you can salvage, well give you $25.'' They would then probably resell them for $100.

title: Rhapsody In Blue And White
description: According to a vast unscientific poll, blue is the most popular color in the world. And when it is contrasted with white -- as in the English countryside on a crystal afternoon, unmarried clouds ripening in a cornflower sky -- then the world's favorite hue is even more dazzling.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Despite the Downturn, High-End Projects Proceed
description: WHEN Jane and John Hamburger heard of homes being built on a historic waterfront property on the South Shore, they sensed they were about to realize their dream house. For two years, they had searched for the right location to build a house that they had seen in a home-planning publication, Mrs. Hamburger said.

title: Articles Not Updated for Sept. 16 Late Print Edition
description: Because of a production error, early-edition versions of Pages 6, 8 and 22 appeared in copies of the Late Edition on Sunday in the New York region. Here are the updated versions of the affected articles.

title: Concern Lingers as Limited Air Travel Resumes
description: As the number of commercial flights around the country continued to increase yesterday, Logan Airport in Boston opened for the first time since the terrorist attacks on Tuesday. That left Reagan National Airport in Washington as the nation's only major airport still closed, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Poll Finds Strong Support for U.S. Use of Military Force
description: As they move from shock to fury, Americans are bracing for the United States to go to war, and they overwhelmingly say the nation should take military action against those responsible for the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: 'Still She Haunts Me'
description: The sky was yellow gray that first day. Drifting past them were ragged dark clouds with bright burning edges. Dodgson and an old friend, Reginald Southey, were carrying their cameras and equipment to the cathedral. Southey had long hair tucked behind his ears and the swarthy coloring of a sailor, even though he was studying to be a physician. Dodgson had recently photographed him with his arm draped around the shoulder of a skeleton, to capture his good-natured morbidity. The casual, friendly approach medical men took toward death.

title: Some Therapists Fear Services Could Backfire
description: For many mental health professionals the disaster was a summons. Therapists of all varieties and degrees of expertise set up impromptu grief counseling centers, offered their wisdom on television and radio and sped to the site of the devastation to provide crisis support for rescue and emergency workers.

title: 'New York Is Once Again A Part Of the Country'
description: FOR the first time since the farce of a Presidential election, New York is once again a part of the country. Some may not like us out there, but they have recognized that we are a limb of theirs, a member of their immediate family, and for our part we feel again proudly, fiercely American.

title: THEATER: A Symbolic Nation Aspires to the International; A Symbolic Nation Aspires to the International
description: WOULD the idea of holding a Quebec arts festival in New York have occurred to anyone 20 years ago? Probably not. We Quebecers were then still searching for an identity, unsure of our relationship to the Americas, embroiled in a literary and theatrical adventure in a French language that wavered among standardized forms, archaisms and original expressions invented to communicate our lives in our seasons. Our cinema aspired to documentary values.

title: Still Paying Heed To Graham's Cry
description: PEARL LANG has been described as both lyrical and powerfully intense for much of her six-decade career in modern dance, first as a lead performer in the Martha Graham Dance Company and later as a choreographer in her own right. Those poles are represented in the program of new dances and revivals Ms. Lang and her company will present at Kaye Playhouse in Manhattan from Sept. 28 to Sept. 30, ranging from the turbulent drama of Ms. Lang's new ''Hamlet -- Time Out of Joint'' to the lyrical first movement of her signature ''Shirah.'' And Ms. Lang herself, small and sweet-voiced yet formidable, personified that serenity and fierceness in a recent conversation before rehearsal at the 92nd Street Y.

title: London's Stage Migration
description: THERE promises to be a decidedly trans-Atlantic feel to the theatrical landscape in London's West End this fall. Were Robert de Niro, Dustin Hoffman and Clint Eastwood to take over the three roles in Yasmina Reza's seemingly immortal ''Art'' -- and almost stranger things have happened in the course of the play's five years and 20 different casts at Wyndham's Theater -- it would be no great surprise.

title: A Bottle of Red, A Bottle of White
description: I couldn't control the urge. The couple sitting to my right at Le Rendez-Vous restaurant in Kenilworth had a bottle of Chteau Ducru-Beaucaillou on their table. I couldn't see the vintage but Ducru, as it's called in the wine world, is one of my favorite wines as well as one of Bordeaux's great chateaus.

title: Choose Your Weapons
description: The Gorham, a 115-room hotel at 136 West 55th Street, gives new meaning to the old expression about knocking someone over with a feather. Its Pillow Fight Menu offers children (and adults, for that matter) a free choice of themed pillowcases, including Pokmon, 102 Dalmatians, Winnie the Pooh and Blues Clues. Information: (800) 735-0710 or www.gorhamhotel.com.

title: Anatomy of a Verdict
description: What troubled me is that 12 citizens could so grossly ignore the mandates of the law, dictated to them by the trial judge, to arrive at a not-guilty verdict and then have the nerve to blame the law for that travesty of justice. The jury was charged to determine whether the defendant was guilty beyond a reasonable doubt -- not beyond any doubt -- based on the facts in evidence.

title: Finally, a Doctor Is in the House
description: RESIDENTS of Beacon Falls, a rural town of about 5,300 on the banks of the Naugatuck River, say they are accustomed to always having to go somewhere else. A Big Mac attack or a Dunkin Donuts Coolatta craving means driving to next-door Naugatuck or Seymour. Shopping at Wal-Mart or renting a video from Blockbuster also requires mini-excursions to other communities.

description: For Disaster Relief

description: MOST Long Islanders like to arrive at restaurants for dinner between 6:30 and 8:30. With luck and reasonable service, they are on their way home around 10. But at that hour there is another group of restaurantgoers who are still wondering where to eat.

title: A Sense of Foreboding in Canada's Diverse Muslim Haven
description: The imam of Quebec Province's oldest mosque had a message of survival for his congregation on Friday: ''You have to handle this with wisdom.'' Outside, an informal security patrol watched the streets and sidewalks for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MARY
description: BERNSTEIN-Mary. On September 14. Loving wife of the late Sol, beloved mother of Barbara. Services will be held today at 10:45 AM, at I.J. Morris Inc., 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, CLARE
description: SHEA-Clare. On September 14, 2001, age 65. Loving daughter of the late Ambrose and Clare Shea. Dear sister of Joseph Shea, Nancy Shea and Marge Shea McCarthy. Proud aunt of seven. Doting grand-aunt of eight and attentive cousin of many. Former resident of Belle Harbor, Minneapolis and Annapolis, current resident of Hicksville. Reposing at Denis S. O'Conner Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr., Rockaway Beach. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Francis de Sales Church, Tuesday, at 9:45 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting Monday 2-5 PM and 7-10 PM.

title: Elizabeth Cox, Cameron Barrett
description: Elizabeth Hill Cox, the daughter of Barbara Cox Sachs of Summit, N.J., and the late Winston Hill Cox, was married on Nantucket yesterday to Cameron Michael Barrett, a son of Jaleh and Michael L. Barrett of Reston, Va. The Rev. Stanley E. Johnson, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Siasconset Union Chapel in Siasconset, Mass.

title: Roman Holiday, Child in Tow
description: THIS is an especially inviting time for a Roman holiday: the city is still in a sparkling, spruced-up state following the Jubilee Year 2000, and the dollar is strong against the lira, making a stay relatively affordable.

title: New Rochelle Studio Offers A Nook for Writers to Work
description: As a writer, Melanie Hulse knows the value of a quiet place to work. That's why she opened The Writing Mews, a studio in New Rochelle where writers can go for uninterrupted peace and quiet.

title: In for the Long Haul
description: Tomorrow, Americans will try to return to normal. This is a resilient country, and even in New York City, most citizens have already chosen to go back to their regular routines as quickly as possible. In general, we are not a people that spends much time looking back. ''Move on'' is practically the national mantra.

description: CHANCE IN THE HOUSE OF FATE

title: Anne Dewey, Carleton Goodnow
description: Anne Elizabeth Dewey, the daughter of Nancy R. Dinkel of Tampa, Fla., and Edward A. Dewey of Jasper, Ga., was married yesterday to Carleton Throckmorton Goodnow, the son of Diane T. Goodnow and Edward B. Goodnow of Darien, Conn. The wedding, which was to take place at Trinity Church, near the site of the attack on the World Trade Center in New York, was moved to the home of the bridegroom's parents. Ann S. Mandel, a civil marriage celebrant, officiated with the Rev. Dr. Stephen Ankudowich, an Episcopal priest.

title: Reader's Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com . My neighbor, a retired New York City fire officer, a black man who rose to a high rank in the NYFD, left a message for us to look after his house because he was "going in to help out." It's been 14 years since his retirement, and he got his gear together and went off to help.

title: 'Orderly Lines Of Jittery New Yorkers'
description: TREKKING up the West Side of Manhattan on Tuesday, in the exodus from the World Trade Center towers engulfed in smoke and flames, I tried to moor my disbelief and horror to something that if not reassuring was at least recognizable: the city's history.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE MEANS OF ESCAPE, by Penelope Fitzgerald. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $11.) This posthumous collection of short stories, which includes two new ones for the paperback edition, displays the author's talent for undermining her protagonists' narratives through the counterstories of marginal figures, who tend to overtake the tales they infiltrate. Last year in these pages, Richard Eder praised the author's ''power to subvert her stories, dismantling and enlarging them at the same time.'' Before turning to fiction, Fitzgerald wrote The Knox Brothers (Counterpoint, $16), an affectionate biographical memoir of her father (a former editor of Punch) and three uncles (among them a cryptographer and a priest), the accomplished offspring of an Anglican bishop. In 1977 one reviewer called this a ''remarkable performance.''

description: A compelling article! The house could have fallen down around me, and I would not have noticed until I finished reading it.

description: To the editor:

description: So you've had it with running-in-the-surf fragrance ads. You're finished with ozone-spiked, surgically scrubbed, gender-free scents so devoid of sexuality that if you spray one on before hopping into bed, your boyfriend has to turn on the light to see if there's a girl beside him or a load of fresh laundry.

title: Before & After; Order of Magnitude: The Toll and the Technology
description: ANTHROPOLOGISTS tell of primitive tribes with just six numbers in their counting system. One, two, three, four, five and many. One word must serve for anything so big it cannot be counted on a single hand.

description: Ahmed Shah Massoud, a legendary guerrilla commander in a cocked beret and the leader of the last remaining resistance to the Taliban who rule most of this country, died today of wounds received in an assassination attempt, Burhanuddin Rabbani, the opposition's nominal leader, announced.

title: Fashion in Bad Times: Best Foot Forward
description: IN London after the crash of 1929, and several years before her magazine career commenced, Diana Vreeland opened a lingerie shop. In Paris during the Nazi occupation, the ''swing kids'' dressed in outlandish American-style clothing and rebelliously listened to American music. In 1963, Jacqueline Kennedy's comportment, good manners and thoughtful choice of clothing at the time of President John F. Kennedy's assassination taught bravery to a generation overwhelmed by grief.

title: Packages Put Europe on Sale
description: FIVE nights in Paris, including air fare, for $439? A round trip to Ireland, plus a week's rental car and lodging, for $449? These are the kinds of prices travelers will see on packages to Europe this winter.

title: The Little Miracles Performed by Cover Crops
description: NOT many home gardeners know about cover crops. They are plants traditionally grown to prevent soil erosion, conserve nutrients and improve tilth, but they also present exciting alternatives to weeding, hauling mulch, even fertilizing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMOSE, CELIA
description: SAMOSE-Celia. In loving memory of your birthday, September 19. Grandchildren

title: Ashlee Cowgill, John Morningstar
description: Ashlee Armstrong Cowgill, a daughter of Ann Wakefield Armstrong of New Canaan, Conn., and Norman Bruce Cowgill of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to John Edward Morningstar, the son of Ruth Ann and John C. Morningstar of Westminster, Md. The Rev. Elizabeth Krentz-Wee performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan.

title: Susan Howard, Joshua Berkowitz
description: Susan Paula Howard and Dr. Marc Joshua Berkowitz were married last evening by Rabbi David Gelfand at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: 'Close-Up Death Ought to Change a City'
description: MY husband phoned to say that an airplane had flown into the World Trade Center. He called a while later about a second plane. ''All right, I'll go look,'' I said.

title: Weekend of Heartache: Let Us Honor the Dead; We Are All Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Andy Warhol'
description: ON AUGUST 6, 1945, the United States dropped the A-bomb on Hiroshima. That day, Andrew Warhola celebrated his seventeenth birthday. Asexual albino Andy, author of a: a novel , was born Andrew Warhola, but eventually he dropped the ultimate a in his last name. The extra a was clunky, ethnic. Dropped objects incite curiosity and dread; repressed from sight, they reappear. He may have dropped the a because it allowed his name to symbolize more belligerently: Andy War Hole. In any case, he retained a fondness for the letter a ; its dialectical opposite, as far as he was concerned, was the letter b .

title: Weekend of Heartache: Let Us Honor the Dead; Gathering Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching Across Globe, and in New Jersey Hotels and Malls
description: Hundreds of law enforcement agents in New York City and northern New Jersey are tracing the movements made by several terrorists before Tuesday's attacks and digging into possible support from others in the area, officials said yesterday.

title: Philadelphia Airport Adds a Terminal
description: US Airways has opened a $100 million terminal at Philadelphia International Airport for passengers on its regional jets and turboprops, part of a major expansion of its facilities there. The new terminal means that most passengers will no longer board and deplane on the Tarmac, where buses carried people to and from the existing terminals.

title: Moonlighting Becomes You: It's the Love, Not the Money
description: THEY work all day. Then they work at night. Instead of enjoying spare time or just hunkering down in front of the television set, they pursue a second career. What's in it for these moonlighters? Not just the extra money. Pursuing a dual career is about passion and fulfilling dreams. The tradeoff: time.

title: Sept. 9-15; 2nd Heart Replacement
description: Tom Christerson, 70, become the second recipient of a self-contained artificial heart at Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky., where the first, Robert Tools, is mending slowly. Dr. Laman A. Gray Jr. said the new patient looked ''absolutely wonderful.''

title: Word for Word/Last Words; Voices From Above: 'I Love You, Mommy, Goodbye'
description: MOST victims of sudden calamity -- a car accident, say, or an earthquake -- never get a chance to say goodbye. Yet in a surreal twist to last week's hijackings and terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, many airline passengers and office workers spent their final moments sending electronic beacons to those they would soon leave behind. Delivered by cellphone, by e-mail and even by voicemail, these dispatches -- frantic, defiant, tearful, bracing -- became indelible last words for friends and loved ones.

title: Your Home; Weighing No-Cost Refinancings
description: FOR most people who have a mortgage on their home, the decision to refinance is typically based on a rather straightforward calculation: are the savings that will be realized by refinancing to a lower interest rate enough to justify the expenses of refinancing?

title: 'An Old Wife's Tale'
description: My mother and father had three daughters. This was a circumstance, we children often heard it said, that my father did not mind in the least; on the contrary, my mother and he would smilingly insist, three daughters would one day bring him the happiness of having three sons-in-law. This was said so often, indeed, as to become suspect even to me, the youngest and hence by rights the most credulous member of the family. Will it surprise anyone to be told that when the time came, my father was in the end barely able to maintain civil relations with any of his sons-in-law?

title: Before & After; In a Changing Skyline, A Sudden, Glaring Void
description: THE World Trade Center towers never inspired the loyalty and affection of New York's great skyscrapers of the past. A spectacular site but a lackluster performance, at best a colossal piece of minimalist sculpture -- so ran the consensus. If anyone derived aesthetic pleasure from them, it was offset by the pity they aroused for having been built during the early 1970's, that low-water mark of architectural modernism.

title: Reports From the Notebook, and From the Heart
description: As the terrible week unfolded, reporters recorded what they could and editors made sure that most of that voluminous report appeared in the paper. But often, powerful observations, bits of telling dialogue or deep personal experiences were, for one reason or another, not in the newspaper. They remained in notebooks or indelibly in the mind.

title: Corrections
description: Amap and chart on Friday cataloging damage to buildings in Lower Manhattan misstated the condition of 14 Wall Street. It is not on city inspectors' list of buildings with confirmed structural damage, and the owner expects to reopen it on Monday.

title: 'Under a Desk On Prospect Park West'
description: WHEN I was in seventh grade, two planes collided a block from my elementary school. Students at the Brooklyn Ethical Culture School in 1960 usually spent our time learning to play Haydn's ''Toy'' Symphony on the triangle. But that day in Park Slope the older children were told to help evacuate the younger ones.

title: 'These Fantasies Have Been Horribly Realized'
description: THE hijacked planes that zeroed in on New York and Washington with such murderous accuracy obviously chose their targets for a reason. They didn't attack Los Angeles and Miami, after all. Why not? It's reasonable to assume that they chose cities and buildings that they believed had great symbolic and actual potency: the respective headquarters of the military and financial institutions whose decisions have tremendous impact throughout the globe.

title: The Farmer-Businessman Behind the Plan
description: GETTING the state to consider his proposal for a Tappan Tunnel is a result of a yearlong campaign by Alexander Saunders, an environmentalist from Garrison perhaps best known locally for the annual barn dance he gives for friends and neighbors.

Collins and Atwood Collins III of Darien, Conn. The Rev. John M. Dennis, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Church in Baltimore.

title: Gansevoort Street
description: Gansevoort Street, a dark and melancholy beauty, runs its modest course from east to west in downtown Manhattan's desolate riverfront neighborhood and empties into the opaque waters of the Hudson. It was, for most of its life, merely remote and sinister; it is now remote, sinister and fashionable. In that regard, it could probably exist nowhere else.

title: A Park Just Made for a Poet
description: JULIA DE BURGOS was a Puerto Rican poet who exalted the rivers and the seas, so it may seem odd that 48 years after her death a small park in a landlocked mill town in Connecticut will be named after her.

title: Buildings? Replaceable. But These Lives Aren't.
description: ON Tuesday evening, I sat in the Church of the Incarnation in Midtown Manhattan, trying to make sense of the stupefying. When I picked up the nearest Bible, it fell open to the Book of Lamentations, Jeremiah's elegiac depiction of Jerusalem razed by Babylonian invaders.

title: Before & After; Talking of the Towers
description: EVEN before their official opening in 1973, the World Trade Towers dominated the New York City skyline. They were so big that, seen from afar, the whole of Manhattan seemed to tilt slightly, sliding toward the two silver giants at the bottom of the island.

title: New Jersey Calls It a Night.; Her Days Start At 3:30 A.M.
description: MARY ANN BARKUS begins her day at an hour few people ever see. She gets up about 3:30 a.m., throws on her running clothes and jogs into the night with her bull mastiff, Dexter. At 5 a.m., she is lying on the wood deck of her second floor apartment in Bordentown, stretching and staring up at the stars. By daybreak, she is saying her prayers, speaking softly to a place inside herself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ALVIN
description: SCHWARTZ-Alvin. 89 years old. Died peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family on September 12, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Spear Schwartz. Loving father of Jane and Edward Stein, Amy and Charles Spielman, and Thomas and Lonnie Schwartz. Adored by his grandchildren Philip and Frances Stein, Laura, Eric and Jenny Spielman, and Ilyse and Adam Schwartz. Also survived by his sister Carol Rozen and brothers Lester and Henry Schwartz. In lieu of flowers, contributions to his favorite charities, ''Temple Beth El of Great Neck'', North Shore LIJ Health System, or The Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation or the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: The Family Mobile
description: I am the youngest of eight children, a large family by most standards. Your article highlights the impressive accomplishments of the Kayes children: computer-science major, engineering graduate, adoption-agency employee, college student. I, too, could list the impressive credentials of me and my siblings. We are all college graduates, some with master's degrees and Ph.D.'s. But scratch the surface, and you will find the pitfalls of growing up in a large family. (We have the psychotherapy bills to prove my point.)

title: Anatomy of a Verdict

In my case, after days of acrimonious and manipulative debate, we were unable to reach a unanimous verdict. Dysfunctional-family dynamics were played out -the process feeds contention. (We even argued for a considerable time about ''reasonable doubt,'' which had been poorly defined.)

Twelve people, each with different life experiences, wrestle with the evidence, with the credibility of witnesses, with one another, applying their collective common sense, conscious of the weight of their responsibility.

On one hand, the trauma of the terrorist attack on the twin towers and the Pentagon could leave players less than inspired when they resume playing this week. On the other hand, they could be eager to get back to what they do best and forget the rest, at least for three hours a night.

title: Sept. 9-15; Approval on U.N. Post
description: Thanks to the climate of solidarity in Washington, President Bush's nominee for ambassador to the United Nations, John Negroponte, sailed through a confirmation hearing with a vote of 14-3, and seems certain of quick confirmation by the full Senate. But some senators suggested that Mr. Negroponte sought to minimize human rights abuses in Honduras, where he was ambassador in the 80's. During that time, scores of people were abducted, tortured and killed by military and police units. ''I did not believe then, nor do I believe now, that these abuses were part of a deliberate government policy,'' he said at the hearing. ''To this day I do not believe that death squads were operating in Honduras.'' Stephen Kinzer

title: The Simple Life in Paris
description: GEORGE ORWELL'S classic ''Down and Out in Paris and London,'' with its seamy world of plongeurs, cheap hotels and rotgut wine, set a very low threshold for budget stays in Paris. I was looking for a less drastic solution, one that would provide reasonable comfort yet meet my own restricted budget imperatives.

title: CELEBRATION; Istanbul
description: No one knows just how many people live in Istanbul, since migrants arrive daily, but everyone agrees that the figure must be at least 12 million. It dwarfs most Western European cities, and is probably older than any of them. At its back lie the lowlands of Thrace, on which Istanbul closes its gates. Instead it looks east to the hills and mountains of Asia, whose snows gleam invitingly on winter days.

title: Supporting Cast
description: At 8:50 Wednesday morning on a deserted Fifth Avenue, a ray of hope and patriotism flashed as a bicyclist came into view carrying a large American flag, a beacon of hope after Tuesday's unspeakable attack. Later that afternoon, thousands with homemade signs gathered spontaneously along West Street beside the Hudson River to cheer rescue workers traveling to and from the disaster zone. By Thursday, flags were appearing on construction sites and apartment buildings. West Street at Houston Street had been turned into a canteen. Bottled water and peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwiches made on the spot were served from the temporary street dividers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURELL, EVELYN GILSON
description: TURELL-Evelyn Gilson. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine deeply mourn the passing of Evelyn Gilson Turell, a generous benefactress, and the wife of the late Dr. Robert Turell, a prominent surgeon, who served Mount Sinai and his patients with dedication and distinction for fifty-eight years. Evelyn Turell's outstanding support of Mount Sinai included the establishment of the Robert and Evelyn Turell Professorship in Endoscopic Surgery and other contributions to medical research. Mrs. Turell will be remembered fondly, and with gratitude, for her loyalty and thoughtful generosity. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Nathan Kase, Interim Pres. & CEO The Mount Sinai Medical Center and Interim Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Barry R. title: 'Playing the Race Card'
description: In 1853, the year after she had become a celebrity with the publication of her novel Uncle Tom's Cabin , Harriet Beecher Stowe embarked upon a tour of Europe. In a book of letters describing her travels, she narrates a visit to Windsor Castle. Passing unmoved before a succession of paintings by such masters as Van Dyke and Caneletto, she suddenly finds herself transfixed before a marble monument by an unnamed sculptor. It is a scene depicting the death of the Princess Charlotte, daughter of King George IV. Stowe describes the sculpture in great detail. On the terrestrial side, the princess has just "thrown herself over in a convulsion, and died" (Stowe 1854, 2:45). Around her are four figures bowed in mute despair. On the celestial side, however, the princess's spirit is seen to rise toward heaven. "Two angels, one carrying her infant child and the other with clasped hands of exultant joy, are rising with her, in serene and solemn triumph" (45).

title: CELEBRATION: ISTANBUL; The Mood
description: Istanbul is a city absorbed in constant contemplation of an enigma, so much so that sometimes it doesn't know itself. Is it Oriental or Occidental, secular or Muslim, ugly or beautiful, rich or poor? Here the arrogant certainty of New York or London is lacking. Its inhabitants regard their city with an appealing ambiguity and perplexity, yet it surely has as much to offer as any other on earth. The skyline of the old city still takes the breath away (and one notes with gratitude that no modern structures have been allowed to challenge the supremacy of Hagia Sophia and the Mosque of Suleiman). The Bosporus is still an azure ribbon or rope twisting between wooded hills, villas and palaces.

title: A Scrap of Beethoven Better Left Unheard?
description: ONE dismaying sign that the classical-music field remains stuck in place is the hoopla stirred up every time some musicology sleuth claims to have recovered some work by a past master. Apparently, any scrap of music, however sketchy, by a great dead composer is bigger news than a new work by a worthy living composer.

On eight of them the words appear along a single line, on two the words are perpendicular to the ruling, and on two they are scrawled diagonally (one of these last has been written on an inverted card, turned so that the red top line and margin are at the bottom). Three are in all caps, three have only the initial letters capitalized, three are all lowercase, two others show the "N" capitalized but not the "g." In the last of them the word "not" appears in all caps, but the word "guilty" is all lowercase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCERLEAN, JOHN THOMAS JR.
description: McERLEAN-John Thomas Jr. Of Larchmont, NY, died at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. He was 39 years old. Born July 27, 1962, in New York City to Agnes and John McErlean Sr. He was raised in Larchmont and attended Iona Prep and St. Michael's College in Vermont. He received a BA in Business in 1984. He was a parishioner of St. Augustine's Church and a member of the Larchmont Yacht Club. He was an avid sports fan and served as coach for a variety of children's teams in his community.
