title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, DANIEL M.
description: LEWIN-Daniel M. The co-founder of Akamai Technologies, murdered on September 11th aboard American Airlines flight 11 which crashed in New York City. A resident of the Boston area, 31 years of age, Danny was born to be a leader and an inspiration to all he met. In a tragically short life, he excelled in each and every one of his endeavors, whether it be as a distinguished soldier, student, scientist, business figure and family man. With a multitude of interests, and a larger than life presence, Danny's passion, brilliant mind and warm smile were only some of his endearing qualities. Dedicated to his family, Danny possessed a unique ability to balance both the daily demands of academia and the workplace, with a constant flow of affection for his wife and children. While his accomplishments began to grow, along with his circle of friends, his modesty remained intact. He founded Akamai Technologies, in 1998, with his professor F. Tom Leighton and fellow graduate student, Jonathan Seelig. In a short time, and under Danny's harddriving leadership and vision, Akamai grew to be one of the top technology companies in the world. As chief technology officer, he was responsible for Akamai's research and development strategy, creating innovative Internet infrastructure services that would produce an entirely new industry segment, & forever change the way people and companies distribute content, data, and applications. Akamai's 1,100 employees and global customer base will miss him dearly. Born in Denver, Colorado, Danny immigrated to Israel with his family in 1984. Upon completing public high school, ORT, in Jerusalem, Danny served for four years in the Israel Defense Forces. He rose to the rank of captain in what is considered the Army's most elite unit. Following his active military service, Danny was married in Jerusalem and began his studies at the Technion, Israel's premier technology university. Soon after, Danny worked at IBM's research laboratory in Haifa, where he was a full-time research fellow and project leader while simultaneously completing two undergraduate degrees, computer science and mathematics summa cum laude, and celebrating the birth of his first son. In 1995, the Technion named him the year's Outstanding Student in Computer Engineering. At IBM, he was responsible for the development and support of the company's Genesys system, a processor verification tool that is used widely within IBM and in other companies such as AMD & SGS Thompson. In 1996, Danny and his wife, Anne, welcomed their second son and moved to Cambridge, Mass. where he received a scholarship to study at MIT under the tutelage of MIT Professor, and soon to become close friend, Tom Leighton. He published and presented several breakthrough papers at top computer science conferences and received several awards, including the 1998 Morris Joseph Lewin Award for Best Masterworks Thesis Presentation at MIT. His Master's thesis included some of the fundamental algorithms that make up the core of Akamai's services. He received a Master's degree from MIT in 1997 and was a Ph.D. candidate in the Algorithms groups at MIT's Laboratory for Computer Science upon his death. His embrace of risk, and affinity for speed and freedom, was also demonstrated by his personal pursuits: motorcycles, sports cars, and skiing. His love of country and appreciation for culture was shown in his early training in classical music and his knowledge of Israel's politics and history. In addition to his many friends and colleagues, he is survived by a close-knit family. Danny was a devoted husband to Anne, his companion throughout adulthood, a fellow immigrant to Israel, and a student and teacher of art and literature; a loving father to sons Eitan and Itamar; loyal son of Drs. Charles and Peggy Levine, and brother to Jonathan and Michael, of Jerusalem. Contributions in Danny's memory can be made to the Daniel Lewin Science Scholarship Fund, dedicated to providing scholarships to students pursuing careers in science. Contributions should be directed to Hale and Dorr Capital Management LLC, 60 State Street, Boston, MA. 02019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, DAVID SHELBY
description: BERRY-David Shelby. The family of David Shelby Berry is stunned by his sudden death Tuesday morning, September 11. He perished from the terrorist attack on Two World Trade Center. David, 43, was executive vice-president and Director of Research at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, Inc., specialists in banking and financial services, located on the 89th floor of the South Tower. He is survived by his cherished wife Paula Grant, and three adored sons: Nile Philip Berry, 9; Reed Nicholas Berry, 7; and Alexander Ashton Berry, 5. The family lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn. David was born on May 31, 1958 in Oklahoma City, and attended the Casady School there. He graduated cum laude from Yale University in 1980 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Philosophy and Physics, and received a Diploma of Distinction from the London School of Economics in 1984. A Charter Financial Analyst, he joined Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in 1986, and became a member of their Board of Directors and operating committee. He was a frequent guest on television financial news programs, and regularly quoted in financial publications. In addition to his immediate family, David is survived by his mother Nancy Michaels Berry, New York City; his father Charles N. Berry, Jr., Oklahoma City, Oklahoma; two brothers, C. Nelson Berry III, Seattle, Washington and Michaels C. Berry, Bainbridge, Washington; three nephews, Norris Hawk Berry, Charles N. Berry IV, and William Stinson Berry, and a niece Anna Lauren Berry, all of Seattle. Memorial services will be held in New York City and Oklahoma City. In lieu of flowers the family requests that contributions be made to St. Ann's School, Pierpont Street, Brooklyn Heights, New York or the Oklahoma City Community Foundation, PO Box 1146, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma 73103. He graced our lives with his presence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, GLENN CREW
description: FOWLER-Glenn Crew, 77. A reporter and editor for the New York Times for 37 years until his retirement in 1991, died on September 10, 2001, at NYU Medical Center. He had covered news on many fronts from city and state politics to retailing, and had also been editor of the real estate section. The cause of death was a sudden recurrence of prostate cancer, quiescent since its inception nine years ago. Throughout his last six years Glenn waged a valiant, all-out battle to transcend the effects of his 1995 stroke, and made dynanmic comeback after comeback until the end, never losing his indelible spirit, sparkle or infectious grin. Born in Manhattan, November 26, 1923, he was a graduate of Columbia University, did graduate work in political history at NYU, was a sports reporter for United Press and a news reporter for Women's Wear Daily before joining the Times. For many years Glenn was a colorful cast member of the riotous annual political lampoons staged by two noted New York journalist groups -the Inner Circle and the New York Financial Writers Association -and also was a longtime member of three others, the Silurians, the Downhold Club of UP Writers and the National Real Estate Editors Association. During W.W. II he served as a lieutenant in the Navy, often in the thick of action in Europe. One hair-raising instance he survived took place on Normandy Beach where the landing craft of soldiers he commanded was shot out from under him by enemy fire as he landed it, after which he was rescued by another landing craft and took over for its skipper who had just been killed. Until his stroke Glenn was an avid skier and runner who completed 12 NYC Marathons and several in Boston and China. A distance runner who was never lonely, he made friends everywhere, continuing to do so throughout the years of his stroke. Overcoming the terrible loss of speech he had sustained from the stroke with his signature grin and a personal sign language he continually created with a dedication he brought to everything, he kept up a continuous regimen of therapies that helped him often to free himself from wheelchair and cane, and travel, swim and dance almost as before. Glenn is survived by his beloved and devoted wife Jessica and daughter Kathryn. He will be mourned by a legion of close friends. Services will be held on Sunday, September 30, at 3 PM, at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street. A reception is planned for the near future at the Fowler residence.

description: The land of a thousand hills, as Rwanda is known, has become the land of a thousand memorials, a thousand trials, a thousand bad memories that linger.

title: Uncertainly, Market Reopens Today
description: In a triumph of determination and intense effort, America's stock markets plan to reopen this morning for trading, less than a week after the worst terrorist attack in history devastated Lower Manhattan.

title: At Houses of Worship, Feelings Are Shared and Comfort Is Sought in Greater Numbers
description: Almost from the instant they learned that terrorists had attacked Manhattan and Washington on Tuesday, Americans have turned out in unusually high numbers to houses of worship. Some slip in quietly during off-hours for private prayer; many more show up for scheduled services.

title: Edgy Afghans Pouring Toward Pakistan Border
description: An abundance of Afghans gathered outside Pakistan's consulate here today. They were apparently feeling closer to eternity than they liked and thought it a good idea to get permission to leave the country.

title: Cardinal Egan Leads Prayers for Victims, and Applause for Rescuers
description: In a Mass that mixed poignancy and newly stirred patriotism, Cardinal Edward M. Egan yesterday deplored the ''faceless criminals'' who attacked the World Trade Center. He also read a message from Pope John Paul II that urged New Yorkers ''not to be conquered by evil, but to conquer evil with good.''

title: Investigators Discover That 3 Attackers on Planes Attended Same German University
description: To the deep embarrassment of German security officials, a small technical university on the southern edge of this wealthy port city unknowingly harbored a cell of Islamic fundamentalists, a group that included at least three of the hijackers who carried out and perished in the terrorist attacks on Tuesday.

title: Airport to Stay Shut for Now; Some Urge Permanent Move
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport would have to be closed indefinitely because of its proximity to the seats of government, and some lawmakers and aviation authorities said it should be shut down permanently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIK, WILLIAM J.
description: WIK-William J., 44. Victim of the World Trade Center terrorist attack, of Crestwood, NY on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Kathleen Norton Wik. Devoted father of Tricia, Katie and Danny. Son of Carol and the late Raphael J. Wik, Jr. Brother of Ray, Tommy and Kathy Simon. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Monday. Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church Crestwood on Tuesday, September 18 at 10 AM.

title: Americans, Seeking Escape, Look to Hollywood for Relief
description: Depressed by last week's bombings, Americans sought escape and answers at movie theaters and video stores across the country over the weekend.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about companies that might choose to move out of Lower Manhattan misstated the day the New York Stock Exchange was expected to reopen. It was today, not Friday.

title: Essay; Of Human Missiles
description: One Sunday morning a generation ago, the C.I.A. chief William Casey dropped in at my house for a cup of coffee and gruffed, ''You got a map of Afghanistan?''

title: Business Will Resume on Drastically Redrawn Map
description: The tens of thousands of New Yorkers who will return to work in the financial district today will pick their way through a radically redrawn map of Lower Manhattan. And a tour of these recently re-opened streets yesterday provided a preview of the jarring scenes that will greet workers flooding back into a part of the city that has literally been carved out of the mayhem surrounding it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, FARRELL PETER
description: LYNCH-Farrell Peter. Age 39, of Centerport, on September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Eileen. Devoted father of Katie, Meghan and Annie. Son of Rosetta and Farrell Patrick Lynch of Merrick. Brother of Ellen, Kieran, Brian and the late Sean. Visitation Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM, at Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave. (Route 110), Huntington. Mass Thursday, at 10 AM, St. Patrick's Church, Huntington. In lieu of flowers the family asks support of United Leukodystrophy Foundation; send to: Krabbe Research, 2304 Highland Dr, Sycamore, IL 60178, for Stephanie and James Slater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, PAUL
description: WIENER-Paul. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our Board member and community leader, Jonathan Wiener, upon the loss of his father. May he and his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: City Opera, Trying to Recapture Its Concentration
description: Responding to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's request for a return to normalcy, the New York City Opera opened a delayed season Saturday with two premiere productions, occasions filled with complex and conflicting feelings among audience and cast members. In an eloquent prelude to the afternoon performance of ''Der Fliegende Hollnder'' (and again in the evening), Paul Kellogg, the general and artistic director, took a moment to address the emotions and turn them into a sort of reaffirmation.

title: A Father's Absence Hits 2 Households Hard
description: The photograph shows a 32-year-old man with short black hair, standing under a tree in a neighborhood park, his arm around his 9-year-old daughter. On her face is an ear-to-ear smile.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, GLADYS
description: NEWMAN-Gladys. September 17, 1977. 24 years have passed since you left us. You are in our hearts always. Love Leslie, Alan, Jonathan, Justin, Keri, Arnold, Giulia, Rebecc

title: Dinner, but No Check
description: Over the weekend, many restaurants in cordoned-off TriBeCa did what they always do: they fed people. It didn't seem to matter that nobody was paying for the food.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about companies that might choose to move out of Lower Manhattan misstated the day the New York Stock Exchange was expected to reopen. It was today, not Friday.

title: One-Club Bid Splits Players: Traditional And Modern
description: There are two schools of thought about responding to an opening bid of one club. The traditionalists bid ''up the line,'' while the modernists use a style that goes back half a century and bid a four-card major ahead of a diamond suit of any length unless the hand is worth two bids.

title: Those at Towers' Margin Elude List of Missing
description: Most of the people listed as missing in the twin towers disaster were part of the World Trade Center's life as an elite corporate community. Determining who was missing among them after the terrorist attack, however painful, would not be that hard. And the most prominent would be mourned with much eloquence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARRON, EDWARD W.
description: MARRON-Edward W. Age 81, of Ho-Ho-Kus NJ, died September 14, 2001. Beloved husband of Evelyn M. (nee Del Balso). Loving father of Edward W. Marron Jr. of HoHo-Kus, Peter C. Marron of HoHo-Kus, Barbara Manginello of Saddle River, NJ, Joan C. Marron of New York, NY, and Catherine Peru of Fairfield, CT. Adoring grandfather of eleven, and devoted brother of Edythe Coolahan of Boynton Beach, FL., and Doris Glingler of Rome, Italy. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Tuesday 10 AM, at St. Gabriel R.C. Church, Saddle River, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Valley Hospital, Van Dien and Linwood Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ 07450 in Memory of Edward W. Marron would be appreciated. For further information, call Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, New Jersey, 201-444-7650.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARGRAVE, TIMOTHY J. (T.J.)
description: HARGRAVE-Timothy J. (T.J.). 38. Of Readington Township, Associate at Cantor Fitzgerald, was lost in the World Trade Center tragedy. Mr. Hargrave was born in New York City and raised in West Milford, NJ. He was a resident of Readington for four years and coached his children's soccer teams. T.J. was employed by Cantor Fitzgerald in New York City for the past seven years. Mr. Hardgrave is survived by his wife, Patricia Mitchell Hargrave, daughters, Corinne, 8, Casey, 6, and Amy, 4. He is also survived by his mother, Kathryn Hargrave; brother, James V. Hargrave Jr.; and sisters, Maureen Murphy, Patricia Mansfield, Kathy Quinn, MaryAnn Struble, Jeanmarie Hargrave and Carolyn Kelly. He was predeceased by his father, James V. Hargrave Sr. A memorial service will be held 12 PM, Wednesday at Readington Reformed Church in Reddington NJ. Mr. Hargrave's family and friends have established a trust fund for his children, donations can be made to National Financial, FBO CC&A Hargrave, P.O. Box 218, Stanton, NJ 08885. T.J. Hargrave was a child actor and starred in the TV movie, ''The Prince of Central Park'' and was a semi-regular player on the ''Guiding Light'' soap opera.

title: Editorial Observer; New York Notes: 8 Million Survivors, in Need of Affection
description: Manhattan is awash in donated clothes, donated food, donated blood, donated manpower. ''Here's a way you can help us,'' said Rudolph Giuliani to the nation yesterday, trying to divert further shipments. ''Come to New York, go to a play. . . . Spend some money.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, LARRY
description: LEWIS-Larry. Owner of ''Lewis of Woodhaven Dept. Store''. Beloved husband of Frances, adored father of Jeffrey and Barry, cherished grandfather of Kim Lewis Forrester and the late Randy Berzolla, devoted great-grandfather of three. Services today 10:30 at ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', 9860 Queens Blvd., corner of 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Media Trying, With Dignity, to Stem Huge Losses in Advertising
description: Images of death, destruction and mourning make an unseemly backdrop for pitching new cars, beer brands or fancy vacations, and that awkwardness is creating a costly predicament for the media industry in the aftermath of last week's terrorist attacks.

title: In This Section
description: RESPONDING TO TERRORISM

title: World Bank and I.M.F. Cancel Annual Meeting in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The World Bank and International Monetary Fund announced today that they had canceled their annual meeting, which had been scheduled for Sept. 29 and 30 in Washington.

title: Oklahoma
description: It is not unusual for foreign students like Mr. Moussauoi to call the Airman Flight School in hopes of becoming pilots. Among such students who considered the school in July 2000 were Mohammed Atta and Marwan al-Shehhi, two of the hijacking suspects on the jetliners that crashed into the World Trade Center.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Government Strikes Confident Economic Chord

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAVALKOFF, DINAH
description: ZAVALKOFF-Dinah. In Montreal on September 13, 2001, at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Abe. Devoted mother and mother-inlaw of Norman and the late Mona, Ruth and the late Henry Lindenbaum. Grandmother to Avi, Michael and Philip Lindenbaum and Brian and Anne Zavalkoff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, EDITH
description: GREENBERG-Edith. On September 15, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Loving sister of Dorothy and Sam. Dearest aunt and great-aunt. We will miss you greatly.

title: Letters: The Moods of America: Grief, Rage, Resolve
description: To the Editor:

title: Twin Towers' Images Become Big Sellers
description: New Yorkers are not famously fond of tourists, but since the wrenching change in the city's skyline, they've been behaving like them. For sentiment or profit, people are snapping up postcards, T-shirts and anything else bearing images of the World Trade Center, and snapping pictures of the gap left by its absence.

title: Reshuffled Pitching Rotations Could Determine Races
description: Walt Jocketty, the St. Louis Cardinals general manager, was talking about his team's state of readiness to resume the season tonight.

title: Police Officers Swiftly Show Inventiveness During Crisis
description: No other large police force in the country had developed such sophisticated antiterrorism strategies. None had done as much training or had received as much expert counsel on how to prepare for a terrorist catastrophe.

title: The Moods of America: Grief, Rage, Resolve
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, SHIRLEY
description: LEVINE-Shirley. On September 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Sam, loving mother of Judith and Harvey Mayer and Susan and Marshall Bykofsky, cherished grandmother of Bradley, Robyn, David, and Ari. Services Thursday at 10 A.M., from Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: Legislature In California Gives No Aid To a Utility
description: State legislators have ended their session without bailing out Southern California Edison as demanded by Gov. Gray Davis, who said he would call lawmakers back to the Capitol.

title: Americans Ousted From Youth Tourney
description: The United States under-17 men's national team had boasted of never having allowed more than two goals in international games and of having allowed only 25 goals in 18 games. All that changed in Sunday night's 5-3 loss to France in the FIFA under-17 world youth championship in Bacolet, Tobago.

title: Extra Security Doesn't Bother Players
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17  A couple of hours before he got into the batter's box and the game came back, Matt Lawton, the Mets' leadoff hitter, acknowledged that he would not feel completely safe. The terror of last Tuesday would be with him, even between the lines.

title: Intelligence and Terrorism
description: The rush has already begun to ''unshackle'' the Central Intelligence Agency and its fellow spy agencies so that they can better combat terrorism. Some easing of restrictions may be warranted in light of last week's terrorist attacks on New York and Washington. But any changes must be carefully weighed by the Bush administration and Congress. The temptation will be great to take steps, including loosening limitations on domestic spying, that could end up compromising important democratic principles without yielding any tangible gain in the fight against terrorism.

title: Investigators Explore Boundaries Of Everything the Law Allows
description: Law enforcement officials have extensive powers to detain people when investigating attacks on the country, legal experts said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ISIDOR M.
description: COHEN-Isidor M. 3/30/1907 to 9/17/1951. A tragic death a long time ago. We still remember. Diana, Arthur, Sandy

title: A New War And Its Scale
description: When President Bush and his top aides talk about military action to end Afghanistan's support for terrorism, they are focusing on attacks to punish the Taliban and undermine their control over the country, not a full-scale American occupation.

title: The Moods of America: Grief, Rage, Resolve; The Next Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Access Providers Curb Both Terrorist Postings and an Anti-Islamic Backlash
description: For Internet service companies, the aftermath of last week's terrorist attacks has meant new scrutiny of the material that their online users can view and post.

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGGERTY, JAMES J., RT. REV. MSGR.
description: HAGGERTY-James J., Rt. Rev. Msgr. On Sept. 14, 2001. Pastor Emeritus, St. Saviour R.C. Church, Brooklyn, NY. Formerly associated with St. Michael's, Brooklyn, NY; St. Mel's, St. Teresa's and Our Lady of The Angelus R.C. Churches, Queens, NY. Resident of Breezy Point for 50 years. Beloved son of the late James and Mary Ann Haggerty. Loving brother of Mary, Bert and Eileen, Noreen and Jack. Loving uncle of ten nieces and nephews, and six grandnieces and grandnephews. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc, 98-07 Ascan Ave (corner Metropolitan Ave), Forest Hills, Sunday 7-9 PM, Monday 2-5 and 7-9, Tuesday 2-5 PM. Mass of Transferral, St. Saviour R.C. Church (8th Ave and 6th St, Brooklyn, NY) Tuesday, September 18, 7:30 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Saviour R.C. Church, Wednesday, September 19, 10:30 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Lawmakers Hear Ashcroft Outline Antiterror Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  Attorney General John Ashcroft and Congressional leaders opened talks today on an emergency package of antiterrorism legislation that would expand the Justice Department's ability to use wiretaps in cases of suspected terrorism or espionage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN AUKEN, KENNETH W.
description: VAN AUKEN-Kenneth W., 47. Bond trader at Cantor Fitzgerald, of E. Brunswick, NJ, formerly of Staten Island, on Sept. 11, 2001. Husband of Lorie (Schafler). Father of Matthew & Sarah. Brother of Karen Renzo & Janice Booth. Son of Warren Gordon and Eleanor Liland Van Auken. Son-in-law of Myrna & Joseph Schafler. Brother-in-law of Craig Booth & Marcy Schafler. Uncle of Brandon and Zachary Langley, and Natalie & Emily Barbato. Memorial service 10:30 AM, Thursday, Sept. 20, Brunswick Memorial Home, 732254-9393. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund.

title: President Bush's First Win
description: New York City and George W. Bush were never a natural couple until last week. Now Mr. Bush has managed to reach out in ways both symbolic and practical. In its greatest hour of need, the city must be grateful that he rose to the occasion, and demonstrated that he is president of the entire country.

title: This Week
description: Impressionists on Display

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When they see us in the streets, wearing the flag, they know that we are not afraid of them, and that we will defeat them.''

title: Older Works That Seemed Appropriate to the Moment
description: Nothing is normal now. Friday's concert by the Friends and Enemies of New Music -- one of the first concerts to take place in New York City since the events of Tuesday morning -- went on somberly. The audience at CAMI Hall, across the street from Carnegie Hall, was subdued. Those present who had arrived on foot, whether through the streets or across the park, would have passed groups of people gathered in the darkening light with candles: standing outside firehouses, on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum or seated around the Bethesda Fountain. Some of these groups were silent, others were singing patriotic songs, not with gusto as on other occasions, but with quiet fervor, making those songs into prayers.

title: German Deal for U.S. Water Utility
description: In the first deal in the United States since the terrorist attacks of last week, American Water Works of Voorhees, N.J., has agreed to be sold to RWE, a German utility, for more than $5 billion, executives close to the transaction said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THEBNER, EMANUEL
description: THEBNER-Emanuel, 95 years on September 14, 2001. Beloved father, grandfather, great-grandfather and brother. Practicing attorney for over 75 years. Friend, counselor and advisor to many. You will be in our hearts forever.

title: Wall Street's Driven Steward Presses for Business as Usual
description: The man who will try today to tug American finance back to its feet decided to place grief counselors on the trading floor of the stock market when it reopens this morning. Asked if he had sought any psychological help since his world collapsed on Tuesday, Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, seemed startled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORGES, SUZANNE F.
description: PORGES-Suzanne F. Died at home in NYC on September 13. Beloved mother of Robert F. and George W. Cherished mother-inlaw of Felicia and Nicole. Grandmother of John A. and Vicki Eisner. Great-grandmother of Dylan Robert Porges. Born in Vienna in 1908 she escaped the Holocaust and immigrated with husband and young children in 1938. She lived for many years in Forest Hills, NY and West Stockbridge, MA, where she had a long, prolific career as a portraitist, still-life and landscape painter. Her strength, courage, humor and adaptability will always be an inspiration to her family. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Friday, September 21, at 5 PM.

title: City Center Says Thanks
description: City Center has announced that it will offer free tickets, when available, to fire and police personnel and Emergency Medical Service workers during the fall season. Participating programs and companies include Salvador Tavora's ''Carmen,'' playing at the theater through Sunday afternoon, Encores!, American Ballet Theater, Alvin Ailey American Dance Company, Gypsy Caravan and New York Festival Flamenco, Ballet Nacional de Cuba and the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players. Information: (212) 762-1206.

title: Arts Groups at a Tragedy's Center Try to Assess Where to Begin
description: Liz Thompson was in the lobby of the north tower of the World Trade Center on Tuesday morning shortly before 9, making initial plans for a new piece of art in the building for the Christmas season.

title: Merger Deals Are Stalled Amid Doubt
description: For investment bankers it is the equivalent of an insurer's ''acts of God'' clause. It's called the ''material adverse change,'' or MAC, proviso, and it can enable companies to back out of all sorts of business deals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOUT, TIMOTHY C.
description: STOUT-Timothy C., 44. Of Dobbs Ferry, NY on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Tim was born in Boston on August 19, 1959. Devoted husband to Maryellen (nee Fanelli), loving father of Timothy Jr., 6, Matthew, 5, and Shannon, 4. Cherished son of Thomas and Elinor Stout, caring brother of Caroline Duncan and Jordan Stout. Mass Friday 9:30 AM Sacred Heart Church, Dobbs Ferry. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 79 PM, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to Twin Towers Fund, P.O. Box 26999, New York, NY 10087-6999 benefiting the families of policemen, firemen and emergency service personnel who gave their lives to save others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIVEN, JOHN B.
description: NIVEN-John B., July 5, 1957 to September 11, 2001. We love you and we will miss you. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, New York on Tuesday, September 18th at 2:00 PM.

title: The Moods of America: Grief, Rage, Resolve; Buy American
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: A Day of Worship; Excerpts From Sermons Across the Nation
description: In houses of worship across the nation this weekend, clergy came before congregations with the difficult, yet urgent task of interpreting the single subject that has dominated Americans' consciousness since last Tuesday, when terrorists attacked New York and Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUINN, FRANCIS NOEL
description: McGUINN-Francis Noel. Of Rye, New York, died tragically and without cause on September 11, 2001, at One World Trade Center. Mr. McGuinn worked for Cantor Fitzgerald on the 105th floor as the Managing Director of Emerging Markets. Mr. McGuinn was born to Edwin John (deceased) and Vera Sheehan McGuinn on Christmas Day, 1952. Born in Brooklyn, his family moved to Rye in the 1960's where they sent their children to Resurrection School. Mr. McGuinn attended Iona Prep High School where he developed and nurtured his love of history and the teachings of the Jesuits. He went on to receive an undergraduate degree in business from Fairfield University and then to accomplish his MBA at Iona College in New Rochelle, New York. Mr. McGuinn's career on Wall Street spanned over 20 dedicated years including the companies of Chapdelaine Corporate Securities, Garban/Intercapital and then onto Cantor Fitzgerald. At Cantor, he managed a desk of 50 dedicated traders for Emerging Markets while developing an electronic trading platform for Emerging Markets for Cantor's E-Speed Company. Mr. McGuinn took an active and lively interest in many charities, including The Catholic Sisters of Charity, Hale House, The American Red Cross and The Foundation for Cancer Research to name a few. He was a member of Westchester Country Club in Rye, New York, The New York Athletic Club and The Fairfield University President's Circle. Mr. McGuinn will forever be remembered for his incredible sense of clarity and purpose and for his tremendous capacity to love and embrace those that came into his life. His loving wife, Lynn Sofia McGuinn of Rye and three daughters Danielle, Elizabeth and Carolyne survive him. Siblings are Edwin J. McGuinn of Greenwich, Tracy McGuinn Donovan & Trish McGuinn Lawrence both of Westport, Connecticut. Services will be held at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, New York, from 9 AM to 11 AM, Tuesday, September 18th. Immediately following there will be a Memorial Mass at the Church of the Resurrection at noon. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Frank McGuinn Memorial Scholarship Fund/Resurrection Grammar School, Rye, N.Y. 10580.

title: Brazil Urges Activating Rio Pact
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 17  Brazil has called on the Organization of American States to activate a regional collective security agreement when its members meet in Washington in a special session on Wednesday. In doing so, it disregarded skepticism throughout Latin America about the wisdom of standing up with the United States in responding to last week's terrorist attacks.

title: The Mayor's Remarks: 'You're All My Heroes'
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's address yesterday at the New York City Fire Department promotion ceremony, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: With No Miracle in the Rubble, Hope Grimly Shifts to Acceptance
description: Day after day come the numbers that never seem to add up, from the number of the confirmed dead (190) to the number of those still categorized as ''missing'' (4,957). But of all the statistics being solemnly shared in the aftermath of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center last week, two in particular bleed the reservoir of hope.

title: Companies, Even Rivals, Help
description: As companies work to recover from the terror attacks in New York, many are receiving offers of help from their longtime bitter competitors, and Citigroup has donated $15 million to a fund that will provide scholarships to the children of victims of the terrorist attacks.

title: San Antonio
description: In San Antonio, federal agents searched the office of a 34-year old radiologist, said Dr. Gerald D. Dodd, chairman of the radiology department at the University of Texas Health Sciences Center at San Antonio. The radiologist, identified in local news reports as Albader Alhazmi, is from Saudi Arabia and has been enrolled in the Health Sciences Center's diagnostic radiology residency program for nearly five years, Dr. Dodd said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPLIK, PERRY H.
description: KOPLIK-Perry H. Died peacefully at the age of 94. Beloved husband for 67 years of Estelle (Schulman). Devoted father of Michael and the late Kenneth. Cherished father-inlaw of Joyce and Diane. Much adored grandfather of Abigail, Kathryn, Michelle and David. For information contact Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 212288-3500.

title: Trying to Plan for the Unthinkable Disaster
description: Business disaster recovery experts have been confronted by a stunning new form of devastation that few had imagined before Tuesday's terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.

title: AFTER THE ATTACKS
description: PROMOTIONS AND TEARS -- When 168 officers and firefighters were promoted, there was the usual mayoral speech about leadership and responsibility. But unlike those at other, usually joyful, promotion ceremonies, the speeches by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani (right) and top Fire Department officials were delivered through tears, resonant with urgency and trepidation, pride tempered by loss, and words of battle, comradeship, risk and courage. PAGE A7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERBELL, MARGARET NICOLL
description: TERBELL-Margaret Nicoll. Widow of Thomas Terbell, passed away on September 10 of pneumonia at age 90. She is survived by a daughter, Margaret Gerli Whittelsey, a son, John E. Gerli Jr.; a step-daughter, Joan Knowles and a step-son, Thomas G. Terbell Jr. She is also survived by 4 grandchildren, five great-grandchildren and nine step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on October 18 at 3 PM at Christ Church, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: The Moods of America: Grief, Rage, Resolve; A Moral Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Sections
description: Section A today is devoted to the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, with the editorial and Op-Ed pages, A14-15. Other international, national and metropolitan news is in Section B. Section C consists of Business Day and SportsMonday (Section D does not appear). The Arts is Section E. Corrections appear on Page B2.

title: Florida
description: Federal agents continued their work yesterday in Delray Beach, Fla., with the search of an apartment at the Delray Racquet Club, which has been connected to two suspects.

title: M.L.S. Gets Ready To Begin Playoffs
description: Major League Soccer, which canceled the final 10 games of the regular season because of last Tuesday's terrorist attacks, will begin the playoffs Thursday. All playoff teams will wear Statue of Liberty patches and black armbands on their uniforms.

title: Japanese Market Falls on Fears of a Stock Selloff in U.S.
description: Tokyo, Sept. 17  Japanese stocks and the dollar fell sharply in Tokyo today as investors braced for a selloff in the American stock market.

title: The Moods of America: Grief, Rage, Resolve; New York Stories
description: To the Editor:

title: Latin Grammy Awards Try a Taste of Reality
description: Hundreds of top music executives and artists gathered in the international ballroom at the Beverly Hilton Hotel last Monday for a formal dinner and pre-party for the Latin Grammy Awards, which were to be broadcast live the following night on CBS. The dinner doubled as a celebration honoring Julio Iglesias, who had been named man of the year by the Latin Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, the branch of the National Recording Academy that runs the Latin Grammys. In a big night intended as a warm-up to an even bigger night, a dozen stars of Latin music, including Celia Cruz, Arturo Sandoval, Alejandro Sanz and Jon Secada, performed in tribute.

title: What's an Industry to Say To Skittish U.S. Travelers?
description: THE difficulties for advertisers and agencies as a result of the attacks last week on New York and Washington probably loom largest for a marketing category at the heart of the disaster: transportation.

title: Cheney Describes His Nerve-Center Role in First Hours of Crisis
description: Within an hour after the first passenger jet hit the World Trade Center, Vice President Dick Cheney told President Bush to stay away from Washington, ordered the Congressional leadership evacuated, dispersed cabinet members to emergency shelters and urged Mr. Bush to direct fighter jets to shoot down any rogue airliner that threatened the Capitol or White House.

title: Partner Pulls Out of Yankee Cable Deal
description: Less than a week after agreeing to invest $150 million in YES, the Yankees Entertainment and Sports network, Quadrangle Group pulled out over the weekend.

title: Central Banks in U.S. and Europe Cut Interest Rates by Half Point
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  In a bold move to try to keep the stock markets from tumbling, the Federal Reserve today cut interest rates by half a percentage point to 3 percent.

title: September 17th: Closings and Openings
description: Streets below Canal Street and east of Broadway have been reopened to pedestrians using public transportation. The rest of the area below Canal Street remains closed, with a strict no-access area between Chambers St. and Rector St. ( See NYC map .)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about the Rev. Mychal Judge, a Fire Department chaplain who died ministering to World Trade Center victims, misstated the location of the parish where he served from 1979 to 1986. It is in West Milford, N.J., not in New Hampshire.

title: Hulking Neighbor Buries a Church
description: The tiny bell cote of St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church at 155 Cedar Street had long been a delicate spiritual counterpoint to the massive World Trade Center towers behind it, one of them only 250 feet away.

title: Editors Rush to Revise Long-Made Plans
description: Whether at newsweeklies or women's magazines, editors scrambled last week to make their next issues relevant: to give voice to the terrors of the World Trade Center disaster and to provide context for articles that might otherwise seem callous or irrelevant.

title: From A.T.M.'s to Bond Trades, a Difficult Comeback
description: The Bank of New York, which processes about half of all government securities trades and operates the fourth-largest retail branch network in the New York metropolitan area, was having mixed success in getting its operations running by yesterday.

title: The Moods of America: Grief, Rage, Resolve; A Firefighter's Creed
description: To the Editor:

title: William I. Spencer, 84, Is Dead; Leader in Evolution of Citibank
description: William I. Spencer, who as the No. 2 executive at the holding company for what became Citibank helped propel the bank to the top of the industry, died on Sept. 9 at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Sports of The Times; For the Giants, Images of Smoke and Lessons of Spirit
description: FROM outside Giants Stadium, you could look across the Meadowlands and see smoke still rising slowly into a baby blue sky from the ashes of what had been the twin towers of the World Trade Center. The smoke that had resulted in the ''Giants Game Postponed'' sign near the tollbooths to the empty parking lots. The smoke that had the American flag, the yellow New Jersey state flag and the black POW-MIA flag flying at half-staff in the breeze above the north side of the empty stadium.

title: Arizona
description: The authorities believe that Hani Hanjour, one of the hijacking suspects, lived in the Phoenix area off and on since as early as 1991, and was training to be a pilot. In fall 1996, and in December 1997, Mr. Hanjour attended the CRM Airline Training Center in Scottsdale. But he was not diligent, and he did not receive a private pilot's certificate, said Paul V. Blair, the center's controller.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANE, SHIRLEY
description: LANE-Shirley. September 17th, 1997. We love you madly.

title: Israel Wants Cease-Fire To Precede Truce Talks
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel said today that he would try to help the Bush administration draw Arab nations into a coalition against terrorism by permitting truce talks here -- but only if a cease-fire creates ''absolute quiet'' for 48 hours beforehand.

title: Battery Park City Residents Only Visit
description: Gus Ouranitsas, the resident manager of 200 Rector Place, has been sleeping in the lobby for almost a week -- a sentinel at one of the evacuated apartment buildings in Battery Park City, a 92-acre complex in the shadow of the ruined World Trade Center.

title: Bush Warns of a Wrathful, Shadowy and Inventive War
description: A day after proclaiming flatly that the nation was ''at war,'' President Bush and his senior advisers took pains to warn Americans today that it would be a war unlike any other, fought in the shadows, testing the patience of the public and leaders alike, but that nations failing to join the crusade would face the ''full wrath of the United States,'' as Vice President Dick Cheney put it.

title: Lawmakers Hear Ashcroft Outline Antiterror Plans
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft and Congressional leaders opened talks today on an emergency package of antiterrorism legislation that would expand the Justice Department's ability to use wiretaps in cases of suspected terrorism or espionage.

title: Bracing for Reaction When Trades Resume
description: For a nation that became enamored of the stock market over the last decade, investing seemed a trivial, even forgotten pursuit, over the last week. Yet as the market prepared to reopen after a strike to the heart of Wall Street, investors faced an unavoidable question: What should I do now?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASNER, SUSAN
description: CASNER-Susan. Beloved wife of Harry Miller and mother to Amanda and Zachary Miller, sister of Martha Ives and Anne Darkoff, died at age 53 of Lou Gehrig's Disease. She was an inspiration to all of us who knew her. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to ALSA, New York Chapter, 116 John St., NY, NY 10038. Services Monday, September 17, 10 AM at The Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, NY.

title: U.S. Binds Wounds in Red, White and Blue
description: The signs of the pain inflicted by the terrorists span New York, from the dust cloud over the southern tip of Manhattan to the faces of the missing tacked onto walls in Greenwich Village to the thousands who watch heartbreaking images of the World Trade Center hulk on giant television screens in Times Square.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTZ, JOHN C.
description: HARTZ-John C., 64. Of Basking Ridge, NJ and East Orleans, MA, died September 11, 2001 at World Trade Center New York City. Senior Vice-President Fiduciary Trust International. President Somerset Hills Country Club, Bernardsville, NJ. Graduate of Groton School, Trinity College and Columbia Business School. Predeceased by his first wife, Catherine, survived by his wife, Elinore, his children John C. Jr. of Palm Beach, FL, and Catherine B. of Boston. Also by stepchildren Hadley F. Gates and David A. Pollet, both of Boston, and sister Elizabeth H. Forster of New York City. Memorial service at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, NJ on Thursday, September 20 at 11 AM. Contributions in his memory to New York State World Trade Center Relief Fund, P.O. Box 5028, Albany, NY 12205, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUGHLIN, TIMOTHY JOHN
description: COUGHLIN-Timothy John, 42. Lost but never to be forgotten, in the World Trade Center disaster, of New York and of Westhampton Beach (formerly of Manhasset). Senior Managing Director of Cantor Fitzgerald Securities and of ESpeed. Loving husband of Maura (O'Callaghan) and devoted father to Ryann Elizabeth, Sean Thomas and Riley Francis. Cherished son of Alice (Breen) and Frank Coughlin. Brother, like no other brother, to Frank (Jr.), Dennis and Rob. Special son-in-law to Aggie and John O'Callaghan. Extraordinary brother-in-law of Craig (his wife Kristin) and Thomas O'Callaghan and of Ellen, Nancy and Kathleen Coughlin. Wonderful uncle to Kevin, Frankie, Billy, Alice, Tara, Eamon, Patrick, Claire and Brendan Coughlin. Loving godson and nephew of Lillian (Blake) and the late Daniel Coughlin, and loving nephew of Marion and the late Dennis Breen, Bianca and the late Raymond Breen and the late Miriam and Francis (''Dr. Frankie'') Breen. Beloved nephew of the late Elizabeth and Augustine (''Uncle Brother'') Coughlin. Survived also by many cousins of the Breen and Coughlin families. The family will receive friends on Tuesday, September 18th from 7 to 9 PM and on Wednesday, September 19th from 2 to 5 PM and 7 to 9 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street) NYC. Memorial Mass Thursday September 20th, 10 AM at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue (at 51st Street), NYC. Please, in lieu of flowers donations may be made to either of St. Mary's High School, 51 Clapham Avenue, Manhasset, New York 11030 or to Stonehill College, 320 Washington St., North Easton, Massachusetts 02357, in each case attention: Timothy J. Coughlin Fund.

title: NATION SHIFTS ITS FOCUS TO WALL STREET AS A MAJOR TEST OF ATTACK'S AFTERMATHS
description: An informal coalition of government and business implored the leaders of Wall Street today to do what they could as a patriotic duty to keep the stock markets from tumbling when they reopen on Monday morning.

title: Sikh Owner Of Gas Station Is Fatally Shot In Rampage
description: In a shooting rampage on Saturday, a gunman in Arizona fatally shot the Sikh owner of a Chevron gas station, and then, 20 minutes later, shot at but missed a clerk of Lebanese descent at a Mobil station. Soon afterward, he fired several shots into the home of a family of Afghan descent, but hit no one.

title: Rebel Chief Who Fought The Taliban Is Buried
description: Thousands of Afghan fighters streamed through the dusty mountain trails of the Panjshir Valley today to bury Ahmed Shah Massoud, their legendary commander who held together the last remaining resistance to the Taliban government.

title: The Moods of America: Grief, Rage, Resolve; New York Stories
description: To the Editor:

title: City to Create Commission To Oversee Reconstruction
description: New York City will form a reconstruction commission with extraordinary powers to lead the recovery from the terrorist destruction of the World Trade Center, officials said yesterday, as the city prepared for today's return of business and government to Lower Manhattan.

title: Amid the Rubble, A Steeple Stands
description: Perhaps no flock gathered more gratefully than Trinity parish, which has worshiped in Lower Manhattan for 304 years. And did so again yesterday.

title: Bush Faces the Greatest Test
description: During the Cuban missile crisis, John Kennedy grimly joked that he had earned his salary that week. Crises, of course, are not all a commander in chief is paid for. But in the wake of the bolt out of the blue last week, history shows us how much presidential leadership can affect the way Americans react to a foreign assault.

title: The Power of Words
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Tunnel Vision; His Last Train to the End of the No. 1 Line
description: When Carlos Johnson woke at his usual hour -- 3:30 a.m. -- on Tuesday, Sept. 11, he did not know that hundreds of miles away, a 190-ton jet sat on a runway in Boston, bound for the precise place he was bound that day.

title: 44 Victims Are Remembered, and Lauded
description: The families of those who died aboard United Airlines Flight 93 gathered in the mountains of southwestern Pennsylvania today, in a place that is already being described as a sacred battleground in the war against terrorism.

title: 'Dear Mr. or Mrs. Fireman'
description: Of all the efforts being made to take care of the rescue workers, perhaps the most consoling touches have been the notes from schoolchildren posted near the collapse site. ''Dear Mr. or Mrs. Fireman,'' begins one note posted in St. Joseph's Chapel, and from a novice speller, ''Dear Mr. Frieman.'' They call the rescue workers heroes, thank them, and encourage them to get home safely.

title: Review/Fashion; The Unexpected Comfort of the Familiar
description: With a small American flag on the sleeve of his gray pinstripe suit, Oscar de la Renta opened a week of scaled-back American fashion presentations yesterday at his Seventh Avenue showroom, the first since the spring 2002 collections were interrupted because of the World Trade Center tragedy. The models, all six of them, wore stars and stripes armbands, too.

title: Good at Action Films. Maybe Too Good.
description: Is the depiction of violence America's most heavily exported cultural product? After the events of last Tuesday, the question hangs in the air. The issue of violence in movies was raised in Senate hearings last year and figured to some degree in the presidential campaign.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Benefits column of the City section on Sunday for a fund-raising dinner planned by Habitat for Humanity has become outdated. The event, scheduled for this Thursday in Grand Central Terminal, has been canceled.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Conservative Joins Panel
description: A prominent conservative evangelical Protestant, the Rev. Richard D. Land, was appointed by President Bush to a two-year term on a federal panel that monitors religious freedom abroad. Mr. Land, who is president of the Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission at the Southern Baptist Convention, said he would become one of three members appointed by the president to the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom, which was established by Congress in 1999. It has nine members, six appointed by Congress. In an interview, Mr. Land said he was ''gratified that we now have a clearly identified evangelical on this commission.'' Gustav Niebuhr (NYT)

title: Pakistan's Choice
description: The ruthless attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon last week are, by all accounts, the handiwork of zealots trained and organized in the Western-backed jihad against Communism in Afghanistan. Now that a global campaign against terrorism is being mobilized, the United States government must take extra precautions to avoid creating a new monster while dealing with the existing one.

title: Comforting and Cajoling to a Chant of '4 More Years'
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani carries many figures around in his head -- the number of those missing or dead, how many millions of pounds of rubble have been removed from Lower Manhattan -- but there is one number in particular that follows him around wherever he goes these days.

title: Technology's Role to Grow In a New World of Security
description: Security experts are describing a new kind of country, where electronic identification might become the norm, immigrants might be tracked far more closely and the airspace over cities like New York and Washington might be off limits to all civilian aircraft.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Precaution Keeps University Closed
description: Even though the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have called off meetings in Washington scheduled for the end of the month, George Washington University said it would still cancel classes from Sept. 27 to Oct. 2. Gretchen King, a spokeswoman for the university, said law enforcement officials told the university that 10,000 to 15,000 of the 100,000 protesters who had been expected to turn out for the meetings may still come to the city. Earlier this month, citing the possibility of disruptions, the university told students, faculty members and staff members that they should leave the campus during the meetings scheduled for Sept. 29 and Sept. 30.

title: Bomb Threat Diverts Jet Bound for Kennedy
description: The authorities diverted a New York-bound Virgin Atlantic 747 jetliner to Canada yesterday after the airline received a bomb threat in London, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRISON, META
description: MORRISON-Meta. Beloved wife of the late Ed Morrison, passed away September 12, 2001. She is survived by daughters Susan Appelbaum of Charlotte, NC, and Nancy Solomon of Weston, MA; grandchildren Julie Stein, Lauren Appelbaum, Mitchell and Leslie Solomon; great-grandsons Benjamin and Jamie Stein. A graveside service will be held Thursday, September 20, 11:30 AM, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Memorials may be made to Hospice or to the donor's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TATNALL, HENRY CHACE, JR.
description: TATNALL-Henry Chace, Jr. Age 71. On Friday, September 14, 2001 in Princeton, N.J. after a valiant battle with leukemia. Mr. Tatnall enjoyed a long career in banking in Philadelphia, New York and Princeton. Husband of Alexandra Wentworth Tatnall. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 22nd, 2PM at All Saints Church, Princeton, N.J. Inquiries to Bringhurst Funeral Home, 610668-9900.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINARDI, WILLIAM G.
description: MINARDI-William G. of Bedford, NY suddenly and tragically on September 11, 2001. Derivatives Broker; firm of Cantor Fitzgerald. Beloved husband of Stephanie. Loving father of William M., Robert P., and Christine A. Cherished son of Elizabeth and the late William J. Minardi, and son-in-law of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew Higgins. Dear brother of James and Dolores Minardi, Joanne and Rick Pitino, Mary and the late Donald J. Vogt. Brother-in-law of Anne Farrell and Dr. and Mrs. Matthew Higgins. Adored uncle of Matthew, Luke, and Martin Minardi, Michael, Christopher, Richard, Ryan and Jacqueline Pitino, Devon, William and Patrick Vogt, Grace Higgins and the late Daniel M. Pitino. Loving and cherished friend to many. Celebration of Life and Mass of the Resurrection Thursday, September 20th, at 5:00 PM at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, 2 Green Street, Mt. Kisco (corner of Main Street; 914-666-5986). Contributions in William's memory may be made to the Daniel Pitino Shelter; 501 Walnut Street, Owensboro, KY 42301.

title: After a Pause, Arts Companies Find Their Role; Nationwide, People Turn to Theaters and Concert Halls for a Sense of Community
description: The Lyric Opera Company in Chicago, considered one of the country's finest, will go on with opening night as planned next Saturday. As is traditional, the insurance company Aon will sponsor the evening.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Daredevil in Distress

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASNER, SUSAN
description: CASNER-Susan. Beloved wife of Harry Miller and mother to Amanda and Zachary Miller, sister of Martha Ives and Anne Dankoff. She was an inspiration to all of us who knew her. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to ALSA, New York Chapter, 116 John St., NY, NY 10038.

title: The Times Postpones Celebration of Its 150 Years
description: One hundred fifty years ago today, the first issue of the New-York Daily Times came off the press. It was written and edited in a candlelit loft in the middle of a horse-and-buggy town where what is now called Times Square was still a wide-meadowed farm.

title: Defending Skyscrapers Against Terror
description: No one designs a skyscraper to withstand the direct hit of a fully fueled 767, and construction engineers agree that such an attack would have doomed almost any high-rise.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B.

title: As Talks End in Seoul, Two Koreas Plan More Exchange Visits
description: North and South Korean negotiators today broke through a six-month hiatus in negotiations with a sweeping agreement approving a new round of family reunions between the two countries scheduled to start next month.

title: Glenn Fowler, 77, Realty Editor at Times
description: Glenn C. Fowler, who was the real estate editor of The New York Times from 1956 to 1972 and worked at the paper for 36 years, died on Sept. 10 at the New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 77 and lived in the Gramercy Park area of Manhattan.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?; The Rebuilding
description: To the Editor:

title: Rituals for Grieving Extend Past Tradition Into Public Displays
description: New York became a city of memorials and funerals this week, a citadel of grief and prayer and remembrance.

title: Stress Will Chase Some Into the Depths of Their Minds
description: For some, the ultimate legacy of last week's events will be memories that gradually turn malignant, as dangerous as any cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, GLENN C.
description: FOWLER-Glenn C. The New York Financial Writers' Association regrets the passing of its longtime member, Glenn C. Fowler. The Association wishes to express its deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Susan Rodetis, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: SAS Board Quits
description: Scandinavian Airlines System's board quit after an independent panel criticized its handling of a marketing accord with Maersk Air of Denmark that led to a European Union fine. The panel said in a report that even though the nine-member board was not aware of the pact, it showed a ''lack of activity'' after a June 2000 office raid by European Union antitrust investigators. Maersk is a unit of the A. P. Moller Group.

title: Quitters Never Win? Not True
description: Contests that offer smokers the chance to win money if they can prove they have quit appear effective at helping them break their addiction.

title: Dolphins' Bowens To Miss Next Game
description: Miami defensive tackle Tim Bowens will miss Sunday's game against the Oakland Raiders while recovering from knee surgery.

title: Hope Is Found in the Cloud of Alzheimer's
description: ''The Loss of Self: A Family Resource for the Care of Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders,'' by Dr. Donna Cohen and Dr. Carl Eisdorfer, W. W. Norton & Company, $27.95.

title: In This Section
description: BACK TO BUSINESS

title: Many Individual Investors Want to Buy, Then Buy More
description: Bill Mason came to work early today, expecting the worst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLAN, MARGARET C.
description: DOLAN-Margaret C., September 16, 2001. Beloved sister of Ann D. Connolly. Loving aunt of Thomas, James, John, Ann and Frank Connolly. Also survived by greatnieces and nephews Kim Milewski, Kevin, Jim, Kelley, Tom Connolly, Maddy, C.C. Medenica. Reposing Tuesday night 7-9pm at Hillebrand Funeral Homes, Inc., 63-17 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:45am, Saint Thomas The Apostle RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Subdued Giants Struggle To Put Game Faces On
description: One by one, the Giants emerged from their locker room, turning to walk through the alleyway that leads to the team's grass practice field next to Giants Stadium. One by one, they closed ranks to navigate a corridor recently narrowed by shoulder-high, stacked rows of goods bound for the relief effort at the site of the World Trade Center. One by one, the Giants stepped on the practice field and stole glances over their left shoulders, looking east to the new Manhattan skyline.

title: Wall Street Returns to Work, Finding Good in Falling Prices
description: Barricaded, its stone pillars bandaged in American flags, dust lapping its sidewalks, the New York Stock Exchange re-opened yesterday in a burst of patriotism and closed at a sharp low, its rallies and deeper dips mirroring its patrons' mixed mood of defiance and fear.

title: A Spartan New Set of Standards For Airlines and Most Passengers
description: As airline stocks plunged and the airline industry worked feverishly behind the scenes yesterday to secure a financial rescue package from Washington, executives and industry consultants agreed that no matter what happened next, air travel had changed for at least the near term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNER, EDMUND
description: HARNER-Edmund, on September 17, 2001. Survived by his daughter Lorraine, granddaughter Marina, sisters Stephenie Durski and Adele Cardone along with many nieces and nephews. Mass of the Resurrection Wednesday, 1 PM, St. Matthew's Church, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Visiting tonight, 7-9 PM, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to Rosary Hill Home.

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Airline In Turmoil
description: A worldwide investor allergy to airline stocks drove the stock of Air New Zealand, already reeling from grave financial troubles and the failure of a subsidiary, down 40 percent, to 12 United States cents a share. The company, New Zealand's only national carrier, hopes for $350 million in a rescue package from the government and major shareholders, but half that money may go straight to laid-off workers at Ansett, its Australian unit, which shut down last week. Confusing matters further, the administrators brought in to run Ansett, PricewaterhouseCoopers, resigned today under pressure from unions over a claimed conflict of interest. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?; The Giuliani Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Traveled Across U.S. In His Quest to Be a Pilot
description: He kept to himself, managing to melt unnoticed into the sprawling suburban neighborhoods here. And he was so polite and timid that when he arrived from his native Saudi Arabia without any toiletries, he did not even ask his hosts for a spare toothbrush.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?; True Patriotism
description: To the Editor:

title: At Marathon, Groups From as Far Away as New Zealand Testify to Life Unfolding
description: The musicians at the Bowery Ballroom on Saturday and Sunday, sharing two bills made up of the remnants of the postponed College Music Journal Music Marathon, were, on the whole, abashed.

title: Cautiously, A Resumption Of Politics
description: No one knows how long it will be before New Jersey voters have any appetite for politics, or for politicians. But there is an election for governor in seven weeks, and today, one of the candidates ever-so-gingerly sought to restart his campaign.

title: The Fed's Statement About Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates:

title: 'Blast' to Close
description: ''Blast!,'' a musical revue with a 60-member company, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street. The show will have run for 176 regular performances and 13 previews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAVALKOFF, DINAH
description: ZAVALKOFF-Dinah. In Montreal on September 13, 2001, at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Abe. Devoted mother and mother-inlaw of Norman and the late Mona, Ruth and the late Henry Lindenbaum. Grandmother to Avi, Michael and Philip Lindenbaum and Brian and Anne Zavalkoff.

title: On a Free Boat Ride, 'It Hurts to Even Look'
description: They came by the hundreds, hoping that an early morning ferry ride from Brooklyn to Lower Manhattan would somehow ease the anxiety of returning to work to offices in the middle of a disaster area.

title: E.P.A. Enforcement Nominee Withdraws
description: The Ohio environmental regulator nominated by President Bush to be the top law enforcement official of the Environmental Protection Agency withdrew his name from consideration today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAGER, J. ALLEN, M.D.
description: YAGER-J. Allen, M.D. 97. Of Newton, MA. Formerly of NJ. Adoring husband of Hilda, devoted father of Paul and Henry and beloved grandfather, brother, uncle and friend. In his distinguished 62 year medical career, positions included practicing cardiologist, World War II Navy doctor, Paterson, N.J. Health Commissioner, State Department Consultant in Africa, Vice President Group Health, Inc. and Medical Director Phoenix House. His keen intellect, warm humor and indominable spirit will be missed. Funeral service Thursday, 12:30PM, at Gutterman Musikant, Hackensack, NJ. Contributions can be made to The New York Times 9/11 Fund, City College of New York, or the NYU Medical School.

title: Everything Is Different As Yanks Resume
description: An emergency broadcast signal blared loudly over the public-address system at Comiskey Park during the Yankees' workout today and the heads of players turned quickly, their attention jarred until they realized it was only a test. A loud pop emanated from the light banks during batting practice, and players glanced warily. A plane flew high overhead, and Luis Sojo and others looked up and tracked its path. Everything is different, Sojo said later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMM, STEPHEN
description: LAMM-Stephen. Loving son of Esther Miller, adored father of Suzanne Dukes, Spencer and Samara, dear brother of Marlene Spigner. Graveside service 1 PM, Thursday, September 20, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: A Regimen for Resistance
description: Just 5 percent to 17 percent of adults suffering sore throats have bacterial infections that require antibiotics. But when sufferers see their primary care doctors, a new study reports, almost three-quarters of them will be given drugs anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, CHRISTOPHER PAUL
description: SLATTERY - Christopher Paul. Victim of World Trade Center disaster. Memorial Service Saint Dominic's R.C. Church, Anstice St., Oyster Bay, L.I. Thursday, Sept 20th, 12PM. Beloved son of Linda and Jim Slattery, brother of Daniel and Erin, uncle of Conor and Devon. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund, N.Y. Firefighters 9-11 Disaster Relief Fund or September 11 Fund (United Way).

title: Attacks and Harassment Continue on Middle Eastern People and Mosques
description: A continuing wave of attacks yesterday on Muslims, Sikhs and others who appear to be Middle Eastern brought condemnation from President Bush and murder charges against an Arizona man accused in a weekend shooting that has been deemed a hate killing.

title: Parties, Love Notes and Other Small Memories That Now Loom Large
description: The official number of deaths in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood yesterday at 201, and the medical examiner has identified only a few dozen victims; almost 5,000 are listed as missing. Those glimpsed on this page include six who have been confirmed dead: Bill Biggart, Pamela J. Boyce, Timothy Haskell, Joseph Lovero, Daniel W. McNeal and Yamel Merino.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?; The Giuliani Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ALVIN
description: SCHWARTZ-Alvin. United Cerebral Palsy of New York City notes with sadness the passing of our longtime friend and supporter, Alvin Schwartz. Our deep condolences to his children Tommy, Jane and Amy and the entire Schwartz family. Leo Hausman, Chairman Martin C. Hausman, President

title: Bad Numbers Still Felt Good On a Day Unlike Any Other
description: Never before has a day in which the stock market tumbled so far seemed like a good day. But yesterday was a day unlike any other. The losses were smaller than many had expected, and they reflected a surge of buying by ordinary Americans, who were evidently convinced that it was patriotic to be bullish.

title: Fashion Wonders What It Will Look Like Now
description: On Thursday morning Alexandra Hamilton, a fashion industry publicist, ascended a set of subway stairs at Times Square to return, begrudgingly, to her job on Seventh Avenue. Like so many New Yorkers whose work could provide no immediate contribution to the relief effort, the questions on her mind were existential: How can I do what I do? What does it matter? How, she wondered, would anyone be able to sit blithely at a fashion show ever again?

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Pastor's Trial Postponed
description: The genocide trial of a Rwandan pastor and his son was postponed because the attack on the World Trade Center had held up the flight of one of the lead defense lawyers in the case, officials at the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda said. Ramsey Clark, who is representing the Rev. Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, was delayed in reaching the tribunal in Tanzania. Officials said they intended to begin the proceedings today, a day late, bringing to 17 the number of people on trial. Mr. Ntakirutimana, a retired Seventh-day Adventist pastor, and his son, Gerard, a church doctor, are accused of organizing the killing of members of their congregation in April 1994.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Engineers Tackle Havoc Underground
description: On Friday afternoon in Midtown Manhattan, George J. Tamaro, professional engineer, was holding court among conference tables stacked with blueprints dense with threadlike lines. He was trying to resurrect what had suddenly become a ghost world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTADT, BETTY
description: EISENSTADT-Betty. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, dear mother of Marvin and Barbara, Gladys, Ira and Deirdre Howley, Ellen and Herbert Cohen, cherished grandmother and loving great-grandmother. Service Thursday September 20, 10am. ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn NY (opposite Kings Plaza). Donations can be made to The Maimonides Research and Development Foundation, 4802 10th Ave, Brooklyn NY 11219.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Sections
description: News of the terror attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B. The Metro Report begins on Page A24 and SportsTuesday on C15. Section D does not appear today.

title: There's Little Sign of Panic In Firm's Hot-Stove League
description: Like clockwork, Gene Morgan arrived at 10 a.m. today at the main branch of Charles Schwab to hash over the stock market with a group of fellow retirees. Mr. Morgan, 80, a retired lawyer, wore his characteristic pinstriped suit, and he said it was precisely days like these that reinforced the importance of dressing well, even when just hanging out with friends.

title: Rabbis Revise Sermons To Soften a Stark Prayer
description: Each Jewish New Year brings the recital of a centuries-old prayer that says: on Rosh Hashana, it is written who shall live and who shall die; who shall see ripe old age and who shall not; who shall perish by fire and who by water. Repentance, prayer and charity can avert, or temper, judgment's severe decree, the prayer concludes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, IAN
description: SCHNEIDER-Ian. 45, Senior Managing Director of Cantor Fitzgerald, died September 11 in the World Trade Center tragedy. Beloved husband of Cheryl Fisher Schneider, dear father of Rachel, Jake, and Sophie Schneider. Son of Teresa Schneider and the late Nathan ''Nat'' Schneider. Son-inlaw of Reggie and Dr. Robert Fisher. Brother of Joel (Mary Jo) Schneider, and George (Pam) Schneider. Brother-in-law of Cathy Gurvis Felsenthal and Allen Felsenthal, Brian and Gaby Fisher, Kevin and Jennifer Fisher. Adoring uncle of Christine and Drew Ian Schneider, Sam Felsenthal and Jenna Felsenthal. Grandson of Anna Curtis and Bessie Fisher. Also survived by the Detroit Hermelins, Orleys, Curtis, and Weinberg families, and the Kogans from San Francisco. Services were held Sunday at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel, South Orange, NJ. Memorial contributions to the Ian Schneider Foundation at Jewish Community Foundation of Metro West, 901 Route 10, Whippany, NJ, 07981-1156.

title: Blair and Chirac Head to U.S. For Talks and a Show of Unity
description: As some European allies began to express caution about the administration's plans for military action, the leaders of France and Britain were preparing to arrive here this week to show solidarity and discuss with President Bush their contributions to a coalition against terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASKWITH, MIMI
description: ASKWITH-Mimi. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of its esteemed founding member. We extend deepst sympathy to her husband Bert, her children Dennis, Jeff, Patricia, Kathy and to the entire family. Alfredo F. Borodowski, Rabbi Bernard Dienstag, Cantor Sarah A. Zemel, Hazzan Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Emeritus Katherine Teich, President Steven Chill, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOUT, TIMOTHY C.
description: STOUT-Timothy C., 42. Of Dobbs Ferry, NY on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Tim was born in Boston on August 19, 1959. Devoted husband to Maryellen (nee Fanelli), loving father of Timothy Jr., 6, Matthew, 5, and Shannon, 4. Cherished son of Thomas and Elinor Stout, caring brother of Caroline Duncan and Jordan Stout. Mass Friday 9:30 AM Sacred Heart Church, Dobbs Ferry. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 79 PM, Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to Twin Towers Fund, P.O. Box 26999, New York, NY 10087-6999 benefiting the families of policemen, firemen and emergency service personnel who gave their lives to save others.

title: Wall Street Returns
description: If any further evidence were needed that America has entered a strange new era, it was the fact that many stock market experts felt it was reasonably good news when the Dow Jones industrial average dropped only 685 points yesterday.

title: Text: Rudolph Giuliani's Speech
description: Following is the text of a news conference by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani In New York today, as recorded by The New York Times :

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, THOMAS J.
description: COLLINS-Thomas J. Age 36, of NYC, formerly of Dix Hills, NY. Tragically in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Julia, loving son of Thomas and Dorothy, dear brother of Colleen Campbell, Timothy Collins, and Jennifer Hamel. Visitation at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington NY. Visiting hours today, 2-5pm and 7-9pm with Mass of Resurrection, Wednesday, 10:45 at St. Patrick's Church, Huntington NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Thomas Collins Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 80, Huntington NY 11743.

title: While a Nation Mourned, the Band Played On at Some Tracks
description: He was talking about a sprinter he trains named Peeping Tom -- how lately he had lacked enthusiasm for his morning workouts -- but it took barely a sentence yesterday for Patrick Reynolds to mention the ineffable malaise of his own. He can fortunately call his connection to the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center last week an ''almost tragedy.''

title: Foreign Affairs; The Big Terrible
description: By quirk of fate I have been in Jordan for much of the World Trade Center crisis. Sitting here, I've been struck by the number of e-mails that have reached me from friends around the Arab-Muslim world -- from Kuwait and Cairo, from Lebanon and Turkey -- all just wanting to say how upset they were with what happened and checking if the family was O.K. In their own way, they each echoed what a secretary in Jordan tried to say to me in the most eloquent broken English -- that this terrorist attack was ''the big terrible.''

title: Unified State Legislators Pass Tougher Antiterrorism Bills
