description: The State Legislature approved a package of new antiterrorism measures today that would have had no chance politically two weeks ago, but proved to be unstoppable in the wartime atmosphere enveloping New York after the attacks last Tuesday.

title: Americans Are Ousted From Tourney
description: The United States under-17 men's national team had boasted of never having allowed more than two goals in international games and of having allowed only 25 goals in 18 games. All that changed in Sunday night's 5-3 loss to France in the FIFA under-17 world youth championship in Bacolet, Tobago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDER, MORRIS T. (TEDDY)
description: GOLDER-Morris T. (Teddy). On September 11, 2001, in Florida. Graduate of NYU and Captain in the US Army. Chancellor of Knights of Pythias. President and owner of T.P. Industries. He was loved and cherished by his family. He is survived by his beloved wife Louise, children Bennett, Mark and Betsy; grandchildren, who loved him so much, Bradley, Bennett, Michael and Lindsey. Funeral was held.

title: FASHION
description: For most of the fashion world, it is not, and will not be, business as usual, as it looks ahead to London, Paris and Milan. With the cancellation of the New York shows, a few houses had private showings yesterday, including Calvin Klein. Page 8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, ARCHIBALD R.
description: MURRAY-Archibald R. The Association of the Bar of the City of New York is deeply saddened by the passing of Archibald R. Murray. Arch served on the Association's Executive Committee from 1978 to 1983, and was its Chair from 1981 to 1982. Arch also served as President of the New York State Bar Association from 1993 until 1994. Arch was a fighter for access to justice, most notably during his tenure as Attorney-inChief and Executive Director of The Legal Aid Society. With great pride, the Association voted in early September to confer its Association Medal to Arch. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Kay Murray.

title: U.S. Widens Power to Detain Immigrants in Emergencies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Bush administration today announced a major expansion of its power to detain immigrants suspected of crimes, including new rules prompted by last week's terrorist attacks that would allow legal immigrants to be detained indefinitely during a national emergency.

title: Group Struggling to Shed Association With Terrorism
description: Aziz Omar and his family began fleeing Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, when the Soviets invaded in 1979, eventually settling in this modest suburb about 45 miles southeast of San Francisco. They found themselves among other middle-class, politically moderate refugees who were re-establishing themselves in what has become the largest Afghan enclave in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERRY, DOUGLAS MACMILLAN
description: CHERRY-Douglas MacMillan 38, tragically lost September 11 at the World Trade Center. Husband of Sarah, awesome father of Emma, Isabel and Jack. Son of Douglas and Anne, brother of Meg Smith and Barbara Schenck. Brother-inlaw of Drew Smith. Bill Schenck and Burns and Ruth Patterson. Uncle of Barbara, Kevin and Mollly Smith, Sarah and Alex Briggs and Amanda and Robert Patterson. Son-in-law of Remington and Duane Patterson. Loved beyond measure by family and friends alike, he graduated from Mariemont High School, Cincinnati, Ohio and Ohio Wesleyan University and was Vice President, Professional Services Group at AON. Memorial Service to be held on Thursday, September 20 at 11:00 AM at Morrow Memorial United Methodist Church, 600 Ridgewood Rd, Maplewood, NJ. Donations may be made to Cherry Children Fund, P.O. Box 222, Maplewood, NJ 07040. For information Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn, Maplewood, NJ 07040

title: World Briefing | Africa: Namibia: Regional Meeting On Land Problems
description: Senior officials from nine southern African nations opened talks in Namibia's capital, Windhoek, on ways to deal with the inequity of land distribution in their countries, a problem that has stirred violence and tension in Zimbabwe for months. In Zimbabwe and in some other countries like Namibia and South Africa much of the fertile land is owned by the small white populations, a legacy of colonial and white minority rule. In Zimbabwe, the problem has helped fuel the country's political and economic turmoil, and neighboring countries are eager to avoid such trouble. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRWIN, GLENN
description: KIRWIN-Glenn. Taken from us suddenly on September 11, 2001, in the World Trade Center tragedy. He was a loving husband to Joan, a wonderful father to Miles and Troy, a cherished son of Barbara and Paul, an adored brother of Jon, Peter, Andrew, Daniel and Jennifer, a devoted son-in-law to Sara Oyster and G. Stewart and Jan Boswell, a treasured brotherin-law to Bernadette and Romy Kirwin, Stewart M. and Gay Bos well, and Margaret Surbaugh, a beloved uncle to Brooke Kirwin, Sara and Katherine Surbaugh, James, Saxon and Lucy Boswell and friend to many. Glenn was a Partner at Cantor Fitzgerald, and a Senior-Vice President of eSpeed. He was the light in our lives and he will always be in our hearts. A me morial service was held on Monday, September 17, 2001, at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck, Rd., Scarsdale, NY. Donations may be made to The Cantor Fitzgerald Foundation, 101 Park Ave., 45th Floor, NY, NY 10178-0060, Attn: Phil Ginsberg or the Macular De generation Foundation, P.O. box 8752, San Jose, CA 95157.

title: Bin Laden Is Wanted in Attacks, 'Dead or Alive,' President Says
description: President Bush declared at the Pentagon this morning that he wanted Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect in last week's terrorist strikes, brought to justice, and he pointedly recalled the frontier posters urging the capture of criminals ''dead or alive.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUDINA, RICHARD JOSEPH
description: CUDINA-Richard Joseph. 46, of Glen Gardner, NJ, formerly of Secaucus, NJ, on Tuesday, September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Georgia (nee Sedelmeyer). Dear brother of William, his wife Anita; Marcus, his wife Madeleine; and Christopher, his wife Mary. Caring uncle of Melissa, Erica, Barbara and Bertram Richter; Marcus, Christen, Brian, Colin, and various other nieces and nephews in Ohio. Numerous cousins and extended family from Dorset, England also survived. Funeral Mass to be celebrated at St. John the Baptist R.C. Church, Fairview, NJ, 9 AM, Saturday. Visiting hours Friday, September 21, 1-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Red Cross NY Relief Fund, PO Box 97089, Washington, DC 20013, or The Salvation Army, PO Box C635, West Nyack, NY 10994-1739 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Relatives of Missing Find a Place for Their Comfort
description: Virtually overnight, the New York City government has put together a family center for relatives of people missing in the terror attack on the World Trade Center that veteran disaster workers say transcends anything they have ever seen.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Sabena At The Edge
description: The Belgian airline Sabena may be knocked into bankruptcy by last week's attacks on the United States, the airline's chairman, Fred Chaffart, said. Mr. Chaffart said reservations were drying up and fuel, insurance and other costs were climbing fast. The airline, which has not made a profit in nearly two decades, is embroiled in a fight with its unions over a proposed $399 million bailout plan that calls for eliminating 1,600 jobs. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Catholic Leader in Northern Ireland Resigns Party Post
description: John Hume, a leader of the Catholic civil rights movement in Northern Ireland for the last 40 years and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, announced today in Belfast that he was stepping down as head of the province's Social Democratic and Labor Party.

title: After a War Starts at Home, the Guard Prepares to Take It Abroad
description: Lt. Col. Mario T. Castagliola sat on a park bench in the mottled shade of Hope Garden park yesterday, inside the perimeter of the World Trade Center security area. He was clean-shaven and intent in camouflage fatigues, but he smoked one cigarette after another, right down to the filter, and his right knee bounced uncontrollably as he spoke. He noticed the jumpy knee, ground the filter into fluff and dared the suggestion of a smile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEGENDY, ANN (ANIKO)
description: LEGENDY-Ann (Aniko). Age 92. Peacefully died September 16. For many years we loved her very much; now we will miss her.

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from September 18.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?; Faithful, Not Radical
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDINER, ELMER
description: BENDINER-Elmer. We mourn the death of author-journalist, Elmer Bendiner. Elmer died peacefully in his sleep on the morning of September 16, 2001. He will be missed by all those who knew his keen wit, his modesty and his intelligence. Elmer Bendiner's memory is cherished by his many friends and his devoted family, which includes Esther, his wife of 60 years, his brother Robert, daughters Winnie and Jessica, son-in-law Paul, grandson-in-law Kaushik and his granddaughter Gabrielle. A memorial tribute will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURR, BARRY D.
description: BURR-Barry D., Washington Depot, CT-of Juniper Meadow Road, died Saturday in Litchfield, CT. He was the husband of Jean ''Jammy'' Burr. Memorial service Saturday, September 29 at 11:00 AM at St. John's Episcopal Church, Washington Green, CT

title: East Timor Lures Experts In Helping New Nations
description: They are the new missionaries. Steeped in the values of democracy, human rights and the rule of law, they travel from one emerging nation to another to share their gospel.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stalwart Tries to Keep Things in Perspective
description: By early afternoon yesterday Bill McLaughlin, head of block trading at Bear Stearns, was worried. The stock market, which had fallen, and then rallied, was plummeting again. Such a pattern, according to people who chart stock movements, often portends continuing declines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRU, GEORGINA, ANN D.
description: BRU-Georgina-Ann D. 56, of Woodstock, VT, died Friday after a long battle with breast cancer. Graduate of Columbia University and former Director of Nursing at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Moved to VT in 1991 and had been the Director of Nursing at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, NH. Survived by mother, Dorothea Bru, Wilder, VT; brother Ronald of Nashua, NH; sister, Elizabeth Patricia Bru of Santa Rosa, CA, one nephew and cousins. Memorial service Saturday, 2 PM, in chapel at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Lebanon, NH. Memorial donations to Children's Hospital at Dartmouth, c/o DHMC, One Medical Center Dr., Lebanon, NH 03756

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telecom Spending
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest telephone company, said it might cut its capital expenditure budget to stop its debt from increasing further, though it did not specify how much the budget might be reduced. A budget cut ''is only a possibility,'' a Deutsche Telekom spokesman, Hans Ehnert, said, confirming comments by the chief executive, Ron Sommer, above, in an interview with Financial Times Deutschland. Deutsche Telekom has also been selling assets as it seeks to trim debt.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Judge Backs Bridge Funding
description: A county judge refused the request of a citizens group to stop state financing for a second bridge at the Tacoma Narrows in Puget Sound. In January, the Peninsula Neighborhood Association had asked the judge, Richard Strophy of Superior Court, for an injunction to block the second bridge, which would connect Tacoma and Gig Harbor. In 2000, the State Supreme Court ruled that an agreement between the Department of Transportation and United Infrastructure Washington to build the bridge violated state law because it mandated new tolls, which are the dominion of the State Transportation Commission. The Legislature adjourned its 2001 session in a stalemate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMANN, AUDREY M.
description: HARTMANN-Audrey M. Beloved wife of Peter W. Loving mother of Karin, Christiane and Anton. Grandmother of ten and good friend of many. Died on Sunday September 16, 2001 at Lawrence Hospital. She is survived by her five siblings. Visiting hours are at the The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St, Bronxville, N.Y. on Thursday, September 20 from 5 to 8PM. Services are on Friday, September 21 at Christ Church, 17 Sagamore Rd, Bronxville, N.Y. at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be sent to either the Metroplitan Opera Association, Inc, Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023 or Christ Church, in memory of Audrey M. Hartmann.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Decision Due on Braves Series
description: The Mets will decide on Tuesday where they will play this weekend's series with the Atlanta Braves. The three-game series, which starts Friday, is scheduled for Shea Stadium. But with much of Shea's parking lot being used to load and unload relief supplies for Manhattan, the games may be shifted to Turner Field in Atlanta.

title: They Had Everything They Needed, Except Survivors to Treat
description: Two hours after the World Trade Center collapsed last Tuesday, Bellevue Hospital, New York's premier public hospital, was running in full disaster mode.

title: Making Planes Safer By Making Fuels Safer
description: Crashed jets do not as a rule explode. They burn. And that, scientists say, raises the possibility that advanced fuels may one day make commercial planes safer, less likely to flare with the intensity of the jets that slammed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: A Newly Cleaved View of the City
description: Uptown on Sunday, Lincoln Center bustled with a performance of ''The Magic Flute,'' and the cafes were packed and the shops crowded. Downtown, outside Da Silvano restaurant in Greenwich Village, diners stopped and nervously stared as motorcade after motorcade of police cars, ambulances, construction trucks and Humvees, many with lights flashing and sirens wailing, passed repeatedly through the night.

title: Lenders Cancel
description: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank formally canceled their annual meetings today, citing security concerns about an event that attracts many financial ministers and heads of government to Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, JUDITH
description: GREEN-Judith. We mourn the loss of a cherished friend, a best selling author whose wit and joy of life enriched the lives of all who knew and loved her. Our condolences to her daughter Christina, son Nicholas, and family Martin Richards, Sam Crothers and the Producer Circle

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, DOUGLAS B.
description: GARDNER-Douglas B. It is with profound sadness and a sense of utter despair that the Educational Alliance notes the tragic and unconscionable loss of our Trustee, Douglas Gardner, on September 11, 2001. Doug supported the Alliance's annual benefits and fundraising events and sports programs for our City's teams. We offer solace and sympathy to his loving family. Richard A. Cantor, President Robin Bernstein, Exec. Dir.

title: In the Shadow of Wall Street, Merchants Look for Assistance
description: They may work in the shadow of Wall Street's office towers, but most of the 375,000 or so people who commute every morning to the financial district are not high-paid stockbrokers. They are florists and jewelers, card-shop owners and newsstand workers, clothing-store clerks and shoe-repair men.

title: Familiar Voice Lifts the Market Before the Bell
description: Rose-Ann Sgrignoli, 39, a major in the Marine Corps, sang yesterday morning for the third time before the New York Stock Exchange trading room.

title: Fits and Starts as Companies Strain to Restore a Sense of Normalcy
description: Prayer sessions gave way to paperwork. Memorial services were replaced by the Monday morning meeting. Sputtering at times but managing not to stall, America's corporate machinery began to whir again yesterday.

title: A New Feeling for Bonds, Municipal and Human
description: PAM DOWER, municipal bond broker, has never considered her job particularly meaningful.

title: Pushing Quality of Life Until the End
description: On the wall of her office at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York, Prof. Christine Cassel, 55, has hung an impressionistic still life that a friend painted shortly before dying. ''I keep it there,'' Dr. Cassel said recently, ''to remind myself of all the valiant attempts people make to find meaning at the end of their lives.''

title: Some Airlines Searching Every Piece of Baggage : In Airports, Long Delays At Check-In
description: PARIS  As governments around the world tightened security at airports on Monday, passengers found a radically changed world to the one that existed one week ago.

title: Worn Spacecraft Takes On Another Challenge, Comet Borrelly
description: An aging and battered spacecraft, pushed though space by a unique ion drive engine, will attempt to beat long odds later this week by flying close to the heart of a large comet.

title: Afghanistan, for Ages an Affliction to Mighty Empires, Is Not Easily Subdued
description: Afghanistan, a poor and landlocked country, appears to be positioned for another round of what 19th-century imperialists called the Great Game, the battle for influence by outsiders, once mostly the Russians and the British, over a defiant land that a British viceroy once called a poisoned chalice.

title: Partner Pulls Out Of Yankee Cable Deal
description: Less than a week after agreeing to invest $150 million in YES, the Yankees Entertainment and Sports network, Quadrangle Group pulled out over the weekend.

title: Airline Industry Confident About Proposed Bailout Plan
description: The White House and Congressional leaders vowed today to move quickly on a multibillion-dollar emergency aid package for the airline industry, which has reported a disastrous drop in passenger traffic after last week's terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DERECSKEY, CHARLES G.
description: DERECSKEY-Charles G., 75 of Elizabethtown and Washington, DC, died Saturday, September 15, in Plattsburgh, NY. A graveside mass will be held Wednesday, September 19, at Norton Cemetery in Keene, NY, at 11 AM.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: General Mills Profit Climbs 18%
description: General Mills, which makes Cheerios and Wheaties cereals, said today that its first-quarter profit rose 18 percent as the company sold more yogurt and snacks.

title: City Celebrates Its Heroes, and Grieves Over Their Loss
description: They wore dress blues and full gear. Brothers, sons, sisters, daughters, fathers, mothers, friends, strangers to the more than 300 firefighters, police officers and other emergency workers the city said were lost in the wreckage of the World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPLIK, PERRY H.
description: KOPLIK-Perry H. We will always remember the great times we had together. Gladys and Eddie

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?; True Patriotism
description: To the Editor:

title: WALL ST. REOPENS SIX DAYS AFTER SHUTDOWN; STOCKS SLIDE 7%, BUT INVESTORS RESIST PANIC
description: The stock market survived the first day of trading in six days with significant losses but without a disastrous plunge yesterday. Stock prices plummeted seconds after the opening bell but never succumbed to the frenzied selling that government and business leaders had worked hard to avoid.

title: Rescuers See Hope in Trip Into the Dark Of a Tunnel
description: Capt. Nicholas Gaudiosi of Ladder Companies 7 and 14 and other firefighters stood on West Street collecting lights, tools, a carbon monoxide detector and heavy ropes. They were about to climb into a PATH train tunnel that lead beneath the rubble of the World Trade Center.

title: Inventories Fell in July; Sales Gained
description: Inventories of unsold goods at United States companies fell in July for a sixth consecutive month and sales increased before last week's terrorist attacks, which slowed business, the government reported today.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Vietnam: Accusations Of Crackdown
description: Religious and human rights groups have accused Vietnam of starting a new crackdown on critics of the Communist Party and on Buddhists. The New York-based group Human Rights Watch said more than a dozen political dissidents were interrogated in what it called the severest pressure in years. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOCHBERG, CAROL ELAINE
description: HOCHBERG-Carol Elaine. September 16, 1998. We are late. We are sorry. We were distracted. One more year has passed. But not a day goes by when we don't think of you. You taught us how to lead our lives. We give to others as you gave to us. And for that we love you. And we will never forget you. Scott H. Cooper and Family Michael Kriner & Aileen Greenberg-Kriner & Family Donald & Ione Spear & Family

title: American Express and Citigroup Expect Earnings to Be Hurt
description: Two financial services companies said yesterday that the terrorist attacks last week on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon would significantly reduce earnings and would cost them millions of dollars.

title: Patriotism Does Not Erase the Trepidation
description: A couple of hours before he got into the batter's box and the game came back, Matt Lawton, the Mets' leadoff hitter, acknowledged he would not feel completely safe. The terror of last Tuesday would be with him, even on the field.

title: Flags, Songs and Tears, And Heightened Security
description: There were American flags on the backs of uniform jerseys, flags on baseball caps and batting helmets, and flags fluttering throughout the stands. There were moments of silence and renditions of ''God Bless America.'' There were tears, there was relief, there were unexplainable feelings and, once again, there was baseball.

title: On Doomed Flight, Passengers Vowed to Perish Fighting
description: They told the people they loved that they would die fighting.

title: A Reality Show for Your Desktop, but There's a Catch
description: Mark Daggett doesn't need Napster. A disc-jockey brother sends him music files, giving him scant incentive to scour the Internet for others. But Mr. Daggett is quite familiar with the virtues and vices of online file-sharing services. So rather than using Napster or one of its imitators, he has created a software program that demonstrates their perils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIGH, RICHARD HARTMAN
description: HAIGH-Richard Hartman of Falmouth, MA September 15, age 87. Beloved husband of Cynthia Eldred Haigh, and of the late Isabel Emery Haigh. He is also survived by his first wife Elin Anderson Neumann of Yarmouth, MA. Father of Deborah H. Dluhy and her husband Robert of Belmont, MA, Douglas E. Haigh and his wife Sandra Moreno of Santa Monica, CA, Jessica V. Haigh of Westwood, MA, Alan L. Haigh and his wife Alison Smith of Brookline, MA, Alison V. Zaino and her husband Boniface of New York, NY. Stepfather of Jeffrey R. Davis of Harwich, MA and Christopher E. Davis of Falmouth, MA. Grandfather of five grandchildren: Leonore A. Dluhy of Los Angeles, CA, Evan M. and Charlotte E. Haigh of Santa Monica, CA, Sylvia V. Haigh of Brookline, Isabel Rose Zaino of New York, NY. Step grandfather of Jennifer R. Davis of Falmouth, MA. Burial private. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORELL, GEORGE WILLIAM
description: MORELL-George William. 47, of Mt. Kisco, NY was lost in the tragedy at the World Trade Center where he was a Partner and VicePresident in the Mortgage Department of Cantor Fitzgerald. Beloved husband of Robbie (nee Novak); loving father of Nancy Jeanne, George, Jr., Kelsey Jane and Harrison; cherished brother of Rita Shea, Anthony Morell, Mary Jane Haggerty, Catherine Raddatz, Gaspar (Jay) Morell and Mark Morell. He was a member of the Westchester Country Club, the Downtown Athletic Club and Mashomac Fish and Game Preserve, and was active in numerous community and other activities. A tribute will be held on Wednesday, September 19 from 3:00 to 5:30 PM at the Bedford Historical Hall, followed by a memorial candlelight mass at St. Patrick's Church at 6:00 PM. The Hall and Church are located on Route 22 in Bedord, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the George Morell Memorial Fund.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I want him -- I want justice. And there's an old poster out West, as I recall that said: 'Wanted: Dead or Alive.' ''

title: A Rift Over Rio Grande Water Rights
description: After one of the driest summers on record along the border here in South Texas, tensions are growing between local farmers and Mexico over water rights to the Rio Grande.

title: Pentagon Activates First Wave of Guardsmen and Reservists
description: The Pentagon began activating thousands of National Guard and Reserve troops across the nation today, as military commanders briefed President Bush on plans for the mobilization he called ''a strong symbol of this nation's resolve.''

title: Tie to bin Laden Aide
description: Investigators are examining a link between two hijackers who attacked the World Trade Center and a former Boston cab driver who is on trial for a foiled plot to kill Americans in Jordan on Jan. 1, 2000. The three shared a relationship with a suspected operative for Osama bin Laden.

title: Returning to the Office On the First Monday Since the City Changed
description: The subway trains were running downtown again yesterday. The Staten Island Ferry crisscrossed the harbor. The mayor reoccupied City Hall. But on this sunny late summer day when tens of thousands of workers returned to their Lower Manhattan offices for the first time since the World Trade Center attack, little, in fact, was normal.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Candidate For Superfund
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has proposed adding the century-old Curtis Bay Coast Guard Yard to the Superfund cleanup list. The 113-acre site, just southeast of Baltimore in Anne Arundel County, is contaminated with chemicals dating to its use in shipbuilding during the first half of the 20th century. The Superfund National Priorities List consists of sites where contaminants have harmed or could harm public health or the environment. The E.P.A. set a 60-day comment period on the proposal. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOECHELER, GARY EDWARD
description: KOECHELER-Gary Edward. Loving husband of Maureen, devoted father of John and Paul, beloved son of Monica and the late Edward Koecheler. Brother to Gene Koecheler, Mary Jo Heine and Judith Schneider. Memorial mass at 3 p.m. Friday, Sept. 21, 2001 at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY. Contributions in Gary's memory may be made to Maryknoll Mission, 10 Pinesbridge Rd, Ossining, NY 10562

title: Dead and Missing
World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pirelli Strategy
description: Europe's biggest cable maker, Pirelli, gave Italy's two largest banks veto power over strategy in return for aid in financing the purchase of control of the dominant phone company, Olivetti. Pirelli gave the two banks, IntesaBci and UniCredito Italiano, the right to sell back stakes in Olivetti if they did not approve of Pirelli's takeover of the company and its units. In July, Pirelli united with the Benetton family to buy 27 percent of Olivetti. Pirelli is awaiting a European Union antitrust ruling. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRASER, GLEN ROBERT
description: FRASER-Glen Robert. December 1, 1970. Deceased September 18, 1999. You're forever in our hearts and prayers. Rest in peace. With love, the family of Jim Fraser. God Bless America.

title: Big Insurance Brokers Need Help After Trade Center Blast
description: Two days after escaping from the 92nd floor of 2 World Trade Center, Brian Cohen, who works for one of the world's largest insurance brokers, was on the phone to a big client, J. C. Penney, in Plano, Tex.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEVALIER, SWEDE JOSEPH
description: CHEVALIER-Swede Joseph. 26, of Locust, NJ, an equities trader at Cantor Fitzgerald, died September 11 at World Trade Center. Graduate of Cornell University, 1998, The Peddie School, Christian Brothers' Academy, Rumson Country Day School. Member of Phi Delta Theta and Sphinx Head Honorary. Visitation will be held Wednesday, September 19, 7 PM, at St. Mary's Catholic Church, Colts Neck, NJ and a funeral mass will follow on Thursday at 9 AM. Contributions may be made in his memory to Cornell University, Attn: L. Robinson, 55 Brown Road, Ithaca, NY 14850

title: G.M. Agrees to Buy Part of Daewoo Motor
description: General Motors has reached an agreement to buy most of the Daewoo Motor Company from Daewoo's creditors for about $1 billion, but leave the most troublesome parts on the creditors' hands, at least for now, people in the industry said.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Nikki Oden, Diana Scott, Murrells Inlet, S.C., July 18, 2001

title: Measure Backing Bush's Use of Force Is as Broad as a Declaration of War, Experts Say
description: The resolution passed by Congress authorizing President Bush to use force in response to last Tuesday's terror attacks is nearly as wide-ranging as a declaration of war, some legal analysts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAUBART, ALEXANDER, RABBI
description: GRAUBART-Alexander, Rabbi. We mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. He served pulpits in California and Chicago and as vice president of the University of Judaism in Los Angeles. For the past nine years, he was the chaplain at Evanston Hospital in the Chicago area. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Jean, sister Judy, children Amy Katz, Beth, Jonathan, Hadara, Eytan and our colleague Rabbi Philip Graubart and to all who were touched through this rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: F.B.I. Says More Warrants Issued
description: Barry Mawn, the assistant director of the F.B.I.'s New York office, said today that more warrants had been issued for material witnesses in last week's terror attacks. Investigators had said Sunday that two of the warrants, which are used to detain people who might have significant information about a possible crime, had been issued and that three more were being prepared.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: UNDERGROUND ASSESSMENT -- Engineers are helping the city assess conditions in the basement of the World Trade Center, providing officials with detailed information so that wreckage can be removed safely. SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1

title: Imam Had Unusual Visit At Mosque Before Attacks
description: Two days before last week's terrorist attacks, a Muslim cleric suspected of ties to the Osama bin Laden organization led prayers at a Texas mosque at which he had agreed not to preach because of the controversy surrounding him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, FRANCIS E.
description: DONNELLY-Francis E. Psychotherapist, writer and a founder of The Studio Museum in Harlem died peacefully in his sleep Thursday, September 13. He is survived by his companion of 24 years, Michael Kahn; his beloved niece Meg Lucas and her partner Barbi Schreiber; his dear friend Martin Skea and his partner Kelly Gryder and the hundreds of friends and clients who he has guided, helped and loved. He spent his last two days volunteering as a grief counselor in the wake of Tuesday's attack. It is expected that the February production of his play, ''Two Little Indians,'' will go ahead as planned. A celebration of his life will be announced in the near future.

title: Trying to Play the Angles In a Tragedy's Aftermath
description: To Steven Goldstein, it was the most obscene kind of opportunism.

description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Reopens, And Share Prices Fall

title: U.S. Looks to Help Airlines Left Reeling After Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The Bush administration began preparing a relief package for the airline industry today as the government continued to marshal support for a campaign to hunt down the terrorists behind last week's attacks.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: From Dust to Red Tide

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: After 120 Years, Puffins Are at Home Off Maine Coast
description: Since 1973, Dr. Stephen W. Kress has done whatever it took to persuade puffins to put down roots once again on Eastern Egg Rock, an 11-acre island off the mid-Maine coast in Muscongus Bay. He stocked the island with chicks and decoy puffins to make them feel at home, and then cleared out the hungry gulls. Now he can declare victory.

title: Feeling the American Aftershock
description: After months of economic crisis had given way to a few weeks of relative calm, last Tuesday's terrorist attacks on the United States threaten to send South America's two largest economies, Argentina and Brazil, into a steep downward spiral.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, HERMAN S.
description: SANDLER-Herman S. American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra's Board of Directors and staff and the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra-mourn the loss of our esteemed Board President, Herman S. Sandler whose life was lost in the attack on the World Trade Center. His consummate leadership, vision for the future and total commitment to the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra and the State of Israel will always be missed. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Suki; his daughters Pamela, Jordana, Gillian; his mother, and all the family. We cannot begin to describe the sadness of his loss. Herman was the inspiration and leader of the AFIPO family, our friend, who believed that the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra's role as a cultural ambassador would lead to world peace and understanding. On this Rosh Hashanah and in the years to come we shall remember Herman and his great contribution to us and to the world. Zubin Mehta IPO Music Director for Life and Board Co-Chairman Itzhak Perlman AFIPO Board Co-Chairman Albert Schussler President Emeritus Charles I. Petschek Lynn Syms Elaine Wolfensohn Vice Presidents Suzanne K. Ponsot Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, HAROLD M., SR.
description: MILLS-Harold M., Sr. On September 16. Cherished father of Nancy L. Fardelmann and Margaret M. Michael. Loving grandfather of Robert M. Becker, William N. Becker, John O. Becker and Alexandra M. Michael. Also four great grandchidren. Funeral service Thursday 1:30 PM, Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Ave., Forest Hills, NY, 718-268-7711. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery. Your love, devotion and integrity will forever be in our hearts and memories.

title: Sports of The Times; Fans Fly The Colors In Public
description: ONE of the lesser-known aspects of the Declaration of Independence is the unalienable right to cross a golden bridge on a soft late summer night and pay your way into a ballpark and buy a beer and a hot dog -- or a tray of sushi, for that matter -- and take a seat with a great view of an old American city.

title: Op-Art
One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Courts Reopen to Echo of Silence, Instead of Gavels
description: John F. Geida, a Manhattan defense lawyer, spent yesterday morning fumbling around a dark office on Thomas Street looking for case files and phone numbers.

title: During Traumatic Times, Small Acts Can Bring a Measure of Comfort
description: On Wednesday, reeling from the unfathomable tragedy of the previous day, my husband baked bread, cooked comfort food and invited two single friends to supper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLLET, AUDREY B. (AUDREY BROWN, M.D.)
description: BOLLET-Audrey B. (Audrey Brown, M.D.). On September 14, 2001. Beloved wife of Jay, loving mother and mother-in-law of Jeffrey and Laura. Adoring grandmother of Marissa and Jennifer, cherished sister of Joan and Eileen. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St, Port Washington, NY, Monday and Tuesday, 24and 7-9 PM. Mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church. Interment to follow at the Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: Taliban Refuse Quick Decision Over bin Laden
description: Afghanistan rebuffed an American demand relayed today by Pakistan that the Taliban government immediately and unconditionally surrender Osama bin Laden to head off a military showdown, but Afghan leaders set a high-level meeting for Tuesday to make a final decision.

title: Citing Safety and Taste, Groups Cancel Shows and Exhibitions
description: Faced with anxiety in the audience and myriad logistical hurdles, cultural institutions around the city have been forced to cancel and postpone dozens of performances and exhibits because of concerns over safety or subject matter after last week's terrorist attacks.

title: Oracle Sees Sales Off 15% In Key Software Category
description: The Oracle Corporation, the maker of business software, said today that the threat of war could drive sales of its software licenses down 15 percent, a sharper decline than the company had expected before the terrorist attacks last week.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Surprise Strike By Chechen Rebels
description: Rebels in Chechnya surprised Russian troops with their strongest and most coordinated attack in months, downing a helicopter in the capital, Grozny, that carried 10 senior Russian commanders and mounting a sustained attack by at least 300 guerrillas on government offices in the province's second-largest city, Gudermes. The Russian commanders, two generals and eight colonels, had held talks with Chechnya's pro-Russian administration. Their helicopter was shot down with a shoulder-fired missile. In the attack in Gudermes, about 20 miles east of Grozny, at least 10 Russian servicemen and an unknown number of rebels died. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com. As we share in the horror and grief of last Tuesday's attacks, let us be mindful that our government appears to be hurrying to involve us in horrible acts of war that will bring grief and loss to many more innocent people. We must not allow ourselved to be pushed into a protracted and unwinnable war. Retaliation against innocent civilians by bombing any country will only bring more violence down upon us in the short and long term. Now is the time to re-assess the foreign policy of the last decades that has created so much hatred against our country. There is no justification for the acts of last Tuesday, but those acts do not justify the destruction of more innocent lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHA, ANTONIO AUGUSTO (TONY)
description: ROCHA-Antonio Augusto (Tony). Suddenly, on September 11, 2001, of East Hanover, formerly of Kearny, NJ. Beloved husband of Mrs. Marilyn (nee Marques). Devoted son of Augusto Nunes and Mrs. Rosa Correia (nee Tome) Rocha. Dear son-in-law of Manuel and Mrs. Maria (nee Ribeiro) Marques. Loving father of Alyssa Marie Rocha and Ethan Agustus Rocha. Dear brother of Jason Rocha. Relatives and friends are welcomed to attend the funeral on Wednesday, September 19th at 8:30am from the Shaw-Buyus Home for Services 138 Davis Avenue, at Bergen Avenue, Kearny. Thence to the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark, where at 10:00 am the funeral mass will be offered. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ. Visitation Tuesday 2:00 to 4:00 and 7:00 to 9:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Red Cross would be appreciated.

title: Securing the Skies
description: All airports but Washington's Reagan National have reopened in the aftermath of last week's attack, but commercial aviation in the United States has been forever altered. The premium is now on security instead of convenience and speed. That is the only sensible course after hijackers seized control of four passenger planes and turned three of them into weapons of mass destruction.

title: Fred De Cordova, TV Producer, Dies at 90
description: Fred De Cordova, who skipped lightly and most often anonymously among the pinnacles of American show business, most prominently as producer of ''The Tonight Show'' for Johnny Carson, died on Saturday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 90 and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Reaching for Transcendence With a 5-Piece Ensemble
description: Charles Lloyd's music isn't dense with arrangements. In the spirit of mid-1960's Coltrane, which is what it often sounds like, it puts big windows on its own creative process, opening itself up for maximum honesty and sometimes maximum danger. Mr. Lloyd, as a tenor saxophone improviser, has grace in his long, patient strokes, his lines festooned with arpeggios; he has a tenor saxophone tone that's thin, light, gorgeous and rare. What he doesn't have much of is a contingency plan.

title: Both Sides in Mideast Promise a Halt to Violence
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 19  After Yasir Arafat of the Palestinian Authority instructed his security forces today to hold their fire even in self-defense, Israel forswore all offensive action and ordered its troops out of Palestinian-controlled territory, possibly setting the stage for the first truce talks here since midsummer.

title: Barest Count, by Three of Hundreds of Companies, Has 1,500 Missing
description: Rescuers combed mountains of rubble at what had been the World Trade Center today in a grim search for survivors among the thousands presumed dead in its collapse. Investigators meantime cast a worldwide net for those behind the hijackers who slammed jetliners into the twin towers in New York City and the Pentagon in Virginia in the worst terrorist attack in American history.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TANNENBAUM, LONA
description: TANNENBAUM-Lona. Five years later your irreplaceable presence remains palpable, precious and preeminent. A.H.T

title: Ignoring What the Doctor Ordered
description: Many doctors have learned the hard way that just giving prescriptions to patients is no guarantee that the drugs will actually be taken as directed. Now it appears that even reminding the patients makes little difference.

title: Bank of England Joins Others in Cutting Rates to Fight Slump
description: LONDON, Sept. 18  The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter point today, to 4.75 percent, joining other central banks in fighting to keep the global economy from sinking into a deep recession.

title: Of Altruism, Heroism and Evolution's Gifts
description: For the wordless, formless, expectant citizens of tomorrow, here are some postcards of all that matters today:

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoke and the Search for Survivors at Ground Zero
description: The smoke was even more oppressive the second day. By then our triage center had moved closer to ground zero and the search was on for survivors.

title: The industry tries to grapple with the mood of consumers and the direction of the economy.
description: AS Madison Avenue continues to re-evaluate what exactly business as usual may mean after last week, analysts are pondering the short- and long-term effects on advertising related to consumer mood and the direction of the economy.

title: Rome Journal; So Many to Mourn: An Envoy's Sad Baptism
description: Not so long ago, the new United States ambassador to the Holy See, R. James Nicholson, was a regular on the Washington shout shows as chairman of the Republican National Committee. Last year, he was hawking computer mouse pads that mocked Al Gore's comments about his role in inventing the Internet.

title: Berkshire Moves Away From Offer For Bonds
description: Warren E. Buffett backed away from a tender offer yesterday, saying that he was free to do so because the attack on the World Trade Center amounted to a war involving the United States.

title: A Show of Pride as the Everyday Routine Resumes
description: Four blocks up the street from the New York Stock Exchange, opposite the Federal Reserve Bank, sits 55 Nassau Shoe Repair. At precisely 7:30 a.m., the doors were unlocked and the tiny shop was reopened for business.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Merger Of Drug Makers
description: Japan's biggest maker of over-the-counter drugs, Taisho Pharmaceutical, agreed to buy Tanabe Seiyaku for $2.66 billion in stock, adding a business that will quadruple its prescription drug sales. Tanabe shareholders will get 0.55 share of a new company, to be formed April 1, for each of their shares, the companies said. Taisho's shareholders will get one share for each share they own. The ratio values Tanabe, which developed the high blood pressure drug Cardizem, at 1,290 yen a share, a 10 percent premium over its close Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RYDEN, ALBERT G.
description: RYDEN-Albert G. September 18, 1981. For thy sweet love remembered.

title: Blackburn's Athletic Skills in Net Impress Rangers
description: It is customary in the National Hockey League for a first-round draft choice to appear in at least one preseason game, even though the prospect has no chance to make the opening-night roster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, SHIRLEY
description: LEVINE-Shirley. Dear Shirley, your brothers and sisters mourn your death. Fond rememberances of years spent together will never be forgotton. Bernard and Ruth Rubins, Muriel and Harold Zeveloff, Roberta and Frank Tankowitz, Marilyn and Herman Schwartzman

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: A Booming Economy
description: The government said that the economy is flourishing despite some flooding in the central provinces earlier this year, the state news agency reported. Finance Minister Luisa Diogo said the economy grew 14.9 percent in the first six months of this year compared with the same period in 2000. The growth rate exceeded expectations; officials had predicted a 10 percent increase.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, EDWIN HAVILAND
description: MILLER-Edwin Haviland, Professor Emeritus of English at New York University died September 17th at age 83 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Rosalind, father of Pamela Miller Ness, father-in-law of Paul M. Ness. He was a distinguished scholar of American Literature, publishing numerous biographies and critical studies of Whitman, Melville and Hawthorne. He received a B.A. in English from Lehigh University in 1940, an M.A. from Pennsylvania State University in 1942, and a Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1951. A memorial service is planned for a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Public Library, Berg Collection, 42nd St. & 5th Avenue, New York, NY 10018, or the Allentown Art Museum, 5th and Court St, Allentown, PA 18105.

title: Gifts From the Rich, and Lemonade Stands
description: As charities in New York grapple with the enormous needs of victims of the World Trade Center attack, The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund has received donations or pledges worth nearly $6.5 million.

title: Bin Laden Operative Is Linked To Suspects
description: Federal investigators are examining a possible link between the hijackers who crashed into the World Trade Center and operatives for Osama bin Laden who plotted to kill hundreds of Americans and other tourists in Jordan on Jan. 1, 2000, officials said yesterday.

title: Many Come to Bear Witness at Ground Zero
description: They came yesterday in streams of thousands, from faraway places like South Carolina, England and Italy and nearby ones like Wall Street, Long Island and the Upper West Side. They carried cameras and video equipment, and a mix of emotions about why they felt drawn to this awful place and whether their coming was something shameful or oddly necessary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASESCU, ELINOR
description: BASESCU-Elinor. 74, died of cancer on September 15. Wife of Sabert; mother of Claire, Neil and Maria; mother-in-law of Arthur, Elizabeth and Mary; grandmother of Jacob, Rebecca, Max, Simon, Sophie, Dylan and Alex. She was an amazing, complicated, incredibly warm, generous and greatly cherished human being. Talented actress, teacher, scholar of the theater. A creative life-force extraordinaire. Memorial gathering Sunday, September 23, 1 PM, Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, Saxon Woods Rd, White Plains

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Rifts and Rivalries in England's North Country
description: The Geiger counter that the Mint Theater Company waves over theater history in search of long-unperformed treasures has identified a still-ticking nugget in ''Rutherford and Son.'' A 1911 family melodrama written by a young Englishwoman, Githa Sowerby, the play has the emotional depth, narrative pull and linguistic potency to retain an impact today.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?; The Giuliani Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vow to Rebuild
description: Larry Silverstein said he fulfilled a longstanding dream on July 24 and acquired control of Wall Street's most recognizable address, the World Trade Center. Since last week's terrorist attack, however, Mr. Silverstein has largely kept out of the public eye.

title: All of a Sudden, A Jittery Nation Of Checkpoints
description: With National Guard reservists guarding dams and utilities, Coast Guard cutters holding up normal vessel traffic in major ports and public gatherings shadowed by patrols in the air and bomb-sniffing dogs on the ground, a swell of homeland defense not seen since World War II rose across the nation yesterday in response to last week's terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERSON, JOHN H.G.
description: PIERSON-John H.G., 95, September 15 at home in Lenox, MA. He leaves his beloved wife, the former Harriet-Anne Duell. Born in New York City, son of Charles Wheeler and Elizabeth Groesbeck Pierson. Yale College, 1927. Economist U.S. Government, helped author Employment Act of 1946, which he later strove to strengthen. Worked for U.N., in New York, Asia. In 1960's, planted first of 18,000 trees on Syros, described in his book ''Island in Greece.'' Wrote on modern forms of mysticism-Japanese Zen, Indian Vedanta-as influenced Europe, America. Clubs included Century. Also leaves daughter Elizabeth Pierson Friend of Villanova, PA, son John T.R. Pierson of Cambridge, MA, stepson Robert M. Wood of Escondido, CA, six grandchildren, one great-grandchild. Predeceased by two earlier wives, Gertrude Trumbull Robinson and Sherleigh Elizabeth Glad.

title: Brain Scans Foretell Memory Problems
description: Healthy people over 60 on a course to develop memory problems show distinctive changes in their brains that can be seen with PET scans, even if the people experience no symptoms, a new study reports.

title: Lifesaving Lessons for Heart Patients
description: Doctors like to speak about the medical advances that allow them to save many patients in the first hour after a heart attack.

title: Falwell Apologizes for Saying An Angry God Allowed Attacks
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell apologized last night for saying that last week's terrorist attacks reflected God's judgment on a nation spiritually weakened by the American Civil Liberties Union, providers of abortion, supporters of gay rights and federal court rulings on school prayer.

title: Vodafone Set To Lift Stake In Japanese Phone Giant
description: The Vodafone Group said today that it planned to buy an additional 21.7 percent of Japan Telecom's stock, a purchase that would lift its stake to a controlling two-thirds of the company. It currently owns 45 percent.

title: Dust Is a Problem, but the Risk Seems Small
description: As thousands of workers streamed back into Lower Manhattan yesterday for the first time since the terrorist attacks, federal officials said they faced no significant health risk.

title: Stock Investors Shrug Off a Plunge and Wait
description: As the trading rituals of capitalism re-established themselves yesterday, individual investors watched the sobering saw-toothed lines of the indexes and the ever-tumbling prices, feeling the apprehension of badly shaken markets.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Foreigners Sell Stocks
description: The threat of military action in the region after last week's terrorist attacks has foreign institutional investors cashing out their Indian equity holdings, throwing an already shaky Indian stock market into a steep decline. The benchmark Bombay index fell 5.25 percent yesterday, reaching an eight-year low, and analysts said it would fall further after yesterday's weakness on Wall Street. The value of the Indian rupee also fell. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Moving to Jersey City Until Further Notice
description: From where E. Stanley O'Neal, the president of Merrill Lynch, stood yesterday morning, eating cantaloupe with a plastic fork, the raucous trading floor behind him looked like a familiar Wall Street landscape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, LAWRENCE
description: MARK-Lawrence. On September 17, 2001. Born August 9, 1919. Beloved husband of Annette. Loving father of Jane and her husband Frank, and Wendy. Grandfather of Andrew Lazes and his wife Julie. He'll be missed dearly by his family and friends. He took us flying and made us laugh. Funeral service Thursday, September 20, 2001, 10:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St.).

title: Donors Flood Blood Banks, but a Steady Stream Is What's Needed
description: When Americans learned of last week's terror attacks, tens of thousands -- 15,000 in New York City alone -- donated blood.

title: Ashcroft Wants Quick Action On Broader Wiretapping Plan
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today that he would press Congress to vote this week on a package of counterterrorism measures that would dramatically expand the ability of the Justice Department to place wiretaps on telephones and computer terminals.

title: In Fast-Moving Market, Speculators Can Do Little to Stem Losses
description: Andrew Rosstein had had enough. A few minutes before noon, he bolted from the E*Trade office on Madison Avenue at 55th Street and stumbled down the sidewalk, in tears.

title: Mozart Casts His Spell and Leavens Sadness With Hints of Healing
description: In recent days people have been comparing notes on the music they turn to in time of tragedy. One woman said this past week that she could listen only to Bach. Another friend wanted a big, tangible statement of emotion, on the order of the Mahler Eighth.

title: 'The Birds Are on Fire'
description: The tragedy at the World Trade Center has produced scores of stories about people whose cool heads and courage saved lives. Among them are the public-school teachers who evacuated several schools that were dangerously near the collapsing towers and moved a total of 8,000 children to safety without a single serious injury. Their achievement is all the more amazing given that the disaster struck on the third day of the school year, requiring many teachers to deal with frightened children whom they hardly knew.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?; True Patriotism
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorkers Take Time Out to Remember the Destruction
description: New Yorkers took time out to remember today: their initial stunned disbelief at the unheralded destruction, the agonizing loss of so many lives, and those for whom hope is fading.

title: One Week Later: How to Answer the Horror?
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Atomic Secrets, Loyalty and Bitter Deceit
description: THE BROTHER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNAK, SHIRLEY
description: PASTERNAK-Shirley. We were saddened to learn of the passing of Shirley Pasternak, aged 95, dear Mother of Alvin Rose, who was loved by all. Our deepest condolences are extended to her family. Co-workers of Answer America

title: Drought Chokes Off Iran's Water and Its Economy
description: Just a few years ago, before the vast wetlands dried up, the season the locals call The Winds of 120 Days was a period of relative bliss in this remote corner of Iran.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages yesterday about the City Center's offer of free tickets to fire and police personnel misstated the telephone number to call for information. It is (212) 763-1206.

title: First Silence, Then Traders Start to Get In the Groove
description: At the entrance to the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, Ralph Nicolucci was standing in the same spot where he had been six days ago, again smoking a cigarette under a brilliant autumn sky and listening to the lapping of the Hudson River.

title: N.F.L. Is Tightening Security As Games Resume on Sunday
description: Fans attending N.F.L. games on Sunday will find parking moved farther away from stadiums, longer lines because of inspections for weapons and security increased in both ''visible and not-so-visible ways,'' Milt Ahlerich, the league's senior director of security, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, DANIEL JAMES
description: SHEA-Daniel James. Of Pelham Manor, NY died with his brother, Joseph Shea, at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Age 37, he was born February 26, 1964 to the late Joseph C. Shea and Joan A. Shea in New Rochelle. Dan attended St. John's University, and had worked at Cantor Fitzgerald since 1991 where he was a Managing Director and a Partner of the firm. He was a parishioner of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, a member of La Ronde Beach Club, and the Pelham Country Club. His charitable activities are too numerous to list. He was an avid sports fan, and particularly enjoyed golf. His generous spirit, loving heart and devotion to his family was exemplary. He will be greatly missed by all those who knew him and enjoyed his magnetic smile and passion for life. His incredible sense of humor and gift in telling stories will bring smiles to his numerous friends forever. He is survived by his wife Ellen; his three children Colin 4, Abigail 2, and Margaret Jean 7 months. He is also survived by his mother, Joan Shea; sister Kathleen Shea Munson, brothers Frank and Tom Shea and Eric Munson, and ten nieces and nephews. The family will be receiving friends on Tuesday, September 18th, 4-9pm at 965 The Esplanade, Pelham Manor, NY. A Memorial Mass is scheduled for Wednesday September 19th at 3:00pm at St. Ignatius Loyola Church on Park Avenue @ 83rd Street. Donations in lieu of gifts or flowers should be made to Westchester Community Foundation, Shea Family Memorial Fund, 470 Mamaroneck Avenue #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAUBARD, ABRAHAM
description: GRAUBARD-Abraham, 79, of Boca Raton, Fl, formerly of Closter, NJ. Died September 15, 2001. Beloved husband for 53 years of Florence (Kurzer) and adored father of Marsha and Robert Greenstein, Sharon Graubard, and Jeffrey Graubard and Diane Brown. Cherished grandfather of Emily, Daniel, Adam and Ethan. Devoted brother of Meyer Graubard and Harriet Feldshon, and dear in-law and uncle. His love, intellect and optimism will be with us all of our days. Services will be Thursday September 20 at 11:30am at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The National Parkinson Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Ave, Miami, Fl 33136-1494.

title: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on Retaliation
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's answers to reporters' questions yesterday morning during a visit to the Pentagon, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: Haunting Question: Did the Ban on Asbestos Lead to Loss of Life?
description: As the World Trade Center was being built in the late 1960's and early 1970's, scientists were learning that asbestos fibers in materials commonly used to fireproof steel beams could cause cancer in workers and bystanders who were intensively exposed to the fibers, especially around mines and manufacturing plants dealing with asbestos.

title: Suddenly, It's Nostradamus, The Best Seller
description: Within hours after last Tuesday's terrorist attacks, sales of books related to the disaster surged as people desperate for information and explanations rushed to purchase treatises on terrorism and the Arab world and biographies of the World Trade Center. And -- as often happens in the aftermath of dark and jarring public occurrences -- many of them loaded up on works that some believe predicted the tragic event. In this case, they have turned in surprising numbers to the writings of Nostradamus, a 16th-century French soothsayer credited by some acolytes with predicting apocalyptic events including the rise of Nazi Germany, the Challenger space shuttle explosion and the AIDS epidemic.

title: Corrections
description: Alisting in the Benefits column of the City section on Sunday for a fund- raising dinner planned by Habitat for Humanity has become outdated. The event, scheduled for this Thursday in Grand Central Terminal, has been canceled.

title: A Grim Reality, a New Map
Fed Cuts Rates By Half-Point In an Attempt To Aid Stocks
description: The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point before the stock market reopened today, and promised that it would go to great lengths to keep financial markets operating smoothly in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks.

title: The Economy, Too, Will Recover
description: The United States economy and the broader global economy were probably in a mild recession before the devastating terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. The shock that America now feels can only make matters worse for a while. Yesterday's wrenching drop in world financial markets suggests that investors have been quick to figure this out.

title: Memorials and Benefits
description: The arts continued yesterday to respond to last week's terrorist attacks with memorial performances, relief efforts and open doors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALVATERRA, FRANK G.
description: SALVATERRA-Frank G. Frank Salvaterra was at his office on the 104th floor of Two World Trade Center on September 11, 2001, at 9 A.M. when tragedy struck. Frank was a partner of the investment firm of Sandler O'Neil & Partners responsible for the firm's equity research, sales and trading. He previously was in a management position at Merrill Lynch and was a recognized and respected specialist in trading of bank stocks. First and foremost, Frank was a devoted husband and father to Sally Calvin and their three lovely children, Gabrielle and Isabelle, 9, and Christian, 7. Frank recognized the importance of family and friends and maintained a balance of a successful business career and loving attention to his family and friends. Frank's genial and caring manner made it clear that he knew the true values of life. He always had time for his children and friends and never missed a birthday, school event or social activity which was important to Sally and their children. Frank was born in Brooklyn and would have celebrated his 42nd birthday on October 4. His father Mario and sister Lillian predeceased him. He is survived by his mother Antoinetta Salvaterra, and a sister and brother-in-law Drs. Carmen and Gerry Barcak of Baltimore; and Sally's parents and sister Donald and Louise Calvin of Manhasset and Jane Calvin Palasek and Alexander Palasek of Port Washington, NY. Also a nephew Alexander Christian Palasek and nieces Danielle and Christen Barcak. Frank graduated with honors from the Bronx High School of Science. He graduated from Boston University with honors and was awarded an MBA from New York University. Frank and Sally have homes in Manhasset and Shelter Island, NY where they spent their last weekend fishing and attending the annual end of summer party. Frank's memory is being honored by an out pouring of gestures of kindness from business associates and friends from all walks of life who loved and respected Frank for both his professional ability and his devotion to his family and friends. A celebration of Frank's life is to be held at the Congregational Church of Manhasset, Northern Blvd, at 2 P.M. September 19, for family and friends. If you wish to join in celebrating Frank's life and carry on as he did in his life, please do an act of kindness for someone in need.

title: The Big City; Fantasies Of Vengeance, Fed by Fury
description: IN normal times, David Gonzalez would be on the sidewalk of West Broadway selling Andean handicrafts. These days, he is on Canal Street selling American flags, and not merely because the market has changed. Mr. Gonzalez, who was born in Peru 52 years ago, has passionate feelings about terrorism.

description: China moved a step closer today to entering the World Trade Organization, formally concluding 15 years of talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENOIR, JOHN ROBINSON
description: LENOIR-John Robinson, 38, of Locust Valley, NY, victim of the World Trade Center terrorist attack. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Andrew and Courtney. Also survived by his parents, John and Patricia Lenoir, brother Patrick and sister Kate. Vice President at Sandler O'Neill Partners. Forever remembered with love and admiration by his family and friends. Memorial service 11:30 AM, Thursday, September 20, St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley. In lieu of flowers, donations to Duke Univ. Athletics, Box 90542, Durham, NC 27708.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAF, EDWIN J. III
description: GRAF-Edwin J. III, recently of Rowayton, CT, and formerly of New Canaan CT is missing in the The World Trade Center disaster of September 11. Mr. Graf, known as Ed was employed at Cantor Fitzgerald Securities as a Vice President where he worked as a bond broker in 1 World Trade Center. Cantor Fitzgerald is a leading inter-broker dealer for government securities. Ed was born on February 10, 1953 in Libertyville, IL, the son of the late Edwin J. Graf, former COO of the Singer Corporation, and Margaret K. Graf who resides in Ellicott City, MD. The Graf family lived in New Canaan for over 20 years. Ed's brother Michael Graf and his wife Rezan and their two children currently live in New York. His sisters, Margie Labesky, Suzy Fennell, Marybeth Graf-Brohawn and Katie O'Brien live in Maryland near their mother. Ed was 48 years old and a 1971 graduate of New Canaan High School. He then attended Villanova and graduated from Middlebury College. An outdoorsman at heart, loving bicycling, tennis, paddle and skiing, Ed was also an accomplished climber and mountaineer leading many route climbs in Yosemite and the Grand Tetons as well as Eastern wall climbs in NY, VT and NH. He was also a sub-3 hour marathoner, registering a personal best in the 1980 NY Marathon at 2 hours 49 minutes. Relocating to NYC 4 years ago, Ed then chose to move to Rowayton, CT because of his passion for living on the water and his enjoyment at being near his hometown of New Canaan, CT. Ed's true passion and dedication was to his family and children, Kristen, Tyler and Wesley. He leaves behind his mother, siblings and children as well as his close friends. The memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 22 10am at the Church of the Resurrection in Ellicott City, MD. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to an educational trust which is being established for the benefit of Mr. Graf's children. Such donations can made to Susan Graf Fennell, Trustee of the Graf Family Trust, 2429 Hannon Court, Ellicott City MD 21042.

title: Somber Jets Try to Regain a Game-Week Rhythm
description: There was a small piece of concrete today in the locker of Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde, a relic of his weekend of remembrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, MAX
description: HABER-Max. American Friends of The Hebrew University is deeply saddened by the passing of our dear Council of Trustees member, Chicago Chapter Board Member and Benefactor Max Haber. Having no family of their own, Max and his wife Rita decided to make The Hebrew University of Jerusalem their ''child''. Many of the programs at the University have benefited from their generosity, and Max was a member of the Hebrew University Board of Governors. As Max was a Russian concentration camp survivor, of particular importance to him and Rita were the Max & Rita Haber Division of Holocaust Studies and The Max & Rita Haber Chair in Contemporary Jewish History. They also created The Dr. Siegfried Haber Chair in Medicine in memory of Max's brother. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Rita and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, JEROME, M.D.
description: SILVER-Jerome, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Geraldine, loving father of Robin (Michel Delouvrier) Silver and Matthew (Rena). Fond grandfather of Sophie Silver-Delouvrier. Dear brother of Ruth (David) Rosenthal and Leonard (Shirley) Silver. Memorial service Thursday, September 20, at 12 noon at Weiss Memorial Hospital Auditorium, 4646 North Marine Drive, Chicago. For information: The Weinstein Family Services Devon Chapel, 773-761-2400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATERA, BARBARA
description: MATERA-Barbara. Costume maker and designer, died September 13, 2001 at New York University Medical Center. She is survived by her husband and business partner, Arthur Matera, her sister, Pauline Ritchie-Fallon, her nieces, Ann Wills, Eve Grasham, and Lynn Ritchie-Fallon, 3 great nephews and a great niece. A Requiem Mass will be celebrated on Friday, September 21, 2001, at Holy Cross Church, 329 West 42nd Street, beginning at 10 A.M. Mr. Matera requests that in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights Aids, 1650 Broadway, New York 10036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORGES, SUZANNE F.
description: PORGES-Suzanne F. Died at home in NYC on September 13. Beloved mother of Robert F. and George W. Cherished mother-inlaw of Felicia and Nicole. Grandmother of John A. and Vicki Eisner. Great-grandmother of Dylan Robert Porges. Born in Vienna in 1908 she escaped the Holocaust and immigrated with husband and young children in 1938. She lived for many years in Forest Hills, NY and West Stockbridge, MA, where she had a long, prolific career as a portraitist, still-life and landscape painter. Her strength, courage, humor and adaptability will always be an inspiration to her family. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Friday, September 21, at 5 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JAMES FRANCIS IV
description: MURPHY-James Francis IV. 30, of Garden City, LI, died Tuesday, September 11, in the World Trade Center. Jim, who worked for Thomson Financial was attending a trade show on the 106th floor in Tower 1. Born in Rockville Centre, NY, on February 12, 1971, Jim was raised and attended school in Garden City, then graduated in 1993 from Mt. St. Mary's College in Emmitsburg, MD, where he met his wife, Jeanine (nee Kelly), and the two were married on May 1, 1999, at St. Rose of Lima in North Wales, PA. His parents, James F. and Helen Marie Murphy's only son, Jim is survived by four adoring older sisters, Kathleen Murphy of NYC, Elizabeth Cooke of Pacific Palisades, CA, Helen Marie Sweeney of Garden City, LI, and Kristin Hubschman of Williston Park, LI. He was a loving uncle to Emily, Sophie, Luke, Kate, Colin and Andrew. Jim will be greatly missed as well by all his cousins, aunts and uncles including Msgr. John Fagan, Msgr. Emmet Fagan, Jane Fucigna, Sr. Kathleen Fagan, RSHM, Jack Murphy, Rosemarie Codus, and Ed Murphy. He will always be remembered for his sense of humor, his deep love for his wife and family, his cherished friends, and his joy in playing golf. A memorial Mass will be held on Wednesday, September 19, at 2 PM at St. Joseph's R.C. Church at 450 Franklin Ave. in Garden City. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations may be made to Little Flower Children's Services, Wading River, NY 11792. God is holding Jim's hand, we now ask that He hold ours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE RHAM, LEE (NEE MCCABE)
description: de RHAM-Lee (nee McCabe), 89 died September 16, 2001. She was predeased by her son Tom and her husband Richard, and is survived by her son Pierre and her daughter Emily. A funeral service will be held at St. Philip's Church in Garrison on Thursday, September 20th at 11 AM. Contributions may be made to the American Red Cross.

title: Bank of England Joins Others In Cutting Rates to Fight Slump
description: LONDON, Sept. 18  The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter point today, to 4.75 percent, joining other central banks in fighting to keep the global economy from sinking into a deep recession.

title: Puffins Return to Maine
CNN Returns to Its Element but Faces High Expectations
description: One CNN correspondent was ordered out of Afghanistan on Monday under threat that his life was in imminent peril. Another correspondent became so ill he collapsed on camera while in the middle of a report. But CNN continues to promise that the network will be in a position to provide exclusive coverage of any American military action that might take place there.

title: Tank Younger, 73, First Star From Black College to Play in N.F.L., Dies
description: Tank Younger, a star fullback and linebacker for the Los Angeles Rams in the decade after World War II and the first athlete from a historically black college to play in the National Football League, died Saturday in Inglewood, Calif. He was 73.
