title: N.F.L. Will Keep 16-Game Regular Season
description: The National Football League will play its full 16-game regular-season schedule, Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: About.Com Replaces Top Executive
description: Primedia Inc. named William Day chief executive of About, the Internet media company it acquired in a $690 million stock deal last February. Mr. Day, currently the president and operating chief of About, was a founder of About.com. He will continue as president of the unit, Primedia said. Scott Kurnit, who stayed on as About chief executive after the merger, will continue as chairman of About until the end of the year, when he will also leave the Primedia board.

title: Homeless and Helpless in Romania
description: One of the most dismaying images in ''Children Underground,'' Edet Belzberg's raw, cinma vrit portrait of homeless Romanian children scrounging on the streets of Bucharest, is the silver-smeared face of a 14-year-old girl addicted to inhaling Aurolac, a toxic metallic paint. Macarena, as she is nicknamed, is the most disoriented of the five orphaned and runaway children whom the film follows over the course of a year. As Macarena, who was brought up in an orphanage, fantasizes dazedly about having a family waiting for her in another country and a twin sister with the same name, she seems lost beyond repair.

title: Braves Series to Go On at Shea
description: The Mets will proceed with their three-game series against the Braves at Shea Stadium this weekend after considering a switch to Atlanta. The Mets made the decision today after a two-hour conference call with officials from Major League Baseball, the New York Police Department and the Parks Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, JOSEPH PATRICK
description: SHEA-Joseph Patrick. A resident of Pelham Manor, NY died with his brother, Daniel Shea at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Age 47, he was born August 4th, 1954 to the late Joseph C. Shea and Joan A. Shea in New Rochelle. Joe grew up in Manhasset, N.Y. attended St. Ignatius Loyola School in New York City, and graduated from Georgetown University where he was an active alumnus. He worked at Cantor Fitzgerald where he was a Senior Executive Managing Director and a Partner of the firm. Joe was also a Member of the Board of Directors of eSpeed. Joe was a parishioner of Our Lady of Perpetual Help Parish in Pelham, N.Y., a member of the La Ronde Beach Club in West Hampton, N.Y., and the Pelham and West Hampton Country Clubs. He coached many children's baseball and hockey teams over the past ten years. He was active in many charitable causes in the community. He was an avid sports fan, and particularly enjoyed playing golf and hockey. His strength of character, uncompromising integrity, common sense and dry sense of humor were legendary. He was admired and loved by all whose lives he touched at work and at home. He adored his wife of sixteen years, as well as his four wonderful children. He is survived by his wife Nancy, his four children Patrick 14, Peter 12, Casey 10, and Daniel 7. He is also survived by his mother, Joan Shea, sister Kathleen Shea Munson, brothers Frank and Tom Shea and Eric Munson and nine nieces and nephews. A Memorial Mass is scheduled for Wednesday September 19, 2001 at 3:00pm at St. Ignatius Loyola Church on Park Avenue at 83rd Street in NYC. Donations in lieu of gifts or flowers should be made to the Westchester Community Foundation, Shea Family Memorial Fund, 470 Mamaroneck Ave #

title: A View From Newark and a New Perspective
description: Iarrived at Newark International Airport at 8:25 on Sept. 11, 2001, thinking about Barry Bonds. One day earlier, I had been assigned to cover Bonds's pursuit of Mark McGwire's single-season home run record, so I was about to get on an airplane, travel to Houston and attend a press conference that Bonds was scheduled to conduct that afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALLEN, ANNE
description: TALLEN-Anne. On September 18, 2001. Beloved wife of Nathaniel (Teddy). Devoted mother of Sheila and Irwin Cohen, Diane Spigel and Bette Tallen. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey and Karen Spigel, Robin Spigel, Allison and Kevin Stahl. Sweet great grandmother of Jacob Stahl. Services at Riverdale Temple, West 246th Street and Independence Avenue, Thursday, September 20 at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, DANIEL L.
description: SMITH-Daniel L. Of Northport, NY (formerly of Smithtown, NY), on September 11, 2001, tragically at The World Trade Center, age 47. Employee of Euro Brokers, V.P. of Maxcor Mortgage Corporation. Devoted husband of Mary (nee Harkin). Beloved father of Elizabeth and Michael. Dear son of the late Tracey and Helen (nee McCarthy) Smith. Cherished brother of Susan Hicks, McCarthy Smith, M.D., and Sean Smith. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Visiting at Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport. Memorial Mass 11AM Saturday, September 22, 2001, at St. Philip Neri Church, Northport. Donations to the Smith Children's Education Fund, C/O Fleet Bank, 680 Fort Salonga Road, Northport, New York 11768, appreciated. Hours on Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Too Much of This Cookie Isn't Enough
description: At first glance, the ciambella pastries made daily at Agata & Valentina, 1505 First Avenue (79th Street), look as if they're too big for one person. But the risk of single-handedly polishing off the entire flaky yet moist, twisted and knotted ring, about six inches in diameter, is very real. And before you know it, the nut-rich, buttery thing is gone, with only a few crumbs to show for it. Originally a Sicilian treat, ciambellas are now sold all over Italy. The ones at Agata & Valentina are made with almond paste and sliced almonds or, for a somewhat lighter result, with Sicilian pistachio paste and studded with pistachios. Either way, they're $1.50 each. Drizzled with bittersweet chocolate, an embellishment they hardly need -- but who's complaining? -- they're $1.75 each.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, ROBERT BENHAM
description: BECKER-Robert Benham. Husband to Ruth. Father of Peter, Paul and Michael. Brother to Carol. Grandfather to Rachel, Erica and Josh. Died Monday, September 17, 2001, at his home in North Salem, NY. He was surrounded by family and friends who loved him, and by a love created out of his selfless and unconditional ability to give. A gifted artist and designer who contributed his support, without reserve, to the Yeshiva University Museum. He will be missed, but ever kept alive in our hearts and in our prayers. Services 10 A.M. Wednesday at The Community Synagogue of Rye, NY. The family prefers memorials in his memory to the Alzheimer's Foundation of Westchester and the Hospice of Westchester.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Leader For Health Plan
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber has appointed Jean Thorne, a longtime aide, to lead the proposed expansion of the Oregon Health Plan, which offers coverage to the poor and uninsured. The Legislature ordered the state to seek federal waivers to improve access to health care and to low-cost private insurance for children, the elderly and low-income residents. In her new role, Ms. Thorne, who currently advises the governor on education and work-force issues, will work to secure federal waivers to carry out the expansion. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, JERROLD (JERRY)
description: CLARKE-Jerrold (Jerry). Age 59, passed away at home on September 15, after a courageous and zealous battle against cancer. He is survived by his adoring wife Dianne, his mother Gussie, his children Michael and Stefanie, David and Dara and Steven and Mia, his stepchildren Kim, Caryn and Rob, his grandchildren Elijah and Jacob and his brother and sisterin-law Alan and Mayda. Jerry was a partner at SLCE Architects, which was his passion for over thirty-four years. Funeral services will be held at Temple Or-Elohim in Jericho, New York on Thursday, September 20th, at 12 noon. His family, friends and colleagues will forever remember him with love and admiration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOGLER, ELIZABETH CLAIRE (BETH)
description: LOGLER-Elizabeth Claire (Beth). 31 years old, of New York City and formerly of Rockville Centre, Long Island, tragically on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center. Beth was a Vice President of E-Speed, a division of Cantor Fitzgerald on the 105th floor of the World Trade Center. She was born October 16, 1969 in Rockville Centre, LI. Beth graduated from Sacred Heart Academy in Hempstead, LI. She attended Mt. St. Mary's College in Emmetsburg, MD and graduated from Adelphi University in Garden City, LI, where she also earned her MBA. She was engaged to be married on December 30, 2001. Loving daughter of Robert and Claire Logler of Rockville Centre. Beloved fiancee of Douglas Cleary of Scarsdale, NY. Dear sister of Brian. Sister-in-law of Jane Ellen. Godmother and aunt of Caroline Jane of Garden City, LI. A memorial service will be held Friday, September 21, at St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Little Flower Children's Services, Wading River, NY 11792.

title: City Campaigns Grind to a Halt After Attacks
description: From the mayor's race to the contests for City Council, what had once been one of the most crowded and chaotic elections in the city's history has practically ground to a halt, leaving candidates in a state of suspension.

title: Teach More Than Where To Put H in Afghanistan
description: SCHOOL reformers often call for critical thinking, but this means little if students think critically only when there are no consequences. Now, as the nation debates how to respond to last week's terror, the consequences are big enough to matter.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 9 p.m. yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, FRANK BENNETT
description: REISMAN-Frank Bennett, 41, cruelly and tragically taken from his dearly loved and loving family and friends in the terrorist attack September 11 on the World Trade Center. Frank is survived and will be sorely missed by his cherished wife, Gayle, his darling children, Kasey 11 and Dillon 9, and by his loving parents, Evie and George. He was a most dear son-in-law to George and Bea Kleinman as well as a very special brother-in-law to Elise and Dr. Harvey Weingarten, Loren and Jill Kleinman and an adored uncle of Stacey, Benjamin, Dawn, Cari, and Jason. Wherever he went he made friends; with his kindness, sweet nature, sense of humor, intellectual quickness, and sincere interest in people he was the exemplar of the term ''GreatGuy''. Frank attended The Elisabeth Morrow School, he graduated in '77 from Dwight-Englewood School and earned a B.A. at Skidmore College in the Class of 1981. Following college and a ''tune-up'' of winter mountaineering in the Adirondacks High Peaks he hiked the Northern section of the Appalachian Trail from Maine to Pennsylvania and then joined his family's manufacturing company, Natalie Lamp & Shade Corp. Afterwards, he was an equities trader with Franklin Resources and for the last 5 years has been at Cantor Fitzgerald's trading desk on the 104th floor of the WTC. A memorial service will be held at 2:30 PM on Sunday, September 23 at The Jewish Center, 435 Nassau Street, Princeton, New Jersey.

title: Attacks Called Great Art
description: The composer Karlheinz Stockhausen caused outrage in Germany when he described the terrorist attacks in the United States last week as ''the greatest work of art ever,'' Agence France-Presse reported yesterday.

title: Joint Telethon to Aid People Who Suffered Losses in Attack
description: The four main broadcast television networks are planning a joint effort to raise money for individuals and families who have suffered losses in the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.

title: At the Site, Little Hope Of Uncovering Survivors
description: With little more than mammoth knots of steel and pulverized concrete remaining of the World Trade Center, officials acknowledged yesterday that it was unlikely that anyone in the buildings, even in the underground concourses, had survived the inferno of the towers' collapse last week.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, DAVID OTEY
description: CAMPBELL-David Otey, is missing in the World Trade Center tragedy of September 11th. Dave was employed at Keefe, Bruyette and Woods as a Senior Vice President of Equity Sales. He was loving husband to Cindy, loving father to Chip and Timmy. Survived by his parents Jane and Bev Campbell, sisters Mary Ann Anthony and Barbara Jean McKee. Dave's true dedication was to his family, friends and community. He was the Treasurer of the Somerset Hills Soccer Club for many years before taking over as the President of the Ice Hockey Boosters for Delbarton School and active at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Basking Ridge. His love of life and commitment to his family and friends will be with us all our days. Mass of the Resurrection will be held on Thursday, September 20th, 7 PM, at St. Mary's Abbey, Delbarton School, 230 Mendham Road, Morristown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Campbell Boys' Educational Fund, C/O John W. Albohm, Esq., 141 Dayton St, Ridgewood, New Jersey 07450 or to The American Red Cross NY Relief Fund, PO Box 97089, Washington, D.C. 20013.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLOSOFF, MORTY
description: WOLOSOFF-Morty. Formerly a home builder, hotel owner, investor in cable systems, died in Mount Sinai Hospital on September 17th. He resided in the Sherry Netherland Hotel and also had a home in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Wolosoff was 87. He was an early developer in St. Petersburg, FL., having built there the country's largest covered marina. He was a major contributor to many charities including The American Cancer Society, United Jewish Appeal, The Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Juvenile Diabetes Association, Multiple Sclerosis Group, Arthritis Foundation, American Red Cross. Mr. Wolosoff was a boat enthusiast, having owned several large boats. The last was built over a 3-year period in England. It was lost in a mistral off the coast of France after having lived aboard only three weeks. He was a member of the City Athletic Club. Mr. Wolosoff is survived by his wife Gloria Goodman Wolosoff and a daughter Wendy Hays. Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11:30AM on Thursday, September 20.

title: Afghans at Queens Mosque Split Over bin Laden
description: At New York City's largest Afghan mosque, supporters of the Taliban have chosen to pray in the basement or outside in the parking lot. They have not returned to the mosque for daily prayers since last Friday, when their imam denounced the attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: Debate Weighs Merits of Schools for Homeless
description: After reading his class a book called ''Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day,'' Jeff Bequeaith asked students to write about their own very bad day. Daniel, a sixth grader, recalled a morning he rose to find no clothes in his closet and no food for breakfast. Then he missed the bus for school.

title: Scarcity of Afghanistan Targets Prompts U.S. to Change Strategy
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld bluntly acknowledged today that the difficulty in identifying bombing targets in Afghanistan was leading the Pentagon to develop a broader, more unconventional type of campaign -- leaving the door open to ground troops, including commando units.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer's Profit Falls
description: Net profits at Switzerland's biggest life insurer, Swiss Life, dropped to $157 million, hurt by stagnant premiums and lower capital gains on its portfolio. Its six-month results were based on different accounting standards so they were not directly comparable with figures for 2000. Revenue from gross premiums was up slightly over last year but operating expenses for insurance were less than half of last year's. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Ryder Cup Timetable Is Due
description: A new date for the postponed Ryder Cup is expected to be announced today. The most likely possibility is that the Ryder Cup will be played Sept. 27-29, 2002, the week after next year's American Express Championship in Ireland. Players competing in Ireland would be able to travel easily to the Belfry in Sutton Coldfield, England, for the Ryder Cup the following week.

title: A Network Of A.T.M.'s Out of Service In New York
description: The Bank of New York said that its 350 automated teller machines remained out of service on Tuesday and that it might not get them connected until the end of the week.

title: Sports of The Times; Giving In Wasn't The Answer
description: WHEN the call for help came on the third Saturday in June, Herb Brown said, ''Yeah, sure, I'll go,'' without a moment's consideration for his professional obligations, or the possible peril. He soon learned that he had agreed to coach a playerless team that had surrendered to a plague most Americans felt secure from, until last week.

title: Trying to Regain Equilibrium in a World Turned Upside Down
description: And now, people must all carry on with jobs that will never be quite the same. Here are first-person accounts of how seven Americans coped in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks.

title: Sports of The Times; Calm Needed During Time Of Anger
description: PERHAPS the greatest sports hero in America, and possibly in the world, is a Muslim. His name is Muhammad Ali, the boxing champion nonpareil. We have Muslims for whom we have cheered or continue to cheer in America, from Kareem Abdul-Jabbar in basketball to Ahmad Rashad, the former football player who is now a broadcaster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISKENDERIAN, ARAM OF MERRICK
description: ISKENDERIAN-Aram of Merrick, L.I. on Tuesday, September 11, 2001 tragically at the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Sheri, devoted father of Meryl, Kara, Alex and Jason. Loving son of Aram and Patricia, and loving sonin-law of Jack and Elaine Pearlman. Cherished brother of Haig and Anita. Also survived by four loving nieces and many friends. His joyful presence will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 20 at 7:30 at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Mets Are United for a Final Charge
description: Late-season motivation comes in many forms, and the Mets have found theirs in the service they can perform with their play. They are still alive in the National League East race, and they believe some good can come from that.

title: Consumer Spending Returning to Normal
description: In the shoe department at Marshall Field's at the Old Orchard Mall in Skokie, Ill., this weekend, Valerie Whelan teetered on her left foot as she pulled a black sandal with multicolored beads onto her right.

title: Boeing and United Plan to Lay Off Thousands
description: As the airline industry continues to hemorrhage cash in the wake of last week's terrorist attacks, the Boeing Company said last night that it would lay off 20,000 to 30,000 workers by the end of 2002 because of fewer orders for aircraft.

title: Fighting Back, While Preserving Our Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Meeting Jakarta Leader; Islamic Militancy Is Likely Topic
description: When the presidents of the United States and Indonesia meet in Washington on Wednesday, they will share an urgent concern: the threat of militant Islamic violence.

title: Footlights
description: Beethoven and 'Macbeth'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTADT, BETTY
description: EISENSTADT-Betty. 91 years old. Widow of Benjamin Eisenstadt, longtime Trustee and benefactor of Maimonides Medical Center, who served as Secretary, Vice Chairman and Chairman during his 20 year tenure. Among Maimonides' major facilities, a testament to their generosity, are the Eisenstadt Administration Building and the Gellman Pavilion, named in memory of Dr. Abraham Gellman, Mrs. Eisenstadt's brother. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Eisenstadt's children: Marvin, Ira, Gladys, Ellen, and the entire Eisenstadt family. Martin D. Payson, Chairman, Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff, President and CEO Maimonides Medical Center

title: Memorial Service Set in Central Park Delayed
description: The memorial service planned for this Sunday in Central Park, which city officials had said could draw one million people, has been called off, in part because of concerns that a city now far more conscious of its vulnerability could not guarantee the safety of such an event.

title: World Leaders List Conditions On Cooperation
description: After a week of unconditional support from abroad, the Bush administration confronted its first significant difficulties today in building a broad international coalition to support using military power and other means against a still-faceless terror network rooted in Afghanistan and elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLODNER, PATRICIA M.
description: COLODNER-Patricia M., 39, on September 11, 2001. Beloved wife of Warren H. Colodner and mother of Colby (9) and Jordan (2-1/2). Daughter of Marie Pitchford and sister of Dean, Stanford and James Pitchford. Step-daughter of Sylvia Colodner and step-mother of Gregory Colodner and Courtney Dallaire. A memorial service will be held at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, this Friday, September 21, 2001, at 2:30 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in memory of Patti to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, POB 650309, Dallas Texas 75265-0309 by request of her family.

title: Devils Focus on Game, but Safety Is a Concern
description: Some of the Devils expressed concern for their safety regarding their exhibition game against the Rangers tonight at Madison Square Garden, the first major sporting event in New York City since last week's terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center towers.

title: A Challah of Prayers and Memories
description: I LEARNED how to make challah years ago from Ada Baum Lipschitz, an elderly woman in Brookline, Mass. Her hands were racked with arthritis, but no matter how terrible the pain, every week she made the bread, which is traditionally eaten on the Sabbath and Jewish holidays.

title: Trying to Regain Equilibrium in a World Turned Upside Down
description: And now, people must all carry on with jobs that will never be quite the same. Here are first-person accounts of how seven Americans coped in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks.

title: F.D.A. Approves New Version of Amgen Drug
description: Amgen said yesterday that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a new version of its top-selling anemia drug that requires fewer injections. The approval opens new markets for the company.

title: Pressed Back Into Service
description: For decades, the remains of firefighters who died in the line of duty were carried to funerals on a fire engine that had been dedicated to that solemn purpose and no other. But the caisson, as the Fire Department calls the equipment, was not used at the burials last weekend of Chief Peter Ganci, First Deputy Commissioner William Feehan, or Chaplain Mychael Judge. Nor was it to be used at the four funerals for firefighters today.

title: U.S. WIDENS POLICY ON DETAINING SUSPECTS; TROUBLED AIRLINES GET FEDERAL AID PLEDGE
description: The airline industry, which has already indicated that it will lay off 44,000 people in the wake of last week's terrorist attacks, won assurances of billions of dollars in financial help today from Congress and the Bush administration. But lawmakers said they had not settled on details of the package and suggested that the aid would come with conditions.

title: Chefs Remember
description: On Oct. 11, many restaurants in New York and around the world will donate at least 10 percent of their profits to a scholarship fund for the children of food service workers who died in the terrorist attacks last week.

description: PELTON-Mervin J. Of Great Neck, New York, on September 17, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Flora. Loving father of Dr. Stephen and Irene, Benjamin and Marcia, and I. David and Donna. Cherished grandfather of Erik, Jacklyn, Leslie and Josh, Garrett, Corey, Brett and Bari. Devoted brother of the late Shirley Bergman. Funeral service Thursday, 12 Noon at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, L.I.

title: Triumph And Cheers Greet Yanks In Return
description: Flag-waving fans wiped away tears and loudly sang ''God Bless America,'' and when first baseman Paul Konerko failed to scoop a throw out of the dirt and allowed the Yankees to score a first-inning run, the fans came together in heart and soul again. They groaned, in perfect harmony.

title: Taiwan Is Cleared for Membership in W.T.O.
description: Taiwan won formal clearance today to join the World Trade Organization, one day after China received clearance.

title: Wartime Rhetoric
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill understood the power of words and put them to effective use as they rallied America and Britain during the bleakest hours of World War II. President Bush, who is waging a different kind of war, must also find the right rhetoric to lead the United States and a coalition of diverse nations in this unconventional battle. Inflating expectations, and shifting tone from day to day, will not serve Mr. Bush or the nation well.

title: Europe Proposes Big Changes in Law Enforcement Rules
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 19  The European Commission proposed radical changes to European law enforcement today in the wake of the terrorist attacks in the United States.

title: Fighting Back, While Preserving Our Values; New York, We Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Reckonings; What to Do
description: Is everything different now? Yes and no. Last week's atrocity has shaken us and realigned our priorities. But many things remain the same. Among them is the basic quandary of U.S. economic policy, which has by no means gone away. It has simply become more fraught.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Gold funds, a haven in times of turmoil, are turning a profit for investors this week.
description: EVEN after catastrophes, someone makes a profit. So far this week, it has been investors in gold funds, which are seen as a haven in times of turmoil.

title: The Real Comfort Foods
description: MINDLESSLY nibbling on a piece of tasteless cold pizza last Thursday (a food I almost never eat even when it is hot and tasty), I chatted with a colleague, who said she had been nibbling all day, too. A woman who generally sticks to fruit and lentils, she had consumed shortbread cookies, doughnuts, a chocolate shake and potato chips. Both of us, and many others around the country, were responding to our feelings of stress in a time-honored fashion. Eating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCH, SIGMUND
description: KOCH-Sigmund, 79. Of East Norwich, NY. Died Friday, September 14, 2001 at Weinburg Campus in Buffalo after a prolonged illness. Born February 15, 1922 in Vienna, Austria he was the son of the late Joseph and Regina Koch. He was a member of the Jewish War Veterans and an educational consultant at the NYIT. He is survived by three sons, Steven Koch of Albany OH, Todd and Jonathan Koch of Buffalo, NY, two daughters-in-law Rhonda and Josie and two grandsons and two granddaughters. He was preceded in death by his wife Shirley Koch. Funeral services will be held Friday, September 21 at 9:30AM at the Beth Moses Cemetery office in Farmingdale, LI with a processional to the graveside following at 10AM. There will be a graveside memorial service. Please omit flowers. Donations to the American Diabetes Association will be greatly appreciated.

title: Statue to Fallen Firefighters to Make Its Home in New York
description: He rests on bended knee, one hand resting on a helmet, the other touching his forehead in prayer  a huge bronze statue of a firefighter grieving for fallen comrades.

description: FRIEDMAN-Matthew. Beloved husband of Linda. Devoted son of Rhoda and the late Melvin. Services 12:45pm Thursday at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: U.S. WIDENS POLICY ON DETAINING SUSPECTS; TROUBLED AIRLINES GET FEDERAL AID PLEDGE
description: The Bush administration today announced a major expansion of its power to detain immigrants suspected of crimes, including new rules prompted by last week's terrorist attacks that would allow legal immigrants to be detained indefinitely during a national emergency.

title: 60's Lessons On How Not To Wave Flag
description: TODD GITLIN is no flag waver, not by a long shot. Back in the 1960's, he was a leader of Students for a Democratic Society. Let's just say that he spent way too much time with people who spelled America with a K.

title: Finding Ways to Reassure Employees
description: A measure of a good manager is knowing how to respond to the needs of employees. But how do you respond to their fears if the worst terrorist attack in American history just happened in your backyard?

title: Playing a Guitar as if It Were a Full Band
description: Melissa Ferrick's head gleamed as she stood onstage Monday at the Bowery Ballroom. The light hit that shaved pate as if it were a reflector warning the world that this feisty singer-songwriter was zooming into its lane. "I'm gonna grab my soul and leave my ego at the door," she sang in "Welcome to My Life" as her fervent audience cheered. Her devotees may love Ms. Ferrick for her rock 'n' roll heart, but her ignited mind gave her show its excitement.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Challenge To Research Limits
description: Johns Hopkins University, the Kennedy Krieger Institute and the University of Maryland Medical System have asked Maryland's highest court to ease limits it imposed on medical research involving minors. A ban by the Maryland Court of Appeals on enrolling minors in nontherapeutic studies that involve risk could ''cripple the pursuit of critical medical and public health research,'' said Krieger, which is affiliated with Johns Hopkins. The court imposed the limits in August in a ruling on lawsuits by two mothers who said they had not been warned of the risks when their children took part in a 1990's Krieger study on the effectiveness of techniques to remove lead paint.

title: Design Goal: Keeping Jets From Misuse As Missiles
description: In the aftermath of the attack on the World Trade Center, aviation experts have begun considering changes in aircraft design that would help prevent terrorists from turning passenger airplanes into kamikaze weapons.

title: Short Orders
description: Ciao, an Italian restaurant and wine bar, has opened at 185 Bleecker Street (Macdougal Street), a location that is like home to its owner, Marcello Assante. His first job in New York was at Caffe Reggio on Macdougal Street.

description: LEVINE-Shirley. On September 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Sam, loving mother of Judith and Harvey Mayer and Susan and Marshall Bykofsky, cherished grandmother of Bradley, Robyn, David, and Ari. Services Thursday at 10 A.M., from Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: A Valley of Top Zinfandels
description: THROUGHOUT the wine-producing world, California almost alone grows zinfandel. While it flourishes all over the state, many of the most distinctive zinfandels come from the Dry Creek Valley, which carves a narrow swath near Healdsburg and Geyserville in northern Sonoma County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELFO, FRANK
description: MELFO-Frank. The Episcopal Actors' Guild mourns our loyal Council member and friend, Frank Melfo.

description: To the Editor:

title: No. 1 Anthem: 'God Bless America'
description: The simple melody of ''God Bless America,'' first written by Irving Berlin in 1918 as a Broadway show tune, has been outperforming the national anthem this week, wherever citizens and untrained singers gather to express their patriotic feelings.

title: Touring an Injured City
description: The red double-decker bus pulled into Midtown traffic along Eighth Avenue yesterday with Sigmund Cowan bellowing over a loudspeaker, instructing everyone to remain seated during the tour. Everyone, then, numbered just four: two couples, one English, the other German, all in New York City for the first time.

title: A Fine Roughness: On the Trail of a Spirit Called Marc
description: HARD to find outside the districts where it is produced, with a name that is often mispronounced, marc is a heady, earthy-tasting French relative of moonshine. It makes some people gag. A few nuts like me love it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, JUDITH
description: GREEN-Judith. We mourn the loss of a cherished friend, a best selling author whose wit and joy of life enriched the lives of all who knew and loved her. Our condolences to her daughter Christina, son Nicholas, and family Martin Richards, Sam Crothers and the Producer Circle

title: Scholarships Honor Heroes
description: A $5 million scholarship fund will be established at New York University to benefit the dependents of the firefighters, police officers and emergency medical personnel who lost their lives while responding to the attack on the World Trade Center last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SULLIVAN, TIMOTHY
description: O'SULLIVAN - Timothy. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend & long-time employee who died tragically on September 11 at the World Trade Center. Tim began his career in 1973 as personnel manager and in 1976, through his retirement in 1997, was Deputy Director of Administrative Services. His responsibilities and accomplishments included acting as WCS Labor Relations and Employment Specialist. He was a central figure in labor negotiations between cultural institutions and NYC. Tim was instrumental in establishing the Cultural Institutions Retirement System, the largest multi-employee pension plan among NYC cultural institutions. He was an instructor for 20 years at the AZA's professional training school, as well as the AMA. Tim served on the Board of St. Barnabas Hospital and Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Tim's dedication, concern and his embodiment of Irish humor and cheer will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the WCS/Tim O'Sullivan Victims Relief Fund C/O Wildlife Conservation Society, 2300 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, New York 10460. David T. Schiff, Chairman Steven E. Sanderson, Pres. & CEO

title: Jets Come To Assist However They Can
description: The buses carrying the Jets rolled up to Chambers Street, just a few blocks north of the horror of the World Trade Center attack.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIDES. The dollar fell against the euro and the Japanese yen. In New York, the euro settled at 92.68 cents, up from 92.44 cents on Monday. The dollar traded at 117.23 yen, down from 117.73 yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORDOVER, ALFRED
description: ORDOVER-Alfred. 75. Died June 20 at his home in Saugerties, NY. Beloved husband of Mary Neill Ordover, father of Sarah and Andrew Ordover, step-father of Josh and David Touster and Cynthia Hendricks. Loving grandfather of Rachel and August Stolba. Retired Vice President of NBC, an avid and astute collector of modern art, and a dedicated supporter of new artists. A memorial service at the O.K. Harris Gallery is planned for the fall. For information call Mary Neill Ordover 845-247-9312.

title: False Alarm Aboard Plane
description: The F.B.I. and airport police evacuated a plane tonight on the runway at Dulles International Airport after a crew member mistakenly declared an emergency, the authorities said.

title: NATO Nations Vow to Support U.S., but Few Have Much to Offer Militarily
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 18  As the United States prepares its response to last week's terrorist attacks, many military analysts say that the NATO alliance, though it has pledged its support, at least politically, has very little to offer the United States militarily.

title: Trucker Lowers Estimates
description: J. B. Hunt Transport Services, a trucking company, said today that earnings for the third quarter would be lower than forecast because shipments declined and costs rose. The company expects to earn about 5 cents a share, below the 28 cents a share predicted by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Hunt earned 26 cents a share in the year-earlier quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, WILLIAM I.
description: SPENCER - William I. The Trustees, faculty and staff of The Colorado College mourn the passing of 1939 alumnus William I. Spencer, a CC trustee since 1967 and chair of the board from 1984 to 1991. The retired president of Citicorp Citibank, Mr. Spencer was also a generous supporter of the college. The William I. Spencer Citicorp Scholarship Fund, established by Citicorp in honor of his retirement, provides CC students with financial aid based on athletic and academic merit. Mr. Spencer was awarded an honorary degree from CC in 1994. A tremendous student-athlete, he was the co-captain of CC's first intercollegiate hockey team in 1938. He recently served as Honorary Chair of the CC Athletic Hall of Fame. On behalf of The Colorado College community, we extend our sympathy and appreciation to members of the Spencer family. William R. Ward, Chair of The Colorado College Board of Trustees Kathryn Mohrman, President of Colorado College

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cuts At Bank
description: Germany's third-largest bank, Dresdner Bank, said it would extend its reorganizing program by cutting an additional 1,300 jobs in an effort to reduce costs by 15 percent through the end of 2003, or 1.3 billion euros ($1.2 billion) annually. The chief executive, Bernd Fahrholz, said the measures were vital for strengthening the company's earnings potential. As at Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, Dresdner Bank is struggling with rising costs and slumping profit and had already announced reductions of 5,000 jobs, about 10 percent of the work force. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATERA, BARBARA
description: MATERA-Barbara. In Memoriam: We, the employees of Barbara Matera, Ltd., express our heartfelt sorrow at the passing of Barbara Matera, as well as our gratitude for being a part of her unique world. Barbara, as our mentor and teacher, believed strongly in our ability to accomplish our goals as she inspired us to overcome every obstacle. Striving for perfection in the smallest detail, she encouraged us to take pride in the work we produced and to live up to the reputation of quality, which is the trademark of Barbara Matera, Ltd. That reputation enabled us to work with the most talented people in show business, which enriched our lives. No effort was ever too great when it came to the comfort of the performer, the correctness of the costume or ''that special something'' that could enhance a performance. The delight she took in her approach to solving problems made it seem as though each challenge could be worked out through determination. Her creative spirit will live on in all these qualities that she generously shared with us & in the costumes that will forever belong to Broadway, ballet, opera and motion pictures. We feel proud to have been counted as a part of her large, extended family.

title: Trying to Regain Equilibrium in a World Turned Upside Down
description: And now, people must all carry on with jobs that will never be quite the same. Here are first-person accounts of how seven Americans coped in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks.

title: Reassessing the Athlete After a Transforming Moment
description: Athletes are among the most self-absorbed people. It is why they are great performers, able to shield distraction the way lead shields X-rays. And it is also why they have alienated many fans with increasing inaccessibility and loutish behavior. Television ratings for sports events are plummeting and attendance at games is largely static as athletes convey a growing sense of entitlement and a shriveling sense of public responsibility.

title: Reaching the Sky, And Finding a Limit; Tall Buildings Face New Doubt As Symbols of Vulnerability
description: In their audacious pursuit of astonishing height -- to glorify a god, immortalize a builder, mark a spot or lure a tenant -- architects have created pyramids, domes, minarets, campaniles, spires and skyscrapers. But at the World Trade Center, they inadvertently created something else. Targets.

title: The 'Gruesome Work'
description: On 130 barren and dusty acres of the now closed Fresh Kills landfill, investigators have set up an elaborate process to sift through the rubble and twisted steel from the collapsed buildings.

title: Marathons Won't Let Attacks Stop Them
description: Extra precautions will be taken, security will be heightened and last-minute changes can be expected for the Marine Corps Marathon on Oct. 28 and the New York City Marathon on Nov. 4.

title: Online Travel Agency Shares Post Losses for a Second Day
description: While airline stocks have borne the brunt of the market's sell-off this week, shares of online travel agencies, once among the only places of refuge for dot-com investors, have also been hit hard.

title: On Doomed Flight, Passengers Vowed to Perish Fighting
description: They told the people they loved that they would die fighting.

title: Honeywell Expects to Miss Wall St. Estimates
description: Honeywell International said here today that it would not meet analysts' earnings estimates and planned to cut more jobs. It said it expected airlines to reduce purchases of avionics and cockpit control equipment.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell on expectations for weaker demand, which was already slowing before terrorist attacks last week. In New York, crude oil for October delivery fell $1.11, or 3.9 percent, to $27.70 a barrel.

title: Rethinking The Security At Airports
description: Over the past three decades, with airplanes hijacked to Cuba, intentionally blown up over Scotland, and exploding mysteriously off Long Island, federal and local officials have repeatedly examined the effectiveness of airport security in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, LAWRENCE
description: MARK-Lawrence. On September 17, 2001. Born August 9, 1919. Beloved husband of Annette. Loving father of Jane and her husband Frank, and Wendy. Grandfather of Andrew Lazes and his wife Julie. He'll be missed dearly by his family and friends. He took us flying and made us laugh. Funeral service Thursday, September 20, 2001, 10:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St.).

title: Selections From the U.S. Attacked Forum
description: On Tuesday, September 11, the NYTimes.com's Readers' Opinions area opened a forum for readers from around the world to share their thoughts on the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Here is a selection of comments, excerpted from the forum's first three days. They range from outpourings of sympathy and grief to eyewitness accounts, to analyses of what to do next.

title: Fearing Trouble Aloft and Below, Many Pass Up Flights
description: Tania Burgos had looked forward to flying to her new home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., from New York last week, savoring a faintly remembered thrill of riding on an airplane years ago.

title: With Little Left, Japan Shaves Rate
description: With its short-term interest rates already effectively at zero, the Bank of Japan had no real way to join the Federal Reserve, the European Central Bank and other central banks in easing monetary policy today.

title: Exploring Technology to Protect Passengers With Fingerprint or Retina Scans
description: Governments and airlines seeking to reduce the threat of airplane hijackings by terrorists have a wide range of security technologies to choose from.

title: In a Square, A Sense Of Unity; A Homegrown Memorial Brings Strangers Together
description: By Monday night the generally low-key crowds at the southern end of Union Square Park were beginning to talk about wanting to get on with life and about grief fatigue.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Glacier Yields Bodies
description: Almost 30 years after a small airplane crashed into Mount Rainier, the bodies of the three victims have been recovered from the Cowlitz Glacier. The three -- Bill Steitz, Kenneth Fry and Dean Bride -- were killed in January 1972 when their Piper Cherokee Arrow crashed on a flight from Pasco to Seattle. A search at the time turned up no evidence of the crash, but rangers at Mount Rainier National Park found some remains in 1992. The rest of the remains were discovered on Thursday and delivered to the coroner, a park spokeswoman, Maria Gillette, said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASESCU, ELINOR
description: BASESCU-Elinor. 74, died of cancer on September 15. Wife of Sabert; mother of Claire, Neil and Maria; mother-in-law of Arthur, Elizabeth and Mary; grandmother of Jacob, Rebecca, Max, Simon, Sophie, Dylan and Alex. She was an amazing, complicated, incredibly warm, generous and greatly cherished human being. Talented actress, teacher, scholar of the theater. A creative life-force extraordinaire. Memorial gathering Sunday, September 23, 1 PM, Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, Saxon Woods Rd, White Plains

title: Democrats in Senate Budge On Missile Defense Money
description: In an effort to avoid a partisan debate after the terrorist attacks last week, Senate Democrats have agreed to withdraw a budget provision that would have restricted certain kinds of spending on missile defense.

title: Private Schools Top Public
description: Private high schools in New York City edged out public schools in producing semifinalists in the 47th annual National Merit Scholarship Program. According to lists of the semifinalists released last week, 182 private and parochial high school students in the city qualified as semifinalists for the program, compared with 168 students at public high schools in the city. The National Merit Scholarship Program will award $32 million in scholarships to roughly 8,000 students nationwide next spring.

title: In New York's Galleries, a New Context Seems to Remake the Art
description: The effects of the shattering tragedy on Sept. 11 will undoubtedly be seen in contemporary art in the not-so-distant future. But it has already created, virtually overnight, a new category of outsider art: the astounding impromptu shrines and individual artworks that have proliferated along New York's streets and in its parks and squares.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Soccer Stake For Adidas
description: Adidas-Salomon A.G., a leading maker of sporting goods, shoes and apparel, agreed to buy 10 percent of Bayern Munich A.G., Germany's top soccer club, for 75 million euros ($69 million) in stock. The transaction will make Adidas-Salomon the soccer club's sponsor, supplier and licensee through 2010, the companies said in a statement to the Frankfurt exchange.

title: Rough Night in Detroit
description: Before the Rangers' preseason opener in Detroit on Monday night, the teams lined up together at center ice to observe a moment of silence before the singing of the national anthem. Rangers Coach Ron Low called it a show of unity.

title: Terror in America / 'We're Going to Smoke Them Out': President Airs His Anger
description: WASHINGTON  Speaking with unusually raw intensity, President George W. Bush says that he wants the militant Islamic leader Osama bin Laden brought to justice "dead or alive."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, MARIANNE
description: CAMERON-Marianne. On September 15, 2001. Beloved daughter of the late James and Mae (nee Crowley) Cameron. Adored sister of the late James J. Cameron. Reposing at Vanella's Chapels, 29 Madison Street, New York City, until Thursday, 10 AM, Mass of Resurrection, St. James Church, 10:30 AM. Visitation Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. For further information, please phone Vanella's, 516-766-4424.

title: N.Y.U. Program Named
description: New York University School of Law will name its global law school program after RITA E. HAUSER, who graduated from the law school in 1959, and her husband, GUSTAVE M. HAUSER, who earned a master of law degree from the law school in two years earlier. The seven-year-old program, which focuses on legal systems around the world, brings 20 foreign law professors and judges and more than 325 foreign law students to N.Y.U. each year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Up At Supermarket Chain
description: Britain's largest supermarket chain, Tesco, said that first-half sales rose 14 percent, to 11.5 billion ($16.9 billion), as the company opened more stores in Europe and Asia. Tesco is one of the few companies that says it makes money from delivering groceries ordered online, and it recently exported its system to the United States in a deal with GroceryWorks, an online start-up in which Safeway owns 50 percent. For the period, net income at Tesco increased to 324 million ($475 million) from 284 million ($416 million) last year.

title: Chefs Remember
description: On Oct. 11, many restaurants in New York and around the world will donate at least 10 percent of their profits to a scholarship fund for the children of food service workers who died in the terrorist attacks last week.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Computer Program Takes Toll On Internet
description: A malicious computer program took its toll on the Internet yesterday, causing slowdowns on the network as it attacked personal computers and corporate servers. Computer security experts said the program called either W32.Minda or W32.nimda can be spread via e-mail messages, or passed directly from one server computer to another, or can be contracted by a user seeking to download an infected Web page. Elias Levy, chief technology officer at Security Focus, a computer security company, said the program is technically considered both a ''virus,'' which is a type of program attached to other programs or documents and typically spread via e-mail, and a ''worm,'' which attacks other computers directly. Mr. Levy said the program did not appear to cause damage to infected computers. The program does, however, consume processing power as it seeks to attack computers -- a phenomenon which appears to have slowed down Internet traffic. The Internet Traffic Report, which measures Web traffic patterns, said response times at various Internet hubs were nearly half the normal levels. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: For a Dessert Wine, A New Course
description: Ever since the first drops of balsamic hit American salads, sweet vinegars have been the rage. Banyuls, a dessert wine from southwestern France that is similar to tawny port, is the latest base for such a vinegar. There are now two amber-colored barrel-aged Banyuls vinegars sold in Manhattan. One of them, Vinaigre de Banyuls, made by L'toile and sold at Fairway markets, has a lovely fruitiness. It is $7.29 for about 17.5 ounces. title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Dabhol Seeks Payment
description: Dabhol Power, the Indian unit of the Enron Corporation that is locked in a dispute over utility payments with an Indian state, has asked the federal government of India to make good on a guarantee for unpaid bills. Dabhol is seeking $64 million in bills it says the state of Maharashtra owes for power supplied from April through June. A spokesman for Dabhol said the company invoked the payments guarantees to protect the company, its lenders and suppliers. The power plant, which produces 2,184 megawatts and is valued at $3 billion, is shut down as a result of the dispute. Enron owns 65 percent of the operation. Saritha Rai (NYT)

The Brotherhood Synagogue has established a fund in Jeff's memory in appreciation of his dedication to the prayer life of the congregation and its children. A memorial service will be held at the Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South, NYC on Thursday, September 20 at 2:30pm.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Stalled
description: Two of three plants of Daewoo Motors in Korea suspended operations after parts suppliers stopped sending their products while demanding more than $600 million in overdue payments from the bankrupt company. A Daewoo spokesman said assembly lines shut down in plants in the Pupyong section of Inchon and in Kunsan, on the southwest coast. The company's creditors hope to reach terms by Friday for a sale to General Motors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: In Temple, Seeking Meaning And Promise in a New Year
description: The rabbi wore a camouflage yarmulke under his flak helmet. The altar was a stack of buckets topped with a plastic bread tray. The blowing of the shofar was nearly drowned out by diesel engines from trucks and bucket loaders.

title: Private Schools Top Public
description: Private high schools in New York City edged out public schools in producing semifinalists in the 47th annual National Merit Scholarship Program. According to lists of the semifinalists released last week, 182 private and parochial high school students in the city qualified as semifinalists for the program, compared with 168 students at public high schools in the city. The National Merit Scholarship Program will award $32 million in scholarships to roughly 8,000 students nationwide next spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, DAVID THOMAS
description: WEISS-David Thomas, age 50, died tragically on Tuesday September 11 in the attack on One World Trade Center. Loving and adored husband of Marcia, treasured father of Gina Rose, beloved brother of Andrew Weiss and Arline Levine, dear son-in-law of Sheila Keller, cherished brotherin-law of Ronnie Weiss, Jonathan and Glori Keller, Barbara Keller, Philip and Daphne Keller, and beloved uncle of Todd, Pamela, Rachel, Joseph, Sarah, Reuben, Jane, Mollie, Steven and Shari. David was Vice President and Deputy General Counsel of Cantor Fitzgerald and eSpeed. In his professional life he was a brilliant attorney whose commitment to integrity and excellence was unrelenting. In his personal life he searched for spiritual growth and strove for intellectual understanding. He was a very private man with a kind, sweet and generous heart and a tremendous passion for music. But above all else was his limitless devotion to his family. His truly magnificent soul will live on forever in the hearts of those of us who were blessed to have shared our lives with him. Memorial service will be held on Friday September 21 at 11:00 AM at The Brotherhood Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South, New York, NY. Donations in memory of David T. Weiss can be made to The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, The World Jewish Congress, or Cantor Fitzgerald Foundation (101 Park Avenue, 45th Floor, NY, NY 10178, Attn: Phil Ginsberg).

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: New Contender For Helms's Seat
description: State Representative Dan Blue, a Democrat, has joined the race for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Senator Jesse Helms, a Republican. Mr. Blue filed a notice of candidacy with the State Board of Elections on Monday. He has postponed a formal announcement until after the General Assembly resolves a budget impasse. Mr. Blue, a 52-year-old lawyer from Raleigh, is serving his 11th term. In 1991, he became the first African-American speaker of the North Carolina House, a post he held for four years. Mr. Blue will face Elaine Marshall, the North Carolina secretary of state, in the Democratic primary in May 2002.

title: Measure for Measure, Minus the Spoons
description: Though there may be enough variations on measuring spoons -- nonstick, narrow ones that fit into bottles and ones with odd measurements like 1 1/2 tablespoons -- yet another has broken into the field. Only there are no spoons involved. The Mini-Measure is the size of a shot glass, and, like Pyrex measuring cups, it has measurements in bright red on the side. It will measure up to six teaspoons and two tablespoons, broken down by the one-half tablespoon. There are ounce measures and milliliters as well. If you've wrestled with a ring of measuring spoons while trying to pour droplets of almond extract into a teaspoon, you'll see the genius in this little glass. The Mini-Measure costs $6.50 for a pair at A Cook's Companions, 152 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn; (718) 222-1868. AMANDA HESSER

title: Learning Outside Classroom
description: The 106 students of Solomon Schechter High School in Manhattan began their first day of classes on Sept. 10 without ever walking into school. Instead, they spent the day at the Jewish Museum's Marc Chagall exhibition, where they led Jewish prayers, ate a traditional Russian breakfast and viewed the artist's work. They learned about Russian Jews in Chagall's time, the Russian Jewish influence on American Jewry today and the parallels between their classmates' recent immigration experiences and that of their grandparents and great-grandparents.

Gregorio of Linden improperly brokered a deal to build a station in Linden where New York's trash would be moved from barges to rail cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, LOUIS
description: AUERBACH-Louis. Age 75, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Bergenfield, NJ and Marlboro, NJ, died Monday, Sept. 17, 2001 at his home. Born in Poland he was a Holocaust survivor, coming to the US in 1947. In America, the country he loved, his life was testament to what strength, determination and a strong work ethic can achieve. Before retiring in 1991, Mr. Auerbach owned various restaurants in NYC including the world famous Stage Door Deli in Manhattan. Louis Auerbach is survived by his beloved wife of 53 years, Helen Auerbach of Boynton Beach, FL, his daughter Pamela Auerbach of Edgewater, NJ, his son and daughter-in-law, Steven and April Auerbach of Franklin Lakes, NJ, his brother Baruch Auerbach of North Miami, FL and his two grandchildren Nicole and Lana Auerbach. An extraordinary man whose memory will live on, he will be greatly missed by his family, friends and the lives he touched over the years. Services will be held on Thurs at 1 PM at the BloomfieldCooper Jewish Chapel of Manalapan, NJ. Donations may be made to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, DC.

title: Insurers, Reaching Out to the Public, Hope to Alter Their Image
description: A number of major life and property insurers have been using newspaper and radio advertising to reach out to the public since last week's terrorist attacks. And some say the ads, in which the companies offer compassion and toll-free information numbers, could improve the industry's often negative reputation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, ALYS JANE
description: FARRELL-Alys Jane. Died at Central Suffolk Hospital Riverhead New York on September 16, 2001. She was born and raised in Wyoming Valley, PA. She graduated College Preparatory School-Wyoming Seminary. She went on to attend Syracuse University and Tobe-Coburn School of Fashion Design in New York City. Known to all her friends as ''A.J.'', she was the Past President of the Suffolk County Chapter of the American Heart Fund. She was also past president of the Westhampton Garden Club and was involved in many other local causes. She owned and operated the Sea Shell in Westhampton Beach for 27 years. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Don Farrell, her sons Lee and Sean Farrell, a granddaughter, Ashley Farrell, her daughter-in-law Rene Farrell, and sister Marilou Kaye of New Jersey. She reposed at the Follett & Werner Funeral on Tuesday. A Mass of Resurrection was celebrated at the Church of the Immaculate Conception. Interment followed at the St. Mary's Cemetery in Wilkes-Barre, PA. In lieu of flowers donations to American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

The moves could set the stage for the first truce talks here since midsummer.

description: IN Celtic tradition, the frenzied skirls and drones of the bagpipes led the boys into war and back again. This week, across the city, the pipers of the New York City Fire Department are loudly escorting too many of their own to eternal rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, ARCHIBALD R.
description: MURRAY-Archibald R. The Board, the President's Council, the management and staff and the Civil Support Division of The Legal Aid Society mourn the death of Arch Murray, who was a pillar of the Society, serving as its Attorney-in-Chief and Executive Director from 1975 to 1994 and as the Chair of its Board from 1994 to 1998. He was a dear friend, a tireless supporter, a great leader of the organized Bar and a true advocate of justice for the poor. He received the Society's highest honor, the Servant of Justice Award in 1998, a title which exemplified his life's work. We will deeply miss our dear friend. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Kay, and his family. D. Stuart Meiklejohn, Chair Daniel L. Greenberg, President and Attorney-in-Chief

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pirelli Seeks New Terms
description: Citing a ''changed international context,'' Pirelli said it wanted to renegotiate its deal with the holding company Bell S.A. over the acquisition of Olivetti. In July, Pirelli paid 7 billion euros ($6.5 billion) to Bell for 23 percent of Olivetti. Since then, the stock price of Olivetti has fallen 50 percent. No money or shares can change hands until the European Commission reviews the transaction. The review is expected later this month. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: U.N. Delays General Assembly Session of World Leaders Indefinitely
description: The United Nations announced today that it was delaying indefinitely the annual speeches by world leaders that traditionally bring platoons of politicians to New York in September because of the strain this would place on the city's security services.

description: St. John's men's basketball team will begin the season with an exhibition against the Harlem Globetrotters at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 10.

Its handsome bar invites hanging out, and the stone fireplace promises to be as warming as a family hearth once the weather turns cold. The staff is welcoming, and it's owned by a mother and son, Carol Weissman and Craig Skiptunis. What more could you want?

title: European Cookbooks, American Accents
description: For American cooks who crave food with a certain European style, a new effort is under way to bring European cookbooks to American kitchens. Bernard Jarrier-Cabernet and Carole Peck, who own Good News Cafe in Woodbury, Conn., and Dennis Pistone, a typesetter, have founded Ici La Press, which has just published ''The Magic of the Truffle'' by Christian tienne ($24), the translation of a book by a chef who is a truffle expert and has a restaurant in Avignon. It gives recipes for the black truffle and mentions summer truffles, but ignores Italian white truffles, which are not found in France. The company also publishes out-of-print American cookbooks. The first of these is ''The Flavors of Sicily'' by Anna Tasca Lanza ($38). Ici La Press plans to publish books by Michel Bras and Alain Ducasse, both Michelin three-star chefs. The books are expected on the Web site www.icilapress.com and in stores in the coming weeks.

title: American and United Airlines to Cut a Total of 40,000 Jobs
description: American Airlines and United Airlines, the nation's two largest air carriers, announced today that they would lay off a total of 40,000 employees, in the sharpest cutbacks yet for the beleaguered airline industry following last week's terrorist attacks.

title: At Colleges, a Toll Both Emotional and Practical
description: In a meeting room at New School University framed by the powerful orange murals of Orozco, a group of professors traded ideas on how to handle their classes, their fragile students and themselves in the wake of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Anarchists Rounded Up
description: A hundred sites were searched across northern Italy and 60 people were questioned as part of an investigation by the Milan prosecutor into possible terrorist activities by Italian anarchists. The groups are suspected of being involved in plans to attack targets like the Milan cathedral, but the prosecutor said the searches were not linked to the attacks in the United States. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the differing viewpoints of uptown and downtown residents of Manhattan after the World Trade Center attack misspelled the surname of an assignment manager for the CNN business network who spoke about life on the Upper West Side. He is Gene Bloch, not Block.

description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Guerrillas Rounded Up
description: Troops have rounded up scores of suspected guerrillas in Chechnya after a surprise assault by rebels killed 10 soldiers in Gudermes, the province's second largest city, and killed 13 more in a missile attack on a helicopter in Grozny, the capital. The attacks, the largest in recent months, belied Russian claims that two years of war had left the Islamic-led separatists incapable of mounting a serious offensive. Military spokesmen said Russian troops had killed 17 guerrillas in Gudermes and taken 13 more into custody. Twenty-two suspects were held Tsotsin-Yurt, including several accused of carrying out the attack on the helicopter, the Interfax news service said. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: President Jacques Chirac of France came to New York today with very strong words of praise and admiration for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the people of the city for how they handled the devastation and "drama" at the World Trade Center.

description: Tens of thousands of Afghans are on the move, fearing that a week of speculation will soon give way to actual events, with American bombs plunging from the skies.

description: The Bank of England cut interest rates a quarter- point today, to 4.75 percent, joining other central banks in fighting to keep the global economy from sinking into a deep recession.

title: Stock Markets Hold Steady a Day After the Big Sell-Off
description: The United States stock market moved a little lower yesterday but still seemed to indicate that many traders were hoping the economy would start to recover relatively soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, BRIAN JOSEPH
description: MURPHY-Brian Joseph. Devoted husband of Judith Bram Murphy, active and loving father of Jessica and Leila, beloved son of Harold and Christina, adored brother of Ann, Harold and Cynthia, cherished son-in-law of William and Jane Eisner Bram, dearly beloved nephew of Marguerite, dear brother-in-law of Steven Eisner Bram and Elizabeth Rothstein, and wonderful uncle to Joshua, Danielle, Zachary, and Callahan and fantastic and loyal friend of hundreds, perished in the tragic events that took place on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Brian graduated from the Wilbraham and Monson Academy Class of 1976, Williams College Class of 1980, and the Columbia University School of Business Class of 1987. He was a Vice President at Cantor Fitzgerald/eSpeed Division and a partner in his family's ReMAX Real Estate Company. Brian's life was filled with family, integrity, loyalty and acts of kindness. A man of high morals and solid principles, his faith in God, family, and love was unshakable. He will be deeply missed by all those he touched. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church on Lexington Avenue and 66th Street on Tuesday, September 25 at 3:30 P.M. Donations may be made to Williams College, the Brian J. Murphy Class of 1980 Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 231, Williamstown, MA 01267.

title: Who Says Tuna Has to Give Up Its Taste When It Goes in the Can?
description: Canned tuna is a fine convenience food, but most of the time it's hardly a food worth celebrating. There are some exceptions, though: the imported tunas packed in olive oil, with thick, rosy chunks that come apart in meaty layers, not gritty shreds. This is the best tuna for a salade nioise, or, to make things simpler, a Provenal pan bagnat. I drain the tuna, but not too thoroughly, gently break it up, add a quick splash of good red wine vinegar and perhaps some capers, and pile it on a roll with a slice of red onion or tomato.

title: Leslie Sbrocco's Cellar Suggestions
description: What is it that makes wine great? Many think it's a $100-plus price tag, but it's not. Two words that tend to describe just about every fabulous wine are balance and complexity . A world-class bottle has all its parts (oak, tannin, fruit, acidity, alcohol) integrated seamlessly and offers something new with each sip. Here are three new Napa Valley releases that reach near perfection without costing a fortune:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Blowin' In The Wind
description: Environment Minister Noel Dempsey decreed a 14-cent fee for each plastic bag used to carry groceries. The Irish use 1.2 billion bags every year, or 325 per person, he said, and they are the most visible form of litter in the countryside, where they get caught in trees and hedges and along riverbanks. Starting in February, stores will be required to charge customers for each bag. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Windows That Rose So Close To the Sun
description: NEW YORK has many bars and restaurants with views of the city. Windows on the World was something else, a restaurant that seemed suspended halfway between the earth and the moon. From 107 stories, the views extended for 90 miles. Manhattan, Brooklyn and New Jersey spread out in sharply etched detail. The river bridges looked like fragile steel filaments from a quarter mile up, and New York Harbor threw back tiny sparks of sunlight.

title: After the Horror, Radio Stations Pull Some Songs

title: Crime Reports Plunge, With One Brazen Exception
description: With the city's attention fixed on the worst attack in its history, it is none too surprising that other crime news has fallen by the wayside. But it was nonetheless remarkable that a signed Picasso could be reported stolen in broad daylight from a Madison Avenue art galley and go largely unnoticed.

title: Business Suite Is Taking On New Meaning
description: The investment bankers at Lehman Brothers Holdings are finding out this week that when your company gets blown out of its headquarters, it's good to have friends in the hotel business.

description: The Taliban movement began with a gang rape, or so the story goes. In the spring of 1994, two young girls were abducted by the type of sadistic hellions who then held sway in a lawless Afghanistan.

description: Last Wednesday, not 36 hours after the attack on the World Trade Center, aides to New York's two senators were briefed for the first time on President Bush's plan to seek $20 billion in emergency disaster relief and military spending.

description: High on a cliff near the northern tip of Cape Breton, isolated for most of the year by cruel weather, a Tibetan Buddhist community is taking a lead in defining Buddhism for the West.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: A Sense Of Racism
description: More than 80 percent of the members of ethnic minorities in Ireland feel that racism is a serious problem and that the government is not doing enough to combat it, according to a survey of 600 people by Amnesty International. Women reported more racism and discrimination than men; just over half of those surveyed do not feel confident reporting racist incidents to the police. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Rightist Denies Immigrant Slur
description: Umberto Bossi, leader of the Northern League, denied responsibility for an anti-immigrant flyer that was distributed Sunday at the party's annual gathering in Venice. The flyer bore an image of Osama bin Laden and the words ''Illegal Immigrants = Islamic Terrorists.'' Italy has become an important point of entry for immigrants from Albania and points east, and nearly 1,000 landed in the south over the weekend. On Friday the center-right cabinet approved a draft law introducing tougher immigration regulations, including prison terms for illegal immigrants who return after being expelled. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: Attacks Strike Hard at States' Economies
description: The terrorist attacks last week are beginning to deal a blow to state economies, damaging tourism and travel-related industries, chipping into sales tax revenues and, with the prospect of war on the horizon, throwing many states into uncertainty about their economic future.

title: Rescuing the Airlines
description: Even before last week's terrorist attack, this was shaping up to be one of the worst years ever for the nation's airlines because of the abrupt economic slowdown. Now this could become the year that many carriers, even some of the largest, simply don't survive. Hence the sense of urgency at the White House and on Capitol Hill to draw up a relief package. Commercial aviation, the industry most severely affected by last week's terrorist attacks, is critically important to the overall economy. Congress cannot stand aside and allow an act of war to destroy the nation's transportation network.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Poll Gives Democrat The Edge
description: Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, a Democrat, would defeat Representative Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., a Republican, by a 23-point margin if the two squared off now in a race for governor, a poll shows. Mr. Ehrlich, a four-term congressman, has yet to seek the Republican nomination, but is widely viewed as his party's best hope in the 2002 race for governor. In the Gonzales-Arscott poll, Ms. Townsend, a daughter of Robert F. Kennedy, demonstrated a particularly strong showing among black voters, leading Mr. Ehrlich, 81 percent to 7 percent, with 12 percent undecided. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, DANIEL JAMES
description: SHEA-Daniel James. Of Pelham Manor, NY died with his brother, Joseph Shea, at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Age 37, he was born February 26, 1964 to the late Joseph C. Shea and Joan A. Shea in New Rochelle. Dan attended St. John's University, and had worked at Cantor Fitzgerald since 1991 where he was a Managing Director and a Partner of the firm. He was a parishioner of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, a member of La Ronde Beach Club, and the Pelham Country Club. His charitable activities are too numerous to list. He was an avid sports fan, and particularly enjoyed golf. His generous spirit, loving heart and devotion to his family was exemplary. He will be greatly missed by all those who knew him and enjoyed his magnetic smile and passion for life. His incredible sense of humor and gift in telling stories will bring smiles to his numerous friends forever. He is survived by his wife Ellen; his three children Colin 4, Abigail 2, and Margaret Jean 7 months. He is also survived by his mother, Joan Shea; sister Kathleen Shea Munson, brothers Frank and Tom Shea and Eric Munson, and ten nieces and nephews. The family will be receiving friends on Tuesday, September 18th, 4-9pm at 965 The Esplanade, Pelham Manor, NY. A Memorial Mass is scheduled for Wednesday September 19th at 3:00pm at St. Ignatius Loyola Church on Park Avenue @ 83rd Street. Donations in lieu of gifts or flowers should be made to Westchester Community Foundation, Shea Family Memorial Fund, 470 Mamaroneck Avenue #

Survivors include a son, Bruce Arkin of Pawleys Island, SC, and a daughter, Linda Arkin of Brooklyn, NY, two granddaughters, Valerie Catanzaro and Lori Kunkle and two great-grandsons, Matthew and Michael Catanzaro. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, EDWIN HAVILAND

Beloved husband of Rosalind, father of Pamela Miller Ness, father-in-law of Paul M. Ness. He was a distinguished scholar of American Literature, publishing numerous biographies and critical studies of Whitman, Melville and Hawthorne. He received a B.A. in English from Lehigh University in 1940, an M.A. from Pennsylvania State University in 1942, and a Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1951. A memorial service is planned for a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Public Library, Berg Collection, 42nd St. & 5th Avenue, New York, NY 10018, or the Allentown Art Museum, 5th and Court St, Allentown, PA 18105.

KLM said it is impossible to estimate the amount of its full-year loss. KLM will probably announce cuts next week, said Frank Houben, a company spokesman. The company had discussed cutting capacity by 10 percent, he said.

title: The Mideast Is Also Changed
description: As the Middle East watches for America's reaction to the attacks on its soil, Israelis worry that Americans may now think that supporting Israel is too costly, while Palestinians fear that America's pain may translate into anti-Arab sentiment and added empathy with Israel. But if the aim of the cease-fire steps announced yesterday is merely tactical, both sides miss the point entirely. The disaster we now face profoundly affects the lives of Israelis and Palestinians regardless of American reaction: In the disaster that befell America, they should see the grim prospects of their own future if they maintain the violent course of the past year.

title: A New Election Day
description: New Yorkers have an opportunity next Tuesday to show their patriotism by going to the polls and voting in the primary elections. The terrorist attack occurred on New York's regularly scheduled Election Day. It is time to finish what we started on the morning of Sept. 11. A healthy turnout for the rescheduled primaries would demonstrate that while terrorists can delay, they cannot destroy such a basic part of our democracy.

title: A Rare Sip in America
description: MARC DE BOURGOGNE from Joseph Cartron is probably the most widely distributed label in the United States. Produced by a specialist distiller in Nuits-St.-Georges in Burgundy, it is a well-made spirit, thoroughly drinkable if not quite in the same league as the longer-aged marcs from the major wine estates in the same region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, CELIA
