title: When the Path to Serenity Wends Past the Stove
description: WHEN a friend called to say she had suddenly felt compelled to bake an apple pie last Saturday, I understood why. Anyone who cooks even casually knows the feeling. Cooking is almost always a mood-altering experience, for good or for bad, and at its best it is do-it-yourself therapy: more calming than yoga, less risky than drugs.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Deal Lifts Rambus
description: Shares of the memory chip designer Rambus rose $1.11, or 16.7 percent, to $7.76, after the company announced an expanded patent-licensing agreement with Intel worth $200 million over five years. The giant chip maker uses a Rambus design, called RDRAM, to increase the performance of its fastest Pentium 4 processors. Intel will pay Rambus $10 million a quarter for five years, starting in the current quarter. The new agreement reaffirmed Intel's support for chips based on Rambus designs.

title: For Cellphone Holdouts, Worry Closes the Sale

The country will go after those ''folks'' if it has to ''smoke them out and get them running.'' And they are ''evil-doers, those barbaric people.''

title: Fear in the Open City

In this open city, it seems so easy to feel that you can invent yourself and create a unique life. This has been -- and undoubtedly will be -- the enduring allure of the city. For me, being a New Yorker has meant a sense of belonging and of coming home.

title: New Visors Have Buyers Hunting High and Low
description: Handspring has done something about the confusing array of hand-held computers on the market: they've added to it. The company has announced two new Visor hand-helds, one aimed at the high-end business user and the other at the entry-level consumer. The standard Visor Pro comes with 16 megabytes of RAM (up from 8 megabytes for most high-end Visors) and a 33-megahertz Motorola Dragonball chip that offers double the speed of earlier models. The Visor Pro also uses a rechargeable battery instead of AAA's. Handspring says that a charge will last several weeks with normal use (vendorese for your mileage may vary). The Visor Pro has a retail price of $299 and is available at www.handspring.com and in stores.

title: Taking Refuge on the Internet, a Quilt of Tales and Solace
description: FEW corners of cyberspace were untouched by last week's horror. Reactions to the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon continued to stream onto the Web, becoming the inescapable focus of e-mail lists and sites devoted to everything from genealogy to Broadway. Wholly new sites sprang up seemingly within minutes of the towers' collapse. The Net became a single chat room with a single topic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALVIN, THOMAS EDWARD
description: GALVIN-Thomas Edward. A resident of Manhattan, died at the World Trade Center on September 11, 200l. Age 32, he was born November 29, l968 to Diverra Galvin and John M. Galvin in Bronxville, NY. He grew up in Greenwich, CT. and graduated from Greenwich High School in l986. During his high school years he captained the Greenwich High Golf Team, and was named All-State and All-County Scholastic Golf in l986. He graduated from Georgetown University in l990 where he also was captain of the varsity golf team. Tom continued to be a competitive amateur golfer and was a long time member of the Winged Foot Golf Club. He worked at Cantor Fitzgerald since l994, where he was a Senior Vice President, Corporate Bond Broker. He volunteered his free time to a variety of charitable causes. Tom was loved by all who knew him and will be greatly missed. He is survived by his parents Diverra and John Galvin, his sisters Lynn Galvin and Kathy Callahan, and his brother John Galvin, Jr. He was a devoted uncle to John's daughters Emily and Eliza and Kathy's sons Jack and Charlie. A memorial mass is scheduled for l0:00 A.M. Saturday, September 22, 200l at St. Michael the Archangel Church on North Street in Greenwich. Donations in lieu of flowers or gifts should be made to The Thomas E. title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Artificial Heart Recipient Does Well
description: Tom Christerson, 70, the second recipient of a self-contained artificial heart, is breathing on his own, taking daily walks in an intensive care unit, and otherwise recovering well at Jewish Hospital in Louisville, his doctors said. They said Mr. Christerson's kidneys, which had been failing before the implant on Sept. 13, have improved dramatically. The first recipient, Robert Tools, 59, who had his implant on July 2, is also recovering well, taking daily walks around the hospital and undergoing physical rehabilitation.

description: IN the short term, last week's terrorist attacks had the same effect in the personal-technology business as they had in every other walk of life: they changed our priorities.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 2 Men Arrested In Drug Seizure
description: Two men, one from California and the other from Arizona, were arrested in Hunts Point Tuesday night after the seizure of more than half a ton of illegal drugs hidden in a tractor-trailer, the authorities said. The men, Fidel Rodriguez, 53, of Lake Elsinore, Calif., and Robert Serrano, 37, of Nogales, Ariz., were found hiding on the roof of a stall for the tractor-trailer. Officers from the Drug Enforcement Task Force searched a false compartment in the tractor-trailer and found about 700 pounds of cocaine and other drugs along with $2.4 million in cash, the authorities said. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Neighbors, Shining Through; When the Nest Resists The Storm

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurers On Credit Watch
description: Standard & Poor's put the credit ratings of five of Japan's eight major life insurance companies on watch for a possible downgrade, citing weak capital levels and high exposure to Japan's slowing economy. The assets of the five companies, Asahi Mutual Life, Meiji Life, Mitsui Mutual Life, Sumitomo Life and Yasuda Mutual Life, are dwindling dangerously as the stock market weakens, S.& .P said. title: Colonial Judaism Through the Eyes Of a Silversmith

The exhibition also includes 10 of his synagogue decorations, like the Torah-scroll finial above. Through Dec. 30 at the Yale University Art Gallery, 1111 Chapel Street, New Haven; (203) 432-0600. Admission is free. The catalog from Yale University Press is $60. EVE M. KAHN

description: Despite repeated rescue efforts over the summer, scientists fear that an injured North Atlantic whale has died. The 50-ton whale, named Churchill by researchers, drew attention in June when it was spotted off Cape Cod with a length of marine rope cutting into its jaw and a spreading infection. Scientists tried six times to remove the line. The Center for Coastal Studies in Provincetown said it had not received a signal from the whale's transmitter since Sunday, a sign that the whale may be dead and its carcass submerged. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about the release of the names of 39 people confirmed dead in the attack at the World Trade Center referred incorrectly to the father of one victim, Keith McHeffey. The father, whose name was not given, does not work at the World Trade Center. The article also misstated the given name of Mr. McHeffey's former sister-in-law, who was quoted. She is Mary McHeffey, not Amanda.

title: On Doomed Flight, Passengers Vowed to Perish Fighting
description: They told the people they loved that they would die fighting.

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September; Life and Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Insurers Promise to Speed the Payment of Claims
description: When the first lists of victims in the World Trade Center attack were published, claims specialists at MetLife, one of the nation's biggest life insurers, began searching records to see if they were customers.

title: Corrections
description: A drawing in Science Times on Sept. 4 with a reader's letter about Capt. Robert F. Scott's 1912 expedition to the South Pole was published in error. It duplicated an illustration for the Q & A column, about the muscle spasm known as charley horse. The letter should have carried a Library of Congress photograph of the expedition.

title: Market Place; Bond Investors Show Signs of Optimism
description: Bond investors are known as the financial market's worriers, but yesterday they became the optimists on the economy.

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions Face Elections Board Before Primary
description: With less than a week to go before a hastily rescheduled primary, the city's Board of Elections is facing a set of serious challenges, from trying to inform poll workers of the new elections schedule, to figuring out whether possible runoffs in some citywide races would have to be held using paper ballots, to a lawsuit filed by a group of voters and candidates seeking to postpone the primary election yet again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCKETT, EDWARD H. II ''TED''
description: LUCKETT-Edward H. II ''Ted'' 40, of Fair Haven, NJ on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center tragedy. Partner and Vice President of Cantor Fitzgerald, NYC. Husband of Lisa (nee Lindeman). Father of Jennifer Grace, William Stone II, and Timothy Wyatt. Son of Diana W. and the late William Stone Luckett, brother of Kathryn Luckett-Brown, Alexandra W. Luckett, and James Taylor Luckett, son-in-law of Neil and Connie Lindeman, brother-in-law of Mark Lindeman. Memorial Services will be held on Monday September 24, 10am at St. Georges by the River Episcopal Church, Waterman Ave. Rumson, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Luckett Childrens Educational Trust C/O Arthur H. Tildesley, 130 Pine Cove Road, Fair Haven, New Jersey 07704, in memory of Ted for the benefit of his children, Jen, Billy and Timmy.

title: Administration Seeks to Shift Farm Policy From Subsidies
description: The Bush administration called today for a major shift away from the current farm policy, arguing for more conservation and international trade over an existing approach that it said was too generous to wealthy grain and cotton farmers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Politics Is Adjourned
description: In the second week of post-complacency America, the need for President Bush and the leaders of Congress to assemble a bipartisan package to rescue the faltering economy is becoming clearer each day. It was a particularly reassuring sign yesterday that House Speaker Dennis Hastert and other Republicans reached out to consult not only with Alan Greenspan but also former Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin for ideas on what such a package might entail. Mr. Bush now has the opportunity to deliver on his longstanding pledge of a cooperative relationship with Democrats on the economy.

title: Jets Are Still Making Introductions on Defense
description: Time has been elastic, extending and bending to absorb the tragedies of last week. It seems like so much longer than 10 days ago that the Jets lost to Indianapolis in the season opener and the most pressing issue on their minds was how bad the defense looked.

title: US Airways' Dim Outlook Deteriorates
description: It was only a week ago that the annual meeting of US Airways promised to be a nasty confrontation between management and union workers angry over executive pay and the airline's strategy after the collapse of its proposed merger with United Airlines.

title: Damage on Lines Near Towers Is Less Than Officials Feared
description: The president of New York City Transit toured subway tunnels yesterday near the worst devastation from the World Trade Center collapse, and reported that the N and R lines, thought to be extensively damaged, had not been pierced by falling steel beams, as earlier thought. But transit officials cautioned that their original projection of those lines running normally in a few weeks was probably too optimistic.

title: Super Bowl Date Appears Fixed
description: The National Automobile Dealers Association will not change the date or location of its convention in New Orleans, making it less likely that the National Football League can move the Super Bowl back one week.

title: Beyond Water's Edge, Coast Guard's Armed Patrols Assume Vital Importance
description: From the bridge of his Coast Guard cutter, Cmdr. Gary M. Smialek could see Battery Park 350 yards away, and beyond that, smoke still drifting from the wreckage around the World Trade Center.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, JOSEPH RYAN
description: ALLEN-Joseph Ryan. Victim of The World Trade Center tragedy on September 11, 2001. Son of The late Nellie Jane Allen. Brother of Kevin, John, Michael and Jennifer. Uncle of Robert, Patrick, Stephen, Mikey, Jackie and Jennifer. Funeral Mass St. Joseph's Church Bronxville on Saturday September 22 at 9:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Cantor Fitzgerald Family fund.

title: Safety Concerns Turn to Closing Gaping Holes in Security of Noncommercial Aircraft
description: With the country focused on safeguarding airliners from terrorism, aviation experts say private cargo, charter and corporate aircraft may now be more vulnerable to hijackings by suicide attackers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCEBOLD, C. EDWARD
description: SCEBOLD-C. Edward. 9/16/01. Beloved father of Alexandra, Brenda and Brian. Husband of Jamie. Former husband of Jo-Ann. RIP.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, HERMAN S.
description: SANDLER-Herman S. American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra's Board of Directors and staff and the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra-mourn the loss of our esteemed Board President, Herman S. Sandler whose life was lost in the attack on the World Trade Center. His consummate leadership, vision for the future and total commitment to the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra and the State of Israel will always be missed. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Suki; his daughters Pamela, Jordana, Gillian; his mother, and all the family. We cannot begin to describe the sadness of his loss. Herman was the inspiration and leader of the AFIPO family, our friend, who believed that the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra's role as a cultural ambassador would lead to world peace and understanding. On this Rosh Hashanah and in the years to come we shall remember Herman and his great contribution to us and to the world. Zubin Mehta IPO Music Director for Life and Board Co-Chairman Itzhak Perlman AFIPO Board Co-Chairman Albert Schussler President Emeritus Charles I. Petschek Lynn Syms Elaine Wolfensohn Vice Presidents Suzanne K. Ponsot Executive Director Zeev Dorman,(Chairman) Baruch Gross Gabriel Vole IPO Management Avi Shoshani IPO Secretary-General

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DAVID RONALD
description: COLLINS-David Ronald. Age 69. On Monday, September 17, 2001 after a valiant battle with cancer. Mr. Collins was an accomplished writer, composer, singer, cabaret artist and stage performer. A beloved brother and uncle, and cherished friend to countless many. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Ascension in NYC at 2:30PM on Saturday, September 22. The graveside service will be in Dayton, Ohio at 11AM on Wednesday, October 17. Memorial contributions should be made to The Church of the Ascension in NYC, the American Cancer Society, or any relief fund officially associated with the WTC tragedy.

title: Text: Mayor Giuliani's Briefing
description: Following is the text of a news conference by Mayor Giuliani and a delegation of United States senators today in New York City, as recorded by The New York Times :

description: NORTHWEST

title: For a City Still in Shock, Picking Up Life's Routine
description: Tony Muzi, a 42-year-old accountant at HBO in Midtown Manhattan, went for a run on his lunch hour this week. A man named Mark ate a salad in Bryant Park. Jim DeLorme, an auto mechanic and amateur artist from Point Pleasant, N.J., came into New York to sketch on his day off.

title: PAKISTANI DEFENDS JOINING WITH U.S.
description: Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, went on nationwide television tonight to offer a tense, sometimes emotional defense of his decision to join the United States in the hunt for Osama bin Laden. General Musharraf said the situation presented this volatile Muslim nation of 140 million people with its gravest crisis in the 30 years since it lost its last major war, with India.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUSE, ROBERT A.
description: CHUSE-Robert A. Age 93. Of Leonia, N.J. Beloved husband of Eve. Loving brother of Bette Chuse Silverman (Rockville Centre, New York), Lillian Chuse Wurzberg (Long Beach, N.Y.) and Emanuel Chuse (Upper Darby, PA.). Cherished grandfather of Rebecca P. Chuse (Denver, CO.). He was the author of the book, ''Pressure Vessels, The ASME Code Simplified'', published by McGraw-Hill, and was a member of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Services at Wien & Wien Memorial Chapels, 402 Park St., Hacksensack, N.J., Thursday, September 20th at 1:30 P.M.

title: Baseball Chipping In to Help
description: Major League Baseball and the Players Association said they would each donate $5 million to a relief fund to help people affected by last week's terrorist attacks in New York and near Washington.

title: George Ireland, 88, Title-Winning Coach at Loyola, Dies
description: George Ireland, who coached Loyola University of Chicago to the 1963 national basketball championship while taking a highly visible stride toward integration in college athletics, died last Friday in Addison, Ill. He was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JAMES G.
description: SMITH-James G. September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Donna, adored father of Will, Rob, Kristen and Caroline. Son of Mona Smith. Brother of Barbara Lewthwaite and Suzanne Koorse. Memorial service on Friday, September 21, St. Joseph's Church, Franklin Avenue, Garden City. In lieu of flowers, please make charitable donations to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSEN, DON
description: NELSEN-Don. Died September 8th at 75. Former Daily News jazz and drama critic. Survived by his wife, Ricki Fulman, mother Olive, son Bobby, three grandchildren. Contributions can by made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September
description: To the Editor:

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Other Buildings Called Sound

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLATSCH, LAURENCE
description: POLATSCH - Laurence. Taken from us suddenly on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center tragedy. He was the loving and adored son of Linda and Buddy, cherished brother of Danny, devoted grandson of Rose Lerner, and beloved great-nephew, nephew, cousin, and friend to many. He will always be remembered for his love of life, wonderful sense of humor, warmth, and generosity. A celebration of Larry's life is to be held on Friday, September 21 at 2:00pm at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, NORMAN
description: DIAMOND-Norman. On Sept. 19, 2001. Of Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Michael and Scott Diamond and Barbara Warshaw. Dear brother of the late Sylvia and Florence. Loving grandfather of Jana, Cortney, Erica, Tara, Keri, Justin and Chance. Religious services will be held Friday at the Sanctuary of Abraham & Sarah, Emerson, N.J. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or Disaster Relief Fund, World Trade Center. For time of service, please call Wien & Wien, 1-800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZSTEIN, ROSELLA
description: HERZSTEIN-Rosella. After a prolonged illness, on September 18, 2001. We will miss her. Beloved wife of Joseph; sister of Alfred, Jeane, Pearl & Frances. Survived by Herbert, Karen, Susan, Wilma, Steven and William. Memorial to be announced. Donations to the Education Foundation, New York State League of Women Voters, (518) 465-4162; or to any of the charities for the World Trade Center victims/rescuers and their families.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Price Gouging After Attacks
description: State Attorney General Mark Pryor filed suit in state court today against five Arkansas gasoline retailers who he said had engaged in price gouging soon after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, violating the state's Deceptive Trade Practices Act. Mr. Pryor seeks refunds for consumers and civil penalties that could reach $10,000 a sale.

title: 'Kiss Me, Kate' to Close
description: ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' a revival of the 1948 Cole Porter musical comedy, with book by Samuel and Bella Spewack, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Clinton. Directed by Michael Blakemore and currently starring Burke Moses and Carolee Carmello, the show will have run for 769 regular performances and 28 previews.

title: Afghan Clerics Urge bin Laden to Leave; White House Says Unacceptable
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 20  Afghanistan's top clerics recommended today that the accused terrorist Osama bin Laden should be persuaded to leave the country, a development that the leader of Pakistan's largest Islamic party described as "a ray of hope."

title: S.E.C. Plans An Extension Of Its Waiver Of Some Rules
description: Federal officials are preparing to extend an order waiving certain trading regulations to permit companies and executives to help prop up the price of their shares.

title: Fact-Driven? Collegial? This Site Wants You
description: FOR all the human traffic that the Web attracts, most sites remain fairly solitary destinations. People shop by themselves, retrieve information alone and post messages that they hope others will eventually notice. But some sites are looking for ways to enable visitors not only to interact but even to collaborate to change the sites themselves.

title: First-Person Reports From Art's Cutting Edge
description: The ideas and works featured in ''Art:21 -- Art in the 21st Century'' were going to be a tough sell even before last week's awful events. For many people ''visual art'' still means the ''Mona Lisa'' and not much more. A guy who hangs hubcaps on a wall or a woman who takes pictures by sticking a pinhole camera in her mouth and opening her lips were going to be viewed skeptically no matter what.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINARDI, WILLIAM G.
description: MINARDI-William G. of Bedford, NY suddenly and tragically on September 11, 2001. Derivatives Broker; firm of Cantor Fitzgerald. Beloved husband of Stephanie. Loving father of William M., Robert P., and Christine A. Cherished son of Elizabeth and the late William J. Minardi, and son-in-law of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew Higgins. Dear brother of James and Dolores Minardi, Joanne and Rick Pitino, Mary and the late Donald J. Vogt. Brother-in-law of Anne Farrell and Dr. and Mrs. Matthew Higgins. Adored uncle of Matthew, Luke, and Martin Minardi, Michael, Christopher, Richard, Ryan and Jacqueline Pitino, Devon, William and Patrick Vogt, Grace Higgins and the late Daniel M. Pitino. Loving and cherished friend to many. Celebration of Life and Mass of the Resurrection Thursday, September 20th, at 5:00 PM at St. Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, 2 Green Street, Mt. Kisco (corner of Main Street; 914-666-5986). Contributions in William's memory may be made to the Daniel Pitino Shelter; 501 Walnut Street, Owensboro, KY 42301.

title: At 'Phantom,' Empty Seats And Defiance
description: For an escape, a respite or an act of defiance, a few people straggled into the Majestic Theater on West 44th Street yesterday to see a matinee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARKOFF, SAM
description: ARKOFF-Sam. The Troma Team deeply mourns the passing of Sam Arkoff. He was a great filmmaker, friend, role model and mentor. His giant cigar glows forever in our hearts. Lloyd Kaufman and Michael Herz Troma Entertainment

title: Racing Is First Sport to Return to a Hurt City
description: They gathered in the winner's circle for a moment of silence in business suits and jeans and the pastels and geometric shapes of racing silks. Horseplayers nearby tucked their racing programs beneath their arms and came to attention as the bugler, Sam Grossman, blew a haunting rendition of ''America.''

title: The War on Terror Is Not New
description: Viewed from England, what happened last Tuesday looked not like Pearl Harbor II, but like the London Blitz. That was one of many reasons for the outpouring of sympathy for America after the attacks on New York and Washington.

title: Unwilling to Give Up Yet, Rescuers Find Crevices but No Survivors in Them
description: Rescue workers squeezing through crevices no wider than sewer grates have found surprisingly large caverns beneath the rubble of the World Trade Center. But officials cautioned yesterday that there was still little hope that many of the missing had survived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPA, EDWARD J.
description: PAPA-Edward J. On September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. He was 47 years old. Born July 1, 1954 to the late Charles A. and Genevieve K. Papa, he was a graduate of Chaminade High School and Boston College. Devoted husband of Patti (nee Nick) for 26 wonderful years. Dedicated father of Michelle, Maggie, Elizabeth and Kacee. Cherished brother of Charles, Marianne, Catherine, and his loving twin Michael. Dear sonin-law of James and Gail Nick. Also survived by many caring nieces, nephews, aunts, cousins, in-laws, and loyal friends. A Memorial Mass of Resurrection and celebration of Eddie's life will take place at his parish Church of St. Dominic, Anstice St. in Oyster Bay, New York, at 10:00 AM, Saturday, September 22, 2001. Friends wishing to honor him are invited to contribute to the Papa Children Memorial Fund, C/O 60 Highwood Rd, Oyster Bay, New York 11771. May God bless all of our families and keep them in His care.

title: Brahms as Soothing Balm
description: First the New York Philharmonic, stranded in Germany last week, scrapped the season-opening gala it had planned for tonight, with Anne-Sophie Mutter as the soloist in Beethoven's Violin Concerto. Kurt Masur decided to substitute a single work, Brahms's ''German Requiem,'' which he considers perhaps the most poignant example of a secular version of the form.

title: Stocks End Down Sharply as Worried Investors Sell Off Shares Again
description: Stocks dropped sharply again today, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling more than 4 percent, as investors' fears about a recession grew along with their uncertainty about the scope of American retaliation for last week's terrorist attacks.

title: A Screen That Thwarts Those Prying Eyes
description: Say you're on an airplane, and you don't want those Nosy Parkers around you to see that important e-mail message you're reading on your hand-held. Or maybe you just don't want them to see that that you're actually playing Minesweeper.

title: Stage Union Takes Pay Cut at 5 Plays
description: Responding to a plea from beleaguered producers, officials of the Broadway stagehands' union said yesterday that they would accept a 25 percent reduction in pay for the next four weeks for five long-running shows in the wake of decreased tourism and theater attendance related to last week's terrorist attacks.

title: Awww, That's Cute Enough To Frame (With a TV Screen)
description: The Hobbesian choice between watching television at your friend's house or looking at baby pictures at your friend's house has finally been resolved. Thanks to Microsoft, you can look at baby pictures on the television at your friend's house.

title: World Briefing | Pacific: Nauru: First Refugees Arrive
description: The first group of 100 Afghan refugees who had been stranded at sea for three weeks arrived at this tiny island after Australia turned them away. Hundreds more are on their way here, where United Nations officials are to process applications for refugee resettlement. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: I.M.F. Bankers Get Ready To Give Pakistan a Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund is prepared to go ahead with a sizable loan for Pakistan and is closely monitoring the financial situation in Turkey as it seeks to counter a world economic slowdown and support front-line states in the battle against terrorism, officials said today.

title: Detroit, With Its Sales Falling, Is Urged to Help Spur Economy
description: Two top Bush administration officials made an unscheduled visit to Detroit today to urge the auto industry to do what it can to help stimulate an economy on the brink of recession.

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September; In Charge of Recovery
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CORCORAN, MABELLE H.
description: CORCORAN-Mabelle H., age 100, formerly of Brooklyn, died on September 22nd, 2000. Memorial services will be held at 11:00 A.M. Friday, September 21, 2001 in the Church of St. Gabriel Catholic Church. Interment will be in St. John's Cemetery.

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September; Disgraceful Layoffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Sad Fairy Tale With an Extremist's Letter: It's Opera
description: ''The Little Match Girl,'' arguably Hans Christian Andersen's saddest fairy tale, tells of an impoverished child who on a freezing New Year's Eve dares not go home to her brutish father because she has sold no matches. To warm herself she lights a match and sees a food-laden table that quickly vanishes in the dark. A second match brings forth a cheerful Christmas tree. And yet another summons the spirit of her grandmother who then carries her away to ''brightness and joy'' in the sky. The next morning the little girl is found frozen to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUER, DAVID, RUMSON
description: BAUER-David, Rumson, NJ. Victim the World Trade Center Attack. Graduate of Red Bank Catholic and Villanova University. Mr. Bauer was head of Global Sales for E-SPEED, Division of Cantor Fitzgerald. Prior to joining ESPEED, Dave was with Credit Suisse First Boston; where he was head of Fixed Income Global Sales. He also worked for Lehman Brothers as a Managing Director; Mr. Bauer began his career with Merrill Lynch. He was a member of Rumson Country Club, Sea Bright Lawn Tennis, Monmouth Beach Bath & Tennis and Due Process Golf Club. He was an excellent athlete and participated in all sports. He was a past President and Founding member of the Villanova Financial Club and was recently inducted into the Villanova Hall of Fame for his football accomplishments. David was on the Board of Family & Children's Services and with his wife was honored with the Helen Hoffman Award for Community Service. He was a member of Holy Cross RC Church, Rumson. Surviving are his wife, Ginny, three children, David 16, Stephen 14 and Jacqueline 12. Parents Walter and Dorothy Bauer, Red Bank; brother, Robert Bauer, Landenberg, PA; sisters Gretchen Bauer, Dalton, GA, Heidi Pollard, Oceanport, NJ. Mother-inlaw Virginia Samaras, Little Silver, NJ. A Celebratory Mass will be held Friday, September 21, at Nativity Church, Fair Haven, NJ , 12:30PM. Memorial donations may be made to Tuberous Sclerosis Alliance, 801 Roeder Road, Suite 750, Silver Spring, MD 20910

title: In Crisis, Giuliani's Popularity Overflows City
description: Perhaps it was yesterday, when the president of France proclaimed that the French had begun praising the ''Maire-hros'' -- which he called the French equivalent of ''Rudy the Rock.'' Or maybe it was a few days before, when Barbara Walters promised the nation that she would reveal the mayor of New York as he had never been seen before. And surely the clues were already there last week when the president of the United States came to visit the site of terrorist devastation and the rescue workers there saved their loudest exaltation for the mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SHIRLEY (NEE UNGER)
description: SCHWARTZ-Shirley (nee Unger). Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of Carole S. Hyatt and Charles Schwartz. Loving grandmother of Cynthia, Jeffrey, Ariel. Great-grandmother of Robin, Alex, Aron, Amy. Godmother of Stewart Unger. ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEUSTON, GEORGE FRANKLIN
description: HEUSTON-George Franklin. Artist from Garrison, NY. On 9/16/01. Born South Bend, WA 8/24/06. Husband of Gwendolyn R. Heuston 6/ 23/12-6/20/96. A fine artist, studied anatomy at P&S Columbia, drawing with George Bridgman, Art Students League and painting at National Academy of Design. Painted in lifeboat during 7 days after his merchant ship, SS Santa Rita, was sunk by U-boat. Believed only paintings created under such conditions. Exhibits 1939 through present. Son, Paul Heuston survives. Joint service for Gwen and George to be held at St. Philip's Church, Garrison on 9/21. Gifts to National Maritime Historical Society, Peekskill, NY appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEIN, LEON EDWARD
description: WEIN-Leon Edward. Dearest Friend.

title: Playing an Acoustic Guitar As if It Were a Full Band
description: Melissa Ferrick's head gleamed as she stood onstage Monday at the Bowery Ballroom. The light hit that shaved pate as if it were a reflector warning the world that this feisty singer-songwriter was zooming into its lane. ''I'm gonna grab my soul and leave my ego at the door,'' she sang in ''Welcome to My Life'' as her fervent audience cheered. Her devotees may love Ms. Ferrick for her rock 'n' roll heart, but her ignited mind gave her show its excitement.

title: A Wounded Heart
description: For Milton Glaser, the graphic artist still celebrated for his 1975 ''I New York'' poster, it came like a thunderbolt on the morning after.

title: In This Section
description: U.S. FORCES ON THE MOVE

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Steuben Day Parade Canceled
description: The organizers of the 44th German-American Steuben Day Parade have canceled Saturday's march because of the trade center attack. The chairman of the parade committee, William Hetzler, urged people to attend a service for the victims and their families at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 9:30 a.m. Saturday instead. ''Now is the time to come together with one purpose, to help our city and our nation heal, to show our profound support for all who are deeply affected by this catastrophe, and to work together to rebuild our city and our nation,'' Mr. Hetzler said in a news release. Among the victims at the trade center were firefighters, musicians and sponsors of parade floats who regularly participate, he said. Daniel J. Wakin

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about the release of the names of 39 people confirmed dead in the attack at the World Trade Center referred incorrectly to the father of one victim, Keith McHeffey. The father, who was not identified, does not work at the World Trade Center. The article also misstated the given name of Mr. McHeffey's former sister-in-law, who was quoted. She is Mary McHeffey, not Amanda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRY, JOSEPH JOHN
description: BERRY-Joseph John. Of Saddle River, N.J. Joe was a victim of the World Trade Center tragedy. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Cherished father of Joseph Scott, Todd Patrick and Kimberly Ann. Our family and community have lost a person of great integrity, generosity and unbridled love for his fellow man. His children have lost their mentor, best friend and guiding light in all things. His wife has lost her partner, her best friend, her love. Joe was a man that always had a smile on his face and his family was his first priority. We are grateful to have had such a man in our lives and his spirit and philosophies will live through us and guide us always. Joe grew up in Woodhaven, Queens, attended Molloy High School, received his BA in Economics and Math from Queens College and his MBA from St. John's University. He was Chairman and Co-CEO of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, Inc., an investment banking firm headquartered in the World Trade Center. For the last two years, Joe was honored as one of the top fifty Irishmen on Wall Street by Irish America Magazine. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at 12:30pm on Saturday, September 22 at St. Gabriel's Church, 88 East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ. No flowers please. Donations are requested to the Joseph J. Berry Scholarship Fund, Archbishop Molloy High School, 83-53 Maton Street, Briarwood, NY, 11435, attention Brother Richard. 718-441-2100

title: Voices Not Silenced, Feet Not Stilled; As They Return to Work, Artists Talk Performing in a Time of Tragedy
description: Roger Bart has a major role in a Broadway blockbuster, but suddenly all the hoopla over his show, ''The Producers,'' seemed frivolous. ''I remember thinking how strange it was to hear an anchorman on TV say this and that would remain closed but that Broadway shows would be open again,'' he said. ''I felt a little embarrassed.''

title: For a Village of Two-Story Buildings, the Skyscraper Attack Reverberates
description: They were from the same rural village in Guyana, without electricity, telephones, or buildings higher than two stories. But aspiration and global markets put them both inside New York City's tallest towers at the moment when terrorism struck America.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business yesterday about the discount rate in Japan misstated the reduction. The rate was cut to 0.1 percent from 0.25 percent, not 0.15 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOFFA, MARY CATHERINE NEE MURPHY
description: BOFFA-Mary Catherine nee Murphy. Taken from her loving family at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Loving daughter of the late Anne and John Murphy, dear sister of Margaret Trudeau, Elizabeth Murphy and Diane and Charles Brierley, devoted aunt of Maureen and Michael Trudeau and Kristen and Jennifer Brierley. Former wife of John Boffa. Memorial service at Thomas M. Quinn and Sons Inc, 35-20 Broadway, L.I.C., NY. Visiting hours Friday 6 to 9 PM. Memorial Mass will be celebrated at Most Precious Blood RC Church, Sat. 11:15 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Twin Towers Fund, GPO, POB 26999, NYC 10087-6999 or The American Red Cross.

title: Economic Scene; Gross domestic product vs. gross domestic well-being.
description: SHORTLY after the planes slammed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon last week, a reporter called to ask, ''What effect will the terrorist attacks have on the economy?''

title: Senate Democrat Opposes White House's Antiterrorism Plan and Proposes Alternative
description: The Democratic chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that he opposed the Bush administration's proposals to broaden the government's powers to detain and deport immigrants suspected of terrorism and offered a separate package of counterterrorism legislation.

title: Pilotless Copter Gets a Look as an Investigation Tool
description: REMEMBER those radio-controlled model airplanes you played with as a child? A grown-up version of a helicopter has been developed by researchers who hope that it will one day help stranded flood victims, follow cars in high-speed chases and provide traffic reports, all without the aid of a human pilot in the air -- or even one on the ground. Last week, it was nearly put into action to help investigators with the crash of United Airlines Flight 93 near Pittsburgh.

title: In the Gaza Strip, Anger at the U.S. Still Smolders
description: Two symbols of Palestinians' anger against the United States hovered over Gaza City shortly after noon on Saturday. The city went to the streets, all heads craned up. The two black dots above were American-made Apache helicopters, searching for targets.

title: Museum-Quality Furnishings
description: For most people, museums are just for looking. But ''Objects for Use: Handmade by Design,'' an exhibition at the American Craft Museum, showcases 400 pieces of furniture, housewares and other useful items that are all available to buy. A list at the museum gives contact information for the artists and the places that sell their work. This queen-size four-poster bed ($2,400, allow four to six weeks) is by Brad Smith, a woodworker from Worcester, Pa., who calls his style rusticated contemporary. Mr. Smith can be reached at www.bradfordwoodworking .com or (610) 584-1150. A cutting board, above left, 14 by 20 inches in a combination of laminated hardwoods by David Levy of Davis, Calif., is $200; (530) 758-6624 or www.davidlevycreations .com. Hand-forged steel kitchen utensils, above right, by Thomas Latan of Pepin, Wis., cost $25 to $200, and the rack is $65; (715) 442-2419. The exhibition opened Saturday and runs through Jan. 6 at the museum, 40 West 53rd Street. A comprehensive book, also called ''Objects for Use: Handmade by Design'' (Abrams, $75), contains photographs and the list of sources. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September; The Architects
description: To the Editor:

title: Novelists Reassess Their Subject Matter
description: In the hours after the terrorist attacks last week, many American novelists, whether engaged in themes far removed from the horrific events or not, asked themselves if what they do had turned irrelevant.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Premieres Diverted

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: JDS Revises Loss Figures
description: JDS Uniphase, which in July reported a $50.6 billion loss for the fiscal year that ended June 30, said yesterday that a fuller analysis revealed an even bleaker result. The company, which supplies telecommunications network components, added $1.1 billion to its previously reported losses for its third quarter and $4.2 billion to its fourth quarter. The $5.3 billion in losses, like the bulk of those previously reported, reflects the difference between what JDS paid for a number of acquisitions and their worth after the crash in technology stocks. But because JDS paid for the acquisitions with its own inflated stock, the red ink is largely a matter of accounting. JDS also said it was adding $76 million to the $270 million it wrote off in its fourth quarter to reflect the declining value of unsold products in its inventories, a move that suggests that the downturn in demand for its products has worsened since July. Still, JDS shares rose 35 cents, or 6.5 percent, to $5.70. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUTZ, RUTH
description: SCHUTZ-Ruth, age 85, died peacefully in her home in Manhattan's Greenwich Village. She is survived by her loving husband of 61 years, Nathan R.; adoring children, Carol and Tom; devoted grandchildren, Michael and Daniel; loyal sisters, Gertrude and Sylvia; wonderful brother and sister-in-law, Bernie and Adeline. Because she lived, loved and taught art, she helped leave this world a slightly better place than she found it. She will long be remembered for her intelligence, her beauty and her devotion to her family and the arts. Services to be held Thursday, September 20, 2001, 10 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations can be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Hospital or the American Red Cross.

title: Using a Cellphone Signal to Hunt For a Victim in Desperate Need
description: SOME people in or near Lower Manhattan were surprised last week when they turned on their cellphones and were almost immediately called by their wireless carriers. The companies, it turns out, were monitoring cellular signals near the collapsed World Trade Center towers to try to find survivors who might have been trapped or were otherwise unaccounted for.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Growth Slowing
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Europe's largest oil company, has lowered its target for annual growth in oil and natural gas output to 3 percent. The company said it took the action because of slowing demand for energy and delays with new fields in Africa and the Middle East. The forecast was cut from an average of 5 percent growth a year through 2005. Shell's new goal is the same as its larger rival, the Exxon Mobil Corporation, though lower than those of smaller peers like BP and TotalFinaElf.

title: Surge of New Technologies Erodes U.S. Edge in Spying
description: For decades, the United States used its technical expertise to gather electronic signals and eavesdrop on the intimate conversations of its adversaries, including Kremlin leaders in their limousines. Fleets of satellites blanketed the globe, overhearing all manner of signals, messages and conversations, day and night.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about William Spencer, former president of Citibank, omitted his permanent residence and a reference to one survivor. Mr. Spencer lived in North Palm Beach, Fla., and is survived by a grandson in addition to two granddaughters.

title: Dealt a Heavy Blow, A Commodities Dealer Struggles to Carry On
description: When Didier Varlet, the French-born chief executive of Carr Futures Inc., a global futures trading firm, ran through disaster drills, they always involved computer backups, new telephone lines and ways to get his employees up and running.

title: Merrimac Coup Is Unused, And a Bad Contract Makes
description: There are probably more bridge players than historians who are aware of an episode in the Spanish-American War when the United States Navy sank a cargo ship to block a vital harbor channel in Santiago, Cuba. The ship was the Merrimac, not to be confused with the Merrimack of Civil War fame, and it gave its name to an important defensive maneuver at the bridge table. As might be expected, it is an attempt to interfere with the opponents' communications.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Worm's Spread Is Said To Slow
description: The incidence of infection by a powerful new computer worm appeared to slow yesterday, but security experts warned that there might be ongoing effects. The malicious program, known as the Nimda Worm, emerged on Tuesday, spreading to tens of thousands of computers and exploiting vulnerabilities in Microsoft software, according to the Computer Emergency Response Team. The CERT Coordination Center, based at Carnegie Mellon University, warned that the worm included code that would try to resend infected e-mail messages every 10 days. In addition, the worm is designed to render infected computers vulnerable to remote access so online intruders may view or alter files on those machines, security experts said. But the experts said the worm was such an enormous piece of computer code that they had not yet fully assessed it. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Essay; Equal Time for Hitler?
description: The primary source of information for the average Afghan is the radio, often a transistor made 30 years ago. The 20 transmitting towers of the Taliban's Radio Shariat (meaning ''Islamic law'') are spewing out hatred of America all the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALLEN, ANNE
description: TALLEN-Anne. On September 18, 2001. Beloved wife of Nathaniel (Teddy). Devoted mother of Sheila and Irwin Cohen, Diane Spigel & Bette Tallen. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey and Karen Spigel, Robin Spigel, Allison and Kevin Stahl, and Meredith Cohen. Sweet great grandmother of Jacob Stahl. Services at Riverdale Temple, West 246th Street and Independence Avenue, Thursday, September 20th at 1 PM.

title: Terror Strikes America / Political Strategies: Schroeder Urges Europe To Stand Against Foes
description: PARIS  Germany is ready to take military risks to back up its commitment of unlimited solidarity with the United States, Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder said on Wednesday, and called on Europe to strengthen its cooperation in a battle against terrorism.

title: Once Is Not Enough For This DVD Recorder
description: Until recently, DVD writers had only been able to write to discs once. Hewlett Packard's DVD100i, the company's new internal combination DVD+RW/CD-RW drive, takes DVD writers to a new phase of sophistication.

title: A Real Beach House
description: To the Editor:

title: New Stadiums Slip Far Down On the List Of Priorities
description: Last week's terrorist attacks are expected to delay any planning for new Yankees and Mets stadiums for the foreseeable future, according to sports finance experts and current and former government officials.

title: Game Makers Scale Back; Players Have Other Ideas
description: IN response to last week's terrorist attacks, game makers have modified or delayed the release of games with scenes that might now be considered insensitive. But some game players have gone on the offensive.

title: Bush and Leaders Confer on Way To Bolster Weakened Economy
description: President Bush and the leaders of both parties in Congress began considering plans today to boost the faltering economy, but they signaled that they would take time to assess the spreading damage from the terrorist attacks before deciding on a package.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pirelli Cuts Olivetti Price
description: After Tuesday's announcement that Pirelli wanted to renegotiate its deal with Bell, a holding company, over the acquisition of Olivetti, Pirelli has persuaded Olivetti's former chief executive, Roberto Colaninno, and Bell investors to buy bonds that are scheduled to be repaid six years from now in Olivetti shares. In addition, two Bell investors have agreed to give Pirelli a billion euros ($954 million) in loans at rates that are cheaper than the credit that is given to rivals. Pirelli expects to save 775 million euros ($720 million) under the new terms. In July, Pirelli teamed up with the Benetton family to buy a 23 percent controlling stake in Olivetti from Bell. Since then, the price of Olivetti stock has fallen 50 percent. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Billions Will Be Spent On Replacing Technology
description: Just six hours after two jets slammed into the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, one securities firm crippled by the attack ordered 200 new PC's from Dell Computer.

title: Late-Afternoon Rally Stems Steep Losses; Dow Declines 1.6%
description: Stocks plunged most of yesterday, then recovered sharply in the final hour of trading as investors struggled to reconcile a raft of ugly profit reports with the hope that the economy might recover strongly next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNCAN, NATHANIEL HAMMOND
description: DUNCAN-Nathaniel Hammond, 14, of London, England and Chatham, Massachusetts, died Sunday at Children's Hospital in Washington, DC, almost a year after he was first diagnosed with a brain tumor. After initially receiving treatment in London, he had come to Washington in May. His parents, Jim and Laura Duncan, and his brother Sam were at his bedside when he died. Nat attended Emanuel School in Battersea. He was a junior counselor at Camp Monomoy on Cape Cod, and commuted between Washington and Cape Cod this summer to be able to attend camp while receiving treatment. Nat's principal interests included archery, real (court) tennis, theater and his Labrador retriever, Laddie. In addition to his parents and brother, Nat is survived by his grandfather, J. Bruce Duncan, and by aunts, uncles and cousins. Nat's funeral will be at 2 p.m. on Saturday, September 22, at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan, Connecticut. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church in Battersea later this fall. Contributions in Nat's memory may be made to the Children's National Medical Center in Washington.

title: Peace Signs Amid Calls for War
description: The drumbeat for war, so loud in the rest of the country, is barely audible on the streets of New York.

title: An Odd Business Felt Even Odder
description: For all but the grieving, the rescuers, the reporters at the scene, there's the sense of having been marginalized this past week. People have been getting back to work, cautiously, and that is true in book publishing as elsewhere. But nonetheless there's the feeling of cessation, abeyance, except for those publishers and literary agents who by circumstance had work at the ready that was precisely of the moment. I received several books on Afghanistan and Islam yesterday from publishers, for instance.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Long-Distance Service Approved
description: Verizon Communications, the dominant local telephone company in the eastern United States, gained approval from the Federal Communications Commission to offer long-distance service in Pennsylvania. The F.C.C. required proof that Verizon had sufficiently opened its network to competition on the local level in Pennsylvania. The company already has approval to offer long-distance service in New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, ROBERT
description: BECKER-Robert. Yeshiva University Museum is deeply saddened by the loss of a cherished friend and advisor. Bob's aesthetic sensibility and skilled designs are reflected in YUM's exhibitions, galleries and offices. YUM presented Bob with the Omanut award in recognition of his two decades of dedicated service. We will miss Bob's enthusiasm, creativity and thoughtfulness. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ruth, and his entire family. Erica Jesselson, Chairman Sylvia Herskowitz, Director

title: Venturi, Scott Brown Rides a Post-Postmodern Wave of Fame
description: The husband and wife team of Robert Venturi, 76, and Denise Scott Brown, 70, who wrote postmodernism's early manifestos, are once again media stars. Mr. Venturi, who won the Pritzker Prize in 1991, was the cover boy of Architecture magazine in May, and the couple are on the October cover of Metropolis. Now comes a panel discussion of their work, which includes a government building in Toulouse, France, left. The architect Rem Koolhaas and other panelists will gather on Sept. 29 at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue (34th Street). They will also explore the future of architecture after the attack on the World Trade Center. Tickets are $20, reservations required; (212) 817-8215. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: In the wake of the tragedies that occurred on September 11, readers share their thoughts on travel safety.

title: I.R.A. Offers to Renew Contact With the Disarmament Panel
description: The Irish Republican Army offered today to renew contact with the international panel charged with supervising the disarming of Northern Ireland's paramilitary groups. But it made no mention of any disarmament move of its own, a step considered essential to keep the peace accord from coming to a halt this weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, CHRISTOPHER MICHAEL
description: DUFFY-Christopher Michael. A resident of Crestwood. Died on September 11, 2001 in the attack on the World Trade Center. He was born February 19, 1978 in the Bronx to John and Kathleen Duffy. Chris grew up in Crestwood and attended Annunciation Grammar School and graduated from Fordham Preparatory School in 1996, where he captained the lacrosse team. He received his B.A. in Finance from Villanova in May 2000 and joined the investment firm Keefe, Bruyette & Woods the following month as an assistant trader on the firm's equity desk. He is survived by his parents, John and Kathleen, his brothers Brian and Kevin, his sisters Kara and Caitlin, and his grandmothers Anne Downey and Alice Langan. The family will be receiving friends on Friday, September 21, 2001 between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY. Celebration of Life and Mass of the Resurrection Saturday, September 22, 10:30 AM at the Annunciation Church, Westchester Avenue, Crestwood. Donations in lieu of flowers should be made to The Chris Duffy Memorial Scholarship Fund, Fordham Preparatory School, East Fordham Road, Bronx, NY 10458.

title: Boeing Plans Big Layoffs As Recession Threatens
description: PARIS  Boeing said Wednesday that it would lay off as many as 30,000 workers and American Airlines said it would cut at least 20,000 positions, as the fallout from the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington hit hard in the aerospace and tourism industries.

title: Mets Will Donate One Day's Pay to Fund
description: When the Mets return to Shea Stadium on Friday for their first home game since last week's terrorist attacks, they will be playing without pay. In a meeting before batting practice today at PNC Park, the Mets decided to donate a day's salary to a charity headed by the former Met Rusty Staub.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, KATHLEEN ANN
description: LYONS-Kathleen Ann. Peacefully on September 19, 2001 of Deer Park. Age 57. Beloved daughter of Kathleen J. Lyons and the late Edwin T. Lyons. Dearest sister of Mary Pat and Thomas E. Lyons. Loving aunt of Thomas J., Dr. Michelle Brooks and Brendan Lyons. Cherished great aunt of Ethan, Cyrus and Connor. Coordinator of Volunteers at the Planting Fields Arboretum. Former French and Spanish teacher. Reposing at Mangano Funeral Home Inc., 1701 Deer Park Avenue, Deer Park, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 79:30 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 AM. St. Matthew R.C. Church, Dix Hills. Interment in St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations in Kathleen's memory to the Good Shepherd Hospice, 655 Deer Park Avenue, Babylon, New York 11702.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Dividends From State Fund Drop
description: Dividends from the state's Permanent Fund, paid out annually to almost 590,000 Alaskans from revenues on oil exploration, dropped $113 this year to $1,850. Revenue Commissioner Wilson Condon attributed the fund's lower earnings to the past year's dip in the stock market. The fund was established in 1978 to attract people to Alaska.

title: NATO, Though Supportive, Has Little to Offer Militarily
description: As the United States prepares its response to last week's terrorist attacks, many military analysts say that the NATO alliance, though it has pledged its support, at least politically, has very little to offer the United States militarily.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Has Failed to Trace Bin Laden's Money Trail

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We signed up knowing the risk. Those innocent people in New York didn't go to work thinking there was any kind or risk.''

title: N.F.L. Officials Approve Pact and Will Be Back Sunday
description: N.F.L. game officials voted yesterday to accept a new contract that the league had recently offered, ending a lockout during which replacements officiated N.F.L. games for the first time. The regular officials will return to the field for Sunday's games.

title: Yankees' Channel Names Executive
description: John Filippelli, executive producer of ABC Sports since 1999, was named executive vice president for programming and production of the Yankees Entertainment and Sports Network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCCHI, JOHN P.
description: BOCCHI-John P. 38, on September 11, 2001, unfortunate casualty of WTC. Resided New Vernon, NJ. Beloved husband of Michele Cirrincione Bocchi, loving father of Matthew, Nicholas, Michael and Paul. Dear son of Camillo and Elena Bocchi of Fort Lee NJ. Wonderful brother and uncle. For info call Doyle F.H. 973-539-0622.

title: Battery Park Set to Reopen To Residents Of North End
description: More than a week after the World Trade Center attack, officials will begin allowing Battery Park City residents to return to their homes today, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SULLIVAN, TIMOTHY F.
description: O'SULLIVAN-Timothy F. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Cultural Institutions Retirement System deeply mourn the loss of a great friend and a wonderful colleague who was taken from us at the World Trade Center on September 11. Tim was the long-serving representative to CIRS from the Wildlife Conservation Society and since his retirement in 1997, he has remained active as a consultant to our Board. Tim's wisdom and vast knowledge of New York's cultural institutions, his marvelous sense of humor and his strong belief in the CIRS plans are an inspiration to all of us. Tim's proudest accomplishment was the role he played in bringing financial security to thousands of Cultural Institution and Daycare employees. Tim was an example to us all and his light will shine on us forever. He will be missed by all of us and we extend our deepest sympathy to his family. William E. Havemeyer, Chair Robert M. Fox, Exec. Director Raymond Miller, Assoc. Director

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Sale Plan
description: The government said it would try again to sell off much of its controlling stake in Korea Telecom, the country's dominant telephone company, perhaps as soon as January. Previous plans to sell the stake failed. Unconfirmed reports that the government planned to relax a ceiling of 5 percent on any one investor's stake in the company prompted a 3.2 percent rise in Korea Telecom's stock price yesterday. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Love-in-a-Sandwich

title: Clemens Puts Name Into Record Book
description: The phone calls from family and friends began at noon today and came to Roger Clemens in rapid succession; good luck, best wishes. But no one mentioned how Clemens had the chance to become the first pitcher to win 20 of his first 21 decisions. They just kept reminding Clemens that he was a representative of New York.

title: Primary Voters Reject Seattle Mayor After One Term
description: For the first time in 65 years, voters here have thrown out an incumbent mayor in a primary election, ousting the one-term mayor, Paul Schell, on Tuesday after a turbulent four years in which the city's image took a battering and its economy stumbled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHUGH, MICHAEL EDWARD JR.
description: McHUGH-Michael Edward Jr. Of Tuckahoe, New York, died tragically and innocently on September 11, 2001 at One World Trade Center. He was 35 years old. Mr. McHugh worked as the director of sales for TradeSpark, a subsidiary of Cantor Fitzgerald, a brokerage firm, located on the 105th floor of the World Trade Center. Mr. McHugh was born to Michael and Eileen McHugh on March 9th, 1966 in the Bronx. His family moved to Stony Point, New York in 1972. Mr. McHugh was in the midst of his second term as a Tuckahoe Village Trustee. He spent his last days campaigning as the Republican nominee for the Westchester County Board of Legislators from the 10th district, which includes Eastchester, Tuckahoe, and New Rochelle. Mr. McHugh is survived by his wife Maria Cermele McHugh, sons Michael Edward III, 6, Christian Salvatore, 3, and Connor Joseph, 1; his parents, Michael and Eileen McHugh of Stony Point, N.Y.; brother, John, of Stroudsburg, PA.; and sister, Darby, of East Hampton, N.Y.; grandmother Ellen McHugh of County Meath, Ireland and in-laws, Pina and Sal Cermele of Eastchester, N.Y. The family will receive visitors at Romano Family Funeral Home, 24 Depot Square, Tuckahoe, NY, Friday from 2-4 and 7-9. A Memorial Mass will be held at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale on Saturday, September 22 at 9:45 AM. In lieu of flowers. memorial donations can be made to the Michael McHugh, Jr. Memorial Fund, PO Box 112, Eastchester, New York 10709.

title: 3 Studies Show Drug Can Slow Kidney Disease
description: A widely used class of blood pressure drugs can sharply slow the progress of kidney disease in people with the most common form of diabetes, delaying by two to three years the need for dialysis or a transplant, researchers are reporting.

title: Neighbors, Shining Through; A Place to Live, Or to Leave?
description: WHEN Diane Alexander moved to the financial district in 1997, the neighborhood had no decent supermarkets, no 24-hour drugstores and few restaurants besides those catering to a lunch crowd. Ms. Alexander got used to lugging her groceries home on the bus.

title: It's Going to Take More Than Elbow Grease
description: LAST Thursday, when Mary Miss and her husband, George Peck, returned to their loft apartment near the disaster site, they took one look around and vowed to return the next day with reinforcements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, AARON
description: JACOBS-Aaron. Of Manhattan, 27 years old, was a European equities trader at Cantor Fitzgerald. He died September 11 in the senseless tragedy of the World Trade Center attack. His great enthusiasm for life expressed itself in sports, his many friendships and travel. He was the much loved younger brother of Joshua and son of Alice and Larry Jacobs of Newton, MA. He is survived by his fiancee Jeannine McAteer of Jersey City, his grandparents Alex and Harriet Katz of Phoenix. All will miss his sparkle and good sense.

title: Blair, Rallying Support for Anti-Terrorism Coalition, Tours New York
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain arrived in New York today to offer comfort to relatives of the estimated 300 Britons feared dead in the attacks on the World Trade Center and to help rally support for the United States-led coalition against terrorism.

title: Metro Matters; Our Daily Tribute to Differences Provokes Dislike Among Many
description: As readers of this space must know, Matters is not your most emotional of columns. A temporary departure from routine, however, for two reasons. One is Mohammad Salman Hamdani. The other is the Rev. Jerry Falwell.

title: NATO Willing to Do More in Macedonia
description: NATO indicated today that it was prepared to extend its mission in Macedonia by providing soldiers to guard European observers monitoring the peace process there.

title: A City's Pledge of Allegiance: Shop Till You Drop
description: THE SAVAGE GIRL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACCARINO, JOE
description: YACCARINO-Joe. September 20, 1996. ''Parting is not goodbye. We'll be together again.'' As always, Nanc

title: America's Fear of Flying Has Devastating Effect On Tourist Businesses
description: With millions of people around the country putting off vacations, canceling convention plans and halting all but the most essential business trips, the nation's normally busy travel rhythms have abruptly ground down to virtual slow motion.

title: Disaster Forges a Spirit of Cooperation in a Usually Contentious Congress
description: There is something different about Washington when the Web site of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has not only stopped bashing Republicans but also quotes their speaker, J. Dennis Hastert, saying, ''As a united people, we must show our colors.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASMUSSEN, ROBERT ARTHUR
description: RASMUSSEN - Robert Arthur. Born November 14, 1958 in Fargo, N.D. to Robert and Elizabeth Rasmussen, Robert grew up in Hunter, N.D. and graduated from Dakota High School in 1977. He received a Bachelor of Science in Construction Engineering from North Dakota State University in 1982. Robert married Anna Worner of Fargo, N.D. in 1986. They lived in Boston, MA. for three years and moved to Cortlandt Manor, N.Y. in 1989. He received his Master of Business Administration from New York University and was a Chartered Financial Analyst. The family moved to Hinsdale, IL. in 1999. Robert had been employed by M.A. Mortenson Construction, Minneapolis, MN. from 1984 to 1986, when he joined Turner Construction in Boston. He was a consultant with Coopers & Lybrand in New York, N.Y. for two years prior to joining Vestek in 1996. Robert is survived by his wife Anna, daughter Taylor (7), and sons Jack (2-1/2) and Samuel (1-1/2); his mother Elizabeth (Rev. Jerry) Protextor, Hawley, MN.; brothers Kent (Susan) Rasmussen, West Fargo, N.D. and Jonathan Protextor, Fargo, N.D.; sisters Rebecca (Todd) Holte, Fargo, N.D. and Katherine (William Drehkoff) Protextor, Chicago, IL.; and several aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his father, Robert Kent Rasmussen. Robert Rasmussen was last seen on the 78th floor of 2 World Trade Center, approximately 45 second prior to the airplane's impact. He was identified via photo by a survivor. Memorial services for Robert Arthur Rasmussen will be held Friday, September 21st, 11AM at Hawley Lutheran Church, Hawley, MN. A memorial service was held on Monday, September 17th at Redeemer Lutheran Church, Hinsdale, IL. Memorial donations may be sent to the following fund established for the education of Robert's children: Robert A. Rasmussen Memorial Trust Fund, c/o Leaders Bank, 2001 York Road, Suite 150, Oak Brook, IL. 60523.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS-Ruth. Three years today. Her song has ended but the melody lingers on. We miss you. Joyce, Jason, Greg and Jordana

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September
description: To the Editor:

title: Quantum Theory Could Expand the Limits of Computer Chips
description: USING principles of quantum theory to manipulate light is the stuff of rarefied research, not the factory floor. But quantum theory may turn out to have surprisingly practical applications in manufacturing faster computer chips.

title: A Search for a Symbol
description: WHEN I give people who live in my town directions to my house, I usually say it's the yellow one at the end of the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHAI, JOSEPH
description: MATHAI-Joseph. Formerly of Boston and New York, September 11th. Beloved husband of Teresa (Louzado). Son of the late Dr. C. Mathai and Aleyamna (John) of India. Loving father of Michelle & Robert, both of Arlington. Brother of Jacob, John, K.K., and Cherian. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Funeral from the Keefe Funeral Home, 5 Chestnut St. (Rt. 60, adjacent to St. Agnes' Church), Arlington, on Saturday at 8 AM. Funeral Mass in St. Eulalia's at 9 AM. Relatives and friends invited. Visiting hours Friday, 6-8PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Joe may be made to the Children's Room Center for Grieving Children, 819 Mass Ave., Arlington, MA 02476, or Society for the Propagation of the Faith, 49 Franklin St., Boston, MA 02110.

title: Roadblocks Cited in Efforts to Trace bin Laden's Money
description: Asix-year struggle to uncover Osama bin Laden's financial network failed because American officials did not skillfully use the legal tools they had, did not realize they needed stronger weapons, and faced resistance at home and abroad, officials involved in the effort say.

title: A New Retail Store That's a Puzzle of Mirrors and Spotlights
description: The new two-story Max Mara store in SoHo, left, is eager to fool the eye. Upstairs, there are concrete walls that look like felt stitched with semicircles of steel cable resembling loose loops of thread. ''Max Mara is known for its pontino stitch, an exaggerated hand stitch on the seams, or edges of the sleeves,'' said Fernando Correa Granados, an assistant to Ducciomaria Grassi, of Studio Grassi in Italy, an architect who designed the store with flexibility in mind. On the lower floor, chunky angular pull-out shelves use magnets for handles and contain spotlights for the shelves below. Mirrored panels reverse to leather. The store, which cost $5 million to build on a former parking lot, is at 450 West Broadway (near Prince Street). ELAINE LOUIE

title: Boxes That Capture Light
description: ''Most rooms are overlit,'' said John Wigmore, 31, an artist whose medium is light. His pieces, filling a niche between art and custom furnishings, are made with incandescent bulbs and parchment from Pearl art supplies. They become, Mr. Wigmore (below in his Brooklyn loft) said, ''the center of attention'' but unassumingly. His first line (11 pieces for wall, floor or table, from $600 to $5,000) can be seen by appointment at the Pucci showroom, 44 West 18th Street; (212) 633-0452. DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEST, LOUIS ALLISON (''AL'')
description: WEST-Louis Allison (''Al''). Of Queens, N.Y., on September 15th. Beloved husband of Judith (Prioleau) and father of Tracey and Darrel; father-in-law of Michael Bolden and Samantha (Kopp) West; adored grandfather of Nicholas and Allyson; brother of Jacqueline; uncle of Eric, Mark, Marie, Christine, Jennifer. Grand-uncle, Playwright and Friend. He will be forever loved and missed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Phone Profit Warning
description: First-half revenue in the biggest division of Cable and Wireless probably contracted about 5 percent in the six months that will end on Sept. 30, the company said, because of slumping prices for voice and data services. The unit, which has operations in the United States, Britain, Europe and Japan, was expected as recently as May to report an increase in its revenue for the first half. In addition, Cable and Wireless said that the remainder of its fiscal year promised to be equally as weak as the first half. That forecast prompted a drop of 12 percent in its stock price, to 275 pence ($4.04) a share. That price was a nine-year low for Cable and Wireless. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Warns On Outlook
description: Shares of Adobe Systems Inc. slid 13.3 percent after the graphic design software maker warned that it would miss its earnings and sales forecasts this quarter. Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., reported third-quarter earnings, excluding special items, of 28 cents a share, matching Wall Street's expectations despite a revenue shortfall. But the company lowered its fourth-quarter prediction to 27 or 28 cents a share, from 31 cents, because of rapidly declining sales in Japan and weak demand among American ''creative professionals.'' Bruce Chizen, chief executive of Adobe, said the forecast did not take into account the potential impact of last week's terror attacks, which he said would hurt Adobe's business if they pushed the economy deeper into its malaise. In light of that risk, Mr. Chizen said, ''anything I say today would be nothing more than a guess.'' Adobe's shares fell $4, to $26.10. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Another Smithsonian Director Resigns
description: Spencer R. Crew, director of the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History, unexpectedly announced his resignation today.

title: U.S. Case Against Microsoft Could Take Years to Conclude
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The government today proposed a schedule for the remaining proceedings in the Microsoft ( news/quote ) antitrust case that, by taking years to conclude, could have limited effect on the software company's new operating system.

title: One Week Late, Lions Are Eager for Opener
description: There will be football played at Columbia on Saturday, and the weekend can't get here soon enough for the players and the coaches alike.

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September; A Civic Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Moves To Toughen Laws to Fight Terrorism
description: The European Commission proposed drastic changes today in European law enforcement in the aftermath of the terrorist attack on the United States.
