description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYNES, W. WARD
description: HAYNES-W. Ward, 35, of Rye. A commodities broker for Cantor Fitzgerald, he died tragically and without cause on Tuesday, September 11, at One World Trade Center. A lifelong resident of Rye, he was a devoted husband to Ann, a loving father to T.J., 12, and to his four-year-old twins, Elizabeth and Billy. He was the cherished son of Barbara Haynes and the late Hayter Haynes; the classic big brother to Katie Pepe and T.J. Haynes; and the beloved grandson of Mrs. Thomas G. Burke. He is also survived by two uncles, Mr. Thomas W. Burke of Rye and Mr. John B. Burke of White Plains, their families-and more friends than you can count. A 1984 graduate of Rye High School, Ward graduated from Northeastern University and had worked as a golf picture editor for Sports Illustrated. He joined Cantor Fitzgerald last month. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 22, at 2 P.M., at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye. In lieu of flowers, the Haynes family requests that contributions be made to the W. Ward Haynes Family Education and Charity Memorial Fund, C/O DeCaro and DeCaro, P.C., 3000 Westchester Avenue, Purchase, New York 10577.

title: Blair as Statesman Outshines Politician
description: His speech to the Trades Union Congress's convention last week had been touted in the British press as one of the most potentially confrontational moments of the prime ministership of Tony Blair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, HENRIETTA
description: BROWN-Henrietta. Beloved wife of Joseph. Beloved mother of Judith and Allan Moskowitz. Adored grandmother of Lisa and Ed Herr and great-grandmother of Eddie Herr. Dear sister of Bernice Foreman and Hilda Corn. Services at ''Boulevard-Roverside Chapels'', 1895 Flatbush Avenue (at Avenue L), Brooklyn today at 12:15PM.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Domain Rollout Is Delayed
description: Web addresses with the new .info extension will become functional on Saturday, three days later than planned, according to Afilias, the company that manages the .info database. The delay is intended to allow domain registrants and companies that register Internet addresses more time to prepare for the rollout of .info names in light of last week's terrorism. Afilias also extended until Saturday the deadline for registrars to submit applications for .info names to be considered in the first round of registrations open to the public. The addresses scheduled to begin working this weekend were registered during a special period open to intellectual-property owners. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, ROBERT CARROLL, JR.
description: McLAUGHLIN-Robert Carroll, Jr. 29, tragically lost in the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Elizabeth and devoted father of Nicholas. Loving son of Judith and Robert McLaughlin. Cherished brother of Catherine, Julie, Steven and Michael. Treasured son-in-law of Anita Lizas and Theodore Lizas. Brother-in-law to Sylvia, Michael, James and Sandra, Theodore and Michaela and many other family members and friends. Rob was born in Mineola, NY on December 6, 1971 and graduated Chaminade H.S. and Lehigh University. Rob was Vice President of Emerging Markets at Cantor Fitzgerald. He worked for them in London, Hong Kong and New York. Rob gave so much to so many people during his life and what he gave us will remain with us always. He will be sorely missed by everyone whose life he touched. A memorial service will be held at St. Joseph's Church, 130 Fifth St., Garden City, NY on Friday, September 21 at 4:30PM. In lieu of flowers please send donations to The Nicholas James McLaughlin Educational Fund, Potomac Bank of Virginia, 133 Maple Ave. East, Vienna, VA 22180 C/O of Dolores Zimmerman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURELL, EVELYN. EVELYN
description: TURELL-Evelyn. Evelyn, you were a big part of our lives. We will miss you greatly. Dora Amini and Family

title: Engineers Say Buildings Near Trade Center Held Up Well
description: Though buildings near the World Trade Center show evidence of damage like blown-out windows or gashes on their facades, none appear to be slumping, leaning or subsiding, and none are in danger of imminent collapse, engineers said yesterday after a detailed series of inspections.

title: The Right Connections; The Simple BlackBerry Allowed Contact When Phones Failed
description: ''BIG WTC explosion. I'm going to street. I'm scared.''

title: Typhoon Deals New Blow to Taiwan Manufacturers
description: Just as the world's air cargo traffic was beginning to flow again, a deadly typhoon has disrupted production in Taiwan, one of the most important suppliers of computers, semiconductors and other electronics to the United States technology industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSON, LILIAN YOHALEM
description: SELIGSON-Lilian Yohalem. Age 101. Died at home, September 19th. Widow of Harold P. Seligson, Esq. Mother of Carl H. and the late Paul Y. Seligson. Mother-in-law of Brenda and Bonnie. Grandmother of Susan and Greg Pattenaude, Judy and Tim Keller, Barbara and Bob Zweig, James Lieberman, Nina and Ari Priven and Eric Drath. Great grandmother of Kate and Andrew Pattenaude, Emily Zweig, Rachel, Regan and Sadie Keller, and Aaron and Mariel Priven. Services private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Doctors without Borders, PO Box 2247, New York, New York 10116.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, GRACE E.
description: DAVIDSON-Grace E. A longtime resident of New Jersey, died on September 14th, 2001. Lifetime companion of Patricia Valoon, beloved sister of Lavinia M. Davidson and brother-in-law George Hastings, and devoted aunt to 11 nieces and nephews, including Lauren Lazzaro of Westwood and Susan Fillgrove of Franklin, New Jersey. She was a graduate of Butler University in Indiana, the Columbia Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing and Teachers College, Columbia University. She had a long and distinguished career in nursing, achieving preeminence in positions in the Army Nurse Corps during World War II and later on the Skidmore College faculty. She retired from the Army Reserves with the rank of Major. The capstone of her career was her service as the Chief Nursing Officer at the NYU Medical Center in New York City, a position she retired from in 1979. She was an active member of the Presbyterian Church at Tenafly, the Dumont Women's Club and the Republican Party. Family and friends are invited to attend memorial services on October 6, 2001 at 11:00AM at the Presbyterian Church at Tenafly or October 9, 2001 at 4:30PM at NYU Medical Center. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested for the Davidson-Valoon Scholarship Fund in Nursing at New York University Division of Nursing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, JAMES STEWART
description: GORDON-James Stewart (83). Retired Roving Editor for Readers Digest. Died September 18th at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. He is survived by his brother, Raymond Gordon in Pittsburgh, two sons, Tom StewartGordon in Dallas and Charles Stewart-Gordon in Eugene, Oregon, and a daughter, Christina Bellinger in Newburyport, MA. Two daughters, Belle Stewart-Gordon and Katherine Stewart-Gordon, predeceased him. While married to Faith Stewart-Gordon, he contributed to the success of her restaurant, the Russian Tea Room. A collector of paintings and ceramics, he built the restaurant's paintings and objects collections. During his 30 years with Readers Digest, he wrote about travel, sports, personalities and crime, primarily from London. Prior to joining the Digest, he created successful parodies of ''MAD'' and ''Playboy'' and wrote for Parade Magazine. His novel, ''Escape from Vermont,'' was well-received. He was a member of the Union Club for many years. During WWII, he served with the Coast Artillery and in counter-intelligence. Prior to the war, he attended Haverford College. Funeral services Friday, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: The View From Wall Street
description: On the steps of Federal Hall in Lower Manhattan, George Washington stands on the spot where he was inaugurated in 1789 and with an outstretched right hand seems to ask for calm. Like most of Wall Street a week after the event the nation has still not quite found a name for, he stands in a haze of airborne grit that renders him slightly out of focus. The rumble of New York has been replaced by the more immediate roar of generators parked up and down nearly every side street in the district. To get to their jobs, most of which began again with the resumption of trading on Monday, Wall Street workers of every kind have to confront a sensory discontinuity that is every bit as sharp as the emotional discontinuity that many of them feel.

title: KODAK, HURT BY SLUMP, PLANS TO LAY OFF EMPLOYEES
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit would be more than a third below estimates and it planned to lay off employees because sales had been hurt by an economic slump now spreading overseas. Third-quarter earnings, before restructuring costs, will not exceed 65 cents a share, the company said. Kodak was expected to earn $1.03 a share by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Profit at Kodak, which is based in Rochester, has fallen in each of the last four quarters as film sales have declined.

title: Britain to Tighten Controls On Its Air and Sea Borders
description: Britain said today that it would tighten border controls to reduce the number of people seeking asylum here and to deter terrorists after the attacks on New York and Washington.

title: Stuart Sherman, 55, Performance Artist and Playwright
description: Stuart Sherman, an innovative performance artist and playwright who also worked creatively in film, video, sculpture and other visual arts, died on Friday in San Francisco. He was 55. Mr. Sherman lived in Manhattan but had been peripatetic in recent years.

title: President Outlines Vision for 'New War'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 — President Bush, in an extraordinary address to a joint session of Congress, demanded that Afghanistan's ruling Taliban immediately deliver the leaders of Osama bin Laden's terror network to the United States and close down every terrorist camp in the country or face the full military wrath of the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, CECILIA
description: COLE-Cecilia. On Tuesday September 18, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Mark Cole. Survived by nieces and nephews. Private services. Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union NJ.

title: The Frankfurt Airport Steps Up Its Scrutiny
description: Among the 63,500 employees at Frankfurt's giant airport there are almost as many nationalities as there are among the millions of passengers who pass through the airport each year.

title: Roadblocks Cited In Efforts to Trace Bin Laden's Money
description: A six-year struggle to uncover Osama bin Laden's financial network failed because American officials did not skillfully use the legal tools they had, did not realize they needed stronger weapons, and faced resistance at home and abroad, officials involved in the effort say.

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLOSOFF, MORTY
description: WOLOSOFF-Morty. Formerly a home builder, hotel owner, investor in cable systems, died in Mount Sinai Hospital on September 17th. He resided in the Sherry Netherland Hotel and also had a home in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Wolosoff was 87. He was an early developer in St. Petersburg, FL., having built there the country's largest covered marina. He was a major contributor to many charities including The American Cancer Society, United Jewish Appeal, The Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Juvenile Diabetes Association, Multiple Sclerosis Group, Arthritis Foundation, American Red Cross. Mr. Wolosoff was a boat enthusiast, having owned several large boats. The last was built over a 3-year period in England. It was lost in a mistral off the coast of France after having lived aboard only three weeks. He was a member of the City Athletic Club. Mr. Wolosoff is survived by his wife Gloria Goodman Wolosoff and a daughter Wendy Hays. Funeral services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11:30AM on Thursday, September 20.

title: Sports of The Times; Turning The Switch Back On
description: THERE was the appearance if not the sense of normalcy yesterday when the Giants wound down practice.

title: To Party or Not to Party, When the Gala Is for Children
description: Whether in good times or bad, New York's socially motivated big givers usually find a way to celebrate, but last night's gala for 700 -- the first since the attack on the World Trade Center -- had an upper-crust resolve that even Edith Wharton would have appreciated.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 9 p.m. yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, ARCHIBALD R.
description: MURRAY-Archibald R. Fordham University and the Board of Trustees mourn the loss of our alumnus and colleague, Archibald R. Murray. A graduate of the Fordham School of Law, he applied his significant legal talents to serving the public interest throughout his career and most especially during his leadership of the Legal Aid Society. His service as a Trustee and Chair of the Board's Student Affairs Committee exemplified his characteristic commitment to Fordham University and the needs of its students. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, Kay Crawford Murray, and their family. Paul B. Guenther Chair of the Board of Trustees Joseph A. O'Hare, S.J. President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCER, GEORGE E., III
description: SPENCER-George E., III. Of West Norwalk, CT. is missing in the World Trade Center disaster of September 11, 2001. Mr. Spencer, also known as Twig, was employed by Euro Brokers in the Credit Derivatives Division. George was in his office on the 84th floor of Two World Trade Center when tragedy struck. George, the devoted husband of Cathy and father of Ted 22, and Lisa 20, both of Salt Lake City, Utah, was born on September 5, 1951 in Cleveland, Ohio. George, the son of Dr. and Mrs. George E. Spencer, Jr., of Mt. Dora, Florida, graduated from the University School in Shaker Heights, Ohio and Trinity College in Hartford, CT. George's younger brother Geoffrey, his wife Sandy, and son Jonathon, live in Davidson, NC. An outdoorsman at heart, George loved biking, climbing and sailing. George's true passion and dedication was to his family as well as his close friends. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, September 22nd at 2PM at the Congregational Church, 23 Park Street, New Canaan, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the American Red Cross.

title: Bush and Leaders Confer on Way to Bolster Weakened Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  President Bush and the leaders of both parties in Congress began considering plans today to boost the faltering economy, but they signaled that they would take time to assess the spreading damage from the terrorist attacks before deciding on a package.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Manchester: Man Accused Of Running Drug Ring
description: Bail of $1.5 million has been set for a Hartford man arrested on charges that he ran what the police describe as a wide-reaching crack cocaine ring. The man, Vincent Drake, was arrested Friday after a six-month investigation. The police reported that he was seen making a delivery to a customer in a McDonald's parking lot in Glastonbury. Two suspected accomplices were arrested with him; a fourth was arrested in Manchester. Mr. Drake is charged with 67 drug and racketeering violations; his next court date is Oct. 10. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B.

title: A New Leather That Can Take the Heat And the Moisture
description: Want to upholster your outdoor furniture in leather, but afraid it won't weather well? Many surface coatings do not fully protect leather against spills like red wine or against moisture from wet bathing suits. Both can leave permanent stains. Acqua, a new upholstery leather, has waterproofing that penetrates the hide, making it protected enough to be used at poolside or on a boat. A liquid left on it for 10 hours will not leave a stain, which means this covering might last even in a child's playroom. The slightly grained leather comes in 17 colors and costs $5.95 to $8.50 a square foot, depending on the quantity ordered. (An 84-inch sofa will require 250 square feet of leather. The lower price applies to orders of more than 1,000 square feet.) From Spinneybeck, 105 Wooster Street (Spring Street). More information and dealer locations are available from (800) 482-7777 or www.spinneybeck.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: For Those Awaiting Verification of a Loved One's Fate, a Special Kind of Grief
description: The families, friends and colleagues of victims of the terrorist attacks may be struggling with a particular type of sorrow that is often felt by people who lose loved ones to disasters in which bodies are never found.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Radio Station Reopens
description: The leading private radio station was allowed to resume broadcasts, a month after the government shut it down. The station, Radio Phoenix, has become a key outlet for criticism of President Frederick Chiluba and his aborted effort to run for a third term. The station's license had lapsed, but many people doubted that caused the closing because other journalists were being arrested and charged with defaming the president. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tuition Aid For Terror Victims
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said he would propose a law guaranteeing a college education to the families of those killed or seriously wounded in the attack on the World Trade Center last week. The proposal, announced Tuesday, would cover a student's tuition, room and board, books and other expenses at a public university in New York State, or provide a similar amount -- as much as $47,000 over four years -- for a private college or university in New York. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Mideast Truce Holds, With Scattered Violence
description: Israelis and Palestinians largely held their fire today, in a mutual gesture of good will aimed at restarting talks toward a full truce.

title: Two Nations Cut Interest Rates
description: Following the lead of the Federal Reserve, the European Central Bank, the central banks of England and Japan and others, the monetary authorities of South Korea and New Zealand lowered their benchmark short-term interest rates yesterday, joining in a worldwide effort to forestall recession and reassure financial markets after the terror attacks in the United States last week.

title: La Rumorosa Journal; To Risk Death in the Desert: An Inalienable Right?
description: In recent years, more than 650 immigrants have died trying to cross the barren territory that stretches from here into southern California. Crossing it on foot, say Mexican immigration agents who patrol the area, is only slightly easier than scaling Mount Everest, requiring training and special gear.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FODOR, DAVID LAWRENCE WILLIAM
description: FODOR-David Lawrence William. Age 37, of Garrison, N.Y. died in the tragedy at the World Trade Center. Husband of Claudia Petrone. Brother of William and Richard. Private cremation in Ferncliff Crematory. Clinton, Inc. Cold Spring, N.Y. 845-265-3333.

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, RUTH (NEE SLAWIN)
description: SEGAL-Ruth (nee Slawin). On Sept. 18, 2001 of Fairfield, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Max M. Devoted mother of Peter (Ellen) Segal, Jane Segal & Carl (Cassie) Segal. Cherished grandmother of Oliver Segal, Leslie Segal, Erin Segal and Zachary Segal. Funeral from Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ. Thursday, September 20th, at 10 A.M. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: BUSH ORDERS HEAVY BOMBERS NEAR AFGHANS; DEMANDS BIN LADEN NOW, NOT NEGOTIATIONS
description: President Bush ordered heavy bombers and other aircraft to within easy striking distance of Afghanistan today and insisted that its ruling Taliban turn over Osama bin Laden and other suspected leaders of a terrorist organization believed to be behind last week's attacks in New York and Washington.

title: Two Masses, the First of Many, for Fallen Police Officers
description: As the coffin passed on a quiet Bronx street yesterday, the police officers stood at attention and saluted with white-gloved hands. One officer, his hand wrapped in a bandage instead of a glove, gingerly removed it from its sling and raised it toward his head.

title: Fugitive on F.B.I. List Arrested Outside Chicago
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 — A man believed to be a close associate of Osama bin Laden and wanted for questioning in last week's terrorist attacks has been arrested near Chicago, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Rome Offers to Bow Out for New York's 2012 Bid
description: Italian Olympic officials said yesterday that if other candidate cities agreed, Rome would step aside in favor of New York City's bid to be host of the 2012 Summer Games.

title: Support Grows for Federal Control of Airport Security
description: Senior Senators pushed today for a federal takeover of airport security, as aviation experts prepared to offer testimony at hearings on Thursday on what happened last Tuesday and what to do now.

title: In a Wounded Land, the Drums of September; To Honor the Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Money for Families Of Attack Victims Could Vary Widely
description: Although financial relief for survivors of those who died in the World Trade Center attack may total in the hundreds of millions of dollars, some families now stand to receive no more than $30,000 in direct aid, according to officials involved in government and private relief efforts.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: State Revenue Projections Drop
description: State revenue projections have dropped $101 million to $22 billion for the fiscal period from July 1, 2001, to July 30, 2003, figures from the Office of Financial Management show. Dr. Chang Mook Sohn, the state's lead economist, said future projections could be affected by declining consumer confidence, the shaky financial markets and layoffs in the airline industry.

title: Cleanup Specialists
description: A NUMBER of companies clean textiles. Clean Bright Process (212-283-6400 or 516-333-7073) charges a minimum of $125 a visit, $2.50 a square foot to clean Oriental carpets and $25 a linear foot for upholstered furniture; there is a surcharge of up to 50 percent for construction-related dust.

title: Religious Leader Takes His Calling to Ground Zero
description: AMID faces gray with grief and grime, theirs are fresh, even smiling. Among blackened uniforms and sooty equipment, their yellow T-shirts are bright buoys. They are clean.

title: For a Village of Two-Story Buildings, the Skyscraper Attack Reverberates
description: They were from the same rural village in Guyana, without electricity, telephones, or buildings higher than two stories. But aspiration and global markets put them both inside New York City's tallest towers at the moment when terrorism struck America.

title: Microsoft's Passport Sign-On System Will Work on Rival Sites
description: Microsoft will announce today that it plans to open up its online identification system to make it compatible with competing offerings under development by companies like America Online and others.

title: STAPLES NAMES EX-CAMPBELL OFFICER AS VICE CHAIRMAN
description: Staples Inc., the office supply chain, said yesterday that it had hired Basil Anderson, the former chief financial officer and treasurer of the Campbell Soup Company, as vice chairman to oversee business development. Mr. Anderson, 56, has been on Staples' board since 1997 and is head of the audit committee, the company said. He will report to the president and chief operating officer, Ronald Sargent, and will look after business and financial initiatives. Mr. Anderson will be the vice chairman along with Joseph Vassalluzzo, head of the Staples real estate business, a spokesman, Tom Nutile, said.

title: 3 Held in Detroit After Aircraft Diagrams Are Found
description: Federal agents searching for a suspected operative of Osama bin Laden have arrested three men in Detroit after a search of their house uncovered airport-employee identification badges and a date book with hand-drawn diagrams of aircraft and runways.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Indictment In Bomb Threats
description: A Queens man working as an airport cashier has been indicted on charges that he phoned in two false bomb threats to Kennedy Airport, federal prosecutors announced yesterday. The man, Marcelo Almeida, 27, of Richmond Hill, is accused of phoning 911 at 8:34 a.m. and 9:27 a.m. on Monday and saying that a bomb was inside the international arrivals terminal. The calls were traced to a private work area inside the airport for the food-court operator there, Select Service Partner Airport Restaurants, and workers were interrogated by the F.B.I. Mr. Almeida's lawyer did not immediately return phone calls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLODNER, PATRICIA M.
description: COLODNER-Patricia M., 39, on September 11, 2001. Beloved wife of Warren H. Colodner and mother of Colby (9) and Jordan (2-1/2). Daughter of Marie Pitchford and sister of Dean, Stanford and James Pitchford. Daughter-in law of Sylvia Colodner and step-mother of Gregory Colodner and Courtney Dallaire. A memorial service will be held at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, this Friday, September 21, 2001, at 2:30 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in memory of Patti to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, POB 650309, Dallas Texas 75265-0309 by request of her family.

title: A New Generation of Wireless, Built for Speed
description: Q. What exactly is this ''3G'' technology I've been hearing about?

title: Edward A. O'Neal, 57, Chief of Australian Bank
description: Edward Asbury O'Neal, an American banking executive who helped build one of Australia's best-known building societies into the fifth-largest bank in the country, died at home in Sydney on Sunday. He was 57.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the 20th anniversary of The New Criterion magazine misidentified the target of criticism by Stephen Schwartz in the current issue. He attributed distortions of George Orwell's writing about the the Spanish Civil War to a 1989 British edition of Orwell's book ''Homage to Catalonia,'' not to left-leaning editors and interpreters. (The 1989 edition took what Mr. Schwartz called key chapters and made them appendices.)

title: Editorial Observer; An Imbalance of Power: Afghanistan's Deceptive Strengths
description: As the Pentagon draws up plans for possible military action in Afghanistan, it ought to be thinking in terms of bayonets rather than stealth bombers.

title: New Security Clogs U.S. Borders
description: Traffic congestion at border crossings with Mexico and Canada began to ease a bit today as the United States brought in off-duty Customs agents and National Guard troops to relieve delays caused when security was tightened after terrorists attacked the World Trade Center and the Pentagon last week.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Orange: Local Control To Return
description: Local control returns to East Orange on Oct. 1 after state authorities' three-year-long takeover of its spending, personnel and other financial decisions. The State Local Finance Board voted last week to end a fiscal takeover that followed inadequate tax collection and budget deficits in the fiscal years 1998 and 1999. East Orange, a city of 75,000 people with a municipal budget of $118 million, posted budget surpluses in the fiscal years 2000 and 2001, and now has a tax collection rate of 86 percent, Mayor Robert L. Bowser said. East Orange remains one of five so-called distressed cities; the others are Jersey City, Paterson, Camden and Irvington.

title: Among the Troughs and Corncribs, Modernism Blooms
description: ONLY an architect would relish taking on a whimsically medieval dairy barn, stone troughs and all, and transforming it into a chic loftlike triplex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, CELIA
description: SCHUSTER-Celia. On September 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of David and Richard. Grandmother of Amanda, Benjamin and Ruth. Former President of Hadassah. Longtime resident of Far Rockaway and Cedarhurst on Long Island. Service on Friday at 11:15 AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Miner Seeks Shelter
description: Pasminco, a large zinc and lead producer, filed for the equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, succumbing to low zinc prices, mounting debt and the damage from a failed currency hedging strategy. The company's banks, which provided stopgap loans and urged Pasminco to sell assets, balked at approving yet another postponement of debt repayment. Trading in the company's shares, which have fallen almost 95 percent in the last year, was suspended. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Surveillance Deadline Extended
description: The Federal Communications Commission said it would give telephone companies an extra seven weeks to open their networks to some electronic surveillance. The commission said it would extend the deadline by seven weeks, to Nov. 19 from Sept. 30, for telephone companies and wireless service providers to comply with requests for access to packet-mode communication -- the transfer of data in small pieces or batches. The proposed regulations from the F.C.C. have been challenged by the Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association in Washington. A federal appeals court ruled last year that the F.C.C. had to consider cost and privacy concerns from the companies.

title: Terror Up Close Gave Air Safety A Lift in Britain

title: Japan's Prime Minister Pledges Support for American Retaliation
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said today that Japan's armed forces would actively support any American reprisals for last week's terrorist attacks. It was a sharp departure from past decisions when the country invoked pacifist language in its Constitution requiring it to remain on the sidelines of international conflicts.

title: Mayoral Candidates Discuss Plans for a Transformed City
description: Struggling to adjust to what has become an entirely different agenda for New York's next mayor, the six major mayoral candidates offered a troubled view of New York's future yesterday, as they began discussing ways the city could rebuild, guard against an exodus by business, and ensure the safety of its citizens from future terrorist attacks.

title: Pakistan Leader Defends Joining U.S. in Hunt for bin Laden
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 19  Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, went on nationwide television tonight to offer a tense, sometimes emotional defense of his decision to join the United States in the hunt for Osama bin Laden. General Musharraf said the situation presented this volatile Muslim nation of 140 million people with its gravest crisis in the 30 years since it lost its last major war, with India.

title: For Asthmatic Children, An Extra Health Burden
description: As late summer winds blow smoke from last week's attack around the city, many people with asthma, or any history of the condition, have been complaining about an increased difficulty in breathing, some of them going to emergency rooms in hospitals around town.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Moving Closer To U.N.
description: The lower house of Parliament voted overwhelmingly in favor of joining the United Nations, after endorsements by the cabinet and Senate. But the final word rests with the Swiss people, who will vote in a referendum in March. Opponents say membership would undermine Swiss neutrality, though Switzerland gives $300 million a year to United Nations groups. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: After a Delay, U.S. Envoy Starts in Post At the U.N.
description: John D. Negroponte, the new United States ambassador to the United Nations, formally presented his credentials to Secretary General Kofi Annan today. The presentation ended a hiatus of eight months without an American representative just as the world organization confronts the challenge posed by the terror attack last week.

title: Shaken Giants Waiting For the Whistle to Blow
description: The Giants had vowed to focus on football as they returned to practice today, and it was a promise the team kept while running plays and performing drills in preparation for Sunday's game with the Kansas City Chiefs. But when they were not on the field -- from their first meeting early this morning at Giants Stadium to the last gathering of the afternoon -- the Giants remained enveloped by the events and aftermath of last week's attack on the United States.

title: Keeping the Lifelines Open
description: ON any given day, Dave Johnson knows far more than most people about the many phone calls that are crisscrossing the United States. Mr. Johnson, a spokesman for AT&T, works in the company's global network operations center in Bedminster, N.J., where he and his colleagues monitor 141 vast projection screens that provide minute-by-minute details on the state of the country's largest long-distance system. By watching computerized maps of the United States, they can tell in an instant whether there are any jams in long-distance traffic.

description: The stock market has fallen so far that some members of the wealthy Bass family of Texas have been forced to sell a big stake in the Disney Company to raise cash.

title: In History's Comforting Sweep
description: ''AMERICAN IDENTITIES: A New Look,'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, is an ambitious, often bold reinstallation of works from the museum's permanent collection. With objects of all kinds, it fills a ring of seven large galleries to the brim. The exhibition has been a few years in the planning, but given its encompassing view of American history and culture, it might almost have been ordered up in the aftermath of the events of Sept. 11. It is, in a sense, deeply and comfortingly site specific.

title: Professor Grumpy in a Women's College
description: In ''Mr. Holland's Opus,'' Richard Dreyfuss played a grumpy high school teacher who wanted to be a composer but wasn't because he had a family to support. He is a lousy father to his deaf son and forever frustrated by his perceived compromise. Mawkishness prevails as decades pass so this annoying man can develop into a hero who fights for his school's music program.

title: Five Guys in a Cabin With a Bag Full of Problems
description: ''God, Sex & Apple Pie,'' a comedy-drama written by, produced by and starring Jerome Courshon, breaks little new ground in the yuppie reunion genre, a formula that dates from the earliest years of American independent filmmaking (''The Return of the Secaucus Seven'') and was definitively Hollywoodized by ''The Big Chill.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Edward Asbury O'Neal, an American banking executive who led St. George Bank of Australia, referred incorrectly to the company's status when he joined it, in 1998. It was already a bank -- not a building society, the equivalent of a savings and loan association.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: WebMD President Quits
description: The WebMD Corporation, which links insurers, doctors and patients through the Internet, said Marvin Rich, its president, had resigned and that an office of the president, made up of four executives, had been created. Mr. Rich had been chief executive of CareInsite Inc. and president of its parent, the Medical Manager Corporation, which WebMD bought last year. Mr. Wygod said on Sunday that WebMD's third-quarter profit might lag forecasts, because of travel and shipping delays related to last week's terrorist attacks.

title: How Reality Affects a Play
description: Context is crucial in the theater, which only pretends to exist in a world of its own creation. Most mundanely and tangibly though not insignificantly, a show cannot escape its physical environment. It generally takes place on some kind of stage in some kind of building, the properties of which (size, location, condition) have a palpable effect on the show's artistic strategies and intent, not to mention the expectations of an audience.

title: Rapid developments in terror case and varying standards of taste complicate adjustments of ads.
description: THE scramble by marketers and agencies to adjust advertising that is perceived as inappropriate in the wake of the terrorist attacks last week is proving far more difficult than had been anticipated.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Loss Is Narrower Than Expected
description: Palm Inc., the hand-held computer maker, reported a fiscal first-quarter loss of $38.7 million, or 7 cents a share, bettering analysts' per-share forecast by 2 cents. Revenue was $214.3 million, down by half from a year earlier. Palm, based in Santa Clara, Calif., predicted flat or slightly improved sales for the current quarter and said it did not expect to turn a profit despite the typically strong holiday season. Separately, Palm began shipping its newest product, the m125, a hand-held with an expansion slot and a $249 price tag, aimed at the midlevel market. Carl Yankowski, above, Palm's chief executive, said the company had postponed its October software developers' conference because of the terror attacks, and had delayed the scheduled preholiday release of an always-connected wireless device amid concerns about slumping consumer confidence. The stock fell 36 cents, or 14 percent, to $2.15. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Wireless Companies May Be Near Deal for New Licenses
description: Federal officials and the wireless telephone industry are close to what could be a $17 billion settlement of the lawsuits between the government and NextWave Telecom over the ownership of more than 200 valuable licenses that have been sought by many of the nation's largest wireless phone companies, people involved in the negotiations said today.

description: ''From this day forward, any nation that continues to harbor or support terrorism will be regarded by the United States as a hostile regime.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: New Tools Against Terrorism
description: Justice and interior ministers from the 15 European Union members endorsed sweeping changes in the Continent's legal system. They approved a common definition of a terrorist crime with heavier penalties. And in a move that would do away with the time-consuming extradition process, they endorsed the creation of arrest warrants enforceable in all 15 countries. The changes must be approved at a summit meeting of heads of state today, and at a Dec. 7 European Commission meeting. Then all 15 Parliaments must bring their legal systems into conformity. The ministers urged all member states to do so by Jan. 1, 2002. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: Pope to Leave for Kazakhstan And Armenia This Weekend
description: Despite some nervousness at the Vatican, Pope John Paul II has insisted that he will leave on Saturday for a trip to Kazakhstan, where officials are planning ''unprecedented'' security measures during his four-day visit.

description: Diners ate lobster quesadillas to disco music from the 1970's at B-Bar and Grill in the East Village last Tuesday, on the same night that a young crowd filled the minimalist bar and patio at Glass in Chelsea.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Airport Operator
description: The British airport operator TBI, which runs London Luton, home to EasyJet, and Cardiff International in Wales, recommended shareholders accept an unsolicited $755 million offer from Vinci, a Paris-based construction company. TBI's chief executive, Keith Brooks, originally rejected Vinci's offer of 90 pence ($1.32) a share, as too low. The company said it would back the offer in light of the uncertainty created by last week's terrorist attacks in the United States. Vinci wants to buy TBI to help expand its concessions unit, which manages parking lots, toll roads and stadiums in addition to airports. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Slowdown Is Seen In U.S. Retail Sales
description: Retail sales will rise about half as much as forecast in the fourth quarter as consumers, shaken by last week's terrorist attacks, spend less on clothes and holiday gifts, an industry trade group said.

title: Love in a Mixed Marriage Is Framed by a Lot of Hate

The writer and director, Geoff Cunningham, has clearly set out to address an important problem; he might have succeeded better if he had first addressed the ways people live, speak and behave.

title: Concern Over Proposed Changes in Internet Surveillance
description: Significant and perhaps worrisome changes in the government's Internet surveillance authority have been proposed by legislators in the wake of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Indeed, so much is happening so quickly it's hard to keep track of the legislative process, let alone follow the ongoing debate between fast-moving law enforcement experts and more cautious civil libertarians.

Ross, left, president of the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities. On Tuesday, Gov. George E. title: Morale Building

title: Racial Profiling May Get Wider Approval by Courts

title: Kicking Up a Storm To Keep Chaos And Evil at Bay

It's also about shaping the world to conform to that vision, and shaping it through positive spiritual power: good set against evil, harmony against chaos, that sort of power, always so complicated.

title: Recalling Israel's History: A Tricky Balancing Act
description: ''In Search of Peace, Part 1, 1948-1967'' is a documentary with a split personality. On one hand the film, directed by Richard Trank, is an unabashedly emotional and stirringly inspirational history of Israel that ends with the country's victory in the 1967 war. On the other it is a scrupulous, factual account of two decades of Israel's conflicts with its neighbors that refuses to demonize or to blame the country's enemies.

title: First, Define the Battlefield
description: There is an old Bill Mauldin cartoon in which two elderly gentlemen are sitting in a gentlemen's club. One leans forward and speaks: ''I say it's war, Throckmorton, and I say, let's fight!'' There has been a lot of talk like that in Washington since Sept. 11. And around the country, too: we all feel a little bit like Throckmorton's friend. But is it war? And if it is, how should we go about fighting it?

title: The Neighborhood We Built
description: Nineteen years ago my wife and I, soon to become parents, moved into a solitary tall building in the middle of an empty Battery Park City. While having dinner at Windows on the World, we had seen a sign that read ''Now renting,'' with a phone number. Moving from our Midtown studio to the financial district seemed pioneering and adventurous. But we went.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMAS, ANTHONY
description: DEMAS-Anthony. Of New York City and Madison, CT was lost in the World Trade Center tragedy. Born in Suffern, NY and raised in Brooklyn, NY, Mr. Demas was a graduate of Pratt Institute and earned a PMD from the Harvard University School of Business. Mr. Demas served his country as a First Lieutenant in the U.S. Army. At the time of the tragedy, he held the position of Managing Director at AON Corporation. Previously, he was a Managing Director of Marsh & McLennan, where he worked for thirty-one years. Mr. Demas is survived by his wife, Violetta Veras Demas, and their twin eight-year-old sons, Nicholas and Andrew. In addition, he is survived by his mother, Athanassia Demas; sister, Eve Zelle; father-inlaw, James Veras and his wife, Betty Aspasia; sister-in-law, Lydia Veras, brother-in-law, George Veras and his wife, Kim; two nieces and four nephews. A loving memorial service for Anthony Demas will be held at the Church of Our Saviour, Rye, NY on Saturday, September 22 at 2:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please send memorial contributions to: The Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church, Attention: Anthony Demas Memorial Fund, 302 West 91st Street, New York, New York 10024.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPA, EDWARD J.
description: PAPA-Edward J. On September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. He was 47 years old. Born July 1, 1954 to the late Charles A. and Genevieve K. Papa, he was a graduate of Chaminade High School and Boston College. Devoted husband of Patti (nee Nick) for 26 wonderful years. Dedicated father of Michelle, Maggie, Elizabeth and Kacee. Cherished brother of Charles, Marianne, Catherine, and his loving twin Michael. Dear sonin-law of James and Gail Nick. Also survived by many caring nieces, nephews, aunts, cousins, in-laws, and loyal friends. A Memorial Mass of Resurrection and celebration of Eddie's life will take place at his parish Church of St. Dominic, Anstice St. in Oyster Bay, New York, at 10:00 AM, Saturday, September 22, 2001. Friends wishing to honor him are invited to contribute to the Papa Children Memorial Fund, C/O 60 Highwood Rd, Oyster Bay, New York 11771. May God bless all of our families and keep them in His care.

For their darling siblings, for Warren, whom we have known since he was 16, and for dear Grandma Sylvia, our hearts ache. We express our profound sorrow and extend our caring and concern for all. We know of Patti's loving pride for her children, so evident as we shared together a happy time just two days before the savage attack. All our prayers. Merrilee Colodner/The Messiano's

description: JACOBS-WELSH-Deborah Ann. July 20, 1952-September 11, 2001. We remember our beloved Deborah Ann Jacobs-Welsh, who lost her life tragically while on duty on United Airlines Flight 93 on September 11, 2001. Deborah, of suburban Philadelphia, is survived by her husband Patrick Charles Welsh, her mother Lillian McBride Jacobs, brothers James, Kevin and Bryan, sister Eileen Jacobs Brady, their spouses, and nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her father, George William Jacobs and her brother, Bill Jacobs. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Paul the Apostle R.C. Church, 9th Avenue at 59th St., New York City, on Saturday, September 22, 2001, at 7 PM. Memorial contributions may be made in her name to Catholic Charities, USA -Disaster Relief, P.O. Box 25168, Alexandria, VA. 22313.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Priceline Investor Ends Sale Effort
description: Priceline.com Inc. said Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd. and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., two companies controlled by the Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-Shing, were no longer seeking to sell shares in Priceline, the Internet travel agency, and might actually increase their stake. The two companies currently own 27 percent of Priceline, but a request approved by Priceline's board would allow them to increase it to 37.5 percent. Cheung Kong and Hutchison Whampoa increased their stake in Priceline in June, making them the biggest shareholders. Like other travel companies, Priceline has experienced a drop in business in the wake of last week's terrorist attacks. Earlier this week, the company, based in Norwalk, Conn., cut its quarterly sales estimate to a range of $280 million to $300 million from the previous expectation of more than $341 million. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Delay In An Execution
description: Gov. Mike Easley has delayed the execution of Robert Bacon Jr., set for Friday, because of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Prison administrators in Raleigh rescheduled the execution for Oct. 5, to ensure that Mr. Bacon's lawyers had full access to the courts. Mr. Bacon, 41, was sentenced to die by lethal injection for the 1987 fatal stabbing of his lover's estranged husband, Glennie Clark. Mr. Bacon had challenged Mr. Easley's impartiality in considering clemency because he had previously been state attorney general and county prosecutor. The United States Supreme Court denied Mr. Bacon's appeal on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATES, ANDREW KEITH
description: KATES-Andrew Keith, 37. Of New York City, died tragically September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center. Andy was a devoted and loving husband to his beloved Emily and an exceptional father to his three children Hannah, 5, Lucy, 3, and Henry, 1. He was the adored son of Judith and the late Lewis Kates, and grandson of Beatrice Wasserman. Andy will be missed forever by his brothers Seth and Paul. He was a devoted son-in-law to Kate Terry and Jim Terry. Andy was a graduate of Wesleyan University (1985) and The Harvard Business School (1991). Andy had a rare and generous spirit and an extraordinary sense of humor. His smile and his energy attracted an immense number of life long friends that will miss him dearly. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 23, at 11 AM at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. (between Columbus and Central Park West). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Congregation Rodeph Sholom in memory of Andrew Kates.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Index Dips
description: The book-to-bill ratio, a leading benchmark of the health of the computer chip equipment industry, showed a slight decline in August, a trade association said. The group, Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, said worldwide equipment orders were $742 million, for a ratio of 0.61. That means the industry received $61 in new orders for every $100 in products shipped. The ratio was 0.63 in July, after dipping to 0.44, its lowest point in a decade, in April. Stanley T. Myers, the association president, warned that the impact of the terror attacks on consumer spending ''could further exacerbate the already tenuous situation in regards to chip demand and capacity.'' Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Bronx Firm Indicted
description: A Bronx businessman and his company were indicted yesterday on federal charges of illegally removing and dumping asbestos, a potentially toxic substance, throughout Plattsburgh, N.Y., federal prosecutors said. The businessman, Andre Parker, 35, of Riverdale, and his firm, Parker Environmental Management Group, were charged with obstruction of justice, violations of the Clean Air Act and other crimes. Mr. Parker faces prison if convicted, and fines of as much as $9.5 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Plane Production Plan Dropped
description: Europe's No. 1 aerospace concern, the European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Company, dropped plans to increase Airbus SAS aircraft production and cut expected plane deliveries for three years. The company said it was freezing hiring and curtailing investments as a result of last week's terrorist attack in America, but still hoped to raise profit margins to 10 percent by 2004.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTMAN, DANIEL L.
description: GUTMAN-Daniel L. On September 19th, 2001. Beloved father of Margaret Klosko, Andrew Gutman and Nancy Gutman. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid For Trade Center Janitors
description: New York's largest janitors' union and the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations reached an agreement yesterday to help the 2,000 janitors, elevator operators and security guards who lost jobs because of the World Trade Center attacks. The realty board and the union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, agreed to provide the workers with health insurance and supplemental unemployment insurance equal to 80 percent of their gross pay for six months. Several dozen cleaning contractors also agreed to give preference to those janitors in future hiring.

title: Poverty and Joblessness As Cousins to Bigotry
description: The title character in ''Liam'' is a boy growing up in Liverpool, England, in the 1930's. The director, Stephen Frears, and his cinematographer, Andrew Dunn, render the city and the era as a muted composition of red brick, brown tweed and coal-smudged sunlight. The images of shipyards and union halls abutting rows of identical houses, of men in caps and scarves smoking Woodbine cigarettes in the cold as they wait for casual work, evoke hard times, but they also can't help but appear picturesque, tinted with nostalgia. The movie, like so many others that revisit the turmoil and deprivation of the last century from the perspective of a child, walks the delicate boundary between politically inflected realism and costumed sentimentality.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Deal Expected
description: Executives of General Motors and the government's Korea Development Bank, lead creditor for the bankrupt Daewoo Motors, were to sign a memorandum of understanding today setting the terms for G.M. to gain control of the company. G.M. and its partner, Fiat S.p.A. of Italy, are to take control of two-thirds of Daewoo Motors while assuming none of nearly $17 billion in liabilities. G.M. is to get Daewoo's two best plants in Korea and an option to take over its aging plant in Inchon after buying cars made there for six years. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: New York   America
description: With each concerned phone call, each urgent e-mail to New Yorkers, the question surfaces -- How can we help? The answer now is different than it was last week, when the city needed gloves and bottled water and blood donors. Now New York City needs its visitors, tourists bumping along Times Square, going to the theaters, eating at its restaurants and buying its postcards. When asked what the nation could do to help the city, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani replied: ''Come to New York, go to a play . . . spend some money.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SULLIVAN, TIMOTHY F.
description: O'SULLIVAN-Timothy F. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Cultural Institutions Retirement System deeply mourn the loss of a great friend and a wonderful colleague who was taken from us at the World Trade Center on September 11. Tim was the long-serving representative to CIRS from the Wildlife Conservation Society and since his retirement in 1997, he has remained active as a consultant to our Board. Tim's wisdom and vast knowledge of New York's cultural institutions, his marvelous sense of humor and his strong belief in the CIRS plans are an inspiration to all of us. Tim's proudest accomplishment was the role he played in bringing financial security to thousands of Cultural Institution and Daycare employees. Tim was an example to us all and his light will shine on us forever. He will be missed by all of us and we extend our deepest sympathy to his family. William E. Havemeyer, Chair Robert M. Fox, Exec. Director Raymond Miller, Assoc. Director

title: Album of the Week
description: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Arabian Travels'' (Six Degrees). Before the World Trade Center attack, electronic dance music showed a growing infatuation with music from the Arab world: a source for fervently rough-hewn voices, plaintive string phrases and pinpoint hand-drum rhythms, providing very human elements amid computerized mixes. This album, one of the countless ethno-techno descendants of ''My Life in the Bush of Ghosts'' by David Byrne and Brian Eno, is a collection of studio-made dance tracks that mesh Middle Eastern elements with a synthetic dance-floor pulse. The studio overseers come from Europe, the United States and Canada, but they all seem enthralled by their musical partners, among them singers from Algeria (Dahmane El Harrachi) and Egypt (Amir Abdel Magid). Karsh Kale, a tabla player and dance-music producer, comes up with a three-continent collaboration -- North America, Africa and Asia -- that juxtaposes Indian sarangi (bowed lute), gruff Arabic vocals and a house-music thump. Except for the cheesy final track, ''Euphoria's 1,001 Dreams,'' the hybrids find a middle ground where neither side is stifled -- the kind of collaboration that could now be threatened by a new xenophobia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWTON, DOUGLAS

The Trustees and Staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of Douglas Newton, revered colleague and friend, who was chairman of the Department of the Arts of Africa, Oceania, and the Americas from 1974 until his retirement in 1990. During his distinguished career, he organized scores of exhibitions, and edited or authored more than 24 publications on the arts of the Pacific and other subjects. Formerly Director of the Museum of Primitive Artwhich was given to the Metropolitan in 1969 by Nelson A. Rockefeller-he first arrived at the Metropolitan with the enormous task of transferring that Museum's art collections here. He then supervised the ambitious project to design and open in 1982 the Metropolitan Musuem's Michael C. Rockefeller Wing. He was named the Evelyn A.J. Hall and John A. Friede Chairman of his department in 1982, and upon his retirement was elected a curator emeritus, remaining deeply involved in his scholarly work at the Museum until quite recently. Douglas was an inspiring scholar, teacher and friend who will be missed greatly. Philippe de Montebello, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORGES, SUZANNE FLORENCE, NEE OBERLANDER
description: PORGES-Suzanne Florence, nee Oberlander, artist, died at her home in Manhattan on September 13th, at 93 years, following a long illness. Born in Vienna, Austria, she emigrated to the United States with her husband and young children in 1938, shortly following the Anschluss. She resided for many years in Forest Hills, Queens and later in West Stockbridge, MA. She was an artist and art scholar, a member of Artists Equity, and had a long and prolific career as a portraitist, still-life and landscape painter. She accrued an outstanding art library and slide collection. The latter contained unique views of museum quality. The entire collection of slides was donated to Dartmouth College. Her expertise as an art scholar was recognized by the United States Information Service for which, in 1956, she gave a series of lectures in France on American Art. During her years in West Stockbridge she was active in the community, and continued to foster her academic interests by sponsoring art scholarships for local high school students. In many ways Suzanne Porges was symbolic of the generation of immigrants from Central Europe who grew up in the early years of this century only to have their secure family life and intellectual milieu interrupted by the Second World War. Many assimiliated Jews could not meet the stringent requirements of Aryan purity imposed by the Nazis. The coming of Hitler forced upon her the recognition of her ancestral roots. While not raised as a Jew, her journals reveal that she had no doubts of her ancestry, and how she would be treated. It was her sensitivity and appreciation of imminent danger that prompted her to write to a close acquaintance, William Rosenwald, only a few days following the German annexation of Austria. His assistance enabled the family's rapid exodus from Europe, sparing them catastrophe from the Holocaust. Her family attributes its survival to her vision and initiative. She survived her husband of 38 years, John C. Porges, a prominent obstetriciangynecologist in this city. She is survived by her sons, Robert F., of New York City and Brookfield, CT; and his wife, Dr. Felicia Axelrod; George W. Dallas of Brookfield, CT; and his wife Nicole; grandchildren John A. and his wife Alexandra Gillespie; Vicki M. Eisner of New York and her husband Joseph Eisner, and a great grandson, Dylan Robert Porges.

title: Fighting Terrorism on a Global Front
description: The terrorists who attacked the United States on Sept. 11 aimed at one nation but wounded an entire world. Rarely, if ever, has the world been as united as it was on that terrible day. It was a unity born of horror, of fear, of outrage and of profound sympathy with the American people. This unity also reflected the fact that the World Trade Center, in this uniquely international city, was home to men and women of every faith from some 60 nations. This was an attack on all humanity, and all humanity has a stake in defeating the forces behind it.

title: FEDEX SAYS EARNINGS FELL 36% IN FISCAL FIRST QUARTER
description: The FedEx Corporation said yesterday that earnings fell 36 percent in its fiscal first quarter as customers switched to cheaper, slower shipments to save money in a slowing economy. FedEx said that net income for the quarter ended Aug. 31 fell to $109 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with $169 million, or 58 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Excluding a loss of 5 cents a share for an accounting change, the company posted a profit of $124 million, or 41 cents a share.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Cuts 2,000 Jobs
description: The chip equipment maker Applied Materials Inc. said yesterday that it would lay off 2,000 employees, or roughly 10 percent of its work force, in response to the continued slowdown in the semiconductor industry. The job cuts will include 700 positions at the company's Santa Clara, Calif., offices; 500 in Austin, Tex.; and others worldwide. The company said the job cuts would be completed by the end of the fourth quarter. Since the beginning of the year, the company has taken a number of cost-saving measures, including employee and executive pay cuts, mandatory furloughs and limits on temporary employees. James C. Morgan, chairman and chief executive, said that despite those steps, ''the length and severity of the downturn and lack of near-term visibility'' made the latest cuts necessary. As a result of the layoffs, the company will record a restructuring charge in its fourth fiscal quarter, which will end on Oct. 28. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Foreign Affairs; Hama Rules
description: In February 1982 the secular Syrian government of President Hafez al-Assad faced a mortal threat from Islamic extremists, who sought to topple the Assad regime. How did it respond? President Assad identified the rebellion as emanating from Syria's fourth-largest city -- Hama -- and he literally leveled it, pounding the fundamentalist neighborhoods with artillery for days. Once the guns fell silent, he plowed up the rubble and bulldozed it flat, into vast parking lots. Amnesty International estimated that 10,000 to 25,000 Syrians, mostly civilians, were killed in the merciless crackdown. Syria has not had a Muslim extremist problem since.

title: Giving American Music A French Improvisation
description: The Village Vanguard was untypically and unjustly empty on Tuesday for Martial Solal's opening night. In jazz, the grapevine has largely replaced -- or maybe just outlasted -- press attention, but even the grapevine failed here. Still, how could one expect sell-out crowds? Mr. Solal, born in Algiers and based in Paris for most of his life, has never played at the Vanguard and has played in New York only twice in the last 30 years; he has never had an album on an American label. But he is easily one of the most impressive pianists in jazz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEEN, JEFFREY EARLE
description: LeVEEN-Jeffrey Earle. Age 55 of Manhasset, N.Y., was tragically lost in the attack on the World Trade Center on Tuesday, September 11, 2001. Jeff is the beloved husband of Christine, and father to Jeff Jr. (26), Betsy (25), Andrew (23), Katie (21), and Meg (20). Jeff was a Partner and Senior VicePresident of equity sales at Cantor, Fitzgerald Co., Inc from 1993 until the present. Jeff was loved and widely respected by his colleagues and clients in the brokerage business. He was most devoted to his family and friends. Known by all for his infectious enthusiasm for life, Jeff was raised in Sands Point, Port Washington, N.Y., son of the late William and Virginia LeVeen, brother to Judy, Janice and the late Jerry. He graduated from Schreiber High School in 1964 and from Dartmouth College in 1968 where he was captain of the golf team and a proud member of Phi Gamma Delta fraternity. Jeff also served as SPC5 in the U.S. Armed Services From October, 1968 until October 1970. Jeff will be remembered for his great sense of humor and his loving attention to his family and friends. Jeff's memory is being honored by an overwhelming show of love and support by his friends and business associates. A celebration of Jeff's life will be held at St. Mary's R.C. Church in Manhasset, Long Island, N.Y., on Saturday, September 22, 2001 at 11AM. Donations in lieu of gifts or flowers may be made to the Cantor Fitzgerald Co., Inc. relief fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, MICHAEL JOHN
description: SIMON-Michael John. Born July 27, 1961 to the late Charles and Peggyann Simon of Rye, NY has tragically passed to his eternal rest on September 11, 2001. His wife, Eileen (nee Isacsen), their children, Brittany Radcliffe, Michael John, Jr., and Tyler Ingram have been robbed of a devoted husband and loving father. Family and friends will grievously mourn this supportive, moral man of great character. Growing up in Rye, NY, Michael graduated in 1979 from Rye County Day School. He then attained a degree from Hobart College in Economics and Religion. He was an outstanding athlete in ice hockey, lacrosse, tennis and golf. Michael also completed a cross-country bicycling trip from Seattle, WA to Geneva, NY. Michael continued his love of athletics through coaching his children's teams in soccer, softball and baseball in Harrington Park. He never missed a game or a school function. Michael also leaves behind a brother, Scott (Margaret) Simon, sisters Christine Coats, Kathleen and Patricia Simon and brother-in-law E. Craig Coats. His in-laws Barbara and James Romaine, Cathleen and Robert Isacsen, as well as Kristen and Christopher Klass, Elise and Spiros Polikateros, Bridget and Robert DiMartini, Kathryn Isacsen, James and Fiona Romaine and Lenore and Mark Goley also survive him. His parents as well as his brother-in-law Scott Romaine have predeceased him. Michael leaves behind twenty-two adoring and devastated nieces, nephews and grieving aunts and uncles, Mary Ellen and Martin White and Madeleine and Bill Becker. The whole community of Harrington Park, his Wall Street business associates and clients will surely miss Michael. The premature loss of such a wonderful individual so loved and respected by all that knew him is society's loss. A memorial service will be held at Saint Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Closter, NJ at 1:30PM Saturday September 22nd. In lieu of flowers a special fund in remembrance of Michael has been established for his three children. Please send donations to: College Bound Fund, C/O Scott Simon, 95 Ferris Hill Road, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Titan Buys A Services Vendor

Under the agreement, expected to close by the end of the year, Titan will acquire BTG for $114.9 million in Titan stock and $27 million in cash. The deal values BTG at $13.35 a share. Yesterday, shares of BTG rose 95 cents, or 8.8 percent, to $11.75, while Titan fell 94 cents, or 5.2 percent, to $17.17.

title: NIKE SAYS ITS FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT FELL 5.2%
description: Nike, the shoe and apparel maker, said yesterday that its profit fell 5.2 percent in its most recent quarter as the euro's declining value hurt revenue, and sales in the United States decreased. Profit fell to $199 million, or 73 cents a share, from $210 million, or 77 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue in the period, which ended Aug. 31 and was the first quarter of Nike's fiscal year, fell 0.9 percent, to $2.61 billion from $2.64 billion, Nike said. Sales in the United States fell 3 percent, led by a 7 percent drop in shoe sales, Nike said.

title: SETTLEMENT APPROVED IN WASTE MANAGEMENT LAWSUITS
