The settlement, which strips four former executives of more than $8 million in severance pay and $16 million in stock options, also resolves similar suits in Texas, lawyers told Judge Stephen Lamb of Delaware Chancery Court. The settlement is part of Waste Management's effort to resolve suits stemming from a 1998 buyout by a rival, USA Waste. The executives were accused of overstating earnings by $2.9 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, HERMAN
description: SANDLER-Herman. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York deeply mourn the loss of Herman Sandler, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation, whose life was tragically lost in the attack on the World Trade Center. An exemplary leader of our community, Herman earned enormous admiration and respect for his exceptional generosity and commitment to Jewish and other humanitarian causes. No words can express the depth of sorrow and sadness we feel over Herman's loss. Generations to come will remember him for his leadership, enthusiasm, and kindness. We extend our deepest and heartfelt sympathies to Herman's wife, Suki; to his mother; to his daughters, Pamela, Gillian, and Jordanna; and to the entire Sandler family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS LOWERS QUARTERLY PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: Illinois Tool Works, a maker of auto parts and plastic packaging, said yesterday that third-quarter profit would be less than some analysts' forecasts and that the slumping economy might hurt fourth-quarter earnings. Third-quarter profit is likely to be closer to 65 cents a share than to 70 cents, Illinois Tool said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected 70 cents. The company maintained its full-year earnings forecast of $2.75 to $2.95 a share.

title: Looting Is Reported in Center's Tomblike Mall
description: Shops and restaurants in the retail concourse beneath 5 World Trade Center were looted in the wake of last week's disaster, and police detectives are investigating whether rescue workers were responsible, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIER, BARBARA E.
description: MAIER-Barbara E. On September 19, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Eric. Loving mother of Christian and his wife, Gloria. Devoted sister-in-law of Elizabeth Schuster and sister of the late Christian Schuster. Adoring grandmother of Gregory. Survived by loving nieces, Caroline, Christine and their families. Reposing at John Dormi & Sons Funeral Home, 1121 Morris Park Avenue (near Williamsbridge Road), Bronx. Visiting Friday from 7-9PM. Funeral services in the Woolworth Chapel in Woodlawn Cemetery on Saturday, September 22 at 11 A.M.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Grants For School Police
description: The Justice Department yesterday announced a $6.6 million grant to station 53 full-time police officers in schools statewide. The program is not related to last week's attacks, but rather to school violence in the last decade.

title: The Big City; Is New York City Big Enough for Giuliani and a New Mayor?
description: SUPPOSE one of the mayoral candidates looked into the cameras this weekend and announced:

title: Looting in Center's Tomblike Mall
On the Street: Remembrance
The Write Response
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Even the Delicate Survive
description: People have not only overwhelmed New York with food, blood, labor and money in the wake of the World Trade Center attacks. They have also been giving flowers by the millions -- leaving bunches of them, four and five layers deep, at the doorsteps of fire stations and churches and at impromptu shrines on park lawns, stoops, windowsills and sidewalks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLOOGMAN, RAOUL
description: KLOOGMAN-Raoul. September 21, 2001 of Great Neck, NY. Born in Vienna, Austria, May 25, 1914. Beloved husband of the late Ruth (Weisman) Kloogman. Loving father of Joan Kloogman Borkow, Judith and Jerrald Weinstein, and Helen Kloogman and Michael Gold. Loving grandfather of Dana & Chad, Matthew, Jacob, Rachael, Ari, Dov, Ruthie & Aaron. Loving great-grandfather of Casey, Tanner and Juliette. Loving brother of Edith Green and Nina Ottolenghi. A survivor of the Holocaust, he was a dedicated and respected physician in the Great Neck community for more than 40 years. He died peacefully at North Shore University Hospital, which he helped found. Services will be held Sunday, September 23, 2001 at 12:45 PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Tradition Is Upheld: The New Miss America Will Be Chosen Tonight
description: For a while it looked as if the attack on America would even silence Miss America.

title: Berard May Attempt A Ranger Comeback
description: According to a National Hockey League official, Bryan Berard is nearing a decision on an attempted comeback, which could lead to the 24-year-old defenseman working out with the Rangers in a bid to make the team.

title: Europeans Pledge To Spur Economies
description: European Union finance ministers are standing by a commitment to balance their budgets in coming years while doing what they can to stimulate the economy.

title: Fund to Stay in New York
description: OppenheimerFunds, whose World Trade Center headquarters were destroyed in last week's terrorist attacks, will relocate to Midtown Manhattan, its chief executive, John V. Murphy, said yesterday. OppenheimerFunds, a mutual fund company owned by the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, intends to lease space at Seventh Avenue between 36th and 37th Streets, Mr. Murphy said.

title: Stars Gather on TV to Raise Money and Pay Tribute
description: In the last 12 days, the country has been first traumatized and then saturated by tragic images of the World Trade Center collapsing, and is now enveloped in the language of war. Last night's history-making all-star telecast to raise money for the relief work was shaped by the wise, timely idea that the public was ready for a more eloquent expression of sorrow.

title: Prisoner Is Charged In Shooting of Girl, 7
description: The police arrested and charged a Hartford man today in the accidental shooting of a 7-year-old girl last July -- an incident that prompted wide outrage and a state-assisted crackdown on drug-related crime in this city.

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; 'To Thine Own Self Be True'
description: ''I ask you to uphold the values of America,'' President Bush said to Congress and the nation. That will be a fair test of his policy for dealing with terrorism as the policy unfolds: Does it uphold the values of America?

title: Giuliani, Again? Write Him In, Pataki Offers
description: Gov. George E. Pataki declared yesterday that the primary election on Tuesday would go on as planned, saying, ''This is a country of laws'' and the attack on the World Trade Center should not be allowed to further disrupt the city's election process.

title: Where Death Mostly Tiptoes, It Rushed Violently In
description: WALLACE E. MIL-LER, the Somerset County coroner, typically writes out three or four death certificates a week, most of them for older people who have suffered some form of heart failure. Less frequent are the drug overdoses, accidents and suicides. Until this month, he had never handled a case involving more than two deaths: two babies who died in a house fire; several car accidents with double deaths.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: At Penn State, Unease Extends to Football
description: It is a college football weekend and Jesse Held was busy, taking orders and serving people. A Penn State senior majoring in industrial engineering, Held waits on tables at The Tavern restaurant on East College Avenue, across the street from campus.

title: Dealers: Waiting and Hoping
description: UP and down the Auto Alley on 11th Avenue in Manhattan, car dealers had stories last week about what happened when terrorists attacked. Most had to shut down for a day or two. Customers could not get into the city, and cars could not be shuttled from storage areas in New Jersey. Worse, Lexus of Manhattan lost customers in the World Trade Towers collapse and other customers had cars destroyed in downtown garages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATINI, PAUL
description: BEATINI-Paul, 40. Of Park Ridge, NJ died September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center Disaster. Husband of Susan (nee Fischer) and father of Julia and Daria. He is survived by his parents Michael and Doris, his in-laws Ed and Blanche Fischer, also Michael, Tom, Nan and Mark his brothers and sister. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Presentation, 271 West Saddle River Road, Upper Saddle River, NJ (201)-327-1313. All are welcome to attend. The service will be held on Saturday September 22, 2001 at 10:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, a trust fund has been established for his two children. Those wishing to donate should make checks payable to Susan Beatini, trustee and send to Susan Beatini, 240 Vitmar Place, Park Ridge, New Jersey 07656. Our prayers go out to everyone affected by this tragedy. We would also like to express our deepest appreciation to the firemen, police, rescue workers and volunteers who worked so valiantly to save the lives of others.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cathartic Ceremony, and the Game Begins
description: The public-address announcer reminded everyone at Shea Stadium about what happened in Lower Manhattan on Sept. 11, even though no one needed the reminder. Last night, Major League Baseball returned to New York for the first time since the terrorist attacks that toppled the World Trade Center, creating an emotional and exhilarating scene.

title: Toll Mounts As Northwest Plans to Cut 10,000 Jobs
description: Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would eliminate 10,000 jobs, pushing to more than 70,000 the number of job cuts the nation's largest airlines have announced since the terrorist attacks last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, KAGIN, MELISSA
description: ROSS - KAGIN - Melissa. Loving wife of Andrew; devoted mother of Benjamin and Nicole; cherished daughter of Shirley Cohen; dear sister of Lloyd Kagin; sister-in-law to Nadine. Service Sunday, 12 noon, at Riverside, 21 West Broad St., Mt Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Organ Donor Network of NY.

title: EMC, DATA STORAGE CONCERN, SUFFERS 12% SHARE DECLINE
description: Shares of the EMC Corporation, the largest maker of data storage systems, fell 12 percent after the company forecast a loss, its first in more than 11 years. The company cited competition and the slowing economy. EMC shares fell $1.47, to $11.15, after dropping as low as $10.01. The stock has lost 83 percent of its value this year. Joseph Tucci, who became chief executive in January, said yesterday that EMC would lay off 10 percent of its workers, or about 2,400 people, in the second round of job cuts this year. Sales have slumped as corporations reduce spending on computer-related products.

title: Senate Acts To Provide Coverage To Airlines
description: Congress overwhelmingly acted yesterday to insure the nation's airlines against war and terrorism for 180 days, averting a threatened halt to all flights.

title: Senior Pentagon Analyst Is Charged as Cuban Spy
description: The federal government today charged the Pentagon's top intelligence analyst for Cuba with spying for the Cuban government.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Seen Flat To Lower
description: The governor of the Bank of Canada, David A. Dodge, left, said economic growth in the third quarter would probably be ''close to zero or slightly negative'' because of disruptions from the attacks on the United States, Canada's largest trading partner. The events of last week would also affect the fourth quarter and ''obviously bring with them further economic uncertainty with respect to the timing and extent of a rebound,'' Mr. Dodge said after a speech that he was scheduled to deliver was canceled because of air travel problems brought on by the attack.

title: Jane Dudley, Modern Dancer And Teacher, Is Dead at 89
description: Jane Dudley, a prominent dancer in Martha Graham's company in the 1930's and 40's who was also one of early modern dance's social-protest choreographers and a leading teacher in the United States and Britain, died on Wednesday in London. She was 89.

title: Patriotic and Undaunted, Some Tourists Insist on Autumn in New York
description: Just when it seemed the tourists were fleeing, the restaurants were emptying, the theaters were dimming their lights -- just, in short, when the whole city looked as if it were on the verge of buckling at the knees -- the cavalry arrived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIRARD, SAMUEL R.
description: GIRARD-Samuel R. At age 90, on September 20. Beloved husband of the late Mimi Girard. Loving father of Andrea Girard and Constance Girard. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer Girard Boron and Andrea Girard Boron. Devoted brother of Ethel Ross and Jeanne Rauch. Mr. Girard was a veteran of WWII and a noted artist in New York City. Service Monday, September 24, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the National Glaucoma Foundation.

title: Sports of The Times; Business Is Anything But Usual
description: BY 10:30 a.m. yesterday, Shea Stadium was alive with baseball activity and back to ''normal.'' In 48 hours, the stadium had made a seamless transformation from a staging area for rescue workers to a thoroughfare for game-day preparations. An open space that only a few days ago had been the improvised site of cooperation between ballplayers and relief workers was back to accommodating business almost as usual.

title: Mets' Magic Heralds Homecoming
description: It was like the moment in a church service when members of the congregation shake hands with each other in peace. For a few moments last night, on the infield grass at Shea Stadium, the Mets and the Atlanta Braves were not bitter rivals about to begin a late-September showdown. They were citizens.

title: 'West Wing' Rushes Script Keyed to Attack
description: NBC has postponed the season premiere of its most honored drama series, ''The West Wing,'' scheduled for Wednesday night, to accommodate the desire of the show's creator, Aaron Sorkin, to write a special episode that addresses the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington last week.

title: Pentagon Expert Is Charged as Spy
description: The Pentagon's top intelligence analyst for Cuba has been charged with spying for the Cuban government.

title: Jets Ready To Replay Patriots' Soap Opera
description: The players had stretched and laughed today, the laugh of the week's last practice, and General Manager Terry Bradway pronounced the Jets ready to return to football.

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Attacks on U.S. Challenge the Perspectives of Postmodern True Believers
description: Cataclysms not only cast shadows over human victims but also shake the foundations of intellectual life: wars can shift the direction of scholarship; genocide can upend the presumptions of sociology. The destruction of the World Trade Center and the attack on the Pentagon may have similar effects, challenging the intellectual and ethical perspectives of two sets of ideas: postmodernism (affectionately known as pomo) and postcolonialism (which might be called poco). These ideas, which have affected political debate and university scholarship, are now being subject to a shock that may lead in two directions: on one hand to a more intense commitment, and on the other -- I hope -- to a more intense rejection.

title: National Briefing
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Attacks Leave New Obstacles For Disabled
description: James Tierney, a quadriplegic, followed the usual drill and headed in his wheelchair to the stairwell when the fire alarm went off on Thursday at his Boston office.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cadbury To Buy Orangina
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. agreed to buy Pernod Ricard's nonalcoholic beverages for $643 million in cash to gain Orangina, the popular orange soda. The purchase also gives Cadbury brands like the Yoo-Hoo chocolate drink and Pampryl fruit juice in Europe, North America and Australia. The units had sales of 466 million euros in 2000, with Orangina generating about 40 percent. Pernod is focusing on liquor and wine and plans to sell all unrelated divisions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, JOANNE
description: WEIL-Joanne. Missing in the World Trade Center tragedy. The Board of Governors and membership of Fairview Country Club mourn the sudden loss of our beloved member, Joanne Weil. Joanne grew up at Fairview and will be deeply missed by her many friends and family. On behalf of all our members, we express our deepest condolences to Joanne's parents, Judith and Floyd, and her entire family. Bernard Steinweg, President Leonard Golub, Secretary

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Bankruptcy Extended For Software Maker
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V., the struggling software firm, was granted a nine-month extension to its bankruptcy protection yesterday by a court in its hometown of Ieper, Belgium. It remains under Chapter 11 protection in the United States. The court ordered the company to set aside 80 percent of the revenue from the sale of its noncore assets for creditors and ruled that the new owner of these divisions must guarantee they remain at least partly Belgian. A new management is trying to save the core of Lernout from liquidation, after the previous top executives and founders were accused in an accounting fraud scandal last year. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''So the only master of the world wants to threaten us. But make no mistake: Afghanistan, as it was in the past -- the Great Britain, he came, the Red Army, he came -- Afghanistan is a swamp.''

title: Religion Journal; Abhorring Terror at an Ohio Mosque
description: When worshipers arrived at the Islamic Center of Cleveland for morning prayers last Monday, they had to step lightly. Broken glass and debris lay scattered inside the gold-domed mosque in suburban Parma, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, MICHAEL JOSEPH
description: ARMSTRONG-Michael Joseph, 34, on September 11th, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Beloved fiance of Catherine Nolan. Devoted son of Gabriel and Mary. Cherished brother of Gerard and his wife Kathleen, Marian and Laura. Adored uncle of Jack, Keeley, Liam and Ryan. Dear nephew, cousin and friend. Memorial service Monday, 10 AM St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street. Friends may call Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9, Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Michael J. Armstong Scholarship Fund, C/O Loyola School, 980 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10028.

title: Francis Donnelly, 74, Psychotherapist
description: Francis E. Donnelly, a psychotherapist and co-founder of the Studio Museum in Harlem, died at his home in Manhattan on Sept. 13. He was 74.

title: Roads: Congestion Ahead
description: ANYONE who drives in urban areas knows that roads are clogged, and in some cases, crumbling. Conditions will almost certainly get worse, experts say, in the wake of domestic terrorism.

title: Israel, Living With Terror, Redefines 'Normal'
description: ''Look around,'' urged Esther Ochana, waving a hand to encompass her tiny settlement of Noqedim and the sun-baked Judean hills that surround it. ''Look at the homes, look at the view. Isn't it paradise?''

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Corporations Ask Bush to Move Fast on Offering Stimulus Package
description: The nation's largest corporations urged President Bush today to act immediately to help the faltering economy, putting pressure on the White House to rethink its plan to wait several weeks before deciding on the need for additional tax cuts and government spending.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: United Arab Emirates Cuts Ties With Afghanistan
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 22  The United Arab Emirates broke off relations with Afghanistan today because of the ruling Taliban's refusal to hand over Osama bin Laden, the terrorist network chief suspected of masterminding the suicide attacks on New York and Washington.

title: In the Suburbs, Quiet Pockets Fill With Grief
description: Terror made the reverse commute out of Lower Manhattan. It traveled to Long Island, exiting grimly in places like Rockville Centre and Manhasset. It followed the course of the Metro-North Railroad into Westchester County, stopping with fury in the small towns of Pelham and Bedford. It crossed the Hudson, as many of its victims did twice a day, sweeping through the sprawling New Jersey suburb of Middletown and older towns like Ridgewood. It found the Rockaways off the Belt Parkway in Queens and wreaked havoc.

title: Neil Levin, Executive Director Of Bistate Port Authority, 46
description: Neil D. Levin, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the landlord for the World Trade Center complex as well as the operator of the New York City area's three major airports, port facilities, bridges and tunnels, died on Sept. 11 in the collapse of the twin towers.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE APPOINTEE -- Man in the News; Rising Star in Crucial Job -- Tom Ridge
description: Hours after United Airlines Flight 93 went down in southwestern Pennsylvania on Sept. 11, killing all 44 people aboard, Gov. Tom Ridge was at the crash site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, JUDITH WILLENKIN
description: KINGSLEY-Judith Willenkin. On September 20, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Stephen Kingsley. Devoted and adored mother of Beth. Cherished daughter of Ruth and Lou Willenkin. Devoted sister of Dr. Matthew Willenkin. Loving aunt. She touched many lives. Service at United Jewish Center, 141 Deerhill Avenue, Danbury, CT, Sunday September 23, 2:30 PM.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: SWISS FRANC SOARS. The Swiss franc rose as investors sought shelter after the U.S. threatened to retaliate for terrorist attacks last week. In New York, Switzerland's currency reached 1.5771 francs per dollar.

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toyota Shares Tumble
description: Shares of the Toyota Motor Corporation slid 6.1 percent on reports that it would lower its sales target for 2001 because of weaker sales in Japan. The company denied the report but predicted rough times ahead. ''Our sales will not be as good as expected, but we're not changing our forecasts,'' said Tetsu Kitagawa, a spokesman for the company. Toyota Motor passed NTT DoCoMo as Japan's largest company, but has lost 24.6 percent of its market value since the terrorist attacks in the United States on Sept. 11. The slide comes even though Toyota spent $474 million buying its own shares. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: The Innocent Skyline
description: At the conclusion of ''The Great Gatsby,'' Nick Carraway, a young Midwesterner recently arrived in the metropolis, watches the blinking green light at the end of a Long Island dock. He reflects on the virginal beauty and the promise of New York: ''Gradually I became aware of the old island here that flowered once for Dutch sailors' eyes -- a fresh, green breast of the new world.''

title: Fireworks Ban Is Lifted
description: Ending a nationwide ban imposed after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it would once again allow fireworks and searchlight displays, laser shows, model- rocket launches and the release of party helium balloons.

title: AN AIRLINE BAILOUT
description: Congress overwhelmingly passed a $15 billion package today to bail out the ailing airlines and agreed to set up an open-ended federal fund to compensate victims of last week's terrorist attacks. The plan passed by a vote of 96 to 1 in the Senate and by 356 to 54 in the House.

title: Share Prices Plunge 14% for the Week, Second Worst Ever
description: America's stock markets fell again yesterday, ending one of the worst weeks in their history, as many investors moved their money out of stocks and into less risky assets in the face of a deepening economic slump.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Ex-Ambassador Quits Governor's Race
description: Pete Peterson, a former ambassador to Vietnam, ended his campaign for governor, citing a need for unity after last week's terrorist attacks. Mr. Peterson, who spent six and a half years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam, was one of a handful of Democrats who sought to challenge Gov. Jeb Bush, a Republican, next year. His campaign was quickly eclipsed when former Attorney General Janet Reno joined the race. Mr. Peterson, 66, was waiting to board an airplane at Logan Airport in Boston on Sept. 11 when he learned that two planes from that airport had crashed into the World Trade Center. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the primacy of ''God Bless America'' among anthems that have been sung since the terrorist attacks referred incompletely to the authorship of ''America the Beautiful.'' The music was by Samuel Augustus Ward; Katherine Lee Bates wrote only the words.

title: Some Passengers Singled Out For Exclusion by Flight Crew
description: In San Antonio on Monday, Ashraf Khan, 32, a mobile phone salesman who was trying to get to his brother's wedding in Pakistan, was ordered off a Delta Airlines flight. The plane's captain, Mr. Khan recalled, told him that the flight crew did not ''feel safe flying with you.''

title: An Unwelcome King Rides Roughshod Over a Contract
description: On the cricket grounds of England, it is customary to clap politely when a batsman reaches a half-century. Clapping is therefore in order for two leading personalities on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREELEY, PATRICIA BROPHY
description: GREELEY-Patricia Brophy. On September 19, 2001 at Yale-New Haven Hospital, New Haven, CT. Beloved wife of Laurence E. Greeley of Wilton, CT and daughter of Muriel W. Brophy and the late Dr. F.H. Brophy of Pelham, NY and much loved sister of John O. Brophy of New Canaan, CT, and Theodore F. Brophy of Ocean Ridge, FL, and the late Beverly O. Brophy. A memorial service will be held at the Huguenot Church, 901 Pelhamdale Avenue, Pelham, NY at 11:00 AM, Wednesday, September 26, 2001. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Aplastic Anemia & MDS International Foundation, Inc., PO Box 613, Annapolis, MD 21404-0613, or to the Wilton Playshop, PO Box 363, Lovers Ln, Wilton, CT 06897.

title: For Love of Country, Hurried Vows for the Love Left Behind
description: The sacramental wine, if it can be called that, was blackberry brandy. The eucharist was a loaf of Italian bread. And when the service was finished, and the last head lifted high after the marital blessing, the bride and groom drank beer from a boot.

title: Rousing the Voters
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki have shown their mettle since Sept. 11 in dealing bravely and expertly with the aftermath of the terrorist attack on New York City. Now their voices are needed to rally voters to the polls next Tuesday for the primary elections that were to have taken place on the day of the World Trade Center disaster.

title: Not Just Another Day on the Job
description: Mike Piazza looked as if he needed a nap, a nap that could turn into a deep sleep and stretch for a few days. His blond-streaked hair was tousled, his eyes were glassy, he needed a shave and his voice was subdued. Like millions of Americans, Piazza admitted he was confused, depressed and angry, emotions that he knew would linger for a long time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, LEWIS
description: RUDIN-Lewis. The Board of Directors, staff and residents of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with deep sorrow the untimely passing of Lewis Rudin, a man of unbounded generosity and exceptional personal warmth. Lew Rudin, along with his brother Jack and their extraordinary family, became highly successful businessmen and always believed that their good fortune was a gift to be shared with others. And share they did, with people in need in New York, Israel and around the world. Lew and Jack Rudin's gifts to The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale through the May and Samuel Rudin Foundation that honors their parents, will enable us to extend our high quality services to embrace more older persons. Their support of Project HOPE (Healthcare Offers Permanent Employment), conducted by The Hebrew Home since 1992, has provided an enriched setting, alternative education and vocational programs for students at risk, helping the youngsters graduate from high school and enter the health field. We were pleased to honor Lew and Jack Rudin at our annual dinner in 1993. The Hebrew Home extends its condolences to Lew's beloved wife Rachel; daughter Beth DeWoody; son William and daughter-in-law Ophelia; four grandchildren; brother Jack; and all who loved him, and the thousands whose lives were improved by his selflessness and vision. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. VP

title: NAVIGANT, AIRLINE BOOKING SERVICE, TO CUT JOBS
description: Navigant International Inc., the second-largest provider of airline booking services, will eliminate about 1,200 jobs, or a fifth of its work force, because of lower travel demand after last week's terrorist attacks. The company is also reducing salaries 5 percent to 12 percent and halting capital spending, Navigant said. The company, which is based in Denver, could not be reached for further comment. Navigant said it could not yet provide a forecast of its financial results.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: MOVING TO STOP TERROR

title: Japan Will Set Up Fund to Purchase Bad Loans From Banks
description: The Japanese government unveiled its long-awaited bad-loan cleanup program today, in a campaign intended to mollify foreign and domestic critics before Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi flies to Washington on Monday to meet President Bush.

title: The Vosburgh Stars in a Depleted Lineup
description: Horse racing resumes at its highest levels today with four stakes races at Belmont Park, headlined by the Grade I $300,000 Vosburgh.

title: At Fort Drum, Family and Nuptial Worries
description: Margarita Morales hugged her son, in his beret and military fatigues, at a gas station outside this sprawling Army base this afternoon. She held him long and hard, cheek to cheek, her flesh close to the flesh born of her, and it was hard to keep her tears at bay or to let him go, she said, because when presidents talk of war, it is mothers who pay.

title: H.M.O.'s Plan to Drop Medicare, Calling Fees Too Low
description: Health maintenance organizations serving at least 475,000 elderly and disabled people will pull out of Medicare next year, the trade association for the industry announced today.

title: Already, Grim Statistics for New York Consumer Sales
description: Tidel Robinson had been thinking for weeks about buying a new DVD player, and now there was one on sale for just $99, down from $150, at the Electronics Outlet in Brooklyn's Fulton Mall.

title: Changing His Pinstripes
description: As if the city needed further evidence that life is truly upside down, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said last night that he would attend a Mets game. Yes. He said he wanted to thank them for wearing Fire Department hats, and to show that all partisan bets were off, even in baseball.A reporter could write here now that the mayor is a rabid Yankees fan, but that would insult the reader.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Gunman Kills Federal Building Guard
description: A gunman was wounded after killing a guard at a federal building that houses the Detroit office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The gunman entered the lobby of the building, the Patrick V. McNamara Federal Building, and opened fire after the guard, Ronald C. Sheffield, asked him what was in a bag he was carrying. The shooting occurred two blocks from the federal courthouse where an hour earlier, a judge ordered the continued detention of three Arabs who were arrested in the investigation of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and at the Pentagon. An F.B.I. spokeswoman said there did not appear to be a connection. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEYMOUR, KAREN LYNN
description: SEYMOUR-Karen Lynn. Wife of William Dietrich and mother of Sarah and William Dietrich, was among those lost in the tragedy at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. She is also survived by her father, David Seymour of Littlestown, PA., her mother Catherine Seymour and sister Debra Anderson, both of Sykesville, MD, and her brother Glen Seymour of Abingdon, MD. A memorial service will be held at Saint Vincent de Paul R.C. Church, 250 Bebout Avenue, Stirling, N.J. on Thursday, September 27th at 4PM. A reception will follow at the Primavera Regency, 1080 Valley Road, Stirling, N.J.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B.

title: Clerics Answer 'No, No, No!' and Invoke Fates of Past Foes
description: Within hours of President Bush's speech to Congress on Thursday night demanding that the militant Muslim clerics who rule Afghanistan hand over Osama bin Laden, their envoy gave today what was described as their final answer: ''No, no, no!''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KOMAG INC., San Jose, Calif., a maker of storage disks for computers, said it had filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy recovery plan that has the support of more than half of its creditors. If a bankruptcy judge finds the plan adequate at a hearing scheduled for Oct. 23, Komag will ask for approval by all its creditors and shareholders.

title: Fear and Vigilance as Security Plans Are Reviewed
description: On a weekend that could have been the splendid start of autumn, Americans are dealing with continued threats -- some real, others just perceived -- and slowly recognizing that the worst-case scenarios that many government agencies had planned for have suddenly gotten worse.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDY, MARK
description: HINDY-Mark. A victim of the World Trade Center tragedy on September 11, 2001. In celebration of his life, a mass will be offered at Saint Anselm's R.C. Church, 4th Avenue and 82nd St, Bay Ridge, Bklyn on Monday, September 24th, 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Mark Hindy Charitable Foundation.

title: G.M. to Pay $400 Million To Take Control of Daewoo
description: General Motors formally announced today an agreement with the creditors of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor Company that will give G.M. a brand and a substantial manufacturing foothold in Asia at a bargain price.

title: Afghans Can Be Our Allies
description: As the United States plans an attack against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban regime that continues to shelter him, we need to recognize that destroying Afghanistan will accomplish nothing. The Soviets, the Islamic militants we once armed, and the Taliban and their Pakistani backers have already done so. About a third of the capital, Kabul, is as ruined as the World Trade Center.

title: After Phone Call, British Minister Moves Up Planned Trip to Iran
description: With Britain casting itself increasingly as America's bridge to unlikely and unspoken allies in the fight against terrorism, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw announced today that he would move up a planned trip to Iran to next week. That will be the first visit to Tehran by a British minister of his rank since the Islamic revolution in 1979.

title: Lt. Gen. Timothy L. Maude, 53, an Army Deputy Chief of Staff
description: Lt. Gen. Timothy L. Maude, the Army's deputy chief of staff for personnel, died on Sept. 11 in the attack on the Pentagon, the Department of Defense confirmed yesterday. He was 53 and lived in Fort Meyer, Va.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Prisoners Aid Attack Victims
description: The 5,108 inmates of the state penitentiary at Angola, including about 10 on death row, have contributed $11,060 to the Red Cross to help the families of the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the warden said. Prisoners earn up to 20 cents an hour on the prison farm. Convict leaders have also dedicated most of the $20,000 expected in profit from next month's prison rodeo to the relief effort. ''These guys are criminals, but they are Americans, and they love their country,'' the warden, Burl N. Cain, said.

title: When Droll, Oblique Lyrics Turn Prophetic
description: The World Trade Center attack was never far from listeners' minds when Laurie Anderson performed at Town Hall on Thursday night. No one expected anything else. For two decades Ms. Anderson's songs and stories have mused on subjects at stake in the disaster: cities, information, freedom, technology, mortality and American identity. Her tone has grown less droll and more elegiac, and on Wednesday night what once seemed offhanded or oblique had turned chillingly prophetic.

title: Asahi and Daiwa to Merge, Cutting Jobs
description: Asahi Bank Ltd. and Daiwa Bank Ltd. said yesterday that they would merge, closing a third of their branches and cutting staff by a quarter as the two, Japan's fifth- and sixth-largest lenders, battle a slowing economy and a rise in bad loans.

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYROWITZ, JACOB
description: MEYROWITZ-Jacob. On September 21, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Edith. Loving father of Doris Lavine (Robert). Dear brother of Helen Kaufman. Devoted grandfather of Jeffrey and Scott. Longtime companion of Frances Packer. Service Sunday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Debating Whether New Agency Can Command, or Just Link Commanders
description: The new Homeland Security Agency will be charged with figuring out how more than 40 disparate agencies -- from the Coast Guard to the Treasury Department -- can police American borders, protect against terrorists and respond immediately to any terrorist attack.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLACK, CHARLES
description: BLACK-Charles. The Memorial Service for Professor Charles L. Black Jr., originally scheduled for Sunday, Sept 23, 2001, at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, has been postponed. The new date and time will be forthcoming. For more information, please contact the Dean's office at Columbia Law School at 212-854-2675.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMS, JULIAN
description: SIMS-Julian. Died on Thursday, September 20, 2001. He is survived by his devoted brother and sisterin-law, Seymour and Marilyn Shimkowitz, his nieces Jacquline Teitlebaum and Nancy Sanchez, nephew Neil Simkowitz and best friend Morris Monowitz. For further information please call Hellman Memorial Chapels, 845-356-8600.

title: Schundler Assails New Jersey's Response to Terrorist Attack
description: Making the World Trade Center disaster the focus of his campaign for governor, Bret D. Schundler is criticizing New Jersey's response to the attack and has released his own plan to improve the state's defenses against terrorism and its preparedness for future emergencies.

title: Nationalist Party Expels Taiwan's Ex-President
description: The Nationalist Party of Taiwan expelled its former chairman, Lee Teng-hui today, after he endorsed a rival party and made increasingly harsh charges that current Nationalist leaders were selling out to Beijing.

title: RCN, CABLE AND PHONE PROVIDER, TO BUY BACK DEBT
description: The RCN Corporation said it would spend about $250 million buying back outstanding debt at a fraction of its face value, the second time this year the money-losing telecommunications company has tried to cut its interest expense by buying back debt at cheaper prices. RCN, a provider of cable television, phone and Internet service, is backed by the billionaire Paul Allen. It will pay 19 cents to 36 cents on the dollar for the notes -- about half what it was offering noteholders in May in a $50 million buyback. Other telecommunications companies like Level 3 Communications Inc, the Covad Communications Group and XO Communications Inc. are also buying back their notes and bonds and working with bondholders to try to reduce their debt levels. The deb load of RCN, which is based in Princeton, N.J., is nearly 10 times its stock market capitalization of $260 million.

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, HERMAN
description: SANDLER-Herman, 57. Loving husband of Suki, devoted father of Pamela, Gillian and Jordana, role model and mentor to hundreds of young people. You encouraged us to take risks and gave us innumerable opportunities to follow our dreams, cheering us on as we learned to impact the world as you did so powerfully. You will always remain our awesome inspiration. We love you, Suki, Pamela, Gillian and Jordana. In lieu of flowers, gifts honoring Herman may be made to any of the following organizations: American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, The Rain Forest Foundation, The Perlman Music Program, Carnegie Hall, or UJA Federation of NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 12 about the psychology of suicide bombers misstated the name of the leader of the Assassins, the 11th-century Persian sect that conducted suicide raids on neighboring fortresses. He was Hasan ibn al-Sabbah; Alamut was the name of the Assassins' fortress.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Pakistanis, but Not Many, Angrily Take to the Streets To Denounce Bush's Stand
description: Pakistan's hard-line Islamic groups, deeply opposed to American military action against the Taliban, tried for a show of strength here today but instead managed only a modest display of the intimidating street power they often possess.

title: U.S. Sanctions On Islamabad Will Be Lifted
description: The Bush administration moved today to reward Pakistan, its new partner in the war on terrorism, while European allies signaled their support by endorsing an American military response to the attacks on New York and Washington.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the arts pages on Sept. 3 with an article about the South African playwright Athol Fugard misidentifed the actress shown with him in a rehearsal for his new play, ''Sorrows & Rejoicings,'' which opened the previous week in Cape Town. She was Denise Newman, not Jennifer Steyn.

description: STACKPOLE-Timothy, Captain F.D.N.Y. Ladder No. 103 on September 11, 2001 in the line of duty. Devoted husband of Tara (nee Carlton). Beloved father of Kevin, Kaitlyn, Brian, Brendan and Terence. Loving son of Edward and the late Joan (nee Titus). Loving brother of Edward (N.Y.P.D.) and Patricia, Kathleen and Kevin Buell, Michael (F.D.N.Y.) and Lynn, Patricia Stackpole & Joseph Murphy. Cherished son-in-law of Mary and James Carlton. Dear grandson of Beatrice Casey. Loving brother-inlaw of James & Suzanne Carlton, Kevin and Gina Carlton, Sean, Brian, Megan, and Matthew. Beloved uncle & godfather. Funeral on Monday at 10 A.M. from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass Good Shepherd Roman Catholic Church 11 A.M. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to N.Y. Firefighters Burn Foundation, 21 Asch Loop, Bronx, N.Y. 10475 or The Thomas Elsasser Fund C/O UFOA, 225 Broadway, Room 401, N.Y., N.Y. 10007, in his memory would be appreciated. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 P.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Posts Its Worst Loss Since the Great Depression

title: SBC COMMUNICATIONS SEEKS TO ACQUIRE ALL OF PRODIGY
description: SBC Communications Inc. offered to acquire the 58 percent of the Internet service provider Prodigy Communications that it does not already own for $384 million, or $5.45 a share, an SBC spokesman, Selim Bingol, said yesterday. SBC, which is based in San Antonio, said in a statement that the offer represented a 54 percent premium to Prodigy's closing price of $3.54 yesterday, and a 35 percent premium to the average closing price for the year to date.

title: Democrats in Senate Back Down on Missile Shield Issue
description: Senate Democrats backed down today on missile defense, agreeing to restore the $1.3 billion in spending authority for developing and testing antimissile systems that they had planned to cut from the Pentagon authorization bill.

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLKIN, ANDREW H.
description: GOLKIN-Andrew H. Age 30, tragically on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center. Devoted son of Gerald and Janet Golkin. Adored brother of Susan Golkin. Loved by his aunt Betsy Golkin, aunt and uncle Marian and James Cohen and cousin Charles Cohen, and the late Michael Cohen. Cherished grandchild of the late Estelle and Sy Masters, the late Ann and Saul Golkin, and Georgette Golkin. Beloved by his enormous family of friends. description: JACOBSON-Steven. Tifereth Israel, Town & Village Synagogue mourns the passing of Steven Jacobson on September 11, 2001 at The World Trade Center. Rabbi Laurence Sebert Rabbi Abigail Sosland Cantor Shayna Smith Dr. Lewis Freedman, President

description: To the Editor:

title: Attack Further Delays a Final Decision on Hudson Dredging
description: The terrorist attack in New York has further delayed the Environmental Protection Agency's final decision on a $460 million plan for General Electric to dredge the Hudson River of poisonous chemicals.

title: Microsoft Delays Release of Xbox Game System by a Week
description: The Microsoft Corporation, following a pattern of delays and shortfalls by the makers of video game consoles, yesterday postponed by one week the North American release of its Xbox game system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JAMES JOSEPH ''KELLS''
description: KELLY-James Joseph ''Kells'', age 39, of Oceanside, and formerly of Merrick, with Cantor Fitzgerald at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. For 13 years, the beloved husband of Joanne, (nee Sweningson). Cherished dad of Brianne, Kaitlyn, Colleen and Erin. Beloved son of Maureen and Joseph. Dear brother of Maureen, Kathleen and Ellen, Patricia, Michael and Jacqueline, Jeanne and James Mugan. Loving son-in-law of Arthur and Eileen Sweningson and brother-in-law of Carol McMarrow and Barbara Sweningson. Cherished by a loving extended family and countless caring friends. Family will receive friends at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 445 East Meadow Ave., East Meadow (Exit 25N S.S. Pky) Sunday 2-4:30 and 7-10 PM. Mass at St. Christopher's Church in Baldwin Monday at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to Kells' Girls College Fund, PO Box 570, Rockville Centre, NY 11571-0570 will be gratefully appreciated.

title: Editorial Observer; The Quiet Consolation of the Material World
description: On the first Friday after that sudden Tuesday, I took an afternoon train back homeward out of Manhattan and into the country. Do you remember the day? The clouds were pulling apart in the distance, exposing blue sky along the western horizon. The streets of Harlem took the light and held it, their brick buildings seeming almost to swell with solidity. In the substance of those streets and the surface of the river and the embrace of the railroad bridge into the Bronx, there was a profound, material comfort. Material is the important word. The world into which I was passing exuded nothing but its own repose. It had no news to deliver, or rather only the old, inarticulate news that bricks and water and steel have always delivered.

title: Seeking a Future in Military, Undeterred by Talk of War
description: There is no hard sell here.

title: Hunt for Suspects Widens in Germany : French Hold 7 on Terror Suspicions
description: Acting on a tip about a conspiracy to attack the U.S. Embassy in Paris, the French police made seven arrests Friday in a raid at dawn in the suburbs of Paris.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Tally of Missing May Drop

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, BRIAN
description: MURPHY-Brian. Daddy, your love made us the luckiest children in the world. We will miss you so much because you always made everything right for us. You are the best Daddy in the world. Love forever and ever, Jessica and Leila

title: Corrections

title: A New Order at Shea Stadium: Barricades, Checkpoints and Long Lines
description: Baseball returned to New York last night, but it came back to a city changed.

title: Giuliani and Senator Clinton: Once Rivals, Now Allies
description: Of all the unusual political marriages that have resulted from the terrorist attack on America, few are as intriguing as the one between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: DRUGSTORE CHAIN LOWERS QUARTERLY PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The CVS Corporation said its third-quarter profit would be less than forecast because sales had fallen and the company had increased advertising and offered more discounts. CVS, the second-largest chain of drugstores in the nation, said its earnings would be 30 cents to 32 cents a share, less than the 35 cents to 37 cents it had projected earlier. CVS has been giving out coupons to try to win back pharmacy customers it lost over the last few months, after a pharmacist shortage caused it to cut hours in many of its stores. It has also increased the size of its circulars. Sales may be further reduced by lower consumer confidence after last week's terrorist attacks, CVS said.

title: Tension and Caution Arise In Entertainment Industry
description: The line of cars stretched beneath the ornate archway and down the sloping entranceway to the Paramount Pictures lot this afternoon. Studio guards were being more scrupulous than usual about checking those trying to get into the compound.

title: TV Reception Problems
description: Seconds after the attack began at the World Trade Center, six of the city's eight major television stations, whose broadcast antennas were on the 300-foot mast atop the north tower, lost their signals. That left the 4.5 million people in the region who do not have cable unable to receive WNBC, WABC, WNET, WPIX, WNYW and WWOR.

title: Facing the Limits Of a Just War
description: American aircraft carriers head for the Persian Gulf, and the president steps up his threats against terrorists. It is in times like these, when anger, pain and outraged patriotism are tossed together with talk of war, that moral philosophers, theologians and others who study the ethics of modern warfare begin to worry.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Sympathy From Relatives of the 'Disappeared'
description: At age 72, frail and chain-smoking, Lilia Orfan has one desire as she enters her twilight years: a grave site for the two sons she lost four months apart in the mid-1970's during Argentina's so-called dirty war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASKWITH, MIMI
description: ASKWITH-Mimi. The Trustees and staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage-A Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of Mimi Askwith, beloved mother of our trustee, Patti Askwith Kenner. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire Askwith family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: In Europe, Some Critics Say the Attacks Stemmed From American Failings
description: The killing of thousands in the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington last week has prompted great unity of purpose in the United States, cemented by shared outrage. President Bush has called on the world to unite against barbarism.

title: Arab-Americans Are Finding New Tolerance Amid the Turmoil
description: Before the e-mail note that explained how a ''good Arab'' is a dead one buried in pigskin, before the bomb threat that briefly closed his office and before young white men in a car threatened to kill him, Ismael Ahmed got an urgent telephone call.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, BERNARD E.
description: PATTERSON-Bernard E. ''Bernie,'' tragically on September 11th, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Employee of Cantor Fitzgerald. Loving husband of Navila. Cherished father of Kevin, Scott and Anna. Beloved son of Louise and the late Bernard. Dear brother of Owen and Kevin. A Memorial Mass will be held Wednesday, September 26th, 2001 at 11 AM at St. Dominic's R.C. Church, 96 Anstice St., Oyster Bay. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to either the St. Dominic's Athletic Fields Fund, 110 Anstice St., Oyster Bay or a charity of your choice.

title: Bush Says Shaken Economy Is 'Fundamentally Strong'
description: President Bush tried today to reassure jittery Americans that their country's economy remained ``fundamentally sound'' despite the successive shocks of the terrorist destruction of the World Trade Center, corporate layoffs and the stock market's worst weekly performance since 1933.

title: Novels Gaze Into Terror's Dark Soul
description: A mysterious man with a foreign name meets acolytes at a secret location in the middle of the night. A new recruit is brought before him. Passionate and fearless, the recruit agrees to take a ''vow of blind obedience'': when called upon, he will commit whatever assassination or bombing his superiors dictate, even if it costs him his life.

title: Schools Offer Free Tuition To Children of the Victims
description: Five New York area universities said yesterday that they planned to provide scholarships for dependents of victims in last week's attacks.

title: Police Officer Visits to Reassure a Queens Mosque
description: A couple of days after the attack on the World Trade Center, John Loud, second vice president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, drove around Queens, looking for a mosque. He said he had been worried about Muslims in New York, and wanted to offer them comfort and reassurance. Turning onto 168th Street, he found the Jamaica Muslim Center, whose 2,000 members are mainly immigrants from Pakistan and Bangladesh.

title: More Extremists Find Basis for Rebellion in Islam
description: Even in World War II, troops were sent into battle with assurances from Protestant, Catholic and Jewish chaplains that God was on their side and that their deaths would make them martyrs.

title: Beneficiaries of the Military Buildup Await Their Orders
description: Early last week, Frank C. Lanza, the chief executive of L-3 Communications, an aerospace and communications company in New York, received a not-too-surprising telephone call from military officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAND, ERIC MARTIN
description: SAND-Eric Martin, 36. Of Hawthorne, NY. Died tragically on Setember 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Michele (Rosenblum) Sand, loving father of Aaron Michael, 19 mos, devoted son of Lloyd and Sandra Sand of Lake Worth, Fl. He was a loving and cherished friend to so many. We will all miss him forever. A service to remember Eric will be held on Sunday September 23, 2001 at 11:30AM at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, 2 Banksville Road, Armonk, NY 10504, 914-273-2220.

title: Attack Took Heavy Toll On Many Countries
description: In the 32 years of ''the troubles'' in Northern Ireland, the deadliest single day of terror came in 1974 when 33 people died in coordinated bombings in the cities of Monaghan and Dublin. Last week, when two hijacked planes ripped into the World Trade Center, as many or more Irish may have died.

title: Giants' Defense Hopes to Live Up to Hype
description: It was the most ballyhooed front four in football before the season began. The Giants' defensive line was trumpeted as perhaps tops in the league, incorporating the best of last season's Super Bowl team with the free-agent end Kenny Holmes.

description: To the Editor:

title: BOEING AGREES TO PAY $92.5 MILLION IN INVESTORS' SUIT
description: The Boeing Company agreed to pay $92.5 million to settle a class-action suit that accused it of not telling investors fast enough that the company would take a charge to shut down assembly lines. Shareholders accused Boeing of not informing them in a timely way that the company would take a $1.6 billion charge related to temporarily idling 747 and 737 jetliner assembly lines. In addition, shareholders contended in the suit, filed in October 1997, that Boeing kept its production problems a secret so its stock price would remain high and the company could complete its merger with McDonnell Douglas in August 1997. Without admitting liability, the company decided that settling the suit was ''in the best interests of Boeing and its shareholders to eliminate the risks, expense and significant disruption of continuing litigation,'' Doug Bain, the company's general counsel, said.

title: Europe Moves Against Those Tied to Attacks
description: The pursuit of the network behind the terrorist attacks in the United States spread across Europe today, with arrests of four people in Britain and seven men in France and the issuing of two arrest warrants in Germany.

description: The White House laid out its plans today for payments to federal agencies as part of the emergency relief package that raced through Congress and was signed into law this week.

title: Calibrating the Use of Force
description: It is a reasonable presumption that the terrorists who attacked New York and Washington aimed not just to kill American civilians but also to draw the United States into an indiscriminate and brutish military response that might attract Muslims around the world to their cause. President Bush seems to understand that danger, but with war fever rising in Washington and some of his own advisers recommending a multi-front military campaign, he must design a measured and precise battle plan.

title: Officials Say Number of Those Still Missing May Be Overstated

title: China Sends Labor Advocate Back to Jail

title: Tape Reveals Wild Struggle On Flight 93
description: A desperate and wild struggle took place aboard the hijacked United Airlines Flight 93 before it crashed in southwestern Pennsylvania, according to the plane's cockpit voice recorder, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Correspondent; Remembering and Forgetting
description: Sooner than we expect, after the digging and the funerals but before the cleanup, New York will face the business of organized remembering. We will try to figure out not just how to use that precious and haunted real estate at the southern end of Manhattan, but what, officially, to tell ourselves and our children and their children about what happened on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Minister Resigns After Setback
description: The Supreme Court ruled that the appointment of Jayalalitha Jayaram as the chief minister of Tamil Nadu State in May violated the Constitution. The reason, the judges said, was her disqualification from running for office after being found guilty of abusing her power as chief minister in the early 1990's to buy state-owned property at a price far below the market value. Jayalalitha, 53, a populist leader with a strong following among women and the rural poor, resigned hours after the Supreme Court ruling. The coalition of parties she leads is expected to select a replacement who will do her bidding. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Officials Report No Threat Of Flooding From the Hudson
description: A retaining wall designed to keep the Hudson River out of the World Trade Center's seven-story basement appears sound and seems to be doing its job, according to engineers who have ventured beneath the scene of last week's collapse of the World Trade Center towers.

title: In Game of Give and Take, Orioles Beat Yanks
description: A doctor asked Bernie Williams the usual diagnostic questions after he was beaned Thursday night in Chicago: Do you know what ballpark you're playing in? Do you know what year it is?

title: The Game Is Secondary for Two Coaches
description: When Cardinal Hayes and Archbishop Stepinac meet today in White Plains, the minds and hearts of both coaches will be elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCERLEAN, JOHN T. JR.
description: McERLEAN-John T. Jr. On September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Beth. Adoring father of Ryan, Timothy, Mary Kate and Allie Maeve. Memorial service Monday 11 AM at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers donations benefiting the families of the Police and Fireman slain at the World Trade Center would be appreciated.

title: Officials Are on the Lookout For Relief Effort's Dark Side
description: Every dump truck is being weighed to make sure that it is, in fact, carrying a full load. Drivers are required to sign load tickets to make sure that valuable scrap steel is not diverted to secret dumps. The Federal Emergency Management Agency has imported teams of investigators and auditors, and other officials are starting -- ever so politely -- to ask questions about $1 billion in hauling contracts signed days after the World Trade Center attack.

title: Canada Miffed at Bush Omission
description: When President Bush concluded his speech on Thursday night, a lot of Canadians were left feeling out in the cold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ANDREW K.
description: FRIEDMAN-Andrew K. Of Woodbury, N.Y., age 44. Missing in the tragic World Trade Center attack. Beloved husband and best friend of Lisa Beth Friedman (nee Steinberg). Adored father of sons Michael Dean and Daniel Harris, ages 11. Dearest son of Elaine and Mel Friedman. Beloved son-in-law of Marcia and Al Steinberg. Loving brother of Wendi Gabrielli. Dear brother-in-law of Rani Gabrielli and Susan and David Zankman. Dearest uncle of Danielle Gabrielli, Rachel, Mara and Jane Zankman. Memorial Service on Sunday, September 23rd, 2PM at Woodbury Jewish Center, Woodbury, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to ''Andrew Friedman Memorial Fund.'' Please mail all checks to: Fleet Bank Private Clients, 300 Broad Hollow Road, Melville, N.Y. 11747, attn Dorothy Doyle.

title: Douglas Newton, 80, Curator Emeritus at the Metropolitan
description: Douglas Newton, curator emeritus of the department of the arts of Africa, Oceania and the Americas at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and an innovator in designing museum displays of non-Western art, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil prices fell as jet fuel use plunged and concern grew that the energy needs of manufacturers would weaken. The November contract fell 76 cents, or 2.8 percent, to $25.97 a barrel in New York.

title: Blake Revitalized, On and Off the Ice
description: Jason Blake has a healthy wife, a 6-month-old daughter whom he calls the joy of his life, a new home on Long Island and a new contract with the Islanders. He has also returned to the game he loves, with a new number on his sweater, and he is playing hockey with an animated passion, slapping his stick on the ice and hollering for the puck when he sees a chance to score.

title: Bush Rallies America: Ovations and Doubts
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY/REMAINS OF THE DAY
description: What was lost on Sept. 11? What was left standing? More than two dozen writers and photographers, including Richard Ford, Robert Stone and Andres Serrano, record some of the first aftershocks. A special issue of The Times Magazine.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Dole Makes It Official
description: Elizabeth Dole has officially joined the race for the Senate seat being vacated by Jesse Helms, a fellow Republican. Mrs. Dole filed a notice of candidacy last week with the secretary of the Senate, noting that she had formed a committee to seek the Republican nomination. Her campaign canceled a formal announcement in Salisbury, her hometown, on Sept. 11 because of the terrorist attacks in New York and at the Pentagon. Mrs. Dole, 65, a former president of the American Red Cross and a cabinet secretary in two Republican administrations, will face Richard Vinroot, a former Charlotte mayor, in the Republican primary next year.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 9 p.m. Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, IRWIN
description: SCHREIBER-Irwin. On September 19, 2001. Loving brother of Leona. Adored uncle of Les and Karen and their children Justin and Dara, as well as Ron and Helaine and their children David, Ira and Brian. Service Sunday, 11 AM Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, STUART TODD
description: MELTZER-Stuart Todd. Perished in the World Trade Center disaster. Beloved husband of Lisa. Loving father of Jacob Andrew, 3, and Dylan Ross, 6 months. Beloved son of Zachary and Joyce Meltzer and Howard and Gail Ruderman. Loving brother of Lawrence and Kenneth, Matthew and Dana Kossoy. Memorial service at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Rd., Roslyn, L.I., at noon, Sunday. All expressions of sympathy should be donated to the Meltzer Family Fund for the education of Stuart's two children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPUTO, MARY S.
description: SAPUTO-Mary S. On September 20. Beloved wife of the late Vincent R. Devoted mother of Dennis, Anne Marie and Ronald. Loving grandmother of Michael, Rachel, Adria and C. Ross. title: Injury-Depleted MetroStars Get Ready for the Playoffs
description: The MetroStars rightfully consider themselves the underdogs in their playoff series with the Los Angeles Galaxy starting tomorrow night at the Rose Bowl. They will be without three of their top players in the two-of-three-game series, which continues at Giants Stadium on Wednesday night, and they are having great difficulty scoring.

title: Confidence, in the Economy and the U.S., Is the Long-Term Issue
description: As the Dow Jones industrial average suffered its worst week since the Great Depression, attention inevitably gravitated toward those who were selling stocks, and why they were doing so. But the far more important issue in the long run will be whether this crisis damages confidence in the American economy and in America itself.

title: 91% Support President, Poll on Speech Shows : Americans Back Bush's Ultimatum to Taleban
description: WASHINGTON  The American public and political leadership offered near-unanimous support Friday for President George W. Bush's declaration of a protracted and broad-based war on terrorists and their protectors, including his demand that Afghanistan hand over all suspected terrorists or "share in their fate."

title: For President, a Mission and a Role in History
description: When President Bush first sat down with his full cabinet after last week's terrorist attacks, he told them that nothing about their roles or charges as federal officials would ever be the same.

title: Brahms and Masur Touch the Heart of the Matter
description: Kurt Masur's unabashed belief in the power of music to make big statements and foster healing has sometimes invited kidding. No longer. If ever there was a moment when Americans, particularly New Yorkers, needed musical inspiration and healing it is now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, CARL
description: GREENBERG-Carl. On September 20, 2001. Beloved husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Glen and Stuart. Dear brother of Sonia Goldman and the late Rhoda Grundt. Loving grandfather of Lauren, Jason, Sarajean, Caroline, Marybeth & Kevin. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Insurers Raise Damage Estimates
description: Allianz A.G. and Axa S.A., Europe's largest insurers, raised their estimates for claims from the terrorist strike on the United States to a combined $1.47 billion. Allianz also lowered its earnings estimate for the second time this month. The attacks are expected to result in the most expensive disaster in history, with damages of as much as $73 billion, analysts said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREISMAN, LEAH D.
description: GREISMAN-Leah D. On September 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Jacob Greisman. Loving mother of Dr. Stewart G. Greisman and Lois C. Greisman. Adored grandmother of Laura, Jill and Jack. Mother-in-law of Dr. Lisa Babitz. Sister of the late Juliet Zekster, aunt of Elizabeth Girardat and Gregory Zekster, loyal alumna of Hunter College. Services Sunday, September 23, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Scholarship and Welfare Fund of Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, Room E 1314, NYC 10021.

title: Theater Photo Archive Lost Amid the Rubble
description: They are not people, only pictures of people, and so may barely rate mention as collateral damage in the wreckage that has claimed so many lives. But in an office building crushed last week by the collapsing 7 World Trade Center lie some 35,000 photographs capturing some great moments on the American stage.

title: Britain Again Reinstates Direct Rule on Northern Ireland
description: Britain suspended Northern Ireland's three-year-old government tonight and reinstated direct rule from London for the second time in two months, to forestall yet another crisis over the fulfillment of the 1998 Good Friday peace accord.

title: Truth Is All About Sex, and So Are Lies
description: The level of hypocrisy achieved by ''Love,'' a not only offensive but also incompetent play by David S. Rosenthal, is astonishing and in my experience unmatched -- even by the egregious standards of vanity productions, which this indubitably is. To begin with, it purports -- literally and loudly -- to tell the truth as no other work ever has and then deploys (ploy being the critical syllable) in its advertising a ban on theatergoers under 17. Evidently, in Mr. Rosenthal's opinion, you should get your license for truth with your license to drive, at least when it's expressed in naughty language.

title: Peace Talks Possible as Frail Cease-Fire Holds
description: The cease-fire in Israel clung to life today, despite scattered reports of violence and strong words from Prime Minister Ariel Sharon that again called Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, a terrorist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADAM, LOUIS
description: RADAM-Louis. Loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle & friend. We will miss you dearly.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Peace Reforms Inch Forward
description: Parliament broke up in disarray as it voted on constitutional amendments crucial to the plan to end the conflict here. The majority Macedonian Slav Parliament rejected changing the Constitution to end the pre-eminence of the Orthodox Church and make Macedonia a multireligious state. But legislators did agree on 6 of 18 constitutional amendments, including one that removes any mention of citizens' ethnic origin and guarantees human rights, civil liberties and peaceful coexistence for all citizens. That change meets the demands of ethnic Albanians, a third of the population, and of rebels seeking greater rights for the Albanian minority. However, most amendments passed with only a simple majority and may not win the required two-thirds majority for final approval. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Government Lifts Its Ban on Some Flight Training
description: Major airlines, corporate jets, crop dusters, even aircraft involved in skydiving are back in service. But 10 days after the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, many flight training schools are still closed for business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, ROBERT G.
description: McCARTHY-Robert G. 33, died tragically on September 11, 2001, as a result of the World Trade Center disaster. He was employed on the 104th floor by Cantor Fitzgerald. He is survived by his loving wife, Annie Rosenfeld McCarthy, his four-week old son Shane Robert, his parents Robert and Patricia McCarthy, a sister Mary Jean O'Leary, and a brother Patrick James McCarthy. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, September 26, 2001, at 10:15 AM, at St. Gregory Barbarigo Church, Garnerville, New York. The family will receive friends at St. Gregory's Church on Monday, September 24, and Tuesday, September 25, from 3-8 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Robert G. McCarthy Memorial Fund, PMB 871, 222 Rte 9W, Haverstraw, NY 10927. Higgins Funeral Home, Stony Point, NY.

Mueller III of the F.B.I. walked the streets in their first visit to the World Trade Center, now a crime scene in the largest investigation in the history of the Justice Department and Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSKY, HANNAH
description: LIPSKY-Hannah. The Faculty and Staff of the Divison of Social Work and Behavorial Science Department of Community and Preventive Medicine of the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine are deeply saddened by the death of Mrs. Hannah Lipsky. She was a longterm member of our faculty who retired in 1981 from the Department of Social Work Services but continued on our faculty making important contributions to our Geriatric Services and educational programs. Mrs. Lipsky's contributions to the Medical Center date from 1974 when she came to us as Assistant Director of the Department of Social Work Services and an Instructor in the Department of Community Medicine. Her commitment to social health programs, to social justice and her warm and caring manner contributed to her nationwide reputation as an outstanding social worker. She is survived by her three sons: Michael, David and John, four grandchildren and one great grandchild. Services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at 9:00 a.m. on Monday, September 24th. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Division of Social Work and Behavioral Science of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine to be used for projects.

description: It seemed this week as if the World Trade Center disaster, like a plague of Egypt, had stripped off layers of the city's narcissism and venality, leaving grief-stricken, fearful residents cleansed of the era's more frivolous preoccupations.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Havas Quits Bid
description: Havas Advertising said it would not pursue a $620 million offer for the Tempus Group, blaming a weakening economy and the attacks against the United States. That leaves the WPP Group the sole bidder for Tempus, the British media buyer. ''To make a higher bid would be unreasonable in an environment which is getting worse by the day,'' Alain de Pouzilhac, chief executive of Havas, said. WPP needs approval of at least 90 percent of Tempus shareholders by Oct. 1. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

description: A senior Bush administration official said today that the ''initial phase'' of the assault on terrorism would be aimed at Osama bin Laden and his network in Afghanistan, but that the scale and timing of the next, broader phase had yet to be worked out.

title: United Arab Emirates Cuts Ties With Afghanistan
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 22  The United Arab Emirates broke off relations with Afghanistan today because of the ruling Taliban's refusal to hand over Osama bin Laden, the terrorist network chief suspected of masterminding the suicide attacks on New York and Washington.

title: EARNINGS OUTLOOK CUT AS WEAK CHEMICAL DEMAND IS SEEN
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the largest United States chemical maker, will miss third-quarter earnings estimates as a slowing economy and terrorism reduce demand for chemicals and plastics used in cars, appliances and construction. Dow abandoned its July per-share profit forecast of 25 cents to 35 cents and did not provide a new estimate. Sales have been hurt by last week's terrorist attacks, analysts said. Dow and other chemical makers have been hurt this year as demand weakened for auto parts, building materials and consumer and durable goods.

title: The Weight of Their Years
description: I was moved by the words of 14-year-old Shanna Baronoff (What They Were Thinking, Aug. 26). I can sympathize with her parents' well-intentioned desire to help their daughter succeed in a world that judges the appearance of women so critically. But I can only pity them if they are embarrassed by a child as thoughtful and articulate as she is. Shanna will succeed because she is courageous and smart, not because she wears a size 4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, SCOTT MICHAEL
description: JOHNSON-Scott Michael. Of New York City, died in the attack on civil society at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. He was 26 years old. Scott was born on April 7, 1975 at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, New Jersey. He was a 1993 graduate of the Montclair Kimberley Academy, Montclair, NJ and a 1997 graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, CT. title: 'The Popes Against the Jews'
description: Edward Cardinal Cassidy, Australian head of the Vatican's Commission for Religious Relations with the Jews, called in reporters to announce the long-awaited results of his investigation. It was March 16, 1998 -- eleven years after Pope John Paul II had asked the Commission to determine what responsibility, if any, the Church bore for the slaughter of millions of European Jews during World War II. For the Church, a more explosive subject could hardly be imagined. It had been thirty-five years since Rolf Hochhuth's play The Deputy had first raised the charge of papal complicity in the Holocaust, triggering Catholic outrage worldwide. Yet the suggestion that the Vatican bore any responsibility for what had happened to the Jews continued to grate on Catholic sensibilities. And so nervousness mixed with curiosity as the report was finally released to a public sharply divided between those worried that it might criticize the Church, and those who feared it would not.
