title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALDES, JOHN TERHUNE
description: VALDES-John Terhune. Died September 19th, 2001, in West Palm Beach, after a long illness. A memorial service is being planned for February. Mr. Valdes was born in Philadelphia, December 22, 1923, the son of Mr. and Mrs. V. Francisco Valdes of Ithan, Pennsylvania. He attended the Haverford School and graduated from St. George's School in Middletown, Rhode Island in June of 1941. Mr. Valdes entered Princeton University, but left to become a Naval Aviator and torpedo bomber pilot aboard the aircraft carrier ''Fanshaw Bay'' during the Okinawa campaign. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and four Air Medals upon his release from the Navy in 1945. Mr. Valdes returned to Princeton to graduate in 1948. His interest in the ''Triangle Club'' dramatic group led to his employment at CBS Television in New York as a special effects supervisor on many of the pioneering CBS network shows including ''The Jackie Gleason Show'', ''Ed Sullivan Show'' and ''Studio One''. He was later employed as a television account executive with BBDO advertising agency in New York and Detroit, working on network television shows for the Chrysler Corporation. For several years in the midfifties, Mr. Valdes was co-owner of Radio Station WCUE AM/FM Akron, Ohio. For many years Mr. Valdes was a director of several New Jersey banks, finally retiring to Florida after the merger of the First Colonial National Bank with the First Fidelity Bancorporation. Mr Valdes is survived by six grandchildren and four daughters; Mrs. Stacy Lorenceau of San Martin, California, Ms. Midge Valdes of New York City, Victoria McKellar of Phoenix, AZ and Ms. Fleury Kelly Valdes of Unionville, Pennsylvania and Southern Pines, North Carolina. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Greater New York Red Cross, P.O. Box 3756, Church Street Station, New York, New York 10008.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WHEN Vivien Leigh walks on screen in ST. MARTIN'S LANE (1940), a k a ''Sidewalks of London,'' and emits a screeching Cockney accent, it's as if Scarlett O'Hara were channeling Eliza Doolittle. This British film was released in England in 1938, a year before ''Gone With the Wind,'' and you can see every one of Scarlett's attitudes and expressions in use. Leigh plays a talented, poor and not entirely honest young dancer taken in by a kindly London busker, or street entertainer (Charles Laughton), who falls in love with her. But so does Rex Harrison, playing a well-dressed, well-connected songwriter who gives her her start on the road to West End stardom. Guess which nice guy is left behind? Tim Whelan directed - Sunday at 9 p.m. and Friday at midnight on CUNY.

title: A Shaken State In Mourning
description: HENRY AND TENSY VEGA of New Milford waited by the phone, helpless, knowing that their son, Richard, who worked a few blocks from the World Trade Center, was heading there that day, of all days, for a meeting in one of the towers. But what time was the meeting? He had never told them. Didn't he say it was on the 104th floor, near where the plane hit? So they waited for word in agony.

title: What Terror Keeps Teaching Us; Bringing Jerusalem Home
description: Shortly after we returned this summer from a three-year posting in Jerusalem, we borrowed a house in the woods in central Vermont. The first night, Emma and Adam, our two younger children, couldn't sleep. After learning to achieve deep slumber during the many Middle Eastern nights when tank fire pounded on the periphery of their dreams, they were gripping their sheets because they had heard a hoot. Owls in the trees! My husband and I were thrilled by the mundanity.

title: Smart Women, Foolish Marriages
description: The characters in DARLING? (Picador USA, $23), Heidi Jon Schmidt's second collection of stories, tend to be women of formidable intellect -- they're too smart for the terrible emotional places where they find themselves trapped. Some of them are married to much older men, academics or writers to whom they have attached perhaps more than a modicum of their identities. ''No one is better fitted to see all that's wrong with me,'' the narrator of ''Songbirds'' says of her intellectual husband. In another story, a slightly less self-deprecating narrator and her husband, a poet, spar over a guest list, only to find themselves ''arguing about grade inflation in the universities, the empty 'self-esteem' that leaves students feeling proud, proud of themselves without all the bother of accomplishing anything.'' Schmidt's bitter wit, shot through with insecurity and self-conscious braininess, calls to mind Lorrie Moore, but her voice isn't derivative. Despite the tangled lives these women lead, Schmidt's stories are tinged with hope, and even when the author is at her most biting you rarely suspect she has any contempt for her characters. Often her target is larger, like the cult status enjoyed by creative writing; in a Cape Cod workshop, one of the students carries a popular writing manual along with ''a collection of aromatherapy sachets for writers, with scents for lyricism, insight, courage.'' And at the same time that she calls the importance of intellectualism and art into question, her precise and elegant prose is smart and artful indeed. Emily Hall

title: 'This Is It -- as Happy as I Get, Baby'
description: It would behoove movie and television producers to figure out how to ''get it'' about Nathan Lane, because the rest of us did years ago. Unfortunately, we can't all afford the cost of air fare to New York City, a hotel room and tickets to ''The Producers'' to enjoy his comedic genius. However, we would enthusiastically show up at a local cinema or turn on the television to see him. His fans would have delighted in a sitcom, starring Lane as a diva chef in a five-star restaurant, living in a working-class neighborhood, with Kaye Ballard playing his mother. The substitute is an altered version, purportedly a comedy, which will go on the air this month with Emeril Lagasse.

title: Perspective; SportsWorld Tried to Find Some Balance
description: The night before the attack, I was in a Chicago restaurant partially owned by Michael Jordan across the street from Hoops, the gym where he sometimes works out. The table talk was about the imminence of the eminence's return. Did M. J. still have it? Could he thrill us again? But wasn't it time for all of us to move on, M. J. to a life, the rest of us to new heroes?

description: THEURKAUF-Thomas Francis, Jr. 44, of Stamford, CT, perished Tuesday, September 11, 2001, in the tragic events at the World Trade Center where he worked as Executive Vice President for Keefe, Bruyette and Woods. Tom was born and raised in Glastonbury, CT, received his BS from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an MBA from Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School. Tom leaves his beloved wife Robin (Siegel) Theurkauf of Stamford, CT, and their three wonderful children Tommy, Teddy, and Henry. He was the son of Helen and Thomas Theurkauf, Sr., Glastonbury, CT, brother to Bill Theurkauf, Sterling, MA, Pat Theurkauf and Barbara Theurkauf, both of Glastonbury, CT. In addition, he leaves many nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles and cousins across the United States. Tom will be dearly missed by his family, friends and associates. His Memorial Mass will be held on Friday, September 28th, 10 AM, at St. Patrick-St. Anthony's Church, Church St, Hartford, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The House of Bread, 1453 Main Street, Hartford, CT. 06120.

title: Not Just Another Pale Victorian Aesthete
description: ONE of the unexpected pleasures of the show of work by William Blake at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last spring was the discovery that most of the large monoprints from 1795 on view were donated or bequeathed to the Tate Gallery in London by W. Graham Robertson. W. Graham who? The man is forgotten today; indeed, he embraced oblivion. But in the London of Beardsley and Beerbohm, Shaw and Henry James, Robertson was a promising presence in the art and theater worlds. Today the museums of England owe a debt to his taste and judgment.

description: LEVIN-Neil D. Age 46, of New York City, missing and presumed dead in the World Trade Center attack, September 11, 2001. Neil was the Executive Director of the NYNJ Port Authority, a job he loved. He was a good friend, a mentor and role model for many. He will be deeply missed by his wife Christy Ferer, step-daughters Caitlin and Ali, his mother Gloria, his brother Stanley, sister-in-law Robin, nephew Adam and niece Kim. title: Business; Continental's Blunt Leader Faces Crisis, Again
description: AS the first hijacked airliner smashed into the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, Gordon M. Bethune, the chief executive of Continental Airlines, was at home in Houston, getting dressed for a routine board meeting. Minutes after the attack, his chief operating officer, C. D. McLean, called him with the news. Mr. Bethune ran to the television, only to remember that a contractor working in the backyard had accidentally cut the cable the night before. Mr. Bethune sped to work, where he joined some board members already massed in front of a television in horror.

description: Susan Corinne Blinkhorn and Richard August Gallun Jr., were married in the Adirondacks yesterday. The Rev. Milton Dudley, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Ausable Club in St. Huberts, N.Y.

title: Aftermath; Who Let The Bulldog Out?
description: EVERYBODY'S invoking the guy. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is being compared to him now regularly. And even those who doubt our president's verbal aptitude would have to concede that, in his speech before a joint session of Congress Thursday night, he took his foot from his mouth to take a stride toward the master.

title: Clinging To Belief In Art
description: WHEN my husband and I went to bed on Sept. 11, our house on Duane Street, just six blocks from the World Trade Center, was in total darkness. We felt as if we were in a war zone. I said to him that I felt how futile my artmaking seemed right now: how could balancing shapes with line and color have any meaning or be of any use to anyone? Bob is a poet, and I felt that words were the only way all these feelings that were surfacing could be adequately expressed.

title: A Farewell and a Warning; Keen Vigilance Needed To Stay Free of Racism
description: IN the book ''Nassau, Suburbia, USA,'' the author and historian Ed Smits chronicles the arrival of the Ku Klux Klan in 1922, when it organized on Long Island to combat what it saw as the corrosive effect of blacks and Jews on local society. About 150 people gathered to hear the organizer, who filled the air with venom and hate before the nascent local klavern reconvened in secret to plan its suburban strategy. In 1924, Mr. Smits writes, hundreds of people attended a weeklong series of rallies in Hempstead that culminated with the burning of a cross and the presentation of an American flag to a local church.

title: Personal Business; When Grief Meets the Reality of Financial Planning
description: FIRST came the physical devastation of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, then the emotional shock waves, and now the families of the victims are likely to face financial trauma as well.

description: This

title: Hoping to Fill the Need for Office Space
description: WITH 15 million square feet of office space in lower Manhattan lost on Sept. 11 and another 10 million square feet at least temporarily unusable, companies displaced by the attack on the World Trade Center are turning to suburbs like Westchester, where vacancy rates have been rising.

title: Corrections
description: The New York Online column on Sept. 9, about a Web site called Flneur, misidentified the writer who described a flneur as an urban wanderer. According to the site's editor, Lawrence Levi, it was Baudelaire, not Molire.

title: Explosion by the Hudson, Foreign Espionage, Local Fear: 1916
description: At 2:08 a.m on July 16, 1916, a munitions depot on Black Tom Island, in the Hudson River just off Jersey City, exploded. The island and the depot were completely destroyed. The explosion, felt 25 miles away, illuminated the sky as flaming barges bearing munitions floated down the Hudson. At least four people died, and damage has been estimated as high as $40 million. The incident occurred during World War I when the United States was still neutral though supplying munitions to the Allies. An initial review concluded that the cause was employee negligence, but there was speculation that the explosion had been the work of Germans trying to stop the weapons shipments. In 1939 an American commission concluded that the explosion had been an act of German espionage; the Germans denied it. Carmela Karnoutsos, a professor of American history at New Jersey City University, spoke about the Black Tom explosion.

description: The Nu Horizons Electronics Corporation (Nasdaq: NUHC) of Melville has entered into a franchise arrangement with Oki Semiconductor of Sunnyvale, Calif., to distribute Oki's products throughout North America.

description: A picture has begun to emerge of the men who waged the Sept. 11 attacks: a group of seemingly well-educated young men who slipped into the country and led bland lives while they gained just enough training to take control of a jet in midair.

description: THE John Jay High School football team opened its season two weeks ago, but when the Indians play at Fox Lane this afternoon, starting quarterback Mike Bocklet will be taking his first snaps under center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICCIULLI, WILLIAM E.
description: MICCIULLI-William E. A memorial Mass will be held for William E. Micciulli, 30, of Old Bridge, who died September 11, a victim of the World Trade Center disaster in New York City. He was a Partner and Senior Vice President with Cantor Fitzgerald where he worked as an International Equities trader on the 104th floor of the North Tower. He graduated Monsignor Farrell High School, Staten Island, and earned his Bachelor's degree from Fairfield University. He received his MBA from St. John's University where he was a member of the Beta Gamma Sigma honor society. He was an avid sports fan and accomplished athlete. He excelled as a starting pitcher from Little League through College. He enjoyed golfing and was a member of the Glenwood Country Club. He was also a member of the Jersey Shore Runner's Club and participated in many charity races throughout the State. He will be most remembered for his great sense of humor, caring nature and generosity. He truly enjoyed life, happiest when he was spending time with his family and friends. He was a devoted and loving father, husband, brother and son. He was a great friend and will be missed deeply by everyone who's life he touched. Born in Brooklyn and raised in Staten Island, he moved to Old Bridge three and a half years ago where he began raising his family. Surviving are his loving wife, Colleen (Fitzgerald) Micciulli, two daughters, Emily and Sara, adoring parents, William and Joan Micciulli of Manalapan, two sisters, Joanne Los Kamp and Andrea Madonna, both of Old Bridge & his grandmother, Jacqueline Carmellino of Manalapan. Visitation will be from 10:00 A.M. to 11:00 A.M. Wednesday at St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church, 172 Freneau Ave, Matawan, New Jersey. A memorial Mass will be offered at 11:00 A.M. Wednesday at the Church. Waitt & Nelms Funeral Home, Marlboro, New Jersey, for further information.

description: No one would argue that Rebecca Gomperts is indeed an activist. But her actions demonstrate the degree to which citizens must go to challenge repressive governments (Sara Corbett, Aug. 26). That's not extremism; it's the highest form of civic duty.

title: Coming With Cash, Food and Themselves
description: THERE are countless stories to tell: the man who walked into the Greenwich chapter of the American Red Cross and handed a worker a check for $10,000. ''I don't know what else to do,'' he said. The students in a South Windsor English honors class, who raised $5,000 and a truckload of food and supplies in 48 hours. The residents who filled up shopping carts at Wal-Mart and donated all their purchases to the Salvation Army.

title: C. G. Fabricant Dies at 81; Pushed Heart Illness Theory
description: Catherine G. Fabricant, an early proponent of the theory that herpes infections can lay the groundwork for a common form of heart disease, died Sept. 13 at a nursing home in Ithaca, N.Y. She was 81.

description: Long criticized for doing little to address its reputation for having one of the world's highest rates of civilians killed by the police, the government has begun hearings into two of the year's deadliest clashes.

Dear sister of Ada and Morris. Services were held at the Wien & Wien Memorial Chapels, Englewood, NJ on Thursday, September 20.

title: Why You?
description: In the Salomon Brothers office in London, where I worked in the 1980's, the security was tight. We had what then seemed to me an extraordinary fear of Islamic fundamentalists -- a fear arising from the firm's support for various Israeli causes. Now, with Islamic militants having destroyed, among other things, the downtown New York offices of Salomon, it seems suddenly quaint to think an American investment bank would have to do anything extraordinary to court terrorism. All of a sudden, it seems as recklessly brave for an Israeli Jew to go to work for an American bank as for an American bank to go to the aid of Israeli Jews.

title: Gossip Holds Its Tongue
description: TWO nights after the attack on the World Trade Center, Harrison Ford walked into Da Silvano, a favorite restaurant in Greenwich Village, with a woman on each arm. Mr. Ford has been a constant source of celebrity gossip because of his separation from his wife of 18 years. But what would have turned heads two weeks ago went totally unremarked.

title: Aftermath; Forget the Past: It's A War Unlike Any Other
description: NO one, not Alexander the Great, not the Persians, not the Moghuls or the British or the Russians, has successfully occupied Afghanistan. It is a nation of warriors, where children glue broken glass to their kite strings to cut down other kites, boys are given rifles at puberty and old men keep thrushes in wooden cages trained not to sing, but to fight.

title: Sept. 16-22; Mass Grave Near Belgrade
description: Serbian police said they had unearthed 269 bodies from a mass grave in a police special forces base near Belgrade, the largest mass grave uncovered so far in Serbia. The bodies are thought to be those of ethnic Albanians, victims of mass killings by Serbian forces in Kosovo, who were brought to Serbia in a cover-up operation that police say was ordered by former leader and indicted war criminal Slobodan Milosevic. The police estimate 800 to 1,000 bodies were transported to Serbia during the war in Kosovo. So far they have unearthed 427 in several sites around Serbia; 4,000 have been found in Kosovo. Carlotta Gall

title: Reckonings; A Bad Week
description: In late 1997, when South Korea suddenly found itself in economic crisis, there was a great upsurge of patriotism. Women offered their gold jewelry to the government, to help rebuild its vanished reserves of foreign exchange; millions of people cut back on their spending, feeling that it was irresponsible to buy themselves luxuries when the nation was in danger.

This time, though, it is as if Americans had anticipated the mood of crisis.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: On Language; Infamy

title: With Playoffs Nearing, Ailing Jeter Is Rested
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 23  Derek Jeter usually gathers speed as he breaks out of the batter's box, pumping his arms, his torso and head tilted forward, and he crosses first base in a burst. On Friday, however, Jeter's upper body was upright, he moved steadily and noticeably slower than normal.

title: When the Bodies Are Real
description: WITHIN days of the unspeakable horrors in New York and Washington, film studios moved quickly to distance themselves from images that suddenly seemed offensive. Releases have been delayed or scrapped, and producers are busily editing out any mention of terrorism. This has been done out of respect for the dead and the grieving. And also, it seems, out of some inchoate sense of shame; as if these staples of American culture were suddenly inappropriate. Many ask whether ''normal life'' will ever be the same.

Now he confers by cellphone with various emergency management officials, and tools around ground zero in a golf cart with flashlights taped to its roof.

He was also the head of The Center for Architecture and Building Science Research at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark, NJ. Beloved husband of Cynthia, loving father to three children Ruth, Dan, and Jonathan Ehrenkrantz. Cherished grandfather of Joe and Eliav Ehrenkrantz and Solomon and Micah Klein. description: Penn State's football fortunes continued to decline today with an embarrassing 18-6 defeat to Wisconsin that left Coach Joe Paterno livid.

title: Gimme Shelter
description: Before he grew boredand went on to a health-food obsession, an artist friend of mine chose to live in the early 1900's. His electricity-free farmhouse featured, among other period charms, a coal-burning stove, a genuine icebox stocked with bottled milk and a Model T parked out front. Tweed suits, shirts with detachable wing collars, even long johns, continued the theme into his attire. Life truly was his stage, and he dressed the part.

title: Aftermath; A Rescuer's-Eye View: It Wasn't a Dream
description: GRAY smoke continued to pour from Lower Manhattan, staining September's blue skies during the day and smudging the skyline by night. Television began limiting its dreadful reruns of the smashing jetliners and the steel towers in lethal collapse, instead panning cameras across incomprehensibly vast piles of smoking debris.

title: What Terror Keeps Teaching Us
description: To a 4-year-old boy, as I was on Dec. 7, 1941, the carnage at Pearl Harbor was invisible, as the carnage at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon was largely invisible on the September day of the terror attacks, before crews began to sift the wreckage. The news came by radio rather than by television, in the early evening, in the gathering dark, but it was no less vivid and portentous: ''The Japanese have bombed Pearl Harbor!'' My family lived in a boarding house in a neighborhood of large older houses on the east side of Kansas City, Mo. Awed and uncomprehending, my older brother and I were sent door to door to rouse our neighbors.

title: Italians Hold Large Protest Rally After Parliament Clears Police
description: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets here this week, just hours after Parliament approved a report absolving the police of wrongdoing during a meeting of world leaders in Genoa two months ago. The legislators acted even though reports of brutality there have never been seriously disputed.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: Close Reading: Elements of Tragedy; The Weapon
description: People keep saying ''like a movie,'' ''like a book,'' ''like a war zone,'' and I keep thinking: No, not at all like a movie or a book -- that's no computer-generated image, because you can't see any wash or blur in the background. This is what it really looks like when an actual plane filled with actual human beings and loaded with jet fuel hits a skyscraper. This is the truth.

title: Memorable Teachers
description: Whether you are 9 or 90, there's a good chance there has been an unforgettable teacher in your life. Maybe it was the third-grade teacher who demystified the multiplication tables, or the professor who taught you comparative literature. Maybe it was your dad, who made sure you knew how to drive a stick shift. Maybe it was the physical therapist who literally helped you get back on your feet.

A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 30th, 10 AM, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd Street, NYC. title: Aftermath; The Prospect of a War Without a Wartime Boom
description: WHATEVER else they are, wars are usually good for the economy, at least in the short run. World War II completed the job of pulling the United States out of the Depression. Vietnam helped fuel a nearly decade-long boom during the 1960's.

title: 'London Bridges'
description: London is a town for fog, mist swirling up from the river, the darkness between streetlights. But, although it is never summer in the London of the imagination, the streets are as answerable to sunlight and long evenings as those of any capital in Europe. There are hot, still, August nights in Mayfair, and on such a night, Jeanene Malone had just found out about the Greek optative. On such nights, while visitors ebb and flow in vast human tides through London's centres of shopping, culture and entertainment, in Mayfair, though it lies between the sun-baked yet inviting grass of Hyde Park and the manifold entertainments of the West End, secret, flower-adorned mansions of stock-brick and stucco maintain a patrician silence; unguessed, unseen lives move in secret channels beneath the surface, and the streets are as deserted as the mountains of the moon.

title: The Memorial That Vanished
description: A few years back, an elegant rose granite circle was cut, chiseled and delivered under wrappings to Lower Manhattan. Inscribed on the granite were the names of the six people who had been killed in the 1993 bombing at the World Trade Center: Monica Rodriguez Smith, Steve Knapp, Robert Kirkpatrick, William Macko, John DiGiovanni and Wilfredo Mercado. A few weeks before the ceremony to unveil the monument, someone from the Port Authority noticed that one of the names had been misspelled. With great concern, he went to his boss and said: ''You know how we say that a mistake isn't carved in stone? This one is.''

title: Paperback Advice
description: This

title: A Time to Thank Heroes and Bind Wounds
description: To the Editor:

title: Waiting
description: We needed bodies. Without them, we were useless. And so we kept waiting, staring south toward the billowing smoke, anxiously tapping our feet, hoping the ambulances constantly pulling up with their sirens blaring had somebody inside we could help. They didn't.

title: From 5,000 Feet Up, Mapping Terrain for Ground Zero Workers
description: Using a laser-based instrument, scientists are making accurate topographic images of ground zero, in hopes that they can help firefighters and rescue workers navigate the mounds and chasms of debris and identify areas that may shift or collapse.

title: Symbols of Hope
description: Ccile & Jeanne's -- dove brooch (above, $78 at Ccile & Jeanne) has already caught the eye of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who each bought one. Other jewelry includes White Trash Charms' silver flag necklace ($137 at Intermix) and Swarovski Crystal's New York Braveheart lapel pin, a heart-shaped bauble with stars and stripes ($35 at Saks Fifth Avenue).

title: Anguish for Vast Toll of Children Left Behind
description: From the Cantor Fitzgerald bond- trading firm alone, the estimate is staggering: 1,500. Not the number of victims.

title: Pro Forma Order Sends U.S. Military to War
description: A bland appendix to a Pentagon publication, the Joint Staff Officers Guide, sets forth the recommended phrasing for orders sending the men and women of the United States military off to war.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: New York Overview; For Some, 'Normal' Means Being Able to Go Home
description: In ones and twos, uncertain of what they would find in bedrooms they had not slept in and kitchens they had not cooked in for almost two weeks, tenants began moving back into a cluster of buildings opposite the ruins of the World Trade Center yesterday, as rescue workers dug deeper into the rubble left by the terrorist attacks on the twin towers but found no survivors.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 2 about the musical ''The Fantasticks'' misidentified the character played by Bryan Hull and his tenure in the part. It was the Old Actor, not the Old Man; Mr. Hull played the part for 21 years, not 18.

title: Another Ranked Team Has Easy Time With Rutgers
description: Eleven days ago, Jane Luther Umstadter of Brielle, N.J., was working on the 17th floor of 1 World Trade Center. Today, at 7:45 a.m., she and her husband, Bill, a Rutgers alumnus, were the first tailgaters in the main parking lot before the noon football game in which Virginia Tech routed Rutgers, 50-0.

title: Letters
description: What NATO Is For

title: Sept. 16-22; Shift on Farm Policy
description: The Bush administration called for a major shift away from the current farm policy in a 120-page food and agricultural policy paper that argued for more international trade and conservation and against continuing with large subsidies to wealthy grain and cotton farmers. The report, by Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman, said current subsidies distorted the market and could jeopardize trade agreements. Lawmakers in Congress shaping new farm policy have argued over how much of the annual $20 billion subsidies should be used for conservation efforts. Elizabeth Becker

title: A Time To Ask, 'Why?'
description: A WRITER'S imagination allows him or her to travel anywhere, to conceive the possibility of anything. And yet, in all the twisted story lines I've developed in 20 years of writing television, I could never have imagined the events that occurred on Tuesday, Sept. 11. In comparison, my imagination is pale and shallow.

title: Nuala O'Connor, Glenn Kelly
description: Nuala O'Connor, a daughter of Roisin and Raymond O'Connor of Garden City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Glenn Francis Kelly, a son of Mary Carroll Kelly of Chicago and the late John V. Kelly. The Rev. William G. Brennan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Trinity in Crail, Scotland.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 2 about Sergei Rachmaninoff referred incorrectly to the status of the Russian Orthodox Church in the Soviet era. Though the church was subverted and controlled, and Communists were forbidden to attend services, it was not banned.

title: Looking at the Long Term, Online
description: Despite last week's market decline, hundreds of people have opened accounts at BuyandHold.com, an online brokerage firm for long-term investors, said Peter Breen, its chief executive.

title: What NATO Is For
description: To the Editor:

title: Up From Ground Zero: Memory and Defiance
description: To the Editor:

title: Streetscapes/McKim, Mead & White; A Skeptic's View of a Renowned Architectural Firm
description: MOSETTE BRODERICK has spent much of her professional life studying McKim, Mead & White for her book ''When Architecture Could Fashion a Nation,'' to be published next year by Alfred A. Knopf. Mrs. Broderick, who teaches architectural history and is director of the urban design and architecture studies program at New York University, has gone through letters, bill books, clipping books, local sources and building records trying to better understand America's most famous architectural firm, the designers of the old Pennsylvania Station, the Municipal Building and much of the Columbia University campus.

title: A Voice From the Rubble
description: 'The rescue companies are the eyes and ears for everyone. If you get a report of people trapped, then we'll spearhead our attack up to that particular area. And maybe be able to control the fire enough to warn the guys upstairs that it's really getting bad here, and maybe it's time for them to get out. At Rescue Two, our main duty is looking out for the safety of all the firemen. Really that's what we're there for. And we've shown time and time again that when there's a fireman hurt, we'll drop everything and get him.

title: Sept. 16-22; H.M.O.'s Dropping Medicare
description: Medicare patients say they like health maintenance organizations, in part because many offer prescription drug benefits. But H.M.O's have announced that they would drop at least 475,000 elderly subscribers next year. They said Medicare was not paying enough to cover their rapidly rising costs. In the last three years, private health plans have dropped more than 1.6 million Medicare beneficiaries. Some members of Congress said they would try to increase reimbursement and reduce regulation in an attempt to entice H.M.O.'s to enter or stay in the program. About 14 percent of the 40 million Medicare patients are in H.M.O.'s. Robert Pear

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEYMOUR, KAREN LYNN
description: SEYMOUR-Karen Lynn. Wife of William Dietrich and mother of Sarah and William Dietrich, was among those lost in the tragedy at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. She is also survived by her father, David Seymour of Littlestown, PA., her mother Catherine Seymour and sister Debra Anderson, both of Sykesville, MD, and her brother Glen Seymour of Abingdon, MD. A memorial service will be held at Saint Vincent de Paul R.C. Church, 250 Bebout Avenue, Stirling, N.J. on Thursday, September 27th at 4PM. A reception will follow at the Primavera Regency, 1080 Valley Road, Stirling, N.J.

title: Letters: Nuances of Rule-Breaking
description: To the Editor:

title: Dynasty's Child
description: Balthazar Getty doesn't like his hotel room. ''It was really loud in here last night. Me and Rosie couldn't sleep,'' he says in a gravelly voice, his natural blas tone, with or without the requisite REM's. ''It sounded like the plumbing was exploding. Then someone checked out of the hotel at, like, 5 a.m.'' The room, which Balthazar wants to trade in, is a palatial suite at La Posta Vecchia, a luxurious 19-room hotel perched high atop the seaside villa of Palo Laziale, about 25 miles northwest of Rome.

title: Hudson River Journal; Old Savior of the Waterfront Is Pressed Back Into Service
description: Seventy years ago, the New York Fire Department, hampered by an aging fleet of 10 steam-powered fireboats, launched the John J. Harvey, the most powerful firefighting vessel of its time.

title: Trying to Reflect Oakland's Many Faces
description: IN 1965, when Oakland Ballet was founded, this was a divided city. The treeless flatlands housed the working class, blacks and the poor while the wooded hills, with sweeping views of San Francisco Bay, were home to affluent whites. The city, for years hamstrung by conservative machine politics, was plagued by labor and racial unrest, giving rise a year later to the Black Panther Party.

title: 'This Is It -- as Happy as I Get, Baby'
description: My heart aches for Nathan Lane. But hey! What about me? Last April I bought tickets to see ''The Producers'' in September, as a birthday present for my daughter and son-in-law. Now I find out he's going to be on vacation. And there are no more tickets available through March (when Lane's contract is up). How about a tear for us?

title: Rio Is Easing the Way To Corcovado's Summit
description: THIS city's most renowned landmark, the 98-foot-high statue of Christ the Redeemer that stands atop Corcovado Mountain, celebrates its 70th anniversary next month. In conjunction with the event, the municipal government has begun building a new system of elevators and escalators to make it easier to reach the 2,308-foot summit.

title: Magnolia Malls
description: FIRST LADY

title: Personal Business; A Revised Set of Rules for the Road
description: AFTER the terrorist hijackings, millions of travelers around the world found themselves stranded. Flights were cut short as pilots were ordered to land at the nearest airports, often still far from their destinations. The Federal Aviation Administration then grounded nearly all planes for two days.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: Close Reading: Elements of Tragedy; The Technology
description: I first learned of trouble at the World Trade Center from my husband, who watched the second plane's explosion from inside a Q train on the Manhattan Bridge. He reached me at home on his cell phone. It was only after we had hung up that the thought of him suspended there, above the East River in a subway car, began to unsettle me. Still, I felt curiously calm. He's fine, I thought. After all, I just talked to him.

title: On the Promenade, a Ground Zero of Tears
description: THE best earthbound place to see the Manhattan skyline is from the Brooklyn Promenade. That was why on Sept. 11, soon after the attacks on the World Trade Center, Sandra Fried, a Brooklyn College law student, hurried to the Promenade to see what was left of them. But though the late summer morning was sunny and clear, there was no skyline. All she could see were clouds of smoke, as blank and white as shock.

title: Paddling Past Foliage
description: Traffic in New England can get heavy in fall foliage season. One solution is to view the leaves from the water. Kayak Vermont offers three-day excursions on Lake Champlain that include two nights' accommodations at the North Hero House, an inn on North Hero Island that was built in 1891, as well as all meals from lunch on the first day to lunch on the last day, use of a single or double kayak, guide services, instruction and dining-room tips. Rates are $595 a person, based on double occupancy. Information: (888) 525-3644 or www.vermontkayak.net.

title: Sept. 16-22; Anti-Taliban Leader Buried
description: Ahmed Shah Massoud, the nearly mythic anti-Taliban guerrilla commander, was buried in his beloved Panjshir Valley as thousands of mourners wept at the loss of their hero. Known as ''The Lion of the Panjshir'' for his successful defense of the region against Soviet invaders, he kept the Taliban from conquering it as well.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 9 about Elvis Presley's film career misidentified the Civil War-era composer whose melody for the song ''Aura Lee'' was used for the Presley song ''Love Me Tender.'' He was George R. Poulton, not Stephen Foster.

title: Anne Dewey, Carleton Goodnow
description: NOT content with life on the Upper East Side, Anne Elizabeth Dewey moved to Manhattan's financial district in the 1990's, wandering its 19th-century streets by day and soaking up the sounds of indie bands in smoky clubs by night. She found an apartment beside Trinity Church, in the shadows of the World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEYER, MURRAY P.
description: MEYER-Murray P. Sept. 21, 1986. Always in our hearts, sadly missed. Lucille Ruby, Phyllis and Laurence

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 9 with an essay about the new building of the American Folk Art Museum misspelled the surname of the artist who made the painted work ''Tiger.'' He is Felipe Benito Archuleta, not Archuletan.

title: Investing; New Offices, Mixed Emotions at Fund Companies
description: CHARLES ALBERS and Nikolaos Monoyios spent last week setting up the computer systems needed to manage their portfolios from makeshift quarters in central New Jersey, their temporary home after their offices at the headquarters of OppenheimerFunds were destroyed in the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Women's Civil Group Taking a Modern Turn
description: Facing a divided membership for a second straight year after a century of quiescence, the Ladies Village Improvement Society of East Hampton has selected a new leadership that some see as more likely to diversify from traditional village-beautification projects to more social causes like day care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSAK, MARY
description: RUSSAK-Mary. 96, died peacefully at home on September 19, 2001. A lifelong social work activist and tireless advocate for peace, justice and equality, she remained vibrant and committed to social reform until her final moments. She will be deeply missed and lovingly remembered by her family and many friends. Announcement for memorial service will be in Currents, NYC Chapter, National Association of Social Workers.

title: Fallout
description: On the morning of Tuesday the 11th, I got out of the subway in Midtown at around 9:15 and found a jittery cell-phone voice mail from my wife instructing me simply to call her right away at home. Because I'd been underground for the previous half-hour, I hadn't heard anything about the attacks. And so the first thing my wife said when I reached her made no sense to me at all: ''Pieces of burned documents are floating out of the sky into the backyard!'' Then she filled me in. As soon as I discovered that the subways were no longer running, I began my eight-mile walk back home.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We've never been faced with anything of this magnitude simultaneously. Even people who have dealt with bereaved kids a lot are struggling to understand now how this will be interpreted by children.''

title: Onward
Talk to Me
description: I could not reach anyone. I was at home in Boston. I did not know what had happened. The messages on my answering machine were cryptic: ''I hope you weren't on that plane to New York today,'' and from my sister, ''Is Mom in New York, is Mom in New York?'' and then click.

title: POSTINGS: Report on Homes in Harlem; Town House Prices Rise
description: The economy may have continued on its downward trajectory during the first six months of the year, but that seems to have had little effect on the demand for town houses in Harlem.

title: Welch's Way On the Issues
description: EXCERPTS from ''Jack: Straight From the Gut'' reflect John F. Welch Jr.'s view of the battles he fought with various governments during his tenure as chairman and chief executive of General Electric.

title: Texas Mother To Face Trial In Drownings
description: Andrea Pia Yates, the Houston mother who admitted drowning her five children in June, was found mentally competent to stand trial on capital murder charges today by a jury of 11 women and one man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLOOGMAN, RAOUL
description: KLOOGMAN-Raoul. September 21, 2001 of Great Neck, NY. Born in Vienna, Austria, May 25, 1914. Beloved husband of the late Ruth (Weisman) Kloogman. Loving father of Joan Kloogman Borkow, Judith and Jerrald Weinstein, and Helen Kloogman and Michael Gold. Loving grandfather of Dana & Chad, Matthew, Jacob, Rachael, Ari, Dov, Ruthie & Aaron. Loving great-grandfather of Casey, Tanner and Juliette. Loving brother of Edith Green and Nina Ottolenghi. A survivor of the Holocaust, he was a dedicated and respected physician in the Great Neck community for more than 40 years. He died peacefully at North Shore University Hospital, which he helped found. Services will be held Sunday, September 23, 2001 at 12:45 PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Habitats/St. John's University, Hillcrest, Queens; Resident Advisor Sets Up His Home in a Dormitory
description: ALTHOUGH he is 49, Brother Mike Sheerin had until recently never decorated an apartment nor had his own place. For all his adult years, Brother Mike, a member of the Roman Catholic Marist order, had lived in houses in various parts of the city, with other brothers.

title: After Attack, Subdued Tone Dominates Nassau Race
description: In the days leading up to the Sept. 11 Democratic primary, Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove raced from rally to train station to diner to festival, explaining to anyone who would listen why he was the best candidate for Nassau County executive.

title: Up From Ground Zero: Memory and Defiance
description: To the Editor:

title: The End of the Suburbs
description: What makes the New York suburbs work is a kind of osmosis. Men and women (the early birds, anyway) leave their homes -- their ranches, their splits, their Tudors, their Colonials, their McMansions -- while the dew is still wet; they're siphoned into the city and up into the mighty towers of midtown and Wall Street; and in the cool of the evening they're exhaled again. This process (and the greenbacks it photosynthesizes) keeps our enclaves leafy and prosperous, and it accounts for that deep, almost churchly silence that settles over a suburban neighborhood in the middle of a weekday morning -- after the commuters have driven away and the carpools have whisked the kids off to school, but before the FedEx truck comes around and the yard crews turn up with their mowers and blowers.

title: Weekly Game Continues, Without Unofficial Referee
description: GYM bags and Gatorade bottles are always left alongside the basketball court, but this morning there were also candles. They were there to commemorate the life of 48-year-old Bob Speisman who, everyone knew, would want the game to go on.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 23, 2001
description: Weeks

title: The Spirit Is Classical, But the Style Is Harlem
description: DANCE Theater of Harlem was created 32 years ago to give black dancers an entry into the white world of classical ballet. ''Do your own thing, but have the technique to compete'' was the mantra of its founders, Arthur Mitchell, a black star of the New York City Ballet; and Karel Shook, a white ballet teacher who encouraged black dancers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYROP, SYLVIA KALB
description: SYROP-Sylvia Kalb. Devoted wife for 55 years to Bernard, loving mother of Marc and Steven, dear sister of Florence and the late Leonard, caring mother-in-law of Nancy and adoring grandmother of Jeremy, Isaac & Sam. Funeral services will be held on September 23 at Parkside Memorial, 11 AM, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, DORIS HELENE (NEE TARNOWER)
description: GOTTESMAN-Doris Helene (nee Tarnower). On September 21. Beloved wife of Nathaniel. Devoted mother to Daniel and his wife Jennifer, Robert and his wife Lina and Jonathan. Predeceased by her son Edward. Loving grandmother to Melissa and her husband Andrew, Adam and Michael. Great-grandmother to Sarah. Services will be held on Monday, September 24, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, Long Island at 1 PM. Shiva Monday to Tuesday at home of Robert, 7 Brookview Ct., Stonybrook, Long Island.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Deeply Affected, but Scrambling to Meet Demand
description: WITHOUT exception, players in New Jersey commercial real estate offices find themselves in a horribly awkward position -- hurt and damaged as people and companies, perhaps, but thrust into the catbird seat as a prime source of office space for companies displaced from downtown Manhattan.

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com. I'd like it if we were to follow a more thoughtful and direct approach aimed solely at the terrorist networks. My fear is that we'll attack indiscriminately and end up creating a new generation of terrorists. Or, at the very least, killing those who just aren't a part of this. I don't think that Bush is following that approach.

title: Flickering Candles, Falling Tears and Smiles for a New Baby; And Life Goes On
description: The Ocean Park Diner on Park Avenue, the main thoroughfare in Long Beach, sits directly across from the Long Island Rail Road station, and during the morning rush it is usually bustling with commuters to New York City. On Sept. 11, as the attacks played out on a television set mounted on a back wall, patrons and workers in the diner were overcome with shock, panic and agony.

title: Look Beyond Commerce
description: THE events of last week, as unbearable as they were to witness, were ameliorated by the almost total absence of popular culture from the nation's airwaves. Award ceremonies and concerts were canceled. No blockbuster movies opened. No new television shows premiered. It was a temporary respite from the cultural din. Hyperbolic and aggressive selling was not only muted but also seemed, when one stumbled upon it, to belong to an already distant past made irrelevant by the tragedy of Sept. 11. Within this chaos, there was a deep if momentary silence that encouraged us to re-examine ourselves as a people and a culture.

title: A Time to Thank Heroes and Bind Wounds
description: To the Editor:

title: New Style for Garden City Park Favorite
description: IF you liked Caffe Angelica you will love Ecco. The casual Garden City Park cafe has been transformed into a more formal restaurant with new diverse menu selections augmenting the traditional dishes that made the original spot a western Nassau favorite.

title: POSTINGS: Four Parcels Ready for Development; New Focus on Queens West Office Sites
description: The Queens West Development Corporation has a site: four large parcels of waterfront property across the East River from the United Nations. And the site has a pre-approved project: nearly 2.5 million square feet of commercial and retail space. And the project has a designated developer: LCOR, the builders of 101 Hudson Street in Jersey City. And the developer has an architect: Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, designers of the Ernst & Young headquarters being built at 5 Times Square.

title: As Demand Soars, Flag Makers Help Bolster Nation's Morale
description: In a corner of the Annin & Company flag factory here, 19 miles from where the World Trade Center once stood, Kishawn Carter, 24, a New Jersey native, works beside Samy Yousef, 45, an immigrant from Egypt, talking about Osama bin Laden, the Middle East and war.

title: Suddenly, the Magic Is in Short Supply
description: ONE are the Mickey T-shirts and the Pooh paraphernalia. After the terrorist attack on New York, Disney stores in Manhattan swapped the colorful merchandise that usually fills their display windows for huge posters quoting the company's founder, Walt Disney: ''Tomorrow will be better for as long as America keeps alive the ideals of freedom and a better life.''

title: Chinese Region Felled by Nature's Blows
description: BAYINDELIGAR, China  It doesn't quite match the 10 plagues of ancient Egypt  the pastures here have not been overrun by frogs or fleas, at least not yet.

title: Grand Sheik Keeps Alive Fun of Laurel and Hardy
description: AS far as Ira Shprintzen is concerned, Laurel and Hardy are the ultimate kings of comedy. This explains why this tax accountant and real estate agent from New Rochelle has spent the last 35 years as both a member and a president of the Laurel and Hardy Appreciation Society, better known as the Sons of the Desert.

title: United Arab Emirates Breaks Diplomatic Ties With Taliban
description: The United Arab Emirates, one of only three countries to have recognized the Taliban government, broke off relations with Afghanistan today because of its refusal to hand over Osama bin Laden, the terror network chief suspected of masterminding the suicide attacks on New York and Washington.

title: It Takes Words, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: The Star's the Thing
description: Why not consolidate -- and just wear a stripe of stars? Catherine Malandrino's belt of red leather stars linked with small hoops is $198 at Henri Bendel. Those who want a matching handbag can opt for Mitzi Baker's red leather Maud bag, which has its own red bow ($297 at Verve).

title: Peering Into the Abyss of the Future
description: THE clouds came boiling up the street and obliterated every thing and every body. Inside, said those who were there, the world looked dark, murky, ghostly. People were disoriented; they lost their bearings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROTH, IDA
description: ROTH-Ida. September 26, 2000. Our beloved ''Granny''. One year in a world without you. Forever in our hearts. Diane and Larry

title: Fallout of Waging War: Struggle Over Afghanistan
description: As the Bush administration contemplates military strikes in Afghanistan, some officials fear that too strong a blow could create a dangerous opportunity for Afghanistan's powerful neighbors to compete, even clash, over control of the territory.

title: Modern Gothic
description: Deep in the woods of Fayette County, Pa., hidden by rhododendron and mountain laurel, there is a small footbridge that's seldom used. Take a few steps across it, over a thin creek, and you come face to face with a rain-stained crypt. Inside lie the bodies of Edgar and Liliane Kaufmann. Each year, about 140,000 sightseers pass within 100 yards of the couple, but almost no one knows they are there. That's because their shrine is not part of the official tour at Fallingwater, the weekend home designed in 1936 for the department-store magnate and his wife by Frank Lloyd Wright. The house, of course, is an American icon, the epitome of Wright's organic architecture. It appears to float over a thundering waterfall on Bear Run, a wonder of Modernist design. It is also haunted by a critical flaw -- and, some say, a ghost.

title: Intermodal Railroad Stop Beats Airport Growth
description: Bill McShane's opinion essay, ''Skewed Priorities in the Republic Plan'' [Sept. 9], fails to disclose his own monetary interest in opposing the intermodal railroad stop envisioned for Republic Airport. The same plot of land that would be needed by the railroad for this plan is also needed by Republic Airport to carry forward its plan to expand its runway to accommodate more planes. Mr. McShane, who is president of a flight services company at Republic, would greatly benefit from this increased traffic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, FRANCIS HENRY
description: BRENNAN-Francis Henry. Loving husband, brother, son, uncle and loyal friend. Senior Vice President and Limited Partner Cantor Fitzgerald. Victim of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. Born Sept. 25, 1950 in Brooklyn, NY. Frank grew up in Rockville Centre the eldest of six children of the late Frank Sr. and Mary Brennan. At 6'7'' and with a soft hook shot he was one of the stars of the legendary St. Agnes High School Basketball Team of the late 1960's where he was tabbed with the nickname Zelmo. Frank graduated from St. Agnes and went on to star at Quinnipiac College in Hamden, CT. While his stature made him hard to miss visually it was his good nature, sense of humor and generosity that separated Frank more than his physical prowess. After graduating from Quinnipiac Frank went on to manage and own several nightclubs on Long Island, most notably Solomon Grundy's of Bay Shore. In the early '80's Frank took his talents to Wall Street where he ultimately became one of the best and most well known Government Securities brokers. There are few in the business who haven't been touched by him. A longtime bachelor he found the love of his life and wed Barbara Hanley in 1988. Of all his successes Frank was most proud of his association with The New York Police and Fire Widow's and Children's Benefit Fund where he was recently named to the Board of Directors. Along with Barbara Brennan of Oak Beach, Long Island Frank is survived by his mother, Mary of New Canaan, CT and his brother Brian and sisters Kathleen Carey, Ellen Flaherty, Mary Jones and Sarah Jerome. The family requests that donations be made in Frank's name to The New York Police and Fire Widow and Children's Benefit Fund P.O. Box 3713, Grand Central Station, NY, NY 10163. A memorial service will be held Saturday September 29 at St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre at 9:45 AM.

title: Office Vacancy Rates Increase to 11 Percent
description: The national economic slowdown caused Long Island's office market to cool off the first six months of the year, producing a drop in leasing activity and an increase in office availability, according to a report from Insignia/ ESG, the real estate services company.

title: New Zealand Glaciers: Trips for the Fit
description: Visitors to New Zealand have several ways of exploring Fiordland, the scenic glaciated country in the southwest corner of South Island, including hiking and kayaking.

title: A City Rises to the Occasion
description: IN one awful instant, this patchwork city that is part high-tech, part high finance and part third world assumed an even more integral role in the region's stability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ROBERT S.
description: BROWN-Robert S. Of Brooklyn, New York, on September 20, 2001. Visitation Tuesday, September 25, 4 to 8 PM at J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home, 179-24 Linden Boulevard, Jamaica, NY 11434. Church service Wednesday, September 26, 10 AM at Concord Baptist Church, 833 Marcey Avenue and Lewis Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11216. Burial will take place at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Regulators Warn of Fraud
description: Businesses, organizations and individual volunteers are clamoring to help victims of the attacks, but a few people may be up to no good. State securities regulators are warning people to be wary of financial schemes, in particular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKEY, JOSEPH DERMOT, JR.
description: DICKEY-Joseph Dermot, Jr. Loving husband of Irene, devoted father of Joseph and Elizabeth, treasured brother of William and Walter and their families, and beloved nephew of Isabelle Lawson and Eileen McPeake died on Tuesday, September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center tragedy. Joe, the son of Irish immigrants, grew up in the Bronx where he attended Fordham Prep High School. He graduated from The University of Wisconsin in 1972 and received an MBA from SUNY Binghamton. Over the past twenty years, Joe worked tirelessly to build a successful career on Wall Street. At the time of his death, Joe was a Managing Director of Cantor Fitzgerald, working in the Interest Rate Swaps department. He was on the 105th Floor of Tower 1, directly above where the first plane hit. Honest almost to a fault, generous and kind, Joe was greatly admired and respected by all who knew him. He was an eternal optimist and had an unforgettable passion for life. But Joe always measured his own success on how good he was to his family. And he was an exceptional husband and father. He taught them to embrace life, take on new challenges and to love the outdoors as much as he did. In their early years together, Joe introduced Irene to the city and took her on long strolls in Central Park. On Fire Island, Joe taught his children how to swim out past the break, how to stay on top and out in front of the ocean's barrels. He coached his children's basketball teams, sat proudly on the sidelines at Joseph's crew regattas, and never missed an opportunity to play the back nine with Elizabeth. A savvy New York sports fan, Joe took the kids to see the Knicks, Rangers and Yanks, and enjoyed catching the Wisconsin Badgers on TV and talking sports with those around him. Although Joe has been taken from us all far sooner than we were ready to give him up, the whole family feels blessed to have had him in our lives. His smile and laugh will remain with us forever. Please join the family on Friday, September 28th to remember and celebrate the extraordinary life of Joseph Dermot Dickey, Jr. A memorial service will be held at 10:30AM at St. Mary's Church in Manhasset, followed by lunch at Leo's, a local restaurant. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution in the memory of Joseph D. Dickey, Jr. to the families of the New York fire fighters who lost their lives trying to save our Joe and countless others. UFA Widows' and Children's Fund: 204 East 23rd Street, NY, NY 10010.

title: After The Fall

Last year Michael Lind published a short essay deploring the cultural gap between novelists and politicians, attributing it partly to geography, partly to insularity. Writers celebrated by the Northeastern literary establishment tend to huddle together in that region, he says, teaching creative writing at small liberal arts colleges. Presidents and Congressional leaders, on the other hand, hail from the South and West, the land of George W. Bush supporters -- a world that these writers know little or nothing about.

title: A Mystery Man Who Created Monsters

The monstrous spirits and mischievous demons that people his late 15th- and early 16th-century portrayals of hell assumed a special place in Christian iconography. Centuries later, the Surrealists borrowed his imagery to express the secular nihilism of modern life. And to this day many artists are still drawn by the peculiar vision of this late medieval Dutch master.

title: Windows on the World
description: 'I do not have a conscious memory of taking most of these pictures. I was on total autopilot the day of the attack. I don't really remember finding that statue covered in debris. And I can barely recall these firefighters who are struggling to clean out their eyes -- though, looking at it now, I can remember exactly how much my own eyes burned from the smoke.; I shot 14 rolls of film the afternoon of the attack. I'm not a war photographer, so this wasn't an easy experience for me. The constantly shattering glass was terrifying and distracting, and my camera kept getting completely covered in ash. But because for years I have been taking documentary pictures of New Yorkers out on the sidewalks, there is a way in which I was prepared. It sounds crazy to say it, but these images are a direct extension of what I've been doing all along: capturing life on the streets of this city.'

title: 9 Failures of The Imagination
description: 1.It began for me here, in the same room where I sit now, in Boerum Hill. It began as a non sequitur crackle of sunlight thunder, on a gorgeous morning after an evening of thunderstorms. I ignored the sound, took a shower instead, wondering about the sports page: had Roger Clemens won his 20th? The phone rang, and a friend asked: ''Did you see it?'' So I went to the window, and saw. In this part of Brooklyn the towers are the nearest bit of Manhattan, easily visible from upper stories or rooftops. Neighbors commute -- excuse me, commuted -- to them by walking across the Brooklyn Bridge. Both planes had arrived by the time I looked out the window. My denial slid from the fact of it -- they're on fire, wow -- to tangential irritations, stuff I had to get done this week. I'd re-enact this denial again and again in the next hours: the mind's raw disinclination to grant this new actuality, cognitive dissonance run riot. I'd entered -- we'd all entered -- a world containing a fresh category of phenomena: the unimaginable fact.

title: Filling the Void

They spent the day looking up at a once familiar skyline and seeing something disorientingly blank. And that's how they realized that they were in position to do something that few others could do. They knew those buildings; they had spent six months actually working there, out of an unusual art studio on the 91st floor of the north tower, putting together a light sculpture that was to have been installed next year on the radio antenna on top. In planning this work of art, which had been commissioned by the group Creative Time, they had studied the towers, viewed them from all over the city, immersed themselves in the culture of the place. They went to happy hour at Windows on the World; they walked down from the 91st floor, just to see how long it would take (about 45 minutes).

He was 81 and lived in Manhattan and Gaylordsville, Conn.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01; Love Lost
description: I remember very well the day my father died. It was the early morning of a Saturday in 1960. I was 16. My father was 55. I was awakened by the sound of his loud breathing -- gasping, really -- and by the sound of my mother's voice from the room beside mine. We lived in a new suburban house in Mississippi. ''Carrol?'' I heard my mother saying. ''Carrol, wake up.'' Her voice was pleading, becoming uncertain, becoming afraid. My father's heavy, gasping breaths continued. I got up and walked down the short hall to the open doorway of his room and looked in. As it was so long ago now, I don't remember if my mother was leaning over his bed, or sitting on it, or if she was touching him, or standing beside him shouting. I only remember that my feet were cold because it was February. And I remember my pajamas being blue. And I remember that what I did was get on my knees in my father's bed and shake him, shake his shoulders, pat his face -- he seemed to be sleeping, possibly having a nightmare -- saying as I did the name I called him. ''Daddy, Daddy, wake up.'' I could smell his large, sweaty body, feel his flaccid self, loose-limbed and malleable, his cheeks and mouth relaxed. He had quit gasping. I tried to open his mouth with my fingers and breathe in air. I tried to push down hard on his chest. I tried to move him. I put my arms around his shoulders and shook him. I heard my mother say, ''Oh, God, no, no, no.'' And I felt dread and terror, love and ferocity, confusion, physical exertion, a need for greater ingenuity, for greater efficiency, and I felt failure. In short, I experienced all the small and large coefficients of a son's unswerving love.

description: DUDLEY'S has had a checkered past, if rumors of its romantic history have any basis. Built around 1900, it may have at one time been a brothel, but it is certain that it was a speakeasy. During Prohibition, liquor was smuggled from riverboats through a tunnel that ended at a trap door in the floor of this old clapboard house. The building's more recent distinction is that it is painted purple.

description: KELLERMAN-Peter Rodney, 35. Of New York City and South Egremont, MA on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center tragedy. Partner of Cantor Fitzgerald. Cherished brother of Elyssa Kellerman and Pamela and George Fox. Uncle Pete was adored by his nephews Max, Aaron, Billy, Matthew, Charlie and Ben. He was the most loving and giving friend. description: Leland's essay was enlightening and entertaining. The only thing missing was a descriptive term. I came up with ''distorian.''

title: This Is What A Day Means
description: ''What are days for?'' the poet Philip Larkin asked. We used to know the answer to that. Days were for living, for working, for the rituals of normalcy that make up the way of life we have come to know as American. These days had their ups and downs; they had their surprises and shocks. But they had as well a sense of reliability or modest predictability. We barely noticed these small moments of routine that, strung together, formed the ballast of a culture: the commutes to work, the family outings, the plane rides to friends, the coffee breaks and household chores. They acquired a rhythm that, although we easily forgot, took a revolution to begin, a civil war to resolve and dark and bloody wars to defend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, JOHN J.
description: DOHERTY-John J. Of Hartsdale, NY, an employee of AON Risk Services of NYC, missing since September 11, 2001 in the tragedy of the World Trade Center. He was the dear husband of Mary Birde Doherty & the loving father of two daughters, Barbara and Maureen. Beloved uncle of Cathy Hammacher, Anne Rauh and Jennifer Foley and many other loving nieces and nephews. He is predeceased by his sister, Irene Billings. His family and friends will gather in commemoration and celebration of John's life on Tuesday, September 25 from 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers, Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: For Two Women, New Take on 'Housework'

But while building a 4,000-square-foot dream house in Cold Spring Harbor, Susan Greene and Jacqueline Goldner were often incorrectly pegged as interior designers or real estate agents. Anything but builders.

title: In Toronto, Solace in The Sound Of Laughter
description: AT the Toronto International Film Festival, which ended last Sunday, the comedies pleased audiences more than at any time in recent memory, and for obvious reasons. Two romantic comedies, the French ''My Wife Is an Actress'' and the German ''Mostly Martha,'' registered more intensely because they were informed by autobiography -- one literally, the other spiritually. In both cases, the protagonists get in their own way. ''My Wife Is an Actress'' stars its writer-director, Yvan Attal, as a petty bourgeois -- a sportswriter married to Charlotte (Charlotte Gainsbourg). Yvan plays, well, Yvan, a man who has to wrestle with his small-minded jealousies over his wife's make-out sessions with the suave British actor (Terence Stamp) she's working with, an envy compounded by her ease with English and Yvan's lack of fluency.

title: 'Chasing the Hawk'
description: When I think of him now, I see him at dawn, driven from his bed by the sun and headed down to the ocean for his morning dip. But having never actually witnessed it, I find it odd that of all the images I hold of him in my head, this is the one that returns most often. By the time it had become part of his daily routine, I no longer lived at home, and when I visited, I was never up at that hour. Still, it makes a certain kind of sense that this particular ritual should come to mind. Swimming in the morning was something my father did alone, for the specific purpose of being by himself, and I always think of him that way -- alone and apart. He was away a good deal of the time, and even when he was among us, he was a solitary man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYROWITZ, JACOB
description: MEYROWITZ-Jacob. On September 21, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Edith. Loving father of Doris Lavine (Robert). Dear brother of Helen Kaufman. Devoted grandfather of Jeffrey and Scott. Longtime companion of Frances Packer. Service Sunday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

description: There is still a friend missing, and the weariness resulting from dozens of halting answers to a week of hesitant questions was evident in Wayne Chrebet last week. When a reporter began to ask Chrebet last Thursday about the efficiency of the Jets' offense, he was taken aback.

title: Austro Turf
description: Some people think that architecture critics are in the business of promoting their personal taste. In my case, the opposite is true. I write to get as far away from my taste as possible. This story is an exception, up to a point. There is one architect whose work reflects my taste and incites me to escape it at the same time: Adolf Loos. His designs embody the idea that, in the modern city, taste should be constantly challenged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNEITEL, RUTH
description: KNEITEL-Ruth. The memorial service scheduled for Ruth Kneitel for today, September 23, has been canceled.

title: Military on the Move as Bush Talks With Putin
description: By air and sea, American forces moved into position today for the campaign against terrorism as the Pentagon called up more reservists and President Bush consulted with Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president.

title: Physically Unscathed, But Hardly Untouched
description: JOHN CONDON is an engine man, nine years on the job at the firehouse of Engine 53, Ladder 43 on Third Avenue and 102nd Street in East Harlem. Doting grandmother of Joshua, Jacob, Adam and Jonah, and proud great-grandmother of Mikaela Alice. Loving daughter of the late Rabbi Jacob Kohn and the late Augusta Kohn. But across the nation, from the smallest stock market dabbler to the largest institution, investors are facing an adversity unlike any experienced before. Even stock market veterans who survived the bear market of 1974 say that comparisons to that painful period are of no help.

description: IN the photograph, Jacqueline Kennedy is standing in a boat in India, about to glide away on a silvery lake. But what caught my attention, when I saw this picture last summer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was not the scenery, but the clothes.

Riley of Port Jefferson Station, N.Y., and the late George E. Riley Jr. The Rev. Brian Tomlinson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Chapel in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Dazed Companies Sit on Their Wallets
description: FOR the first time in 15 years, the England brothers have decided that their family-owned trucking company, C.R. England Inc., will not expand its fleet of 2,500 tractor-trailers. ''After the terrorism,'' Dean England said, ''nothing will entice us.''

description: IF you strolled down the main street of the tidy little upscale suburban village of Manhasset last week, everything looked normal, though it was not normal.

title: 'This Is It -- as Happy as I Get, Baby'
description: I am the man who ''proudly walked off with a pile of six'' CD's at ''The Producers'' signing at Tower Records in June, but I did not place my hoard ''on eBay in an hour,'' as Lane suggested. Those precious discs will, rather, be my holiday gifts to close family this year -- each with an accompanying ticket to see Bialystock in bloom.

description: With Japan's population set to shrink further and faster than that of any other economically advanced country over the next half century, foreigners like Steven Gan are acquiring something of the aura of pioneers.

title: Theater's Special Voice
description: ON Wednesday, Sept. 12, I met with the graduate playwrights at Brown University. I had last seen them on Sunday night, Sept. 9, when we had designed their ''bake-off'': a play each of the seven would write, with common devices and structure, in a 48-hour period. It was an assignment received, in short, before the cataclysmic events of the day before, events that would dwarf any Aristotelian notion of dramatic catastrophe.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: Close Reading: Elements of Tragedy; The Villains
description: In 1993, I wrote a New York Times Op-Ed article about the bombing of the World Trade Center that occurred that year. Writing then, I offered the readers the mind's eye of an anonymous conspirator watching from a safe house in Queens or New Jersey, praying for the explosion, knowing it was God's will. Those towers thrusting so immodestly more than a thousand feet in the air, I wrote, must have mocked his passionate intensity.

title: Notebook; Delayed Super Bowl Makes Sense but Hits Snag
description: The N.F.L. is still flirting with the idea of moving this season's Super Bowl in New Orleans to Feb. 3 from Jan. 27 in order to accommodate the missed Week 2 games. It sounds like a good idea. So what is the holdup?

title: Out of the Pool!
description: CANARIES IN THE MINESHAFT

title: At Home In Gritty England
description: AFTER two American films -- the underrated western ''The Hi-Lo Country'' and the charming romantic comedy ''High Fidelity'' -- the British director Stephen Frears returned to Britain for his most recent work, ''Liam,'' which opened on Friday in New York. Like his first feature, ''Gumshoe,'' which he made 30 years ago, ''Liam'' is set in Liverpool. But it's not as if he's returned to his roots. ''Liam'' follows the travails of a working-class Catholic family in the depressed 1930's; Mr. Frears was born far from the River Mersey, in Leicester, to an upper-middle-class Jewish family. But he is returning to a kind of filmmaking at which he excels -- small-budget movies (he likes to call them his ''hooligan films'') with good scripts and fine actors.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: Close Reading: Elements of Tragedy; The Hero
description: One of the running gags of the Giuliani years was ''the bunker'' -- press shorthand for the $15 million Emergency Command Center the mayor built on the 23rd floor of 7 World Trade Center in 1998. The bunker symbolized the mayor's bunker mentality -- his love of crisis, his almost delighted sense that a besieged city needed an untiring and unsmiling defender.

title: Food Allergies: Protecting Kids
description: AS my taste for bologna attests, I am hardly a foodie. And yet at least once a year I find myself asking detailed questions of a variety of chefs.

title: Sept. 16-22; The Struggle for a Cease-fire
description: With the United States dramatically increasing its pressure on Israelis and Palestinians to negotiate, the antagonists in the yearlong conflict agreed to a cease-fire. But 48 hours of ''absolute quiet'' demanded by Israel as a prelude to high-level talks was shattered by staccato violence. By week's end, it was still not clear if the truce would hold long enough for talks to proceed. James Bennet

title: Flickering Candles, Falling Tears and Smiles for a New Baby; Adding Their Own Names

Then as part of a community-wide outdoor vigil in Port Washington on Wednesday evening, she and other clergy read the names during the pauses for prayer. Then Rabbi Davidson invited the crowd of 800 to call out the names they wanted to add. Many did.

title: Left Bank Fulfills Lofty Expectations
description: It was February 1999 in north Miami and the trainer Todd Pletcher remembers the moment vividly: Demi O'Byrne handed Pletcher a sales slip showing they had just purchased a son of French Deputy for $600,000.

description: MIRABILIS

title: Answering the Call Across the Island
description: FROM Great Neck to Montauk, thousands of Long Islanders flocked to lower Manhattan to try to make a difference in the days after terrorists flew two airliners into the World Trade Center and leveled the 110-story twin towers.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: Close Reading: Elements of Tragedy; The Thrill
description: So this is what it's like to go to war, real war, in which real Americans die and tolerance for people with dangerous ideas seems frivolous compared with the need to stop them. Just a couple of weeks ago, I would have dismissed the exchange of civil liberties for safety as a false trade-off. But then I didn't know what it felt like to see even network news anchors grow nervous inside their New York skyscrapers. Every other American-fought war taking place during my adulthood has felt, by comparison, like a media event. Grenada? The gulf war? Army exercises and fireworks displays, with the same relationship to national defense as a burlesque extravaganza has to romantic intimacy. Now I understand the urgent patriotism Steven Spielberg was trying to get across in ''Band of Brothers,'' in retrospect the most prescient television program of the days before the attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANSFIELD, SUSAN P.
description: STANSFIELD-Susan P. On July 12, 2001. Beloved mother of Lindsey Stansfield Pryor. Cherished grandmother of Christina, Toni, Sam and Jack Pryor. Memorial Mass on Thursday, September 27, 2001 at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave. at 76th St.,10 A.M.

description: MALKIN-Al. Dear friend, we shall treasure forever that unique, shining personality, that deep feeling of concern for all that made you so special. Harriet and Joel Laskey
