description: CREATING a landscape to complement a house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright is a challenge akin to choosing the right frame for a celebrated painting.

title: A Louder Public Voice
description: MY company was to have performed at Evening Stars Onstage on the temporary stage set between the Twin Towers the evening after last week's catastrophe. In thinking about the future of dance, I think about my dancers and dancers in general.

title: 'Marie Antoinette'
description: On 2 November 1755 the Queen-Empress was in labour all day with her fifteenth child. Since the experience of childbirth was no novelty, and since Maria Teresa, Queen of Hungary by inheritance, Empress of the Holy Roman Empire by marriage, hated to waste time, she also laboured in another way at her papers. For the responsibilities of government were not to be lightly cast aside; in her own words: "My subjects are my first children." Finally, at about half past eight in the evening in her apartments at the Hofburg Palace in Vienna, Maria Teresa gave birth. It was a girl. Or, as the Court Chamberlain, Count Khevenhuller, described the event in his diary: "Her Majesty has been happily delivered of a small, but completely healthy Archduchess." As soon as was practical, Maria Teresa returned to work, signing papers from her bed.

title: 'Political Fictions'
description: Early in 1988, Robert Silvers of The New York Review of Books asked me if I would do some pieces or a piece about the presidential campaign just then getting underway in New Hampshire. He would arrange credentials. All I had to do was show up, see what there was to see, and write something. I was flattered (a presidential election was a "serious" story, and no one had before solicited my opinions on one), and yet I kept putting off the only essential moment, which was showing up, giving the thing the required focus. In January and February I was selling a house in California, an easy excuse. In March and April I was buying an apartment in New York, another easy excuse. I had packing to do, then unpacking, painting to arrange, many household negotiations and renegotiations. Clippings and books and campaign schedules kept arriving, and I would stack them on shelves unread. I kept getting new deadlines from The New York Review , but there remained about domestic politics something resistant, recondite, some occult irreconcilability that kept all news of it just below my attention level. The events of the campaign as reported seemed to have taken place in a language I did not recognize. The stakes of the election as presented seemed not to compute. At the very point when I had in my mind successfully abandoned this project to which I could clearly bring no access, no knowledge, no understanding, I got another, more urgent call from The New York Review . The California primary was only days away. The Democratic and Republican national conventions were only weeks away. The office could put me on a campaign charter the next day, Jesse Jackson was flying out of Newark to California, the office could connect me in Los Angeles with the other campaigns. It so happened that my husband was leaving that day to do some research in Ireland. It so happened that our daughter was leaving that day to spend the summer in Guatemala and Nicaragua. There seemed, finally, no real excuse for me not to watch the California primary (and even to vote in it, since I was still registered in Los Angeles County), and so I went to Newark, and got on the plane. From the notes I typed at three the next morning in a room at the Hyatt Wilshire in Los Angeles, after a rally in South Central and a fundraiser at the Hollywood Palace and a meet-and-greet at the housing project where the candidate was to spend what remained of the night ("Would you call this Watts," the reporters kept saying, and "Who knows about guns? Who makes an AK?"), my introduction to American politics:

description: STEINER-Seymour, M.D. September 16, 2001, in Phoenix, AZ. Former resident of Mamaroneck, NY. Beloved husband of Arline. He practiced medicine in New York City, where he served three generations of families. He was a source of wisdom and intelligence, of humanity and grace. A musician and loyal friend, a man of honor and of non-judgemental love, he leaves the world bereft of his charm and love of life. Those who wish to honor his memory may contribute to the Steiner Memorial Fund, C/O Arizona Community Foundation, 2122 East Highland Avenue, Phoenix, Arizona 85016.

title: The Movie I Didn't Know How to Write
description: It was an old idea of ours, a movie about blowing up both towers. My brother went to architecture school, but his idea of how they would fall came from forestry: chop them at the bottom to collapse one over the city and the other into the river. We could never figure out who would do it or why, except that in the days when we had this fantasy, around 1980, Lower Manhattan was still mysterious, and we imagined a syndicate of anarcho-dada-surrealist-futurists who pursued destruction for no reason other than beauty.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: Close Reading: Elements of Tragedy; The Image
description: Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn has hills that look out on Lower Manhattan. On the morning of Sept. 11, people were staked out in small groups, strangers trading misinformation and speculation. What was sure and known was that the towers were burning; we could see that from the northern slope of the park. The trees at the edge below us obscure all but the highest landmarks: the tips of the Manhattan Bridge, the roofs of the more ambitious corporate headquarters. The top halves of the twin towers had always overpowered the scene like bullies.

title: Apocalypse Kitsch
description: The pamphlet stuffed in my Montana mailbox announced the arrival of a touring lecture series on the End of Time, to take place throughout the week at the Yellowstone Motor Inn. The cover art was atrocious, done in the lurid, amateurish style that can only be called Apocalyptic Circus Tent. Against a backdrop of flaming urban chaos, replete with smoking rubble and listing skyscrapers, plunging jetliners and racing police cars, panicked businessmen stumbled forward, blood on their collars, horror in their eyes, while high above them loomed a guardian angel. I smiled at the illustration's nave sensationalism -- until, a few days after the tract's arrival, I saw the same spectacle on live TV, reproduced with uncanny accuracy. The only figure missing was the angel.

title: Berard's Tryout Will Have to Wait

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

In essays that combine a personal voice with intellectual ambitions, the Paris correspondent of The New Yorker from 1995 to 2000 interprets the details of everyday bourgeois life in a city that had long captivated him. ''There are profound and hilarious reflections . . . on French cafes, cooking, strikes, fax machines, Christmas trees, plugs, toys, football and hospitals -- and much else,'' Alain de Botton wrote here last year. ''The result is the finest book on France of recent years.''

Sober Holidays Unlimited offers trips designed to support recovering alcoholics and addicts by surrounding them with travelers who share their problems, along with family members. title: A Disaster for the Working Poor
description: One of the tragic byproducts of the destruction of the World Trade Center has been financial crisis for thousands of unskilled, low-income employees who were displaced by the disaster. About 3,500 people who clean the hotel rooms and offices in lower Manhattan lost their jobs when the buildings that employed them were destroyed or closed for the cleanup. With salaries that average roughly $32,000 a year, most have little in the way of savings to fall back on. As New York struggles to recover from the terrorist attack, workers like these have to be among the priorities for help.

title: Action Speaks Louder

Each blow forces her to expel a name -- those of Japanese emperors interspersed with the names of places like Assyria, Hungary, Crimea, Chosun. Random words and occasional sentences in English are the only text. Well beyond the point of spectator endurance, the scene ends as unceremoniously as it began. The woman walks off. The man begins forcefully and rhythmically hitting his own thighs until he collapses. All the while the performers appear strangely passive, as if they were receptacles for a force much larger than themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHFORTH, HENRY ADAMS, JR.
description: ASHFORTH-Henry Adams, Jr. Of Greenwich, CT, died peacefully on Friday, September 21, after a battle with cancer. He was 73. He was the former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of The Ashforth Company, a real estate company headquartered in Stamford, CT, and former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc. Mr. Ashforth was also a director and former Chairman of UNICO Properties, a Seattle based real estate company. He also served as Trustee and Chairman of The Greenwich Library, Trustee of The Greenwich Boys Club, President and Director of The East Side Association, Director of ICD Rehabilitation & Research Center, Chairman of the Young Men's Real Estate Association of New York, Trustee of The New York Association for the Blind, Trustee of The Greenwich Hospital Association, Trustee of The Ethel Walker School, and Trustee of Gallaudet University, sharing his time and knowledge to promote their success. He was also a member of various clubs including The Links and The Racquet Club in New York, The Greenwich Field Club -former president, and The Round Hill Club of Greenwich. In the tradition of his great-grandmother, Elizabeth Milbank Anderson, who started the first free public library in Greenwich in 1895, Mr. Ashforth led the development of its recent addition. He considered this one of his greatest contributions to the town of Greenwich. He served in the U.S. Army as Private First Class from October 1946 to March of 1948 -Korean Occupation Force. Henry A. Ashforth, Jr. was born January 5, 1928 in New York City, the son of Henry Adams Ashforth, Sr. and Elizabeth Anderson Ashforth of Greenwich, CT. He attended Greenwich Country Day School, graduated from Milton Academy and Yale University, class of 1952 and was a member of Scroll and Key and Delta Kappa Epsilon. He was a grandson of Albert B. Ashforth of New York. He married the former Georgia McCampbell Perkins on September 11, 1954, and lived in Greenwich, CT, and Peru, VT. He is survived by his wife; sons Henry Ashforth, III, Andrew B. Ashforth, and Thomas A. Ashforth; three daughters, Elizabeth A. Bacon, Katherine A. Wiener, and Margaret M. Ashforth; and fourteen grandchildren. He is also survived by his stepmother, Elsie L. Ashforth; his sister, Eleanor A. Harvey; his brother, Alden B. Ashforth; his sister, Marna R. Ashforth; and his stepsister, Christina M. Whitman. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, September 25, 2001, at 2:30 PM, at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Greenwich Library, Greenwich, CT.

It finally received clearance to join, and a day later Taiwan, whose economy needs far less adjustment to come into line with major trading partners, was cleared. The two will look to become the 143rd and 144th members at a meeting of trade ministers in Qatar in November. Joseph Kahn

title: 'The Ash Garden'
description: We had very little in the days when the war was still far away, in the remote place I imagined all wars lived when I was a girl. When it finally came to our city in August 1945 it consumed what little we had left, and years later, when there was nothing left at all, I was forced to journey to America to begin my surgeries. Of course, when I was a child it had seemed to me that what we'd had in those early days was sufficient. All but the barest necessities had been taken from us, but we didn't know any better. I often thought of the war as some great famished beast that ate away at the heart of my people. But my family was no different from any other family in the Asaminami district, the area of the city we lived in, and my brother and I never missed what we'd never had. I do not know if our parents and grandfather felt the same way.

title: Coltrane at 75: the Man and the Myths
description: MUSIC is a ''pure'' art; a note or chord or rhythmic pattern has no literal meaning in the way that a poem, a passage of prose, a song lyric, a representational or even an abstract painting can. Yet what we hear in music -- what we think we hear, influenced by the composer's title or some other piece of information we accept as a clue to his intentions -- gradually assumes its own reality. It is often said, for example, that ''Alabama,'' a prayerlike dirge written by the saxophonist John Coltrane and recorded by him on Nov. 18, 1963, was his saddened and outraged response to a church bombing in Birmingham, Ala., two months earlier. The bombing, which took the lives of four young girls, was a turning point in the civil rights movement. Yet if this was what Coltrane meant for the piece to be ''about,'' he kept it to himself in the recording studio, not saying a word about the deaths of those children to the pianist McCoy Tyner or the drummer Elvin Jones, both of whom were sidemen at the session. As far as they remember, the piece didn't even have a name yet. They remember being moved by the piece, but they don't recall Coltrane saying anything at all about the killings after handing out the sheet music.

title: Radical Chic

Spiritually, he underwent similarly radical conversions, from being an atheist to becoming a born-again Christian who prayed with the televangelist Billy Graham. He was also a short-lived Moonie, founded the Cleaver Crusade for Christ in 1979 and the following year formed his own religion, Christlam, along with an auxiliary called the Guardians of the Sperm. title: QUICK BITE/Maplewood; South of the (South Orange) Border
description: There are enough Chinese restaurants in Maplewood and the surrounding towns and villages to build another Great Wall, and more than enough Italian restaurants to feed the extended Soprano family countless meals. But a good, inexpensive Mexican restaurant was as hard to find as Pancho Villa -- that is, until the unassuming Carmelita's Cafe opened here. It offers the standard Mexican fare -- tacos, burritos, enchiladas, fajitas and quesadillas -- all freshly made, served hot and spicy. Add to that the homey dcor and good cheer of its owner, Carlos Aguirre, who grew up in Los Angeles, and his wife, Arlene, who was raised in Hoboken. Mr. Aguirre -- who learned how to cook from his father, a Chihuahuan, and his mother, who came from the hills outside Mexico City -- met his wife in San Francisco while working in the restaurant business, and together they came to New Jersey. The first restaurant they opened was in Hoboken, where they operated for 11 years. But they moved to Maplewood in April because the space in Hoboken was small and the rent not nearly so. This is the real deal, and at a reasonable price, with dinners ranging from $4.75 to the most expensive, at $10. Appetizers cost from $2.75 to $6.50. The friendly atmosphere is free, and so is a peek at the alligator (just ask Carlos). The menu boasts, ''Mexican food so authentic you'll think twice about drinking the water.'' Well, the water is fine, but there is no liquor license, so bring your own tequila.

title: Metro Matters; Like Life, The Vote Goes On
description: NEW YORK has never seen anything like this. The city has held elections during wars, in the aftermath of riots, even had elections delayed at the 11th hour by a court.

title: Hand-Held Satellite Phones Resurface in Tragedy's Wake
description: Iridium Satellite and Globalstar Telecommunications, embattled sellers of hand-held satellite phones, received renewed respect last week when cellphone systems failed in New York and Washington in the wake of jetliner crashes.

title: The Awakened Giant: How Will It Strike Back?
description: To the Editor:

title: Depleted MetroStars Hang On for Tie
description: The obstacles seemed almost overwhelming for the MetroStars tonight. They were playing on the road, a trying task all season. And they were trying to compete without three of their best players, a disadvantage the talented Los Angeles Galaxy seemed ready to exploit.

title: A Request For Patience If the Law Overreaches
description: New Jersey's attorney general today called on the state's many Arab-Americans to help the authorities investigating the terrorist attack on America, but also warned of widespread ''ignorance'' and urged people to report any abusive treatment by law-enforcement agents.

title: Solomon Sagall, 101, Dies; Early Proponent of Pay TV
description: Solomon Sagall, an early proponent of pay television, died on Sept. 6 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in New York. He was 101.

title: Sports of The Times; Lesson for Mets (and Fans): Avoid Cockiness and Keep the Faith
description: NOW the hard part begins.

title: Industry analysts step back to reassess ad spending estimates, and the picture is not pretty.
description: THE deterioration of the outlook for the national economy after the terrorist attacks is leading advertising industry analysts to reassess their estimates for ad spending this year and next. In almost every instance, they are predicting no growth, or steeper cutbacks, for 2001 and 2002.

title: Disquiet in New York: A Siren's Wail Can Bring Shudders
description: Even as the days tick steadily by, unmarred by further atrocities, the presentiment lingers. It subsides for stretches of time, subdued by the exigencies and entanglements of life, but it stubbornly reasserts itself when a fresh rumor erupts, when another police car shrieks past.

title: Drinking to the Rescuers, and Getting Autographs
description: Quench, a bar on Smith Street in Brooklyn, was so crowded Thursday night that dozens of customers spilled onto the sidewalk. Were they oblivious to the city's pain? Seeking to drown their own?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, JOANNE
description: WEIL-Joanne. We are mourning the tragic loss of our former colleague and extend our heartfelt condolences to Joanne's parents and entire family. Herrick, Feinstein LLP

title: Poll Site Changes in Lower Manhattan
description: Aguide to new polling sites in Lower Manhattan.

title: Solidarity Party Shut Out From Polish Parliament
description: The successor to Poland's old Communist Party won a landslide victory in national elections today, not only ousting Solidarity as the governing party but reducing it to a fringe group that will have no seats in Parliament.

title: Bush Signs Order, Asks for Foreign Support
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  President Bush today ordered an immediate freeze of all assets in the United States of suspected Islamic terrorist groups and individuals and gave the Treasury Secretary broad new powers to halt transactions with banks around the world that do not cooperate in cutting off the flow of money to terrorists.

title: Victims of '93 Bombay Terror Wary of U.S. Motives
description: This city, the financial capital of the world's most populous democracy, knows the sudden horror of a terrorist attack that seems to come from nowhere.

title: OBITUARY : George Bailey, Directed Radio Liberty
description: George Bailey, 81, who served as director of Radio Liberty from 1982 to 1985, died in Munich on Sept. 12.

title: Sally F. Reston, Journalist and Photographer, Dies at 89
description: Sally F. Reston, a newspaper publisher, photographer and writer who was for 60 years as much a partner as a wife to the columnist James B. Reston of The New York Times, died Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 89.

title: Finances of Terror
description: Organizing the hijacking of the planes that crashed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon took significant sums of money. The cost of these plots suggests that putting Osama bin Laden and other international terrorists out of business will require more than diplomatic coalitions and military action. Washington and its allies must also disable the financial networks used by terrorists.

title: The Awakened Giant: How Will It Strike Back?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, BRIAN JOSEPH
description: MURPHY-Brian Joseph. Devoted husband of Judith Bram Murphy, active and loving father of Jessica and Leila, beloved son of Harold and Christina, adored brother of Ann, Harold and Cynthia, cherished son-in-law of William and Jane Eisner Bram, dearly beloved nephew of Marguerite, dear brother-in-law of Steven Eisner Bram and Elizabeth and Eric Rothstein, and wonderful uncle to Joshua, Danielle, Zachary, and Callahan and fantastic and loyal friend of hundreds, perished in the tragic events that took place on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Brian graduated from the Wilbraham and Monson Academy Class of 1976, Williams College Class of 1980, and the Columbia University School of Business Class of 1987. He was a Vice President at Cantor Fitzgerald/eSpeed Division and a partner in his family's ReMAX Real Estate Company. Brian's life was filled with family, integrity, loyalty and acts of kindness. A man of high morals and solid principles, his faith in God, family, and love was unshakable. He will be deeply missed by all those he touched. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church on Lexington Avenue and 66th Street on Tuesday, September 25 at 3:30 P.M. Donations may be made to Williams College, the Brian J. Murphy Class of 1980 Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 231, Williamstown, Massachusetts 01267.

title: Federal Role Sought For Airport Security
description: Democratic leaders in the House and Senate said a federal takeover of airport security was the best way to restore public confidence in air travel after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and Republican leaders raised no objection.

title: South Korea Lowers Forecast On Growth to 2%-3% Range
description: The South Korean finance ministry lowered its expectations today for the nation's economy this year in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERLIN, HILDE
description: SERLIN-Hilde. Beloved mother of Patricia and Nancy, grandmother of Adam and Gideon, sister of Erich, and mother-in-law of Richard, died peacefully on September 23, 2001. Her memory will forever be cherished. Service at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY, at 10AM on Tuesday, September 25th.

title: Pay Cut Saves 'Kiss Me, Kate'
description: In a show of solidarity, the cast and crew of ''Kiss Me, Kate'' voluntarily agreed over the weekend to cut their salaries in half to keep their Broadway production open for at least two more weeks. ''Kate,'' at the Martin Beck Theater, was to have closed yesterday because of plummeting ticket sales in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center.

title: Penguin Putnam Chief Plans to Step Down
description: Phyllis Grann, one of the most commercially successful editors and publishers in the book business, is leaving her position as chief executive and president of the Penguin Putnam books division of the media company Pearson at the end of the year, people close to the company said.

title: Back From the Big City, Just Hangin' Out With the Rubes
description: Even the most banal sitcom has been touched by the events of Sept. 11.

title: An Unusual Hand Proves Unusually Interesting
description: A freak hand like the one West held in the diagramed deal at the Eastern Regional Championships is of course rare: 8-5-0-0 occurs once in 31,000 deals. It is also rarely interesting in terms of play, but this was an exception. Would you choose to play or defend six diamonds as South?

title: Giuliani May Try to Keep Job After Term Ends in December
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, reconsidering his position that the mayoral election should go on without him, believes that New Yorkers should be able to decide who leads the city out of these troubled times, even if it includes an extension of his term, people close to the mayor said last night.

title: New Look for Entertainment In a Terror-Conscious World
description: For executives at MGM, the release of a forthcoming movie called ''Gangster'' is problematic. It has action and suspense, mobsters and international terrorists.

title: This Week
description: Aftermath

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: AID For Trade Center Workers
description: The State Labor Department has obtained $25 million in emergency federal aid to provide temporary jobs for those who are out of work because of the attack on the World Trade Center. Details are still being worked out, officials said, and it was unclear yesterday how many jobs would be created. But wages would be similar to those for Port Authority or Department of Sanitation jobs. Eligible workers will include those employed at the trade center, as well as at surrounding businesses ruined or closed by the attack, said Betsy McCormack, a department spokeswoman. The jobs will involve cleanup and other renovation duties. The department has 45 days to work out details, Ms. McCormack said, ''but we plan to move faster than that.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, MARGARET A. ''MAGGIE'' (NEE ADAMS)
description: WEISS-Margaret A. ''Maggie'' (nee Adams). 93, formerly of New York City, died on Sunday, September 23, 2001, in Fairfield, CT, at The Jewish Home for the Elderly after bravely battling a severe long term illness. Beloved wife of the late George Weiss (former Chairman of Bache & Co., Inc.). Devoted mother of John F. Weiss and Georgia W. Morris, mother-inlaw of Sheila R. Weiss, Jack W. Morris. Loving grandmother of John F. Weiss Jr., Graham G. Weiss, Jeffrey D. Morris, William B. Morris. Loving step-grandmother of James E. Bienen and Jonathan P. Bienen and great-grandmother of Hunter J. Weiss and Cheyenne M. Weiss. Vital, dynamic, active and of indomitable spirit, she will be missed. Arrangements private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to The Metropolitan Opera, The New York City Opera, The American Jewish Committee, The Central Park Conservancy or The Bronx Zoo.

title: Eeriness and Everyday Problems
description: After the heightened emotions during the New York Philharmonic's superb performance of Brahms's ''German Requiem'' on Thursday night, a memorial for the victims of the attack on the World Trade Center, it must have been difficult for the musicians to report to work the next day and rehearse the first regular subscription program of the season. Perhaps that explains why there was a sense of letdown in Saturday night's concert. The playing, though often admirable, lacked a degree of focus and energy. The routine of the season has begun, and that reality must be helpful in some ways, and dispiriting in others.

title: Service Center Offers Help To the Victims of Terrorism
description: With many forms of assistance available to victims of the destruction of the World Trade Center, officials yesterday urged those seeking help -- particularly the families of those killed or missing -- to use the central clearinghouse created for them, rather than try to contact city, state, federal and private agencies one at a time.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 9 p.m. Sunday.

title: Braves Come to Town, and Join the New York Family
description: Even before Tsuyoshi Shinjo turned what the Atlanta Braves thought was a two-run home run into an inning-ending double play, the Braves suspected that this was the Mets' weekend and that they had no chance to disrupt it. When Shinjo, the Mets' left fielder, caught Bernard Gilkey's drive about 370 feet from home plate yesterday, the Braves were convinced it wasn't meant to be for them.

title: Eerie Quiet as 'Screaming Eagles' Await Battle Orders
description: The grim drumbeat of war seemed oddly distant today from this sprawling Army post straddling the border of Kentucky and Tennessee.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Chief at Penguin Putnam Is Planning to Step Down

title: Profitability Is Still Possible for Southwest
description: DALLAS, Sept. 23  A decade ago, the airline industry was in its worst recession to that point, brought on by the Persian Gulf war, a broad economic slowdown and brutal fare cuts. But Southwest Airlines ( news/quote ), then a regional carrier in the process of going national, managed to make money even as the rest of the industry lost more than $6 billion over two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, NEIL D.
description: LEVIN-Neil D. Age 46, of New York City, missing and presumed dead in the World Trade Center attack, September 11, 2001. Neil was the Executive Director of the NYNJ Port Authority, a job he loved. He was a good friend, a mentor and role model for many. He will be deeply missed by his wife Christy Ferer, step-daughters Caitlin and Ali, his mother Gloria, his brother Stanley, sister-in-law Robin, nephew Adam and niece Kim. His father was the late Morton H. Levin. A service to celebrate his life will be held at 6:00PM Tuesday, September 25th at Manhattan's Temple Emanu-El, 66th Street and Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you remember children of other missing Port Authority victims through the Neil D. Levin Education Foundation, 101 Park Ave., Suite 2500, New York, NY 10178.

title: Readers' Comments
description: New York Times on the Web readers respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. To send your own comments, send e-mail to shareyourthoughts@nytimes.com. As a Pakistani I deeply mourn the loss of over 6000 precious lives in the WTC tragedy. The barbarism displayed is not merely a crime against the American people but against humanity. Many families in my country, as indeed from many others as well, have also lost their dear ones in the unprecedented and ghastly carnage. For them this world will never be the same again. My full sympathies with those who are going through the pain and sorrow of having lost their near & dear ones. As the world grieves, it also needs to reflect and ponder as to how to eliminate the menace of terrorism from the face of the earth. While it is important that the perpetrators of the crime are not allowed to go unpunished, it is equally important that the innocent are not made to pay the price.

title: Poll Site Changes in Lower Manhattan
description: Aguide to new polling sites in Lower Manhattan.

title: Fiedler Saves Best for Last As Dolphins Jolt Raiders
description: Red, white and blue paper flags were given to the 73,404 fans at Pro Player Stadium today. They held them high before the kickoff, while children, musicians and more flags colored the field. Near midfield, a girl was draped in green, dressed like the Statue of Liberty, torch in tow.

title: The Awakened Giant: How Will It Strike Back?; A Survivor's Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Terror Effort May Provoke Her Foes : Megawati Faces Risk In Backing the U.S.
description: SINGAPORE  With more Muslims than any other nation, Indonesia can play a key role in helping the United States show that it is battling terrorism, not Islam.

title: Jordan Crushes the Ball, and the Mets' Hopes of a Sweep
description: The delirious fans were standing at Shea Stadium yesterday, chanting ''sweep, sweep, sweep,'' while mimicking the Atlanta Braves' tomahawk chop. The Mets were one out from defeating the Braves, the Philadelphia Phillies were losing and it looked like it would be another special afternoon for the Mets. Everything seemed perfect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORMAN, CORNELIUS H. JR.
description: BORMAN-Cornelius H. Jr. and Eleanor M. Of Oakland, Maine. Cornelius, 86, died Wednesday, September 12, 2001 and Eleanor, 87, died Thursday, September 20, 2001. Neil served his country for a total of 23 years, retiring as a Lieutenant Colonel from the U.S. Army in 1956. He was an investment advisor for Rockefeller Family and Associates for 28 years, and was an active member in the Masons for over 50 years. Eleanor and Neil were married on Valentine's Day in 1942. Eleanor was a medical assistant for Dr. Irving Briller in Brooklyn, NY. Neil and Eleanor were both active members at Saint Mary the Virgin Episcopal Church in Chappaqua, NY. A memorial service will be held at the Garden of Maples, Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY at 11:00 A.M. on Friday, September 28th. Memorial gifts may be made to the Maine Alzheimer's Association Research, 163 Lancaster Street, Suite 160B-Portland, ME. 04101.

title: Rightist Judge Shows Strongly In Hamburg
description: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, suffered a significant political defeat today in state legislative elections in Hamburg, with a law-and-order, anti-immigration politician known locally as ''Judge Merciless'' making an unexpectedly strong showing.

title: The Right Time for Talking
description: Over the weekend, New York City voters finally had the opportunity to reassess the candidates for mayor in tomorrow's primaries. At televised public appearances, the contenders attempted to explain how they would govern a city that is so different from the one that existed before the original Election Day, Sept. 11. Their comments demonstrated how important it is now to take a second look at the men who want to lead New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, RUTH LUSTBADER
description: ISRAEL-Ruth Lustbader. Beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother, died in California, September 20, in her 101st year. Born and raised in New York City, a longtime resident and keen observer of the urban scene, she took part in many of our civic and charitable activities, from the Girl Scouts to Civil Defense during World War II to the alumni associations and bookshop of her alma maters, Barnard and Bryn Mawr. Widow of the attorney, J. Leon Israel, she was mother of Eve Finestone and Peter Israel, grandmother of Anne, Stephen & Peter Finestone and Alexandra and the late Elie Israel, and greatgrandmother of Sarah and Rachel Dolan and Miranda and Isaac Finestone.

title: A Voice From the Rubble
description: Lincoln Quappe, a firefighter who worked for three years for Rescue Two in Brooklyn, is among the missing. He spoke with Tom Downey in March.

title: Long-Needed Perspective On the Air
description: You could not watch sports for pure diversion this weekend. Every game, appropriately, had overtones of World War II bond rallies and religious services. Most appropriately, America's cathedral of sport, Yankee Stadium, was the site of a stirring prayer meeting yesterday.

title: Masur to Undergo Transplant
description: The New York Philharmonic announced yesterday that Kurt Masur was withdrawing from two weeks of subscription concerts in December and a New Year's Eve performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony that he was to conduct. He is to undergo an organ transplant in late November in Europe.

title: Primary Candidates Urge Voters to Turn Out as an Act of Defiance
description: Two days before the rescheduled New York City primaries, some of the mayoral candidates invoked the World Trade Center disaster in their campaigns yesterday, asserting they had skills that made them particularly well suited to lead the city through this crisis. They urged New Yorkers to defy the terrorist attack by turning out to vote tomorrow.

title: The Symbolism in Shopping
description: After the company where she worked five blocks from the World Trade Center lost power and telephones almost two weeks ago, Tory Tunnell searched for ways to help the city recover. She collected bags of socks and took them to a donation site. She hoped to give blood, but was turned away because she is recovering from Lyme disease. Unsure of when she would be able to return to her job at Open City Films, she kept looking for a means to contribute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTLER, DEACON JAMES F.
description: BUTLER-Deacon James F., 64. Team Coordinator and Case Manager for Internal Revenue Service. Beloved husband of Barbara. Father of Ellyn Penza. Son of Dorothy. Visitation Monday 2-4 PM at Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue (Rte 110) Huntington. Mass of Transferral Monday 8 PM at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport. Funeral Mass Tuesday 10 AM. Family requests donations to James F. Butler Memorial Scholarship Fund, Pastoral Formation Institute Diocese, Rockville Centre Diocese, 50 North Park Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY 11570-4184.

title: A Pregame Meeting Provides the Inspiration
description: It was a Saturday night team meeting, the kind Giants players have had many times before. But just as these are not normal days in an increasingly confusing world, this was no average gathering. It was one Giants players said they would probably remember for some time, maybe for the rest of their lives.

title: Corrections
description: A byline was omitted in some copies on Saturday from the Religion Journal column, about religious groups' responses to the terrorist attacks. The writer was Gustav Niebuhr.

title: Rebuilding Downtown
description: Virtually everyone in New York City, and indeed most of the country, understands the importance and urgency of rebuilding downtown Manhattan. In the aftermath of the terrorist attack, it is vital to reaffirm the city's status as a premier financial capital and restore hope to a battered neighborhood.

title: Stories of Trade Center, Now Suddenly Obituaries
description: TWIN TOWERS

title: The Awakened Giant: How Will It Strike Back?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATCH, LUZIE
description: HATCH-Luzie. On September 16, 2001 at the age of 89. Ms. Hatch was born in Germany on May 9, 1912. Dedicated employee and officer of the American Jewish Committee. Ms. Hatch, a Holocaust survivor, emigrated to the United States in 1938. She was the proud recipient of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany which was bestowed upon her September 24, 1992 in recognition of her relentless pursuit to ensure that this atrocity would never recur. Interment private. Donations to the American Jewish Committee, 165 East 56th St., NYC 10022 would be appreciated.

title: Investors Try To Adjust To a New Set Of Realities
description: Voices around the country no longer talk of economic booms or Internet riches, of golden-hued nest eggs or second homes on beach property.

title: U.S. Seeks Afghan Coalition Against Taliban
description: The Bush administration is backing efforts to build an internal coalition in Afghanistan against Osama bin Laden and his Taliban supporters. Such a coalition could collect crucial intelligence, provide political support and cooperate militarily in the war on terrorism.

title: Dedicated to New York, Their Children and to Jobs at the Twin Towers
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 261 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 194. In all, 6,453 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: End of Sanctions May Ease Pakistanis' Despair Even as the Afghans' Grows Worse
description: The Bush administration's decision to ease economic sanctions on Pakistan came as a much-needed boost today to Pakistan's government, steadying some of the nervousness that had been mounting since Pakitan's military leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, pledged his backing for American plans for a military thrust into neighboring Afghanistan.

title: Former Communist Who Led Left to Victory in Poland
description: Leszek Miller, Poland's next prime minister, has come full circle. Twelve years ago, as a member of the Central Committee of Poland's Communist Party, he watched it crumble in the face of protests led by Lech Walesa and the Solidarity movement.

title: A False Challenge to News Photos Takes Root on the Web
description: The day after the World Trade Center attacks, Mrcio A. V. Carvalho, a Brazilian graduate student at the University of Campinas, sent an e-mail message to a list of fellow sociologists. In it, he claimed that after the attack, CNN had recycled 1991 images, misidentifying the footage as a picture of a few Palestinians celebrating the terrorist attack in New York.

title: The Awakened Giant: How Will It Strike Back?; A Song for Our Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, NANCY LEE, NEE KLEIN
description: ROSENBERG-Nancy Lee, nee Klein. January 1, 1945-September 22, 2001, Cheltenham High School 1962, Barnard 1966, Columbia Teacher's College 1970, Palmer School 1996. Involved citizen of her community, admired co-worker, book reviewer, teacher, librarian; thoughtful and creative contributor in all of her relationships; valued friend; strong and loving leader of her family; died after a brave and hard-fought battle against leukemia. Nancy is deeply mourned by her devoted mother and caregiver, Adele Klein; by her loving and supportive father and stepmother Simon and Ruth Klein. Her memory is held and cherished in the hearts and minds of her children, Nora and Daniel, and her husband Asher. Gloria, Susan, Janice and Rosaline sustained her with great care during her illness and grieve her loss. A memorial service will be held at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, September 25, 2001, 1 PM, 516-487-9600. Donations in her memory may be made to Barnard College, Temple Isaiah of Great Neck, or the public library of your choice.

title: Putin Offers Backing to U.S. for Anti-Terror Operations
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24  President Vladimir V. Putin tonight offered the United States broad support for antiterrorist operations in Afghanistan, including access to its airspace for humanitarian missions, direct participation in some search-and-rescue operations and weapons shipments to forces opposing the ruling Taliban movement inside Afghanistan.

title: Pronouncements on Irony Draw a Line in the Sand
description: In the magazine business, naming a new cultural moment or the latest turn in popular taste is how reputations are made, like scoops in investigative journalism or predicting a stock's movement in the investment business. And, as New York struggles on after the atrocity of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, some in the media business are doing their part by once again wetting a finger to the cultural winds and attempting a guess at the future mood in their grief-stricken city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, DAVID BRIAN
description: BRADY-David Brian. Age 41. Resident of Summit, NJ, who is still officially listed as missing after the tragic events at the World Trade Center complex last week. Adored father of sons Matthew, 9, Mark, 4, and daughters Erin, 6, and Grace, 1. Dearest son of Alice and Richard Brady. Beloved son-in-law of Joanne and Thomas Eisman. Very best friend of sister Mary Christina Zaremba, brothers Richard, Michael and Scott. A family memorial service will be held Tuesday, September 25, at 10 AM, at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church, Wyckoff, NJ, where Mr. Brady grew up. Mr. Brady, a first vice president and 16-year veteran of Merrill Lynch, is a member of Merrill Lynch's Director's Circle, a group made up of the firm's most successful producers. Because of his expertise, he routinely trained other financial advisors in the New York metropolitan area and elsewhere. ''David is a special person, beloved by his clients and his colleagues, regardless of rank,'' said Phil Sieg, Director of Mr. Brady's office. ''As mark of his kindness and expertise, David's client base, of about 150 families, is made up of virtually all long-term relationships.'' A devout Catholic, he attended Mass daily at a church in lower Manhattan near his office in the World Financial Center. Mr. Brady's wife, Jennifer, requested that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to: Butterflies Hospice Program at Valley Hospital Foundation, 233 North Van Dien Ave, Ridgewood, NJ 07451. The family will host friends and family at Arcola Country Club, Paramus, NJ, immediately following memorial service. For additional information, please contact St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church, Greenwood Ave, Wyckoff; 201-891-1122.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Nikki Oden, Diana Scott, Murrells Inlet, S.C., July 18, 2001

title: As the Economic Ground Zero Shudders, Ripples Spread
description: The attack on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon has worsened the outlook for corporate profits, drastically in some industries and less so in others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZBERG, MINA
description: HOLTZBERG-Mina. Mina Holtzberg, 89 years old died peacefully at her home in Stony Brook, NY, on September 21, 2001. Assistant professor at NYU School of Social Work and Downstate Medical School Family Medicine. Predeceased by husband Milton, who died in the Normandy Invasion and is buried there. Survived by her beloved family, daughter Judy Kaplan, son-in-law Ed Kaplan, grandsons Micah, David and Adam. Tenderly and lovingly cared for by Antra Bortkevica, Dace Medina, Nilce Gonzalez, Yun Kong. Period of mourning Sunday through Tuesday at daughters house. Donations Jewish Guild for the Blind, ACLU, Suffolk County Habitat for Humanity.

title: TV Seeks Normalcy In Troubled Times; A Disrupted Premiere Week Dawns With Comedy and Familiarity Favored
description: The television season finally arrives tonight, tiptoeing in as carefully as it can, still not sure if it is appropriate to try to amuse and entertain a wounded country.

title: Anti-Immigration Posters
description: A week after the attack on the World Trade Center, 40 posters appeared on phone kiosks around Manhattan. ''Immigration will double U.S. population in our lifetimes,'' read one; ''U.S. population now growing at a faster rate than China's,'' read another.

title: Military Plans Must Ensure Oil Flow
description: Oil, long among the abiding interests of the United States in the Middle East, will unavoidably help to shape the Bush administration's planning of the war on terrorism, according to experts on the industry and the region.

title: The Awakened Giant: How Will It Strike Back?; The Faces of America
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001092493151582099 -- No Title
description: Postgame audio from the Giants vs. the Kansas Chiefs provided by SportsAudio.net.

title: Hamas Signals Suspension of Suicide Bombings
description: There have been no Palestinian suicide bombings in Israel since the attacks on the United States, and the militant group Hamas has signaled that it has suspended the bombings.

title: Terror Experts Use Lenses of Their Specialties
description: Since Sept. 11, the words ''terrorism expert'' have been used to describe about three dozen academics, diplomats, former military officers and intelligence officers who have appeared on television news programs or been quoted in print.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, DORIS HELENE (NEE TARNOWER)
description: GOTTESMAN-Doris Helene (nee Tarnower). On September 21. Beloved wife of Nathaniel. Devoted mother to Daniel and his wife Jennifer, Robert and his wife Lina and Jonathan. Predeceased by her son Edward. Loving grandmother to Melissa and her husband Andrew, Adam and Michael. Great-grandmother to Sarah. Services will be held on Monday, September 24, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, Long Island at 1 PM. Shiva Monday to Tuesday at home of Robert, 7 Brookview Ct., Stonybrook, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARL, DAVID M.
description: PEARL-David M., 69. Of Goshen, CT and Delray Beach, FL, beloved husband of Mona, father of Clifford, Todd and Tina, grandfather of Alison, Joshua, Alexander and Bradley, and brother of Glorya, died on Saturday, September 22, at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, CT, having lost his battle against cancer. After graduating from NYU at the age of 20, he had a long and influential career in the apparel industry. He was a longtime supporter of the Joel Finkelstein Cancer Foundation and was honored by Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem for his efforts on behalf of the people of Jerusalem. He was loved and will be remembered by the many people that he touched and helped throughtout his life. A memorial service will be held at Beth-El Synogogue in Torrington, CT at 12 PM, Monday, Sept. 24. He will be laid to rest at the Sons of Jacob Cemetery in Torrington, CT. The family will receive friends and family at their home in Goshen and will sit Shiva until erev Yom Kippur on Wednesday, September 26. The family asks that all contributions made in David's name be given to the Goshen Hospice, P.O. Box 202, Goshen, Connecticut 06756.

title: Drinking to the Rescuers, and Getting Autographs
description: Quench, a bar on Smith Street in Brooklyn, was so crowded Thursday night that dozens of customers spilled onto the sidewalk. Were they oblivious to the city's pain? Seeking to drown their own?

title: The Awakened Giant: How Will It Strike Back?
description: To the Editor:

description: MICCIULLI-William E. A memorial Mass will be held for William E. Micciulli, 30, of Old Bridge, who died September 11, a victim of the World Trade Center disaster in New York City. He was a Partner and Senior Vice President with Cantor Fitzgerald where he worked as an International Equities trader on the 104th floor of the North Tower. He graduated Monsignor Farrell High School, Staten Island, and earned his Bachelor's degree from Fairfield University. He received his MBA from St. John's University where he was a member of the Beta Gamma Sigma honor society. He was an avid sports fan and accomplished athlete. He excelled as a starting pitcher from Little League through College. He enjoyed golfing and was a member of the Glenwood Country Club. He was also a member of the Jersey Shore Runner's Club and participated in many charity races throughout the State. He will be most remembered for his great sense of humor, caring nature and generosity. He truly enjoyed life, happiest when he was spending time with his family and friends. He was a devoted and loving father, husband, brother and son. He was a great friend and will be missed deeply by everyone who's life he touched. Born in Brooklyn and raised in Staten Island, he moved to Old Bridge three and a half years ago where he began raising his family. Surviving are his loving wife, Colleen (Fitzgerald) Micciulli, two daughters, Emily and Sara, adoring parents, William and Joan Micciulli of Manalapan, two sisters, Joanne Los Kamp and Andrea Madonna, both of Old Bridge & his grandmother, Jacqueline Carmellino of Manalapan. Visitation will be from 10:00 A.M. to 11:00 A.M. Wednesday at St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church, 172 Freneau Ave, Matawan, New Jersey. A memorial Mass will be offered at 11:00 A.M. Wednesday at the Church. Waitt & Nelms Funeral Home, Marlboro, New Jersey, for further information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ISAAC
description: STERN-Isaac. The New York Philharmonic deeply mourns the death of Maestro Isaac Stern-renowned violinist, master teacher, beloved colleague and dear friend. Mr. Stern's remarkable career, which spanned more than sixty years, was inextricably linked with the Philharmonic since his debut with the Orchestra in 1944 in a Sunday radio broadcast featuring the Sibelius Violin Concerto, led by Dimitri Mitropoulos. His solo appearances with the Philharmonic numbered more than 100, including the 1960 gala concert led by Leonard Bernstein to benefit Carnegie Hall after its rescue from demolition, an effort spearheaded by Mr. Stern. In 1980 the Philharmonic was honored to celebrate his 60th birthday with a televised concert featuring Mr. Stern as soloist as well as his protegees Pinchas Zukerman and Itzhak Perlman, evidence of the breadth of Mr. Stern's legacy. In 2000, musicians of the Philharmonic also participated in the joyful celebrations marking Mr. Stern's 80th birthday, as well as his 40th anniversary as president of Carnegie Hall. He had most recently appeared with the Orchestra in September 1998 as the special guest soloist for the Philharmonic's Opening Night Concert conducted by Kurt Masur. In recognition of his many decades of outstanding music, as well as his peeless efforts to advance music and its message throughout the world, in 1992 the New York Philharmonic named Mr. Stern an Honorary Member of the Society, the highest honor the organization bestows. From his devotion to saving and sustaining Carnegie Hall to his vital role in the establishment of the National Endowment for the Arts to his enthusiastic dedication to the education of young musicians, Mr. Stern set an exemplary standard for musicians and arts organizations everywhere. He will be greatly missed, but we are grateful for his music, his teaching, and his friendship, lasting legacies that will continue to enrich and instruct us all. The entire New York Philharmonic family-Board, Orchestra, and Administration-extends its heartfelt sympathies and warmest regards to his entire family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Executive Director

title: DUANE READE SAYS ATTACKS CUT PROFIT FOR 3RD QUARTER
description: Duane Reade Inc., New York City's largest drugstore chain, said yesterday that third-quarter profit would be less than forecast because the company lost one store and had to close 20 others after terrorist attacks. Duane Reade lowered its profit projection to 27 cents to 29 cents a share from 43 cents to 44 cents. Sales in the period will be about $280 million, the company said. Last week the company said profit would miss estimates after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center destroyed one store and forced the closing of others south of 14th Street in Manhattan. The company estimates sales lost at the stores total about $12 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 14 Officers Hurt In Riots
description: Fourteen police officers were injured during sectarian riots in Belfast on Sunday night, four of them by a homemade explosive. Flash-point areas between Roman Catholic and Protestant neighborhoods have been experiencing violence nearly every night recently. Assistant Chief Constable Alan McQuillan said the current rash of rioting has been the city's worst since 1981, and ascribed the heavy police casualties to the use of gasoline bombs and pipe bombs. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPSON, ARTHUR
description: CAPSON-Arthur. Retired Science teacher and Junior High School Principal in Brooklyn. He often said his greatest achievements were his daughter Alice, a high school math and computer teacher in Kansas and a graduate of Mt. Holyoke and Harvard and his grandchildren, Beth a high school senior and Jules a junior at Yale. He and his wife Eleanor traveled to the six continents and had been sent by the State Department in 1948 to study the Marshall Plan in Europe. He was a model husband and father and was looking forward to his 90th birthday in two months. Services Tuesday 11:30AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment will be in Kansas City, MO.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWTON, DOUGLAS
description: NEWTON-Douglas. The Board and Staff of the Israel Museum and its American Friends are deeply saddened by the death of Douglas Newton, longtime friend and senior advisor to the Department of Africa Oceania and The Americas. Martin Wright Acting Curator, IM-AOA

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Mugabe's Party Keeps a Seat
description: The governing party of President Robert Mugabe won yet another parliamentary special election, its fifth victory in less than a year, state television reported. Bernard Makokove won the seat in the rural Chikomba District, beating his opponent from the leading opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change. The seat was left vacant this year after the death of Chenjerai Hunzvi, the fiery government militant who rallied the invasions of white-owned farms. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Pondering a Few Loopholes To Let Giuliani Run Again
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will need to navigate two large and cumbersome legal obstacles should he decide to seek a third term as mayor, election lawyers said yesterday.

title: Across Region, a Daily Wave of Remembrance
description: At the Studio Museum in Harlem, people watched slides of work by an artist no longer with them.

title: Jordan Makes His Return Official
description: In the revised N.B.A. Encyclopedia released last winter, Michael Jordan wrote in his foreword about "a very strong connection between the present and the past."

title: How to Protect the Homeland
description: Five years ago, James Woolsey, former director of the C.I.A., and I led a government study that found a lack of preparedness to face catastrophic terrorism. Our warnings and those of similar groups went largely unheeded. On Sept. 11, complacency was wiped away, but the fragmented bureaucratic structure and procedures of our government remain a barrier to action, despite President Bush's decision to name Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania to head a new Office of Homeland Defense.

title: An Atmosphere Charged With Anger and Fear; Looting in the Rubble
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, JOHN
description: O'NEILL-John. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the tragic and untimely death of John O'Neill in the attack on the World Trade Center. John dedicated his life to fighting terrorism and making America safe and secure for all. We will miss his guidance and wise counsel. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun To Show New Computer
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. plans to show off its most powerful computer today, which it hopes will safeguard its position at the high end of the server-system market. The multimillion-dollar, high-performance computer, called the Starcat, harnesses 106 of Suns UltraSparc III computer chips, each running at 900 megahertz. Edward J. Zander, president and chief operating officer of Sun, said he expected to lure some customers away from I.B.M., which makes the mainframe computers that anchor a corporate data center. ''Sun is feeling that with the more powerful system, they can take the place of that mainframe instead of just sitting next to it,'' said Jean Bozman, an analyst with the International Data Corporation.

title: Review/Fashion; Fashions Turn Nostalgic, in Shows Planned So Long Ago
description: Had you been driving on Main Street in Easthampton the Sunday after the World Trade Center attack, and were you able for a few seconds to turn off the newsreel running relentlessly in your head, you might have wondered who had chosen such a surreal moment to shoot a Ralph Lauren ad.

title: On Surgical Innovation And the Questions It Can Raise
description: In a way, Dr. Joseph E. Murray's path as a surgeon was decided at the Valley Forge General Hospital in 1945, at the bedside of Charles Woods, a military aviator who had been severely burned flying fuel to China.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Vandals Hit Oil Equipment
description: Oil exploration equipment was vandalized outside Moab and a postcard left near the site claimed that the Earth Liberation Front, an underground environmental group, was involved. The owner of the equipment, Veritas DGC Land of Denver, has added security to prevent future attacks and to deal with a planned protest. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: As Far as the Giants Are Concerned, It's a New Season, and They're 1-0
description: In their locker room today, the Giants fell into a familiar pattern, putting aside one game as they prepared for the next. Around the room, though, they did so with a sense that their season had almost started anew Sunday in Kansas City.

title: British Insurers Given Leeway On Investing in Stock Market
description: Britain's financial regulator said today that it would temporarily suspend some rules governing how insurance companies invest in the stock market, in an attempt to forestall a snowballing effect when insurers are forced to sell stocks into a falling market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLL, ROBERT J. (BOBBY)
description: COLL-Robert J. (Bobby). Age 35. Of Glen Ridge, N.J, a long time resident of New Rochelle, N.Y. Devoted husband of Jennifer Palmer Coll. Loving father of two beautiful children, Megan Bailey age 2-1/2 and Bobby age 10 months. Beloved son of Edward and Betty Coll. Adored brother of Edward Coll, III, Betsy Weppner, Jeanne Turanica, Suzy Valentino, Peggy Coll, Eileen Coll and Christine Cochet. Respected brother-in-law, caring uncle, loved nephew and trusted cousin and friend. Missing and presumed dead after the World Trade Center attack on September 11, 2001. Bobby was born December 29, 1965, graduated from Fordham Prep, Saint Lawrence University and NYU Stern School of Business. He was Senior Vice President of Financial Markets at Euro Brokers and was actively trying to help others escape from the second tower when it collapsed. Bobby understood that each day was a gift and he worked hard to help us all see how precious a commodity life truly is. Bobby's life has enriched our lives and we are thankful for each moment we spent knowing him. A Mass of Requiem of Life will be held at Immaculate Conception Church, 30 North Fullerton Avenue, Montclair, N.J., 973509-1111, on Friday, October 5, 2001 at 10:30AM. Contributions in Bobby's memory may be made to the Megan and Robert Coll, III Scholar Choice Account and sent to Salomon Smith Barney, 25 Recreation Park Drive, Hingham, MA. 02043.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESTON, SARAH FULTON
description: RESTON-Sarah Fulton. On Saturday, September 22, 2001, Sarah Fulton Reston of Washington D.C. Beloved wife of the late James B. ''Scotty'' Reston, mother of Richard of Edgartown, MA, James of Chevy Chase, MD., and Thomas of Washington D.C. Sister of the late Robert and William Fulton. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Service will be held at St. Alban's Episcopal Church, 3001 Wisconsin Avenue NW, Washington D.C., on Thursday, September 27 at 10 AM. Private interment in Leeds Episcopal Cemetery, Hume, VA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUACKENBUSH, CHRISTOPHER
description: QUACKENBUSH - Christopher. The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club are deeply saddened by the loss of our esteemed member, who died tragically on September 11th at the World Trade Center. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. John D. Martin, President

title: Bayer Sees Delay on Deal
description: Bayer A.G., Germany's biggest drug maker, said that while it was still seeking to complete the purchase of Aventis CropScience by the end of the month, the transaction might be delayed because of legal issues. Earlier this month, Bayer said it would make the purchase of CropScience, jointly owned by Schering A.G. and Aventis S.A., by the end of September.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts to discredit videotape and photographs of Palestinians celebrating the destruction of the World Trade Center misstated measures taken by the magazine Der Stern to verify its contention that the pictures were staged. Officials of The Associated Press in New York and Reuters officials in Jerusalem said the magazine did not approach them before publishing its allegations.

description: Strange things happen to the Mets in September, and Mike Piazza recognizes the pattern.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Interest Rate Cut
description: The Swiss National Bank cut interest rates for the second time in seven days to tamp down the Swiss franc, which has soared against the dollar, the euro and the British pound. The bank trimmed half a percentage point off its benchmark interest rate ''in reaction to the rapid appreciation of the Swiss franc,'' it said. The Swiss economy is expected to grow 1.8 percent this year. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: 7,000 Schoolchildren Learn What It's Like to See Isles Lose
description: The Islanders gave more than 7,000 screaming schoolchildren a valuable lesson in geometry this morning, yielding goals from all kinds of angles. Soon, some students were booing just like older Islanders fans, only at a much higher pitch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNERTY, TIMOTHY J.
description: FINNERTY-Timothy J. Of Glen Rock, NJ formerly of Rutherford, NJ on Tuesday, September 11, 2001. He was employed as a broker for Cantor Fitzgerald, WTC, NY, NY. A member of the Glen Rock Jaycees, he graduated from the University of Scranton in 1990 where he was a member of the Mens Varsity Basketball Team. Mr. Finnerty earned an MBA degree from Wagner College in 1994 and was an assistant coach of the Mens Varsity Basketball Team from 1991-1994. He also coached the St. Catharine RC Church 7th & 8th Grade Boys CYO Basketball, Glen Rock, NJ where he was a parishioner. Beloved husband of Theresa (nee Cassillo) Finnerty of Glen Rock, NJ. Loving son of Peter Finnerty and the late Joyce (nee Spiak) Finnerty of Rutherford, NJ. Devoted brother of Kevin Finnerty of Seattle, WA. Adored grandson of Alice Bannon of Marietta, GA. Memorial Mass Friday, September 28, 2001, 11 AM at St. Catharine RC Church, 905 South Maple Avenue, Glen Rock, NJ. Friends will be received one hour prior to the mass. In lieu of flowers donations to the Timothy J. Finnerty Memorial Fund, C/O Vander Plaat Colonial Home, Inc., Attn: Theresa Finnerty, 13-31 Saddle River Road, Fair Lawn, NJ 07410, would be appreciated.

title: Leading Index Fell in August For First Time Since March
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell in August for the first time since March, a decline that is likely to be extended after the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.

title: Annan Urges New Methods to Fight Terrorism
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan called today on the United Nations to shape new instruments against terrorism, saying that only the organization of all the world's states could give ''global legitimacy'' to a long-term struggle against that ''heinous crime.'' He spoke as the United Nations braced for what field workers in Afghanistan and Pakisttan expected to become a major humanitarian crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADRIAN, MATTHEW TODD
description: ADRIAN-Matthew Todd. Age 43, of NYC, an Immigration Judge for the Executive Office for Immigration Review. Died suddenly on September 22. Born in Sharon, CT and raised in Dutchess County. He was the son of Eleanor Jones Sells of Hilton Head, SC, and Philip Adrian of Henderson, NV. Matthew was a 1981 graduate of Washington College in Chestertown, PA. and received a Juris Doctorate Degree from Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. He was an avid stamp collector and world traveler. He truly enjoyed life and was happiest when he was spending time with family and friends. He was a great friend and will be deeply missed by everyone whose life he touched. In addition to his parents, survivors include his beloved brother, Philip Adrian of Chicago, IL, stepfather James Sells of Hilton Head, SC, four stepsisters, Betsy Sells Knox of Hinesburg, VT, Carolyn Sells Thompson of Germantown, MD, Judy Sells Batchelder of Allenstown, NH, and Susan Sells Gregoritsch of St. Albans, VT. A service to celebrate his life will be held at 11 AM Wednesday, September 26th, at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, 914232-3033. Interment at South Salem Cemetery. Reception following at the Waccabuc Country Club, 90 Mead Street, Waccabuc, New York, 914-763-3144. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Gay Mens Health Crisis, Inc., Attn: Ms. Martell Randolph, 119 W. 24th St., NY NY 10011 212-367-1545.

description: HIRSHFIELD-Robert L. September 23, 2001. Loving husband of Harriet, devoted father of Laurie and Jane, dear brother of Jack and sister-in-law Molly. We miss you very much. Private family service.

title: Title Bout To Be Held At Garden After All
description: As part of the promotion for the bout Saturday between Felix Trinidad and Bernard Hopkins, two large floats shaped like boxing gloves have been placed high atop an entrance to Madison Square Garden.

title: Sallie Wheeler, 70, Who Led Horse Show Back to New York
description: Sallie M. Wheeler, an Anheuser-Busch heiress who led a successful campaign to return the nation's oldest and most prestigious horse show to Manhattan, died on Friday at her home in Keswick, Va. She was 70.

title: Grieving When the Lost Are Never Found
description: For many of the thousands of people who lost loved ones in the massacre of Sept. 11, the continuing search-and-rescue effort leaves a fragment of hope -- either that the missing will somehow be found alive or that their bodies will be recovered so the process of mourning can begin. For some, even a declaration that no more victims will be found alive is difficult or impossible to accept.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOSWEIN, DOROTHY
description: YOSWEIN-Dorothy. Much beloved companion of Martin Fields. Mother of Kathy and Rebecca. Grandmother of Sean and Kelly. Died on September 22, 2001. Her affectionate wit, compassionate devotion to social justice, love for and devotion to her friends, will be sorely missed. Services today at 11:45 AM, Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGARRY, NOACK, KATHERINE ''KATIE''
description: McGARRY - NOACK - Katherine ''Katie''. Of Hoboken, N.J. (formerly of North Merrick, N.Y.). Tragically on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center in her 31st year. Katie attended Sacred Heart School in North Merrick, graduated from Sacred Heart Academy, Hempstead in 1988. She attended St. Bonaventure College, Olean, N.Y. before graduating from St. John's University in 1992. Beloved and devoted wife of Bradley Noack. Cherished daughter of Kathryn and Everett McGarry. Loving sister of Marianne Burke and her husband Joseph, Deborah Brink and her husband Michael, Patrick McGarry, and Ellen Macri and her husband Joseph. Dear daughter-in-law of Jeanette and Robert Noack of Sidney, Australia. Fond sister-in-law of Jennilyn Noack and her husband Justin Sommers and Darren Noack and his wife Alison. Loving aunt of Kevin, Kelly and Colleen Burke, Nicholas Brink, Daniel and Ryan Macri, Edward and Darcy Noack. Katie was a proud godmother to Daniel Macri. Memorial visitation Thursday, September 27, 2001 Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 2515 North Jerusalem Rd (Exit 25N SS Parkway), East Meadow. Memorial Mass Friday, September 28, 2001 1PM at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, North Merrick. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Autism Research Institute, 4182 Adams Avenue, San Diego, California 92116.

description: Continually updated interactive graphics and slideshows on the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and their aftermath are available from this page.

title: Liberals' Ideology Challenged by Urge to Fight Terrorism
description: For many liberals in New York, these are confusing times, as they try to balance their ideals about what the nation should be with their fears of a crisis that threatens to dwarf issues like civil liberties and racism.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages yesterday about a Metropolitan Opera production on Saturday that was the first to be simulcast live in Lincoln Center Plaza misstated the opening day of the company's new season. It was last night; it is not next Monday.

title: President and Chief Leaves Penguin Putnam Books
description: Stories about book publishers and editors fired for failing to generate enough profits are common in the book business. Yesterday, however, the media company Pearson said goodbye to one of the most financially successful publishers in the annals of the industry, Phyllis Grann, president and chief executive of its Penguin Putnam books division.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the At the Movies column of Weekend on Friday about the coming Jackie Chan movie ''The Tuxedo'' misstated the given name of the actor who plays Mr. Chan's boss. He is Jason Isaacs, not Jeremy.

title: Jordan Delays Making His Move
description: Michael Jordan always had a knack for siphoning the most out of a moment, and in his bid for a second comeback to the N.B.A., it appears he is at it again.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Help For Asian Voters
description: A Chinatown group has set up voter assistance centers, one in Chinatown and the other in Queens, that will be open from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. today. Last year, in the presidential election, voters of Chinese and Korean heritage reported difficulty with election officials, such as confusing voters' first and last names, according to the group, Asian Americans for Equality. The delay of the primary because of the World Trade Center attack may add to difficulties, the group said. Chinese and Korean interpreters will be at 1 Pike Steet in Chinatown at 212-477-2265; and at 40-34 Main Street in Flushing at 718-539-7290.

title: A Remote Arkansas Town Knows Terror's Reach Again
description: In both attitude and pace, Batesville seems even farther from New York City than the 1,200 miles that separate the two. Set beside the White River in the foothills of the Ozarks, it is a serenely wholesome town of 9,500 whose phone book is no thicker than a mail-order catalog.

title: PHAR-MOR, DRUGSTORE CHAIN, FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Phar-Mor Inc., which operates 139 drugstores in 24 states, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because of heavy debt and will close 65 stores to reduce costs. In papers filed yesterday in Bankruptcy Court in Youngstown, Ohio, the company listed $345 million in assets and $300 million in debts. Phar-Mor, which also uses the Pharmhouse and Rx Place names for its stores, said that the slowing economy and competition from larger chains contributed to its financial problems. Phar-Mor, which is based in Youngstown, emerged from a three-year bankruptcy reorganization in September 1995.

title: As Tourism Halts in New Orleans, Musicians Play On
description: Life has suddenly become hard in the Big Easy, with many restaurants and night clubs empty, hotels losing millions of dollars in canceled reservations, and Bourbon Street stiller than anyone can remember.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIO, JOSEPH
description: MAIO-Joseph. Tragically stolen from our family after spending what seems like only a few minutes of his precious life with us. Quiet dignity was your trademark but you also combined that with generosity and an unselfish attitude towards everyone with whom you came into contact. You were always a hole-in-one to us and the memory of your sweetness will forever shine in our hearts. Sharri, JoAnn, Chuck, Robyn & Jordan

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Milosevic-Linked Funds Frozen
description: The government has frozen bank accounts connected with government associates of the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, officials confirmed. Accounts of four people -- who were not identified -- were blocked at the request of Yugoslav authorities, the Justice Department said. The three banks involved -- two in Zurich and one in Ticino, a southern canton -- did not say how much money was in the accounts. Banks came up empty-handed in response to an earlier request to locate Mr. Milosevic's funds. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Apartment Rents and Prices Tremble, but Don't Plummet
description: Despite dire predictions about plummeting apartment prices, and despite the bad economic news since the World Trade Center attacks, Manhattan's real estate rental and sales prices have not gone into free fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, THOMAS J.
description: CASEY-Thomas J. Prominent Long Island engineer died on September 22, 2001. Beloved husband of Marion. Devoted father to Chris, Ellen, Kevin, Moira and Mark. Cherished grandfather of Nessa, Caroline, Jessica, Charlotte and Maddy.

title: Support From North Korea
description: North Korea, which has long been branded as a ''rogue state,'' today issued a statement implicitly approving approving United States-led efforts to combat world terrorism.

description: TEITELL-Betty (nee Mermelstein), 95. Former New York City schoolteacher. Wife of the late Irving. Mother of Charles and Janet Langsam and sister of Dr. Edward I. Mermel. Donations to Hospice Care Westchester-Putnam.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Environmental Suit To Be Heard
description: A federal appeals panel is scheduled to hear oral arguments today in a case that combines civil rights law and the environment. The residents of a low-income Camden neighborhood say a cement-additive plant should be shut down because it adds to the already high level of pollution there. The opening of the $50 million plant, built by St. Lawrence Cement Company, was delayed by a federal lawsuit by a group known as South Camden Citizens in Action. An April court order blocked the plant opening but was overturned by an appellate panel in June. Plant proponents argue that blocking the plant will discourage other businesses from moving to Camden. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Captions on Sunday with a picture grouping of New York Fire Department members killed or missing at the World Trade Center reversed the category designations of two firefighters and the assignments of two others. Patrick O'Keefe has been confirmed dead; Capt. William O'Keefe is listed as missing. Thomas W. Kelly was assigned to Ladder Company 15 and Thomas R. Kelly to Ladder Company 105.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Cement Stake
description: Cemex, the world's third-largest cement maker, said it was close to purchasing a $300 million controlling stake in the Thai cement company TPI Polene. Cemex of Mexico said it could acquire as much as 72.5 percent of TPI Polene's equity in the deal. TPI Polene is restructuring a $1.12 billion debt carried over from the 1997 currency devaluation in Thailand. This year Cemex has consolidated its presence in Asia, where it has operations in the Philippines, Indonesia, Bangladesh and Thailand. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNA, VALERIE J.
description: HANNA-Valerie J., 57. Senior Vice President for Technology for Marsh & McLennan, died at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. She is survived by her husband of 29 years Glenn Hughes of Freeville, New York, daughters Lydia Robertson and Denene Ray, foster son Victor Arencibia, mother Joan Haviland, stepmother Mary Hanna, brother Sherman Hanna, sisters Kathleen Hanna and Barbara Hanna and three granddaughters. She was preceded in death by her father Patrick Hanna and son Joel Robertson. Memorial services will be at 10AM September 29 at 295 13th St., Brooklyn and 1 PM September 30 at The Unitarian Church of Ithaca, New York.
