title: Giuliani Considers Restricting Auto Access to Manhattan
description: As New Yorkers continued to resume their normal activities, traffic choked many of the major roads in the city today and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said officials were considering a plan to limit automobile access to the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROTTY, KEVIN R.
description: CROTTY-Kevin R. Of Summit, NJ. Died on September 11, 2001 in the attack on 2 World Trade Center. He was a Managing Director of Sandler O'Neill & Partners. He is survived by his wife Lori, his three children Megan (7), Kyle (5) and Sean (2-1/2). He is also survived by his parents, Mary and Raymond of Frederick, MD, two brothers, Brian of Gaithersburg, MD, and David of Ijamsville MD. A memorial service will be held on October 6th at 2PM in the Presbyterian Church at New Providence, 1307 Springfield Avenue, New Providence, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Kevin R. Crotty Trust (Megan Kyle Sean), Box 1258, Summit, NJ 07901.

title: Foreign Affairs; Terrorism Game Theory
description: When I lived in Beirut in the early 1980's -- the era when suicide bombing was born -- I had a Lebanese friend, Diala, who used to quip that whenever she traveled on an airplane she carried a bomb in her luggage, because the odds against two people carrying a bomb on the same plane were so much higher.

title: Pakistan May Soften Stand On Afghans Fleeing There
description: Jamal Khan, a junkman, deals in old shoes, empty bottles and piles of tin. But his biggest seller is bits of stale bread. Vendors buy his supply at 3 cents a pound and then resell it at this refugee camp, where a paste of boiled, spiced scraps of bread is often the only meal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETTLER, LEON J.
description: BRETTLER-Leon J. Died suddenly on September 23rd. Beloved husband of Jacqueline, loving father of Doug and Martha, Michael and Danielle, devoted grandfather of Andrea & Caroline. Graduated MIT. Served two years in the U.S. Army during WWII. Chairman of the Board of Shapiro, Bernstein Music Publishing, served on the Board of Directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP) and the National Music Publishers Association (NMPA) for over thirty years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, TODD C.

title: Jets Discover the Ability To Sidestep Distractions
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards sat in the courtyard of the team hotel in Boston the night before the Jets beat the Patriots, 10-3, reviewing the notes he had made for himself about his address to the team that evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, EDWARD C.
description: MURPHY-Edward C., 42, of Clifton, NJ, taken from us in the WTC disaster on September 11, 2001 while working at Cantor Fitzgerald. Ed would have been 43 years old today. I can never have another friend like you. Rest in peace, my dear friend. Marc

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, SCOTT MARTIN
description: McGOVERN-Scott Martin. Age 35 of Wyckoff, N.J. Victim of World Trade Center Disaster, September 11, 2001. Cherished husband of Jill (nee Shaffro). Adored father of Alana and Nicole. Loving son of Elisabeth Scott and Martin McGovern, stepson of Anne McGovern. Beloved son-in-law to Renee and William Shaffro. Devoted brother to Tara, brother-in-law to Raymond, Ronni and Steven. Memorial Service Friday, September 28, 2001, 1 P.M. at Christ Church, Franklin Avenue and Cottage Place, Ridgewood, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Scott McGovern Family Fund would be appreciated.

title: People
description: * Lynne Seid, executive vice president and managing director at the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, was named to the new post of chief client officer.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC ARTERY PRODUCT PASSES TEST
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation's experimental drug-coated stent, a metal-mesh tube used to prop open cleared arteries, prevented blood vessels from reclogging, according to a study. Boston Scientific is competing with Johnson & Johnson, the Guidant Corporation and Cook Inc. in a market for drug-coated stents that could be worth $4 billion. The stents are designed to prevent new tissue growth that reclogs arteries after angioplasty procedures. None of the 31 patients who received a Boston Scientific stent coated with the cancer drug paclitaxel had another blockage, said Dr. Eberhard Grube of the Siegburg Heart Center in Siegburg, Germany, the lead investigator. Eleven percent of patients with uncoated stents had new blockages. Johnson & Johnson has released a larger study that showed similar results for its stent, which is closer to market.

title: Television networks wonder how much lower prices for commercial time could go.
description: AS the broadcast television networks belatedly begin the 2001-02 prime-time season, they are anxiously trying to determine if the prices they charge for commercial time -- already softening before the events of Sept. 11 -- will weaken further.

title: Songwriters and Publishers Reach a Deal With Napster
description: Taking a turn from its embattled origins, the Internet music service Napster said today that it had agreed to pay $26 million to settle a copyright lawsuit with songwriters and music publishers, and to make royalty payments to the writers and publishers once it started a fee-based service.

title: From the Past, Images of the Future
description: During a career as a geological engineer, rocket scientist, space historian and author, Frederick I. Ordway, 74, has never lost his teenage love for science fiction. In his travels Mr. Ordway haunted antiquarian bookstores, art galleries and libraries in search of images from a time when the future was full of possibility and the universe was an ocean of wonders awaiting a new breed of sailor. His collection ranges from 16th-century engravings of ships and chariots in the sky to 1950's Collier's magazine articles in which Wernher von Braun and other rocket pioneers presented cutaway illustrations of space stations and moonships. A sampling of these visions of the future has now been published in ''Visions of Spaceflight: Images From the Ordway Collection'' (Four Walls Eight Windows).

Brother of Ann Louise Christsen, Jane Mason and James Alexander McQuilling. Thomas Merrick was born in Flushing, NY, attended Flushing High School and graduated Admiral Farragut Academy in 1939. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOSEWITZ, SHELLEY
description: SOSEWITZ-Shelley. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are deeply saddened by the loss of their dear friend Shelley Sosewitz of Chicago, beloved wife for 48 years of past president, chairman of the board and giant in our organization Ben Z. Sosewitz. A Zionist since youth, Mrs. Sosewitz actively shared her husband's fervent devotion to the ATS, the Technion and Israel. As Technion Guardians the couple committed themselves to building the Technion and the nation through their endowment of the Ben and Shelley Sosewitz Academic Lectureship, funding of the Ben and Shelley Sosewitz Dormitory, and support of all Chicago Chapter projects, such as the Crown Superconductivity Center and the Asher Space Research Institute. Their most recent innovation, the Sosewitz/Jackier Institute for Leadership Development, prepares young leaders for national roles in the organization. Mrs. Sosewitz, a familiar face on many ATS missions abroad and at national board meetings, shared Ben's broad vision, provided quiet inspiration and thoughtful insights. As an accomplished classical pianist she also inspired her students and audiences with her passionate love of music. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ben Sosewitz, daughters Miriam Clarke, Leah Sosewitz and Arna Yastrow, their seven grandchildren and the entire Sosewitz family. American Society for Technion -Israel Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chair Evelyn Berger, President Designate Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Stephen A. Laser, Chicago Chapter President Joel S. Rothman, Chicago Chapter Chair

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Havel Taken Ill

Doctors said his condition was not life-threatening. In 1998 Mr. Havel, the playwright and human rights activist, had a life-threatening case of accelerated pulse and pneumonia. He suffers from chronic bronchitis, and had part of a lung removed in December 1996 following the discovery of a cancerous tumor. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: British Companies Challenge Microsoft
description: A consor tium of British companies have complained to regulators about a Microsoft pricing policy, which they say will cost business an additional 880 million, or $1.3 billion. The group, called the Infrastructure Forum, which includes GlaxoSmithKline, Prudential and Cadbury Schweppes, as well as the BBC and Inland Revenue, wrote last week to Patricia Hewitt, the secretary of trade, to protest the new structure. Instead of allowing companies to upgrade existing software, Microsoft is asking customers to sign up for a three-year subscription, in which they would pay an initial sum and then purchase new software as it is released. A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry said Ms. Hewitt would review the group's concerns. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Ex-Leader Convicted

The son, Hutomo Mandala Putra, is now in hiding. The court ordered Mr. Wahid to pay the equivalent of $53,190. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: With Fear in the Skies, Americans Are Taking to the Rails

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Damage At Muslim's Shop
description: Equipment worth hundreds of thousands of dollars was vandalized over the weekend at an Anchorage printing shop owned by a Muslim, and the authorities are calling the incident a hate crime. The shop's owner, Mike Maad, who has lived in Anchorage for 20 years and is of Syrian descent, found computer equipment and printers smashed when he came to his shop on Saturday. Spray-painted on the wall was the message ''We hate Arabs.'' Some Anchorage residents have established a fund to help Mr. Maad. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Airport Sale Postponed
description: The government deferred until next year the sale of Sydney Airport, blaming turmoil in the airline industry and financial markets for scuttling its plans. Just weeks ago, the airport had been expected to bring about $2.5 billion. Analysts predicted the price would drop about 20 percent; some investors have already withdrawn. The government, which faces an election by year-end and wanted to complete the sale before going to the polls, had already once extended the date for bids. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

Survivors include his wife Lucille Lieberman, daughter Meg Lieberman and her husband, Michael Gold, and three grandchildren; Amanda, Jeremiah & David Gold. Services Tuesday September 25 at 11:00 AM from Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT, with interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York. Memorial contributions may be made to AMERICARES.

title: Disputes on Electronic Message Encryption Take On New Urgency
description: The attacks on the World Trade Center have reawakened a debate on how strongly the public -- and by extension terrorists and other criminals -- should be able to encrypt their electronic messages.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Energy Prices Decline; Stocks Rise on Optimism

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Broadens Accounting Software
description: Intuit Inc. said yesterday that it would broaden its QuickBooks line of accounting software to serve business customers and specific business segments in an effort to increase profit. The new offerings include a $1,500 version of QuickBooks, code-named Hercules and expected to be released next summer, for large corporations. Intuit also said it had agreed to buy Omware Inc., a maker of construction-management software based in Sebastopol, Calif., for $42 million in stock. Steve Bennett, the chief executive of Intuit, said he expected Omware to contribute $10 million to $20 million toward Intuit's bottom line in the first year. He said Intuit was on track to meet its goals for its first quarter, ending Oct. 31, and the rest of the 2002 fiscal year.

title: H.I.V. Drugs May Stem Nerve Disorder
description: Neurologists are closely studying the cases of seven young people infected with H.I.V. who also developed amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, an incurable disease of the nervous system also known as A.L.S., or Lou Gehrig's disease. Scientists are intrigued because the patients' symptoms decreased or disappeared, apparently as a result of the drugs they took to suppress the H.I.V. infection.

title: Voting Today in New York
description: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic primary choices except for the borough presidency in Staten Island, where there is only a Republican primary. Poll hours are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Battle Against Terrorism Has an Agricultural Price
description: In the Vietnam War, Chuck Hendrickson flew Huey helicopters during the Tet offensive. In this new war, with its many fronts and nameless, faceless enemies, his mission is not to fly at all.

title: ALIGNING WITH U.S.
description: President Vladimir V. Putin tonight offered the United States broad support for antiterrorist operations in Afghanistan, including opening Russian airspace to relief missions, taking part in some search-and-rescue operations, and arming anti-Taliban forces inside Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, HERMAN
description: SANDLER-Herman, 57. Loving husband of Suki, devoted father of Pamela, Gillian and Jordana, role model and mentor to hundreds of young people. You encouraged us to take risks and gave us innumerable opportunities to follow our dreams, cheering us on as we learned to impact the world as you did so powerfully. You will always remain our awesome inspiration. We love you, Suki, Pamela, Gillian and Jordana. In lieu of flowers, gifts honoring Herman may be made to any of the following organizations: American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, The Rain Forest Foundation, The Perlman Music Program, Carnegie Hall, or UJA Federation of NY.

title: Newly Popular In Disaster's Wake, Amtrak Seeks U.S. Aid
description: When Tom Daschle, Edward M. Kennedy and other senators came to New York on Thursday to see for themselves the destruction caused by the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, they decided for logistical and security reasons not to travel by plane. Instead, like many Americans over the last week or so, they rode the rails, glad to have an alternative to flying, but unsure about the long-term future of Amtrak, the nation's 22,000-mile intercity rail system.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about Congressional passage of a package to bail out the airlines and an agreement to set up a federal fund for victims misspelled the surname of the president of the Association of American Trial Lawyers, which offered free legal services to victims. He is Leo V. Boyle, not Boil.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a New Jersey candidates' forum sponsored by the Arab American Institute in Newark gave a misspelled surname in some copies for the president of the Arab American Civic Organization, who questioned a candidate for governor. He is Hani Y. Awadallah, not Amadallah.

title: Some Writers Accuse Times Of Hiring Ban
description: The National Writers' Union yesterday accused The New York Times of refusing to work with a group of its members who successfully sued The Times over compensation rights to articles posted on electronic databases.

title: A Wiser Sosa Is Carrying the Cubs
description: Earlier this season, as the Chicago Cubs were leading the Central Division of the National League, Sammy Sosa was asked if it was a burden on the minds of his teammates that the Cubs had not won a World Series in 93 years.

title: Real-Life Cyborg Challenges Reality With Technology
description: Footsore visitors to the Austin Museum of Art in Texas may have been tempted by a recent installation called SeatSale, a plain wooden chair with a scrolling electronic sign and a credit card reader. But the chair has something else special: at the spot where a cushion normally goes are dozens of sharp metal spikes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, HELEN BAYER
description: LIVINGSTON-Helen Bayer. On September 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Norman, loving mother of Tammy and Jerry Weintraub, Louis B. and Mari Livingston, and Toni Bayer. Adored grandmother of Melissa Weintraub Kohl, Amanda Weintraub Ratliff, and Diana, Alex and Annie Livingston. Dear great-grandmother of Gavin and Luke Ratliff. Active in Jewish affairs, she was most recently a cherished Board Member of Manhattan Chapter of Brandeis University National Womens Committee and the Trustee Emeritus of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun.

title: U.S. Prepares to Brief NATO on Strategy to Fight bin Laden
description: As President Bush pressed his case against terrorism with foreign governments, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz prepared to brief NATO defense ministers in Brussels on the overall American strategy to root out the bin Laden terrorist network.

title: Helping New Mothers Regain Control
description: Home visits from nurses who provide training in special exercises can help women suffering from bladder problems and incontinence after childbirth, researchers are reporting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, SEAN PATRICK
description: LYNCH-Sean Patrick. Of New York City, age 34, was tragically lost at the World Trade Center on Tuesday, September 11, 2001. Sean was a Senior Vice President of equity trading at Cantor Fitzgerald Co., Inc. on the 104th floor. Sean is survived by his parents, John and Margaret Lynch of Lynnfield, MA, his brother Michael and his three sisters Kathleen Hallstrom, Colleen Watson, and Laureen Sutera. He was a loving uncle to his ten nieces and nephews. Sean will be sadly missed by his family and many friends. Sean was a graduate of St. John's Prep, Class of 1985, and Boston College, Class of 1989. A Memorial Mass to celebrate his life will be held at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, Lynnfield, MA, on Friday, September 28th, at 10:30 AM. Donations may be made in Sean's memory to New York Firefighters, 9-11 Disaster Relief Fund, Box 65858, Washington, DC 20035-5858.

title: Afghan Rebels Courted by U.S. and Russia to Defy Taliban
description: The tiny, long-ignored embassy of the alliance of Afghan rebel groups fighting the Taliban was buzzing with activity today. American diplomats and Russian generals are coming courting, testing the mettle of the new commander of the Northern Alliance, appointed after his predecessor died from wounds suffered in an assassination everyone here blames on the Taliban's most infamous guest, Osama bin Laden.

title: An Atmosphere Charged With Anger and Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Beauty From Evil: Preserving Felled Tower Facade as Sculpture
description: WHAT do we do with the facade in the ruins?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODRIGUES PEREIRA, REVEREND DR. MARTIN M.
description: RODRIGUES PEREIRA-Reverend Dr. Martin M. Scientist and Chazan, June 7, 1920-September 24, 2001. Born and raised in the Netherlands, where he lived until the summer of 1942, when he escaped from Nazi-occupied Holland. Upon reaching the free world, he volunteered for service with the Free Dutch Forces in England, seeing combat in Western Europe. After World War II, he emigrated to South America, where he was associated with major export firms. At the end of 1957 he came to the United States to pursue further studies, obtaining degrees in meteorology and a doctoral degree in biology and experimental medicine. From then on he has been associated with graduate schools, government laboratories and engineering firms. Since coming to the United States, he served as Chazan for High Holy Day services at the Spanish and Portuguese synagogues: Congregation Shearith Israel in New York City and Congregation Mikveh Israel in Philadelphia. Dr. Rodrigues Pereira's late father was the Chief Rabbi of the Sephardic Jewish community in the Netherlands. He is survived by his wife, Theresia; daughter, Joanne; son, Michael; three grandchildren; brother, Arnold, and sister, Frieda. His son, S. David Rodrigues Pereira passed away in 1986. Services today, 2 PM, at ''Parkside Chapels,'' Queens Blvd. at 66th Ave., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Towers' Former Neighbors Await All-Clear
description: A quarter-century ago, a band of artists dared to do the unthinkable. They looked at the crumpled walls, shattered windows and dripping plaster of an abandoned 19th-century office building in the financial district and saw a home.

title: Bonds's Homer Is No. 67
description: Normally, Barry Bonds can take time in the batter's box to savor the history he has been creating, but tonight he didn't have time to indulge in watching his 67th home run arch over the fence.

title: Works Echo Differently When Life Overtakes Art
description: Does contemporary art have an impact on everyday life? The matter is up for debate. There's no question, though, that life can transform the way we look at new art.

title: An Atmosphere Charged With Anger and Fear; Ways of Fighting
description: To the Editor:

title: INSTINET SAYS CLOSING OF MARKETS REDUCED PROFIT
description: The Instinet Group, the automated stock trading network, said its third-quarter profit would fall because of lost revenue after terrorist attacks closed stock markets in the United States for four days. Instinet, a unit of the Reuters Group, charges commissions to electronically match buyers and sellers of stocks. It expects the attacks to cut $18 million, or 4 cents a share, from its third-quarter pretax earnings. The company now expects to earn 7 cents to 9 cents a share, down from analysts' predictions of about 17.5 cents.

title: A Folk-Song Writer Is Stilled by Discordant Grief
description: FOR the first time in his 30 years as a prolific folk songwriter and poet, Jack Hardy said, he is mute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERNBERG, SYLVIA
description: STERNBERG-Sylvia, 79. On September 23, 2001. Beloved wife of Cantor Ralph Sternberg. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Rachel and Donald Lachs. Dear grandmother of Michele, Marc and Jessica. Devoted sister and sister-in-law of Morris and Dorothy Sherman. Funeral today 9:30 am Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry.

title: Op-Art; Personal Loss
It's Back to Politics, So New Jersey Candidates Talk Taxes
description: The campaign for New Jersey governor was back in full swing today, as Bret D. Schundler unveiled a sweeping tax cut proposal for elderly homeowners while his Democratic rival, James E. McGreevey, released a new television advertisement in which he discusses the recent terrorist attacks.

title: As Thick as the Ash, Myths are Swirling
description: Did you hear?

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Redistricting Panel Meets
description: Members of the state's redistricting commission met in Olympia to search for common ground on new boundaries for the state's 49 legislative and 9 Congressional districts. The Legislature appointed four commissioners, two Democrats and two Republicans, in January. A fifth member, chosen by the commissioners, will act as moderator but will not vote. The commission is supposed to submit a redistricting plan to the Legislature by mid-December. If it fails to agree on a plan, the responsibility for redistricting falls to the State Supreme Court. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Tough but Avid Teacher Is Recalled
description: The first time Itzhak Perlman played the violin for Isaac Stern, he was 11 years old and more than a little petrified.

title: Hurricanes' Dorsey Watches Himself Succeed
description: Clinton Portis chuckles at the rapid evolution of Miami quarterback Ken Dorsey into a serious Heisman Trophy candidate. Both began their college playing careers as freshmen in 1999.

title: Once Appalled by Race Profiling, Many Find Themselves Doing It
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 22  Ron Arnold understands racial profiling. "I'm a black American, and I've been racially profiled all my life," said Mr. Arnold, a 43-year-old security officer here, "and it's wrong."

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Look at Vouchers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 — A long-awaited test of the boundary between church and state reached the Supreme Court today when the justices announced that they would rule on the constitutionality of a publicly financed Ohio program that helps thousands of parents in Cleveland pay their children's tuition at religious schools.

title: $150 Million in Aid Is Pledged
description: The star-filled network fund-raiser on Friday night for victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and their families generated more than $150 million in pledges, organizers said yesterday.

title: Trains Need Help, Too
description: Stranded travelers made a fortuitous discovery when the airlines shut down after the terrorist attacks: The country still has an intercity rail system. Amtrak scrambled to provide additional service to accommodate the surge in demand. In the Washington-New York corridor, Amtrak's stylish new high-speed Acela Express trains are especially busy because of the continued shutdown of Washington's Reagan National Airport.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Gains For The Left
description: The governing center-left coalition took 13 Senate seats from the right in elections on Sunday, though the right retains a nearly two-thirds majority. Some of the gains were expected because of changes in election laws that introduced proportional representation in larger constituencies. But the results were still seen as a victory for the left at a time when the conservative Rally for the Republic party of President Jacques Chirac has been dogged by allegations of corruption. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Agency Offers Up to $30,000 to Each Victim's Family
description: Families of those who have been reported dead or missing in the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks will receive immediate lump-sum grants of as much as $30,000 from the American Red Cross, the organization announced yesterday.

title: Hamming It Up In Another Category
description: 'Emeril'

title: Corrections
description: A casualty list by The Associated Press on Sept. 13 for the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington misstated the name of a passenger on United Flight 175, which crashed into the World Trade Center. She was Sue Kim-Hanson, not Susan Hanson.

title: Talk Radio, a Medium Noted for Vitriol, Shows Some Restraint
description: Vitriol, venom and unfiltered rage are still riding the airwaves of the nation's talk radio stations, but in recent days a huge audience has also heard something that is not usually associated with the medium: restraint.

title: Oil and Gas Prices Tumble, But Stocks Soar Worldwide
description: Oil and natural gas prices plunged yesterday on fears that a sharp worldwide recession would reduce energy demand. But stocks worldwide soared on optimism that the recession would be brief and that the American economy, the world's leader, would eventually shrug off the attacks of Sept. 11.

title: VeriSign Deal Lets It Move Into Billing
description: VeriSign Inc., which provides Internet security and address registration services, said today that it had agreed to buy Illuminet Holdings Inc. for $1.2 billion in stock to sell secure Web billing and other services to phone companies.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: THE NATION'S RESPONSE

title: For Partygoers Who Can't Say No, Experts Try to Reduce the Risks
description: Despite frequent admonitions to ''just say no,'' some people -- from their teens to well past middle age -- will use drugs anyway. Acknowledging that reality, some experts on drug abuse are advocating an approach called harm reduction, which says, in essence, that while drug use should be discouraged, people who do take drugs should be taught to do so in the least dangerous way possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, PATRICK SEAN
description: MURPHY-Patrick Sean, 36. Of Millburn, NJ, missing in the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. A graduate of The University of Virginia, Patrick was a Vice President of Information Technology at Marsh and McLennan. A Memorial Mass will be offered Saturday, September 29, 2001, 12:30 PM at St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, NJ. Patrick is the loving husband of Vera Murphy, loving father of Sean and Maggie; son of Lori and Tom Murphy of Venice, FL; brother of Lori-Jean Murphy of Martinsville, NJ, Thomas Murphy of Clifton, VA., and the late Timothy Patrick Murphy, of Hollywood, CA and son-in-law of Vera and Dominic Profaci of Parlin, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, NEIL D.
description: LEVIN-Neil D. Age 46, of New York City, missing and presumed dead in the World Trade Center attack, September 11, 2001. Neil was the Executive Director of the NYNJ Port Authority, a job he loved. He was a good friend, a mentor and role model for many. He will be deeply missed by his wife Christy Ferer, step-daughters Caitlin and Ali, his mother Gloria, his brother Stanley, sister-in-law Robin, nephew Adam and niece Kim. His father was the late Morton H. Levin. A service to celebrate his life will be held at 6:00PM Tuesday, September 25th at Manhattan's Temple Emanu-El, 66th Street and Fifth Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you remember children of other missing Port Authority victims through the Neil D. Levin Education Foundation, 101 Park Ave., Suite 2500, New York, NY 10178.

title: Nations in Pacific Rim Are Supporting Airlines
description: Threatened by a wholesale grounding of airplanes, governments around the Pacific Rim pledged today to help airlines that are hobbled by soaring insurance rates and sharply reduced coverage for terrorist acts.

title: Group Sees Slow Growth For Tourism
description: Opening its conference here today, the World Tourism Organization put the best face on what it acknowledged were ''difficult times,'' predicting 1.5 percent growth in worldwide tourism this year despite sudden drops after the terrorist attacks in the United States.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Comoros: A Peaceful Island Coup
description: Mohamed Bacar, the leader of the breakaway island of Anjouan, was toppled in a peaceful coup just six weeks after he had seized power himself, local radio reported. The radio reported that Ahmed Abubakar Fundi had been installed as president, replacing Mr. Bacar, who took power in a coup in August. Anjouan broke away from the Comoran Federation, three islands off the Indian Ocean coast of Africa, in 1997. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Winning by Exploiting Mental Game
description: Issues of war and peace and death and life will hover over the National Football League this year in a way that none of its players have experienced before. This season will require adaptability. Who has it? Who can muster it?

title: Anguish of Recent Events Can Awaken Old Trauma
description: In the dreams, George Humphrey is running for his life through a dark tunnel, his pursuer close behind him. He startles awake, his sheets drenched in sweat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASPER, EVA
description: KASPER-Eva. On September 23, 2001, at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Moe Kasper. Loving mother of Lois Vermann & the late Barbara Stieglitz. Dear sister of Maxine Bloom. Cherished grandmother of Allen and Eric Stieglitz, Debbie Baggett, Robert Vermann and Marci Wickham. Adoring great grandmother of seven. Graveside service at Union Field Cemetery, Tuesday, September 25th, 2PM.

title: For a Play From the 60's, a Street With the Right Feel
description: There may be no other street in Manhattan with the echoes of the 1960's of St. Marks Place in the East Village. The facade of the old Electric Circus still glows blue; memories of the Fillmore East waft around the corner; maybe it's faint, but the cafes, T-shirt shops and hole-in-the-wall clothes and craft boutiques (not to mention the famous bookstore) are still dimly redolent of the tie-dyed anarchy of the notorious past.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Money is the lifeblood of terrorist operations. Today, we're asking the world to stop payment.''

title: Primary Day Today
description: Today is the rescheduled Primary Day. Polls will open at 6 a.m. and close at 9 p.m. in New York City and Nassau, Suffolk, Putnam, Westchester and Rockland counties.

title: Sales Are Resumed for Coverage of Airlines for Terror Damage
description: Aviation insurers resumed selling war and terrorism coverage to airlines around the world yesterday, four days after governments stepped in to provide temporary coverage to prevent a shutdown of flights worldwide.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Leak Delays Big Dig
description: A leak has interrupted work on Boston's part of the Big Dig highway construction, raising fears of more delays in the $14.5 billion project. Water began pouring into an excavation early Saturday at 25,000 gallons a minute. Workers had to abandon a crane, now underwater. Officials said it was unclear if the leak would delay the September 2002 opening of the section, which will connect the Massachusetts Turnpike to the tunnel to Logan International Airport. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: HONEYWELL, RAISING FIGURE, SAYS IT WILL CUT 15,800 JOBS
description: Honeywell International Inc., which cut its profit forecasts last week, raised the number of jobs it would eliminate this year to 15,800, or 13 percent of its work force, because of the turmoil in the airline industry. The company will take a third-quarter charge of as much as $700 million to cover the costs of trimming the payroll, the chief executive, Lawrence Bossidy, said at an investor meeting. Honeywell had projected last week that more than 12,000 jobs would be cut. Job cuts will total 5,300 in the aerospace businesses; 6,400 in the automation division; 2,900 in the specialty-materials business; and 1,200 in transportation and power businesses, Mr. Bossidy said.

title: The Times Still Plans to Build An Office Tower in Midtown
description: The New York Times committed itself yesterday to building a new headquarters on Eighth Avenue every bit as tall and every bit as crystalline as in the plan it unveiled last year.

title: BellSouth's Account Is Opened for Review
description: The BellSouth Corporation has begun a review of most of its account, with spending estimated at $150 million to $200 million. Consolidating the major assignments is being considered.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Expands Wireless Access
description: The Federal Communications Commission said it would expand access to airwaves in the range of 2500 megahertz to 2690 megahertz -- currently used for fixed wireless services, like satellite Internet service -- so that they could be used for third-generation services like high-speed Internet access or music downloads. But the commission said it would not take away wireless spectrum used by schools, health-care operations and some companies. WorldCom Inc. and the Sprint Corporation, for example, use the airwaves for satellite Internet service. Telephone companies want to acquire additional licenses to begin providing high-speed Internet and audio and video services. The Commerce Department and the F.C.C. had been looking for additional airwaves to sell and had considered shifting spectrum to commercial operators from the government.

title: U.S. Officers Are Meeting In Islamabad On War Plans
description: Military officers from United States and Pakistan, planning for probable American strikes into Afghanistan, met behind a wall of secrecy here today to work out ways of using Pakistan's air bases, ports and other sites in the war President Bush has promised against international terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, LEWIS
description: RUDIN-Lewis. The Board of Directors, Advisory Council and Staff of the National Association on Drug Abuse Problems (NADAP) wish to express their deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolences to the Rudin family. 30 years ago Lew Rudin, along with several other business and labor leaders, saw the need to bring the pubic and private sectors together to combat the effects of substance abuse on New York's economy by forming NADAP. Lew carried the agency through some difficult times and helped the organization meet the city's growing needs for programs in the field of substance abuse and employment. His commitment, leadership and guidance, as a founder and board member, have helped over 10,000 people become self sufficient and employed. Each year, NADAP is honored to present the Lewis Rudin Award to distinguished leaders in society who also make a difference. We will never forget him.

title: Defense Is Trying to Bar Witness in Auction Trial
description: The lawyers for A. Alfred Taubman, a former chairman of Sotheby's, asked a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan yesterday to bar the appearance of a witness expected to offer crucial testimony against him in his criminal antitrust trial.

title: An Atmosphere Charged With Anger and Fear; Ways of Fighting
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBIN, JACK
description: ALBIN-Jack. Retired New York Times pressman. Beloved husband of Annabelle. Father of Lawrence, Steven, and Justine. Stepfather of Alan and Barry Rosenberg. Grandfather of Joy Albin, Jason, Lindsay, Cheryl, Allicia, & Ian Rosenberg. Brother of Philip Albin and Stella Smith, and nieces, nephews, and cousins in the Albin family. Funeral on Wednesday, September 26th, 10:30AM, Star of David Chapel, Bailey Road, Fort Lauderdale, Florida.

title: An Atmosphere Charged With Anger and Fear; Ways of Fighting
description: To the Editor:

title: Levy Orders Review of Schools' Crisis Plans, Citing Communications
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he was concerned that evacuation plans and public address systems were not adequate at some schools on the the day of the World Trade Center attack. He announced that he would appoint a task force to review the school system's emergency plans.

title: Liberties In a Time Of Fear
description: In the wake of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, nothing is more important than ensuring that Americans are protected on our home soil. But in doing so, we must not let the symbolic need to do something in a time of fear lead us to sacrifice our constitutional commitments to freedom.

title: A Freshman and His Inner Geek
description: Like some cocky television phoenix, this season's best new comedy is born from one of last year's notable flops. Judd Apatow, the executive producer of last season's much loved, quickly canceled ''Freaks and Geeks,'' about high school in the 80's, has came back with ''Undeclared,'' a warm, perceptive, extremely funny show about college freshman facing the most ordinary adjustments. Though it is set today, ''Undeclared'' is essentially ''Freaks and Geeks'' in college.

title: Tunnel Vision; Heavy-Duty Lifters Rushed From the Tracks to the Towers
description: When the words ''rescue and recovery'' are heard, the people who run and repair the 722 miles of the New York City subway are not the first to come to mind.

title: Crime Down 18% as Murders Fall in a City Stunned by Wholesale Death
description: Even as New Yorkers remain jittery over unseen perils, they are nonetheless living in a city that, in terms of crime, has become measurably safer in the last two weeks, according to statistics released yesterday.

title: Pope Condemns Extremism Behind Terror
description: At a meeting with local artists and scientists, Pope John Paul II drew a sharp distinction tonight between ''authentic Islam'' and the extremism that led to the recent terrorist attacks in the United States.

title: Dollar General's Shares Tumble
description: The Dollar General Corporation's shares fell 24 percent, after the company, a discount retailer, said it fired its auditor, Deloitte & Touche, without giving a reason. Shares fell $3.52, to $11.25.

title: New Trouble for Swissair Means a New Revamping
description: The Swissair Group, its precarious finances hit hard by the slump in travel, said today that it would take radical steps to reorganize by reducing its work force and its long-haul flight schedule.

title: Footlights
description: Beauty Beheld

title: An Atmosphere Charged With Anger and Fear; Church and State
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEHRINGER, CHARLES
description: WEHRINGER-Charles. On September 24, 2001. Survived by sister, Janet, of FL, and lifelong friend, Warren Eisenberg, NYC and FL.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Long-Distance Test A Success
description: A group of technology companies has announced a successful test of a network that enables the storage and transfer of data over long distances. The effort, known as the Promontory Project, after the site where America's first transcontinental railroad was connected, demonstrated that large amounts of data can be moved as fast as 10 billion bits a second. The companies say that the network will be essential for managing storage challenges like rolling power failures. Such storage transfers that use Internet protocol connections typically degrade over long distances. But the group said it was able to overcome those limitations. Data centers are usually within 100 miles of their customers. In this test, data was transferred from Newark to Sunnyvale, Calif. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: AOL, Blaming Terrorist Attacks, Says It Will Fall Far Short of Its Goals
description: AOL Time Warner Inc., the world's biggest media company, announced yesterday that it would badly miss its financial goals for the year, largely because the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks exacerbated the erosion of the advertising market.

title: Fusion's Preki Proves His Doubters Wrong
description: BOB GANSLER, the coach of the Kansas City Wizards, the defending champions in Major League Soccer, rarely makes mistakes in evaluating players.

title: Muddle Over Arafat-Peres Meeting Is Frustrating for Bush
description: It has been 11 days since President Bush urged Israeli and Palestinian leaders to sit down immediately and hammer out a truce in their yearlong conflict. During that time, one thing has remained constant here: no meeting.

title: Two Works Offered Appropriately for a Time of Stress
description: As the classical music season gets under way, performers have been reconsidering their programs, trying to find meaningful, moving and soul-healing ways to respond to the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. But the program announced last spring by Les Violons du Roy, a modern-instrument chamber orchestra, and La Chapelle de Qubec, a choir, for their Saturday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall needed no tweaking. The first half of the concert was devoted to Haydn's ''Lord Nelson'' Mass, a work composed during the Napoleonic wars and originally called ''Missa in Angustiis,'' ''Mass in Time of Stress.'' After the intermission the ensembles performed the Mozart Requiem.

title: He's Deep In the Heart Of New York
description: The accent is pure Texas, the twang hitching the words together like a fist-sized belt buckle holding up a pair of jeans. Roger Clemens wears cowboy boots and a few dungaree shirts and loves George Strait, and after seeing a show on Broadway he will walk around Times Square, drawn to the bright lights that are hardly noticed by lifelong New Yorkers.

title: An Atmosphere Charged With Anger and Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: House Approves $582 Million For Back Dues Owed to U.N.
description: The House voted today to release $582 million that the United States owes in back dues to the United Nations, ending a long-running squabble with the organization at a time when the Bush administration says international cooperation is needed to battle terrorism.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Phone Concern Plans Charge
description: British Telecommunications said it would take a 500 million ($730 million) charge this quarter to write down the value of some assets, and warned that it would face large costs should it decide to close Concert, its joint venture with AT&T. Shuttering the unit, which provides long-distance phone and data services to multinational corporations, is only one option, the company said. Another is to keep it running on a smaller scale. A decision is expected by year-end. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYNNE, KENNETH JR.
description: WYNNE-Kenneth Jr. Age 78 of Vero Beach, FL, and formerly of Hamden, CT and Mantoloking, NJ died September 16, 2001 after a prolonged illness. He was the husband of the late Patricia FitzGerald Wynne. Mr. Wynne was born in New Haven, CT and was the son of the late Judge Kenneth Wynne, a former Chief Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, and the late Mary Fielding Wynne. He was President of Venice Amusement Corporation that owns and operates the Casino Pier and Water Works in Seaside Heights, NJ from 1959 to 1987 when he retired. Mr. Wynne is a Past President of the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions and continued to serve on the Associations's Board of Directors until his death. He was also a Past President of the New Jersey Amusement Association and the Seaside Heights Businessmen's Association. Recognized as one of the people responsible for the importation of spectacular European amusement rides into the United States, Mr. Wynne was considered a pioneer in the Amusement Industry. Prior to his involvement in the amusement business, Mr. Wynne was a staff reporter for the Bridgeport, CT Herald. Secretary of the CT Bar Association, and served as Executive Secretary to former Connecticut Governor Chester Bowles. He was also a Director and Producer for WNHC Television in New Haven, CT. Mr. Wynne was a member of the Quinnipiack Club and Mory's Association in New Haven, CT. and the Moorings Club of Vero Beach. He attended Hopkins Grammar School in New Haven, CT. and graduated from St. John's School in Danvers, MA. Mr. Wynne was a 1948 graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, CT. where he was a member of the US Navy V-12 Program. He served on active duty with the US Navy in World War II and was honorably discharged after which he completed his college degree. Mr. Wynne is survived by his four children: Deborah Wynne Stockton (Robert), Kenneth Wynne III (Allyson) both of Vero Beach, FL ; Patricia Wynne Dayton (Richard) of Fair Oaks, CA; and John F. Wynne (Susan) of Pt. Pleasant Beach, NJ. He is also survived by six grandchildren: Natalie Lewis Dougherty of Hoboken, NJ; John R. Lewis, Jr. of New York, NY; Draper Dayton and Kenneth Dayton of Fair Oaks, CA; Patricia Ellen Wynne of Pt. Pleasant, NJ ; and Jesse Carano of Dahlgren, VA. Also survived by one brother and four sisters: John Wynne, Branford, CT; Barbara Secor, Southbury, CT; Betsy Wynne, Branford, CT; Mary Bohonnon, Guilford, CT; and Louise Gigon, Wethersfield, CT. For information Sisk Brothers Funeral Home, 3105 Whitney Avenue, Hamden, CT. Friends may call Friday, September 28th from 4-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Saturday, September 29th at 11:30 AM in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, Whitney Ave., Hamden, CT. Burial will follow in St. Mary's Cemetery, Mount Carmel, CT. In Mr. Wynne's memory, memorial donations may be made to Give Kids the World, 210 Bass Road, Kissimmee, FL 34746.

title: ATMOS ENERGY AGREES TO BUY MISSISSIPPI VALLEY GAS
description: The Atmos Energy Corporation, which distributes natural gas in 11 states, agreed to buy the Mississippi Valley Gas Company for $150 million in cash and stock. Atmos agreed to pay $75 million in cash and issue $75 million in stock to purchase the company, which is the biggest natural gas distributor in Mississippi. Atmos will also assume $45 million in debt. Mississippi Valley, which is privately held, is based in Jackson, Miss. Atmos is based in Dallas.

title: Fuller Tally of Vote in Poland Shows Victors Need Coalition

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Mosquito Copters Grounded
description: A government ban on low-flying aircraft around major airports has grounded helicopters in the Newark area used to spray breeding grounds for mosquitoes that may carry the West Nile virus, Peter Pluchino, Jr., the mosquito control director of Bergen County, said yesterday. Mr. Pluchino said he did not expect the ban to put New Jersey residents in danger because the mosquito-breeding season is nearly at an end. Unlike the two-day nationwide ban expected to be lifted today on all crop-dusting aircraft, the ban against low-flying aircraft near major airports will remain in effect indefinitely, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration said. title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: U.S. Gets Kazakh-Case Evidence
description: Justice authorities said they had sent evidence to American investigators concerning some of the 13 bank accounts blocked on suspicion of corrupt activities by United States oil companies in Kazakhstan. Folco Galli, a Justice Department spokesman, confirmed that information had been sent last week about possible transfers to Swiss accounts of money belonging to Kazakh officials. Swiss court documents indicate the investigation centers on payments to the Kazakh president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, and other senior officials from an American identified as ''G.'' title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, BRIAN JOSEPH
description: MURPHY-Brian Joseph. Devoted husband of Judith Bram Murphy, active and loving father of Jessica and Leila, beloved son of Harold and Christina, adored brother of Ann, Harold and Cynthia, cherished son-in-law of William and Jane Eisner Bram, dearly beloved nephew of Marguerite, dear brother-in-law of Steven Eisner Bram and Elizabeth and Eric Rothstein, and wonderful uncle to Joshua, Danielle, Zachary, and Callahan and fantastic and loyal friend of hundreds, perished in the tragic events that took place on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. Brian graduated from the Wilbraham and Monson Academy Class of 1976, Williams College Class of 1980, and the Columbia University School of Business Class of 1987. He was a Vice President at Cantor Fitzgerald/eSpeed Division and a partner in his family's ReMAX Real Estate Company. Brian's life was filled with family, integrity, loyalty and acts of kindness. A man of high morals and solid principles, his faith in God, family, and love was unshakable. He will be deeply missed by all those he touched. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Vincent Ferrer Catholic Church on Lexington Avenue and 66th Street on Tuesday, September 25 at 3:30 P.M. Donations may be made to Williams College, the Brian J. Murphy Class of 1980 Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 231, Williamstown, Massachusetts 01267.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Deep Cuts At Excite
description: The At Home Corporation, the beleaguered high-speed Internet access and Internet portal company, said that it would eliminate 500 jobs, or 27 percent of its work force, scaling back much of its remaining business tied to advertising. The company, which does business as Excite@Home, will close its MatchLogic division, a unit focused on Internet advertising and e-mail marketing. MatchLogic, based in Westminster, Colo., employed 200 people. It will also eliminate 300 employees working on the Excite portal. Excite will continue to offer basic services including Internet search, e-mail, news and stock quotes. At Home, which is controlled by AT&T, has said it does not have enough cash to remain in business.

title: Proposal to Arm Pilots Gets Mixed Reaction
description: The president of the nation's largest union of airline pilots told Congress today that his members should be allowed to take an F.B.I. training course and then be deputized as federal law enforcement officers, steps that would permit them to carry guns in the cockpit. But the idea got mixed reviews from other aviation experts and from members of Congress.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Bank Acquired
description: Mexico's fourth-largest bank, Banorte, said that it would purchase the government-owned Bancrecer for $175 million. Bancrecer was Mexico's sixth-largest bank before it went bankrupt and was bailed out by the government in 1995. With the purchase, expected to be completed in December, Banorte will still be Mexico's fourth-largest bank, and the only major player that is entirely Mexican-owned. Graham Gori (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLINAN, JOAN MCCONNELL (NEE JOUDZEVICH)
description: CULLINAN-Joan McConnell (nee Joudzevich). Loving wife, stepmother, daughter, sister, aunt, friend. Assistant to the President, Cantor Fitzgerald. Victim of the terrorist attack at the World Trade Center. Joan was born in Brooklyn on August 12, 1954, and was a graduate of St. Vincent Ferrer High School in NYC and Pace University (Psychology 2001). Joan's business career included positions at AT&T, Merrill Lynch, Paine Webber, TeleTV, Lehman Brothers. Her husband, Tom Cullinan and stepsons, John and Will Cullinan of Scarsdale, NY; mother, Bee Savage Joudzevich of Annapolis MD; sisters Blaise Joudzevich of NYC and Brenda Green of Staten Island; brother-in-law Raoul Edwards, and nieces Caitlin and Allison Green of Staten Island, survive Joan. Joan was a most loyal and valuable friend to all who knew her. She was mentor and confidant to numerous women in business and personal areas. Joan recently made plans to enter graduate school to pursue a CSW degree to allow her to become a psychotherapist. She and Tom began the process to adopt a baby from China just days before her murder. Her love, humor, intelligence, caring and generous spirit will be forever with us. We love you Joanie, and we miss you. There will be a Mass of the Resurrection and Memorial Service at St. Paul's Church, 60th Street and Columbus Avenue, NYC at noon on Saturday, September 29, 2001. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Joan Cullinan Memorial Scholarship Fund 14 Whistler Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSER, CARMEN ANGLETON

In 1939 she edited the 5th edition of the poetry magazine, ''Furioso'', along with her brother, James J. Angleton and E. Reed Whittemore, Married Ernest Hauser 1947. Lived in Rome 1947-2001, traveling extensively with her husband in eastern Europe, the middle east, and Mediterranean countries. She was fluent in Greek and Latin and several modern languages and greatly aided other writers in their understanding of Italian and other cultures. She leaves four nephews, two nieces and several grand nieces and nephews. To be buried in Boise, Idaho. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to the American Academy, Rome, Italy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Military Funds To Increase
description: German military spending is to increase over the next few years, Defense Minister Rudolf Scharping said in an interview with the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. The interview was published as Parliament was due to resume its 2002 budget debate, suspended since Sept. 11. Mr. Scharping announced that the army would receive an additional $700 million per year. Germany is often criticized by its NATO partners for not spending enough on defense. The draft 2002 budget foresaw spending of $22 billion for defense, about 1.2 percent of Germany's gross domestic product. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Cuts 2,300 Jobs
description: Advanced Micro Devices said yesterday that it would close two semiconductor-fabrication plants in Austin, Tex., and eliminate a total of 2,300 jobs, or 15 percent of its global work force. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would take a third-quarter charge of as much as $110 million to cover the costs of the cuts, which it said were expected to save $125 million a year in operating costs. Separately, the PC maker Gateway Inc. said it had stopped buying microprocessors from Advanced Micro in favor of its larger rival, Intel. A Gateway spokeswoman attributed the decision to Gateway's efforts to save money by simplifying PC product lines and relationships with component suppliers. Advanced Micro's shares fell 76 cents, or 9.8 percent, to $9.05. Chris Gaither (NYT)

Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. John D. Martin, President

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about strains in relations between Saudi Arabia and the United States misattributed the report that a top Air Force general had been sent to Saudi Arabia to oversee air attacks against Afghanistan. The assignment was disclosed by military officials, not formally announced by the Pentagon.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Worldcom Seeks Rhythms Assets
description: WorldCom Inc. said yesterday that it had submitted a $40 million bid for some of the assets of Rhythms NetConnections, a bankrupt provider of high-speed Internet service. WorldCom, based in Clinton, Miss., said its bid would enable Rhythms to continue supplying businesses with digital subscriber line service. Rhythms had already received permission from the Federal Communications Commission to shut down its network. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Normalcy In the Morning
description: ''Good Morning America'' tipped back toward normality on Monday morning, squeezing an interview with the newly crowned Miss America, Katie Harman, between segments on the Sept. 11 attack and its aftermath.

title: Schrder Urges Milder View Of Moscow Role in Chechnya
description: Western nations today gave a first indication of the price they may be ready to pay for Russian support in the fight against terrorism as Gerhard Schrder, the German chancellor, said the world should moderate its view of Moscow's actions in Chechnya.

title: World Business Briefing | Pacific: Australia: Job Cuts At Retailer
description: Australia's largest retailer, Coles Myer Ltd., will lay off 1,000 workers as part of a large-scale plan to cut costs and improve earnings. John Fletcher, who became chief executive two weeks ago, said realigning the general merchandise and apparel division would save at least 90 million Australian dollars ($44 million) a year by the end of 2004, about one-fifth the company's annual earnings. Coles Myer plans to centralize systems to shore up sagging department store operations, which include Target and Kmart. The company takes in 20 cents of every retail dollar spent in Australia. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: The Interrupted Primary
description: New Yorkers finally completed the primary election yesterday that was interrupted by the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. For many, the very exercise of voting, going back to finish what was started, offered some comfort and pride. Another necessary piece of our democratic infrastructure remained intact, ready for probable runoff elections on Oct. 11 and a general election Nov. 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGEN, SOL
description: BOGEN-Sol. Passed away suddenly on September 22, 2001, at the age of 71. Native of Philadelphia, longtime resident of New Rochelle, Manhattan and, more recently, East Hampton. Cherished father of Kimberlee, Claudia, Melissa and Kristina; treasured grandfather of Katherine, Nicholas and Daniel; beloved partner of Helane Grill; dearest brother of Sara; admired father-in-law of Michael Sullivan. Attended Kenyon College, graduated Columbia Law School 1954. Spent a lifetime of practice specializing in labor law. A private family service was held September 25, 2001. A memorial service will be held in Manhattan at a later date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to The Sol Bogen Classic Studies Scholarship Fund, Kenyon College, Development Office, Gambier, OH. 43022, attention: Mr. Russ Geiger.

title: An Old-World Explorer
description: IN America, Greek cuisine seems to exist on two planes. There is its old form, steeped in ''classics'' like moussaka, baklava and seemingly anything stuffed into phyllo layered with butter. And there is the new form, which tends toward a Mediterranean diet and foods that appeal to modern diners, like tangy tzatziki, eggplant caviar and expensive fish grilled and sprinkled with olive oil. It seems implausible that one country could have such vastly different styles of cooking.

title: Rice Pudding on the Run
description: While on Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, one scorching day last summer, I stopped at Moe's, a Mexican takeout spot, for a cold tamarind drink. The scent of sweet spices and fried dough wafted through the air. A man held a foil pouch containing what looked like a flat calzone with a creamy filling. It was a rice pudding empanada, and I had to try one.

title: The Magic Is Missing as Bonds Approaches 70
description: The instant Barry Bonds's 67th home run darted into the right-field seats at Dodger Stadium Monday night, there was only a mild scrum for the ball.

title: In a whole new climate, the networks scramble to review and revise their own fall promotions.
description: AS the big broadcast networks work frantically to accommodate marketers that must change, postpone or cancel advertising after the terrorist attacks, they are also scrambling to change, postpone or cancel advertising of their own: the elaborate and expensive campaigns to promote the series they will offer for the 2001-2002 prime-time season.

title: Downtown: A Triumph to Reopen, a Struggle to Fill Tables
description: FOR more than a week, most of the restaurants in TriBeCa and the financial district -- including some of the city's most vibrant and popular -- were completely shut down, or devoted to feeding rescue workers and the stalwart people who remained in the neighborhood.

description: Brian Nielsen may be little known in the United States, but what he lacks in name recognition he makes up for in confidence.

description: The Vast Arsenal Against a Shadowy Foe

description: DOES it have to take so long?

description: CLARKE-Christopher ''Buddha'' Mass to celebrate his life Friday, September 28, 12 noon, St. Thomas of Villanova Parish Church, University Campus, Villanova, PA. Donations: Christopher Robert Clarke Scholarship Fund, St. Joe's Prep School, 1733 Girard Ave, Philadelphia, PA 19130.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHFIELD, ROBERT L.
description: HIRSHFIELD-Robert L. September 23, 2001. Loving husband of Harriet, devoted father of Laurie and Jane, dear brother of Jack and sister-in-law Molly. We miss you very much. Private family service.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about people missing in the World Trade Center attack misstated the given name of a Bronx man who was at a breakfast conference at Windows on the World and had recently dropped off his wife's wedding ring at a jeweler known only to him. He is Jeffrey Mark Dingle, not John.

title: An Exhibit On Campus Celebrates Grisly Deed
description: The students did as they were told and today tried to tone down, to the extent such a thing is possible, an exhibit here that celebrates a suicide bombing.

title: Sun Online ID Set to Compete With Microsoft
description: Sun Microsystems is expected to announce an online identification initiative today, presenting it as an alternative to Microsoft's Passport system.
