description: To the Editor:

title: Another Big Supermarket Stock Is Punished on Tokyo Exchange
description: Fearful that Japan's largest supermarket chain, Daiei, may be sliding down the same slope that claimed a major rival 10 days ago, investors rushed to dump its stock as trading resumed after a three-day holiday weekend.

title: Staten Island Mourns Its Heavy Losses; Home to 5% of the City's Population, but 20% of Missing Firefighters
description: Each Saturday after Labor Day, the Staten Island Athletic Club holds a race in memory of Marty Celic, a firefighter who died on the job, at age 23, in 1977. In recent years, Marty's younger brother, Tom, has popularized the race, shortening the distance from 10 miles to 4 and providing plenty of beer at the finish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, NEIL D.
description: LEVIN-Neil D. Our uncle, our friend. We honor, respect and love you. The pain in our hearts is overwhelming. Adam and Kimmy Levin

title: New Chief for Royal Theater
description: The film and theater director Nicholas Hytner has been appointed to succeed Trevor Nunn as director of the Royal National Theater in London. He will take over in April 2003 for a period of five years.

title: Helping the Youngest Victims
description: The attacks of Sept. 11 took the lives of thousands of loving parents. Perhaps 15,000 children, to judge by early estimates, have lost a father or mother. In many cases, that person was a single parent. In New York City the immediate relief effort has been comprehensive and well organized. But the city and state must undertake a complete follow-through to help children and surviving parents after emergency conditions have subsided.

title: From Political Shadows to Center Stage, Giuliani Stays in Character
description: Long before terrorists slammed planes into the World Trade Center, Rudolph W. Giuliani cast a distinct shadow over the mayoral election, formed largely by the good times that had become, rightly or wrongly, synonymous with his name. Now, that shadow has been recast by the bad times in ways that are much more troubling for the men who would be mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORMISTON, KENWORTHY, VIRGI NIA (GINGER)
description: ORMISTON - KENWORTHY - Virgi nia (Ginger). Victim of the September 11, 2001 tragic attack on the World Trade Center. Wife of Jim Kenworthy and mother of Beth and Bill. Survived by her mother, Jeanette, and sisters, Nancy and Sarah. A memorial service will be held at 1:00 PM Saturday, September 29, at the First Presbyterian Church, 12 West 12 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations be made to police or fireman rescue funds.

title: W.W.F. Meets the Web: It's a Body Slam!
description: THE phone rings and it's someone from Shopzone on Wwf.com, the Web site of the World Wrestling Federation. Seems my 10-year-old son has ordered $400 of wrestling merchandise and all they need is his credit card number. I stomp back to our home office and find him sitting in front of the computer, gazing at pictures of scantily clad female wrestlers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ISAAC
description: STERN-Isaac. 81, violinist, died on Saturday, September 22 in New York City. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, friend and mentor. Above all, he was a musician, with a legacy that left an indelible mark on generations of audiences worldwide. Devoted lover of Israel, champion of Carnegie Hall, ardent supporter of countless musical and educational causes, and consummate teacher to generations of young colleagues, he led by example and made a difference to New York, Israel and the world. Survived by his wife, Linda; his children by his previous marriage to Vera Lindenblit, Shira and Don, Michael and Jeannette, and David and Katta; his grandchildren, Noah, Ari, Eytan, Sophia and Talia; and his sister Eva Hornyak and family. Arrangements made by the Mount Sinai Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. Funeral private, memorial concert to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Carnegie Hall Isaac Stern Education Fund.

title: A Syncopated Laptop Joins the Combo
description: Jazz has bumped up against a lot of different kinds of music in the last 40 years, almost immediately creating new genres on contact. But one area that seems surprisingly cordoned off from it is electro-acoustic improvisation: the fairly new, fully abstract music that tends to include one musician busily writing code and generating sounds on a laptop computer.

title: NATO Chief Urges Macedonia to Carry Out Terms of Peace Pact
description: NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, arrived here today and urged Macedonian politicians to help keep the country's peace effort on track by ratifying constitutional changes and passing an amnesty for ethnic Albanian rebels.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Air Service Bid Dropped
description: The French construction company Vinci abandoned its $754 million offer for TBI, which manages London Luton among other airports. Vinci said it received fewer than 90 percent of TBI's shares as of the deadline, which was 3 p.m. on Monday, allowing it to drop the offer. TBI's board recommended the bid last week, after initially rejecting it. In bidding for TBI, Vinci had intended to expand its airport concession business as a way to offset wide swings in earnings at its construction operations.

title: Venture Capital Financing Is Further Sapped by Events
description: Venture capital investing, the high-risk financing of early-stage companies that has been markedly curtailed in the last year, is being further challenged in light of the recent terrorist attacks and growing signs of recession, those investors say.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEHN, PATRICK E.
description: KEHN-Patrick E. April 4, 1943 to September 26, 1981 When clouds flew past the moon and called to lovers everywhere it was a song I did not understand and never have forgotten. Gregory

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: European Court Finds Rights Abuses
description: The European Court of Human Rights has ruled that Turkey denied a fair and timely trial to 16 suspected members of a militant far-left group who were held for years while awaiting a verdict. The court awarded the plaintiffs, all Turkish nationals, a total of $165,000 in damages plus costs and expenses. Turkey, which has been told that it must push through constitutional changes to improve its human rights record if it wants to join the European Union, will now be called on to give its response to the judgment. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: After Attacks, The Shows Flying In Mostly Go On
description: The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra is keeping its three dates at Carnegie Hall, starting with the season-opening performance of Beethoven's ''Eroica'' on Oct. 3. Four arts groups from Australia -- comprising 150 people -- will be flying in on schedule for the monthlong Next Wave Down Under Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which starts on Tuesday. At the Joyce Theater, only one dance troupe has canceled a performance this fall, and that was the Compagnie Marie Chouinard, part of the ill-fated Quebec-New York 2001 festival, which was to have been based in the World Financial Center, now damaged by the terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETTLER, LEON J.
description: BRETTLER-Leon J. Died suddenly on September 23rd. Beloved husband of Jacqueline, loving father of Doug and Martha, Michael and Danielle, devoted grandfather of Andrea & Caroline. Graduated MIT. Served two years in the U.S. Army during WWII. Chairman of the Board of Shapiro, Bernstein Music Publishing, served on the Board of Directors of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP) and the National Music Publishers Association (NMPA) for over thirty years.

title: Telecom Concern Trims Outlook
description: Time Warner Telecom, which sells telephone and Internet services to businesses, said today that third-quarter sales would be less than analysts expected, as customers canceled service and delayed payments. Its shares fell 42 percent, their worst one-day plunge.

title: In Denver, Airline Jobs Continue to Dwindle
description: When the planes crashed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, Ken Pabst was on vacation from his job as a reservation agent for Continental Airlines. He and the other members of his bluegrass band, High Plains Tradition, were at a music festival in Winfield, Kan.

title: Maryland Campus Reels From Tornado That Killed Sisters
description: The University of Maryland began to recover today from a tornado that ripped across campus on Monday evening, killing two students, damaging several buildings and tearing up hundreds of trees.

title: Brokers Try Again for Shared Listings
description: A group of 39 Manhattan real estate brokers has decided to try again to create a shared Web site for residential real estate. Most of these brokers were part of other groups that tried -- and failed -- to create a multiple listing service and Web site over the past two years.

title: New Cutbacks at International Airlines
description: The effects of the terror attacks in the United States and the disruption in air travel that followed continued to ripple through the global airline industry yesterday, with new announcements of cutbacks and government assistance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULLMAN, ROSE C.
description: PULLMAN-Rose C. Devoted wife of the late Irving T. Adored mother of Phyllis L. Donations may be made to the LI Jewish Dialysis Program or a charity of your choice. Services Wednesday, 10:30AM at Schwartz Bros. Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, MICHAEL PATRICK
description: TUCKER-Michael Patrick. On September 11th, 40, of Rumson, NJ was taken from his family too soon in a senseless act that changed our lives forever. He started his career in a basement of a bank to become, 12 years later, a Sr. V.P., a Partner and one of the top traders at Cantor Fitzgerald. Survived by his wife Mary Beth (nee Rozniak Tucker) and four daughters: Taylor, Gaffney, Andy and Morgan. Mother and Father: Dr. Thomas and Mrs. Joan Tucker, sisters, Susan and brotherin-law Bill Jenkins, Cathy Tucker, Maureen Tucker; brothers, John and sister-in-law Tara Tucker, Chris and sister-in-law Herta Tucker. Maternal grandmother, Dorothy Williams. Father and motherin-law; Ron and June Bulka Rozniak; brother-in-law, Ronald Rozniak; sister-in-law, Meg Chaykowsky. A memorial gathering will be held at the Navesink Country Club, Lufborrow Lane, Navesink Section of Middletown, NJ, September 30, 2001, 11-3 pm. The Memorial Mass will be held at Holy Cross Church, Rumson, NJ on Monday, October 1, 2001 at 11 am. In lieu of flowers memorial donations can be made to the Tucker Girls Education Fund, P.O. Box 46, Rumson, NJ 07760

title: What About the Taliban's Stingers?
description: PARIS  Taliban forces in Afghanistan are reported to have up to 100 shoulder-fired Stingers, the U.S.-made missile with the deadliest record against low-flying aircraft of any weapon since World War II.

title: How Voter Survey Was Conducted
description: The Election Day survey was based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting polls throughout New York City yesterday. Questionnaires were available in English or Spanish.

title: A Time of Gifts
description: The patterns of human history mix decency and depravity in equal measure. We often assume, therefore, that such a fine balance of results must emerge from societies made of decent and depraved people in equal numbers. But we need to expose and celebrate the fallacy of this conclusion so that, in this moment of crisis, we may reaffirm an essential truth too easily forgotten, and regain some crucial comfort too readily forgone. Good and kind people outnumber all others by thousands to one. The tragedy of human history lies in the enormous potential for destruction in rare acts of evil, not in the high frequency of evil people. Complex systems can only be built step by step, whereas destruction requires but an instant. Thus, in what I like to call the Great Asymmetry, every spectacular incident of evil will be balanced by 10,000 acts of kindness, too often unnoted and invisible as the ''ordinary'' efforts of a vast majority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARL, DAVID
description: PEARL-David. For our Uncle David. To my sister Mona, her children and grandchildren. We both share your grief at this time of David's passing and only hope that memories of good times you've shared, from the first Lindy's cheesecake to your many construction projects, will bring you eventual peace. Still, we'll all miss him. With much love to your family. George, Margie and Family.

title: A Last Hurrah for Mamma Leone's, Paintings, Sculpture and All
description: There was a real Mamma Leone, Luisa Leone. She opened her first little restaurant, called Mamma Leone's from the start, in the theater district in 1906. The restaurant grew into a tourist destination, serving 4,000 meals a day -- for many years on West 48th Street and then on West 44th -- before closing in 1994. Many of the paintings, sculptures and decorative furnishings from Mamma Leone's will be sold at auction at 10 a.m. next Wednesday at Doyle New York, 175 East 87th Street. The works include ''The Long Awaited Dish'' by Gaetano Bellei, right, estimated to bring $20,000 to $30,000. The artworks will be on display at the auction house from Saturday through Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, PETER GUYDER
description: WALLACE-Peter Guyder, 66, of Lincoln Park, NJ, in the tragedy of Sep. 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. VP Marsh Risk Services. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Father of Alison Smith, Pequannock, NJ and Reagan Koniuch, Kings Park, NY. Father-in-law to Steven Smith and Peter Koniuch. Grandfather of Andy, Zachary, Kristen, Lauren and Benjamin. Memorial Service, Sat., Sep. 29, 4 pm, First Presbyterian Church at 5th Ave and 12th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to First Presbyterian Church, 12 W. 12th St. NYC, 10011.

title: Yankees' Comments Bother Valentine
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine was bothered by comments from Yankees Manager Joe Torre and reliever Mike Stanton that seemed to suggest the Mets were wrong to publicize some of their charitable contributions to victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Strangers Shower Gifts on Schools
description: The offerings, from as far away as Oregon, Tennessee, Canada and France, started pouring in the morning after the attack. A thousand teddy bears from Oklahoma City, delivered to Manhattan in a tractor-trailer. Nearly 5,000 backpacks from a school supplies company. Fifty dollars from a child in Queens who gave up her birthday party to contribute to the cause.

title: Islamic Aid Organization Expresses Anger at Its Inclusion on Bush Terror List
description: In ever needy Afghanistan, Al Rashid Trust is one of the biggest doers of good deeds, rebuilding roads, feeding the poor, providing limbs to amputees and supplying sewing machines to widows so they can eke out a living.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STANSFIELD, SUSAN P.
description: STANSFIELD-Susan P. On July 12, 2001. Beloved mother of Lindsey Stansfield Pryor. Cherished grandmother of Christina, Toni, Sam and Jack Pryor. Memorial Mass on Thursday, September 27, 2001 at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave. at 76th St.,10 A.M. Reception to follow

title: Airlines Adopt Check-Everything Policy
description: For air travelers and flight crews, there seems to be no such thing as an overreaction in the days since Sept. 11.

title: Business Travel; Things aren't what they used to be, as airlines and their employees pull themselves together.
description: IT seems like a long time ago, but it wasn't much more than a week, on one of the first days when the airports were back in business after Sept. 11.

title: Look Toward Green Bay to See Jets' Failings
description: Jets fans who watched ''Monday Night Football'' saw something they had been looking for all season. In the third quarter, Green Bay receiver Bill Schroeder broke toward the middle on a quick slant. Brett Favre took a three-step drop, hit Schroeder in stride with a short pass and Schroeder was gone for a 41-yard touchdown.

title: Columbia Picks a Chairman
description: Columbia University has named DAVID STERN, left, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, as the new chairman of its board of trustees, succeeding STEPHEN FRIEDMAN, who was chairman for four years. Mr. Stern graduated from Columbia Law School in 1966 and has been a Columbia trustee since 1992. He was vice chairman of Columbia's trustees and chairman of the second phase of the university's $2.8 billion, 10-year capital campaign, which was completed last year. KAREN W. ARENSON

title: Bush Expected to Reveal Plan to Bolster Airline Security
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 — President Bush will announce a plan on Thursday to strengthen aircraft cockpit doors and for the federal government to take a more direct role in screening passengers at airports, according to administration officials.

description: BASEBALL

title: Once Appalled by Race Profiling, Many Find Themselves Doing It
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 22  Ron Arnold understands racial profiling. "I'm a black American, and I've been racially profiled all my life," said Mr. Arnold, a 43-year-old security officer here, "and it's wrong."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASPER, CHARLES L.
description: KASPER-Charles L. Deputy Chief, F.D.N.Y. Beloved husband of Laureen. Devoted father of Melissa and Mark Friedman, Kara Kasper and Michael. Adoring ''Granddaddy'' to Dylan Friedman. A 28 year veteran of the F.D.N.Y. Recently promoted to Deputy Chief. He reported in from his home the morning of the World Trade Center disaster. Chief Kasper arrived at the Command Post prior to the collapse. He was last seen directing Fire Operations in the North Tower. There will be a memorial service in his honor on Friday September 28, 2001 at the Veterans Memorial Hall, 1000 Richmond Terrace at Snug Harbor on Staten Island.

title: Wizards Add a Legend And Gain Credibility
description: When the Return became official yesterday, those who must contend with Michael Jordan left little doubt that he would again be a force.

title: Sense of Loss Mars Yanks' Division Championship
description: The Yankees were on the verge of clinching a division title last night, but a raucous celebration seemed wrong to them. Wrong time, wrong place; this was the Yankees' first home game since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Pulling the Plug on Big Ed's Live Music Webcasts
description: A YEAR ago Jeffrey M. Cotton was broadcasting live music from Big Ed's roadhouse in Reno, Nev., on the World Wide Web. For a heady season last summer and fall, Big Ed's was on a par with the Kennedy Center's Millennium Stage in Washington, the Great American Music Hall in San Francisco, the House of Blues chain and the Digital Club Network -- all of which were putting live music online.

title: Runs, Hits and Healing at Stadium
description: The fans knew it was supposed to be business as usual last night. But there were more than a few things that just did not feel quite right to them.

The assignment was disclosed by military officials, not formally announced by the Pentagon.

description: RODRIGUES PEREIRA-Reverend Dr. Martin M. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to his family. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: First Lady Salutes Protectors of New York Schoolchildren
description: Laura Bush, the first lady, returned to New York City yesterday and to her signature issue, education. But her message differed from those of previous visits with schoolchildren and teachers, shaded now by the cloud of grief that has hung over the city since the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: A Literary Landmark
description: A self-described ''writer of songs and nonsense,'' Margaret Wise Brown was the author of popular children's picture books, particularly ''Goodnight Moon'' and ''The Runaway Bunny.'' In the mid-1930's she enrolled in the Bank Street College of Education's teacher-training program in Manhattan, where she decided she wanted to write children's books. In recognition of its relationship to the writer, the college was designated a literary landmark last Wednesday by an organization that promotes libraries, Friends of Libraries U.S.A. The designation was sponsored by Books for Kids HarperCollins Publishers. LEONARD S. MARCUS, who wrote a biography of Ms. Brown, spoke at the ceremony.

title: Asian Flair and a Side of People-Watching
description: ON paper, Thom has all the credentials for hip, downtown success. It's in a slickly designed new SoHo hotel, 60 Thompson Street. The partners have already stamped their passports with Indochine and Bond Street, so they know how to please the right crowd. The chef is Jonathan Eismann, formerly of China Grill and more recently the much-applauded chef and owner of Pacific Time in Miami Beach, one of the first, and best, of the new-wave restaurants that made South Beach look like a serious dining destination for a while. He is, in his spare time, a professional model.

title: With Berman Set to Concede, Thompson Seems to Be Victor
description: William C. Thompson Jr. appeared to have won the Democratic primary for city comptroller last night, edging out Herbert E. Berman in a tight and hard-fought race.

title: The Specter of Biological Terror
description: The terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon have ratcheted up fears that an even more terrible assault could lie ahead -- this time with biological or chemical agents. Nothing that happened on Sept. 11 has changed the underlying reality that biological and chemical weapons are extremely difficult to make and disperse. But the attacks have changed our perception of the malevolence and determination of today's terrorists. The suicidal zealotry of the men who flew airliners into buildings, their willingness to prepare for years, their desire for mass casualties and their deep-seated hatred of Americans leave little doubt that they would escalate to even more dreadful weapons if they could.

title: Win or Lose, for No. 22 It Was a Special Day
description: The day was unusual for Roger Clemens all around. He visited a New York fire station for the first time yesterday afternoon, and he lost a game last night. The visit made more of an impression on the Yankees pitcher even though the loss was only his second of the season and his first after 16 consecutive victories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISHKIN, LEWIS
description: MISHKIN-Lewis. Beloved husband of Lois (Wachsberg), loving father of Jay (Marcie), and Robin (Kenneth) Abrams, cherished Pop-pop of William, brother of Neil. Died September 25. Services today at 10:30am Temple Emanuel, 756 E Broad St, Westfield NJ.

title: A Shift in the Ritual, and Meaning, of Voting
description: Marjorie Severence, from Queens, voted in a primary election yesterday for the first time in her life. She is 67, and said it just felt urgent and relevant to vote now.

title: Gucci Warns That Results Are Suffering
description: A growing list of luxury goods makers, which had been largely untouched by the developing economic slowdown, are reporting that demand has fallen sharply since the terror attacks on the United States.

title: House Republican Leaders Balk at Any Help for Laid-Off Workers
description: House Republican leaders balked today at the idea of helping thousands of laid-off workers by extending unemployment compensation and health care benefits despite a commitment last Friday by Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to consider such legislation.

title: State Dept. Protests Move By U.S. Radio
description: The Voice of America broadcast a rare interview with the leader of Afghanistan's Taliban yesterday, four days after outraged State Department officials argued that he should not be given a taxpayer-financed platform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MURRAY
description: LEWIS-Murray. Age 93. Formerly of NYC. Died September 22, 2001 Lifelong educator in NYC schools. Humanitarian and fighter for peace, for justice, and for a healthy environment. Conqueror of cancer and McCarthyism. Retired in 1973 and moved to Lenox in 1998. Survived by his wife of 71 years: Gertrude Lewis, two sons, six grandchildren, two greatgrandchildren with two more due within two months. Shalom.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm sure there are Delta Force people here. This is a place that gives you a relaxed feeling. That's probably something they need after all the time they spend practicing the awful things they do.''

title: For Displaced Companies, Details on City Aid Are Few
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, one of the larger tenants of the World Trade Center, is simultaneously trying to find temporary space for 1,900 workers and a permanent home, in a matter of weeks.

title: Disaster's Aftershocks: Number of Workers Out of a Job Is Rising
description: More than 100,000 New York City workers are likely to find themselves unemployed, at least temporarily, as a result of the World Trade Center disaster, according to government estimates released yesterday.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: On the Diplomatic Front

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about comments on talk radio about the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington omitted the given name of a conservative talk radio host whose criticism of liberals has softened slightly. He is Rush Limbaugh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, MARTHA FODASKI
description: BLACK-Martha Fodaski. Professor Emeritus of English at Brooklyn College, CUNY, died at home on September 21, 2001. The teacher, mentor and author of ''Shaw and Joyce: The Last Word in Stolentelling'' is survived by three children-Steven Wilde, Corinna Stewart, and David Fodaski, and a foster daughter, Danielle Black, and four grandchildren-Nick and Kira Stewart and Colin and Jeremy Fodaski.

title: Maxwell Tretter, 95, Executive At New York Housing Authority
description: Maxwell H. Tretter, executive director of the New York City Housing Authority in the mid-1940's, died on Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 95.

title: In County Cavan, Joy at News of 4 Irish Survivors
description: The World Trade Center catastrophe has shattered hundreds of families abroad whose loved ones were killed in the attack. But some families in County Cavan, Ireland, were rejoicing yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the surge in demand for United States flags misstated the ending date of the Persian Gulf war, which brought a decline in demand. It was Feb. 27, 1991; Jan. 17 was the start of the United States' air campaign.

title: The Vast Arsenal Against a Shadowy Foe; At Arlington
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudis Criticize the Taliban And Halt Diplomatic Ties
description: Saudi Arabia announced today that it was severing diplomatic ties with the Taliban government of Afghanistan, ending a relationship that grew out of attempts to free the country from Soviet control and deepened with the drive to create a unified state based on strict Islamic law.

title: Senate Backs Plan to Close Military Bases In 53-47 Vote
description: The Senate narrowly endorsed another round of military base closings today, overcoming opponents who argued that because of the uncertainty of terrorist threats, this was no time to cut back defenses.

title: Probe Sends Postcards From Comet's Core
description: A dying spacecraft making a last effort to capture scientific data has produced the best look at the glowing heart of a comet, scientists said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Technology Post Filled At Intel
description: Intel named Patrick Gelsinger, a vice president, to be chief technology officer, the first such appointment in the company's 33-year history. Mr. Gelsinger, 40, will coordinate long-term research on computing, networking and communications technologies. He will report to Craig Barrett, Intel's chief executive, the company said. Intel needs to expand its chip portfolio beyond personal computers into telecommunications and computer networking as sales weaken amid a slowing global economy and as consumers find fewer reasons to upgrade PC's.

title: Clinton's Fiscal Chief Has the Ear Of Congress
description: Needing advice about economic policy in the wake of the terrorist attacks, the Senate Finance Committee summoned the chairman of the Federal Reserve and a treasury secretary to a closed-door meeting this morning.

title: The Vast Arsenal Against a Shadowy Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGURTON, JAMES R., SR. ''DOC''
description: SAGURTON-James R., Sr. ''Doc'' Age 88. Of Mendham Township NJ. On September 23, 2001. Husband of Wilma (nee Lewis). Father of Dr. James R., Jr. of Mendham Township, Dr. Joan of Hopewell Junction NY, Frances Seigle of Gilford NH and David of Long Pond PA. Brother of Catherine of Brick NJ. Also survived by nine grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Predeceased by a daughter Nan, his parents, a brother Harry and two sisters, Mary and Agnes. Mass of the Resurrection will be offered on Friday, September 28 at 11AM at St. Joseph Church, Mendham. Interment St. Joseph Cemetery. Friends may call at the Bailey Funeral Home, Inc, 8 Hilltop Road, Mendham, on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Memorial gifts e to the Collection for the Poor, St. Joseph Church, New St, Mendham NJ 07945

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEATROUR, HENRIETTE
description: NEATROUR-Henriette. On September 23, 2001. Wife of Richard. Memorial service will be held at Church of the Ascension at 5th Avenue and 10th Street, Manhattan on Friday October 5th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to Supportive Care Program, St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 West 11th St, NY, NY 10011.

title: The Call of the Native City
description: We played badly on Monday the night before the attack. On Tuesday, the Loews corporate jet was grounded in Denver. I was champing at the bit to get back into action in New York. We were calling around and thought there might be a need to bring blood to New York, but the Red Cross said no more blood was needed. They were flooded in blood. We did find out there were four Federal Emergency Management Agency people in Denver on a project who needed to go to New York. We put the plane at the disposal of the agency.

title: On the North Fork, 18 Goats Find Full-Time Jobs
description: Anthony Perullo was on his way to becoming a doctor when he discovered medical school was not for him. Mr. Perullo, who has a degree in biochemistry from the State University of New York at Stony Brook, began to wonder why no one was making cheese in the flourishing wine country on the North Fork of Long Island. About a year ago Mr. Perullo, 34, jumped into the breach and now, with 18 goats on a small plot of land in Mattituck called Captain Kid Dairy, he is making several kinds of chvre.

title: By Getting Out and About, Heart Recipient Gets a Lift
description: The first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart left the hospital for the first time in recent days, taking trips to a park in Louisville, Ky., his doctors said yesterday.

title: WELLS FARGO PLANS TO BUY BACK $1.3 BILLION IN STOCK
description: Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $1.3 billion of its shares over time for uses that include acquisitions and employee benefit plans. The repurchase would involve as many as 30 million shares, the company said in a statement. The shares will be purchased on the open market and represent 2 percent of the San Francisco-based company's 1.7 billion shares outstanding. The buyback is in addition to an existing plan that Wells Fargo began in February to buy back 25 million shares.

title: Why E-Mail Is Creating Multiple E-Personalities
description: JEFF BEZOS, the chief executive of Amazon.com, has an approach to e-mail that his corporate peers might consider insane. He has made his e-mail address public -- jeff@amazon.com -- and says that he reads every message that appears in his box.

title: Couples Looking to Adopt Find a Shifting Spotlight
description: IN searching for a second baby to adopt, Carol Veihmeyer and Doug Cecil of Atlanta spent six months writing letters and making contacts before they turned to the Internet. In that time, Ms. Veihmeyer said, they also became smart about the Web and overcame an ambivalence about making their lives public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, FRANK
description: LOWE-Frank of Ventura, CA, formerly of Forest Hills, NY, on September 21 after a short illness. Beloved husband of Eva, devoted father of Robert and father-in-law of Sylvia. Proud grandfather of Jeremy and Danielle. He will be missed.

title: TV Notes: Normalcy in the Morning
description: ood Morning America" tipped back toward normality on Monday morning, squeezing an interview with the newly crowned Miss America, Katie Harman, between segments on the Sept. 11 attack and its aftermath.

title: Giuliani's Plea to Motorists: Give Curbs on Driving a Try
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today coupled a strong plea for people traveling to Manhattan to use public transportation with a request that people unhappy with the driving restrictions going into effect on Thursday to "all work together" and give them a try.

title: Buoyed by a Michael Jordan Letter, a Severely Ill Boy and His Parents Live in Hope
description: Tired of counting her tears, her pennies and the days her 6-year-old son might have left to live, Doreen Blair-Skipper was looking forward to going back to work.

title: Campaigns In New Jersey Are Adapting To Attacks
description: The candidates for New Jersey governor are quickly adapting their campaigns to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, but in slightly different, if characteristic, ways.

title: Frequent Fliers Then, Frequent Fliers Now
description: Many Americans may be putting off plans to fly, but hard-core business travelers are refusing to desert the skies.

title: Afghanistan Remains a Major Drug Trader Despite Taliban Ban on Poppy Growing
description: The Taliban government in Afghanistan has earned tens of millions of dollars from the export of heroin and other narcotics since it proclaimed last year that it was ending opium poppy cultivation, American officials say. Cutting off this important source of revenue is part of the Bush administration's economic campaign against the regime, the officials said.

title: New Face Of Council Emerges From Pack
description: A vastly reconfigured City Council began to come into focus last night as early returns showed that a range of well-known elected officials, new political faces and family members of old council members won primary races.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, EDWARD ''TEDDY'' FRANCIS III
description: MALONEY - Edward ''Teddy'' Francis III, 32, of Darien, a former Greenwich resident, died Tuesday, September 11, during the attacks at the World Trade Center, where he was an account manager for the Cantor Fitzgerald subsidiary TradeSpark. Born October 11, 1968, in Berlin, Germany, he was the son of Sally and Edward ''Eddie'' Francis Maloney Jr. of Greenwich. Mr. Maloney attended Eagle Hill School in Greenwich and Proctor Academy in Andover, N.H. He graduated from New England College in Henniker, N.H. Mr. Maloney was a member of the Apawamis Club in Rye, NY. He developed a passion for several sports, including ice hockey, lacrosse and football. He practiced for a time with his beloved New York Rangers, his family said. He coached ice hockey for Greenwich Academy and the Greenwich Skating Club. In addition to his parents, he is survived by his wife of three years, Brinley Long Maloney of Darien, who is expecting the couple's second child in November, a daughter to be named Teddy Bray Maloney. He is also survived by a 14-month-old daughter, Mason Lore Maloney of Darien; a brother, Mark Tierney Maloney of Darien; a sister, Sally Tierney Maloney of Boston; his maternal grandparents, Mary and Jim O'Neal of Rye; his paternal grandmother, Jeanne Cawley Maloney of Rye; and several aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews and cousins. He was predeceased by his paternal grandfather, Edward Francis Maloney Sr. There are no calling hours. A memorial Mass will be celebrated at 11 a.m., Friday, September 28, at The Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Trust for Teddy Maloney's Children, c/o Holland, Kaufmann & Bartels LLC, Attorneys at Law, 289 Greenwich Ave., Third Floor, Greenwich, CT 06830-6562.

title: Italian and French Oils That Speak Californian
description: Two grapeseed oils, one Italian and one French, created by the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten are infused with herbs, giving them a lovely green color, rich aromas and distinctive flavors. The Italian is made with basil, oregano, rosemary and sage; the French is seasoned with rosemary, thyme, tarragon and summer savory. The French blend is more highly perfumed; the Italian has a more balanced intensity. The herbal component is stronger in these grapeseed oils, produced by California Grapeseed, than in infused olive oils because the base oil is neutral. They're excellent in marinades and for seasoning grilled foods, especially vegetables and fish, and can be used, sparingly, in salad dressings. Unlike many infused oils, they will work for a quick saut. The oils, in patterned tins, are $20 for 30.4 ounces at Williams-Sonoma stores.

title: Spending Weakens as Confidence Wanes
description: In the 10 days of September before terrorists struck the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, consumer confidence plunged more sharply than at any time since the last recession, the Conference Board reported yesterday, suggesting that the nation was moving quickly toward a recession even before the attacks.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about funerals and memorials after the World Trade Center attack misstated the job held by one victim, Fanny Espinoza, at Cantor Fitzgerald, the bond trading company. She was a compliance officer, not a food server.

title: Jordan's Back, Again
description: After months of expectation, Michael Jordan made his return to the basketball court official yesterday by signing a two-year contract with the Washington Wizards. Jordan, who led the Chicago Bulls to six National Basketball Association titles and is considered by many to be the greatest player in league history, is making his second comeback -- this one at age 38.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNULTY, SEAN
description: McNULTY-Sean, July 21, 1971September 11, 2001. Sean worked for Cantor-Fitzgerald at World Trade Center. Memorial Mass October 5, 7PM, at St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church, Park Ave at 84th. Ewing Funeral Home, 941-488-7737.

title: Sponsors Defect
description: The future of Bill Maher's late-night talk show on ABC, ''Politically Incorrect,'' remains in some doubt in the wake of withdrawals from the show by both advertisers and some affliates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, HERMAN
description: SANDLER-Herman, 57. Loving husband of Suki, devoted father of Pamela, Gillian and Jordana, role model and mentor to hundreds of young people. You encouraged us to take risks and gave us innumerable opportunities to follow our dreams, cheering us on as we learned to impact the world as you did so powerfully. You will always remain our awesome inspiration. We love you, Suki, Pamela, Gillian and Jordana. In lieu of flowers, gifts honoring Herman may be made to any of the following organizations: American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, The Rain Forest Foundation, The Perlman Music Program, Carnegie Hall, or UJA Federation of NY.

title: Company Sites Are Holding Offices Together
description: ON Sept. 10, if you had clicked on the Web site for Cantor Fitzgerald, the leading brokerage firm for Treasury bonds, you would have seen the predictable thrum of a company doing business online, complete with flashy graphics and animation.

title: COCA-COLA AGAIN REDUCES ESTIMATE OF SALES VOLUME
description: The Coca-Cola Company cut its estimate of this year's volume sales for a second time on concern that demand in the United States may slow. Case sales will rise 4 percent to 5 percent in 2001, the company said in a statement, less than the 5 percent to 6 percent projected in April. As recently as 1997, sales rose as much as 9 percent. Third-quarter case sales will rise 4 percent to 5 percent, Coca-Cola said, in line with analysts' estimates. The reduced forecast means growth at Coca-Cola will be little changed from last year, when case sales rose 4 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAINE, JAMES J., JR.
description: STRAINE-James J., Jr., of Oceanport, N.J., on Tuesday, September 11, 2001, at the World Trade Center, New York City, husband of Tricia (nee Carr) Straine, father of Finn and Charlie; son of James J., Sr. and Mary Straine, Warren, N.J.; brother of Michael, Summit, N.J.; Kevin, New York City; Dan, Red Bank, N.J.; sister Katy O'Hara, Hackettstown, N.J.; and son-in-law of John J. and Dolores Carr, Holmdel, N.J.; born February 5, 1965, Lawton, Oklahoma; graduated 1988 from East Carolina University, Greeneville, N.C., employed in fixed income sales by Cantor Fitzgerald, New York City, since September 1996. A memorial service for Mr. Straine will be held at 10AM, Friday, September 28, at St. Catharine's Church, 108 Middletown Road, Holmdel, N.J. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the James J. Straine, Jr. Memorial Fund, c/o Mr. and Mrs. James J. Straine, Sr., 20 Indian Rock Road, Warren, N.J. 07059

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERKNESS, LINDSAY C., III
description: HERKNESS-Lindsay C., III. Of New York City. Age 58. Died September 11, 2001 in the attack on the World Trade Center. He was a Senior Vice President at Morgan Stanley. Survived by his brother, Wayne and dog, Gaston. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to Trinity College, Connecticut, or Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Long Island.

title: Former Rebels in Colombia Take the Capitalist Road
description: When a venerable Colombian company that makes light fixtures badly needed capital, salvation came from an unusual source. A group of former guerrillas, pooling government money they received on laying down their arms, bought 17 percent of the factory three years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALD, VICTOR
description: WALD-Victor. The Solomon Schechter HS of NY mourns the loss of the father of one of our students. Victor was a warm and caring man, a scholar in history, and a devoted father and husband. He is survived by his beloved wife and children. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Carol S. Kekst, Board Chair Rabbi Judd Levingston, Principal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SADDLER, JOE (SANDY)
description: SADDLER-Joe (Sandy), enjoyed a thirteen year professional boxing career consisting of 162 fights, culminating with winning and the holding of the Featherweight Championship of the World for nine years. In the second year of his career, 1945, determination and resilience led Sandy Saddler to fight an astonishing 24 times. Sandy Saddler was the epitome of a gentleman, unfailingly polite, selfeffacing, intellectually curious, always generous to a fault. Indeed, Sandy will be missed. Aquarius Media Corporation Terry Levene

title: The Vast Arsenal Against a Shadowy Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUDNOW, BETTY
description: CHUDNOW-Betty. The Congregation of Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst, records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We express our sympathy to her family. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President

title: Renaming an Operation to Fit the Mood
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld renamed the war against terrorism Operation Enduring Freedom, hoping to put an end to the latest glitch in the Pentagon's efforts over the years to match the national mood to the name of a war operation.

title: Added Security for Dams, Reservoirs and Aqueducts
description: Cities and states are reassessing the safety of their drinking water, probing for weaknesses and shoring up defenses in what experts consider the unlikely event of a terrorist attack on water supplies.

title: Stocks Slump in Afternoon Trading
description: Stocks wandered lower today as investors found little reason to believe that the economy might recover from its downturn anytime soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALGER, DAVID
description: ALGER - David. The Chapin School is deeply saddened by the loss of David Alger, an outstanding trustee and a true friend of the school. He served on the Board of Trustees with dedication and distinction and touched the lives of so many in the Chapin community. He will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife, Josie, and his daughters, Cristy and Roxana. Cera B. Robbins, President, Board of Trustees Sandra J. Theunick, Head of School

title: As Providers, Friends, and Shoulders to Lean On, They Put Others First
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 279 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 209. In all, 6,398 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: Unions at Airlines Assail Management For Denying Benefits
description: Labor-management relations in the airline industry, rocky before Sept. 11, have grown rancorous, with unions enraged at what they say are moves by several carriers to use the national emergency to deny pay or benefits to workers idled as air travel stalls.

title: Comfortable in Middle, Barrow Is Now a Leader
description: This is Mike Barrow's ninth year in the National Football League: four at Houston, three at Carolina and two with the Giants. He has been a starter for the last eight years, a rock at outside linebacker, middle linebacker, defensive end or any other role a defensive coordinator could conjure up.

title: Comedians Return, Treading Lightly; Escaping Into Work And Feeling a Duty To Keep People Laughing
description: The days after the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center were, in the words of one downtown comedian, ''perhaps the least funny time in history.''

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 9 p.m.Tuesday.

title: Between the Body Slams, the W.W.F. Shows a Sensitive Side
description: Ten years ago, with the Persian Gulf war just ended, the main event of the World Wrestling Federation's Wrestlemania show in Los Angeles featured Hulk Hogan, the blond and bronzed hero of kiddies, against Sgt. Slaughter, a turncoat Iraqi sympathizer. In Slaughter's corner stood his muse, General Adnon, a Baghdad-born Saddam Hussein stand-in. Hogan beat Slaughter and exultantly draped himself in the American flag.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD CUTS 1,000 JOBS AND TRIMS FORECAST
description: The American Standard Companies, the maker of Trane air-conditioning systems, said falling sales of some cooling systems were dragging profit below forecasts and had resulted in 1,000 job cuts at the unit. American Standard, which also makes faucets and toilets, said third-quarter profit would be $1.23 a share on a 4 percent drop in sales. It had been expected to earn $1.42 by analysts.

title: Knicks Cut Longley And Pick Up Burrell
description: On the day Michael Jordan announced his return to the N.B.A., the Knicks parted with Luc Longley and added Scott Burrell, who agreed to terms. Both were once teammates of Jordan.

title: Small-Scale Specialists
description: When it comes to ultrasmall-scale science and technology -- from individual atoms to large molecules -- New York may soon have a corner on the market. The National Science Foundation announced last week that of the six national nanotechnology centers it is creating, three will be in New York, at Columbia, Cornell and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. The foundation will spend about $10 million per center over the next five years to foster research in extremely small technologies that it hopes will transform electronics, medicine and other fields.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNAN, MICHAEL L.
description: HANNAN-Michael L. Of Lynbrook, NY, age 34. Tragically at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Dedicated employee of Marsh & McLennan. Beloved husband of Andrea (nee LaMarche). Adored father of Rachel and Alexandra. A cherished son of Barbara and the late Lawrence Hannan. Special grandson of the late John and Grace Hannan and Francis and Irene Hertel. Dear son-in-law of Sabine LaMarche and David LaMarche. Loving brother of Jennifer and Steven Muller, Craig and Kathleen Hannan, and Peter Hannan. Dear brother-in-law of Derek and Melissa LaMarche, Katrina and Richard Sparano and KellyJo LaMarche. Terrific uncle to Danny and Jane Muller and Jack and Margaret LaMarche. Devoted nephew of Dorothy Hertel Ryan, Marion O'Connor, Kathleen Hannan, John and Evie Hannan, Richard and Roberta Hertel, Peter and Lynn Hertel and the late Sr. Anne Hertel, OP. A wonderful and loyal friend to all who knew him. Friends may visit at Donza Funeral Home, 333 Atlantic Avenue, East Rockaway, NY 11518 on Thursday, September 27 and Friday September 28, from 4PM to 9PM. A Memorial Mass celebrating Michael's life will be held on Saturday, September 29, 2001 at 11AM at Our Lady of Peace Church, Lynbrook, NY 11563. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to a fund being established for the benefit of Rachel and Alexandra Hannan, c/o Keith and Monica O'Reilly, 62 Adams Street, East Rockaway, NY 11518; to Our Lady of Peace School, 21 Fowler Avenue, Lynbrook, NY 11563 for a scholarship fund being established in Michael's name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERR, STANLEY S.
description: HERR-Stanley S. On September 24th, 2001. Husband of Raquel Schuster-Herr. Father of David L., Deborah A. and Ilana R. Herr. Beloved brother of Judith N. Herr. Funeral services and interment to be held in Baltimore, Maryland., on Tuesday, September 25, 2001. Contributions in his memory may be to The Stanley S. Herr Fund for Disability Rights and Social Justice. Make checks payable to The UMBF, 515 West Lombard St., Baltimore, MD. 21201. For further information call Sol Levinson Funeral Home, 800-338-1701.

title: CONGRESS GETS PLEA TO DROP TAX BENEFITS FOR INVESTORS AND WIDEN ECONOMIC RELIEF
description: Influential advisers and key members of Congress expressed opposition today to two of the main Republican proposals for stimulating an already weakened economy as new figures suggested that the terrorist attacks would inflict heavy damage on jobs, spending and the business outlook.

title: Nobu Matsuhisa
description: I LOVE big shrimp, like Japanese botan shrimp and the meaty ones from Santa Barbara, Calif. In classic Japanese cooking, shrimp like these would be dropped into a broth or boiled as served with sushi. But I think boiling dilutes their great flavor, and they are better when stir-fried.

title: The Vast Arsenal Against a Shadowy Foe; New York Tableaus
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, SCOTT MARTIN
description: McGOVERN-Scott Martin. Age 35 of Wyckoff, N.J. Victim of World Trade Center Disaster, September 11, 2001. Cherished husband of Jill (nee Shaffro). Adored father of Alana and Nicole. Loving son of Elisabeth Scott and Martin McGovern, stepson of Anne McGovern. Beloved son-in-law to Renee and William Shaffro. Devoted brother to Tara, brother-in-law to Raymond, Ronni and Steven. Memorial Service Friday, September 28, 2001, 1 P.M. at Christ Church, Franklin Avenue and Cottage Place, Ridgewood, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Scott McGovern Family Fund would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PEERCE, BARBARA POSTER
description: PEERCE-Barbara Poster. Mom, it's been 30 years since you left us and our thoughts have been with you every day. Love, Steve, Margie and Carol.

title: With Voters Few and Far Between, Typical Obstacles at the Polls Fail to Materialize
description: All year long, there were predictions of bedlam at the New York City polls, of a primary sabotaged by an antiquated voting system that could not handle a record number of candidates running because of term limits. But yesterday, turnout for the rescheduled primary was unusually low, apparently because the primary was overshadowed by the events of the last two weeks, and as a result, the process did not founder.

title: In Crowded Field, Runoff Appears Likely for Gotbaum
description: In the race for public advocate, surveys of voters leaving the polls indicated last night that a runoff would probably be needed to determine the Democratic nominee for the city's No. 2 position.

title: Bali Bridge Match in Doubt As U.S. Teams Refuse to Go
description: The World Bridge Federation is considering whether to cancel its world championships next month in Bali, Indonesia. But even if they go on as scheduled, teams from the United States and several other countries say they will not participate unless the location is changed.

title: Making Death Official
description: With little hope that survivors will be found in the wreckage of the World Trade Center, city and state officials set up a method yesterday for the mass distribution of death certificates.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for challah last Wednesday misstated the amount of vegetable oil in Step 2. It should be half a cup. The corrected recipe follows.

title: FERRER AND GREEN HEAD FOR RUNOFF IN MAYORAL RACE
description: Struggling to choose a new mayor precisely two weeks after a terrorist jet attack devastated the World Trade Center, New York City Democrats yesterday apparently extended the primary contest an additional 16 days by sending two candidates, Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer, into a runoff for their party's nomination, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls.

title: In Hills Far From the Taliban, Faces of Hate and Compassion
description: Resuming life's routine in an Allegheny backwater, Loretta Macomb snips hair once more at the House of Style over in Marlinton, fighting back the occasional tear. ''There I go again,'' she says, sad about the terrorism tragedy as she labors at the beauty arts on a customer seated before the shop mirror.

title: In the Heart of TriBeCa, A Pioneer Presses On
description: IT wasn't the usual lunch crowd at Tribeca Grill last Thursday. Instead of Miramax executives holding court, rescue workers slept in booths while the kitchen staff labored over the daily special: roast beef sandwiches to be passed out at ground zero.

title: Germaine Bre, 93, a Scholar Of Modern French Literature
description: Germaine Bre, a prolific scholar of French literature who helped introduce a generation of Americans to the work of Camus, Sartre and other modern French writers, died on Sept. 22 at her home in Winston-Salem, N.C., a spokeswoman for Wake Forest University said. Ms. Bre was 93 and had been Kenan professor of humanities at Wake Forest from 1973 until 1984.

title: In County Cavan, Joy at News of 4 Irish Survivors
description: The World Trade Center catastrophe has shattered hundreds of families abroad whose loved ones were killed in the attack. But some families in County Cavan, Ireland, were rejoicing yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: EMI Expects Lower Profit
description: The EMI Group -- the third-largest music company in the world, with artists who include the British pop star Robbie Williams -- said pretax profit for the 12 months ending March 2002 would decline by one-fifth as consumers in the United States and Latin America bought fewer records. The announcement set off a 35 percent decline in the EMI share price. EMI said sales weakened further after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. Its stock fell to 2.14 ($3.13). Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Heroic Rescue Figures May Top Holiday Wish Lists
description: Toy analysts and manufacturers expect this holiday season to bring a boom in sales of toys with rescue themes, like Matchbox firetrucks and muscular police officer action heroes, as parents look for playthings to inspire their children after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about interparty civility in Congress after the terror attacks, and an editorial the same day, misstated the timing of the Bush administration's withdrawal of two nominations. The choice of Mary Sheila Gall to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission was withdrawn before the attacks, but the action was announced later. The name of Donald Schregardus for chief enforcement officer of the Environmental Protection Agency was withdrawn shortly after the attack, but the decision was made earlier.

title: Ice Cream, as Easy as Pie
description: THE latest innovation in home ice cream makers is actually a low-technology twist on the old-fashioned method.

title: Some Families Doubt Sincerity of Cantor
description: Maybe it was the finality of it. On Sept. 15, the bond trading firm of Cantor Fitzgerald dropped its missing employees from the payroll.

title: Commandos Left A Calling Card: Their Absence
description: This is as placid and pretty a town as anyone could imagine, complete with stately old homes, antique shops, a store that sells homemade fudge and an ice cream parlor across from the clapboard train station. People here say they believe it is also home to some of America's most fearsome commandos.

title: Spain Rediscovers Its Rich Heritage
description: REMEMBER when good Spanish wine -- sherry excepted -- came from Rioja? The operative word here is ''good.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADISON, PHILIP
description: KADISON-Philip, of White Plains, NY died unexpectedly on September 22 in his sleep. A retired stockbroker of Adbest, Inc., he was a graduate of Harvard University, a member of The Hasty Pudding Club and a long standing member of The N.M.C. He was an accomplished pianist and composer, a loving husband and father, brother and uncle. He will be sorely missed. Memorial contributions may be made to The National Wildlife Federation.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Nikki Oden, Diana Scott, Murrells Inlet, S.C., July 18, 2001

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Short-Selling Curbs
description: Financial watchdogs and industry regulators in Britain have quietly urged insurers to stop lending shares in an effort to reduce the practice of short-selling. The move is intended to help stabilize the stock market, which has fallen since the attacks in the United States. Short-selling, in which an investor borrows stock and sells it in the hope of buying it back later at a lower price, can accelerate already falling share prices. The Financial Services Authority and the Association of British Insurers have suggested that insurers temporarily cease the practice, although neither body has drafted a formal directive. Legal & General, which manages more than $147 billion in assets, voluntarily decided to stop lending shares this week. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEO, KIAT HUAT
description: YEO-Kiat Huat, age 50, of Red Bank, New Jersey, died last night at Riverview Medical Center. Dr. Yeo was born in Malaysia and came to the USA to pursue his medical studies. He completed his undergraduate studies at Columbia Union College and the University of Maryland at Baltimore. Dr. Yeo attended medical school at St. George's University School of Medicine, Grenada, West Indies, where he received his Doctor of Medicine in 1983. He completed his post-graduate training in internal medicine as well as a subspecialty fellowship in pulmonary diseases/ critical care at Coney Island Hospital, Brooklyn, New York. Dr. Yeo has been an associate of the Medical Health Center in Middletown since 1995. He was also on staff at Riverview Medical Center, Jersey Shore Medical Center, Monmouth Medical Center, and Bayshore Community Hospital. Dr. Yeo was a compassionate doctor who always had time to sit and talk with his patients and their families. He was a member of the American Medical Association and the American College of Chest Physicians. Dr. Yeo is survived by his wife, Mei; his sister, Mrs. Itwaru; his niece, Vivian and many loving colleagues and friends. The family requests that memorial donations be made in his memory to the American Red Cross September 11th Fund, c/o PO Box 4148, Middletown, NJ 07748.

title: An Exotic Import: Hardly Plain Vanilla
description: NEW YORKERS may love to talk up their cheesecake, but -- and I'm going out on a fragile limb here -- they haven't tasted my mother's. It is a fine example of the classic, sensible dessert. Hers is dammed up with a crust made with Nabisco chocolate wafers and butter. The bottom layer is a fluffy pool of cream cheese, eggs and sugar. The top is a thin layer of sour cream and sugar. She flavors both layers with vanilla extract, which enriches the cream cheese and softens the bite of the sour cream. I long considered it a perfect recipe.

Newsprint prices have fallen 6 percent this year as the slowing economy has reduced spending on newspaper advertising.
