description: HOENIG-Helene. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to her daughter, Doris Greenberg, and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: In the Search for Suspects, Sensitivities About Profiling
description: New Jersey Attorney General John J. Farmer Jr. tried yesterday to reassure Muslims, Arabs and others that he would not sanction or condone racial profiling by the law enforcement agents who are searching for suspects in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Chef Leaves Atlas

title: Prosecutors Outline Fraud Case Against Ex-Mayor of Newark
description: Prosecutors in the federal bribery and fraud trial of a former Newark mayor, Kenneth A. Gibson, said in opening arguments today that school officials in Irvington, N.J., were betrayed by Mr. Gibson, who is charged with defrauding the district of more than $1 million in a construction contract scheme.

title: Editors' Note; SPECIAL TODAY/Tools for the Aftermath
description: For businesses, relief agencies and investigators, the Internet has taken on new importance as they move from the shock of Sept. 11 to take on new and daunting tasks. SECTION H

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRALEY, HELEN BAKER
description: STRALEY-Helen Baker. Died peacefully on September 23, 2001 at home in her 100th year. Beloved wife of the late Charles V. Straley. Loving mother of Harriet Clowes and the late James F. Also survived by her daughter-in-law Janet Straley. Cherished grandmother of eight and great grandmother of 12. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Ave, Rockville Centre, NY Friday 2-4pm only. Religious Service Friday 7:30pm at the Church of the Ascension, 71 N. Village Ave, Rockville Centre. Interment Sunset Memorial Park, Seasterville, PA. Saturday 12pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Organ Fund of the Church of the Ascension, 71 N. Village Ave., Rockville Centre, NY 11570 would be appreciated.

title: Nation's Deepest Coal Mine Now Ranks Among Deadliest
description: The low-sulfur coal coveted by power plants exists in abundance beneath the green ridges near this central Alabama town, but to get it, miners must take the longest elevator ride in the country to a dark and risky office: 175 stories straight down, past cracks and crevices packed with highly volatile methane gas.

title: Spitzer Plans to Coordinate Charity Efforts for Victims
description: With more than 140 groups raising money for victims of the World Trade Center attacks, State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said yesterday that he planned to take the lead in coordinating the relief efforts of private charities.

title: BizTech: Tapping Into a New Phone Generation
description: TOKYO  Battered by the tech wreck and on the brink of recession, Asia still has a thing or two to teach the rest of the world about telecommunications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRD, GERALD HUGH
description: BIRD-Gerald Hugh. On September 23 after a brief illness. Beloved son of the late Mary D. and Michael L. Bird. Dear brother of Francis Bird and Agnes McCormack. Devoted uncle of Daria and Andrea McCormack and greatuncle of Angela McCormack. Funeral mass Thursday, September 27, at 10 AM, Church of the Epiphany, 2nd Ave. at 22nd St. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Catholic Worker, 36 East 1st St. would be appreciated.

title: Yankees Back, Again
description: The Yankees made the playoffs for the seventh year in a row last night, clinching the American League East title when the Red Sox lost to the Orioles. When that score was posted at 10:37 p.m., it no longer mattered that Roger Clemens was on his way to losing for the first time since May 20, 4-0, to Tampa Bay. The fans, emotionally charged by a ceremony before the team's first game at Yankee Stadium since the terrorist attacks, stood and roared in appreciation.

title: Thinking Man's Talk With Thinkers
description: SHOP TALK

title: Steinbrenner Says Victory Is Far From Only Thing
description: George Steinbrenner visited Lower Manhattan yesterday for the second time since the World Trade Center disaster and said in a television interview that he had such an ''empty feeling'' as he looked up at where the twin towers used to stand. Steinbrenner said some workers quickly noticed him and reminded him that, even in these troubled times, they were Yankee fans.

title: Olgiata Journal; Afghan King Is Courted and Says, 'I Am Ready'
description: This sprawling, gated enclave north of Rome is the kind of place where people of a certain wealth and standing pay handsomely for walled villas in leafy environs. Since the terror attacks on the United States, one of them is finding his seclusion almost under siege.

title: Cruise Operator Out of Business
description: Renaissance Cruises ceased operating yesterday, becoming the industry's first casualty of the terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGIOVANNA, BALDWIN J.
description: DiGIOVANNA-Baldwin J. On September 25, 2001. Beloved husband of Josephine. Loving father of Lawrence, Rosanne and Joanne. Dear brother of Anthony. Proud grandfather of Pamela, Alexandra and Sara. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Ave. at 97 St., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 AM, St. Ann's Church, S.I. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Vincent's Services, 66 Boerum Place, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, LEWIS
description: RUDIN-Lewis. The staff and trustees of The Parrish Art Museum are deeply saddened by the passing of Lewis Rudin, a dedicated philanthropist whose interests and reach were broad and deep. His steadfast and long standing support in education and community service has benefited so many institutions wherever he resided. We send our condolences to his family who share his devotion to community and public service. Mildred C. Brinn, Chairman of the Board Trudy C. Kramer, Director The Parrish Art Museum

title: Mets Do Just Enough To Give Appier Reward
description: The most passionate fans who showed up at Olympic Stadium tonight were the ones who gathered in the lounge of the visitors' clubhouse after the game. The Mets had just completed a crisp and tidy victory, shutting out the Montreal Expos behind Kevin Appier, 2-0, and they gathered on couches with dinner plates and playoff hopes.

title: Squad 1 Spared Relocation
description: After two weeks of misery, the surviving firefighters of Squad 1 in Brooklyn have some good news to report.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: U.S. Agrees To Trapping Ban
description: The Department of Agriculture has agreed to comply with a state law banning certain body-gripping traps and poisons. As a federal agency, the department's Wildlife Services Division is probably exempt from complying with the ban, which was approved as Initiative 713 by 55 percent of Washington voters last year. Earlier this month, the Humane Society and Christine Gregoire, the state's attorney general, asked Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman to respect the state initiative. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: In Investigation, Internet Offers Clues and Static
description: ALL investigations begin with a tip, a lead, a scrap of information as slight as the seat number passed along by a flight attendant aboard a doomed airliner on Sept. 11. But what has changed in recent years is the speed at which that information can be acted and built upon across the nation or around the world.

title: To Make More Money, Cut the Noise
description: THE technology that allows users to share music files over the Internet is also proving useful in swapping shares of stock.

title: The Vast Arsenal Against a Shadowy Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats In Nassau Nominate An Outsider
description: In an upset, Thomas R. Suozzi defeated his party leadership's candidate today and won the Democratic primary for Nassau County executive, bringing him a step closer to the helm of one of the state's wealthiest but most financially troubled counties.

title: Architects, Planners and Residents Wonder How to Fill the Hole in the City
description: The destruction of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 cut a huge hole in the fabric of New York City. But already, even as the grief and mourning go on, the city's wound is becoming a kind of repository of ideas about what the site, and the city around it, should become.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Regrets Over Algeria War Victims
description: Jacques Chirac became the first French president to acknowledge that his country had done little to try to protect the thousands of Algerians who fought on the French side during the war of independence from 1954 to 1962. When a defeated France finally pulled out of its North African colony, victorious Algerian revolutionaries massacred thousands of the French loyalists -- so-called harkis -- and their wives and children, many of whom had been disarmed. ''It is time for France to take an honest look at this little-known piece of history,'' Mr. Chirac said during ceremonies for France's first national day of remembrance for the French loyalists. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Recipe: Pasta With Yogurt and Caramelized Onions, From Kassos
description: Adapted from "The Glorious Foods of Greece"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAMER, RICHARD
description: ABRAHAMER-Richard, of Fox Point, WI, formerly of Flushing, NY. Beloved husband of Judith (nee Kallus). Loving father of Vilma (John) Illingworth. Devoted grandfather of Leah and Shayna. Holocaust survivor. Services will be held in Milwaukee on Wednesday. Goodman Bensman Funeral Home, 414-964-3111 goodmanbensman.plan4ever.com

title: The New Ratings
description: The first night of the new television season provided some indications that viewers were eager to get back to watching prime-time programs, and delivered several messages to networks about what those viewers were likely to watch.

title: Bush Warmly Praises C.I.A.; Senator Questions Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Fifteen days after devastating terrorist attacks caught the United States by surprise, President Bush went out of his way today to praise the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, WILLIAM
description: SIEGEL-William. September 23, 2001 of Somers, NY. Loving husband of Rhoda. Father of Stuart (Addie) of NYC and Richard (Jenny) of West Newbury, MA. Doting grandfather of Catie, Anna, Gennie, Cal, Ned and Pete. Memorial services will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to either Green Chimneys Childrens Services, Caller Box 719, 400 Doansburg Rd, Brewster, NY 10509-0719 or The James A. Baker Institute for Animal Health, College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853.

title: Giuliani Talking to Candidates About Plan to 'Maintain Unity'
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said today that he would ask the candidates for mayor to discuss a plan to "maintain unity" in the city during its current crisis, but the mayor declined to say whether that plan included extending his term in office.

title: Finance Ministers Agree on October Meeting
description: The finance ministers from leading industrial nations agreed today to meet in early October to discuss global economic prospects in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 that dealt a shock to the already sputtering United States economy.

title: The Other War, Against Intolerance
description: THE day after the attacks, an Amtrak train was detained here, and police officers seized a bearded man wearing a turban, suspecting him of complicity. The authorities cordoned off downtown, disrupting commuters' and students' travel home. The city's Muslim minority feared hostility and repression.

title: Struggling Wall St. Is Loath to Cut Jobs
description: On Wall Street, the burning question is not if, but when.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz review in Weekend on Friday about an appearance by the Paris-based pianist Martial Solal at the Village Vanguard referred incorrectly to the rarity of his exposure in the United States. He has indeed released an album on an American label -- ''Martial Solal: At Newport '63,'' for RCA.

title: The Vast Arsenal Against a Shadowy Foe; New York Tableaus
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Even with oil prices down, OPEC is expected to maintain production levels.
description: FACING stiff international pressure to keep oil prices low as the global economy slumps, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to maintain current production levels when it meets today at its headquarters here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, RICHARD H.
description: STEWART-Richard H., 35, is missing from the World Trade Center disaster. A bond trader with Cantor Fitzgerald, he formerly worked at Lehman Brothers. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held Friday, September 28, 11 A.M. at The Lawrenceville School chapel. In his memory, an Ice Hockey Scholarship fund has been established at The Lawrenceville School, P.O. Box 6125, Lawrenceville, New Jersey 08648.

title: Consider the Source
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Keeping Up to Speed On Antivirus Protection
description: Q. Less than a year ago I purchased a Dell computer with Norton 2001 installed. I have recently been getting messages telling me that my virus definitions update has expired and I should subscribe, which involves a fee. Isn't the free program already installed adequate? What is the virus definition update?

title: Adapting Technology; At the Disaster Site, Measuring a Building's Fate With the Pulse of a Laser
description: WORLD Trade Center Building 4 still stands amid the devastation of the twin towers in Lower Manhattan. But the building, a smoke-blackened, nine-story structure at the corner of Liberty and Church streets, was heavily damaged in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, and vehicles hauling debris from the disaster site could trigger its collapse, endangering rescue workers.

title: Agile in a Crisis, Robots Show Their Mettle
description: THESE rescuers are unaffected by the carnage, dust and smoke that envelop the remains of the World Trade Center. They are immune to the fatigue and heartbreak that hang in the air. They are, literally, robots: small, mobile machines that whir, blink and burrow alongside the emergency workers and rescue dogs, combing the debris.

title: Real Madrid Remains Perfect
description: Real Madrid beat Anderlecht, 4-1, to maintain its perfect start in European soccer's Champions League, while Roma beat Lokomotiv Moscow, 2-1.

title: Money for (Almost) Nothing
description: Imay be going out on a limb here, but it looks to me as though the economys high-flying days are truly over for a while.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARCY, DWIGHT DONALD
description: DARCY-Dwight Donald. Age 55, Senior Attorney at the Port Authority of NY and NJ, died on September 11, in the attack on the WTC. Resided in Bronxville, NY with his beloved wife Veronica and sons Kieran and Ryan. Also survived by his sister Joan D. Sorgi of Darien, CT; his brother Keith T. Darcy of Pound Ridge, NY; his aunt Claire Menagh of Manhattan; his uncle George Kindermann of New London, NH; and several nieces and nephews. Mr. Darcy, a Bronx native, graduated from Fordham Prep, Fordham University, and the Fordham University School of Law. He began his legal career as an Assistant D.A. in the Bronx in 1971, and joined the Port Authority in 1977. While at the Port Authority, Mr. Darcy specialized in labor relations, serving for many years as the Head of the Labor Relations Division. Active in charitable works in NYC, Mr. Darcy served as president of the Catholic Big Brothers of NY, as well as president of the Parish Council of St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville. He was voted a life member of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of NY, and made an affiliate member of the Marist Brothers for his many years of service on the board of Mt. St. Michael Academy in the Bronx. A Memorial Mass in celebration of Mr. Darcy's life will be offered Friday, September 28, at 10:00 AM at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville. Contributions can be sent to the Dwight D. Darcy Memorial Scholarship Fund at Fordham Prep, East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY 10458 or to the Catholic Big Brothers of NY, 45 East 20 St., NY, NY 10003.

title: Bali Loses the Bridge Tourney This Year
description: The World Bridge Federation announced yesterday in Paris that its championships would not be played as scheduled in Bali, Indonesia, next month.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Eritrea: Officials Defend Crackdown
description: The government said today that its crackdown on opposition leaders and journalists was prompted by disloyal and insulting acts against the ruling party. The Eritrean People's Front for Democracy and Justice criticized the dissidents for speaking out against the president, Isaias Afewerki, while the country was in a fierce battle with neighboring Ethiopia last year. Along with 11 opposition leaders, the government has arrested numerous journalists and closed all the country's privately owned newspapers. The government said the critics were guilty of abdication of responsibility in Eritrea's difficult hours and possibly of grave conspiracy. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLERMAN, PETER
description: KELLERMAN-Peter. The management, brokers and staff of Ashforth Warburg Associates mourn the loss of Peter Kellerman, son of our colleague Joyce Gales, at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. To Joyce, to Peter's wife Robi and to the whole family, we extend our deepest love and sympathy. Frederick W. Peters, President Jane Bayard, Executive Vice-Pres.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about a memorial service at Yankee Stadium for the victims of the World Trade Center attack misstated the given name of a man embracing his wife, Evelyn Lopez, who lost her brother. The man was John Stephens, not Daniel.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: How an Unhesitating Ruse At Play 1 Saves the Contract
description: The oldest of the championships postponed yesterday by the World Bridge Federation is the Bermuda Bowl, first played in 1950. Two of the last three Bermuda Bowl competitions have been won by an American team led by Nick Nickell, a New York financier. One of these, played in Beijing in 1995, is the subject of a new book, ''Win the Bermuda Bowl With Me'' by Jeff Meckstroth, one of Nickell's teammates, and Marc Smith. It is available for $21.95, including mailing, from Baron Barclay Bridge Supplies, at (800) 274-2221.

title: America's Move: Room for Guns and Butter?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lloyd's Expects Claims From Attacks to Top $1.9 Billion
description: Lloyd's of London, the world's biggest insurance market, said today that it expected to face 1.3 billion in claims ($1.92 billion) related to the terrorist attacks on the United States, making it the most costly single calamity in Lloyd's 320-year history.

title: Arafat and Peres Renew Peace Vow Despite Nearby Clash
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Shimon Peres, the Israeli foreign minister, jointly pledged a renewed drive for peace today, though the choreographed harmony of their meeting was marred by a clash within earshot between Israeli and Palestinian fighters that injured three Israeli soldiers.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: Readers share their insights and answer other readers' travel questions.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Syracuse: Three Arabs Leave University
description: Three Arab students have temporarily left Syracuse University, in part because of reports of harassment of those of Arab heritage. The students, two from Kuwait and one from the United Arab Emirates, have been granted a leave of absence to return to their home countries, said Kevin Morrow, a university spokesman. They left not because of actual physical or verbal assaults, ''but because their parents perceived potential problems might occur,'' he said. Kuwait's embassy in Washington is offering one-way emergency airline tickets to students worried about their safety. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: 1 Night, 4 Firsts From Harlem Dance Theater
description: Just when everything related to the World Trade Center tragedy seems not so much said as resaid and when still another rendition of ''God Bless America'' promises a ritualized expression of faith in God and country, invigorating emotions can erupt from these same rituals.

title: Coca-Cola and Procter Call Off Joint Venture
description: Coca-Cola machines will not be dispensing cans of Pringles around the world after all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDOWELL, JOHN F., JR.
description: McDOWELL-John F., Jr. Age 33 of Manhattan was tragically lost on September 11, 2001 in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. John was a vice president in equities at Sandler O'Neill & Partners. He was the beloved son of John F., Sr. & Patricia. Brother of Megan and fiance of Bebe Morrissey. His love of life and laughter inspired us all. He will be greatly missed by family and friends. Memorial services will be held Saturday, September 29th at noon at St. Rosalie's Catholic Church, Hampton Bays, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Sandler O'Neill Foundation and Mercy High School, Riverhead, NY. For information contact R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, Hampton Bays, New York.

title: As Renaissance Shuts Down, More Failures Are Seen as Possible
description: The shutdown of Renaissance Cruises on Tuesday, the industry's first casualty after the terrorist attacks, could be repeated at other lines, analysts of the industry say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISHKIN, LEWIS
description: MISHKIN-Lewis. Our beloved brother-in-law and uncle, we will always remember you. Love, Sunny, Gary, Alissa and Steven

title: I.M.F. Sees World Growth At Its Weakest In a Decade
description: The global economy is likely to grow at its weakest rate since the early 1990's, though it may narrowly avert a recession this year, the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: Bush Announces Air Security Plans and Seeks to Reassure Public
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27  Trying to soothe the frayed nerves of reluctant American travelers, President Bush announced today that the federal government would take on a larger role in airport security and that more than 4,000 National Guard troops would begin protecting the nation's 420 commercial airports within days.

title: Ferrer's Choice: Appeal to Pride, Or Embrace All
description: Fernando Ferrer won a spot in a Democratic runoff in large part, Democrats said yesterday, because he rallied black and Latino voters with his promise to represent the ''other New York,'' and by embodying the hope of electing the city's first Puerto Rican mayor.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From replacing alternators to belt squeals, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Adds A Lawyer
description: Microsoft hired a prominent trial lawyer, Daniel K. Webb, in preparation for a new court battle with government antitrust enforcers over its Windows monopoly. Mr. Webb, 56, a former United States attorney in Chicago and the lead prosecutor in the Iran-contra trial of John Poindexter, the former national security adviser, will join the trial team in Microsoft's fight with the Justice Department and 18 states. Mr. Webb successfully defended General Electric in 1994 from charges it conspired to fix the price of industrial diamonds. The case was dismissed after prosecutors had presented their evidence in trial.

title: At Work and at Home, Lives Filled With Aspirations and Inspirations
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 300 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 232. In all, 6,347 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: A Chef Who Wants to Reunite His Cooking Family
description: MICHAEL LOMONACO says he owes his survival to a miracle. As the top chef at Windows on the World, he normally arrived at his 106th-floor kitchen at 8:15 each morning.

title: Much of the Policy Criticism Aimed at U.S. Turns Muted
description: Early in September, Oxfam, the British humanitarian organization, was circulating a petition calling on the United States to ''put health before wealth'' by supporting relaxation of international patent policies that Oxfam says make vital medicines too expensive for developing countries.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Top Rebel Killed By Mine
description: Separatist Tamil rebels accused the government of assassinating one of their senior leaders, Shankar, by exploding a Claymore mine under his vehicle in the rebel-held north. They said the killing was another blow to a Norwegian-brokered effort to restart peace talks between the rebels and the government. The government denied any role in the leader's death. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  O'NEAL, EDWARD A.
description: O'NEAL-Edward A. On September 9, 2001. Former Vice Chairman of Chemical Banking Corporation. In loving memory of our friend and colleague. J.P. Morgan Chase & Co.

title: Officials Balk At the Release Of Indictment Of bin Laden
description: A public accounting of the evidence against Osama bin Laden and his allies has been delayed indefinitely by an internal struggle over declassifying secret information, government officials said today.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Professor Jokes About Attack
description: A professor who has taught ancient history at the University of New Mexico for 29 years faces disciplinary action for telling his students after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks that ''anyone who can blow up the Pentagon gets my vote.'' The professor, Richard Bethold, apologized for the remark, calling it ''incredibly stupid.'' A growing number of university officials called for his resignation, and the president, Bill Gordon, said he intended to pursue disciplinary action. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit For Publisher
description: The publisher of the Harry Potter books, Bloomsbury Publishing, said that its first-half sales doubled to 22.7 million ($33.4 million) and that it expected further increases as the fictional boy wizard makes his film debut. Pretax profit rose to 2.85 million ($4.2 million), compared with $273,000 the previous year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEYER, JAMES (JIMMY) GERARD
description: GEYER-James (Jimmy) Gerard, 41. Of Rockville Centre, NY. Suddenly and tragically on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center. Employee of Cantor Fitzgerald. Beloved husband of Cathy (Rosenfeld) Geyer. Devoted father of Michele, Matthew, and Laura. Loving son of Jo Ann and Philip G. Geyer. Dear brother of Philip J., John and Geralyn (Gigi) Marasco. Also survived by many friends and relatives. A memorial mass will be celebrated at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre, on Friday, September 28 at 4:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the James Geyer Family Fund, 801 Woodward Avenue, Ridgewood, N.Y. 11385

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Expanded Counseling Services
description: The state government is expanding the availability of psychological counseling for residents of New York City and nearby counties after the attacks on the World Trade Center, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. The state asked for and received $22.7 million from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which is overseeing disaster relief. The grant covers individual and group crisis-counseling services, referrals, outreach and education for the five boroughs, as well as for Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Putnam and Dutchess Counties. The State Office of Mental Health operates a Web site at www.omh.state.ny.us/, but it was not yet updated yesterday to reflect the program. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Steinbrenner Making Torre Prove Himself
description: Joe Torre clutched a baseball bat wrapped by a sanitary sock, like a baby clinging to a rattle, after the Yankees secured their fourth straight American League East title on a surreal and subdued Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium. Apparently the drained Torre needed something to hang on to after an evening of retrospection and relief.

title: Angelenos' Divide With New York Vanishes
description: This city's attitudes toward New York were always a cocktail of sweet and sour ambivalence, blending braggadocio, competitive pride and cool indifference, with a twist of culture envy.

title: The City's Glory, Seen by Writers
description: It's hard to know what to say about the city, New York, at a moment like this, other than no matter the catastrophe, you can still wander out from the office after work with a sense of excitement, the heady possibility that just around the corner something extraordinary could happen to you. Not the violence, which certainly has never been missing, but a roving and unabashed adventure that could connect with you suddenly and positively, leave you caked with fun and joy. Writers have always known that New York is special and have been drawn to it since the beginning, some to embrace it with abandon and others to slug it out with the city as if in a prizefight.

title: In Close Race, Ferrer Voters Serve as Boost To Thompson
description: William C. Thompson Jr. won the Democratic primary for city comptroller by a wider-than-expected margin, garnering about 54 percent of the vote to 46 percent for Herbert E. Berman. Mr. Berman conceded late Tuesday night.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Jamaica: Help For Airline
description: Facing a decline in visitors, the prime minister of Jamaica, P. J. Patterson, announced steps to help the airline and tourist industry. The government will provide $8 million in additional funds for increased overseas marketing and advertising, and to cover higher insurance costs for Air Jamaica. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Griffey Homers After Request By a Mourner
description: Katrina Marino has tried to maintain any connections to her husband, Kenny, a New York City firefighter missing since the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center. She sends e-mail messages to the friends he played Strat-O-Matic baseball with, she returned to Rescue 1 in Manhattan and looked through his locker, and she treats a stash of his bubble gum like a shrine.

title: Cellphones For a Song, Just in Case
description: THE malls of America are a lot less crowded these days. But there's one fascinating exception: phone centers, which are doing a thriving business.

title: America's Move: Room for Guns and Butter?
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIMEDIA, PUBLISHER, FORECASTS LOWER EARNINGS
description: Primedia Inc., a leading publisher of consumer magazines, said it expected its results this year to fall short of Wall Street forecasts because the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks extended a slowdown in advertising spending. The company, which publishes New York, Seventeen and Motor Trend magazines, among others, now expects earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization to be less than last year's $250 million, after saying in July it would earn $280 million to $300 million. Third-quarter profit from continuing businesses will be $33 million to $36 million, Primedia said.

title: America's Move: Room for Guns and Butter?
description: To the Editor:

title: Transcript of Mike Gray's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, September 18, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Mike Gray, producer, documentarian and screenwriter of "The China Syndrome" This discussion was one in a continuing series organized by forum participants.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: America's Move: Room for Guns and Butter?; A Time to Grieve
description: To the Editor:

title: Mad Cow Disease Sets Off a Scare in Japan
description: A beef scare is sweeping Japan after British scientists confirmed a case of mad cow disease in a Tokyo suburb, the first case of the disease outside of Europe.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Wins Voicestream Contract
description: Nortel Networks of Canada said it had won a $300 million contract to supply equipment for the VoiceStream Wireless cellular telephone network. VoiceStream, which was acquired this year by Deutsche Telekom, will use the equipment in metropolitan Cincinnati and Buffalo. The contract for Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, shows how wireless carriers are moving forward with purchases of equipment needed to provide enhanced data and voice services to customers. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Indictment In Killing Of Sikh
description: A Mesa man accused in the shooting death of the Sikh owner of a gasoline station has been charged with first-degree murder and 11 other counts. The authorities said the victim, Balbir Singh Sodhi, 49, was wearing a turban when he was shot to death on Sept. 15 by Frank Silva Roque, a 42-year-old machinist who assumed Mr. Sodhi, a native of Northern India, was Middle Eastern.

title: Poverty Rate Falls Sharply Among Hispanics, Study Shows
description: Even as the gap in poverty rates between whites and blacks narrowed nationally in 2000, it failed to change in New York City, according to a new analysis of Census Bureau data by an advocacy group for the poor.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Life Refigures Art

title: Maine Brings Manhattan Some Lessons of Island Life
description: North Haven is a small enclave 15 miles off the coast of Maine. There are 350 year-round residents, more than 50 of whom are acting and singing in ''Islands,'' a new musical that was created with and about the people who live on the island. The cast ranges from children in kindergarten to schoolteachers, the local minister, carpenters and roadworkers. Entire families are in the show. The narrator is the island's postman, David Cooper, and his son and two granddaughters are in the chorus.

title: Italy's Premier Calls Western Civilization Superior to Islamic World
description: The Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, in a briefing for journalists, praised Western civilization today as superior to that of the Islamic world and urged Europe to ''reconstitute itself on the basis of its Christian roots.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKINSON, ELLOTT F.
description: PARKINSON-Ellott F. On September 25, 2001. Beloved husband of Lee Ward Parkinson. Devoted father of Ann Eraugey of England. Loving brother of John and Doris of England. Stepfather of Dr. Richard Ward and Dr. Kenneth Ward. Cherished grandfather and stepgrandfather. He was a British citizen who served on a British Navy air carrier in WWII. He was a very special person and he will be missed very much. Family will be receiving friends on Saturday, 2-4, 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral service on Sunday, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 E 77 St, NY, NY 10021.

title: Insurers Ask Help to Survive Future Losses
description: Insurance executives told Congress today that they had plenty of money to pay for about $40 billion of losses from the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. But they said they urgently needed help to provide coverage for possible future violence.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Cuts
description: Air Canada said it would lay off 5,000 workers and reduce its fleet by 84 aircraft in response to a drop in traffic. The carrier, which accounts for about 80 percent of Canada's air traffic, was already cutting 4,000 jobs after its takeover of Canadian Airlines. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Fertile Soil For New Crop Of Farmers
description: WHEN Will Raap came here 20 years ago, he was an urban planner looking for a city that hadn't forgotten its farms. Growing up in Fremont, Calif., he lived near fruit farms. ''Now, it's all malled,'' he said. ''There are no farms left.''

title: Bush Shows Reluctance To Approve Guns for Pilots
description: Indicating that he thought there were better options to increase flight security than arming pilots, President Bush said today that he would introduce ''confidence-boosting'' measures on Thursday to try to convince frightened Americans that it is safe to fly.

title: Posada's Suspension Reduced
description: Jorge Posada's suspension was reduced from six to five games yesterday and he began serving it by missing last night's game against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. Barring rainouts, Posada is eligible to return Tuesday against the Chicago White Sox.

title: F.A.A. Shows Off Force That Protects Airliners
description: Two hooded men sped down the aisles of the airliner, holding knives to the necks of flight attendants while one of the men bellowed: ''This is a hijacking, nobody move. This is my plane. I'll kill you.''

title: Living Under an Electronic Eye
description: IN 1928 Justice Louis D. Brandeis made a prediction. Someday, he wrote in a dissent to a Supreme Court decision on wiretapping, the government may find ways to reproduce documents in court without removing them from ''private drawers.'' Such methods, he warned, will expose ''the most intimate occurrences of the home.''

title: A Wagnerian Hero in Verdi's Poisoned Magic Garden
description: Verdi's ''Otello'' has seduced Ben Heppner, and it is easy to see why. This splendid Canadian heldentenor, the opera world's Tristan of choice, falls so naturally into the title role. He has the bearing, the command and the dignity and, to go with them, an incendiary yet calibrated violence of emotion. He is already a worthy actor, and Sir Peter Hall's careful direction of detail in this new production at the Lyric Opera of Chicago has made him a better one.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: A Huge Excavation Job

title: In America; The Return of Politics
description: This is a city in which it is tough to stay oriented, and that is especially true with politics, which is emerging with a vengeance from its post-Sept. 11 hiatus.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNETMUSICNET SAYS TECHNOLOGY IS IN PLACE MusicNet, a joint venture backed by three major record labels that plans to sell music over the Internet, said it had completed the technological foundation of its service. Richard Wolpert, left, a board member of MusicNet, said a preview of its service would be offered for journalists and industry analysts next week. But the public unveiling of the product could be two months away, MusicNet officials said. The company, which had planned to begin a service by the end of the summer, insisted it had met its revised timetable. MusicNet, which is backed by AOL Time Warner ( news/quote ), Bertelsmann and the EMI Group, as well as RealNetworks ( news/quote ), said it had designed a basic template that Internet sites can use to sell music for download on a subscription basis, though the price and structure of the service remain unspecified.   Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDIN, LEWIS
description: RUDIN-Lewis. Another pillar of our community is gone, but has left his mark forever. Friend and colleague in many endeavors, he was always ready to help a worthy cause. Our deepest sympathy to his family. The Weiler and Arnow Families

title: What's Doing Around Town
description: From Broadway and Off Broadway to concert halls and jazz clubs, New York City's stages are returning to normal schedules. Here is a sampling of performances.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Uncasville: Worker Falls To His Death
description: A construction worker at a $1 billion addition to the Mohegan Sun casino died on Monday after falling 17 stories, the state police said. The man, whose name was not immediately released, died shortly after 7:05 p.m., the evening before the addition was to open. There was no information on what caused the fall, but the police said there was no evidence to suggest a homicide. The worker was an employee of Perini Building, the construction contractor. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: MILITARY CALLED JUST ONE ELEMENT IN WAR ON TERROR
description: Facing some skepticism from NATO allies over going to war to eradicate terrorism, the Bush administration said today that military operations would not be the ''primary piece'' of its campaign.

title: A New Kind of War
description: President Bush is rallying the nation for a war against terrorism's attack on our way of life. Some believe the first casualty of any war is the truth. But in this war, the first victory must be to tell the truth. And the truth is, this will be a war like none other our nation has faced. Indeed, it is easier to describe what lies ahead by talking about what it is not rather than what it is.

title: America's Move: Room for Guns and Butter?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lone-Driver Limits Meet Mostly Road Resignation; Many Commuters Say Sacrifice Makes Sense
description: Some compared it to sneaking totalitarianism, and they asked what other unalienable rights would soon disappear. Others were not quite so upset. They simply compared it to martial law.

title: Red, White and Blue Christmas
description: Earlier this year, as Saks Fifth Avenue was starting to plan its ad campaign for Christmas 2001, it chose to highlight a piece of jewelry: a white-gold-and-diamond bracelet shaped like the Manhattan skyline, including the World Trade Center's twin towers.

title: Transcript of Joseph D. McNamara's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, September 25, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Joseph D. McNamara. Mr. McNamara was appointed a research fellow at the Hoover Institute at Stanford University in 1991. He was chief of police for the city of San Jose, California, for fifteen years. This discussion was one in a continuing series organized by forum participants.

title: A Grim Formality Is Made Easier for Families
description: Practically speaking, the process could not have been made any easier. Forms were streamlined, waiting periods eliminated, fees waived.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the results of the City Council primary election referred incorrectly in some copies to the relationship of the Rev. Ruben Diaz, a Bronx candidate, to Assemblyman Ruben Diaz Jr. The candidate is the assemblyman's father, not his son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONROY, KEVIN F.
description: CONROY-Kevin F. On September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Georgette (nee Newman). Loving father of Matthew, Jamie, Christine and Jill. Brother of Michael and Ellen, and Edward and Barbara. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Dedicated employee of Marsh and McLennan. Memorial Mass Saturday, September 29, at 12:30 PM at Immaculate Heart of Mary. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the NYPD and FDNY Widows Benevolent Fund, 40 Fulton St., NY, NY 10038.

title: Phony Bomb Threats Flood in After Terrorist Attacks
description: In the fretful days since the attacks of Sept. 11, many thousands of previously law-abiding Americans have become walk-on aggravators of the national psyche.

title: Reliant to Buy Orion Power For $2.9 Billion
description: Reliant Resources agreed yesterday to acquire Orion Power Holdings, an electric power generator started only three years ago by former bankers from Goldman, Sachs, for $2.9 billion in cash, executives said.

title: Editors' Note; A Nation Challenged
description: News of the terrorist attacks and their aftermath appears today in Section B.

title: Gunman Kills 14 and Himself in Attack on Swiss Legislators
description: GENEVA, Sept. 27  A man armed with a grenade and an assault rifle burst into a parliamentary session in the central Swiss town of Zug today and killed 15 people, including himself, and injured a number of others.

title: A Bouquet of Patriotism
description: In New York City, there is a growing demand for patriotic flower arrangements. Mix these high-contrast colors softly, with ''muted shades of red, white and blue,'' said Renny Reynolds, whose shop, Renny, is on the Upper East Side. His bouquet has red Forever Yours roses, burgundy amaranthus, white nerines, white roses and blue delphiniums ($65); 505 Park Avenue (59th Street), (212) 288-7000. At VSF in Greenwich Village, Todd Rigby, an owner, had similar advice. ''Mix textures, and don't make them gaudy,'' he said. VSF's $50 bouquet, above, uses dahlias, roses and nerines (red), Queen Anne's lace and lisianthus (white), and gentians (blue). VSF is at 204 West 10th Street (Bleecker Street), (212) 206-7236. ELAINE LOUIE

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Menem Wins Privacy Ruling
description: The Supreme Court has ordered a weekly political magazine to pay $60,000 in damages to former President Carlos Saul Menem over a series of stories reporting that he had an illegitimate son whom he refused to recognize. The court did not rule on the accuracy of the reports, but ruled that they violated the former president's privacy. The reports were published near the end of Mr. Menem's two terms in 1999. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Several Council Races Are Undecided, and May Take a While to Call
description: As the face of the next City Council began to take shape with the unofficial results from Tuesday's rescheduled primary election, it became clear that several of the races remained too close to call and were likely to remain that way for several days, if not weeks.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Nikki Oden, Diana Scott, Murrells Inlet, S.C., July 18, 2001

title: If No Ones Hears Digital Radio, Does It Make a Sound?
description: Digital radio made its debut this week in parts of the United States. But that doesn't mean many people were listening.

title: America's Move: Room for Guns and Butter?; 'Enduring Freedom'
description: To the Editor:

title: States Are Asked to Pull Over Any Truck Allowed to Carry Hazardous Cargo
description: Confronted with a new potential terrorism threat, the Department of Transportation is asking state law enforcement agencies to pull over every truck with hazardous materials placards and to check the drivers' credentials and paperwork, officials said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: MusicNet Says Technology Is In Place
description: MusicNet, a joint venture backed by three major record labels that plans to sell music over the Internet, said it had completed the technological foundation of its service. Richard Wolpert, left, a board member of MusicNet, said a preview of its service would be offered for journalists and industry analysts next week. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONLON, MARGARET M.
description: CONLON-Margaret M. On September 25, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Joseph W. Dear mother and mother-in-law to William and Jean Conlon of New York City, Andrea and Rowland Gersen of Unionville, Pennsylvania and Jane and James Goble of Freeport. Cherished grandmother to Peter Conlon and Joseph, Alison and Ted Gersen.

title: Primary Turnout Much Higher Than Forecast
description: Turnout for Tuesday's rescheduled primary in New York City, which had initially been judged unusually low by many politicians and election experts, appears to have been far higher than expected, suggesting that the gloom sowed by the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center did not deter people from voting.

title: Consumers indicate they want companies to respond to attacks in an optimistic manner.
description: A PICTURE is beginning to emerge of how consumers may change their behavior and attitudes as a result of the terrorist attacks as several agencies offer the results of surveys taken after Sept. 11.

title: America's Move: Room for Guns and Butter?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Return of Michael Jordan; Alas!
description: Michael Jordan has done it all. Six championship rings, 10 scoring championships, best all-time career scoring average, five most-valuable-player trophies, all-offensive and all-defensive teams -- you name it, he's got it, been it and done it. Moreover, he even made a successful comeback in 1995, a rare accomplishment, after an unsuccessful detour into minor league baseball. But one comeback was enough.

title: Piazza Hurt And So Are Mets' Hopes In Division
description: The Mets' pursuit of a playoff spot is fragile under any circumstances. They must win almost all their games and get a lot of help from the teams ahead of them. Their hopes almost took a crippling blow in the first inning tonight when their best player, catcher Mike Piazza, was forced from the game after taking a foul tip off his right thumb.

title: The January Slowdown Makes an Early Arrival
description: At the moment that terrorists attacked the World Trade Center and indirectly administered a body blow to his business, Barry S. Sternlicht was in one of the most secure spots in America.

title: Bonds May Take Pavano And Trachsel Off Hook
description: By the end of next week, Steve Trachsel and Carl Pavano will know if those highlights they keep seeing will finally go away.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sun Offers Details On ID System
description: Sun Microsystems and 33 other companies and organizations announced yesterday an online identification initiative, the Liberty Alliance. The project, they said, is an effort to make sure that the technology for identifying the customers for a coming generation of Internet services is open and based on industry-standard technology. The Liberty partners said their software technology would be jointly developed and freely distributed, providing a standard they said would be crucial for the growth of electronic commerce. The alliance includes nontechnology companies like American Airlines, Bank of America and Fidelity Investments. But leading technology companies in the group, like Sun and RealNetworks, are rivals of Microsoft. Microsoft last week said that its online identity system, Passport, would include industry-standard technology so that it can share information with other online identity and authentication systems. The impact of Liberty will be as an insurance policy, to make sure Passport really is open instead of a closed, proprietary Microsoft technology, said David Smith, an analyst at the Gartner Group. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: GIULIANI EXPLORES A TERM EXTENSION OF 2 OR 3 MONTHS
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was exploring the possibility yesterday of getting the three mayoral candidates to agree to an extension of his term for two or three months to ease the transition to a new administration, as New York attempts to recover from a terrorist attack.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Demonstrations Held Outside U.S. Embassy in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 27  With hundreds of protesters burning American flags outside the gates of the United States embassy and with fringe groups threatening to kill Americans, the State Department said today that most of the embassy staff members could leave the country if they choose.

title: Boxing Returns to Normal
description: WHEN Bernard Hopkins walked into the Theater at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon for a news conference, there was stunned silence as Hopkins and his bodyguards settled into their seats. Hopkins wore his normal workout gear, but what jolted reporters was his headgear: a black bandanna with three large, white letters across the front. WAR.

title: U.S. Embassy In Kabul Is Destroyed By Protesters
description: Thousands of Afghan protesters turned a Taliban march to the abandoned American Embassy in Kabul into a frenzied attack today, chanting Osama bin Laden's name and waving white flags of Islam as they torched the compound, burned American flags and hacked at the mothballed chancery building with an ax.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Talks On Squatters Break Off
description: Talks intended to resolve a legal battle between government officials and white commercial farmers broke down as the two sides argued in the Supreme Court about whether the police had restored order on farms occupied by black squatters. The government says it has arrested and convicted unruly squatters, but the farmers say many incidents are still ignored by the police. Officials are discussing a proposal by the farmers, who have offered to sell some land in an effort to resolve the long-running dispute. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Ban on Shipping Nuclear Waste Is Lifted
description: The Energy Department said today that the moratorium on the shipment of low-level nuclear waste, put in place on the day of the terrorist attacks, was lifted earlier this week, sending truckloads of material to disposal and storage sites around the country.

title: Art for Sale, but Will Anyone Be Buying?; In Attack Aftermath, Traditionally Lucrative Fall Season Faces Uncertainty
description: In the months leading up to the $500 million fall art season there's always uncertainty, but not since the Persian Gulf war has there been anything like this. In the wake of the terrorist attacks, collectors, dealers and auction house officials are coping with personal and financial losses. There have also been last-minute postponements of major shows and disruptions of shipping and travel plans.

title: Deutsche Bank Puts Off Sale of Its Daimler Stake
description: Deutsche Bank said today that it had shelved a plan to sell part of its 12 percent stake in DaimlerChrysler. Shares of Daimler have slumped 27 percent since the terror attacks in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, HERMAN
description: SANDLER-Herman, 57. Loving husband of Suki, devoted father of Pamela, Gillian and Jordana, role model and mentor to hundreds of young people. You encouraged us to take risks and gave us innumerable opportunities to follow our dreams, cheering us on as we learned to impact the world as you did so powerfully. You will always remain our awesome inspiration. We love you, Suki, Pamela, Gillian and Jordana. In lieu of flowers, gifts honoring Herman may be made to any of the following organizations: American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, The Rain Forest Foundation, The Perlman Music Program, Carnegie Hall, or UJA Federation of NY.

title: Book Says Nixon Considered a Woman for Supreme Court
description: Though he regarded women as too ''erratic'' and ''emotional,'' President Richard M. Nixon was strongly inclined to nominate a woman to the Supreme Court in 1971, according to White House tapes cited in a new book.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Hispanic Nominee For Court
description: Gov. Gray Davis nominated Carlos R. Moreno, 52, a Federal District Court judge in Los Angeles, to serve as an associate justice of the California Supreme Court. The nomination of Mr. Moreno, left, who was appointed to the federal bench in 1998 by President Bill Clinton, must be approved by the three-member Commission on Judicial Appointments. He would be the only justice on the seven-member court appointed by a Democrat, and the first Hispanic on the court in more than a decade.

title: Bloomberg Raises His Profile and Promises New Strategy
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican nominee for mayor, said yesterday that his multimillion-dollar advertising campaign would be back on television and radio by this weekend and that voters should give his rsum a fresh look in light of the World Trade Center attacks.

title: Footlights
description: Out of Africa

title: Leadership for a Wounded City
description: Before Sept. 11, New York City voters were thinking about choosing the leaders of an almost wholly new government to take office on Jan. 1. They were looking for candidates who would sustain the successes of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's administration, like reducing the crime rate and welfare rolls, while tackling issues it did not successfully address, like school performance and affordable housing. They wanted a new mayor to listen more carefully to those who felt excluded from City Hall. With signs of an economic downturn, many voters also hoped our new leaders would be able to negotiate hard choices fairly and get more out of city government.

title: Company Says Bid by Raider Is Still Too Low
description: Harold C. Simmons, the billionaire corporate raider, lost his latest takeover bid yesterday -- at least for this round.

title: State Seeks to Play a Role In the Reconstruction Effort
description: Officials in Albany and Washington say that the effort to rebuild after the destruction of the World Trade Center will be controlled primarily by the state and federal governments, not the city, although they concede that as yet, they have little idea what that effort would look like or how it would be managed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the opening page of The Metro Section yesterday, with an article about the mood of voters, omitted a full name in some copies for a 42-year-old Brooklyn caterer who was still researching her decision on Primary Day. She is Bonnie Boyle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, STEVENS, ALINE
description: LARKIN - STEVENS - Aline. Sep tember 24, 2001 of Buffalo, N.Y. Wife of Raymond D. Stevens, Jr. Mother of Raymond D. Stevens, III, Larkin E. Stevens, Courtney S. Price and Hunter H. Stevens. Also survived by four grandchildren. Daughter of Aline D. Larkin and the late Charles H. Larkin, II; sister of Charles H. Larkin, III. A Memorial Service will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Buffalo, N.Y. Thursday, September 27th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to Disaster Relief Fund of the American Red Cross, 786 Delaware Ave, Buffalo, N.Y. 14209 or the charity of choice. For information George J. Roberts & Son Funeral Home 716-832-2123.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUDNOW, BETTY
description: CHUDNOW-Betty. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Betty Chudnow. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband Mark, and their family. Richard J. Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

description: WASHINGTON -- President Bush is rallying the nation for a war against terrorism's attack on our way of life. Some believe the first casualty of any war is the truth. But in this war, the first victory must be to tell the truth. And the truth is, this will be a war like none other our nation has faced. Indeed, it is easier to describe what lies ahead by talking about what it is not rather than what it is.

title: Military Families Turn, Gingerly, to the Net
description: AT 34, Christopher Michel sounds like an old geezer. A Navy navigator and mission commander in the early 1990's, he calls himself ''a representative of the old school, the old generation.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Lycos Forecasts Profit
description: Lycos Europe, the Internet service owned by Bertelsmann and Lycos, said it expected cost reductions and 300 job cuts to help it become profitable by December 2002. The company lost 202.2 million euros ($186.8 million) in the fiscal year that ended in June, Lycos Europe said. It lost 39.8 million euros ($36.7 million) in the fourth quarter after a loss of 45.4 million euros in the third.

title: Judge Rules That Police Policy Violates Officers' Free Speech
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that New York City police officers do not have to notify the department before they speak as private citizens to government agencies, investigative bodies or private groups.

title: Giuliani Acknowledges Desire to Extend Term for Months
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is scheduled to leave office when his term ends on Dec. 31, acknowledged today that he would like to stay on as mayor and help the city administration through a smooth transition process after the terrorist attacks in New York City.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Schools Closed by Disaster Are Losing Some Children
description: The idea of sending her daughters to unfamiliar, severely crowded schools while their Battery Park City neighborhood recovered from the World Trade Center attack was too much for Suzanne Schiffman. So she fled New York City last week and signed the girls up for school in the Hamptons, where their summer home has become a semipermanent refuge from the chaos of Lower Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Cutbacks
description: The South Korean carrier Asiana Airlines said it was cutting 3 of its 14 weekly flights to Los Angeles beginning Oct. 8 and was eliminating several flights in Korea. At the same time, Asiana said it was cutting 360 jobs or 5.3 percent of its 8,600-member work force. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Terrorists Are Sought in Latin Smugglers' Haven
description: For decades, this seedy border town has struggled with its reputation as the contraband capital of South America. But now the so-called Triple Frontier suddenly confronts a much bigger problem: 40 F.B.I. agents and police officers from three other countries are scouring the area for evidence that the region has become a haven for Islamic terrorists.

title: Filtering the Web For Young Users
description: YOUR children may say they have to do some online research, but you're afraid that they're really checking out questionable Web sites that have nothing to do with their studies. Or you worry that they may stumble across a pornographic site during an innocent search, or encounter unsavory characters in chat rooms.

title: The Excavation: Planning, Precision and Pain
description: Cranes crisscross against the skyline. Steel-treaded vehicles with scissorlike hands crawl up mounds of wreckage, snapping at twisted beams. Work crews lash cables to the tottering remains of a skyscraper, yanking and twisting, until pieces of the structure finally shiver and tear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MAHONY, MATTHEW T.
description: O'MAHONY-Matthew T. Husband of Lauren Murphy O'Mahony. Son of Helen O'Mahony Bradley of Centereach, NY. Celebration of Life Mass at Saint Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue (between 83rd and 84th), Wednesday, October 3rd at 3PM. In lieu of flowers a donation can be made to: The Matthew T. O'Mahony Memorial Garden Fund, c/o Sue Medoff of Sunnyview, 140 Arch Bridge Road, Ghent, NY 12075. Or donations can also be made to Cystic Fibrosis, 420 Jericho Turnpike, Suite 320, Jericho, NY 11753.

title: Mom Gets a Place in the Woods
description: THIS month, Johanna Winter-Harper was thrilled to enter the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., to study painting. Her joy came to a halt on Sept. 11. ''I felt the desire to be in a safe haven with all my loved ones,'' she said, ''and the most logical place in the world for me would be our house in Maine. It signifies all that is safe, strong, comforting, beautiful.''

title: The Very Rich: Different, Dastardly and Murderous
description: With cultural pundits huffing and puffing on no evidence at all that the age of irony has vanished, Fox's ''Pasadena'' offers an early test case. A mock soap opera and murder mystery about a rich and callous family, the series walks the line between using its genres and satirizing them. The style owes a lot to David Lynch's ''Twin Peaks,'' but such clever, tongue-in-cheek escapism has never been easy to sell on television. (How many successful ''Twin Peaks'' clones popped up?)

title: Ask Your Palm To Use 'Qat' In a Sentence
description: If you happen to be sitting on the subway next to a Palm user who is loudly cursing the letter Q, don't be alarmed. She might be playing the latest game to become available for hand-helds that use the Palm operating system: Scrabble.

title: Corrections

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deadline For Emergency Food Aid
description: People who get food stamps but whose food was lost through power failures or other events after the attacks on the World Trade Center can get replacement food stamps quickly, state officials said yesterday. But the deadline is midnight tonight to report the losses at (877) 472-8411 (for those who speak English and Spanish) and (718) 557-1015 (for those who speak other languages). As many as 10,000 households in Lower Manhattan receive food stamps. Separately, residents who do not currently qualify for food stamps may be eligible for emergency benefits and can call the same numbers.

title: Hilliard Will Play for the Giants With Pain in His Toe
description: Charting the progress of Ike Hilliard's recovery from toe surgery has been the Giants' longest-running melodrama, with enough mysterious twists and turns to make it a mini-series. Today at Giants Stadium, Hilliard, who has been as circumspect with his comments as he has been hobbled on the practice field, finally got a speaking part in the production.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ISAAC
description: STERN-Isaac. With profound sadness, the Board and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc., mourn the passing of our great friend, musician, humanitarian and national treasure, Isaac Stern. During his more than 60 years on the world's concert stages he was an inspiration to audiences and to all who knew him. Through his leadership he redefined what it meant to be a musician. While he once described Carnegie Hall as ''an affirmation of the human spirit,'' he himself was the incarnation of the human spirit. His vision and energy had a profound impact on the cultural life of this great city, an impact that will be felt for generations to come. He led the fight to save Carnegie Hall confirming New York's position as the capital of the music world. Isaac paid no attention to obstacles in his life's many passions, in particular in his support of the State of Israel and to arts education. He touched countless lives; his legacy is immeasurable. Lincoln Center joins with Carnegie Hall and the global family of music makers and music lovers in mourning his loss. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Linda, his sister Eva Hornyak, his children Shira, Michael, and David, and to his grandchildren. Beverly Sills, Chairman Gordon J. Davis, President Jane S. Moss, VP, Programming Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about military recruiting in poor and working-class neighborhoods misstated the surname of a recruiter in some copies. He is Sgt. Leon Shivers, not Chivers.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Since Sept. 11, my bookmarks file -- the list of Web sites I frequently visit or plan to -- has taken on an Orwellian cast. The Terrorism Research Center (www.terrorism.com) now cohabits uneasily with ESPN

title: Demand Up for Security Services
description: As the airlines and tourism industries reel from the fallout of the terrorist attacks, companies that offer security and protection say they are being overwhelmed with demands for their services from businesses, public agencies, colleges and cultural institutions.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Bolivia: Coca Growers Demand Land
description: Coca growers and other peasant union leaders have threatened another wave of road blockades if President Jorge Quiroga does not stop eradicating the coca fields and grant them land. President Quiroga has promised to continue the aggressive coca eradication policies of the former president, Hugo Banzer, who resigned to undergo cancer treatments several weeks ago.

title: After Democratic Victory, Suozzi Turns to Republicans
description: A day after he won the Democratic primary for Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi returned to the campaign trail today, preparing for a race that many believe will be less challenging than the one he faced Tuesday.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Rocky Hill: Son Arrested In Mother's Death
description: A woman who reportedly had tried to have her troubled son committed to a mental health center was found dead last week, the police said, and the son, Aaron Azeredo, 20, was arrested yesterday and charged with first-degree murder. He was being held at a state mental health center and bail was set at $1.5 million. The woman, Deborah Hall, was found on Friday near her apartment complex, dead from multiple stab wounds, said Lt. John Herbst, a police spokesman. Lieutenant Herbst said that the arrest warrant was based on interviews with friends and family. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Azeredo was released from prison on Sept. 14 and that his mother had wanted him committed, but that hospital authorities had refused. Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Street Runs Through London; Many Firms Were Able to Shift Business to British Offices
description: Like many executives in London, Gerard LaRocca, the global chief of operations for Barclays Bank's investment-banking arm, was speaking on the phone with a colleague in New York when the first plane hit the World Trade Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the creation of a Web site for shared listings by Manhattan real estate brokers included a company erroneously among the participants. They do not include Insignia/ESG, the commercial arm of Insignia Financial Group.

title: Fred V. Morrone, 63, Is Dead; Led Port Authority Police
description: Fred V. Morrone, the superintendent of police and director of public safety for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died in the Sept. 11 collapse of the World Trade Center towers, where the agency had its headquarters, his family said. He was 63 and lived in Lakewood, N.J.

title: NATO and Macedonians Agree on Scope of New Force
description: NATO and Macedonian officials agreed tonight on the scope of a new military force to take over as the initial NATO mission ended today.

title: Chrysler Awards for Designs That 'Make Us Curious'
description: The 2001 Chrysler Design Awards will be awarded to seven people on Oct. 17. ''They engage us in a visceral, direct way, and make us curious,'' said Leslie Gill, a Manhattan architect who helped oversee the awards, which are $10,000 each. One winner is Kathryn Gustafson, a landscape architect from Seattle who designed the fountains and the Arthur Ross Terrace at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan, below. Another is the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister, who created a 1996 CD cover for Lou Reed, shown above left. ''His work is fresh, personal and emotional,'' said Tod Williams, a juror. Other winners are Susan Kare, who designed icons for the Apple Macintosh; Daniel Rozin, for new interactive technology; Thom Mayne, and the team of Robert Mangurian and Mary-Ann Ray, all architects. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Mother Gets $750,000 in Suit Against Her Daughter's Killer
description: The mother of a 7-year-old girl who was raped and murdered in 1973 was awarded $750,000 yesterday in a lawsuit against her daughter's killer, after she lobbied successfully for the repeal last year of New Jersey's two-year statute of limitations on wrongful-death suits.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank Expects Profit Fall
description: Switzerland's second-largest bank, the Credit Suisse Group, said its third-quarter profit would drop substantially below last quarter because of the drop in the markets after the attacks on Sept. 11. The aftermath will ''exacerbate the already difficult economic and market conditions experienced by all our businesses,'' particularly Credit Suisse First Boston, the bank said. The group's second-quarter net income declined 23 percent. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

description: Imay be going out on a limb here, but it looks to me as though the economy's high-flying days are truly over for a while.

description: PALAZZOLO - Richard ''Rico''. Lost in WTC September 11th. Memorial Mass Sunday, September 30th, at 2 PM, Holy Spirit Church, 500 Jericho Tpke., New Hyde Park.

title: Generals Given Power to Order Downing of Jets
description: President Bush has authorized two midlevel Air Force generals to order commercial airliners that threaten American cities shot down without checking first with him, a senior military officer said today.

title: Designers Look Beyond Debris
description: ON Tuesday night, an impressive sampling of New York architectural talent streamed into the Great Hall at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art to share grief, locate friends and discuss how not to be left out of the rebuilding process in downtown Manhattan. For these architects, engineers and design professors, Sept. 11 was both a tragedy and a call to take a creative stand.

title: Apartment Market: All Bets Off
description: BEFORE the World Trade Center attack, they were, they remembered, in a state of bliss. Their TriBeCa loft, over Bubby's restaurant, was too small for them and their twin babies, but they had just found their fantasy apartment in Brooklyn Heights, a two-bedroom loft with wide-angle views of Lower Manhattan.

title: Airline Bailout Encourages Other Industries to Lobby for Government Assistance
description: The $15 billion airline bailout approved overwhelmingly by Congress has lobbyists for other industries lining up now to make the case that their clients, too, need federal aid.

title: A Hub for Hijackers Found in New Jersey
description: In this neighborhood of Latinos, African-Americans and recent immigrants speaking dozens of languages, the handful of young Arab men who came and went drew almost no notice. In their apartment above a bodega, they did not play loud music. They appeared not to speak English.

title: Once Appalled by Race Profiling, Many Find Themselves Doing It
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 22  Ron Arnold understands racial profiling. "I'm a black American, and I've been racially profiled all my life," said Mr. Arnold, a 43-year-old security officer here, "and it's wrong."

title: Merrill's Asset Management Chief Will Leave
description: Jeffrey M. Peek, who ran the asset management division at Merrill Lynch and who was passed over for the firm's presidency in July, is leaving, Merrill said yesterday.

title: Talk of Chemical War Grows Louder on TV
description: ''Should you buy a gas mask?'' Diane Sawyer asked her viewers Tuesday on ''Good Morning America'' on ABC. ''Should you get vaccines for your kids?''

Contributions in memory of Dr. Ha may be made to South Nassau Communities Hospital Pediatric Rehabilitation, 1 Healthy Way, Oceanside, NY 11572.

title: Is This Country Living? Ask the Cows
description: MY town's annual agricultural fair fell on the Saturday after the attacks on New York and Washington, and I think everyone was relieved when the selectmen decided to go ahead with the event. The turnout, 500 people at least, was huge for a town our size, all of us more pleased than usual to come together as a community.

title: Edwards Asks for Tolerance As Jets Continue to Develop
description: With the Jets 1-1 and still struggling to find their comfort level with the new systems, Coach Herman Edwards suggested today that an extra dose of patience might be necessary when watching the team.
