title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEARY, KEVIN
description: CLEARY-Kevin. The Fordham Law School community records with profound sorrow the tragic loss in the World Trade Center of Kevin Cleary, Class of 1991. Love of life and family were the marks of his character. We extend our deep sympathy to his family. John D. Feerick, Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUSMAN, JOSEPH H.
description: BUSMAN-Joseph H. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Paul and Judy. Adored grandfather of Rachel and Sarah. Loving brother of David. Services 12:30 PM Friday at Bet Torah, Mt. Kisco, NY.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARGILL INC., Wayzata, Minn., the largest agricultural producer, said it would build a plant to produce corn syrup in Shanghai in an equal joint venture with Global Bio-Chem Technology Group, Hong Kong, a corn processor. The 100,000-metric-ton-a-year factory is expected to cost $10.3 million.

title: The Reasons Behind the Return
description: As he prepares for yet another return to basketball, most of the salient questions have been answered. A sculptured, committed and re-engaged Michael Jordan is scheduled to lace up a nouveau line of Nikes on Oct. 30 in the season opener at Madison Square Garden, providing his legions the who, what, where, when and how.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBO, NICHOLAS WILLIAM
description: LAMBO-Nicholas William, 81, of Secaucus, NJ, and Palm Beach, FL, passed away peacefully on September 25, at Englewood Hospital. Cherished husband of Mary Lambo; loving father of Mark and his wife Lisa, Linda and her husband David Shasho; proud grandfather of Jarrett and Parker Lambo; brother of Rosalie and Helen. Nicholas served 4 years in the Air Force in WWII as Commander of the American Legion and UNICO; he was a founding member of Plaza National Bank and Meadowlands Hospital; founding member Montammy Golf Club in Alpine, NJ and Vice President of the Montammy Fund; trustee of FairlieghDickerson University. Visitation Thursday September 27, 2-4 and 79 PM at Mack Memorial Home, Secaucus, NJ; funeral service Friday, September 28 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Englewood Hospital in Englewood NJ and Meadowlands Hospital in Secaucus, NJ, in the name of Nicholas Lambo.

title: Rites of Grief, Without a Body to Cry Over
description: Hundreds of families in the World Trade Center attack, already robbed of the intimacy of the deathbed, are now being cheated out of the rituals of mourning. Having the deceased dressed in her favorite clothes for a Catholic wake, scattering ashes in a river for a Hindu ceremony, reading prayers at the Jewish cemetery, cocooning the body in a white shroud for a Muslim burial: they are traditions born of faith and handed down across time. And none of them are possible.

title: Worldwide Outlook for Tourism Leaves Little Room for Optimism
description: Delegates and speakers at the conference of the World Tourism Organization today offered bleak new estimates of the immediate impact of the terrorist attacks in the United States on tourism worldwide.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: LVMH Names Director
description: LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world's biggest luxury goods group, said it had appointed a former Procter & Gamble executive, Antonio Belloni, as its managing director. Mr. Belloni, 47, replaces Myron Ullman, who will become chief executive of the United States arm, LVMH Inc. Mr. Belloni joined LVMH in June after 22 years at Procter & Gamble.

title: Plan to List Who Receives Disaster Aid Stirs Concern
description: In an effort to coordinate the flow of charity to victims of the World Trade Center disaster, State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer has proposed creating a formal list of every person who gets help and how much money each receives.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 2 Arrested In Immigrant Fraud
description: Two men, one a minister, have been charged with stealing more than $260,000 from illegal immigrants by telling the immigrants that they could get them green cards, said Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx district attorney, left. The men, the Rev. Errol O'Connor, 48, of the Bronx, and Emanuel Felder, 33, of Uniondale, N.Y., were arrested on Tuesday and face grand larceny and other charges. Prosecutors say that Mr. O'Connor, of the Pentecostal Deliverance Ministries in the Bronx, falsely claimed in radio commercials that he could obtain resident alien status for immigrants for a fee, which averaged about $4,000. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Man Caught In 2000 Plot Is Helping Investigators
description: Nearly forgotten until Sept. 11, an Algerian-born operative for Osama bin Laden's network was sitting in a federal detention center just south of here, awaiting sentencing for his role in a plot to bomb Los Angeles International Airport during the 2000 millennial celebrations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLLINS, MICHAEL L.
description: COLLINS-Michael L. Died September 11, 2001 at The World Trade Center offices of Cantor Fitzgerald. Services Saturday October 6, 2:30pm at Presbyterian Church of Upper Montclair, NJ at Inwood & Norwood Avenues.

title: In TriBeCa, 'Open' Signs And Empty Sidewalks
description: JUST two weeks ago, TriBeCa was a thriving neighborhood thick with shops for the well-appointed home. On Sept. 11, all business stopped. Store owners have gone without electricity and phone service, cut off from the deliveries and pedestrian traffic that are their lifeblood. Even today, TriBeCa remains in the limbo that city officials call Zone 2.

title: Iran Won't Join U.S. Campaign, Leader Says
description: Iran's supreme religious leader declared today that his nation would not take part in a campaign led by the United States, accusing Washington of using the Sept. 11 terror attacks as a pretext to further its own interests in the region.

title: A Biometrics Camera That Looks You in the Eye
description: With a new system from Panasonic, users won't have to remember passwords to log on to their computers each morning. But they will have to be awake enough to allow a special camera to stare deeply into their eyes. The Panasonic Authenticam captures and stores digital images of up to six users' irises. When any of those people logs on to the computer, the camera uses recognition software to compare the user's iris with the stored images in search of a match.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHU, RAYMOND
description: CHU-Raymond. On September 24th. Husband of Elaine. Loving father of Steven and Karen. Caring father-in-law of Mayling and James. Devoted grandfather of eight. Visiting Friday 3-7PM at Chinese Cheung Sang Funeral Home, 22 Mulberry St. New York City. Funeral Saturday 10am. Interment at Cypress Hills Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Cuts At Bombardier
description: The aerospace and transportation equipment group Bombardier said it was cutting production of regional and corporate aircraft, reflecting lower demand. The company, based in Montreal, also said it would not meet profit forecasts and would write off 927 million Canadian dollars ($590 million) related to the development of a turboprop aircraft and a financial services unit. About 3,800 workers will be laid off in Canada, the United States and Britain. Robert Brown, chief executive, now expects Bombardier to deliver about 370 aircraft this year, about the same as 2000, but down from 410 that had been expected. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIGIOVANNA, BALDWIN J.
description: DiGIOVANNA-Baldwin J. On September 25, 2001. Beloved husband of Josephine. Loving father of Lawrence, Rosanne and Joanne. Dear brother of Anthony. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 AM, St. Ann's Church, S.I. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Vincent's Services, 66 Boerum Place, Brooklyn.

title: Canada Supports U.S. Freeze on Terrorists
description: Canada said yesterday that it had frozen the assets of groups identified by the United States as linked to terrorism. But the finance minister, Paul Martin, speaking in Parliament two days after President Bush named 27 such groups and individuals, did not identify any groups that might be operating in Canada.

title: A Sacrifice for Commuters
description: Add paralyzing gridlock to the long list of aftershocks from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. In an effort to make traffic in New York City flow more easily, beginning today vehicles with a single occupant will be banned from crossing into Midtown and Lower Manhattan on weekdays from 6 a.m. to noon. This will mean inconvenience for a number of commuters, but the action is more than a little justified. Americans have been telling each other for the last two weeks that this is wartime, and that they are prepared to make sacrifices. This is going to be one of them.

title: Shares Resume Slump on Gloom Over Economic Prospects
description: Stocks fell yesterday as corporations provided investors with more reasons to doubt that the economic downturn, already worsened by the terrorist attacks, would end soon.

title: Redskins' Problems May Begin With Schottenheimer
description: Probability became predictability and prickly warning signs spiraled into a fiasco among the Washington Redskins yesterday when Coach Marty Schottenheimer released quarterback Jeff George.

Loving father of Lorrie Gordon, Leslie McQuilling, T. Merrick McQuilling II, Ann Denihan & Patricia Spellman. Fatherin-law of Catherine McQuilling, Harold Gordon, Laurence Denihan and Richard Spellman. Brother of Ann Louise Christsen, Jane Mason and James Alexander McQuilling. Thomas Merrick was born in Flushing, NY, attended Flushing High School and graduated Admiral Farragut Academy in 1939. He joined the US Navy in 1941 and graduated from the USS Naval Academy in 1945. He served in the Pacific Theatre. Following W.W. II he was employed by Standard Oil of Indiana, Daniel K. Ludwig, shipowner and Amerada Hess. In 1972 he founded the world renowned oil tanker brokerage firm of McQuilling Brokerage Co. Inc. He was the past president of the American Legion Hague Post and a long standing member of North Hills Country Club, Manhasset, NY. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset from 2-4 Tuesday and 2-4 and 6-8 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial 11:45 AM St. Mary's RC Church Manhasset. title: A Penchant for Stars and Bars
description: The American flag pattern turns up over and over again in folk art. The flag ''has been a popular motif since the 19th century,'' said Frank Miele of the Frank J. Miele Gallery, which opened this summer on the Upper West Side. A 20-by-33-inch hooked rug on burlap (above, $2,000) by Polly Minnick of Georgia is made of wool strips from old garments. A wood serving tray (below, $75) is based on an idiosyncratic flag painting (note the ahistoric 16 stars) by Warren Kimble, a folk artist in Brandon, Vt. A 20-piece porcelain dinnerware set, based on the same painting, is $145; mugs are $15 each. Four glass tumblers cost $35. A 20-piece cutlery set is $48. The Frank J. Miele Gallery is at 196 Columbus Avenue (69th Street).

title: Pitt Chases Spirit of Past Glory
description: On a white wall in the new headquarters of the Pittsburgh Panthers' football team hangs a black-and-white photograph of Marshall Goldberg, his rugged facial features surrounded by the flaps of a leather helmet. Goldberg was an all-American halfback during one of the team's great eras, the late 1930's, but he is more than just a memory.

title: Human Rights Group Cites a Setback in Haiti
description: In Haiti, respect for human rights and the rule of law has fallen to its lowest point since democratic rule was restored in 1994, according to a report by Amnesty International, to be released on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWMAN, SHAWN E., JR.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, STEPHEN L.
description: SINGER-Stephen L. Beloved husband of Linda, father of Juliette and Ian, Stuart and Sally, and Lauren and Steve. Grandfather to Kyle, Tyler, Samantha, Will, Spencer and Scott. Passed away on September 25, 2001 after a courageous bout with cancer. A native of New Rochelle NY, Mr. Singer graduated from Harvard College in 1957, Harvard Business School in 1959, and the University of Birmingham, England. In 1959, he joined Finlay Fine Jewelry and became President and CEO in 1976. In 1983, he started an estate jewelry firm that now runs over 1000 events a year. Mr. Singer was always active in many industry and charitable organizations. Most recently, he actively served on the boards of Project A.L.S. and American ORT. Within the jewelry industry, he was a member of the 24k Club of New York, the Plumb Club, JIC, JSA, AGS, JVC. He has always given generously to education and the arts, Harvard, the American Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum were among his favorites. His greatest enjoyments and memories include traveling with Linda, playing in his pool with his grandchildren, working out and playing backgammon at the Harvard Club, tennis at QRC, and gardening in his backyard. He will be greatly missed by many, but most by his adoring family. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Project A.L.S. Services to be held Friday, September 28, 11:45am at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In a Time of Stress, Knitting and Quilting
description: Perhaps it's the time for knitting or quilting, which offer a chance to be with others while being productive. ''Knitting is meditative and calming,'' said Marjorie Forman, an owner of Downtown Yarns, a new East Village store where you can buy yarn, from cotton to cashmere, and take knitting courses at all levels. Taught by experts, they consist of two or four classes; classes are $25 each and last two hours. The store is at 45 Avenue A (Third Street); (212) 995-5991. Sew Brooklyn, a Park Slope shop that sells quilting and knitting supplies, offers 23 quilting classes. The classes, freehand composition to machine quilting, are taught by professionals. Two two-hour classes are $50; eight two-and-a-half-hour classes, $190. For information: www .sewbrooklyn.com. The store is at 228 Seventh Avenue (Third Street), (718) 499-7383.

title: British Arrest 7 Near Air Base
description: The British police arrested six Iraqis and a German on Wednesday after men described as stowaways were found hiding in a truck outside an air force base in eastern England used by American forces.

title: A Retooled RealPlayer Competes for Music Lovers
description: Streaming media is quite common on the Web these days, but as many companies have found, a steady stream of revenue is also needed. RealNetworks, which has made the RealPlayer software for viewing Internet audio and video since 1995, recently announced plans for its new RealOne media subscription service and updated user software, the RealOne Player.

title: Pettitte's Elbow Injury May Affect Playoff Plan
description: Andy Pettitte was the lone question mark in the Yankees' dominant rotation. They were hoping last night that he would right himself after his recent pitching woes, solidifying what could be the most dominant playoff foursome in baseball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIAFARDINI, CHRISTOPHER
description: CIAFARDINI-Christopher. Died Tuesday, September 11, 2001 in the tragic destruction of the World Trade Center in New York City. He was 30 years old and a Vice President, Financial Analyst at Fred Alger Management, Inc. He joined Fred Alger Management, located on the 93rd floor of World Trade Center Tower North, in March of this year. Born May 8, 1971, Christopher leaves behind a loving family and many close friends and admiring co-workers. He is survived by his father, Edward, of East Norwich, New York; his mother, Maggie, of New York City; and an older brother, Dominic, also of New York City. Christopher also leaves behind loving grandparents, and numerous aunts, uncles and cousins. ''Christopher was a quiet, deliberate man who had strong opinions and high ideals,'' Dominic recalls of his brother. ''He had a passion for Wall Street, and was so happy to be working high in the sky for Fred Alger Management.'' Prior to Fred Alger Management, Christopher worked at Merrill-Lynch, Morgan Stanley, Gruntal, and CitiGroup. Christopher attended Oyster Bay High School on Long Island, NY. He graduated with distinction from the University of Colorado at Boulder in 1993, receiving a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics. At Boulder, Christopher was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, the Golden Key National Honor Society, and Omicron Delta Epsilon International Honor Society in Economics. Christopher also attended the Johnson Graduate School of Management at Cornell University, where he received a Master of Business Administration in May 1999. Because of his dedication to his educational pursuits, Christopher was awarded a Johnson School merit-based scholarship. He greatly enjoyed his experience there and sought to continue his connection to the university after graduation by joining the Cornell Club in New York City. To honor his affection for Cornell and the Johnson School his family has established a scholarship in his memory. The family requests that in lieu of flowers and other expressions of condolence, contributions be made to: The Christopher Ciafardini Scholarship, care of SC Johnson Graduate School of Management, Cornell University, 221 Sage Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853. A Memorial Mass will be held for Christopher on Friday, October 5, at 10:30 AM at St. Thomas More's Church, 65 East 89 St. (between Madison Ave. and Park Ave.), in New York City.

description: This ancient trading city languishes on a plateau surrounded by sheer-walled mountains on three sides and a tract of land so vast and forbidding that for centuries people have described it as ''the dump where Allah put the rubbish of Creation.''

title: Ferrer and Green Divide The Spoils of Their Rivals
description: Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green began New York's first mayoral runoff contest since 1977 yesterday by beginning to carve up the support of the two candidates they vanquished in Tuesday's Democratic primary.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Exodus Files For Bankruptcy
description: As expected, Exodus Communications, the nation's largest Web services company, sought bankruptcy protection yesterday. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., also said it had obtained a commitment for $200 million in financing from GE Capital that would allow it to pay employees and finance ongoing daily operations. Exodus has suffered from the closure of many Internet companies that once purchased its Web services and data storage services. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Essay; All Is Not Changed
description: Legend has it that when Lord Cornwallis formally surrendered to General Washington at Yorktown, ending the Revolutionary War, the redcoated band played ''The World Turned Upside Down.''

description: We guessed at the spot. There. Below the southern wall of what had been the north tower. That was where they had parked the Ryder truck in the basement garage back in 1993. They lit the fuse and ran.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages yesterday about the exhibition ''Art and Home: Dutch Interiors in the Age of Rembrandt'' at the Newark Museum misstated its opening date. It has been postponed to Oct. 17 from this Sunday.

title: Arab Allies Not Jumping to Join U.S. Side
description: Only Iraq, among all Arab countries, has so far failed to condemn the strikes on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. But not even close American allies in the region, such as Egypt and Saudi Arabia, have said clearly that they would enlist in the American-led campaign against terrorism.

description: Fernando Ferrer won a spot in a Democratic runoff in large part, Democrats said yesterday, because he rallied black and Latino voters with his promise to represent the ''other New York.''

description: MAYBE our universe didn't turn upside down as thoroughly as we had thought. That was one of the more surprising conclusions to be drawn yesterday from the New York City primary.

title: A Lower-End Organizer Dreams of the Big Time
description: Palm has added yet another model to the mix of hand-held computers. The new M125 is intended to bridge the gap between the company's entry-level models and the more feature-laden M500 series. The unit has the same shape as the M100 and M105 but adds the expansion slot of the M500 models, which supports the Secure Digital and MultiMediaCard plug-in cards.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Record Label Loses On Copyright Ruling
description: UMG Recordings Inc. infringed copyrights owned by the writers and publishers of ''Love Me Tender,'' ''White Christmas'' and other songs by transmitting them over the Internet, a federal judge ruled. United States District Judge John Martin said UMG, a unit of Vivendi Universal, Europe's biggest media company, failed to get the necessary licenses from composers and publishers of the songs. The decision is the latest to protect the intellectual property rights of copyright holders against those who seek to distribute their works over the Internet.

title: Slow Pace by Athens Has the I.O.C. Worried
description: The International Olympic Committee expressed growing concern yesterday about the slow pace in Athens of building sites for competition, roads and housing in time for the 2004 Summer Games.

title: Nine Arrested as Licenses For Trucking Are Studied
description: As part of a Justice Department investigation prompted by concerns about a possible new terrorism threat, nine people were arrested today on charges of fraudulently obtaining commercial driver's licenses in Pennsylvania to allow them to transport hazardous materials, including explosives, fuels and poisons.

title: Adm. Daniel J. Murphy, 79; Served in Wars and Government
description: Adm. Daniel Joseph Murphy, a retired Navy career officer who held positions in the Carter and Reagan administrations, died on Friday in a hospital in Rockville, Md. He was 79 and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: Nation-Building in Afghanistan
description: The United States has a long and calamitous history of toppling unfriendly foreign governments. The damaging repercussions of cold-war coups in Iran and Guatemala haunt Washington to this day. As President Bush draws up plans to deal with Afghanistan, apparently the first target in the war against terrorism, he must do a better job than some of his predecessors in thinking through the potential consequences of American intervention. There are a lot of tripwires on the road to Kabul.

title: The Return of Michael Jordan; Hooray!
description: Maybe it's because I've reached a certain age, but I tend to think of someone who is 38 years old as a young whippersnapper. So I'm delighted that the aging Michael Jordan is returning to basketball as a player. Naysayers may think he is a pathetic over-the-hill athlete who lacks the common sense to rest on his considerable laurels. Yet, according to reports from young pros who have played pickup games with Jordan recently, it will be a while before he needs a walker. The Knicks coach, Jeff Van Gundy, guesses that on any given night Jordan could still be the best player on the floor.

description: Thousands of residences, businesses and government offices in Lower Manhattan are still without telephone service two weeks after a terrorist attack demolished the World Trade Center and damaged critical communications facilities.

title: Issue Now: Does U.S. Have a Plan?
description: Two weeks after the devastating attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the question of the hour here is this: Does the Bush administration have a well-defined plan of action in what it calls the war on terrorism, or is it groping its way toward a plan?

title: National Briefing | West: California: Poll Finds Governor Trailing
description: A poll by the nonpartisan Field Institute has found greater disapproval than approval of the job performance of Gov. Gray Davis, reversing the support he enjoyed until the energy crisis this year. The poll found that Mr. Davis, a Democrat, trailed his potential Republican opponent in next year's race for governor, the former Los Angeles mayor Richard J. Riordan, who has not even formally announced his candidacy. In the survey, 45 percent of respondents in the survey chose Mr. Riordan in a head-to-head race to 42 percent for Mr. Davis. The survey was conducted on Sept. 7-10 among a random sample of 1,003 California adults, of whom 722 were registered voters. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: David Santiago, 49, Leader In Fight Over Public Housing
description: David Santiago, a community advocate who fought for black and Hispanic access to public housing projects in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in the 1980's and who more recently coordinated protests against the United States military presence in Vieques, died on Sept. 17 in Fairfax, Va., near his home in Annandale, Va. He was 49.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; What's Eating Those Giant Media Stocks?
description: The stocks of almost all major media companies have fallen since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But some are down more than others, and one -- Vivendi Universal -- has even risen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, JOHN
description: MORAN-John. The Fordham Law School community records with profound sorrow the tragic loss in the World Trade Center of John Moran, Class of 1991, FDNY. He was a gentle man and a scholar with a wonderful smile. We extend our deep sympathy to his wife, children and family. John D. Feerick, Dean

title: Democrats Have Trouble Finding 2002 Candidates
description: Top Democratic officials say the terrorist attacks have severely hampered their recruitment efforts, particularly for candidates for the Senate, and have upended their entire political game plan for the midterm elections next year.

title: Hopkins Fights for More Than Another Title
description: Unbeaten since 1993 and having defended his middleweight title 13 consecutive times, Bernard Hopkins has waited a long time for Saturday night.

title: PEABODY ENERGY EXPECTS PROFIT IN 3RD QUARTER
description: The Peabody Energy Corporation, the largest coal producer in the nation, said yesterday that it would earn a profit in the third quarter instead of the loss expected by Wall Street analysts, partly because of higher coal prices. Peabody, which is based in St. Louis, will earn 5 cents to 10 cents a share in the quarter, which ended Sept. 30, the company said. Analysts had expected the company to lose 3 cents a share in the third quarter, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. ''The demand and pricing in both the East and the West have remained at high levels,'' said Vic Svec, a spokesman for Peabody.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Ex-Senator Endorses Dole
description: Former Senator Lauch Faircloth has endorsed Elizabeth Dole in her bid to fill the seat being vacated by Senator Jesse Helms, a fellow Republican. Mr. Faircloth, a Republican who lost his re-election campaign in 1998 to John Edwards, considered running for the Helms seat but withdrew after Mrs. Dole let it be known that she expected to run. Like Mr. Helms, Mr. Faircloth holds significant influence with the conservative wing of the state's Republican Party. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon Starts A Travel Venture
description: Getting into what, until two weeks ago, was the hottest area of the Internet, Amazon.com introduced a department where its shoppers can book travel and buy travel-related merchandise. Mainly, the section includes links to reservations from Expedia.com, the big travel site controlled by Microsoft. It also has links to Hotwire.com, which offers heavily restricted discount tickets, and tour packages from the National Leisure Group. Amazon was set to unveil the section two weeks ago, but put off its debut in the aftermath of the terrorist attack and subsequent falloff in travel. Analysts said Expedia will pay Amazon some fees in return for sending it customers, but the effect on both companies' financial results is expected to be modest. Amazon shares fell 74 cents, or 10.4 percent, to $6.35. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Jazz Emergency Fund, which helps jazz musicians in need, included one performer erroneously among participants in a benefit concert that night in Harlem at the Apollo theater. They did not include Max Roach.

title: F.B.I. Releases Photos of Hijackers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  The Federal Bureau of Investigation today released photographs of all 19 men believed to have been the hijackers who took over four airliners on Sept. 11, crashing two of them into the World Trade Center, another into the Pentagon and a fourth into a field in Pennsylvania.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Attack On a Power Station
description: Gunmen said to be members of the rebel group Unita attacked a power station on the outskirts of the capital, Luanda, the state news agency reported. At least three people were killed in the attack. In August, the rebels attacked a train 80 miles south of Luanda, killing more than 200 people. In May, the rebels raided Caxito, 35 miles from Luanda, killing at least 79 people. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Delta Announces Job Cuts and Reductions in Service
description: In the latest blow to the ailing airline industry, which has lost billions of dollars because of the terrorist attacks, Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would cut up to 13,000 jobs worldwide and reduce its flight schedule by 15 percent because of a plunge in the demand for air travel.

title: After Cuts, the Devils Have No Backup to Brodeur
description: Martin Brodeur is the only goaltender remaining with the Devils after the team assigned the other four to their top minor league affiliate yesterday. The Devils said they had not decided on Brodeur's backup. They can recall a goalie, or select one in tomorrow's waiver draft.

title: CENDANT NAMES NEW CHIEF OF ITS AVIS UNIT
description: The Cendant Corporation, a leading franchiser, named David Siegel as the chairman and chief executive of its Avis Rent a Car System Inc. unit. Mr. Siegel, 39, was chief operating officer at the Budget Group from November 1999 through May 2000, and before that was president of Continental Airlines's Continental Express unit. The position at Avis had been vacant since A. Barry Rand resigned in March 2001, Cendant said. Mr. Siegel will be responsible for sales, marketing, finance and human resources at the car rental company. Cendant bought the 82 percent of Avis Group Holdings it did not already own in March.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Detainee Policy Debated
description: Bergen County is considering accepting more illegal immigrants at its county jail, which is expanding. Negotiations were already under way with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which pays the county to house 52 detainees at the jail. The change is likely to be decided by the next sheriff, who will be elected on Nov. 6. The Democratic candidate, Ken Zisa, who is a state legislator and the Hackensack police chief, opposes more detainees. The Republican, Joe Trella, said that in view of the attacks on Sept. 11 and the possible need to detain more illegal immigrants, Bergen County should help the agency. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: OPEC Holds Informal Talks; Decision on Output Likely Today
description: Ministers from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries ended informal talks today without announcing a decision on daily production levels, but delegates at the meetings said the group planned to leave output unchanged.

title: Jesse Jackson Says He May Try to Meet With Taliban Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 — The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he may try to meet with Afghanistan's Taliban rulers in an effort to persuade them to hand over Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda terrorist associates.

title: Anthrax Scare Prompts Run on an Antibiotic
description: Many New Yorkers -- and to a lesser extent, people across the country -- are stocking up on Cipro, an antibiotic that they believe can be used to treat anthrax.

title: The Investigation So Far
description: In a widening investigation into a possible terrorist plot, nine more people were arrested yesterday on charges of fraudulently obtaining licenses to transport hazardous material. And two others were ordered jailed on suspicion that they had information about the plot to commandeer the airplanes that crashed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GILMORE, THOMAS
description: GILMORE-Thomas In Memoriam. June 19th, 1914February 25, 2001. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gilmore, nephew.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Hospital Plans Layoffs
description: A financially troubled hospital said yesterday that it would lay off workers, but that it would continue to provide care to the poor. The hospital, St. Joseph's Regional Medical Center, is cutting its budget because of reduced federal money and shrinking payments from managed-care companies. About 4,000 people work at the hospital, but it was not immediately clear how many would be laid off, said Michael Heller, a spokesman. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Agriculture Secretary Says Wartime Budget Leaves $171 Billion Farm Bill in Doubt
description: Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman said today that the Bush administration was uncertain whether there was enough money to finance the $171 billion House farm bill, raising the possibility that farm subsidies might be the first major program to feel the pinch of the new wartime budget.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Former Executive Pleads Guilty
description: A former executive of Grand Union, the bankrupt supermarket chain, has pleaded guilty to federal charges of embezzling $2 million, the United States attorney's office in Newark announced Tuesday. The executive, Donald Vaillancourt, submitted false invoices over 16 years from fake companies he created, prosecutors said. Mr. Vaillancourt, 57, who had been a Grand Union vice president and spokesman, faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine when he is sentenced on Jan. 9. Mr. Vaillancourt's lawyer, Michael Critchley, did not immediately return calls seeking comment.

title: For Students, Unexpected Doubts
description: When J. C. Gaither started business school last year, he knew that the job market might soften while he was working toward an M.B.A. But, he says, he had no idea just how much.

title: National Institutes of Health Go From Campus to Fortress
description: Every other Wednesday for the past five years, Gary Daum has come to the National Institutes of Health for what he calls ''wonderful therapy,'' though not the psychiatric kind. Mr. Daum's therapy is music.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Japan Sinks Fishing Boat
description: A Japanese patrol boat rammed and sank a South Korean fishing boat to keep it from fishing in Japanese waters, Japanese authorities said. South Korea said the boat had been fishing near the Japanese economic zone east of Pusan. Japan called the ramming an accident. The waters near the border have been a frequent point of debate on sovereignty over an islet northeast of Pusan held tenaciously by South Korea but claimed by Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, BETTY
description: MANN-Betty, of Little Neck, NY and of Boca Raton, FL, died on September 18, 2001; born May 3, 1920. Beloved wife of Ira, devoted mother of Stevie, Ricky and Freddie, loving mother-in-law of Susan and Susan, cherished grandmother of Eric, Lauren, Jordan, Lindsay and Stacy. Caring daughter, sister, aunt and friend. She was a great and selfless woman who will always be in our thoughts and at our side. We love you with all our hearts, always. Larry and The Kids

title: Economic Scene; In responding to terrorism, the administration is falling short on the economic front.
description: DIPLOMATIC and military efforts may rightly take precedence, but the White House has provided minimal economic leadership since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. What action has been taken, notably the aid to airlines, has been more a reaction to a clear-cut emergency than part of a coordinated plan.

title: Pressing for Rules to Follow Terrorists' Cash
description: Disrupting the finances of Osama bin Laden's terrorist network and others will require a global crackdown, including an end to laws in tax haven countries that allow secret bank accounts, the Senate Banking Committee was told today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, RENEE JUDITH

She was an inspiration to all who knew her, with great spirit, determination, fortitude and conviction. She will be in our hearts forever. Services Friday, 11:30AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Spain Arrests Six From Algeria
description: Spanish authorities said today that they had arrested six men from an Islamic terrorist cell connected to Osama bin Laden who are suspected of assisting militants planning suicide attacks against American targets in Europe.

title: In Black and White, A Palatial Touch For Home Floors
description: The new Vietri ceramic tiles, above, look starkly contemporary, especially in black and white, but are old traditional patterns. The tiles have been hand painted for centuries in Vietri, Italy, best known in this country for its colorful salad bowls decorated with fish, birds and flowers. The 19th-century tile floor below at the Marigliano Palace in Naples can be reproduced with new black and white tiles. The eight-inch tiles can be used on walls or floors, but are not recommended for high traffic areas. The cost is $10 to $12 a square foot at Exinc, 155 East 56th Street, which also carries borders and other sizes.

description: For the young men from the Middle East at the Washington State University campus here, the hardest phone calls are the ones from Mom.

Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. John D. Martin, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEPLIN, MARC SCOTT
description: ZEPLIN-Marc Scott. Age 33. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our son-in-law, Marc Zeplin. Beloved husband of Debra and devoted father to Ryan (3) and Ethan (9 months), Marc is also survived by his loving parents, Leonard and Leona; sister, Joslin; and many relatives and friends. Marc was a vice president at Cantor Fitzgerald, and was in the World Trade Center on September 11th. He received his BA and MBA from the University of Michigan. His love, humor, intelligence, caring and generous spirit will forever be with us. We love him and miss him; he is in our hearts always. In Marc's memory, the family requests that donations be made to the Alliance-College Education Fund (please donate separately for Ryan Zeplin and for Ethan Zeplin), c/o Debra Zeplin, 14 Shelley Lane, West Harrison, NY 10604. Diane and Robert Rosenberg

title: Suspects in Hijackings Exploited Loopholes in Immigration Policy
description: For Hani Hanjour, identified as the pilot who flew the jet that rammed into the Pentagon, blending into the American landscape began in Saudi Arabia with a $110 application for a four-week English course in California. He had only to prove that he had $2,285 to pay for the lessons, along with room and board. He never turned up for class.

title: In the Next Chapter, Is Technology an Ally?
description: OVER the last two weeks, computer scientists and others who think about technology have wondered aloud about its likely role in countering terrorism -- or in carrying it out. Have the limitations and dangers of technology been overlooked? Where, on the other hand, might technological innovation emerge or be redirected as a result of recent events?

title: Sports of The Times; Boxing Returns To Normal
description: WHEN Bernard Hopkins walked into the Theater at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon for a news conference, there was stunned silence as Hopkins and his bodyguards settled into their seats. Hopkins wore his normal workout gear, but what jolted reporters was his headgear: a black bandanna with three large, white letters across the front. WAR.

title: Who's in First Is Clear, but as for Second, It's Still a Mystery
description: With the results of Tuesday's primary for public advocate still up in the air yesterday, officials at the Campaign Finance Board said they would consider authorizing payments for more than two candidates to campaign for the runoff if it remained unclear who had come in second.

title: Prague Journal; Reunion: Prey of Nazis And Their Champion
description: For more than 40 years, Nicholas Winton said nothing about how he rescued 669 children, most of them Jewish, from Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia and brought them across Hitler's Germany to his native Britain.

title: Scrambling to Survive, at a Small Chelsea Caterer
description: The New England chicken potpie and the shrimp pasta salad were about to be loaded into the delivery vans at Jason's Catering -- regular buffet lunches en route to the World Trade Center for 300 employees of two companies that were the small catering firm's linchpin clients.

title: Not a Tourist Site
description: In an executive order issued Tuesday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, amateur photographs of the ruins of the the World Trade Center are prohibited, because the site is a crime scene, according to the mayor's office, and should not be a tourist attraction. Yesterday, as warning signs spread along barricades, officers began enforcing the order with vigor, warning photographers and videotapers (the news media is not barred) that their cameras would be confiscated.

title: The Times Are A-Changin'
description: Just two weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks and President Bush's declaration of war on terrorism, a peace movement is beginning among musicians. While they have stood united in their condemnation of the attack and their willingness to help with relief efforts, they remain divided on what to do next.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 20 about George Ireland, former basketball coach at Loyola of Chicago, misidentified the Bronx high school attended by Ron Miller, one of his players. It was Christopher Columbus, not De Witt Clinton.

title: Too Free, Or Not Too Free?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: On the Border
Scenes from Quetta, Pakistan
Japan Is Hoping Weaker Yen Revives Growth
description: The yen dropped to a one-month low against the euro and a two-week low against the dollar yesterday as the Bank of Japan sold its currency for the sixth day since Sept. 17 in an effort to steer the economy away from a recession.

title: Kara Walker -- 'American Primitive'
description: Brent Sikkema

title: Cellular Pioneer Puts Up 'For Sale' Signs
description: Craig O. McCaw was always a man in a hurry. He began building the nation's first cross-country cellular phone network when he was in his 20's. Before he turned 50, he sold it to AT&T for a profit of $840 million. Then he invested that money in new telecommunications ventures and rode the technology stock tsunami to a $9 billion fortune last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARCY, DWIGHT DONALD
description: DARCY-Dwight Donald. Age 55, Senior Attorney at the Port Authority of NY and NJ, died on September 11, in the attack on the WTC. Resided in Bronxville, NY with his beloved wife Veronica and sons Kieran and Ryan. Also survived by his sister Joan D. Sorgi of Darien, CT; his brother Keith T. Darcy of Pound Ridge, NY; his aunt Claire Menagh of Manhattan; his uncle George Kindermann of New London, NH; and several nieces and nephews. Mr. Darcy, a Bronx native, graduated from Fordham Prep, Fordham University, and the Fordham University School of Law. He began his legal career as an Assistant D.A. in the Bronx in 1971, and joined the Port Authority in 1977. While at the Port Authority, Mr. Darcy specialized in labor relations, serving for many years as the Head of the Labor Relations Division. Active in charitable works in NYC, Mr. Darcy served as president of the Catholic Big Brothers of NY, as well as president of the Parish Council of St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville. He was voted a life member of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of NY, and made an affiliate member of the Marist Brothers for his many years of service on the board of Mt. St. Michael Academy in the Bronx. A Memorial Mass in celebration of Mr. Darcy's life will be offered Friday, September 28, at 10:00 AM at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville. Contributions can be sent to the Dwight D. Darcy Memorial Scholarship Fund at Fordham Prep, East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY 10458 or to the Catholic Big Brothers of NY, 45 East 20 St., NY, NY 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, PETER
description: BRENNAN-Peter. On September 11, 2001, in his 30th year. New York City Firefighter of Rescue 4, lost his life tragically in the line of duty while trying to help others at the World Trade Center disaster. He is survived by many loving family members and friends. Gathering of family and friends will be held on Sunday, September 30th from 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Hauppauge Fire Department Headquarters, 855 Wheeler Road (Rte 111), Hauppauge, NY. A Memorial Mass will be held on Monday, October 1, at 11 AM, at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Ronkonkoma, NY. There will also be a memorial service on Tuesday, October 2, at 7 PM, at St. John's Greek Orthodox Church, Blue Point, NY. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be sent to: The Peter Brennan Children Trust, P.O. Box 1425, Ronkonkoma, NY 11779. For further information please contact Moloney's Lake Funeral Home, 132 Ronkonkoma Ave, Lake Ronkonkoma, NY 11779; 631-588-1515.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSINGER, ROSE
description: LASSINGER-Rose. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Stephen A. Kreiss, President

title: Money for (Almost) Nothing
description: Imay be going out on a limb here, but it looks to me as though the economy's high-flying days are truly over for a while.

title: Familiar Formula Carries the Streaking Mets
description: The franchise player was hurt. The starting pitcher had nothing. The first baseman and manager had been ejected. But the utility infielder hit a two-run home run to spark the team to a come-from-behind blowout victory.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Big Companies' Shares Rally on Hopes They Offer Safety
description: Stocks of large companies rose yesterday in an afternoon rally, as investors sought relatively safe places to place their money through an increasingly cloudy economic downturn.

title: $17 Million Given Since Attack, In Donations Large and Small
description: The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund has received donations and pledges totaling $17.2 million, according to the Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund.

title: A New Vision Of 'Citizen Kane'
description: At age 60, Orson Welles's ''Citizen Kane,'' released on DVD this week by Warner, has fresh relevance on disc -- no mean trick for a movie that many viewers feel they have seen more than enough of. The film had to come to DVD sooner or later, and here it is, with two movielong commentaries by the critic Roger Ebert and the director and Welles biographer Peter Bogdanovich; a fine documentary, ''The Battle Over Citizen Kane,'' about the conflict between Welles and the newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst, on whose life the film is based; and a variety of extras, from storyboards to ad campaigns.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Cuts At Agfa
description: Europe's largest maker of photographic and industrial film, Agfa-Gevaert, said it might have to cut up to 4,000 jobs, or 18 percent of its work force, in a bid to restructure. The director of corporate communications, Christian P. Vermeulen, said the move was intended to refocus Agfa on digital technologies, which will soon account for half of its business. It plans to reduce its expenses by 550 million euros ($505 million) in 2001 and 2002 to pay for the reorganization.

title: United Nations Proposes Joint Effort Against Terrorism
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 28 — The Security Council today pressed toward the adoption of a resolution committing all 189 countries in the United Nations to crack down on terrorist movements and their supporters, and to freeze their financial assets around the world.

title: The Man of the Hour: Should Giuliani Stay On?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MELLON FINANCIAL, Pittsburgh, owner of the Dreyfus mutual fund family, said it would create Mellon Growth Advisors, an asset management unit to be based in Boston and focusing on equity investing for institutional clients.

title: Bush to Increase Federal Role in Security at Airports
description: Trying to soothe the frayed nerves of reluctant American travelers, President Bush announced today that the federal government would take on a larger role in airport security and that more than 4,000 National Guard troops would begin protecting the nation's 420 commercial airports within days.

title: Britain May Require ID Cards for All
description: The British government is considering issuing mandatory identity cards to its citizens as part of a broad package of antiterrorism measures.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: An Auctioneer's Day

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Battleship To Open As Museum
description: The opening of the battleship New Jersey as a museum, delayed since Labor Day, is likely to occur by mid-October, the retired admiral leading the project said yesterday. The board of the Home Port Alliance, the nonprofit group that is overseeing the $22 million refitting of the warship as a museum, will set an opening date at its Monday meeting, said Tom Seigenthaler, a retired admiral who is the group's executive director. Plans to open the ship by Labor Day were delayed by a lack of ramps for handicapped access and local permits like a certificate of occupancy, Mr. Seigenthaler said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOENIG, HELENE SCHILLER BASKIND
description: HOENIG-Helene Schiller Baskind passed away September 25, 2001. Our beloved mother, grandmother, great grandmother. An indomitable spirit, her greatest delight was to live her life for her deceased husband's children, grandchildren and friends. She was a wellspring of grace, strength, caring and love. She had a beauty and depth which touched everyone who knew her. She will live in our hearts forever. Weezie, David, Derek and Kara, Jordan, Jaimie and Raven

title: Excerpts From Bush Speech on Travel
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech on airport security yesterday at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: First Requiems, Then Resolve
description: WHEN Gordon J. Davis, the president of Lincoln Center, convened the directors of the center's resident performing groups on Sept. 12, the day after the attack on the World Trade Center, the shock of the disaster was fresh, and life in New York was virtually frozen. But Mr. Davis believed that it was important to meet, partly to decide what to do next, and partly to make sure that all of the arts center's constituent organizations were fully informed about plans for everything from memorial concerts being planned to heightened security on the plaza and in the halls and backstage areas.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 3
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: The Big City; Most Heroes Would Leave. Not Giuliani.
description: ''THE city is used to politicians who submit to whatever is the safest thing to do,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said during his first term. ''I think the city needs to be broken of that.''

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Premier To Visit New York
description: Prime Minister Jean Chrtien of Canada and leaders of the Canadian Parliament will visit New York on Saturday to express sympathy and support for the city. Mr. Chrtien, who went to the White House for talks on Monday but did not stop in new York, has been under fire from the political opposition, who accuse him of having an uncaring attitude. At least 25 Canadians are still missing from the Sept. 11 attacks. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: In a Shattered City, the Construction Leader Is King
description: EDWARD J. MALLOY may be the most powerful man in New York City you've never heard of.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STACK, CHRISTINA
description: STACK-Christina. Died September 25, 2001 at her home in Woodstock, NY. Beloved sister of Tara and Lee; accomplished and beautiful artist. Memorial service in Woodstock at Christina's home, 2PM Friday, October 5, 2001.

title: Fox Pledges Full Support For the U.S.
description: Abandoning Mexico's history of neutrality in times of violent conflict, President Vicente Fox said today in an interview that Mexico pledged ''unconditional support'' to the United States in its war against terrorism.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Jesse Jackson Says He Might Go to Taliban to Seek Turnaround
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he might try to meet with Afghanistan's Taliban rulers in an effort to persuade them to hand over Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda terrorist associates.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Power To Down Jets Is Last Resort, Rumsfeld Says
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that sufficient safeguards were in place to prevent Air Force fighter jets flying patrols over American cities from mistakenly shooting down a commercial airliner.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: $20 Million For Immigrant Care
description: After a federal agency backed out of paying the medical bills of illegal immigrants, state lawmakers approved $20 million for hospitals to cover the immigrants' unpaid emergency room bills. The state had long paid for such services but did not include the money in the budget after the federal Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services agreed to take over financing in the Clinton administration. The financing was to expire on Oct. 1. Under the Bush administration, the federal government will pay for care only for certain illegal immigrants, like pregnant women and children. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Married but Seldom With a Husband
description: To categorize Moufida Tlatli's film ''The Season of Men'' as a feminist critique of the subservient role of women in a traditional Islamic environment would be to understate the depth of anguish that this complicated portrait of an unhappy Tunisian family uncovers. The film, which opens today at the Screening Room, is a relentless cri du coeur eviscerating a sexual ethos so repressive that at least one woman is nearly driven crazy by a gut-gnawing mixture of fear, shame and desire.

title: A Spare Setting for a World-Weary Dandy
description: When Robert Carsen's production of ''Eugene Onegin'' opened at the Metropolitan Opera in 1997, I thought it was beautiful. To my surprise, many others disliked it. Its detractors found it too spare, leaving the singers adrift on a huge empty stage that swallowed their voices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIMAN, BRETT O.
description: FREIMAN-Brett O., 29. On September 11, 2001, a victim of the World Trade Center tragedy. Beloved son of Herbert Freiman and Bonnie Freiman. Cherished brother of Michael, Alison, Pamela and Adam Rentzer. Dear step son of Ellen Freiman and step brother of Michael, Peter and Jeffrey Malkin. Adored uncle of Jacob and Bryan Rentzer. Memorial service at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Bdwy, Hewlett, Long Island, 5PM Sunday, September 30th. Donations in his memory may be made to N.Y.S. World Trade Center Relief Fund, 1-800-801-8092.

title: Pageantry Aside, Pitt Is Merely the Latest Pushover for Miami
description: It will take more than cool northern weather and sentimental rituals to stop the top-ranked Miami Hurricanes. They are big, fast, talented, confident and in the habit of winning. Although they trailed by a point early tonight and were not always sharp, the visiting Hurricanes wore down the Pittsburgh Panthers, took a 33-point lead and coasted to a 43-21 victory at Heinz Field to go to 3-0.

title: Technology Briefing | Services: E.D.S. To Manage Mortgage Services
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a leading provider of computer services in the United States, won a 10-year, $679 million contract to process mortgages for the Westpac Banking Corporation, one of Australia's largest banks. E.D.S. said it would run the Westpac mortgage operations center in Adelaide, South Australia, which handles about 700,000 accounts. About 1,300 Westpac employees will work for Electronic Data.

title: Guard Is Up for Stadium Security Officials Across the Country
description: The football stadium sits across the Hudson River from the smoking debris of the World Trade Center. There will be more people with guns and uniforms there this weekend than at some minimum security prisons. They will look in bags and look over cars and scrutinize the tickets of tens of thousands of fans standing in long, long lines.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Ex-Dictator Facing Trial
description: A judge ruled that the former dictator Jorge Videla would be put on trial for the abductions of 70 foreign nationals while he led a military junta between 1976 and 1981. General Videla is already under house arrest on charges that he was involved in the kidnapping of children born to mothers held in captivity. The reported abductions and executions of foreigners occurred as part of the Condor Plan, a coordinated effort by South American military leaders to eliminate leftists living in exile in Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Bolivia and other countries during the 1970's. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JERRY
description: SHAPIRO-Jerry, 84. Former President, Shapiro & Son. Passed away September 23 at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. Survived by his beloved wife, Anita, daughters, Carolyn Bonheim and Eileen Mantell, and six grandchildren. Service September 30, 11am, Temple Sholom, Greenwich, CT. Contributions to The Martin J. Shapiro Fund of The Crohns & Colitis Foundation, 200 Bloomingdale Road, White Plains, NY 10605.

title: At a Waiting College Campus, an Echo of the 60's
description: Far from the funereal wreckage on the East Coast, a sense of waiting for retaliation is as tangible here at the University of Oregon as it is at the Pentagon, which has already cautioned that there will be no booming D-Day punctuation of a state of war with the terrorists.

title: Ads' Message To Tourists: Come Back!
description: The blood banks are full. No more volunteers are needed at ground zero. But city officials have a message for people from other cities and countries who want to help in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center: come and spend your money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGHILTERRA, LOUIS STEVEN
description: INGHILTERRA - Louis Steven. Died September 11, 2001 in the attack on the World Trade Center. Louis was the Senior Vice President and Treasurer of the Fiduciary Trust Company. His office was on the 95th floor of Building 2 of the World Trade Center. Louis is survived by his wife Diane McGill Inghilterra and his 2-1/2 year son old Louis Sam, his mother Theresa Chirico Inghilterra, a sister Donna Inghilterra and a niece Christine Inghilterra. His father was the late Louis V. Inghilterra. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 29th 1PM at the Church of Saint John and Saint Mary in Chappaqua, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to a trust fund set up for Louis' son, Louis Sam Inghilterra. Please make checks payable to Diane Inghilterra, c/f Louis S. Inghilterra UTMA NY, POB 77, Chappaqua NY 10514.

title: Layoffs Push Jobless Claims to 9-Year High
description: The number of workers seeking unemployment benefits surged to the highest level in nine years as people dismissed after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks began to file claims for state aid.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: For Many Displaced Residents, Frustration Turns to Anger
description: As New Yorkers try to return to normalcy, about 8,000 residents still displaced from their apartments near the World Trade Center calamity only wish they could.

title: S.E.C. Cites 6 Employees In Fraud Case At HBO Inc.
description: The former general counsel and the chief financial officer of HBO & Company, the health care software maker, were cited by the Securities and Exchange Commission today along with four other former employees on charges that they helped inflate the company's revenue before its 1999 merger with the McKesson Corporation.

title: Funky Digs With Lots of Space for Performance-Oriented Hipsters
description: The venerable Sculpture Center has a new home and a new look that is nothing if not funky, at least for the time being. Forsaking its charming 1885 carriage house on East 69th Street, this 72-year-old institution has relocated to a 1908 brick building where trolley cars were once repaired. This small step up in the history of transportation architecture involves a major shift in locale. Its new home is in Long Island City, Queens: a grimy brick structure whose ceilings soar to 40 feet. It is hard by an off-ramp of the Queensboro Bridge and a short walk from the P.S. 1 Center for Contemporary Art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALAZZOLO, RICHARD ''RICO''
description: PALAZZOLO - Richard ''Rico''. Lost in WTC September 11th. Memorial Mass Sunday, September 30th, at 2 PM, Holy Spirit Church, 500 Jericho Tpke., New Hyde Park.

title: Car Rental Companies Preparing for a Slump
description: FEWER people are flying, and more are expected to be driving. Still, that is not good news for the $19.5 billion rental-car industry, since more than two-thirds of its business is done at airports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALAND, MORRIS
description: SALAND-Morris. Of Merrick on September 26, 2001. Beloved husband of 65 years to Ruth. Devoted father of David and his wife Michelle, Richard and Fredric and his wife Corliss. Also survived by his grandchildren; Andrew and his wife Erinn, Joshua, Steven and Ariel. Graveside services Friday 3 p.m. at Mount Ararat Cemetery Farmingdale. Donations to Alzheimer's Association Nassau/Suffolk Chapter 579 Monroe Street, Cedarhurst, NY 11516 appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLERMAN, PETER RODNEY
description: KELLERMAN-Peter Rodney, 35. Of New York City and South Egremont, MA on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center tragedy. Partner of Cantor Fitzgerald. Husband and soulmate of Robi Meltzer Kellerman, devoted son to Joyce Gales and beloved son-inlaw to Jeri and Steven ''Papa'' Meltzer and stepson to Michael Gales. Cherished brother of Elyssa Kellerman and Pamela and George Fox. Uncle Pete was adored by his nephews Max, Aaron, Billy, Matthew, Charlie and Ben. He was the most loving and giving friend. He will live in our hearts forever. A memorial service will be held October 1, 2001 at 11:00 A.M. at The Park Avenue Synagogue on Madison Avenue and 87th Street.

title: The Investigation So Far
description: The government released new photographs of the suspected hijackers that raised additional questions about their identities as Pakistan prepared to send a top general and several Islamic clerics to Afghanistan in a last-ditch effort to persuade the Taliban leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, to hand over Osama bin Laden.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Cisco Completes Allegro Acquisition
description: Cisco Systems, the large maker of computer-networking equipment, completed the purchase of the 60 percent stake that it did not already own in Allegro Systems, which makes network-security software and hardware, for about $109 million in stock. Cisco bought its initial 40 percent stake in Allegro, which is based in Milpitas, Calif., in December. Cisco paid a total of $181 million for the company, which has 39 employees, a Cisco spokeswoman said. Shares of Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., fell 99 cents, to $11.24.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Construction Spinoff
description: The British company that built the Millennium Dome in London, John Laing, said it would sell one of its troubled construction units for a symbolic 1 ($1.47) to the O'Rourke Group. In addition, the chairman, Martin Laing, the great-great-grandson of the company's founder, will step down. The shares fell more than 50 percent, to 116.5. John Laing also said it lost 56 million ($82.6 million), or 54.3 pence a share, in the first half of the year, in contrast to a profit of 14.5 million ($21.4 million), or 18.3 pence a share, last year. It said it would take a 30 million write-off ($44.3 million) on the sale of the unit, which builds offices and commercial projects. It also plans to issue new equity to shareholders in an effort to raise about 73 million ($108 million). After the sale, John Laing will focus on building houses and government-financed projects. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Guidance for Hijackers
description: The authorities said they had found a document that appeared to be a guide for the hijackers in preparing for their attacks. According to The Washington Post, the writings exhorted the hijackers to overcome their fears, and offered a promise of ''infinite paradise.''

title: Gesture Changes Image of Pope's Health
description: It was around midnight on Thursday in Armenia, where John Paul II had started the day, when the ailing 81-year-old pope was finally heading home after a punishing six days of meetings, speeches and prayer services there and in Kazakhstan.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Japan Relations 'Damaged'
description: Tokyo must take ''sincere steps'' to improve relations with Seoul before the Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, can expect to meet the South Korean president, Kim Dae Jung, according to Foreign Minister Han Seung Soo. Mr. Han said Mr. Koizumi's visit to a Tokyo shrine that memorializes Japan's war dead and his refusal to demand revisions of contentious textbooks had ''damaged the basic spirit'' of a joint declaration in 1998 by Mr. Kim and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi. Korean officials are investigating the latest incident, Wednesday's battering by a Japanese patrol boat of a Korean fishing boat that Japan says was fishing in Japanese waters. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Martin's Backup Awaits His Shot
description: At some point Monday night during the Jets' game against San Francisco, Coach Herman Edwards will probably turn to running back LaMont Jordan and tell him the only thing he thinks Jordan still needs to hear from him: ''Don't fumble the ball, whatever you do.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the National Briefing column yesterday about a University of New Mexico professor who was threatened with disciplinary action for having joked about the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks misspelled his surname. He is Richard Berthold, not Bethold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, BENNETT LAWSON
description: FISHER-Bennett Lawson, 58, of Stamford, CT on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. description: A week ago, Americans applauded President Bush's clarity of vision when he declared, ''Either you are with us or you are with the terrorists.'' But in the Middle East, more complex calculations are playing out.

title: The Harvest Moon
description: Tuesdays full moon is also the harvest moon. In two out of three years this title is usually bestowed upon the September full moon, but Tuesdays full moon comes the closest to the autumnal equinox so this year it falls in October.

description: 21st-Century Middle Ages

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEL, ROBERT. ''BOB'' ''BOBBIE''
description: TURKEL-Robert. ''Bob'' ''Bobbie'', heroic, optimistic always, brave, caring, kind, loving and sweet. All these and more are descriptions of our son, who passed away in his sleep Sunday night fighting Cancer. He thought he would win. He didn't. Family receiving at home Thursday evening 7:30 P.M. Funeral services Friday, September 28, 12:30 P.M. ''JCC'' Jewish Community Center of White Plains (Congregation Kol Ami), 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains. Thelly and Mel Turkel Ann and Jane Turkel
