description: Law and Order Criminal Intent

title: Hollywood Soul-Searching
description: Much of the entertainment industry has come to a virtual standstill in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, as the various players assess the propriety of productions already finished and the public mood about projects yet to be made. ''I don't think Hollywood knows where its place is yet,'' said Terry Press, marketing chief for DreamWorks.

title: THREE COMPANIES WIN SYSTEM CONTRACT FOR MEDICARE
description: The Health and Human Services Department said yesterday that Electronic Data Systems, Oracle and PricewaterhouseCoopers had won a contract to create a new accounting system for Medicare and Medicaid. The potential value of the contract is about $328 million, the agency said. PricewaterhouseCoopers will integrate systems, Oracle will provide accounting software, and Electronic Data will oversee the Internet applications. Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, has 53 different accounting programs used by private insurance companies to process and pay nearly three million Medicare claims each day. The new project will replace those programs and mainframe computers with a Web-based system.

title: AT&T Looks To Baby Bells For a Buyer
description: AT&T, the stumbling communications company once known as the mighty Ma Bell, is seeking to sell its telephone operations to one of its Baby Bell offspring.

title: Many Paths to Action, in New York and the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 8 p.m. Thursday.

title: Business Travelers Balk at 'Hassle Factor' on Electronic Tickets
description: As business travel starts to pick up, some regular travelers have been reluctant to fly because of confusion about airport security procedures for the use of electronic tickets, the National Business Travel Association said yesterday.

title: Fertility Ethics Authority Approves Sex Selection
description: In a letter that has stunned many leading fertility specialists, the acting head of their professional society's ethics committee says it is sometimes acceptable for couples to choose the sex of their children by selecting either male or female embryos and discarding the rest.

title: With War in the Air, Home's but a Dream; Mexican Migrants, Fearing Impenetrable Border, Are Staying Put
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: MetroStars Join Parade of Uprisings in the Playoffs
description: The Major League Soccer playoffs have taken quite a twist. With 3 points being given for a victory and 1 point for a tie, and a team needing 5 points to advance to the semifinals, the sixth-seeded MetroStars are just a point away from the semifinals. They lead the Los Angeles Galaxy, 4-1. San Jose, seeded No. 5, is already in the semifinals, after upsetting No. 4 Columbus, 6-0. Miami, the best team in the regular season and the top seeding, is tied, 3-3, with the defending champion Kansas City Wizards, who are seeded eighth.

title: A Lost Boy in a Plot to Keep The Fashion Industry Afloat
description: An evil band of international fashion designers want to end the tenure of a new prime minister of Malaysia, who plans to stop the exploitation of child labor. (The designers are all sitting in the shadows so they can't be identified, even though one is clearly meant to suggest Karl Lagerfeld, who looks like a supervillain from a Bond movie, anyway.)

title: S.E.C. Needs a New Home, Fast
description: Nine years ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission moved into three floors at 7 World Trade Center, where it and its 320 employees sent a clear signal that the nation's securities cop was very much on the beat.

title: Stocks End a Terrible Quarter With a Day of Gains
description: Stocks rose sharply today, ending a dismal third quarter, as investors displayed some confidence in the long-term health of the United States economy.

title: Holly Lane
description: Schmidt-Bingham

title: In Stopping to Save Woman, Rescuers Saved Themselves
description: The six firefighters would have moved faster if they hadn't stopped to help a weary woman trying to flee. They would have moved slower if they hadn't been able to coax her along, to tell her that if she wanted to see her children and grandchildren again, she had to keep moving down the stairs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a decision by the United States to pay past dues to the United Nations misstated the comparison of the House and Senate bills. They are identical, not similiar, and therefore do not face further negotiations.

title: Capturing the Serenity Where Turmoil Reigns
description: Kenro Izu is partial to paradoxes. He lives in New York City in the 21st century, yet he follows in the footsteps of 19th-century landscape photographers. He goes on arduous treks to remote places, lugging a custom-made camera that produces 14-by-20-inch negatives; with the requisite accessories, it weighs about 300 pounds. And he makes his own platinum-palladium prints.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Ex-Charity Chief Is Sanctioned
description: In an unusually sweeping action, the state attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, left, who oversees charities in New York State, has banned the former head of a charity from making any decisions, fiscal or otherwise, with any other charity for 10 years. Mr. Spitzer said yesterday that the former head of the Urban League of Northeastern New York, Aaron Dare, had committed no crime but had so mismanaged the organization that he must be banned from decision-making at other charities. Mr. Dare, who acted as his own lawyer in dealings with the attorney general, could not be reached for comment because he has an unlisted number. ''The Urban League is broke,'' said Darren Dopp, Mr. Spitzer's spokesman. ''It's going to be dissolved.'' Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, MARY
description: BERNSTEIN-Mary. I mourn the death of my darling litlle mother, gone two weeks today. Zestful and charming in her prime, spunky and funny even in her illness, her loss is irreparable. My Mother, my best friend. Barbar

title: Dancing Their Way Through Life, With a Laugh and a 'Woo-hooo!'
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 305 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 238. In all, 5,960 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives.

title: How Do You Redeem a Man? Take Him Out to the Ballgame
description: Hardball

title: Rangers Weighing Options Regarding Their 18-Year-Old Goalie
description: If Chris Osgood is available in Friday's N.H.L. waiver draft, the Rangers may claim him, and if they do, they would probably try to trade him. Strange? No, because they are intent on giving 18-year-old Dan Blackburn every chance of making the team.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL EXPECTS TO EXCEED PROFIT FORECAST
description: Eastman Chemical, which plans to split itself into two companies by the end of the year, said yesterday that it would beat analysts' estimates for third-quarter earnings. Eastman, based in Kingsport, Tenn., said it would meet or exceed its own profit estimate of 47 cents to 53 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected the company to earn 46 cents a share. Eastman is the largest maker of plastics used in soda bottles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, DR. MILTON
description: SILVER-Dr. Milton. September 25, 2001. Loving husband of Mary. Devoted father to Laura and Julie. Brilliant doctor, dearest friend, forever in our hearts. Amy and Ron Finestone

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Yale's Endowment Rises
description: Despite a lackluster stock market, Yale University's endowment grew 6 percent, to $10.7 billion from $10.1 billion, in the year ended June 30, Yale's president, Richard C. Levin, announced yesterday. The endowment's investment returned 9.2 percent during the fiscal year. Mr. Levin called the return ''an extraordinary investment performance'' during a year when the nation's stock prices tumbled. Yale's endowment has quadrupled in value in the last decade and is second only to Harvard University's $19.2 billion.

title: PENNEY SAYS IT WILL ADD 14 STORES WITH NEW FEATURES
description: J. C. Penney said yesterday that it plans to spend $100 million to add 14 stores by the end of the year. The planned stores will have new features like wider aisles for baby strollers, improved lighting and signs to help shoppers find brand-name products, the company said. The first of the new sites will open on Oct. 5 at the Mall at Wellington Green in Wellington, Fla. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., operates about 1,080 J. C. Penney stores and 2,650 Eckerd drugstores.

title: Christina Ramberg
description: Adam Baumgold

title: Big Push to Accelerate Vaccine Effort
description: With concerns growing about the threat of terrorism using biological weapons, the government is stepping up its effort to enlist biotechnology companies to develop and produce vaccines, drugs and other defenses against such an attack, according to industry executives.

title: ANDERSEN ACQUIRES A BUSINESS OF PRICEWATERHOUSE
description: Andersen, the accounting firm formerly known as Arthur Andersen, said yesterday that it had acquired Price Waterhouse Management Consultants, part of the French consulting business of PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm. A spokeswoman for PricewaterhouseCoopers in New York said the firm considered the decision of the French business to join Andersen ''a breach of their legal obligation'' and said the firm was ''considering our legal remedies.'' The French business employs about 450 consultants, an Andersen spokesman said, and the addition will roughly double the number of consultants Andersen has in France. Details of the transaction were not disclosed. Management consulting last year accounted for about 19 percent of Andersen's $8.4 billion in revenue. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Many Paths to Action, in New York and the World
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Showtime at the New York Film Festival
description: The 39th New York Film Festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, opens tonight and closes on Oct. 14. All films are shown at Alice Tully Hall with the exception of the late show tonight and the closing-night film, which will be shown at Avery Fisher Hall. Several events are planned at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. They include ''Blue Wild Angel: Jimi Hendrix Live at the Isle of Wight,'' a remixed version of the original by its filmmaker, Murray Lerner (Oct. 6); and ''Il Mio Viaggio in Italia,'' a four-hour film featuring Martin Scorsese and the Italian films he reveres (Oct. 12 and 13). Tickets to each screening program are $14. ''Fifth Views From the Avant-Garde,'' a five-part series, is to be shown on Oct. 13 and 14. ''The Outsider Looking In: The Films of Leonardo Favio,'' a series of 11 programs, is to be shown tomorrow through Oct. 11. Walter Reade screenings are $9; $5 for Film Society members; $4.50 for those 65+ at weekday matinees. ''Making Movies That Matter: The Role of Film in the National Debate,'' a discussion with critics and filmmakers, will be held on Oct. 6 at 11 a.m. at Alice Tully Hall; general admission, $10. Box office: (212) 875-5600. Many festival screenings are sold out. (Returns may be available.) Tickets: $10 and $15, except tonight's screenings, which are $17; the closing night screening, which is $17 and $30; and the Festival Centerpiece screening of ''Mulholland Drive,'' which is $12 and $20; available at the Tully Hall box office, (212) 875-5050. Unless otherwise noted, the films shown were made this year. Some are scheduled for commercial release, with dates noted.

title: Charles Cannell, 88; Improved Survey Accuracy
description: Charles Frederick Cannell, an expert on scientific surveys whose studies widely influenced how survey interviews are conducted, died on Sept. 18 in an automobile accident in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 88 and lived in Ann Arbor.

title: Gold Prices Are Likely to Rise, but the Gains May Be Fleeting
description: Heady days are here again for gold bugs. Or are they?

title: Subway at Trade Center to Take Years to Rebuild
description: New York City Transit officials have determined that damage to the No. 1 and 9 subway tunnels and stations in Lower Manhattan is so extensive that the line will need to be completely rebuilt for more than a mile.

title: The Mayor's Dangerous Idea
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani wants to extend his current term of office into 2002, postponing the inauguration of a new mayor for several months. This is a terrible idea. Neither New York City nor the nation has ever postponed the transfer of power because the public was convinced it could not get along without the current incumbent. The very concept goes against the most basic of American convictions, that we live in a nation governed by rule of law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, DR. RAYMOND
description: KAUFMAN-Dr. Raymond. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member Jeanne Kaufman upon the loss of her husband, a senior statesman of our community. We extend our sympathies to his children, grandchildren, sisters, brothers and to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi David Sable, President

title: Islanders, Stocked With Goalies, May Still Take a Shot at Osgood
description: The Islanders, still chained to their recent past, get to pick first in yet another draft at noon Friday. The N.H.L. waiver draft is quite different from the league's annual entry draft. The Islanders could choose a goaltender who has already won a Stanley Cup, not merely someone who might win one for them someday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Korean Trade Deficit
description: Korea suffered a current account deficit in August, the first monthly shortfall in 16 months. The Bank of Korea reported a loss of $110 million in current accounts, which measure goods, money and services moving in and out of the country, after reporting surpluses since April 2000. The current accounts showed a surplus of $438.8 million in July and $893.7 million in August of last year before the country was hurt by falling exports of semiconductors and other electronic products. The trade surplus in August was $723 million, $130 million less than in July. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: 14 Killed in Attack on a Swiss Legislature
description: A 57-year-old man armed with an assault rifle stormed into a regional legislature today, killing 14 people in a hail of gunfire and detonating a hand grenade before shooting himself dead with a pistol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, BARBARA L.
description: KAISER-Barbara L. 84, died September 26, 2001, in New York City. She attended Wellesley College where she was Phi Beta Kappa her junior year; and Columbia University Law School, where she was Harlan Fisk Stone Scholar and on the Law Review. Married to Dr. Irwin Kaiser in 1938, during the war she worked for the War Labor Board. After earning a Master's degree in Political Science she taught Constitutional Law at the University of Utah, and practiced private law in Westchester before serving as a judge of the Family Court until her retirement. She was President of the Women's Bar Association of Westchester and a member of the ACLU. Judge Kaiser is survived by her sister Judith Pestronk; her children Susan, Peter, Richard, Margaret, Steven, and James; and her grandchildren Chad Currier, Guy Currier, Rachel Farber-Kaiser, Emily Farber-Kaiser Perry, Deborah Farber-Kaiser, Mireille Kaiser, Sarah Kaiser-Schatzlein, Alice Kaiser-Schatzlein, Ariel Kaiser, Michael Kaiser-Nyman, Robin Kaiser-Schatzlein, Samuel FarberKaiser, Christopher Kaiser-Nyman, David Kaiser-Jones and Amy Kaiser-Jones. A ceremony will be held this weekend at the George Davis Funeral Home in New Rochelle; call 914-632-0324.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Aug. 31 about ''O,'' which adapts ''Othello'' into a story about a high school basketball star, misidentified the city that is the setting of the film ''10 Things I Hate About You,'' an adaptation of ''The Taming of the Shrew'' to a high school setting. It is Seattle, not Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENBERG, ELEANOR A.
description: SCHOENBERG-Eleanor A. Suddenly on September 25, 2001. Beloved wife of Saul. Devoted daughter of Anna Melenkivitz. Dear sister of Edward and Joseph Melenkivitz. Cherished aunt to Adam, Rory, Amy and Laura. Sister-in-law to Judith Bindler and aunt to Robert Bindler. Loving friend and colleague. Eleanor possessed true beauty, style and grace. She suffered greatly during her last years and can now rest in everlasting peace. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISHER, BERNARD
description: FLEISHER-Bernard. Known as Bernie, of Greensboro, NC, died September 26, 2001. Funeral 2 PM, Friday, September 28, 2001, Beth David Synagogue. He leaves his wife Rhoda, daughters Nancy and her husband Craig, Sally and husband Robert, Amy and husband Ken, grandchildren Kimberly, Mark, Joseph, Elena, Max and Ian. Hanes-Lineberry, Greensboro, NC, in charge; 336-292-1081.

description: Kara Walker `American Primitive'

description: SUDDENLY, balance sheets matter.

description: BASF, the German chemical conglomerate, had already warned investors last month that profits would be down this year. Today, assessing the fallout of the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the message was far more pessimistic.

title: Past Recalled for Japanese-Americans
description: Ever since that life-altering day, Janice Mirikitani said she had a horrible fear that past wrongs could be repeated.

title: Lechters Asks Permission to Seek Buyer
description: Lechters Inc., a leading retailer of household goods, has asked a bankruptcy judge for permission to find a buyer for all the company's assets or close its 325 stores and liquidate.

title: Asia Casts a Wary Eye to the West
description: Mark Lettenbichler expected a flood of canceled bookings in the days after the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington. What worries Mr. Lettenbichler, the general manager of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here, is that his guests have not yet returned.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Arezzo is a regional capital in southern Tuscany, and it stands to reason that a restaurant bearing the name would not betray the franchise. The chef, Margherita Aloi, is a further guarantee. Ms. Aloi is one of the three Italian ''mothers'' Pino Luongo brought from Tuscany to create Le Madri in 1989. Actually, Ms. Aloi, only 18 at the time, was not a mother, but she was Tuscan, and youth has given her an urge to play a bit, but not too much, with the food she grew up with.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Plan to Reopen Airport

title: Regulators Find No Evidence That Advance Knowledge of Attacks Was Used for Profit
description: After almost two weeks of investigation, financial regulators around the world have found no hard evidence that people with advance knowledge of the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington used that information to profit in the international securities markets. And a number of officials are beginning to express doubt that such a plan existed.

title: New Jersey Candidates Woo Black Voters at Convention
description: The major-party candidates for governor wooed potential voters at the annual New Jersey Black Issues Convention, making a stop that has become a rite of passage for major candidates in the last two decades.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Number of Uninsured Drops for 2nd Year
description: The number of Americans without health insurance declined last year for the second year in a row, after rising steadily for more than a decade, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLING, HOWARD G., JR.
description: GELLING-Howard G., Jr. Tragically on September 11, 2001 at the age of 28. Howard was a Managing Director at Sandler O'Neill and Partners, working on the 104th floor of Two World Trade Center. Beloved husband of Christine O'Reilly, devoted son of Howard, Sr. and Dorothy, loving brother of Deborah and William, dear grandson of Margaret Cleary and Myrtle Gelling. Also survived by many loving aunts, uncles and cousins. Howard touched so many in such a short time. His generosity and enthusiasm for life are an inspiration for those who knew him. A Memorial Mass will be held on Monday, October 1, 2001 at 10:30am at the Church of Our Lady of Victory, Floral Park, N.Y. To honor Howard's memory, donations can be made to Xaverian High School/Howard G. Gelling, Jr. Memorial Scholarship care of Xaverian High School Development Office, 7100 Shore Road, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11209.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Expands Printer Line
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's leading maker of computer printers, will begin selling its first entry-level laser printer on Monday. The monochrome LaserJet 1000 will have a retail price of $249 and represents a challenge to smaller competitors that have sold laser printers for around $200. Hewlett-Packard said the printer was suitable for small businesses and home offices. Separately, the company said it had hired Flextronics, an electronics manufacturer, to take over production of its expensive large-format printers. As part of the deal, which Hewlett-Packard said would reduce its operating costs and add manufacturing flexibility, Flextronics will take 250 Hewlett-Packard employees onto its payroll. Financial terms were not disclosed. Hewlett-Packard shares rose 20 cents, to $16.20. Flextronics shares fell 11 cents, to $15.49. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Balloonists Stay Home
description: Foreign bal loonists are canceling reservations to participate in the Kodak Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta because of increased charges for air freight. The event, one of New Mexico's most popular tourist attractions, will begin on Oct. 6. In the past, foreign balloonists shipped gondolas, tanks and other equipment into the United States for about $1,200 to $2,000. Since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, airlines have imposed costly security measures on air cargo, which have tripled the expenses. Officials could not say how many pilots had canceled. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARKMAN, CELIA D.
description: STARKMAN-Celia D. In her 98th year, loving wife of the late Harold, devoted mother of Sue and Wyn Robins, James and Eve Starkman, grandmother of Frannie and Jackie, Hannah and Billy, Amy and Wendy, and seven great-grandchildren, sister of Edward Levy, Miriam Horowitz and the late Sally, Morrie, Fan, Hannah and Marcy. Services at Plaza Memorial, 10 AM, Sunday September 30, 91st St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Rebel Head In Macedonia Gives Order To Disband
description: Ethnic Albanian rebels declared today that they have formally disbanded and are returning to civilian life, ending their eight-month insurgency for more rights in Macedonia.

title: Bruegel the Elder Explains It All for You
description: WE could all do worse right now than to lose ourselves for a while in the Met's show of drawings and prints by Bruegel, who knew a thing or two about vice and virtue.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Gas Price Gouger To Pay Refunds
description: An Iowa company that charged sharply higher gasoline prices at stations in Illinois after the terrorist attacks must give refunds to customers under a settlement reached with the Illinois attorney general, Jim Ryan. Mr. Ryan filed a lawsuit two weeks ago accusing the company, Casey's General Stores Inc., of charging customers as much as $5 a gallon. The company must also donate $25,000 to the American Red Cross and pay $5,000 to cover state legal expenses. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Playoffs Set, Yanks Turn Attention To Injuries
description: Joe Torre sat in the Yankees dugout Wednesday, grateful for the one thing the Yankees could boast about: a fearsome foursome of starting pitchers, one comparable to the Atlanta Braves' best pitching staffs of the past decade. Until then, Torre could choose any of his top four pitchers and not have a significant drop in quality.

title: For Nicaragua's Atlantic Indians, Autonomy Means Neglect
description: For generations, the Miskito Indians nestled in the remote jungles along the Atlantic Coast have been cut off from the rest of the country by distance, culture and even the weather.

title: Farm Vendors Get a New Spot, in Brooklyn
description: The greenmarket outside Brooklyn's Borough Hall is open on Tuesdays and Saturdays. But yesterday, passersby saw the familiar tents of . . . a greenmarket? The farmers who were there had lost their usual spot at the World Trade Center.

title: $5 Billion Pulled From Stock Funds
description: Investors pulled more than $5 billion from equity funds in August, according to an industry report.

title: Paul Fusco -- 'R.F.K. Funeral Train'
description: Bonni Benrubi Gallery

title: School Colors Become Red, White and Blue
description: Until two weeks ago, the theme for Friday's homecoming celebration at Jonesboro High was ''Old School,'' and each class had been asked to construct a float representing a different decade. Poodle skirts and tie-dyed T-shirts would be de rigueur. After the events of Sept. 11, the student council changed the theme to ''Pride and Patriotism,'' and students have cleaned local stores out of red, white and blue crepe paper.

title: U.S. Marshals May Be Key To Reopening Of an Airport
description: As pressure builds to reopen Ronald Reagan National Airport, the only airport still out of service, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta said today that he would back a plan to place federal marshals on every flight using the airport as a requirement to reopen it.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER EXTENDS CHIEF'S CONTRACT
description: DaimlerChrysler said yesterday that its supervisory board had extended the contract of its chief executive, Jrgen E. Schrempp, through April 2005 to ensure continuity atop the company. DaimlerChrysler, based in Stuttgart, Germany, said Jrgen Hubbert, a board member who heads the Mercedes-Benz car division, would also stay through 2005. ''With the key players Jrgen Schrempp and Jrgen Hubbert, continuity and stability is guaranteed,'' Hilmar Kopper, chairman of the supervisory board, said in a statement. ''Within the next few years, the appointment of younger candidates as members of the board of management will have priority.''

title: 4 Settle Charges Over Trading In Merger Deal
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused a former Citibank vice president and three others of trading on inside information ahead of the $27 billion purchase of the Associates First Capital Corporation by Citigroup Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, STEVEN
description: GELLER-Steven. Beloved husband of Debra. Loving father of Hali. Son-in-law of Suzanne and Irving Karpas. Brother of Toby Landau and Martin Geller. Steven was lost in the World Trade Center tragedy on September 11, 2001. He celebrated life and adored his family. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 30th, 10 AM, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd Street, NYC. Contributions in Steven's memory may be made to the Dalton School, 108 East 89th St, NYC, or to Congregation Rodeph Sholom.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Police And Protestants Clash
description: The police clashed with more than 300 Protestant rioters at a flash point in north Belfast, above. Similar violence on Wednesday left 33 officers injured by a barrage of stones, homemade explosives and flaming bottles of gasoline. When rioters used automatic weapons on Wednesday, the police took the rare step of returning fire, with fewer than 20 live rounds and plastic bullets. Sir Ronnie Flanagan, chief constable of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, said the rioters had tried to attack a Catholic neighborhood, and that they had been organized by the Ulster Defense Association, a Protestant paramilitary group. But Protestant residents said the riots had begun as a peaceful protest against intimidation by Catholics. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about military-related Web sites misspelled the surname of a public affairs officer aboard the aircraft carrier Harry S. Truman. He is Lt. Cmdr. Cappy Surette, not Surett.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, ROBERT THOMAS
description: JORDAN-Robert Thomas, 34, who brought joy to so many lives, is among the missing after the tragic attack on the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Rob was the son of Robert O. Jordan of Weston, CT and Anne Stewart of Newport Beach, CA. He was employed by Cantor Fitzgerald where he was a bond trader. Rob was born in New York City in 1967 and graduated from St. Andrews School in Middletown, DE in 1986. He attended Orange Coast College where, under the guidance of his friend and coach, Dave Grant, he became an accomplished oarsman. In 1991, Rob graduated from the University of California at Berkeley, where he again distinguished himself on the varsity crew. Rob is survived by his wife, the former Elizabeth Russell, his mother and step-father, Anne and Robert Stewart, his father and step-mother, Robert and Susan Jordan, and three brothers, Nicholas R. of Minneapolis, David O. and Harrison E. of Weston, and one sister, Alexandra S. of Weston. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Rob Jordan will be held on Sept. 29th at 2PM at Norfield Congregational Church in Weston, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family has established a memorial fund to purchase a crew boat in Rob's name. Donations may be sent to the Rob Jordan Memorial, c/o Dave Grant, Orange Coast College, 2701 Fairview Rd., Costa Mesa, CA 92628.

title: From the Outside, Former Presidents Lend the Support of Insiders
description: Several friends of the Bush family say former President George Bush counseled his son President Bush in the days after the attacks on New York and Washington to tone down his bellicose language about hunting down terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAVIS, ARTHUR R.
description: TRAVIS-Arthur R. 86, of Guttenberg, NJ, died September 24. He served as a US Army Lieutenant, receiving the highest noncombat award. In business, he was respected for his integrity, serving as president of Sacony and Helen Harper. He will be remembered for his warmth, optimism and sensitivity. Surviving are his wife, Lila, his daughter, Patricia Rosenberg, his son, Thom, stepchildren, Laura Evans, Michael, Peter and Paul Shames, two sisters, and seven grandchildren. A sister, his first wife, Virginia, and a grandson predeceased him. The memorial service will be at 1 PM, Friday, September 28, at Wien and Wien Memorial Chapel, 129 Engle St, Englewood, NJ. title: Foreign Affairs; Talk Later

I scanned my brain for an analogy and finally said: Imagine how Egyptians would feel if three suicide bombers rammed airplanes into the Pyramids, with thousands of people inside. The World Trade towers were our Pyramids, built with glass and steel rather than stones, but Pyramids to American enterprise and free markets, and someone has destroyed them.

title: When a Surrogate Father Is a Mind Reader in Trouble
description: It really isn't hard to make a talented actor look like a blithering fool. All it takes is the deployment of some choice mouthfuls of mush with instructions to squeeze out tears. And mush, delivered with a trembling, quasi-biblical solemnity, is what emanates from Anthony Hopkins most of the time in ''Hearts in Atlantis,'' a nostalgic fiasco so shameless it makes movies like ''Simon Birch'' and ''Frequency'' seem as austere as the work of Robert Bresson.

title: MASSEY ENERGY OFFERS DETAILS ON LOWER PROFIT ESTIMATE
description: Massey Energy, a coal producer, offered additional details yesterday on its earlier announcement that it would miss profit estimates in its fourth quarter. Massey said it expected to earn 4 to 10 cents a share in the period, which ends Oct. 31. The profit would be below its previous forecast of 20 cents to 26 cents. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expected the company to earn 16 cents a share. On Tuesday, the company said it would miss estimates because of lower production and higher costs for employee training.

title: Overpowering Colors And Dizzying Theories
description: To bask in the big, color-drenched puzzles created by Alfred Jensen (1903-1981), you don't really need to grasp the arcane theories on which he based them. As the sculptor Donald Judd once put it, the theories were ''important to him but completely irrelevant to the viewer.'' Even Jensen experts confess themselves baffled by some of his private cryptographies. (He himself admitted that his arithmetic was ''a little unconventional.'')

title: Headlong Heartbreak

If you asked him why he decided to display such showmanship only at this point in his life, he might respond, ''Because you never asked me.''

Passed away on September 25, 2001 after a courageous bout with cancer. A native of New Rochelle NY, Mr. Singer graduated from Harvard College in 1957, Harvard Business School in 1959, and the University of Birmingham, England. In 1959, he joined Finlay Fine Jewelry and became President and CEO in 1976. In 1983, he started an estate jewelry firm that now runs over 1000 events a year. Mr. Singer was always active in many industry and charitable organizations. Most recently, he actively served on the boards of Project A.L.S. and American ORT. Within the jewelry industry, he was a member of the 24k Club of New York, the Plumb Club, JIC, JSA, AGS, JVC. He has always given generously to education and the arts, Harvard, the American Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum were among his favorites. His greatest enjoyments and memories include traveling with Linda, playing in his pool with his grandchildren, working out and playing backgammon at the Harvard Club, tennis at QRC, and gardening in his backyard. He will be greatly missed by many, but most by his adoring family. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Project A.L.S. title: CITING DEBT LOAD, MOODY'S CUTS DISNEY'S CREDIT RATING
description: The Walt Disney Company's credit ratings were cut yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which cited the increased debt load the company will assume after it completes its $5.3 billion purchase of Fox Family Worldwide. Disney's senior unsecured debt rating was dropped to A3 from A2 and its commercial paper rating was lowered to P2 from P1. The downgrades were also a result of Disney's stock repurchasing and Moody's expectation that the company's theme parks, its ABC television network and consumer products divisions would face ''significant pressure on performance'' for at least 18 months, Moody's said.

title: The Economic Stimulus We Need
description: It is time to get past the debate over whether or not the United States economy needs a fiscal stimulus and get on to the questions of how large and what kind. While history offers no real parallels to the terrorism of Sept. 11, it is all but certain that the American economy entered a recession on that day -- if not before. Prior to the attacks, only the mighty consumer was keeping the economy above water. And while the official data will be mum for some time, consumer spending probably fell off a cliff on Sept. 11. The longer we wait, the more likely it is that the terrorists will score a victory over our economy.

title: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: 11 Indictments In '99 Killings
description: United Nations prosecutors indicted two Indonesian soldiers and nine East Timorese militia members for the crime of extermination in the killings of 65 people in Oecussi, an isolated enclave, in 1999. ''They segregated young males between 16 and 30 who were educated, tied them up and shot or macheted them to death,'' said Mohamad Othman, the United Nations prosecutor general in East Timor. title: Aid for a Terrorized Economy
description: With the nation almost surely cast into recession by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, leaders in Congress and the White House have been looking for ways to stimulate the economy. They have already pledged $40 billion to reconstruction and counterterrorism. To further spur consumption and investment, Washington should focus on the households and growing businesses that need extra cash most. Any stimulus should be temporary and designed to preserve the government's long-term fiscal health.

title: A Lonely-Hearts Club In Need of Salsa Dancing
description: In ''Born Romantic'' a collection of London lonely-hearts achieve romantic satisfaction thanks to the seductive power of salsa dancing and the counseling of a cabdriver wise in the ways of love. With the exception of this cabbie, warmly and wryly played by Adrian Lester, the male characters are agglomerations of longing and eccentricity. The women they long for are a bit less sharply defined. Frankie (Craig Ferguson), a divorc obsessed with the swinging macho mannerisms of the early-60's Rat Pack, becomes enamored of the aloof, swan-necked Eleanor (Olivia Williams). A fleshy rocker named Fergus (David Morrissey) arrives in the city determined to win back Mo (Jane Horrocks), the fiance he abandoned eight years ago. And Eddie (Jimi Mistry), a nervous thief who lives with his punch-drunk father, develops an unexpected crush -- ''more than a crush, a stampede,'' he declares -- on the nerdy, germ-phobic Jocelyn (Catherine McCormack), who puts flowers on the graves of people whose loved ones are too far away to do it themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, STEVEN JAY
description: WEINBERG-Steven Jay. Born December 7, 1959, tragically lost at the World Trade Center, September 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Laurie. Adoring father of Lindsay, Sam and Jason. Cherished son of Marilyn and Leonard. Loving brother of Paul and dear son-inlaw of Sondra and Sheldon Rudin. Memorial service Nanuet Hebrew Center, 11:00 AM Friday.

title: Pop Star and Public Officials Join Campaign for Tolerance
description: American Muslim and Arab groups have enlisted government officials, Islamic scholars and even a teenage pop star to combat what many fear could be a rising tide of harassment and hate crimes.

title: Bush Administration to Join U.N. Effort to Raise $584 Million for Refugees
description: Facing signs of a rapidly expanding refugee crisis in Afghanistan and neighboring countries, the Bush administration said today that it was joining an urgent United Nations effort to raise $584 million in food and other assistance during the next six months.

title: In this new campaign, the words of the advertisers are written on the subway walls.
description: SUBWAY passengers in Atlanta who looked through the dark windows of their moving train yesterday saw glowing full-motion ads for Dasani, the bottled water from the Coca-Cola Company. The start of the unusual advertising campaign, originally scheduled for Sept. 11, the day of the terrorist attacks, was a quiet event, but it may herald a new age in outdoor advertising.

title: Excerpts From Letter Thought to Be Instructions

title: Life's Harsh Realities And Sparkle Are Forever
description: Eddie Miller (Robert Forster), the stolid protagonist of ''Diamond Men,'' a small, finely acted slice of American life, is the sort of character the movies normally shun like the plague for lack of glamour. A lonely widower in his late 50's, Eddie is an itinerant jewelry salesman who plies his trade in Pennsylvania, driving from town to town through territory where he has built up a network of loyal vendors.

title: Viewing New York's Past But Seeing the Present
description: In 1945 a plane crashed into the Empire State Building. As told in ''New York: An Illustrated History,'' the companion book to Ric Burns's colossal PBS series, a B-25 Army bomber lost its way in the fog, then flew into the building and burned. Fourteen people died, but the building stood so firm that tenants returned two days later.

title: Stanley Herr, 56, Dies; Aided the Retarded
description: Stanley S. Herr, a lawyer whose career of crusades for the mentally disabled altered the legal landscape from schools to death rows, died on Monday at his home in Baltimore. He was 56.

It has headquarters in Wyoming, not Utah, and runs programs throughout the world.

The investment was the first venture capital round for the 14-year-old, privately held company, which sold storage services instead of products until last year. The company, based in Los Angeles, said it was profitable and hoped to go public as early as next spring. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

description: President Bush unveiled a package of sensible proposals yesterday that would expand federal oversight of airport security and boost public confidence in the safety of air travel. But as he engages Congress on the issue, Mr. Bush needs to take another step and press for creation of a federal transportation police force to assume direct responsibility for all airport security functions.

Loving son of Josephine (nee Hulley) and the late William J. Linn, Sr. Devoted grandfather of Gianna, Danielle, Frankie and Lisa Tummolo. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Bourse Venture
description: The owner of the Stockholm bourse, OM A.B., agreed to take over Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company's stake in Jiway, their pan-European exchange. Morgan Stanley is quitting the venture amid a slump in trading. OM shares fell as much as 9.1 percent, to 65 kronor, the lowest level since December 1996, after the company said it would integrate Jiway. The move will cut profit this quarter by 145 million kronor ($13.5 million), a spokeswoman, Anna Eriksson, said.

title: Love and Death in Verona, Bellini's Way
description: Any performance of Bellini's ''Capulets and the Montagues'' needs two things not mentioned in the title: a Romeo and a Juliet. The new production at City Opera, which opened on Tuesday, has both outstandingly. Sarah Connolly as Romeo presents a plaintive but consistently strong mezzo, a voice beautifully capable of the serene Bellinian glide. Mary Dunleavy as Juliet (called Giulietta here) offers all the silver and crystal the role demands while adding a passionate determination.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sonus Networks Forecasts Loss
description: Shares in Sonus Networks, a maker of network equipment, lost more than half their value after the company warned that it would post a loss in the current quarter. The company, based in Westford, Mass., said quarterly sales, hit hard by the deepening slump in the telecommunications market, were likely to be more than 25 percent below expectations. The company said it would report a third-quarter net loss of 5 cents to 7 cents a share, excluding charges, on revenue of $40 million. Sonus also said it would take charges of $435 million to write off good will and $31 million for restructuring costs. For the year, Sonus expects revenue of $170 million to $180 million and a net loss of 8 cents to 10 cents a share. Analysts expected Sonus to be profitable in the current quarter. The stock price plunged $3.52, or 55 percent, to $2.88. Sonus officials remained optimistic, however. ''The transformation of the world's telecommunications network is well under way,'' Hassan Ahmed, the company's chief executive, said. ''Our view of the long-term opportunity has not changed.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Bridge Project To Advance
description: A $175 million bridge-expansion project will proceed, despite some uncertainty about financing, officials said. The Alfred E. Driscoll Bridge over the Raritan River, the Garden State Parkway's busiest crossing, will have its two spans renovated and a third added to ease traffic. Jack Lettiere, an assistant state transportation commissioner, said money would come from a new account in the State Transportation Trust Fund, although officials have not yet determined which taxes or fees would finance the account. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

After criticizing Mr. Bush some two months ago, former President Jimmy Carter is telling the public to support the president with ''complete unity.'' title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, NIGEL BRUCE
description: THOMPSON-Nigel Bruce. A memorial service will be held for Nigel Bruce Thompson, at Grace Church (Broadway at 10th Street), on Saturday, September 29th at 2 PM. Nigel is the beloved husband of Rosana (nee Galvan), son of Patricia and Norman, brother to Neal and Mark, grandson to Evelyn Mills, son-in-law to Ruben and Ana Galvan, and brother-in-law to Nicole Barth and Virginia Galvan. Nigel, age 33, worked as a Foreign Exchange Broker at Cantor Fitzgerald and was unfortunately one of the victims of the World Trade Center tragedy. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the United Way's ''September 11th'' Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORMISTON, GINGER
description: ORMISTON-Ginger. Died tragically on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center. We mourn the death of our very special friend, Ginger. She made us feel like a part of her family with her love, her great sense of humor, and her easy acceptance of others. Ginger made our daughter, Maia, feel like a sister to her two children, Beth and Billy. Our love goes out to them and to her husband and our friend, Jim Kenworthy. She will always be in our hearts. Michelle Ackerman David Frieser

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNDEN, MICHAEL P.
description: LUNDEN-Michael P. Died tragically in the senseless attack on the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Michael is survived by his beloved wife Michelle Brooks Lunden and his nine-month old son Matthew J. Lunden. Other survivors include his mother Rosemary Ritt, his father Francis Gerard Lunden, his sister Tracy Lunden, his brother Mark Lunden, six nieces and nephews, his in-laws, and a legion of friends across the United States. Over the past fifteen years, he distinguished himself as a Vice President & Partner at Cantor Fitzgerald. Most recently, he joined Cantor's Tradespark division for the opportunity to develop new markets in the growing field of energy futures. A devoted husband, doting father, and loving son, Mr. Lunden possessed a veritable penchant for life. He is best remembered by his family and friends for the radiance of his ever-present smile, the vivid aquamarine color of his engaging eyes, and the inordinate magnitude of his heart. Mr. Lunden graduated from Fairfield University in Fairfield, Connecticut where he earned his BS in Finance in May 1986. He was a longtime member of the New York Athletic Club and a parishioner of St. Paul the Apostle Catholic Church on the Upper West Side, as well as Our Lady of Good Counsel in Cutchogue, NY. A Memorial Mass will be held in his honor on Friday, September 28th at 3 PM, at the Church of Our Savior, 59 Park Avenue in New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be directed for the benefit of the Matthew J. Lunden Education Fund, c/o Merrill Lynch, 5500 Sears Tower Chicago, IL 60606.

The Swiss-born Modernist architect, theoretician, painter, sculptor and writer (1887-1965) is not particularly known for his tapestries, but he did many drawings for them and clearly felt tapestries were works of art.

title: Resilient New York
description: The Manhattan skyline -- shown here, circa 1950, in a photograph by Gottscho-Schleisner -- forms the backdrop for the finale of Ric Burns's series ''New York: A Documentary Film.'' The last two episodes, beginning Sunday night on PBS, trace the city's history, through highs and lows, from 1929 through the 1990's. And even though the World Trade Center's twin towers are understandably not the focus of the film, this is still a story of resilience: a reminder of how often New York City has rebuilt itself.

title: Works From Two Americas By a Quintet From Canada
description: The Americas Society opened its concert season on Monday evening with a program given by five players -- a piano quintet -- from Musica Camerata Montral. The musicians duly brought some Canadian music, but as three of them were Argentine by birth, they could also claim Astor Piazzolla as part of their heritage, and he dominated the second half of their concert. Thus providing sounds from Qubec and Buenos Aires, the ensemble was something of a dream ticket for the society.

title: National Briefing | The Plains: Oklahoma: State Parades Open-Shop Law

Russell Perry, the state's secretary of economic development, said his office was already contacting companies to let them know of the change. The referendum, which 54 percent of the voters approved, erased a state law requiring workers in union shops to pay dues even if they were not members of the union. Only about 8 percent of Oklahoma jobs are covered by union contracts. Ross E. Milloy (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Miami School Chief Fired
description: The Miami-Dade County school board voted 6 to 3 on Wednesday to fire the school superintendent, Roger Cuevas, citing unsatisfactory job performance and leadership skills. Mr. Cuevas, 58, will remain in his job until the next board meeting, on Oct. 24. The board will then name an interim superintendent and begin a national search for a permanent one. Mr. Cuevas, an employee of the schools for 32 years, has been in charge of the system, the nation's fourth largest, since 1996. He is being allowed to choose between a buyout worth more than $600,000 or a demotion to deputy superintendent.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Debt Reduction Plan

Olivetti plans to sell as much as 4 billion euros in stock and convertible bonds to existing investors, the company said. It also aims to sell assets worth 1 billion euros. Telecom Italia is expected to sell businesses worth 5 billion euros. Pirelli, which teamed with the Benetton family to buy control of Olivetti in July, needs to reduce net debt of 42 billion euros, more than half of which is Telecom Italia's. Olivetti owns 55 percent of Telecom Italia.

title: The Cataclysmic in Everyday Life
description: I am the child of Holocaust survivors. I write that not to assert authority, but to introduce a perspective common to those of us who grew up in the households of survivors. That is, I learned from my parents, with little being said about it, that everyday life -- including its routine, its safety, its security and its freedom -- was a momentary accident likely to disappear. A life without traumas was not something to which one felt entitled, even if, as was certainly the case for me, childhood brought no cataclysms. Today I think back with admiration to the work that my parents put in to produce what they must have believed was an illusion of normal life in a free society.

title: Security Cameras Planned for Mall in Trade Center Ruins
description: In the wake of two looting arrests at the World Trade Center site, the police are planning to install security cameras in the ruins of the retail mall beneath 5 World Trade Center, a senior police official said.

title: Issues of War and Peace, Unity and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Hawaii Reeling as Events on Distant Shores Keep Its Beaches Bare
description: It was bad after the Persian Gulf war broke out. It was bad when Hurricane Iniki leveled Kauai in 1992. It was bad, quite frankly, for most of the 1990's, when recessions first in California and then in Japan reverberated here, and Hawaii sat out the mainland boom years.

title: Oklahoma's Turn as the Focal Point
description: Usually this time of year, college football enthusiasts gaze south -- at the Southeastern Conference, where national title contenders are eliminated almost weekly in bitter rivalry games, or toward perennial powers like Florida State and Miami. But today, the big-game spotlight will shift out to Oklahoma, where the Sooners, the defending national champions, take on Kansas State in a Big 12 matchup.

title: Missed Opportunities Will Return to Haunt
description: Seven of 10 Mets batters reached base against Tom Glavine in the second inning and part of the third last night, which should have been the ingredients for a rout. Glavine was not fooling anyone. His pitches were appetizing, his location suspect and his legs should have been wobbly. The Mets pounded four straight hits at one point and balls darted around Turner Field as if it were an arcade.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Issues of War and Peace, Unity and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands of Jobs at Stake As Terminal Shops Struggle
description: Retail businesses at the nation's airports, which have expanded to resemble malls in the last few years, are experiencing huge losses from the decline in travel after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Politics That Fray Civic Unity
description: THE 20th Amendment to the United States Constitution seemed worth rereading yesterday.

title: Ailing Yanks Limp Past the Orioles
description: Former teammates speak of Cal Ripken and recall ugly bruises disappearing in a day, an unstable knee seemingly healing overnight, an impossibly deep reservoir of energy. Ripken played in 2,632 consecutive games, but now the Baltimore Orioles' third baseman has only nine games remaining in his career and is playing his final series in Yankee Stadium this weekend.

title: U.N. Requires Members to Act Against Terror
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously adopted an American-sponsored resolution this evening that would oblige all 189 member states to crack down on the financing, training and movement of terrorists, and to cooperate in any campaign against them, including one that involves the use of force.

title: From Heights of Trade Center to Lawns of Suburbia, Shattered Dreams
description: The official number of bodies found in the destruction of the World Trade Center stood at 306 yesterday, and the city medical examiner had identified 238. In all, 5,960 could be missing. Here are glimpses of some of those victims who have been officially declared dead, and whose families have been notified.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the new restrictions on vehicles entering Manhattan misspelled the surname of a city Transportation Department spokesman who reported few traffic problems at the affected bridges and tunnels. He is Tom Cocola, not Cucola.

title: George Bush, G.O.P. Moderate
description: The rush by President Bush and Congress to endorse bipartisan cooperation after Sept. 11 was to be expected. The surprise is that the harmony has held up. Mr. Bush has transformed himself into a moderate, while Democrats are shelving some of their liberal agenda. At the Capitol, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve and a Republican, and Robert Rubin, Bill Clinton's Treasury secretary, have been anointed the twin wise men of the economy, whose every joint appearance is treated with awe. Measures on presidential war powers, airline bailouts, aid for New York and even overall spending have been hammered out by Republicans and Democrats together. Partisan plotting is out of season. Lunching with a legislator from the other party is au courant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 21 about patronage at Massport, the agency that operates Logan International Airport in Boston, included an erroneous reference from a former Massport executive director to a former airport security chief. The chief was a state trooper who provided security for former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis during his presidential campaign. He was not a driver for Mr. Dukakis's wife, Kitty.

title: Center Is Round-the-Clock Guard for Chemical Threats
description: With the nation on edge about whether terrorists' next attack will be chemical, a chemical industry emergency center here is, as always, staffed around the clock. But it is already focused on the chemical hazards at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Posters of the Missing Now Speak of Losses
description: The first wave of paper rained upon the city from the World Trade Center like death's disembodied proxy. As if in answer, a second wave rose up from the photo albums and word processors of thousands of desperate families.

title: A N.Y. Home:City Inspires Italian Photographers
description: NEW YORK  When Maurizio Bacci, a photographer who normally focuses on fashion, rushed to the ruins of the World Trade Center, the pictures he took were published across Italy.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Arts & Ideas last Saturday with an article about just wars misidentified soldiers killed on Buna Beach in New Guinea in 1943. They were members of the United States Army's 32nd Division, not marines.

title: Notes Found After the Hijackings
description: Following are excerpts from a four-page document used by the terrorists responsible for the hijackings of four airplanes on Sept. 11. The document was released by the F.B.I. yesterday and translated for The New York Times by Capital Communications Group, a Washington-based international consulting firm, and by Imad Musa, translator for the firm.

title: New Drug-Offender Program Draws Unexpected Clients
description: Christine Tello, her hair dyed flamboyant pink, mumbled as she tried to explain to Judge Stephen Marcus why she had not obeyed his order to report to a residential drug treatment center.

description: THEY say nobody cares about Barry Bonds.

description: Where do we stand, two and one-half weeks after the terrorist attacks? How effective has the Bush administration been? I think the record is good, but with some serious shortfalls.

title: A Company Pays Tribute
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies, an insurance and financial services company that had offices on seven high floors of the World Trade Center's north tower, held a memorial service at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for its 292 missing employees.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Faster Growth Seen
description: India's economy expanded at an annual pace of 4.4 percent in the quarter ended June 30, stronger than expected, as farms emerged from a two-year drought and lower interest rates supported consumer spending. The advance in India's fiscal first quarter was more robust than the fourth quarter's 3.8 percent pace and economists' expectations of 3.4 percent growth.

title: PRAECIS PHARMACEUTICALS ENDS TESTS OF PAIN DRUG
description: Praecis Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it would not proceed with trials of the Latranal drug for chronic back pain after a test failed to show that the experimental medicine worked. Latranal had reached the second of three stages of testing generally required before Food and Drug Administration approval. Results were from a 300-patient study. Earlier this month, Amgen Inc. ended support for a partnership with Praecis for developing the prostate cancer drug Plenaxis.

title: Milan Designers Break the Mold
description: MILAN  After designing at some of Italy's finest ready-to-wear and couture houses, Nicola Del Verme, Joanne Yulan Jong and Carlos Osman, independent designers with their own labels, know exactly what it takes to give clothes and accessories a sophisticated edge. Their killer cuts, artisan touch and business minds have made them Milan's leading new creative talents.

title: Board Issues Runoff Funds To 4 in Race For Advocate
description: In an unusual move, the city's Campaign Finance Board has authorized runoff payments for all four eligible candidates in the race for public advocate amid concerns that a clear second-place finisher will not emerge until late next week.

description: Fernando Ferrer has all but dared Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to attempt to seek a third term, and yesterday, the mayor answered him with silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIGALL, WILLIAM JASPER, JR.
description: STIGALL-William Jasper, Jr. Of Scarborough, New York, died September 14, after a short illness. Death came soon after his 90th birthday and publication of his World War II memoir, ''A Shower of Frogs''. Born in Chicago, Mr. Stigall graduated from the University of Illinois and Goodman School of Drama, Art Institute of Chicago. He was a decorated veteran of the Eighty-Second Airborne Division, a stage director, actor, college professor, author and traveler. His plays ''Six Women Remember William Shakespeare'' and ''Emily Bronte. Storyteller'' have been widely produced in New York. He is survived by his wife Phyllis Graham Pooley Stigall and their son Dr. Samuel G. Pooley of Honolulu, and granddaughter Cecelia M. Pooley of Laytonville, CA.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: West Nile Virus Alert Grows
description: The State Health Department extended warnings about the mosquito-borne West Nile virus to 12 more counties, placing a total of 48 of the state's 67 counties on alert. The state has confirmed seven human cases of West Nile virus encephalitis this year. It extended its alert area on Thursday after finding the disease in dead birds in the 12 counties. Among them was Miami-Dade, the state's most populous county, with 2.2 million people. The West Nile variety of encephalitis, a brain inflammation, was unknown in the Western Hemisphere until it was documented in the New York area in 1999.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is worse than Christmas.''

title: MANDALAY, CASINO CONCERN, SEES INCOME DECLINE
description: The Mandalay Resort Group, owner of the Luxor and Circus Circus casinos, said that its fiscal third-quarter earnings would fall significantly short of last year's and that it would cut 15 percent of its Nevada staff, or 4,300 people. Mandalay, which is based in Las Vegas, said earnings for the quarter ending Oct. 31 will be less than the 38 cents the company earned a year earlier. The company was expected to earn 35 cents, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson Financial/First Call. Mandalay gets about 70 percent of its cash flow from its Las Vegas casinos, which also include the Mandalay Bay. Travel to Las Vegas, where half the visitors come by air, has fallen as conventions and meetings are canceled after this month's terrorist attacks and tourists cut back on travel.

title: Journal; The End of the Beginning
description: Rudy Giuliani is being mercurial again. Nostradamus is falling off the best-seller list. CNN's ratings have dropped 70 percent from their post-attack peak. Jay Leno delivers a joke linking Osama bin Laden to Anna Nicole Smith. (Had it been funny, I'd repeat it.) Scattered among the bulletins of widespread layoffs are austere TV commercials in slo-mo black-and-white in which corporations pledge their solidarity with the American spirit.

Services at Plaza Memorial, 10 AM, Sunday September 30, 91st St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Accord On River Cleanup
description: The City of Portland and local businesses signed an agreement to analyze pollution in the Willamette River, the first step in a cleanup that will take years. The Environmental Protection Agency declared the river a Superfund location, a designation reserved for the country's most contaminated sites, after discovering high levels of mercury, tar and other toxic substances in the sediments. The city has agreed to pay $850,000, or 25 percent of the cost of the $3.4 million analysis; the federal government and at least 10 businesses that operate in the harbor will cover the remainder. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Deal to Add $25 Billion To Budget
description: The White House and leaders of both parties in Congress have agreed to provide the full $18.4 billion increase President Bush sought for military spending and to allocate more money to education, in a deal that could avoid a partisan fight over government spending for 2002, officials said today.

title: Trinidad-Hopkins Fight Is a Clash of Iron Wills
description: As Bernard Hopkins and Felix Trinidad posed for pictures after yesterday's weigh-in, Hopkins took several steps toward Trinidad, forcing the two fighters to stand nose to nose.

title: Fox Will Not Use '1st and Ten' Line
description: Fox Sports is eliminating the popular, computer-generated ''1st and Ten'' line from its N.F.L. coverage until further notice as part of its cost-cutting efforts. Fox had been using the feature, which shows how far away a team is from a first down, on two games a week. The cost of the electronic line to Fox is $20,000 to $25,000 a game.

title: United Makes Further Reductions in Effort to Weather Crisis
description: United Airlines will cut the total number of passengers it can fly by 6 percentage points more than it had previously indicated as it tries to survive a huge decline in passenger traffic since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, the airline said yesterday.

title: Stocks End The Week On an Uptick
description: A strong week eased the pain for investors only slightly as the stock market ended its worst quarter since the crash of 1987.

title: A NATION CHALLENGED
description: Mourning Amid the Rubble

title: Two New Spy Series at Unexpected Risk
description: The premiere for ''The Agency,'' a new CBS series about the Central Intelligence Agency, was to have opened in an old section of Cairo. Audiences would have seen an episode in which a jeep full of armed soldiers invades an ancient marketplace and they quickly infiltrate a building. There they find a man tied to a chair, his mouth stuffed with a gag made from an American flag. A soldier tugs at the gag, and the man explodes, killing everyone.

title: The Liszt Who Contradicts His Popular Flashy Persona
description: Recordings have done a great deal to round out our impressions of Franz Liszt. With most of his grand symphonic essays, spacious choral works and intimately scaled art songs available on disc, listeners today have an opportunity to take the full measure of this complex and often puzzling composer. Yet most listeners still regard Liszt as a composer of splashy, picturesque, finger-breaking works, some sublime and others bombastic and trashy.

title: Praxair to Cut About 900 Jobs
description: Praxair Inc., a leading producer of industrial gas, said today that it would cut close to 900 jobs and miss fourth-quarter profit forecasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, EMANUEL
description: KLEIN-Emanuel on September 28, 2001, age 94. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Loving father of Harvey and Phyllis (Patti), David and Arnold. Dear brother of Leonard and Charlotte. Adoring grandfather of Laura, Daniel, Sarah and Aaron; great-grandfather of Julia Rose. Service Sunday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions: Kittay House, c/o Rise Landsman, 2550 Webb Ave, Bronx, NY 10468.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STACK, CHRISTINA
description: STACK-Christina. Died September 25, 2001 at her home in Woodstock, NY. Beloved sister of Tara and Lee; accomplished and beautiful artist. Memorial service in Woodstock at Christina's home, 2PM Friday, October 5, 2001.

title: GENESIS MICROCHIP TO BUY RIVAL FOR $241 MILLION
description: Genesis Microchip Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, Sage Inc., for about $241 million in stock to bolster its portfolio of semiconductors used in flat-panel computer screens. Genesis will exchange 0.571 share for each Sage share. The transaction values each share of Sage at $15.59, or 37 percent more than Thursday's closing price of $11.36. Genesis makes chips used in computer monitors while Sage makes chips used in flat-panel televisions, computer monitors and Internet appliances. Genesis is based in Thornhill, Ontario. Sage is based in Milpitas, Calif.

title: In New War on Terrorism, Words Are Weapons, Too
description: The title of his show is ''Politically Incorrect,'' which, until recently, was politically acceptable. But in a time when public discourse is constrained by barriers of taste, propriety and patriotism, the comments on Sept. 17 by the late-night talk show host Bill Maher were denounced as both incorrect and unacceptable by two major sponsors, a dozen affiliate stations and even the White House.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Growth Forecast Lowered
description: Reflecting higher local interest rates and a worsening global economic picture after terrorist attacks on the United States, Brazil's central bank lowered the country's economic growth forecast to 2 percent from 2.8 percent for 2001. Fears of a recession were reduced, however, after the government revised the second-quarter gross domestic product up to 1.82 percent from a previously announced growth rate of 0.79 percent. Analysts say that lower economic growth will help keep a lid on inflation, which is already expected to exceed the central bank's goal of 6 percent this year. The government forecasts inflation of 6.5 percent. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Berard Clears Hurdle to Start Comeback
description: For Bryan Berard, the waiting was the hardest part.

title: A War on a Small Scale, Possibly Long and Risky
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  The Bush administration is putting aside the American military's longstanding insistence on using overwhelming force to vanquish its enemy. Instead, Pentagon planners are now focusing on commando raids and limited air strikes to root out Osama bin Laden's terrorist network in Afghanistan.

title: The Mayor and the Limits of Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: You'll Enjoy Her Company If You Wear Your Galoshes
description: ''Warm Water Under a Red Bridge'' is the Japanese filmmaker Shohei Imamura's tribute to the concept of release, and for Saeko (Misa Shimizu) that euphoria is an expulsion of water from her body. At this orgasmic eruption, fish gather at her feet, and during peak moments she lets loose a freshet with the pressure of a fire hydrant.

title: 'SNL' Opening Night
description: When the first ''Saturday Night Live'' of the season goes on the air tonight, the NBC show will commemorate the Sept. 11 attack on its hometown with some famous New Yorkers as guests, according to several sources involved in planning for the show.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about retailers that are altering their marketing plans in the wake of the terrorist attacks misstated the ownership of Lord & Taylor, which said it would still open its Christmas windows, but without a celebration. It is part of May Department Stores, not Federated.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Upswing In Production
description: South Korea's industrial production unexpectedly rose 4.5 percent in August from July, after four months of declines. Sales of cars produced by the Hyundai Motor Company were one reason for the upturn. Analysts had expected a drop of at least 0.5 percent in production. The finance ministry has forecast economic growth of 0.5 percent for the third quarter and 2 percent for the year, a decline from last year's 8.8 percent pace. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Evan Lottman; Film Editor, 70
description: Evan A. Lottman, a film editor whose work was nominated for an Academy Award, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 70.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article in The Metro Section yesterday about Mexican migrant workers described their lonely and indigent lives on the East End of Long Island and their fear that antiterrorism measures would result in border shutdowns and strand them in this country. The article was illustrated with a photograph of a man in a house shared by 15 Mexicans. He wore a sombrero emblazoned with a Spanish vulgarism. The choice of picture evoked an ethnic stereotype, and the publication of the vulgarism violated The Times's standards. The picture should not have appeared.

title: A Lennon Tribute Revived
description: ''Come Together: A Night for John Lennon's Words and Music,'' a concert at Radio City Music Hall that was postponed after the World Trade Center attack, has been rescheduled for Tuesday at 8 p.m. Tickets are available by calling Ticketmaster, (212) 307-7171); prices range from $53.50 to $203.50.

title: Bridge Federation Moves Championship Play to Paris
description: The president of the World Bridge Federation, Jos Damiani, said yesterday the world championships would be played in Paris starting Oct. 21. The event, which features the Bermuda Bowl for Open Teams, the Venice Cup for Women's Teams, the Senior Teams and the Transnational Teams, had been scheduled for Bali, Indonesia, but that plan was canceled earlier this week when American players expressed a strong reluctance to travel to that area.

title: Doleful Bonds Funnels Emotion Into His Pursuit
description: Instead of reveling in the thought of breaking Mark McGwire's record of 70 home runs in his own ballpark this weekend, Barry Bonds's somber voice was at the whisper level of someone telling a secret.

title: Berlusconi Stands By Remarks on Islam
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy in no way apologized today for his widely condemned remarks that Western civilization was superior to Islamic culture.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Girding Against Colombia Guerrillas
description: The Interior Ministry said it was reinforcing the frontier region with Colombia with more than 100 police and special forces to protect the border from incursions by Colombian guerrillas. Officials reported an incursion of six members of Colombia's largest rebel group last month. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: PRESIDENT SAYS U.S. IS 'IN HOT PURSUIT' OF TERROR GROUP
description: President Bush said today that the United States was ''in hot pursuit'' of both Osama bin Laden and the Taliban forces harboring him in Afghanistan.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Rail Line Moves Ahead
description: A regional mass transit agency approved a plan for the initial segment of a light rail line in Seattle, and said it expected to break ground by next summer. The $2.1 billion, 14-mile project is significantly smaller than the plan approved by Seattle voters in 1996, which would have connected the University District north of downtown to Seattle-Tacoma International Airport in the south. At $150 million a mile, the current line will begin downtown and stop short of the airport, with a shuttle covering the last mile. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Illusions and the Normal Life
description: PRINCETON, N.J. -- I am the child of Holocaust survivors. I write that not to assert authority, but to introduce a perspective common to those of us who grew up in the households of survivors. That is, I learned from my parents, with little being said about it, that everyday life  including its routine, its safety, its security and its freedom  was a momentary accident likely to disappear. A life without traumas was not something to which one felt entitled, even if, as was certainly the case for me, childhood brought no cataclysms. Today I think back with admiration to the work that my parents put in to produce what they must have believed was an illusion of normal life in a free society.

title: After Havoc, Reviving a Legacy
description: Frederick Moulton Alger III is not a man easily given to sentiment. He gave up his American citizenship six years ago in a calculated attempt to preserve his fortune, built during a 40-year career in the money management business. He turned over day-to-day management of his firm, Fred Alger Management, to his brother, David, who had worked by his side since 1971.

title: In New York Visit, O'Connor Foresees Limits on Freedom
description: Describing herself as ''still tearful'' after viewing the World Trade Center site, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor told a law school audience in Manhattan yesterday that as part of the country's response to terrorism, ''we're likely to experience more restrictions on our personal freedom than has ever been the case in our country.''

title: Again, Democrats Find Giuliani at Center of the Race
description: Just a few days ago, Mark Green was preparing for a runoff campaign in which he would stress unity -- a contrast with Fernando Ferrer's advocacy for ''the other New York'' -- while offering a sober discussion of how to rebuild the city. Mr. Ferrer was preparing to cite his work rebuilding dilapidated housing as Bronx borough president, while urging that New York, in its rush to recover, not neglect problems with housing, health care and education.

title: Response To Attack Splits Arabs In the West
description: Since the end of the First World War, when the French and British willy-nilly carved up the decaying Ottoman Empire, people have been divided over who is to blame for the veil of misery that shrouds millions of people across the Arab world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, LEO J., D.D.S.
description: GOLUB-Leo J., D.D.S. Age 79. Beloved husband (Audrey, Stonington, CT.), father (Mark and David, Stamford, CT.), grandfather of thirteen. Died Wednesday September 26, 2001 of natural causes. B.A., D.D.S. (Columbia University). Spirited intellectual and passionate advocate for liberal causes. Son of Dr. Jacob and Rose Golub, pioneers in Jewish education and the Jewish Reconstructionist movement. Committed to Jewish life at the SAJ in New York City. President of YPL. Dentist, Trumbull, CT. Owned and operated Holiday Inns in Connecticut and Ohio, and software company, Mystic Management Systems. Instrumental in the creation of B'nai Torah and Council for Better Schools (Trumbull, CT.). His family and friends will always remember his zest for life, his charismatic personality and his brilliant and articulate mind. Funeral services Sunday, 11AM, Byles-Macdougall (New London, CT.) and Sunday 8PM, Temple Beth El, (Stamford, CT.)

Most of the others were too busy keeping the memory of their loved ones alive. They were printing fliers and filling out police reports and even waiting by the telephone.

description: PRATO  While Florence rests proudly on its laurels as the cradle of Renaissance culture, the nearby Tuscan city of Prato is becoming known for some of Italian fashion's most innovative, sophisticated yarns and fabrics.

title: Competition Forces 3 Casual Brands to Rethink Strategy : Life in the Global Fast Lane
