title: Indonesia Radicals Issue Threats of Holy War
description: Holy war against America could be tough for Usmady Arafat, one of the angry young would-be warriors who marched through the rain here today with masks and headbands chanting, ''Go to hell America.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, HERMAN
description: SANDLER-Herman, 57. Loving husband of Suki, devoted father of Pamela, Gillian and Jordana, role model and mentor to hundreds of young people. You encouraged us to take risks and gave us innumerable opportunities to follow our dreams, cheering us on as we learned to impact the world as you did so powerfully. You will always remain our awesome inspiration. We love you, Suki, Pamela, Gillian and Jordana. In lieu of flowers, gifts honoring Herman may be made to any of the following organizations: American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, The Rain Forest Foundation, The Perlman Music Program, Carnegie Hall, or UJA Federation of NY.

title: Economy Is Still Teetering Near Recession, Data Show
description: The economy grew in the second quarter at the slowest pace since 1993 and consumer sentiment plunged this month after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, threatening to stifle the tentative growth left in the economy's record expansion.

title: Hospital Fined by Health Dept. In Death of Boy During M.R.I.
description: The State Department of Health fined the Westchester Medical Center $22,000 yesterday for 11 safety violations that it said resulted in the death of a 6-year-old boy during a scan with a magnetic resonance imaging machine in July.

title: Ezra Ehrenkrantz, Architect, 69
description: Ezra Ehrenkrantz, a versatile architect, died on Sept. 22 at his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 69.

title: Marines on Okinawa Say They're Wary as They Gauge the Possibilities of a Combat Role
description: The exotic tropical island of Okinawa, the United States Marines' one permanent base overseas, has long been considered the dream assignment as the first taste of life abroad for recruits.

title: With Bailout Hopes Fading, Japan Banks Face the Music
description: The deadline is at hand for Japan's banks to start swallowing the bitter medicine of bad-loan write-offs and portfolio markdowns, and the government is showing no inclination to sugar-coat it with a taxpayer-financed bailout.

title: Security Cameras Planned for Mall in Trade Center Ruins
description: In the wake of two looting arrests at the World Trade Center site, the police are planning to install security cameras in the ruins of the retail mall beneath 5 World Trade Center, a senior police official said.

title: F.B.I. Expert On bin Laden And Terrorism Is Mourned
description: Perhaps the most fitting tribute to John P. O'Neill, the counter-terrorism expert killed in the World Trade Center attack, came a few days after his death, when some unexpected help in the terrorist investigation arrived from overseas.

title: U.S. Prepares Big Packages Of Assistance For Its Allies
description: In the most significant reward for its new partners against terrorism, administration officials said today that they were planning to ask Congress for $500 million in new economic assistance to Pakistan.

title: Beliefs; Amid Islam's complexity, scholars are challenged to influence change without compromising.
description: Authentic Islam, the world has been told repeatedly in recent days, condemns terrorism, rejects violence against innocent civilians and advocates peace. The message has come from many of the highest Muslim religious authorities, from American Muslim organizations, from the pope, from the president and from many others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ANNE W.
description: STERN-Anne W., on September 28. Devoted wife of the late Dave. Loving mother of Elinor Parsont and Stanley. Cherished Nana of Diane, David, Michael, Judi and Joanne. Adored Great-Nana of Rachelle, Jeffrey, Nicholas, Benjamin, Anneke and Lilian. Her family was her life. Service Sunday 12 Noon at Riverside, 21 W. Broad St, Mt Vernon, NY. Contributions to Children's Service League of Westchester will be appreciated.

title: Issues of War and Peace, Unity and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: A Man Who Sells Watches Must Endure a Test of Time
description: ''What Time Is It There?,'' the newest film from the Taipei director Tsai Ming-liang, may be one of the most unusual in some time. This work, shown today and tomorrow night at the New York Film Festival, certainly stands alone among cinematic achievements this year. Mr. Tsai has managed to create an underplayed melodrama about family dynamics and dysfunction that harks back to the spare, unchecked heartache of Yasujiro Ozu. (Echoes of his powerful influence can also be seen in Shohei Imamura's ''Warm Water Under a Red Bridge,'' also part of the festival.)

title: Front-Line Taliban Foes Eager to Help U.S.
description: Ignoring the threat of Taliban snipers, Gen. Baba Khan swaggered across the top floor of this demolished airfield's control tower this afternoon and pointed southward. ''On the other side of those mountains,'' he said, his voice filled with yearning, ''is Kabul.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FETTER, JEANETTE
description: FETTER-Jeanette. On September 26, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Simon Fetter. Devoted mother of Henry and Lois, Steven and Bonnie, and Robert and Tammy. Loved by grandchildren Jennifer, Jessica, Sarah, Deborah, Samuel, Jacob and Joseph. Graveside service at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York, September 30th at 10:30 a.m.

title: A. Joseph Debe, 73, Creator Of Unusual Stock Derivative
description: A. Joseph Debe, who had worked for more than two decades to create a stock derivative that became popular in the late 1980's, died at his home in Garden City, N.Y., on Sunday. He was 73.

title: Microsoft Talks Ordered by Judge
description: A federal judge has ordered Microsoft and the government to start a new round of negotiations to settle the long-running antitrust case. Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly gave the lawyers two weeks to reach a deal on their own. If they fail to reach a deal, she said, she would appoint a mediator and require them to report back to her every 10 days on the progress of the talks.

title: Jets Say Farrior Is Key To Defense
description: James Farrior arrived with this label: the first pick of the Bill Parcells Jets' regime. Not only that, Farrior was a linebacker, and everyone in football knew about Parcells and linebackers and their spectacular success together.

title: The Mayor and the Limits of Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: Northwest and American To Pay Severance Benefits
description: American Airlines and Northwest Airlines, facing the anger of their employees, have dropped plans to deny severance benefits to thousands of workers that they plan to lay off in their post-Sept. 11 slump.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Settlement In Bias Suit
description: The State Department of Transportation has agreed to settle a longstanding racial discrimination lawsuit for about $60 million, with most of the money going to about 2,400 African-Americans who are current or former employees of the department. They had claimed they were discriminated against in both hiring and promotions. The case was first filed in federal court in 1985. The state signed a consent decree in 1994 requiring it to set up race-neutral personnel practices, but agreed last year that it had failed to do so. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the violinist Isaac Stern on Monday (and in some late editions on Sunday) misidentified the occasion on which he donned a gas mask with the Israel Philharmonic during the Persian Gulf war. It was at a rehearsal in 1991, a time of Scud missile alerts, to see if he could play while wearing it, not at a performance later, when audience members wore theirs.

title: Judge Orders Talks to Settle Microsoft Case
description: A federal judge today ordered Microsoft and the government into a new round of intensive negotiations to settle the long-running antitrust case. Should talks fail, she indicated, the company faces the prospect of a quick series of hearings next spring to enable her to fashion a tough and broad penalty.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electronics Outlook Lowered
description: The Japanese electronics company, NEC, lowered its profit forecast because of slumping demand for cellular phones, computers and other items that use its semiconductors. The company, which planned to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange, will lose 150 billion yen ($1.26 billion) in the year to March 2002, instead of a 65 billion yen profit previously forecast. The company has been in talks to sell some of its factories. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sales of New Municipal Bonds Up 37%
description: Municipal bond issuance rose 37 percent in the third quarter, as falling interest rates encouraged states, cities and other governments to refinance, Thomson Financial Securities Data said yesterday.

title: German Data Led U.S. to Search For More Suicide Hijacker Teams
description: In the hours following the Sept. 11 terror attacks, German intelligence agents intercepted a phone conversation between jubilant followers of Osama bin Laden that led the F.B.I. to search frantically for two more teams of suicide hijackers, according to officials in both countries.

title: The Exodus From Afghanistan
description: A refugee crisis is brewing in Afghanistan that dwarfs the 1999 departure of 800,000 ethnic Albanians from Kosovo in the wake of Slobodan Milosevic's spasm of ethnic violence there. Millions of Afghans are fleeing their homes, partly in disgust with the Taliban but mostly in fear that America is getting ready to bomb their country. They are joining millions who have already fled, victims of 22 years of war and drought.

title: Pakistan Says No U.S. Troops Are Presently on Its Soil
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 29  Pakistan denied today that any American troops were in Pakistan, but a carefully-worded foreign ministry statement appeared to leave open the possibility that Pakistan has been used as a staging area for special forces operations inside Afghanistan.

title: Issues of War and Peace, Unity and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: San Gabriel Journal; A Cool Tea Heats Up Night Life
description: On most nights, after the stores have been shuttered and the working people have turned off the lights, young Asian-Americans descend upon this Los Angeles suburb and transform the main drag into an incandescent necklace of activity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRENKEL, PETER J.
description: FRENKEL-Peter J. The partners and personnel of Fawn Associates and its affiliates mourn the passing of our partner and friend, Peter Frenkel. His warm and generous demeanor coupled with his sense of humor were key elements of our partnership mix for over four decades. He will be remembered with the greatest fondness and he will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LENORE NATHAN BLOCK
description: ROSENBERG - Lenore Nathan Block. Of Buffalo NY, died peacefully September 27, 2001, in her ninetieth year. She is deeply mourned by her son, the writer Lawrence Block of New York City; her stepsons, Richard Rosenberg of Laguna Beach and Arthur Rosenberg of Albuquerque; her daughters-in-law, Lynne Block, Karen Rosenberg, and Loretta Mackay; her grandchildren, Amy Reichel, Jill Block, Alison Pouliot, Gretchen Faber, Diane Sweeney, Kenneth Rosenberg, David Poohina, and Jennifer Reyes; her greatgrandchildren, Sara and Marisa Reichel, Joseph Harrison, and Laura Rosenberg; and her brother and sister-in-law, Hi and Mim Nathan. She was predeceased by her two husbands, Arthur Jerome Block and Joseph Rosenberg; her daughter, Betsy Molina; and her brother, Jerry Nathan. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Cornell University, an accomplished painter, a woman of infinite warmth and wit, she's gone where the Saturday Review still publishes a Literary Cryptogram every week, and where there's an endless supply of unworked Double-Crostics; where Rubinstein and Horowitz and Art Tatum take turns at the piano, and where her favorite cities of New York and Paris and London are just around the corner. She was a great and gallant lady, and her absence leaves an enormous permanent gap in the skyline.

title: Disturbance Causes Flight To Be Diverted
description: An unruly passenger whose actions caused an Air Canada flight to return here on Thursday escorted by two F-16 fighters was charged in federal court today with interfering with flight crew operations.

title: Islanders Stretch Budget for Osgood
description: The Islanders acquired the big-ticket goaltender Chris Osgood at noon yesterday with the idea of keeping him for a long time. Barely an hour later, Osgood said that at the very least, his new team was capable of making the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: So You Wanna Be a Rock 'n' Roll Star?
description: If there's one philosophical tenet underlying the last decade of Hollywood films, it's this: If you go for it, you'll get it. Just believe in yourself, follow your dream, and like Rocky and his many descendants, you'll find your talents rewarded and your fantasies fulfilled.

title: F.B.I. Focusing on Navigational Device
description: In the days since the terrorist attacks, investigators have been trying to determine how hijackers with limited piloting experience, who had apparently never flown jumbo jets, managed to navigate the airliners with enough precision to change course abruptly and strike the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Scholars Divided on Giuliani Bid
description: Politicians have responded in different ways to an adoring public. Julius Caesar declined attempts by his constituents to have him wear a crown, explaining, ''Non rex sum sed Caesar'' -- ''I am not a king but Caesar.'' (Though in the end, his closest advisers got him out of office by stabbing him.) And George Washington refused to give in to public desire to keep him permanently in the presidency, stepping down at the end of his second term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, BENNETT LAWSON
description: FISHER-Bennett Lawson, 58, of Stamford, CT on September 11, 2001 at the World Trade Center. He is survived by his wife of 32 years, Susan Huntington Fisher, their children, Louisa Huntington Fisher and James Bruen Fisher, his mother, Elsie Lawson Fisher, two brothers and four sisters. A senior vice president of Fiduciary Trust Company International, Ben contributed considerable time to numerous non profit organizations. A memorial service is October 1 at 11 AM at St. Barnabas Church, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Ben's memory to the Pomfret School, Pomfret, CT or Save the Greenwich Lighthouse Fund, Let There Be Light, Inc., 21 W. Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT 06830

title: President Says U.S. Is in 'Hot Pursuit' of Terror Group
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  President Bush said today that the United States was "in hot pursuit" of both Osama bin Laden and the Taliban forces harboring him in Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEATROUR, HENRIETTE
description: NEATROUR-Henriette. On September 23, 2001. Wife of Richard. Memorial service will be held at Church of the Ascension at 5th Avenue and 10th Street, Manhattan on Friday October 5th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to Supportive Care Program, St. Vincent's Hospital, 153 West 11th St, NY, NY 10011.

title: The Mayor and the Limits of Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Honduras: Regional Antiterrorism Project
description: Representatives of Central America's governments announced that they would create a comprehensive regional security plan to combat terrorism and organized crime. The heads of state, who met soon after the Sept. 11 attacks in New York and Washington, proposed that the Central American Security Commission present a plan in 20 days to coordinate security, intelligence and border control activities in the region. Several nations are already examining bank accounts held by Arab residents, while Nicaraguan officials are investigating claims that immigrant smugglers provided false documents to scores of Arab immigrants. In previous years, the region has also been a conduit for arms smuggled to Colombian guerrillas. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Pakistan Says No U.S. Troops Are Presently on Its Soil
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 29  Pakistan denied today that any American troops were in Pakistan, but a carefully-worded foreign ministry statement appeared to leave open the possibility that Pakistan has been used as a staging area for special forces operations inside Afghanistan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REALINI, CAROL
description: REALINI-Carol. Loving mother of Anna. Devoted sister, aunt and friend. Brilliant, loving, giving life force. Services Sunday, September 30, 1:30PM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave. Receiving at: Barbara Shapiro, 110 East 13th St, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHN, STEPHEN M.
description: CAHN-Stephen M. Age 61, of Worcester, MA, native of NYC, an attorney specializing in juvenile law; beloved husband of Dr. Marjorie (Eckmann) Cahn; devoted father of Amy Laura Cahn of Brooklyn and Patrick Cahn of Northampton, MA; devoted son of William M. Cahn, Jr. and Margaret (Millhauser) Cahn of Purchase, NY; beloved brother of William M. Cahn III of Armonk, NY, and the late Peter A. Cahn of NYC. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM, on Sunday, September 30, in Perlman Funeral Home, 1026 Main St, Worcester, MA. Memorial observance 4 to 7 PM, Monday, October 1, through Thursday, October 4, at his residence, 295 Salisbury St, Worcester, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to YOU, Inc, 81 Plantation St, Worcester, MA 01604 or to Massachusetts Children's Trust Fund, 294 Washington St, Suite 640, Boston, MA 02108. A Memorial service will be held at a future date in time.

title: Engineers Seek to Test Steel Before It Is Melted for Reuse
description: The huge steel columns and beams of the World Trade Center are being hauled off to be melted and recycled before engineers can inspect the twisted metal, which they say could hold important clues on how to build safer skyscrapers in the future.

title: Bush Considering Plan for Limited Reopening of Reagan Airport, Officials Say
description: Administration officials said today that President Bush could announce by Tuesday whether Ronald Reagan National Airport would reopen, and under what circumstances.

title: Giants' Line Is Rested for Saints Test
description: As if the Giants needed another concern in their matchup against the New Orleans Saints' sack-hungry defensive line Sunday, Lomas Brown watched practice today from the sideline.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the National Briefing column yesterday with a report about journalists who settled a lawsuit against Los Angeles was published in error. It showed David Horowitz, president of the Center for the Study of Popular Culture, not the televison reporter David Horowitz, who took part in the suit.

title: The Mayor and the Limits of Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: Detainees' Accounts Are at Odds With Official Reports of an Orderly Investigation
description: Law enforcement officials around the country are often asking scattered questions in chaotic interrogations of people held as part of the investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks -- or not asking any questions at all, lawyers, relatives and some of the detained people say.

title: Plants May Rise for a Concrete-Starved Manhattan
description: City officials and construction executives are considering building concrete plants on the waterfront in Manhattan for the first time in more than a decade because traffic jams on bridges have stalled trucks' delivery of concrete to building sites and have idled hundreds of workers.

title: Mets' Late Drive Hits a Familiar Roadblock
description: The Mets are a feel-good story these days, and there was polite applause for them tonight at Turner Field. The Mets have always been good guests here, after all. They are good ol' boys from up north, never meaning no harm.

title: No Threats to Bridges, City Officials Say
description: While security checkpoints have tied up traffic going in and out of New York, city officials said yesterday that there had been no threats of attacks on the city's bridges and tunnels.

title: Wounds of a Bitter Conflict
description: The terrorist attacks on Washington and New York shocked me. The entire world has been convinced that it is essential to stand against this evil together, uniting the efforts of many countries. Our country is committed to taking this path, as President Vladimir Putin has declared many times already.

title: Switzerland Feels Chill of Insecurity After Shooting
description: ZUG, Switzerland  Switzerland, which prides itself on its accessible political system, on Friday was in the midst of self-examination on whether it could retain its traditional openness after the 14 murders in this pretty lakeside town.

title: Lincoln Center Sees Chief Quit In Abrupt Exit
description: After an often stormy tenure of only nine months, Gordon J. Davis resigned abruptly yesterday as president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, casting new clouds over the center's $1.5 billion refurbishment plan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bleak Advertising Forecast
description: The British advertising agency Cordiant Communications Group said that it expected revenue for 2001 to fall 5 percent as a result of a weakening economy that has worsened since the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States. Cordiant, which owns the Bates Worldwide advertising network, had originally expected revenue to grow 11 percent this year. ''Trading conditions in our industry are currently the most difficult experienced in recent years,'' the company said, as projects and campaigns are canceled. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Merger Of Exchanges Possible
description: The London Stock Exchange said it had approached the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange about a merger in an effort to cement its position as a leading venue for share and derivatives trading in Europe. Earlier in the day, Liffe -- as the electronic trading platform for commodities, currency and equities is called -- said it had received several overtures. After trading volume surged in the first half of the year, ''we are not surprised to have received a number of approaches,'' the options exchange's chairman, Sir Brian Williamson, said, according to Bloomberg News. Liffe named Credit Suisse First Boston to help evaluate offers. The London Stock Exchange has been looking at ways to shore up its position after a failed attempt to merge with the Frankfurt market last year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: 2 Deaths Haunt Sleuth in a Murder Capital
description: Death was once a science for Irma Rodrguez Galarza.

title: 9 Athletes Get Physicals So They Can Play Soccer
description: Stephen McCormack, 15, was running late for school on Sept. 11. Despite his tardiness, he stopped at a coffee stand for a cup of hot chocolate. As he sipped it, the bright morning suddenly turned dim.

title: Issues of War and Peace, Unity and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Watch Italy Chief's News Media
description: Here is the long-awaited plan for how Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi will deal with the inherent conflicts of interest that result from owning a number of the news media outlets that cover him and the other companies with business before his government: Parliamentary leaders from his own coalition will appoint the members of a watchdog group that will monitor possible conflicts, and report back to Parliament.

title: Quetta Journal; Giving Proper Burial to Holy Books
description: The web of hand-dug tunnels extends deep into the bowels of the mountain south of the city, offering concealment and security. Well-worn carpets line the three miles of dirt floors, and electric lights hang from the ceilings.

title: Issues of War and Peace, Unity and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: WAITS INCREASING FOR AIR TRAVELERS
description: More rigorous screening procedures and an increase in business and leisure travelers have produced daunting lines at airports around the country in the past two days.

title: Some Inspirational Words
description: Bill Clinton urged a group of Harlem high school students yesterday to defy terrorism by moving on with their lives. He said that they were in a ''unique position'' to lead Americans in being tolerant and humane rather than fearful of their neighbors, because blacks themselves had suffered so much discrimination and abuse.

title: Wounds of a Bitter War
description: MOSCOW -- The terrorist attacks on Washington and New York shocked me. The entire world has been convinced that it is essential to stand against this evil together, uniting the efforts of many countries. Our country is committed to taking this path, as President Vladimir Putin has declared many times already.

title: Making Audiences Laugh and Then Feel Ashamed
description: ''Don't worry, your movie's a hit.'' These are the last words of Todd Solondz's ''Storytelling,'' which will be shown tomorrow and Sunday in the 39th annual New York Film Festival. The line is spoken by Scooby Livingston (Mark Webber), a New Jersey high school student whose so-called life has been grist for a documentary grandiosely entitled ''American Scooby'' and made by a desperate nebbish named Toby Oxman (Paul Giamatti). With unsparing rigor and unsettling calculation, Mr. Solondz has made it unlikely that anyone, sarcastically or otherwise, will call his new movie a hit. It is, nonetheless, a bracing slap in the face -- in several faces, really, including the director's own.

title: Dead and Missing
description: As of 11 a.m. Friday.

title: New Charges Against Milosevic Tie Him to Croatia War Crimes
description: A second indictment has been issued against Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, charging him with war crimes in Croatia, officials of the United Nations war crimes tribunal said today.

title: Dark Tale With the Power to Brighten a Night
description: It wasn't surprising that there were patches of empty seats on Wednesday night for the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Berg's ''Wozzeck.'' In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, audiences may be avoiding an opera about a delusional soldier in 1820's Leipzig who supplements his meager pay by performing menial tasks for an overbearing captain and offering himself as a subject for crackpot medical experiments. The opera ends when Wozzeck murders his common-law wife for giving in to the brutish advances of a husky drum major and then drowns himself.

title: Bohemian Funk Takes Its Cue From Eccentric Interiors
description: MILAN  Bohemian Funk was born the day Chandelier opened its doors on Milan's Via Broggi last January. The brainchild of the creative director Antonio Coppola, this bar-restaurant has interiors as dreamlike and lush as a Federico Fellini movie. Baroque thrones cosy up to Moroccan couches in the red-lit bar. Chandeliers drip from the painted ceiling of the dining room. Murano glass mirrors multiply a thousand-fold the candles in rococo candelabras.

title: Issues of War and Peace, Unity and Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Gander Takes Early Lead And Makes Sure It Holds Up
description: Gander had jumped out in front the moment the starting gate opened, but he almost seemed to be waiting for the favorites in the Meadowlands Cup tonight to dash past. As expected, Include and Broken Vow turned on the speed as the race moved around the final turn and into the stretch.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY/THE FEAR ECONOMY
description: The terrorist attacks did not threaten American business so much as their timing did. Even before Sept. 11, there were global signs that the old fixes were not working. A report by Paul Krugman in The Times Magazine.

title: Violence Flares on Intifada Anniversary
description: Some 80 Palestinians were wounded today, most of them by bullets, as Israeli troops opened fire on Palestinians demonstrating, throwing stones and, at times, shooting on the first anniversary of their renewed intifada, or uprising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMGARDEN, BERTRAM H.
description: BLOOMGARDEN - Bertram H. Age 87. On Yom Kippur, Thursday, September 27, 2001. Beloved husband, for over 50 years, of the late Clara (Belenky). Survived by his dear wife Ruth (Solomon) and her children. Loving and caring father of David and Lucette Bloomgarden, Judith Bloomgarden and William Keller, Nancy Bloomgarden and William Bronner. Devoted grandfather of Seth, Marc and Eron Bloomgarden, Belle Keller, and Gregory and Caitlin Bronner. Graduate of NYU School of Commerce and Finance. He was a man of great integrity and intellect. Longtime resident of Great Neck, NY, and Royal Palm Beach, FL. Retired past President of Belenky Brothers Jewelers, and well respected in his field. His loving family will always miss him. Service Sunday, 2:15 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations in his memory to the Red Cross for the benefit of the victims of the World Trade Center tragedy or to the charity of your choice.

title: Pakistanis Fail in Last-Ditch Bid to Persuade Taliban to Turn Over bin Laden
description: A last-ditch effort by Pakistan to persuade Afghanistan's ruling Taliban to hand over Osama bin Laden failed today when a group of militant Islamic clerics flew back to Pakistan and reported that the Taliban's leader had dismissed any possibility of a handover.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ban On Diesel Fuel Postponed
description: The Supreme Court extended until Oct. 18 a deadline for thousands of Delhi buses to switch from diesel fuel to a cleaner form, compressed natural gas. The deadline had been Sunday. Most of the bus fleet is still running on diesel, despite a three-year-old court order to switch to gas. The judges asked authorities in Delhi, with some of the worst pollution anywhere, to return with a detailed new plan for the conversion. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: A War on a Small Scale, Possibly Long and Risky
description: The Bush administration is putting aside the American military's longstanding insistence on using overwhelming force to vanquish its enemy. Instead, Pentagon planners are now focusing on commando raids and limited air strikes to root out Osama bin Laden's terrorist network in Afghanistan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: London: Spy Loses Appeal
description: The Court of Appeal rejected arguments by David Shayler, a maverick British spy, that he should be permitted to reveal state secrets in the public interest. Mr. Shayler's lawyers rejected the ruling and said they would take their case to the House of Lords, the highest judicial body. The lawyers argued that a denial of his argument would constitute a breach of his human rights. Mr. Shayler will go on trial in November on charges of breaking the Official Secrets Act by writing articles in 1997 about Britain's internal security service, MI5. He has pleaded not guilty. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Clark T. Rogerson, Expert On Fungi, Is Dead at 82
description: Clark T. Rogerson, whose fascination with the microscopic world of fungi brought tens of thousands of specimens to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, died on Sept. 7 in Ogden, Utah, where he moved after he retired. He was 82.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MDU RESOURCES GROUP INC., Bismarck, N.D., a distributor of natural gas in North and South Dakota, said it had acquired Bell Communications Inc. and Bell Electrical Contractors Inc., two closely held electrical and communications contractors in St. Louis, to expand in Missouri. Terms were not disclosed.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Justice To Retire
description: Justice Fred L. Banks Jr., the only black on the nine-member State Supreme Court, will resign from the bench on Oct. 31 to join a private law firm in Jackson. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove will appoint a replacement who would face election in November 2002 for the remaining two years in the term.

title: City to Sell Debt as It Waits For Promised Federal Billions
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said it could take a year to clear the site of the World Trade Center, the city prepared yesterday to sell $1 billion of debt on Tuesday to tide it over until the promised federal aid for the cleanup materializes.

title: At Home Files for Bankruptcy; Will Sell a Unit
description: The At Home Corporation, a once-mighty Internet portal turned high-speed access provider, filed for bankruptcy protection today, a victim of shrinking online advertising revenue and the collapse of the dot-com bubble.

title: Luxury Groups Battle a Wave of Counterfeit Goods
description: MILAN  When it was discovered in late summer that someone had broken into the Florence headquarters of the Ferragamo luxury goods group, investigators were initially at a loss to explain the purpose of the burglary.

title: The Long View From the End of Life
description: Old age doesn't automatically confer wisdom and artistic profundity. But when it does, as in the case of the Portuguese-born, Paris-based director Manoel de Oliveira, who is still making movies at 92, what can emerge is a remarkable mixture of appreciation and sadness, colored with an implacable, clear-eyed awareness of looming extinction. ''I'm Going Home,'' the director's newest film, isn't the first one in which he has gracefully taken the long view from the far end of life.

title: Going From Divine Love To the Secular Variety
description: Through nearly 10 years of sustained success, Anonymous 4 has concentrated on sacred music from the Middle Ages. No longer. The four singers' new concert program, which they gave on Sunday afternoon in ''Music Before 1800'' at Corpus Christi Church, was devoted to love songs by the 14th-century Florentine master Francesco Landini -- works they also sing on their latest album.

title: Helping Farmers Help Nature
description: With timely help from an unexpected source -- the Bush administration -- Americans who have long wanted to overhaul the government's discriminatory and wasteful farm programs suddenly have a fighting chance to succeed. In what is shaping up to be the first big legislative struggle since before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the House is expected next week to take up a $171 billion, 10-year farm bill. title: The Way We Live Now: 9-30-01: Close Reading: Elements of War; The Roughneck
description: Walk onto any construction site in New York and you'll find five-gallon plastic buckets everywhere. For products like joint compound, paints, glues and lubricants, they're the containers of choice, and when emptied they become the industrial equivalent of a pointed stick, the most basic tool there is. By the night of that dreadful Tuesday, rescue workers had created bucket brigades to pass debris from the edges of the destruction, one line to pass the filled buckets out, another line to pass the empties back in. This is a kind of work as basic as the five-gallon plastic bucket itself, all hands, all back, all heart. It's the kind of work most New Yorkers believed no longer mattered in Manhattan.

The only other mechanical-action pipe organ in the state is at the Princeton Theological Seminary. Opus 12, as the organ is known, required more than a year for Richards, Fowkes & Company in Chattanooga, Tenn., to build and cost $396,000. It was built to fit this relatively small church, which has a congregation of about 300, and designs from the interior were incorporated into the cabinet of the organ, said Mark Trautman, the church's organist. Christ Church was founded in 1745 and was the site of the third public reading of the Declaration of Independence. The church's old organ was damaged by lightning in 1995. Karen DeMasters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTS, CHARLES HENRY II.
description: WATTS-Charles Henry II. September 27, 2001; Freedom, NH. Charles H. Watts II of Freedom, New Hampshire and Boston, Massachusetts, died unexpectedly of a heart attack yesterday at his farm in New Hampshire. He was the beloved husband of Patricia McQuillen Watts. Born in 1926 in Bronxville, New York, Mr. Watts was the only child of Charles H. and Mabel L. Watts. He married Patricia Dorothy McQuillen, also of Bronxville, in 1951. After completing his Ph.D. in American Literature at Brown University in 1953, he became an Assistant Professor of English at Brown and was later named Dean of the College. In 1963, at the age of 37, he was named President of Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pennsylvania, where he served for twelve years, leading the school through an important period of change and growth. Following his time at Bucknell, Mr. Watts returned to Brown University to help launch a major capital campaign. He then joined Beneficial Financial Corporation (later acquired by Household Finance) in the position of General Director. Mr. Watts, whose father, Charles H. Watts, was one of Beneficial's original founders, was also a member of the Beneficial Board from 1959 until 1998. He received honorary degrees from Franklin College (D.Lit., 1965), Dickenson School of Law (L.L.D., 1968), Alderson Broaddus College (H.H.D., 1969), Brown University (L.L.D., 1975), and Bucknell University (L.H.D., 1979). Throughout his career, Mr. Watts served on numerous academic, corporate and civic boards. He was a member of the board of the Riverdale School (1959-1974), Bucknell University (1964-1976), the Peddie School (1971-1985), and St. John's College (1976-present). He was also an active board member of the John Carter Brown Library at Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island. In addition to the library, he was deeply committed to Trinity Church, in Boston, and the Society for the Preservation of New Hampshire Forests in Concord, New Hampshire. Mr. Watts was an avid conservationist throughout his life and worked with both the Audubon and New Hampshire Forest societies to preserve the natural environment in New Hampshire. Mr. Watts and his wife opened High Meadow Farms, in Freedom, New Hampshire, in the mid-fifties with the late Percy Taylor, also of Freedom. The farm, which operated commercially for nearly forty years, sold eggs, apples, wood and hay. Mr. Watts is survived by his wife, Patricia, and their three children: Katharine L. Watts and her son Cooper; Caroline W. Collins and her husband Peter and their children Dylan and Abigail; Charles H. Watts III and his wife Holly and their children Samuel, Isabel, and Isaac. Services will be held at Trinity Church, in Boston, on Wednesday, October 3, 2001, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, offerings will be gratefully accepted by Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston, MA 02116; or by the John Carter Brown Library, Brown University, Providence, RI 02906.

Two horses from Britain competing in marathon grass races loped early under dawdling fractions and then charged home for the wire to win.

title: Theater; Performers and Audience Join Hearts
description: TWO nights after Sept. 11 and the terrorist attacks, Broadway reopened, and I returned to the theater to put my fears on hold, suit up in sequins and sing and dance the classic American backstage musical ''42nd Street.'' I was worried that it was too soon and too disrespectful to go back to work. Not to mention that I was still scared of the city and unsure about what was going on. How could I smile at a time like this?

title: Elizabeth Falk, Martin Piecuch
description: ''We married the same way we met: on the stage,'' Martin Piecuch said of his marriage to Elizabeth Falk, which took place yesterday during a musical performance at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

title: From the Sub Base to Airports, Security Has Tightened
description: FOR more than 10 years the Submarine Force Library and Museum has annually played host to about 300,000 visitors, who can tour the Nautilus moored outside or see exhibits on submarine warfare inside.

title: Music; A Master Of X-Rated Hip-Hop
description: FORGET Eminem. The most foulmouthed master of skewed comedy in hip-hop is Kool Keith, a man of a thousand cartoonlike alter egos and endless bizarre, pornographic raps. In an uncommonly long and productive career in rap, he has appeared as Dr. Octagon, a villainous gynecologist; Black Elvis, an alien ''rock star'' in a stiff plastic wig; Dr. Dooom, the murderer of Dr. Octagon; Rhythm X, Mr. Gerbick, Keith Korg, Robbie Analog, the mysteriously pedestrian Matthew and, strangest of all, himself.

description: Shauna Beth Bavar, the daughter of Ann Bavar and Dr. Trevor Bavar of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Douglas Salmon, a son of Maria Di Dia Salmon and Douglas Salmon of Leonia, N.J. Cantor Helene Reps officiated at Reid Castle on the Manhattanville College campus in Purchase, N.Y.

description: A Scarsdale-based Web site that provides listings of part-time and temporary jobs is offering free postings to businesses in an effort to help families affected by the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Travel Advisory: Hotel; A Star Checks In
description: This is not a hotel suite for those with stage fright. The Serrano Hotel, at 405 Taylor Street in San Francisco's Theater District, this month opened a suite dedicated to the American Conservatory Theater, decorated with memorabilia from the company's 35-year history in the city. Other touches include a bedroom designed to look like a stage, with the bed facing walls resembling the auditorium as seen from the stage, a proscenium, and theatrical lighting and curtains. The A.C.T. Suite costs $329 to $429 a night, plus tax. Information: (415) 885-2500 or www.serranohotel.com.

title: When Only a Burger Will Do
description: Anyone whose mom worked wonders on ground beef with grated cheese and Lipton Cup-a-Soup knows that stuffed burgers are the ultimate twist on American comfort food. Lately, very fancy versions have been warming the stomachs of many an apprehensive New Yorker. The reigning champion, from DB Bistro Moderne, is stuffed with foie gras, black truffles, root vegetables and wine-braised beef ($26). ''It's been much more popular in recent weeks,'' said its creator, the chef Daniel Boulud, explaining that it helped people ''reconnect with their pasts.'' At Slate Restaurant Bar and Billiards, burgers packed with blue cheese, mushrooms and peppers ($11) have been flying off the grill. ''People want simpler, more comforting foods right now,'' said Aaron Bashy, consulting chef.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Sunday with an article about mixed feelings in the Islamic world toward the United States misidentifed people who had gathered near a Kentucky Fried Chicken advertisement in Islamabad, Pakistan. They were bystanders who were watching, not the protesters who were gathering.

title: For Haunted Survivors, the Towers Fall Again and Again
description: Inez Graham is at war with her memory. She spends most of her days sobbing and afraid, battling images of flames and falling debris and trying to quell the soundtrack of screams in her head. A ringing phone, a plane overhead or a passing truck make her hunker down in fear. She refuses to go outside. She tells friends not to visit and says the smell of smoke, like some unseen phantom, lingers around her home in Newark.

title: China's About-Face: Support for U.S. on Terror
description: Despite a history of condemning American incursions abroad and a chronic fear of encirclement by the West, the Chinese government has expressed strong support for the new American war on terrorism. It even seems to accept the idea of limited American military strikes in China's own neighborhood.

title: Next Year's Garden: Visions of Perfection
description: ICELEBRATED the autumnal equinox with friends who have an old log house overlooking a pond. Elizabeth had picked slender pods of okra from her garden, and made a spicy Indian dish with lentils and mangos.

In her 98th year, loving wife of the late Harold, devoted mother of Sue and Win Robins, James and Eve Starkman, grandmother of Frannie and Jackie, Hannah and Billy, Amy and Wendy, and seven greatgrandchildren, sister of Edward Levy, Miriam Horowitz and the late Sally, Morrie, Fan, Hannah and Marcy. Services at Plaza Memorial, 10 AM, Sunday September 30, 91st St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIEB, YOLAND J.
description: GRIEB-Yoland J., 45-year resident of Northport, on September 28, 2001, in her 87th year. Longtime member of Catholic Daughters and The Rosary Society. Enjoyed gardening, bowling and traveling. She visited all 50 states. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Marie Edison, Caroline Schlegel, Christopher, and Virginia Acker. Devoted grandmother of nine. Dear sister of Stewart Walker, Yvonne Vekasy, and Yvette Meehan. Reposing at Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Ave, Northport, NY. Donations to American Diabetes Association or The Arthritis Foundation in her memory appreciated.

title: Music; Call Her a Musician, Pure and Simple
description: THE teenage trauma of adapting to eyeglasses, of fending off primitive insults like ''four eyes,'' remains but a dim memory. Few seem to care or even notice that someone deep into middle age wears glasses. So when an interviewee -- an impeccably well-mannered one, at that -- calls you a ''blind writer,'' it comes as a jolt.

title: Vaccine Supplies May Be Needed
description: A STATE health official said last week that the terrorist attacks should not make the shortage of the tetanus vaccine, which has been affecting the nation, any worse in Connecticut, but said the state has been put on call by the federal C.D.C. that it might have to send vaccine to New York for victims or rescue workers injured in the recovery.

title: Princeton's Splithoff Is Too Much for Columbia
description: Princeton quarterback David Splithoff accounted for four touchdowns and linebacker Chris Roser-Jones intercepted two passes, returning one for a score, as the Tigers thumped Columbia, 44-11, tonight at Princeton Stadium in the Ivy League opener for both teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORAN, HAROLD A.
description: HORAN-Harold A. Age 91. Of Woodbury, CT formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Died Sunday, September 23, 2001. He was the husband of the late Helen M. Horan for 67 years. Born March 27, 1910. Son of Henry F. and Marion E. Horan. Beloved father of Robert A. of Woodbury, CT. and Richard A. of Indianapolis, IN. Grandfather of Thomas C. and Gregory M. He was predeceased by his son, Harold F. Horan. He was a graduate of Columbia University and New York University Graduate School. He was Emeritus Professor of Chemistry at St. John's University in Queens, NY where he served from 1930 to 1975. A Mass of Christian Burial was held September 28 at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Washington, CT. Burial was in the North Cemetery in Woodbury, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MARSHA
description: SMITH-Marsha. 88, on September 28, 2001. Loving mother of Judy Smith, brother of William Rosman, grandmother of Matthew SmithBurlage, wife of the late Alex Smith, friend to many. She and her stories will be in our hearts forever. Services at Sigmund Schwartz Funeral Home, 182 2nd Avenue, at 9:30 AM, Sunday.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-30-01: The ethicist; Gun Play
description: Where we live, hunting is common. When our two school-age children are invited to a friend's home, we tell those parents that because a relative of ours was injured in a gun accident, we do not allow our children to be in homes where guns are kept and then ask if they keep guns. We are polite, but play on their sympathy. Our problem: the story is a lie -- no such relative, no such accident. But asking straight out is not as likely to net us the truth. Are we justified in lying? Anonymous, Ohio

title: Private Sector; Celebrating a Shave, Quietly
description: King Camp Gillette had two big ideas. The first, which he laid out in a book published in 1894, was for a giant publicly owned corporation that would replace government and allow people to live a life devoted to the arts. The second was for an inexpensive and disposable razor blade. The second idea was much better.

description: TWO years ago I was invited to be the artistic director of the 2002 Adelaide Festival of Arts, the oldest and most adventurous of the major Australian festivals, so I moved here and have spent the first two years of the new millennium on the other side of the planet.

description: Asked by President Bush to choose sides in the war on terrorism, most of the world has chosen to side with the West, but not without adding the kind of caveats bound to create fault lines in an American-led coalition.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-30-01: On Language; Words At War
description: 'You are about to embark upon a great crusade,'' General Eisenhower told his troops on the eve of D-Day; he later titled his memoirs ''Crusade in Europe.'' American presidents liked that word: Thomas Jefferson launched ''a crusade against ignorance,'' Theodore Roosevelt exhorted compatriots to ''spend and be spent in an endless crusade'' and F.D.R., calling for a ''new deal'' in his acceptance speech at the 1932 Democratic convention, issued ''a call to arms,'' a ''crusade to restore America to its own people.''

title: Reckonings; The Hitchhiker Syndrome
description: They started arriving literally before the dust had settled. The Washington Post dubbed them ''hitchhikers'' -- people who want to use the patriotic bandwagon as a vehicle for their favorite policy proposals. To its credit, the Bush administration has for the most part been cautious about letting the hitchhikers on board. But will that restraint last?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORD, MONTGOMERY MCCULLOUGH ''MONTE''
description: HORD-Montgomery McCullough ''Monte'' 46, of Pelham, New York, a Vice President and Partner of Cantor Fitzgerald, died at the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001. Born in Grand Island Nebraska on August 24, 1955 to the late Thomas and Gloria Hord, he grew up in Central City, Nebraska and graduated from the University of Nebraska. Monte began his business career in Chicago at the Chicago Board of Options Exchange in the late 1970's. He worked at the Board until he and his wife, Lisa Sharp Hord, moved to New York in 1992 to work with Nomura Securities. Monte was committed to enhancing the quality of life in his community and volunteered many hours in support of those causes. He was a man of great integrity and kindness. Monte will be forever missed. Monte was a loving husband to his wife Lisa and devoted father to his three young children Molly, Sophie and Jackson. He is also survived by his sisters, Sara Beck of Lincoln, Nebraska and Debra Taylor of Colorado Springs, Colorado, and his brothers, Dan Hord of Wilmette, Illinois and Stacy Hord of Biloxi, Mississippi, and his two aunts Gerdi Heath and Marlene Otte. A memorial service is planned for Friday, October 5th at 2:00 p.m. at Christ the Redeemer Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, New York. Donations can be made to the Montgomery Hord Children's Fund c/o Ms. Kimberly Sharp, 19 Oxford Road, Pittsburgh, PA 15202.

In the first hours after the attacks, they agonized over whether to race back to New York, postponing the wedding.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-30-01: Close Reading: Elements of War; The Unscathed
description: At 10:30 on the morning of Sept. 11, my voice mail recorded an anxious phone message -- an ex-girlfriend of a decade ago calling from upstate to see if I was O.K. Other messages and e-mail arrived over the next few hours. Two came from old college pals I have barely seen in a decade. One came from a guy whose parents live next door to mine in Buffalo. By early afternoon, that ex-girlfriend had even called my mother.

title: Travel Advisory: Hotel; Canine Room Service
description: Any dog owners who have been cooped up in a tiny hotel room have some idea of how their pet feels when staying at a kennel. The Muse, a 200-room hotel at 130 West 46th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, offers some relief with a Pooch Package that includes a basket of dog treats, food and water bowls waiting in the room upon arrival, a dog-walking service and one room-service meal for the pet. Grooming is available for an extra charge. The rates are $265 weeknights and $195 weekends, plus taxes and tips, based on single or double human occupancy (and no limit -- within reason -- on dogs). Information: (877) 692-6873 or www.themusehotel.com.

title: Art/Architecture; A Master Craftsman For America
description: DECADES before the Revolutionary War began in 1775, both Tories and Whigs helped make the silver workshop of Myer Myers the busiest place for status-symbol shopping in Lower Manhattan. Myers, the leading silversmith in New York in the late Colonial period, lived and worked in a house at the center of the city's business district, on King Street, now called Pine, one block north of Wall Street and about six blocks south of where the World Trade Center towers stood.

title: Colors

The same style was observed at other evening events last week, which included the opening of Dance Theater of Harlem and the New York Botanical Garden's annual Rose Garden dinner-dance, both on Tuesday.

title: Teachers Who Mattered
description: Whether you are 9 or 90, there's a good chance there has been an unforgettable teacher in your life. Maybe it was the third-grade teacher who demystified the multiplication tables or the professor who taught you comparative literature. Maybe it was your dad, who made sure you knew how to drive a stick shift. Maybe it was the physical therapist who literally helped you get back on your feet.

title: Sales Drop and Spending Waits as Uncertainty Grips Economy
description: In the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, sales are falling in nearly every sector of the economy -- from autos and home building to high technology and department stores -- as gloom spreads beyond the airline and travel industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, TIMOTHY E.
description: REILLY-Timothy E. A victim of the World Trade Center tragedy, 40, of Brooklyn, NY, formerly of Larchmont, NY, died September 11, 2001. Tim was born on October 5, 1960 in Bronxville, NY to Charles J. Reilly and Claire Hughes Reilly. He attended Holy Family Grammar School and Iona Prepartory School both of New Rochelle, NY. Tim graduated from Stonehill College in Easton, Massachusetts in 1982. He was a co-captain of his college tennis team. Mr. Reilly began his career in the insurance business with the New York-based independent insurance adjustment firm Edward R. Reilly Company, Inc., a firm founded by his grandfather in 1934. At the time of his death, he was a Vice President in the National Property Loss Department of Marsh USA, a unit of Marsh & McLennan Companies. An avid golfer and tennis player, Mr. Reilly was a member of the Knights of Columbus, the insurance fraternal order, the Loyal Order of the Blue Goose, and was a parishioner at the Church of the Assumption in Brooklyn Heights, NY. He was a 20 year resident of Brooklyn Heights. He is survived by his mother Claire Reilly Walcovy and step-father Robert O. Walcovy of Larchmont, NY, brothers Charles J. Reilly Jr. also of Larchmont and Brendan H. Reilly of Essex, Massachusetts, sisters Kathleen E. Reilly of North Salem, NY, Erin M. Weincek of Louisville, CO, and Maureen L. Reilly of Brooklyn, NY. Visiting hours will be held on Thursday, October 4, 2001 at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY (914). 834-0144 from 2-4 p.m. and 7-9 p.m. A memorial service will be held at 11 a.m. on Friday, October 5, 2001 at Saints John and Paul Roman Catholic Church at 280 Weaver Street, Larchmont, NY (914) 834-5458. In lieu of flowers, the family would like donations to be made to The Holy Rosary School Fund, PO Box 463, North Salem, NY 10560.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONOWITZ, LYDIA
description: ARONOWITZ-Lydia. 80, passed away on September 29, 2001. Who brought joy to so many lives, both young and old. Those who knew her for merely hours or a lifetime were always drawn to her love of life, warmth, spirit and sense of humor. She had friends all over the world. Her kindness, generosity, strength, dignity, love of learning, enthusiasm, sense of fun and laughter, curiosity and sparkle were an inspiration to all who knew her. Her love, joy and devotion to her children, grandchildren, in-laws, nieces and nephews, relatives, friends and neighbors were legend. She was the devoted and everloving wife of the deceased George Aronowitz. Loving mother of Merrill Stone and Stephen Aronowitz. Devoted mother-in-law of Andrew Stone and Julie Aronowitz. Adoring grandmother of Adam and Todd Stone and Jordan Aronowitz. She was an active member of Womens American ORT in Lake Success, NY, and the Great Neck Chapter of B'nai Brith. She was a member and resident of the Fountains Country Club in Lake Worth, FL. Beloved member of the Pelham NY Community. She was a graduate of City College of New York. Services Monday, 9 A.M. at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contribitions may be made in her name to Women's Amerian ORT. She will live in our hearts forever.

title: GIBSON FRAUD TRIAL BEGINS
description: The trial of former Newark Mayor Kenneth Gibson and two associates, who are charged with defrauding the Irvington Board of Education of more than $1 million in connection with the construction of a middle school and renovations on two other Irvington schools, began last week in federal district court in Newark. Mr. Gibson, 69, who was mayor of Newark from 1970 through 1986, was the owner of an engineering firm that served as construction manager for work on the schools between 1991 and 1995. In addition to Mr. Gibson, Camille Savoca, 54, vice president of the firm, and William Bernowich, 54, an employee, are charged in the 18-count federal indictment with being involved in the scheme. Karen DeMasters

title: Islam and the Opposition to Terrorism
description: Last week, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei of Iran, one of the most conservative and anti-American Muslim clerical leaders, called the fight against terrorism a ''holy war.'' He joins a host of learned Muslims who have loudly condemned terrorism as forbidden in Islamic law in the wake of the attacks on Sept. 11. Last May, the grand mufti of Saudi Arabia and the highest authority on Islamic law in that country, Abdul Aziz bin Abdallah Al al-Shaykh, stated publicly that those who kill themselves in attacks do not, as they might imagine, die as martyrs but as suicides, suicide being unequivocally forbidden in Islamic law.

title: Temporal Vertigo
description: I got my last haircut in Kabul, but Sept. 11 found me standing on John Street in lower Manhattan with about 20 volunteer rescue workers, amid masses of scorched paper and debris, watching fires burn near where the World Trade Center used to be. A recently returned humanitarian aid worker, I had rushed downtown when the towers collapsed. Brushing dust and ash out of my hair -- still short from my haircut -- I felt the low-level shock that came often in Afghanistan, the kind of shock I felt when I saw dead bodies, starving children, Taliban enemies hung from lampposts by cable. I marveled at the fact that I was feeling this familiar emotion in the financial district of Manhattan, an unusual place to be in shock. For a moment I felt that I had somehow not escaped Afghanistan, that I had brought its disaster home with me to New York.

title: Theater; Uncovering the Humanity In Rootlessness and Race
description: THE opening night of ''Cloudstreet'' in Sydney in January 1998 is already part of Australian folklore. If anyone had suggested at the end of the first act that Justin Monjo and Nick Enright's five-hour adaptation of Tim Winton's novel would triumph in Melbourne, Zurich, Dublin, the London fringe and at the Royal National Theater in London, he would have been clapped into a straitjacket. If anyone had forecast that Neil Armfield's production would land at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where it opens at the Harvey Theater on Tuesday, the kickoff event of BAM's monthlong Next Wave Down Under festival of Australian arts, he would have been shoved into a padded cell. At that point, the play's creators were in near despair.

title: 'Peter Taylor'
description: wedding of wide social interest throughout the state," the Nashville Tennessean called the marriage in Washington on January 8, 1908, of Miss Katherine Baird Taylor, daughter of Tennessee Senator Robert Love Taylor, to Matthew Hillsman Taylor, a promising young lawyer of Trenton. Nine years later to the day, the union would produce their fourth child and second son. Named after his father, but always called "Pete," the son would take the name Peter Taylor only years later. In retrospect it seems that the union provided the perfect background for a writer, tying him so closely to the matrix of a culture, the "long green hinterland that is Tennessee," as he spoke of it. A perfect background, of course, if one had the sensibility and the talent to know how to use it.

title: Texts for Our Time

Disaster and terror have reigned there for weeks: hijacked submarines, luxury cruise ships that sink inexplicably, hostages and SWAT teams, natural environments sullied by murder or biological disaster. Serial killers (domestic terrorists of a sort), joined by the homicidal dating prospects of single women and the good husband who is actually a secret criminal.
