title: Shapeliness Got in the Way
description: In 1933, three years before Walker Evans traveled to Alabama with James Agee to document the lives of tenant farmers for Fortune magazine, he went to Cuba on an assignment to illustrate the American journalist Carleton Beals's book ''The Crime of Cuba.'' Andrei Codrescu speculates in his essay in WALKER EVANS: CUBA (Getty Publications, $24.95) that Evans's publishers may have been disappointed with the pictures he submitted. Beals wrote a fervent expos of American complicity with the practices of the oppressive Machado regime; Evans captured more of the formal beauty of Havana. ''He tried to photograph misery, but shapeliness got in the way,'' Codrescu writes. Indeed, Evans's pictures are lyrical observations of Havana's streets and people: the cinema with posters advertising American movies, a crowd assembled on the steps of the Capitol, a barbershop, women and children in doorways, a shrine to the Virgin Mary. His images of prostitutes, the homeless, children and workers show the despair of unemployment and destitution, but Evans framed them within a ''cornucopia of formal elements,'' Codrescu remarks. ''Cuba's streets, buildings, slums, peddlers and beggars,'' he writes, ''were almost irresistibly photogenic.'' Evans's later, more celebrated photographs that appeared in ''American Photographs'' and ''Let Us Now Praise Famous Men'' benefited from this trip to Cuba. In these striking pictures of Havana we see the emergence of Evans's style -- unpretentious, precise and poignant. Sarah Shatz

title: Perspective; A Big Day in Baseball History
description: When Cal Ripken - who broke Lou Gehrig's record of 2,130 consecutive games played - announced he would retire, the 40-year-old third baseman did so at a news conference on June 19, which would have been Gehrig's 98th brithday. Ripken had played in 2,632 games in a row, from May 30, 1982, to Sept. 20, 1998, when he voluntarily ended his streak against the Yankees, Gehrig's former team. Today, Ripken plays for the final time at Yankee Stadium. Here are other great moments from this day in history that linger in the memory and the lore of New York baseball aficionados.

title: At a University That's Flush, No One Anted Up
description: It isn't often that upperclassmen at Princeton University are at a loss for words. Nor is it any more frequent that alumni are at a loss for money.

title: Keeper Of the Flame
description: Your writer describes Doba Levin's 19 years of pregnancy, childbearing and breast feeding as actions that divest her of ''autonomy.'' A superficial definition of the word would support this. As the mother of 14 children and a spiritual guide to many more, Levin is not independent in the sense that she is free to schedule her days as she chooses. But in terms of moral independence, she is powerful indeed.

title: San Francisco Journal; Bonds Delivers for a City in Search of Cheer
description: The fans know that these are not just games anymore.

title: Contrarians Have a Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Unforgettable Teachers
description: Whether you are 9 or 90, there's a good chance there has been an unforgettable teacher in your life. Maybe it was the third-grade teacher who demystified the multiplication tables, or the professor who taught you comparative literature. Maybe it was your dad, who made sure you knew how to drive a stick shift, or the physical therapist who literally helped you get back on your feet.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-28

title: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; Security Is Tightened At Canada's Airports
description: WITHIN days of the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, air travel in Canada changed significantly, as tighter security was imposed at airports once known for relatively uncrowded check-in halls and quiet efficiency. Although flights within Canada were back to 80 percent or more of regular levels within a week of the terrorist hijackings in the United States, passengers were meeting long delays and choked airport departure areas. More Americans visit Canada than any other country but Mexico, with 4,367,890 arriving in Canada by air in 2000.

title: Sept. 23-29; A Glimmer of Hope
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Shimon Peres, the Israeli foreign minister, met this week in the Gaza Strip and pledged ''maximum efforts'' to sustain a cease-fire. But their meeting was preceded by a bomb attack that injured three Israeli soldiers near a Gaza refugee camp, , and the next morning an Israeli raid on the camp killed three Palestinians.

title: 'SNL' Debuts With Tribute
description: In a decidedly solemn opening to ''Saturday Night Live,'' last night, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani paid tribute to the city's emergency workers and those killed on Sept. 11, saying ''our heroes met the worst of humanity with the best of humanity.''

title: Women looking At Women
description: As a 16-year-old girl, I read your magazine on women with great interest and from cover to cover. I want to thank you for an issue that made me think about what I want to do with my life. Articles about the C.E.O., the stay-at-home mom, the law associates -- all were thought provoking. Whatever I decide I want to be doing in 10 years, you covered it. I will keep your magazine for a long time.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture on Page 24 of Arts & Leisure today showing a city of the future as envisioned in Fritz Lang's 1927 film "Metropolis" is printed in mirror image in some copies. The word "Eranot" should appear on the facade of a building at the right.

title: A Kinder, Safer Workplace
description: What changes are most likely to occur in the workplace because of Sept. 11? The Society for Human Resource Management posed that question to 5,673 human resources professionals a week after the terrorist attacks.

title: Sports of The Times; Warlike Hyperbole, but Peaceful Ending
description: IT was during a midweek gathering in a corner of Madison Square Garden far from the arena's boxing ring that the father and guiding spirit of the Puerto Rican icon, the man known in the trade as Papa Trinidad, addressed his son's sycophantic support group.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Authentic Responses
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheaper Chic
description: Marc Jacobs keeps a lot of balls in the air, but his lower-priced Marc line really shows his stuff. From left: Cotton T-shirt, $95, shirt jacket, $178, and pants, $138; silk blouse, $148, and denim skirt, $128. At Marc Jacobs, 403 Bleecker Street. Blouse at Scoop, 532 Broadway. Skirt at Bloomingdale's. Hair: Michio for Frame. Makeup: Alexsandra Byrne for MacPro Cosmetics. Models: August Kochanowski and Coreen McGiven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNESEY, REV. JAMES JOHN, S.J.
description: HENNESEY-Rev. James John, S.J. Beloved brother of Eileen Cameron and Mary Ellen. Reposing in the Jesuit Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Rd. on Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-5pm. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday at the Fordham University Church at 7:30. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc. Directors 718-654-0500

title: In Terror's Aftermath
description: The economic impact of the World Trade Center attack has been deeply felt in the city's restaurant industry. Tourism is down and many New Yorkers have been too upset to dine out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOSIN, GERTRUDE (LIPPMAN)
description: BOOSIN - Gertrude (Lippman). Loving wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Lois Harris (Dr. Irwin), Kenneth (Kathryn), Elaine Feit (Matis). Grandmother of Roger Kahn, Shari Nestler, Douglas Kahn, Dr. Steven Feit, Debra Fein, Dr. Daniel Feit, Jaclyn Feit, Karyn Leit and Gregory Boosin. Great-grandmother of 15. Sister of Helen Felber and the late Leo Lippman.

title: Cuba Libre
description: MONA AND OTHER TALES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, JUDITH (JUDY)
description: GREEN-Judith (Judy). Died at home in New York City on Friday, September 14, after a ten month battle with pancreatic cancer. The beloved mother of Christina Green Gerry and Nicholas William Green. Judy was born and raised in New York City and graduated from Vassar College. Along with her husband, the late William J. Green and their children, she spent twenty years living in Bedford, New York where she was a member of the Waccabuc Country Club. She was the author of several best selling novels as well as a journalist for a number of magazines including Architectural Digest, Tatler, George and Avenue. Her favorite times, however, were spent traveling the world, fishing and antiquing. She will be missed beyond words by the many friends worldwide that she cherished so very dearly. There will be a memorial in December as Christmas was her favorite time of year. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her name to the American Cancer Society.

title: The Big Easy, Child Size
description: PEOPLE who live in New Orleans are accustomed to having house guests. And most visitors are undemanding: grateful for a free room, they come equipped with lists of restaurants and clubs, and quickly head out the door for a meal at Galatoire's, a crawl through funky music halls, a walk in the Garden District.

title: Perspective; Immigrant Dream Disturbed, but Not Defeated
description: A trinket saleswoman from Dakar, Aissetou Ndiaye Lo, brought her 13-year-old son to New York last month to be educated, to become rich and famous and to be safe. Exactly two weeks after they arrived, the American Dream was horrifically jarred. Had she second thoughts? Did she fear for her boy's safety?

title: Helen Harris, Chase van der Rhoer
description: Helen Marie Harris, the daughter of Martha M. Harris of Rego Park, Queens, and the late William A. Harris, was married on Friday to Chase Thomas van der Rhoer, a son of Nancy M. Ermenidis of Severna Park, Md., and James P. van der Rhoer of Kinshasa, Congo. The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, ALLEN L.
description: GRUBER-Allen L. Beloved husband of Harriet. Devoted father of Neal Gruber and Enid Gruber-Anderson. Cherished grandfather of Jared Joseph and Oren Louis Gruber, and Dane Elliot Anderson. Loving brother of Elaine Seligman. Services Monday, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. He was an Air Force veteran of WWII and a mason, and will be deeply missed.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THE AZTEC TREASURE HOUSE

title: Quakers Try To Balance Patriotism And Pacifism
description: LIKE other New Yorkers, the city's small Quaker community reacted to the World Trade Center attack with grief, horror, outrage and fear. But, like other pacifists, they faced an additional challenge: maintaining a strict belief in nonviolence after an act of violence had touched them so directly.

title: Schundler Uses Images of Trade Center Rescue Work in Ad
description: Bret D. Schundler released a new campaign commercial today that shows firefighters and police officers working amid the smoke and debris of the World Trade Center attack site.

title: Frugal Traveler; Tea, Temples and Hot Spots In Old Kyoto
description: NOT long after arriving in Kyoto, I began obsessing about tea and its accessories. Poking around narrow lanes and busy shopping streets, I spotted teacups everywhere.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-30-01: Close Reading: Elements of War; The Grunt
description: It wasn't their regular drinking night, but Army Sgt. Chris Barlow and Specialist Patrick Blevins needed a couple of 12-ounce distractions. They went to Hurricanes, a club off base, and found the bar empty, the pool tables barren. ''Before this, no one ever bought American flags,'' said Barlow, 25, a tank gunner from Carmel, Ind. ''You couldn't even find an American flag to buy. It takes a national disaster for people to be patriotic.'' Sucking down Budweisers and cigarettes, Blevins and Barlow looked less like young soldiers than college boys with a lot on their minds. There was the low pay, the sorry benefits, the military downsizing and now the increasing possibility that their units would be called to fight for a citizenry that barely acknowledged their existence until the attacks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 16 about last words from victims of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 omitted attribution for an account by Daphne Bowers, who recounted her daughter's final telephone call before the World Trade Center collapse. Ms. Bowers made the comments to Reuters; they were later transmitted by Cox News Service.

title: From Waging War To Waging Politics?
description: When Gen. Wesley K. Clark retired from the United States Army last spring after serving as supreme commander of NATO during the Kosovo campaign, he returned to his hometown, Little Rock, Ark., and accepted a banking job with the Stephens Group, one of Arkansas's financial powerhouses.

title: Too Close for Comfort, and Too Far; Miles Away, And Feeling The City's Tug In Its Darkest Hour
description: SOME moved for personal reasons. Others grew tired of city life. But when the twin towers were attacked, former New Yorkers grieved as if they had never left. Their distance also stirred many other emotions, from nostalgia for old haunts to guilt at being absent during the crisis. Many had the impulse to visit, and some are even contemplating a return, even from thousands of miles away.

title: A Hometown Pianist
description: Joseph Kalichstein lives in Maplewood, but there are a lot of places he might be. He spends a good share of time, for instance, at the Kennedy Center, where he is chamber music adviser. He could also be playing the piano on a national or European concert tour with the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, in which Jaime Laredo is the violinist, and Sharon Robinson is the cellist. He might even be on a solo tour.

title: Algerian Accused of Role in U.S. Attacks Was a Mystery to His Neighbors in England
description: Three months before the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, Lotfi Raissi, who the authorities allege was involved in planning the attacks, moved into an apartment here with his wife. They were a mystery to their neighbors in the small complex and to shopkeepers a block away, avoiding all conversation and even eye contact, neighbors said today.

title: Wanted: Teachers Who Mattered
description: Whether you are nine or 90, there is a good chance there has been an unforgettable teacher in your life. Maybe it was the third-grade teacher who demystified the multiplication tables, or the professor who taught you comparative literature.

title: The Way We Live Now: 9-30-01; Recapturing The Flag
description: Sept. 11 made it safe for liberals to be patriots. Among the things destroyed with the twin towers was the notion, held by certain Americans ever since Vietnam, that to be stirred by national identity, carry a flag and feel grateful toward someone in uniform ought to be a source of embarrassment. The force of the blows woke us up to the fact that we are part of a national community. This heightened awareness could be the disaster's greatest legacy, one that liberals should not fear but learn to use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, DAVID MARTIN
description: WEISS-David Martin. FDNY Firefighter David Martin Weiss, 41, of Maybrook, NY, was declared missing on September 11, 2001. Born and raised in Freeport, NY, he joined the Freeport Volunteer Fire Department in 1978 and the Iron Workers Local 580 in New York City. He was appointed to FDNY in 1989 and became a member of Manhattan's elite Rescue Company 1 after receiving the Emily Trevor-Mary B. Warren Medal for a daring rescue attempt of a man in the East River. In addition David was a recipient of various awards including Firefighters Quarterly Man of the Year 1993, Firehouse Magazine Heroism Award and a NYC Transit Award. Survived by his children Michael and Alissa Weiss, his mother Joan Weiss Prowler and step-father Robert Prowler, brother Barry Weiss, sister Michele Little, companion and her children Kathryn Emhardt and first wife and friend Karla Weiss. His father Michael Alan Weiss preceded him in death in 1981. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 30, 1:30 P.M. at Central Synagogue, Lexington and 55th, NY, NY. Donations may be made to Rescue Company 1, 530 W. 43rd St, NY, NY, 10036.

title: Business; A Company Faces a Calamity's Personal Side
description: EDMOND ENGLISH, the president and chief executive of the TJX Companies, has just gone through the worst three weeks of his business life. Another difficult period is just beginning.

title: The Long Way Home; On a return from the Amazon, four flights in two days, much confusion and some graciousness
description: ON Sept. 11, I was staying in an isolated jungle lodge up the River Negro from Manaus, where it flows into the Amazon 900 miles inland, in northwestern Brazil. A group of us -- journalists from the National Press Club in Washington on vacation -- came in from a sweaty three-hour jungle walk, hungry and laughing, to find people clustered around a small TV with fuzzy reception. The sickening footage unfolded over and over with commentary in Portuguese. Some of us cried at the images, but we couldn't decipher the extent of the disaster.

title: Rebecca Brown, David Schroeder
description: Rebecca Anne Brown, who teaches deaf children, and Dr. David Arthur Schroeder, a cardiology fellow, were married yesterday by the Rev. William S. Mitchell, a Disciples of Christ minister, at Stonehedge Gardens, a restaurant in Hood River, Ore.

title: INVESTING WITH/Harold J. Levy And David L. Cohen; First Eagle Fund of America
description: HAROLD J. LEVY and David L. Cohen, managers of the $450 million First Eagle Fund of America, try to use merchant-banking principles to pick investments for their fund.

title: Refugees From Afghanistan Flee Out of Fear and Find Despair
description: Refugees arriving here after arduous journeys from Afghanistan are describing scenes of desperation and fear at home as the threat of American-led military attacks turns their long-running misery into a potential catastrophe.

title: Remains Of the Day
description: Reading the Sept. 23 issue online, I was struck by the words that open the magazine: The Way We Live Now. I had never given them much thought before -- my eyes skipped over them as they might over the salutation of a letter. This morning, however, I had trouble moving past them. And for the first time, I stopped to read those five words again and again, and to consider them.

title: Parish Pulls Together to Mourn Its Own
description: THE day of the terrorist attacks, people began wandering into the Church of St. Michael the Archangel on North Street in Greenwich. No service was scheduled. But that evening, as some arrived weeping, some in stunned silence, the priests began an impromptu mass.

title: Music; A Gossamer Web Of Giddy Vocalism
description: BEL CANTO is an elusive and much-abused term for a style of opera singing that revolves, for lack of a better summary, around principles of vocal intoxication. Put your finger through that gossamer web of sound, and you will find that there isn't anything behind it: streams of voice, pouring down golden across the regular pattern of pat instrumental accompaniments, like brilliant sun falling on wallpaper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, ARTHUR STEPHEN
description: FINKELSTEIN-Arthur Stephen. Age 61, of Port St. Lucie, Florida, formerly of Baldwin, NY. Died suddenly on September 24, 2001. Beloved husband of Arlene Geraldine (nee Goldberg). Devoted father of Curtis (Rosemary), Risa Brandon (Alan) and Eric. Cherished son of Leah and Erik. Proud grandfather of Michael Cohn and Noah J. Fletcher-Finkelstein. Donations to be made to the American Heart and Lung Association. Services will be held at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY, Monday, October 1 at 11AM. Interment to follow at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Killings of 14 Lead Swiss To Reconsider Love of Guns
description: Its reputation as a peaceable country under siege, Switzerland has begun to examine its national love of firearms.

title: Happy Ending, but Rights Issue Casts Shadow on Royal Romance
description: There has been a sigh of relief across the country, above all in Amsterdam, over royal wedding plans, now that a careful diplomatic intervention has paid off.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Madison, Brooklyn; Spacious, Gracious and Close to School
description: JAMES MADISON HIGH SCHOOL was built 75 years ago to serve the growing families of the surrounding area when much of the farmland there was giving way to urbanization. The resulting rectangular blocks would end up almost exclusively residential, some of them featuring the spacious Spanish-style terrace homes for which the area is known.

title: The Nation; Will the Court Reassert National Authority?
description: THE Supreme Court's federalism revolution has been overtaken by events.

title: Finding Time, And Hope, In a Bottle
description: I the Burlington County community of Mount Laurel next weekend, a nice intergenerational tableau will unfold at an old farmstead. It would be a pleasant little story in normal times. Now, in times that are anything but normal, it may well provide a dose of hope, a reaffirmation.

title: From Children, Expressions of Sorrow and Thanks
description: In nearly every school in Westchester, teachers, principals and counselors met with students to try to explain the events of Sept. 11 and offer reassurance and consolation. There were memorials, assemblies and student-sponsored vigils.

title: Q and A
description: King Arthur and Robin Hood

title: Private Sector; Once Forlorn and Forgotten, Now a Lobbyist's Cause
description: Mix a millionaire Chicago options trader with a former United States national security adviser and the exiled king of Afghanistan, and a lobbying force emerges. The Chicago businessman, Joseph J. Ritchie, has been joined by Robert C. McFarlane, who counseled former President Reagan on security issues, to promote Muhammad Zahir Shah, the 86-year-old exiled king.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIGHT, ARTHUR S.
description: LEIGHT-Arthur S., 70 years. Dear brother of Lester. Cherished uncle and great-uncle. Fellow of the Society of Actuaries.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Television/Radio; Fighting to Balance Honor and Profit On the Local News
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Last Tango
description: THE BEAUTY

title: 'Family Business'
description: When Allen began his first term at Columbia University in the Fall 1943, he was precocious intellectually, but, at barely seventeen years of age, he lagged behind his Ivy League classmates in terms of maturity and sophistication. Most of his classmates had come from wealthier families and stronger educational backgrounds. This, however, meant little to Ginsberg, who, after his youth with his mother, had great empathy for the underdog and an attraction for people who were different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMORE, GEORGE GORDON
description: GILMORE-George Gordon. Formerly of Irvington, NY, died Monday, September 24, 2001, at Wesley Health Care Center in Saratoga Springs. He was 87. Born June 28, 1914, in NYC, he was the son of the late George and Freda (Hirt) Gilmore. A graduate of George Washington High School in NYC, Mr. Gilmore attended Fordham University and later transferred to Harvard University where he graduated Magna Cum Laude. He was a teacher for many years, first at the Gow School in South Wales, NY, then in North Hollywood High School for many years. He then moved to Irvington, NY, where he taught at Sleepy Hollow High School, retiring in 1972. Mr. Gilmore enjoyed traveling and writing, and wrote a weekly column for the Washington Star newspaper in Washington, NJ. He especially enjoyed residing in Stowe, VT, every summer for the past four decades. He was predeceased by a brother Francis W. Gilmore. Survivors include a sister-in-law, Irene V. Gilmore of Albany; two nieces, Karen and Paula Gilmore both of Albany; two nephews, Michael Gilmore of Rexford and Steven Gilmore of Albany; a great-niece and several great-nephews. Services will be held at a later date at the convenience of the family. Memorial donations may be made to the American Heart Association, North Eastern NY area, 440 New Karner Rd, Albany, NY 12205.

title: Liberties; We Love the Liberties They Hate
description: I have studied the Bushes, father and son, for two decades and I can tell you certain things with absolute certainty.

title: Habitats/Park Avenue and 38th Street; Staying in Her Garden, Not House on Greek Isle
description: AFTER the World Trade Center was attacked, Elaine Moore Hirsch made a plane reservation for Greece, wanting nothing more than to flee the city for her little house in the mountains on the island of Sifnos.

title: A Monument to the Towers of Pain and Might; We Will Recover
description: To the Editor:

title: Firefighter's Daughter's Plea To Redefine the World Hero
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paperback Nonfiction
description: This

title: Footlights; Museum Gets Back to Business
description: Like many of its counterparts in Manhattan, the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers waived its admission fee for several days after the terrorist attacks. Now regular admission fees have resumed, and the museum is asking visitors to contribute to the September 11 Fund in lieu of additional donations to the museum. The fund, established by the United Way and the New York Community Fund, channels money to those directly affected by the Sept. 11 attack.

title: Hernndez, With Tight Elbow, Joins List of Ailing Yankees
description: Clinching the American League East title Tuesday night was supposed to rid the Yankees of their angst. Instead, each day since has brought them a new worry.

title: Gayle Weiswasser, Daniel Feldman
description: Gayle Deborah Weiswasser, the daughter of Sandra Schrut Weiswasser and Stephen A. Weiswasser, both of Washington, was married there last night to Daniel F. Feldman, the son of Dina and Ronald Feldman of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi James Perman officiated at the National Museum of Women in the Arts.

title: SOME EXPERTS SAY U.S. IS VULNERABLE TO A GERM ATTACK
description: The United States is inadequately prepared to confront bioterrorist attacks, according to a broad range of health experts and officials. The nation must develop new vaccines and treatments, they say, but it must also fortify its fragile public health infrastructure, the first line of defense in detecting and containing biological threats.

title: Sept. 23-29; A Sudden Swiss Horror
description: A man armed with an assault rifle and other weapons stormed the regional legislature in Zug, Switzerland, killing 14 people and injuring 15 before shooting himself to death. He was identified as Friedrich Leibacher, 57, who had carried on a two-year dispute with local authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLERMAN, PETER RODNEY
description: KELLERMAN-Peter Rodney, 35. Of New York City and South Egremont, MA on September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center tragedy. Partner of Cantor Fitzgerald. Husband and soulmate of Robi Meltzer Kellerman, devoted son to Joyce Gales and beloved son-inlaw to Jeri and Steven ''Papa'' Meltzer and stepson to Michael Gales. Cherished brother of Elyssa Kellerman and Pamela and George Fox. Uncle Pete was adored by his nephews Max, Aaron, Billy, Matthew, Charlie and Ben. He was the most loving and giving friend. He will live in our hearts forever. A memorial service will be held October 1, 2001 at 11:00 A.M. at The Park Avenue Synagogue on Madison Avenue and 87th Street.

title: Film Series
description: BAM ROSE CINEMAS  Killing the Koala: Australian Films of the 90's. Sat.: Armstrong's "Oscar and Lucinda" (1997) and Woods's "Looking for Alibrandi" (2000). Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Ave., Bklyn. (718-623-2770)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, EDITH (MILLER)
description: LESSER-Edith (Miller) of Washington, DC on Friday September 21, 2001. Loving wife of Arthur. Beloved mother of David and Elisabeth. Devoted grandmother of Jacob, Zachary and Stephen Jackson and dear sister of Dusty Cohn.

title: Sept. 23-29; High Altitude Jitters
description: President Bush last week authorized three mid-level Air Force generals to order hijacked passenger jets that threatened American cities shot down without checking first with him. The authority could be used by the generals, stationed in Florida, Alaska and Hawaii, only if there were not enough time to consult with senior military officials or the president.

title: Showing the Candidate, the Flag and the Rescuers
description: A 30-second television commercial titled ''Leader'' was released Friday by Bret D. Schundler, the Republican candidate for governor of New Jersey and former mayor of Jersey City, in his contest with James E. McGreevey, the Democratic mayor of Woodbridge. It is running at a cost of $200,000 per week, an amount so small as to suggest that few New Jerseyans will see it more than once.

title: Labels of Analyst Varied, But 'Spy' Came as a Surprise
description: A few days after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, Ana Belen Montes, a top Defense Department intelligence analyst, sent an e-mail note to an old friend saying she was all right and had not known anyone who died at the Pentagon.

title: An Economy on the Edge
description: FOR New Jersey, the turn of the new century was rich. Wall Street was riding high, and a good share of its wealth filtered across the Hudson River. Telecommunications and computer companies were expanding, fed by the New Economy investment wave. Developers were building starter mansions and shopping centers on any cornfield they could rezone.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: ONE PALESTINE, COMPLETE: Jews and Arabs Under the British Mandate, by Tom Segev. (Owl/Holt, $18.) Relying on personal histories and anecdotes as well as his own wry insights, Segev (at right), a newspaper journalist, tells the complex story of the period when Britain ruled the Holy Land (1917-48) from all three perspectives: British, Arab and Jewish. His ''enormously important book,'' which was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2000, is ''perhaps the best single account of Palestine under the British mandate,'' Omer Bartov wrote here. Righteous Victims: A History of the Zionist-Arab Conflict, 1881-2001, by Benny Morris (Vintage, $18), is a dispassionate work by an Israeli historian that begins with the arrival of the first Zionists in 1881 and analyzes the misunderstandings and cultural rifts that have plagued both sides ever since. The result is a ''sophisticated and nuanced'' narrative that brings together ''the latest scholarship,'' Ethan Bronner said here in 1999. In Persian Mirrors: The Elusive Face of Iran, by Elaine Sciolino (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14), a senior correspondent for The New York Times who has visited and covered the nation since the 1970's maintains that the influence of the revolutionary mullahs has waned as the population has grown younger. ''Sciolino makes a persuasive case that Iran is one of the few places in the world in which the claims of theocracy and democracy vie with more or less matched force,'' Diane Johnson wrote in these pages last year.

title: Wild Ride With a Cabby Who Is Afraid of Bridges
description: MOST of us think of cabdrivers as a resilient crew. Forced to drive over potholes all day in a battered, foul-smelling car, they see and hear the worst of New York and have learned to navigate through it. Many are immigrants who have endured tragedies in their own countries, and to their luxury-softened customers, they often seem indestructible.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Through the Eyes of Our Children
description: STUDENTS around the state were able to immediately see the World Trade Center disaster on Sept. 11 on televisions in their schools. In some cases, classes all but stopped as children and teachers sat transfixed. Many students almost immediately were also given an outlet to express their feelings about the attacks on paper, in words and in art. Some of the work is sweet, some as harsh as the circumstances. On this page and two others inside are examples of their work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, HENRY
description: SHERMAN-Henry. Loving husband of Ruth. Father of Steve and Jane Sherman, and Phyllis and Allen Goldin. Loving grandfather (Poppy) of Addison and Ashley Sherman. Loving brother of Jack and Evelyn Sherman, and Abe and Roma Roffman.

title: Trying to Find 'Normal' In a Mug of Beer
description: EARLY Friday evening, Kelly McShawe, 23, walked into the Lazy Boy Saloon, which was already filled with people. Even the 20 sidewalk tables were taken, packed with patrons talking animatedly and ordering from the bar's menu of nearly 500 beers.

title: Anna Coatsworth, Jonathan Simon
description: Anna Catherine Coatsworth, the daughter of Patricia and John H. Coatsworth of Cambridge, Mass., was married in New York yesterday to Jonathan Paul Simon, a son of Sybil Kern of Watchung, N.J., and Jay S. Simon of West Orange, N.J. Justice Martin Evans, who is retired from the New York State Supreme Court, officiated at the Metropolitan Club.

title: Atlantic City's Striving Airport Is a Victim
description: Things had been ramping up nicely at Atlantic City Airport. Plans were afoot for more than $20 million in improvements.

title: Escaping Into Reality
description: The 12-year-old skeptic Bastian Bux (played by Mark Rendall, above) learns to dream again, guided by the spirit of his dead mother, in ''Tales From the Neverending Story,'' a Hallmark Channel series to have its premiere on Saturday at noon. Based on the novel by Michael Ende, ''Tales'' turns the pages of a leather-bound book that, once opened, transports Bastian into Fantasia, a magical land holding the solutions to his earthly problems.

title: Private Sector: Once Forlorn and Forgotten, Now a Lobbyist's Cause

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHBURN, GERALDINE KAY
description: FISHBURN-Geraldine Kay. Died Tuesday, September 25, 2001, in Oxford, OH. She was 88. Ms. Fishburn was born July 29, 1913, in NYC to Joseph and Tillye Koerpel. Her career as a professional actress began at the age of 12, when using the stage name Geraldine Kay. She appeared in a Broadway production directed by Guthrie McClintic. After building a successful stage career on the East Coast, she moved to Chicago in 1941, where she married Alan M. Fishburn, a radio writer and director. She received two of Chicago's Joseph Jefferson Awards and was a member of the First Resident Acting Company at the Goodman Theatre. During her career, she appeared with Leslie Howard, Montgomery Clift, Claude Rains, Sidney Greenstreet, Alla Nazimova, Ginger Rogers, Phyllis Diller, Leonard Nemoy, Ray Walston, Gloria Swanson, Eileen Herley, Sandy Dennis and Ray Milland. She served as a Councillor for the Chicago office of Actors' Equity and continued that involvement when she returned to New York in 1979. She is survived by a son, two grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. She will be buried with her parents and sister, Constance Korrel, in New York. Inquiries to Smith & Ogle Funeral Home, 513-523-4411.

title: Great Expectations

To those concerned about balancing a career and a family, I can only say good luck! I graduated from law school in 1982, and my friends and I have been struggling with the family-career issue for almost 20 years. The reality is that when a choice must be made between professional advancement and taking care of the family, many women choose the option that allows them to spend more time with their families. While this is often a fulfilling choice, it is still a difficult one, and it explains in part why so few women make it to the upper echelons of law and business.

''For instance,'' she said, ''I might juxtapose a self-portrait by Van Gogh with a Japanese woodblock of a warrior. The warrior becomes an emblem of the interior struggle of Van Gogh. He's pointing an arrow at Van Gogh's head.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MICHELLE HERMAN
description: GOLDSTEIN-Michelle Herman. ''Fragrant Memory.'' How quickly flowers bloom and die before they get their chance to wollow in the sun and wind and glitter in their dance. Their fragrance shared for time so short though lingering in our minds. Their beauty creating memories of so many a vibrant kind. Michelle, a flower, bloomed for us. She danced the dance of life. She loved, she cared, she brought us joy. To all she brought her light. A more vibrant person few could know, but like flowers she died to soon. A fragrance now within our memories from out of the tower's ruins. So when next you see a flower and enjoy its fragrant bloom remember Michelle Herman Goldstein, our flower who died too soon. The Sherry Family

title: Streetscapes/161 West 93rd Street; A Building That Recalls the Days After Pearl Harbor

A few traces of the aftermath of Pearl Harbor survive in New York, especially in an elegant 1912 building at 161 West 93rd Street that was seized by the federal government during World War II.

title: Art/Architecture; Slowing the World in Order to See It
description: THOMAS EAKINS committed many unnatural acts, and we are about to catch him at it at the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Thursday through Jan. 6). Using only brushes and paint, he turned flat surfaces into luminous deep spaces filled with all kinds of places, people and things. It is the dishonest enterprise of illusion, making something out of nothing. This required intelligence, cunning and a deep sense of craft. The magic of reducing our big, booming three-dimensional world to a small, quiet two-dimensional surface is one of the great enchantments in the history of painting. Very few painters become artists. The American Thomas Eakins is an artist of a very high order.

The referendum in Ventnor, originally scheduled for November, has been postponed because of the Sept. 11 attacks. The referendums in Margate and Longport are not yet scheduled. Robert Strauss

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWN, JOSEPH H.
description: CROWN-Joseph H. A man of great strength, rich talents and devotion to family died at age 93, surrounded by his family, shortly after Yom Kippur in Cuernavaca. His professional career was marked by his passion and dedication to justice and civil liberties, from which he was never deterred by his work in the sophisticated and highly-regarded analysis of taxation issues. His energies were invaluable for the National Lawyers' Guild. His voice was among those that appealed to the President for an end to the arms embargo to Republican Spain. His insight and wisdom were the foundation for the work of the Lawyers' Committee Against the War in Vietnam to which his comprehension of constitutional law was crucial. His continued writing until very recently in both the Mexican and American press gave rational and effective expression to the issues of environmental deterioration. His involvement in current events and his interest in chess continued until his final days. His love and devotion to his family and friends are not diminished by his death.

title: 'War in a Time of Peace'
description: For a brief, glorious, almost Olympian moment it appeared that the presidency itself could serve as the campaign. Rarely had an American president seemed so sure of reelection. In the summer and fall of 1991, George Bush appeared to be politically invincible. His personal approval ratings in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf War had reached 90 percent, unheard of for any sitting president, and even more remarkable for someone like Bush, a competent political insider whose charisma and capacity to inspire had in the past escaped most of his fellow citizens. Of his essential decency and competence there had been little doubt, and the skill with which he had presided over the end of the Cold War had impressed not merely the inner club that monitored foreign policy decision-making, but much of the country as well. With exceptional sensitivity, he had juggled and balanced his own political needs with the greater political needs of his newest partner in this joint endeavor, Mikhail Gorbachev. For Bush was quite aware that Gorbachev's political equation was much more fragile than his own, and he had been careful to be the more generous member of this unlikely two-man team that was negotiating the end of almost forty-five years of terrifying bipolar tensions.

title: 'Venice: Lion City'
description: Wherever you turn, in Venice, lions strut or lurk, colossal or miniature, placid or menacing. Entering the city from the Basin (Bacino) as diplomats did in the Renaissance, you pass between two high columns on the Piazzetta by the Doge's Palace. One is topped, mysteriously, by a man standing on a crocodile that has a dog's head. The other has the city's famous emblem, a bronze lion with its wings spread for takeoff, its paws already dancing on the ground. It may not look so large, up there on its pillar, but it measures fifteen feet from the tip of its muzzle to the end of its tail and five feet from its perch to the small of its back. Viewed from the balcony of the Doge's Palace, or from the ground with opera glasses, it reveals its natty mustache over a leering grin, its opaque white eyes, its intricately curled mane -- not a lion one wants to be on the wrong side of. It has an exotic history. Restorers decided in the 1980s that the bulk of its body is roughly 2,300 years old. The city it guards is a newcomer to this veteran, who has seen empires rise and fall, but has spent his last 850 years at this sentinel post (with only a brief time of Napoleonic captivity in France).

Such are the gougres that the pastry chef Nicole Kaplan pipes out daily at Eleven Madison Park almost in rebuttal to the overly worked, what-the-hell's-in-this, fussy mouth-amusers we can't seem to dodge at just about every restaurant in town. As a nibbly with a drink (in Burgundy, Kir is preferred), they are just about perfect as bar food or as savory bonbons between the ordering ritual and the arrival of the bread, which is when they are served at Eleven Madison Park. Gougres truly appetize, waking up the buds for other taste sensations instead of clobbering them as many starters do. title: Word for Word/Islam's Argument; 'You Expect Us to Help You?': Iran Gets Its Two Cents' Worth
description: EVER since the attacks of Sept. 11, the Bush administration has been exploring whether Iran will be on the American side in its war on terrorism. Iran shares a 560-mile border with Afghanistan and supplies weapons and other support to factions opposed to the de facto Taliban government, and its cooperation in such a coalition could be crucial. So when Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme leader and the most powerful official in the country, delivered a speech on the matter last Thursday, administration officials were listening closely.

title: A Tall Member Of the Family
description: EVERY time I saw the footage of the World Trade Center towers collapsing, my heart sank afresh with them. Not because of the horror I felt over lives taken so brutally. This seemed like melancholia. How could I be mourning the loss of steel towers?

title: Political Briefing; A Different Picture Of a Bush-Gore Race
description: A number of national polls taken since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 show President Bush's job approval rating spiking up 40 points or so, to almost 90 percent.

title: An Act Of Terror Reshapes The Globe
description: EN route to Spain to marry Prince Pedro of Castille in 1348, England's Princess Joan foolishly paused in plague-ridden Bordeaux, fell ill and died, dooming an English-Spanish alliance that could have remade Europe. A Serbian madman murdered an Austrian archduke in 1914, and the echoes of that deed -- World War I, an imperial carving-up of the Middle East, totalitarianism's rise -- still resound nine decades later.

title: Large U.S. Force Is Assembling As Bush Decides How to Strike
description: The United States has now amassed a military force of 28,000 sailors, airmen and troops, more than 300 warplanes and two dozen warships spread for thousands of miles across a military theater with Iraq and Afghanistan at its heart.

title: PRESCHOOL FOR POOR STUDENTS
description: Advocates for poor New Jersey school children and state officials returned to the State Supreme Court again last week. Lawyers for the Newark-based Education Law Center argued that the state Department of Education has failed to live up to a 1998 court ruling ordering state financing of preschools in the state's 30 poorest districts. Deputy Attorney General Nancy Kaplen said preschool enrollment had risen to 28,000 from 6,000 in the districts in three years. But center lawyers countered that there are about 54,000 eligible children and that the state was inadequately financing the programs. Kathleen Cannon

title: Travel Advisory: Museum; A Distillation of Russia
description: It's as much a part of Russian cuisine as caviar, and much cheaper. So no surprise that St. Petersburg has toasted vodka with its own museum. The Russian Vodka Museum, 5 Konnogvardeisky Bulvar, (812) 118-4591, traces the drink's history back 500 years with bottles, handwritten recipes and even a moonshine machine run by monks. Admission is about $1; a tasting of up to seven vodkas, with caviar and pancakes, about $14.

title: Remaking the Military
description: Tomorrow, the Defense Department will formally unveil the long-range planning report Congress requires every four years. Advance accounts suggest that it will reflect some of the new attention directed to homeland defense, fighting terrorism and growing instability in Central Asia. Yet it is already evident that bolder changes will be needed. Military responses to terrorism will bear little resemblance to the cold-war-era conflicts American forces are still being trained and equipped to fight.

title: Keeper Of the Flame
description: I was eager to see how you would present the advances that women have made in religion (Samantha M. Shapiro). It was a surprise to discover that your representative woman was Doba Levin, whose role, important as it may be, is clearly ancillary to that of her husband. In an age when increasing opportunities and status are being accorded to women in a wide variety of faith traditions, it is puzzling that you selected one who has no independent status and whose life seems, in all essential areas, to be distinctly premodern. There are women who serve ably as ministers and priests, as bishops, rabbis and nuns. There are women whose scholarship is broadening our views of our religious traditions. These women did not acquire their roles by marriage, not even a marriage that was granted the imprimatur of her tradition's leader. While Levin's power may be real, her status and independence are clearly circumscribed.

description: A terminal at Logan International Airport was abruptly closed for arriving and departing flights this morning after two passengers entered the terminal through an emergency door, an airport official said.

title: Footlights; Programs of Music and Remembrance
description: There are at least two opportunities today to find shared solace in music. The Westchester Philharmonic, along with student choruses and a men's glee club, will perform from 3 to 6 p.m. in a free program called ''Yonkers Unites: A Service of Healing and Hope.''

title: Small Change, Big Acts of Kindness
description: ON Wednesday, Abraham Shirinzada, an Afghan coffee vendor, stood in the garage on 30th Street in Manhattan where he stores his cart and spoke about the concern his customers have shown after the attacks. Some have overtipped him to make up for the days he didn't work that week. Others have gently asked if his wife and children in New Jersey have been harassed for their nationality, or for being Muslims.

title: Diversify? Yes, It Still Makes Sense
description: AS world economies have become more intertwined in recent years, investors have come to believe that stock markets around the globe move in tandem as well. So many investors have abandoned diversification strategies that involved moving money into foreign markets. Why take the trouble to buy shares in a foreign beverage manufacturer when you can just buy Coca-Cola, which operates around the world?

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: LOVE, laughter and Academy Award-winning acting and writing light the way to choice films this week. Oscars for screenwriting (Horton Foote) and acting (Robert Duvall) capped the Australian director Bruce Beresford's efforts in TENDER MERCIES (1983). In a keenly observed tale played out against a bleak Texas landscape, Mr. Duvall stars as MacSlege, seemingly a down-on-hs-luck alcoholic drifter who offers to pay off a motel debt by working for the lonely owner, Rosa Lee Wadsworth (Tess Harper), a mother widowed by the war in Vietnam. Mac turns out to be a famous country singer, trailing a past that includes his ex-wife (Betty Buckley) and a spoiled, troubled daughter (Ellen Barkin). As Mr. Duvall creates a memorable portrait, the laconic Mac and Rosa Lee find love in an era of fractured relationships and families - Wednesday at 3:45 p.m. on AMC.

title: Michael L. Katzev, 62, Dies; Underwater Archaeologist
description: Michael L. Katzev, an archaeologist who combined luck, scholarship and eight years of meticulous toil to raise, preserve and interpret one of the oldest and most intact seagoing cargo vessels ever discovered, died on Sept. 8 at his home in Southport, Me. He was 62.

title: The Sounds Of Instruments For 43 Tones
description: LONG before recycling became popular, Harry Partch was finding new uses for brass shell casings, nose cones from airplane gas tanks and Pyrex bottles from a radiation laboratory. Partch (1901-74), an experimental American composer who wrote music based on a scale of 43 tones per octave, used these and other found objects to create instruments that would make the sounds he wanted. Over his career, he invented more than two dozen string and percussion instruments, giving them fanciful names like cloud-chamber bowls, spoils of war and harmonic canon.

title: Ideas & Trends; 1984 + 17: Crisis Monitoring
description: WAR changes everything, both on the battlefield and at home. In the past, when war has been declared, American society has been fundamentally reordered for what the government deems is the common good. Voluntary food rationing in World War I, with ''wheatless days'' and ''meatless days,'' evolved into the mandatory rationing of food and shoes during World War II. Civil liberties were rationed, as well, with freedom of speech restricted. Slogans filled the air: ''Loose Lips Sink Ships.''

title: SOAPBOX; Edging Back to a Routine
description: TODAY will be my first time working in Manhattan since the World Trade Center disaster. What should I wear? Black, the ubiquitous New York garment color, seems more appropriate than ever. To add further empathy to my attire, I attach a big silver lily pin to my jacket. I wear flat shoes in case I have to run. I stick a dust mask in my tote bag.

title: Car Sales Drop Sharply In Aftermath of Sept. 11
description: Apparently the last thing people want to do in a time of tragedy and uncertainty is buy a car. Dealers around Westchester say that since Sept. 11, car sales have been down sharply and show no quick sign of improving.

title: Monitor Is Needed On Ground Water Supply
description: As chairman of the Nassau County Water Resources Board, I am writing in response to the Aug. 12 article, ''As Water Use Rises, Keeping an Eye on the Supply.'' On the one hand, the county and the state have regulatory programs in effect to identify and address specific ground-water quality issues. If there is a spill of gasoline, if hazardous waste is found at an abandoned industrial site or if drinking water standards are exceeded at a particular well, an immediate response is forthcoming. One or more governmental officials are handed responsibility for developing and overseeing a solution to the problem and a specific regulatory framework is set in motion.

Chockablock with retro furniture and kitschy knickknacks, the shop is a paean to dcor from the 50's through the 80's -- minus snooty 90's self-importance.

title: Film; Making Argentina Matter Again
description: DURING the 1960's, Argentine cinema carried the torch for revolution in Latin America, blasting onto screens worldwide with polemical force. But by the 90's the country was better known for telenovelas, the overwrought television soap operas avidly watched by millions more people than ever saw the revolutionary film classic ''The Hour of the Furnaces'' back in 1968. In the intervening decades, with few exceptions, Argentina became something of a cinematic backwater.

title: BATTLESHIP BERTHED
description: The U.S.S. New Jersey was moved last week without ceremony to its mooring on the Camden waterfront, where it will serve as a museum and memorial. The 1.5-mile move from the South Jersey Port Corporation docks, where the battleship had undergone final renovations, to its mooring near the state aquarium and other waterfront tourist attractions had been scheduled for Sept. 16 but was postponed because of the Sept. 11 attacks. Coast Guard officials, still worried about terrorism, approved the move only seven hours before it took place last Sunday at dawn. The museum is expected to open in the next several weeks, though no specific date has been set. Robert Strauss

title: Our Towns; A Terrorist at the Shell Station? No, but That Goatee Looks Suspicious
description: WHEN Magdy Beshara, the Egyptian-born owner of the Shell station here on Route 9, heard that the F.B.I. was looking for him in connection with the terrorist attacks, he was not worried. description: Tenacity is a well-recognized attribute of the grandmaster, but it sometimes infects organizers as well. After Alexandre Lesiege and Kevin Spraggett tied for first place in the Canadian Closed Championship in Montreal at the end of August, theere was a tie-break series of four games. But the two grandmasters drew four games straight, thus denying their backers their wishes.

title: Waves of Panic Reveal A Skewed Geography
description: LAWRENCE, Mass., the small city northwest of Boston where Francisco Plcido lives, is not part of New York. But before Sept. 11, that fact was not so clear to Mr. Plcido's wife, Yolanda, who lives in the Dominican Republic. When the attack on the World Trade Center occurred, Mr. Plcido had to give his frightened wife a quick geography lesson.

For reasons less fathomable, there is also one named for Bo Derek. title: Celebrating Life
description: Arts organizations across New Jersey have been scrambling in reaction to the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center. Some have canceled or postponed events; others have dedicated performances and scheduled benefits. Most are scrutinizing their offerings for content that could be construed as offensive. Yet those in the arts hope that their work will help people heal.

title: Handyman's Special
description: Talk about cheap and cheerful: they don't make a shopping cart big enough to hold it, but you can buy most of the house shown here at your local discount home-improvement store. When Steven Harris, a New York architect, was asked to design a loftlike house for a woman in Mayport, Fla., his mandate was to make it flexible (to accommodate visitors) and low-cost (she wanted to maximize her retirement fund). So Harris began with the idea that ''the cheapest building would be a metal shed.'' Given the ''iffy'' neighborhood, Harris's design focused the house on a courtyard. He specified insulated panels for the interior walls, a material that he says ''looks like compressed shredded wheat'' for the ceiling, and commercial vinyl tile for the floors. And because the design is modular -- it's based on the dimensions of the sliding-glass doors he found at Home Depot -- it can be big or small. And at $45 a square foot, who's counting? (This two-bedroom house would cost $75,000 to build in Florida.)

title: Through Children's Eyes and Adults' Pocketbooks
description: OVER the last two weeks, classrooms throughout the Island have been forums for students to express their emotions about the World Trade Center disaster. Many students have prepared messages for emergency workers, and others have composed personal drawings, poems and essays. Here and on Page 8 are samples of some expressions from Long Island students.

title: Political Briefing; A Vulnerable Senator And 2 Possible Rivals
description: There is still talk that Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire, a hard-right, sometimes quirky Republican, is one of the most vulnerable Senate candidates in the country. But there is no longer much talk by his detractors that he surely will soon come to his political senses and abandon his effort to seek a third term. Rather, the talk now is about how successful he has been at raising money for another run.

title: Music; Waiting for Our John Lennon
description: IF the Vietnam War was the first war that America witnessed on television, then the war on terrorism is the first one that Americans are coming to terms with on the Internet. E-mail boxes overflowed with communiqus from eyewitnesses and survivors in Manhattan, many of which painted a picture far bleaker than that on the news. Then there were editorializing e-mails like the Afghan-born novelist Tamim Ansary's plea for the civilians of his native country and an anonymous writer's suggestion that instead of sending soldiers and bombs, American forces should bring food and other gifts to cripple Afghan support for the Taliban. Other e-mails offered links to Web sites where small slide shows and Flash animations, all accompanied by music, served to drive home a point in a way that sometimes only art can.

title: Investing; Forecasters Try to Assess the Terror Factor
description: SENDHIL MULLAINATHAN, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has spent the last two weeks plugging worst-case possibilities into his economic and market forecasts.

title: Knowing Her Place
description: In the face of all the current pressure to pretend that one's coworkers are one's friends or even part of a ''workplace family'' (which doubtless may ring true for any workers whose friends and families give them annual salary reviews), it was refreshing to read about Alexandra Lebenthal and her assistant, Tania Dougherty, who have a good professional relationship but recognize that they ''are not friends'' (Robin Pogrebin). Such honesty leaves both women free to choose their friends on the basis of personal affinity.

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; Take Me Out to the Takeout
description: There's a little takeout food shop in every town that's always got exactly what you're in the mood for. At least, there should be. In Hoboken, Anthony David's is that place. Once a 1930's grocery, the spot, run by Anthony and Liz Pino since 1998, has the original tin ceilings and hardwood floors. Mornings start with muffins, croissants and bagels, and coffee brewed from a special blend of dark-roasted Costa Rican Tico beans ($1.25 a large cup), strong and aromatic, but low in acidity. Midday pangs can be quieted with Anthony's sandwiches (all $5.50). The grilled pepper chicken sandwich, layered with goat cheese, caramelized onions, tomato, arugula and a tangy balsamic aoli, is a feast between slices of whole-grain bread. There are also a fresh mozzarella and tomato sandwich, dressed with basil pesto on a rosemary ciabatta, and a French chicken salad sandwich with Granny Smith apples and Swiss cheese. The shop can also help you impress your friends with a fancy ''homemade'' dinner. It might start with golden crab cakes, or a bowl of Mediterranean chopped salad studded with feta, roasted red peppers, and chickpeas. For the main course, there is pepper-crusted ahi tuna with soba noodles; spicy lamb sausage tossed with fresh herbs and tomatoes over pappardelle; or messy, juicy, barbecued pork chops (all entrees $9.75 to $22 a pound). Remember to hide the takeout containers.

title: Rites for Victims Resonate Across Metropolitan Area
description: It was a time to cry yesterday. Not the irrepressible tears for the World Trade Center crumbling before our eyes, but the intimate, seemingly unbearable tears of losing someone who was loved.

title: OPINION; A Hamptons Summer of Delight
description: WHEN our Connecticut friends used to ask me where our beach house was, I would answer, ''Long Island'' and hope they would let it go at that. If they pursued the matter and asked, ''Where on Long Island?'' I would mumble ''Amagansett,'' hoping they would not recognize it as being in the Hamptons, whose reputation as a gathering place of the rich and famous was an embarrassment to those of us who are neither.

title: As Talk of War Heats Up, An Afghan Neighborhood Is Chilled
description: FROM his second-floor office in Flushing, Queens, Aziz Afridi has a bird's-eye view of the neighborhood that many of the city's 20,000 Afghans call home.

title: Jacqueline Glassenberg, Damon Hemmerdinger
description: Jacqueline Deborah Glassenberg, the daughter of Judith and Albert Glassenberg of New London, Conn., was married at her parents' house last evening to Damon John Hemmerdinger, the son of Elizabeth and H. Dale Hemmerdinger of New York. Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut officiated.

title: Airlines' policies on refunds and changes
description: Three weeks ago, Mark Rotella, of Jersey City, was looking forward to his weekend trip to Tampa departing Sept. 21. Like most budget-conscious travelers, he had picked his dates carefully, aware that cheaper tickets are often nonrefundable and carry steep fees for changes. Yet following the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, he was planning to postpone his trip. ''I'm not afraid to fly and I'm all for heightened security,'' Mr. Rotella said. ''But for a two-day weekend I don't know if it's worth it to spend three hours checking in.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ROBERT M. (BOB)
description: LEVINE-Robert M. (Bob). Amidst the collective pain and bereavment engendered by the tragic events of September 11, 2001, my heart weeps for the loss of a cherished friend. Bob, the beloved husband and true soulmate of Roberta has left us too soon. Together, they were a constant source of strength and compassion for Laurie and myself as we each endure the loss of our husbands in the not too distant past. Every memory that we have shared is a bond of love that connects our lives and keeps us close at heart. When I think of Bob, Ken and Harvey who traveled by our sides down life's road, I am not filled with sadness that they left us behind, but rather I am filled with gratitude that they were once with us. They will be with us forever in the way we live and in the way we love. Diane

title: Seeking Reassurance, and Finding It in Fishing
description: MONTAUK, N.Y. -- We gurgled through the placid, opaque green water of Montauk Harbor in the guide David Blinken's 23-foot Contender as we had on so many other fall afternoons, debating green fly or white, floating or sinking line. As always, we were filled with childlike anticipation at the prospect of casting our flies to the striped bass and false albacore that were amassed in large schools in the shadow of the Montauk Point lighthouse, gorging on an infinite number of hapless baitfish.

title: BEAUTY
description: Sun-burnished cheeks and wind-tossed hair may be instant signifiers of class and youth, but real sun and wind are not exactly madame's best firneds. Paige Smitherman, who did the face at right, rubbed Perfecting Browne Powder from Chanel - on cheeks, nose, chin, forehead - over a base of Forget Foundation by Linda Cantello. Gold shadow, brown eye-liner pencil and a touch of lip gloss complete the look. Cantello is of the opinion that you should splurge on the most expensive bronzer you can find, since it is so much cheaper than taking an actual vacation. And so much better for your skin. Dan Sharp, who styled the do, achieved its distinctly unwashed-for-weeks texture with a squirt of Big & Beautiful Extra Body Mousse, followed by Sleek & Chic Straightening Gloss Serum, both by Umberto Gianini. Of course, the choppy cut, which was done on dry hair with scissors, is the key. ''It's not about perfection or balance,'' Sharp muses. ''It's about uniqueness.''

title: At a South Jersey College, a Coach of Very Straight Shooters
description: In 1972 Helen Bolnick started an archery team at what is now Atlantic Cape Community College in Mays Landing, and she is there again this year developing young archers. In all, she has trained 23 all-American collegiate archers, eight of them women. Most her team members had never shot before. This year she was named developmental coach of the year in archery by the United States Olympics Committee, though she has never coached an Olympian. Now in her 70's, Ms. Bolnick has retired as a health and physical education faculty member, but she still coaches the archery team. She recently talked about the sport.

title: Editorial Observer; Cultural Predictions in the Wake of the Terrorist Attack
description: Within a few hours of the terrorist attack on New York and Washington, every sector of American society began to reason out what the impact on our national life might be. It was a natural reaction, and it added up to the most astonishing burst of predictive energy most of us have ever witnessed. Scientists have calculated that the collapse of the World Trade Center released a force equivalent to one-twentieth of the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima. But there is no calculating the energy that has been expended in imagining what the future now might bring. Analysts with suitable tools, like economists and serious historians, tried to use those tools to picture the near- and long-term consequences. Everyone else took a wild guess.

title: An International Toy With a Japanese Accent
description: POKMON may be pass, but the nation's children will keep snapping up toys made by Japanese companies like Takara, Bandai and Tomy. That, at least, is the thinking of Donald Wisniewski, who hopes to ride the popularity of Japanese-sounding names to help sell the Cbiko, a pocket organizer and wireless communicator that almost every youngster seems to want.

title: Travel Advisory; Fall in Pennsylvania: Pumpkins and Hayrides
description: Apples and pumpkins are two of the autumnal themes at upcoming events in Pennsylvania. The three-day Applefest in Franklin, on the Allegheny River about 70 miles north of Pittsburgh, is held this Friday through Sunday. Originally a pie-baking contest, it now includes arts and crafts, puppet shows, tours of Tiffany windows and horse-drawn buggy rides. Activities will be staged throughout downtown each day, starting at 10 a.m. Information: (888) 547-2377, www.franklin-pa.org.

title: Ground Zero Diary: 12 Days of Fire and Grit
description: The last of the big fires erupted at 3:30 a.m., a rushing orange-and-red wall that swiftly overwhelmed the ruined Marriott Hotel. Dozens of firefighters sat in office chairs in the open air at the corner of Liberty and West Streets. Their faces were brightened by flames. Some slept, slumped backward in fire-retardant coats.

title: Fire Dept. Asks If There Are Some Fires It Shouldn't Fight
description: The New York Fire Department, reeling from its losses in the World Trade Center attack, is pushing 300 more recruits than normal through its training program. It has turned to retirees to augment its depleted ranks. It has snapped up fire equipment destined for other cities.

title: Village Tallies a Loss Beyond a Good Meal
description: DINERS at Millie's Place, one of Great Neck's most popular restaurants and a local institution, opened their elegant menus three weeks ago to find an inserted letter from the owner, Millie Gubbins, announcing that she planned to close her doors after 25 years in business. There was a dispute over the lease, she explained.

title: An Inspiration Lives On in His Mind
description: ALLAN WEXLER, architect and conceptual artist, moved to New York in 1973, just as the World Trade Center was being completed. At the time, the twin towers were controversial among architects and urban critics, many of whom objected to the oversize, blocky structures that had so radically altered the skyline.

title: 'Lightning Field'
description: Her hands are white and long and lithe. They make elusive, fleeting frames -- flirtations of shapes, really -- on anything they touch. Anything in the world. I would follow those hands out to the desert. I would. I would watch them on the black leather curve of the steering wheel. I would watch them light a cigarette with the glowing car lighter after it made a low pop and smelled vaguely of burnt food. And I would watch them as she gestured when she spoke, as if she were weighing air or beckoning someone near. At times I notice her watching her own hands, admiring their white elegant angles and delicately draped bones. When I notice her watching her own hands, I look away, my eyes shy from shame.

title: Christina Townsend, Bancroft Jones
description: Christina Ann Townsend, a daughter of Joanne E. Townsend of Rowayton, Conn., and Charles H. Townsend of New York, was married yesterday in Peru, Vt., to Samuel Bancroft Jones, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Benjamin Jones IV of New Canaan, Conn. Kermit F. title: The Way We Live Now: 9-30-01: Close Reading: Elements of War; The Father Figure
description: On a day when countless children in America lost their fathers, the rest of us started searching for a father, too. When a nation is under siege, it wants someone to tell us what to do, to protect us from bullies, to tell us that everything's O.K. and that it's safe to go home now. It's an impulse, perhaps, that we never outgrow. But as we've learned this month, the definition of what constitutes a plausible national father at a time of tragedy is as much in flux in the 21st century as the definition of war. F.D.R. and Churchill -- the patriarchs who served Western civilization during the greatest international conflagration of living memory -- projected a patrician, if not Victorian, authority that might not play today even if we had leaders who could match their eloquence. For that matter, our nation has become so much larger and complex since World War II that one size of national dad may no longer fit all. In a matter of days, we've gone through several.

title: Dance; A New Stage for Modernists: the Nightclub
description: MODERN dance has experienced a resurgence in a seemingly incongruous place -- the nightclub. The hugely popular ''Lisa LeAnn and Terry Dean Put on a Dance Show,'' for instance, presents experimental choreography once a month at the Galapagos Art and Performance Space, a club in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Organized by two veterans of Elizabeth Streb's modern dance company, Terry Dean Bartlett and Lisa LeAnn Dalton, the show typically features short works by about 10 choreographers. The packaging is at once artfully chic and casually homemade. It is dance created by, and generally for, members of the MTV generation -- an updated realization of a much-maligned high school tradition: the talent show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SESINOVA, ALENA
description: SESINOVA-Alena. September 11, 2001, World Trade Center, Tower One, 96th floor. Irreplaceable, beloved friend, who having escaped Communist Czechoslovakia, fulfilled her dream of coming to America. A passionate intellect, she loved life & had a heart of gold. Among all of her endearing qualities, she will always be remembered for her fondness for spicy foods & red wine & the comical situations that resulted from, more often than not, the latter. She is survived by her companion of 22 yrs, her mother in Prague & her friends on both continents. Nanette Shaw & Isa Goldberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKELEY, GRAHAM
description: BERKELEY-Graham. In loving memory of Graham, beloved son of Charles and Pauline Berkeley of Shrewsbury, Shropshire, England, graduate of the Royal College of Music, London and at his untimely death, Director E-Commerce Solutions, Compuware Corporation, USA. Graham Berkeley, 37, was a resident of Boston and his beloved Provincetown, MA. Graham embraced life and the many friends he made in turn embraced his warmth, charm, intelligence, wicked sense of humor and love of music. An accomplished classical violinist, a fan of the opera, fitness enthusiast and a world traveler, Graham was a true Renaissance man. After a ten year effort, Graham finally received his Green Card for US residency in June; he was planning on a move back to New York at the end of September. Graham met his death on September 11, in the World Trade Center attack in the city and country he loved so much and where he had so many valued friends. He will be sorely missed by his parents, his brothers Chris and Roger, and by all who were blessed to know him. A memorial service will be held in New York City on Friday, Oct. 12, at 12:30 PM at Grace Church, 802 Broadway, corner East 10th Street. There will be a reception for family and friends immediately following the memorial service.

title: Untouched, But Touched
description: UNTIL this month, the Gullen family loved being typical. The four of them live in Forest Hills, Queens, where for 22 years they have rented the same dim apartment on a leafy street with birdbaths and lawn jockeys. They are big coffee drinkers. They know all their neighbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, MADELEINE (MADGE), G.
description: JACOBSON-Madeleine (Madge), G. Of Chevy Chase, MD, formerly of Larchmont, died on August 21, 2001 at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, MD at the age of 97. Mrs. Jacobson was born in Philadelphia on May 29, 1904 to Milton and Sophie Goldsmith. She grew up in New York City and graduated from Teachers College, Columbia University. She worked as a dietitian for many years. She married Charles A. Jacobson, Jr. an alumnus of Harvard College. She and her husband moved to Larchmont after World War II and she lived in Larchmont until 1994 when she moved to Maryland to be near her daughter and family. While living in Larchmont she was actively involved with a number of organizations including The Westchester Ethical Society, League of Women Voters, United Nations Association and PTA. She and her husband always welcomed friends, relatives and sometimes foreign students into their home for as long as they wanted to stay. She will be remembered for her hospitality and as someone who was always helping people and working for organizations that tried to make the community and/or the world a better place. She is survived by her daughter Susan (Sue) Jacobson Pardo and two grandchildren David and Rebecca. Her husband Charles Jacobson pre-deceased her. There will be a memorial service at the Washington Ethical Society, 7750 16th Street, NW, Washington, D.C. on Saturday, October 6 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to Make-AWish Foundation Gift Center, P.O. Box 29119, Phoenix, AZ 85038 or The Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, 7 Saxon Wood Road, White Plains, NY, 10605.

description: MAJ. MICHAEL GEORGE is an instructor at the United States Military Academy in West Point.
